column2: WE would like to applaud and support "Editorials in Radio" in last Sunday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Republican Congressional investigation of speculation in the basic food markets has reached a crossroads and a crisis.

IT is doubtful if the day will ever dawn when one will be able to expound a religious faith in positive affirmations without either implicit or explicit dissent from other religious outlooks. True, there is a basic spiritual unity in human nature the world over; but every one of mankind's religions has its own fundamental distinctive quality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, and Tighe Woods, acting Housing Expediter administering rent, called upon Congress today for legislation extending and strengthening rent control, preferably for a two-year period.

Walter Hendl, young assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted that orchestra in a well-designed program at Carnegie Hall last night, and pleased the sold-out house by doubling as piano soloist in Mozart's great D minor Concerto.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Well known to millions of resort visitors, the famous Resort-to-Ocean City "fast-line trolleys" will go out of existence tomorrow after forty-two years of service.

ONE of the most brilliant of contemporary journalists was Raoul de Roussy de Sales, best known to American readers by his "The Making of Tomorrow." I have recently been turning the pages of the diaries he kept from 1938 until his death in 1942; they were published last year under the title, "The Making of Yesterday."

W. A. DARLINGTON'S speculations last week concerning the place George Bernard Shaw is likely to occupy in the estimation of future generations of playgoers are little short of amazing. Asserting that topical plays are solely of a transitory interest, he evidently overlooks the instances in which such dramas have, with the passage of time, given genuine pleasure as valid portraits of a vanished era.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Secretary Clinton P. Anderson also made public today a list of "big traders" in cottonseed oil and wool tops during the twenty-three-month period ending Nov. 30, 1947. The only trader identified as a public official was Edwin W. Pauley, an assistant to the Secretary of the Army.
Matters continue to move at an accelerated tempo as events rush on toward the opening of another baseball campaign.

AFTER months of quiet preparation, the Warner Brothers surreptitiously initiated a new program last week for the production of low-budget films. The reason for the studio's official silence on the subject is the chronic fear which exists in Hollywood of the label B pictures -- a term which primarily designates a low cost category but has acquired a derogatory qualitative significance, secondarily.

RONNE ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Jan. 13 -- (Delayed) -- This expedition has opened up a great new portion of the Antarctic, and in course of this exploration has come across numerous natural features it has been named after those whose encouragement and active help have been so important to our present undertaking.

IT used to be argued, and I think it is accepted by many people, that poetry is a flower of racial childhood and must wither away as civilization advances. For civilization is based on reason and restraint, poetry on imagination and passion; poetry (they say) is dreams, and civilization the daylight that disperses them.

AT one point in this story Desmond Shannon, with commendable self-restraint, refers to his client as a "slab-sided, pot-bellied son of a misbegotten she-camel." On other occasions, when there are no ladies present, he expresses himself less elegantly.

The demand by women for sheer hosiery was cited yesterday as a controlling factor in the answer of the Textile Machine Works and Berkshire Knitting Mills of Reading, Pa., to a Federal civil antitrust suit in Federal Court here.
ot in a small community out on Long Island.

THE head of the English Department in a California high school is shot dead in her own office during school hours, and no one admits hearing the shot or seeing anything that can be of help to Sheriff Jim Erickson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Congressional action to investigate the high profit margins in the home-building industry and to consider moves to reduce such profits was urged today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont.

The sad state of undergraduate comic magazines, as noted in R. C Lewis' "Inquiry Into College Humor," seems at last to have come to the attention of college editors themselves. So happy a sign is this that I take the liberty of quoting (from the Alabama Rammer Jammer, Oct. 1947):

Fordham's Jerome Connolly soundly beat Reginald Pearman, New York University's Olympic 800-meter hope, at 1,000 yards. Leslie MacMitchell of the New York A. C., an enigmatic laggard for the past year, blew his mile rivals off the track with a devastating last-lap sprint.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 (AP) -- A source close to the Yale football picture tonight disclosed that there is every indication that Howie Odell's successor as the Blue's gridiron coach will be "an elderly man willing to go along with the available material."
Two boys received high praise yesterday from Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy for warning the occupants of a burning tenement building and enabling them to reach safety.

Deterred by high prices, many buyers in the wholesale markets last week were eliminating the upper price brackets, and in some instances dropping certain lines previously carried entirely, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.
The Mediterranean Sea, ancient center of civilization, became a new strategic focus last week in the "cold war" between the United States and Russia.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 17 (UP) -- General of Army Dwight D. Eisenhower' name will be placed in the Oregon Republican preferential primary, it was announced today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Anti-British demonstrations spread to Shanghai and other big Chinese cities today as British women and children fled to this British Crown colony from Canton, where rioters Friday burned the British Consulate and a number of other buildings and injured at least six British subjects.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in the British Isles today:

Angered over the tax-free advantage of numerous Federal agencies and corporations, the American Municipal Association last week girded itself for a drive on Congress to enact legislation that would add more than a billion dollars to municipal treasuries all over the country.
Some leading equipment companies in this district are cutting back expenses and taking other steps to be forehanded about a "bust" in 1948, it was learned yesterday.

As a regular reader of your Sunday articles I have been interested in your discussions of reaction to "Crossfire," "Gentleman's Agreement" and "The Fugitive." I have always maintained that the functions of a true critic, a great critic, are to see merit in any great work of art whether or not it agrees with the critic's opinions.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 17 -- A compact organization for handling aid to the Netherlands under the Marshall Plan is being established here with Dr. Hans M. Hirschfeld, one of the nation's foremost economists, at is head, it was learned today.

DURING my recent concert tour in the Scandinavian countries, I had time to investigate musical conditions there. The standards are exceedingly high from a creative as well as interpretive point of view. Although there are hardly any Swedish and Norwegian composers known on this side of the ocean, it will not be long before several will have a chance of being introduced to American audiences.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- No sooner had the unofficial truce called over the holiday season come to an end than Italy broke out again in a rash of Communist-instigated strikes and agitations. The bank strike attracted particular attention during the two weeks that it lasted, but it was merely one of many that tied up vast sectors of the Italian economy.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 16 -- Nearly thirty years after Samuel Gompers turned his sympathy for the Cuban cigar workers into the first Pan American Federation of Labor, Mr. Gompers' successors in the American Federation of Labor have helped to organize the Inter-American Confederation of Labor, CIAT, which they hope will last longer than its predecessor.

" THE BENNETT PLACE" is the story of the effects of one woman's suicide on a group of people in a small Midwestern university town. Katherine Bennett, who lived in the Bennett Place up on the hill and whose family had founded the town and the university, had become, without her wishing it, a kind of symbol to the people of Sparta; a symbol and at the same time a reproach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A strong movement developed among Democrats today for revision of President Truman's tax adjustment bill to draw support from the party's conservative wing and prevent a possible bolt of some Administration supporters.

PRAGUE, Jan. 17 --Czechoslovakia's second largest political party and principal rival of the Communists, the Czech National Socialist party, expressed open dissatisfaction today with the absence of Czechoslovakia from the Marshall Plan group.

WHEN the curtain goes up on the "ANTA Album" at the Ziegfeld this evening, about two hundred boys and girls from current musical shows will begin an abundant evening by singing Irving Berlin's "There's No Business Like Show Business."

REPRESENTATIVE of the hard-boiled school of fiction, "Night Cry" tells the simple, starkly brutal story of homicide at the hands of a police detective. Though the story has the usual romantic trappings, Stuart never lets them get out of hand.

Warning that latent anti-Semitism in this country might flare to dangerous proportions if the economic situation changes, Jacob Blaustein, chairman of the executive committee, American Jewish Committee, said last night steps must be taken now to curb future racial discrimination in the United States.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will conduct Verdi's "Requiem" at a special concert at Carnegie Hall on Apri 26. Like all his recent appearances at which admission has been charged, it will be a benefit performance. This time the beneficiary will be the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, which has been staffed entirely by women doctors since it was founded ninety years ago by America's woman medical pioneer, Elizabeth Blackwell.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Relic, the colt expected to be second choice to Warren Wright's Citation in the Kentucky Derby, began his 3-year-old campaign today with a smashing victory in the six-furlong Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park.

THESE two books, both based on traditional forms of entertainment, will help children from 6 to 12 to work off their excess energies with a minimum of trouble for grown-ups. Robert North's "Town and Country Games" is a compendium of games for any occasion where a group is gathered together, and the more, of course, the merrier.

RANGING in material from recipes for serving a large group to recipes for two, this new group of cook books covers four different fields of cooking. The first of these is in restaurant cooking. J. H. Breland, instructor of commercial cookery in the Isaac Delgado Trades School in New Orleans, has organized a volume of recipes for serving twenty-five persons.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was at such a slow pace that many brokers suggested the "Summer schedule" be put into operation and a five-day week inaugurated. Of course, there were exceptions to this apathy in stocks which recently headed upward, such as Follansbee Steel and Plymouth Oil.
JOHN RUSSELL YOUNG, Washington's nearest equivalent to a mayor, brings to the role of city father a background as unique as the District's voteless government.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 -- Los Angeles, which like a growing boy has suddenly noticed that it is bursting its municipal seams, is considering abandoning its horse-and-buggy form of government for an adaptation of New York's borough system.
I CANNOT tell you my delight in reading your comments on "The Fugitive" in the Jan. 11th TIMES. When I saw "The Fugitive" it was clear to me that I witnessed a chef d'oeuvre.

A UNIQUE opportunity to observe the interesting flora and fauna of parts of Florida is offered tourists this winter. Naturalists of the National Audubon Society guide two sets of wildlife tours in these areas.

Pupils in public and parochial junior high schools of the city pledged their assistance yesterday in behalf of starving children in other parts of the world during the Youth Forum conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

GOETHE, the prince of Erlebnisdichter, of writers of their own experience, once said that he did not so much write what he had experienced as that he experienced what he would write. In this study Barker Fairley, Professor of German at the University of Toronto, reasonably tries to explain both the experience and the works as aspects of the developments of Gothe's personality, his Inner Life.

MADRID, Jan. 1 -- Students of the Madrid University Law School, who have been on strike since Friday morning, have agreed to return to classes on Monday, Fernando Cancellas, chief of the Madrid district for the National University Students' Syndicate, said today.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Just a month ago the House of Lords, represented by five peers, sitting as the equivalent of the American Supreme Court, passed a judgment in a marriage case that has aroused extraordinary controversy throughout Britain. Every newspaper has had its flood of "letters to the editor" and it was clear that thousands of Britons felt that the very foundations of marriage were being assailed.

IN this story of the Beloved Physician we see St. Luke first as a young Greek, dissatisfied with the hollow, meaningless ritual of his pagan priesthood, turning from it to set out upon a search for truth and beauty. It was a time of violence in which a small but ever-increasing group of courageous, dedicated people struggled to live as Christians.

The annual meeting of the Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of New York State will be held in the Astor Hotel next Thursday and Friday, Miss Jane H. Todd, president and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, announced yesterday.

THESE four volumes -- 3,100,000 words, 1,600 articles, 1,540 illustrations, 800 contributors -- add up to an encyclopedic history of the decade from 1937 to 1946. To call them simply "eventful" years is to understate the dislocation, hysteria, revolution, murder, yes, and progress which characterized them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) Air National Guard units in Maine, Nebraska and California soon will be buzzing around the skies in Jet-propelled P-80 Shooting Stars, the Air Force said today.

SUBSTANTIAL reductions in the prices of Rolleiflex and other foreign cameras are announced by Burleigh Brooks, Inc., importer of cameras. The new price listed by this company for the Automatic Rolleiflex, with Schneider Xenar f/3.5 lens in Compur Rapid shutter is $245; with Zeiss Tessar f/3.5, $275. The Rolleicord with Zeiss Triotar f/3.5 in Compur Rapid lists at $165, the Praktiflex, with Victar f/2.9 lens, $121.25. Prices include carrying case, excise tax.

IN this story of the Beloved Physician we see St. Luke first as a young Greek, dissatisfied with the hollow, meaningless ritual of his pagan priesthood, turning from it to set out upon a search for truth and beauty. It was a time of violence in which a small but ever-increasing group of courageous, dedicated people struggled to live as Christians.

The annual meeting of the Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of New York State will be held in the Astor Hotel next Thursday and Friday, Miss Jane H. Todd, president and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, announced yesterday.

THESE four volumes -- 3,100,000 words, 1,600 articles, 1,540 illustrations, 800 contributors -- add up to an encyclopedic history of the decade from 1937 to 1946. To call them simply "eventful" years is to understate the dislocation, hysteria, revolution, murder, yes, and progress which characterized them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) Air National Guard units in Maine, Nebraska and California soon will be buzzing around the skies in Jet-propelled P-80 Shooting Stars, the Air Force said today.

SWAZILAND, a native kingdom under British protectorate, is bordered by the Union of South Africa on three sides and Portuguese East Africa on the fourth. King Sobhuza II is the symbol of the nation -- the "father and son of the people."

BRANCHES of foliage bring freshness and richness to rooms in winter. Needled or broad-leaved evergreens from the garden, or tropical branches from the florist can be loosely composed in large containers for important arrangements on the piano, table or mantel.

The Manhattan College quintet gained its tenth victory in 13 starts last night when it conquered the Scranton University squad, 74 -- 50, in the Jaspers' gymnasium. Ahead most of the way, the Kelly Greens had a fairly easy time of it and sent 14 men into the fray.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 17 -- After dropping its last six contests, the Dartmouth basketball team finally succeeded in breaking into the victory column tonight by downing Penn, 64 -- 60, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Counsel for the International Typographical Union indicated in cross-examination of government witnesses before a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner today the course of the defense against slowdown charges leveled at the Chicago union.

THE peace and quiet of country life appeal to Barney and Muriel Gantt. both writers who have found the city too disturbing. They rent a farmhouse in Bucks County where neighbors are few and far between. The peace and quiet are rudely interrupted when the woman who supplies the Gantts with eggs is found dead of what the coroner diagnoses as food poisoning.

The United Nations Commission on Korea is moving cautiously in attempting to carry out its mission. It apparently still is hopeful that the Soviet Government will recognize its authority and allow it to oversee free elections in both the Soviet-occupied and United States-occupied zones for establishment of an independent Korean government.

Upward adjustments made last week in the prices of several steel products probably foreshadow other price increases on all steel items in the near future, although the industry would prefer to hold the price line at its present level, according to financial observers.
A DEVICE appropriately called the "Pocket Ear" is one of the newest gadgets developed by radio engineers in their search for improved television studio production techniques.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall in a statement today said that the European Recovery Program neither provided for nor contemplated the acquisition by the United States of overseas military bases in return for the assistance to be given to Europe.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Skim, a Fantasy Farm entry ridden by Jockey Ben Strange, breezed home winner in the $2,000 Robert E. Lee feature at the Fair Grounds today.

DHAHRAN, SAUDI ARABIA -- (By Wireless). IT was all a little like a tale from the Arabian Nights -- even to the magic carpet. We had left Giebelstadt in Germany where the runways were partly covered with snow just thirteen hours before. And here we were climbing out of a Superfort on the United States Air Force base at a place in the vast Arabian desert within sight of the blue Persian Gulf.

WICHITA, Jan., Jan. 17 -- The Sedgwick County (Wichita) unit of the national peace-time blood-collection program of the American Red Cross was opened formally yesterday by Basil O'Connor, Red Cross chairman.

Utter disdain from the other National Football League moguls greeted Alexis Thompson's proposal for a common draft with the rival All-America Conference, as the annual meeting of the older circuit closed shop at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- Ken Henry of the United States and Hiyo Chang Lee of Korea won warm-up races today as speed skaters tested their blades for the first time against rivals they will meet in the winter Olympics, Jan. 30-Feb. 8.

IF it's true, as our West Coast tipsters tell us, that caution is rife in Hollywood and that pictures with any vital substance are likely to be out for the next few years, then we take small but some sustaining comfort from the fact that Alfred Hitchcock is still around, for Mr. Hitchcock is one of the few directors who can make a picture -- and make it good -- by sheerest style.

Many women of society in this city and in Bermuda are actively interested in plans for a charity ball to augment the Lady Cubitt Compassionate Fund, which will be held Jan. 30 in the Silver Grill of the newly-reopened Bermudiana Hotel in Hamilton, Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The first exchanges of students, professors and specialists under terms of the Fulbright Scholarship Act were authorized today by President Truman's Board of Foreign Scholarship in travel grants.

HERE is a delineation of American westward expansion from the Louisiana Purchase to the end of the Mexican War. The author, Walter F. McCaleb, has stuck nimbly to his pattern and turned out a highly competent account of these significant five decades.

Much of the current discussion of inflation is serving to perpetuate an already widely held fallacy with respect to the relationship between the quantity of money and the level of prices. This fallacy was clearly stated in a letter to THE TIMES that appeared on Jan. 11, signed by members of various faculties of the University of Chicago.

Arab attacks on Palestinian Jews since partition was voted Nov. 29 last were characterized in a statement issued here yesterday by the American Christian Palestine Committee as an attempt to nullify by force "the first great decision of the United Nations."

A new three-way plan to insure delivery of scarce steel sheet and pipe has been worked out by purchasing agents here who have large quantities of scarce metal scrap to sell. Instead of ordering through regular wholesale channels, however, these deals involve a three-cornered transaction between the mills, scrap brokers and the industrial buyer, spokesmen explained, and the methods almost completely set aside the historical pattern of steel trading.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, arrived here this morning from Geneva on his tour of possible sites for the next General Assembly meeting, scheduled to be held somewhere in Europe in September.
A can of salmon and three milk bottles, well aimed, foiled a holdup last night in the delicatessen of Alfred Diedrich at 1696 Second Avenue, between Eighty-seventh and Eighty-eighth Streets.

MR. KATKOV'S story -- what there is of it -- is stripped for action. A young Jewish newspaper man is in love with a Gentile girl and can't marry her -- in his town (St. Paul, Minn.) Jewish families are uncompromising about marriage with Gentiles.

ALTHOUGH few "series" of stories hold up to the high level of the first success, this fourteenth story of Freddy the Pig, and his colleagues on the Bean farm, a complete and self-contained story, is as funny, as absorbing and as unobtrusively instructive as the very first one.

THE exhibition of Vermont landscapes and other prints by John W. Doscher on view through Jan. 31 at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, suggests the varied photographic possibilities of country life, but does not back up the idea with an adequate demonstration.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Jan. 17 -- Miss Gail Macomber, competing unattached, flashed down the mile-long Tecumseh Trail through a snowstorm in one minute 39.6 seconds to win the women's eastern downhill skiing championship today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The board of trustees of Washington and Lee University was informed at a meeting in the Mayflower Hotel today that $939,231 had been contributed to the $3,000,000 bicentennial fund begun a year ago to finance developments considered necessary for the school's advancement into its third century in 1949.

Regarding Mr. Downes' article last Sunday on Dr. Koussevitzky's address at a dinner of the Bohemians, may I shape my impressions in the forth of answers to some quotations from Dr. K.'s remarkable challenge to our superficially educated society.

THE rediscovery of all but forgotten artists comes about in two ways. Modern taste will suddenly find painting in the past which is strangely responsive to its way of seeing -- such as El Greco's emotional, expressionist art. Or, painters whose historic interest almost equals their artistic one will assume new importance for a nation examining its past.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Three railroad operating unions, unsuccessful in settling a wage-and-working rule dispute with the railroads after three months of conferences, issued three conflicting strike predictions today and accused the carriers of paying substandard wages.

Notwithstanding the fact that the present American Merchant Marine has been reduced to approximately one-half its wartime peak in number of vessels and men, the number of reports on injuries and illnesses actually has increased, according to Bruno J. Augenti, president of the Marine Index Bureau, Inc., 60 John Street.

Ever since the United Nations General Assembly made its fateful decision last Nov. 29 to split Palestine into two separate Jewish and Arab states a "war of partition" has been going on in the Holy Land. Last week the fighting -- between the Arabs, who want all Palestine for their country, and the Jews, who want partition -- reached its most violent stage.

DURING the year recently ended forty-one Governments added portraits or figures or statues of 129 personages to philately's expanding gallery. In addition to those effigies the names of four others were inscribed on stamps for the first time.
A can of salmon and three milk bottles, well aimed, foiled a holdup last night in the delicatessen of Alfred Diedrich at 1696 Second Avenue, between Eighty-seventh and Eighty-eighth Streets.

MR. KATKOV'S story -- what there is of it -- is stripped for action. A young Jewish newspaper man is in love with a Gentile girl and can't marry her -- in his town (St. Paul, Minn.) Jewish families are uncompromising about marriage with Gentiles.

ALTHOUGH few "series" of stories hold up to the high level of the first success, this fourteenth story of Freddy the Pig, and his colleagues on the Bean farm, a complete and self-contained story, is as funny, as absorbing and as unobtrusively instructive as the very first one.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette rejected today an Italian request for retraction of an article assailing Premier Alcide de Gasperi of Italy, and repeated its charges.

Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, permanent representative of the Philippines to the United Nations, received yesterday the gold medal of the International Benjamin Franklin Society "for distinguished world statesmanship in 1947" at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

The question has been raised whether the Russians themselves believe the things they say about American and British aims in Europe. It will be recalled that on two occasions at the London meeting of Foreign Ministers Secretary Marshall replied to long tirades of Secretary Molotov by saying he could never be convinced that Molotov himself believed what he had just said.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -- The Zionists today announced "punitive action" against Arab snipers' strong points outside Jaffa, in the Salameh and Tel Arish areas, during the night. They claimed twelve buildings were blown up, with twenty-four persons killed.

The recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Bergen Evening Record supporting the expansion of the Port Authority along lines of activity not jointly concerned with the States of New York and New Jersey, and using the earning power of the profitable tunnels and bridges to furnish the financial security for its net bond issues for such expansion, indicates a dangerous line of editorial thinking.

A proposal for the establishment of a three-member United Nations mediation commission to help settle Indian-Pakistani fighting in the Princely State of Kashmir was taken under consideration yesterday by the two disputing dominions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Law "imposes new responsibilities" on union members, Larry Gruber, outgoing president of Local 5, Chicago Photoengravers Union, AFL, told the local membership today at the union's annual meeting.

Carmen Gracia, new Spanish coloratura soprano, will make her debut, and four older members of the company will assume important new roles during the twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season. The matinee "Ring" cycle will also be concluded during the week with the presentation of the new production of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Bobby Layne, University of Texas star, ran and passed the West to an easy 34 to 20 triumph over the East today in a college all-star game that attracted a meager crowd of 3,083.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, today appointed twenty-three steel men to an advisory committee to supervise the steel industry's voluntary allocation program. They will consider agreements to carry out the law aimed at controlling inflationary forces.

There are winter days when clouds are piled like snowdrifts in a blue sky. Winter's wardrobe is chiefly a symphony of gray hues. Meadow grasses are gray-brown above the snow; alders and willows are gray-border stitching along the gray-ice ribbons of creeks. Thin gray shadows run from the trunks of maples and oaks on the upland ridges and stone walls are gray chains along the roads and around the mowings.

Husbands who grumble over their wives' inefficiency around the house will be left without a leg to stand on this spring when housewives begin coming home from City College carrying diplomas in home-making.

Formation of the Committee to Arm the Jewish State, with Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York as honorary chairman and Dean Alfange, head of the American Christian Palestine Committee of New York, as chairman, was announced here yesterday.

The Rev. Thomas McCandless, rector of St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, has announced his retirement from the active ministry to take effect on June 30. In a letter to the vestry, he explained that he felt the "weight of years" and that "new times, new ways and new men" would always be good for the church.

The market for sterling "forwards" was hit with particular force from Wednesday on, as rumor circulated again of a possible devaluation of the pound. This was traced to the early meeting of the British Chancellor of the Exchequer and the French Finance Minister on the subject of an adjustment of the sterling-franc rate which, observers say, cannot but have repercussion on the sterling-dollar rate.

ROUXVILLE, South Africa, Jan. 8 -- An extinct amphibian about six feet long, the Capitosaurus, may play an important role in the developing of theories on land connections between the continents, according to Prof. Charles L. Camp of the University of California, currently here searching for fossil remains of mammal-like reptiles.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- The Communist party paper Unita reported today the "indignation" of all classes in Taranto, but especially of the Communist and Socialist workers, over the impending arrival in that port of the United States Mediterranean Fleet and its marines.

Use of public funds for the support of parochial schools would constitute an opening wedge for the ultimate union of church and state and should never be tolerated, the Rev. George A. Crapullo, pastor of the Irving Square Presbyterian Church, Wilson Avenue at Weirfield Street, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon.

The wealth and income status of agriculture is much more favorable than it was before the war and the gap between the average farm income and city income has been greatly narrowed in recent years and may have been closed on a family basis, according to a study by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Farm income, at $29,700,000,000, was at an all time high in 1947, 21 per cent over 1946, the previous record year, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The industrial output in the Soviet Union reached the average quarterly level of 1940 in the last quarter of 1947 and the gross output of all industry last year increased by 22 per cent over 1946, according to an announcement today by the Soviet State Planning Commission.

Probably, as Arthur Krock suggests on Jan. 8, the authors of the President's tax proposals do not expect them to become law. Nevertheless analysis of them seems desirable because it will indicate the sort of economic thinking that prevails in the White House as we face the growing inflationary peril.

WASHINGTON, Jan 18 (AP) -- Zinc-producing states in the East boosted production in 1947 to nearly the normal annual rate of 159,986 tons after a slump to 138,488 tons in 1946, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- According to reliable information here, the British Government is increasingly alarmed about the gradually deteriorating international situation. British diplomatists appear to feel that there is a danger the Soviet Union, as well as its puppets, may some day take the drastic step of recognizing General Markos Vafiades' "Free Greek" provisional government if and when it is able to achieve a sufficiently dramatic military victory.
The Cabinet Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 18 -- Fawzi el-Kawukji, commander in chief of the Arab "People's Army for the Liberation of Palestine" now forming in Syria, said today that he was glad of partition because "that is one issue that will oblige the Arab states to put aside their differences and will prepare the way for a greater Arab nation."
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Rammin' Ralph Kiner today signed a one-year contract to play with the Pirates in 1948 for a reported salary of $30,000.

Although the world today is "obsessed with the concept of unity" a "terrifying" disunity exists "within the fold of Christ," Msgr. James H. Griffiths, Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate, declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mess in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Despite the loss of Doug Bentley in the opening period with a six-stitch gash beside his left eye, the Chicago Black Hawks cracked a jinx of long standing tonight by whipping the second-place Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 4, in a National Hockey League game before 13,119 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Senate investigators disclosed today that the Treasury saw little if any chance of obtaining tax revenues from more than $117,000,000 of profits they said were made from Arabian oil by two foreign corporations owned by two American oil companies.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- The atmosphere of a crisis over extreme food shortages in some areas and the fears of persons in other areas that their meager supplies may be seized to help their fellow countrymen, appears to have spread throughout the bizonal area.

VIENNA, Jan. 10 -- Out of 1,500,000 displaced persons in Austria, Germany and Italy near the end of last year, according to what must necessarily be a rough estimate, only 175,000 Jews were listed on the latest International Refugee Organization compilation.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 18 -- Political observers here noted with interest the participation today of Dr. Josef Baumgartner, until recently Bavarian State Minister of Food and Agriculture, in a session of the rapidly-burgeoning Bavarian party.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Richard Gonzales of Los Angeles was leading Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 9, 11 -- 9, when darkness and cold weather brought a halt to their best three-out-of-five-set match for the Florida West Coast tennis championship here tonight.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 18 -- Kalle Nergaard, 21-year-old star of the Norwegian Ski Association, gave a thrilling performance in leading a field of seventy-three amateur and open racers in the first annual Victor Constant memorial giant slalom held under ideal weather conditions today on the eastern flank of majestic Mount Mansfield.

Although the outlook for bank earnings during 1948 now seems favorable, banking leaders are evincing increased concern over taxes, the inflationary prospects, and the implications of the growing shortage of equity capital. These matters, it was clearly demonstrated last week, are now uppermost in the minds of banking spokesmen, who took pains to emphasize them in their annual reports to shareholders at year-end bank meetings.

Bishop Arne Fjellbu, dean of the Lutheran Cathedral of Nidaros, Trondheim, Norway, will spend the next two months on a preaching visitation in this country under the auspices of the American Committee for the World Council of Churches, the headquarters of which are in Geneva, Switzerland.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- The establishment of a permanent international body to combat crime and set up standards of punishment throughout the world will be urged here tomorrow by Viscount Templewood, formerly Sir Samuel Hoare, at a special meeting of United Nations officials, it was learned today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 18 -- The first step in a Southern plan to solve the controversial problem of providing higher education and preserving racial segregation policies was taken today when the $8,000,000 Meharry Medical College was offered informally to the Southern states for joint operation as a regional medical school for Negroes.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, having announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, is expected to speak out soon on two national issues: racial and religious discrimination and Government taxation and finances.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Montreal's Canadiens protected their fourth-place berth in the National Hockey League by sharing a 1-1 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden. The visitors had to play the last forty-eight minutes without Maurice (The Rocket) Richard, who drew a game misconduct penalty.

Sid Tanenbaum, the ex-Violet sharpshooter who scored more points than any other player in the history of basketball at New York University, comes back to Madison Square Garden tonight. The slender star is listed to make his local debut as a member of the Knickerbockers as they tangle with the Philadelphia Warriors at the Eighth Avenue arena.

The United States Government has realized $1,700,000,000 from sales of war-built merchant vessels by the Maritime Commission, under the authority granted the agency in the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946, it was learned yesterday.

A diamond Fashion Show will be given on Wednesday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre, under the auspices of Van Cleef Arpels, in aid of the Share Through CARE Committee, a national group endeavoring to promote the sending of CARE packages to Europe.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- President Truman's program, as set forth in his state of the Union message, was hailed tonight as "an economic bill of rights for the youth of America" by Chairman J. Howard McGrath of the Democratic National Committee.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The food shortages in the British zone in Germany and the resulting unrest are causing grave concern to the British Government, already disturbed by the discovery of "Protocol M" disclosed by the British as a Communist plan for defeating the European Recovery Program in Germany.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Robert Jahn, Bogota, N.J., salesman, captured the men's senior title without taking a first place today in the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships. He finished second in the 880 and mile and third in the 220 to rack up 50 points.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Arne Ulland of Norway, making his first jumps in the United States, today won the forty-second annual Norge Ski Club meet with leaps of 188 and 191 feet.
Eight new films, including importations from France, Italy and Russia, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Untenanted for six weeks, the Playhouse formally receives "The Survivors" this evening. First nighters will please bear in mind that the curtain is announced to rise at 8 on the dot. Allegorical in scope, the Peter Viertel-Irwin Shaw melodrama aims to compare two turbulent eras -- the post-Civil War period with that of the present.

A program designed to help Puerto Rican immigrants adjust themselves to their new environment was proposed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. W. Stanley Rycroft, executive secretary of the Committee on Cooperation in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican leader on domestic matters and a candidate for his party's Presidential nomination, today spoke out his views on the European Recovery Program.

Murray Weinstein, vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, resigned yesterday as Bronx County chairman of the American Labor party at a meeting of the county executive committee at 1353 Edward L. Grant Highway.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The Progressive Citizens of America adopted practically without dissent today sweeping proposals for change in the nation's foreign and domestic policies. These proposals in summary are tantamount to the platform on which Henry A. Wallace's Presidential bid will be fought.

Building an early lead they refused to relinquish, the Valleyfield Braves skated to a 5-3 triumph over the New York Rovers in a Quebec Senior Hockey League struggle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
The Port of New York Authority has protested against railroad efforts to reduce carload rates on canned citrus fruit from Florida to east coast ports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Merian Cooper, partner with John Ford in Argosy productions, has announced three stories which he is preparing to produce after his current "Mr. Joseph Young of Africa." The new projects are "The Yellow Mountain," which Cooper and Ruth Rose have written; "Revenge," a story by Peter Prague, and "Mature," a story by Katherine Clifton.

WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- The Polish Government has instituted new controls over translations of foreign literature, in line with President Boleslaw Bierut's call for an "offensive along the entire cultural front" to reflect the "turning point that the nation is undergoing."

Unless church members gather to do the Lord's work when they go to church on Sunday, the church becomes no better than a social club, Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton declared yesterday in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

The first of two boxing shows slated for this week in the St. Nicholas Arena tonight will find Willie Beltram and Dennis Brady, rival Bronx lightweights, colliding in the ten-round feature. On Friday night, Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight, is to tackle Joe Curcio of Newark.

An old French friend has just see me, from Paris, a newspaper clipping taken from L'Aube of Dec. 13, 1947 Its heartfelt comment on our "Friendship Train" seems to me in the be French tradition of wit and iron. Other Americans might like to see as a sample of what the French for about this gesture of international good-will:

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- With the approval of the Swiss and French Governments, Switzerland's two largest commercial banks, the Swiss Bank Corporation and the Credit Suisse have granted in equal parts to Charbonnages de France a credit of $10,000,000 for the purchase of machinery and equipment to modernize collieries in Lorraine.

Through the cooperation of the University of Puerto Rico and New York University, a teachers' workshop will be conducted next summer in Puerto Rico in an effort to improve the educational program for Puerto Rican children in the New York metropolitan area, Ernest O. Melby, dean of the N.Y.U. School of Education, announced yesterday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 18 -- The principals in a labor dispute that has blocked delivery of 40,000 gallons of fuel oil to a distributor in near-by Collingswood, where hundreds of homes are without oil, conferred today for almost ten hours with a state mediator but reached no agreement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- An extension of rent control to June 30, 1949, without further relaxation and providing for the restoration of controls over residential hotel accommodations was proposed today by Republican Senators Irving M. Ives of New York and Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 -- A report of a special committee of the American Council of Judaism urged today that the council's fourth national conference here adopt a declaration that the nationalism of the Zionist state must be confined to the boundaries of that state and that only the United States Government represents American citizens in political matters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Foreign Agricultural Relations Department of the Department of Agriculture reported today that the Soviet Union had developed "a significant grain export program."

Jerome Connolly of Fordham, conquerors of New York University's vaunted Reginald Pearman at 1,000 yards in the meet record-equaling time of 2:14.2 last Saturday night, was voted the outstanding performer in the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field championships.

A survey by the Long Island Association reports that 1947 was a prosperous year all around for the entire Long Island area. The most outstanding phase of the "boom" is considered to be the upsurge in the building of homes; 24,974 units were erected last year as compared to 14,111 in 1946.

New York took yesterday's snowstorm in stride and by nightfall Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell reported "everything in good shape." A bright sun during the day and 8,000 workers cleared the main traffic arteries of the snowfall, officially recorded at 2.6 inches in Manhattan but measured at from 4 to 6 inches unofficially in the suburbs.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Two goals in the last period gave the Czechoslovak Olympic ice hockey team a 6-to-5 victory over the United States Amateur Hockey Association Olympic representative today in an exhibition game here.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation and its affiliate, the United States and International Securities Corporation, had a combined net asset value of $70,831,801 on Dec. 31, 1947, after eliminating United States and Foreign's investment in its affiliate, valued at about $16,594,900, according to annual reports of the corporations made public yesterday.

A recital of extraordinary musicality and insight was provided by Martial Singher, Metropolitan Opera baritone, for a good-sized audience at Town Hall, yesterday afternoon. The French artist was greeted by enthusiastic applause, which was doubled at the finish of each selection.

For the third time in recent years Canada last week gave us a free lesson on how to deal with inflation. As Washington continued its dreary and unedifying exhibition of making a political football of the issue, the Canadian Government was quietly going into action.

The New York Rangers matched goals with the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Phil Watson and Eddie Slowinski scored for the Blue Shirts and Max Bentley and Ted Kennedy accounted for a pair of tallies that brought about a 2-to-2 tie before a capacity crowd of 15,925.

For the first time since the outbreak of the war, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, is conducting a large-scale organizing drive in the metropolitan area. The drive grew out of the withdrawal of a number of dress manufacturers from the trade associations that have union shop agreements with the union and the fear that the spread of open-shop conditions would undermine union wage scales and employment opportunities.

Yehudi Menuhin was definitely in the vein at his violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall, providing his large audience with a series of performances which proved extraordinary in their skill and effectiveness. For this event the artist had arranged a program of sharply contrasted works, with Bartok's Sonata, No. 3, in G, for violin alone, and the Concerto No. 2, in F sharp minor, by Vieuxtemps, as its featured offerings.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 18 -- Miss Sue Neidlinger of Hanover swung through a wide open, 30-gate course down the lower half of the Tecumseh Trail today in 62.9 seconds to win the women's Eastern slalom skiing crown in a field of eighty contenders.

The Mayor's planning commission has recommended the building of a subway under Second Avenue and the demolition of the Third Avenue elevated line, last remnant of an engineering monstrosity. When Charles T. Harvey proposed an elevated railway in 1867 and received permission to build a cableroad on stilts from the Battery Park to Cortlandt Street there were protests enough from property owners.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Sooner or later the question of sterling devaluation in terms of dollars was certain to arise, and in the last few days it has come to the front with a rush, partly as a result of the publication of American proposals for aid under the European Recovery Program and partly because of impending talks on Anglo-French economic relations.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Good Offices Committee of the United Nations said today it would send military advisers into the field this week to confer with Dutch and Indonesian commanders on implementation of the truce ending the bitter Dutch-Indonesian warfare.

The month of February will provide a new test for both the emotions and the reason of the American people. The opportunity to save the lives of millions of children, suffering or dying in war-devastated and famine areas, will be put squarely before them with the beginning of a drive in their name. This is the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children.

Hand-glazed leather upholstery in clear vibrant colors that have not been much in evidence since before the war is the highlight of the newly decorated "House in Town" suite that reopens today at W. J. Sloane. Chairs and sofas in such shades as lipstick rose, coral, agate blue and lacquer orange lend sparkle to rooms furnished mostly with sedate antiques.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A group of prominent citizens denounced universal military training today as one more important step toward military control of American civil life.

RICHARD CRESSON HARLOW, an outstanding authority on ornithology, oology, botany and spinner-plays, has retired as football coach at Harvard and there is genuine regret at his departure along the banks of the Charles. Dick Harlow grew into the post at Cambridge as if he were hand-tailored for it and became as much a part of things at the Square as a Saltonstall, a Cabot or a Lodge.

Twenty-one applications to take children into boarding homes for foster care were received at the New York Foundling Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street at Lexington Avenue, by the close yesterday of a two-day "open house" period designed to acquaint the public with the need for more foster and adoption homes.

President Truman's address at the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner on Thursday, Feb. 19, in Washington, has been scheduled for broadcast by NBC, starting at 10 P.M. The dinner is sponsored by the Democratic National Committee.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Reports from Jewish sources claimed tonight that Abdul Khada el-Husseini, commander of the Arab forces in the Jerusalem district and kinsman of the Mufti, had been wounded in an attack on the Hertif Jewish settlement west of Jerusalem.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- A proposal for a $2,000,000,000 project that would completely utilize the waters of the Nile and double Egypt's arable land was announced yesterday by A. Daninos, one of this country's foremost engineers. He contemplates construction of a dam and reservoir that will have four times the capacity of Boulder Dam.

Irregular net changes characterized a dull week in cotton trading with moderately easier prices throughout the session. Active futures contracts at the close of trading on Saturday registered a net decline of 24 to a gain of 9 points, compared with a drop of 19 points to a gain of 14 at the close of the previous week.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) Carding a one-under-par 71 on his final round, E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., annexed the $10,000 Richmond golf tournament today with a seventy-two-hole total of 273.

Unforgettable memories of great moments in the theatre passed in review last night at the Ziegfeld Theatre, where the "American National Theatre Album" was presented, to promote the nation-wide work of the American National Theatre and Academy, a non-profit organization which holds a Federal charter.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 18 -- Dutch foreign trade figures for 1947, although displaying a marked increase over the previous year, nevertheless are not fully satisfactory because of the large surplus of imports. Imports were 4,256,000,000 guilders and exports were 1,860,000,000, leaving an adverse balance of 2,396,000,000.

After eliminating Charles Brinton, the national champion, in the semi-finals, A.C. Ingraharm of the home club encountered stern opposition and bowed to S.W. Pearson Jr. of the Philadelphia Cricket Club as play in the Harry Cowles squash racquets tournament came to a close at the Harvard Club yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 18 -- The United Nations plans to ask the fifty-seven member nations to send at least one student each to Lake Success this summer to work as internes, or unpaid members of the Secretariat, it was learned today.

Handy Harman's thirty-second annual review of the silver market, issued today, said that relatively stable market conditions may be expected to continue, under the assumption that demand for silver from the arts and industries will remain about present high levels and that the Bank of Mexico will continue to buy silver under the new coinage program there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Despite steadily rising prices buyers last year pushed the nation's retail store sales up to a record $118,000,000,000, an $18,000,000,000 increase over 1946, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Currency notes continue to pour back into the Bank of England at a record rate. In the last reported week nearly 25,000,000 was returned, making a total of 62,000,000 since Christmas, against less than 43,000,000 in the same period a year ago.
The Harlem community was asked yesterday to shoulder a larger measure of social responsibility by the Rev. James H. Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master, 86 Morningside Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A year-end tabulation of television and radio receiver production, including FM, by member companies in 1947, showed a record total for the industry of 17,695,677, the Radio Manufacturers Association reported today.

"All the King's Men," a novel about a cracker dictator whose resemblance to Huey Long was not coincidental, won the Pulitzer Prize for Robert Penn Warren in 1947. The book had its beginnings in play form; now Mr. Warren has reworked the material of the novel, drawn on the original play and turned out a dramatization that the Dramatic Workshop of the New School is displaying these evenings at the President Theatre.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 18 -- With historic documents from state and local archives serving as a back drop, Montclair Freedom Week opened this afternoon at the Montclair High School with a special program of rededication to democratic ideals and the American heritage.
Howard J. Warnken has been promoted from assistant treasurer to assistant to the president of American Type Founders, Inc., Elizabeth, N.J.

British wool cloth manufacturers have been warned that the American public has about reached the limit of clothing price rises and that fabrics which they hoped to sell in this market must therefore be priced "right," according to the report of the wool textile mission which visited the United States last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- An Army C-47 transport plane crashed into the roof of a supply building while taking off at near-by Andrews Field, Md., today, killing the pilot and seriously injuring three other occupants.

It is distressing to learn from Palisades Interstate Park officials that an estimated 75 per cent of the deer in the 40,000-acre Bear Mountain portion of the park and adjacent Rockland County forests will die within the next few weeks unless they are fed and protected from dog packs.

A thorough overhauling of the Police and Fire Departments to increase efficiency and save $8,000,000 a year was recommended yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission in the third section of the report on its recent survey of five city departments.

Tolerance and conviction are essential to democracy, Dr. Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, declared yesterday morning at the service of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Grain prices continued to advance last week with all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and soybeans selling at new seasonal peak prices except May wheat and December corn, with overall records established on May and cash corn, oats, soybean futures and the cash article.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee today sought the counsel of several prominent lawyers and men with long experience in public life in drafting curbs on communism.

Buyers shopping for spring and early summer goods in the New York wholesale markets last week spurred activity considerably, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Preparing dinner so that all the foods are ready to serve at the right moment is one of those homemaking tasks that beginners in cooking find particularly difficult to master (it's a problem for many experienced housekeepers, too).

ATHENS, Jan. 18 -- One of the biggest battles yet fought between Greek Regular Army forces and guerrillas on territory not adjoining the frontier is taking place now in the Naupactus (Lepanto) area north of the Gulf of Corinth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Republican national committeemen were gathering tonight from all the states in high optimism that their party would elect the President this year, but with each faction asserting that its man would win.

Eleven members of the "official" United States Olympic hockey squad left New York last night via an American Overseas Air Lines plane for the fifth Olympic Winter Games starting Jan. 30 at St. Moritz, Switzerland. Heading the party was Jack Hutchinson, team manager and Olympic hockey chairman.

Approximately twenty-five art exhibitions have been announced this week by local galleries. Today's openings include recent paintings by Elsie Driggs at the Artists' Gallery; water-colors by Sandy Sutherland at the Village Art Center; paintings by Alexandra Pregel at the Milch Gallery; sculpture by Glen Chamberlain at the Clay Club, and oils and water-colors by Emeline Hayward North at the Salpeter Gallery.

EAST WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- In a blustery wind suited more to kite-flying than skiing, Walter Brostek of the Edelweiss Ski Club, Greenfield, Mass., won the Westchester County jumping championship on the Norswift Club's 50-meter hill at Silver Lake today.

Two ways of making peace were on trial yesterday. In New Delhi an emaciated little man asked for a glass of lime juice and drank it. He had been without food for nearly 122 hours. Ave Gandhi, the granddaughter of his brother, "laughing but near tears," ran down the hallway past the waiting reporters, calling out in Hindustani, "The fast is broken."

Consumer acceptance of new ideas in food pre-packaging will govern the direction of currently-manifested moves to extend this marketing technique in supermarkets, a spokesman for the Atlantic Commission Company, produce buying affiliate of the A P Food Stores, said last week.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Five British automobile manufacturers plan to invade the United States market on a large scale for the first time. At least two intend to compete permanently with American manufacturers on their own ground.

Acting as individuals rather than as members of any organization or pressure group, thirty-four well-known New York women, including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, sent a telegram yesterday to Governor Dewey urging continued financial support from the state for children's day care here.

NANKING, Jan. 18 -- After a series of anti-British demonstrations in which the British Consulate at Canton was burned to the ground, the Control Yuan issued a communique today urging the Government to press for the return of Hong Kong and Kowloon to China.

The Political Action Committee for Palestine announced yesterday that it had sent an open letter to President Truman urging him to "stop the murder of innocent people" in Palestine and to "prevent the outbreak of another war."
Air-conditioned automobiles, said our visitor, soon will be commonplace, and as a result we all will be wearing transparent head coverings, akin to diving helmets, when we walk in the street.

Fifteen hundred members of New York Typographical Union No. 6, AFL, voted yesterday to approve Mayor O'Dwyer's request that they remain at work pending negotiations for a new agreement to cover 4,000 printers in book, magazine and job printing shops in this city.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, who broke his fast at 12:30 P.M. today after 121 hours, did so when he apparently was convinced that it had achieved its purpose of improving communal harmony.

The American President Lines will send off its first authentic post-war contingent of cruise passengers next month on the second sailing of the new liner President Cleveland. Officials of the company in New York said final figures on the coming voyage were not available, but that it would mark the turning of the line from exclusively commercial traffic to cruise customers.

As the great debate over the European Recovery Program proceeds, not only in Congress but throughout the watching world, this project is being subjected to the fire of criticism and suspicion from two opposite sides, with the anomalous result that the American Government is being compelled to defend it on two fronts.

Uncertainty over the final form of proposed allocation and rationing of such basic commodities as oil, steel, coal, lumber and textiles is dislocating and holding up many large 1948 advertising campaigns originally planned to promote expanded sales programs, it was learned in a check of agencies last week.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The French party line-ups came out substantially unchanged in what was regarded as a test election today in the suburban municipality of Malakoff.

Mrs. William Marston Seabury, chairman of the New York women's division of the Committee for the Marshall Plan to Aid European Recovery, 537 Fifth Avenue, said yesterday that the committee sought signatures to a petition to Congress urging prompt action on an European Recovery Program along the lines suggested by Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

The right to elect representatives in place of appointed delegates to the United Nations should be sought by the people of all nations, Hilda Yatsing Yen, public liaison officer of the department of public information of the United Nations, declared yesterday.

A disparity between the budget requests of the Board of Education and the standards set by the high school committee of the United Parents Associations, particularly in guidance counseling and remedial work, was pointed out yesterday by the latter.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The British Government has decided that the controversial post-war airliner Tudor I, rejected last April by the state-owned British Overseas Airways Corporation as unsuitable and uneconomic, is to be used if final tests to be held over the coming weeks are successful.
Moshe Shertok, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted yesterday that the "authority of the United Nations must operate on the spot in Palestine."

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, announced plans yesterday for expansion of the university. Before seventy-five members of the Fordham Alumni Sodality, Father Gannon said that in addition to the $200,000 project for rebuilding the college chapel as a memorial to Fordham's World War II dead, the university intended to remodel Duane library to make room for fifty-four thousand more volumes.

THE summer of 1787 was the hottest in many years. For four months, with the exceptions of Sundays and a ten-day adjournment, a small group of men dressed in the stiff, formal clothes of the period gathered for five to ten hours a day in the State House in Philadelphia. There they argued and debated, compromised and denounced, persuaded and orated, while sentries paraded outside to make sure that their deliberations were kept secret.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 -- In spite of the current shortage of scrap metals, the steel industry last week pushed its operating rate up 1/2 point to 98 1/2 per cent of the theoretical capacity of 1947. On the basis of the new 1948 capacity, which amounts to about 94,200,000 tons a year, activity last week was about 96 per cent of capacity.

A $60,000,000, five-year construction program for Young Men's Christian Associations throughout the country was outlined here yesterday by John W. Ogg, senior secretary of the organization's building and furnishings service.

Individual tenants and spokesmen for tenant, civic and consumer organizations will appear today before the City Rent Advisory Committee to detail their objections to any blanket increase in rentals of the 1,600,000 dwellings here that are under Federal rent control.

The preservation of liberty and civic rights in this country is related to the maintenance of free and democratic government in western Europe, speakers asserted last night in a symposium at the closing session of the forty-first annual meeting of the American Jewish Committee, held in the Hotel Commodore.

An anthology dealing with music as a therapeutic agent in hospitals and mental institutions will be issued by Henry Schuman on Feb. 25 under the title "Music and Medicine." The volume contains sixteen essays by experts in the field.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- James R. Kitts, the drawling Texan who became head football coach at Virginia Polytechnic Institute here in 1941, resigned that post today because of what he termed "misfortunate happenings that occurred last year."

Events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Alexander Uninsky, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor, Joseph Szigeti, violin, Town Hall, 8:30; Musicians Guild, Kroll Quartet, Leo Smit, piano, Carleton Sprague Smith, flute, Attilio Poto, clarinet, Nell Tangeman, mezzo-soprano, Times Hall, 8:45; Budapest String Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40; The Byzantine Singers, Christos Vrionides, conductor, Community House, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue, 8.

A 55-year-old practical nurse was near death in Beth David Hospital last night, the victim, the police said, of a bullet fired late Saturday night by two 'teen-age schoolboys practicing with a .22-caliber automatic pistol on an Upper East Side tenement house roof.

Mayor Israel Rokach of Tel Aviv, speaking at a meeting of the national executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America, appealed yesterday for the lifting of the embargo on arms to Palestine. He expressed the hope that the British Government would open the port of Tel Aviv to permit increased immigration and receipt of supplies required for economic needs and national defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The issue of placing military men in civil positions headed for a showdown today after President Truman invited the Congressional Armed Services Committees to the White House over the controversial chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee today cleared for House action this week a measure allowing the Government to sell $250,000,000 worth of seized German and Japanese property in this country and give part of the proceeds to civilian war victims.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The "Duesseldorf plan," on the basis of which strikers in the Ruhr returned to their jobs last week, appeared to have fallen through today. The Bavarians balked at sharing their fat rations with the Ruhr workers, and the British and United States authorities decided to refuse the extra sugar rations requested by the German bizonal authorities.

Two teen-age schoolboys, arrested on Sunday after they unwittingly had wounded a 55-year-old nurse while practicing with a 22-caliber pistol on a tenement roof, confessed yesterday to having taken part in twenty-five recent apartment house robberies on the upper East Side, the police of the East Sixty-seventh Street station announced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, said today that he had appointed ten new members to the National Petroleum Council, an oil-gas industry group which advises the Federal Government. The council will hold its first 1948 meeting on Thursday.

The cotton futures market closed 7 to 26 points lower yesterday, with near months showing the most weakness. March cotton came in for considerable liquidation, although it closed 4 points under May, compared with 5 points on Saturday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The first three choices in today's fifth dash, one of two six-furlong features at Hialeah Park, obliged by finishing as their odds indicated -- the order being Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Music, Jule Fink's Royal Lover, and L. J. Hollenbach's Roi Rouge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The proposals of Mr. Baruch and Senator Taft to give the director of the European Recovery Program full control of its actual operation and its staff help further to assure that Congress will reject the effort of the Bureau of the Budget and the State Department to make this official -- to be known as the Economic Cooperation Administrator -- a mere subordinate of that department.
ROME, Jan. 19 -- The twenty-sixth national congress of the Italian Socialist party opened here this morning with about 600 delegates and ten foreign delegations present.

Bernard M. Baruch is invariably an inspiring figure when he appears to present his views on a public issue, and his appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday in behalf of the Marshall Plan was no exception to the rule. His plea for support of the European Aid Program was pitched on a high moral and patriotic plane and was studded with typically Baruchian phrases.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 18 (Delayed) -- Chinese Government troops are not planning to abandon all the places in Manchuria that they now hold north of Mukden, Gen. Lo Tso-ying, deputy commander of the Government's North-east Forces, said in an interview here today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The Palestine Arab Higher Committee curtly informed the United Nations today that it was determined to reject partition and anything connected with it.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Howard Greer's custom collection, augmented by his own ready-to-wear spring and summer fashions, features princess effects. Soft afternoon dresses, silk prints with jackets and just-above-the-ankle dinner dresses express the summer mood of simplicity.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Francis L. Whitmarsh, New York, president of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, today denounced current agitation for Government price control, declaring that such a program will not correct our current inflated position.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The office of the chief of Jewish mobilization announced tonight that all Jewish men and women in Palestine between 25 and 40 would be enrolled in defense work by Feb. 1.

Three hundred handicapped persons received job training and employment last year in fourteen different work classifications through Good-will Industries of New York, it was announced yesterday. These statistics were presented at the Ritz Tower, where the women's division of the organization held the first meeting of its $150,000 fundraising drive.

New York's Knickerbockers played before their biggest crowd last night in Madison Square Garden -- the attendance of 17,537 also was a record for the Basketball Association of America -- but they disappointed nearly all of the customers.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 -- The release of gold held by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to the Greek Government to back Greece's Economy has been arranged by the American Mission for Aid to Greece, Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the mission, announecd today.

On Jan. 10 THE NEW YORK TIMES published an editorial calling on Mayor William O'Dwyer to recite chapter and verse to the state where the city needs its aid. The Mayor has shown that he is fully able to justify in detail his requests to the state, and I am not presuming to speak for him.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Two of the most colorful personalities in the United Nations, Dr. Charles H. Malik of Lebanon and Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz of Chile, appeared today as the most likely rival candidates in the forthcoming election for the Presidency of the Economic and Social Council.

Lavern Roach's next opponent will be Marcel Cerdan, FrenchMoroccan middleweight who holds the European championship. They will clash for ten rounds in Madison Square Garden on March 12, it present plans materialize.

Fred Livingston, arbitrator, announced last night completion of arbitration hearings involving the National Maritime Union, CIO, and Atlantic and Gulf ship owners and operators. The NMU is seeking a 25 per cent cost-of-living increase for its claimed membership of 90,000 seamen.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- New York State's birth rate in November continued the decline that started last September, H. E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, reported today. Nevertheless, the number of births for the first eleven months of 1947 reached a record total of 300,000.

Promptness of collections in Latin America for United States exports improved slightly in December, marking the first gain since May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The Bank's data were based upon figures from twelve large New York banks.

On Dec. 11 you printed a letter from me in which I contended that corporate profits since 1939 show greater gains than do wages. In an editorial reply printed that same day you refuted my line of reasoning and quoted figures-10 establish precisely the opposite conclusion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The National Football League's greatest passing team today hired one of the nation's finest passers.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- The Government of India has placed an immediate ban on all raw cotton exports except certain specified low grade varieties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Countess Marianna von Moltke is entitled to a new trial to determine whether she was justly sentenced to serve four years in prison as part of a Nazi spy group in Detroit, the Supreme Court ruled by six to three today.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan 19 -- Over the objections of Senator Albert W. Hawkes, a group of leading New Jersey Republicans tonight gave unanimous endorsement to State Senator David Van Alstyne Jr of Engelwood, who is expected to seek the United States Senatorial nominations in the spring primary.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Bernard M. Baruch finally said in public today what astute students of world politics and economics have been saying in private for quite a while.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A witness for the American Federation of Labor International Typographical Union tied the union's demand for a sixty-day cancellation clause to its policy of maintaining closed shop conditions for the first time today in the unfair labor practice hearings before a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee has voted, 68 to 6, to withdraw all American teams from the winter games at St. Moritz, Jan. 30-Feb. 8, if the Amateur Hockey Association's much-disputed entry is permitted to compete.

New York registered the coldest temperature of the winter -- 7.2 above zero -- at 7:45 A. M. yesterday, but the Weather Bureau predicted warmer weather today. Yesterday's highest temperature was 24 degrees at 4:10 P. M.
A city-wide parking ban for all but essential service vehicles whenever two inches of snow fall here or a great emergency occurs was recommended yesterday by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway decided yesterday to sell to bankers an issue of $8,280,000 of one-to-fifteen-year equipment trust certificates in preference to $8,840,000 of one-to-ten-year certificates. Award was made to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., whose bids were high for the certificate issue on either basis.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Dr. Diego Luis Molinari, Argentine trade expert, said today that Argentina planned to establish a big export center in the United States free-trade zone near New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States has made no effort to take part in combined British-Australian experiments with rocket weapons, it was said today by John Dedman, Australian Minister of Defense and Post-War Reconstruction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman requested Congress today to transfer the United States Employment Service and the Bureau of Employment Security to the Labor Department.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club yesterday announced a program of fifteen stakes for its 39-day meeting, first of the New York turf campaign, which will open at the Jamaica track April and continue though May 15.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Miss Dodie Post of Reno, Nev., 24-year-old captain of the United States women's Olympic ski team, broke the small bone in her left leg today while leading her seven team-mates in training on the downhill course near here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed in December totaled 753,406 bales of lint and 101,645 bales of linters.

HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- On the assumption that the proposed International Trade Organization will be set up here, it was tentatively agreed today to establish an interim commission to prepare for the first ITO conference. The decision was made on the first reading by a working party chosen for this purpose by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and, with stop loss orders uncovered, the close was about the bottom.
