Wheat futures fell 4 3/4 to 6 1/4 cents a bushel and corn 1 1/2 to 4 cents the spread between May corn and wheat narrowing to 33 1/4 cents at the close compared with 42 cents a month ago.

Sooner or later that D'Oyly Carte crew was bound to put to sea in the saucy craft known as "H.M.S. Pinafore" and for loyal Savoyards it was only a matter of waiting. Last night the launching took place at the Century Theatre and, as might have been expected, it was a gay launching, indeed.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Regular army troops arrived in the provincial capital of Cucuta in seven transport planes today and moved immediately into the strife-torn areas of Santander del Norte Province where Conservative and Liberal party members had been battling each other for the last week.

The money market was easier yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1/4 of one per cent compared with 1/4 to 3/8 of one per cent on Friday. The member banks here which reported excess reserves of $385,000,000 on Wednesday night, subsequently invested a large part of this total and lost some funds in transfers and income tax collections, although the two latter items were small elements in the situation, it was learned.

Police Commissioner Wallander's view, as expressed to a joint legislative committee, is that traffic in midtown Manhattan is "fluid," that the police are dealing effectively with traffic and parking, and that the Mayor's special traffic committee is "contributing steadily to curbing congestion and if left alone can and will do the job ably."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Grave concern is felt in the highest military quarters over the strategic oil shortage and the possibility of a loss or interruption to this country of the heavy flow from the Near East, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, told Congress in substance today.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Local elections in three widely separated French Departments showed losses for the Communist party, with corresponding gains for the de Gaullists and some Center candidates, according to returns that became known today.

Mayor O'Dwyer contributed yesterday to the March of Dimes campaign when he received 3-year-old Terry Tullos, the "March of Dimes Poster Boy," at City Hall. The Mayor also aided the Salvation Army, which is seeking $1,000,000 in the city.

A concern that has specialized in rug cleaning and repair since 1863, T. M. Stewart, Inc., officially opened its first retail showroom yesterday at 16 East Forty-ninth Street, in the store formerly occupied by Artek-Pascoe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, raised a new and unexpected objection to Republican tax-reduction plans today with the contention that it would be economically "dangerous" at present to divert more capital into private investment.

Praise was mingled with criticism yesterday when spokesmen for fifty-five teacher, parent and civic organizations told the Board of Education how it could improve its record budget estimate of $208,965,145 proposed for the New York public schools in 1948-49.

Senator Taft has gone out on a long and brittle limb in at least two of the statements he made in his radio broadcast on the ERP. First, he said that "the Marshall Plan in effect proposes that we increase our exports to Europe by about $3,000,000,000 during the next twelve months."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three independent directors of Missouri Pacific Railroad Company today asked that the road be permitted to liquidate its debts by direct agreements with creditors and stockholders.

A mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair during the week of Feb. 23 was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan on three men who had been convicted of the shooting on Jan. 8, 1947, of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- India and Pakistan agreed today to submit their quarrels -- which both sides have warned may flare into war -- to a three-member mediation and investigation board of the United Nations.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York has done well to emphasize again the need for a revised approach to hospital planning made necessary by changing age patterns of patients. Because our life span curve is now upward, the greatest need in general hospitals is found to be beds to serve persons in the second half of life.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union turned down an invitation today to send administrative experts here to give their opinions on the best structure of the proposed international agency for the control of atomic energy.

While Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle rested on his statement yesterday that the Citizens Budget Commission report on the Fire Department was "untrue and erroneous," Harold Riegelman, counsel for the commission, insisted that the responsbility for correcting "the waste of millions of dollars in the department" rested with the Fire Commissioner.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- A flare-up in oil shares was the feature of an otherwise quiet stock market here today. The activity was laid to the belief that Foreign Secretary Bevin would refer to "safeguarding of British oil interests" in his foreign affairs speech to the House of Commons this week.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 -- This capital, which was already strangely quiet in the midsummer heat with thousands of its inhabitants at resorts, has become even quieter within the past few days. The police have closed down more than forty-five bars and confiterias, which are a kind of elaborate confectionery, for overcharging for non-alcoholic drinks.

Announcement was made yesterday of the election of Richard E. Dougherty, vice president of the New York Central System, as president of the American Society of Civil Engineers for 1948. The four-day annual meeting, which 2,500 persons are expected to attend, will open tomorrow at the Commodore Hotel.

Dennis (Pat) Brady, Hartford, Conn., lightweight, won a unanimous decision over Willie Beltram of the Bronx in the feature tenround bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Ruby Goldstein scored it 6 -- 3 --1 while Judge Agnello tabbed it 6--4.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 6 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks sales were up 4 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The long-standing conflict between life insurance companies and savings banks, arising out of the entry of savings banks into the life insurance field ten years ago, has been reconciled.

The State Board of Social Welfare Committee investigating the city's relief administration is holding private hearings on the extent to which the left-wing United Public Workers Union, CIO, influences the supervisory personnel of the Department of Welfare, Henry Root Stern, chairman of the board, said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 19 -- Urging capital and labor to cooperate in combating inflation, Emil Rutz, Sunnyvale, Calif., retiring president of the National Canners Association, today termed full production the nation's best safeguard against spiraling prices.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey advised a Communist Daily Worker reporter tonight to "go find a soap box."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Federal Trade Commission's thirty-third annual report was submitted to Congress today and for the first time it contained minority recommendations. They urged, among other things, that trade practice conference procedure and rules be given a "clear statutory basis" and that the chairman be designated by the President.

Mayor O'Dwyer was told yesterday that efforts to arbitrate between Harlem merchants and community groups had collapsed, and that the situation created by repeated picketing and statements charging 125th Street merchants with unfair business practices and job discrimination had reached "serious proportions."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Radio network executives indicated strongly today that if their contracts with the American Federation of Musicians lapsed at the end of this month, they would use the Taft-Hartley Law to test the union's right to restrict the use of musicians on television, FM and transcription broadcasts.
Heavy bookings for liners operating on the North Atlantic during the coming summer season were indicated yesterday in reports from the local offices of three major operators.

Two hundred and seventy-seven contributions amounting to $676 were received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES for its Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, increasing the total of the thirty-sixth annual appeal to $358,513.46.
John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, reported yesterday on a three-month visit to India.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Player contracts carrying bonus clauses based on outstanding performance were outlawed today in America's 56 minor baseball leagues.
The United States liner Washington arrived here yesterday from Newport News where she was reconverted recently for North Atlantic passenger service after wartime duty as a troopship.

A. Terry Fahye, president of the Consolidated Steel Mills Company and allegedly the central figure behind an abortive attempt to gain control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation, was arrested yesterday on order of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Republic announced today the purchase of "Police State," a screen story by Martin Van Laas, described by the studio as a romantic melodrama laid in an imaginary country in occupied Europe. Al Demond has been assigned to write the photoplay, which will fit into the screen's anti-Communist ideological cycle.

" The Economic Reports of the President" is issued today by Reynal Hitchcock. The book contains the full text of the three reports thus far issued by the President, five days after the most recent one was transmitted to the Congress. It has an introduction by the Council of Economic Advisers.

Crawford H. Greenewalt yesterday became the tenth president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., succeeding Walter S. Carpenter Jr., who was elevated to chairman of the board, following the retirement of Lammot du Pont from the latter post.

CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- A Royal Air Force airplane returning to Cairo from Palestine was hit by more than a score of bullets fired by an Egyptian Spitfire that intercepted it while flying over the "prohibited" area of El Arish near the coast of the Sinai peninsula, it was disclosed today.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine said today that sixty-five Americans attending school in Palestine under the GI Bill of Rights had enlisted in the Haganah.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Oklahoma State Regents for Higher Education today established a Negro School of Law in Oklahoma City as a branch of Langston Negro University, but a Negro leader said immediately that there would be "no acceptance of a Jim Crow law school."

Alexander Uninsky, Russian pianist, who has given a Carnegie Hall recital each season since his debut five years ago, made his annual appearance there last night. He confined his program to five composers -- Scarlatti, Beethoven, Chopin, Debussy and Stravinsky.

Tenants' spokesmen yesterday countered the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee's request for a "modest 15 per cent" rent increase with a request for a "modest per cent decrease" in rentals on 1,600,000 Federally controlled dwellings in this city and Long Island.

Gene Martel, elected president of the Screen Directors Guild at the organization's third annual convention at the Hotel Astor on Saturday, yesterday promised to continue the policy of raising the standard of entertainment films, as well as of those of other types.

New York University's highflying quintet once again will put its unbeaten record in jeopardy tonight when it meets Colgate's Red Raiders in the opening contest of a collegiate twin bill. In the afterpiece, Western Kentucky, rated as one of the nation's top units, will clash with L. I. U. The doubleheader will be the last at the Garden until Feb. 17.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 19 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's five-day fast is generally considered here to have lightened the tension between the Dominions of India and Pakistan and to have lessened the talk of war.
Opening its promised inquiry into Long Island Rail Road operations during the big snow last mouth, the Public Service Commission found itself yesterday under heavy commuter fire.

Declaring that the city's Zoning Resolution adopted in 1916 is obsolete in many respects, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, announced yesterday that his agency had taken preliminary steps to bring it up to date.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- Four members of the Stern Gang who survived a fight with the police and troops at Raanana on Nov. 12 were sentenced today to life imprisonment in the first terrorist trial since the partition of Palestine was recommended by the United Nations.

Proof of the role that the Metropolitan Museum of Art plays in adult education was given yesterday by the attendance figure of 2,168,870 for 1947, contained in the annual report of Roland L. Redmond, president of the institution. Mr. Redmond's report was made at the annual meeting of the museum's corporation, and was his first since he took office last March.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 19 -- Though his desk was literally buried under a "snow slide" of correspondence, Gov. Ernest William Gibson of Vermont, who hails from Brattleboro, one of the pioneer skiing communities of this country, wasted little tinge in welcoming a fellow skier.

Leslie MacMitchell, former holder of the national mile championship, will undertake a big job this week-end when he will compete in two major indoor track meets. The former New York University star will run the mile in The Philadelphia Inquirer games on Friday in Convention Hall and the next night he will participate in the Boston K. of C. games in the Boston Garden.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 19 -- The Turkish Government holds that the United States State Department has overestimated the country's financial ability in its appraisal of the needs of nations participating in the European Recovery Program.

Prospects were bright yesterday for extending the run of "Crime and Punishment," starring John Gielgud, three weeks beyond the announced closing date of Saturday, Jan. 24. The production, in difficulties because of a large overhead ($19,500), has obtained promises of concessions from the National Theatre, where it is now installed, members of the acting company and the author.

D-F-S Again Heads Radio List Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., announced yesterday that it again has topped the list of agencies making the highest annual gross radio time network expenditures in 1947 with a billing of $21,155,292. The achievement marks D-F-S's fourteenth year as the top radio agency.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The first of many bills expected at the current session of the Legislature to provide a new salary figure for Assemblymen and Senators was introduced tonight by Assemblyman John J. De Pasquale, Bronx Republican, and Senator Fred G. Moritt, Brooklyn Democrat.

Our city scout has been having another look at Fifth Avenue -- starting at his favorite spot, the Plaza, and taking in the prospect of the Park, which at the moment of his inspection had just got spread over its wintry blanket -- gone a bit dingy -- a fresh sheet of snow, dazzling white in the morning sunshine.

Reflecting a new high record of sales, earnings of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last October were the largest in its history, increasing 68 per cent over the previous peak attained in the preceding fical year, Benjamin Abrams, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The United Nations Commission on the Status of Women completed its second annual session here today, issuing recommendations for the advancement of women in all fields.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The registration of men and women not "gainfully employed" began in Britain today. As a result of the registration the Government expects to add some thousands of workers to productive payrolls under its employment order that can compel idlers to work.

A shabby old man who had lived alone amid a pile of junk in an East Side tenement flat left an estate of more than $50,000 to the State of New York, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday.
A flurry developed yesterday after an excited observer reported that ammunition, apparently destined for Arab use, was being loaded aboard a freighter at Jersey City.

A $10,000 scholarship program offering prizes to art students throughout the country was announced yesterday by the Society of Illustrators at a luncheon in the society's clubrooms, 128 East Sixty-third Street.

Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger announced yesterday what he had suspended two attendants at the Traffic Court in Stapleton, S. I. He said an investigation had disclosed that many persons reported paying larger fines than had been recorded on the court's books.

A protest against the policy of dismantling Germar industrial plants was advanced yesterday by Common Cause, Inc., in the form of a twenty-one page pamphlet discussing the political and economic aspects of the problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The meeting of New Jersey Republican leaders at Trenton tonight to select a party candidate for the United States Senate drew hot protest today from Representative Charles A. Eaton of that state, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Unemployed football coaches have at least fourteen college and professional jobs to shoot for including those at such major schools as Navy, Yale, Harvard, West Virginia, Auburn and Colorado, The Associated Press reports.

A drop yesterday of 1 1/2 cents a pound in the wholesale prices of the two top grades of butter brought hope to housewives that an increase of a half cent in the price of milk, which had been threatened for Feb. 1, might be averted.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 -- The American-born Clarence D. Howe has been named Canadian Minister of Trade and Commerce at a moment when the Geneva agreements and the Canadian import restriction program have in different ways affected normal trade relations across the United States border.

Indicating stronger emphasis by the Foreign Trade Administration on price criteria, licenses for imports of certain products into Greece have been offered if 5 to 10 per cent price reductions on total amounts of the respective orders were made, it was reported here yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, British amateur golf champion, won medalist honors today as a field of sixty-two posted qualifying scores in the fortieth tournament of the Winter Golf League of advertising interests.

Flash selling engulfed the stock market shortly after midday yesterday and produced one of the severest reversals of the new year. Offerings of rails and oils, augmented by sales in the steel section, caused extreme losses of 3 points during the liquidation, although timid bidding during the later trading reduced losses by about half.

The owner of a good bird dog who exhibits reasonable pride in the ability of the animal is merely conforming to the standard, but the man who brags about his friend's dog is the kind of sportsman you don't meet on every corner.

Chamber music to warm the most obdurate heart was presented in the Musicians' Guild concert, the second of a series of four, at Times Hall, last night. The characteristic program contained two classical works by Mozart and Haydn, one Romantic by Faure and one modern by Hindemith, and the large audience consumed every note with all indications of pleasure.

Being dramatists first and reformers second, Peter Viertel and Irwin Shaw have written a rattling good play with a meaning. It is "The Survivors," which was played with gusto at the Playhouse last evening. The authors are demonstrating the futility of killing. But instead of presenting it as a political argument, they have embodied it in a rousing gun drama laid in Missouri after the Civil War.

" Furia" ("Fury"), an Italian-made drama, will have its local premiere tonight at the Rialto. Rossano Brazzi is starred in the offering, with Isa Pola, Gino Cervi, Umbarto Pararo and Adriana Benetti among the supporting players. Goffredo Alessandrini directed the production, which is being presented by Westport-International Films and released by Film Classics.

The first National Lingerie and Negligee show drew several thousand visitors including numerous local and out-of-town buyers to the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, yesterday. Each of the participating 110 manufacturers of women's slips, nightgowns, housecoats and other intimate apparel, featured spring numbers.

NOW that another generation of young writers who went to the wars too young and returned from them too old has begun its own series of fictional self-examinations the long shadow of Ernest Hemingway seems to stretch even farther across modern American literature. The precedent he established for post-war fiction was technically brilliant rather than enduringly enlightening.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Details concerning the alleged existence in France of three secret anti-Communist groups headed by a "directory" with headquarters "near Lucerne" in Switzerland were given today by France-Presse, the semi-official French news agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A sixty-member United States Committee for the International Children's Emergency Fund was organized in the East Room of the White House today. Its first task will be seeking of gifts to the American Overseas Aid -- United Nations Appeal for Children. Mrs. Oswald Lord of New York, was elected chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- By a vote of 6 to 3, the Supreme Court today prevented California from barring ownership of land by Fred Oyama, a minor American citizen, whose Japanese father, Kajiro Oyama, paid the purchase price for the tracts.
TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- Black market money rates ranging from 15 to 30 per cent a month rule throughout Japan, according to a survey by the Hypothec Bank of Japan.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- James M. Symes, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was elected a director of the Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trusts at the 135th annual stockholders meeting today.

In extension of the CBS plan for "mood programming," on Tuesday nights, that network will offer a succession of dramatic shows, beginning Feb. 3, when "Christopher Wells" will be transferred to the 9:30 P. M. slot from its present Sunday evening hour at 10 o'clock.

NANKING, Jan. 19 -- Although the United States State Department has publicly sketched a Chinese aid program based on commodity credits, China is eager to have 50 per cent of the program used as American dollar backing for currency reform here, it was learned today.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Jan. 19 -- The Holyoke Municipal and Electric Department's application for further development of the Connecticut River's power resources "promises to open up all of New England to public power," according to Attorney Willard W. Gatchell, chief counsel for the Federal Power Commission.
The city's housing problem for fish may be closer to solution now than it ever has been since the old Aquarium at the Battery went the way of Castle Garden about seven years ago.

PRAGUE, Jan. 19 -- Moscow has denied to Georgi Dimitrov, Communist chief of the Bulgarian Government, support for his demand that Czechoslovakia sign a defense alliance against all eventual "aggressors," according to information available here.

One southpaw and two right-handed pitchers were announced yesterday by the Yankees as having signed their 1948 contracts, bringing the total now enlisted under the George Weiss banner to seventeen -- still two behind the Giants, who rested on this lead and announced no signings at all.

Commercial Cables and Mackay Radio laid the basis yesterday for breaking off collective-bargaining relations with the American Communications Association, CIO, which called a strike against the two companies nineteen days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Congress approved today and sent to the White House a bill giving the sanction of permanent law to the State Department's foreign information program and forecasting a great increase in its volume to rebut the propaganda of the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Canada, the United States, Argentina and South Africa will continue major targets of British exports in the coming years regardless of any European Recovery Program, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told a press conference today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 19 -- Six German defense attorneys who spent the week-end in jail here were released today on their own recognizance, pending a decision by the International Military Tribunal, after a hearing into the incident that led to their being held on contempt of court charges.

State Superintendent of Insurance Robert E. Dineen urged yesterday that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation be re-empowered to aid distressed insurance companies through the medium of purchases of or loans on preferred stocks.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 -- Declaring "our allegiance to the United States is single, indivisible and exclusive," the American Council for Judaism set itself against involvements with the political destiny of the "Zionist State" to be established by the United Nations decision to partition Palestine.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Free, competing markets have enabled the country's farmers to achieve the big crop production necessary for the requirements of the American people, Richard F. Uhlmann asserted today after he was installed as president of the Chicago Board of Trade at the annual meeting.

The New York University College of Engineering, in an effort to provide additional space needed for veterans studying engineering, has acquired, through the Federal Works Agency, a building constructed during the war for the Navy, Dean Thorndike Saville announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- With his face screwed up in an impish grin, former Prime Minister Winston Churchill, looking fit and well, stepped from a Dakota airplane at Northolt Airport here this afternoon after his holiday at Marrakesh, Morocco, where he had worked on his memoirs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The main issues that will be debated at the forthcoming International Maritime Conference in Geneva are taking shape as comments flow in from governments to the United Nations regarding a draft constitution for the proposed international shipping organization.

A performance of Verdi's "Requiem" will be given for the benefit of the New York Infirmary by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, Arturo Toscanini conducting, and the Collegiate Chorale, under the direction of Robert Shaw, on the evening of April 26 in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Toscanini has not conducted the work since 1940.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- An official free market in hard currencies and gold, alongside an official market at a controlled rate, is understood to be under consideration by the French Government in devaluating the franc to stimulate exports.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- The Japanese Socialist party, the dominant grouping in the national Government since last year's general election, took a sharp turn to the left tonight as it concluded its third annual convention.

Attorney General Tom C. Clark was asked yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, to modify his "current practices and announced future policies with respect to restrictions prohibiting foreign educators and journalists from accepting invitations to lecture and participate in conferences at American universities."

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Substantial pressure for cutting state contributions to local relief costs has developed as a result of mounting outlays in New York City and growing dissatisfaction with the city's welfare administration, Governor Dewey said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Legislation to authorize President Truman to prepare a complete standby system for the rationing of meat was introduced in the Senate and House by Republicans today. Congress, however, would have the final say on when, or whether, rationing actually would return.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Republican National Committee, holding its pre-convention meeting here, tonight heard the speaker invited to address its banquet, Senator William F. Knowland, give unequivocal endorsement in principle to the foreign-aid policy of the United States. He did not discuss administrative phases of this program.

Live-aloners, whether bachelors or career women, whose housekeeping facilities are limited, should appreciate the new coffeemaker that has come to Hammacher - Schlemmer's, 145 East Fifty-seventh Street. Not only does it make a single cup of good coffee in three minutes, but it will, if you like, boil an egg at the same time.

On hand to counteract some of the criticism that has been heaped upon officials in recent weeks, Matty Begovich, John Marshall's coach and one of the more prominent arbiters hereabouts, caused quite a stir yesterday as the basketball writers convened for their I weekly luncheon at Leone's.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Coin Machine Industries, Inc., today opened its annual coin machine show here, to run for four days, with 209 exhibit booths and 122 exhibitors, featuring some innovations.

Asked at the PCA convention in Chicago "if he would repudiate Communist support, as President Roosevelt had," Henry A. Wallace replied: "I'll have to look up the record and find out what FDR really did."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Following are excerpts from Bernard M. Baruch's statement to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the Marshall Plan:

Dr. Oscar Lange, former Polish representative in the United Nations Security Council and now a member of the Polish Socialist party's Politburo, has protested in a message from Warsaw against a reference to him in a dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Dec. 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The 233,000 telephone workers who are members of the Communication Workers of America (independent) do not want a strike this year but they expect a wage increase, according to Joseph W. Beirne, CWA president.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Extensive reorganization of the United States and British Military Governments is expected to result from the recent designation of powerful committees by the Military Governors, Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The first inter-European fiscal clearing carried out through the Bank for International Settlements at Basle last week did not produce very significant results, it was learned today.

FOR more than a quarter of a century the National Football League has been behaving in the one-big-happy-family style. Big brother kicks little brother in the shins, little sister pulls big sister's hair and the baby yowls steadily. But the NFL has finally come to realize that the All-America Conference no longer can be merely ignored and it's gotten around to uniting against the common foe -- just as the average family will unite.

A showing of millinery made by Otto Lucas of Bond Street, London, for Saks Fifth Avenue was presented yesterday at the Hotel Plaza. It included shallow crowned brims inspired by the bonnets in Renoir paintings, small draped models fashioned of scarfs and ensembled with three-cornered shawls, manipulated felts that combined three colors and all manner of little bonnets and high-crowned sailors.

Fair to brisk buying on a small quantity basis by owners of small and some medium size furniture stores marked the opening yesterday of the fifty-seventh annual winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange. Buyers from larger outlets, furniture chains and department stores either did not attend or concentrated on "note taking."

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight that New York will sponsor a state Freedom Train and lend it historic documents from the state archives for display in various sections of the state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Bernard M. Baruch urged Congress today to underwrite a world recovery program based on a guaranteed ready market here for the raw materials of all nations, and an all-out production effort coupled with wartime controls on food prices, wages and profits.

Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, rejected yesterday an offer made by officers of the Liberal Party that they endorse the Democratic nominee for Congress in the Bronx to be selected to succeed Representative Benjamin J. Rabin, now a Supreme Court Justice.

The world-wide demand for Bibles is "insatiable," officials of the American Bible Society reported yesterday to twenty-six editors of Protestant periodicals at a meeting in the organization's headquarters at 450 Park Avenue.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 19 -- A subcommittee composed of representatives of France, Canada, Syria and the Philippines to study the election laws of North and South Korea has been created by the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea, it was announced today.

VIENNA, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Russia, in a move interpreted as an attempt to sabotage the Marshall Plan, has doubled the price of oil she supplies Austria from fields in the Soviet occupation zone, authoritative sources said tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Germany, with her near-starvation and her Russian-inspired campaign of sabotage against the European Recovery Program, will be the center of interest when Parliament resumes its session tomorrow.

A display of antique Chinese silver arranged by the Chinese Art Society of America was opened last night with a private view for members and guests at China House, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street. The exhibit will be open to the public from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. Mondays to Fridays through Feb. 19.

The American Zionist Emergency Council made public yesterday through Rabbi Israel Goldstein, its acting chairman, an exchange of correspondence with Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, in which the council complained about Great Britain's behavior in Palestine.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 20 -- Upon the completion today of two days of examination of seven defense attorneys in the Krupp case who walked out of court Friday in a demonstration against rulings of the judges, the tribunal announced that it would give its decision tomorrow.

ROME, Jan. 20 -- The twenty-sixth Socialist congress was considered certain today to approve an electoral alliance with the Communists when the "autonomist" leader, Giuseppe Romita, withdrew his motion against creation of a "people's bloc" embracing all Left Wing parties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman transmitted to Congress today a report of the National Advisory Council on International Monetary and Financial Problems showing that Russia ranked next to the United States in gold holdings while the gold balances of Western European nations had been seriously drained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee reaffirmed today its stand against a measure which would have permitted Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, the President's nominee for chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board, to retain his military pay and position while serving in a civilian post.

Testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee in opposition to Republican tax-reduction plans, W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, argued that it would be economically "dangerous" at present to divert capital into private investment at a rate higher than that now prevailing.

EAST CHICAGO, Ind., Jan. 20 -- A device for speeding the unloading of freight cars carrying frozen commodities such as coal and iron ore received its first public demonstration today at the Inland Steel Company's Indiana Harbor Yorks here.

The arbitration of wage review issues between the American Communications Association, CIO, and a committee representing ship owners and operators on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts opened yesterday in the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street, before Arbitrator Frederick R. Livingston, former United States conciliator.

Mayor O'Dwyer surprised his audience yesterday and demolished a few political precedents when he asked a group of foreign language newspaper editors and publishers to hold off a resolution of support until the end of his term in 1949.

ATHENS, Jan. 20 -- Twenty-three more officers of the joint United States military and planning group arrived in Athens this morning. In making the announcement, Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the mission, added that the number of United States Army officers here now and ready to act in a liaison capacity was fifty.

There's been an innovation in the packaging of natural cheddar cheese that eventually may make the familiar round wheels of store cheese as obsolete as their former accompaniment, the cracker barrel. A covering of Pliofilm so thin and transparent that it hardly seems to be there at all replaces the coating of paraffined cotton gauze that has been used for so long to keep air from reaching the product.

The Detroit Red Wings, two points behind the first-place Toronto Maple Leafs, clash with the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. The home skaters, none too secure with a three-point edge over the fourth-place Canadiens, need a victory to enhance their position.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The House today voted to grant permanent residence in the United States to Victor A. Kravchenko, member of the wartime Soviet Purchasing Commission who renounced communism and his native land in his book, "I Chose Freedom."

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 20 (AP) -Eight persons were killed and 140 injured today in six hours of wild rioting set off by more than 6,000 students protesting the revised British-Iraqi alliance. The police fired on the rioters and arrested hundreds before order was restored.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the acquisition of screen rights to "Some of These Days," Sophie Tucker's autobiography, written by the 63-year-old stage star in collaboration with Dorothy Gibbs and published in 1945 by Doubleday Doran.

When a dress designer of fame turns her attention to uniforms for men and women, it is news. This is the case with Helen Cookman, whose name has been associated with the creating of many smart coat and suit fashions. To her the revival of the Chesterfield coat has been attributed: it was her model that put it into the fashionable class for women.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The names of ten young men chosen as "outstanding" in the United States in 1947 were announced today by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 -- President Juan Peron will go aboard the heavy cruiser Albany Friday to call on Vice Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, commander of the United States Atlantic Fleet, whose flagship docked here this morning on a six-day courtesy visit. With the Albany is the 2,200-ton destroyer George K. Mackenzie.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Douglas MacArthur-for-President movement -- being fostered by Northern Republican friends -- cropped up in his native Arkansas today, then took a sidetrack.

After more than a month of hearings on charges of unfair labor practices against the Stork Club brought before the State Labor Relations Board by a union of kitchen workers, both sides announced yesterday that they were on the verge of a "reasonable settlement."

The role of oil in the Middle East has greatly improved foreign trade possibilities in that area, now rated as a $300,000,000 market, F.H. Jewell of the Davis Lawrence Company. proprietary medicines and flavoring extracts, said yesterday. He added, however, that Americans and not the United Nations are being blamed for the partition of Palestine.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Walter Mulbry, assistant to Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler, and Mexican Commissioner Alejandro Aguilar Reyes will confer here this week, presumably to outline plans for taking the Mexican League into organized baseball, it was announced tonight.

JERUSALEM Jan. 20 -- Eight Jews were killed today in one of the heaviest engagements to date when an Arab force estimated to number 500 attacked the Jewish settlement of Yehiam in the north, nine miles northeast of Nahariya.

The Baruch Plan recommending American purchases of world commodity surpluses drew sharply critical reactions from industrial purchasing agents here yesterday. They warned that the proposal envisaged world-wide extension of United States domestic agricultural price policies, often described as the "ever normal granary."

HAVANA, Jan. 20 -- The right of any nation to stockpile strategic materials for purposes of national security was guaranteed at today's session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment. This action was taken at the request of the United States delegation by the Committee on Intergovernmental Commodity Agreements.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen said tonight he believed "too high prices" for food and other necessities of life could be lowered by careful government handling of "limited powers that would not disrupt production."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Economic integration of western Europe through a monetary and customs union would end Russia's efforts to dominate the Continent and should be a stated objective of any Marshall Plan legislation, John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The United Nations has drawn up its first comprehensive report on the economic troubles of the world from 1945 to 1947 and will present it to the Economic and Social Council as the foundation stone for the work of next month's session, it was disclosed today.

Designs for costumes and scenery commissioned by the Ballet Society of New York for its productions during the last year and a half were shown yesterday in a preview of the exhibition that will be open to the public today in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

A strike of 200 iron workers that would have delayed progress on new schools, hospitals, power plants and housing projects was averted at a City Hall conference last night, just six hours before the scheduled tie-up.
To the many honors which have gone to James A. Farley tonight will be added a mark of recognition from the sport which was his springboard to the stature of an international figure.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- With true French esprit, Maud Roser calls her collection of hats shown today the "Roofs of Paris." Very charming little roofs they are, to cover a youthful head and shade a smooth brow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The 770 correspondents accredited to the United Nations will have to apply for new credentials by March 1, under the terms of an agreement between the United States and the world organization, it was disclosed today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, British amateur golf champion from New York, today won his first-round match in the fortieth tournament of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests, despite a concession of twelve strokes to his opponent.
The Cabinet Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Owen J. Roberts, former associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, headed a five-man "personnel security review board" established today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
Morris A. Schacht has purchased four vacant parcels of land in Forest Hills West, Queens, from the Art-Mar Building Corporation in an all-cash transaction.

AS I write these words the press is carrying conflicting accounts of the implications for Jewry of the partition of Palestine. As president of the American Jewish Committee I deem it important that there should be a clear statement of what I believe to be the philosophy and attitude of the American Jew.

Fourteen hundred engineers and firemen employed on the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad threatened yesterday to strike at 4 A.M. Monday, six days ahead of the date set for a national walkout of rail employes.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Public interest in the stock market here today was at a low ebb, most jobbers reporting their sections to be "idle and dull."
Results of the election of officers for Bronx House, 1637 Washington Avenue, were announced yesterday by Graenum Berger, headworker at the settlement. Voting took place last week.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 20 -- Dr. Miguel Acosta Saignes, director of the University School of Journalism here, to whom a visa to enter the United States was refused recently, declared today: "I am not and have never been a member of the Communist party."

The tramp or bulk-carrying segment of the American merchant marine inevitably faces sharp curtailment of its activities at the end of the European Recovery Program, and perhaps before the end, Jesse E. Saugsted, chief of the shipping division of the Department of State, said yesterday.
Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander indicated yesterday that the trucking and garment industries had almost agreed on a plan to relieve traffic congestion in the garment area.

To the accompaniment of a derisive commuter chorus, an official of the Public Service Commission gave the following testimony yesterday about Long Island Rail Road service during last month's record snow:

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Holy Cross Crusaders, defending N.C.A.A. basketball champions, took charge at the start tonight and sped to a decisive 76-49 victory over previously unbeaten Rhode Island State's at times bewildered Rams before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.
Findings of an opinion poll on the child day care program here were released yesterday by the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, Inc., 136 East Fifty-seventh Street.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- The hunger strike wave hit the occupation forces directly for the first time today as German telephone operators staged a one-hour sit-down strike on the switchboard handling all long distance official military calls in this city.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- In a speech in which he announced that he would retire from office as Prime Minister and from the leadership of the Liberal party, W.L. Mackenzie King this evening made an attack, for him unprecedented, on Communist tyranny.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Counsel for various groups of stockholders of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation, New York, agreed informally at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange

The capacious Broadway Theatre is to be restored to the legitimate fold once more. After waging a losing battle with a picture policy, the house, which is under lease to United Artists, will reopen next Wednesday night with "The Cradle Will Rock." This will represent one more episode in the fabulous history of Marc Blitzstein's brain-child, which the author-composer quaintly describes as "a play in music."

The five-story forty-three-family apartment house at 315 Mount Eden Avenue, northeast corner of Topping Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the heirs of Thomas Stevens to Harry Levine. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, is assessed at $170,000 and was sold for cash above mortgages of $130,000. Armstrong Brothers and Richard Dickson Son were the brokers in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $25,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, due 1978, and 150,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock -- a total of $40,000,000.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 20 -- One thousand Socialist-led striking dockworkers screamed Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister of India, into silence here today. They then clashed with industrial workers affiliated with the Congress party.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet propaganda machine is concentrating its efforts on convincing the world that the United States interferes directly in the affairs of other nations. According to that propaganda, the United States seeks to line up the Western Allies for a new war, which Washington is said to be preparing.

Spud Chandler, who could well give the Yankee pitching staff that additional lift to put the Bombers over the top for another pennant, became the club's eighteenth signer yesterday, according to announcement by General Manager George M. Weiss.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,959, against '3,348 last week and 2,174 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 949 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,736 last Tuesday.

Dean Ackerman of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism sets forth sound American doctrine in his telegram to Attorney General Clark protesting the restrictions being placed by the Justice Department on visits to this country of foreign educators and journalists. As matters stand, a prospective visitor, no matter what his professional attainments, must also meet whatever test of his political views Mr. Clark decides upon before he can enter the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The grain markets reversed today their performance of Monday and closed sharply higher on the Board of Trade. Buying of wheat futures by cash interests and mills featured trading in that grain. Reports were current that the Government purchased around 1,000,000 bushels of cash wheat in various positions, following the taking of 2,000,000 bushels the previous day.

The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel may be fastidious about its guests, but Monday night it had to let the bars down a bit to accommodate a collection of monkeys, birds, fish and insects. But then, the creatures were a bit on the elite side, having been carefully selected from the collection of the Bronz Zoo.

In a spectacular rescue four stories above the street, Fireman Joseph Mead of the Thirty-second Battalion passed two adults and two infants from a window to other firemen on an aerial ladder last night during a small but smoky fire at 186 Amity Street, Brooklyn.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Delegates to a fourth special convention called to select a new Bishop of the western New York Episcopal Diocese voted unanimously today for Dr. Lauriston L. Scaife, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Pittsburgh, Pa.

Because freshmen aren't eligible for Saturday afternoon's West Point Relays, New York University's 19-year-old Larry Ellis will make his debut on the "big-time" track circut that night. He'll run against Gilbert Dodds, the master miler, in the Boston Knights of Columbus games.

"I Walk Alone," a melodrama produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount, which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Burt Lancaster and Lizabeth Scott are starred in the offering adapted from the play "The Beggars Are Coming to Town." Kirk Douglas, Kristine Miller and Wendell Corey are featured and Byron Haskin directed.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The dispute over which of two United States ice hockey teams should play in the winter Olympic games starting Jan. 30 was heading for a showdown with all principals sticking to their guns today.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Dewey's suggestion that the state's contributions to local relief costs be reduced as a means of forcing New York City to improve its welfare administration has been rejected flatly by Republican legislative leaders, it became known today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange had weak and strong moments yesterday, and final prices were 4 points net lower to 15 points net higher than Monday's closing levels.

Anybody following international news, as he peruses every day the dispatches in the papers about our relations with Soviet Russia, must ask himself now and then: "Has the United States ever before been the object of such a continuous barrage of innuendo, invective, denunciation and insult as is being aimed at it nowadays, week after week, from Soviet Russia or the European nations domination?"

One year ago today Gen. George C. Marshall arrived at the White House and in the presence of President Truman, the Cabinet and ranking members of Congress took the oath of office as the new Secretary of State of the United States. Almost two years had then passed since the most devastating war in history had come to an end.

Ten thousand volunteer workers participated yesterday in special "dedication day" events designed to aid the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York to meet its $15,000,000 fund-raising goal for its 116 affiliated institutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A demand made seventeen days ago by Edwin W. Pauley that a Senate investigating committee convict or acquit him of using "inside" information in commodity speculation was made public today by its chairman, Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan.

The handicap of being only 8 years old and having no money proved no deterrent to Walter Smith of 28-27 Thirty-seventh Street, Astoria, Queens, when he decided on Monday to visit an uncle in Montreal.

The arrest of a second top Communist leader for deportation was disclosed here yesterday. The new prisoner is Claudia Jones. Like Alexander Bittelman, who was arrested last week, she is a member of the National Committee of the Communist party of the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Coming to grips for the first time with the crucial problem of security in the Holy Land, the United Nations Palestine Commission today reached a general understanding that an international armed force would be needed to enforce partition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Representative Willis Bradley, Republican, of California, asserted today that the transfer of 500 American ships to foreign countries under the European Recovery Program would mean "immediate loss of 30,330 jobs" for American merchant seamen.
Eight-year-old Ferruccio Burco, said to be the youngest conductor and orchestral director in the world, was among 374 passengers who arrived from Italy yesterday on the Gdynia America liner Sobieski.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Legislative action on a measure to validate New York City's emergency rent laws, which are under attack in the courts, is being stymied by a dispute between the city and Republican legislative leaders over its provisions.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- The port of Boston, expecting to enjoy a steady flow of business during the height of the wool importing season, faces the prospect of having to turn away in-bound vessels for want of storage space. The heavy snow and a truck strike were blamed today by J. Alexander Crothers, director of the Port Authority, for the condition.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in a resolution adopted last night, urged Congress to withdraw as soon as possible the Connally amendment to the United States declaration of acceptance of jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice.

The signing by the Netherlands Indies Government and the Republic of Indonesia of a truce to be supervised by the United Nations Committee of Good Offices has been followed quickly by acceptance by both sides of a Committee formula for settlement of political differences. Either agreement would be of little value without the other.

An increase in permissible individual and corporate tax deductions to encourage contributions to voluntary hospitals and non-profit educational institutions was recommended yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president of Beekman-Downtown Hospital.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The surrender of the Palestine mandate and the withdrawal of British troops may be advanced from the announced dates of May 15 and Aug. 1, respectively, the Earl of Listowel, Minister of State for the Colonies, told the House of Lords today.

A public center for information on the United Nations was opened yesterday at 535 Fifth Avenue by the American Association for the United Nations and Women United for United Nations. The center will be open every day except Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. to provide literature and other information about the international organization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House Republican Steering Committee gave its approval today to the Knutson tax reduction bill without change.

The Public Service Commission of New York has granted permission to five railroads to file revised tariff schedules providing for a flat 10 per cent increase in intrastate commutation, school and other multiple fares, the commission announced yesterday. The railroads affected are the New York Central, the Erie, the Delaware Hudson, the Baltimore Ohio and the Pennsylvania.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's sales last year set a record at $708,494,186, upon which net earnings equivalent to 4.54 per cent were realized, the 1947 report showed yesterday. The sales volume exceeded by $95,387,883 the previous peak in 1946.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -Senator Albert W. Hawkes, New Jersey Republican, today denounced Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey as seeking a "political dictatorship."

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- In expectation of early approval of devaluation of the French franc by the International Monetary Fund in Washington, it was believed here tonight that the Cabinet might hold a special meeting Friday to consummate the change by an official decree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska sounded a note of warning against over-confidence today to members of the Republican National Committee whose elation at Henry A. Wallace's third-party bid fairly has bubbled over during their two-day meeting here.
For the first time since he entered City Hall two years ago Mayor O'Dwyer was rebuffed yesterday on the appointment of a citizens' committee to seek settlement of a major strike.

Detectives of the Grand Avenue station, Brooklyn, had a mystery on their hands yesterday in the shape of a bar of soap. It was brought to the station house by James Brown, 28-year-old unemployed Navy veteran, of 1069 Dean Street, Brooklyn, who found two foreign watches a $1 bill and several ancient gold coins, all apparently was souvenirs, inside the soap.

The Public National Bank and Trust Company had net earnings of $2,334,858, equal to $4.25 a share in 1947, compared with $2,667,449, or $4.85 a share, for 1946, stockholders were told at the annual meeting held yesterday at the bank's main office at 37 Broad Street.

Eight Americans have been selected to make trips abroad as substitutes for Fiorello H. LaGuardia, who died before he could make the round-the-world tour awarded to him in 1947 by the One World Award Committee, it was announced yesterday.

LIFE for a sports writer is not all beer and skittles. Sometimes it's beer and vittles. Just the other night the baseball brothers tossed a dinner in honor of Burt Shotton and tonight the boxing branch of the fraternity will stage a dinner with Gus Lesnevich as one of the main objects of their affections. Both are exceedingly wise choices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Spokesmen for American shipping interests here today questioned the proposed foreign ship aid program under the European Recovery Program and alleged that the program would put foreign shippers in a better competitive position than they held in 1938.

The "Voice of America" broadcasts to interpret this country abroad "must represent the conscience of America," Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, labor and public relations consultant, declared yesterday at the Astor Hotel.
Random notes:

This week the American Internees Committee, representing the citizens of the United States who were imprisoned in Japanese civilian prison camps in the Pacific area during the Second World War, are issuing thousands of postcards to voters in this country with the request that they sign them and then mail them to their respective Representatives in Congress.

Of the total loans of the Bankers Trust Company outstanding on Dec. 31 last year, 65 to 70 percent were in the commercial field, S. Sloan Colt, the bank's president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. Responding to questions by stockholders, Mr. Colt disclosed that approximately half of the bank's loans mature in one year.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 -- A home-made bomb was exploded on a garden wall about 150 feet from Mohandas K. Gandhi this evening as Mr. Gandhi, who on Sunday ended a five-day fast for interreligious harmony in India, was concluding his daily prayer meeting message.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 20 -- Soviet-directed propaganda attacks on the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea beamed here from Moscow and North Korea appear to be centrally and carefully organized.

Directors of the Barnsdall Oil Company voted a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a common share, payable on March 6. In 1947 shareholders received four quarterly dividend of 25 cents plus extras of 15 cents in June and September and one of 25 cents in December.

The Citizens Budget Commission published yesterday the fifth and final section of its report on city departments. It criticized the Sanitation Department for failure to save $7,000,000 a year. Mayor O'Dwyer meanwhile expressed confidence that the commission's demand for savings of $30,000,000 in five departments would not hurt his chances of getting additional state aid from Albany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The United Kingdom, France, Germany and Italy will receive nearly three-quarters of the aid contemplated under the $6,800,000,000 proposed to be spent under the European Recovery Program during the first fifteen months, if the program as eventually voted and administered conforms relatively closely to estimates submitted by the State Department today to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Formation of the Radio Television Critics Circle of New York was announced yesterday. Its purpose, according to the announcement, is to "encourage more serious consideration, criticism and evaluation of both radio and television."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP) -- President George M. Trautman of America's fifty-seven minor baseball leagues warned executives of those loops today they "must stay away from all Canadian and United States high school players."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Permission for Dr. Henning Friis, a Danish Government official, to visit the United States has been delayed because he was once a member of the Communist Youth Union, the United States Embassy said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Steel mills are making progress in their fight to overtake excessive demand in many lines, C.F. Hood, president of the American Steel and Wire Company of Waukegan, Ill., reported tonight. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Waukegan-North Chicago chamber of commerce.

A consolidated net profit of $1,283,445, after taxes and all charges, was reported yesterday by Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., for the quarter ended on Dec. 31. The net, equivalent to 42 cents a common share, was based upon net sales of $41,128,206.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the Soviet commander, demanded in the meeting of the Allied Control Council here today that the United States and Great Britain disband the bizonal economic administration they had set up for their zones of Western Germany.

The East Side Chamber of Commerce decided last night to abandon the campaign to change the name of the Bowery. This decision was announced at the Parkside Hotel, where it was said that Bowery merchants had voted, 65 to 64, to keep the name that was good enough for the Dutch.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The Textile Workers Union of America, CIO, was enjoined today from taking control of the affairs of Lodi Local 1983, Federation of Dyers, Finishers, Printers and Bleachers of America, thus adding another chapter to a series of stormy proceedings involving the federation and the parent union.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The Labor Government's bill to grant Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh increased annuities of u40,000 ($160,000) and u10,000 ($40,000), respectively, passed its second reading in the House of Commons today by 294 votes to 17.

A record total of $9,802,045,727 in savings deposits in the 131 mutual savings banks of New York State at the end of last year was reported yesterday by John Adikes, president of The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 580 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-eighth Street, has been sold by Dr. Arthur Weil, who bought it in 1946, to the West End and Eighty-eighth Street Realty Corporation, headed by Ira Senz.

The first sizable building project to be undertaken by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York since the construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will be started within the next few weeks, Bishop Charles K. Gilbert announced yesterday.

More than half of all persons convicted of felonies in Kings County Court during 1947 were between 16 and 25 years of age, according to the annual report prepared by Francis J. Sinnott, county clerk, and made public yesterday.

Justice was tempered with mercy during the Felony Court hearing yesterday of Daniel Walpole, $40-a-week moving van worker, who was described by his attorney as having yielded to impulse when he stole a tricycle last Saturday as a belated Christmas gift for one of his sons.

The stock market moved in an irregular course yesterday although mild recovery developed in some of the recently depressed rails, oils and steels. Price changes were generally fractional and, while on balance the list closed on a fairly even keel, the combined averages edged closer to the December lows on a net loss of 0.64 point.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Snapping a Calumet Farm slump which had begun with Armed's setback in the Gulfstream Park Handicap last Thursday, Faultless and High Shine carried the famed silks to first and second positions in today's featured Robert E. Lee Purse at Hialeah Park.

The commodity business of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, one of the largest stock, bond and commodity brokerage houses in the country, was reported yesterday to have fallen off 33 to 40 per cent since Oct. 5, when President Truman criticized "gambling" on commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended to the ICC yesterday that the division of fares between the Hudson Manhattan and the Pennsylvania Railroad on commuter fares between Newark and other points on the Pennsylvania and the H. M. stations in New York be changed from the arrangement under which the H. M. receives 40 per cent of the joint fares.

A pageant in prints was paraded before an audience assembled in Brooke Cadwallader's sophisticated show room yesterday morning. A series of stories was unfolded as the manikins displayed the fascinating silk squares and oblongs that make the scarves for which this creator of fabric designs is now so well known.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- A rise of 13.1 per cent in Britain's wholesale price index was registered in 1947, the Board of Trade announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- The battle of the franc is the battle of the ordinary Frenchman to survive. It is closely linked to the political struggle, to the last-ditch stand of the middle class and to the confusion and disorientation of labor following the schism in union ranks. All groups in this country are groping for new positions in a realignment of forces that is now in full process.

Matching results of a market survey that indicate expanding demand for champagne, Robinson-Lloyds, Ltd., will break toward the end of February a 30 per cent increased campaign for Dry Imperator New York State Champagne, it was announced yesterday. The initial six-month drive will use newspapers in twenty large cities coast-to-coast, six class magazines and spot television in ten cities.

The campaign to raise $5,000,000 for the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn., has reached the $950,000 mark in less than nine months, Dr. Alexander Guerry, vice chancellor of the university, announced here last night. He addressed 100 persons at the annual dinner of the institution's New York Alumni Association, held at the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Max Bentley, speedy center of the Toronto Maple Leafs and one of the few players in the history of the National Hockey League to have won the individual scoring championship two years in a row is making a strong bid for his third consecutive point-getting crown.

Close to its first defeat of the season, the N.Y.U. basketball team rallied to conquer Colgate, 64 -- 59, for its twelfth straight victory last night at Madison Square Garden. Then, while a crowd of 18,146 fans stifled yawns, Western Kentucky routed L.I.U., 62 -- 47.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Mounting returns from Louisiana's Democratic Gubernatorial primary tonight pushed Sam H. Jones and Earl K. Long well ahead of two other contenders for the nomination that means election.

Waxey Gordon, "beer baron" of the prohibition era, denied yesterday knowledge of the attempted $9,150,000 purchase of stock of the Follansbee Steel Corporation by a former associate, A. Terry Fahye. The latter, a triple-identity person, was arrested on Monday in the mystery deal.
A.B. Recknagel, has been appointed technical director of the St. Regis Paper Company, which is consolidating its forestry activities.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A broad investigation of professional sports was demanded today by a Buffalo legislator, who said gamblers apparently had "fixed" some events.

Assertions by representatives of Metropolitan Theophilus, head of the Russian Orthodox Church of North America, "that demands were made that the American churches pledge loyalty to the Soviet Government are false and miselading, and are detrimental to the American public," Archbishop Macarius of New York, exarch of the Patriarchal Russian Orthodox-Church, Moscow, declared here yesterday.

FOR some time now members of the more "advanced" literary circles have been talking with considerable respect and admiration about a young man named Truman Capote. Only 23 now, precocious, self-confident and genuinely gifted, Mr. Capote has been getting himself a reputation by his short stories. This week his first novel, "Other Voices, Other Rooms,"* is published.

Once a country determines that any of its industries is being injured or threatened within the meaning of the "escape clause" in trade agreements it cannot be prevented from withdrawing a concession by unilateral action, it was declared last night by Lynn R. Edminster, vice chairman, Tariff Commission.

Theatre Arts, the magazine that has grown in thirty-two years to an international institution in the drama and related fields, is scheduled to pass out of existence with its February issue, it was learned yesterday.

Lakewood Farm, the former Douglass J. Crawford property on West Park Avenue and Wyckoff Road in the Wayside section of Shrewsbury township, N.J., has been sold by Joseph Scarano to Joseph Mazza, who plans to occupy the residence and use the large barns for a boarding stable. John L. Minugh was the broker.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Implementing a constitutional amendment adopted by the voters last November, Senator Frederic E. Hammer of Queens and Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett of Suffolk County, both Republicans, introduced companion bills today to set up the new Tenth Judicial District, comprising Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bobby Riggs, the professional champion, turned in a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Jack Kramer in the seventeenth match of their current tennis series before a near-capacity crowd of 4,500 tonight. The triumph put Riggs back in the lead with a margin of 9 to 8 in their tour.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The University of Maryland assured itself today of the services of football coach Jim Tatum for the next five years and simultaneously scratched him from the list of prospects for the vacancy at near-by Navy.

C.W. Davies of the Montclair A.C., registered an upset when he eliminated the second seeded player, H.V. Richard of the New York A.C. to gain the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B singles championship at the Downtown A.C. last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Ending his bitter opposition to President Truman, A.F. Whitney took the 220,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen back into the Democratic fold today to strive for the re-election of the man he once denounced as a "political accident."

Complete with an "atomic pinball machine" to demonstrate with colored lights and ringing bells the erratic travel of neutrons in an atomic pile, an atomic energy exhibit sponsored by the Brookhaven National Laboratory opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The United Nations Security Council decided today to establish a three-nation commission and instructed it to go to Kashmir as quickly as possible in an attempt to mediate differences between India and Pakistan over the disputed area.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Stella Lewandowski today became a citizen of the United States, in whose armed forces three of her five sons were killed. Today would have been the twenty-third birthday of one of the dead boys and her voice broke as she took the oath of allegiance.

The Army transport Joseph V. Connolly, swept by fire in the Atlantic ten days ago, has drifted 150 miles northeast of her original position 900 miles east of New York, the Army Port of Embarkation reported yesterday. The ship still was smouldering and wallowing in heavy seas, foiling attempts to put a salvage party aboard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman said today that American traders in foreign markets faced many complications last year because of the "self-seeking economic and political objectives of various nations."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A House Administration subcommittee referred to the Justice Department today, for a ruling on constitutionality, a bill proposing to "bar un-American parties from the election ballot."

It is not surprising that demands are being heard up-state, as remarked by Governor Dewey, for a reduction in the state's contribution to local relief costs. The wasteful practices uncovered last spring in New York City, first by chance disclosure in court proceedings, later by city and state inquiries, made such demands almost a certainty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A new drive for House action on a universal military training program was opened today by Representative Walter G. Andrews, chairman of the Committee of the Armed Services. Mr. Andrews indicated that he might resort to a sure-fire parliamentary tactic to force the long-pending UMT bill to the House floor for a voting decision.

Declaring that fur skin prices are "too high," Sol Rosenberg, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, last night urged manufacturers voluntarily to delay production on 1948 lines. He spoke at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Two nove have been chosen for April b'y the Book-of-theMontk Club. One is "Great i{is5 chief," Josephine Pinckney's story about a dreaming druggist in Charleston in the 1890's who becomes a sorcerer. Viking has set the tentative date of March 22 for publication.

Competitive sale yesterday of three public utility bond issues totaling $59,000,000 drew bids from nineteen investment banking syndicates, but indications of investor interest in the prospective offerings were such that two of the three winning banking syndicates decided to reduce the marketing prices from levels first announced in order to make the offerings more attractive to institutional buyers.
Peter Kasius, regional director of the Federal Social Security Administration, declared yesterday that Federal policy on relief never had advocated an indulgent relief administration.

George Szell, who was guest conductor with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony earlier this season, led the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, and before the season is over he will be back with his own orchestra, the Cleveland.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 20 -- The nation's food canners were told today that although indications are that the present "economic boom" will continue well into 1948 with the American housewife having more money to spend on food than ever before, numerous business "pitfalls" loom.

A new formula for the grading of engineering teachers' salaries was adopted yesterday by the board of directors of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which opens its three-day annual meeting this morning at the Commodore Hotel.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the appointment of Assistant District Attorney George P. Monaghan as chief of the homicide bureau of the District Attorney's office to succeed Jacob Grumet, who resigned Jan. 15 to enter private law practice.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Testimony on the charge that the American Federation of Labor International Typographical Union coerced its Chicago subordinate into a position that amounted to a refusal to bargain and to an attempt to impose a closed shop developed conflicts on questions of fact in a National Labor Relations Board hearing today.
STORRS, Conn., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Paced by Tony Lavelli, Yale's basketball team tonight defeated the University of Connecticut quintet, 57 to 50.

New ready-made slip covers styled to resemble custom-made chair and sofa covers in both color and pattern are being introduced to New York homemakers by Macy's and the Sure-Fit Products Company. Four patterns and numerous color variations are offered in the ensembles.

Mortality among physicians is higher than among most other professional groups, Dr. Louis I. Dublin, second vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, last night told a meeting of the Medical Society of the County of Kings at 1313 Bedford Avenue.
The butcher's and grocer's high prices are crowding the fruit and vegetable man to the wall, a group of independent produce retailers complained yesterday.

The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, and the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop, will be among the special guests at the double bill performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of St. Barnabas House.
Nylon, adorner of feminine limbs, is challenging the centuries-old monopoly of sheep gut in the realm of music, it became known yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Attorney General Tom Clark announced today that he was suggesting that the Government help defray expenses of the defense in cases of Federal employes accused of disloyalty.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Following is the text of a resolution on the Indian question adopted today by the United Nations Security Council:
