GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization today received a 1948-49 budget of $155,027,000. The budget was presented by William H. Tuck, executive secretary, at the opening of the fifth meeting of the IRO.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Jacob M. Lomakin, former Soviet newspaper man, served notice on the United Nations subcommission on Freedom of the Press today that he considered its discussions that "vague" and "wrong from top to bottom."

Draft rights to Charley Conerly, the University of Mississippi's all-around star, were obtained yesterday by the New York Giants of the National Football League. In the process of rebuilding the club, which last season finished in the cellar, the Giants traded Halfback Howie Livingston, four-season veteran, and an unnamed player, to the Washington Redskins, who had the original draft rights to Conerly.
The Houghton Company announces that Sue R. Magee has become associated with its apartment advisory agency.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) -- C.M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, opposed today sale of a $28,000,000 surplus blast furnace and coke plant to the tucker Corporation, new Chicago automobile concern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced late today he would ask the brewing industry to stick to the Luckman voluntary agreement through February to give time for a written poll on a new voluntary grain-saving plan.
San Francisco announced yesterday it would receive bids until Feb. 2 on bond issues totaling $27,000,000. Dated Feb. 1, 1948, the bonds will come due Feb. 1 from 1949 to 1968.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Board of Trade announced tonight that it has furnished the United States, which requested it, with "some indication" of the amounts of rubber Britain may be prepared to sell from Malayan stocks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- States east of the Rocky Mountains are faced with petroleum shortages which will persist throughout the winter, the House Armed Services Committee was told today by Max W. Ball, director of the Interior Department's Oil and Gas Division.

VIENNA, Jan. 20 -- The Austrian Government will announce tomorrow that, despite the 100 per cent increase by the Russians in the wholesale cost of Austria's own oil from the confiscated Zistersdorf fields, the price of gasoline to the Austrian consumer will be raised only 87 groschen per gallon, or 19 per cent.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 -- The second session of the Japanese Parliament since the enactment of the new Constitution is scheduled to open tomorrow. An important legislative program lies ahead, but with the newly-organized political parties in such a state of disorganization that the dissolution of the Diet and a fresh general election are likely to occur before any important action can be taken.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Drafting of bills that would give the Public Service Commission broad powers to ration gas during periods of emergency has been completed by the commission's law staff and they will be introduced in the Legislature this week by Senator Floyd E. Anderson of Broome County and Assemblyman Stanley T. Shaw of Tompkins County, both Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The risk that Latin-American countries might be driven into "economic autarchy" as an alternative to acceptance, by them, of the European Recovery Program on this country's terms was cited today in a report published by the Foreign Policy Association.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Three of the four participants this afternoon in THE NEW YORK TIMES "What's on Your Mind?" forum, expressed confidence that the Little Assembly of the United Nations would perform an important role, even without Russia and her five satellite nations.

Closer cooperation of manufacturer, wholesaler and independent retailer will enable all three to meet the dominating threat of large integrated chains and syndicates, it was pointed out yesterday by Frank A. Thomas, president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute.

At the end of 1947 Great Britain and Ireland were building 54.5 per cent of the world total of merchant ship tonnage, while United States shipyards were handling only 3.4 per cent, according to a report from Lloyd's Register of Shipping yesterday.

High schools and coaches will draw up their own football schedules this year in Public Schools Athletic League competition, it was announced yesterday at the circuit's monthly meeting of the High School Games Committee at the Hotel Astor.

Elton B. Moray, 45 years old, a dapper confidence man with a clipped British accent and a long police record, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison by Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday on his plea of guilty to the charge of having impersonated a State Department officer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 20 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, warned today that while the Government might subject its employes to loyalty checks, interference with the freedom of universities inspired by panic would have a "most disastrous" effect.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 21 (AP) Bob Feller signed his 1948 contract today at a figure which President Bill Veeck of the Indians said should "continue him as the highest paid player in baseball."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 21 -- Strikes grew in intensity, although not in numbers, today. Germans appealed for more food from the United States, the rank and file denounced German Government officials for having mismanaged affairs and dire predictions of catastrophe in the next months were voiced.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen called tonight upon the young men and women of the country to adopt an "affirmative advocacy of modern people's capitalism" that will emphasize to the world that in America it is "as different from the imperialistic monopoly capitalism of a century ago as is the ruthless economy of Russia different from the Utopia painted by Karl Marx."

The December support level was finally pierced yesterday by the Stock Market when a wave of selling engulfed the list in the final hour. The deluge of offerings came after the market had exhibited rallying powers, but the heavy sales in the last period, which kept the reporting tape behind actual floor transactions for almost ten minutes, produced losses of as much as 2 points.

On Dec. 30 there appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES a news release concerning my report on the mental health of displaced persons in Cyprus. I was astonished -- and so were many people who are familiar with the report -- at the caption, "Good Mental Health Found in Cyprus DP's."

A marked change in the general attitude of manufacturers toward wholesalers has taken place in recent months, according to Henry Matter, general manager of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, yesterday. Manufacturers are turning more and more to jobbers for assistance in their distribution problems, he held, and he attributed the interest to changes in wholesaling which has increased its effectiveness.
The superintendent of the Long Island Rail Road placed yesterday some of the responsibility for its breakdown last month at the door of the "official United States Weather Bureau."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, British amateur champion from New York, today posted a 2-over-par 72 to lead the way into the semi-finals of the fortieth tournament of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests.

The testimony of Secretary Forrestal before a House Armed Services subcommittee is disquieting, even if the facts have been presented time and time again. Our domestic economy is linked closely with petroleum, so that even apart from military needs we cannot afford to accept with indifference the decline of our once great oilfields.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21.(AP) -James F. Merkel, state securities division chief, said today that Ohio had barred sales of securities coupled with the sale of series "E" Federal savings bonds, commonly known as war bonds. Use of savings bonds to promote sales of securities in speculative ventures such as oil wells was described by Mr. Merkel as "merely bait to attract funds."

Two young backstop understudies, who could well make it interesting for Yogi Berra and Aaron Robinson when Manager Bucky Harris assembles his Yankee squad at St. Petersburg on March 1, yesterday became the latest to hop aboard General Manager George M. Weiss' band wagon of contract signers for 1948.

WASHINGTON Jan. 21 (UP) -President Truman today greeted a group of Baptist missionaries as "frontier purveyors of peace" and praised them for carrying the message of American good-will throughout the world.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Government announcement said today that two officials of the Argentine Embassy had been expelled from Russia for trying to smuggle out two unnamed Persons in trunks by airplane on Jan. 2.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Benjamin Fielding, New York City Welfare Commissioner, was accused today of waging a political campaign to placate organized groups interested in day care centers for children while neglecting more pressing needs of the city's children.

United States policy in the Mediterranean is backed by an eighteen ship task force, manned by 12,000 to 13,000 men in the highest possible state of training, Vice Admiral Forrest Sherman, newly appointed commander of this country's forces in the area, declared yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 (AP) -Jack S. L., ridden by R. L. Baird, captured the $3,000 Hammond Handicap at the Fair Grounds today. Second was Silver's Pride, with Robert Montgomery up, and third was May Fly, with Gerald Porch riding.

An expanded advertising campaign by the Park Tilford wine and liquor division, using 200 daily newspapers and twenty national magazines, will support what company executives describe as the biggest sales program in the company's 108-Year history, it was announced yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malay States, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The rulers of nine Malayan States signed pacts with Britain today marking the creation of the Federation of Malaya for the almost 5,000.000 residents of the peninsula. Only the Crown Colony of Singapore remains under British rule outside the Federation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Counsel for the American Federation of Labor International Typographical Union proposed today that the unfair labor practice case against the Chicago local union go to an immediate decision, without oral arguments or briefs, but the Government declined.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Electrical power shortages, the rising costs of fuel and transportation, and the need for more industrial and farm production were cited today by the State Power Authority as reasons why the St. Lawrence seaway project should be undertaken immediately.

WEIMAR, Germany, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- A press rigidly controlled by the Soviet Military Administration has convinced a great part of the Soviet-zone Germans that the Marshall Plan is nothing but a device designed to allow United States capital to split up Germany and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Former President Herbert Hoover challenged today the basic concept of a continuing European Recovery Program and urged that Congress limit any appropriation for world rehabilitation and relief to $4,000,000,000 for the fifteen months beginning April 1.

The Board of Education added yesterday three items totaling $95,000 to its record budget estimate and despite the opposition of two members to other items, approved unanimously a proposed expenditure of $209,060,145 for New York's public schools in 1948-49.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- A union contract with a union shop provision, similar in terms to one signed yesterday by a mailers local of the International Typographical Union, AFL, with Baltimore newspaper publishers, was rejected on Dec. 9 by ITU Local 2, Chicago Mailers Union, when offered by the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association.

The American people are becoming increasingly shocked and alarmed by the bloodshed in Palestine which has followed the vote of the General Assembly of the United Nations on Nov. 29 to partition the Holy Land. In this alarm they seem to misunderstand the function of the Security Council under the Charter of the United Nations, and the hope that lies in its powers.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 21 - The immediate need for rapid expansion of facilities to train social workers in all specialized fields, but particularly in psychiatry, was stressed today by leaders in social work education. They are here to attend the annual meeting of the American Association of Schools of Social Work which begins officially tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Congressional policy leaders moved away today from long-range legislative planning for the electionyear session.

Further optimism regarding the firming of interest rates was indicated yesterday by William N. Enstrom, president of the Irving Trust Company, in an informal discussion following the bank's annual shareholders' meeting. A rise to 2 per cent on loans to business concerns with the highest credit rating from the current level of 1 3/4 per cent is a "possibility" this year, according to Mr. Enstrom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Captured Nazi documents reveal that the Soviet Government in the years 1939 to 1941 was bent on land-grabbing, on plans for the division of Europe, and on self-seeking in Asia. A 357-page volume containing 260 documents on NaziSoviet relations was published by the State Department today.

Specialty store buyers are showing a greater interest in popular price dress lines now on display in New York showrooms, according to manufacturers yesterday. A greater proportion of customers are smaller operators seeking price lines up to $12.75 wholesale, they said, while larger buyers have increased spring orders on numbers ordered previously.

Appointment of Dr. Spencer Miller Jr., Highway Commissioner of New Jersey, as adjunct professor of management and industrial relations at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance was announced yesterday by Dean John T. Madden.

Many luncheon parties were given in connection with the showing of diamonds arranged by Van Cleef Arpels in behalf of the Share Through CARE Committee, which was held yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

HAVANA, Jan. 21 -- Arbitration of disputes between member nations of the proposed International Trade Organization is not to be referred to the International Court of Justice. This was agreed today at a meeting of the subcommittee on organization matters at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 19 (Delayed) -- The United States charge d'affaires, Robert Menninger, has formally protested to Syrian Premier Jamil Mardam Bey against a tax law now pending before the Parliament. The law would levy a 5 per cent tax on all imports from the United States and a 2.5 per cent tax on imports from sterling areas while imports from France would be exempt from taxation.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, gave a reception yesterday in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel in honor of Col. Julius Klein of Chicago, National Commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States. Colonel Klein, who is at present commanding officer of the Thirtythird Quartermaster Group and Attached Service Troops of the Illinois National Guard, was honored for his service in both World Wars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -Several Senators met today in secret session to map what Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts described a "strategy" to be used in opposing the proposed St. Lawrence seaway legislation which the Senate will consider next week.

The Citizens Budget Commission has now completed publication of its report on five city departments, made at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer and with the helpful cooperation of city employes and business specialists. There is no question that the city will follow up the recommendations of this report, which sees the possibility ultimately -but not immediately -- of a $30,000,000 annual elimination of waste motion.

NANKING, Jan. 21 -- The Foreign Ministry delivered a note to the British Embassy tonight demanding compensation for the eviction of 2,000 Chinese squatters from Kowloon City. China claims jurisdiction over this six-acre parcel of land, which is geographically part of the British Leased Territory of Kowloon on the mainland opposite Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A strong declaration against the third party Presidential aspirations of Henry A. Wallace will be adopted tomorrow at a meeting of the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, it was forecast here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 -American railroads were warned today that every increase they put into effect in the cost of transportation of perishable products meant further diversion of business to trucks and other carriers.
Following ars textual excerpts from documents pertaining to Nazi-Soviet relations between 1939 and 1941 as made public yesterday by the State Department :

The weather around New York was generally nasty enough yesterday to justify the Weather Bureau's advance prediction of "snow, sleet and rain," but the precipitation ended at noon and the temperature rose. A predicted snowfall of three to five inches did not materialize.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad last year had a net income of $3,257,326 after charges, taxes and contingent interest, equal to $1.93 a share on the common stock outstanding, William White, president, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- A major diplomatic crisis between the French and British Governments developed today when, after a long discussion, they found themselves in a complete deadlock over the manner and extent of the proposed devaluation of French currency.

With textiles coming into greater supply, the peak of prices has about been reached, Sylvan Gotshal, of Weil, Gotshal Manges, attorneys, asserted last night at a forum on textile prices sponsored by the Textile Chapter of the American Veterans Committee in the Hotel Capitol.

F. Barry Ryan Jr., national champion, and W. D. Hoag, both of the home club and both at scratch, made their initial starts in the annual Bulldog squash tennis handicap tournament winning ones on the courts of the Yale Club last night.

The performance of Wagner's "Siegfried," given as the third of the matinee "Ring" cycle at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon, was one of exceptional excellence. Particularly this was the case in the first act. The Siegfried, Set Svanholm, not only looks the part and sings it very effectively, but is also admirable as an actor.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (AP) Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler and organized baseball are ready to make peace with the Mexican League and welcome back the many stars who jumped their teams for higher pay across the border in 1946, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A threatened strike of 1,400 engineers and firemen employed by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, set for Monday at 4 A.M., was postponed today forh)0*0*0*ithirty days as a result of a conference today at the office of the National (Railway) Mediation Board.

The order of popularity among evening radio programs is now headed by Bob Hope, who made the jump from eighth place, according to the latest statement from the C. E. Hooper organization. Fibber McGee and Molly, the erstwhile leaders, are now fourth.

Amid the pomp and circumstance so dear to the heart of the Asiatic and the Englishman, Great Britain and the Malayan rulers yesterday signed the agreements establishing the Federation of Malaya. It was another step down the path of vanishing Empire and colonialism.

Because it is not properly selling its product, the hosiery industry is operating at levels far below its true potential, it was declared last night by Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research for the J. Walter Thompson Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Increased national production as a result of enormous expenditures for producers' durable goods equipment was forecast today by Ewan Clague, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
Harold F. Cummings has joined the Vitamerican Oil Corporation as vice president in charge of sales. He formerly was with Merck Co. in the administrative sales division.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Grain markets turned reactionary in late trading on the Board of Trade today after an early upturn had carried May oats up 2 5/8 cents a bushel to a new seasonal peak and May corn to within 1 cent of the record for futures.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
The Florence Crittenton League, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Tonight at 8:30," with Gertrude Lawrence in the leading role, on the night of Feb. 24 at the National Theatre.

Liquor industry executives here received official notice of the serious setback in total industry sales for the first eleven months of 1947, when they received the Distilled Spirits Institute report of apparent consumption yesterday, spokesmen revealed.

Mayor O'Dwyer presented yesterday to forty seniors in the city's high schools scholarship checks for $200 each to help them through their first year in colleges or technical schools. The scholarships were awarded by the Columbus Citizens Committee, Inc., from a fund of $8,000.

PRAGUE, Jan. 21 -- Czechoslovak Mister of Justice Prokop Drtina charged today Communists employed in Communist party headquarters in Olomouc with preparing to assassinate three Ministers and asked that a Communist deputy's immunity be lifted for having plotted against the security of the republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen, heading back to the capital after another campaign swing through the West and South, is expected to decide before the week's end whether he will oppose Senator Robert A. Taft in the Ohio Republican Presidential primary.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Emperor Hirohito, former "divine" ruler of Japan, whose sacred mission was "bring all the world under a single roof," is now classifying himself as a member of "we the Japanese people." He made this clear today at the opening of the session of the second National Diet under the new American-written Constitution.

The new owners of the Longchamps chain of nine restaurants have reached an amicable settlement in another of the long list of woes they inherited from the chain's old owners, who are now in Federal prison for income tax fraud.
It is still "all or nothing" so far as his 1948 legislative program is concerned, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday.

The four-man committee appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to seek settlement of the strike of 2,350 radio and cable workers in this city decided yesterday to go in for a modern version of Mohammed and the mountain.

Proposals to consolidate the banking operation of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company with another small bank or banks, if offered, would receive the consideration of the company's management, Harold W. Hoyt, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

A step toward restoration of the Port of New York as the grain gateway of the United States was taken yesterday when the Port of New York Authority opened its new $350,000 grain gallery at its terminal on Gowanus Bay, Brooklyn.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 (AP) -A bitter, no-holds-barred contest for Governor of Louisiana was in prospect tonight between Earl K. Long and Sam Houston Jones, both of whom have held the office before.
Under heavy trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, the market yesterday closed 5 to 68 points net lower, with March and May showing the most pronounced weakness.

The largest construction job in history, a $2,483,000,000 project to make the Panama Canal virtually invulnerable to any kind of attack, including that by atom bomb, was recommended yesterday by Col. James H. Stratton, supervising engineer of the Panama Canal.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- The Committee for Public Order met today under the chairmanship of Vice Premier Randolfo Pacciardi and considered measures necessary to face the rising tide of lawlessness caused by a seemingly endless chain of Communist-instigated strikes and agitations.

The same hunter who carries a .410 or a 28-gauge shotgun in the quail covers often proves to be the man who will be found in a duckboat on Great South Bay with a 12-gauge magnum, both barrels bored full choke.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Britain's recovery depends upon Britain's own efforts, the Marquess of Linlithgow, chairman of the Midland Bank, says in the annual statement of the bank which will be published tomorrow.

Dr. Allen O. Whipple, Professor Emeritus of Surgery at Columbia University, has been named chairman of a group to make a national appeal to doctors and hospitals for medical and surgical supplies needed in war-devastated areas, the Medical and Surgical Relief Committee announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The picture of a hesitant, fearful Japan being goaded toward war in the spring of 1941 by Adolf Hitler and his Foreign Minister, Joachim von Ribbentrop, is given in the documents on Russo-German relations published by the State Department today.

Advice on how to handle snow and ice damage to plants and trees caused by recent storms was given yesterday by Clarence E. Lewis, instructor in woody plants at the School of Horticulture of the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute in Farmingdale.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 -- A charge by the Soviet newspaper Izvestia that the Arab League was reactionary and operated on Fascist lines brought a retort from the league today. Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha replied that the Russian press was unjustified in its accusation and adding that "Communist dictatorships are not, in the eyes of the Arab people, a better system of Government."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, told the House Labor Committee today that he expected a new contract being negotiated with the broadcasting industry would "settle" the question of "live music" broadcasts by stations on frequency modulation and television circuits.

The eleven-week-old strike of 1,200 sandhogs on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel ended last night with an agreement calling for a wage increase of $2 a day. The men, who have been idle sinceh)0*0*0*iNov. 3, will return to work this morning.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- History in its most important sense will be made here tomorrow when Foreign Secretary Bevin reports on Britain's new foreign policy to the House of Commons. Inspired guessing here tonight is that he will announce Britain's willingness to take part in a United States of Europe and to work toward that goal.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The United States' twelveman A.A.U. Olympic hockey team arrived today and expressed concern over the high altitude after its initial workout on the Kursiline rink.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 -Yale ran its string of consecutive dual meet swimming victories to twenty-seven by overpowering the La Salle College natators, 51 -- 24, in Payne Whitney pool tonight.

Helene Druke and Walter Shaw, duo-pianists, gave their first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The carefully devised program contained the Introduction and Fugue from Reger's "Introduction, Passacaglia and Fugue," Op. 96; Busoni's "Duettino Concertante, after the Finale of Mozart's Concerto in F major"; Liszt's "Concerto Pathetique," the Debussy-Ravel "Fetes," the SchuhannDebussy "Etude en forme deanon," No. 4, and items by Arensky, Rachmaninoff, Beryl Rubinstein, Copland and Petyrek.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The United States in a statement presented to the Far Eastern Commission today announced that it was planning measures for making Japan "self-supporting at the earliest possible time."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -Veterans would have a choice of taking a windfall dividend on their GI insurance in cash or having it applied to their premiums, under a new proposal made today by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Republican, of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Committee on Veterans Affairs.

Using substitutes throughout the fourth quarter, Fordham easily captured its tenth straight basketball victory, 58 -- 50, from the New York State Maritime Academy last night at the Fort Schuyler gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today a further extension, from Jan. 19 to Jan. 27, of the date for filing requested findings and supporting briefs in opposition to the proxy solociting material filed by the management of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

The produce dealers' complaint, reported yesterday, that housewives were cutting down drastically on purchases of fresh fruits and vegetables because meat and dairy products deflate their budgets, may mean that families are just not eating enough of these foods.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 27 The National Canners Association today called on the Government for immediate adoption of a program to secure sufficient foreign workers for the harvesting of food crops during 1948.

Eric Rosenblith, violinist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. Mr. Rosenblith, who came to this country from Vienna, made his American debut in 1941, when he was 21. After his second local recital in 1943, he was called into the Army, and had not made a subsequent appearance in this city until yesterday evening.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Fourteen persons were injured, two seriously, when an Eastern Airlines plane skidded, crashed and burned on an icy runway at Logan Airport at 4:20 A.M. today.

The executive board of the Greater New York CIO Council called on the United States Immigration and Naturalization Serviceh)0*0*0*iyesterday to rescind an order barring the re-entry into the United States of Charles A. Doyle, CIO leader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In the presence of a distinguished assemblage, including high officials of church and state from all parts of this country and from countries abroad, Archbishop Patrick A. O'Boyle, consecrated a week ago by Francis Cardinal Spellman in St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, was installed today as the first resident Archbishop of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall issued a statement today saying that John Foster Dulles was "pitifully uninformed" in his criticism that the Army administration in Germany acted as if it hadn't heard about the European Recovery Program.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 -- The Arabs renewed their attack on the Jewish settlement of Yehiam, near the Lebanese border, before dawn today. Although on a small scale compared to yesterday's attack, it confirmed a change in Arab tactics from casual, disorganized fights to organized raids.

Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, after describing himself as a foe of price ceilings and rationing, went on record yesterday as favoring "something in the way of controls" if 1948 is a bad crop year and meat is in extremely short supply, as predicted.

Excellent progress toward rehabilitation was made last year in the Philippines, it was reported yesterday by C. A. Richards, president of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce, at its annual meeting at India House. Mr. Richards, who is a director of the export division of the Interchemical Corporation, was re-elected head of the organization.

The Governor Inspected proposed sites for new state buildings with Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly and Public Works Commissioner Charles H. Sells. Worked on executive budget. Addressed New York State Agricultural Society.

Approximately 63 per cent of the 228 leading bankers throughout the United States participating in the latest credit survey of the American Bankers Association believes that bank loans will continue to increase during the first six months of this year, it was reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- A brief, four-line statement guaranteeing freedom of information was approved here today by a group of international journalistic experts for inclusion in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Dr. Ivan Kerno, United Nations Assistant Secretary General for Legal Affairs, said today that the United Nations Balkan Committee had found it impossible to attempt its task of conciliation because of the attitude shown by the Soviet Union and Poland, which have refused to serve on the committee, together with the policy of non-cooperation followed by Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria.

CAIRO, Jan. 21 -- Inscriptions on sandstone mortuary slabs discovered on the Sinai Peninsula near ancient turquoise mines are said to be the oldest form of characters from which the English alphabet originated. They are believed to be from the fifteenth century B.C. land to antedate the Exodus.
The American Museum of Natural History will put on public view for the first time beginning today one of the great treasures of anthropology.

Hospital affiliation for "general practitioners" of medicine was announced yesterday-by Dr. A. A. Karan, director of Bronx Hospital. Dr. Karan said the institution was establishing a general practice section in its staff, to which twentyfive physicians would be admitted initially.

An aggressive drive to enlist top industrial management, labor educational and community groups in support of a campaign to increase public understanding of the American economic system will be started Feb. 1 by a joint committee of the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In this space recently was reported a movement by nine young Americans, veterans of special public service during World War II, to induce Congress to create a Specialists Reserve Corps. This group is designed as a pool of talents and skills which the government always needs and will need more acutely than ever if the European Recovery Program is authorized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -Shipowners today proposed a "get tough" program to cut down on the growing crop of stowaways who are illegally entering the United States on American ships.

THERE has been increasing agitation of late to do something about the basketball rules which seem to satisfy no one. Many of the suggested changes are so radical that Dr. James Naismith, the inventor of the sport, must be spinning uneasily in his grave. However, he should be the last person to be concerned because the dribble diversion no longer is the same game that he conceived more than a half century ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 The United States has bluntly told Yugoslavia that she has no right to interfere in the administration of the joint Anglo-American zone of the Trieste Free Territory, Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, disclosed today.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Premier Tito of Yugoslavia has made another proposal to the United States in an effort to obtain the release of frozen gold funds in America which formerly belonged to the Royal Yugoslav Government and which are estimated at $70,000,000.

A cowboy suit that caught fire and caused the death of an 8-yearold boy provoked a damage suit that resulted yesterday in a $64,500 verdict for the youngster's father. The costume was presented by Milton A. Henry, president of the M. A. Henry Company, to James McCormack, doorman at 15 West Eighty-first Street, as a Christmas gift for the latter's son, Thomas, who died on May 12, 1945.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Great Britain and France were informed of the decision of the State Department to publish today the volume of diplomatic correspondence on Nazi-Soviet relations from 1939 to 1941 that were captured from the German foreign office by British and American arms near the end of hostilities.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Four battleships and a battle cruiser, including some of the oldest and best-loved ships in the Royal Navy, are to be scrapped, Viscount Hall, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Lords today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Reporting to stockholders of the County Trust Company at their annual meeting here today, Andrew Wilson Jr., chairman of the board of directors, said the net current operating earnings of the bank for 1947 after taxes amounted to $489,513, compared with $339,059 in 1946.

From the collection of Nazi-Soviet documents for the war years 1939 to 1941, seized by American troops in Germany, made public last night by the State Department and printed extensively in THE TIMES this morning, we cite one item as typical. It is taken from the "secret additional protocol" to the celebrated Russo-German NonAggression Pact of Aug. 23, 1939.

" Dollars and Sense" was the theme of a showing held in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. An unusual exhibition for the gilded hall, it was the first showing of popular-priced fashions to be held on its platform and runway.
United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended with last December consolidated net income of an estimated $11,613,000.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- A fresh bout of selling knocked more millions of pounds off the market value of British Government securities in the stock markets here today.
BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- United States and British troops will be used to collect food from German farmers unless voluntary deliveries show an early improvement.

Two new films will oven in midtown theatres today. At Loew's Criterion, the attraction is "T-Men," a topical drama produced by Edward Small and released by Eagle-Lion Films. Dennis O'Keefe is starred in the offering, which was directed by Anthony Mann and features Jane Randolph, Alfred Ryder, June Lockhart and Wally Ford...
A challenge of the will of Clifford B. Harmon, Westchester real estate dealer and aviation enthusiast, who died in 1945, was revealed yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A peremptory demand that the Administration produce at once a major plan to aid the Government of China, while Congress is heavily engaged on the European Recovery Program, has been served on Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

As a result of the recommendation by the Citizens Budget Commission that the Police Department save funds by assigning only one man to radio patrol cars, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander has ordered a ten-day trial of the method in outlying sections of the five boroughs.

Members of the Bronx County Democratic Committee of the Twenty-fourth Congressional District nominated Karl Propper, former president of the Bronx Bar Association, for Representative last night at a meeting in Public School 62 at 660 Fox Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Housewives appealed to a Senate committee today for lower prices on meat and other commodities, but independent packers warned that restored controls would only find meat counters bare and a greater black market reborn.
Following is the text of Zetter sent by AdoZf Hitler to Benitol!olizi ow tlze eve of tle rmo invasion of tzz. It is ores ofthe captured Na,i do.merits publked yesterday:P June 21, 1941.

Visitors to New York contribute $4,500,000 a year to the city treasury through the 5 per cent tax on transient rooms, according to a survey released yesterday by the Hotel Association of New York City.

Establishment of an American fund to stabilize Chinese currency will not provide a complete solution to the problem of expanding Chinese export volume, A. Guy Hope, consul at Shanghai, declared yesterday. He stated that such a currency stabilization fund is regarded by several American and Chinese businessmen as practically the only step necessary to step up Chinese exports to this country, an essential development if American exports to China are to expand.

During the current housing crisis, methods involving the exercise of a form of pressure against tenants have sometimes been used to turn rental apartments into "cooperatives." Many truly "cooperative" projects are, of course, unexceptionable -- when, for instance, the tenants of a building willingly agree to purchase their own apartments.

New mortgage loans amounting to about $29,140,000 were contracted for during 1947 by the Institutional Securities Corporation, which is owned by the savings banks of New York State, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting by Robert E. Pratt, president.

The close-checking tactics of the Detroit Red Wings brought them victory in their National Hockey League game with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The opportunists from the automobile city forced the local skaters to fashion all the breaks, and when they were presented the Red Wing puck-chasers capitalized just enough to carve a success, 4 to 3.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan told close to 390 persons attending the tenth annual beefsteak of the Boxing Writers Association of New York at Ruppert's Brewery last night the "boxing must clean up or close up."

In his new role as head man of the All America Football Conference's Dodgers, Branch Rickey yesterday named Carl Marvin Voyles, 46-year-old Oklahoman, as head coach and almost in the same breath defied the National Football League.
The President Ended efforts to install General Kuter as chairman of Civil Aeronautics Board with rebuke to Senate committee that blocked appointment.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan told the United Nations Palestine Commission today that it was "not possible" for Britain to comply with the recommendation of the United Nations for the opening by Feb. 1 of a major seaport to permit substantial Jewish immigration into the Holy Land.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Seven days before the invasion of Poland, Germany and Russia cold-bloodedly and secretly planned to carve eastern Europe. Then, as Poland crumbled, Russia began a doublecross that won her a larger share of the territorial booty.

Mrs. Harriet Gardiner Lynch Coogan, widow of Manhattan's first Borough President and a descendant of John Lion Gardiner of Gardiner's Island, who died Dec. 18 in the Biltmore Hotel, where she had lived in seclusion for the last thirty-two years, left an estate of $2,521,000 and no will.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -Following is the text of the statement by General McCoy to the Far Eastern Commission today:

Dallas, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Feb. 10 on $6,000,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1948, and due from Aug. 1, 1948, to Feb. 1, 1958. Interest must not exceed 4 per cent.

" The Portrait of Gertrude Stein," one of Picasso's earliest works and a recent bequest to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, makes its appearance today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fiftythird Street, under an agreement reached by the two institutions last September.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 19 (delayed) (AP) -- Russian officers declared here today that the Germans "are not our friends" and criticized the occupation policy of the West, which they said was fostering a resurgent Germany.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Sacha Guitry, appearing in his first play since the liberation, has received a unanimous zero for his efforts from Parisian theatre critics. All found that his play on the life of Talleyrand, "The Limping Devil," was really not a play at all but a series of disconnected scenes getting thinner, emptier and more monotonous as they go along.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board hung up a twelve-year monthly record in the number of cases received and elections conducted in December, 1947. It announced todayh)0*0*0*ithat the 2,064 cases handled in that month were an all-time high.

The Gilbert and Sullivan addict who told this department recently that he had been digging into musty records in order to learn the facts concerning the "Pinafore" craze, which engulfed New York and the rest of the United States when that sprightly show first burst upon the American theatrical horizon long, long ago, has turned from excavating to theorizing.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A Communist party speaker at a Lenin memorial meeting in Moscow said tonight, in the presence of Premier Joseph Stalin, that "British and American imperialism are rushing to share the same fate a Germany," a Moscow radio broadcast reported.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,053,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks at the week-end stood at 98,751,000 barrels, compared with 96,698,000 a week earlier and 96,354,000 on Jan. 18, 1947.

" THE CIRCUS IN THE ATTIC"* is a collection of short stories by Robert Penn Warren, whose excellent-novel, "All the King's Men," won the Pulitzer Prize last year. They are good stories mainly, about the South and the academic life, and they are written by a man who obviously hates cliches whether in phrases or point of view and will go to considerable pains to avoid them for himself and for his readers.

When the dental clinic at Grand Street Settlement, 283 Rivington Street, reopens next Wednesday, the neighborhood will have its first settlement clinic open to all children of the area from age 2 to 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall denied today that the Army Department here or the American Military Government in Germany had done anything which in his opinion would hamper the European Recovery Program.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 21 -- Declaring that the Soviet Union is doing its utmost to prevent recovery in Europe, Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State, declared today that this nation's European Recovery Program had replaced the long-sought great power leadership as the last best hope for recovery abroad and American security at home.

Gyorgy Sandor, Hungarian pianist, has certainly given recitals enough since his debut here eight years ago, yet his appearance last night at Carnegie Hall showed that the fixed program requiring sustained interpreting must remain a nervous ordeal for him.

NANKING, Jan. 21 -- After a month's delay caused by the difficulty of opportioning seats in advanceh)0*0*0*iamong the participating parties, a three-day national Parliamentary election began here today. There was the same lack of popular enthusiasm that marked China's first experiment with a democratic election in November.

Slightly higher interest rates and continued efforts on the part of the United States Treasury to maintain 2 1\2 per cent interest on long-term obligations were forecast yesterday by J. Luther Cleveland, chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company, at the bank's annual meeting.
MIAMI. Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Incline, a 12-to-5 shot running in the silks of the Washington contractor Joseph Tucci, captured today's mile-and-a-furlong Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah Park.

Palestine Commission -- Heard British representative Sir Alexander Cadogan reject recommendation of General Assembly for opening a major port in Palestine by Feb. 1 to permit beginning of large-scale Jewish immigration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -Lewis Milestone will direct the screen version of Libby Block's novel, "Wild Calendar," as his next production for Enterprise, it wash)0*0*0*ilearned from the studio today. The picture is scheduled to start within two months and Arnold Nanoff is completing the scenario, which is described by Enterprise as a domestic comedy laid in Denve.

BAGHDAD, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -The Iraq Regent and Crown Prince and political leaders decided at a meeting here today that the new Anglo-Iraq treaty signed at Portsmouth, England, on Jan. 15 "does not realize the national aims of Iraq" a Royal Palace statement announced tonight.

The District Attorney's office and the police have widened the investigation of wills prepared by Fred Lasch, undertaker who has been indicted for forgery, and yesterday were studying eight documents left mostly by elderly women who named Lasch their undertaker and often the executor of their estates.

Despite a disappointed welcoming committee, Miss Sonja Henie, renowned figure-skating star, arrived in New York yesterday and, to the surprise of a hundred hockey fans, gave a brief exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night.

Though he will be 81 years old in March, Arturo Toscanini is planning to go to Italy early in May to conduct a program in memory of Arrigo Boito at La Scala in Milan, it was learned yesterday. The program will consist of scenes from operas by the composer-librettist, the thirtieth anniversary of whose death falls on June 10.

When the Ninth Division of the First United States Army captured the German Foreign Office documents in April, 1945, many GI's wondered why anyone should get excited over stacks of paper when cities, towns, palaces, hotels and wine-cellars were falling by the hundreds.

The autobiography of Tom SuIgrue, author of "There Is a River"and "Starling of the White House,"Iwill be published by Holt on April12, under the title of "Stranger inthe Earth: The Story of a Search."'.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman ended today his efforts to install Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board with a rebuke to the Senate Armed Services Committee.

W. Sanger Green, United States manager for Irish Air Lines (Aer Lingus), announced here yesterday that its regular transatlantic service would begin on March 17. President Truman earlier in the day had approved the Civil Aeronautics Board's grant of a foreign air carrier permit.

The "distorted impression" that the state contributes 80 per cent of the city's public welfare costs is "simply not true," Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding declared yesterday in a communication to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Democratic program bills, exclusive of those pertaining to the "package" program of Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York, went into the legislative hoppers in the Senate and Assembly today. The bills cover rent control, housing, labor, state aid, discrimination and child care centers, implementing the program outlined recently by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, State Democratic Chairman.

" Angel Street," the psychological melodrama by Patrick Hamilton, will be revived tonight at the City Center, the civic playhouse, as the second of three productions by the newly established New York City Theatre Company. The acting group, which hopes to take its place beside the City Center's regular program of operas, symphony and ballet, started its career early this month with "Volpone."
The Cabinet Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

A study of clarifying amendments to the Robinson-Patman Act to be made by the American Labor Association, was noted yesterday at the symposium held by the Section on Food Drug and Cosmetics Law of the New York State Bar Association.
The Religious Society of Friends in Brooklyn appeared yesterday to have saved its school and meeting house from being torn down to make way for a city jail.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 21 -- Dinner hour at the United States-requisitioned Grand Hotel here was punctuated tonight by an explosion of a small bomb, which blew out all the panes from a large window and sent a party of diners tumbling in all directions.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 21 -- As a Rumanian delegation left Bucharest today to sign a treaty of mutual assistance with Hungary, it was reported that a secret protocol extended the military clauses of the Balkan agreements already signed to all the allies of the signatory.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 21 The Governors of Missouri River Basin states decided today to carry their efforts to obtain sufficient funds for development of the valley through flood control, irrigation, navigation and hydro-electric power direct to Congressional appropriation subcommittees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Excerpts from the statement on the Marshall Plan made today by former President Herbert Hoover to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations of the United States Senate, follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- With an eye to bolstering their case for tax relief, Senate and House Republican leaders agreed at a joint meeting today to press for a quick decision on how deeply Congress should slash President Truman's $39,700,000,000 budget.

The birth rate of the Soviet Union is more than twice that of the United States, the National Committee on Immigration Policy asserted yesterday in a pamphlet entitled "Immigration and Population Policy."

In your editorial "Year-End Figures" you state that the Truman Administration, even after deducting "war items," is spending considerably more than twice as much as the Coolidge Administration did for an equivalent length of time. Without speaking of the specific figures involved, shouldn't we consider the fact that the entire price structure has changed since the Coolidge Administration?

An errant Liberty ship sent several dozen workers in an office on Pier 13, East River, at Wall Street, scurrying for safety yesterday when the vessel crashed into the two-story pier shed at 11:45 A.M.

An unauthorized strike by 250 union employes of the Shelton Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Fortyninth Street disrupted services from 12:30 to 3:30 P.M. yesterday. The walkout in the thirtytwo-story building ended when union officials, arriving two hours after the strike started, arranged for a grievance meeting with the management this morning.

The New York City League of Women Voters will ask Mayor O'Dwyer to appoint a non-partisan commission of experts on economic matters to study the city's financial problems and make recommendations for their solution, Mrs. Donald Hutchinson, vice president in charge of municipal affairs, announced yesterday.

A warning against drastic use by the Government of monetary controls was sounded yesterday by George Whitney, president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., at the annual meeting of stockholders of the banking house. Cautious and wise use of their authority must be exercised by the authorities to avoid any serious disturbance of the natiqn's economy, he said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. Jan. 21 -- Secret negotiations between India and Pakistan broke down tonight and the United Nations Security Council will be faced tomorrow with a demand for an immediate investigation into all the disputes that have brought the two Dominions near the point of War.
BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -Miss Peggy Kirk carded a 2-underpar 75 today for a two-stroke lead at the end of the first eighteen holes of the $3,000 Belleview-Biltmore women's open golf tournament.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, accused Hollywood today of trying to "squeeze" the British Government into lifting its 75 per cent duty on foreign film profits here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Andreyevitch Gromyko, known and feared among the corps of interpreters here as the most exacting man to translate and the most outspoken critic of the language experts, interrupted today's debate in the working committee of the Commission for Conventional Armaments to offer his first words of praise to an astounded novice interpreter.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 21 -The Army basketball team, paced by the 16 points of Bud Shepherd, overwhelmed Williams College, 53 -- 27, today before a small crowd in the field house.

ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- An announcement of the Ministry of Supply said today that to exercise more effective control over the distribution of supplies and prices, the Ministry would be reorganized with wider powers. The department of imported commodities will be abolished, with the state-sponsored Agricultural Bank assuming most of its functions.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey tonight warned farmers against expanding production further and advised them to pay off their debts and to strive for increasing their production efficiency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The tenth anniversary of the March of Dimes campaign for infantile paralysis victims was celebrated today by a nation-wide broadcast from the White House.
Public utility bond issues totaling $55,000,000 will be offered to investors today by underwritingh)0*0*0*imanagers, as follows:

JERUSALEM, Jan. 22 -- Mrs. Golda Myerson, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, left here by plane for New York today to mobilize United States Jews behind the Zionist efforts to form their new state in Palestine.

The appointment of Daniel D. Strohmeier as vice president in charge of the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company was announced yesterday by A.B. Homer, president. Mr. Strohmeier, who has been assistant to the division's vice president since 1942, succeeds the late W.H. Collins.

A way must be found to bring down building costs so that millions of persons who now are not eligible for public housing projects but cannot afford the current high prices for housing can have homes, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday.

A $134,000,000 sewage treatment program, needed by New York to cleanse waterways surrounding the city and to provide safe conditions for bathing and other recreation is being held up by "other urgent needs," it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, in the Commodore Hotel.

Having successfully shaken "Volpone" out of their systems, the players of the City Center company have hurried into an excellent performance of "Angel Street," which they presented last evening. As a creep-show, Patrick Hamilton's Victorian melodrama remains close to the top of the class -- literate and harrowing simultaneously.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman has lost an opportunity for open support by the Council of Economic Advisers for his controversial $40 tax credit plan and other economic policies, it was learned today, because the council has split over the question whether it should end its attitude of objective detachment.

Believing that to complement other fashions this spring, hats should be extremely feminine and eye-appealing, Anita Andra indulged to the fullest her liking for flowers, veils and scarf-draped trims in her spring collection shown yesterday at 558 Madison Avenue. Used for trim or to fashion entirely many of the models were such French fabrics as striped moire, paint-dotted malines and fine veilings.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- Offering a number of design changes, the 1948 Chevrolet models were announced today by the Chevrolet division of General Motors Corporation. They will be placed on display by dealers in New York City within a few days.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The British had 158 airplanes with which to defend Malaya and the vital naval base of Singapore when the Japanese struck in December, 1941.

A blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court found Samuel Tito Williams, 19 years old, guilty last night of first-degree murder, with a recommendation of mercy. The jury, all men, deliberated six and a half hours.

The stock market labored yesterday under the shadow of Wednesday's late selling wave, absorbing further liquidation until a technical rebound of limited proportions developed in the final hour. Most losses were fractional, although a few key industrials fell 1 to 2 points.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Supported by all parties in the house of Lords Lord Vansittart proposed today that the kid-glove attitude toward the Soviet Union on the issue of its refusal to allow the Russian wives of Britons to join their husbands here, be changed to one of retaliation.

Another fall of snow visited the North Country yesterday and reports indicate that good to excellent skiing -- a habit thus far this winter -- will be found at every point. The heaviest accumulation of snow in years now covers the network of trails and slopes in the Northlands. With the prediction of cold weather for the week-end, conditions should be ideal.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Mexican High Commissioner of Baseball Alejandro Aguilar Reyes announced tonight that "all differences between the Mexican League and organized baseball in the United States have ended."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A proposal that the working day be increased by an extra hour, at existing overtime rates, was advanced today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as a major step to combat inflation and increase production.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Great Britain became today the champion and proposer of a "western union" of European countries. In launching this vast conception, whose economic and political links would reach around the world, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin put an end to centuries of British traditions and policies.

A field mechanic for the Consolidated Edison Company was killed yesterday by gas poisoning while at work in an excavation at Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue. Two other employes, who had come to his aid, were overcome.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 22 -- Czechoslovakia's election campaign is practically launched and two of the parties announced in their press today that elections could be expected early in May, probably on the first Sunday. The date will be set at a meeting of the National Front Coalition next Wednesday.

We think the late Philip A. Benson, for many years president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, would highly approve the memorial that has just been created for him. Some seventy-six savings banks of New York State and individuals have established at the Long Island College of Medicine an endowed fellowship fund of $34,200 for resident research in tribute to Mr. Benson's life and work.

The date of June 19 has been set for the Bermuda race, which is held every other year by the Cruising Club of America in conjunction with the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club. It will be started again off Newport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 17, 1948, totaled 811,286 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,161 cars, or 2.4 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 16,774 cars, or 2.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 61,843 cars, or 8.3 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturers, had a net income in the fiscal year ended last October of $28,509,657 after taxes and all charges, equal to $8.24 a share on 3,459,988 shares outstanding, the annual report to stockholders showed yesterday.

I am afraid that your editorial of Jan. 12 referring to the dispute between the Minister of Health and the medical profession in Britain gives the erroneous impression that the doctors are quibbling over trivial details, and that because the Minister has entered into what he euphemistically terms 'negotiations' with the profession, that he cannot be planning tyranny.

The Newark Board of Education will open its frequency-modulation station WBGO-FM Thursday, Feb. 5, in a program from 2:30 to 3:30 P.M. The station, assigned to the wave length of 91.1 megacycles, is situated atop the Central Technical and Commercial High School building at High and New Streets.

Department of Commerce sizing standardization plans applicable to virtually all segments of the boys', girls and infants' apparel industry have been accepted by more than thirty-six knit underwear manufacturers in the field, Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, revealed yesterday.

PARIS, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Premier Robert Schuman said that the Cabinet decided early today that the French Government would hold its position on devaluation of the franc through creation of an "export franc."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Refrigerated Cargoes, Inc., of New York City asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to start a coastwise steamship service between New York and Jacksonville and Fort Pierce, Fla. Transportation of general commodities and commodities requiring refrigeration is proposed.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- Incidents occurred in Milan and Florence today during demonstrations staged by the unemployed. They assumed particular gravity in Florence, where they degenerated into rioting in which sixteen persons were injured and where a general strike was declared late this evening.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- District Judge Justin Hinshaw today ruled the University of Oklahoma could deny the entrance of a Negro to its law school provided the state has a separate school ready for Negroes by next Monday, but left two alternatives in the event it could not be in operation.

The Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Diocese of New York has taken action approving the principle of a Fair Educational Practices Act for the State of New York. If enacted, such legislation will prohibit discrimination on the basis of race, religion, color or national origin in the educational institutions of the state.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- The Southam Group, Canada's largest newspaper chain, has just completed its second year of publication under strike conditions, which at one time crippled five of its six influential dailies in key cities across the Dominion.

Little misses, from christening to teen-age, may now wear adaptations of real Paris styles by Rene Mola, of Dominique of Paris. M. Mola brought fifteen of his models to New York and has personally supervised their execution. The copies were placed on exhibition yesterday on the seventh floor at Lord Taylor's.

Reduction of bank earnings "below expenses and a reasonable return on capital" may become an alternative to the special reserve plan proposed by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, according to M.S. Szymczak, a member of the board.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Spokesmen for professional athletes and club owners united today in opposing legislation which would outlaw -- in Massachusetts at least -- the much discussed reserve clause in players' contracts and forbid trades of players without consent.

Max J. Jelin, 40-year-old theatrical producer, was killed yesterday in an explosion of the kitchen gas stove in his fourteenth-floor apartment at 300 East Fifty-seventh Street. The blast ripped out the walls adjoining two other apartments in the new eighteen-story building.

When the City Department of Markets conducted its regular weekly survey on food prices here yesterday, it found a few items that had declined slightly. Butter, for example, dropped from 97 cents a pound to 93. Tariffs on Grade A eggs decreased 2 cents, with the large now 79 cents and mediums 69 cents.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Stripping off overcoat and sweater and tying a rope around his waist as hundreds looked on, Robert Macko, 16 years old, East Rutherford High School junior, dived into the icy Passaic River at 8:30 o'clock this morning to rescue Mrs. Sadie Levine, 53, of 21 Aspen Street, Passaic.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Strand the attraction is "Treasure of Sierra Madre," an adaptation of the novel by B. Traven, produced by Warner Brothers and starring Humphrey Bogart.

Two sharply conflicting views on how to rehabilitate Europe with the least possible harm to the United States' domestic economy were presented last night by Senator C. Wayland Brooks, Illinois Republican, and Willard L. Thorp, assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

Hart H. Fleming, formerly a vice president of the National Foam System, Inc., has been elected president. He succeeds Fisher L. Boyd, who has been made chairman. Frank R. Wallace, president of the Tabor Manufacturing 'Company, has been elected a director of National Foam.
Random notes.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The United Kingdom appealed today to India and Pakistan to resume their broken-off negotiations on bringing peace to the princely state of Kashmir.

PARIS, Friday, Jan. 23 -- French officials said that the International Monetary Fund, meeting in Washington, simply could not reject the French devaluation plan, for it was indispensable to save the French financial situation.

Declaring the plight of the blind and the handicapped in Europe worse than that of any other group, the American Foundation for the Overseas Blind announced yesterday it would seek $300,000 to help replace schools, workshops and materials destroyed in the war.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 22 -- The Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee adopted today a six-year combined Federal and state program calling for a budget of $2,415,541,831 for the development of land and water resources in the Missouri River Valley.

With the closing date for entries Jan. 31, twenty-two nations have filed entries for the 1948 Davis Cup competition, it was announced yesterday by Walter Merrill Hall, chairman of the Davis Cup Committee of Management. The official draw is expected to be made during the first ten days of next month.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 22 -- The Government of Brazil appeared greatly strengthened today when representatives of democratic party organizations signed a pact to support the regime and back President Eurico Gaspar Durra.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Bernard M. Baruch has endorsed Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, who was president of the United Nations General Assembly last year, for the Nobel Peace Prize for 1948, it was learned today.

Accused of stealing $10,493 in funds received by mail for purchase of passenger overseas reservations, Joseph T. Featherstone, 31-year-old manager of the international ticket office of American Airlines, Inc., 18 West Forty-ninth Street, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on an indictment charging grand larceny and forgery.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 22 -- Finland's turn to join the Soviet Union's system of military security pacts with its satellites appears to be close at hand, informed political circles in the Finnish capital believe.
Three additional wills were uncovered yesterday in which Fred Lasch, upper East Side undertaker, had been the executor and which had been filed by his friend and attorney, Bernard Mastromonaco.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The British Foreign Office said today that representatives of the United States, Britain and France would meet in March to decide what would be included in "the first two volumes" of a series based upon, more than 2,000,000 captured German diplomatic documents.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the board of trade in the early trading today with wheat breaking 6 cents, corn 5 cents and oats 4% cents at the extremes, but on the break aggressive support developed headed by cash interests and a strong rally followed.

The 6,185-ton liner Acadia, built sixteen years ago for the Eastern Steamship Lines, is becoming the mystery ship of the Atlantic seaboard. Released from war duty a year ago, she is still not in service, despite the urgent need for passenger tonnage under the United States flag.

Virtually all of the estate of Lieut. Lester N. Hofheimer of the Army Air Forces, who was killed in action on Dec. 12, 1943, was bequeathed for charitable purposes. This was disclosed in a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Estate Tax Commissioner Charles W. Ferry.
St. Paul, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Feb. 3 on $1,000,000 of bridge improvement bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1948, and due Feb. 1 from 1949 to 1978.

A further contra-seasonal rise of $16,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System occurred during the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the latest increase brought the total of such borrowings to $5,343,000,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- To encourage the immediate construction of new homes to relieve the housing shortage in New York City, Assemblyman Frank J. McMullen, Republican, of Brooklyn, proposed today partial tax exemption for new homes and apartment houses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- During the week ended Jan. 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $529,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

THERE was enough steam generated at the boxing writers' dinner the other night to have blown a manhole cover as high as the Empire State Building. District Attorney Frank Hogan fired the first blast when he admonished the ring game to "clean up or close up." It was a ringing challenge that had the mob from Jacobs Beach squirming uncomfortably.

TWENTY-EIGHT years ago Joan of Arc was canonized a saint, 517 years after she was burned to death in Rouen market place for a variety of personal, political and religious reasons. The illiterate peasant girl from Domremy, on the border of Lorraine, is the national heroine of France, a legendary figure about whom most Americans, in spite of her fame, know surpris ingly little.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Michael Strauss Jacobs, for nearly twenty-five years one of the world's leading fight promoters, announced today that "win, lose or draw," he will "retire from boxing forever" after a return match this spring between heavyweight champion Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Wolcott.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 -- The movement to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President spanned the continent today with the formal organization of a group to press his electoral fortunes in the key state of California.
Heard Britain ask India and Pakistan to resume negotiations, and adopted agenda labeling dispute as "India-Pakistan" case.

The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company and its subsidiaries had a net income in 1947 amounting to $2,650,000, equal to $1.37 a share, against $2,701,000, or $1.40 a share, the year before, Robert V. White, president, reported yesterday.

Everybody knows that ours is a crowded city. Reminders of that fact are all around us. Visiting firemen and commuting citizens who are caught in town overnight are hard put to find a place to lay their heads.

Lever Brothers Company will spend nearly $500,000 on a national advertising campaign in support of its "$100,000 Fur Contest" which opens Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday. The sales promotion drive will continue for six weeks, during which five separate contests will be held.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- A mass conference of teen-agers of all nationalities will be held at the United Nations headquarters to help promote the coming international campaign for funds for underfed youngsters throughout the world's war-devastated areas.

With due apologies to the weather man, another "ice" show arrived in New York last night. Residents in this area, unenthusiastic to say the least about this winter, reacted differently at Madison Square Garden last night when Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue were presented.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Excerpts from Foreign Secretary Bevin's address before the House of Commons today on world affairs follows:

Bruno Walter gave a memorable concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. One could not imagine a performance more eloquent and impressive than the reading of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony. And the symphony is undoubtedly Bruckner's greatest work in the form.
BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk, carded a 3-under-par 74 today for 149 and a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the 72-hole Belleview- Biltmore women's open golf tournament.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 22 -- The United States and British Military Governments officially disclosed today the lowering of food rations for the so-called normal consumer from 1,550 calories daily to 1,400 in some areas and as low as 1,200 in others.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he was planning changes in the engineering policies of the Department of Sanitation, with emphasis on more extensive mechanization of its functions through development of multi-purpose motorized equipment. Reorganization of the department's engineering policies, he said, probably would begin "in a couple of months."
Age and experience in their favor, two 5-year-olds triumphed over twenty-two competitors to become the champion bubble blowers of the Children's Aid Society.

Open-market operations in the market for United States Government obligations during the period Nov. 12 through Jan. 21 resulted in a net reduction of $464,000,000 in the Federal Reserve System's holdings of those securities, it was disclosed yesterday. In the period, $2,994,000,000 of bonds was purchased while $3,458,000,000 of short term obligations was sold or redeemed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States military governor of Germany, returned here today for consultations. He predicted an easing soon in the food situation there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Russian Army consists of more than 175 divisions, some forty of which are in Germany, Poland, and the Danubian and Balkan areas of Soviet-occupied Europe, the Senate and House armed services committees were told by the nation's top military leaders in an executive session a few days ago.

Proposed amendments to the city's zoning resolution, intended to encourage private investors to construct parking lots and parking garages to ease traffic congestion, soon will be submitted to public hearings, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the planning agency, announced yesterday.
The case of the "House of Genius" at 61 Washington Square South, and five neighboring buildings, was placed on trial yesterday before Municipal Court Justice Abram Goodman and a jury.

Young couples who have been saying, "We want modern furniture, but can't afford it," probably will want to re-figure their budgets after they visit Macy's midwinter furniture show, which will open Monday morning.
It seems to the writer that the methods being employed by Police Commissioner Wallander to solve New York City's traffic problems will do much to drive commerce away from New York.

The recital given by Frederick Jagel, the Metropolitan tenor, last night at Town Hall marked the twentieth anniversary of his career before the public in this country. It was in the season of 1927-28 that the Brooklyn-born artist made his debut in Verdi's "Aida" at the Metropolitan, after returning from Italy, where he had sung operatic roles in the leading cities.

Pointing out that dry goods wholesalers must retain their prerogatives in directing merchandising operations, Flint Garrison, consultant to the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, warned yesterday that the advice of bankers cannot always be relied upon.

SEAFORD, Del., Jan. 22 -- A preview of new nylon fashions and home accessories held at the du Pont plant was interrupted by women reporters who clamored to know why "nylon stockings do not wear as well as pre-war pairs." The blame was placed largely on consumers themselves by Warren A. Beh, director of sales of the company's nylon division, who reported that nylon had been improved in strength since its pre-war debut.

The radio broadcasting industry was warned yesterday against lowering standards under pressure of new and keen competition during a three-man "Look at 1948" panel at the luncheon meeting of the Radio Executives Club in the Hotel Roosevelt. Prognostications offered by representatives of the advertising field ranged through general optimism over immediate business prospects, concern over the approaching crisis of inflation and the outcome of the Presidential election.
