LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The announcement of the terms of the new Australian conversion loan depressed British Government stocks in the stock markets hero today. The new Australian issue carries interest at 3 per cent, was priced at 98 1/2, and will mature in 1963 to 1965.

Persons buying automobiles under finance arrangements paid excessive interest rates, and dealers selling the cars received kickbacks, according to testimony given yesterday before a legislative investigating committee, holding a hearing on installment financing, at the Bar Association, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- The Soviet zone of Germany faces a food crisis the next few months that may force the Soviet Government to import grain from Russia, Maj. Gen. Timoffei Duderov, military governor of the State of Saxony, disclosed today.

HONOLULU, Jan. 22 -- Former native residents of Bikini atoll, who were moved to Rongerik at the time of the atomic bomb tests will be re-established on a self-sustaining basis, the Navy announced today. Dr. Peter Buck, director of Honolulu's Bishop Museum, and Leonard P. Mason, Associate Professor of Anthropology at the University of Hawaii, will aid the Navy in carrying out the program.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 22 -- A subcommittee of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea will attempt to consult with nine Korean political figures of the north and south zones, the committee announced today. The nine include Cho Man Sik, former leader of the Chosen Democratic party, a North Korean anti-Communist who has been held under house arrest by the Soviet authorities since January, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The American Foreign Service Journal, which is published by the United States Diplomatic Corps, came out his week with the observation that there is a lack of sympathy or understanding between the State Department and Congress.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The Montclair Forum held a discussion at the high school tonight on "What Does Freedom Mean?" as part of this community's Freedom Week celebration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Through broadcasts of its "Voice of America" to all continents, the State Department began informing the world, including the Russian people, today of the volume it had issued on Russo-German relations during 1939-41.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- There are some embarrassments even for the case-hardened Politburo in the Nazi-Soviet correspondence (1939-1941) that has just been published by the State Department in a masterfully-edited volume.

HAVANA, Jan. 22 -- Earl O. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States who arrived here Sunday, expressed confidence today that the World trade Conference would have satisfactory results. He came to Havana to consult with members of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

The 260 documents on Nazi-Soviet relations, captured from the German Foreign Office and published yesterday by the State Department, will be issued in two editions by Didier Thursday. There will be a cloth-bound edition at $2.50 and a paper-bound edition at $1.

Preliminary plans for modern quarters for the New York Association for the Blind in the present location of The Lighthouse at 111-15 East Fifty-ninth Street and 110-14 East Sixtieth Street were filed yesterday in the Manhattan office of the Department of Housing and Buildings.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved over a wide range yesterday and closed 17 to 32 points net higher.

Planned for wear at home now or to take along on a Southern vacation were the Kay Dunhill fashions presented yesterday at Franklin Simon. Priced at $10.95, $12.95 and $14.95, the print and solid color dresses in crepe and spun rayons represented excellent fashion values.

The State Labor Relations Board, in a two-to-one decision, ordered R.H. Macy Co. yesterday not to carry out its promise to give triple pay to employes who stayed at work in the face of picket lines established by striking drivers in July, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations split wide open today on the merits of a third party. Thirty-three executive board members voted in favor of a strong resolution declaring it "politically unwise to inject a third party into the political scene in 1948."

Despite the low ebb of production, Broadway theatres aren't plentiful at all. Here's an illustration to prove the point. "Kathleen," a romantic comedy about contemporary Ireland, has been booked into the Manfield, for a week, beginning Feb. 3.
Three armed thugs held up the South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association branch at 188-21 Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, yesterday and escaped with $8,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark declared today that proposed regulations governing alien visitors to the United States would in no way affect the admission of "bona fide journalists" so long as they were not inadmissible under the existing immigration laws.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- The International Refugee Organization plans to resettle 400,000 displaced persons this year, William Hallam Tuck, executive secretary of the Preparatory Commission, said yesterday.

A resolution urging passage by the Senate of the Miller bill "without amendment" was adopted yesterday by the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Law Section of the New York State Bar Association at its third annual meeting in the hall of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports during 1947 totaled $2,775,000,000, more than three times the average of the pre-war years 1935-39 and 20 per cent greater than in 1946, C.D. Howe, newly appointed Canadian Trade Minister, reported today.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Bamberger's fifty-fifth furniture show will open Monday morning featuring more than thirty decorated rooms newly dressed in summery colors and fabrics.

In former President Herbert Hoover the European Recovery Program has come face to face with perhaps its most formidable critic. Mr. Hoover, writing at length and in detail to Senator Vandenberg, carries the more weight because he has no political ambitions, because he has reached an age where partisan considerations cannot be foremost in this thinking, and because he has had wide experience in administering foreign relief.

The Giant Portland Cement Company announced yesterday that it will pay all outstanding dividend arrears units, having a total face value of $21,729, on Feb. 9, at $31.67 per unit, at the Girard Trust Company, Philadelphia.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- A pro-boxing champion, a high school football star, a triple-threat college quarterback and an Olympic skater were honored tonight as New Jersey's outstanding athletes for 1947 at the eighth annual sports dinner of the Newark Athletic Club.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- William Noble's Kay Gibson, a nominee for the $20,000 added Black Helen handicap on March 2, sped to a hollow triumph in today's Glamour Girl Purse, a seven-furlong dash restricted to fillies and mares.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22 -- Criticizing the professional groups of the nation as inactive at this critical period in world history, Dr. Ralph Fuchs, professor of law at Indiana University, tonight called for cooperation among the leading professional associations in an attack on major social problems.

In his annual budget message President Truman recognized that the rapid increase in living costs in the last eighteen months has "placed a serious burden" on government employes, retired federal workers and similar groups. Instead of recommending cost-of-living increases in pay now, however, he felt the "wiser approach" was to enact a comprehensive program for holding living costs down.

Bail of $40,000 was forfeited yesterday by Albert Edward De Palma, 47-year-old Toronto, Canada, stock dealer who allegedly made nearly $1,500,000 through the sale of worthless stocks in this country, when he failed to appear before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter in a proceeding calling for his removal to Cleveland to face Federal charges.

Following are further excerpts from documents pertaining to Nazi-Soviet relations between 1939 and 1941, in addition to those published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The documents were made public by the State Department.

According to the Government's statistics last issued, the national income increased from 168 billion dollars 1943 to 310 billion dollars in 1947. All the wages of factory workers increased from $43 a week to $50 a week. There is a fallacy in statistics like these a period of inflation.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Wilhelm Hellman Of Sweden won the prize, but Gordon Wren of Winter Park, Colo., stole the show today as ski jumpers tested their hickory slats in the last big warm-up for the Winter Olympics starting Jan. 30. Although his best jump of 63 meters (206 feet 8 1/3 inches) was beaten by two Americans, the Swede tallied the highest point total -- 319.8 -- because of superior form.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -Indian opinion has reacted favorably to the plan in the Security Council to establish a Kashmir commission. But commentators unanimously expressed disappointment at the commission's loose terms of reference and at the lack of immediate action to halt Pakistan's alleged aid to invaders fighting the Indian Army in the northern princely state.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein's investigation into an alleged attempt to capture control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh turned up yesterday a Queens manufacturer who complained that he had lost $9,000 in a "gray market" steel deal witnessed by Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, former beer baron.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Extension of rent control for varying periods was urged today by spokesmen for veteran and consumer groups. Also, a representative of a New York landlord group proposed that the law be extended for one year with a general rent increase of 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate-House Budget Committee organized today for a quick decision on a budget-cutting target. The chairman, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, protested that no "realistic" estimate of expenditures could be made within the allotted time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- With farm products rising sharply to a new peak, average primary market prices advanced 0.6 per cent during the week ended Jan. 17, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Without any notice to Rosamond Gilder, editor and drama critic of Theatre Arts Magazine, the monthly has been sold to another periodical, Stage, of which Alexander Sandor Ince is president. Both magazines are to be merged, with the first issue slated for April publication.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Fantastically high prices, particularly for steel and structural concrete, are holding back completion of the state's extensive highway construction and rehabilitation program, Charles H. Sells, Superintendent of Public Works, told county highway superintendents today.

In his impressive statement yesterday on the "grave decisions" made by the British Government following the collapse of the London Conference, Foreign Secretary Bevin bluntly declared that Soviet Russia has embarked on a career of expansion not only in Eastern but also in Western Europe which might lead to Russian domination of that continent.

A gala operatic performance, involving many stars of the company and acts from three favorite operas, will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday evening, Feb. 15. for the benefit of the newly established Welfare Fund, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- North American players here under suspension for jumping organized baseball in the United States to join the Mexican League were keeping their fingers crossed today, hoping that nothing interferes with Commissioner A.B. Chandler's reported plans toward a peace treaty with the reformed circuit south of the border.

Plans for decentralizing the State Department of Health to make public health facilities more readily available to the people by operating on a basis of counties rather than the district system, were presented last night by Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman flatly rejected today suggestions by former President Herbert Hoover that Congress virtually scrap the European Recovery Program in favor of a $3,000,000,000 fund for world destitution relief and a $1,000,000,000 loan program to revive Continental industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The petroleum industry today drafted a program for voluntary agreements to pool scarce oil products as Secretary of Interior J.A. Krug warned Congress that fuel oil rationing may be necessary next winter.

Edward J. Regensburg, treasurer of E. Regensburg Sons, has been re-elected president of the Cigar Manufacturers Association, with Harry P. Wurman as vice president, Stephen Herz treasurer and Samuel Blumberg secretary

The National Council of Jewish Women announced yesterday that its new contract with the Social Service Employes Union, Local 19, CIO, contained a clause providing for the dismissal on charges of malfeasance of any employe who, in the performance of her duties, "willfully fails to carry out the employer's program or who wilfully carries out any program other than that of the National Council of Jewish Women."

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The State Youth Commission, at a three-hour conference with New York City officials, agreed today to reconsider its refusal to grant state funds for the operation of day child-care centers under the supervision of the City Welfare Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- George S. Jackson of New York, who says he has more than five times as much direct ownership in the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company as the three-hundredths of 1 per cent indirect ownership of Robert R. Young, chairman of the C. O. board, has asked Robert J. Bowman, C. O. president, to answer several questions arising out of the activities of Mr. Young and the railroad.

Tragic memories of the Normandy invasion were revived for more than 400 persons yesterday morning when a simple religious service for 1,753 newly-returned war dead was held at the Brooklyn Army Base, First Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, on a pier that was bleak, damp and cold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development showed the first profit in its history during the last quarter of 1947, the treasurer of the bank reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- During a rapid exchange of charges, Zechariah H. Chafee of the United States answered Soviet criticisms of American "imperialism" and, in turn, condemned the 1939 agreement between Russia and Germany to carve up Europe between them as "real imperialism."

The United States Steel Corporation, largest producer of steel in the world, has joined seven other major domestic corporations in the University of Chicago's newly organized industrial membership program in atomic research, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the university.

Lumber production in the Northeast this spring will equal or exceed the comparable period last year, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary, Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, predicted yesterday. Mr. Broderick said that "perfect winter logging weather" in the Adirondack and Northern New England timber regions has virtually assured most mills of satisfactory output.

With the spotlight on the mile run, the field for which includes most of the leading challengers of Gilbert Dodds but not the indoor eight-furlong king himself, the busiest week-end of the 1948 indoor track season will get away winging tonight before a full house of 12,000 at Convention Hall in Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Henry F. Pringle of Washington, historian and author, tonight protested the suppression of vital documents of World War II, including the minutes of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conferences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- In an uprising against "bureaucracy" and delegated Congressional powers, the House, by a vote of 220 -- 134, moved today to strip from the Secretary of the Interior his right to authorize reclamation projects.

PEIPING, China, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Strong Communist forces struck suddenly today at Paoting, capital of Hopeh Province, and three columns penetrated within three miles of the city, Government military dispatches admitted.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- With the puzzling problem of what to do about an international armed force to enable it to impose partition on the Holy Land heavily overshadowing its deliberations, the United Nations Palestine Commission began work today on its first report to the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican, of Pennsylvania, proposed today that James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, be permitted to collect a special royalty on "commercial phonograph records" as a solution to his dispute with the recording and radio industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Seemingly confident and in good humor, President Truman admitted today the possibility of a back porch campaign as he engaged in a running banter with reporters at a press conference.

The National Arts Club is holding its fiftieth annual exhibition of painting and sculpture by members this week in the club galleries. Exhibits range from conventional portraiture, and objectively descriptive treatment of picturesque landscape to modified expressionist and romantic modes.

Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz was charged with responsibility yesterday for the differences between his fellow jurists on the Kings County Court bench and the District Attorney over control of the court calendar.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler would be happy to see organized baseball in the United States and Mexico come to an agreement, he said tonight, but until he hears from Walter Mulbry, secretary of baseball, on the Mexican situation, there is nothing to be done.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 22 -- A twenty-four-hour work stoppage involving 1,200,000 workers throughout Bavaria was scheduled to begin at midnight as a protest against food shortages. It is estimated that the stoppage will cause an economic loss of 27,000,000 Reichsmarks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Supplies of eggs, milk, milk products and meat will be smaller in the coming months than in the last year, according to representatives of the National Grain Trade Council.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 22 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today declared the United States needs friends in western Europe if this country is to remain strong and the principles of individual liberty and representative government are to be successfully defended.

There are no indications now of any general price reductions this year on hardware, equipment and durable goods, and no foreseeable prospects of a recession, I.M. Remen, retail promotion manager of Montgomery Ward Co., revealed yesterday during an interview at the annual meeting of the American Designers Institute, Inc., at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

It being his seventy-fourth birthday, Gustavus Town Kirby, the "elder statesman" of amateur athletics in this country, was honored at a dinner in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The event was sponsored by the Boys Athletic League in cooperation with twenty-seven other organizations.

Still skipping along, two at a time, George M. Weiss, general manager of the Yankees' vast baseball enterprises, yesterday announced that another pair of Bombers had signed 1948 contracts. At least one of them, Vic Raschi, the tall righthander, is a full- fledged Bomber.

A minor detonation, calculated to give at least a slight jolt to Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, was touched off by Tom Lockhart, business manager of the New York Rangers who doubles as president of the Amateur Hockey Association, at yesterday's weekly hockey luncheon in Leone's Restaurant.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- The fifth session of the Interim Commission of the World Health Organization opened in Geneva today on a note of disappointment over the slowness of nations in approving the constitution for a permanent organization.

The Howard Stores Corporation, Samuel Sennet, president, has leased from Beatrice D. Marony the store, basement and second floor comprising 13,500 square feet in the building at 120 East Eighty-sixth Street through John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker. The lease is for twenty years at an aggregate rental of $300,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- William Rowland and Louis K. Ansell, Film Classics producers, announced today that their next picture would be "Medal of Honor," a photoplay which Allan McNeil is writing about intolerance and prejudice against Mexicans in Texas.

Once again, food packages addressed to individuals in this country are entering the Port of New York in large quantities and are greatly overtaxing the facilities of the United States Customs Service, it became known yesterday.
Sam Minskoff Sons have just closed two deals in Westchester County, where they bought a taxpayer site in Hartsdale and sold a six-acre building tract in Greenburgh.

The annual reports of closed-end investment companies in the Tri-Continental Group, released yesterday, show that on Dec. 31, last, the net assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation, before deducting funded debt, were $46,073,519 compared with $46,488,540 on Sept. 30, 1947, and $47,890,209 at Dec. 31, 1946.
The city had a three-hour snowfall yesterday morning, adding two more inches of snow to an already full winter, after the Weather Bureau had predicted slight snow flurries for yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Secretary John W. Snyder asserted today the Treasury had "no intention of letting the prices of Government bonds go below par."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- President Juan D. Peron this morning received Vice Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, commander of battleships and cruisers of the United States Atlantic Fleet, whose flagship, the cruiser Albany, is here on a six-day courtesy visit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Senator C. Douglass Buck of Delaware, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee conducting an inquiry into the operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that he believed his committee would recommend that the RFC be continued beyond June 30, its expiration date.
Support for legislative measures designed to curb the teaching of communistic doctrines in the public schools was voiced yesterday by the executive committee of the Broadway Association, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 22 -- The National American Wholesale Grocers Association endorsed today the four-point program announced by the committee for the Marshall Plan to aid European recovery as embodying the essential principles necessary for successful operation of the plan.

Moshe Shertok, head of the Political Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, called on the United States and other major nations in the United Nations yesterday to set up machinery immediately to curb the forces of disorder in the Holy Land.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Trans World Airline, Inc., in filing today an appeal with the Civil Aeronautics Board for reconsideration of the latter's refusal to grant retroactive airmail pay adjustments, coupled its appeal with charges against the board including misstatements, propaganda, partisanship and dictator tactics.

Mme. Jacqueline Patenotre, member of the French Radical-Socialist party and first woman member of the Council of the Republic, portrayed France yesterday as a country in an extremely poor financial condition that could be remedied with the aid of the United States European Recovery Program.

We deeply hope that a housing program is being developed in Washington that will be worthy of the prolonged study, widespread travel and painstaking examination of witnesses that several members of Congress have been participating in for five or six months. The Joint Congressional Committee on Housing held its first hearing in early September.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a stop-gap measure extending by one month the Federal Government's authority to restrict the use of grain by distillers. Approval was granted by a voice vote.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The "Eisenhower-for-President" boom was deflated today by one of the longest statements of its kind in American political history.

Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight, received credit for a two-round knockout victory over Joe Curcio, Jersey City, last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, when Referee Frank Fullam halted their scheduled ten-round bout after the second session had progressed 2 minutes 37 seconds.
New city laws to prohibit -- or, at least, regulate strictly -- the keeping of more than two dogs in a residence are being studied by the Board of Health, it was disclosed yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's announcement today that he would not be a candidate for President brought an immediate retort from State Representative Joseph H. Geisel, Manchester, N.H., Republican, that this was "the work of professional politicians."

Dress jobbers in the New York market are facing competition of non-union producers in the unit price field who have built up million dollar volumes in the last two years, according to trade sources yesterday. One or two of the newcomers, it was said, are doing a business in excess of $4,000,000 annually in the popular price field, while several more have reached the $1,000,000 mark

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- State units of the Independent party of the International Typographical Union, AFL, are scheduling meetings, at which they will endorse a platform and candidates to oppose Woodruff Randolph, ITU president, and other officials on the union's Progressive party slate at elections in May.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Winston Churchill warmly supported today Foreign Secretary Bevin's plan for a Western European union but issued a grave warning that there was a "very real danger" of drifting into war. He urged the Western democracies to make a last determined effort on a high level of secret diplomacy to reach a settlement with the Soviet Union.

Thanks to the help of an anonymous business man in his home town of Decatur, Ill., Private Harold Simms, 25 years old, a cook in Company U, Training Signal Regiment, Fort Monmouth, N.J., got rid yesterday of the major obstacle blocking his path to the altar with his bride-to-be, Miss Renata Lenaro, an Italian girl, who has been held at Ellis Island since Dec. 23, pending the posting of a $500 bond.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., had an operating income deficit in 1947 of $1,895,722 in the sale of gas, according to testimony presented yesterday before the Public Service commission in connection with the company's application for an increase in rates.

Aiming at the establishment of Bronx Chapter of the National foundation for Infantile Paralysis, three women political leaders forgot election rivalries yesterday to pledge the cooperation of their parties in an attempt to double the $110,000 raised by the Bronx in last year's March of Dimes campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Democratic leaders today summoned all of their party members of the House to meet next Wednesday for a closed-session study of the $6,300,000,000 Knutson income tax reduction bill which the Republican high command has decided to support "as is."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A definite Chinese aid program has been worked out by the State Department, Secretary of State Marshall said today, but it is not ready for Congress yet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Recommendations for the outright decontrol or the relaxation of control of rental units in the upper and luxury brackets, with extended rent control for all other units, were made to Congress today by both a labor and a realty spokesman.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday. Final prices were 16 to 27 points net lower.
WARSAW, Jan. 23 -- The Polish Government remained silent today on British Foreign Secretary Bevin's speech but there was no mistaking its effect on the public.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The first Russian reaction to Mr. Bevin's speech was negative.
The Long Island Rail Road was back to normal by 1:10 A.M. on Dec. 28, almost two days after last month's big snow started, Eugene L. Hofmann, superintendent of the line, asserted yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Mrs. John A. Horn of Pelham Manor, who has been active for many years in the work of the Pelham Manor Club, the Westchester Cancer Committee, the Westchester League of Women Voters and the American Red Cross, was nominated here today for president of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Circus Clown, one of four Flamingo Stakes nominees in the field of six 3-year-olds, splashed six furlongs over a sloppy track to an impressive triumph in today's Conquistadores Purse at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Bleriot H. Lamarre, who has pleaded guilty to giving false testimony to a Senate Committee about Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers' war-time contracting deals, won an indefinite postponement of sentence today pending the outcome of Meyers' own perjury trial next month.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, national titleholder, moved into the second round of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship tonight with a default victory over Harral Tenney of New York.

Steady small quantity purchases by small and medium size retailers featured the fifty-seventh winter furniture market which ends today in the New York Furniture Exchange, exhibiting manufacturers reported yesterday. Larger furniture stores and chains placed some orders toward the end of the week but their contribution to over-all volume was slight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The state of the Union was discussed for an hour and a half last night in the White House study by President Truman and Bernard M. Baruch.

Every big bookmaker has been driven out of this city, Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday. He added that never before in the history of the city had the Police Department so rigidly enforced the laws against gambling.

The Fountain Pen and Mechanical Pencil Manufacturers Association yesterday agreed upon twelve industry-wide fair trade practices and submitted them on a preliminary basis to the Federal Trade Commission. Discussion and adoption of the rules, marking the industry's first attempt to arrive at an overall fair trade practice code, occurred at a commission hearing in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Harlem real estate brokers attending the real estate workshop conducted by the Greater New York Urban League of 204 West 136th Street accused bankers yesterday of refusing credit to qualified Negro operators solely because of race.
One of the longest administrations in the history of the United States Lawn Tennis Association will come to an end today.

"THE CONTINENTAL TOUCH,"* by Joseph Wechsberg, is a ribald satire on the Balkan international set. Mr. Wechsberg's story of a wily, amorous and ruthlessly ambitious adventurer's progress in Europe and America is not always remarkably subtle, but it has a good deal of pace and vigor to it and it certainly covers a lot of ground.
The New York State Waterways Association adopted a resolution yesterday opposing the $500,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project.

Long Island University, despite a 13-point advantage in the second half, had to stage a spectacular closing rally to defeat Texas Wesleyan's basketball team, 49 -- 48, at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night. Fewer than 1,000 spectators were treated to the dramatic finish, as the Blackbirds recorded their eleventh victory of the campaign.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- A detailed German plan for the permanent internationalization of the Ruhr industries is being closely studied by the French Foreign Ministry and the general disposition among the French is favorable, it was learned here today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Excerpts from the speeches by Winston Churchill and Prime Minister Attlee today before the House of Commons follow:

ROME, Jan. 23 -- The Socialist party congress ended today after approving a motion calling for a close electoral alliance with the Communists. Communists and Socialists are to form a People's Front and present a single ticket to the voters in the national elections.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- French acceptance of joint sponsorship with Britain of Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal for a French-British treaty with the Benelux countries (Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg) as a nucleus for Western unity has not concealed the real differences between the two powers over the ultimate aims of the project.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The American Council on Education announced tonight that representatives of forty-one of its member organizations approved a statement opposing universal military training.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 23 -- The sudden advocacy of a Western bloc as outlined by Mr. Bevin has caught the Netherlands more or less unprepared.

One hundred years ago this month a German exile named Karl Marx, who had renounced his own country and had been expelled from France, let loose upon the world a document which forms the basis of one of the two violent philosophies and forces that have turned the twentieth century into an age of revolution and war.

LAKE, SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, today expressed the belief that the Korea Commission, which has been barred from the Soviet zone, should go ahead with its efforts to set up a provisional government in the United States zone of Korea.

A better understanding of the limitations as well as the advantages of chemical textile finishes is needed, according to Richard E. Sumner, manager of the textile resin department of the American Cyanamid Company.
The preliminary annual report of the Caterpillar Tractor Company disclosed yesterday a net income for 1947 of $9,956,912 after all charges, including $5,728,443 for taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Not in vain but to the ultimate benefit of all sufferers from sea sickness were the miseries of that affliction endured among the troops during World War II, for out of their tribulation, and because of it, has come relief in the form of a "novel pharmaceutical product of proven efficacy" as a remedy or preventive.

The fear that railroad consolidation moves might leave the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad as an exclusively New York-Buffalo line was a major reason for the road's acquisition of some 40,000 shares of the common stock of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, William White, president of the Lackawanna, said yesterday in a letter to stockholders.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Pharawell, a 7-to-2 shot ridden by Jockey Willie Badgett, splashed home the winner in the Memorial Hospital feature at the Fair Grounds today. Valdina Infant was second and Nostalgia third.

A "New Look" doll, dressed from head to foot by leading Fifth Avenue couturieres and complete with padded girdle is the latest addition to the collection of 1,000 dolls owned by Miss Theo Redwood of the Warwick Hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The announcement of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today removing him from the field of possible candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination was greeted by supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey with unalloyed joy.

The Avenue Playhouse today will present a new French romantic drama, "A Lover's Return," starring Louis Jouvet and Gaby Morlay. Music for the film, which features the corps de ballet of the Paris Opera, was composed by Arthur Honegger, who also plays a brief role.

New York City was hit by a new cold wave last night and early today that sent the temperature to 5.6 degrees at 1 A.M., breaking the previous low mark of the winter, 7.2 degrees, established on Monday. At 2 A.M. the mercury had risen to 6.3.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- India entered a heated denial today of Pakistan's charges that the New Delhi Government was guilty of planning the extermination of millions of Moslems.
BOSTON, Jan. 23. (AP)-The Weather Bureau tonight issues this wenter sports bulletin:

Two books about music will be issued by two concerns next month. Knopf has scheduled for Feb. 16 Virgil Thompson's "The Art of Judging Music," containing the best of his columns in The New York Herald Tribune from 1944 to 1947. Allen, Towne Heath will bring out on Feb. 25 "Romain Rolland's Essays on Music.

The Eagle Picher Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 45 cents a common share, payable on March 10. The company, whose fiscal year ends on Nov. 30, paid 30 cents quarterly with extras of 15 cents in September and December.

The contemporary imperativeness of the Weather Man has generated a new interest among laymen in signs that foretell storms. The average citizen reads the weather prediction in his morning paper and feels a certain smug satisfaction if the experts are proved wrong.

Prices of stocks in some key sections were firmer through most of yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange, but an irregularly lower movement took place in the final hour to produce a mixed close. Fractional changes predominated, except in a few issues and, while the list leaned to the lower side in terms of the number of declines, the combined averages advanced 0.11, due to strength in a few high-price industrials.

A program to retrain "emotionally crippled" children in Displaced Persons camps in Europe and Cyprus was formulated yesterday by representatives of ten social welfare organizations meeting at the call of the Jewish Board of Guardians.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 23 -- West Bengal's new Ministry of twelve members, headed by Dr. B.C. Roy, was sworn in today by Gov. C. Rajagopalachari at Government House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Organized labor and industry joined in support of the European Recovery Program today as the $17,000,000,000 project gained new impetus under British sponsorship of a western democratic union.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Heavyweight champion Joe Louis today vowed to spurn his "distracting" hobby of golf until after he tees off on Jersey Joe Walcott in their expected return match in New York next June.
KINGS POINT, L.I., Jan. 23 -- The St. John's quintet overcame an early drive by the United States Merchant Marine Academy to score a 71-46 victory at O'Hara Hall tonight.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- Negotiations have been nearly completed whereby the Swiss Government will advance 20,000,000 francs [equal to about $4,600,000] to the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization as custodian for private agencies engaged in the resettling of victims of German persecution, it was learned today.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, who is the chairman of President Truman's Committee on Civil Rights, will be the principal speaker at the annual dinner on Thursday evening in the Roosevelt Hotel, marking the opening of the Protestant Fund Campaign.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday that the Police Department would need $98,540,767 of city funds for its operation in the fiscal year beginning July 1, Mr. Wallander explained that this figure was $9,395,891 above the department's present annual financial needs.

Moscow kept its silence yesterday on the second day since the State Department on Wednesday made public the captured Nazi diplomatic papers disclosing secret Russo-German dealings for the period 1939-41.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Sensational treatment of the news, especially in sex matters, by the United States press was denounced today by Jacob M. Lomakin, former Soviet newspaper man and member of the United Nations Subcommission on the Freedom of the Press.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that he could not accept the Presidential nomination "even under the remote circumstances that it were tendered me."

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Union has officially refused to permit the chairman of the United Nations Commission on Korea and a member of the commission's secretariat to enter North Korea, it was learned here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Beau Jack of Augusta, Ga., former world lightweight champion, came from behind to defeat Johnny Bratton, flashy 20-year-old Chicago lad, on a technical knockout tonight in the eighth round of their savagely fought battle in the Chicago Stadium.

ABOARD THE U.S. COAST GUARD CUTTER BIBB, Jan. 23 -- The United States Army transport Joseph V. Connolly, which last November steamed slowly up New York Harbor to bring home the first of the American war dead from Europe, will start tomorrow another and presumably her last voyage to New York.

Gustavus T. Kirby has been honored many times in an active life. Probably no honor ever pleased him more than the testimonial dinner given by the Boys Athletic League this week on the occasion of his seventy-fourth birthday. It is difficult to think of anyone in amateur athletic circles more deserving of such a tribute.

As one accustomed to regarding the accuracy and objectivity of THE NEW YORK TIMES as absolute values, I was surprised and disappointed to read in the issue of Jan. 12 an editorial called "For the Children" which criticized the association of the United Nations Appeal for Children with American Overseas Aid -- the new federation of foreign relief agencies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -The text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's letter to Leonard V. Finder follows:

Indications were yesterday that "Music in My Heart," the musical based on an incident in the life of Tchaikovsky, will not tour after its closing tonight at the Adelphi Theatre. It was explained by a spokesman for the show that difficulties were being encountered in retaining members of the company.

For the second time this month Mrs. Beatrice Rothman, 38 years old, of 1776 Topping Avenue, the Bronx, was committed to the Women's House of Detention after having been convicted of failing to provide heat for tenants in a three-family Bronx house of which she is co-owner and operator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The International Monetary Fund continued to struggle today with the French proposal to devalue the franc. Informed sources said that its directors were doing everything possible to reach a decision during the week-end.

From Geneva our correspondent Michael Hoffman reports that the International Refugee Organization will urge member nations to take a "fair share" of the 625,000 displaced persons in German, Austrian and Italian centers. The terminology "fair share," it was felt, would "go down better with the United States and the other potential receiving governments" than a "rigid quota system," which was recommended and bitterly fought out at the last meeting of the Preparatory Commission for IRO.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The Newark Ministerial Association at a meeting today in the Newark Y.M.C.A. adopted unanimously a resolution censuring Dr. John S. Herron, Newark school superintendent, for banning The Nation from the high school library shelves. Dr. Herron had ordered the magazine removed because, he asserted, in three of its November issues it carried articles "virulently anti-Catholic."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Harry Romm, New York theatrical agent, has concluded an agreement with Columbia to produce two pictures for the company, the first to be "Ladies of the Chorus," a photoplay by Harry Sauber about burlesque at the turn of the century.
Attorney General Tom Clark and John Lord O'Brian, former Assistant Attorney General, expressed strongly conflicting views here yesterday regarding President Truman's loyalty program.

A diligent convict who had studied law from books in the Sing Sing Prison library while serving a fifteen-year to life sentence imposed on trim in June, 1942, was rewarded yesterday for his years of study. Bronx County Judge Harry Stackell, who had reversed his decision last Oct. 7 after listening to the convict's appeal, wiped away the prisoner's fourth offender status by vacating one sentence as having been illegal.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers swapped second place for first with the Boston Celtics tonight as the trounced the Celtics, 74 -- 58, before 5,561 persons, the largest pro basketball crowd of the season Boston Garden. The loss dropped Boston back into a second-place to with Philadelphia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Children from ten countries have already accepted invitations to attend a conference next month of teen-age children from all over the world to promote the coming international appeal for funds to help feed needy children in war-devasted countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Harold E. Stassen accused Edwin W. Pauley today of profiting on a grain market break caused by a member of the Truman Cabinet and of plunging into heavy new speculation after he himself had become an official of the Administration.

General Eisenhower's statement that he "is not available for and could not accept" the Republican Presidential nomination is likely to rank in history with the declaration, in somewhat similar circumstances, of his famous predecessor Sherman. It is, as he himself says, a "bald statement," describing a decision which is "definite and positive."
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Radio Manufacturers Association today adopted a plan which it said is designed to end "shoddy work and overcharging by a distinct minority of radio repairmen."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis announced a settlement today of the dispute between thirty Westchester county fuel companies and Local 456 of the Teamsters' Union, AFL. The dispute resulted in suspension of oil and coal deliveries on Jan. 5 and 6 because of a truck drivers' strike at the Pelham Coal and Oil Company.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The French Government has warned the United States and Britain that it would withdraw from the International Monetary Fund if the Board of Governors of the Fund refused to approve the French project for a free market in gold and convertible currencies in France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- United States naval units in the Mediterranean were described today as a "task force afloat" by Admiral Richard L. Conolly. He commands the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean naval forces, with headquarters in London.

The City Council committee on rules, privileges and elections withheld action yesterday after a public hearing on the seating of Simon W. Gerson, Communist, to succeed the late Peter V. Cacchione of Brooklyn, also a Communist. Councilman Walter R. Hart of Brooklyn, chairman of the committee, said that it would meet to consider a course of action after studying the official minutes of the hearing.
The Southwestern Public Service Company announced yesterday that it had issued to common stockholders of record on Jan. 21 warrants to purchase 103,113 additional common shares.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The railroads and the country as a whole face a serious situation in the current threat of a railroad strike or its alternative, a third round of wage increases, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today at a joint meeting of the Mid-West Shippers Board and the Traffic Club of Chicago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission will put the "crucial question" of an international armed force to implement the partition of the Holy Land up to the Security Council in a special report early next month, Dr. Karel Lisicky, chairman of the commission, said today.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 23 -- As the twenty-four-hour work stoppage initiated by the Bavarian labor unions entered its final phase tonight, in protest against the impending cuts in the fat and meat rations, reports from communities throughout the state indicated an orderly observance with but one exception.

Two Broadway corner properties fringing on the Times Square area passed to new control yesterday in transactions involving a total of almost $2,000,000. Both parcels were sold by United Chain Buildings, Inc., Robert N. Schwartz, president, in whose ownership they had remained for many years. Harry S. Campbell was the broker in the deals.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 -- Fawzi el Kawukji, veteran commander of Arab guerrillas, crossed into Palestine last night from Syria and is carrying out a reorganization of the Arab forces, an authoritative Arab source reported today.

PARIS. Jan. 23 -- Gilbert Orcel's showing confirms the newest trend toward the pancake hat without demarcation between brim and crown. With grays predominating, whether in straw, felt or fabric, large or small, the hat is a gracefully undulating plateau or pancake held on by a velvet bandeau in back.

The State Labor Relations Board approved yesterday an agreement reached on their own by the Stork Club and the Chefs, Cooks, Pastry Cooks and Assistants Union, Local 89, AFL, ending more than a month of unfair labor practices hearings before the board.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Gerald Karver, Penn State's 1947 outdoor "triple crown" champion, won the first major test of the 1948 Mile Sweepstakes tonight, with a driving stretch run that carried him to the tape three yards in front of the blanketed Browning Ross, Leslie MacMitchell and Tommy Quinn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States Military Government in Germany will ask Congress for $700,000,000 to buy food for the Germans during the next fiscal year, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today. He held a brief press conference at the Pentagon between the Congressional committee hearings at which he is appearing.
Under Governor Dewey's administration, state aid to schools has soared more than twice as fast as school costs, Charles D. Breitel, special adviser to the Governor, declared yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 23 -- Precautionary measures were put into effect today throughout Cuba by military authorities to prevent disorders by Communist workers over the death of Jesus Menendez, Communist member of the House of Representatives and leader of the sugar workers union.

Solemn obeisance was paid the past in the first half of the program given by Hugh Ross, conductor, and the chorus of the Schola Cantorum last night in Carnegie Hall. This was sufficiently edifying, so far as subject matter was concerned, with the Brahms "Liebeslieder" with two-piano accompaniment by Luboshutz and Nemenoff, intended no doubt as frivolous relief for this portion of the entertainment.
Municipal Court Justice Abram Goodman brought the trial of an eviction suit to a sudden end last night by directing a deadlocked jury to return a verdict in favor of the landlord.

WARSAW, Jan. 23 -- The Polish Government spokesman, Maj. Gen. Viktor Grosz, said today that he was forced to express "astonishment" over the action of the crew of a United States Air Force plane in flying here yesterday from Berlin without clearance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations placed the Marshall Plan at the top of its program today after bitter exchanges between Philip Murray, CIO president, and Harry Bridges, head of the Longshoremen's Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Truman, according to a source close to the White House, feels that the Fine Arts Commission has let him down with respect to that controversial porch being built on the structure's south portico.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Asserting that advertising is one of the strongest factors in America's current high standard of living, Frank R. Pierce, president of Dearborn Motors Corporation, recommended today that industry set up an "advertising reserve" in good times to be spent in bad times to help promote sales.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- The German Bizonal Economic Council concluded an emergency session today with the passage of unprecedentedly stern measures for the collection and listing of food. The measures will penetrate every single household in the United States and British zones, in addition to farms and factories.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Fourteen thousand Chicago school teachers tomorrow will begin their sixth week without a pay check following the Board of Education's decision today, in the face of strike threats and sit-down strikes, not to use $9,500,000 cash reserve to meet the payroll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today raised reserve requirements of New York and Chicago banks from 20 to 22 per cent of their net demand deposits, effective on Feb. 27. It explained its action is "a step toward restraining further inflationary expansion of bank credit."

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth arrived yesterday with 1,852 passengers, among them the Rev. Dr. Arne Fjellbu, Lutheran Bishop of the Diocese of Trondheim, Norway, who will tour American cities at the invitation of the American Committee of the World Council of Churches

NANKING, Jan. 23 -- The Academia Sinica gave its informal approval today to the projected Reynolds-Boston Museum aerial expedition for gauging the height of the uncharted Amnemachin Mountain range south of Koko Nor in Tsinghai Province.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- On the eve of the opening here of the annual General Assembly of the National Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, Jewish communal leaders today drew up plans for a nation-wide campaign to raise $250,000,000 for the United Jewish Appeal this year.

Merchant vessels of all nations are threatened with delays as a result of the shortage of fuel oil in New York, according to reports in shipping circles yesterday. New York is not the only port affected, and other shipping areas along the Atlantic seaboard are reporting a steadily tightening situation, with delays ranging from several-hours to two days.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- A minimum state speed law, which would make it unlawful for a motorist to drive so slowly as to impede the normal flow of traffic, was proposed in the State Legislature today as part of a program of fifteen bills sponsored by the New York State Police.

Retail trade here this week maintained about the same pace an earlier in the month. Several department stores here had increases ranging around 10 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, with the average increase around 5 to 6 per cent.

A total of $6,500,000 has been collected to date in the campaign to raise $15,575,000 for the projected New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, Nevil Ford, general chairman of the fund drive, announced yesterday.
Winchester has been engaged in pushing aside some of the popular myths concerning the rifled slug and its value to the big game hunter, and the results of the experiments are quite interesting.

Rossbach Homes, Inc., report the sales of four dwellings in their fifth group of houses which is rapidly nearing completion at 164th Street and Seventy-third. Avenue in Flushing, Queens. The houses, at 164-11, 164-13, 164-17 and 164-47 Seventy-third Avenue, were sold to Joseph Fenner, Irwin Rosenbaum, Morton Sobell and Joseph G. Kaplan, respectively.

PRAGUE, Jan. 23 -- Editors and non-Communist party spokesmen protested explosively today against the national radio's reports of the Minister of Justice's disclosures Wednesday of seditious Communist activities in Olomouc. They claimed the radio's report had been censored and represented a high point in the Communist Ministry of Information's policy of using the national raido as an instrument of Communist party policy.

Any feeling we may have had that tea is a peculiarly British drink, rating no more than a passive nod of approval from most Americans, was dispelled yesterday, when we spent several hours visiting New York's tea district. Enthusiasm for the beverage runs high on Front Street, where its tasting and testing is nothing short of a ritual.

Schoolboy swimmers attacked records with more vigor than they have in years as the Public Schools Athletic League held its individual swimming championships in the Columbia University pool last night. New marks were created in five of the eight events on the program and two others came close to being bettered.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Arraigned before United States Commissioner Thomas W. Clohosey here today on a charge of withholding clients' income tax returns totaling $6,000, Sidney Neidich, 33 years old, an accountant of 12 Carpenter Place, Union, was held in $2,500 bail to await action of the Federal grand jury.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Army today denied allegations of brutal and unjust treatment of military prisoners at Camp Gordon, Ga., a disciplinary camp.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- An American woman dancer died heroically on the deck of a Japanese submarine, scorning a blindfold and calling good-by in Japanese to her executioners, a surprise witness at the war crimes trial related today, ending a search of nearly four years for the missing woman.

The leaders of today are as unprepared to plan a city functionally adapted to the needs of tomorrow as the leaders 150 years ago were in planning a city for the needs of the present, it was said yesterday at the concluding sessions of the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the Hotel Commodore.

As the first step in a campaign for prompt disposition of unnecessary papers and records now cramming storage places to capacity, Mayor O'Dwyer reactivated yesterday the dormant Municipal Archives Committee, headed by Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, director of the Municipal Reference Library.
Here are two complaints about etiquette that will interest every parent. Read them to the end and you'll see why.

American stores interested in French merchandise will resume buying on the more favorable basis of the proposed export franc, spokesmen here said yesterday. They added, however, that prolonged delay in establishing the value of the franc in terms of American dollars would serve only to continue the buying "freeze" noted during much of last year, because of high French prices.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- After having suddenly rescinded their demand that the Austrian consumer pay twice as much for Austrian oil, the Russian occupation forces are trying to force the Austrian Government to buy back its own rolling stock seized by the Soviet Army as "war booty."

HAVANA, Jan. 23 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment will suspend its sessions tomorrow while the body of the Communist labor leader Jess Menendez, who was also a member of the Cuban House of Representatives, lies in state in the Capitolio, where the Conference holds its meetings.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP) -- James Bickford's No. 1 United States Olympic bobsled crew today roared down the iced tunnel in the fastest time this season. This near-record performance confirmed its position as favorite in next week's Olympic four-man event.

Representatives of the marine department of the American Communications Association, CIO, and ship owners and operators on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts completed arbitration yesterday afternoon of wage demands before Frederick R. Livingston, arbitrator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Department of Labor solicitor, William S. Tyson, said in a memorandum opinion today that a majority union's failure to file non-Communist affidavits did not disqualify it from acting as a bargaining representative and that an employer, therefore, was not barred from bargaining with the union.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- No history will survive, if every effort is not made to preserve a free society, which alone dares to face up to its past, Dr. Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr., Associate Professor of History at Harvard University, warned here this afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Threat of a withdrawal of all hockey teams from the winter Olympics, voiced today by a Canadian spokesman, followed failure of two United States groups to settle their quarrel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Wheat stocks of 795,000,000 bushels were on hand Jan. 1, the largest in history on that date, the Agriculture Department reported today, virtually assuring the 450,000,000-bushel wheat-export goal for this crop year.

To determine the effect on present-day basketball of recently proposed rule changes, the Columbia and Manhattan varsity quintets will test the suggested innovations under game conditions in an informal scrimmage at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory next Friday afternoon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Kay Francis, star of the stage play "State of the Union," became seriously ill from an overdose of sleeping pills today and police detained her stage manager for five hours while they investigated.

A property on Manhattan's lower West Side, whose realty history can be traced back to an original grant held by the Church of England, changed hands yesterday when the estate of Theodore S. Tenny sold the two front three-story apartment buildings and two three-story rear studio structures at 47 and 49 King Street to a client of Thomas M. Graham Co. for cash over a first mortgage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- General Eisenhower's assertion today that he would "not be available for and could not accept nomination to high political office" disrupted a press conference here called to announce the merger of the Illinois Eisenhower-for-President Club with the National Draft Eisenhower League, Inc.
A 32-year-old taxi driver was booked last night on a charge of grand larceny for the theft Thursday night of a woman's handbag said to contain $7,500 in jewels and $200 in cash left in his cab.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, has requested the State Department to relax its embargo on arms shipments to seven middle east countries to the extent of permitting Jews in Palestine to buy surplus United States arms for defense purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today placed in its docket a letter addressed by George S. Jackson of New York to President Truman, and an enclosed letter addressed to the president of the Federation for Railway Progress, founded by Robert B. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company.

The Soviet Government has made the expected negative reply to the request of the United Nations Commission on Korea for permission to enter North Korea to carry out the mandate given it by the General Assembly in October. The answer is in diplomatic double-talk -- merely calling attention to the former position of Moscow on the Korean question -- but there is little doubt as to the intent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate confirmed unanimously today the nominations by President Truman of fifty civilians who had distinguished themselves as officers in World War II to be generals of the Officers Reserve Corps of the Army of the United States and the National Guard.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Three of golfdom's top performers tonight were tied for the lead at the end of the first round of the $10,000 Phoenix open tournament, each recording six-under-par 65's around the Phoenix Country Club course.

Queens -- the largest in area of the city's five boroughs, with 2,300 or more miles of streets -- has been experiencing serious difficulties in garbage removal since the record snow storm of Dec. 26, it was learned yesterday. A shortage of Department of Sanitation trucks and the miles of snow-clogged side streets have intensified the problem.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP)- Skiing was the ''best of the sea-son'' today at thirty-seven New York State ski centers.

Albert F. Wilson, executive vice president of Bing Bing, Inc., has purchased the residence of Carroll Coleman in Pleasantville, N.Y., for use as a country home. Alys Moehlenpah was the broker. The property comprises about one and one-half acres of land.

Customs officials and the police in Astoria, Queens, were confronted with an international jewel mystery yesterday when Allan Licht, 37 years old, was accused of stealing $170,000 worth of uncut diamonds which, as a courier, he asserted, he was trying to smuggle into this country.
GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- The arrest of a Hungarian journalist by Swiss police on a charge of espionage threatened today to create a diplomatic incident between Switzerland and Hungary.
DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Gen. Omar Bradley, chief-of-staff-designate, said tonight that "as far as I am concerned, the Army's dirty linen will get a public airing."

The visitor from the news room dropped in on this department just after our lunch time and -- perhaps because it was only the start of his day and the weather typically mid-winter -- seemed at a loss for anything cheerful to say.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Grain markets made a weak close on the Board of Trade today after an early advance had carried May oats to a new high on that delivery.

The county court is a constitutional court and, as such, is not the puppet either of the Legislature or the district attorney, John W. Davis, counsel for the board of judges of Kings County court, declared yesterday in upholding the right of the jurists to control the court's calendar.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- With the stock markets here today suffering from the usual week-end slackness, satisfaction with Foreign Secretary Bevin's "Western Union" speech in the House of Commons yesterday was not reflected in prices.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso, Minister of Development, announced today that agreements had been concluded with foreign oil companies operating here whereby Venezuela's share of the oil produced here will be sold back to the producing companies.

Toll routes never will be freed by self-liquidation, and the Merritt Parkway is not "truly a toll road," delegates were told yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers in the Commodore Hotel.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, had a narrow squeeze today after carding an 80 for eighteen holes, but she managed to hold a one-stroke lead with her 229 at the end of fifty-four holes in the Belleview-Biltmore Women's Open golf tournament.

The National Draft Eisenhower League, of which Stuart Scheftel is chairman, postponed dissolution yesterday but in view of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's refusal to be a candidate for the Presidential nomination there seemed no doubt that the league would abandon its efforts to elect Eisenhower delegates to the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- As a step in compliance with an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission to cease to be a holding company, the United Corporation asked the commission today to permit it to distribute 1,452,949 common shares, or about 50 per cent of its Niagara Hudson Power Company holdings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate today prepared to debate the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway and power project as its next business. Consideration is set for Monday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was leading in Presidential polls by the Fortune and Gallup organizations when he announced yesterday his decision "to remove myself completely from the political scene," according to The Associated Press.

Dr. Tibor Nyilas of Salle Santelli appeared reasonably certain of a place on the United States Olympic fencing team as a result of his performance last night in the saber competition at the New York A.C. The event was one of a series being conducted to form a basis for the team selections.

Today's events: "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera Company, 2 P.M.; Jascha Spivakovsky, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Gloria Greene, piano, Town Hall, 3; American Youth Orchestra, Dean Dixon, conductor, Brooklyn Academy, 3; National Music Festival, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; Robert Goldsand, piano, Town Hall, 5:30.

Machinery and equipment orders totaling more than $200,000 have been placed here as first steps in an equipment buying program which will be expanded in future months as part of Argentina's five-year plan, New York engineers revealed yesterday. Other orders from Argentina for compressors and pumping equipment will be placed as further progress is made after trial installation of first units, they said.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 -- The Dominion Government decreed today equal rights for untouchables in Ajmer-Merwara, a small province in Rajputana governed directly by the Central Government through a chief commissioner.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Lew Tendler's 19-year-old son, Milt, signed a baseball contract today and the former lightweight boxing contender said the lad was picking the diamond over the ring because "his mother wants him to keep his good looks."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 23 -- Describing it as a development "long overdue," Benjamin E. Youngdahl, president of the American Association of Schools of Social Work, tonight urged coordination in the organizational structure of the professional social work groups throughout the nation.

Demands for trade-in deals have increased 25 to 100 per cent, it was revealed here yesterday in a national survey conducted by the Associated Equipment Distributors, national association of construction equipment marketers.

ATHENS, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Albania has reinforced her military units in the past two days along a four-mile stretch of the Greco-Albanian frontier northwest of Konitsa, according to press dispatches from Greek Army headquarters at Larissa.

Mikhail Sheyne, Russian pianist, who made his local debut in 1939, presented a program devoted to works by Chopin last night at Town Hall. The compositions performed comprised the "Ballade" in F minor, the Sonata in B flat minor, all twenty-four Etudes of Op. 10 and Op. 25, two mazurkas, and the Waltz in A flat, Op. 42.

Frederick Brown has acquired the square block property in Flushing, Queens, bounded by Auburndale Lane, Forty-second Avenue, 172d Street and Station Road, from R. H. Macy Co. The parcel, 535 by 200 feet, contains a one-story building, 152 by 260 feet, which the present tenant, the United Parcel Service of New York, expects to give up about Oct. 1.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 23 -- Finland's Leftist Premier, Mauno Pekkala, is so annoyed by press criticism of his coalition Government that he has about made up his mind to resign, according to some of his friends.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The State Department endorsed today Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal for a union of Western European countries.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Details of the manner in which Britain expects to administer the gas industry when Parliament sanctions the nationalization of that part of British economy, became known with the publication of the text of the bill today.

The New York State Bar Association, through its president, Robert E. Lee, protested yesterday against an advertisement prepared by The Woman's Home Companion entitled "Behind the Black Robes." The material was attacked "as a most unjust reflection upon the honor and capacity of the judiciary."
Auburn, Ala., will receive bids on Feb. 2 on $600,000 of water revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1948, due Feb. 1, 1949 to 1978, and callable on Feb. 1, 1951.

F. Barry Ryan Jr., national champion, withdrew from the Yale Club's Bulldog squash tennis handicap tournament yesterday because of a back injury and thereby defaulted his match to C.E. Marshall, a Yale clubmate, in the third round.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- The Polish Government asked the British Control Commission today to permit the extradition of Heinrich Wilhelm Kopf, Minister-President of the State of Lower Saxony, as a war criminal.

A 77-year-old Arizonan, blind, hard of hearing and partly crippled, who came to New York last week from Phoenix by bus on what he had planned as the first leg of a trip to Europe to visit relatives, was persuaded yesterday by agents of the Travelers Aid Society to abandon the overseas venture.

Bob Trout, for many years associated with the Columbia Broadcasting System, has joined the news staff of NBC. He will receive assignments in both radio and television, his first chore being an appearance next Thursday at 9:15 P.M. on "The NBC Television Newsroom."

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Indonesian Republican Government resigned tonight, and it appeared that the truce negotiated by the United Nations between the republic and the Netherlands Government might be shattered before it was much more than a week old.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Beverly Hills, Calif., inventor today sued a Chicagoan and two corporations for $15,000,000, alleging infringement of a patent on an automobile "pop-out" cigar lighter.

Trailerships, Inc., which operates converted LST naval craft between New York and Albany, has been asked by the Albany municipal authorities to undertake regular transport of kerosene up the Hudson River because of a critical shortage of the fuel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Joseph M. Dodge resigned today as deputy for Secretary of State George C. Marshall for the Austrian treaty because of his responsibilities as president of the Detroit Bank and president of the American Bankers Association.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Beverly Hills, Calif., inventor today sued a Chicagoan and two corporations for $15,000,000, alleging infringement of a patent on an automobile "pop-out" cigar lighter.

Trailerships, Inc., which operates converted LST naval craft between New York and Albany, has been asked by the Albany municipal authorities to undertake regular transport of kerosene up the Hudson River because of a critical shortage of the fuel.

The date was June 19, 1945. Gen. Dwight David Eisenhower, back in America after leading Allied victory in Western Europe, rode in an open car through thirty-seven miles of New York streets. More than 4,000,000 people gave him a roaring welcome such as even the metropolis had ever before seen.

A BOOK by Victor Mollo of England, recently published in that country and not, unfortunately, available in an American edition, goes into greater detail in describing the present bidding practices of the leading British players than any previously published.

KOALA bears and kangaroos, the Southern Cross, merino wool, fighting Anzacs and "Waltzing Matilda" make good copy and all school children can identify them as Australian. There, too often, knowledge ends, and to nearly all but the specialist, Australia remains a remote and vaguely considered never-never land.

COLOMA, Calif., Jan. 24 -- A "vision of world peace" and "the will to achieve it" were demanded today by Gov. Earl Warren as Westeners by the thousands poured into this hamlet in the Sierra Nevada foothills to celebrate the one-hundredth anniversary of the discovery of gold.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 24 -- Announcement has been received here of the appointment of William R. Davlin as chief of the Area Development Division of the Department of Commerce. Mr. Davlin is widely known in the South as an expert in regional economic development and as a former research technician with the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senator Owen Brewster of Maine, chairman of the Senate War Investigating Committee, today accused big oil companies of "placing or planting" their man in the State Department "to influence our foreign policy."
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Eleven Russian correspondents touring the United States zone of Germany will not be permitted to visit displaced persons camps.
The Committee for the Marshall Plan to Aid European Recovery termed yesterday the scheme by former President Herbert Hoover for help to Europe a relief plan that would keep that region on the dole.

STRINDBERG, to paraphrase one of show business' waggish axioms, is what closes Saturday night. Whatever they think of the somber Swede in the colleges and libraries, where he has been running longer than "Life With Father," any box-office treasurer in town can tell you about the swift mortality of all efforts to uplift New York audiences with Strindberg's works.

MADRID, Jan. 24 -- The rapprochement between France and Spain received something of a setback today with publication in the Falange organ Arriba of a bitter editorial accusing France of being solely responsible for Spain's exclusion from the European recovery program.

DURHAM, N. H., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Election of Dr. Arthur Stanton Adams, provost of Cornell University, as eleventh president of the University of New Hampshire, was announced today by Frank W. Randall, president of the University's board of trustees.

THIS is the time of the year when the concert halls open their books and the scramble for dates is at its most hectic. The report is that even more people are seeking to give concerts in 1948-49 than in the current record-breaking season.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Leading members of the United Nations Good Offices Committee flew to the capital of the Indonesian Republic today to find out whether the Republican Cabinet crisis would mean the end of the week-old truce between Indonesia and the Netherlands.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Argentina suspended future meat shipments to Britain today for the second time this month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- Smilin' Ed McKeever, Notre Dame's war-time football coach, resigned as gridiron mentor at the University of San Francisco today, reportedly to become head coach of the Chicago Rockets of the All America Conference.

WHEN Sacha Guitry's new play failed to make its scheduled appearance in Paris last month, the usual wave of backstage gossip spilled over bistro bars; for since his brief imprisonment after the war everything M. Guitry does and does not do has been front-page news in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The State Department will relieve the Army Department of the administration of Germany on June 30, at the end of the 1948 fiscal year, unless present plans are changed.

A number of recent developments point to the urgent necessity for re-examining the haphazard lack of system by which we staff our Government on all levels, federal, state and municipal. Yesterday's TIMES, for instance, reported some remarks made before the American Society of Civil Engineers, meeting in New York City, by the executive director of the Tax Institute, Inc.

ROBERT E. SHERWOOD has written a sequel to "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," which is scheduled to be performed on the Ford Theatre on NBC from 5 to 6 P. M. on Feb. 15. The event is said to mark the first time that a top ranking playwright has written a sequel to a stage success for use on the air.

A petition to set up a fourth variety of cocker spaniels comprised solely of black and tans has been sent to the American Kennel Club by the American Spaniel Club, that variety to be accorded its own winners' classes, championship points and status in the sporting group.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The Chicago Teachers Union, AFL, with a membership of 8,000, today authorized its executive committee to call a strike, effective Tuesday, if teachers' pay checks at the new, increased salary scale were not released, or if the City Council failed to approve the record-breaking $103,000,000 school board budget.

THE account of the education of public school superintendent Ralph Mallison is a lively piece of satire, even if one suspects the author didn't mean it quite like that.
