A young man of average ability but outstanding personality, a good politician "with a desire to boss," and a "fine, bold concern" for what he thinks right, Mallison makes his way up by pluck and luck from running a small-town school.

THE title of Sir Norman Angell's provocative book is suggested by a text from the Gospel of St. Matthew. "The devils * * * went into the herd and behold, the whole herd ran violently down a steep place into the sea, and perished in the waters."

UNDERHILL, Vt., Jan. 24 -- Middlebury College's well balanced ski team, upset by the University of New Hampshire skiers in the morning downhill, came back with vengeance in the afternoon slalom today to take a lead over three other leading Eastern collegiate teams in the University of Vermont's invitation ski meet.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 -- The farmer in the Deep South is thinking more about producing all that he can in 1948 than about any other problem. Little time is being devoted at meetings of farmers in Louisiana and Mississippi to discussion of proposed price or wage controls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In the next few weeks the United Nations Appeal for Children -- a world-wide appeal for voluntary contributions to aid the starving and sick children of Europe and the Far East -- will open in forty-four countries. Immediately at stake are the lives of twenty to thirty million children and nursing mothers in Europe, and more than twice that number in the Far East.

JOHN HUSTON, whose "Treasure of Sierra Madre" opened to critical kudos here on Friday, will launch his independent company with an adaptation of Dostoievsky's "The Idiot," it was learned last week. The new company, known as Horizon Pictures, was formed last year by Huston and Sam Spiegel and should begin to function in May when Huston completes "Key Largo," his last directorial chore for Warner Brothers.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- While snow fell outside in a storm of blizzard proportions, America's Olympic-conscious athletes, paced by the incomparable Gilbert Dodds, blasted meet records right and left in a series of brilliant performances in the Boston Garden tonight.

Patrons of the Brooklyn Public Library read more books last year than previously, yet residents of the borough "cannot feel too proud of her standing" as the figures show they read only one and one-third books a person each year, according to the annual report of Dr. Milton James Ferguson, chief librarian.

THE day by day history of international affairs seldom mentions the men who carry the diplomatic mail over the world. They are the couriers of the Department of State. They personally transport the official messages of American diplomacy to and from United States embassies, legations and consulates in other nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- One down and one to go was the box score on political enigmas in Washington late this week. With the Eisenhower question out of the way, conjecture focused on Henry Wallace and the new third party: specifically on how much and what kind of following the apostate ex-Cabinet officer would sweep into his train.

THE ethical view of the universe involves us at last in so many cruel and absurd contraditions, where the last vestiges of faith, hope, charity, and even of reason itself, seem ready to perish that I have come to suspect that the aim of creation cannot be ethical at all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations, advocating extension of rent controls for at least two years, told Congress today that workers feared being evicted from their homes more than feared loss of their jobs.

Out of the voluminous report of the President's Commission on Higher Education, the newspapers, no doubt, have presented its most important recommendations for Federal action. They fall into two categories and involve the use of Federal funds.
Harbor shipping slowed almost to a standstill yesterday as a combination of swirling snow and high winds disrupted liner and freighter schedules.

DURING the war the Royal Institute of International Affairs decided to publish a comprehensive account of the evolution of Soviet foreign policy from 1929 to Soviet entrance into the war in 1941. The beginning year was chosen because several studies available in English have covered the preceding period.

THE English literary scene presents, at the moment, a slightly paradoxical picture. There is a very large, war inflated and astute reading public, and a spate of new books. Yet both writers and publishers will tell you that little of importance is being published, that the young writers have not really begun yet, and that the older generation is finding it hard to write and harder still to escape from the past.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Johnny Lujack, Notre Dame's famed quarter-back, twice consecutively named for all-America honors, today signed a four-year contract to play professional football with the Chicago Bears of the National League.

THE tenth International Salon of Nature Photography will be held May 18 through June 14 in the Central Hall of the Buffalo Museum of Science, according to an announcement by Hobbies, the museum's official magazine.
Snow driven by winds of forty to fifty miles an hour, plus low ceilings and reduced visibility combined yesterday to bring regular air transport to a halt in the metropolitan area.

A GOOD friend of this reviewer -- a normal and peaceful human being -- can't understand why the movies, even some of the best, make so much of fist fights and the determination of arguments by force. People in average circumstances don't fight so much, he says.

Bishop Arne Fjellbu of the Lutheran diocese of Nidaros, Trondheim, Norway, who arrived Friday on the Queen Elizabeth for a series of speaking engagements under auspices of the American Section of the World Council of Churches, said in an interview at the committee's office, 297 Fourth Avenue, yesterday morning that "the world today is in deadly peril through lack of confidence."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In future political campaigns, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower win be recalled as the man who said "No" more than any other man in American history. In the past year he has denied that he was a Presidential aspirant at least a dozen times, directly or through friends.

Academician Eugen S. Varga, the Soviet Union's number one economist, is in disgrace. His "error" was in reporting in a sensational book commissioned by the Soviet Communist party that no economic crisis loomed for capitalism and economic analysis showed the Soviet Union and Anglo-American capitalism could and should collaborate.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- At the 143d annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy, which opened with a preview tonight, eight prize awards were announced. Three of these went to New York artists: Jack Levine and Steve Raffo, painters, and Victor Glinsky, sculptor.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 24 -- The United States and British Military Government embarked today on an intensified double-barreled publicity program in connection with the current food crisis in Western Germany.

" Priestley Appraises New York" reminds me of an afternoon I spent in the Thomas Nelson Page Library of the English - Speaking Union in London. Glancing through several English literary magazines I was astonished to find an article which solemnly stated that the United States was more and more reverting to its Indian ancestry by drinking firewater and in its excessive love of dancing.

CALVIN SPRING, an Irishman with a "handsome, magnetic face," has two children and a wife. When he gives a strange girl "a wink of pure joy," she answers him "with a gay chirp." When he enters a public library "with the long, springing lope of the man who is born to run a mile," girls in the library promptly abandon their reading and turn "very pale."

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- An Army deserter who attempted a hold-up in the First National Bank, one of the city's largest financial institutions in the Loop, was captured today buy guards after he had menaced three tellers and scores of customers with his pistol.

THE strange behavior of the driver of a motor hearse arouses the curiosity of Detective Inspector Septimus Finch, who is just about to return to London after finishing up the case which had brought him to the seaport town of Woolston. He postpones his departure in order to learn what the hearse driver is up to, and that is how he makes the acquaintance of the people at Olinda House, the home of Roger Blaine.

The advantage of a home floor apparently means little so far as the New York Knickerbockers are concerned. At the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night Joe Lapchick's lads bowed, 72 -- 58, to the Baltimore Bullets and saw their average at home drop to an anemic .333.

JERSEY CITY. Jan. 24 -- A total of 1,340 athletes, representing sixty-four schools in New York and New Jersey, turned out for the first major schoolboy track and field meet of the 1948 season today at the Jersey City Armory and a Brooklyn entry, Boys High School, carried off major honors.

The movement of emergency fuel oil was not affected by the storm yesterday, but city administration heads were taking every precaution that deliveries should be made where possible if the snow reached its predicted depth.

THE author of this novel -- his first -- has been working in Hollywood for a decade on such epics of Dixieland as "The Little Foxes," "Jezebel" and "Saratoga Trunk," and was responsible, if that is the word, for the original story for Disney's "Song of the South."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- The rebuilt track in Army's cavernous field house was the scene of four meet records today in the fifth annual West Point relays -- two of them set by Army athletes and the others by young men from Manhattan College.

Members of the Greater New York CIO Council will make an active campaign for the election of former Assemblyman Leo Isacson, American Labor party nominee for Representative in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District, Saul Mills, secretary of the Council announced yesterday.

NASHVILLE, TENN. AN eighth-grade boy raised himself up on tiptoe to see the Farewell Address written and signed by "G. Washington." Behind the schoolboy an aged Negro woman stood before the original draft of the Emancipation Proclamation, her face close to the glass case, squinting to read the slightly faded scrawl of Abraham Lincoln.

One of the most comprehensive groups of twentieth century French illustrated books of quality ever to be auctioned publicly will be offered at 2 and 8 P. M. tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The United States should not commit itself beyond a year to providing funds for European economic recovery, Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, asserted last night. He spoke at the annual dinner of the New York State Bar Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Fabled Kashmir, now the center of an acrid political dispute between India and Pakistan, has a boundary dispute on its hands, too. The question is whether the northern border of Kashmir joins directly with Soviet Russia.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 24 -- Smiling Jim Demaret of Ojai, Calif., today emerged as the pacesetter in the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament, touring the Phoenix Country Club course in 33, 33 -- 66 for a 36-hole total of 131 and a three.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 24 -- The attack upon fundamental principles of social work made in the recent welfare investigations in New York City and Baltimore has brought home the need for social workers "to go all-out" to fight political forces that want to push them out of their jobs, Miss Marion Hathway, Professor of Public Welfare in the School of Social Work of the University of Pittsburgh, declared today.

TWO years ago American manufacturers of small private airplanes were in the midst of a feverish contest to outdo one another in describing the glorious future they foresaw for the personal aircraft. The more optimistic of them saw the sun all but blotted out by the wings of the private airplane and the citizen flier.

Hanson Baldwin in his article "U. S. Task in Greece," published Jan. 14 in your distinguished newspaper, makes the following remarks: "* * * Despite the partial success of recent governmental operations around Konitsa, the Greek Army has not been conspicuously successful in rounding up and eliminating the guerrillas.

EQUALLY at home in the thick of a fast-moving historical romance -- and in the wake of that globe-girdling sleuth, Major North -- Mr. Mason has turned out another thundering good yarn to satisfy a well-earned public.

HERE is Mrs. Burt again and another story of suspense, set in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains, with four main characters and at least as many plots. The cast is made up of a family of Bairds and a neighbor, Sandy Cameron, with whom the Bairds have been a-feudin' nigh on to ten years, ever since the Cameron house spoiled the view for the Bairds.

MARY ROBERTS RINEHART has shifted from her well-known line of mystery stories and turned out a rather long novel, covering a lot of territory -- 1919 to date. "A Light in the Window" is a readable, entertaining chronicle of the Wayne family of Fifth Avenue.

MERLE MILLER, a young Iowa-born newspaper man who has traveled the well-trodden road from city room to Luce to Yank, has (just as inevitably) settled at his typewriter to do another novel about the veteran's reconversion.

General Eisenhower can hardly be said to have withdrawn from the Presidential race in his statement last Friday, for his words show that he never thought of himself as being in it. Apparently he had believed that a previous statement, issued on his behalf last October, had made his position clear.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Colchester United, most sensational non-league team in several years of Football Association cup competition, upset Bradford by 3-2 in the feature game of today's fourth-round play.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Smoky Joe, the ungainly little ferryboat that gained local notoriety over the years because of the many rescues in which she figured while plying between Baltimore and the eastern shore, is leaving the scene of her past glory.

Six original organizers of the National Draft Eisenhower League announced yesterday their support of former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota for the Republican nomination for President as Stuart Scheftel, League chairman, directed dissolution of the League in deference to the wish of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and called on its State chairmen to disband their organizations.

A HELICOPTER, though slow and awkward compared with its fixed-wing sisters, can, of course, do things much better than its sisters. So that the reader may fully realize this, things happen fast to the Harding Brothers' Helicopter Service.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- The arrival of Gen. Wei Li-huang to take command in this beleaguered bastion of the Chinese Government in Manchuria has inspired cautious hope among the inhabitants that the Communists may be defeated and their present strangle-hold on Government areas broken.

NEWEST in the pictorial Regions of America series this volume is also one of the most enticing. One wishes it were twice as long, which is perhaps the main objective of the series -- to send children of the middle years further in their quest for knowledge of our country.

" SINS OF NEW YORK" is more than just a collection of pieces about the city's rugged individualists. It is proof again, if still needed, that the crime reporters are the best in the business. They have an enthusiasm for their trade not found in the ranks of, say, the art critics, and a delight in the morbid peculiarities of their subject.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 -- To provide better preparation for students who seek careers in government and foreign service, Princeton University has developed plans to reorganize and expand its School of Public and International Affairs. In honor of an illustrious alumnus and former president of the university, the name of the institution will be changed to the Woodrow Wilson School.

IN this second volume of 'The Tennessee," Mr. Davidson writes of the role of the river in the Civil War, Reconstruction and the reign of TVA. He believes the Federal armies won the war in the West, and hence the war itself, because their commanders were river-conscious and used the rivers, as the Southern commanders did not.

Two years ago a man turned up in the clinic of Dr. Robert A. Katz of New Orleans, complaining of discoloration of the left index, middle and ring fingers and excruciating pain. The doctor resorted to every known method of alleviating pain with no results. He decided to try diethyl oxide (ether) intramuscularly, but first on himself.

Roger Neighborgall, a young man from Duke University who wasn't in the event formally until half an hour before it was held, took the 1,000-yard run at the handicap track games in the 104th Field Artillery Armory, Jamaica, last night.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- A British scheme for a series of political and military alliances linking non-Communist Europe from Greece to Scandinavia with the imperial and dominion power of Britain has been stalemated until now by the delicate and difficult financial negotiations in Paris.

AFTER waiting in vain for a nod of encouragement from the public, "The Survivors" closed last evening. The first play to bring a current idea into the season gave eight performances before bored and skimpy audiences.

LONDON. IN the battle of ideologies that today sweeps across Europe one fact among many of great significance stands out. It is that this struggle is not simply one between communism and capitalism but between communism and socialism.

COLLECTIONS of essays are rarely as stimulating and various as this one. Each contributor was apparently asked to honor Professor Kallen -- German-born educator, Professor of Philosophy at the New School for Social Research, author of "William James and Henri Bergson," "Education, the Machine and the Worker" and other books -- as best he saw fit.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- United States Ambassador James C. Dunn hit hard today at the anti-American campaign of the Italian Communist press in a speech he delivered at Bari for the arrival in that port of the 300th ship bearing supplies under the post-UNRRA relief program.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 24 -- British policy here in recent months has been a balancing act, with the performer getting pelted from both sides with all sorts of criticism.

SHORTAGES and privations are the main features of life in Germany today. What makes them so much harder to bear, and what contributes enormously to the widespread feeling of sullenness and apathy is the realization that there is also virtual stagnation almost everywhere.

ALPENA, Mich., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Defending women's champion Betty Mitchell of Winnipeg and George Fisher of Chicago ruled opening day in the North American outdoor speed skating championships on snow-swept ice today.

JUDGING from this book of short pieces on widely disparate topics, Mr. Kircher would seem to have a fair share of the ingredients necessary for the contemporary humorous essayist: a skeptical and strong-willed wife, two uninhibited children named Junior and Sister, a shower that alternateIy freezes and scalds him and a rack of handsome pipes that burn his tongue off whenever he tries to smoke one of them.

The city and its environs, shivering through the coldest night of the winter Friday and plowing through a snowstorm that reached blizzard proportions yesterday, last night figuratively put its head down to buck an approaching fresh assault of nature.

POLICE blotters in every city and state tell the ugly -- and continuing -- story of motor-car accidents. It is a record written in blood. In 1946 in the United States 1,200,000 men, women and children -- a number equivalent to the population of Albany, Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse combined -- were struck down on our highways.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 24 -- Trailing at the intermission, 32 -- 22, Fordham's undefeated basketball team came back strong in the second half tonight to overcome St. Peter's, 67 -- 52, before a crowd of 1,000 at the Jersey City Armory.

In a small auditorium in Brooklyn, far from the rehearsal halls in which Broadway hits are readied, work is under way on what will be one of the most dramatic shows seen in New York this season. When presented in the spring there will be no well-known names of actors, designers or directors on the printed program.

THE volume on New Zealand that Prof. Horace Belshaw has edited is an excellent introduction to that much publicized country. It notably and very importantly differs from its predecessors in that evaluation and criticism play as prominent a role as description and explanation, particularly in the discussions of measures initiated by labor since 1935.

Jascha Spivakovsky, pianist, gave his first American recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Mr. Spivakovsky, who is a brother of Tossy Spivakovsky, the violinist, came to this country recently from Melbourne, Australia, and, on his way to this city, made an appearance as soloist with the Kansas City Symphony Orchestra.

DEMANDS for road-building equipment for shipment abroad under the Marshall Plan and the effect these demands will have on highway construction in the United States are among the most important subjects on the agenda of the annual conference of the American Road Builders Association, which opens tomorrow in Washington.

VERY rarely indeed are potatoes mentioned on anyone's list of favorite foods, yet there's no vegetable that is eaten more often. Nearly always plentiful and comparatively cheap, potatoes are valuable not only for calories but, since they are consumed in such large quantities, they also provide vitamins and minerals. Perhaps it's because they are so familiar that they're usually taken for granted.
The suburbs, increasingly storm wise, were expecting the worst of last night's blizzard threat and moved smartly to offset the effects of the new snowfall.

ACCORDING to the author's note, "The earliest story in this book was written in 1930, the latest in 1946, but the order here is not chronological." As a matter of fact, the first appears to be last and the other way round, for "Prime Leaf," the final story in the volume, appeared in "American Caravan IV" in 1931, whereas the first -- and title -- story was published in Cosmopolitan last autumn.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 24 The same X-ray that makes pictures of the interior of the human body is now measuring the thickness of red-hot metal strips emerging from the rollers in giant steel mills, too hot to be measured otherwise.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 24 -- Playing its best game of he season, the Dartmouth basketball team tonight crushed Army's quintet, 57 -- 43, before a capacity crowd in Memorial Gymnasium.

Settlement of the twenty-three-day-old strike against the Western Union Cable Division was in prospect last night after two days of intensive conferences between representatives of the company, the American Communications Association, CIO, and a citizens' mediation panel appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer.
The tentative timetable for the United Nations plan to partition Palestine into separate Jewish and Arab states is this:

Theatre parties at Broadway theatrical productions continue as a popular means of raising funds for philanthropic organizations. The Play Schools Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Make Mine Manhattan," the new musical, on the night of Feb. 3 at the Broadhurst Theatre.
TO your critic's suggestion at the end of a recent Sunday article, calling for change in stage designing and production, I add a plea about lighting. There exists at present a fad against footlights.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 -- A reduction of personnel has been started by the secretariat of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, it was learned today, in an effort to keep within the staff's $1,000,000 budget.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- On Thursday, Jan. 22, 1948, Great Britain resolutely turned her back on centuries of traditional policies and launched herself on a new and daring voyage into the unknown future.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Soviet-licensed Berlin newspapers today attacked British Foreign Secretary Bevin's speech as creating a western bloc in which western Germany and the Ruhr would be included.

REFLECTING the trend in record-making to present 'a comprehensive view of certain aspects of a composer's work, Victor and Columbia are represented by fat releases this month. The former presents an album of Chopin Etudes, with Alexander Brailowsky as the pianist (eight twelve-inch disks).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The declaration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower calling for the removal of his name as a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency gave renewed impetus today to conjectures that Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, of Michigan, might become a dark horse nominee in event of a convention deadlock between Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, of New York, and Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Administration moved through its Senate leadership today to counteract the effect of Herbert Hoover's attack on the European Recovery Program and prevent a rallying of scattered opposition forces in support of his counter proposal.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Hector McNeil, Minister of State in the Foreign Office, affirmed tonight that the British Government was still prepared to talk things over with the Soviet Union in an effort to iron out the widening differences between the two countries.

Senator William F. Knowland of California denounced yesterday the attitude of Soviet Russia on atomic energy and the power of the veto, and advocated that there be no "appeasement of international blackmailers" to preserve the peace.
The Government of France honored Holcombe Ward yesterday as his eleven-year term as president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association came to an end.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- While this Army post overlooking the Hudson River was shrouded in white as a heavy snowstorm accompanied by strong winds struck this afternoon, hundreds of ski-shod cadets zipped down Silver Depository Hill.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Jack Hutchinson of Boston, manager-coach of the United States Olympic Committee's ice hockey team practicing here for the winter Olympics, predicted today that the rival club from the Amateur Hockey Association "is going out on its ear."

Billy Nicholls, captain of the New York A. C. trio, found his game last night as he led the Winged Footers to a 17-to-9 triumph over the Squadron A Falcons in a Metropolitan High Goal League match at the Squadron A Armory.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- India and Pakistan agreed today to resume their direct negotiations. These were broken off, in a deadlock, on Wednesday.

IT would seem that one fight is won. Yesterday's advance guard in painting has been driven back, for the non-objectivists and surrealists are now waging a defensive warfare from the questionable vantage points of a few specialized galleries, a couple of English and American "little" magazines, and one major museum.

WE seem to have entered a period characterized, among other things, by its numerous revivals of literary reputations. They come now in rapid succession. They have paralleled in time the multiplication of anthologies, but I doubt whether the two tendencies have more than a partial basis in common.

Theatres were among the chief sufferers in yesterday's storm. Although most Manhattan department stores closed at 5 P. M., a half-hour to an hour early, they said business was average for a Saturday until the middle of the afternoon.

In "Communism to the South of Us," Walker Lowry declares: "The Spanish and Portuguese, unlike the colonists of North America, did not drive the Indian from the land; they bound him to it as serf and slave."

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Albert Stanford, a 22-year-old North Carolina Bible student who advised George Bernard Shaw to "stop running from the God and the Bible," received an answer from the playwright today.

The New York County Chapter of Catholic War Veterans called yesterday afternoon by a vote of 81 to 56, for outlawing the Communist party in the United States Three identical resolutions were adopted, one each to be sent to municipal, State and Federal legislative bodies.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 24 -- The Minister of Information, Vaclaw Kopecky, a Communist and for many years editor of the Czech equivalent to The Daily Worker, rejected today in an address to employes of the national radio the idea of parity or coalition control of broadcasting.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 -- The acute shortage of labor, more perhaps than any other single factor, is coloring the thinking of Wisconsin's farmers today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two CIO leaders have asked the United States Maritime Commission to scrap obsolete ships in order to provide steel for new ones, but they got no promise of action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Organized labor is facing a triple crisis. A "showdown" has begun on three fronts: (1) labor's attitude toward a third political party, (2) toward the Marshall Plan and (3) toward inflation.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Ocean Queen, 40-foot cutter owned by R. M. Demere of the Savannah (Ga.) Yacht Club, won the 52nautical-mile Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Cat Cay sailing race today in a corrected time of 18 hours 43 minutes.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Five of Army's minor sports teams, although shadowed by the activities of the fifth annual West Point relays, nevertheless enjoyed a highly successful afternoon winning all varsity events.

DURING the dog days of last summer a new and somewhat brash personality -- Abe Burrows by name -- developed a program moored halfway between broad slapstick and clever satire. It appeared then that his methods and madness would merit deeper investigation if the program became a listening habit.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Holy Cross maintained its domination of New England collegiate basketball teams by conquering the Yale quintet by a score of 56 -- 44 before a capacity crowd of 2,400 in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.

A BLONDE movie actress, Renee Wilson, plays hookey from the studio to rescue her brother, Hal, who is in a jam. Hal has established himself in a Nevada town whose chief industry is gambling and he has in some mysterious way become the owner of a hotel.

LIKE the late Lecomte du Nouy (whose "Human Destiny" was a best seller), John O'Hara Cosgrave was much concerned about man's soul. Du Nouy, a biologist by training, relied on science to prove that evolution has purpose and direction given by God, that man can evolve spiritually just as he evolved physically from a lowlier biological form.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- The Communist problem in Chile, and in a sense throughout South America, is currently best symbolized by the case of Communist Senator Pablo Neruda, which has become something of a cause celebre up and down the West Coast
MIAMI, Jan. 24 -- A resolution denouncing the third-party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace was adopted here today by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.

TIDINGS of considerable joy will come to the stanch band of devoted Thirkellites with the notice of the new novel, "Private Enterprise." It is as gay and delightfully disgruntled as any Thirkell book about Barsetshire. In that list it should probably have top honors.

ONE of the oldest of stories, getting ready for and taking care of a new baby, is news for millions of families every year. The story is told again, in the motion - picture medium, by a 16-mm. color film, "Know Your Baby," produced by Crawley Films for Canada's Department of Health and Welfare.
MUCH has been said about the rudeness and insolence encountered at the box offices of our New York theatres, but now I must take up the cudgels for at least one box office.

The United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York successfully prosecuted more than 96 per cent of its criminal cases in 1947, United States Attorney J. Vincent Keogh announced yesterday in his annual report.

In an ancient timbered room in Flushing, Queens, heated by two wood-burning stoves, a handful of civic and religious leaders gathered yesterday to commemorate the signing of a protest that brought to its signers first persecution and finally freedom of worship.

NEW YORK has its own version of the FBI, which for the last year and a half has been unearthing crime and graft in the city. At its head is a young man with curly black hair, smiling Irish eyes of blue and a mouth with a faint suggestion of a cupid's bow. In appearance he looks more like a member of an all-American football team than an investigator of criminal activities.

IT is eighteen months since the civil war China formally began and, while there is as yet no decision, one thing can already be said. The Nanking Government, the Government of Chiang Kai-shek and the Kuomintang, has lost the war. The Communists have not won it, but the Nanking Government has lost it. In other words, Nanking no longer has a chance to win; the Communists might.

THE good melting-pot citizen has long since assimilated into his everyday understanding large doses of the Irish temperament. All the way from Mr. Dooley to the brilliant epigramania of Shaw and the civilized subtleties of Elizabeth Bowen we have enjoyed the impact of a wry alien spirit, without caring to inquire too closely into its ancestry.

THEODORE MAYNARD in these pages presents another of his sensitive and accomplished portraits of the great figures of Catholicism. In these portraits his choice of subject, as well as his execution, has been unfailingly happy. Sir Thomas More (canonized by the Roman Catholic Church in 1935) possesses inexhaustible attractiveness both in his own person and as the protagonist in an important phase of the historical tragedy of western Christendom.

" KEY LARGO" and "Brute Force," which Richard Brooks adapted for the screen, and "Crossfire," which he wrote originally as a novel, "The Brick Foxhole," are all savage indictments of social wrongs. Melodramatic and hairy chested, they demonstrate the shock technique of the movie's current approach to controversy.

IN a time when novels in general are tending to go more and more deeply into psychological analysis, or more and more fervently into propaganda, or more and more extravagantly into a maudlin gingering up of the past, it is good to read a book whose chief virtue is that relatively neglected one in contemporary fiction -- effective storytelling.

Walker Lowry's article is interesting and objective. Though it has some ideas that I do not share, the conclusion about the policy the United States should follow to avoid the spread of communism in South America is correct.

SIDNEY G. BERNARD'S prize-winning picture, reproduced on this page, illustrates that once the idea has been fully visualized by the photographer, the actual mechanics of taking a picture can be handled quickly. The print took second place in the recent annual competition of the Manhattan Camera Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Edwin W. Pauley asserted today that he had been falsely accused of profiting in speculation as an "administration insider" only because of the "selfish ambitions" of his accuser, Harold E. Stassen, a Republican Presidential aspirant.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- A solution to the problem posed by 800,000 displaced persons in Europe is the major social issue which must be solved before Secretary of State Marshall's European Recovery Program can be a success, Harold Glasser of Chicago, former assistant director of the Office of International Finance of the United States Treasury, declared tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A major earthquake somewhere in the Southwest Pacific, described by one seismological station as apparently the biggest since the disastrous Japanese quake of December, 1946, was recorded today on seismographs in United States and Hawaii.

JENA, Germany, Jan. 17 (Delayed) -- The famous Zeiss Optical Works, which were almost completely dismantled by the Russians in March, 1947, are producing camera lenses at 80 per cent of the pre-war rate, Dr. Hugo Schade, director of the Carl Zeiss Foundation, disclosed today.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- Arab fervor for the campaign against the partition of Palestine rose to new heights today as Moslems celebrated the Prophet Mohammed's birthday with fiery political speeches in the mosques and with collections of funds on the streets throughout the Arab world.

DORE SCHARY, RKO production chief, said last week in his first press discussion of the Hollywood Communist scare, in which he himself has been a controversial figure, that he sees no signs of a change in screen content to avoid subjects of social significance.

Figures released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics were cited yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers in reply to allegations by critics of the Taft-Hartley Act that provisions of the act would increase labor strife.

For over forty years the conservationists have been warning us that exhaustion of our oil resources was imminent. Each prediction of doom had hardly been uttered when some wildcatter struck oil in a huge, unsuspected field of California, Texas or Oklahoma.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 (AP) -- First Lieut. Fred Scheunemann of 6829 Ottawa Avenue, Chicago, was shot and wounded last night by an intoxicated Russian soldier, United States authorities said today. Lieutenant Scheunemann, an Air Force officer attached to Templehof Field, is in a hospital with a bullet in his shoulder.

JUST before the senior prom Ann Coleman discovers that because of family finances she will have to delay her college education until her older brother has finished his engineering course. Thus she is brought face to face with a subtler problem than that solved by the suffragettes a generation ago, but one in which women's rights are still very much involved -- the right of equality in family matters, professional position and pay.

ANYONE interested in how writing is written (the phrase is Gertrude Stein's) should find a kind of paradise in the Lockwood Memorial Library at the University of Buffalo. Here, under the direction of Mr. Charles D. Abbott, has been assembled what is probably the most extensive collection in existence of manuscripts and worksheets pertaining to contemporary poetry, to say nothing of the books themselves.

TWO beautiful girls are in love with Al Madigan, who has just returned from the war. One of the girls tells Al that the other girl is planning to kill him. This may be the truth, or it may be a jealous woman's way of winning him away from her rival.

A taxicab driver who was said to have retained a handbag and contents valued at $7,500 left in his vehicle was paroled yesterday, in Felony Court. His story that he was about to return the bag when arrested is to be investigated before a hearing on Friday.

SIX men and two women -- and a rather strange lot they were -- meet at Draakfontein, stout Allan Conrad's home in remote southern Rhodesia, to hunt, drink, flirt, and enjoy a visit to a truly primitive and unspoiled region.

GENEVA, Jan. 24 -- Important developments in the international control of diseases are presaged in the forthcoming report of the executive secretary of the World Health Organization, it was learned today.

The evening of Dec. 15, 197, marked a major turning point in Russian-American relations. On that evening in London the Big Four conference on Germany collapsed. Secretary of State George C. Marshall said: "The Soviet Union alone refused to agree." Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov said: "The Western delegations have united into a single front against the Soviet Government."
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- Earl Mountbatten, Governor General of India, will relinquish his appointment in the third week of June, it was stated authoritatively today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 24 -- There is "ample evidence" that the investment of Federal funds in the Tennessee Valley has increased the prosperity and productivity of the region and has benefited the entire country, according to Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

In the spring of 1939 war was in the air. For six years Hitler had been attacking the "degenerate" democracies of the West and even more vehemently Soviet Russia and Communism. For six years he had been on the march in a bloodless (for the Nazis) conquest of Europe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Ventan Yablonski, Columbia University fullback from Worcester, Mass., has been signed by the Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League to a 1948 contract, Ray Bennigsen, president of the Cardinals, announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- The California farmer does not like proposals to restore price controls; he thinks that he himself is out of pocket with every new wage rise for labor and he believes the consumer in the cities is paying too much for food.

GENEVA, Jan. 24 -- Britain proposed the creation of a new "working capital fund" to expedite the mass resettlement of refugees at today's private meeting of the preparatory commission of the International Refugee Organization.

THOUGH it has had several names during its history and it has been sponsored by different groups in eight cities, the peregrinating annual National Folk Festival run by Sarah Gertrude Knott and M. J. Pickering has come to be a recognized feature of the country's musical life.

LAWTON, Okla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- An intoxicated Fort Sill soldier ran berserk in an army tank-like 21-ton self-propelled 155mm howitzer here just before midnight, leading military police on a twelve-mile chase through the heart of town before they trapped him with a road-block.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 24 -- Palestine was awaiting a new Arab offensive today, with more than 700 uniformed armed Arabs reported concentrated about Tubas, ten miles northeast of Nablus.
PATRONS who are given to nostalgic sighs over the early days of motion pictures may be happy to learn that a young man named Jack Searl has set a new and determined course toward screen recognition.

James A. Burke, Queens Borough President, in a sharp letter to Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell, denounced yesterday the Sanitation Department's handling of snow and garbage removal in Queens ever since the storm of Dec. 26.

The thing that impresses me about "Mr. Priestley Appraises New York," is the qualities which he has in common with other great men who visit America and leave behind their commentaries. Their self-righteousness and certainty reign supreme.

Opinion was divided yesterday among high school students who took part in the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR, concerning the effectiveness of school curriculums in providing adequate training for adult responsibility.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 -- With the Calumet Farm's Armed and Faultless scratched and Buzfuz hoisting the distress signal after gaining an early lead, Delegate plowed through mud to an easy conquest in today's Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park.

When President Truman first broached his ten-point anti-inflation program to Congress on Nov. 17, the predominant Republican reaction was hostile. His proposals -- especially those calling for price controls and rationing -- were termed "the end of economic freedom."

J. Victor Carton, Prosecutor of Monmouth County, N. J., said yesterday that he had received a request for the return of sixty-eight tons of war explosives seized early this month on a farm near Asbury Park.

THE news that came out of the 1948 winter furniture market -- the wholesale showings held simultaneously this month in Chicago and Grand Rapids -- can be boiled down to two statements: (1) prices have gone up and (2) "modern" is here to stay.

With bitter memories of the effect of the Dec. 26 storm on traffic, operating divisions of transportation companies started early yesterday to meet the threat of the new snowfall. They were aided by light Saturday traffic -- most commuters had left the city by noon, before the storm developed in intensity -- and also by ample warning.

Although it has been their practice more often than not to stray afield when it came to making their annual awards, the New York baseball scribes, rounding into form for their twenty-fifth anniversary dinner and jubilee in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria next Sunday night, this year decided to stick close to home.

On Oct. 16 fifty-one members of the Political Science Faculty of Columbia University issued a statement urging that Congress be reassembled, and that early action be taken to provide aid for Europe. The undersigned members of various Harvard faculties subscribe to the views expressed by our colleagues at that great center of learning.

JUST ten years ago this week in this Review: Sinclair Lewis had a new one, "The Prodigal Parents," which occasioned from J. Donald Adams the following: "If 'It Can't Happen Here' was mediocre as a piece of creative writing, it at least bore evidence on every page of intense and fiery conviction.

A record number of 10,474 New York City teachers, representing about one-third of the staff, are taking in-service training courses under the auspices of the Board of Education. The courses are designed to help teachers keep pace with changing pedagogical practices and to qualify them for salary increases.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 24 -- The attitude of the Northwest's farmers toward possible restoration of price controls is best characterized by the recent annual meeting of regional wool growers in this city. The men who raise sheep voted a voluntary four-mill-a-pound levy on their wool to accumulate a fund with which to resist "any revival of the OPA."

EVEN in a full-length novel like "The Dark Daughters," Rhys Davies' talents as a short-story writer show through. Somewhere near the end of his book, in clear-cut relief, stands his imaginative concept complete: a house of hate dominated by three harpies who torment their father to death for his sins.

BERNARD SHAW once wrote a novel called "An Unsocial Socialist." Had he added the syllable "ist" to the second word he might have psychoanalyzed himself and prophesied his own intellectual journey at a single stroke.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Palestine Government today charged seventeen Arabs with the murder of forty-two Jews in the Haifa oil refinery riot last Dec. 30. Twenty others were charged with wounding Jews.

Four hundred delegates from all parts of the country gathered here yesterday for the opening session of the two-day National Conference on American Policy in China and the Far East at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Continuing its investigations toward the establishment of revised minimum wages, minimum manning scales and reasonable working conditions for crews employed on Government-subsidized vessels, the Maritime Commission will hold a public hearing here on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

Mr. Priestley has evaluated our great American city on a purely material basis. He has failed to find the pulse of New York. He has failed to acclaim her generosity and her hospitality to his own countrymen and to those of all lands.

Antioch College's administrative council, composed of members of the faculty and student body, is attempting to maintain student representation on the campus that is typical of all elements of the population. A majority of college students come from families in the higher wage brackets.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- The "report to the children" to be presented by the United Nations Appeal for Children here on Feb. 14 will be directed mainly to the children of Secretariat employes and delegates who are already in the neighborhood of Lake Success, it was declared today by Dr. Aake Ording, director of the appeal.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 24 -Cornell's basketball team won its ninth game in fourteen starts tonight, defeating Pittsburgh, 52 -- 40, after the Panthers had held the count down to 19 -- 17 at the half.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Justin Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said today that any Federal supervision of radio program content would mean a "licensed press" status for radio.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, expects the final decision on the American ice hockey squabble to affect the whole future of sports.

THE United States Congress has a decisive role to play in this year of decision. How is it to act so that the best interests of the nation will be served? On what should it base its decisions? As representatives of the people should Congressmen follow the people's will or lead it? This is a dilemma as old as democracy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Police Commissioner John C. Prendergast announced today that he would notify police in all districts to begin immediate enforcement of Chicago's curfew law, which has been on the books since 1910. It bars children under 18 years of age from the streets between 10 P. M. and 6, A. M. unless accompanied by parent, guardian or other adult.

For many an ex-service man a bit of nostalgic memory was revived by recent news stories that the puffing, chugging Fort Dix Railroad, after thirty years of service to its country in peace and war, had reached the end of the line. The seventeen miles of narrow-gauge tracks, along with five ten-ton engines and fifty-two cars, were honorably discharged at the close of the war.
OMAHA, Jan. 24 -- Midwest farmers are playing a cautious waiting game as they plan for the 1948 growing season. Their reaction on four important questions can be summarized this way:

The liner Uruguay returned to private passenger service yesterday as control of the vessel was handed back to the Moore-McCormack Lines by the Maritime Commission. She is the second of the company's three "Good Neighbor" passenger ships to be reconverted for post-war service between New York and the east coast of South America.

An editorial footnote makes the point that Mr. Priestley was speaking only of New York and did not pan America as a whole when, in line with Russia's Ilya Ehrenburg, he crowed: "All that is wrong with our age, even when at its most prosperous, is shown here in sharp focus."

ARTHUR STANLEY RIGGS' "Velasquez: Painter of the Truth and Prisoner of the King" might have been written fifty years ago when the great Spaniard was a star of the prevailing bourgeois fashion. Indeed, Mr. Riggs writes with his eyes so tightly shut against the day's evaluation that one logically wonders if the book is not a belated publication of a long-shelved manuscript.

THE one important novelty of the current Metropolitan Opera season, Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes," first heard in America at Tanglewood two seasons ago, will have its New York premiere about two weeks hence.
NOT to be outdone by their colleagues in the world of drama and film, most, if not all, of the radio critics formally banded together last week in a Radio-Television Critics Circle of New York.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner, announced yesterday that the use of attendants instead of internes on city and voluntary hospital ambulances, a wartime measure, would be continued indefinitely.

NEWS ITEM: "A former New York University student, Henry Grunwald, recently sold a script to RKO Radio Pictures for $5,000. Grunwald, a motion-picture major, graduated from New York University in 1944. * * *"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal and former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts in an exchange of comments today assailed the contention made by opponents of universal military training that "mass armies" were obsolete and that such training was unnecessary.
Raymond Duncan, toga and sandal clad, walked off the pier of the French liner De Grasse at West Forty-eighth Street yesterday, unconcerned over New York's worst winter season in years.

Boris Matusewitch, concertinist, and his brother Sergei, accordionist, gave a joint recital in Times Hall last night before a good sized and highly enthusiastic audience. The program was devoted almost entirely to the repertoire of concert pianists and violinists in transcription, and included the first performance of Two Preludes dedicated to Boris by Robert S. Lissauer.

Brooklyn Technical High School's rifle team was declared the Public Schools Athletic League's city champion after scoring an easy victory in the winter tournament yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium range. The winners posted a five-man total of 899 of a possible 1,000 points, with Midwood High recording 886 for second place.
ALMOST every girl has imagined herself a nurse or doctor. These books strip away unreal glamor but do show that women can succeed in these professions.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, today assured the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea that "the American command will lend every possible assistance" to the commission in conducting elections for a Korean assembly, upon which it is intended that a Korean government will be based.

There are many reasons why Lake Mattamuskeet, that broad, shallow expanse of water on the North Carolina coast, is the gathering place of thousands of big Canada geese during the fall and winter, but plenty of feed and large sanctuary areas are two of the important reasons.

Aided by the play of Hunter Lott Jr. and Diehl Mateer Jr., Haverford College sophomore, Philadelphia teams held the edge in the University Club's invitation squash racquets doubles tournament for the Lockett Trophy yesterday.

ONE of the most fascinating phases of the hoss-racing game is the naming of the horses. The Jockey Club is currently up over its collective ears in the task of sorting out the tags for some 6,000 nags; virtually all of them new 2-year-olds who finally have reached the stage where they need more accurate identification.

EXHIBITIONS this week by a literalist of collage, Kurt Schwitters; a mystic, Giacometti, and a surrealist, Lepri, all Europeans, provide eloquent testimony to the climate of nihilism and despair artists were confronted with in Europe between and after wars and perhaps indicate three kinds of important failures art may make in time of stress.

WHEN the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo returns to the City Center on Feb. 15 for its spring season of four weeks, it will have two novelties in the repertory. One of them is Ruth Page's "Billy Sunday," and the other is Alexandra Danilova's first appearance in New York in the title role of "Giselle."

IT is a shame that the reputation of a great contemporary artist such as Picasso should be exploited to sell shoddy translation, insensitive editing and the disfiguration of an interesting critical idea. Especially so, when, in the process, the work of a poet of the quality of Paul Eluard is done such callous injustice as in "The Inner Life of Pablo Picasso."

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- British air authorities said today that permission had been granted to the United States Government to land military transport aircraft en route to or from the eastern Mediterranean at Royal Air Force fields at Castel Benito near Tripoli in Libya and at Luqa on Malta.

Much time and patience still are necessary to build world peace, in the opinion of Cordell Hull, "elder statesman," whose behind-the-scenes story of his twelve tumultuous years as Secretary of State will be published serially in THE NEW YORK TIMES beginning tomorrow.

The United Fruit Company's Veragua, another of this port's familiar pre-war passenger ships, is due here Tuesday on her first visit as a private merchant vessel since before the war. Fresh from a complete reconversion job at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Key Highway shipyard in Baltimore, the Veragua will complete a shake-down cruise to Porto Barrios, Guatemala, upon her arrival here.

That the thyroid gland has some influence on the course of infectious diseases has been dwelt on more than once by keen medical observers. Some of these observers think that thyroxin, the hormone secreted by the gland, checks the growth of bacteria, just as the sulfa compounds and penicillin do, but opinion in general has leaned to the theory that the whole defensive mechanism of the body is reinforced.

A blizzard swept over southern New York, southern New England, the coastal areas of the middle Atlantic states and central and southern Ohio and Indiana yesterday and last night. The storm was expected to moderate this morning in New Jersey and southward, and later in the day in the southeastern part of New York and southern New England, leaving a total snowfall of six to twelve inches over much of the storm area.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Jan. 24 -- Sel Hannah, chairman of the Franconia Ski Club's race committee, blazed across a ten-mile cross-country course in Franconia Notch this afternoon in 54 minutes and 51 seconds to take first place in his club's annual mid-season Langlauf event.

BOSTON Jan. 24 -- New England farmers, largely processors in the country's agricultural pattern, are very largely opposed to a return of price control. They view labor's wage demands with mixed feelings, but close ranks solidly again in expressing apprehension over high food prices in the city.

THIS essay is likely to appeal more to admirers of Bernanos than to those interested in Joan of Arc. M. Bernanos paints an impressionistic picture of the trial of Joan, giving his own version of the tragic conflict between the judges and the Maid. To make the court look worse, he insists that its proceedings were perfectly legal, and denies that its actions can be explained by pro-English sympathies.

CAN anything decent come out of the cultural offices of the Soviet Union? We would least of all expect it to be art criticism. Yet here is Alexander Romm's little book on Matisse, which, though not quite decent, is as serious as it can afford to be and contains only the absolutely required minimum of Stalinist vulgarity.

NANKING, Jan. 24 -- Compulsory military training for all men between the ages of 18 and 45 is scheduled to begin in China next month, it was disclosed today. The step is designed to establish a Min Ping (People's Militia) similar to that existing in the Communist areas for purposes of local defense.

Mayor O'Dwyer quickly mobilized the resources of all city departments and agencies to cope with storm conditions yesterday and authorized the Sanitation Department to throw 1,600 vehicles and thousands of men into the battle to clear main artieries and transit routes. A force of 18,700 men will be at work today.

I resent Mr. Priestly's estimate of us New Yorkers very much! "Beauty is in the eye of the beholder," and, if he found no beauty here on his visit, perhaps it was because there was only dislike and the desire to criticize, deep in his heart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board, through its general counsel, Robert N. Denham, defended today the constitutionality of the provision in the Taft-Hartley law which denies the benefits of the law to unions whose officers refuse to foreswear communism.
We awoke this morning into a veritable wintry fairyland. Last night's snowstorm added the last touch to a winter scene to which the best Currier Ives would seem pallid and flat by comparison.

TOKYO, Jan. 24, -- Restrictions are being placed on the travel of United States and other Allied correspondents in the Far East under regulations now enforced here by the occupation army authorities, according to a report made public today by the executive committee of the Tokyo Correspondents Club.

PRODUCER THERON BAMBERGER'S plan to stimulate greater interest in the theatre both here and on the road finally has come out of committee and a decision is imminent. Briefly, according to Mr. Bamberger's scheme, the League of New York Theatres would set up a public relations office to sell the theatre as an institution on a year-round basis, cooperate with local managers throughout the country and act as a clearing house for information.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The strike of Chicago newspaper printers is two months old today, and it is possible now to know some of its effects on the six major dailies, which have continued publication with typewritten - photoengraved newspapers, and their readers.

DES MOINES, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Fred D. Hawkins of Des Moines, chairman of the Midwest Council of Negro Republican Clubs, announced today that the organization's present sentiment favored Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for the Presidential nomination with Harold Stassen of Minnesota as second choice and Gov. Dwight Green of Illinois as running mate to either of the men.

THE recent criticism of the New York Philharmonic's performance of Honnegger's "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher" in French is, I think, a reflection upon the letter writer as well as a commentary on the cultural level and attitudes of the American public.

The other day I saw a double feature bill, "The Life of Walter Mitty" and a "Dick Tracy" film. The villains in both were men with crippled bodies. The villain in "Walter Mitty" had a club foot and the villain in "Dick Tracy" had a steel hook for a hand and a paralyzed foot.
WHEN Jason Amry was a merchandising major at the renowned school of finance of a certain ivy-clad eastern university, his fraternity classmates used to recite a little couplet:

MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 24 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is urged to reconsider his decision not to run for President in 1948 by Leonard V. Finder, publisher of The Manchester Evening Leader, in an open letter made public today.

BETWEEN the third quarter of 1946 and the third quarter of 1947 personal incomes after taxes increased by the enormous amount of $18.3 billions. Personal savings, however, did not increase. On the contrary, they dropped by a small amount. All of the huge gain in personal incomes after taxes was spent for consumer goods.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The diplomatic battle between the British and French Governments over devaluation of the franc this week overshadowed -- at least in Paris -- Foreign Secretary Bevin's fervent but general appeal for a Western European union under leadership of the British and French.

THE returns aren't all at hand, but the first reviews around the country of Ross Lockridge Jr.'s mighty long saga of the American Dream, "Raintree County," suggest that a considerable myth is in the making about Mr. Lockridge himself.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The French Government made all preparations today to announce the devaluation of the franc tomorrow to 216 to the dollar, accompanied by a free market in which the franc and the dollar could be bought and sold at a rate determined by supply and demand.

There are few things more revolting to witness than prostitution of truth on the screen. When Hollywood goes out of its shallow depth for once and grapples with a serious social theme as in "Gentleman's Agreement," this prostitution, as revealed in the phony sequences, stands out all the more in rasping contrast to the few honest moments.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Two handsome champions from abroad, Endeavor II of Argentina and Shannon II of Australia, made impressive but losing debuts in a $5,000 race at Santa Anita today, while May Reward scored an upset in the $50,000 added San Felipe Stakes for 3-year-olds.

ATHENS, Jan. 24 -- The opinion is widespread in Greece that unless the guerrilla menace is brought to an end the country will cease to exist as a sovereign state and in time will be drawn in behind the Iron Curtain. Chances of survival and chances of winning against forces currently draining the nation's life blood are generally seen as one and the same.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Hans Roth, competitor from Palestine in the slalom and downhill events in the winter Olympic games, said today he did not know not if the rest of his team would get here in time to participate.

Gloria Greene, pianist who made her debut four years ago at the age of 13, gave a recital in Times Hall yesterday afternoon. She chose to play an all-Schumann program, and that composer's wide variety of expression, his feeling for the piano and the clarity of his intentions proved him an excellent choice for the young lady's accurate fingers and serious approach.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- Today's edition of Echo der Woche, a weekly published in Munich, contained an unusually long article on the conditions inside and surrounding the former German concentration camp in Buchenwald.

THE lives and habits of more than fifty American birds, from blackbird to wren, are described and pictured in this interesting, informing book. The many illustrations -- sometimes three or four on a page, sometimes full or even double-page size -- are colorful and attractive.

PONTRESINA, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Miss Andrea Mead, 15-year-old schoolgirl from Rutland, Vt., upheld American prestige today by winning the women's downhill race in pre-Olympic ski competition. Stein Eriksen of Norway won the men's race with the best United States performance a fourth place finish by Steve Knowlton of Aspen, Colo.

The controversy still raging over traditional moldboard plowing versus stubble or soil-mixing plowing points up an important issue. Any method of soil stirring that permits vital humus and essential chemicals to be lost through wind or moisture erosion is harmful to the welfare of the nation.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- a full account of the British negotiations with France over her decision to devalue the franc is expected to be given to the House of Commons here Monday by Sir Stafford, who returned from Paris tonight.
On Monday, March 8, THE NEW YORK TIMES will publish the first of eighteen copyrighted daily articles from the book, "The Goebbels Diaries."

Radio-agriculture may be one of the developments of the atomic age that is now dawning, the French Academy of Sciences was recently told by Paul Becquerel, nephew of Henri, who discovered radioactivity. Nephew Becquerel states that treatment of seeds with solutions of salts of the radioactive elements greatly increases their yield.

ANGELS are enjoying a flurry of unusual popularity in the current market for stage screen and fiction. Mr. Ronald Mitchell's angel, Joe, is a good, shrewd fellow but trails no clouds of glory. He wears exactly the same clothes as does his earthly counterpart when standing thirstily before the beer tap in the Black Bull tavern.

THE week's only dance performance in the district that is whimsically known as Broadway will be the Dance Festival for the benefit of the Spanish Refugee Appeal at the Ziegfeld Theatre tonight. It is a fairly busy week, however, in the smaller and outlying halls.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 -- Although inflation has made the Government prices paid for land more unsatisfactory than ever to the former owners, occupation officials have found that Japanese landlords are almost completely acquiescent in the rural land reform.

As part of a comprehensive examination of the functions of city agencies, the Mayor's Executive Committee on Administration is about to begin an intensive study of the report recently submitted by the Citizens Budget Commission, it was learned yesterday.
Speedy enactment of the Marshall Plan was urged yesterday by the national board of the Young Men's Christian Association at its annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The Premier of Trans-Jordan, Tawfik Pasha Abdul Huda, reached London today to discuss delicate problems connected with Palestine. He was accompanied by the Foreign Minister, Dr. Fawzi Pasha Mulki, and Brigadier John A. Bagot Glubb Pasha, commander of the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion.

Contracts awarded last year for building and engineering work in the thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains amounted to $7,759,868,000, an increase of 4 per cent over the volume of $7,489,722,000 for 1946. The total for 1947 was described yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, which compiled the figures, as the largest for any peacetime year.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jewish war veterans urged today that the Governor of New York be given the power to cancel the tax exemption of any educational institution found to have discriminated against students because of color, creed or race.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Charles D. Tucker of Indianapolis, president of the Independent party within the International Typographical Union, said today his party would not lead the union "into further chaos, expensive litigation [and] unnecessary strikes."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Lieut. James A. Dillian of Akron, Ohio, a Coast Guard communications expert, will leave here by plane tomorrow to test the radio communication and radio-beacon service provided by the Coast Guard's ocean weather station vessels.

Metals, aircraft components, welding equipment, incinerators, industrial equipment and miscellaneous supplies are among the new offerings of Government-owned surplus goods announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

Prof. Clarence A. Manning of Columbia University's Department of East European Languages received yesterday an honorary degree of Doctor of Philosophy from the Ukrainian Free University, formerly of Prague, Czechoslovakia.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Indications that the existing program of the Soviet Communist party is being altered have been received here, although exactly what changes are contemplated by the Central Committee are not yet known.
Mart Manley, vice president of the Electrolux Corporation, has been appointed chairman of the Vacuum Cleaner Manufacturers' Association national committee to succeed Thomas F. Kelly.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Spreading their scoring evenly over three periods, the Boston Bruins defeated the New York Rangers, 6 -- 4, to tie them for third place in the National Hockey League tonight before a sell-out 13,900 crowd. Woody Dumart sparked the Bruins with two goals, the first tally coming while Boston was playing shorthanded.

Accommodations for tourists in Great Britain are now "quite good" and the country can cope easily with 100,000 to 150,000 visitors this year, Stanley Adams, chairman of Thomas Cook Son, Ltd., said yesterday.

The Roman Catholic Church "has never sought nor will it seek" political power and influence in this country, the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of the Diocese of Rochester, declared yesterday at a thanksgiving mass marking the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of St. Agnes' Roman Catholic Church, 143 East Forty-third Street.

The letter in your edition of Jan. 14, signed by eight Christian Americans, could not in the name of fairness be allowed to pass without challenge, containing as it does so many slanders against "one of the leading Powers of the Christian world, namely Great Britain."
DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Don Morrison scored in the last six minutes to give the Detroit Red Wings a 1-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens before 13,656 fans tonight.

The annual dance festival for the benefit of the Spanish Refugee Appeal took place at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night, with many of the biggest names in the dance field on the program and the house sold out, as usual, well in advance.

The Ship Operators and Owners Association has urged the Maritime Commission to withdraw from berth services all American ships chartered from the Government by such services and used in tramp shipping, it was announced here yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- The development of the Missouri River Valley is a "man-sized job," compared with the "test-tube experiment" of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska declared today during an aerial survey of flood-control works on the Missouri River from Omaha to St. Louis.

The house that sold for $6,000 in 1939 today brings $11,625, or an increase of 93.8 per cent over the pre-war level, according to an interesting analysis of costs found in a "test" home that is generally accepted in building circles as a yardstick for comparing current prices with those of a little less than a decade ago.

American foreign policy in the Far East was criticized sharply in five resolutions adopted unanimously yesterday by 400 delegates at the closing session of the National Conference on American Policy in China and the Far East at the Hotel Roosevelt.
OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- The Government of Alberta has charged thirteen Canadian citizens with conspiracy to publish a defamatory libel of one of its employes and the organization under his control.

" No nation of atheists has ever been discovered; man is incurably religious," Bishop Herbert Welch of the Methodist Church said yesterday in a sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. Opening a week's "Clinic in Christian Living," Bishop Welch declared that it was not "what we worshiped but how we worshiped."

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Pravda, Communist party newspaper, declared today that British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's proposal for a union of western Europe was actually the plan of John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser of the United States Department.

Since the D'Oyly Carte Savoyards opened here Dec. 29, it has been our pleasant duty to remind the faithful concerning the weekly change of bill every Monday morning. The fifth offering, which will be presented this week, is "The Gondoliers."

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- A Communist was elected Mayor of the Parisian suburb of Malakoff when de Gaullist and Third Force councilmen chosen in last Sunday's election voted for their own nominees rather than consolidate their fourteen votes against the Communists' thirteen.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Repairs were made today to battered craft which yesterday completed the 52-mile Fort Lauderdale-to-Cat Cay sailing race to open the Southern Ocean Sailing Conference schedule.
Eisenhower backers in more than half the sixteen states in which they have been organized will support Harold E. Stassen, a leader of the National Draft Eisenhower League predicted yesterday.

While it would be folly to think of another war, it is necessary, in order to keep the peace, "to maintain an Allied military force that must be kept on the most modern level," former French Senator Jacques-Louis Dumesnil warned yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 25 -Through snows and freezing temperatures, on Sundays and often at night, the brothers Edward and Benjamin Cicoria, and their brother-in-law. Eugene Chariamonte, are laboring to tear down a building they put up with their own hands for a dry cleaning establishment in which they had prospered.

Mayor O'Dwyer will be the principal speaker Thursday afternoon at a mass meeting of city business, labor and civic organizations opposed to the St. Lawrence Seaway project, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Two possible drastic revisions in the European Recovery Program were suggested today to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and leader for the program in the Senate.

Cotton prices fluctuated irregularly last week, with selling pressure especially pronounced in spots and in near-by future deliveries. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 88 points to up 5 points.

The Metropolitan Opera, which completes its presentation of Wagner's "Ring" cycle for matinee subscribers with "Goetterdaemmerung" on Thursday, will start presenting the cycle for evening subscribers next week, when it presents "Das Rheingold" again on Feb. 6.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Chicago Black Hawks knocked Toronto out of its first-place tie with Detroit in the National Hockey League tonight by holding the Leafs to a 4-4 tie before 16,512 fans. Detroit's 1-0 victory over Montreal put the Red Wings one point ahead of Toronto.

PRAGUE, Jan. 25 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party raised a bitter outcry today against a proposal to shorten the term of compulsory military service from two years to sixteen months. This contrasted with the Communist stand in such countries as the United States, where the Communists oppose compulsory military service.

In keeping with its policy of developing all possible sources of non-aviation revenue at the airports it operates, the Port of New York Authority has announced that facilities for serving light lunches will be opened at the International Terminal at La Guardia Field some time this week.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Called upon to act with urgency on France's new devaluation, the National Assembly must deal with renewed Communist obstruction when it reassembles here tomorrow. Before Premier Robert Schuman can present his survey of the Government's monetary measures, the Asssembly has to install its officers against whom the Communists still are standing out in open revolt.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 25 -The Government has prepared a bill establishing a new youth organization in which the membership of all Polish boys and girls up to 20 years of age will be compulsory, it was learned today. The bill will be presented to Parliament Wednesday.

Because industry has actually entered the "third round" of wage increases, the proposal of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to extend the work week under a five-hour increase at overtime rates was made too late to be seriously considered in metal-working plants in the East, industry spokesmen declared over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- New techniques for compelling the blood vessels to help heal broken and diseased bones, particularly valuable in treating stubborn fractures resulting from motor accidents, were described today by Dr. Donald S. Miller of Chicago before the annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons.

Realization of a world of goodwill within our lifetime is not essential to the final achievement of that goal, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared yesterday in his sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft declared tonight that Harold E. Stassen's "attempt to split the Republican party" by entering Ohio's Presidential primary had "no chance of success."

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Dewey will recommend that the state contribute $3,000,000 this year toward the cost of teacher training in the four New York City municipal colleges, it was disclosed tonight as he met with Republican legislative leaders to discuss his budget proposals.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Stolid Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, South Africa, today won a torrid, three-day golfing battle from colorful Jim Demaret of Ojai, Calif., and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago when he came from behind on the final eighteen holes to capture the $10,000 Phoenix open golf championship with a 72-hole total of 268.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- Luis Morones, Mexican labor leader whose charges against the American Federation of Labor on the Argentine issue were unanimously rejected by the Lima Conference, received a hero's welcome here last night.
