The Committee for Freedom of North Africa has taken emphatic exception to statements made in Paris Friday by Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Resident General of Morocco, who was quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES as having said that independence for the French Protectorate was only a distant possibility.

ROME, Jan. 25 -- Italian industrialists are not a little concerned over the devaluation of the French franc. They fear that this will accentuate the disadvantage in which Italian goods already find themselves as far as prices are concerned on world markets.

There has been "no significant redistribution" of population in the post-war period and the "ghost towns" and blighted industrial areas predicted have as yet failed to materialize, according to an analysis of post-war distribution of population by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.

Your editorial of Jan. 17 regarding Governor Dewey's announcement of his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President contains one misstatement of fact which in fairness to the Governor should be corrected.

Hailing the European Recovery Program as a genuine plan to avoid the recurring necessity of foreign relief, the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace urged Congress yesterday to free the measure from the "pitfalls and delays of election-year wrangling."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) Announcement that Ed McKeever, until Saturday coach of the University of San Francisco football team, had signed a three-year contract to coach the Chicago Rockets was made today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The forty-six-nation International Monetary Fund rejected today the French Government's plan to devalue the franc and expressed "regret" that France had decided to effectuate the program despite the Fund's opposition.

THE most monumental work yet printed on sports is Frank Menke's huge volume, "Encyclopedia of Sports." It arrived at this desk several months ago but it's not the type of book one reads at a single sitting. It takes months of constant browsing to give its 628 pages the thorough attention they deserve. Here are some scattered samples which were picked at random during a snowbound week-end:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of Cincinnati, vehemently denied today recent charges of a Protestant manifesto that Roman Catholics sought to breach the wall separating church and state in the United States.

The sixth Leap Year Assembly will be held on Feb. 28 at the Ritz Carlton. Edward Everett Watt Jr. heads the committee for the event, a feature of Leap Year here since 1924, with the exception of 1944.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,084,636,019. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The official "Summary and Recommendations" of the fourth report of the President's Commission on Higher Education follows:

Meat loaf, always an expedient relied on by thrifty housewives to save pennies, today is more to the point than ever. With hamburger steak averaging 55 cents a pound in stores here now, this ground beef must be made to provide as many servings as possible if it is to have been a worthwhile purchase.

The combined volume of thirty-seven advertising agencies which billed $10,000,000 or more in 1947, totaled about $939,000,000 according to the copyrighted "annual billings" summary appearing in today's Advertising Age. J. Walter Thompson Company reached a record $103,000,000 according to the summary, while Young Rubicam rose from $59,000,000 in 1946 to an estimated $65,000,000 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Recommending a drastic revision of the university and graduate school teacher training programs, the fourth report of the President's Commission on Higher Education, made public today, uged the adoption of higher professional standards for college teachers.

I note in the account of the untimely death of Habeeb Ahmed Faruqi carried in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16 that the article gave an accurate picture of Mr. Faruqi's standing and prospects in Teachers College.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet Union's displeasure at the opposition by the bulk of the Finns to a defense pact between the two countries is believed to be behind a change in the basis of Finnish transit privileges through the Russian-held Porkkala enclave.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- In spite of the refusal of the International Monetary Fund to authorize its action, the French Government announced tonight that it would devalue its currency, beginning tomorrow, in a double fashion.

Settlement of the twenty-four-day-old strike against the cable division of the Western Union Telegraph Company was still deadlocked yesterday although an agreement was reached on all but one issue, "hot traffic," according to Theodore W. Kheel, director of the New York City Labor Relations Division.

Bishop Arne Fjellbu of Trondheim, Norway, was the principal speaker last night at an interdenominational service in Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, 144 St. Felix Street, Brooklyn. He spoke under the auspices of the Evangelical Lutheran Churches of New York and New Jersey and the Brooklyn division of the Protestant Council of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The University of San Francisco today appointed Joe Kuharich to succeed Ed McKeever as head football coach.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 25 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey is seriously ill tonight with a gastrointestinal hemorrhage aboard the Panama liner Ancon, according to a message received by Canal officials. The Ancon, delayed by bad weatehr, reported yesterday she expected to reach Cristobal tomorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Fear that Britain may lose her post-war struggle to maintain the value of the pound mounted here tonight in the wake of the French decision to devalue the franc.

PONTRESINA, Switzerland, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Barney McLean, captain of the United States Olympic ski team, and 15-year-old Andrea Mead led American forces to unexpected victories today in the final big pre-Olympic tests before the winter games get under way at St. Moritz Friday.

A continued increase in food and apparel prices, and to a lesser extent in those of other necessities, between last Nov. 15 and Dec. 15 sent the consumers' price index for New York to a new high, it was reported yesterday by the United States Department of Labor.

Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons has received $5,000 from a father grateful for the college's help in his epileptic son's recovery of health. The money will be used for continued research on epilepsy at the college.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Production, sales and earnings of the International Harvester Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1947, were the largest in the farm-equipment company's history, John McCaffrey, president, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, headed by Harry Bridges, called off its pickets today after four months of marching in front of a Sears, Roebuck Company store, and issued a blast at the Taft-Hartley Law and Mr. Bridges' West Coast rival, Harry Lundeberg, of the AFL.

Albert W. Lockyer, realty consultant and appraiser of White Plains, will discuss market trends at the January meeting of the Queens North Shore Chapter of the Long Island Real Estate Board tomorrow night at the Sanford Hotel in Flushing.

Man's surest guarantees against desperation and disillusionment are very often the "great traditions" of his faith, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor emeritus of the Riverside Church, said yesterday morning at the church.
Seven new films, including importations from France and Italy, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Iron and coal shortages have combined to increase large scale open-pit and strip mining in both Canada and the United States, with vast future demands continuing for large power shovels used in this work, Harvey T. Gracely, president of the Marion Power Shovel Company, Marion, Ohio, revealed here during an interview last week.

After an afternoon and night of snow, sleet, and high wind had given this area a taste of blizzard conditions, the new storm center that was headed this way veered into the Atlantic, leaving only 4.6 inches of snow and a bright clear winter day yesterday.

Schools of law should revise their courses to train students for the responsibilities of public service, a report released yesterday by the Russell Sage Foundation declared. Entitled "Lawyers, Law Schools and the Public Service," it summarized studies begun in 1939 by Dr. Esther Lucile Brown, director of the foundation's Department of Studies of the Professions.

The annual report of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, showing the extent and variety of service to the people of this city in the fiscal year ended last June 30, was issued yesterday. Activity declined from the peak wartime years but was in excess of pre-war periods.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Russian construction organizations were criticized during the current session of the Moscow Soviet. It was pointed out that one apartment house, started twelve years ago, is still unfinished. Work on other apartment buildings, begun more than a decade ago, remains uncompleted.

The gravest danger to the American merchant marine in the post-war period comes not from without but from within, Lewis D. Parmelee, president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines and national president of the Propeller Club of the United States, said yesterday.

Eleven persons -- one of them a woman -- identified with the United Jewish Appeal arrived at La Guardia Field at 9:35 o'clock last night from the West preparatory to departing by plane tomorrow on a tour of "inquiry and information" concerning Zionist problems in Europe and Palestine.

On "recommendation" of the American and British Military Governments, the German Bizonal Economic Council has issued stern laws to intensify the collection of German food and to stop hoarding and black markets. These measures follow a wave of hunger strikes that swept through "Bizonia" after a new cut in the official rations.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The British Government fully concurs with the grave rebuke of France and her new dual-value franc made by the International Monetary Fund in Washington. This was made clear in a joint Anglo-French communique issued simultaneously tonight with the Monetary Fund's statement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Edward and Robert Golden, United Artists producers, will film "Barnstorming," the life of Frank Bacon, as their next picture after the current "Texas, Brooklyn and Heaven," Edward Golden has announced.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 18 (Delayed) -- The eight correspondents making a conducted tour of the Soviet zone were permitted today to visit the home of a second lieutenant in the Soviet Army of occupation. There was much evidence that Soviet authorities prefer to have their occupation personnel remain in the army rather than become civilians.

;'Orders for winter goods and other heavy merchandise last week were quite heavy as the nationwide cold spell continued, accordir[g to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WHAT was "the master tale of the American frontier"? From the story of Pocahontas and Captain John Smith to the story of Wild Bill Hickock and Calamity Jane, with a hundred others in between, candidates are so numerous that few people would care to make a choice. But John Myers Myers has no doubts. To him one episode of extraordinary heroism sur passes all, the siege of the Alamo.

The Palestine crisis provided the theme yesterday morning for an animated exchange of opinion between Randolph S. Churchill, son of Great Britain's wartime leader, and the members of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Members of Washington's diplomatic corps attended the annual Red Mass at Washigton's Catholic University today and heard the Most Rev. Raymond A. Kearney, Auxiliary Bishop of Brooklyn, appeal for more Godliness in the everyday affairs of men and nations.

Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of the President's Air Policy Commission, accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the planning board for the International Air Exposition to be held here July 31 through Aug. 8 as part of the city's celebration of its Golden Anniversary.

HARRISMITH, South Africa, Jan. 16 -- A search for Thaba Bosigo, the Basuto's "Mountain of Darkness," has occupied the paleontologist of the University of California's South African expedition for the last ten days.

Contrary to the popular belief that only large companies maintain research laboratories, about one-half of the products of smaller concerns have been developed from their own research, according to a survey of 983 manufacturers by the National Association of Manufacturers, released over the week-end.

Continuing its campaign to have the as yet unreleased Twentieth Century-Fox film, "The Iron Curtain," withheld from distribution as "inimical to the aims and welfare of the United States and United Nations," the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship has presented an appeal to Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

Martha Briney, soprano, who had been heard here previously with the New York City Opera Company in 1944, gave her first local recital last night at Town Hall. The program presented by the youthful vocalist was out of the ordinary, consisting almost entirely of seldom-sung offerings, and featuring the prologue and Therese's first-act aria from Poulenc's opera bouffe, "Les Mamelles de Tiresias," which received a first New York performance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- The Presidents' Conference of the International Walther League, official youth organization of the synodical conference of Lutheran Churches, today ended a two-day meeting here with a recommendation that the dues system of the league be abolished and that "Christian growth conferences" be held on a nation-wide basis.

The traditional ritual of the blessing of the waters to mark the Greek Orthodox Church celebration of the Feast of the Epiphany was marred yesterday when four divers failed to recover the symbolic gold cross that Archbishop Arsenios had tossed into the ice-chocked Hudson River.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- Nearly one thousand persons in Switzerland, mostly small savers, received last week a printed circular from the Nederlandsche Bank in Amsterdam informing them curtly that old florin bank notes deposited as required before July 29, 1945, with the Swiss Bank Corporation "to safeguard the interests of holders" were now worthless.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said tonight that further inflation and still higher prices are inevitable unless steps are taken to control the situation. It declared that "continued inflationary developments can lead only to severe reaction, unemployment and financial loss later."

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 17 commenting upon the services rendered by probation officers of the Domestic Relations Court and elsewhere hits the nail on the head. I cannot speak with any personal knowledge as to the situation existing in the Magistrate's Court, or the Court of Special Sessions, but I can do so with regard to the probation officers in my court.

In place of the fire hazard, "falls and bumps" have become the most common instances of carelessness in New York homes, according to inspections made in 440,000 homes by the Greater New York Safety Council, it was announced yesterday.

Nine of thirty-five contestants advanced to the final bracket as the preliminary and semi-final rounds in the foil competition of the Olympic fencing tryouts were completed yesterday on the strips of the New York Athletic Club.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 -- Arabs and Jewish convoy guards fought today in a ravine outside Jerusalem. British armored cars with two-pound cannon and automatic weapons broke up the struggle in which at least ten Jews and two Arabs were reported killed.

In his message to Congress on the State of the Union, delivered on Jan. 7, President Truman proposed that a "cost of living tax credit" be extended to the people of the United States, consisting of a credit of $40 to each individual taxpayer and an additional $40 for each dependent.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 25 -- Without waiting for Marshall Plan aid, a group in Alsace is completing plans for a 1,100,000,000-franc bond issue as a start toward financing the region's recovery, it was learned today. The plans for the internal self-help loan follow the successful launching of a similar loan in Lorraine.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- "Diamond Lil," which was presented at the Prince of Wales Theatre here last night, was a personal success for its author and star, Mae West.
A decrease in contributions to private philanthropies in 1947 as compared to 1946 was indicated yesterday in a report by the John Price Jones Corporation of New York.
PARIS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The text of today's French Government communique on the franc, as given by Finance Minister Rene Mayer:

The racial covenants issue now before the Supreme Court is discussed by Attorney General Tom C. Clark and Solicitor General Philip B. Perlman in "Prejudice and Property," which will be published by Public Affairs Press on Feb. 23.

Prominent this week among openings in local galleries are exhibitions by two of the most distinguished and controversial figures in the modern movement, Picasso and Matisse, and an annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and drawings.

High school graduates with business school training are "preferred" as office workers by 38 per cent of the 500 personnel directors of firms in the metropolitan area queried by Public Opinion Polls, Inc., for the Drake Business Schools, Inc.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP) -- La Crosse, Wis., skipped by Harry Watkins, today captured the coveted Mitchell Medal in the Grand National curling bonspiel, while Caledonia No. 1 of New York City, led by Jock MacFarland, won the Allen Medal.

In evaluating future highway requirements the Eno Foundation for Highway Traffic Research has pointed out that the road of tomorrow must be of type, location and design that will eliminate delay and congestion, relieve the driver of strain and be free from accident potential.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday that an average monthly rental of $55 to $60 a room for new privately constructed housing in Manhattan was evidence that "we cannot hope to meet any great housing emergency at present."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -The text of a statement by Board Chairman Camille Gutt of the forty-six-nation International Monetary Fund on France's devaluation of her currency follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The new Russian Ambassador today called for expanded Soviet-American trade as a step toward better diplomatic relations. He said the people of both countries "are equally interested" in bettering these relations.

ALPENA, Mich., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Miss Betty Mitchell, 19-year-old Canadian star from Winnipeg, and George Fisher, 21-year-old University of Illinois junior from Chicago, swept the boards here today to take the major senior North American speed skating championships.

The United Nations Security Council should send an international force to Palestine to maintain peace, Dr. Jorge Garcia Granados, delegate from Guatemala to the United Nations, said last night at a dinner of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The decision to go ahead with the devaluation plan in the face of British protests and the disapproval of the International Monetary Fund is the hardest any French Government has had to make since the war. In London they are talking of Sir Stafford Cripps' unsuccessful trip as "the defeat of Paris."

ROME, Jan. 25 -- According to Foreign Ministry sources, the Italian Ambassador in London, Duke Tommaso Gallarati Scotti, informed Foreign Secretary Bevin yesterday that Italy was ready and eager to participate in any agreement for economic cooperation that might be concluded between the western European states.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 25 -- Fawzi el-Kawukji, Commander in Chief of the Arab People's Army, was reported today to be preparing to leave for Palestine. The number of his men who have crossed the Lebanese and Syrian frontiers to gather in the mountain region around Nablus in Palestine was said to exceed 3,500.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Pound for pound, cash corn and wheat now are selling at virtually the same price. Experts say this condition ultimately will result in the feeding of increased quantities of wheat to livestock, especially in areas where wheat is plentiful and corn scarce.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued jointly by the French and British Governments on devaluation of the franc:
Some kind of a record for dispatch may have been set at the season's third concert of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors at Times Hall last night.

Frank Stanton, president of CBS, predicted yesterday that within twenty-five years pocket receiving sets powered by sunlight and personal sending sets small enough to be carried about will be in popular use. He also foresees facsimile newspapers with pictures in full color printed before breakfast on home receivers and globe-girdling color television.

Competition on a substantial scale has returned to industrial purchasing of contract services on mechanical installations of all types, procurement executives revealed over the week-end. Types of installations in which real competition is now apparent for the first time since before the war include industrial and commercial electrical, sheet metal, power equipment, plumbing and heating and millwright services, they reported.

Josef Raieff, Russian-born pianist, marked the tenth anniversary of his playing in this city with a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was his fifth program there. During the decade his career was interrupted by service in the United States Army.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- Steel men here believe the industry soon will enter a period of semi-controlled steel distribution. With the major steel committee under the new voluntary allocation program already named, it will not be long before an additional organization will be set up in Washington, according to officials here.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The City of London has been regaled in the last few days by the publication of leading British bankers' views on our economic position. These are expressed annually to bank shareholders and rarely fail to attract considerable public attention, although they are as a rule rather "high brow."

Twelve hundred families in Brooklyn that use gas for heating were deprived of it for that purpose yesterday as consumption outran the maximum output of one company by 25 per cent. The homes affected were in the southern section of the borough supplied by the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company. By tonight, according to the company, it was considered possible that all 2,400 families heating with gas would be without that source of heat.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Hardwood flooring output may establish a new high mark this year to keep pace with the expected increase in building activity, Allen Harris Jr., president of the National Oak Flooring Manufacturers' Association, said today.

ATHENS, Jan. 25 -- Advices reaching Athens today said rebel forces, which had been observed concentrating anew in the area of Konitsa in Epirus, had early yesterday attacked the Greek army detachment guarding the Borozani Bridge near the Albanian border. The attack was without success.

A delightful program of choral music accompanied and unaccompanied was given at the concert of the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Robert Shaw, conductor, and the Collegiate Choir. The Bach Motets Nos. 3 and 5 opened and closed the program.

Never an unfriendly word passed between the President and me during my twelve years in the State Department. Naturally a few emphatic differences rose between us, which we thrashed out earnestly and bluntly but in friendly spirit. Our association in general was very agreeable.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Jan.25 -- Reidar Andersen, Norway's great stylist, who swept everything in North America during a previous visit in 1939, had to be content with a runner-up post to Merrill (Mezzy) Barber of Brattleboro, Vt., in a thrilling invitation ski jump held today on the natural Norsemen hill carved out of Schunnemunk Mountain.
In behalf of the American Merchant Marine Library Association Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Beecher Stowe will give a book tea this afternoon at their home, 1 Beekman Place.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 25 -- The first big wave of hunger strikes and demonstrations, predicted by Allied observers several months ago, appeared to be over today.
GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- Details of a new and drastic plan by the Polish Government for a nation-wide attack on syphilis became known here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Radically new types of naval vessels are included in a small naval construction program which Congress will be asked to approve at this session, it was learned today.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 -- Pathan tribesmen mounted on camels were reported today to have invaded Jaisalmer, a Princely State of 16,000 square miles area and 93,000 population in the western Rajputana desert.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- With the snow banked on shore but the harbor here free of ice, eighteen irrepressible winter skippers and their crews completed five races today. The interclub group winner was Jack Sutphen and first among the six moth competitors was Mrs. Allegra Knapp Mertz.

The stage was set for New York's first big track show of 1948, the forty-first annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, in an exciting week-end of competition at Boston, Philadelphia and West Point.

MANILA, Monday, Jan. 26 -- The Philippine Weather Bureau has reported that another earthquake of moderate intensity shook Iloilo at mid-afternoon Sunday, about twelve hours after the series of tremendous shocks that caused at least twenty-one deaths and heavy property damage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company today to stop a number of sales practices which it found tended to restrain trade unlawfully and create a monopoly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- An appeal to American Jews to furnish $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 immediately to the Jews of Palestine was made today by Mrs. Golda Myerson, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- India and Pakistan, which will go into private session in New York tomorrow in another attempt to settle the Kashmir dispute, will submit substantive proposals that are completely opposed on the key question of troop withdrawals from the Princely State, it was learned today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- The thirty-five-acre West Point ski development on Silver Depository Hill was dedicated today to the memory of Capt. Samuel Victor Constant Jr., Army ski coach who was fatally hurt while preparing for the national downhill-slalom championships at Cannon Mountain, Franconia, N.H., in 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Twenty-two representatives in Congress from California joined today in a bi-partisan appeal to President Truman and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for quick, affirmative action in support of Henry J. Kaiser's plan for a $45,000,000 expansion of his steel plant at Fontana, Calif.

Former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, announced here yesterday that he would enter the Ohio Republican primary against Senator Robert A. Taft of that state to get a test of the differences between them on both foreign and domestic policies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- World peace and world prosperity are the double stakes the United States is playing for in helping to restore the economy of Europe, Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, declared today in a countrywide broadcast arranged by the Democratic National Committee.

In both public and private schools current problems are forcing difficult decisions. Increased expenditures are pressing school budgets. The higher costs of materials and work are reflected in general community tax increases over the nation. School administrators are seriously concerned over proposals to reduce the vocational courses now given in most larger communities.

The Federal Office of Rent Control reported yesterday that 252,759 leases embodying voluntary rent increases up to 15 per cent had been filed in the New York City Defense Rental Area since July 1, when the amended rent law permitted such increases under certain conditions.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 25 -- Shipbuilders fear the European Recovery Program is a threat to their industry. The United States State Department commodity report called for a cut in the program for their shipyards.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The State Department's reply to Foreign Minister Bidault's recent letter referring to France's utilization of United States interim aid funds is expected momentarily here. The annex to the French-United States accord of Jan. 2 provided that an equivalent sum in francs be deposited here to offset the value of these shipments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Jan. 17 to 23 are given in the appended tabulation:

TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- Forced to abolish afternoon sessions last Wednesday and to close altogether on Saturday because trading was too heavy for their limited facilities, the Tokyo and Osaka stock markets reopened today with prices again sharply upward.
To prove that "with a little help a man can get off the Bowery and return to normal society," the Bowery Comeback Association picked a war veteran and a bartender yesterday to start its experiment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A famed baseball manager, a noted New Haven surgeon and a distinguished golf teacher tonight received gold keys for "Meritorious Service to Sports" from the Connecticut Sports Writers' Alliance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -A large-scale program to stamp out tuberculosis by immunizing 15,000,000 persons will be undertaken by the World Health Organization, it was announced here today. The program -- which was mapped out at the group's meeting in Geneva today -- will be carried out in conjunction with the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Government officials in general indicated today that they were optimistic about the chances of success for France's new monetary program. It was apparent, however, that some of them were keeping their fingers crossed.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 26 (AP) -- It looked tonight as if the Navy's search for a civilian football coach may be centering in the Big Six -- and the top of the conference, at that.

Four persons were hurt, three seriously, at 10:45 A. M. yesterday when they were struck by two heavy iron poles, knocked down by a truck after it had been in collision with a bus at Whitehall and Pearl Streets. The bus driver was treated for shock and the lone passenger refused medical aid.

The first tentative formula looking toward duplication of network musical programs over both frequency-modulation and standard stations was advanced last night by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in the course of negotiations with network representatives.

A nation-wide upswing in the number of students enrolled in nursing schools was reported yesterday by the department of studies of the National League of Nursing Education at 1790 Broadway. Its January survey of nursing schools throughout the country recorded that 38,210 students were admitted to state-accredited schools of nursing last year, an increase of 7,311 students over the previous year.

BALBOA. C. Z., Jan. 26 -- His condition improved, Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey was carried down the gangplank of the liner Ancon tonight by two Canal Zone policemen to a waiting ambulance, which took him to the Margarita Hospital, a few miles from Cristobal.

Despite the highest operating costs in its history and trying shortages, new records in production, sales and earnings were established for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 by the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, the annual report to stockholders said yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Speedy action on state legislation validating New York City's emergency rent laws was assured tonight as word reached here that the Appellate Division had affirmed a decision holding the city controls void.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- A subcommittee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment rejected tonight by vote of eight to two a Czechoslovak motion to the effect that the conference lacked competence to consider a United States proposal that nations occupying Germany and Japan, in accepting this projected World Trade Charter, would also accept it in behalf of Germany and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, chairman of the Senate Post Office Committee, said today he had directed that an investigation be made at the Memphis and Knoxville, Tenn., post offices, following the filing by the National Alliance of Postal Employes of charges of racial discrimination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen and Enginemen today announced capitulation in its long fight against agreeing to accord equal treatment to Negro firemen.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A 3-year-old filly named Liza Lee was the big show on today's stakeless card at Hialeah Park when she captured the third race and electrified the crowd with a straight pay-off of $245.60 for $2.
Forty thousand homeward-bound commuters were delayed up to thirty minutes last night by the derailment of a Long Island Rail Road train entering Pennsylvania Station at the start of the rush period.

Color-music-paintings by I. J. Belmont are again being shown in several store windows in connection with the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial concert which is to be given on Friday for the benefit of the National Infantile Paralysis Fund.

A last-minute effort will be made today by the City Labor Relations Division to avert a strike of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, AFL, that would tie up an estimated 200,000 private automobiles and 10,000 to 15,000 trucks used in the transportation of food.

The rules controversy started by Matty Begovich at the basketball writers' luncheon last week continued yesterday as the scribes gathered for their weekly session at Leone's. This time it was Coach A1 Baggett of Brooklyn College who held the spotlight, and he immediately cast a vote against new departures, generally, that is.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 25 -- Establishment in Chicago of the first all-Lutheran post-graduate theological seminary in this country, was proposed here today to the executive committee of the National Lutheran Council.

"The Last Dance," a free adaptation by Peter Goldbaum and Robin Short of August Strindberg's "Dodsdancen," opens tonight at the Belasco Theatre, with Oscar Homolka and Jessie Royce Landis sharing stellar billing. Featured in the five-character play is Philip Bourneuf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Charges that President Truman sent Congress "a phony budget" on the European Recovery Program and "doctored" figures to suggest total Federal expenditures under $40,000,000,000 in fiscal 1949 were made today by Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

Barnard College will receive "at least $100,000" from the estate of Mrs. Ada M. Donelle, it was announced yesterday in the final report of Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve as dean of Barnard. In the report, which covered the academic year that ended June 30, 1947, Miss Gildersleeve, now dean emeritus, said the college had received gifts totaling $47,710 in the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Harold E. Stassen has, in part, restored the prospect of drama at the Republican National Convention of 1948. General Eisenhower's self-elimination removed the possibility that the convention would include the dramatic element in its most thrilling- form -- the true "draft."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 -- The Presidential elections in Paraguay that had been scheduled for Feb. 15 have been indefinitely postponed, it was learned today from a private source in Asuncion. Eduardo Loizaga Caballero, counselor of the Paraguyan Embassy here, said he had no information on the subject.
LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 26 -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft announced today plans for an all-out campaign to win delegates for him in the Nebraska Republican Presidential primary.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 26 (UP) -- The wholesale slump in horse racing receipts in Florida this winter is only a headache to the rich tracks but to little Sunshine Park the depression is a crisis.

Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman was elected president of the National Horse Show Association yesterday and Walter B. Devereux became the new secretary at a meeting of the board of directors at 90 Broad Street. The National probably will be in Madison Square Garden Nov. 2 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Strong Congressional forces opened a campaign today to halt the export of American oil. Simultaneously, the Administration, confronting a petroleum shortage described as of great concern to civilian and military authorities, proposed an immediate beginning on a program of synthetic oil production to cost ultimately about $9,000,000,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- The stand of Congressional candidates on repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law will overshadow inflation and all other issues in determining whether they have the support of the American Federation of Labor, William Green, president, said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- A world government composed of the United States, Great Britain and the democracies of Western Europe was called for today by Dr. Harold C. Urey, scientist who helped develop the atomic bomb.

Traffic at Broadway and 110th Street (Cathedral Parkway) was halted for several hours late last night and early today by a four-alarm fire that caused damage estimated at $200,000 to a two-story brick building running from 2838 to 2844 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Truman today appealed to top leaders of both parties for a bipartisan drive in support of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

Warmly applauding the plan to provide England with a Tea Party by way of compensation for the tea that was thrown overboard during the Stamp Act period, it is in order to state that New York enters the picture as well as Boston.

New investments made by the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company in 1947 amounted to $110,031,691, Peter M. Fraser, president of the company, said in his annual report to policyholders released yesterday. The average gross rate of return was 3.74 per cent, compared with 3.42 per cent in 1946.
I am writing concerning your editorial outlining some of-the reasons for the increasing growth in membership of the Automobile Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce has informed Representative Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, that $2,769,751 of electrical machinery and engines, turbines and parts went to Russia from the United States in the first eight months of 1947.

Not that there is any particular news value in the statement, but the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company is at the peak of form this week. In their fifth production they have got down the curriculum as far as "The Gondoliers," which they put on at the New Century last evening. Dressed to the teeth in some of Charles Ricketts' most ravishing wearing apparel, the production is particularly handsome.

Many of your readers may have received Christmas gifts which they are unable to use. Through your column will you let them know they can put them to good use by sending them to Sheltering Arms Children's Service? We will sell them in our Thrift Shop, called the Nearly New Shop, and the money received will enable us to purchase layettes for some of the homeless babies for whom Sheltering Arms provides foster home care.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The dollar rate in French and foreign banks was pegged today at 212 French francs for the general public pending the opening of a free market in foreign exchange for dollars and Portuguese escudos, which is expected Thursday or Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Spokesmen for the lumber industry presented a united front against price controls and allocations today on grounds that attempts to regulate "a most complicated business" would result in less production and higher costs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Parking congestion throughout the country was described today as "a huge cancerous growth destroying the vital elements of commercial life and individual transportation" at the annual conference of the American Road Builders Association here.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 5 per cent over the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended Saturday the increase was 4 per cent.
Conferred with members of his staff on the Executive budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Philip J. Kurens, Queens manufacturer, repeated to House investigators of the steel "gray market" today his story of how he lost $9,000 in a deal with A. Terry Fahye, and witnessed by Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler.

Pfc. Harold Sims and his Italian fiancee, Renata Lendaro of Pradilis were reunited yesterday with the help of the American Red Cross, an anonymous busines man from Decatur, Ill., a score or more of unofficial advisers, and an assist from the Immigration Service.

In his recent article in our Magazine, Thomas C. Desmond, New York State Senator and chairman of the Committee on Affairs of Cities, long an expert on traffic control and safety, wrote regarding traffic accidents: "About 90 per cent of such accidents are the fault of the motor vehicle operator. . . .

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Dewey recommended in a message to the State Legislature tonight that it adopt a resolution approving an amendment to the Federal Constitution that would limit future Presidents to two terms in office. If, as expected, the Republican-dominated Legislature approves the resolution, New York would become the nineteenth state to have ratified the proposal.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -In the face of "aggression" by the Arab states, an international armed force as well as the arming of a Jewish militia is essential for implementing the United Nations plan for partitioning Palestine, Mrs. Golda Meyerson, head of the political department in Jerusalem of the Jewish Agency, said today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- Arab efforts to make a concerted organized invasion of Palestine are bogging down because of a series of internal feuds. The Arab League will meet here, probably Feb. 5, in an attempt to straighten out the personal animosities that are delaying military action.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 -- The recurrent suggestion that as a result of the nonconvertibility of sterling, Argentina would be forced to halt shipments of tinned meat to Great Britain was quashed this morning -- possibly for good.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to a mild scare as the result of the devaluation of the French franc, but the action had been so well advertised in advance that the reaction was limited. The gold stocks followed the usual pattern of firming during changes in major currencies but some quick shifts by professionals reduced peak gains.

A joint meeting between the executives of the Motion Picture Export Association and the directors of the Motion Picture Association of America will take place this afternoon at the MPAA headquarters, 28 West Forty-fourth Street, to review the industry's foreign market problems.

New York's service restaurants, which abandoned meatless Tuesday with the turn of the year, already are conserving more meat through a week-around reduction in the number of meat dishes on their menus, the Society of Restaurateurs reported yesterday.

Clinics maintained by agencies affiliated with the Planned Parenthood Federation of America are beginning to play an important part in the prevention of cancer, it was reported here yesterday. The examinations made at many of these clinics are being broadened to include tests for early signs of the disease, speakers noted at two meetings in the Roosevelt Hotel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- A strike of nearly 9,000 Chicago school teachers, scheduled for tomorrow, was called off late today after the city council passed the school board's $97,972,000 tax levy, based on the board's record-breaking $103,461,537.61 budget.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- A resolution calling for voluntary contributions by governments to a special fund for large-scale resettlement in the form of colonization projects was approved unanimously today by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization.

The move by the French Government in devaluating the franc has brought protests both from the British Government and from the International Monetary Fund, whose function it is to pass on such eases of unilateral currency action. At this writing, however, it does not appear that either of the objecting parties is prepared to force a showdown on the issue.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The immediate resumption of French exports to hard-money countries, virtually halted since rumors of yesterday's devaluation were first circulated, was predicted here today by a spokesman for the National Federation of French Import and Export Companies. He expressed the opinion that the franc-price of goods would remain stable for some months.

We believe that Senator Vandenberg and the Brookings Institution have made progress in answering the question as to how and by whom the European Recovery Plan is to be administered. The Vandenberg proposal, based on the Institution's study, seems to give the ERP administrator more authority than the President and Secretary Marshall contemplated, but not so much more that a fair and good compromise is not possible.

The reaction yesterday in the foreign exchange market in New York to the devaluation of the French franc bulked largely on the "conversational" side. Bankers and dealers in currencies took a position on the sidelines to await subsidence of the confusion that accompanied the new schedule.
An ex-convict, said by the police to have pilfered 1,000 telephone coin boxes since 1921, was held without bail yesterday. He was seized Sunday by two detectives in a Bronx building hallway.

Newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities reached a total of 2,008,535,854 lines during 1947, for an increase of 16.1 per cent over 1946, an analysis by Media Records disclosed yesterday. The total for December, 1947, was 186,913,274 lines, a gain of 14.5 per cent over the like month of 1946.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 -- The wives and children of members of the United States Consulate here sailed for home from Haifa today aboard the Saturnia. Palestine meanwhile continued to enjoy a comparative lull in violence which is believed a prelude to the first fully organized Arab attacks on the Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- Shoe merchandisers must clarify in the minds of consumers the meaning of present costs and secure acknowledgment that shoes provide inherently greater dollar value than almost all other goods, it was declared here today by Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners' Council of America, Inc.

HAVANA, Cuba, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Fourteen entries, four of them from the United States, have been received for the seventeenth annual International Star Class regatta, which will be held here Jan. 31 to Feb. 7, racing officials announced today.

Cornelis M. de Jong, passenger traffic manager of the Holland-America Line, reported yesterday that applications for summer travel to and from Europe were coming into the office at 29 Broadway in considerable volume. He said he expected that all sailings of Holland-America ships from early June to late July would be fully booked.

Striking members of the cables division of the Western Union Telegraph Company resolved "unanimously'' at a meeting yesterday to support union negotiators in their refusal to send men back to work "under conditions which would require them to handle struck copy," an official of the American Communications Association, CIO said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Mrs. Ads Lois Sipuel Fisher, the young Negro woman for whom the Supreme Court recently ordered Oklahoma to provide a legal education, today asked the court to compel Oklahoma to admit her to the State University Law School.

The New York City public libraries have just submitted to the Budget Director their requests for funds. Perhaps more than most other public or commercial activities our libraries have been handicapped by the present inflationary situation. Normally noted for their low salaries, the public library systems are now losing more and more of their well-trained employes and are failing to attract new trainees who will stay.

The fuel shortage in the city was relieved somewhat yesterday, but officials warned that the situation was still serious and might lead to considerable hardship unless gas and oil users heeded pleas to conserve supplies.

ISLAND PARK, L. I., Jan. 26 -A family of nine -- mother, father and their seven children -- has been living for nearly three months in the boiler room of this village's firehouse, it was disclosed today.

Brother Charles Austin, director of Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, N. Y., received the CYO Club of Champions Award for 1947 at the annual board of directors dinner of the Catholic Youth Organization last night at the Hotel Park Lane.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A movement is developing inside the State Department and the Cabinet to extend the bipartisan or nonpartisan foreign policy to all questions relating to Palestine.

MADRID, Jan. 26 -- Reduction in export prices of olive oil and olives have brought about sharp increases in the export of these items to the United States within the past few days, figures received here today from Andalusian olive centers indicate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Harold E. Stassen's decision to enter the Ohio Republican Presidential primary took on new political interest today as it was learned that he conferred here Saturday night at some length with Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio's favorite-son candidate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Middle West Corporation received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to distribute to its stockholders, as a capital distribution in partial liquidation of the corporation, stock of the Central Illinois Public Service Company, Springfield, Ill.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 26 (AP) --- The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee tomorrow will tackle the delicate problem of which of two hockey teams will represent the United States in the games starting here on Friday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, today criticized Eugene Varga, the prominent Soviet economist, for the view that a planned economy is feasible in a capitalist state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- An over-all inventory of the country's welfare needs, the first of its kind, was started here today under the auspices of the National Social Welfare Assembly and the Community Chests and Councils.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- France's international diplomatic position has been shaken by British opposition to the franc devaluation but by no means necessarily broken. The British financial opposition is not so important in this case as potential efforts by the Soviet Union and the French Communist party to wreck the stability of France's Government.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The convention and equipment exhibit of the National Automobile Dealers Association opened here today with eighty-five companies exhibiting in 120 booths, and 10,000 dealers expected for the four-day meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Tighe E. Woods, Federal housing expediter, said today "there is only one cure for rent control and that is a lot of rental accommodations."

NEW DELHI, Jan. 26 -- Since the first of the year, the Dominion of India's States Ministry has erased from the map of India more than half of the crazy-quilt patch-work of Princely States that covered 40 per cent of the area and governed one-fourth of the population of the subcontinent.

Sales of Government bonds probably would find an almost "bottomless market" the first day support was withdrawn by the Federal Reserve, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, declared yesterday.
The Seafarers International Union of North America, AFL, will meet with the Atlantic and Gulf Ship Operators Association at 29 Broadway at 10:30 A. M. today to discuss cost of living increases.

ROME, Jan. 26 -- The international manpower conference to draw up plans for the most efficient utilization of Europe's labor reserves opened today in what formerly was Benito Mussolini's office in the Palazzo Venezia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Albania's latest charges against Greece have been forwarded by the Secretariat here to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, stationed at Salonika, it was announced today.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman received a miniature gold reproduction of the Statue of Liberty from Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday. He accepted the statuette on behalf of forty Jewish leaders who are leaving today for Europe and Palestine.

One interesting subject on which more light is thrown by the State Department's publication of the Nazi-Soviet documents of 1939-41 is the role and function of the press in totalitarian states. Thus Ribbentrop, early in this correspondence, calls the attention of the Russian Charge in Berlin to the changed "tone of our [German] press with regard to Russia" in the summer of 1939.

WARSAW, Jan. 26 -- The Polish Government considers the Anglo-Polish military alliance, which brought Britain into the war against Germany in 1939, as legally valid but outdated by the "new political situation," Gen. Victor Grosz said today.

A 26-year-old former lieutenant in the Army Air Forces was accused yesterday of acts of treason. The prisoner, Martin James Monti of Florissant, Mo., was taken into custody by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at Mitchel Field, L. I., minutes after he had received a general discharge under "honorable conditions."

Any big bulge in French imports into the United States must await determination of the "free" rate of franc exchange, for it will have a vital bearing on the prices to be charged by manufacturers and exporters in France, it was reported in import circles here yesterday.

An Appellate Court's ruling yesterday that part of the city rent law was invalid was followed quickly by announcement that the City Rent Commission would continue to operate as usual, under a stay granted by the court. Meanwhile, the Legislature at Albany was reported ready to correct the legal flaw found by the courts in Local Law 66, one of the Sharkey Rent Laws enacted by the city last summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -President Truman said today that national preparedness meant preparedness for peace and not for war. He endorsed plans of the Reserve Officers Association for National Security Week, Feb. 12-22, and expressed the hope that the program would be observed in every state and community.

Luncheon guests at the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel were whisked yesterday by Belle Irene Gillis of the Tailored Woman on an imaginary fashion trip through tropical lands. Points sartorially visited were Bermuda, Nassau, Mexico, Florida and Havana.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -While they condemned religious discrimination, journalistic experts agreed today that a specific ban on publications that incited race hatred could not be included in the proposed international convention on human rights.

New honors have come to a many-sided personality in aeronautics -namely, James H. Doolittle. Last evening he received the award of the Fellows of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences as this year's Honorary Fellow, one of the highest honors the aviation profession can bestow.

A survey of the "third round" of price increases shows that industrial supply and equipment manufacturers are following a very conservative policy in announcing 1948 changes, New York distributors revealed here yesterday. They reported that average increases applying generally to hardware and tools amount to about 5 per cent.

Repeal of the Federal Wage-Hour Law was urged yesterday by Frank W. Whitty, president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, as a necessary step in any attempt to stabilize prices. He spoke at the fifty-fourth annual convention of the group in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 26 -- Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, called on the United States tonight to support the immediate establishment of a United Nations police force in Palestine to carry out the partition program.

On the basis, perhaps, that old friends, if not the best, are those who cannot be excelled, the Roth Quartet last night in Town Hall presented three familiar works, and played them with a sympathy and gusto which gave much pleasure to the audience.
As a result of events in Greece and Korea, the United Nations is now confronted with a situation which calls for some action to reassert its authority.

NANKING, Jan. 26 -- Members of forty guilds and labor unions in Chengtu, capital of Szechwan Province, were scheduled to go on a one-day fast today and use the food and money saved for the relief of the evicted Kowloon City squatters, the Central News Agency reported.

Recent developments in furniture construction that make possible rounded silhouettes instead of sharp angles have been used in a new group of modern bedroom pieces introduced yesterday at Namm's. Plywood and blond mahogany veneers have been bonded and molded electronically to form rounded drawer fronts on all of the storage pieces.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26 (UP) -- Mike Jacobs, Sol Strauss and Felix Boccicchio wound up in a bitter stalemate today in their efforts to fix purse arrangements for the proposed return match between Champion Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott for the heavyweight title.

Robert Lazarus, formerly vice president and secretary of F. R. Lazarus Co., Columbus, Ohio, yesterday was elected president. Charles Y. Lazarus and Ralph Lazarus were elected vice presidents, and. Mrs. Jessie Ross was named secretary.

Two new products that merit a place on the pantry shelf reserved for foods that can be made in a hurry are 7-minute pies, one complete chocolate and the other lemon. One tidy package contains two paper bags, the larger with the ready-to-mix ingredients for the pastry, the other with prepared material for the pie filling.

MUKDEN, China, Jan. 26 -- If present plans are carried out, the United States will continue to have official representation in Manchuria regardless of the outcome of the Communist-Government struggle in China's northeastern provinces.

Three more pitchers, all righthanded, were added to Manager Bucky Harris' staff yesterday with the announcement by the Yankees that Karl brews, Randy Gumpert and Don Johnson had turned in their inked contracts for 1948. These signings bring the Yankee total to twenty-five -- which happens to be the player limit on May 15, but fortunately for the world champions, not the roster limit, which is forty.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. Wheat futures closed 3 1/4 to 5 cents lower, about the lowest, despite purchases by the Commodity Credit Corporation estimated at 2,000,000 bushels or more, largely in the Southwest.

At a moment when the Jewish population in Palestine faces its hour of greatest peril and the very physical survival of large Jewish masses in the countries of the Middle East is in the balance, the American Council for Judaism, as reported in your issue of Jan. 18, has found it opportune to raise once more an issue which has been repeatedly passed upon, disposed of and set at rest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Two prominent labor attorneys of the Government agreed today that employers may -- but cannot be compelled to -- bargain with a union whose officers have failed to sign non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Law.
Weakness developed again yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 18 to 41 points net lower than Saturday's closing levels.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 26 -- Prices of guns in the Middle East have trebled under pressure of an intense demand from Arabs and Jews since the Palestine partition plan was announced. International gunrunning is developing into a big business, much like that in the Spanish civil war.
Mayor O'Dwyer issued an invitation last night to the residents of the forty-eight states to visit New York next summer to participate in the city's Golden Anniversary.

Notice of an appeal from a decision by former Supreme Court Justice J. Edward Lumbard Jr., denying the right of Hamportzoon Choolokian, 48-year-old shoemaker, to take three of his children from Catholic institutions when he returned to Armenia last November, was filed with the County Clerk yesterday.

I often had occasion to see the President in the early morning, when he was still in bed. Usually he had already been up, eaten breakfast and returned to bed to conduct the first business of the day. I found his bed strewn with newspapers, documents, letters and telegrams.

Officials of the New York public school system have protested an announcement of the State Education Department that an agreement permitting the city high schools to emphasize modern history over ancient and medieval history would be ended next year.

Danny Kapilow, promising young Brooklyn middleweight, entered the ring at the St. Nicholas Arena last night a 1-to-3 shot to beat rugged Tony Riccio of Bayonne, N. J., in the feature ten-round bout and was lucky to win on a split decision.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- C. W. Bailey of Clarksville, Tenn., former president of the American Bankers Association, urged banks today to deny credit to the speculative farmer "who bins his wheat or cribs his corn purely for higher prices." At an anti-inflation meeting of the ABA, Mr. Bailey said country bankers "must assume a position of leadership in our communities.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- In a speech that was received coolly and critically by members of most parties Premier Robert Schuman defended the franc's devaluation before the National Assembly today, and he asked it to pass the Government's bill to create a free market in gold.

To aid retailers in reducing operating costs, wholesale salespeople are beginning to train retail salespeople in properties and qualities of merchandise they sell, I. Jerome Harris, president of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

Except for reports on improvements in the stability and control of helicopters, the entire first day of a four-day meeting of the Intitute of the Aeronautical Sciences in the Hotel Astor yesterday was devoted to discussions of airplanes attaining the speed of sound and the power plants to drive them.

MANILA, Jan. 26 -- President Manuel Roxas reported to the opening of the third session of the first National Congress today that the Philippines had successfully passed her post-war economic crisis and that her program of rehabilitation now was far advanced.

PARIS, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- Marcel Cerdan, French and European middleweight champion, scored an easy victory over Giovanni Manca of Italy at the Palais des Sports tonight, knocking him out in the second round of their ten-round fight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The successful transplanting of wisdom teeth in the jaws of young patients to fill gaps caused by the loss of regular molars was reported today by Dr. Harland Apfel of San Pedro, Calif.
Jesse Frankel, formerly a sales manager in the textile machinery field, has joined M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., as assistant to S. L. Hagan, vice president in charge of sales.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The economically merged United States and British zones of Germany exported $222,032,860 worth of goods and services during their first year of joint effort to reduce occupation costs, William J. Logan, director-general of the Joint Export-Import Agency, announced tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -Argosy Pictures, the John Ford-Merian Cooper producing company, which has previously released its films through RKO, today announced the signing of a distribution contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for Ford's next venture, a screen adaptation of Peter B. Kyne's story, "The Three Godfathers," published in 1913.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Net income of Deere Co., manufacturer of agricultural machinery, increased to $13,863,540 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 from $9,565,579 in the preceding year, Charles Deere Wiman, president, informed stockholders today in the annual report.

NUMEROUS accounts of the French resistance movement have been published in this country but none like Remy's "Memoirs of a Secret Agent of Free France,"* of which the first volume, "The Silent Company," is now available, Remy is one of the several pseudonyms used in the underground by Col. Gilbert Renault-Roulier, one of France's most notable heroes of the last war.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- An attack by Moslem tribesmen on non-Moslem refugees in a camp at Parachinar, in the North West Frontier Province, Pakistan, was reported today to have resulted in 130 deaths and a number of kidnappings.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Louis Hollander, president of the state Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted tonight in a letter to members of the Legislature that his organization was "unalterably opposed" to fixing a $900,000,000 ceiling for the unemployment insurance reserve fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Charges of sixty-one officers of the Army Nurse Corps in Japan that they are being discriminated against in matters of quarters and leave and are imposed upon by Army officers' wives were laid before Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall today by Representative Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine.

The Tennessee Eastman Corporation, subsidiary of Eastman Kodak Company, announced yesterday it has discontinued use of the word "rayon" as a generic name for its cellulose acetate textile fibers and the products made from them.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- The selection of Paris as the site for the United Nations General Assembly session this year is becoming increasingly probable as a result of the devaluation of the French franc, according to most observers here.

Women in England have become increasingly conscious of hair style as a result of clothes rationing, Peter B. Raymond, British hair stylist who calls himself Raymond of Mayfair, declared yesterday. Here for his first visit since 1939, Mr. Raymond said at the Madison Hotel that "women are paying a great deal of attention to their hair in England because it is the only thing in the style line for which ration coupons are not required."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 26 -- Under the terms of the new Bizonal Economic Administration, the Germans will be able to form an interzonal police force on specific economic questions -- including food collection -- if the proper legislation is passed by the projected quasi-government, it was explained today by a high Military Government official.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- A rush by speculators in the stock markets here today to buy gold shares following the devaluation of the French franc led to losses of millions of pounds in prices of British Government securities and to a flare-up in South African gold shares.

ATHENS, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said today that, while there was a gain in having United States Army officers to advise the Greek Army in operations against the Communist-led guerrillas, the Greek Army could make no real progress until the United States sent it more artillery.

There is no snap in the municipal market, bond men say, as they point to new repricings evidently needed to keep inventory shelves from getting heavier instead of lighter. Last weekend saw the final breakup of the Atlanta, Ga. account, where long maturities brought out last October on a yield basis range of 1.65 per cent to 1.90 per cent are now quoted in the market up to a 2.50 per cent basis.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind denied yesterday a petition of the National Labor Relations Board to enjoin the Metropolitan Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, CIO, from engaging in acts against the Project Engineering Company, 115 Fulton Street.

Up in New Brunswick the oldest inhabitant is scratching his head and trying to remember whether he ever saw snow as deep as it is right now. According to reports from the deep woods, deer and moose are floundering helplessly in the deep drifts, and in some areas they have yarded up in large concentrations.

Straightforward decorating devices, such as the effective use of color and the careful selection of wall coverings and rugs, have accomplished impressive results in a group of five model rooms that went on view yesterday at Stern's. They demonstrate that neither custom-made furniture nor fabulous one-of-a-kind accessories are indispensable elements of fresh and original interior schemes.

Construction work on the Board of Transportation's $7,000,000 central office building in Brooklyn will start this summer, William Reid, chairman, said yesterday. It is scheduled to be ready for occupancy at the end of 1949.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to take part in discussions of the composition of the International Atomic Authority -- who will serve on it, how they will be chosen, etc.; and the Control Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission decided to dissolve a group that had been working on the subject and make a new start.

Net income of the Celotex Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last October increased to $6,227,929 after taxes and all charges from the $3,824,324 earned in the preceding year, Bror Dahlberg, president, reported in the annual statement mailed yesterday to stockholders.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Several bills desired by the New York City administration were introduced in the Senate tonight by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan 26 -- A special United Nations committee today adopted a joint Chilean-Venezuelan draft resolution calling fop immediate establishment of an economic commission for Latin America and outlining the proposed commission's powers and functions.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, women's national amateur golf champion from Atlanta, Ga., fired a men's-par-equaling 72 today to win the medal by three strokes in the qualifying round of the sixteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's golf tournament.

GROSSINGER LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Irving Jaffee, who carried the colors of the United States in the Olympic Games of 1928 and 1932 as a speed skater, hopes he's wrong, but he said today he'll be very surprised if the American boys win more than one speed skating event in this year's contests.

Aggressive action against "mistaken statements" about the carbonated beverage industry, and the necessity of further sharpening sales campaigns previously intensified by the industry's sharp swing back to pre-war competitive conditions, were urged yesterday at the opening business session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the New York State Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, Inc., in the Hotel New Yorker. Some 450 delegates representing as many companies took part.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- The structure erected at Bretton Woods to prevent monetary chaos in the post-war world has been destroyed by the first big blow leveled at it -- the unilateral French action in devaluating the franc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -Income tax reduction made progress in Congress today as a House committee decided to vote tomorrow on a $6,300,000,000 slash and the Senate Republicans agreed to back a cut of undetermined amount.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- London couturiers' collections of spring fashions opened today with an emphasis on the now-popular hourglass silhouette, which leading designers forecast will remain the vogue for some time.

EVERYONE has long admitted that the baseball season never ends. As soon as the active part of it halts, the conversational part of it begins. But football always was different. It used to shut up shop on Thanksgiving Day and there wasn't a peep out of it until the next September. As Shakespeare neatly phrased it, however, them days is gone forever.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The House of Lords begins a debate on its own destiny tomorrow when it will consider the Labor Government's Parliament Bill to reduce its power of veto from two years to one.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Welsh members of Parliament rose in their wrath today and smote the Labor Government. It was one of those explosions of national feeling that serve to let off steam and at the same time remind the English that Great Britain is composed, in addition to Englishmen, of Scots, Welsh and Irish.
The Marine Midland Corporation reported yesterday net operating income of $5,557,685 for 1947, equal to 99 cents a share, compared with $5,353,254, or 95 cents for 1946.

Spring coat production has stepped into high gear with January output keeping up the record pace set last month, it was learned from women's apparel manufacturers yesterday. A tendency toward slowness in fabric deliveries, they said, was the only factor which may prevent satisfactory shipments for Easter.
Hoist the storm warnings and tighten up the reserve clause. Jorge Pasquel, the moneyed Mexican magnate, wants more baseball players. Price is no object.

An anthology containing selections from the work of writers who have won Nobel Prizes, entitled "The Nobel Prize Treasury," will be published by Doubleday on March 11. Marshall McClintock, who edited the anthology, has "tried to choose pieces representative of the author's best work."

The President Nominated Gen. Omar N. Bradley to be Chief or Staff of the Army. Nominated Thomas Bayard IVcCabe to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. His callers included the Rev. Dr. Mar Ivanios of India with _mhassador Henry F. Grady and Secretary of State Marshall.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Legislative action requiring all public officials in the state to take oaths denying affiliation with communism and fascism was advocated today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Ada Lois Sipuel Fisher, 23- year-old Negro, today spurned a new law school created especially for Negroes and once again renewed her fight in the United States Supreme Court for admission to the University of Oklahoma Law School, which rejected her because of her race.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- The general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, ordered today the expulsion from union office of ILGWU officials who refused to file non-Communist affidavits with the National Labor Relations Board.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Konstantin Flink, who was master of American cargo vessels during World War II, is sending a food package to Germany to repay a wartime favor of a Nazi submarine commander.

The wheels of government began to turn yesterday to make fact what has been foregone conclusion: that Gen. Omar N. Bradley would be the next Chief of Staff, United States Army. President Truman announced his intention in this matter last November. Even before that, General Bradley had made a trip to Europe to familiarize himself with the problems of command.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel, sitting at Jamaica, Queens, refused yesterday to issue an order calculated to bar Communists and certain other groups from after-hours use of the public schools.

MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 27 -- Hundreds more fled in panic from Iloilo city on Panay Island during the night as three new moderate to strong earthquakes -- more than forty hours after the first devastating shocks early Sunday -- brought additional casualties and damage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Ralph Helstein, international president of the United Packinghouse Workers, CIO, announced today at a press conference that the union was seeking a wage increase of 29 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The House of Representatives received today from Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett a defense of the policy of the United States in regard to industrial rehabilitation of Germany. Information on the extent of dismantling German industrial plants was asked in a resolution introduced by Representative Francis Case, Republican, of South Dakota.

There can be no reduction in the huge air arm recommended by the President's Air Policy Commission and no whittling of the Marshall Plan appropriations until Russia acknowledges international law and its enforceability by international armed forces under the United Nations, Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of the commission, said last night.

VIENNA, Jan. 26 -- New Russian suggestions for the settlement of the disputed economic clauses in the proposed Austrian peace treaty are estimated here to represent a reduction of slightly more than 50 per cent from the value of Russia's former claims.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Britain will continue in close political and economic collaboration with France despite their difference over the devaluation of the franc, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, assured the House of Commons today.

The Acme Wire Company declared a 75-cent dividend payable to common stockholders on Feb. 14. In 1947 shareholders received 50 cents each in February, May and August; $1 in November and 50 cents in December.

Robert Lange, director of the North American service of the French broadcasting system, outlined yesterday plans for new transmissions and programs for American stations now carrying English-language programs prepared in France.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Duquesne University, unbeaten in twelve previous starts, went down before the "13" jinx and Texas Wesleyan by a score of 57 -- 53 in a game that was followed by a near riot tonight at the Gardens.
The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, has begun a drive to bring within its ranks about 3,000 workers employed by two railroads, it was announced here yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- In the grip of the worst drought conditions in seventy years, California today basked in June-in-January weather.
