Cleveland announced yesterdayl that it would receive bids Feb. 10 on $6,250,000 of various purpose bonds dated March 1, 1948, and due Sept. 1 from 1949 o 1973.

Despite its extraordinary capacity for defying the onward march of the centuries and appropriating to itself a large slice of the conversation indulged in during all eras by members of the human race, talk about the weather has usually had a stigma attached to it, something that has made those partial to it ashamed of themselves and highly critical of fellow-humans guilty of the same weakness.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 26 -- New Jersey Republican administration leaders were agreed today that new state tax sources must be sought to provide additional revenues for education and other governmental costs.
VIENNA, Jan. 26 -- The Austrian Government has asked the Allied Council to endorse its request for the delivery from Germany of Franz von Papen and Baldur von Schirach for trial as war criminals.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- If the Russian practice of hindering Germans going from Berlin to the British and United States zones of Germany continues, there will be some high-level protests soon, it was learned authoritatively here here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Dewey, with the full approval of Republican legislative leaders, will recommend a $20,000,000 temporary pay increase for state employes in his annual budget message to be submitted to the Legislature later in the week.

Directors of the American Tobacco Company voted an extra dividend of 75 cents together with the regular quarterly of 75 cents, payable to common stockholders on March 1. A year ago they received an extra of 50 cents.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today established the Foreign Affairs Ministry, headed by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, as the supreme clearing house for all contacts with the outside world. This was announced in a decree issued by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The many racegoers who figured today's Cocoanuts Purse at Hialeah Park was strictly a two-horse affair between Cencerro and Kingarvie proved eminently correct, for the pair completed the mile-and-afurlong turf course event as named.
Charles Adams has been appointed general sales manager of the K-D Lamp division, Noma Electric Corporation. He formerly represented the division in the Southeastern sales territory.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Such obvious precautions as increased safeguards against the smuggling of currency and gold from Britain are already in force. The Treasury went to work today, therefore, to raise other defenses against adverse effects that new French monetary policies might have upon the pound sterling.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Senate and Assembly Republicans, in separate conferences, split today on the issue of increasing pay of members of the Legislature as authorized by the constitutional amendment approved by the voters last fall.

New York may well be proud or the handsome show staged yesterday noon in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Cooperating to make this, the fourth annual fashion show of the March of Dimes, the best seen so far were stars of stage and screen, leading New York dress designers, photographers and fashion experts.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The State Senate confirmed today the appointment of Burton Turkus, former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, to the State Board of Mediation.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The institution of the family must meet the challenge of a changing world, a panel of four agreed today on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum series, "What's on Your Mind?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 --President Truman signed today the bill to which Congress gave unanimous final approval last week, to make the "Voice of Amnerica" permanent and stronger for the war of words with Russia.
A bill introduced in the House last week and now on the agenda of the Committee on Banking and Currency would put the United States on a gold coin basis.
ROME, Jan. 27 -- Pope Pius today praised the idea of the Friendship Train and the generosity of the American people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The names of James Bruce, Ambassador to Argentina, and Frank Pace Jr. newly appointed assistant director of the budget, were on a list of traders in commodities futures given out today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The first open indication that bitterness was developing in the Ohio Presidential primary battle came today as supporters of Harold E. Stassen, the Minnesota invader, asserted that their district delegate slates were being raided.

Two shows by artists either never before exhibited in New York or relatively unknown here -- a leading Palestinian painter and work by a group of California watercolorists - are on view this week in local galleries.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 27 Ultimate organic union of American Lutheranism was envisaged here tonight as the logical outgrowth of cooperative inter-church activity now being carried on in this country under the auspices of the National Lutheran Council.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 27 Upholding the right of newspapers to publish all viewpoints, Prof. Zechariah H. Chafee of the United States declared today that he favored publication and full discussion of Communist opinions and study of the Soviet Government system in American schools.

With shipments of finished products reaching a record level for peacetime, net income of the United States Steel Corporation in 1947, before the declaration of divdends, amounted to $126,704,272, the highest annual profit since 1929, Irving S. Olds, chairman, reported yesterday.

While endorsing recent steps taken by the Government away from the freezing of interest rates at excessively low wartime levels, the Committee on Public Debt Policy in its fifth report, released yesterday, attacked the Federal tax system.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission today reset dates for the operation of Havre de Grace race track and authorized an eleven-day meeting there, starting July 6.

The first daily motion-picture newsreel in television will make its bow on Monday, Feb. 16, over the NBC video network (WNBT), it was announced yesterday. The newsreel will be produced by Twentieth Century-Fox's Movietone News in what is said to be the first instance of a major motion -picture concern preparing film especially for the needs of television.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman created today an emergency board to find the facts in a dispute between the country's major railroads and three transportation brotherhoods representing about 125,000 workers. Membership of the board was not immediately announced.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Senate Labor subcommittee took up consideration of proposals for a national health program under trying circumstances today.

An "all-weather" flying tech-nique that will make it possiblefor big airliners to take off, flyand land in all but the most violent weather was predicted yesterday for the riear future by ViceAdmiral' Emery S. Land, presidentof the Air Transport Association.
MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A reorganization scheme approved by a majority of shareholders of St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., was set aside today by Justice Louis Boyer in Superior Court here.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- The Left Wing press was crowing this afternoon over what it claimed was a promise by Premier Alcide de Gasperi to the Left Wing Socialist leader, Pietro Nenni, that Italy would not join the bloc of Western European powers.

The New York Telephone Company sold yesterday a new issue of $60,000,000 of thirty-year bonds at an interest cost of about 3.08 per cent, compared with an interest cost of 2.637 per cent ruling in the sale last July of $125,000,000 of thirty-five-year bonds under the same mortgage.

ATHENS, Jan. 27 -- The life of the present United States mission, scheduled to end June 30, definitely will conclude then, although some sort of similar group will be installed if the Marshall Plan goes into effect, it was learned from completely reliable sources today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States must continue its support of Greece, despite the faults and weaknesses of the Greek Government, the Select Committee on Foreign Aid reported to the House of Representatives today.

There are two classical techniques which a country's central bank employs when it wishes to encourage an expansion of bank credit. One of these is the rediscount rate; the other is what is known as "open market operations." When a central bank embarks upon open market operations it goes into the market and buys government securities.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 -- As British-Argentine negotiations entered a crucial phase tonight, it was learned that Washington was seriously concerned over a possible breakdown as having an adverse effect on the European Recovery Program pending on Capitol Hill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--The Administration rejected today Congressional demands for a full stop to American oil exports, contending that it would bring "calamity" to Western European recovery without doing a great deal to ease the domestic shortage.

A demand for a 20 per cent wage increase for members of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, was made yesterday when the union opened wage negotiations with the Atlantic and Gulf snip Operators Association at 29 Broadway.

Rescinding by the Office of International Trade of over-all licensing of exports to Europe was urged yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council, top policy organization in its field, pending thorough consultation with industry.

In connection with the reference by you in your editorial of Jan. 7 ascribing to John Sherman words to the effect that "the way to resume (specie payments) is to resume," and the letter appearing in your issue of Jan. 16 written by Horace Mather Lippincott, a question is raised in my mind as to the accuracy of either one.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 20 (Delayed) -- The Soviet Army has removed art treasures valued at more than $170,000,000, including Raphael's Sistine Madonna, from the famous Zwinger Museum in this city, it was learned today.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Trading in dollars on the official market was at a complete standstill today as holders waited with impatience for the new free market rates on Thursday.
Early morning and after dark pick-ups and deliveries by truckers probably will begin in the garment district by March 1, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27 Failure of Czechoslovakia to sign articles of the trade agreement drawn up at the International Trade Organization gathering at Geneva last year is causing considerable embarrassment to British manufacturers. They have just awakened to the fact that many of the products they hoped to sell in quantity to the United States will not enjoy the benefits of lower duties offered by the United States until the Czech Government signs the agreement.

WARSAW, Jan. 27 -- Marshal Michal Rola-Zymierski, Minister of National Defense and Commander in Chief of the Army, held secret talks with Russian military leaders in Moscow last week in conjunction with the Russian-Polish economic and political negotiations concluded yesterday, it was learned tonight.

The best recovery in almost two weeks was negotiated yesterday by the stock market as active traders concentrated on news viewed as favorable in financial circles. Increases were limited in most cases to fractions, however, for the bidding proved meager and the dullness during the late trading permitted a reduction in some peak gains.
The clouds that have hung over the proposed return bout for the world heavyweight title between champion Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott apparently have started to dissolve.

Henry K. S. Williams, retired lumber man, who died in San Francisco in 1944, left more than half of his $8,799,316 estate for public purposes, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Estate Tax Commissioner Charles W. Ferry.
Many modern parents are finding it difficult to give their children any "real moral backing," Mrs. Rustin McIntosh, dean of Barnard College, declared yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 27 -Establishment of an inter-industrial committee to revise present purchasing methods of the Armed Forces with a view toward regularizing their purchases on an annual basis, was urged here tonight by F. Eugene Ackerman, executive director of the American Wool Council.

A collegiate welcome, American style, awaited two Estonian girls, first displaced persons brought here from Germany on a scholarship plan, when they arrived yesterday from La Guardia Field at the home of their benefactor, William H. Sudduth of 17 East Eightyseventh Street.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Great Britain will have to spend much more than the 25,000,000 [about $100,000,000] she originally planned on the development of vast acreages of peanuts in East Africa, the Government disclosed today. Already some 4,000,000 has been laid out in preliminary groundbreaking.
JERUSALEM. Jan. 27 -- British troops fought a two-hour skirmish with Arabs on the Haifa-Tel Aviv highway this morning after both Arabs and Jews had broken a tacit truce in that area.

Received a delegation from the New York State League of Women Voters; Lieut. Joseph Regan, former president of the Sergeants Benevolent Association of New York City, and Sgt. Eugene L. Roussin, the present president; and a delegation from the legislative conference of the American Legion.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Palace, the attraction is "Night Song," a drama produced by RKO starring Dana Andrews, Merle Oberon and Ethel Barrymore. John Cromwell directed and Harrieth Parsons produced from a screen play by Frank Fenton and Dick Irving Hyland and an adaptation by DeWitt Bodeen.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 27 The long deferred roundtable conference between the Dutch and their colonies of Curacao and Surinam opened here today. Discussions in the next fortnight will review the principles for a new constitutional structure.

OTTAWA, Jan. 27 -- An estimated 70,000,000 persons in other countries saw Canadian films through commercial distribution within twelve months, the National Film Board said today in its annual report for the fiscal year 1946-47.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 27 -- Closing out what he termed "an excellent day in New Hampshire," Harold E. Stassen, avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, told the state's Young Republicans tonight to avoid sending a personally pledged delegation to the national convention in June.

a wiry youth smashed a show case in a firearms salesroom yesterday and escaped into crowded Fifth Avenue with a 38 caliber automatic pistol after being shot in the right shoulder by the manager of the store.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) - The Senate Commerce Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Wayne C. Coy to be chairman of the Federal Communications Commission after he denied he was the "candidate" of the National Broadcasting Company.

A banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank bought at competitive sale yesterday issues of $3,800,000 of Durham (N.C.) bonds maturing from 1950 to 1983, with a bid representing an interest cost of 2.542 per cent. The bid was 100.0032 for 6s, 3s, 2 1/2s and 2 1/4s.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Officials forecast today that the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers would meet in London soon to seek agreement on an Austrian peace treaty as a result of Russia's revision of her economic claims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The State Department will undertake the civil government of the United States occupation zone in Germany starting about July 1, it was announced today. The announcement was made by Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, in agreement with the State Department.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Large and small pancakes, bristling all over with short stiff raffia fringe, are Rose Valois innovation for the sunny days to come.

YIeaveybecame the first commodity traderto be disclosed in the City Administration when his name appearedyesterday on the list of 738 traders in futures made public by theDepartment of Agriculture in'Washington.Mayor O'Dwyer swore in the retired Army officer on Dec. 8 as a[$12,000 consulting engineerin theIDepartment of Marine and Aviation. As a colonel, he had beenNew York District Engineer of theArmy Corps of Engineers. Uponretirement he gained the higher

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- It was apparent today that the International Monetary Fund was more than a little concerned over the possibility that other members of the forty-six-nation organization might follow the pattern set by the devaluation of the franc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today a petition filed on behalf of the Postmaster General in which the ICC is asked to set aside its order of last December by which it granted railroads a temporary increase of 25 per cent in railroad mail pay rates beginning Feb. 1.

ST. MORITZ, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Bibi Torriani, famous Swiss ice hockey player and member of the Swiss Olympic team when the winter games were last held here in 1928, will take the Olympic oath at Friday's opening ceremony on behalf of the 919 athletes competing in the inter-Olympic games.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Stocks of natural alcohol throughout Cuba were frozen by Government order today in preparation for meeting the gasoline shortage, which threatens to paralyze the economic life of this island. It is estimated that 65 per cent of the trucks and automobiles are paralyzed.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 -- George P. Baker, director of the school of transportation at Harvard University, will take the chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned today, if he is permitted to augment his income with a part-time outside job.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Foreign Office published today a British note to China criticizing -- "exaggerated and misleading" reports appearing in the Chinese-language press over the recent eviction of Chinese squatters from the area of Hong Kong.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Liquidation was on in all grains on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of corn, the May delivery of which broke 9 1/2 cents from the early top before the break ended. Closing trades on corn were on a good recovery from the bottom, with losses of 1 1/8 to 4 1/4 cents.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -Elpis, William Helis' 6-year-old mare, defeated ten other eligibles for the Santa Anita Handicap today, winning the $15,000 Los Angeles Handicap by a length from the well-regarded South American,h)0*0*0*iTalon.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Dewey was assailed today in a Democratic statement as a spendthrift who had exacted unnecessary millions of dollars from the state taxpayers. The assertion provoked an immediate retort from the Governor that his accusers were "scavengers of human misery."

Immemorial custom required the Secretary of State to go out almost daily to luncheons or dinners, especially dinners. Whatever the beneficial effects of this practice, there was no doubt that it absorbed much time and more energy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The Korean People's Representative Assembly, an organization of nationalist parties in the United States zone of Korea, has urged the United Nations to go ahead with the establishment of a Korean government despite the refusal of the Soviet Union to permit elections in its sector, it was announced today.

Francis Muskavitch, 17 years old, one of two teen-age youths who pleaded guilty to killing a Bronx candy store owner during a hold-up, was sentenced yesterday to twenty-five years to life imprisonment by Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett.

Voluntary price reductions by lumber mills, if made at all, will be slight and probably temporary, Norman P. Mason, president of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, said yesterday. He stated that mounting yard inventories in the Northeastern lumber consuming areas recently has led to sparse ordering by retailers and "may" result in some mill reductions up to 15 per cent.

Besides being a great composer, Bach was one of the masters of the spiritual life. And this dual nature of his genius was underlined last night at Carnegie Recital Hall when William H. Scheide's unique Bach Aria Group, after nearly two yeears of rehearsing, appeared for the first time in New York.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor called upon Congress today to authorize President Truman to combat inflation through rationing and selective price controls on essential commodities.
The hound-stealing season seems to be approaching its peak right now, for during the past two weeks a number of owners of both foxhounds and rabbit hounds have written to report stolen dogs.
CAMBRIGE, Mass., Jan. 27 -Amateur astronomers will soon be able to see through telescopes the new Mrkos comet as it swings toward the earth.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Facing a Socialist revolt within his Cabinet against his monetary policy, notably his bill to create a free gold market, Premier Robert Schuman won a vote in the National Assembly tonight for immediate discussion of that bill.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- A lay-off for at least seven days -- the second in less than a week -- was ordered today for about 200,000 automobile and automobile parts workers in the Detroit area when the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, attempting to keep abreast of domestic consumers' demands, shut off supplies to industrial users.

Consistent advertising through daily newspapers is credited with having put Carstairs White Seal whisky at the head of its price class in the metropolitain area since introduction of the product in 1940, according to a facts folder released yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspapaper Publishers Association.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Six members of the University of Illinois physical fitness research laboratory staff will go to the Olympic games in London next summer to carry on a testing project undertaken recently at the university.

The Save the Children Federation will extend into Austria its welfare program now in operation in four other foreign countries, the board of directors announced yesterday at an annual meeting in national headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue.

Pickets were withdrawn yesterday from the 125th Street area of Harlem when merchants who are members of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce agreed to "a code of ethics" that outlawed "a two-price system" and "pulling-in" tactics to attract customers into the stores.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Amid the blaring of whistles from river craft, the steamer Kokoda pushed across the finish line at 10:05 A.M. today for an easy victory over the diesel-powered Helena in their race up the Mississippi River from New Orleans.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Chances of reform of Britain's ancient House of Lords soared high today as Government and Opposition peers agreed to consider counterproposals.

Large orders have been received from Argentina for Americanmade power machinery and equipment scheduled for use under the 5-year plan, it was announced here yesterday by Riley Williams, vicepresident of the Worthington Pump Machinery Corporation, 2 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Following Sir Stafford Cripps' statement in Parliament yesterday that the Government did not believe that any alteration in the par value of the pound would be made necessary or advisable, gold shares relapsed and British Government stocks gained at the opening of the stock markets here today.
A threatened strike of 4,000 garage workers was called off last night following an agreement between garage owners and union representatives to arbitrate all issues in dispute.

Georgie Small of Brooklyn hammered out a unanimous eightround decision over Jimmy Mangia of the East Side in the feature offering at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, before a capacity gathering of 4,000 fans last night.h) 0*0*0*iEach fighter weighed 159 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his wife were among those who attended at the White House tonight the first armed forces reception since passage of the act creating a separate Air Force and uniting it with the Army and Navy under Secretary of Defense James Forrestal.

David Van Alstyne Jr., a partner in the investment banking firm of Van Alstyne, Noel Co., said last night at his home in Englewood that he was astonished by the action of a Montreal court in setting aside the reorganization plan of the St. Lawrence group.

The motion picture industry is prepared to support the fight for democracy by promoting "freedom of action and expression throughout the world," Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said yesterday.

Developments at yesterday's luncheon of the track writers at the New York A.C. included (1) announcement of pairings for the seventy-five relay teams that will compete in the Millrose A.A. games Saturday night; (2) confirmation of line-ups for the Wanamaker Mile and other top events at the meet in Madison Square Garden; (3) a squawk by the walkers, and (4) a plea from Jim Herbert for a starting berth in the Mel Sheppard 600.

Teachers of New York City greeted with delight the resolution passed by the Board of Education at a recent meeting to the effect that "war is not inevitable." This stimulates the teachers to reinvigorate their efforts in behalf of teaching for peace and against all attempts at warmongering.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- Dr. Johannes Semmler was summarily removed as bizonal economics director today for making knowingly false statements about the bizonal economy and "malicious opposition toward the occupying powers."

The dollar value of the Gulf Oil Company offering of 2,269,050 new shares of its capital stock to stockholders was placed yesterday at $115,721,550 in an amendment to the company's registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A 36-year-old former union president was barred from further labor activities as a condition of a suspended sentence yesterday. He had pleaded guilty to obtaining a $5,000 "shakedown" to settle a strike in an upper East Side concern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman today nominated Thomas Bayard McCabe, banker and paper manufacturer, as chairmanh of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. In order to do so, he moved Chairman Marriner S. Eccles down a notch to the vice chairmanship.

The current trend toward higher interest rates will probably be accelerated by the recent action of the Federal Reserve Board to increase reserve requirements in New York and Chicago, according to Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank of New York.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 (UP) -Negotiations for peace between the Mexican League and organized baseball were halted temporarily and possibly permanently tonight as the result of a feud within the Latin circuit which led to the resignation of Commissioner Alejandro Aguilar Reyes.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Assemblyman Lewis W. Olliffe, Brooklyn Republican, proposed today that sections of the Feinberg Salary Law of 1947 pertaining to merit raises for teachers be repealed in so far as they apply to New York City.

A new gigantic calculating machine, known as the IBM Selective Sequence Electronic Calculator, was dedicated yesterday for the use of science. Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, officiated at the affair in the presence of representatives of science, education, government and business, at the company's headquarters, 590 Madison Avenue.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- Tuberculosis, venereal disease, infant and maternal mortality and malaria are held to be the priority ills of mankind by the Interim Commission of the United Nations World Health Organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman today awarded the medal for merit to James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, and three other top officials of the military establishment for their wartime service.

In a review of the nation's shipping situation, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, yesterday called the outlook for the American merchant marine "most clouded," especially with regard to passenger carrying tonnage.

Any possibility of a strike in the near future against the New York City Omnibus Corporation vanished yesterday as the company and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, agreed to a stipulation making all provisions of a future contract retroactive to Jan. 31, present expiration date.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Jan. 27 -James E. Gowen, president of the Girard Trust Company, reported at the institution's annual meeting of stockholders today that bank deposits gained $4,159,000 last year despite a reduction of $11,700,000 of Government funds on deposit.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- A bleak future for the French airplane industry was predicted here today by George Chalandon, Finance Ministry official, who deplored the quality of French material compared to American equipment.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that it would expand its office staff and facilities to make possible "the big business operation which is required" to administer the four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens.
Mr. and Mrs. Spencer H. Logan have come to the Ambassador from Great Barrington, Mass

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Seven United States Olympic skiers, led by Capt. Barney McLean of Denver, Col., were selected today by Coach Walter Prager to carry America's hopes in the downhill and slalom competition of the 1948 winter games which start here on Friday.

Miss Helen Keller, blind-deaf author and educator, will visit countries in the Near East and the Orient during a year's tour to promote education of blind children and the training of home teachers, it was announced yesterday.

Developments affecting the marketing of motion-pictures in England and Continental Europe were reviewed yesterday at a meeting of top industry executives and foreign department managers, presided over by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, 28 West Forfty-fourth Street.

" What basketball really needs," said Columbia Coach Gordon Ridings yesterday, "is a single nationwide standard for equipment and rule interpretation." This requirement takes precedence over any of the numerous changes suggested recently, in the opinion of the former Oregon star who came East fifteen years ago and last year won the Ivy League championship in his first season as varsity coach.h) 0*0*0*iO

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (UP) -- Two little-known amateurs today rose from a field of 120 golfers to knock Curtis Cup team members Miss Polly Riley and Miss Peggy Kirk from championship ranks in first-round matches of the sixteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's golf tournament

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 27 -Estimation by the United States State Department of Turkey as a "possible" cash payer under the European Recovery Program has resulted in strong criticism of the Government and has caused an anti-American reaction in the press and political circles here.

Using a Strundberg play as their source-book, Peter Goldbaum and Robin Short have drawn the portrait of a heel in "The Last Dance," which was acted at the Belasco last evening. The original Strindberg play was "Dodsdancen," which he wrote in 1901.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) -A directed verdict of acquittal in the state's first vote fraud case, growing out of the 1946 primary election here, was ordered today by Circuit Judge James W. Broaddus after arguments of the admissibility of testimony of former grand jurors as evidence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A "common ordinary working man," accompanied by his wife and two of his six children, figuratively took the Senate Banking Committee into his home today and showed the Senators where his money went.
MADRID, Jan. 27 -- Spain is not looking for financial handouts nor does she contemplate living on the fruits of others' labor, according to editorials published here today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,135, compared with 1,959 last week and 1,464 in the similar week of 1947, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 353 arrivals yesterday against 949 last Tuesday.

Coach Lou Little of Columbia indicated last night that he had not made up his mind whether or not to accept an offer to go to Yale as football coach but that he might do so if the terms were satisfactory, The United Press reported.
Your editorial "Tea Party in Reverse" thrilled us and we were pleased to read in the "Letters to THE TIMES" that all that seems to be needed is some organization to get the ball rolling.

Neighborhood volunteers are being enlisted for the first annual maintenance appeal of the Salvation Army in the Bronx. Urbain C. LeGost, assistant vice president of the Dollar Savings Bank and chairman of the Bronx Citizens Salvation Army Committee, reported yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer has taken action to have the city's attics cleaned out, and there are more than 2,000 of them. Specifically, this means he has reactivated the Municipal Archives Committee as the first step in a move to dispose of unnecessary papers and records now cramming storage places to capacity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A legislative formula calling for House and Senate action on the European Recovery Program by April 1, but cutting authorized expenditures to $5,500,000,000 in the first fifteen months, was gaining acceptance on Capitol Hill today.

Total food production losses amounting to more than $1,000,000,000 a year can be prevented and most of the present food shortages can be made up through large scale use of a new pest control chemical now available in commercial quantities, Russell B. Stoddard, an executive of U.S. Industrial Chemicals, Inc., declared here yesterday during a press luncheon at the Yale Club.

A program for stabilizing and expanding the nation's potato chip business -- which last year grossed $200,000,000 -- was outlined yesterday by Herman W. Lay of H.W. Lay Co., Atlanta, and president of the National Potato Chip Institute, in an interview preceding the eleventh annual conference and exhibit at the Hotel Commodore.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen directed the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday to regrade a written examination for police sergeant taken last April by 7,000 first grade patrolmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The fight for ownership of the oil and other mineral rights in the marginal sea, familiarly known as the tidelands, will begin all over again within a month, it was stated at the Capitol today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 Richard Quine and William Asher have signed a deal with Columbia to co-produce and co-direct "Winner Take Nothing," a film to be based on a 1946 magazine story by Richard English about prize fighting, the studio announced today.

Lubka Kolessa, who was a prodigy and then an adult celebrity in Europe, gave her first Carnegie Hall recital last night and turned out to be a pianist of uncommon personality and charm. Her playing showed that she had something of her own to say as a musician, and what she had to say was worth paying attention to.

ALAN REEVE, an English artist and journalist, and Ferdinand C. Lane, an American popularizer of geographical, geological and historical information, are the authors of two recent books which share their most prominent characteristics: mediocre to bad writing and an abundance of interesting facts. Mr. Reeve made a trip from Cairo to the Cape of Good Hope in the autumn of 1945 and winter of 1946 and has written about it in "Africa, I Presume ?"
Industry is reaching the limit of its physical capacity under existing conditions, according to the current Guaranty Survey, monthly review of business and finance of the Guaranty Trust Company.

Twenty-six Jewish leaders from many parts of the United States, who are making a four-week trip to Europe and Palestine to be able to report to their communities on rehabilitation needs, left La Guardia Field for Paris yesterday on a Trans-World Airline plane.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 -Asked for comment on inclusion of his name in the Department of Agriculture list of those who had traded on the commodity market since Jan. 1, 1946, Ambassador James Bruce said today:

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Reliable United States Olympic sources predicted tonight that a settlement will be reached in the dispute over the American hockey representative, which will permit all the other United States teams to compete in the winter Olympics which open here Friday.

Seven officials of the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce will clarify the department's new export licensing policies and answer exporters' questions at an all-day meeting to be held tomorrow in the main ballroom at the Hotel New Yorker, Joseph A. Mack, acting regional director of the New York office of the Department of Commerce, announced yesterday.

" Words to Live By," an anthology containing the favorite quotations of eighty-four eminent men and women, will be published by Simon Schuster on Feb. 23. Edited by William Nichols of This Week magazine, it gives the text and source of each quotation and the story of its influence on the individual's life.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation announced today abandonment of plans to refund $7,657,000 in bonds.
The Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries had the largest sales and earnings in its history last year, Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

The Dollar Savings Bank has leased the one-story building at 1046-48 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, from the David Rosing Company and will use it as a branch office after alterations have been completed. The lease is for twenty-one years at an aggregate rental of $273,000.
A 6,315-ton Coast Guard cutter that engaged in Arctic warfare missions in 1944 has arrived here from Boston to clear shipping channels in the ice clogged Hudson River, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--The House Ways and Means Committee approved the Knutson taxreduction bill today by straight party-line vote of 15 to 9, with one minor revision.
GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization decided today to establish a committee to hear the views of voluntary relief agencies.
Cotton future prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated in a fairly wide range yesterday and closed 20 to 35 points net higher on the day.

The curiously jumbled Mexican baseball situation appeared yesterday to be right back where it had been two years ago, following Jorge Pasquel's robust blast Monday night when the wealthy promoter from south of the border openly declared he again planned to go after the best players his pesos could entice for his Mexican League operations this year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- The longest siege of cold weather in twelve years drained fuel supplies to the danger point today, disrupting vital steel and coal production and forcing industrial shutdowns in at least five states.

Amid the chaos that envelops most of Asia, the Philippine Republic stands as an island of comparative security and order. It is with justifiable pride that President Roxas reports that state of the Philippine nation to the First Congress, which is meeting in its third session in Manila.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Blizzard-swept New Mexico counted three dead tonight in the wake of a storm which covered highways with snowdrifts, sent temperatures plummeting 25 degrees and threatened a fuel shortage in five communities.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The way Max Bentley, Toronto's hard-shooting, stickhandling star has been climbing up the hockey scoring ladder in the last few weeks, the Saskatchewan Speedster is an even-money bet to walk off with his third straight National Hockey League scoring title.

It certainly takes a heap of enthusiasm and/or courage to become involved in an offering that has been seen here on a half dozen separate occasions. And that's what David Lowe is letting himself in for. Despite those scattered presentations of "The Cradle Will Rock" over a hectic decade, Mr. Lowe will bring Marc Blitzstein's play in music into the commodious Broadway Theatre this evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman, Joseph W. Martin Jr., speaker of the House of Representatives, and Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, New Hampshire, agreed today on the widespread need for good roads in this country, and that benefits were to be derived from the improvement of highway construction machinery.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander annouriced yesterday that ail the operations of his department were to be scrutinized, beginning immediately, by a new "analysis unit" charged with the task of promoting efficiency and economy.

Weather Man Says He Sticks Out Neck With a Prediction of No Fall, Only Cold The man in the Weather Bureau predicted last night that today would be snowless, but cold. He said he was sticking his neck out, particularly since snow was headed eastward, although considerably south of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations is writing its own bill to effect the European Recovery Program, and in many important details it will not resemble the draft proposed by the State Department.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Charles (Bud) Wilkinson, youthful University of Oklahoma football mentor, got acquainted today with the Navy football scene, which might be his own stamping ground in a month or so.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 An article in the World Trade Charter that upsets membership qualifications for the proposed International Trade Organization was approved except for two paragraphs today on the second reading by the organization committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

Give a New Englander a big bowl of steaming hot chowder -oyster, clam or even vegetable -and he will be satisfied if the accompaniments are nothing more than crackers or biscuits, a green salad and a fairly substantial dessert.

In two major actions yesterday the City Council asked the State Legislature to authorize a one-year city lottery designed to produce an estimated $100,000,000 for hospital construction, and to validate the city rent control laws.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today became the "favorite son" candidate of the New Jersey Republican Committee for President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Immediate lifting of the embargo onshipments of arms 'to Palestinewas urged today in the House debate and through representationto the Secretary of State by twoNew York legislators.

Mayor O'Dwyer directed yesterday that ninety-six pages of testimony taken recently at a Welfare Department inquiry into communistic activities be fo forwarded to the House Committee on Un American Activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Administration's grain conservation program scored one victory and received several set-backs today.

Because of an "erratic" immigration policy the United States has been "derelict in its duty as a world leader," it was charged last night by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The action of the Superintendent of Schools in banning the magazine The Nation from school libraries was upheld tonight by the Board of Education.

When Capt. Ernest Pretsch of Transcontinental and Western Air checked his meteorological department a few minutes before starting to pilot a Constellation plane from Chicago to New York last night, he was advised to expect high winds aloft.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- ritish officials were stunned by the riotousreaction in Baghdad against thenew Anglo-Iraqi treaty, whichh)0*0*0*wasintended to be the first of a series of Anglo-Arab military alliancesto buttress the ' Middle Eastagainst Soviet encroachment.

The Senate has now embarked upon debate of a subject which has engendered more controversial heat, display of sectional self-interest, and contradictory supporting evidence than almost any other Congressional issue that can be recalled. President Truman, as did his predecessor, has appealed for support of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project on the grounds that it will "strengthen and expand our industry, our agriculture, our domestic commerce and our foreign trade."

Mayor O'Dwyer confirmed a report yesterday that he had directed John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, to look into the circumstances surrounding three candidates for the $9,000 post of Municipal Civil Service Commissioner.

Construction of a new one-story and basement store building at the northwest corner of Central Avenue and Halstead Street, in East Orange, N.J., is scheduled to start early in March, according to Norman Tishman, vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, owner-builder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Navy desires to keep as many combat vessels in use during the coming fiscal year as it did this year, John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, said today. The budget estimates which have gone to Congress envisage such procedure, he explained.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- United Nations backing for a "universal arms policy" setting aside the United States Government's embargo on arms shipments to the Middle East was sought by Moshe Shertok today when he presented the Zionist case for a big Jewish militia to the Palestine Commission.

" There will be no sighs of regret," you announce. Is not this a bit peremptory? If those who remember the "old pot-bellied stove," the ticket agent, and the ticket-chopper on the L station, are indeed "oldsters" -- does not that status entitle them to at least one sigh apiece at the passing of an old friend?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Navy desires to keep as many combat vessels in use during the coming fiscal year as it did this year, John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, said today. The budget estimates which have gone to Congress envisage such procedure, he explained.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- United Nations backing for a "universal arms policy" setting aside the United States Government's embargo on arms shipments to the Middle East was sought by Moshe Shertok today when he presented the Zionist case for a big Jewish militia to the Palestine Commission.

" There will be no sighs of regret," you announce. Is not this a bit peremptory? If those who remember the "old pot-bellied stove," the ticket agent, and the ticket-chopper on the L station, are indeed "oldsters" -- does not that status entitle them to at least one sigh apiece at the passing of an old friend?

Federal Judge John Bright reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss a suit for $300,000 in damages brought against Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler and four other defendants by Daniel L. Gardella, former New York Giant outfielder.
Research into problems concerning human reproduction, world poverty and overpopulation has been initiated to save "tremendous loss" in human life, it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The National Social Welfare Assembly today adopted seven reports of expert commissions in as many fields as national goals.
GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- The British and United States Governments have agreed to the transfer of the entire control of the Saar's coal production to the French Government, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Indiana and Michigan Electric Company of South Bend, Ind., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to borrow an aggregate of $6,000,000 from the Guaranty Trust Company and the Irving Trust Company, both of New York.

The Foreign Ministers' deputies who continued work on a peace settlement for Austria after the collapse of the London Conference have received new Russian proposals which appear to cut the previous Russian demands on that country by more than half. These proposals are hailed in Austria, which seeks to get rid of the Russian terror at any price, as a "great and decisive step forward."
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 27 -- There were strong indications here today that the United Nations Commission on Korea would refer the Koreanquestion to the "Little Assembly" this week.
Your editorial of Jan. 22 entitled "Impending Oil Crisis" is indicative of the growing awareness of the alarming shortage of oil and the urgent need to do something about it.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The annual legislative conference of the New York department of the American Legion urged New York today to take the lead in enacting legislation to outlaw the Communist party.

A decline in revenue to New York State of approximately 28 per cent from boxing and wrestling in 1947 was reported to Thomas J. Curran, Secreteary of State, by the State Athletic Commission in the annual report made public yesterday.

We had lunch yesterday with a man who hunts and fishes all over the world and doesn't even have to write a line about it, and now, having returned from fishing at Acapulco, Mexico, by way of Sonoro and other hunting spots, he is planning a trip to Nairobi.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- Having found German ministerial officials unable or unwilling to cope with the problem of raising production in the Russian zone, the Soviet military administration announced today in the Soviet Army newspaper, Taegliche Rundschau, that it would take over the problem.

Looking fit as the result of his intensive training with the Norwegian Olympic team, which he coached for the past few months, Reidar Andersen, one of the greatest ski jumpers the sport has known, yesterday was introduced to the press at the Stockholm Restaurant.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- The United States and British Military Governments concluded today final talks with the Germans on details of the new economic government of the bizonal area with the full expectancy that the French Government would shortly open negotiations for the merger of its zone with those of the United States and Britain.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- British Government took an unprecedented step tonight of holding a formal reception for merchandise buyers here from the United States and Canada to view dress collections of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 29 -- The Moscow radio said today that Russia had sent formal protests to the United States and Britain over American proposals to reopen the Mellaha air base, outside Tripoli in Libya. The broadcast, quoting a Tass, Soviet news agency, dispatch from New York, said Russia contended that United States operation of the airfield in the former Italian colony would contradict the terms of the Italian peace treaty.

With more freezing weather due in the East after a brief respite promised for today, the nation's longest cold wave in twelve winters brought suffering and curtailed industrial production yesterday to areas from the Canadian border to New Mexico and the Gulf States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- President Truman will make a special appeal to Congress tomorrow to keep controls on grain for whisky-making, it was reported tonight. The law expires Saturday.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 -- Russell K. Haight Jr., 25-year-old ex-GI from New York, who served for two months as a brigadier general in the Free Kashmir rebel army was to leave Karachi today by air for the United States.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 28 -- Carroll H. Smith, physical health leader, said today that there was a lack of qualified physical education teachers in schools in New York City and throughout the state because of low salaries. Mr. Smith is president of the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The median income of American families from civilian wages or salaries outside of farming in 1946 was more than double that of pre-war 1939, the Census Bureau reported today.

Sam Minskoff Sons, builders, filed plans yesterday for an eighteen - story and penthouse apartment building to occupy the site of the former Havemeyer ressidence at 1 East Sixty-sixth Street, northeast corner of Fifth Avenue. The proposed building will have about ninety apartments, a restaurant and three doctors' offices and will cost $1,465,000. Rosario Candela are the architects.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The Assembly was forced today by lack of a quorum to defer action on the Stephens bill validating New York City's emergency rent and eviction laws despite an emergency message from Governor Dewey urging immediate approval.

Ordinarily when the President announces an appointment its importance, newswise, centers on the appointee. In the nomination of Thomas B. McCabe of Philadelphia to succeed Marriner S. Eccles as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, however, this generalization does not hold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The House Republican leadership publicly cast aside today with an air of finality the universal military training plan long urged by President Truman and a bipartisan group in Congress.

A strike that would tie up wholesale and retail bakeries supplying 70 per cent of the city's baked products was set yesterday for midnight Saturday as prolonged negotiations covering 10,000 workers reached an impasse.
The crisp, clear atmosphere that enveloped New York yesterday seemingly helped produce some spirited action in the metropolitan sphere of influence in baseball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Albert Bennett-Fey, also known as A. Terry Fahye, told a House subcommittee today all about how to try to pick up steel but not how to get it, because "something always happened" and all his deals for sheet steel, "fishtails" and "coil ends" fell through.

For the third successive week the nation's crude oil production has reached new high levels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Daily average gross production last week averaged 5,336,287 barrels daily, an increase of 10,150 over the 5,326,137 in the previous week.

The 15 per cent limitation on tax-deductible contributions to charity for the individual and the 5 per cent limitation on corporations should be abolished or drastically revised upward, J.K. Lasser, tax authority, told sixty leaders of welfare organizations yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Golden Rule Foundation at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- If the European Recovery Program is adopted it will bring about a "severe shortage" of construction equipment and cause at least a year's lag in road building throughout the country, George L. Bell, associate director of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce, forecast today.

Although dry cargo shipments moving through Pacific coast ports of the United States in 1947 showed an increase of 43 per cent over 1946 totals, they were 25.6 per cent below the volume registered in 1939, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Party lines were tightened at mass meetings today as the legislative formalities were completed for the opening of House debate tomorrow on tax reduction. Rallies of House Democrats and Republicans, held in quick succession behind closed doors, each ended with the opposing party leaders reporting near-unanimity in his ranks on what shaped up as an election-year issue of the greatest importance.

The scheduled sale on Feb. 2 of $6,000,000 of bonds of the Tampa Electric Company will demonstrate a competitive-bidding transaction in which the issuing company has invited three bidding managers to participate. Last year Tampa Electric, which is under no compulsion to sell securities by the sealed-bid-and-deadline procedure, solicited marketing "opinions" from five underwriting establishments before selling its security issue.
The editorial "Alcoholism Survey," which appeared in THE TIMES of Jan. 18, serves further to focus attention on the seriousness of what generally is termed the alcohol problem.
San Antonio, Tex., announced yesterday that it would take bids on Feb. 12 on $6,000,000 of sewer bonds dated. Feb. 15, 1948, and due from 1949 to 1968.

The fifteen two-story houses and four one-story dwellings, containing a total of thirty-eight apartments, at 5501-17 Ocean Promenade, Edgemere, Queens, have been sold by Sarah and Kalman F. Rosenbluth to the Sadowsky Realty Corporation.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Dr. Albert M. Harris, 35 years old, who developed a test for discovering cancer, died of the disease today without knowing that his own body had given a positive reaction to the test.

The need for increased effort to control employe health conditions was a main topic of discussion at the annual managers' meeting of Federated Metals Division, American Smelting and Refining Company, which closed yesterday after a three-day session at the Ambassador Hotel in New York, company officials disclosed in a statement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A legal obstacle to the holding of two jobs caused George P. Baker, director of the School of Transportation of the Harvard University Business School, to refuse today to accept the chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board.
Dr. Abraham Stone, president of the American Association of Marriage Counselors, said yesterday he was amazed how little "sophisticated people" knew of the facts of life.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Following is the text of a French memorandum to the British and United States Governments on the proposed organization of their zones in Germany:

Two Bronx boys were killed yesterday afternoon when the sled on which they were riding down the steep grade of Teller Avenue north of East 167th Street crashed into a street car at the foot of the grade.
Dr. Donald B. Tresidder, president of Leland Stanford University at Palo Alto, Calif., was found dead last night in his suite at the Hotel St. Regis. His age was 53.

The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee has approved the Tobey joint resolution (S. J./Res. 173), which would extend the authority of the Maritime Commission to sell, charter and operate vessels to July 1, 1949, but has ordered written into it a provision that conflicts directly with the ship transfer feature of the Marshall Plan, it was learned yesterday.

Win in the city, to most people, is something to be tolerated, battled or avoided. New Yorkers are more interested in its velocity than in its direction, because the barriers they have erected against its course across this island cause winds to wander puckishly and perversely in several directions at once, including the vertical.
Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared last night that the hope for world peace and security depended upon the children of Europe.

A regimen of self-imposed economic austerity aimed at curbing purchasing power was urged yesterday by Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing, Columbia University, and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, to stem the current wave of inflation, which, he warned, "will carry this nation to disaster" unless stopped.

A survey made public here yesterday by the Air Transport Association and the Port of New York Authority shows that most airline passengers here travel to and from Manhattan and that most of them leave or return to their own homes rather than offices or hotels.
Tenants of four houses at 15 to 21 West Eighty-fourth Street opened yesterday a fight to keep their landlord from evicting them to make way for a new $1,000,000 apartment structure on the site.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- The "hunger strikes" by German workers in the last two weeks are healthy manifestations of the impatience of German labor with the failure of its own food officials and German farmers, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Pravda, official newspaper of the Communist party in the Soviet Union, today flatly opposed any movement toward an Eastern European confederation of Russia's satellite states, and revealed a considerable cleavage of opinion in the hitherto monolithic Communist front.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The British-Italian economic and financial talks, which have been going on here since Jan. 12, closed tonight without the British being able to persuade the Italians to abandon their dual rate for the lira.

PRAGUE, Jan. 28 -- Czechoslovakia's resistance to Mr. Dimitrov's desire for a defensive alliance against all possible "aggressors" and to his confederation schemes is felt here to have been underwritten by Pravda's rebuke to the Bulgarian Premier.

A "Telephone Numbers Game," a quiz which will have as its aim the distribution of dollar bills, is scheduled for debut on WOR Monday night at 10 o'clock. Listeners will be requested to write down their telephone numbers or the last five numerals of their social security numbers, after which an announcer will make a statement and instruct participants to encircle a given number if the statement is correct, a second given number if false.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 28 -- Maurice Pate, executive director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, stated today that he had found nowhere in his European inspection tours any evidence of discrimination in the use of the organization's supplies.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Bills paving the way for restoration of the old Aquarium in Battery Park, New York, and its maintenance as a national monument were introduced in the Senate and Assembly today at the request of Mayor William O'Dwyer and the New York City Administration.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Britain's Trades Union Congress took action today to force a show-down on the European Recovery Program in the World Federation of Trade Unions. By so doing the TUC is defying the Soviet bloc, which thus far has succeeded in preventing the WFTU from taking a stand or even calling a scheduled conference in Paris in February.

Gross revenues of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., rose to a new high of $64,958,405 in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 1, 1947, increasing $11,023,540 over the $53,934,865 shown in the previous year, according to the annual statement issued yesterday.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Six Negroes today applied for admission to four different schools at the University of Oklahoma in a renewed effort to break down the state's racial segregation in education.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Bills increasing from $3,000 to $5,000 the size of life insurance policies that may be issued by savings banks were introduced today by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens of Brewster and Senator Paul A. Fino of the Bronx, both Republicans.

Operations of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation for the three months ended on Dec. 31, first quarter of its fiscal year, resulted in a net profit after taxes of $5,640,974, according to a report issued yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 28 -- The Vatican radio said in a broadcast today that Russia had resumed violent religious persecution in eastern Poland, which had been halted in 1942, and that the aim of the new anti-religious drive was to force 6,000,000 Catholics to join the Russian Orthodox Church, which is controlled by the Kremlin.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 25 (Delayed) -- No major battles have taken place in Manchuria in the last two weeks. Communist troops have continued to attack isolated points in limited strength but the main forces have been relatively inactive.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28 -- The Government-appointed boss of one of Argentina's six national universities today used the Government's subsecretariat of information to circulate an open letter that has been printed so far only in the semi - official Government daily Epoca to declare that the Argentine universities are free from Government interference.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The New York Rangers took undisputed third place in the National Hockey League standings before 16,171 fans tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2. The Blue Shirts had been tied for the position with the Boston Bruins, who lost to Detroit, 4 -- 2.

The New York-New Jersey Conference for Toll Reduction asked the Port of New York Authority yesterday to reduce toll charges on bridges and tunnels under its jurisdiction. The request was in the form of a resolution adopted at a meeting in the Automobile Club of New York, 28 East Seventy-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Economists and the head of a large city called upon Congress today to take prompt and effective measures to fight inflation. An industry spokesman maintained that inflation was being nutured by the "constant Washington bludgeoning of the manufacturing industry with accusations, criticisms and threats."

Sloane-Blabon, Inc., has notified its distributors of a 3 per cent price increase on standard gauge inlaid linoleum, Wilbur Newman, vice president, disclosed yesterday. He also stated that some small zonal price adjustments are being made in felt base rugs with the maximum increase set at 1 1/2 per cent.

"A Woman's Vengeance," which arrives at the Winter Garden, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Charles Boyer, Jessica Tandy and Ann Blyth head the cast of the romantic drama which was produced and directed by Zoltan Korda from the screen play by Aldous Huxley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Mr. Clark's action appeared likely to soften substantially Congressional pressure for an export embargo. Even before it came, some influential House Republicans who have been active on the issue were retreating from a total embargo.

Defending the work of his department, William J. Powell, sanitation commissioner, asked Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday for $58,278,683 for operations during the 1948-49 fiscal year. If granted, the department would get an increase of $11,056,949 over its present budget.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- The Villanova basketball team routed Army in the Field House today, 84 to 50. At no time after the first five minutes of play was the outcome in doubt as the Wildcats poured it on the cadets.

Negro firemen now employed on Southern railroads will accept no compromise with the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen short of full union membership, A. Philip Randolph, chairman of the Provisional Committee to Organize Colored Locomotive Firemen, announced yesterday.

I have read with the utmost dismay recent reports published in THE NEW YORK TIMES and elsewhere regarding the condition of the Schomburg Col lection of the New York Public Library and the impending resignation of Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick from his position as director there.

WARSAW, Jan. 28 -- In an effort to build up reserves to provide the Government with bank credits, a bill was introduced in the Sejm [Parliament] today to make bank savings compulsory for all Poles with incomes of more than $600 a year. The bill will become law tomorrow.

Within the next three years scientists should have enough basic knowledge of man-made rain and snow to be able to divert large snow or rain storms from big centers of population to relatively isolated areas, Dr. Irving Langmuir, associate director of the General Electric Research Laboratory, said yesterday.

Avon Estates, Inc., bought for investment from the Clinton Trading Company the five-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 38 Gramercy Park, corner of Twenty-first Street, in a transaction reported yesterday by H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc., broker.
A "Cat Plan" to augment the Marshall Plan, by sending American cats to keep rats from pilfering European food reserves, was proposed yesterday by the American Feline Society.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 28 -- The widespread "spiritual vacuum" in American society today is "the fruit of an educational policy which for thirty years has ignored God," the Rev. Dr. Morris Wee of Chicago, executive secretary of the Student Service Commission of the National Lutheran Council, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- After first refusing, Isadore Ginsberg of New York agreed today to give a Congressional committee confidentially the names of dealers he has bought gypsum from.
A drive for members by the Merchant Marine Veterans of America, Inc., was announced here yesterday by Frank E. Rack, port director of the New York State Anchorage of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Department of State has lost its fight for control over many aspects of the European Recovery Administration in Washington and unless it strengthens its embassies in the Marshall Plan countries the guess here is that it will lose considerable prestige there as well.

Start of a five-year experiment that may change the whole course of treatment for persons with infantile paralysis and other disabling diseases was announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, which will end its annual March of Dimes campaign tomorrow.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 -- While the British took sudden steps today to tighten the frontier so as to reduce Arab infiltration into Palestine, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver asserted that without an international force in Palestine the whole possibility of a Jewish state was jeopardized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered today the first collective bargaining election among lawyers. It will poll ten or eleven lawyers employed by American Lumbermen's Casualty Company of Illinois at its New York office (342 Madison Avenue) to determine whether they wish to be represented by the Independent Insurance and Banking Employees Union.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- As usual, Joe McCarthy had little to say today when introduced formally as new manager of the Red Sox, but did relax long enough to promise: "I'll do the best I can and give all I've got."

May I request space in your columns to comment upon the letter in your issue of Jan. 21, written by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, as to the position of American Jews and their attitude "toward this newly to be created state."
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A Coast Guard icebreaker cut into the Port of Albany tonight, leading a ship loaded with fuel oil for this frigid city.

FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A chartered Immigration Service plane crashed and burned in western Fresno County this morning, killing twenty-eight Mexican deportees, the crew of three and an immigration guard.

Terming the record snowstorm of Dec. 26 "an act of God," the Long Island Rail Road issued yesterday in City Court, Jamaica, Queens, a general denial to a commuter's recent suit against it for $2,000 damages. The commuter contended that he had been "wrongfully imprisoned" on a snowbound train.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Charges that the Lobbying Act of 1946, as now interpreted by the Department of Justice, violates fundamental civil rights, were made by the National Association of Manufacturers in a plea for an injunction filed in the Federal District Court today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 28 -- Funeral services in Ankara today for Gen. Kiazim Karabekir. President of the Turkish Grand National Assembly, who died two days ago of a heart attack at the age of 65, provided still another occasion for Turkey to proclaim her determination to resist any possible aggression from Russia.
Members of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade yesterday strongly urged the use of normal trade channels in the functioning of the Marshall Plan.

AS I entered the State Department our Government was already preparing for the Economic Conference to be held in London. The preparatory meetings under the auspices of the League of Nations had been held at Geneva, and an elaborate agenda drawn up.
A bill authorizing the creation of a board to guard against pollution of state waterways will be introduced in the Legislature soon, it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The United States has been pouring oil abroad into foreign export channels at the annual rate of nearly 150,000,000 barrels, despite a growing domestic shortage.

PARIS, Thursday, Jan. 29 -- Withdrawal from circulation of all 5,000-franc bank notes and the closing of banks throughout France until Saturday were announced early today in a statement issued by the Ministry of Finance.
An appeal for the planting of trees was made yesterday by Miss Dorothy H. Jenkins, garden editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address at Times Hall, 240 West 43d Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 28 -- The twenty-four man executive board of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, AFL, today called upon Henry Wallace, "in the interest of liberalism," to withdraw his candidacy for President "so there will be no division of "progressive forces in 1948."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall declared today that no consideration was being given at present to a relaxation of the American embargo against the shipment of terms aug ammunition to Palestine.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- The competence of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment to decide the status of Germany and Japan in the proposed International Trade Organization was questioned again today by Czechoslovak and Polish delegates.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The British Amateur Athletic Board declared war today on the newly established Olympic committee of Eire over which country will get the services of athletes from the six counties of Northern Ireland.

The Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association yesterday unanimously adopted a resolution urging that exportation of lumber under the Marshall Plan be "carefully considered and controlled so as not to unnecessarily impair the supply of lumber needed in this country."
An exhibit that will feature a reproduction of an Eighteenth-century southern New England "Main Street," is now under construction on the east balcony in Grand Central Terminal.

Foreign capital investment in Argentina is turning to Africa as a result of the Peron government restrictions, Joshua B. Powers, president of the Export Advertising Club, declared yesterday. Not only is Argentina losing dollars which she needs sorely, he said, but this money is being used to deprive her of future markets.

In belatedly announcing the full list of their selections in the National Football League's college player draft, the New York Giants yesterday revealed that they had their eyes on Bruce Gehrke, rugged Columbia end. Gehrke's All-America wingmate, Bill Swiacki, already has signed with the Giants for 1948.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority said yesterday in its report for 1947 that traffic on its five bridges and the Queens Midtown Tunnel was the heaviest in the authority's history. Revenues from all facilities amounted to $11,869,870, and the traffic was at a peak of 58,908,684 vehicles.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 -- The American Federation of Labor expressed the hope today that the newly formed Inter-American Confederation of Labor would develop into a world labor organization to fight the spread of communism and fascism.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- To save dollars the Ministry of Defense ordered a sharp cut today in the rations of the British armed forces serving at home, a cut that will bring their diet down to the approximate level of "intermediate" civilian workers.

Guy W. Vaughan, president of Curtiss-Wright Corporation, declared yesterday that some aircraft companies never would get from under the load of bank loans they were forced to make last year because of lack of military and transport business and increased costs on such production and development orders as they took to keep plants busy.

Emetia (Joe Pledge) Polizio, 46-year-old gambler, who touched off last summer's investigation of police protection of bookmakers, was sentenced yesterday in Queens County Court to six months in the city penitentiary. He was found guilty by a jury on Jan. 7 of bookmaking.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company, after more than three months of wrangling with the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today that it would amend its material for a pending proxy solicitation which the commission has described as "inadequate."

Formation of a National Wallace for President Committee with New York headquarters in the McAlpin Hotel and with Elmer A. Benson, former Farmer-Labor party Governor of Minnesota as chairman, was announced yesterday by Henry A. Wallace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 21:

Support of British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin's league of Western nations against "the communism of the East" was advocated yesterday by James W. Gerard, Ambassador to Germany in World War I, at the annual meeting of the Pilgrims of the United States in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Running one-fifth of a second faster than the classy Cosmic Missile in last year's inaugural edition, A.C. Ernst's Alfoxie easily captured today's $10,000 added Jasmine Stakes in 1:10-3/5 for six furlongs at Hialeah Park.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- France's recent objections to the pattern of organization of the proposed new Bizonal Economic Administration in Germany, contained in a memorandum to the United States and British Governments, were made available today.

IN "Our Own Baedeker"* Russell Maloney and -- Eugene Kinkead have gathered their mildly cockeyed historical and geographical pieces from The New Yorker together to make a useful and entertaining book. It is illustrated magnificently with maps and pictures by Carl Rose, and introduced in a singularly scholarly and irresponsible manner by Geoffrey Hellman.

The City Council usually contents itself with proposing city expenditure of money and then neatly bows out when the question arises of how the money shall be raised. But now, in a vote of thirteen to four, it has brought forth the idea of a city-conducted lottery to raise $100,000,000 in one year for city hospital construction.

A block of 1,213,443 shares of newly issued capital stock of the Gulf Oil Corporation having a market value of $71,594,137 was marketed in less than thirty minutes yesterday at $59 a share by a nation-wide network of securities houses which included 207 underwriters and 550 dealers.

VIENNA, Jan. 28 -- After sternly warning the conference of provincial governors that those provinces which fell behind in food collections from their own farmers would receive proportionately less imported American food, the Austrian Government today raised the food ration of normal consumers from 1,700 to 1,800 calories.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- After the Socialist rebellion against the Government's financial policies had crystallized into declared opposition, Premier Robert Schuman said tonight that he would ask the Cabinet at a special meeting tomorrow to decide whether to demand a vote of confidence from the National Assembly on this issue.
John Guter has been appointed sales manager of the Armstrong Food Company, division of the Borden Company, producing dog food.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Oils were the liveliest group in the stock markets here today as the French political crisis over the devaluation of the franc checked speculative activity in gold shares.

Eighty-nine colts and a quartet of fillies, representing racing folk in fifteen states and Canada, have been named for this year's eightieth running of the $100,000 added Belmont Stakes, it was announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association.
