CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Richard J. Finnegan, editor of The Chicago Sun and The Daily Times, announced today that the two papers would merge, effective Monday. The new publication will be known as The Chicago Daily Sun and Times.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 -- A wage inrease program will be set up by leaders of the United Steel Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, at a three-day meeting here opening Feb. 16, the union announced today.

First details of a new five-point industry-wide purchasing advisory program in the soap and glycerine field were outlined here yesterday by Eugene A. Moss, vice president of Swift Co., Chicago, during the annual convention of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 28 -- Former Premier Saleh Jabr fled in disguise by air to Trans-Jordan today, escaping possible reprisals from countrymen angered by an alliance he signed with Britain that failed to realize "the national aims of Iraq."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A minimum billion dollar cut in President Truman's $6,800,000,000 request for starting the Marshall Plan appeared certain today after Harriman Committee spokesmen labeled "excessive" the Administration's allowance of $2,300,000,000 as a margin above actual disbursements in fiscal 1949.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Paced by defenseman Jimmy Thomson, the Toronto Maple Leafs scored two goals in the last period tonight to tie Montreal's Canadiens, 3 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before 13,993 fans. The result left the Leafs in second place and the Canadiens fifth in the standings.
Although strike activity in New York State in 1947 was less than half the record volume of 1946, the State Board of Mediation was busier than ever in averting strikes, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The National Commission on Youth, looking toward a fifth decennial White House Conference on Children to be held in 1950, today tallied losses and gains in the child welfare field thus far in this decade.

To maintain a position of liquidity, woolen wholesalers should be willing to yield part of their profit, and sometimes profit itself, it was declared last night by Hyman Weinstein, president of the Woolen Wholesalers National Association, at a meeting of that organization in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Assuming that advertising by American manufacturers in France will be treated in the same way as exports, advertising appropriations in dollars now will buy more than twice the space in French publications, according to Dr. Francis Elvinger, yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 -- An all-out effort among its 365,000 employes, 15,000 dealers and all plants to increase the flow of scrap iron and steel into the steel mills was begun today by General Motors Corporation to maintain production and employment this year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- United Nations journalistic experts agreed today that freedom of the press must be restricted by matters "which must remain secret in the vital interest of the state" or which may incite persons to attempts against governments by revolution.
William M. Paris, president of the Fleischmann Malting Company, was elected yesterday a director of the parent company, Standard Brands, Inc. He has been with the subsidiary since 1912.

The vacant plot, about 100 by 249 feet, at 8200 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Thomas G. Grace to Max Bauer. The parcel is assessed at $21,000. Slomka Brothers and Sam Abrams, Inc., were the brokers in the transaction.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert was elected one year ago yesterday as the Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, succeeding the Right Rev. William T. Manning, who had retired twenty-eight days before after an active episcopate of twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of State Marshall gave out today a summary of a preliminary analysis of the proposals made in London early this week by the Soviet Government on German assets. As a result of these proposals the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers may be convened in a new effort to conclude an Austrian peace treaty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A brief but exhaustive inquiry by a special House subcommittee today into purchase of explosives from the War Assets Corporation for shipment to Palestine left inquirers apparently convinced that the sales represented no illegal acts.

Ernest Martin Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College from 1916-1945, was elected yesterday president of the National Life Insurance Company of Montpelier, Vermont. He succeeds Elbert S. Brigham who, a year ago, announced his intention to retire at this time after being president of the company since 1937.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Contending that the political organs of the United Nations, with their nationalistic debates, have rarely succeeded in peace-making, the delegation of Lebanon today proposed to the Little Assembly that a nine-man permanent committee of conciliation be created, in which all disputes between Governments might be solved in a nonpolitical atmosphere.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Eddie Bush of Wilmington, Del., staged a major upset in the second round of match play of the Helen Lee Doherty Women's Golf Tournament today by defeating favored Miss Margaret Gunther of Memphis, Tenn., 1 up.

"The Ides of March," the first novel in twelve years by Thornton Wilder, will be brought out by Harper on Feb. 18. Mr. Wilder, twice winner of the Pulitzer Prize, has centered his story around the eight months preceding Caesar's assassination in 44 B.C.
With the four seeded players drawing byes, eleven first-round matches in the Metropolitan Class A singles squash racquets were run off at the University Club yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Grain markets closed higher generally on the Board of Trade today after fluctuating nervously within a range of 5 cents a bushel on wheat and corn.

ST LOUIS, Jan. 28 -- The purchase of the Government-owned Mississippi River unit of the Federal Barge Lines at a suggested price of $6,400,000 was tentatively proposed yesterday by a group of business men from thirteen Midwestern cities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- A special United Nations committee, created by the Economic and Social Council to consider the need for an economic commission for Latin America, completed its work today with unanimous approval of a report recommending immediate establislnnent of such a commission.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- In the last few months British woolen manufacturers have produced some of the lightest-weight worsted woolen and tropical suitings that have yet been made. In Norman Hartnell's collection, shown here today, these new fabrics in small dogtooth checks and chalk stripes were dramatized by original panel treatment.

From Washington comes news that the State Department will definitely take over the administration of the American occupation zone in Germany about July 1. This in no sense signalizes the approaching end of the occupation, or even preparations for it. On the contrary, as the announcement says, "the military duties of occupation will, of course, still be performed by the Army."

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Powdered milk rushed to France as part of the interim emergency aid will not be distributed until April, it has been learned from official sources. It was explained that France can supply her own milk needs until that time.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Charges of State Department collusion in a British plot to destroy the possibility of implementing the partition of Palestine were made by the Nation Associates in i a letter to President Truman, a copy of which was sent to every member of the United Nations Palestine Commission today.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- Although Japanese industry generally remains in the doldrums, and the Government's financial difficulties promise little save fresh complications, there are a number of developments in the occupation policy concerning Japan that justify continued optimism in the stock markets.

MANILA, Jan. 28 -- President Manuel A. Roxas announced today that he had signed a proclamation granting amnesty to all Filipino citizens accused of treason for alleged political collaboration or for having traded with the enemy during World War II.

DURHAM, N.H., Jan. 28 -- Harold E. Stassen declared his readiness today to debate presidential campaign issues with Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York, "anywhere and at any time, under impartial auspices."

A liberal use of white straws, small high-crowned sailors, bretons that featured side width and interesting treatments of tulle and veiling distinguished the Milgrim spring collection of custom-made millinery seen yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Resales of two of the former Hoboken Land and Improvement Company's industrial properties in Hoboken, N.J., are reported by J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Politicians in both major parties, and doubtless those few who are in charge of strategy for Henry A. Wallace, are now definitely interested in Harold E. Stassen. The questions they are asking are -- What does he hope to achieve, and what does he expect to achieve?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire criticized today President Truman's demotion of Marriner S. Eccles from the chairmanship of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System and asserted his intention of finding out "who the forces were who went to the President and objected to Mr. Eccles and were successful in getting him removed."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, today issued a complaint against General Motors Corporation asserting that by refusing to carry out its promise to bargain with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, on an insurance plan, it had violated the law and was guilty of an unfair labor practice.

The stock market scored yesterday its second advance in successive days, an accomplishment seldom recorded this month. The gain was greater than on Monday and carried prices up fractions to as much as 2 points. The combined averages rose 0.62.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- To say that the revived $500,000,000 Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaway and power project would be self-liquidating was "illusory," Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts told the Senate today.

In 1903, his Doctor of Philosophy degree from the University of Koenigsberg, Germany, only a few months old, Dr. Alexander Marx came to the youthful Jewish Theological Seminary here to head its small library and teach Jewish history.

WASHINGTON, Jan., 28 -- Organized labor apparently is not disposed to "gang up" on Senator Robert A. Taft in his contest with Harold E. Stassen for Ohio delegates to the Republican National Convention, inquiries indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Truman acted today to build up the high command of the air force by sending to the Senate nominations of seventy-two officers to be permanent major and brigadier generals. On the list were also thirty-one nominations for temporary grades of major general.

Pakistan and India having been unable to agree on a solution of the Kashmir question, the United Nations Security Council again has been forced to resume direct consideration of the matter and will have to make the decision. That seems to be the one thing on which the two British Dominions can agree.

Like a football coach briefing his star quarterback on the eve of the big game, Emil Von Elling, New York University's veteran track mentor, yesterday took aside Reggie Pearman for a "skull session" on the peculiar technique involved in indoor running.

The former Bedell Building, a thirteen-story store and office structure at 17-19 West Thirty-fourth Street, through to 26-32 West Thirty-fifth Street, opposite the Empire State Building, has been sold by the Bearchie Corporation to the Lerner Stores, who occupy the store, basement and second floor on a long-term lease.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Dr. David S. Rhone, Director of Public Safety, and six other present or former city officials were indicted today by a Camden County grand jury on charges of misconduct in office.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 28 (AP) -- George Sauer, 37-year-old Kansas football mentor, headed for home tonight after doing "a lot of listening and talking" about a coaching post at the naval academy.

One American worker who hasn't improved his position during the past seven years is the college professor, who works longer hours, teaches more students and gets less real purchasing power than he did in 1940. These facts are taken from the fourth report of the President's Commission on Higher Education, made public this week.

ATHENS, Jan. 28 -- Reports from Florina said that Team 2 of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, which is stationed there, hastened to the scene of a battle a few miles to the north in a border region yesterday. The reports declared that a strong rebel force had attacked a small army garrison at the village of Aghia Paraskevi and that the foray "obviously" had been launched from Yugoslav territory.

Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, gave his annual recital last night at Carnegie Hall. For this appearance, his twenty-fifth in the auditorium, he had prepared a schedule composed of Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 31, No. 3; Schumann's "Carnaval," a Chopin group, items by Rachmaninoff and Prokofieff and Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsody," No. 8.

Christopher Maikisch, 40 years old, who had spurned an opportunity to plead guilty to second-degree murder prior to going on trial earlier this month, received yesterday a mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair for slaying a man who had taunted him about his pet dog.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The petroleum industry, acting swiftly on the heels of Justice Department approval, ordered into effect today a sixty-day cutback in gasoline production and other conservation measures to meet the critical fuel oil shortage.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Herbert V. Bousquet, a Sing Sing Prison guard for the last twelve years, has been supplementing his salary by smuggling money to convicts for a fee of 20 per cent, according to charges filed here today.

The bewilderingly sudden shift of state Democratic strategy that now pictures Governor Dewey as a "spendthrift" instead of a "miser" has at least the virtue of novelty, which is certainly rare enough in politics. Only a few weeks ago the Democratic State Chairman, Mr. Fitzpatrick, far from urging economy, was suggesting that the state's "$70,000,000 surplus" be used to aid cities and towns that were hard pressed.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi protested yesterday on "arbitrary" cut of $1,250,000 by the Federal Security Administration on Tuesday in the original budget of $6,500,000 alloted to New York State for administration of unemployment insurance in the first six months of this year.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The United States ski team got an encouraging break in the draw for starting positions in the Olympic Games, eighteen-kilometer (11.2 miles) cross-country race today, even though another two-foot snow fall prevented badly needed practice sessions for the American athletes.

NANKING, Jan. 28 -- A dearth of advisers to supervise the detailed aspects of Washington's projected Chinese aid program was listed here today by an authoritative source as a leading factor in having delayed the State Department's presentation of the program to Congress.

THE road to London is a long one. It stretches out for 3,000 miles in distance and for six months in time. It's a road that's strewn with pitfalls which don't include the watery ones marking its length. This road leads from the United States to the Olympic Games and practically every competitor in the Millrose meet at the Garden on Saturday hopes fervently that his feet are planted firmly upon it.

George Abbott's new musical entry, "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'!", bows at the Adelphi Theatre tonight at 8:30. A parody of the ballet business, the show stars Nancy Walker, cast in the role of a beer baron's daughter who backs a ballet company so she can dance in the ensemble.

GENEVA. Jan. 28 -- Considerable improvement in the European timber supply outlook was reported by Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, at today's opening meeting of the commission's timber subcommittee.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and ended mixed, 19 points higher to 2 points lower.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The high-flying Detroit Red Wings gained a firmer grip on their National Hockey League lead by topping the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, tonight before 13,900 fans at the Garden. The fourth Detroit goal, made by Ted Lindsay, came after the Bruins had removed Goalie Frankie Brimsek during the last minute of play.

Unless your housekeeping habits are as methodical as an electric clock, you may, like many another, find yourself cutting out recipes for future reference, only to lose them among the pages of a cook book or in the welter of a kitchen drawer.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Swiss defied the authority of the International Olympic Executive Committee tonight by refusing to obey an order throwing both disputed United States hockey teams out of the winter games starting Friday.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday for 1947 a net income of $2,306,082, including a credit adjustment in taxes of $7,350,156, equal to 36 cents a share on the road's capital stock. This contrasts with a net deficit in 1946 of $10,449,268 after a carryback tax credit of $21,142,300.

It is a toss-up whether the fact that the Knickerbockers scored their first victory at home since Christmas night, thereby tying for the lead in the Basketball Association of America's eastern division, was more notable than that the New Yorkers almost succeeded in blowing a close decision to cellar-dwelling Providence last night.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- If the Arab Legion, Trans-Jordan's national army, should launch an aggressive attack against the proposed Jewish state in Palestine after the departure of the British forces, the legion's annual subsidy of about 2,000,000 from the British Treasury will be withdrawn, a British Government spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Librarians and rural Sociologists from forty states today discussed the value of collaboration between librarians and sociologists in seeking a scientific approach to good rural library service. The discussion took place during a workshop sponsored by the joint committee of the American Library Association and the Rural Sociological Society preceding the opening here tomorrow of the American Library Association's midwinter meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28, (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today industrial production declined slightly in December from the post-war record of the previous month.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Alejandro Aguilar Reyes announced tonight that Jorge Pasquel had asked him to remain as commissioner of the Mexican Baseball League Aguilar said Pasquel had made the request in a telegram from Montreal tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The United Kingdom backed Pakistan's plea today to give priority in the United Nations Security Council to debate on organizing a plebiscite in the Princely State of Kashmir.

ROME, Jan. 28 -- The Pope today received Don Juan of Bourbon, pretender to the Spanish throne, with whom, according to Vatican circles, he discussed the situation in Spain. Although Don Juan arrived at the Vatican accompanied by a private secretary and some members of the Spanish nobility, the Pontiff spoke only to him.

ST. MORITZ, Jan. 29 (UP) -- As snow fell on this picturesque little valley town in the Swiss Alps, both the local citizenry and the athletes of twenty-seven nations were disturbed and annoyed tonight by the chaotic state of affairs on the eve of the opening of the fifth winter Olympic games.

The reactions of teacher and civic groups which have been campaigning for increased state aid to education were unanimously unfavorable yesterday to the report of Governor Dewey's special committee on education.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee tonight announced that four "regulars" of the United States military ski team would represent America in the Winter Olympics military ski event to be held Sunday, Feb. 8.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- The technique of the film forum, whose use in libraries the American Library Association is encouraging, was demonstrated tonight before 600 delegates representing 16,000 libraries at the A.L.A.'s winter meeting here.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- The entire economic system of this country would collapse if people stopped risking their capital, Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Ex change, declared today in denouncing "ignorant or hypocritical" persons who give the word "speculation" the connotation of evil.

The houses we live in today reflect old ideas, out-dated theories and horse-and-buggy notions about domestic needs and efficiency, according to a study released yesterday by the Woman's Foundation, Inc. Unless an acceptable solution to the housing question is reached, the report concludes, the other remedies advanced to solve family problems such as divorce and juvenile delinquency hardly can be put into effect.

Purchases of United States Government bonds by the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Jan. 28 amounted to $808,433,000, the greatest figure since the report of $1,143,000,000 on Dec. 31, financial observers noted yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 29 -- The Swedish Government has agreed to give 1,500,000 [about $6,000,000] to the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization for aid in the resettlement of victims of Nazi persecution, it was announced here today.

MUKDEN, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -Central Government military and political leaders are fighting a losing economic battle against the Communists in Manchuria. The outcome will be a major factor in determining whether the Nationalists can maintain themselves in China's northeast.

A new quonset hut campus was started yesterday at the downtown building of St. John's University at 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, as veteran students from its School of Commerce started their second semester in a quonset hut classroom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Highway perils created by about 200,000 "gypsy" truck operators through the employment of over-tired drivers and under-inspected vehicles were described today by W. Y. Slanning, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Motor Carriers.
Two police captains in charge of strategic precincts lost their commands and eleven other captains were shifted yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Making his first appearance in the tournament, Richard S. Rothschild of the Downtown A. C., defending titleholder, won a difficult second-round match in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Class A championship at the University Club yesterday.

America's alley cats should not be shipped abroad to combat rats in European countries because they would not get enough to eat, Sydney H. Coleman, executive vice president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, declared yesterday at his office, 50 Madison Avenue.

Piano playing of remarkable sensitivity was displayed by Anita Weinberg in Times Hall last night. Capable of adapting her dynamic range and even her tone quality to the music at hand, she played works of Scarlatti, Beethoven and Mendelssohn with faithfulness to the individual styles and expression.

The first crack in the seemingly monolithic Russo-Communist bloc in Eastern Europe appears to have been opened by differences of opinion between Soviet Russia and Czechoslovakia on the one hand, and Bulgaria and Yugoslavia on the other.

A large Westchester County business property has changed hands with the sale by the Westchester Lighting Company of the one-story taxpayer and two-story office and display building at 291-303 Main Street and 1 to 13 North Broadway, in White Plains.

Adoption of a new code of standards of practice in handling art work, which constitutes extensive revision of previous standards and includes regulations governing business deals with photographers; was announced yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Seven of the eleven members of the United Nations Security Council lined up today behind a move for a plebiscite in Kashmir and brought a quick complaint from India that she was being "brushed aside."

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 29 -Maine Republican voters were assured today by Harold E. Stassen that he would not rend the party to gain the Presidential nomination. Coming to the Pine Tree State for the last two days of a New England tour, the former Governor of Minnesota added, however, that neither would he yield to reactionary or isolationist elements within the party.

The man in the street may well be confused just now as to how much the European Recovery Program will cost the country during the first fifteen months, under President Truman's proposals or any other proposals. We suspect some persons at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue are confused, too.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, is expected to develop in a speech Tuesday night at Troy, N.Y., the broad national implications of the attacks the New York State organization has been leveling at Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

HAVANA, Jan. 29 -- The International Chamber of Commerce today urged the complete deletion of the article on international investments in the proposed world trade charter in its present form on the ground that it was "prejudicial to the revival of international private capital movements."

A carload of surplus Signal Corps equipment valued at more than $100,000 and purchased by the Board of Education from the War Assets Administration for $90 will soon be used by students in New York's public schools, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee, planning to get the European recovery program under floor debate by March 1, authorized Senator Kenneth Wherry, Majority Whip, today to hold the Senate in session daily next week, if necessary to dispose of the pending resolution to sanction the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman challenged Congress today to approve his request for $6,800,000,000 for starting the European Recovery Program or reject the undertaking entirely. He said the amount was absolutely essential and that the program should be accepted in its entirety or not started at all.

The possibility of Broadway stagehands not reporting for work next Monday was admitted last night by a prominent member of the League of New York Theatres, the managerial organization which acts for producers, theatre owners and operators.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The unprecedented series of Labor party byelection successes was broken today when a Conservative won a narrow victory at Camlachie in Glasgow. In thirty-five previous by-elections since the general election of July, 1945, Labor had held all of its twenty-two seats.

A large group of the city's retail bakeries and three bakery union locals were invited yesterday by the State Board of Mediation to attend a joint meeting at 2 P.M. today to discuss means of averting a strike scheduled for midnight tomorrow.

In your issue of Jan. 28 there was published a letter from John Schreiber, who is doubtless well informed with regard to coal as a fuel. His comments on the future of oil as a means to automatic heating, the expressed choice of a majority, unfortunately only serve to add to the present confusion of facts.

An explanation of the American form of government by Representative Wright Patman of Texas, entitled "Our American Government: The Answers to 1,001 Questions on How It Works," will be published by Ziff-Davis, Feb. 20. It will be issued in a cloth edition at $2.75 and paper bound at $1.50.

Some irregularity developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with final prices 25 points higher to 3 points lower than the day before. The March and May contracts showed the most strength.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Fifty persons were injured, several seriously, today when Chinese troops and police charged with bayonets into crowds of stone-throwing students in downtown Shanghai and on the Tungchi University campus.
Random notes.

Frequency modulation radio received last night what its leaders called "the green light" as James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, authorized duplication of musical programs over both standard and FM stations.

David Van Alstyne Jr., who is opposing Senator Albert W. Hawkes for the Republican United States Senate nomination in New Jersey, said yesterday he would intensify his efforts to get the nomination, a reference to a demand that he withdraw from the contest made by Representative Harry L. Towe, campaign manager for Mr. Hawkes.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Otto Mayer, secretary of the International Olympic Committee, said early today that all nine nations entered in hockey competition would play as scheduled and let the committee decide at the end of the winter games whether to award official Olympic medals to the winning team.

Representatives of more than 200 business, civic and labor groups constituted themselves yesterday into the Citizens Committee in Opposition to the St. Lawrence Seaway, at a conference in the office of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York in the Woolworth Building.

Delays in transit this week caused some irregularity in supplies of meat, the United States Department of Agriculture reports, but in view of the continued light demand, housewives should find what they want, at least in the way of steer beef and lamb.

A literally punch-drunk cat suffering from the after-effects of too much eggnog, a cat that would eat only after hearing a tune played on a harmonica and a beakless parrot were among the patients successfully treated last year at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Friday, Jan. 30 -- After a revolt among the majority, which nearly upset the Cabinet, the French National Assembly adopted today the Government's surprise bill to withdraw more than one-third of the nation's currency circulation represented by banknotes of 5,000-franc denomination.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Master Min, Brookmeade Stable castoff flying the yellow and red silks of Gustave Ring, routed nine other sprinters to pay $17.80 for $2 in 'today's Seashell Purse before 12,939 racegoers who wagered $877,191 at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- An emergency board recommended today that eighteen short-line railroads follow generally the pattern of the hourly increase of 15 1/2 cents awarded by an arbitration board to non-operating employes of the major railroads.

Many will rejoice, as I do, over the statements quoted in THE TIMES of Jan. 9 of Director John C. Whitehorn of the Department of Psychiatry and Johns Hopkins University, who addressed the New York Society for Clinical Psychiatry at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Cinema Dante, the attraction is "Rossini," an Italian-made biography of the composer, starring Nino Bosozzi in the title role. Dialogue and excerpts from the Rossini music are Italian and there are English titles.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The worst wave of strikes in the country's history was predicted for this spring and summer in a statement adopted today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 29 -- Premier Georgi Dimitrov and his Cabinet Ministers never have considered the creation of an Eastern European bloc, as charged in the Western democracies, nor has Mr. Dimitrov planned a customs union for that area, according to a statement issued by the Bulgarian official news agency today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The administration of New York City through a representative of Mayor William O'Dwyer, advocated today an extension of strengthened rent control through June 30, 1950, with restored controls over residential hotel accommodations and greater protections for tenants.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey's committee on a state educational program recommended today that state aid for education be increased by $30,000,000, of which $6,600,000 more would go to New York City.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Argentine Government today assigned interviewers, or appointed Governors, to three provinces where Interior Minister Angel Borlenghi said political unrest had developed.

Returning for another fortnight as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch introduced to this country a 23-year-old French pianist, Nicole Henriot, who made her debut with Schumann's A minor Concerto.
Will you please say a kind word through your columns in behalf of the thousands of birds, pigeons, squirrels, and deer which starve and perish needlessly during the cold winter months.

BOSTON. Jan. 29 -- The Army funeral ship Joseph V. Connolly, abandoned at sea Jan. 12 when swept by flames while en route to Europe, sank today in a violent snow squall while being towed to New York. There was no one aboard.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 -- Jerusalem is becoming virtually isolated behind a curtain of fear. No one comes to Jerusalem or leaves his neighborhood except for dire necessity. He does not go abroad after sundown and even in daylight there are many districts that he would not dare walk through.

Carmen Gracia, Spanish soprano, made her New York debut in last night's performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The youthful artist was entrusted with the exacting role of Rosina, which she had assumed at her first American appearance, on Jan. 20, in Philadelphia, with the company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Emma Debeljak, a native American, is facing trial on suspicion of having harbored a man wanted by the police, a Government spokesman said today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 29 -- Czechoslovakia's anti-Communist parties today finally raised the formal issue of erecting a legal barrier against the bit-by-bit destruction of remaining private enterprise within the state and eventual transformation of the entire economy into a totalitarian, state-capitalism operation.

Archbishop John T. McNicholas of Cincinnati, chairman of the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, announced here yesterday a campaign for $5,000,000 to be conducted in the Catholic churches of the United States on Laetare Sunday, March 7, for relief of the starving people in the war-stricken countries of Europe and the Far East.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Lord Vansittart, former pemanent Under Secretary of the Foreign Office, called for a bold and even risky British foreign policy in a speech today.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Expressions of Balkan solidarity came from two capitals of southeastern Europe today in the face of Pravda's frown.

The building containing doctors' offices and other professional suites at 133 West Seventy-second Street was sold by a syndicate represented by Victor Whitehorn to the West Seventy-second Street Realty Corporation, of which A. Shipper is the president.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (UP) -- American correspondents abroad are a combination of reporter and "reconnaissance worker-spy," David Zaslavsky, a leading Moscow editorial writer, said today in an article in the magazine October, organ of the Union of Soviet Writers.

A social program to reduce racial and religious tension in lower Harlem was projected yesterday at the opening of the 110th Street Community Center, Inc., 31 West 110th Street. The agency plans to serve up to 600 families of all races and creeds who live in the area bounded by the two rivers, between Ninety-sixth and 135th Streets.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan 29 (AP) -Lanky Dave Douglas of Wilmington, Del., found the cold desert weather to his liking today and spanked out a seven-under-par 63 to set the pace in the first round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

He said that Old Man Winter, who had saved Russia from Napoleon, had now become the ally of the friends of Russia in this country. Our young women are all walking around in boots the way the pictures show the Russian women are doing.

The top bout at Madison Square Garden tonight will feature heavyweights Gino Buonvino, powerful slugger from Bari, Italy, and Jackie Cranford, promising Washington, D.C., battler. These gladiators are scheduled to travel over the ten-round route, and a crowd of 12,000 fans is expected to see them perform.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $288,000,000 last week. According to the figures issued yesterday by the Rederal Reserve Bank of New York, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans declined $19,000,000 during the period ended on Wednesday, marking a return to a total of $5,324,000,000, the figure reported on Jan. 7, and following two successive weekly rises since that time.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- In the second part of a study of state fiscal affairs, released today by Democratic leaders in the State Legislature, Governor Dewey was charged with having followed "a double standard of fiscal morals," one for the state and a second for local governments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Wheat prices rallied 3 to 5 cents a bushel from the early low on the Board of Trade today. Although the best prices were not maintained, closing trades were 1/2 to 2 cents higher than yesterday. Corn was under pressure and off around 4 cents at one time, finishing with losses of 3/4 to 1 3/4 cents.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Commenting early today on the indefinite status of hockey in the Olympic Games, President Brundage of the United States Olympic Committee said: "The A.H.A. may play, but it will not be an Olympic game."

The third and final hearing in the Maritime Commission's investigation of minimum wages, manning scales and working conditions aboard Government-subsidized merchant vessels opened yesterday with testimony from four maritime unions.

Hank Greenberg, whose closing years as one of baseball's great players seems to be charting a curious course, probably will be back in the American League this year and if so it will be in the livery of the Cleveland Indians.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- A Government move to ban all foreign films from Argentina was reported today in motion-picture circles and in two local papers. An attache of the United States Embassy who specializes in films confirmed the step, although the exact circumstances are not yet clear.

Donald Dickson has sung a good deal in different parts of the country since he appeared in the Metropolitan Opera's 1937 spring season, but the young baritone's recital last night at Town Hall was only his second concert in this city. His first was in October, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A House debate over tax reduction in a general election year is certain to produce familiar but none the less interesting exercises in plain, practical politics, and the current carnival of oratory abides by the tradition. Except for a very few serious members, everyone is out to cut down individual taxes -- their differences being only on details which are also the product of politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Asserting that voluntary measures were unworkable, President Truman requested today Congressional authority until Oct. 31 to reduce the consumption of grain for liquor-making by 23 per cent of the average monthly use in the 1947 fiscal year.

Observations of cosmic rays made from a B-29 flying at altitudes of 30,000 to 40,000 feet promise to provide the first definite evidence for the existence of the neutral meson, one of the most elusive fundamental constitutents of the material universe, it was reported yesterday at the annual New York meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.

Much has been made of the fact -and it is, of course, a fact -- that there is a very definite distinction between speculation, on the one hand, and gambling on the other. Gambling, as has frequently been pointed out, involves an avoidable, unnecessary, risk. Speculation, on the other hand, is the assumption of a risk that is inherent in the nature of the price system under which we live.

Current expansion plans in the rayon industry are totally inadequate to relieve existing shortages in the textile trades, according to a survey of the industry released yesterday by Oscar Kohorn Co., Ltd. The company, which builds and operates rayon plants, mainly abroad, maintains that the actual and potential demand for rayon yarn and staple will continue to out-strip available supply by a substantial margin for the next five years.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Curtis Cup team members, Miss Louise Suggs and Miss Dorothy Kirby, both of Atlanta, Ga., and two Miamians advanced to the semifinals of the Helen Lee Doherty Challenge Cup golf tournament today.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 30 -The Moscow Radio reported today that Russia had protested to the United States over presence of American warships in Italian ports.

With a larger group of scientists becoming interested in the problems involved in forecasting the weather, some additional research and an increase in the number of meteorologists may result in more accurate forecasts being made, F. W. Reichelderfer, Chief of the United States Weather Bureau, said last night.

The French liner De Grasse has been booked almost to capacity for transatlantic crossings from April through October. It was announced here yesterday. The only openings for the summer season are limited first-class accommodations available for eastbound crossings in July and August and westbound in July.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 29 -- (AP) Students at the University of Oklahoma, some dressed as mourners, cremated a copy of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution today in protest against the state's ban on Negro students at the institution.
The city's appropriations for snow and ice removal this winter passed the $8,000,000 mark yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted an additional $1,000,000 in one-year budget notes.
Sales and earnings of the Hercules Powder Company last year were the largest in its history, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday by Charles A. Higgins, president.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who renounced all Presidential possibilities last week, will transfer command of the Army next month to Gen. Omar Bradley, his principal subordinate in the final campaigns of the war.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Jack Heaton of New Haven, Conn., will have the honor of carrying the American flag in tomorrow's opening parade for the winter games, J. Lyman Bingham announced tonight.

Defense bases in the Far East negotiated under 100-year treaties now make it possible, for the United States, through business groups, to build up the economy of the Orient, Paul V. McNutt, former Ambassador to the Philippines, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Official quarters indicated today that the British Government would politely reject the Soviet note of protest against the United States reoccupation of the potentially important military airbase at Mellaha in the former Italian colony of Tripolitania.

For the sake of humor they have turned the folklore of the ballet into a good knockabout musical comedy, "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'!", put on at the Adelphi last evening. Reversing the usual sex arrangement, Jerome Robbins has "conceived" it, as the program explains, and George Abbott, the carnival maestro, has staged it with the authority of the old-school style in song entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 24, 1948, totaled 771,992 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 39,294 cars, or 4.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week; 49,936 cars, or 6.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 63,438 cars, or 9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- In a polite but blunt open letter replying to a "benevolent attack" upon him by four leading Soviet scientists for his support of "world government," Dr. Albert Einstein today criticized the Soviet Union for its stand on international control of atomic energy development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House Democratic leadership, threatened with wholesale desertions to the Republican camp on the tax issue, sought tonight to work out a tax reduction substitute around which to rally the divided minority forces.

Earth revolves on its axis and travels its path around the sun. Bodies of matter millions of miles distant wheel into line twice a year and the seasons follow each other with unvarying regularity. The uplift of spring levels into the lushness of summer. And when Nature's time of replenishment is fulfilled autumn's banners proclaim the time of thanksgiving for another harvest.

Republicans are playing politics in thwarting a vote by the House on the Universal Military Training bill, James F. O'Neil, national commander of the American Legion, charged yesterday at La Guardia Field upon his arrival from Albany.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 29 -- A turbulent debate in the Bavarian Parliament today over the school reform program demanded by the United States Military Government brought to a head the gradually waxing sentiment of resistance against the authority of the occupying powers.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Continued uncertainty over the French political situation helped to discourage business in the stock markets here today.

" Romeo and Juliet," starring Maurice Evans and Dorothy McGuire, will be offered at 9:30 P.M. on Sunday, Feb. 8, over the ABC network (WJZ), according to word from the "Theatre Guild on the Air." It is said to be one of the few times that Shakespeare's work has been accorded a full hour on the air.
Twenty-one contributions amounting to $396 were received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES for its Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, increasing the total of the thirty-sixth annual appeal to $360,125.57.

Diversion of refrigerators and other appliances in short supply from dealers through alleged misrepresentations of home builders is not occurring in top name brand merchandise, an executive for the metropolitan area distributor of one of the country's largest appliance producers stated yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Seven restrictions on the liberty of the press were approved here today by the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of the Press, despite the doubts evidenced by some members that some of the limitations were loosely worded.

Howard S. Palmer, president-ofIthe New York, New Haven [Hartford Railroad; announced yes-[terday the appointment of GeorgeIT. Carmichael as executive assist-[ant, in addition to his duties asIvice president in charge of accounting, public relations, advertising and iudustrial development.

WARSAW, Jan. 29 -- A throng of diplomats and Government officials gathered in a heavy rain today to welcome Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz and his mission home from Moscow as the Polish press continued pouring out hosannahs for the Soviet aid they had obtained.

James G. Denezis has purchased the five-story apartment house with stores at 28-15 and 28 19 Twenty-third Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, from the Henley Properties Corporation. The property, assessed at $60,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $87,000.

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The boxing ring at the American Legion Coliseum here was decked out in gladioluses and palms today as the Community Concerts Association made ready for the appearance tomorrow night of Miss Helen Jepson, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

Large investments in new paper and pulp production capacity, exclusive of newsprint, should make it possible for the industry to meet heavy requirements for most grades of paper, E. W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, predicted yesterday.

The State Committee of the American Labor party condemned the major party leaders of the Assembly and Governor Dewey yesterday for failure to get a quorum at the meeting of the Assembly on Wednesday, resulting in postponement of action on the Stevens bill to validate this city's rent control laws.

Forty-seven large-scale rental housing projects in eleven states are completed, under construction or contemplated as direct investments by life insurance companies to provide shelter for nearly 200,000 persons, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

The Mathieson Alkali Works, in its annual report mailed to stockholders, announced yesterday net earnings of $2,930,565 for 1947 after provision for taxes, contingencies and all charges, on record net sales of $24,630,056.
Strong winds of gale force sweeping the North Atlantic shipping lanes have caused delays for westbound ocean liners.

By what right -- and with what hope of political profit -- does the Republican leadership of the House of Representatives clamp down the lid on Congressional discussion and prevent the question of Universal Military Training from coming to a vote?
Three handicapped young persons at Welfare Island's Goldwater Memorial Hospital were graduated yesterday from the "school without a school building."

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- In a collection composed almost entirely in beige, gray, navy and black, Digby Morton showed a more restrained line of the hour-glass silhouette in lightweight country tweeds with a trend toward fuller and longer skirts for town.

The Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture has purchased the three-story dwelling at 53 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, from Richard S. Childs and Mary Childs Draper in the first transfer of the property since 1900. The property occupies a plot about 100 by 97 feet and is assessed at $120,000.

Catering to the interest in scientific examination of pictures, which was recently stimulated by the exposing of the Vermeer forgeries in Holland, the Metropolitan Museum opens today a small, fascinatingly installed exhibition. The various methods to check paintings used in its own laboratory are displayed by means of enlarged photographs, models and a few actual paintings which have been subjected to treatment.

The culminative opera of the "Ring," "Goetterdaemmerung," given as the final matinee performance of the first cycle of the season at the Metropolitan, was presented yesterday. The performance, scenically and on the interpretive side, was on the whole the finest of the series.

A group of rooming-house tenants reported yesterday on the results obtained after they had organized, in nautical fashion, to recover rental overcharges paid to their landlord at 404-406 West Twenty-third Street.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 29 -- The Lutheran churches of America have allotted $300,000 for the construction of thirty "rubble" churches in Germany during the current year, the Rev. Dr. S. C. Michelfelder of Geneva, Switzerland, executive secretary of the Lutheran World Federation, reported here today to the annual meeting of the National Lutheran Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Democratic National Committee has selected the portrait of President Truman that it will use as the official campaign picture "if the President is a candidate," it was learned today.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 29 -Repercussions of the devaluation of the French franc appeared likely to cause a financial split between Syria and Lebanon, it was stated today.

No postponement of over-all licensing of exports to Europe, scheduled to become effective March 1, is planned by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce, Thomas C. Blaisdell Jr., assistant to the Secretary of Commerce for International Trade and director of the OIT, said here yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 29 -- Parliament today passed the bill that will marshal an estimated 2,000,000 Polish boys and girls between the ages of 16 and 21 into a single youth organization for professional physical, ideological and military training.
The likelihood of a more severe shortage of fuel oil next month brought the following developments yesterday as the East remained in the grip of a protracted cold spell:
Gilbert Dodds, it was brought out yesterday, still does have some worlds to conquer in the mile run.

Frank A. Hoel has been promoted to assistant regional manager in the Atlantic Coast region by the Chevrolet Motor Division of the General Motors Corporation. He formerly was zone manager in New York City.

Leaving a shoe box jammed with $10,800, bank books showing deposits of $45,000 and $2,000 in Government bonds on a neighbor's front porch, a 72-year-old Queens widow wandered away from her home and was discovered yesterday morning, thirteen hours later, in her sister's apartment in Manhattan.

Directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation authorized yesterday an increase in the dividend on the common stock after the issuance of the corporation's financial statement for 1947, which showed record net earnings of $51,088,375 as gross business crossed the billion-dollar mark for the first time in a non-war year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- One of the most popular themes in the Marshall Plan hearings on Capitol Hill is that the Marshall Plan countries should get together and do a little more planning in preparation for the arrival of the dollar train.

CHAPEL HILL. N.C., Jan. 29 -The Department of Histor of the University of North Carolina today was exonerated of charges made recently by Leonard Bernstein, Harrisburg, Pa., graduate student, that he was advised by the department to discontinue his work for a doctorate in history because of his religion and political views.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The Soviet Union served categorical notice on members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today that existing stockpiles of atomic bombs possessed by the United States must be destroyed before the Soviet Government would agree to the setting up of the proposed international atomic control authority.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 29 (AP) -Forty-eight South Carolina legislators declared today that the national Democratic party no longer represents the South and asked that the state's Democrats meet to reconsider their position in the national party.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay sought to explain to a large group of German newspaper men today how classic democratic ideals might be applied to the critical economic and governmental problems of this country.
The second annual campaign of the Protestant Fund of Greater New York was opened last night at a dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel attended by 700 church, business and civic leaders.

A second woman was hold as a material witness in connection with the slaying of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, an ex-convict, when General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan set $25,000 bail yesterday on Miss Constance Fernandez, who was described as the victim's sweetheart.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- During the week ended Jan. 28, member bank reserve balances decreased $29,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -William A. Bacher, who recently obtained a release from his producing contract with Twentieth Century-Fox, has announced the establishment of two independent production companies, Trinity Films and Bacher Productions, Inc., with James Nasser, owner of the General Service Studio, as his partner in the first organization, and Ward Wheelock, advertising executive, as his partner in the second.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Several industries are incurring outof-pocket expenses in the cold war against communism which should be reimbursed by the Government, President Truman was told today by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States has opened exploratory efforts to put on a firmer contractual basis its access to Middle Eastern oil, a reservoir officially held to be indispensable to the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations will strongly support the British Trades Union Congress in its attempt to force a showdown on the European Recovery Plan in the World Federation of Trade Unions.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Representatives of the New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association went to Washington today to explain to government authorities tentative plans for a coast-to-coast "drug train" to collect medical supplies for Europe.

Having been idle for more than a week because of examinations, New York University's unbeaten quintet will return to action tonight against Brooklyn College at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. In the preliminary, the N.Y.U. freshmen will face the Kingsmen's yearlings.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 29 -Periodic check-ups of employes' opinion by management because "people should not wait to get sick before going to see the doctor" was advocated today by W. P. Reymond Jr., Baton Rouge, La., employe relations manager, Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Social sciences were not adequately applied in the Army and Navy during the war because of interference by "high brass," it was reported yesterday at the opening session of a three-day conference of the Community Service Society at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Generally lower prices for foods and agricultural commodities caused a decrease of 0.7 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Jan. 24, acording to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This decline interrupted the persistent advance of the past eleven weeks and lowered the bureau's composite index of commodity prices to 164.4 per cent of the 1926 average.

JACKSON, /Vfiss., Jan. 29 (P)-Senator James 0. Eastland, Democrat, of /W/ssissippi, said today!that if Southern Democrats xthhold from the Democratic partytheir electoral votes, "a Southernman will emerge as President ofthe United States."

ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- Following a number of assertions recently in the local press to the effect the Greek National Army was insufficiently equipped to fight the guerrillas Maj. Gen. William G. Livesay, chief of the United States Army group under the American Mission for Aid to Greece, issued a statement today affirming a diametrically opposite view.

Helen Clay Frick, daughter of the noted steelmaker, has refused to allow John D. Rockefeller Jr., to give paintings by Botticelli, Goya and Fragonard to her father's collection, it was learned yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board applied in Federal court here yesterday for an injunction restraining General Motors Corporation from putting an insurance plan into effect for employes represented by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, until the board can act on charges of unfair labor practices made against the company by the union.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 -- Terrorists renewed their activity in Jerusalem tonight with the killing of two British policemen in Ben Yehuda Street, a busy center of the city. The shooting was described as being similar to those perpetrated by the Stern Gang, but for the present no Jewish organization has acknowledged responsibility.

It is with great feeling and, I might add, with even greater concern that I read in one of our national newspapers that your London correspondent, an American, has reported to your paper there is a large anti-American feeling and tendency among the peoples of this country.
The first test of a new plan to place trained Puerto Rican women as household workers will start next month in Scarsdale, it was announced yesterday.

The stock market went all out yesterday toward recovery, making the best advance since late last rear. It was the third consecutive day of higher prices and the activity was the heaviest in a week. While interest diminished during the afternoon, the highest prices reached in the morning in most cases were held, and transfers on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,060,000 shares, compared with 860,000 on Wednesday.

From the stewards of The Jockey Club, following a meeting at their 250 Park Avenue offices, came the announcement yesterday that the 7-year-old Australian race horse Shannon had been accepted for registry in the American Stud Book.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that its net income in 1947 was $7,285,125, despite an operating deficit of $5,273,829.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Anticipating a strike of their 200 bus drivers at 12:01 A.M. Sunday, the Rockland Coaches, Inc., and Spring Valley Motor Coach, Inc., announced today there would be no advance sale of February commutation tickets.

FRANCIS AMBRIERE'S "The Long Holiday"* was both a popular and a critical success in France. It sold more than 200,000 copies and won the Prix Goncourt for 1946. Although there have been several more dramatic and personal accounts by French prisoners of war than his, there has been none that I know of that offers so comprehensive a record of the life that was led in Germany by some 1,700,000 Frenchmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Treasury Department approval was alleged today by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, of income tax deductions to contributors to eight organizations and schools cited by Attorney General Tom C. Clark as being of questioned loyalty to the United States.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- Democracy has entered the Imperial poetry contest for the first time since it was established, reportedly 2,200 years ago. Today fifteen winners were received by Emperor Hirohito and their poems were read.
Frank A. Sweeney has been elected vice president in charge of sales for the National Portland Cement Company.

DISCOURAGING as it as, the London Economic Conference had a few lighter shades. Mrs. Hull and I attended King George's reception. We had also planned a much-needed little outing which required us to go from the reception to a country place some miles distant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Engineers Public Service Company, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to consummate short-term bank borrowings in the amount of $1,100,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman asserted today that the shortage of meat was becoming increasingly acute; that rationing, though not imminent, was being studied by the Ad ministration, and that rationing would be ineffective without price control.
Formation of a new commercial organization for the relief of Europeans that will act as American and Canadian agent for the nonsectarian Swiss charity, Caritas, was announced here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission decided unanimously today to help arrange for the formation of a Jewish militia in Palestine. Accepting the offer of the Jewish Agency to cooperate in the establishment of such a militia, the commission designated one of its members to negotiate with Britain as the mandatory power and with the agency.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The use of public school buildings for Communistsponsored meetings would be prohibited by a bill introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman George P. Stier, Democrat, of Queens.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 29 (UP) -Mohammed el-Sadi, former President of the Iraqi Senate, formed a new Cabinet today to replace the Government of Saleh Jabr, who fled the country yesterday following two weeks of riots protesting the new Anglo-Iraq alliance he had signed in England.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Tran Ngoc Danh, chief of the Viet-Nam delegation to France, was quietly arrested here today by the French judiciary police. Although the arrest was made under cloak of secrecy, it appeared that Danh was booked on charges of inciting acts to endanger French territory and publication of false news.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A liquidation plan for the Northern States Power Company, a Delaware organization, modified to provide, among other things, for a specific increase in the participation by the common stockholders, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Net earnings of the Proctor Gamble Company, transferred to surplus for the six months ended on last Dec. 31, were $20,257,421, equal to $3.15 a share on the outstanding common stock, the company announced today. This was after an appropriation of $28,500,000 as an addition to the reserve for inventory price decline.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today ordered new limitations on the use of tin in beer, animal food, coffee and paint cans, provided Congress permits Federal controls to continue.

J.J. Singh, president of the India League of America, predicted yesterday that Mohandas K. Gandhi's assassination might touch off a wave of fanaticism in India. He also said he feared that Mr. Gandhi's death would expose other Indian leaders who believe in Hindu-Moslem unity to "cowardly assassins."

If New York University's basketball players were as successful in their mid-year exams as they were in the game at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night, all hands will rate "A's" in all subjects.

Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson received a request for $23,268,299 yesterday for the coming fiscal year from the City Bureau of Retirement and Pension. The director also heard a plea for $25,355,390 for the 1948-49 budget of the Division of Charitable Institutions.

Mel Ott, manager of the hard-hitting but soft-pitching Giants, held court in the West Forty-second Street offices of the club yesterday after his arrival from his Metarie, La., home and came up with the startling prediction that the 1948 National League pennant race "will be a dogfight."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 30 -- The Rev. Dr. William G. Sodt of Milwaukee, newly elected president of the National Lutheran Council, called today for a united front of American Lutheranism to combat "militant atheism and materialistic secularism."

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 30 (AP) -- A Negro will be admitted to the University of Arkansas School of Law if he reapplies, Lewis W. Jones, president, announced today. Applications of Negroes for undergraduate work raised another question, the president added.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Wider application of the piece-rate and bonus systems are to receive special attention in the thousands of trade union contracts that will be signed in the Soviet Union during January, February and March.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- A loan system, under which corporations, unions and farm organizations Would make their "most promising young executives" available for temporary Government duty, was proposed today by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A fighting nucleus of eighteen Senate Republicans agreed late tonight to press for important changes in the Administration's European Recovery Program as the party's legislative leaders brushed aside President Truman's demand for approval of the full $6,800,000,000 asked for the first fifteen months of operations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The proposed Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway and power project underwent a second day of oral assault in the Senate today.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- France's "bank holiday" takes the mind of an American back to the dramatic start of the Roosevelt Administration, when for a few days all the banks were closed and the people did what they could without money while they waited in fearful expectation for the new administration's next move.

Church World Service, the new headquarters of which are at 214 East Twenty-first Street, proposes in its 1948 program the distribution of $34,740,000 in funds and supplies, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. A. Livingston Warnshuis, executive director of the interdenominational and reconstruction agency. The total is $20,000 larger than the cost of last year's program.

Reuben Leitner, 32 years old, a taxicab driver, of 32-06 Twenty-ninth Street, Astoria, Queens, was released yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg. He had been charged with grand larceny.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 30 -Dr. Hans Ehard, Minister-President of Bavaria, rejected today the proposed charter for the German Economic Administration in the bizonal area presented by the United States and British Military Governments.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The State Banking Department announced today it has approved a certificate of reduction of capital stock of the County Trust Company, 169 Main Street, White Plains, from $2,676,912, consisting of 167,307 shares at a par value of $16 each, to $2,660,800, consisting of 166,300 shares at the same value.

Under Governor Dewey's budget, submitted yesterday to the Legislature, the city will receive only $9,600,000 of the $84,000,000 of additional direct state aid sought by Mayor O'Dwyer in the legislative "package" he plans to send to Albany early in February.

At a luncheon of the Poetry Society of America a few days ago, at which 250 poets got together to do honor to their patron muse, one of the most prominent among them, in the course of a speech, remarked, in wrathful accents:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A radio station can broadcast horse race results if the information is not given with such urgency or detail as to suggest that gamblers might benefit, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today.

The city's independent neighborhood tailors who do on-premises dry cleaning will be forced out of business if the Board of Standards and Appeals adopts regulations suggested by dry cleaning chain stored and wholesalers, it was charged yesterday at a hearing conducted by the board in its offices in the Municipal Building.

BOMBAY, India., Jan. 30 -- The death of Mohandas K. Gandhi today revived the embers of communal antipathy that he latterly lived to extinguish. In the first short, sharp outburst of fierce communal rioting after news of his death today, six persons were killed and thirty-two admitted to hospitals with injuries in street fighting.

Dr. Harvey Nathaniel Davis, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, was honored last night for his twenty years as head of the institute. He received an honorary degree of Doctor of Engineering and a special alumni association award at a dinner in the Astor Hotel. Eight hundred alumni and presidents of twelve Eastern colleges took part.

Rear Admiral Russell S. Berkey will leave his post as commander, United States Naval Base, New York, Monday to go by air to the Far East, where he has been assigned as commander, Support Group, Naval Forces, Far East, it was announced yesterday at Third Naval District Headquarters, here.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 -Mohandas K. Gandhi was killed by an assassin's bullet today. The assassin was a Hindu who fired three shots from a pistol at range of three feet.

Mme. Antonina Vallentin, European author, journalist and commentator, is planning to sail on the America March 21 for her first visit to the United States. Her new book, "Mirabeau: A Man of the French Revolution," is scheduled for Feb. 20 publication by Viking.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The American College of Surgeons made public today a list of 3,143 hospital in the United States and Canada that have won approval, following the annual hospital standardization survey completed on Dec. 31. The list for New York City, Long Island and Westchester follows:
PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Fire today destroyed a warehouse filled with approximately $5,000,000 worth of food and clothing. Police said that a disgruntled former worker might have set it.

The police have taken temporary custody of the shoe box containing cash, bonds and bang books representing $57,800 that Mrs. John Albers, 72 years old, of 140-18 Lux Road, South Jamaica, Queens, left on a neighbor's front porch Wednesday night.

How many of our restaurants in New York City are at present serving food under the most sanitary conditions, where the kitchen is borderline, or where the place is filthy? It seems to me that in a city as large as New York some sort of a plan should be adopted to let the public know how their favorite eating place rates with the Department of Health.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan 30 -Trough friendly intermediaries but not yet through diplomatic channels, the United States has informed President Juan Peron its serious concern over the possible breaking off of Anglo-Argentine economic negotiations. Informally, but unmistakably, it has been made clear to the Argentine President that Washington feels a breakdown of the talks would have an adverse affect on the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Secretary of State Marshall has expressed the hope, in a communication to British Foreign Secretary Bevin, that the British can make additional fish and grains available for occupied Germany, in view of the food situation there, it was learned today.

It is impossible to allow Ernesta Barlow's letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 16 to go unchallenged. She writes in favor of Universal Military Training and leads with the plaint, "It is very confusing, really." Her confusion stems from the fact that Mr. Wallace and Senator Taft, although engaged in a race for the Presidential nomination, are both opposed to UMT.

The cost of pictures currently being produced will be substantially lower because of economies which Loew's, Inc., has effected throughout the organization and quickening of activities in production, J. Robert Rubin, vice president, told stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan, 30 -- The physical education, health and recreation teachers of the schools of New York State today criticized the majority report of Governor Dewey's special committee on education for not recommending enough state aid and backed the stand of Commissioner of Education Francis T. Spaulding, who, as lone dissenter, filed a minority report.

Because the Republican majority in the Legislature so faithfully follows his leadership and because the Governor himself has always decided so fully in advance what he wants, the annual budget message in New York State provides a very accurate preview of developing policy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- The ambitious hopes once entertained for the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe have been virtually abandoned, and it will largely confine itself to an attempt to bring about technical improvements in European trade and communications, informed sources said today.

VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- Col. Gen. L.V. Kurasov, Soviet High Commissioner for Austria, insisted at today's meeting of the Allied Council that the council disapprove the United States-Austrian interim and agreement signed here four weeks ago.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 30 -Harold E. Stassen warned tonight against "short-cut alliances or negative combinations" in building the foundations for security. His address, which closed out a five-day tour of New England, was to the Institute of Politics of Bowdoin College.
Dr. John Pollard of the Institute of Human Relations, Yale University, assailed yesterday the "American caste system" as responsible for the "many" who espouse Marxian doctrine.

Attesting to the continued popularity of adult education, the annual report of the New School reveals a sharp increase in the number of students now attending classes in the late afternoon and evening. During the past academic year 7,000 students were enrolled at the New School, with another 2,000 turned away because of lack of space.

GENEVA, Jan. 30 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization decided tonight that refugees leaving their countries of origin or habitual residence after next Sunday should not be eligible for international aid.

James F. O'Neil, national commander of the American Legion, said last night that the Legion believes that what is best for America must be the paramount consideration of any modification of the immigration quota system.

The town house of Mrs. Paul Pryibil at 25 East Sixty-ninth Street, one of the finest for its size in the city, has been purchased by Dr. Horace I. Stern for his residence and office, it was announced yesterday. The six-story limestone front building occupies a lot 27 by 100 feet and contains an electric elevator.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Ways and Means Committee approved today a provision for incorporation in the Knutson tax reduction bill whereby estate and gift levies would be cut about 25 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- The final draft of a declaration on freedom of information, which is to be incorporated in the forthcoming covenant on human rights, was approved today by the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and the Press. The vote was 10 to 2, with Jacob M. Lomakin and Lev Sychrava, Russian and Czechoslovak experts, respectively, in the minority.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Parliamentary sanction was given today for the Government's devaluation of the franc and its accompanying monetary policy.

Thanks to James C. Petrillo's belated if none the less welcome decision to permit duplication of musical programs over both FM and standard stations, frequency modulation radio now is in a position to assume its rightful place as the superior form of sound broadcasting.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Speed skaters from eleven nations agreed tonight to protest to the International Olympic Committee and the International Skating Union against the use of the Skating Union's rules in the fifth winter Olympic Games.

THE thousands of American travelers who annually stream through the great Mexican town of Monterey will never know the inner life of the place that is shown in "Step Down, Elder Brother."* This is a new novel by Josephina Niggli, whose book of sketches called "Mexican Village" won a good deal of critical praise a couple of years ago.

Faced with a rise of about $25,000,000 in their tax bills for the coming fiscal year on the basis of the tentative assessed valuations announced yesterday by Harry B. Chambers, president of the Tax Commission, property owners are likely to present many applications for reductions, realty leaders said last night.

The Katy Ferguson Home at 162 West 130th Street, a temporary shelter for young Negro unmarried mothers, will start a drive Tuesday for $30,000 to meet operating expenses and the costs of necessary building improvements, it was announced yesterday.

Major attention in the market for new capital next week will be centered on three types of financing -- municipal, public utility and railroad equipment. On Monday, four syndicates are to bid for $27,000,000 of serial bonds of the city of San Francisco with maturities running to 1968.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 30 -- Described by state police as the "phantom burglar" who has been sought for three years by police in Danbury and other northern Fairfield County communities, Harry W. Shepherd, 37 years old, of Danbury, was picked up in Bridgeport last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The National Association of Broadcasters, in closing the New York office of its affiliate, the Association of Women Broadcasters, had no intention of "treating the AWB like a step-child," A.D. Willard Jr., executive vice president of the NAB, today told the woman broadcasters convention.
