As the saddened National League club owners, stunned by the sudden death of Herb Pennock, which occurred just as their annual schedule meeting was getting under way, continued with their session in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, speculation ran high on who would now take over the active direction of the Phillies.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Governor Dewey told the Legislature tonight that a reduction in heavy state aid toward public welfare costs was one "alternate" method of discouraging "irresponsible" local administration.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey submitted another record-breaking budget to the Legislature tonight, calling for appropriations of $799,600,000, including deficiencies for the current year, but estimating expenditures in the new budget year at a figure of $753,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that "in view of the serious shortage of fuel oils," in this country it had ordered an 18 1/2 per cent cut in exports of petroleum products during the first quarter of this year. Its action will reduce from 11,850,000 to 9,650,000 the barrels of petroleum designated for overseas.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's budget message:

Threat of a walkout by approximately 600 stagehands -- electricians, property men, carpenters and other technicians -- that would have affected the operation of more than thirty Broadway legitimate houses was averted yesterday as representatives of Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, and officials of the League of New York Theatres, the association of owners and operators, agreed to extend their contract until Monday.
BOMBAY, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Bloody rioting broke out in Bombay today a few minutes after the news of Mr. Gandhi's assassination spread.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Truman urged the public tonight to give generously to the March of Dimes campaign declaring it would be many more years and might cost many more millions of dollars before infantile paralysis was eradicated.

The Public Service Commission granted yesterday to the Long Island Lighting Company and its subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company permission to file applications for interim increases in gas rates of $2,325,000 annually.
Two boxing championship bubbles were burst last night in Madison Square Garden when two second choices in the betting supplied as many upsets.

While hampered by extreme cold weather, retail trade here managed to maintain about the same rate of gain as in previous weeks. Department store volume was up about 5 per cent, with gains of individual stores ranging up to 10 per cent over the corresponding week of 1947.

Five Protestant denominations have adopted the official policy of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America renouncing segregation of Negroes, it was reported yesterday afternoon at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the council's department of race relations at the parish house of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, 61 Gramercy Park North.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- With 35,000,000 Americans having no access to public libraries, 32,000,000 of whom live on farms or in small towns, the American Library Association, at tonight's session of its mid-winter conference, discussed means of alleviating this situation.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Election of Benson Ford as a vice president of the Ford Motor Company and director of the Lincoln-Mercury division of Ford was announced at the company's offices today.

One of the early advocates of the employment of tactical air power in close cooperation with ground forces and certainly one of its most successful practitioners, Air Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham has spent his entire adult life in the military service of Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Business dropped 1 to 9 per cent in 1947 for stores handling women's year, shoes, furs, liquor, flowers and jewelry, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The United States Maritime Commission tonight flatly opposed the transfer of 500 United States ships to European countries as proposed by the State Department under the Marshall Plan.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the International Olympic Committee's announcement of the banning of ice hockey fro mthe Winter Olympic Games:

MARSEILLE, France, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The wreckage of a United States C-47 transport plane that vanished Tuesday en route from Southern France to Italy was located today in the Alpine foothills near Digne, France, by a United States B-17 bomber, A few minutes later the B-17 Flying Fortress crashed and burned in the same area.

Leonard Eisner, pianist from Brooklyn, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. The gifted young artist failed to live up to the expectations aroused by his performances at his previous appearance here last season. In the interim, his playing has become noisy and mannered. Moreover, in an overambitious program, he did not display the interpretive insight shown before in works of a less demanding nature.

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating two hours yesterday, acquitted Edwin A. Carlson, an official of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, of being an accomplice of William B. Benjamin, convicted swindler, and Irving Poretz in the theft of $219,000 from a finance concern. Poretz has pleaded guilty to the theft.
B.W. Maxey, chief cost accountant of the Glidden Company since 1942, has been promoted to controller.

Mrs. Fannie M. Salter, last woman keeper of a lighthouse in the country, will retire from active duty today, bringing to a close a period of 120 years or more during which women have been part of the United States lighthouse service.

The annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School at St. George, Va., was given last night in the ballroom of the Pierre. The fete is sponsored each year by the school's New York auxiliary, founded by Mrs. George Gordon Battle, now honorary chairman.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, the national amateur champion from Atlanta, and her runner-up in the 1947 title tourney, Miss Dorothy Kirby, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final round of the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament tomorrow.

The Whitney Museum opens today its 1948 annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and drawings. It is a large and uneven show, divided numerically between traditional and modern -- especially ultra-modern-work.

The opening of a company-wide anti-inflation drive through a three point firm-price program was announced here yesterday by William B. Given Jr., president of the American Brake Shoe Company, following a two-day conference with twenty-five key executives in charge of the company's sixty plants throughout the country.

The Contine tal FM network, comprised of twenty-nine frequency modulation stations, received authorization last night from James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to resume the presentation of new "live" musical programs.

WASHNGTON Jan. 30 -- The Government's suit against the General Motors Corporation to restrain it from making effective an insurance plan because it had not bargained the subject out with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, has led the joint House-Senate Committee on Labor Management Relations to decide to make the subject of welfare funds a major part of its future investigation.

NANKING, Jan. 30 -- Kuomintang members elected to the National Assembly as "independents" announced in a newspaper advertisement today that they would defy the demand of the party leadership that they give up their seats to help the Kuomintang carry out its election commitments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A struggle in Congress was forecast today between the advocates of continued Government ownership of its $567,000,000 wartime synthetic rubber plant and those proposing its sale to private industry under certain conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The action today of the Department of Commerce in reducing exports of petroleum products represented the third out in estimates of first quarter export quotas. The original figure of 17,000,000 barrels was trimmed to 11,850,000 earlier in the month.

Tenants in a ten-family house at 511 East Eighty-eighth Street, shivered in freezing weather yesterday afternoon when an explosion in one of the building's gas pipes smashed most of the windows in the front of the five-story structure.

The stock market encountered yesterday a moderate flurry of selling which arrested the forward motion that marked the three preceding sessions. Prices were irregularly lower at the close, with small changes in both directions, although a few issues responded to corporate developments, mainly more favorable dividend actions. Volume slumped to 890,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, compared with 1,060,000 on Thursday.

A star-studded program of music and speeches brought to an official end the tenth annual appeal of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, in the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The last phase of the upward swing in the business cycle has been reached, Alan H. Temple, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, asserted yesterday. There is every indication, however, he said, that the last phase will be a long one and the peak has not been reached in either business or prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that Senate speculation investigators forced him to make public the names of commodity traders who had no connection with the Federal Government.

A slight increase in domestic production of fats and oils, reaching a total of 9.7 billion pounds of both edible and inedible kinds, plus some improvement in foreign output, can be expected during the 1947-48 crop year, Charles E. Lund, chief of the foodstuffs division, Department of Agriculture, stated yesterday.

LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 30 -- The Foreign Ministers of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have agreed to accept in principle British Foreign Secretary Bevin's invitaton to enter a union of western European nations, authoritative sources said today. A communique on the political decisions of the three countries will be published tomorrow.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -Skiing conditions at twenty-one New York State winter sports centers ranged from excellent to fair today with "good" conditions prevailing generally.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 30 -- America's post-war business boom is beginning to spend itself, and the recession that appeared in 1947 will return this year without a last-minute reprieve, C.F. Hughes, business editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared today at the Chittenden Hotel here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- Zionist hopes of getting United Nations help in organizing and arming a Jewish militia in the Holy Land received a crushing blow today when Sir Alexander Cadogan told the Palestine Commission that the British Government could not allow the formation of any such forces prior to the termination of the mandate.

Reflecting the record volume of sales transacted last year by the Johns-Manville Corporation, the consolidated net earnings for 1947 increased to $9,486,633 or $3.23 a common share from the $5,836,613 or $2.01 a share earned in 1946, Lewis H. Brown, board chairman, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 30 -- Orville Wright, who with his brother, the late Wilbur Wright, invented the airplane, died here tonight at 10:40 in Miami Valley Hospital. He was 76 years old.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Indian shares and those with Far Eastern connections were marked down as a precautionary measure in the stock markets here today following the news of the assassination of Gandhi.

"Significant new work" on the development of atomic weapons and the construction of new atomic furnaces of advanced design were reported last night at the annual dinner-meeting of the American Physical Society, at the New Yorker Hotel, by Prof. Robert F. Bacher, physicist member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, charged today in a Soviet-published letter that 206 Soviet citizens were imprisoned in the United States zone of Germany. He demanded their immediate release.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Director General of Public Spectacles said today that censorship of all new foreign films has been discontinued since Wednesday. The move is equivalent to banning foreign films because no movie can be shown on the screen without prior approval by the censorship board.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Riskolater, the Circle M Farm's chief reliance for the approaching Widener and McLennan Handicaps, began his 4-year-old campaign with a length triumph in today's seven-furlong Key West Purse.

The atmosphere was distinctly unfavorable to landlords in Flushing Magistrates Court yesterday, as Magistrate Paul Balsam heard charges that the Montclair Construction Corporation had failed to heat adequately its eighty-apartment building at 35-35 Seventy-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey recommended to the State Legislature today that it appropriate sufficient funds to the State Youth Commission to enable the commission to restore its support to the child day care centers in New York City in event that it should decide to do so.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather confused yesterday and the market closed 23 points lower to 10 points higher than the day before.
The Y.M.C.A. here has raised $373,905 in its 1948 campaign for $449,471, it was announced yesterday at the drive's final report luncheon at the Commodore Hotel.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP) -Stewart (Skip) Alexander, of Mid-Pines, N.C., came out of the gathering dusk tonight with a 7-under-par 63 to take a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Tucson open golf tourney with a 36-hole score of 130.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A Congressional joint committee which had observed Russian infiltration by propaganda in twenty-two foreign countries called today for an aggressive blanketing of "a demoralized and groping Europe" with truth about the United States and its people.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 30 (AP) -Approximately 1,000 United States marines will be sent shortly to the Mediterranean, Fifth Naval District headquarters announced today.

NANKING, Jan. 30 -- Minister of Social Affairs Ku Cheng-kang disclosed today that about $1,000,000,000,000 (Chinese) worth of residual UNRRA supplies would be distributed throughout China as relief following UNRRA s waiver of the restriction limiting the distribution to areas south of the thirty-fourth parallel.

The Atlantic area northeast of Bermuda was being searched last night for survivors of a British South American Airways plane that disappeared in the area early yesterday morning with a crew of six and at least twenty-two passengers, but hope had almost been abandoned.

New York's first major carnival of the indoor track season -- the forty-first annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association -will present the singular Gilbert Dodds and an all-star cast in a varied program of topflight competition at Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- In Congress today members of both parties expressed concern that the effect of Mr. Gandhi's assassination on world peace prospects might not be good.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The dispute over American ice hockey teams reached such a pitch tonight that cancellation of the winter Olympic Games became a possibility only hours after their opening.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The American College of Surgeons announced in its bulletin today that 3,143 hospitals in the United States and Canada have qualified for approval, following completion of the thirtieth annual survey on Dec. 31.

Children between the ages of 4 and 10 will sit side by side with their parents in City College classrooms at 11 o'clock this morning in the first of a series of classes they will attend together in emotional and social problems, art and French.

Judge George W. Smythe of the Westchester County Children's Court urged yesterday that leaders of business and industry take a greater interest in children's problems. He said the problem of improving the conditions of a child's life merited an interest in his behavior equal to that shown in better housing, public health and aged persons.

Lewyt Schedules Big Campaign The Lewyt Corporation, vacuum cleaner manufacturers, will break in late February a heavy advertising campaign calling for expenditure of more than $1,700,000 for magazine, cooperative and institutional advertising, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, in death, has won the unanimous tribute of Britons -- something he never hoped for or expected during his life. Nowhere outside of India has the shock of his assassination contained the feelings and emotions evident here today because Britain and Mr. Gandhi have been linked for good or evil over the last forty years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- What was described as "a discussion of the weapons of three years from now" was ended here today by the Air Force's highest authority on requirements and characteristics of the aircraft and armaments considered essential for any air warfare of the future.
New York's land and buildings, regarded as the richest segment of real estate in the world, have risen in value to $17,684,240,921 on the city's tax books for the coming fiscal year.
BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this winter sports bulletin (skiing excellent unless otherwise noted):

A program of unusual interest was presented by Naomi Sanders, soprano, in her debut recital at Times Hall last night. The attractive young singer imbued Debussy's "Trois Poemes de Stephane Mallarme" with the delicate inflections appropriate to their intimate expression. Her light voice and accurate intonation were well adapt, ed to the songs about a sigh, a petition to a porcelain princess and a fan.

A new 16-inch, direct-viewing television tube, said to provide higher definition than any model now on the market, has been perfected by RCA-Victor and is scheduled for introduction in sets produced next autumn, it was learned yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A munitions scandal linked to Switzerland and Argentina was reported uncovered today with the arrest of two high Government officials and the director of two nationalized nitrogen plants on charges of "industrial espionage and foreign currency abuses."
A wide difference of opinion was heard yesterday after the Columbia and Manhattan College basketball teams had "scrimmaged" in the much awaited "clinic" game at the 69th Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Registration statements covering bonds, common stock and warrants were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by three companies.

OGALLALA, Neb. Jan. 30 (AP) -The Union Pacific's City of San Francisco streamliner left the rails in the early-morning darkness today, spreading wreckage along a half-mile of track and injuring at least eighteen persons, none seriously.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the acquisition of screen rights to "Stars in My Crown," a 1947 novel by Joe David Brown about a Tennessee preacher of the post-Civil War period. William Wright has been assigned to produce the film version.

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 30 -Standing within the ropes of a prizefight ring in the Sarasota Coliseum of the American Legion, Helen Jepson, Metropolitan opera star, thrilled 1,500 Sarasotans and winter visitors with her lyric soprano voice tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Joint Committee on Atomic Energy laid down today a firm policy that the production of atomic weapons, rather than work on peacetime applications of atomic energy, must be the "vital business" of the United States for the foreseeable future.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Governor General Mohammed Ali Jinnah, leader of this Moslem Dominion, tonight expressed his deep sorrow over the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi and his sincere sympathy with Hindu India on the loss of a great man.

In one of the few unequivocal avowals to be made by a leading Communist here on the question of loyalties, Alexander Bittelman said yesterday he would not bear arms against Soviet Russia "in any war."

Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Hindu reformer and nationalist leader, was looked upon as a saint by millions of his followers, who bestowed upon him the admiring appellation of "Mahatma," literally "the great-souled one."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The prospect of a consumer diet of "parched corn and boiled hay" if meat rationing were restored, was offered today by a livestock producer and was echoed by a number of his colleagues.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- The uneasy fear that the death of Mohandas K. Gandhi would bring bloodshed and new disaster to India ran today like a thread through a day of gloom at the United Nations.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey was reported today to favor removal of the State ban which prohibits the use of oleomargarine and other butter substitutes in any institution that receives any of its support from tax moneys. It was learned further that he has prevailed upon legislative leaders to support implementing legislation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Grain markets were under pressure on the Board of Trade today. They opened with losses, moved above the previous close and then broke sharply in the late trading when a renewal of liquidation in corn started a selling movement in other grains.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Britain has told the French Government that in view of the "urgency" of the situation in Germany there will be no delay on the British side in carrying out plans for the economic reconstruction of the bizonal area.

Irving Haim, head of International Distributors, wholesale liquor dealers, of 5 East Fifty-second Street, appeared yesterday before the State Liquor Authority, 1775 Broadway, in connection with the Authority's refusal to renew his liquor license, which will expire on Feb. 29. His company does an annual business of more than $10,000,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- In a statement that opened the way for abandonment of its opposition to universal military training, the American Federation of Labor demanded today that the country's normal peace policies be revised "in accordance with the requirements of common-sense national defense."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, the American member and chairman of the Far Eastern Commission, issued a statement today denying that discord had recently arisen within the Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Acting on an objective mentioned in his recent state of the union message, President Truman requested today that Oscar R. Ewing, administrator of the Federal Security Agency, study "feasible goals" for improving the health of Americans in the next ten years.

Today's lone film arrival is "Open Secret," a melodrama using anti-Semitism as its theme, which will be presented at the Gotham. The picture, featuring John Ireland, Jane Randolph, Roman Bohnen and Sheldon Leonard, was produced independently for release by Eagle Lion.

Careful measurement of the amount of ultra violet light the earth receives from the sun eventually might provide an accurate method of predicting climatic conditions over long periods, Capt H. B. Hutchinson, USN, told the final session yesterday of the American Meteorological Society meeting at the American Museum of Natural History.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened last night in the threatened city-wide bakery strike, asking the principal parties to the dispute to meet at City Hall at 11 o'clock this morning with Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city Labor Relations Division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The National Association of Manufacturers, borrowing President Truman's reference to controls being the method of a police state, maintained today that proposals to combat inflation through the reinstitution of controls would mean "a police state in America."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a letter to Secretary of State Marshall today urged that a "strong protest" be made to the Greek Government concerning "the vicious anti-labor law passed by the Greek Government on Dec. 8."

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 30 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts, an old adversary of Mohandas K. Gandhi, expressed today his personal condolences and those of South Africa, where Mr. Gandhi embarked on his political career.

Like a publishing firm that has just learned that one of its books has unexpectedly turned out to be a best seller, Ruzak Industries is somewhat overwhelmed at the tremendous demand for one of its plastic products, styron refrigerator boxes.

The handling of cargo continues to be the greatest single expense in the operation of a vessel, according to L.H. Quackenbush of the operating department of the States Marine Corporation. Although great strides have been made in the moving of some bulk commodities, virtually no progress has been made with regard to general cargo, he added.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- The United States Government conformed fully with international law and usage in all matters appertaining to the presence of United States warships in Italian ports, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

WARSAW, Jan. 30 -- Russian technology will be placed at Poland's disposal to build up her industry, particularly the chemical industry, with the capital goods and credit obtained in the newly concluded Russo-Polish trade agreements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman designated freight cars, farm machinery, oil equipment and home building as industries of "prime national interest and importance" today and urged the steel industry to aid them under the new voluntary allocation program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi shocked the capital today. Fears were expressed that it might lead to serious complications in India.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- In a broadcast to the German people tonight, Clarence L. Adcock and Sir Gordon MacReady, co-chairmen of the Bipartite Control Ofice, severely criticized the Germans for refusing to understand that a world shortage of food existed.
H. Hume Wrong, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, suggested last night that the war-time integration of Canadian and American economies be continued in peace time.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- While all parties in Britain are considering the reform of the House of Lords Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, distinguished member of the Chamber, introduced his own reformation scheme today. He proposed that the King should appoint the Lords of Parliament on the nomination of the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The National Commission on Children and Youth today started work on a mid-century White House conference on children and youth to be held in 1950.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Distribution of unclaimed and uninherited Jewish property among surviving European Jews was recommended here today by Milton Winn, New York lawyer, who has just completed a tour of Turkey, Greece and Czechoslovakia for the American Jewish Committee.

The New York City Housing Authority sold $4,918,000 of temporary loan, notes due Aug. 16 to Chase National Bank, C.J. Devine Co., Inc., and Salomon Brothers Hutzler at a bid of 1.45 per cent plus $30. Proceeds of the sale will help pay development costs of the following four City-aided $12.50-per-room apartment projects: Woodside Houses, Queens; Eastchester Houses, the Bronx; Sheepshead Bay Houses, Brooklyn, and South Beach Houses, Staten Island.

Hundreds of families in the city were reported by their landlords to be in cold homes for lack of fuel oil last night as temperatures dropped toward zero in Manhattan and toward subzero levels in the suburbs.

The New York Curb Exchange reported yesterday a net income of $26,848 for 1947, compared with $347,579 for 1946. A loss from the sale of real estate caused surplus to decline by $583,143. An increase in surplus of $347,579 was reported for 1946.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Fifth Winter Olympic had opened today as a "symbol of "good-will" but soon developed into the wildest day in international sports history, marked by sabotage of two United States bobsheds, fist fights and new protests against official decisions.

A hush goes round the world today as the frail body of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is carried in mournful procession from the Birla House in New Delhi to the banks of the sacred river Jumna, there to be turned to ashes. Out of the ashes we do not know what flowers will spring.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 30 -- The sharply conflicting views expressed by Rightist leaders in consultation with the United Nations Temporary Commission's subcommittee regarding the solution of the Korean problem has led to a bitter controversy between the forces of Dr. Syngman Rhee and those headed by Dr. Kim Koo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The House Appropriations Committee expressed doubt as to the value of the President's Council of Economic Advisers today and recommended a 33 1/3 per cent slash in funds requested for its operation in the next fiscal year.

Having made her New York debut at Town Hall last year, Donna Grescoe took on Carnegie Hall last night. The 20-year-old violinist from Winnipeg also took on an exacting program. The net impression last night was that of a talented, modest and personable young woman who was being asked to carry more onerous assignments as a performer than she was ready for.

VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, the Austrian Minister of Foreign Affairs, himself a Tyrolean, tonight told the German-speaking inhabitants of South Tyrol that they had so far received from the Italian Government an equitable settlement of their demand for autonomy and should be satisfied with their lot.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 -- United States citizens fighting in the armed services of the Jews or the Arabs will lose their passports and their right to protection, the United States Consulate General warned Americans in Palestine tonight. Furthermore, naturalized citizens, it was said, would lose their American nationality if they fought for a foreign power.

We are considerably ashamed of the light view of responsibility to the legislative process apparently felt by most New York City members of the State Assembly, as witnessed by their wholesale absence on Wednesday. We recently urged that if a legislator was worth his salt he was worth $5,000 a year.

The working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission has come to the dead end of the street in its effort to find some way around the obstacles that have blocked agreement on the bomb. With two exceptions, all nations which have ever been represented on the A.E.C. --

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A deicing system said to be of exceptional value for the prevention of ice or frost formation on aircraft, vessels, or other moving vehicles, was one of 293 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

A. Terry Fahye, a broker who was author of a flamboyant and unsuccessful scheme to buy up the controlling stock of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh for $9,000,000, was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions.

Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo in Queens Felony Court dismissed yesterday for lack of evidence a charge of grand larceny against Allan Licht, who was accused of the theft of $170,000 worth of uncut diamonds he had smuggled out of Belgium for delivery here.

Ezra Hannon has purchased the two-family house at 1964 Eightieth Street, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, from Ida Waxler. Slomka Brothers, brokers in the sale, arranged a mortgage of $8,000 for fifteen years.

The newly constructed one-story factory building at 31-09 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Charles J. Mandia to the Johnke Manufacturing Company of New York City, manufacturer of custom-built photographic equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The State Department was prepared tonight to reject the two protests received recently from Russia, one on the reopening for United States use of the airfield at Mellaha in Tripolitania, Libya, and the other against the presence of United States warships in Italian ports.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Opposition to the State Department's plan to transfer 500 American ships to European countries to enable them to carry their own relief supplies was disclosed today on behalf of the Maritime Commission by Commissioner Joseph K. Carson, former Mayor of Portland, Ore.

AFTER the initial shouting over fabrics made of glass had dropped to a conversational level, many decorators quietly crossed them off their lists except for jobs in restaurants, hotels and places where fireproof trimmings are imperative.

The firm stand taken last week by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce has apparently convinced many exporters that they will have to "live with" the new export control regulations, although objecting to them in principle.

The decision of the French Government to increase the official price for dollars in terms of the French franc by almost 100 per cent and to establish a free, unstabilized, fluctuating market for gold and dollars at even higher rates must arouse the greatest concern over France's economic and political future.

Integration of the American economic policy of aid to Europe with a political "Marshall Plan" was urged yesterday by James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a morning lecture at Town Hall.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- A Russian plan for currency reform was offered today. It is reported to be substantially the same as the system now employed by the bizonal Joint Export-Import Agency.

The performance of "Tonight at 2:30," with Gertrude Lawrence in the leading role, on the evening of Feb. 26 at the National Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Turtle Bay Music School. Mrs. J. Mortimer Duval is chairman and Mrs. William Howard Schubart vice chairman of the benefit committee.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The American Federation of Grain Processors, AFL, today asked President Truman to "avert" a strike called for "shortly after Feb. 10" which, the union warned, would affect 75 per cent of the grain milling industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- There are two sets of Marshall Plan worriers in the State Department -the short-range worriers, who are concerned mainly about getting the plan through Congress, and the long-range worriers, who are concerned about what will happen when the bill does get through.

DANNY KAYE, now entertaining in person in London, may star in a film version of "Father Goose," the biography of Mack Sennett by Gene Fowler, if current negotiations for the book are successful. "But Danny won't be playing Sennett," Sylvia Fine (Mrs. Danny Kaye) opined darkly last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The thrusts of critical legislators at the margin between expenditures and authorized funds in the European Recovery Program, a so-called "gap"' of $2,300,000,000, were blunted today by a spokesman for the Harriman Committee.
A change in racing tactics carried the great Gilbert Dodds to a new world indoor record of 4:05.3 for the mile last night.

THE first industrial agreement under the voluntary program enacted by Congress recently to curb inflation was adopted last week by petroleum producers. With approval of the Justice Department, the industry has decided to concentrate upon the output of heating oil at the expense of gasoline in order to meet critical shortages.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 31 -- Fordham University's eleven-game victory streak was snapped here tonight as the Syracuse quintet, paced by Bullet Bill Gabor, with 22 tallies, and Ed Stickel, with 20, defeated the Rams, 78 -- 65.

JERUSALEM (By Wireless). THURSDAY, Jan. 15 -- Started the day with a walk downtown for the Palestine Post. The newsboy who served all this part of town was murdered a few days ago by Arabs and nobody else dares take the job of delivering papers. The Arabs have been making a particular campaign against the Post and presumably the other newsboys are afraid of the same fate as this one.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 31 -- Grief-stricken crowds turned in fury today on premises connected with the Hindu Mahasabha, the extreme anti-Moslem political organization, of which Nathuram Vinayak Godse, the assassin of Mohandas K. Gandhi, was known to be a member.

Where do bats go in the summer after hibernating in caves during the long winter months? This and many more questions about the habits and life history of the bat may be answered as a result of the untiring efforts of Dr. Harold B. Hitchcock of the Middlebury College Biology Department.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 -- Ch. Knightscroft Symphony, Irish setter owned by Miss Helen Naylor of Bluebell, Pa., topped her breed for one of the outstanding victories of the thirty-fifth all-breed show of the Maryland Kennel Club, starting its two-day run today.

Ernest Ansermet, Swiss conductor returned to lead the NBC Symphony for his third broadcast performance early yesterday evening. Known here for more than thirty years as a conductor of Stravinsky compositions, he chose that composer's "Symphonies of Wind Instruments (in memory of Claude Achille Debussy)" as the novelty of the performance.

John F.X. McGohey, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced yesterday in his annual report that in 1947 his office had obtained convictions in 99.1 per cent of the criminal cases it prosecuted. He said it also had been successful in 97 per cent of the civil cases in which he and his staff represented the Federal Government.

BACK in the late Twenties, when beer barons, between homicides, played "angel to Thespis, nothing was impossible and legitimate theatres were built. Show business was so rosy then that Will Rogers greeted the opening of the Ziegffeld Theatre with a wire that ended: "I hope you never have to put in a movie screen."

IN AS MUCH as February will be a day longer than usual this year, the producers have decided not to skimp on the number of plays to put into it. Since most theatrical offerings look better before you see them than afterward, it may promote some cheer this morning to survey the fifteen or sixteen productions they are preparing for the month.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 -Boston University's hockey squad routed Princeton 8 -- 1, in Baker rink tonight for its fifteenth victory in seventeen starts. It was one of the roughest ice matches seen here this year.

"YOU can blow your top on a puff." This minute quote is the key to the title of this first novel and is supposedly descriptive of the results of smoking marijuana. Greenwich Village is the setting, and, along with a good deal of talk about narcotic exaltation, cosmic truths and art transcending the boundaries of existence, the story deals with a literary hack, Archie Grau, and

WAY back in 1946 there occurred an event which, though temporarily obscured by the many alarms and excursions since then, may in the end be recognized as one of the most momentous in the post-war years. Congress passed a law declaring it to be the responsibility of the Government "to coordinate all its plans, functions and resources * * * to promote maximum employment, production and purchasing power."

With the outlook for a reduction in income taxes this year improved, more attention is being given to the probable favorable effect of such a development on the market for new investments. The need for such a revision of taxes to stimulate investing has recently been voiced by several influential political leaders and investment dealers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) -Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said tonight that "the spread of Communist power throughout the world constitutes the greatest menace to our nation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, rejected today a protest from the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship against "The Iron Curtain" of the films as impairing relations with Russia.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 31 -- George Sauer today resigned as head football coach at the University of Kansas to accept a four-year contract for the same job at the Naval Academy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph Martin Jr. said today that saboteurs could "execute a sudden coup, and take over the government" if, what he described as a powerful campaign being waged to destroy confidence in Congress, was successful.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- A deliberately induced business slump to counter-act the rise in prices resulting from the devaluation of the frac, and the recent heavy taxes is the present aim of the French Government, it may be said on high authority.

Before the largest assemblage of basketball addicts in the history of the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory -- the box-office count was 5,381 -- New York's Knickerbockers defeated Boston's Celtics, 66 to 64, in a thriller-diller last night. The Knicks are the pace-setters in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America.

APPROXIMATELY the one-thousandth anniversary of the birth of Avicenna, the great Arabian philosopher who was also a physician, mathematician, astronomer and writer, is being commemorated by Persia (Iran) with a series of stamps in the following values, colors and designs:

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Officials of London's Science Museum, where the Wright brothers' original airplane has been on display for twenty years, said today they expect Orville Wright's will to specify what is to happen to the craft.

Customs collections made at this port during January, the first full month of merchandise entry under the new reduced tariff plan, totaled more than $22,500,000, an increase of approximately 17 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, it was made known yesterday.

One disloyal person in the employ of the Government is too many, Attorney General Tom C. Clark told the members of the Queens County Bar Association last night at a dinner at the Biltmore Hotel. "So long as I am Attorney General," he said, "I shall resolve every doubt in favor of the Government, but at the same time I shall not violate the civil rights of any citizen."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -The amount of money in the hands of the public has dropped by more than $1,000,000,000 since Christmas, officials said today. They called it the biggest drop of the kind ever to occur in so short a period.
TO the momentous questions of the day -- What will Russia do? Will the Marshall Plan succeed? Shall we have inflation? add this one: What is modern art?
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Devaluation of the French currency this week precipitated, or rather accentuated, a crisis in France that is at once political and economic.

REDDING CENTER, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles O. Perry lived only two doors from the town firehouse, but for all the good that proximity did them last night they might as well have lived two miles or 200 miles away.

YOUNG people who have the knack of getting along with others, who look forward -- often vaguely -- to some kind of job in which they can "work with people," will find this a highly stimulating book. These sketches of ten men and women are not intended as blueprints to success in specific fields.

THE blurb-writer for Mr. Monsarrat's wartime tryptich has labeled it "three magnificent short novels, each exploring a phase of man's capacity for devotion." Using a slightly different yardstick, the present reviewer would describe "Depends What You Mean by Love" as three longish short-stories in one slim volume -- all told with economy, and a genuine emotional tempo.

ALTHOUGH a favorite for many years, the flowering quince is only now coming into its own. When its first great bloom bursts forth in early spring and brightens the landscape with a blaze of color, there is hardly a more beautiful shrub in the garden.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this Review: "A Modern Tragedy," a second novel by Phyllis Bentley, "has profound significance for all who are struggling to understand this our so muddied present," wrote Critic Percy Hutchison on page 1. . . .

THE "beloved country" referred in the title of Mr. Paton's novel is South Africa, and the exhortative "Cry" is a brief, agonized expression of the very tone and substance and meaning of the whole remarkable book.

The International League, holding its annual schedule meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, announced that it would open its 1948 championship season April 22. In the inaugural games, Montreal will play at Newark, Toronto at Jersey City, Buffalo at Baltimore and Rochester at Syracuse.
A personal appeal by Mayor O'Dwyer won postponement late yesterday of the city-wide bakery strike that was scheduled to start last midnight.
ROME, Jan. 31 -- Italy and the United States will sign a treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation Monday.

HAVANA -- This week marks the beginning of Havana's carnival, a combination of Mardi Gras, Mummer's Day and New Year's Eve party that runs for six weeks, until March 14. While not even Cuba's fiesta lovers could maintain the pace unbroken for such a long time, there are enough of them, and right now enough Americans here, to keep things at a pretty high pitch.

ATHENS, Jan. 31 -- Premier Sophoulis said today that the Greek Ambassador in Washington had been instructed to inform the United States Government that the Greek Government had decided to call for legislation to cancel the anti-strike measure adopted last December.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Russian Finance Minister Arseny G. Zverev proposed tonight to a joint session of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) the largest budget in the history of the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Philanthropic institutions and foundations have contributed to date "well over" $1,000,000 in the campaign to raise $15,575,000 for the projected New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, it was announced yesterday. About 160 personal and corporate foundations have donated an average of $7,500 each to the proposed medical center.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- Americans finished as runners-up and in third place today in two events on which they had set their hearts as the fifth winter Olympic Games suddenly changed their complexion from one of verbal war to sturdy competition.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- To help 400,000,000 children, underfed, ill-clothed and suffering from years of war, the United Nations will send out tomorrow an appeal for assistance from peoples throughout the world.

World-wide scientific survey of the upper atmosphere, with rockets and balloons, to obtain better weather forecasts was urged last week by Dr. Aristid V. Grosse at a meeting of the Metropolitan Long Island Group of the American Chemical Society's New York Section.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Weakness continued to predominate in grain futures pits today on the Board of Trade, although there were occasional rallies from the low points.

ONE of the best and easiest house plants is the marica, commonly known as the Twelve Apostles because of its leaves, which are usually a dozen in number. The two well-known varieties, northiana and gracilis, differ little except in size.

THERE has never been anything like a Hooper rating in Japan, but thanks to the industry and perseverance of the Radio Unit of General MacArthur's Civil Information and Education Section, plans are now ripening for an audience survey which for the first time will consuit the tastes and interests of the Japanese public.

The difficult Palestine problem got no simpler last week when, after the United Nations Palestine Commission voted uanimously to build up and arm Zionist militia forces, it met the blank refusal of the British Government to permit such a step prior to its surrender of the mandate. The commission was willing to subscribe to giving the same rights to Arabs in Palestine but had before it no request to take such action.

TORONTO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Howie Meeker's third period goal enabled Toronto to defeat Detroit, 3 -- 2, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and tie the Red Wings for the National Hockey League lead. Meeker, winner of the rookie trophy last year, decided the game shortly after the halfway mark of the final chapter when he converted passes from linemates Ted Kennedy and Vic Lynn.

I DID not know until after I had my tickets for Saturday afternoon that "The Survivors" would be closing that night, so I went with mixed feelings. Part of the time I forgot where I was for being on the stage playing, too. It was real and I felt the audience was with the cast.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- A general tightening up in export licenses for goods, particularly raw materials, sold to soft currency counties has been ordered by the British Government since the devaluation of the French franc. The purpose is to prevent the siphoning of dollars that Britain might earn into the hands of other countries.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -Pakistan, as well as India, is shadowed in grief today over the death of Mohandas K. Gandhi. Moslems in the predominantly Moslem Dominion realize that Mr. Gandhi was a staunch friend of their brother Moslems in India and they are apprehensive of new religious violence now that India's great peacemaker is no more.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Official Washington is interested in the new Soviet Ambassador, Alexander Semenovich Panyushkin, because, in contrast to his immediate predecessor, Nikolai V. Novikov, he is a distinctly friendly type, although soft-spoken and even shy in manner.

SUCH a to-do about an old book! It all begins when a new client comes to Simon Lash and employs him to trace the person to whom a copy of a certain book by Horatio Alger Jr. was presented fifty years ago. The inscription on the flyleaf read, "To Stuart, on his 11th birthday, from his Aunt Clarissa, February 2, 1897."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Dick Surpliss and Henry Stern of Saranac Lake today won the Adirondack A.A.U. two-man, half-mile bobsled championship in a zero-weather flight down the Mount Van Hoevenberg ice chute.

LOS ANGELES -- California's winter tourist season is not up to par, if par is the booming business reported last year and the year before. But Californians are quick to note that their holiday vacation trade has not fallen off as sharply as Florida's, and that while business is slow, it has not yet reached the state that could be described as a "slump."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 31 -- The statement made at a recent New York Exporters Association luncheon to the effect that "Uruguay is fast becoming a slow payer, delaying payments four to six months" caused considerable feeling in business circles here.

Through a new process chemical by-products of pulp and paper-making soon will be used to produce industrial vegetable fats and rosin, and eventually even edible foodstuffs. John H. Hinman, president of the International Paper Company, revealed last night at a dinner for more than 500 New York employes in the Waldorf-Astoria, celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the organization.

The temperature in New York City during January averaged about 25 degrees -- 6 degrees below normal. The month ended with the most prolonged cold wave in a dozen years and yesterday the temperature went to zero in the city and 10 below in the suburbs -- records for the year.

Probably at no time in the history of the income tax in the United States has there been such a divergence of expressed opinions as to the impact of the tax and the manner in which it should be imposed. Many of the variances, however, appear to be dictated by political proclivities rather than by considerations of what is best for our national economy.

HOW the Marine Air Arm grew and the great part it played in defeating the Japanese is the story Capt. De Chant has to tell. And it is a great story. The fight that was made by the Wake Island squadron of twelve planes during the first eighteen days of the war and the battle against odds of the first marine fighter and bomber squadrons on Guadalcanal were unsurpassed.

A MAN without a country for five years, Louis Jouvet of the Gallic stage and screen wandered with his troupe over South and Central America during the French occupation, when he brought to Valparaiso, Guayaquil, Caracas, Haiti, Quito and cities below the Equator the ideas and words of the classic and contemporary French poets, Moliere, La Fontaine, Villon, Archard, Giraudoux and others.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Once again from the miasma of controlled information in the Soviet Union have come rumors of Stalin's illness and even of his death. As has so often been the case in the past, these rumors appear to have been highly inaccurate. But the fact remains that the Soviet leader is now 68 years old and faces the inevitable end of all mortals.

VIENNA, Jan. 31 -- New Russian proposals for settlement of the disputed economic clauses of the Austrian treaty represent, at face value, slightly more than a halving of the estimated worth of their former claims under the Potsdam clause concerning German external assets in eastern Austria.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The United States regained possession of the Lapham International Trophy today when a fifteen-man American squash racquets team defeated Canada, 15 to 5, at the Hartford Golf Club. It was the seventeenth United States victory in the twenty-seven years of squash racquets rivalry between the two countries.
The board of governors of the Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, approved last night at its annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel an $8,000,000 "Blueprint for the Future."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) -A field goal and foul by Johnny Ballots, Hazleton, Pa., sophomore, climaxed a stirring second-half Temple rally and gave the highflying Owls a 51-to-50 victory over St. John's College of Brooklyn in the second game of a basketball double-header before 3,743 at Convention Hall tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The New York State Progressive Citizens of America, in a resolution formally endorsing the third-party Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace, served notice today that few Democratic candidates for Congressional or legislative office in 1948 could hope for support from the Wallace group.

A STUDY by the Eno Foundation for highway traffic control shows that the average posted speed limit is generally ignored by the motorist even at the risk of arrest. This flouting of legal edicts is ascribed to speed limits that are too low or to the inability of most drivers to determine safe and reasonable rates.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- The Foreign Ministry instructed the Italian Ambassador to Moscow today to inform the Russian Government that if any protest was to be made over the presence of United States warships in Italian ports Italy would do it.
The stock market has reached its first testing period of 1948.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Proposed salary increases for members of the Division of State Police would make them the highest paid state troopers in the country. Provision for raising the maximums for each grade would make permanent prior emergency compensation and add new compensation. It is made in the proposed state budget.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Ford Local 600, of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, has approved compliance with the Taft-Hartley requirement that union officials must file affidavits attesting to non-membership in the Communist party.

The extent to which man has concentrated his life, his labor and his treasure in one irregular space thirtysix miles long and seventeen miles wide always reawakens a sense of aw when New York assesses anew its real property. The most valuable real estate in the world comes to $17,684,240,921 on the city's tax books this year, an increase of nearly three-quarters of a billion dollars.

PRAGUE, Jan. 30 (Delayed) -Formal charges were made today by the Socialist party and the Czech National Socialist party before the Parliamentary Security Committee that the Minister of the Interior had placed Communists in command of the police virtually from top to bottom.

The fencers of Eastern District High School of Brooklyn carried off the honors for the second year in a row in the interscholastic tournament sponsored yesterday by New York University's Washington Square College and the P.S.A.L.

Eleanor Steber appeared in the title role of Massenet's "Manon" for the first time last night at the Metropolitan, and James Melton sang Des Grieux, a role in which he had not previously been heard with the company. The opera was conducted by Wilfred Pelletier, who had not been on the podium before this season.

A continuation of high level business volume throughout industry during January was revealed here in the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, disclosed in advance of publication Feb. 4.

THE passage of the Foreign Service Act of 1946 effected so many changes in the American Foreign Service that all existing studies of our diplomatic machinery were automatically outdated. For students of government and prospective candidates for the service there was an obvious need for an analysis of the effects of the new legislation.

With product demand at an all-time high, textile manufacturers are asking themselves whether they will be prepared to meet real competitive conditions in a buyers' market which has a good possibility of developing before the end of 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -Dr. T.F. Tsiang, who was recently appointed permanent Chinese representative to the United Nations, expressed the belief today that the Nanking Government would be able to establish peace and economic order if it could get $500,000,000 a year in outside aid for the next three or four years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, today announced the conclusion of consultations with Chile on her foreign exchange budget for this year. Chile, he said, has proposed, and the Fund agreed to a program aimed at simplification of the existing multiple exchange rate system there.

GIAN-CARLO MENOTTI, who staged his short operas, "The Telephone" and "The Medium," for Broadway last season, will stage two of his other operas this spring for the New York City Opera Company. They will be "The Old Maid and the Thief" and a revised version of "Amelia Goes to the Ball."

THERE'S pleasantly diverting reading in Kathleen Wallace's latest book about a reunion at a women's college in Cambridge, England, a year after World War II has ended. The interest centers on six women, all of the same class of some twenty years before, who are anxious to forget austerity worries and recapture some carefree moments of their youth.
GENEVA, Jan. 31 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization ended its fifth session today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 31 -- Prague University students decisively defeated the Communist group in today's voting of 300 delegates of the Student Association of Prague University and other institutions of higher learning in Bohemia. A Democratic student bloc, consisting of Czech National Socialists and People's party supporters, elected twenty-six members of the board of directors to the Communists' ten and the Social Democrats' four.

The driver of a midget automobile racer and three mechanics were severely but not seriously injured at 11 o'clock last night when the racing car hurtled over a one-foot-high guide rail at the Eighth Regiment Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

Thomas Ryan, pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was heard in a program made up of Bach's "Toccata" in D. major, Beehoven's Sonata, Op. 109, Schumann's "Kreisleriana" and the Sonata by Bartok.

THIS is a biography of Katherine Conway Felton, pioneer California social worker, who organized and developed San Francisco's Children's Agency and Associated Charities to the point where they became models for other cities throughout the nation.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 31 -- Gandhi held no political office in India yet he was the most powerful figure in the Government. This slight, wrinkled, 79-year-old man in a white loin cloth, who was often called "the Architect of Free India,'' a living saint, and the greatest Indian since Buddha, seldom occupied himself with day to day affairs, but when he did he got his way.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- The same misery that was Mudville's after Casey struck out rent the heart today of fifteen young Americans who, in the words of one of them, consider themselves "fall guys for the United States Olympic Committee."

LONDON (By Wireless). LIKE all Americans I have had some impression of the vast difficulties of post-war reconstruction in Europe; of what Europeans are doing to help themselves, and of what help they are getting from beyond their borders. Since my last trip to Europe a year ago, I have had to depend on newspaper stories, statistical reports and the accounts given by returning travelers.

Putting off a decision on the Marshall Plan in the "dire extremity" the world is facing may result in aid going to Europe "too late," Senator Irving M. Ives warned last night. The junior Senator from New York predicted, however, that the differences would be resolved in Congress and a "reasonably satisfactory plan" adopted with sufficient funds to make it effective.

WASHINGTON. SELDOM in this country does the voice of the people break through the wall of professional politics and call on a major party to nominate for President one man and no other. Even then it may be silenced before the event by devices well known to the politicians. And it may be silenced by a statement from the intended beneficiary that he would not accept the nomination if tendered.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The unauthorized Jewish immigrant ships Pan York and Pan Crescent, which sailed from behind the "Iron

Baseball's currently whirling off-season will spin into its final act tonight when more than 1,400 guests, including representatives from all sixteen major league clubs as well as a host of minor leagues, will gather in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to attend the twenty-fifth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 31. -- Bobby Locke of South Africa, playing straight as an arrow from tee to green, took the lead after the third round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament today, stroking a 4-under-par 66 for a 54-hole total of 199.

THE current miniature retrospective exhibition of paintings by Matisse -- examples of his art from 1906 to 1928 -together with a show of recent work by Picasso, enables students of the modern movement to obtain new light on these two veterans of modernism.

COOKING with beer is a trick that seems to have been forgotten by American housewives. According to early cookbooks, colonial dames frequently added a tablespoonful or more of beer to give a malty tang to fish, meat and cheese dishes.

AS no doubt was inevitable, the "amateur hours" of radio have come to television in sudden profusion, the DuMont Network (WABD) having unveiled two hours of tyro talent on Sunday evenings. For the period from 7 to 8 o'clock the staff of the late Major Edward Bowes is spinning the wheel of fortune for a parade of ambitious performers, while from 5:30 to 6:30 the veteran Bob Emery comes on with his "Rainbow House."

WHEN a bidder finds himself in a bad spot, the laws always permit him to pass, and very often that is the best and cheapest thing he can do. This theory seems hard to put into practice, though. Some of the most dangerous bids are based on sheer fright.

The average hunter, especially the one who gets in at least one annual deer and bear hunt, is slow to change, but anyone who has done much tramping in the woods during the past season must have noted the great increase in the use of telescope sights.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 -- With a burst of speed in the final strides, Flashco whipped favored On Trust and eleven other rivals in the first running of the $128,500 Santa Anita Maturity Stakes today.
Drama, film and literary critic in Berlin for twenty-five years, now teaching in Columbia University's English Department.

MARSEILLE, France, Jan. 31 -Interim aid shipments to Marseille, France's largest port, are being handled as efficiently as the war-damaged state of the port's facilities will allow, according to a survey completed tonight. Goods made available under the United States dollar grant plan are being forwarded rapidly to industrial consumers, and very little is reaching the black market.

America's power has imposed upon it responsibilities and isolationism no longer is possible, Admiral Thomas C. Kincaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, said last night. He spoke at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel marking the installation of Rabbi Charles E. Shulman as spiritual leader of the Riverdale Temple, 246th Street and Riverdale Avenue.

Your editorial "Schooling for Government" in THE TIMES of Jan. 25 is most welcome to all teachers and practitioners of public administration. Government has become so important in our lives in modern times that every encouragement is needed for the expansion of training outstanding young men and women for the public service.

Dr. T.Z. Koo of China, secretary of the World's Student Christian Federation, will be principal speaker at a dinner at 6:15 P.M. Tuesday at the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, opening a Brooklyn drive for a total contribution Of $65,000 to the 1948 Protestant Fund, according to announcement yesterday by Walter Bruchhausen, Brooklyn campaign committee chairman.

ED WYNN started a night club engagement the other day and Broadway was bathed in sentiment. It was an honest sentiment, an honest nostalgia for an age that is in temporary decline, the age of the clown.

A new mathematical compass to guide physicists in the dark jungles of the nucleus of the atom, promising to lead them to hitherto forbidden domains of knowledge concerning the innermost workings of the material universe, was given yesterday at the annual New York meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University by Prof. Julian Schwinger of Harvard University.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 31 -- A resolution approving universal military training and calling for the creation of a new Cabinet post to formulate a "sound national policy" was passed today at the final session of the annual conference of the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.

DAMASCUS, Jan. 31 -- The big overriding United States interest in the Middle East is oil. Recently much has been heard about the trans-Arabian pipeline which was supposed to be finished early in 1950, but is being held up by the failure of the Syrian Parliament to ratify the transit agreement.

WHAT may prove a direct hit, a stratagem, or a dud, is the news coming from the American Booksellers Association. "In an effort to cope with growing competition from book clubs," the ABA announces, it is starting a plan to lease plates on certain major titles of publishers in order to 'print, bind, distribute and to some degree advertise the title."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 31. -- Backers of Harold Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, avowed today that they could win the pledged support of at least ten of the fiftythree delegates to be elected from the Buckeye State in the Republican primary balloting on May 4.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Leaders of the MacArthur-for-President movement profess to see no setback for their cause as a result of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement that "nothing in the international or domestic situation especially qualifies for the most important office in the world a man whose adult years have been spent in the country's military forces."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31 -Ahead virtually all the way and enjoying a 15-point spread midway in the second half, Army's basketball team weathered a late surge by the University of Maryland to defeat the Terrapins, 48 -- 44 today.

The assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi, 78-year-old Hindu leader in India, was listed as one of the year's outstanding news events at a current events quiz, conducted yesterday by the Youth Forum, which is sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 31 (AP) -George Fischer of Chicago took a commanding lead in his quest for the men's senior title in the first day of the national outdoor speedskating championships today.

YOUR critic last week took the public to task for failing to offer a nod of encouragement to the late, not too lamented "The Survivors," and for flocking instead to "Strange Bedfellows." As a member of this general grouping, the "public," I take strong exception to the remark.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 31 -Navy turned back a favored Bucknell quintet, 51 -- 36, today with a strong second half surge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Residents of states north of the Missouri and Ohio Rivers and on the Atlantic Seaboard are now enduring one of the best forecasted fuel oil shortages. In midsummer and even before that, Government and oil industry spokesmen were saying that only a mild winter would stave off such trouble.

Many types of heating and ventilating equipment will be shown at the five-day Air Conditioning Exposition which opens at 2 P.M. tomorrow in Grand Central Palace. Known as the Eighth International Heating and Ventilating Exposition, the dispaly will be staged in conjunction with the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers in the Hotel Commodore.

Mahatma Gandhi went on his last journey yesterday in a funeral car strewn with roses, through a rain of flowers from balconies and roof-tops. The people who loved him had thronged the grounds of Birla House during the night and they pressed tumultuously all along the lines of the slow-moving , funeral procession and into the heat of the flames from the burning ghat on the bank of the Jumna.

REMY, the pseudonym of one of the first and most successful of General de Gaulle's spies, belongs to the school of memoirists who write historical novels in reverse. Instead of making fiction seem like history, he makes history seem like fiction.

Highly prized imperial Chinese white jade carvings, Chinese ceramics and other Oriental art objects from several collections will be auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh St.
Twenty-five per cent of the 206 candidates who took the physical examination for policewomen at the Municipal Civil Service office, 299 Broadway, yesterday were estimated to have passed the tests.

THE valuable new material Helen Landreth has unearthed in the Irish State Paper Office in Dublin Castle has enabled her to tell for the first time the true story of Robert Emmet's pathetic rebellion in 1803.

Although their operations and earnings are running at record levels for peacetime while their backlog of orders remains undiminished, steel companies last week exhibited real pessimism over their problems of labor and materials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Republicans in Congress and outside it are developing or sharpening many points of intra-party friction, and the causes for this are both plain and usual in the circumstances.

MRS. FERRO'S novel is too neat to be true. You feel that it might have been blue-printed with a ruler and a compass and assembled on an adding machine: reality is scaled down to the size of a digit. But if the method is cold, the good-will is warm.

Poland feels that all major economic problems should be dealt with through the United Nations, Dr. Oscar Lange, Polish delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, said yesterday at LaGuardia field on his arrival from Paris after a two-month stay in Poland.

Last week in France was a week of finance and politics. The Schuman Government -- an uneasy coalition of Catholic Popular Republicans, Socialists and other groups in the so-called Third Force -- put into effect a drastic devaluation of the franc. The Government's action was taken over objections by the forty-six-nation International Monetary Fund, of which France is a member, and by Great Britain.

Extremely cold weather hampered retail trade here last week but volume held to about previous rates of gain over last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 5 per cent over 1947. Calls for winter apparel increased.

Even under the disadvantage of being hung next door to two rooms full of Picasso's latest paintings Theodoros Stamos' new show at the Betty Parsons Gallery casts its own particular spell. It is a narrow, precarious piece of enchantment, occasionally precious, often contrived, but for all that imaginative and personal.

One evening a little over 25 years ago, a group of Washington notables were having dinner at Friendship, the home of the late Evelyn Walsh McLean. Two of the guests appeared particularly distraught and, to Mrs. McLean's anxious inquiry, responded that their daughter, a girl in her middle teens, was on the verge of a diabetic coma and it was only a question of time.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- Contrary to initial indications, the new Bizonal Economic Administration to be proclaimed in a few days not only will have superior powers to those originally given to the present Economic Council but also will operate on a broader jurisdictional base.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- India's delegates to the United Nations were anxiously awaiting instructions from New Delhi last night on how to go ahead with the drawn-out Kashmir case in the light of upsets at home caused by the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- Sixteen proposals designed to speed rehabilitation of Japan's export cotton trade are being carried to Washington by the American cotton mission brought here at Gen. MacArthur's request.

JOHN ROBERT MIZE is a large, phlegmatic individual who is mild-mannered and not easy to know. Stanley Raymond Harris is a medium-sized, friendly individual whom strangers are inclined to address as "Hiya, Bucky" in the initial greeting. They are singularly contrasting personalities and the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association will pay tribute to them at its silver anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria tonight.
NEWARK, Del., Jan. 31 (UP) -- The University of Delaware today followed the initiative of the University of Arkansas and voluntarily lowered its barriers against admission of Negro students.

Part of the greatness of Orville Wright -- the first man to make a sustained flight in a heavier-than-air machine -- was that he never aspired to be, nor did he pretend to be, anything more than he was: a first-rate mechanic with imagination. Which is not to detract one whit from his stature in the history of aviation.

THE negotiations that customarily occur at this time of the year, regarding players' contracts for the next season, are now in process between the Philharmonic-Symphony Society and the American Federation of Musicians of this city.

IMMERSING Greer Garson in a bubble bath might come under the heading of mere routine for Cecil Blount De Mille, who is accustomed to staging such spectacles with frequent abandon. However, at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, where the sight of Miss Garson attractively arrayed in a few million modestly translucent bubbles, is definitely not routine, the opening sequence for "Julia Misbehaves" was filmed the other day in an atmosphere slightly tinged with self-conscious awe.
ATHENS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- All questions regarding the prosecution of warfare against the guerrillas were not settled at today's meeting of the Defense Council.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., is proud of its musical set up. Thanks to the cooperation of a music federation and the town's recreation department, which share the expenses, the community of 45,000 supports a symphony orchestra, a band, a civic chorus, a glee club and a mandolin orchestra, besides providing music scholarships for deserving students.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 31 -- The British planted a six-pounder cannon and a three-inch mortar in Jerusalem today to put an abrupt end to the incessant sniping between the Jewish Yemin Moshe quarter and the Arab villages near by.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Governor Dewey was told today by the president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards that the increase in the constitutional real estate property tax limit proposed by Mayor O'Dwyer for New York City would result in a 25 per cent tax increase to all home owners of the state.
Without religious faith there can be no successful United Nations, Dr. Leo Baeck, leader of German Jews during the Hitler era, told a congregation of refugees here yesterday.

Now that the United Nations, through UNESCO, has taken an interest in the kind of history taught in the member rations, there is talk of efforts to revise sentiments about the past in the interest of world peace and understanding.

A dollar spent today for new construction has a purchasing power of under 52 cents when compared with the 1935-39 period, according to The Lamp, the official publication of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.).

If the record Board of Education budget sent last week to Mayor O'Dwyer is approved, New York City will provide its 850,000 elementary and high school pupils with one of the best educational programs in recent years. Many far-reaching innovations, designed to strengthen the city's school system, are included in the 1948-49 budget.

Seeds for growing a kind of tree that thrived 100,000,000 years ago and was long thought extinct have been received by the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University. To save this rare botanical discovery, the Arboretum will plant some seeds itself and mail some for planting to botanical gardens throughout the country.

Moderate-priced retail dress departments were busy last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Millinery departments were reported doing well in the report, which added that petticoat sections were drawing attention in the lingerie departments and that children's and infants' wear activity was very good.

Continuing the splendid teamwork that has kept them in the ranks of the unbeaten this season, the Squadron A Regulars rode to their seventh straight success last night by topping the New York A.C., 13 -- 12, in a New York division match last night in the Metropolitan High Goal League indoor polo championship tournament at the Squadron A Armory.

LITTLE Fu, son of a merchant in northern China, makes a trip down the Min River to Foochow. The boat shoots the rapids, runs afoul of bandits, and lands safely at its destination. On the way Little Fu hears a professional teller of tales, takes a hand with an oar, sees a lantern festival and goes to a circus in Foochow.
