Harold Edward Stassen was three times Governor of Minnesota; a Navy commander during World War II; an American delegate to the San Francisco conference which set up the United Nations. In foreign affairs he is a Republican "internationalist" (he favors the Marshall Plan, once advocated a world parliament).

PEIPING, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -Current trends in Sinkiang indicate that the predominantly non-Chinese population of China's largest and most remote province, goaded by misrule and enticed to some extent by realistic Soviet propaganda, is moving toward allegiance with the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 -- California's protracted drought, one of the worst in its history, this week brought a wide enough variety of repercussions. The hiatus in rainfall rounded out five weeks in most sections of the state and more in some districts.
Although fluctuations in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange were within a narrow range, final prices were 1 to 12 points net lower than the day before.

DERRY, N.H. -- Venturesome winter tourists looking for something unusual in cold weather entertainment are journeying to Beaver Lake near here where trotting horse races on ice are held every Sunday afternoon and holidays, weather permitting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Key House Democrats agreed today on a tax reduction proposal to be offered Monday as a substitute for the Republican-backed Knutson bill.

In this attractive book Theodore Spencer reprints the greater part of two previously published collections, "The Paradox in the Circle" and "An Act of Life," amplifying these with several new poems. The result is exciting. One finds corroboration of one's earlier estimate of Mr. Spencer as a lyrist: at his best he writes with intelligence and a kind of mentem-mortalia-tangunt humanity; with a saving wit also; the verses go into one's mind, and stay there.

THREE of these volumes are the advance guard of a travel manual series scheduled to appear during the current year under the direction of Lowell Brentano. Long a publisher of travel books. Brentano brings to this venture a sound knowledge of the demands of readers.

Prokofieff's Second Piano Concerto, which was first played here in February, 1930, with the composer as the pianist, by the Boston Symphony, was performed last night by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with Zadel Skolovsky, Canadian-American pianist, as soloist.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- A wage increase of at least $800 a year was urged for all Federal employes in a statement approved today by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 31 -- Another "drought" scare is sweeping across Kansas. Rather than parched fields, it is the possibility of parched throats that causes alarm in this pre-election season. With a popular vote on the repeal of Kansas' prohibition law barely ten months away, there is unprecedented news in nearly a century of Kansas liquor legislation -- the state's Attorney General has moved to enforce the widely flouted dry law.

Canon Bernard Iddings Bell lists among the chief activities of "most of God's children" the "tending of machines." Yet, the Canon Bells of two centuries ago might have thought such occupation beyond the potential of the majority.

THERE were lively doings at Reads Landing, Minn., in 1875. As if it were not enough excitement having a father who owned one of the fastest freight boats on the river, and hunting and trapping every day, Timothy became involved in a couple of mysteries, had an adventure with wolves and ran into river pirates.

THE first volume of the letters of Rilke covered the years from 1892, when he was 17, to 1910. The present collection ends eight days before his death in December, 1926. These two fine books from the pen of the great Czech poet will inspire readers and transport them to a lost world.

More than twenty manufacturers are now taking steps to revise their pricing and packaging methods by adopting new systems which will drastically cut costs of distribution, reduce risks of handling speculative products, eliminate small order losses for distributors and stabilize the dealer profit potentials of their lines, a canvas here revealed yesterday.

In addition to having completed recently two projects with a total of 1,946 apartments, the New York City Housing Authority now has a construction schedule calling for 32,808 more apartments to rent for $12.50 a room and less. Thomas F. Farrell, chairman, reported yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 31 -Cattle, sheep and hogs destined for Hollywood dinner tables now make the 821-mile rail trip from Ogden and Salt Lake to Los Angeles in streamlined style. For the Union Pacific Railroad has been placing roller-bearing cattle cars in service at a rapid rate.

The stock market plodded yesterday through another listless two-hour session with an irregularly higher trend for prices, although trading slumped to the lightest volume since early last November. Alterations in values were small in either direction and interest again was centered in the oils and rails.

THE fortunes of the United Artists Distributing Company, which have been at a low ebb for the last six months, are improving materially, according to present indications. Two independent productions destined for U.A. release have gone before the cameras, ending a long dry spell during which the company's contributors have been inactive.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- With Gaye Stewart collecting four points for two goals and as many assists, the lowly Chicago Black Hawks gained their fourth straight National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins, 7-4, tonight before 13,200 spectators at Boston Garden.

THE question at issue is this: whether or not the first azld last requisite of art is to give no offense; whether or not all that caa!not be lisped in the nursery or fingered in the schoolroom is therefore to be cast out of the library; whether or not the domestic circle is to be for all men and writers the outer limit and extreme horizon of their world of work.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Officials of Rockland Lodge 329. Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, announced tonight a two-month postponement of a strike by 177 bus drivers of five affiliated companies operating in Rockland County and Bergen County, N.J., scheduled for 12:01 tomorrow morning.

A GROUP of well-known radio and stage comedians will do a reversal on their usual casting by performing in serious roles from Shakespeare, Rostand, Ibsen and other great dramatists in a new series of recorded dramatic presentations scheduled to have its debut this afternoon at 4 o'clock on WNEW.

STILL holding its breath for the congested spring season which threatens, the dance world this week has nothing at all to offer in any of the downtown halls and theatres. There is, nevertheless, plenty to go to if you are of a mind to do so, as the following calendar will indicate:

ACCORDING to the almanac, the first day of spring falls on March 20, but whether the season will be advanced or the season will be advanced delayed cannot now be determined. In the meantime, gardens that have been planned for year-round interest display an exciting succession of small early blooms.

The Brooklyn project to send supplies to Breukelen, in the Netherlanls, will be discussed Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by the sponsor, the Brooklyn Heights Garden Club of 101 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- For the fourth time in eight months, Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, Ga., the national amateur champion, defeated her clubmate, Dorothy Kirby, in winning the sixteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty golf tournaments by 5 and 4 here today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The possibility of planting and exploding tiny atom bombs within living human bodies to wipe out localized concentrations of disease has been raised by experiments of that kind on animals.

Prof. Irwin Edman, head of Columbia University's philosophy department, will open a series of ten orientation lectures designed to acquaint members of the United Nations secretariat with American life and culture, it was announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31 -Luis Carlos Prestes, head of the Brazilian Communists, has issued a manifesto attacking the army and judiciary, causing political leaders to demand that Deputy Pedro Pomar, who is chief editor of Tribuna Popular, Communist newspaper, be dismissed from Congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- John L. Lewis was eloquently silent today.

FOR THIS WEEK: Watch out for damage from mice. Seeking shelter this snowy winter, they will eat stored summer flowering bulbs and tulips that have been potted for forcing unless they have been protected with small mesh screens. . . . Sow the fine seeds of such flowers as begonias and lobelia. Vermiculite is a satisfactory medium. . . . Broken branches of zh, rTb8 are good forcing material.
Robert Grant 3d, former national amateur racquets champion, came back into the picture yesterday as the top man once again in one of the fastest of all bat and ball games.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- This sky-bound (8,600 feet altitude) capital is working overtime these days -- with the usual two hours out for lunch and siesta -- setting the stage for the ninth Pan American Conference, now scheduled for the end of March.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31 -- The political tempo has reached a high pitch in Nebraska as Republicans head for their pre-primary convention on Feb. 17 to endorse candidates for delegates to the national convention.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The University of Michigan took the Western Conference basketball leadership tonight by trouncing Northwestern, 53 -- 37, before 7,000 fans.

AMONG those present at the time of the murder is Nigel Strangeways, who is holding down a wartime job in the visual propaganda division of the Ministry of Morale in London. (The V.P.D. is an entirely imaginary organization, but who cares?) Nita Prince, secretary to the director of V. P. D., is [voisoned in the office of the director while seven permorm are looking on.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- The heads of the delegations to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment decided today to appoint a coordination committee ti seek compromise on issues that still deadlock the conference.
"PERENNIALS THROUGHOUT THE SEASONS" will be discussed by Anne B. Wertsner at the third meeting of the midwinter garden course at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, this Wednesday at 2:30 P.M.

AN impressive number of new varieties appear in 1948 catalogues. Some have already been singled out for All-America Selections awards and other honors, but the catalogues still contain others deserving of special notice.

ALTHOUGH these two books cover virtually the same ground, the treatment in each case is quite different. The in troduction to "Traditionally Pennsylvania Dutch," covering Pennsylvania folkways, is pleasantly written and not lacking in appreciation.
In a quick recovery from the shock of having two ring prospects collapse before his eyes, Sol Strauss, director of the Twentieth Century S.C., yesterday improvised two attractive ring matches.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 31 (AP) -- There will be no change in the operation of the Philadelphia Phillies because of the death of Herb Pennock nor any haste to replace him as general manager, President Bob Carpenter said tonight.

A HUNDRED years ago this month there appeared from an obscure printing shop in the Bishopsgate section of London, England, a twenty-three-page pamphlet. Its dark green title page did not carry the name of the author, the then comparatively unknown "Citizen Karl Marx," as the fiery, full-bearded young man of 29 was called by his fellow-exiles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Warning that black market men were already creeping into the channels of meat supply, a spokesman for one of the Big Four meat packers denounced today proposals to restore meat rationing, even though he saw still higher prices in the coming months.

Coincident with the heaviest snows this part of the country has had in many years, Norway has sent seven skiers to the United States for a sixweeks' good-will tour of the East. Reidar Andersen, one of the greatest stylists in ski-jumping history, who swept everything in North America on a previous visit in 1939, leads the Norwegian unit known as "Snoballen," or the Snowball Ski Club.

THERE is a wealth of good reading in this volume of stories, poems, essays and criticism, and an adventurous glimpse into modern literary Britain. In selecting widely from the "little reviews" that have been multiplying like mushrooms on the British Isles, Mr. Baker has gotten a large cross-section of creative and critical writing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 -Princeton University's varsity basketball team won its fifth consecutive game tonight, routing Rutgers, 63 -- 38. It was the largest margin of victory the Tigers have rolled up this season. The visiting Scarlet had decisively trounced Princeton, 65 -- 53, in their previous meeting.

EUROPEANS are frequently puzzled by the American literacy scene. They find it difficult to determine whom we ourselves consider to be our best writers, and why. Just how, they wonder, is the status of these writers arrived at? The Irish novelist, Sean O'Faolain, best known here for his short stories and his fine novel, "A Nest of Simple Folk," has something to say about this confusion in the current issue of The Virginia Quarterly Review.

ARCHAEOLOGISTS are turning their attention again to ancient Iraq. There, 7,000 years ago, man began to develop many of the social institutions and techniques that mold our modern way of life. The mounds of Iraq have yielded important treasure, but the story of man's progress toward civilization is far from complete.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- The American Library Association today announced its "four year goals," a four-point program to bring libraries and their staffs to maximum effectiveness in contributing to the solution of the problems facing America in an atomic age.

LOUIS DE LINC (alias Delinc-Matous, alias Dellinick) was born somewhere in, Central Europe, started visiting night club singers before his high school classmates knew what it was all about, and wore elevator shoes although he was tall.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 31 -- An engineer's technical knowledge of science and engineering must be supplemented with a knowledge of men and organizations to meet the critical production needs of the world today, George A. Stetson, editor of Mechanical Engineering, official publication of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, told the graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology in the midwinter commencement this morning.

THE second performance in the Ballet Society's subscription series on the evening of Feb. 9 at the City Center will be an all-Balanchine program. The main feature of the bill will be the premiere of "The Triumph of Bacchus and Ariadne" with music by Vittorio Rieti and settings and costumes by Corrado Cagli.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- New party New party lines are being drawn in preparation for the next general election, which almost all Japanese commentators are predicting for next spring.
Last Aug. 15 Britain's 200-year rule of India ended. Two new states were born -- states loosely linked to the British Commonwealth by voluntary dominion ties.

LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 31 -- The three Benelux nations, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, issued here today a carefully worded acknowledgment of British Foreign Secretary Bevin's invitation for partnership in a union of western European nations.

THE Passport Division of the State Department issued 202,424 passports during 1947, the second largest number issued and renewed in the history of the division, which goes back to 1914. According to the report of Mrs. Ruth B. Shipley, director of the Passport Division, 1930 was the peak year for that office, with 203,174 passports issued and renewed.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, representing sixty-eight teachers' groups in New York City, and the New York Teachers Guild, Local 2, AFL, joined other organizations yesterday in protesting the Governor's Special Education Committee report.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Five major recommendations were made tonight by a special subcommittee of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs in a study of voluntary foreign aid.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Three long shots -- Master Bid, Love Sonnet and Ned Luck-showed the way home as named in today's Bougainvillea Handicap while a stunned crowd of 18,148 saw Frere Jacques finish last on his favorite turf course, even with Ted Atkinson on his back.

Citrus-fruit growers were among the first to use smudge pots to protect their trees from killing frost. A.W. Farrall, head of the Agricultural Engineering Department of Michigan State College, thought the smudge pot could be greatly improved upon and so, with the assistance of his colleagues, Clarence M. Hansen, W.H. Sheldon and F.J. Hassler, he designed what he called a "frost fighter" to save such high-value crops as strawberries, flowers and fruit.

REUBEN DOWNS loved horses. He helped his father operate a livery stable in Cambridge a century ago. When his father was placed in jail because of debts, Reuben became embroiled with the jailer and barely escaped. He fled to Concord, found employment in a stable, and finally won spectacular acclaim as an employe of the hated railroad.

The greatest peacetime air search of the Atlantic continued in vain yesterday northeast and east of Bermuda as more than a score of military and commercial aircraft searched for survivors of the British South American Airways plane that disappeared early Friday morning.

EVERGREENS, though considered to be extremely slow-growing plants, sometimes startle us with their increase in size. Later in the summer, when an open and balanced effect is especially wanted, the heavy and untidy growth made by some of them becomes oppressive.

The current focusing of attention on meat prices as an avenue of approach to the solution of inflation is both logical and within the realm of possibility. However, both the nature and the effectiveness of the solution that may eventually be reached depends not only on the definition of the problem, but also on a thorough awareness of how and why meat occupies a key position.

A NEW American camera is to be introduced to the public this evening at the exhibition, "Photography on Parade," at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The show is sponsored by the Photographic Manufacturers and Distributors Association, Inc., and it will inaugurate a series of annual events.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- Following a general primary election that set balloting records for Louisiana and this city, the state's largest, the voters are preparing to choose a new Governor in a run-off primary on Feb. 24.

MONTREAL, Jan. 31 -- The New York Rangers outlasted the Montreal Canadiens in a closely-fought game at the Forum tonight, 4 -- 2, to bolster their grip on third place in the National Hockey League. The loss kept the Canadiens in fifth place, 2 points behind the Boston Bruins.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- Twin Star, skippered by Lockwood M. Pirie of the Sheridan Shore Yacht Club of Chicago, won the first race of the Bacardi Cup series this morning as the seventeenth international Star Class yacht regatta began. Twin Star's time for the course was 1:57:48.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- New England's snow drifts melted little this week, but the warm reception given to Harold E. Stassen, avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, did much to thaw out political thinking.

The University of Minnesota has inaugurated a program of business teacher training for the winter quarter on both the undergraduate and graduate levels. The program combines basic courses in the school of business administration and professional courses in education and business education offered by the College of Education.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -Everton fought its way into the fifth round of the Football Association cup and Arsenal maintained its strong position atop the English League's first division in the highlight fixtures of today's British soccer card.

IT really is amazing, when you stop to give it some thought, how very important music and musicians are to the screen and yet what crude abominations have often been fostered in their name. We are not speaking now of music as it is used to establish mood, the so-called "background" music which rumbles or sighs in critical scenes and swells to triumphant crescendos when the final clinch or clairvoyance is achieved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The War Assets Administration reported today that it has disposed of more than three-fourths of the $28,297,784,000 worth of Government surplus property.

THANKS to John Garfield's durable good-will, the Experimental Theatre's production of "Skipper Next to God" has set up shop at the Playhouse for a philanthropic run for the benefit of the quixotic American National Theatre and Academy.

Immediately after the atomic bomb was tested in 1945 Dr. C.A. Tobias and Dr. John Lawrence of the University of California, Berkeley, Calif., decided to find out what happened after uranium was planted deep within living tissue and split. Colloidal uranium oxide enriched with radioactive uranium 235 was injected into white mice.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- The new Iraqi Government will do everything possible to prevent the partition of Palestine, Hamdi Pachachi, Minister of Foreign Affairs, said today.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 31 -- It was learned today that the United Nations Commission on Korea will adopt a resolution outlining the failure to implement the United Nations resolution on Korea in face of the Russian refusal to cooperate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- The price of gift items is up 5 to 10 per cent on the average compared with six months ago, Wallace A. Ollman, general manager of the Merchandise Mart, said today in advance of the two-week gift show and china, glass and pottery market opening at the Mart tomorrow.

THE search for a "Winslow Boy," to appear with Robert Donat and Margaret Leighton in Alexander Korda's screen version of Terence Rattigan's play, is drawing to a close. The other day at the London Film Studios at Worton Hall, director Anthony Asquith, producer Anatol de Grunwald, and the author himself, were testing the final dozen candidates, and exhibiting, it appeared, marked signs of strain.

The willingness of investment bankers to hold municipal bonds of major new issues in inventory until "accumulating investment funds" can absorb them is being written off in Wall Street as a thing of the past as the tax-free yields on high-grade, long-term municipal obligations continue to approach the yield basis at which the market for high-grade taxable corporate bonds seems to be stabilized momentarily.

The Dowager Marchioness of Reading will be guest of honor at a tea to be given Tuesday afternoon in the home of Mrs. Guy Fairfax Cary, 61 East Ninety-first Street, by the officers and board of directors of the AWVS Personal Parcels Service Unit.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- Bettors who ilke a front-runner are backing Earl K. Long to be Louisiana's next Governor, but the players who study the "form" are not so sure.

AN all-metal 5-by-7 automatic focusing enlarger, the Automega E-3, which takes negatives from 5 by 7 inches to 2 1/4 by 3 1/4 and uses a fluorescent lamp, was introduced last week by Simmon Brothers. The enlarger allows for interchange-ability of three lenses, which have focal lengths from 7 1/2 to 3 1/2 inches.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 31 -Syria declared her "financial independence" today by quitting the French franc bloc after the collapse of the negotiations with France and Lebanon.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- In grief and anxiety over the future of their riven native land, Indians in London paid final homage today to Mohandas K. Gandhi. Thousands attended a Hindu memorial service whose oriental ritual seemed both exotic and poignant in the stolid gray Anglo-Saxon surroundings of midtown London.

Summing up opinions voiced in a three-day symposium on "Human Relations in Science and Practice" conducted by the Community Service Society of New York. Dr. Stanley P. Davies, general manager of the society, called yesterday for a merging of the knowledge and technical skills of the research scientist with those of the social work practitioner.
A 42-year-old policeman was in a serious condition last night in the Norwegian Hospital, Brooklyn, after being stabbed by a 23-year-old longshoreman whom he asked to stop smoking in a bus.

MOST of the groups that came to America to escape religious persecution or social discrimination have lost their identity in the melting and fusing processes that are continually in operation in this country. Tucked away in a corner of the rich, rolling farm land of Lancaster County in Pennsylvania is a sect that retains its group individuality and still adheres to basic religious doctrines set down in the seventeenth century.

President Truman's unexpected replacement of Marriner S. Eccles as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board last week caught the financial community almost completely by surprise. With the possible exception of a few insiders, bankers had had no inkling that Mr. Eccles would be asked to step down from the chairmanship in favor of the Philadelphia Republican, Thomas Bayard McCabe, banker and paper manufacturer.

Record cold brought suffering to thousands in heatless homes in the fuel-hungry East yesterday. The sick and the aged were the hardest hit in homes where there had been no heat in many days. At least one death was reported.

Involved in the Marshall Plan for European recovery is the establishment of a distribution system through which virtually all the petroleum requirements of Continental Europe outside the sphere of Russian influence, as well as of the United Kingdom and North Africa, would be supplied from the Middle East fields.

IN 1840 two singular men were born. The Welshman was baptized John Rowlands, the Prussian Edouard Schnitzer, but each is known to history by a name not his own. Rowlands, an immigrant in New Orleans, served with both the Confederate Army and the Union Navy, adopted the name of a benefactor, and as "Henry M. Stanley" became the world-famous correspondent of The New York Herald, African explorer, and "rescuer" of Dr. Livingstone.

BACK in 1933, in the throes of economic crisis, this country ventured into a vast publicownership project known as the Tennessee Valley Authority. Thirteen years later the nation had to consider a state-owned monopoly even more stupendous in size, fearful in its political and military implications.

When President Truman, Stalin and Winston Churchill attended a state dinner in Berlin during the Potsdam Conference they were entertained by two young American musicians in uniform. The pianist was Eugene List, then a sergeant. The violinist was an obscure private named Stuart Canin.

Mayor O'Dwyer, in an effort to put teeth into the voluntary fuel oil allocation program, assigned several thousand policemen and other city employes last night to ride delivery trucks and check on the industry's cooperation.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -- A funeral pyre of sandalwood bearing the rose-covered earthly remains of Mohandas K. Gandhi was set alight by his son on the banks of the holy Jumna River this afternoon at 5 o'clock. It was twenty-four hours, almost to the minute, after an assassin's bullets had shot down India's great leader as he was on his way to prayer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Truman, in a statement today, called upon distillers to continue voluntarily for the time being the limiting of their use of grain to the 2,500,000 bushels a month set by law for January. He specifically asked them not to use wheat in the making of whisky.

IN blunt, forthright phrases private flying was warned last week that it will have to cut down its accident rate if it hopes to survive, much less to grow to be the giant some private fliers think it is destined to become. The watched private flying for many years and usually backs up his words with battalions of statistics.

A book by Dr. Hans Thirring explains why the Germans spent research-time and money on V-missiles rather than on atomic bombs. The book is entitled "Die Geschichte der Atom-bombe," and it is published in Vienna. Thirring makes much of the difference between the American and the German conception of atomic bombs.

New York's first city-wide register, Henry W. Ralph, 61 years old, of 161-12 Eighty-fourth Drive, Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday morning in Queens General Hospital of injuries suffered in an automobile accident.

While most Hollywood producers are anxious to improve the quality of their productions, the public repeatedly has shown it will not support, always, expensive motion pictures produced purely from an artistic standpoint, industry spokesmen told members of the United Teachers Association of New York yesterday.

OTTAWA, Ill., Jan. 31 -- Two powerful Mississippi River towboats, driving in tandem with 5,600 horsepower behind a steel barge fitted as a battering ram, have cut a narrow path through the worst ice in the Illinois River in twelve years.

SOME weeks ago Mr. J.B. Priestley came through New York and when he got back to you he did a talk about it. As I read Mr. Priestley's talk I sighed and chuckled and moaned, "Ah, how true" (I am a lip-reader), and whenever he generalized about the character of the city I groaned.

CAPT. FRANK SWIFT originator of the Windjammer Cruises along the Maine coast during the summer months, has come up with a new idea for winter vacations in Florida in the form of a week-long shanty boat cruise on little-known inland waterways through the picturesque Seminole country.

THIS little book assembles the ripe judgments of the leading living authority on what is often termed the most important event in modern times. The French Revolution has evoked an immense literature: the Widener Library at Harvard, for instance, has more books on the quarter century beginning in 1789 than on the remaining fifteen centuries of French history.
DIGNE, France, Jan. 31 (AP) -The only survivor among twenty-two Americans in two United States plane crashes in the Alps today credited a German prisoner of war with having saved his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Sponsors of the 1948 tax reduction bill are promoting it as a "tax equalization" measure as well, because its enactment would end the income-tax advantage enjoyed for years by married couples living in states having community-property laws.

MRS. SENECA WIBBLE, the richest and most troublesome member of Martin Buell's new parish at Farrington, Col., disapproves of Buell because he is high church. Buell disapproves of Mrs. Wibble on general principles and is determined not to be dominated by her.

MR. FAURE'S third novel is a retelling of the Lady Godiva story in the spirit of the Nineteen Twenties, of the first wave of popular Freudianism, of the debunking biographies of that period, and of novels like John Erskine's "Galahad" and "The Private Life of Helen of Troy."

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 31 -California's Democratic hierarchy, long ridden with dissension, patched up its differences today to the extent of agreeing on a Truman-pledged ticket of national convention delegates to be put on the Presidential primary ballot of June 1.

INYOKERN, Calif., Jan. 31 -The Navy Bureau of Ordnance in a guarded announcement today disclosed that an aerial missile powered by a ram-jet engine had "far exceeded" the speed of sound, 760 miles an hour, on its first test flight at the desert test station here.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The effect of Gandhi's death is bound to be tremendous. Great social forces were instantaneously released as if they were held in catapults.

According to a report released last week, veterans are receiving inadequate counseling and are failing to make full use of their educational opportunities. The report, made by Dr. Louis Long, director of vocational guidance at City College, and Dr. Frederick J. Gaudet of the Stevens Institute of Technology, says that ex-service men are in some cases misled by "quack" counseling agencies.

THERE is no more extraordinary episode in the whole range of modern history than the brief life and the martyrdom of Joan of Arc. The subject has time and again tempted historians, biographers, epic or mock-epic poets, dramatists.

Having completed spring purchasing and amply filled stocks, buyers last week were hesitant about making additional commitments, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.
If there were any doubt about the temperatures we have been experiencing, the thermometer readings could have been roughly checked by watching the rhododendrons.

ATHENS, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Constantine Ventiris, commander of Greece's Northern Army, the major force fighting the guerrilla rebels, was removed from his command today by the acceptance of his resignation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The merits of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project, a subject of controversy for more than half a century, are being considered again in Congress, but prospects are considered slim that there will be a final determination in this election year.

THE Butlin English Holiday Camps, a thriving vacation institution in Great Britain since 1936, is to be transplanted to the United States. William "Billy" Butlin, England's amusement park and resort magnate, was in New York last week laying plans for a Butlin Vacation Village to be built on a 500-600-acre tract somewhere between Miami and Falm Beach, Fla.

Walker Lowry's article, "Communism to the South of Us," is interesting but, in some respects, untrue. No doubt his recent experiences in Ecuador and Central America colored his report. I, who lived only in Argentina, Uruguay and Cuba, cannot place these nations against the terrifying background of poverty, ignorance and backwardness he describes.

THE current literary fashion of telling all about one or another of the more alluring trades now covers the publishing business. In "The Gilded Hearse" there is wholesale tattle on an office full -- and a very luxurious office, too -- of dull vulgarians and total abstainers from decency.

TWENTY-EIGHT years have passed since Hermann Hesse, who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1946, wrote "Demian." In the early Twenties -- a time when World War I was still a traumatic experience, when reason seemed bankrupt, and Freud's investigations were, to some persons, eloquent witness to the inadequacy of the old truths -- this brief, bewitching and bewitched novel created a deep stir among young intellectuals in Europe and even in America.

Scrap yards may soon have claimed all but three of the twenty-three transports built for World War I, ending the saga of what was claimed to be the world's largest fleet of standard passenger liners, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WANDA LANDOWSKA is a great musician because she goes far beyond the notes printed on paper. As a harpsichordist she deals with music that is centuries old and that does not contain comprehensive instructions for performance as composers nearer our own time chose to set it down.

THE Third Annual National High School Photographic Awards contest, sponsored by Eastman Kodak Company, starts tomorrow, ends May 7. Cash prizes totaling $3,500 are offered to high-school students in the United States for pictures in five classifications: (1) school activities; (2) informal pictures of people, young or old; (3) scenes and still life; (4) animals and pets; (5) babies and small children.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -Plans for a $75,000,000 American Red Cross appeal will be outlined by the president, Basil O'Connor, at eighteen regional meetings beginning Monday.

With the temperature hovering near zero, a series of fires swept several buildings yesterday morning in various sections of the city, routing scores of residents and resulting in the death of two persons.

Today the world's most sweeping Appeal opens. It is an Appeal which recognizes no geographic, ethnic or political boundaries, but is truly global in outlook -- the United Nations Appeal for Children. Its possibilities for lasting good are boundless. The world of adults must now give the answer to over two hundred million children in war-devastated and famine areas who are starving, diseased and dying.

Encouraged by a five-day swing through northern New England, Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and aspirant for the Republican nomination for President, passed through New York yesterday. He left by plane for his home in St. Paul, Minn., for a brief visit to his family, after which he will continue campaigning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- With some reluctance, Weather Bureau officials admitted this week that most of the United States had been suffering from an unusually severe winter. Some of the country's top meteorologists concede that, since Christmas, the Eastern States have had more steady cold and more snow than in recent years.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- When the State Department takes over the administration of the United State zone in Germany, the shift will involve a series of problems which will go far beyond the routine of administration.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- France nearly doubled her exports during 1947, according to a breakdown of foreign trade statistics just obtained. Imports rose by about 70 per cent.
NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 1 -- The accent is on tomorrow at the Naval War College here, where 150 officers are studying the art of future war.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1 (AP) -Castor Montoto, Mexican Baseball League treasurer and president of the Puebla Club, today followed the lead of Alejandro Aguilar Reyes, baseball commissioner, and announced his resignation.
GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- Incomplete but concrete evidence that European industrial recovery is a lot farther along than most persons think and most European politicians say is accumulating in Geneva.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, Feb. 2 -- The Prime Minister of India and two other key Government leaders have been marked for murder in a deeply laid conspiracy that police are moving to crush, a high official said last night.

Among the openings this week in art galleries are the thirtysecond annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Artists at the Brooklyn Museum, starting Wednesday, and a retrospective exhibition of John Sloan's paintings at the Kraushaar Gallery, and paintings by Eugene Boudin at the Durand-Ruel Gallery, which go on view today.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings regained sole possession of the National Hockey League lead by blanking the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 0, tonight before 15,578 screaming fans -largest crowd in Detroit hockey history.

An archer shot an arrow out of a bow and it exploded a balloon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. But that wasn't the only explosion heard as the New York baseball writers brought their twenty-fifth anniversary dinner to a rollicking close before 1,500 guests who jammed the grand ballroom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) - President and Mrs. Truman attended a reception given in their honor today by the Congressional Club, known as the "ladies auxiliary" of Congress.

Miss Nell Van Vliet, 21-year-old European women's breast stroke champion, arrived in New York yesterday abroad the HollandAmerican Line's S.S. Nieuw Amsterdam. The Dutch swimmer, who will compete for the Town Club swimming team of Chicago, was met by Mrs. Cora Fogarott, a relative, and the club's coach, Walter Schlueter.

The Council Child Development Center, 227 East Fifty-ninth Street, in the first year of its operation enrolled fifty emotionally disturbed children under 6 years old for full treatment, Mrs. Norman S. Goetz, president of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women, reported yesterday.

Brooklyn's own cavalry unit has had its face lifted. The old 101st Cavalry, pride of the borough with its dashing horses, in the days before mechanized warfare, a unit that served in the Spanish-American War and both World Wars, has a new name.

Swelled by the flotation of several large issues of public utility bonds and a large Federal Home Loan Bank issue, public offerings of new bonds in January totaled $338,446,000 for thirty-nine issues, the largest amount for a January since 1945.

Your recent editorial urged the Mayor either to approve the contribution of land to a Parking Authority or to state that as a matter of principle public money should not be used to house private automobiles. You wrote, "We have often expressed grave doubts ourselves of the propriety of a subsidy for such purposes."

Liberalization of the state's unemployment insurance program through the addition of dependency allowances was recommended yesterday by the State Advisory Council on Placement and Unemployment Insurance in its annual report to Governor Dewey and the Legislature.

AS if things aren't confusing enough, the lads who tenant the press boxes at the ball parks during the sumer months produced their silver anniversary Baseball Writers Show at the Waldorf-Astoria last night and our national game never will be the same again. They mutilated it beyond recognition with buffoonery and burlesque.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Two important issues will get floor-voting tests in Congress this week. In the Senate a vote is expected by Thursday or Friday on the controversial St. Lawrence seaway project, while the House is scheduled tomorrow to pass the Republicansponsored $6,500,000,000 income tax reduction bill.
VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- Russian occupation authorities in Austria have been sending anybody of Russian origin on whom they can lay their hands back to Russia, whether or not they want to go.
Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Seventy-year-old Samuel Sherman, a familiar figure with his violin in the restaurants of the lower East Side, is dead. He slumped over his table in Yonah's Knishe Restaurant, 113 Rivington Street, early yesterday morning while eating his breakfast.
Sunday delivery of 3,500,000 gallons of fuel oil under Mayor O'Dwyer's "watchful eye" policy brought relief from the continuing cold to thousands of heatless homes in this city.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Reidar Andersen, Norway's virtuoso on skis, resumed where he left off in 1939, when he last visited the United States, by capturing both the New York State cross country and ski jumping championships today as a record throng of close to 20,000 jammed all the winter sports facilities in this mammoth Palisades Interstate Park playground.

Inflation has had its origins in a number of circumstances in the last year. Responsible for it in varying degrees have been such contributing elements as shortages of labor and materials, high wages and bottlenecks of one kind or another.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Mingled praise and blame for the Navy's treatment of Negroes was contained in a book it published here today. It is a discussion of the integration of Negroes into the Navy's personnel and was originally written by Lieut. Dennis D. Nelson, only Negro reserve officer now on active duty in the Navy, as a thesis for his master's degree in sociology at Howard University.

Direct obligations of the UnitedStates Government in the hands ofthe public which will mature within twelve months amount to $55,227,246,019. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

THE greatest threat to the trade agreements program came not from foreign countries, not from the Republicans, not from certain manufacturers or growers but from within the Roosevelt Administration itself, in the person of George N. Peek, former chief of the A.A.A.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Miss Anna Lea Lelli, Italian scholar and lecturer who was imprisoned in Rome during the war for her educational ideas, closed an eightmonth tour of the United States here with conferences last weekend with officials on a program for government-sponsored exchanges of students from the elementary grades upward.

The ninth annual American Music Festival of WNYC, the municipal station, will open on the customary date of Feb. 12, Lincoln's Birthday, and end on Feb. 22, Washington's Birthday. During the eleven-day period more than 100 programs are expected to be devoted to American music in all its phases, with emphasis on contemporary American composers, rising and arrived American artists, and works seldom or never heard on the air."

HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 1 - Dr. Ralph P. Bridgman, president of Hampton Institute since 1944 and former dean of students at Brooklyn College, has submitted his resignation effective not later than Aug. 31.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 2 (AP) -Lieut. Gen. Ennis C. Whitehead, commander of the United States Far East Air Forces, was not available today for comment on Russian protests that United States bombers were making an "importunate inspection" of Russian shipping in Japanese waters.

Despite scant hopes for the finding of survivors, the search was continued yesterday for traces of the British European Airways Tudor IV, lost on the way to Bermuda early Friday morning. Coast Guard Headquarters in New York reported last night that weather was improving and that surface ships and aircraft were keeping up the search.

Daniel Ericourt, French pianist, reversed the usual procedure by playing his first recital of the season in Carnegie Hall and his second, yesterday afternoon, in Town Hall. His renditions of works by Debussy and Ravel were well received in the earlier appearance, and to judge by the size and responsiveness of yesterday's audience, he was wise to devote the entire program to their compositions.

ST. MORITZ, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- The International Olympic Committee in a communique tonight reiterated that it could not recognize the current ice hockey tournament being held here as part of the winter Olympic games since it did not recognize the international ice hockey federation as the controlling body of the sport.

The fund-raising campaign to complete the new building of the Free Synagogue will be resumed, it was announced last night by Frederick L. Guggenheimer, president of the congregation. The announcement was made to the congregation at a reception at the synagogue's temporary quarters, the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eight Street.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- Allied newspapers and news agencies tonight were officially informed by Frayne Baker, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's public information officer, that it would hereafter be impossible for them to base correspondents in Japan for purposes of coverage in other sections of Asia.

Seven hundred Christians, Jews and Hindus gathered last night in a small Hindu chapel known as the Ramakrishna - Vivekanauda Center, at 17 East Ninety-fourth Street, to honor the memory of Mohandas K. Gandhi. The crowd overflowed onto the brown-stone steps of the modest house.
Confusion struck the foreign exchange market at the outset of trading last Monday when it faced the news of the devaluation of the French franc announced from Paris on the preceding day (Sunday).

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 -- Steel production was rolling along at top speed last week but customers were still clamoring for more steel. While some sources had thought the supply situation would be better earlier this year, trade sources here indicated that the reverse was true.

The latest annual report of its president, Fairfield Osborn, makes it plain that the New York Zoological Society long ago ceased to be an organization of only local importance. Moreover, it does far more than exhibit strange animals for the education of a metropolis.

h)0*0*0*iThe dairy industry generally in New York State will agree to renewed suspension of the legislative ban on use of oleomargarine and other butter substitutes in tax-aided institutions, Henry R. Rathbun, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, said yesterday at his home in New Hartford, N.Y.

A national emergency information campaign to enlist the cooperation of consumers/during the critical fuel oil shortage has been approved by the board of directors of The Advertising Council, it was announced over the week-end. Twelve advertisements are being prepared by Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, Inc., for inclusion in a newspaper proof sheet to be distributed shortly.

In response to all appeal from the United Nations to help supply food, milk and medicines to suffering children throughout the world, American labor leaders yesterday pledged the full support of the 15,000,000 organized workers in this country.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, has been asked by his colleagues in the federation's executive council to accept the directorship of Labor's League for Political Education, the newly-formed political arm of the AFL, it was learned today.

Joseph R. Apfel, grand master of the Independent Order Brith Abraham, declared last night that the Truman Administration and the United Nations should permit immediate shipment of arms to Palestine for Jewish settlers. Mr. Apfel spoke in the Hotel Commodore at the sixtieth anniversary dinner of the Jewish fraternal organization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 The average American book reader in 1947 seemingly was unconcerned about international affairs, the atom bomb, or the recent war. His interest turned instead to his personal problems first, with housing second and business third, the American Library Association reported today.

Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes" will be presented for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday evening, Feb. 12, it was announced yesterday with the giving out of the repertoire for the "ourteenth week of the season.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 1 (AP) -George Fischer, Chicago, today won the national men's senior speed skating championship by a wide margin, and Miss Loraine Sabbe of Detroit took over the senior women's crown by a slim 10-point edge over her nearest competition.

A new graduate school at Columbia University to train prospective college teachers in the field of general education was proposed yesterday by Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College. Dean Carman's suggestion was made in his annual report to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university.
Aggressive war by the Soviet Union is not probable for at least a decade, considering the present condition of industry, agriculture, reconstruction and national morale.

A property in the heart of the fur district in Manhattan passed to new control in a deal reported over the week-end in the sale by the Zika Film Corporation to the Trump Realty Corporation of the ten-story store and loft building at 291-93 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets.

Four major trends posing top management policy problems shaped up late last week to raise significant questions about prospects for 1948 industrial profits, New York executives revealed over the week-end. In a round table conference which included representatives of rubber, metal fabricating, metal refining and chemcal process industries, spokesmen reached the conclusion that the "third round" of price and wage advances has opened several important new avenues for management actions to be taken immediately.

Having recently returned from an extended visit in Ethiopia, I was surprised to read the letter from Giuseppe Del Giudice in your Jan. 23 issue. He mentions that 5,000 Italians live in Addis Ababa, that some have high government positions, and that Italian is the chosen language of the land.
NANKING, Feb. 1 -- Displaced by the civil war, millions of refugees have flocked to Nationalist-held towns and thrown themselves upon the mercy of municipal administrations unable to support them.

CLARK, N. J., Feb. 1 -- Federal Judge William F. Smith of Newark has set next Tuesday for action on a $152,000 offer for a group of incompleted houses here following an application by the developer, Lexington Homes. Inc., of Clark, Westfield and Cranford, for permission to reorganize under the Bankruptcy Act.

The largest number of conventions in New York City since the first World's Fair year of 1939 will meet here in 1948, according to a report issued over the week-end for publication today by Royal W. Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., to the board of directors of that organization.

A new wage agreement covering 500 Queens workers has been reached between the Associated Retail Bakeries of Queens and Local 17, Bakery and Confectionary Workers Union, AFL, Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 -- A greyhound that had never been in an all-breed event before advanced to the top tonight when Little Andely's Reflection, belonging to Mrs. Harding Mason, got best in show at the end of the two-day Maryland Kennel Club fixture.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- In the week since Police Commissioner John C. Prendergast ordered enforcement of the surfew law, which has been on the statute books since 1921, there has been more controversy over the order aimed at curbing juvenile delinquency than enforcement of it.

The Catholic Church needs more aspirants to the priesthood and the religious life, the Rev. Bernard M. Martin, associate director of finance, Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Six new catalogue sales of Government surplus in this region covering $5,000,000 worth of aicraft parts, a plastic chemical, light metals, welding electrodes and locomotives were announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.
PRAGUE, Feb. 1 -- The United States Embassy is trying to obtain from the Czechoslovak Government treatment in the nation's press equal to that accorded to the Soviet bloc.

LEONIA, N.J., Feb. 1 -- While voters in most other municipalities of New Jersey are undergoing the usual squabbling in the campaign for election of school board members on Feb. 10, those in this community of 6,000 inhabitants, as well as voters in Glen Ridge, are enjoying a placid life because of their solution of election problems through the Civic Conference Plan.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -All authorities in Switzerland qualified to judge agree that for the welfare of Europe as a whole, the French Government in principle took the wisest course in adjusting the official rate of exchange of the franc to practical necessities despite the opposition of the British Government and the International Monetary Fund.

During the last month the members of the American Negro Theatre have been giving a highly competent performance of "Rain" in their upstairs playhouse, 15 West 126th Street. Since business is encouraging, they are going to act it on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings during February.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- With her monetary problems finally settled, France is facing two more questions of almost equal importance. These are attainment of a balance between wages and prices and the assuring of the national meat supply.

The ashes of Mahatma Gandhi's funeral pyre were not yet cold yesterday when further startling events in India threw a lurid light into the abyss between the multitude of Hindus who accepted his teachings and the lesser number who did not. Home Minister Patel's announcement of a plot to kill himself, Prime Minister Nehru and other high Indian officials was followed swiftly by numerous arrests.

The twenty-five-family apartment house at 1921 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Crotona Parkway Mohegan Corporation to Edwin Stroh and Irene Goldstein for investment. Assessed at $65,000, the property is 50 by 135 feet and was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $39,974 in a deal negotiated by William C. Voelker Co. and Patrick R. O'Connor, brokers.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru laid roses and jasmine beside the funeral pyre of the slain Mohandas K. Gandhi in a final tribute before the ashes are consigned tomorrow to the Jumna River, whose waters the Hindus consider holy.

Visitors who come to this metropolis frequently remark that New York will be a great city "when it is finished." But will that day ever come? As the population booms from its 1850 figure of 750,000 to an estimated 8,000,000 in 1950, we go on beautifying, improving and -- tearing down.

A gentleman who has been watching the development of radio for the past couple of decades submits what he says frankly appears to Be a minority report to the effect that the portable radio is threatening the present and future mental stability of the nation's population.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) The Army Medical Department today announced discovery of a new drug for combating scrub typhus. It said it "may mark one of the important landmarks in medical history."

Having proved itself a valuable community asset in the first year of its existence, the Protestant Fund of Greater New York, Inc., 39 Broadway, New York 6, has opened its second annual campaign for funds to support the activities of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., and the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- The Austrian Government is studying the value of Russian confiscated industries in Eastern Austria and Austria's other resources to ascertain whether it can pay out of the country's assets all or part of the cash payment demanded in the latest Soviet economic treaty proposals.

In the first of a series of articles on Soviet Russia beginning today, Mr. Drew Middleton offers the more than welcome assurance that, considering the state of its industry, agricultural reconstruction and national morale, that country would be physically unable to fight an aggressive war against the United States for at least a decade.

Speaker Joseph Martin Jr., ordinarily a calm man, must have startled the members of the National Association of Women Broadcasters last Saturday when he mentioned the possibility that saboteurs might "execute a sudden coup and take over the Government." He was evidently not referring to next fall's election.

The Chicago Black Hawks continued to make things tough for the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. No, the last place sextet didn't score the victory, over the local club, but it did manage to skate off with a 2-to-2 tie in a clash which saw the Blue Shirts dominate in all departments except the all-important one of scoring goals.

Today is Candlemas Day, which puts us midway through the winter. As it is also Ground Hog Day, it is customary for newspapers to print funny stories about the behavior of this extremely unreliable zoological predicter. At that, we can be grateful for at least one cheerful note, for there is nothing funny to look back on.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 2 (AP} -Russia charged in a note to Iran that the activities of the American military mission in that country constitute a threat to the Soviet frontiers, the Moscow radio said today.

JERUSALEM, Monday, Feb. 1 -Arabs penetrated Jerusalem's Jewish area for the first time last night and blew up the building of The Palestine Post, a Zionist organ and the only English-language newspaper in the country.

Anticipating an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines, the Board of Transportation has set up a comprehensive budget bureau to make sure the higher fare will cover all operating and maintenance costs of the city system, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week. Prices fell rapidly under increased selling by large holders of wheat and corn. Corn was especially weak at times as the result of consumer resistance to paying high prices.

Activity in the New York wholesale markets last week was quiet as most buyers were back at stores checking inventories, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) - An Administration source said today that the St. Lawrence seaway project was a "lost cause." Leaders on both sides of the bipartisan issue, however, shied away from predicting outcome of the current Senate fight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican, of New York, predicted today that Congress would approve universal military training in the present session.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The British Navy today intercepted a schooner carrying 280 Jews seeking to enter Palestine without immigration papers. The refugees from central Europe were sent off to Cyprus for detention.

Marcel Hubert, Franco-American cellist who has given many recitals here since his debut in 1926 was heard last night at Carnegie Hall. The novelty of his program was "Legende" by Jean Cras French composer, who combined the career of writing music with serving in the French Navy, in which he rose to the rank of vice admiral before his death in 1932.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- Unless the Government provides loans aggregating 50,000,000 yen, about forty of Japans leading stock brokerage concerns are reported likely to go bankrupt The Osaka brokerage fraternity has sent a plea to Tokyo declaring that two thirds of its sixty member firms were caught short in the recent bull market.

Dan Ferris will be well advised to hold press on the 1948 edition of the A.A.U.'s official track and field guide. Gilbert Dodds has half a dozen more miles to run this winter and who's to say that the power-packing parson won't shave time off his brand-new indoor record of 4:05.3 almost every time out?

NEW DELHI, Feb. 1 -- Indian authorities in four Provinces were today intensively investigating reports linking the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi to a nationwide conspiracy by "a radical communal organization" for the murder of Congress party leaders.
Robert W. LeRoy, formerly executive vice president, has succeeded I. Lawrence Lesavoy, retired, as president of Paper Corporation of America.
Prices of cotton in the domestic market fluctuated narrowly last week and closed with only minor net changes from the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -Sen. Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, recommended today that the United States take the lead in rebuilding European aviation as a service to the welfare and security of all "liberty-loving people" outside of the Russian "iron curtain."

Herman Bohlman, 13 years old, died early yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He had suffered his fatal injuries Saturday afternoon when a hit-run vehicle bore down on him and his little brother George, 3. His sister, Elizabeth, 5, was off to one side of the road and was unhurt.
MUKDEN, China, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- No basically new information or developments are discernable here regarding the old question of Russian aid for the Chinese Communists in Manchuria.

Carmen Torres, Spanish soprano, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall before a warmly responsive audience. With George Schick at the piano, she presented a program containing Mozart's concert aria, "Mia speranza adorata," early classics by Secchi and Cavalli, Spanish songs by de Falla, Granados, Nin and Obradors, and group of French lyrics by Grovlez, Debussy, Poulenc and Ibert.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Representative Frank L. Sundstrom, Republican, of New Jersey, said today that he would introduce in the House tomorrow a bill directing the Secretary of the Treasury to call in and exchange all United States currency. He was proposing this step, he said, as a means of strengthening the European aid program.

The Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor emeritus of the West End Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, presided yesterday at a holy communion service marking the sixtieth anniversary of the church and also the forty-third year since he began his ministry there in 1905.

PAOTOW, Suiyuan, China, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- Erik Sandberg closed the Swedish Holiness Mission in Communist-held Ningwu in Shansi because Communist pressure made the people who visited the mission become fewer and fewer, he reported here.

LONDON, Feb. -- The Soviet Union has protested to the United States against alleged "inspection" flights by United States aircraft in the Yellow Sea and the Sea of Japan, charging that the planes dive on Soviet ships and circle them at mast-top, the Moscow radio reported today.

DUBLIN, Feb. 1 -- With his back to the wall, 65-year-old Premier Eamon de Valera is now nearing the closing stages of one of the toughest electoral battles he has ever waged. After sixteen years in office his Fianna Fail administration has built up a host of discontents.

The American family now may buy virtually all the appliances that contribute to a complete electrical life for $2,274.16, according to J. Louis Albert, editor of the 1948 Standard Merchandise Manual. The manual, a reference guide to current models of standard brands, is being distributed to electrical dealers this week.
ST. MORITZ, Feb. 1 (UP) -- The United States today named its Cresta and four-man bobsled teams for the Olympic contests here.

The twenty-four-year-old George Washington, which operated in pre-war days between New York and Norfolk on the Old Dominion Line, is about to embark on a new career as a passenger ship plying between Seattle and Alaska.

The Guilet String Quartet played in the New Friends of Music series for the first time this season late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Between their performances of Mendelssohn's E minor Quartet and Beethoven's Op. 18, No. 1, Joanna and Nikolai Graudan piano-cello duo played Beethoven's Sonata in A major Op. 69.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 1 -This city was named after Jans Peeck, a Dutch adventurer, but a bridge to be built over near-by Annsville Creek, where Peeck traded whisky to the Indians for furs, will not bear his name if Chester A. Smith can help it.

Forty-five years ago the members of the class of '03 at Public School 84 walked out of their redbrick schoolhouse at Glenmore and Stone Avenues, Brooklyn, to make something of themselves. Yesterday sixteen of them held a reunion at the Biltmore Hotel to take inventory of their achievements in the land to which their fathers and many of them came as immigrants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Tightening restrictions on the movement of alien visitors in the United States constitutes "a step toward the Russian viewpoint," Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York, asserted today in protesting to Attorney General Tom C. Clark against formulation of the new rules.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 -- A young commander of the Haganah, Jewish defense organization, just relieved after having led the defense of 1,700 Jews trapped by Arabs within Jerusalem's Old City walls, came out today to tell the story of the siege.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- A rescue party walked a half mile across the ice of Long Island Sound between Rye and Hen Island to take food and supplies today to 85-year-old Carl Wacks, marooned on the tiny island since Thanksgiving.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The stock markets here experienced last week another period of unsettlement as a result of the French Government's decision to devalue the franc.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- The Paris money black market today was buying the outlawed 5,000 franc notes for 2,500 francs each. This low value was placed on the bills because of fear of the questions to be asked the heavy holders, The income taxes that probably will be slapped on former tax evaders forced to admit their resources, and the long delay expected before the monumental bookkeeping operations involved in the measure are completed.

Parris Mitchell of Kings Row,"a novel begun by the late HenryBellamann and completed by hiswidow, Katherine Bellamann, hasbeen scheduled for publication inApril by Simon Schuster. TheLiterary Guild's May hoice, it features the personal history of Dr.Parris Mitchell, the central figureof "Kings Row."

The recent resolution of the New York City Council calling on the legislature to amend the State Constitution to permit a one-year city lottery was assailed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, the pastor, in his sermon at the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 1 (UP) -Henry A. Wallace, third-party Presidential candidate, called today upon President Truman and other political candidates to take a pledge repudiating the support of any un-American group or individual.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- While left-wing parties launched their election campaign in Rome today by putting the finishing touches on their Communist-dominated People's Front, in Milan they were organizing a private army.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 1 -- A resolution urging prompt action by American leaders to mitigate the plight of displaced persons abroad and approval of the formation of a committee to study means of training students for positions of leadership in international organizations were voted today at the closing session of the National Council of the National Federation of Catholic College Students.

For lack of a groundhog the Kips Bay Boys' Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street, will omit today its annual ceremony to mark groundhog day, G. Dana Younger, the executive secretary, announced yesterday.

More and more window shades are coming out of hiding to serve as decorative features of a room as well as aids to light control.h)0*0*0*iPastel colors are recent departures from traditional dark greens or plain whites. A new group of shades with designs handprinted in modern colorings have just been introduced by one manufacturer.

The New York Rovers' return to home ice yesterday afternoon was an unsuccessful one. Yielding three goals in the third period, the Red Shirts dropped a 4-2 verdict to the high-flying Ottawa Senators in a Quebec Senior Hockey League battle before 12,104 fans at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A vast program of Federal aid to American colleges and universities to permit doubling of existing enrollment is recommended in the fifth of six reports by the President's Commission on Higher Education, made public here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Truman's action in appointing a new chairman for the Federal Reserve System and his search for a new head of the Civil Aeronautics Board have switched more attention to the vacancy to be filled on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Measures taken by the American Bureau of Shipping to eliminate failures of Liberty ship rudders and propeller shafts have been described in a report at the bureau's annual meeting here by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the organization.

The sustained demand for cotton goods ever since the end of the war is due to the deficit created during the war years by the large diversion of production to military and other essential needs, according to a survey by the Cotton-Textile Institute, released over the week-end.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- The Economic and Social Council parent United Nations body responsible for the vast program of studies in the global field of man's economic, social, cultural and educational affairs, will open its sixth session here tomorrow.

George L. Goodman, an impressively gifted young baritone, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The singer, an ex-GI is still a student at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, but he already has nearly all the attributes that make a fine concert artist.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -Louis de Rochemont, who obtained a release from his producing contract with Twentieth Century-Fox last week, has arrived on the Coast to discuss a deal with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to produce films in the documentary style.

If you are cold and there is no fuel in the house, please do not call the police, harassed officers at Police Headquarters said yesterday. All such calls, whether by tenants or landlords, should be made to the borough offices of the Department of Health.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Although the name of Charles Creed has always been synonymous with impeccably tailored suits and coats only this season the accent is on tailored dresses -- for the morning, for lunch dates, for tea and cocktail time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A bulletin issued by the Communist Information Bureau [Cominform] said today that the new Communist international organization had met in Yugoslavia in mid-January.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department has not formally received the latest Soviet protest, and officials would not venture tonight a comment on the basis of reports of the Moscow broadcast reaching them.

Opposition to a general rent increase here was combined yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council with an urgent proposal that the Office of Rent Control be expanded to give quick action on individual landlords' applications for hardship rent increases, as well as on applications by tenants for decreases.

Young persons today ask one question more than any other of a minister, "Why do we need the church?" the Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, said yesterday morning.

Since former Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in his currently published memoirs, has chosen to open the tomb of the 1983 London Economic Conference and since I am made the central figure in two of Mr. Hull's installments, I am constrained to offer a brief reply.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Plans for permanent operation of the atomic laboratory here as a national facility with a strong program of basic research were disclosed tonight by David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Sales of a substantial volume of bank-eligible Treasury bonds in the last week of January followed the announcement that reserves of the central reserve city banks would be raised from 20 to 22 per cent on Feb. 27, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

Former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts and former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson are scheduled to speak at the "Meeting of Citizens on Universal Military Training" Thursday at 8:15 P.M. in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The veteran Elmer Lach accounted for all the scoring with the three-goal "hat trick" to put Montreal's Canadiens back in the National Hockey League playoff running while Goalie Bill Durnan was turning in his fourth shut-out of the season, 3 -- 0, at the expense of the Boston Bruins tonight before a packed 13,900 crowd at the Boston Garden.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP) -- By shooting the best round in his career, Stewart (Skip) Alexander of Mid-Pines, N.C., blazed past some of the biggest names in golf today to vault from a seventh-place tie to win top money in the $10,000 Tucson open.

Four plainclothes patrolmen raided a cocktail party yesterday afternoon in an East Side apartment, given to raise funds for activities of the New York Advertising Chapter, American Veterans Committee, and arrested a woman and two men on charges of selling liquor without a license.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- In a formal statement issued here tonight the Arab Higher Committee of Palestine, supporting charges by British officials that Communists were being shipped to Palestine, declared that Russia had a plan to infiltrate 1,500,000 Communist agents into Western Europe and the Middle East.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 1 -- An early morning fire, coming in the midst of one of the worst snowstorms this city has ever had, today took the lives of a family of five and destroyed the Carolina Country Club's clubhouse.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1 -- Statements by official British sources that two unauthorized Jewish immigrant ships that sailed from Black Sea ports for Palestine last December were carrying many Communist agents aboard were labeled as "fantastic and malicious untruths" here today by Moshe Shertok, political chief of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.
Congregations of two New York churches heard their pastors of many years' standing preach farewell sermons yesterday, in preparation for the assumption of new posts.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 1 -- The Brookhattan F.C. defeated the Baltimore Soccer Club, 3 -- 2, at Bugle Field today in an American Soccer League championship match. At the change of ends the visitors were leading, 2 -- 0.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Apologies, handshakes, a flash snow storm and a 31-to-1 hockey triumph by the United States over Italy marked this third day of the hectic fifth winter Olympics.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1 -It was revealed today that Mohandas K. Gandhi in his last message to the Congress party had suggested that the party become a semi-military organization, "although subscribing to non-violent principles."

The report of the Monsanto Chemical Company, mailed yesterday to stockholders, disclosed unaudited net earnings for 1947 as $15,561,228, equal to $3.59 each on 4,253,019 shares of common stock. For 1946 the company showed a net income of $10,084,149 or $3.49 each on the 1,267,868 shares then outstanding.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (AP) Damage to Southern California citrus crops by recent freezing temperatures ranges from "considerable" in some sectors to "negligible" in others, a California Fruit Growers Exchange spokesman said today.

Charging that the administration of Governor Dewey had been "the most spendthrift and inefficient in the history of the state," Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, called yesterday for a thorough non-partisan investigation.

Heavy exports of non-perishable foods projected under the European Recovery Program, which will add its own great demand for canning and glass-packaging materials to the growing domestic drain on these none-too-plentiful items, will compel a large-scale change-over to freezing, salting and dehydration for preservation of American-consumed food, it was forecast last week by Dr. L. V. Burton, director of the Packaging Institute.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 1 -- A woman and three children were killed when their home burned here early this morning. During the blaze a 6-month-old infant was saved when thrown by its father from a second-story window into a snowbank.

A series of recommendations for consideration by the ninth International Conference of American States at Bogota, Colombia, beginning March 30, has been presented to the State Department by the National Foreign Trade Council and its affiliate, the Council for InterAmerican Cooperation, it was announced over the week-end.

Bound by inflexible tradition, devotees of the D'Oyly Carte brand of Gilbert Sullivan will be surprised tonight when the curtain rises on this week's bill of "The Yeomen of the Guard" at the Century. What they'll see is a radical departure from the conventional scenery and costumes generally associated with that presentation.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- For the first time in more than three years, the passions of hatred and revenge against former Vichy officials and collaborators are beginning to subside. A well-defined movement exists to wind up the purge.
