IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 1 (AP) -A conductor was killed and a score of persons were injured, none seriously, when the Rock Island Railroad's Rocky Mountain Rocket, a high-speed passenger train, bound from Chicago to Denver, struck a freight train a block from the station here.

THE finest novel I have ever read about the tragic plight of black-skinned people in a white man's world is "Cry, the Beloved Country"* by Alan Paton. Without any of the blind rage which leads so many writers on similar themes into bitterness and dogmatism, without any of the customary over-simplification and exaggerated melodrama, Mr. Paton has

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- With Governor Dewey's $799,600,000 executive budget now before it and informal agreements already reached on several controversial subjects, the 1948 session of the State Legislature is scheduled to quicken its pace as it enters its second month tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Henry A. Wallace's political advisers are planning a $3,000,000 campaign fund to finance his third-party candidacy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -James B. Cassidy and Polan Banks, independent producers, have closed a deal with the United Artists Distributing Company for the release of their projected screen version of Levis Browne's 1943 novel, "See What I Mean," which they will produce under the corporate name of Federated Pictures.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Jorge Pasquel, Mexican baseball, mogul, said today he is "ready to make peace with American club owners when and if the offer is made."
Ships on the Atlantic sea lanes reported yesterday that their arrivals would be one to five days behind schedule as they encountered heavy seas, gales and fog.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- There will be a public inquiry into the loss of the Tudor IV airliner Star Tiger that disappeared last Friday on a flight from the Azores to Bermuda with twenty-six passengers and a crew of six.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Supreme Court upheld by a vote of 5 to 4 today the protest of a person who was arrested without a search warrant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Despite the fact that the trip was in foreign commerce, the Supreme Court held today that the refusal of a steamship company to carry a Negro girl from Detroit to Bob-Lo Island, a Canadian resort, violated the Michigan civil rights statute.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 2 -- A program has been ordered in North Korea to tighten the control of the Communist party and to combat "American propaganda."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senate debate on the proposed Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaway and power project turned again today to the question whether President Truman, in urging anew its authorization, followed the Constitution in his recommendations.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- A "whispering campaign" has effectively curtailed the black market dealings of American dependents, mechants along the famed shopping street Kurfuerstendamm said today. Meanwhile, one of the chief topics of conversation among the dependents is the number of men the Army's Criminal Investigation Division is supposed to have checking on all American visitors to various German shops and asking them whether they obtained their marks legally.

The Alleghany Corporation announced yesterday that it had disposed of its bond holdings in the Missouri Pacific Railroad System. These consisted of $3,210,000 of Missouri Pacific first and refunding bonds, and $11,152,000 of the convertible bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board today argued that the Communist affidavit provision of the TaftHartly Act was constitutional and a proper provision by Congress even though Congress had not outlawed the Communist party itself.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Silas Hunt of Texarkana will become the University of Arkansas first bona fide Negro graduate student if he completes enrollment procedure begun today. His application for entrance to the university law school was accepted and he began the enrollment procedure, which university officials said could be completed tomorrow.

ROME, Feb. 2 -- In a simple but impressive ceremony, Ambassador James Clement Dunn for the United States and Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza for Italy signed a treaty of friend ship, commerce and navigation in the famous Hall of Victory in the Palazzo Chigi this afternoon.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The Palestine Commission appealed to the Security Council of the United Nations today for quick action to avert impending catastrophe in the Holy Land.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb 2 (AP) -- One man was killed and another injured tonight in an automobile accident, which had a sequel of explosion and fire that tied up traffic on the Boston Post Road here for nearly two hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today began studies to determine whether governmental policy should encourage open competition in the carriage of air freight or restrict the business in the manner that air mail is given only to certificated air carriers.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- Every member nation will have an equal vote in the annual and special conferences of the proposed International Trade Organization. The one-country, one-vote procedure for policy-making sessions was approved on the second reading today by the Organization Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- Characterizing Henry A. Wallace as a "front, spokesman and apologist" for the Communist party, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor voted unanimously today to reject Mr. Wallace's third-party candidacy for the Presidency.
ATHENS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A Markos broadcast today said that Lukas Koutsopetalos, Liberal member of Parliament, who was captured by guerrillas in Boeotia on Jan. 13, will be released.
Deciding what change in rent ceilings -- if any -- should be recommended to the Housing Expediter is going to be a long, hard task, Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Lou Smith, executive director of Rockingham Park race course, Salem, N.H., was named today as the "sportsman who did most for racing" in the annual New York Turf Writers' Association poll.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Bills to license and regulate the practice of fitting and adjusting artificial limbs and braces were introduced in the State Legislature tonight by Senator Seymour Halpern and Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Republicans, of Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -Warning that this country must learn to use "every shred and drop of what the earth provides," Secretary of the Interior J. A. Krug today appealed for more Federal funds for conservation and development of natural resources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Sentiment in favor of universal military training was increasing throughout the country, President Truman was told today by members of his Commission on Universal Training.

Something sensational has happened. The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, guardian of the sacred fire, custodian of tradition, has broken out a new suit of settings in a new style! Nothing so extraordinary has happened since the Bolshevik revolution.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers who are considering the future of the former Italian colonies spent nearly three hours today discussing a dispute involving a miserable village of mud huts on the East African coast.

Bakery union and company representatives met yesterday for several hours without reaching a settlement as the city's Labor Relations Division continued its efforts to prevent a strike of 10,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A vast, newly consolidated research program, focused on "urgent objectives" is bringing forth new designs in atomic weapons and production is now on a "different" and far heavier scale of assembly.
The edge was taken off the fuel oil shortage in many homes yesterday by the arrival of warmer weather and of oil allocated for February use.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Plans for releasing $1,100,000,000 of blocked private assets in this country for the benefit of participants in the European Recovery Program were announced today by the National Advisory Council.

" Kathleen," the first play by Michael Sayers, Irish author and critic, hitherto known in the literary field as a successful shortstory writer, will make its bow this evening at the Mansfield Theatre under the auspices of Bea Lawrence, associate producer of "Crime and Punishment."

Since our Mayor has invited everybody in the U.S.A. to come to New York for the Jubilee of the One City, it has occurred to the man who takes such satisfaction in enjoying the freedom of the city to favor us with some reflections produced by that sweeping gesture of hospitality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, said today he would wind up hearings on his stand-by meat rationing bill tomorrow after it is made clear to his subcommittee where the Administration stands on rationing needs and methods.

WANGIN PALACE, Suiyuan, China, Jan. 25 (Delayed) -- Famine takes on a strange aspect in this desolate area known as the Ordos, once the home of Ghengis Khan, where a human habitation stands out like a ship at sea and the weather is 30 below zero.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Within the limits of handicaps left by the war Britain is pressing forward as vigorously as the United States to step up efficiency and modernize production methods, spokesmen for industry, labor and the Government contended today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Notre Dame's basketball team defeated a favored Kentucky Wildcat five tonight, 64 to 55, for their thirty-eighth straight home floor victory in a string stretching back to 1943. It was Kentucky's second defeat in twenty games and Notre Dame's ninth victory in thirteen.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week increased 10 per cent over the corresponding week of 1947, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended Saturday the gain was 7 per cent.
ATHENS, Feb. 2 -- A reliable source said tonight that of the about 19,000 Greeks living in Rumania, the vast majority had indicated a wish to come to Greece now and 2,000 had already arrived.

It has been said that Americans eat more cabbage than any other vegetable, with the exception of the ever-present potato. That being the case, Northerners should feel a bit grateful at the moment to the Lone Star State, which is breaking records in sending us the green.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Jovial, but apparently irked about public interest in his domestic affairs, Ted Williams, Red Sox slugger, stepped off a Miami plane early today and was greeted by a small army of newspaper men and a few friends.

Monroe Goldwater, member of the law firm of Goldwater Flynn, was elected last night president of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at a meeting of the directors in the Hotel Biltmore. He succeeded Sylvan Gotshal, chosen chairman of the board.

Return to the gold standard by the United States would be "premature" at this time, the committee on finance and currency of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York declared yesterday. Reporting on the results of a year's study, the committee, headed by John M. Schiff of Kuhn Loeb Co., said it would be wise to defer advocating such a move until conditions in the world's monetary systems are less confused.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 2 -Gen. Helge Jung, Commander in Chief of Sweden's armed forces, today opposed a proposal made by a special Parliamentary committee to slash the defense budget from the equivalent of $320,000,000 to $225,000,000.

Currency depreciation is not likely to spread from France because of "special conditions" now, the National City Bank of New York declared yesterday. It said the French devaluation "will be generally considered as an inevitable step and one essential to French and to European recovery."

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 30 (Delayed) -- Less than a hundred miles of the Chinese Changchun Railway, the joint Chinese-Russian control of which was one of the main provisions of the Sino-Soviet treaty, are now in operation in Government territory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- A compromise proposal -- setting out the rights, practices and obligations of the press -- was adopted here by an international group of journalists as the basis for studying freedom of information.

The United Nations Economic and Social Council, which opened its sixth session yesterday at Lake Success, is the outstanding example of one of the unavoidable compromises of the Charter: the less real power a U.N. agency has the more democratic it can be. The ESC consists of any eighteen members on whom two-thirds of the Assembly can agree.

ALTHOUGH the Baseball Writers Dinner always is a most festive occasion, there was a persistent undercurrent of sadness to it this year. The shock of Herb Pennock's sudden death on the virtual eve of the affair seemed to blunt the gaiety somewhat. It was hard to erase him completely from mind because there was not a better liked man in the sport than the beloved Squire of Kennett Square.

The naming of Nieuw Amsterdam, as this city was known 295 years ago, was celebrated yesterday by the citizens of New York. Also taking part in the ceremonies at the Federal Hall Memorial Museum at Wall and Nassau Streets were representatives of the Netherlands, who reminded the New Yorkers that on Feb. 2, 1653, the Dutch settlers already had made important contributions to the development of democratic Government in this country.

OMAHA, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Democratic State Central Committee today made plans to take "any legal action necessary" to keep Henry A. Wallace's name off Nebraska's primary ballot on April 13 as a Democratic candidate for President.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House passed the Republican tax reduction bill today by a heavy coalition vote of 297 to 120.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2-The Government of India, in what may be one of the most far-reaching steps of its brief history, outlawed today all communal organizations and private armies.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Grit edge issues and the shares of companies operating in India recovered some of Friday's losses in the stock markets here today, reflecting satisfaction that Gandhi's assassination has not so far led to any political upheaval.

Sales of frequency modulation receivers will increase sharply from now on as a result of the termination of James C. Petrillo's ban on duplication of regular broadcast programs on FM stations and networks, Arthur Freed, president of Freed-Eisemann Radio Company, predicted yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A draft treaty to form the basis for British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's proposed western European union was submitted to the French Government last week, it was stated by the Foreign Office today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -The Supreme Court today refused to review an attack by Nahum Birnbaum and others on a reorganization plan for the Chicago Railways Company, former operator of surface transit lines in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Truman requested Congress today to implement his policy of civil rights, offering a ten-point program to outlaw lynching and Jim Crow practices, to establish a nation-wide Federal system of monitoring civil liberties, and to take other affirmative steps to increase the protection and dignity of the individual.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- John L. Lewis upset the equanimity of the bituminous coal industry today by informing the operators that the United Mine Workers of America is free "to take any independent action necessary" because the employers' representative on the Mine Welfare Fund has refused to agree to his proposed pension plan.

The return of Monsanto Chemical Company's $25,000,000 financing to the market in the form of a convertible preferred stock issue was widely discussed in Wall Street houses yesterday. The flotation was originally set as a nonsinking-fund preferred last fall before the market for new issues of senior equity stock faded away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that credit granted to installment buyers increased by $423,000,000 in December, the second month after expiration of Government controls over installment credit.
After thirty years of communism the standard of living in the Soviet Union is low compared with that of Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime chief of the atomic bomb project, said today he was "not a bit worried" about Russia's atomic progress.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 2 -Two of eleven Soviet correspondents visiting the United States occupation zone today visited the House of Correction in Straubing, concerning which Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the Russian Military Governor, made charges last Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- World production of fuel and power is about 20 per cent higher today than in 1937, according to a new index of world energy in the latest issue of the United Nations Statistical Bulletin, to be published tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Wage and working rule demands of three railroad operating brotherhoods could add $1,900,000,000 a year to the operating costs of the country's railroads, Guy W. Knight of Philadelphia, attorney for the carriers, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, strongly advised President Truman today to accept invitations to speak in at least three politically important sections of the nation, preferably in advance of the Democratic National Convention in July.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 8 points lower to 9 points higher.

WARSAW, Feb. 2 -- The Government has introduced new passport regulations designed to halt the steady emigration of Polish Jews since the end of the war. Only about 90,000 Jews remain in Poland, once a home for about 3,500,000.

Charging that Governor Dewey was giving New York City "taxation without representation," a delegate to a United Parents Associations monthly assembly last night urged that the city secede from the state. The delegate, Stanley J. Gluck, representing parents of Public School 130 of Brooklyn, charged that the Governor "was cheating our children," and called on the group's legislative committee to study the legality of secession.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--2. drasticdrop in retail food prices may beexpected in the next six to eighteenmonths, J. Frank Grimes, president of the Independent GrocersAlliance, said today in addressinga midwinter conference here. lielisted these three reasons for theexpected tumble:
Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he did not favor a City Council committee's proposal that excess costs of kerosene in eight housing developments be covered by the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP) -Leland Victor (Lou) Brissie Jr., rookie southpaw pitcher recently signed by the Philadelphia Athletics, and Golfer James E. (Sonny) Fraser of Atlantic City, N.J., were honored tonight as the most courageous athletes of 1947 by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association.

The City of San Francisco, Calif., awarded yesterday at competitive sale five bond issues totaling $27,000,000 at interest costs ranging from 1.5266 per cent for $2,000,000 of one-to-five-year airport bonds, to an interest cost of 2.372 per cent for $7,500,000 of one-to-twenty-year water bonds.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Proposals to increase the state's tax revenues by $37,000,000 to finance institutional, educational and highway needs in New Jersey were sent today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to the Legislature.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- What appears to be the most concentrated wave of resistance to the Allied occupation powers since the end of the war has been making itself progressively deeply felt among Military Government officials.

Commissioner Frank J. Quayle presided yesterday at the formal opening of the Fire Department's new medical division at 278 Spring Street. It will take the place of departmental medical offices in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In a new bid for aid in slashing President Truman's $39,669,000,000 budget estimates for the fiscal year 1949, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, released today a study of costs of governments.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- The exiled King Leopold III of the Belgians, with his wife, Princess de Rethy, and son, Crown Prince Baudouin, arrived here this afternoon from Lisbon aboard the ship Sommelsdijk of the Holland-America Line. Maj. Gen. Genovevo Perez, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, welcomed the party at the dock in the name of President Ramon Grau San Martin.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 2 -- Two former troop carriers are on their way to Mobile under tow and will be converted to passenger-cargo vessels at the Gulf Shipbuilding Corporation's shipyards at an estimated cost of $1,600,000, according to officials of the shipbuilding company.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 2 -Haj Amin el-Husseini, the exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, arrived by air today and received in his hotel representatives of the Syrian Government and Fawzi el-Kawukji, commander of the Arab "People's Army."

Establishment of federally-financed civilian scholarships as proposed recently by the President's Commission on Higher Education was sharply criticized last night by Dr. Gordon Keith Chalmers, president of Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, and chairman of the Commission on Liberal Education of the Association of American Colleges.

The fact that the Navy Department has published a critical analysis of its segregation policies by its only Negro officer is an indication of a changing attitude in that tight-knit officer corps. This is a good time to push the effort for removal of segregation barriers, just as the immediate post-war days provided the best climate for the long-needed reform of military reorganization that culminated in the unification law.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The first of the new defenses that Britain is expected to throw up against the adverse effects that devaluation of the franc may have upon the pound sterling was announced by the Treasury here tonight. A regulation provides that beginning tomorrow only sterling held by the French Government, French colonial governments and approved banks is subject to transfer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the Bush Terminal Railroad to cancel, by March 5, a tariff that would have increased charges for switching of traffic between points on its line in the Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, by as much as 400 per cent.

Lack of self-confidence is the chief handicap among youngsters seeking jobs today, Roland L. Stratford, director of the Children's Aid Society counseling and employment service, declared yesterday at its headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street.
An official committee of college professors listened yesterday for six hours to suggestions for changing the present method of fixing the farm price of fluid milk.

The hordes of baseball men who had been in the city over the weekend were scattering like birds in flight yesterday and today -- although some of them were flying on one wing as a result of sitting in on the New York baseball writers' silver anniversary dinner and show at the Waldorf Astoria Sunday night.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Sardar Valladhbhai Patel his Government would give India the peace for which Mr. Gandhi died or go down in disgrace and defeat. Pandit Nehru delivered his pledge to the Indian Constituent Assembly.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The opening of the sixth session of the Economic and Social Council was marked today by an immediate clash between the United States and Russia.

The Westchester Lighting Company submitted to Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright yesterday a proposal to increase the cost of cooking gas about 26 per cent, with a further jump of nearly 23 per cent for commercial users of gas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Soviet Government today submitted to the State Department a note offering to return to the United States seven tankers and one dry cargo vessel that Russia received during the war under lend-lease.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- Any doubt about the popularity of skiing in the metropolitan area certainly has been dispelled this winter. Record crowds have been visiting near-by facilities and golf clubs and public parks also have been popular.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Calumet Farm claimed today it has so many good horses it skipped for the time being any nominations for the Preakness and will fork over extra dough at the last minute to enter its best in the spring classic at Pimlico.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP) -A list of forty-seven top trotters was named today for the $50,000 Golden West Trot to be held Saturday, May 8, during the Western Harness Racing Association's summer meeting at Santa Anita Park.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The husky sons of Norway swept into the lead tonight in the race for team honors in the winter Olympic games, but an 18year-old American ice artist -Dick Button of Englewood, N.J. -- kept the lagging United States team within sight of a championship.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A number of informed observers in Moscow are of the opinion that the Soviet Union may cite the United States before the United Nations Security Council on a charge of impairing world peace. It should be added, however, that there are no hard facts to back up this opinion.

Tireless punching last night carried Johnny Dell, Brooklyn's buzzsaw lightweight, to a unanimous decision over Johnny La Russo, Bronx, in the principal 10-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena. A crowd of 2,265, paying receipts of $5,264, agreed with the ballots of Referee Frank Fullam and the two judges Tom Guilfoyle and Arthur Susskind (Young Otto) at the end of a torrid struggle.
Staten Island ferry passengers are due to travel in style next year, according to plans for at least two new, streamlined craft announced by the city yesterday.

The controversy over rules, chief topic of discussion among the game's so called cognoscenti in recent weeks, once again held the spotlight at the basketball writers weekly luncheon at Leone's yesterday.

Charging that the Board of Education "broke faith with us," the Parents Association of Public School 54, Manhattan, will sue the board to compel the installation of "adequate" sanitary facilities in the school, it was learned yesterday.

" A Miracle Can Happen," which arrives at the Warner Theatre, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Paulette Goddard, Burgess Meredith, James Stewart, Henry Fonda, Dorothy Lamour and Fred MacMurray are among the principals in the comedy.

A second set of "tolerance jingles," written by Hy Zaret and Lou Singer, will be introduced by Station WNEW at 8:15 P.M. Thursday, Feb. 12, and will be heard on a regular basis thereafter. The series will be known as "Little Songs on Big Subjects" and are designed to be sung within the time of a minute or so.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today appealed for 20,000,000 freedom gardens this year, as backing for the European Recovery Program. This would equal the wartime victory garden peak.

STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 2 -- Practically on the eve of the formation of a new economic government for the bizonal area, some 750,000 workers in the United States and British zones left their jobs this evening, planning not to return to work until Wednesday morning.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- France's free exchange market for dollars and Portuguese escudos was inaugurated in the Paris Bourse today, but the opening of the free market in gold was delayed several days by an unexpected obstruction in the Upper House of Parliament, the Council of the Republic.

More than two-thirds of the pressed metal manufacturers throughout the country started the year 1948 with an average of 45 per cent less steel than last year and more than 90 per cent do not expect to receive any more steel this year than in 1947 or to obtain sufficient steel to meet their needs, Tom J. Smith, president, Pressed Metal Institute, Cleveland, Ohio revealed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today, with moderate strength in the early trading. A return of commission house liquidation developed and showed lack of aggressive support.

The House of Representatives has passed the Knutson Tax Bill by a vote of 297 to 120. This is more than enough (by twenty votes or so) to override a Presidential veto. But it is by no means certain that all of those who voted for the measure yesterday would do so again if the bill should go to the White House in its present form and be returned with the predicted veto.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- United States Steel Corporation will begin operating this year ten of thirteen major facilities now being constructed under a $500,000,000 development program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue has decided to strip tax exemption from eight organizations named on Attorney General Tom C. Clark's list of "subversive groups," officials said tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Whitehall calmly took note today of the Soviet protest over the activities of the United States Military Mission in Iran and waited to see whether the Kremlin's note heralded another diplomatic offensive in the Middle East or was simply a routine diplomatic maneuver.

A patrolman, his wife and six children facing eviction from their five-room apartment at 2428 Lurting Avenue, the Bronx, were saved from splitting up yesterday when an offer of a Brooklyn apartment was made to them through the Bronx Police Telegraph Bureau.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Stephens bill to validate New York City's emergency rent and eviction laws was approved tonight by both the Assembly and Senate. The vote in the Senate was unanimous. In the Assembly it was 145 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Three companies filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering $556,000 of bonds, 1,540,000 shares of common and 40,000 shares of preferred stock.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Richard Button of Englewood, N.J., put on one of the finest precision exhibitions of his career today in winning the compulsory phase of the Olympic figure skating competition for men.

The Little Orchestra Society, under the direction of Thomas K. Scherman, concluded its first season last night at Town Hall with performances of Haydn's Oratorio "The Seven Last Words of Christ" and the New York premiere of Tscherepnin's Chamber Concerto for Flute, Violin and Orchestra.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- As a step toward reducing relief "chiseling," a bill that would empower the New York City Welfare Department to get information from insurance companies as to policy holdings of relief applicants was introduced tonight in the Legislature.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 -- Although one of the best-informed Arab sources said emphatically tonight that Arabs had bombed the building, the Jewish Agency for Palestine indirectly accused British forces of responsibility for the bombing of the Palestine Post's office.

According to official sources in Nanking, China's civil war has caused the greatest mass migration of displaced persons in modern history. The fluctuating struggle is believed to have uprooted at least 33,000,000 war refugees, with another 15,000,000 fleeing floods and famine.

A large group of women, many of them working mothers, picketed the Department of Welfare offices, 902 Broadway, yesterday morning in a protest over the curtailment of the day nursery service in the city's child care centers. Benjamin Fielding, welfare commissioner, issued a statement explaining that the cutting off of such service was due to the failure of the state to give additional financial support for the city's child welfare program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The proposal of Representative Frank L. Sundstrom, Republican, of New Jersey, to call in and exchange all United States currency was disapproved today by spokesmen for the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System, who declared the process would be "expensive and impractical."

Red plastic hearts dangling at their sides, seventy-five volunteers started yesterday a four-week "march" from the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets to help the New York Heart Association raise $500,000.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 2 (P)-Baghdad police still have not returned to the streets since lastweek's rioting in which seventypersons were killed.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The reform of the House of Lords came still nearer today when the Labor Government offered to discuss the subject with the Peers and with leaders of all political parties. However, this offer was presented in terms that puzzled the Conserative Lords and made them suspicious, so tonight there is still a small gap between the opposing sides.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Gerhart Eisler, who has been called the "No. 1 Communist" in this country, was arrested in New York today under a process which, if it works, will keep him in custody until he has served time, been deported, or both.

Chemjo Vinaver, who is both a scholar and a gifted musician, shepherded his excellent little group of thirty-six singers, the Vinaver Chorus, through another program of Jewish music last night at Times Hall. It was the second of the three subscription programs the group is presenting under the auspices of the Friends of Choral Art.

Price reductions up to 6 per cent on refrigerators and others up to 25 per cent on radios were announced yesterday by Philco Corporation at the company's first New York showing of its 1948 refrigerator, home freezer and radio lines.

Every time a pound of margarine comes into the kitchen, which is much more frequently now than formerly, I get angry all over again -- angry that my fellow housewives and I should have to put up with the preposterous situation in which we find ourselves (I refer to the law which makes it impossible to buy the product already colored), and that we do so without more open complaint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall proposed to the Big Four today that one more effort be made to induce the Soviet Union to remove its occupation forces from Austria. He suggested that the Foreign Ministers' deputies meet in London on Feb. 20 to wrestle again with the draft for an Austrian peace treaty.

Custom tailoring volume can be best promoted by a national foundation backed by the tailors and fabric suppliers, Robert Milbank of the National Woolens and Trimmings Association, declared yesterday. Such a foundation would also concern itself with the problem of increasing the number of workers in the industry, he said.

A ten-round lightweight battle between Willie Beltram, Bronx ring favorite, and Joey Carkido, Youngstown, Ohio, is scheduled as the feature attraction tonight at the Park Arena, the Bronx. Beltram, who is undefeated at the Bronx club as a main bout fighter since the engaged in his first feature there in Sept. 1946, will be seeking his eighth triumph as the club's topliner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The State Department today denounced as a distortion of the known facts a recent broadcast from Moscow alleging that the United States was busily militarizing Iran. It also rejected Soviet objections to the visit of United States warships to Italian ports.

The increasing rate of death from heart disease correlates "rather exactly" with the rising level of general insecurity evidenced by individual feelings of anxiety, Dr. Harry Stack Sullivan said last night at the William Alanson White Institute of Psychiatry meeting held at the New York Academy of Medicine.
The Cabinet Food Committee suggests a meatless corn meal and cheese mush for today's main dinner course:

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Berl Locker, a member of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted tonight that the allegation of official British sources that there had been many Communist agents among the 15,000 Jewish immigrants on the refugee ships Pan York and Pan Crescent was "entirely without foundation."

Prices on "dry" groceries will hold to their present levels through 1948 with changes, if any, taking the form of declines, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., asserted yesterday. The prospects on future business in groceries are now generally good, but he warned that manufacturers must hold to top quality to satisfy price-sharpened consumer discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Some of the nation's top sports writers and sports broadcasters today asked President Truman to join them in requesting professional sports leaders to set aside a special "Kid Day."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Citation, champion juvenile of 1947, and winter book favorite in the Kentucky Derby, won the $5,000 Ground Hog purse at Hialeah Park today while his stablemate, the mighty Armed, finished sixth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Louis K. Diamond, nationally known authority on hemotology and Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at the Harvard Medical School, Boston, today was appointed technical director for the American Red Cross national blood-bank program.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Feb. 2 -Food and comforts sent by the people of Boston and New England to Scotland were unloaded here today from the American gift food ship Eucadia, renamed Yankee Friendship for the occasion.

After a firm opening yesterday stock prices drifted irregularly and closed moderately easier in the dullest session in a week. Uncertainty over the ultimate fate of the tax cut bill now under consideration by Congress and the disturbing foreign situation were among the factors that accounted for the mostly indifferent market.

Prince Nobuhito Takamatsu, brother of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, accompanied by his wife and by Prince Kuni, brother of the Empress, it is reported from Tokyo, attended there a few days ago the first performance in Japanese of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado." Prince Nobuhito, we are told, said that it was "very interesting" and that he had "enjoyed it very much."

The piano recital given by Vladimir Horowitz last night in Carnegie Hall, attended by as many as the law would allow in the place, was testimony equally to his distinguished art and to the high intelligence of his public. The program provided nothing of a spectacular character.
Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of the board of the banking house of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., died in his sleep at 11:55 o'clock last night at his home in Boca Grande, Fla.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Paris banks were swamped today with their biggest crowds on record, all swarming to turn in their 5,000franc notes. Branches of United States banks, meanwhile, carried the added burden of caring for thousands of Americans cashing dollars at the new free-market rate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- New state aid for education as proposed last Thursday by Governor Dewey's committee on a state education program would add $924,190 a year to the aid received by Westchester County, the Board of Supervisors was told today by its legislative committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- A slowdown on both lending and spending as a means of combating inflation was recommended here today by Joseph M. Dodge, president of the Detroit Bank and the American Bankers Association. He conferred with bankers of California and Nevada in an all-day closed session.

Two proposals have recently been suggested for obtaining possession of European assets not presently available for the purpose and putting them to work under the European Recovery Program. One of these called for the forced liquidation of $4,300,000,000 of assets held in this country by citizens of European nations which are in line for the Marshall Plan.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi, a Zionist underground extremist group, is preparing an offensive beyond the borders of the proposed Jewish state in Palestine, an underground informant said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -The United States has added two new names -- thallium and gallium -- to its list of rare metals of strategic importance, the Bureau of Mines said today. Disclosing in its annual report that a considerable amount of metallurgical research on rare metals is under way, the Bureau said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -The text of President Truman's message to Congress on civil rights today follows:

As a result of the great increase in the number of hunting archers and the increased interest in bows, arrows and target shooting, the Archery Guild has been formed and has set up headquarters at 132 Nassau Street, New York City.

A collection of 110 Dutch poems, chosen and translated by Adriaan J. Barnouw, has been scheduled for March 8 publication by Rutgers University Press, under the title "Coming After: An Anthology of Poetry From the Low Countries." The book represents fifty-six poets and eight centuries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -The United States has added two new names -- thallium and gallium -- to its list of rare metals of strategic importance, the Bureau of Mines said today. Disclosing in its annual report that a considerable amount of metallurgical research on rare metals is under way, the Bureau said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -The text of President Truman's message to Congress on civil rights today follows:

As a result of the great increase in the number of hunting archers and the increased interest in bows, arrows and target shooting, the Archery Guild has been formed and has set up headquarters at 132 Nassau Street, New York City.

A collection of 110 Dutch poems, chosen and translated by Adriaan J. Barnouw, has been scheduled for March 8 publication by Rutgers University Press, under the title "Coming After: An Anthology of Poetry From the Low Countries." The book represents fifty-six poets and eight centuries.

Customs duties on articles brought in from France are being assessed at ports of entry throughout the United States on the old franc rate of exchange, rather than on the new devalued rate set by the French Government, it was learned yesterday at La Guardia Field.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 -- Although the unofficial but highly efficient ban against foreign films is still in force, two Hollywood offices here, M-G-M and United Artists, have been notified that two of their new pictures will be able to be shown on Buenos Aires' screens before the end of the week.
In your editorial on Palestine on Jan. 13 you said that Palestine "is a critical test for the United Nations." I should like to provide a commentary on this text.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The following is the vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate the Knutson tax-reduction bill:

In anticipation of a $500,000,000 sporting goods market this year, buyers yesterday crowded exhibits of some 400 manufacturers at the merchandise show of the National Sporting Goods Association at the Hotel New Yorker. Estimates put attendance of all types of retail buyers yesterday and Sunday at close to 3,000, which is expected to rise above 4,000 when the show closes on Friday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Seton Hall College's fast-stepping basketball team encountered surprisingly little opposition from Texas Wesleyan tonight and rolled to an easy, 59-to-41 victory over the Lone Star quintet before 3,000 home town fans.

Fearing further price rises later this year, buyers are placing orders now for heating, ventilating and air-conditioning equipment in quantities which indicate a peak sales year for 1948, officials of exhibiting companies said at the opening of the eighth International Heating and Ventilating Exposition at Grand Central Palace yesterday.
MADRID, Feb. 2 -- Spain's great black market scandal flared into the open today as some 1,500 students of the National University, joined by laborers, clamored for the culprits to be hanged.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Two United States fourman bobsled teams set new season records for the Olympic run today, but a few minutes later a crack Swiss team beat them both in final tune-ups for the championship runs tomorrow.

An impressive retrospective exhibition of paintings and graphic work by John Sloan opened yesterday at the Kraushaar Gallery, to remain through February. Mr. Sloan, nearing his seventy-seventh birthday, is entitled, if anyone should be so styled, to be known as the dean of American artists.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 6 per cent in January, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 2 -The $60,000,000 national fund raising campaign of American Overseas Aid and United Nations Appeal for Children opened here today at a luncheon at The Netherland Plaza Hotel.

Maritime Commission hearings on proposed new manning scales, wage rates and working conditions on Government-owned subsidized ships came to a close yesterday at 80 Broad Street with operator representatives asking retention of the $72.50 basic monthly wage set for seamen in 1937 by the commission and union officials urging a Government "hands-off policy" on the ground that the unions could do better bargaining for themselves.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (AP) -AFL carmen today accepted a compromise wage offer and returned to work on the privately owned Hyde and California Street Cable cars after a twenty-six-hour strike.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- A financial and monetary agreement has been reached between France and Lebanon, a former French mandate territory, and will be signed soon, it was reported today.

The executive board of the Council on African Affairs, Inc., voted last night after a five-hour session at the organization's headquarters, 23 West Twenty-sixth Street, to support a nonpartisan policy advocated by Max Yergan, publisher of The People's Voice, who is executive director of the council.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 2 (AP) -- President Romulo Betancourt has protested to Nicaragua that two planes carrying twenty-seven armed, hostile Venezuelans stopped over at Puerto Cabezas, Nicaragua, last month en route to Venezuela to make trouble.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In politics as in war half the battle is won by the commander who can dictate the field of action, and this is the preliminary struggle now going on in Congress. Looking forward to the Presidential contest of 1948, the Republican and Democratic parties are trying to place each other on the ground that will be most difficult to defend or serve as the base of aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Without comment, the Supreme Court refused today to reopen a case affecting the financing of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. It rejected a petition by Randolph Phillips, an owner of bonds of the railroad, who questioned whether Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and Justice Stanley F. Reed should have participated in an earlier refusal of another plea.

Net earnings of the National Steel Corporation for 1947 amounted to $26,838,788 after provision for all charges, including $19,270,000 for taxes and $12,853,292 for depreciation, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday.

Seven former Boy Scouts, all veterans of World War II, have set up a fund to send needy youths to Boy Scout camp next summer. Maurice L. Schoenwald, an attorney, who is the group's chairman, explained that the seven wanted to return to scouting what they had received from it.

The host of friends that Maurice J. (Moe) Casner has made in his fifty-five years as a New York newspaper man were planning to pay tribute to him on Thursday evening, but the dinner and the speeches they prepared are postponed now.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -The International Typographical Union today asked dismissal of a suit for an injunction against violation of the Taft-Hartley Law. The union, in its answer to the injunction suit of the National Labor Relations Board, charged that the Taft-Hartley Law is unconstitutional.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The queues lined up around the banks yesterday and today to turn in their worthless 5,000-franc notes are a sound picture of France in transition. They are not patient like the British queues, for the French, besides being a people difficult to line up and regulate, have never adopted a national attitude of dogged cheerfulness.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 3 -- The Soviet Union has attempted to induce Belgium to deliver uranium and tin in exchange for wheat, it was learned here today. There was never any question of the Russians' getting uranium, but the Belgians did promise to see what could be done on the score of tin.
David J. Greene, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has moved his office to 60 Beaver Street and will clear his transactions through H. Hentz Co.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Stabilization of the economy by concentration on the control of a few basic agricultural and non-agricultural products, such as grain and steel, was recommended today by the National Farmers Union.

The Southwestern Public Service Company announced yesterday that subscriptions for 135,389 common shares, at $21 a share, had been received in connection with its offering of 103,113 shares, which expired on Monday.
TEHERAN, Iraq, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Tension increased today over Russia's charge that United States representatives were engaged in military preparations in Iran that were unfriendly to the Soviet Union.
A preview of the thirty-second annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Artists was held last night at the Brooklyn Museum and the show opens to the public today.

Mayor O'Dwyer's dominant theme in his annual message to the City Council is his insistence that the state does not treat New York City fairly in distribution of aid to localities, but this ought not to obscure the fact that he was able to report some real progress on a number of other fronts during 1947.

The liner Washington starts today the first regular popular-priced service to Europe on a large, fast vessel, according to officials of the United States Lines, which is operating the former luxury ship on bareboat charter from the Maritime Commission.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 3 -- Europe is recovering from the effects of war and "there is no emergency today which remotely justifies reimposing wartime controls in this country," Morris Sayre of Montclair N.J., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said here tonight.

Effectiveness of new financing transactions involving the marketing of common stock, railroad equipment trust certificates and public utility bonds valued at more man $40,000,000 was announced yesterday by underwriting managers as follows:
Births, which set a high record in this city in 1947, declined during January to the lowest level for any month since June, 1946, Health Department statisticians reported yesterday.

In a case believed to be unprecedented here, a New York public high school student who would not take a loyalty oath on the ground that he was a conscientious objector has been refused a graduation diploma by his principal.

Cordell Hull's endorsement of croquet, contained in a recent installment of his memoirs appearing in this newspaper, as a "really very scientific game" and one "more strenuous than most people think" was received warmly by all croquet players who have attempted at one time or another, with indifferent success, to convince a few skeptics that there is more to the game than meets the eye.

In a quick resale, a syndicate headed by Jack D. Weiler and Benjamin H. Swig has disposed of the Brooklyn building at 514-16 Fulton Street, at the corner of Hanover Place, which is leased to J.W. May, Inc., and occupied by May's Department Store.

The President's message to Congress on civil liberties outlines a broad program of legislation to which most of us can readily subscribe, at least in principle. Some items will induce controversy, especially in the Southern states, but even there the opposition will be chiefly against methods urged rather than the purposes to be achieved.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Former Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, has been selected by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor to direct the federation's political campaign against Congressional supporters of the Taft-Hartley Law.

MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- The world-wide fight of the American Federation of Labor agains the expansion of Soviet influence moved forward today with the receipt of formal word that trade union representatives from sixteen European countries would meet in Brussels next month to support the Marshall Plan.

Opened by a lecture on historic quilts by Mrs. Florence Peto last evening, an exhibition of fifty quilted and patchwork examples will go on public view this morning at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Four days after the death of Mohandas K. Gandhi, India and Pakistan renewed their diplomatic battle before the United Nations Security Council today with a new flurry of charges of murder, looting and aggression.

Isidore Ginsberg, accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in a Housing Committee hearing in Washington of being the "most vicious of the gray marketeers," is being sued in Queens for return of money paid for rock-lath that he failed to deliver.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Charles Maas, voted Butler University's most valuable basketball player last year, today said he was offered a $500 bribe to keep down the score of the Butler-Ohio University game last Saturday night.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The British Government charged the Rumanian Government with violation of the peace treaty in a note delivered over the week-end in Bucharest and made public here today. It is understood that Washington sent a similar note at the same time. [The State Department announced Monday the dispatch of such a note.]
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that "very little spoliage" has resulted from shipping potatoes overseas.

Thomas E. Murray, former trustee of the United Mine Workers' weflare fund, issued a statement yesterday criticizing both John L. Lewis, representative of the mine union, and Ezra Van Horn, representative of the mine owners, for their failure to reach an agreement on miners' pensions.

The size of the American Merchant Marine will depend upon two things -- the nation's participation in the transportation re requirements arising from the execution of the Marshall Plan and also the more complete resumption of normal commercial trade between the various countries, according to Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

William Green, head of the American Federation of Labor, has repudiated the rival "union" established by Matt Shelvey, former administrator of the American Guild of Variety Artists, according to an announcement made yesterday by AGVA.

Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to the United States, thanked the members of the large audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for their contribution to Italy. They were there at an operatic program for the benefit of the Permanent Committee to Help Italian Orphans.

In line with its recently adopted policy of answering Russian propaganda with directness and dispatch, the United States Government has promptly rejected one Russian protest regarding American actions as "without foundation," has denounced another protest as a "distortion of the known facts," and is reserving like treatment for two other Russian protests still on the way.

The first monthly "progress report" of the Palestine Commission of the United Nations makes somber reading. In it, this five-man agency which has been instructed to carry out the General Assembly's plan for partition "envisages the possibility of a collapse of security and administrative service" when Britain withdraws, unless the commission receives "adequate means" of enforcing its authority.

Advertising linage in New York City newspapers totaled 10,548,695 lines during January, a decline of 1.58 per cent, compared to a total of 10,718,210 lines for the like period of 1947, according to an analysis of Media Records reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of the House of Representatives told the ninth conference of American Small Business Associations tonight that the Republican party firmly believed that "business along with the rest of the taxpayers is entitled to honest tax relief."

Mayor O'Dwyer and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will support the regular Democratic party nominee for Congress in the Bronx in the special election to be held on Feb. 17, regarded as a test of Truman-Wallace strength in a typical urban area.

Although several factors account for the recent easiness in grain prices, including the improved outlook for this year's wheat crop, especially in Europe, an underlying influence is the prospect of further currency devaluation by European countries.

A new low-cost, lightweight tractor, said to provide the first successful "riding model" rotary tiller, will be introduced by the Frazer Farm Equipment Corporation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Saturday and Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer, president of the company.

One of the most interesting features of the latest report of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission was its classification of the striped bass legislation as "social policy" rather than "conservation measures."

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Danny Kaye, making his first personal appearance in London last night as the star attraction in the vaudeville bill at the Palladium, scored the greatest success seen in the British music hall in many years.

STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 3 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, in an obvious concession to the fears of German political leaders, assured them today that the United States and British Military Governments assumed "responsibility" for the creation of the projected Bizonal Economic Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Former Senator Burton K. Wheeler had not decided today whether to accept the post as director of the American Federation of Labor's League for Political Education, an appointment approved by the federation's executive council at its meeting in Miami.
William J. Flather Jr. has been elected president of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company and Martin M. Reed has been made executive vice president in addition to his present office of secretary.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,072, against 1,135 last week and 1,575 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 628 arrivals yesterday, compared with 353 last Tuesday.

In aiding Europe, America has the double task of deciding what is the right thing to do and at the same time convincing people that it is motivated by the desire to do the right thing, it was emphasized last night by W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce.

In behalf of the 1948 drive of the American Red Cross, fifteen-minute versions of some of radio's most popular programs will be offered on transcriptions over most of the nation's stations. The variety series will start in mid-February and run through March, the drive officially opening during the first week of next month.

Pearl Buck's new novel, "Peony," which will be published by John Day on May 20, is the Literary Guild's June selection. Set in China of a hundred years ago, it is Miss Buck's tenth novel about that country and her second Guild selection, the first being "Pavillion of Women."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 3 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, speaking in English, broadcast to the United States and Britain today about the coming change in relationship between her country and Indonesia. She declared that "colonialism is dead," and that Indonesia could make an important contribution to the success of the Marshall Plan.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 3 -- The anti-trust suit against forty-seven western railroads, New York financial concerns, officers and individuals, with more than 300 alleged co-conspirators listed, started today in Federal Court with the dismissal, by plaintiff, of thirty-four individual defendants, including the late Thomas W. Lamont of New York, and James G. Harbord of Rye, N.Y.

A 65-year-old man was shot and killed about 9 o'clock last night in an exchange of shots between two hold-up men and two plain clothes detectives assigned to protect a liquor store at 35 Columbus Avenue, near West Sixty-first Street.

DUBLIN, Feb. 3 -- Premier Eamon de Valera closed the hardest electoral battle he has ever fought with an appeal tonight to the people of Ireland to give him a majority when they go to the polls tomorrow.

Judging by the enrollment for the men's cooking class being given by the Brooklyn Red Cross, it appears that bachelors are more interested than married men in learning how to prepare foods. From teen-agers to gray-haired gentlemen, all students attending the six-lesson course agreed that their purpose was to master enough of the culinary art so they could whip up a full-course dinner -- for themselves.

Secretary Eddie Brannick, of the Giants, yesterday added three more contract signers to the growing list of contented players and, although one is a pitcher, it is doubtful that Manager Mel Ott will regard his mound problems as solved.

Observers said yesterday that the voluntary steel allocation system being devised by the Government with members of the industry would not deprive steel consumers of any substantial amounts of the metal, even though Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman has requested diversion of steel to four industries he deems most essential.

With virtually all the baseball experts in the land already predicting that the 1948 American League pennant race will be fought out between the champion Yankees and Boston's revitalized Red Sox, local fans will not be kept long in suspense before these top rivals come to grips.

This country has 5,000,000 disabled housewives, Dr. Donald A. Covalt, associate professor of rehabilitation and physical medicine at New York University, declared yesterday in the Junior League Club, 221 East Seventy-first Street. He said housewives were injured or disabled at the rate of 1,000 a day.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Fourteen persons, including a former Right-Wing Socialist Premier, Karol Peyer, went on trial today, charged with having organized a plot to overthrow the Government.

Thomas W. Lamont will no doubt be remembered primarily by his countrymen, and by the world, as one of the great financiers of his generation. And as far as it goes this will be an accurate appraisal. In 1910, less than seven years after he entered the banking profession, and before he was 41, the young Lamont had become a partner in the House of Morgan.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- There are 157,000 refugees in European camps solely because of a lack of shipping to move them, William Hallam Tuck, executive secretary of the preparatory commission of the International Refugee Organization, said today.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Continuation of State Senator David Van Alstyne Jr. as a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator was widely discussed today among party leaders.

The Irving R. Raber Company has sold to J. Eis Sons, electrical appliance dealers, the five-story building containing a store and eight apartments at 107 First Avenue for cash above mortgages amounting to $22,300. The buyer will alter the building and connect it with his adjoining store at No. 105, to provide for expansion.

Ivan Ivanovich gets up before the light comes to the street in the Arbat quarter of Moscow where he lives. Gita, his wife, is still sleeping. She works part time at a factory, does the housework and spends hours standing in line to buy the household's food. These days she is always tired. So Ivan dresses in silence.

Dr. Channing H. Tobias refused yesterday to withdraw his resignation from the Council on African Affairs, Inc., of 23 West Twenty-sixth Street, an organization supporting "the Africans' struggle for democracy and freedom.'' His decision was reached, he said, on the refusal of the organization to pass a motion that would declare it "neither Fascist, Communist nor subversive."
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The only really busy sections in the stock markets here today were the oils and Orange Free State gold shares.
An Australian flag flown from the auxiliary cruiser Monoora during the war in the Pacific was given yesterday to the Veterans of Foreign Wars as a symbol of friendship between the two countries.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (AP) -- What had threatened to become an international incident over the presence on the Austrian winter Olympic squad of three former members of the German army "has been settled very amicably," Dr. Jean Carle, acting president of the International Ski Federation, announced today.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- A "spontaneous" National Parliament will be proclaimed in Berlin on March 18 under Soviet sponsorship, it is firmly believed by high-ranking German Communists close to the Soviet military administration here.

Declaring that the city was saddled with many governmental expenses that should properly be borne by the state government, Mayor O'Dwyer renewed his demand for $84,500,000 in new state aid when he submitted his annual message to the City Council yesterday.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Sweden again took over the winter Olympic leadership from Norway with smashing victories in skiing and skating today as United States athletes failed once more to hit the winner's circle.

After an ownership of about a year, William Intner, operator, has sold the five-story store and apartment building at 1246 Second Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets, to a client of E.J. Feinberg, lawyer. The property is opposite the square block recently acquired by the New York Life Insurance Company for a housing center.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- Dr. Philipp Auerbach, Bavarian commissioner for victims of political and racial persecution, voiced criticism tonight of the American attitude toward the Jewish refugees remaining in Germany.

The St. John's basketball team gained its seventh victory in fifteen starts this season with a 62-46 conquest of Brooklyn College at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 2,561 saw the Redmen register their sixth straight success over the Kingsmen.

Net income of the Barium Steel Corporation last year reached a high of $1,721,111 after taxes and all charges and contrasted with $11,344 earned in 1946, according to the preiminary annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

ST. MORITZ, Feb. 3 -- The historic Olympic flag was stolen tonight from its mast over the Olympic Ice Stadium here, probably by an over-ambitious souvenir hunter. The flag is hoisted the moment the games open and must, according to the games' regulations, fly until they are declared closed. It has a white background with no border.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Shannon II, Australian racing champion, finished a well-beaten third in the seven-furlong Canada purse at Santa Anita today, running four lengths behind the winning Plumper, who negotiated the course in 1:23 2/5.

Resuming its inquiry into the Long Island Rail Road's breakdown during the big snow in December, the Public Service Commission was told yesterday that another major storm probably would bring the same results.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Department of the Army tonight overruled an order by Gen. Douglas MacArthur that had been criticized as limiting freedom of the press.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Coert du Bois, a retired United States foreign service officer, has been named to replace Dr. Frank P. Graham on the Indonesian Mediation Committee of the United Nations Security Council in the event that Dr. Graham is unable to go out with the commission to supervise the proposed plebiscite.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Companion bills setting up a system of permanent voter registration in New York and other cities of the state were introduced today by the chairmen of the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House passed today with thumping election-year majorities two bills adding $350,000,000 or more to the benefits paid out to war veterans in college and in on-the-job training programs.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- At a forum here today on the question "Do women's clubs waste womanpower?" Members of the manor club were told by some speakers that clubwomen were not utilizing their full intellectual and political powers.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The budget committees of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) sharply criticized inefficiency in the Soviet Government and in industry today, charging that costs were far above the planned levels, while housing construction was lagging behind.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 -- Leaders of the Socialist wing of the Congress party demanded today in a formal statement that the Dominion Cabinet resign "in symbolic atonement for the evil deed" of Mohandas K. Gandhi's assassination.

Twenty-nine nations, seven more than last year, have filed challenges for the Davis Cup, it was announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association through Walter Merill Hall, chairman of the committee of management.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. (AP) -- National Airlines' 145 pilots began a walkout just before midnight tonight. Flights departing from Miami for Newark, N.J., at 11:30 P.M. and the 11:59 P.M. flight from Newark to Miami were canceled.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission decided today to send a strongly worded letter to Sir Alexander Cadogan protesting against the British Government's refusal to allow the commission to go to the Holy Land until two weeks before the termination of the mandate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Thoroughly angered Southern Democrats blazed into new revolt today over the ten-point civil-rights program which President Truman sent to Congress yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Two Queens Republicans, Senator Frederic E. Hammer and Assemblyman Henry Schneider Jr., sharply criticized tonight a memorandum to legislative leaders from the New York City administration opposing their bill to compel the city to incinerate all garbage after 1953.
PEIPING, Feb. 3 (AP) -- United States citizens are being evacuated by plane from Changchun, Manchuria's capital, long isolated by the Communists.

THE way toward neutrality legislation in the United States was paved by the hearings of the Nye Committee, established by the Senate to investigate the manufacture and sale of arms and munitions. It is doubtful that any Congressional committee has ever had a more unfortunate effect on our foreign relations, unless it be the Senate Foreign Relations Committee considering the Treaty of Versailles submitted by President Wilson.

A 17-year-old girl, who said she received her inspiration from a movie about Dillinger, and seven young males were arrested yesterday on charges of having committed robberies last week on the upper East Side. They were booked at the East Sixty-seventh Street station on charges of burglary, assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.

SWAINSBORO, Ga., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Hooded Ku Klux Klansmen burned a fiery cross on the lawn of the Emanuel County courthouse tonight after marching in single file around the town square and through the residential section.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Dr. David S. Rhone, Director of Public Safety, and six present and former city officials today entered pleas of not guilty to indictments charging them with misconduct in office.

Joe Falco, 155 1/2, Philadelphia, won the unanimous decision over favored Danny Kapilow, 154 1/4, Brooklyn, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A gathering of 3,800 watched the free-punching clash. There were no knockdowns.

"The Idiot," a French-made adaptation of the Dostoyevsky work, starring Gerard Philippe and Edwige Feuillere, will have its local premiere today at the Golden Theatre. The drama, which was directed by Georges Lampin from a script by Charles Spaak, is being presented by Andre Lelarge and features Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier and Marguerite Moreno.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Southern Democrats, incensed by President Truman's request for Federal measures to outlaw lynching, state poll taxes and "Jim Crow" segregation, and for a Federal Fair Employment Practices Act, are again, as in 1944, threatening to cast their state electoral votes against the Democratic nominees for President and Vice President, to be chosen at the regular national convention of the party.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 3 -- The Stern Group, Jewish extremists, warned the Palestine police today that they would pay with their lives for Sunday night's bombing of the Palestine Post building.
Officials at the Board of Education apparently agree with New York public high school seniors that the recent Regents examination in "American History and World Backgrounds" was too difficult.

Five major innovations in heating and air-conditioning equipment will be pushed by wholesalers and contractor-dealers during 1948, industry spokesmen disclosed yesterday at the International Heating and Ventilating Exposition at Grand Central Palace.

Babe Ruth's delayed vacation finally got under way yesterday when, accompanied by Mrs. Ruth and a male nurse, Frank Delaney, he boarded a train at Penn Station and rolled away at 1:10 P.M. for Miami. His plans are to spend a month there and then begin a tour of the baseball camps.
Bakery unions announced last night a new deadline of midnight Friday for a city-wide bread strike after mediation talks sponsored by the city's Labor Relations Division had bogged down.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 3 -- A score of persons were wounded in Tripoli today in a riot between demonstrators demanding a financial break between Lebanon and France and those demanding a cession of Tripoli to Syria. Tripoli was more or less arbitrarily included in the Lebanese state when the French drew its frontiers during the mandate period.

With Alexander Hilsberg conducting and Jacques Thibaud as violin soloist, the season's seventh Carnegie Hall program by the Philadelphia Orchestra last night was a delightful and stimulating experience. Mr. Thibaud gave an elegant and graceful performance of Mozart's A major Concerto (K. 219), and Mr. Hilsberg led the orchestra not only in sensitively adjusted support of the soloist but in distinctive readings of Prokofieff's "Classical" Symphony and Beethoven's Third.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- New Jersey Legislative leaders, always conscious of public opposition to new taxes, were cautious today in offering support for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's new tax program.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Having tried for several months to induce Washington to enable it to get possession of private French assets in the United States, the French Government was much pleased today by the statement of the Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, that the frozen dollars and dollar securities of Europeans soon would be turned over to their Governments.

The war-devastated Netherlands merchant marine has been rebuilt to about 95 per cent of its 1939 strength, but efficient operation is handicapped by a lack of small vessels, Johannes F. van Hengel, Netherlands Ministry of Traffic representative, declared here yesterday.

An "all-day program" for children handicapped by damaged hearts will start officially today at Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. "The whole day's living is considered part of the program," the president, Mrs. Edwin H. Koehler, explained in an interview yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- John J. McCloy, president of the-International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that he wanted to make it "quite clear" that the bank was not contemplating another bond issue at present.

THE first major league roster to reach this desk as a preliminary to the opening of the spring training season on March 1 contains a striking illustration on its front cover. It's one of those classic Willard Mullin cartoons of the frayed, seedy and bulbous gent who is such an obvious butt-snitching tramp that he is easily recognized as the symbol for our Beloved Bums.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Norman M. Littell, former assistant attorney general, today proposed to the House Foreign Affairs Committee that the European Recovery Program be amended to keep the encouragement of private investments abroad separate from all other phases of the program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A proposal to authorize the Government to prepare stand-by machinery for meat rationing was rejected today by a Senate banking and currency subcommittee. The vote was 3 to 2.

Like John McGraw, Ray Flaherty is a pilot who is not content to stand pat on a winning hand. The coach of the New York Foot-ball Yankees of the All-America Conference led his team to the Eastern championship for the second successive year last December but already he has made important additions to build up the reserve strength of the club.

Failing to receive the box-office encouragement he had counted upon for a pro-labor offering, David Lowe announces the closing of "The Cradle Will Rock" Saturday night at the Broadway. Presented for the seventh time since Marc Blitzstein's "play in music" was first introduced in 1937, the attraction was brought into the large house on Jan. 28 and will quit after the thirteenth performance.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Forty seconds before the game ended, Harvard Capt. George Hauptfuhrer pushed a field goal that provided the Crimson with a 47-45 triumph over Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball contest before 9,038 fans tonight at Boston Garden.

HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- Lockwood Pirie of the Sheridan Shore Yacht Club, Chicago, sailed his Twin Star over the finishing line this morning to win his second successive race of the Bacardi Cup series in the seventeenth international Star Class regatta today and roll up 22 points for the series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Navy promised New York City and State officials tonight to work out a plan by tomorrow afternoon whereby some fuel oil would be lent to the city. The amount and other details of the arrangement win be completed tomorrow, it was said.

Queen Wilhelmina seldom speaks to her subjects. When she does, what she has to say gains added importance. This is true of her report yesterday to the wartime allies of her country on what is being done in the Netherlands Indies to advance the welfare of the people there and to carry out the promises she herself made and those which are implicit in the Atlantic Charter.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- At least 1,500,000 German workers stayed away from their jobs today in a quiet but effective protest against various German food administrations in the United States and British zones.

The stock market suffered its widest reversal yesterday in almost two weeks. Softness in the oils and chemicals brought out sympathetic selling in other major sections, although the key industrials were not generally disposed to join the over-all trend.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Marquess of Salisbury, leader of the opposition in the House of Lords, made a new proposal to the Government today covering the delaying powers of the upper chamber.
