The Cabinet will consider it tomorrow morning when, it is hoped and believed on all sides, the leaders of all political parties will get together to study the reform of the House of Lords.
Governor Dewey drew a "friendly" chiding from the New York building industry yesterday for some harsh things he had said Jan. 22 in a speech here before the Community Service Society at Town Hall.

Out of native love for Ireland, Michael Sayers has written an amateur allegory, "Kathleen," which had an amateur performance at the Mansfield last evening. Although she is Kathleen Fogarty in the play, she is Kathleen ni Houhlihan to Mr. Sayers, and everything she does is fraught with poetic significance.
Continued discussion of situation in Jammu and Kashmir; received two draft resolutions from Indian representative.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Tiny Monaco, 370-acre country nestled among the hills and crags of the Mediterranean shore, threw the United Nations Economic and Social Council into a debate today over her request for a voice in international affairs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings increased their first place margin in the National Hockey League tonight with a 4-to-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 16,112 fans. It was their ninth victory in ten starts against Chicago, and was marked by 19 penalties, six of which were majors for fighting.

Twenty-five members of the Blockade Runners of Haganah, a recently formed organization of former crew members who ran the British blockade off Palestine, picketed yesterday from noon until 2 P.M. in front of 630 Fifth Avenue, where the British visa office is located on the thirty-fifth floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) -M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, today blamed Government regulatory bodies' failure to make "sufficiently prompt authorizations for advances in rates" for his company's small profit earned in 1947.
Shelby County, Tenn., announced yesterday that it would accept bids until March 1 on $2,433,000 of bonds dated March 1, 1948, and due March 1 from 1949 to 1963.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 3 -- The nation's automobile production should equal 5,000,000 cars this year and may exceed that number by 15 per cent, Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, said here today.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- "We should like to know whether the Marshall Plan involves insuring the independence of the French press or replacing it," wrote the Monde today, commenting upon a statement published here that some United States Congressmen desired to see an American newspaper issued in France in French.
Following is the text of the radio address made by Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherdands, yesterday, as issued by the Netherlands Information Bureau:

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Public Service Committees of the State Legislature reported out favorably today legislation which would extend the power of the Public Service Commission to divert and control the supply of gas in periods of emergency.

Samuel Yachter, landlord and owner of a two-story frame house at 210 East Fifty-third Street, in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, attempted yesterday to solve the problem of fuelless oil tanks and rid himself of the complaints of angry tenants.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Some 500 paratroopers were holding "combat" positions in the deep snow and sub-zero cold of this military reservation tonight after the largest winter parachute drop in American military experience.

With the acquisition of 2871 Bainbridge Avenue, in the Bronx, from Mrs. Helena Just, the Grace Evangelical Lutheran Church of Bedford Park has assembled a plot as the site for a new church. Walter M. Lucker was the broker and Theobald J. Dengler was attorney for the buyer.

A funeral service will be held at 10 A.M. Saturday in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, for Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of the board of directors of the banking house of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc. Mr. Lamont died Monday night at his home in Boca Grande, Fla., at the age of 77.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The State Department warned Congress today that any reduction in the $6,800,000,000 asked by President Truman for starting the Marshall Plan "would jeopardize the success of the program."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Pensions for 500,000 workers in the basic steel industry are tied in with John L. Lewis' demand for a $100-a-month pension plan for coal miners, it was learned today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 3 -- One conspicuous effect of the reduction of dollar imports is the gradual disappearance from the book stores here of popular American reprints of the classics.

ATHENS, Feb. 3 -- Minister of Interior Peter Mavromichaelis transmitted to the Cabinet today complaints from forty Peloponnesan Deputies alleging that their constituencies were inadequately protected against guerrilla aggression. sion.

Hundreds of thousands of persons were delayed in getting to work yesterday morning when all service on the East Side IRT subway between Grand Central and Brooklyn Bridge was stopped during rush hours. The tie-up was caused by water from a break in an eight-inch pipe in the city's high pressure system flooding the subway tracks between Twentieth and Twenty-sixth Streets.

Bounced from the ranks of the unbeaten last Saturday by Syracuse, Fordham strives to return to winning ways tonight against the Rutgers basketball team at the Maroon gymnasium. Fordham, with a record of eleven successes and one defeat, had an identical slate last season when it bowed to Rutgers, 69 -- 55, at New Brunswick, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States rejected in a short, terse note today the Russian protest against the agreement reached with Great Britain for temporary use by American air transit planes of the Mellaha airfield in Libya.

The Rev. Dr. William Orlando Carrington, pastor of the First African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, became the first Negro president of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation and Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, 42-year-old West Pointer and President Truman's recent unsuccessful nominee for chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, will be named commander of a new Army-Navy air-transport system.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- W.J. Walden's Circus Clown, one of the second-flight hopefuls for the $50,000 added Flamingo Stakes of Feb. 28, drove to his second straight triumph at Hialeah Park in today's featured Cape Sable Purse.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Liquidation in corn today spread to other grains. Although the latter resisted pressure, the close was lower on the Board of Trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, New York, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, demanded today that the textile industry absorb all increased costs of fabrics to prevent any further rise in prices of the nation's wearing apparel.

Don Strachan of the Princeton Club eliminated Richard S. Rothschild of the Downtown A. C., defending titleholder, in the metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship yesterday at the University Club.

Members of the City Council evoked a spirited and unexpected protest yesterday from Bertha Schwartz, a Bronx Democrat, who gave them a piece of her mind over proposed legislation banning service of drinks to unescorted women in bars.

The National Better Business Bureau, Inc., yesterday took issue with the Federal Trade Commission over a new administrative ruling on use of the word "free," in which the commission decided, by a three-to-two vote, that it considers "free" offers where a purchase is required to be a violation of the FTC Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission heeded today the plea of bondholders affected by the plan of reorganization the commission approved last June for the Wisconsin Central Railway Company, and ordered the proceeding reopened for further public hearing.

The American Veterans Committee disclosed yesterday that it had resorted to court action to combat what was called an arbitrary and discriminatory practice of Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

The sixty-sixth annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York has exceeded its goal, it was announced yesterday by William H. Jackson, general chairman of the 1947 campaign. Mr. Jackson announced that receipts from the 1947 campaign were $2,388,672, an increase of $636,900 over the 1946 campaign returns and $4,785 larger than its goal of $2,383,887.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman extended congratulations on the occasion of the attainment by Ceylon of Dominion status within the British Commonwealth of Nations in a message today to Sir Henry Moore, the Governor General.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- With the Soviet representative, Jacob M. Lomakin, casting the single dissenting vote, the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of the Press today approved, 9-1, a report embodying the entire work of its two-week session.
The New York City Youth Board has made a new application to the State Youth Commission for state funds to continue operation of the existing child day care centers here, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Agreement on a $3,000,000,000 budget-cutting goal was reported "probable" today as Chairman Styles Bridges of New Hampshire called a showdown meeting of Senate-House budget committeemen for tomorrow.

Directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock, payable on March 15. Last year shareholders received 25 cents in March and quarterly dividends of 20 cents in June, September and December, plus a 15-cent extra in the final month.

After nearly forty years in one ownership the five-story business and apartment building at 540 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, has been purchased by David S. Meister, operator, from Land Brokerage, Inc.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Despite the tremendous amount of publicity given to United Statos food imports into Germany, three out of ten residents of the American zone still believe the United States occupation troops are using German food supplies, a Military Government survey disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Tony Owen, motion-picture agent, former Chicago, newspaper man and husband of Donna Reid, film actress, has concluded a deal to produce a cinematic history of The Associated Press for release by Columbia, the studio announced today.

A mortgage of $468,600 figured in the sale of the fifteen-story apartment building at 340 East Fifty-seventh Street by Court Williams Realty Company to Wooster Properties, Inc., according to details of the transaction made public yesterday by the City Title Insurance Company.

Custom tailors will have a much larger labor force to draw upon in the next twelve months and therefore will be in a position to deliver made-to-order clothes in from four to six weeks instead of four to six months as at present, according to Phil Fairchild, newly elected president of the Custom Tailors and Designers Association of America.

American business must voluntarily rid itself of undesirable practices to avoid an excess of Government regulation and safeguard the American free enterprise system, Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of Namm's Inc., and former president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared last night.
The election of H.E. Babcock, Neal Dow Becker and John A. Stevenson to the board of directors of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation was announced yesterday by Victor Emanuel, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman today renewed the Administration request for extension of authority to control imports of fats, oils, rice, nitrogen fertilizer materials and pig iron. He also recommended continuation of allocation controls over tin, antimony and quinidine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Navy's Antarctic expedition found in a hut in McMurdo Sound a report on the rescue of seven men and the death of three others from British Explorer Shackleton's 1915-17 venture.
PARIS, Feb. 3 -- On the second day of the free market the franc was fractionally higher today, closing at 309 to the dollar, compared with 311 at the first session yesterday.

After opening 1 to 6 points lower, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange slumped yesterday, reaching the lows of the day at the close, 5 to 22 points net lower than the day before, with the near months displaying the greatest weakness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Two Democratic Senators tried but failed today to keep Edwin W. Pauley and Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham from being censured publicly for their commodity-market speculations.

A. Howard Myers, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, denied yesterday a half dozen motions made by attorneys for the International Typographical Union to dismiss charges of unfair labor practices filed by the Union Employers Section of the Printing Industry of America.

The new store and showroom building to be erected by the L. and L. Realty Corporation of 303 Greenwich Street, on the corner plot at 1211-17 Avenue of the Americas and 100-2 West Forty-eighth Street will cost $100,000, according to plans filed yesterday by J. Bernard Pfeiffer, architect.

An ensign in the United States Naval Reserve and a former pilot with the Canadian Air Force surrendered to the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday to face charges in connection with the attempt last month to ship TNT to Palestine.

A completely furnished American Federal parlor will be opened to the public at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today at 10 A.M. Presented by the Bertha King Benkard Memorial Fund, the room is in the American Wing. It illustrates an important style period hitherto not represented in the wing, museum authorities said.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 3 -- The Manchester Union, leading morning newspaper of New Hampshire, will announce its active support of the candidacy of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for the Republican Presidential nomination in tomorrow's editions, William Loeb, the publisher, said today.
Further increases in Government purchases of goods and services in 1948 were predicted yesterday by Wesley Lindow, economist for the Irving Trust Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Edward F.P. Eagan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, was assailed on the floor of the State Senate today for, allegedly having failed to properly investigate conditions under which boxing matches are conducted in New York State.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- Travel to Japan has been thrown wide open for allied traders and persons seeking restoration of their property or opportunities for private investment, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced here today. Traders' national quotas have been suspended and the period of their visits raised from twenty-one to sixty days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Consolidation of the air transport systems of the Navy and the Air Force was announced today by Secretary of Defense James Forrestal.h)0*0*0*iIt was the first concrete step in the direction of unification of the armed forces since he took office under the new law last September.

Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, was urged yesterday by Dr. Clyde R. Miller, Associate Professor of Education at Teachers College, "to consider initiating action" to rescind the award of a 1947 Pulitzer Prize to Frederick Woltman, New York World-Telegram reporter.

The city's newly validated eviction control laws passed their first legal test yesterday when Supreme Court Justices James B. M. McNally and Henry Clay Greenberg upheld the validating law signed by Governor Dewey on Tuesday. The action of both the Legislature and courts was hailed by Paul L. Ross, chairman of the City Rent Commission, for the resultant clarification of the status of both landlords and tenants.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 4 -State Senator David Van Alstyne Jr., of Englewood, announced this evening his withdrawal as a candidate for nomination by the Republican party for the United States Senate, in opposition to Senator Albert W. Hawkes.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 Legislation to extend partial tax exemption to housing projects and to extend the provision in the public housing law relating to emergency veterans' housing for one year was adopted in the State Senate today.
The B'nai B'rith, through Frank Goldman, its president, announced yesterday that it had reluctantly decided not to join the permanent American Jewish Assembly.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 4 -- Foreign Trade Minister Hubert Ripka demanded of the Government today that the list of directors of the three banks, to which the commercial banking system in Bohemia and Moravia has been reduced, be revised by a vote of the banks' employes.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The Soviet Union is now building five new railroads to the borders of Manchuria and the satellite Republic of Outer Mongolia, the official organ of the Ministry of Education of the Russian Sovieth)0*0*0*iFederation, Geografia V. Shkole, said today.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has modified his ban on the making of new transcriptions to permit the continuance of such network recorded shows as those of Bing Crosby, Abbott and Costello and Groucho Marx.

This year's snow covering will prove beneficial to perennial gardens, Miss Anne B. Wertzner, field secretary of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, said yesterday at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Allen Tate, whose "Poems, 19221947" was published by Scribners on Monday, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters from the University of Louisville next Monday. Scribners has scheduled for March 29 publication "

Early termination of the long standing disagreement between two groups of stockholders of the $750,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company was assured yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
SOPHIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 4 -- Bulgaria became a one-party state today, her internal and foreign policies openly modeled on and wedded to the Soviet Union.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP) - Notre Dame rallied in the last two minutes on goals by Jim O'Halloran and Leo Barnhorst to shade Butler in a basketball game tonight, 53 - 52.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall reminded Congress today that the European Recovery Program must be approved by April 1 to prevent a vacuum in the pipeline of food and materials to Western Europe and serious embarrassment to this government.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- State Republicans started a drive todayh) 0*0*0*ito increase state aid for education by the $103,000,000 recommended by the Public Education Association as a substitute for the $30,000,000 proposed by Governor. Dewey's committee on a state educational program.

Don Strachan of the Princeton Club, winner of the national title in 1935, gained the final of the Metropolitan squash racquets Class A championship last night when he defeated Bob Reeve of the Bayside T.C. in impressive style,h)0*0*0*i15 -- 14, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 10.
There are no indications that there exists in the Soviet Union any organized political underground opposition to the regime, harsh and repressive though it is.

The Long Island Rail Road's defense of its service during the big snow in December was interrupted yesterday morning about an hour after the sixth session of the Public Service Commission inquiry on the subject had started.

For the first time in the history of the heating and air-conditioning business, dealers and distributors are competing aggressively to get increased allotments from their sources of supply, C. E. Wilson, vice president of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, declared yesterday.

Joseph Clark Grew, former Ambassador to Japan and former Under-Secretary of State, has accepted an invitation to address the "Meeting of Citizens on Universal Military Training" scheduled for 8:15 o'clock tonight in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday.
DUBLIN, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Irish in great numbers voted today for a new Parliament. The dominant issue was whether to oust Prime Minister Eamon de Valera from the power he has held for sixteen years.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 4 -- Dr. Amazasp A. Arutiunian, delegate of the Soviet Union, declared today that he would give Russia's whole-hearted support to Yugoslavia's demand in the United Nations Economic and Social Council that the United States return 1,350,000 troy ounces of fine gold belonging to the National Bank of Yugoslavia.
News sources of the three local major league baseball clubs were almost snowbound yesterday, but the undismayed press agents of both leagues provided a load of fuel for the Hot Stove League.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 4 (AP) -Railroads had to cooperate regarding rates in order to eliminate wasteful competition which once was forcing many lines into bankruptcy, R. V. Fletcher testified today.

PRESIDENT Roosevelt took a lively interest in the progress of the London Naval Conference, which convened on Dec. 9, 1935, and went on to the end of March, 1936. Virtually from infancy, he had had wide experience with ships of all kinds. Even as a boy, he had been particularlyattracted to naval vessels passingin the vicinity of the New Englandshore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today an amendment to Rule X-1101-1 of the Securities and Exchange Act which eliminates the six-month waiting period now required after a distribution of securities before a participating broker-dealer may extend credit on such securities.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- The shaky coalition Government of Socialist Premier Tetsu Katayama appears headed for a new showdown with organized labor -- its principal supporter during last spring's general elections -- with new strikes breaking out in many parts of Japan.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -After trailing an underdog Syracuse University basketball quintet for more than thirty minutes tonight, Temple's Owls drove down the homestretch to a 63-56 victory despite a sensational 36-point performanceh) 0*0*0*iby Bill Gabor, Orange captain.

h)0*0*0*iWASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Prices of commodities in the nation's markets took a nose-dive today and the effect was felt in Wall Street where stock prices slumped in the worst crack since last spring.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Francis J. Bloustein of 3636 Greystone Avenue, the Bronx, as a member of the City Planning Commission for a full eight-year term. Mr. Bloustein, who has been secretary of the commission since 1948, succeeds Newbold Morris whose term expired Dec. 31.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 The career of former Senator Burton K. Wheeler as political director of the American Federation of Labor appeared tonight to have ended before it began.

Pressed throughout by a taller Rutgers squad, Fordham took advantage of free throw opportunities last night to gain its twelfth basketball victory in thirteen starts, 63 49, before a crowd of 3,000 at Rose Hill.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -The British Foreign Office today confirmed that a considerable number of Communist party members had been discovered among the 15,000 Jewish visa-less immigrants in the ship's Pan York and Pan Crescent, who are now detained at Cyprus.

An unusual situation on the New York Stock Exchange has been created by the death of a member. The member had entered into a contract with another individual to sell his membership for a consideration of $59,000. All arrangements had been completed except the waiting period of two weeks necessary for the approval of the transfer by the governors of the Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A $2,500,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $39,700,000,000 budget was recommended today by a SenateHouse subcommittee.

The proposed increase of $745,775,468 in the assessed value of real estate was criticized yesterday by Matthew G. Ely, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. Mr. Ely accused the Mayor of trying to put the real estate owner "between two millstones by boosting assessments and at the same time seeking state legislation to expand the city's taxing andh)0*0*0*iborrowing powers within the constitutional debt limit."

Karl Propper, Democratic nominee for Representative in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx, announced yesterday his "whole-hearted support" of the Marshall Plan for the economic recovery of Western Europe. The special election to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Supreme Court Justice Benjamin J. Rabin will be held on Feb. 17.

)0*0*0*iO When the Japanese launched their attack in the Pacific in 1941 several thousand Americans were caught in the Far East in areas from which there was no escape. Some spent the war years in the hills, existing as best they could on scant rations furnished by friendly natives.

The Stanley Theatre, first-run showcase for Russian films here, will change its policy and hereafter exhibit international pictures, it was reported by David Fine, manager of the house. Under theh)0*0*0*inew policy, however, Russian pictures will be shown but these "will be entertainment pictures devoid of politics," Mr. Fine stated.

An Associated Press news story with New Delhi date line of Jan. 31 as it appeared in your paper Feb. 1 states that the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi was believed to be a "deep-laid plan of extreme Left Wingers to overthrow the old guard of the Congress party now in power."
DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 4 -- With an average price increase of almost 10 per cent, the 1948 Cadillac models were shown to dealers and distributors here today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Moscow Literary Gazette said today that a suggestion (made by a Communist newspaper) that the British Secret Service was connected with the assassination of Mr. Gandhi was not without foundation.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- An all-out campaign to name Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican champion of the bipartisan foreign policy and senior Senator from Michigan, as the party standard bearer for the Presidency in 1948 was initiated tonight by Gov. Kim Sigler and Senator Homer Ferguson, the latter the colleague of the GrandRapids publisher from the Wolverine state.

The possibility of a world federation of nations, growing out of a closer relationship between a federation of European nations with the United States, was discussed yesterday by Frank Owen, editor in chief of The Daily Mail of London, in Town Hall.
The liner Washington left here yesterday afternoon with 126 passengers on her first postwar voyage as a passenger vessel.

Powdery snow accumulated to levels estimated unofficially at five to eight inches in various sections of the metropolitan area last night in an all-day fall that set seasonal snowfall records in several sections.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Feb. 4 -Seven Fairchild "Flying Boxcars" dropped about nine tons of food, gasoline and other supplies today to the "fighting" paratroopers of the 505th Airborne Battalion as "Exercise Snowdrop" neared its end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Urging that any aid granted to foreign countries under the European Recovery Program be administered by an organization of experts, Senator C. Wayland Brooks, Republican of Illinois, said today that to adopt "blindly" the plan would "strangle and stifle our own production until we will be too weak to save them or ourselves."

The government-owned "emergency class" passenger ship Ernie Pyle, which has been operating-between New York and northern European ports, will be withdrawn from service at the completion of her present voyage, Maritime Commission officials announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- The United Nations department of economic affairs reported today that shortages of food were the world's No. 1 economic problem. The scarcity of food, it declared, is the principal cause of the inflation spiral, and it urged "emergency measures" to try to halt world-wide inflation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 4 -- Absolute control of imports and exports, except foodstuffs, cement and pharmaceutical products, apparently will be decreed by the government soon. A bill, sponsored by the Senate, already approved by the finances committee, places in the hands of the government a weapon which may harm American exports to Brazil.
Random notes.

The American Gold Star Mothers of the World War, Inc., charged yesterday in an action filed in the Supreme Court that Mrs. Mathilda Burling, a former president of that organization, was representing herself illegally as the "national president of an alleged corporation known as the American Gold Star Mothers of the World Wars, Inc."

Faced with what they say is the prospect of bankruptcy if forwarding of Marshall Plan relief cargoes is handled by Government agencies, the country's foreign freight forwarding companies are urging Congress to include in the relief legislation a statement directing facilitation of the merchandise through regular commercial channels.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll issued today a memorandum to Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commander of the New Jersey National Guard, in which the general was advised to ignore an order of the Department of the Army that required the segregation of whites and Negroes in National Guard units.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Democratic legislative leaders, in a new statement issued today, accused Governor Dewey of using the post-war reconstruction fund to conceal from taxpayers the true extent of the increased cost of state government during his administration.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Both American men's and women's table tennis teams started well today in quest of world team championships for the Swaythling and Marcel Corbillon Cups at Wembley, with four victories in four matches. Sixteen nations are challenging for the title held by England.

HAVANA, Feb. 4--The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today approved sections of the proposed world trade charter designed to do away with or minimize "invisible" tariffs and red tape that interfere with international trade.

Bruno-New York, Inc., metropolitan area distributor for Bendix automatic electric washers, may terminate dealer allocations if current extensive advertising and promotion "doesn't pull," Gerald O. Kaye, general sales manager, said yesterday.

If the January rate of nylon shipments to the hosiery industry can be maintained, manufacturers of full-fashioned and seamless stockings will have enough nylon yarn to produce over 51,500,000 dozen pairs this year, according to Warren A. Beh, director of sales, nylon division, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., yesterday.
Spring coats and suits were presented yesterday by B. Altman Co. Models for travel, for southern wear and for bright days in town were shown on the third floor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The State Department notified Rumania formally and tersely today that she had failed in every respect to live up to her pledges of a democratic government stipulated in the peace treaty with that country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The resignation of Lee Pressman as general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was authoritatively reported today. He is the last of the influential figures at CIO headquarters marked for liquidation by anti-Communist forces.
Chester Bowles charged here yesterday that the United States and the Soviet Union were engaged in a contest of power politics in Europe with the hungry children of the Continent as the pawns.

Seymour J. Teich has been named assistant to G. F. Holmquist, merchandise administrator of children's wear at Macy's, New York, effective Feb. 9. Joseph E. Frucht, formerly assistant to Thomas W. Johnston, vice president, has been made department manager of boys' clothing.
International air parcel post service should be available shortly after the first of the month, according to airline men here.

LONDON, Feb. 4 The British Foreign Office officially confirmed today a dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of last Sunday reporting evidence in British documents that many Communist agents were aboard the unauthorized Jewish immigrant ships Pan York and Pan Crescent.

Faint radio signals that mayh)0*0*0*ihave been the desperate effort at communication by a survivor of the British South African Airways plane, down off Bermuda since last Thursday night, put on the alert last night all available listening facilities as aircraft and surface vessels were standing by for a dash to sea.

Banks here are being floodedh)0*0*0*iwith apprehensive inquiries from abroad from owners of blocked assets in this country as a result of the recent announcement of the National Advisory Council that such assets will be turned over soon to the Office of Alien Property.

The purchase by the Clan Line of ten freighters with a combined gross tonnage of 71,420 tons from the British Government was announced yesterday by the Barberh)0*0*0*iSteamship Lines, Inc., agents for the company here.

Scoring almost at will in the second half, the New York Knickerbockers passed the century mark for the second time this season in defeating the hapless Providence Steam Rollers, 108 to 69, at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night.

LONDON, Feb. 4 Sales of surplus British military supplies in Palestine are continuing, A. V. Alexander, Minister of Defense, told the House of Commons today, but "every possible precaution" is being taken to assure that warlike equipment does not pass into the hands of Jews or Arabs.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Scoring twice each in a wild third period, Detroit and the New York Rangers played a 4-all National Hockey League tie before 12,842 fans at Olympia tonight with the leagueleading Red Wings bagging the tying goal a half-minute before the final buzzer.

The New York City Theatre Company will offer its third and final bill of the season -- four one act Cnekhov plays this evening at the City Center, the civic playhouse. The program will consist of "A Tragedian in Spite of Himself," "The Bear," "On the Harmfulness of Tobacco" and "The Wedding."

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- It is considered almost certain here in diplomatic circles that Britain will name a new Ambassador to Washington to succeed Lord Inverchapel. There are increasing indications that the man will be Sir Oliver Franks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Thomas E. Dewey's predictions in 1944 that continued Democratic rule would mean widespread post-war unemployment have "utterly failed of fulfillment," Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois asserted today in renewing Democratic attacks on the New York Governor.

The smoky tang of meat roasted over an open pit is what the Smithfield Ham and Products Company has aimed for in the latest addition to its line of canned pork products. That the concern has succeeded is evident from a taste of the new James River Brand Smithfield Pork With Barbeque Sauce, which reveals that special savor made famous by southern cooks.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- Fears that the Communists were organizing an armed insurrection to start if the Left Wing was defeated in the next general election increased today when it became known that the Government had ordered intensified surveillance of the Adriatic coast to prevent the smuggling of arms into Italy from Yugoslavia and Greece.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that arrangements had been made with the Federal Reserve banks, effective March 1, for the telegraphic transfer of Treasury bonds in coupon form.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The reimbursement of all depositors of one or two of the demonetized 5,000-franc banknotes will begin Friday, the French Cabinet decided today. The decision was taken after completion of the operation that in two and a half days had resulted by noon today, in the reduction of onethird of all the French currency in circulation.

The "new look" in men's fashions was on view at the sixtyeighth annual style showing of the Custom Tailors and Designers Association of America last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The showing was for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.

Miss Polly Crawford, 55 years old, a nurse, who was shot while in her home, 416 East Seventy-fourth Street, Jan. 18 by one of two teenage boys who had been practicing with a .22 caliber automatic pistol on a tenement house roof, died last night.

A proposal to amend the constitution of the American Medical Association to admit to membership any qualified physician regardless of race, aimed to eliminate discrimatory practices against Negro physicians, was presented lasth)0*0*0*inight at a meeting of the Physicians Forum at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Two more units of the International Typographical Union, Locals No. 8 of St. Louis, Mo., and No. 103 of Newark, N.J., were charged with unfair labor practices yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Irving M. Ives of New York arrayedh)0*0*0*ihimself today against Governor Dewey, his running mate in 1946, in opposition to the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway project.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Accidents in the United States last year killed 100,000 persons, injured 10,500,000 and caused economic losses totaling $6,700,000,000, the National Safety Council reported today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Cubs today won a ten-club scramble to sign George Zoeterman, 17-yearold left-handed high school pitching star.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 -The tax of 3 cents on each package of cigarettes proposed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, if enacted by the Legislature, will bring to an abrupt end a mail-order business in cigarette sales by the carton that runs into a gross income of millions of dollars annually throughout the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Tax exemption privileges have been removed from eight groups called "Communist fronts" by Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, and listed by Attorney General Tom C. Clark as subversive, it was stated today.

VIENA, Feb. 4 (UP) -- John MacCormac, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent who was mentioned, among other American newspaper men, in a trial in Budapest yesterday as having discussed Hungarian affairs with former Socialist Premier Karol Peyer, said today he never had met or even spoken to Mr. Peyer in his life.

A resolution declaring that exporters view with "great apprehension" the new export control regulations of the Government was unanimously adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Government is expected to ask soon for a grand jury indictment of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for violation of the Taft-Hartley Law ban on political expenditures.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Grain and lard futures on American exchanges declined the permissible limits today, and closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at the bottom. Wheat was off 10 cents a bushel; corn and soy beans, 8 cents and oats, 6 cents.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Babe Ruth arrived at 3:45 P.M. today by train for a vacation. Accompanied by his wife and a male nurse, Ruth left immediately for the Golden Strand Hotel on Miami Beach.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 4 -The Wisconsin slate of delegate candidates for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for the Republican nomination for President in the June convention in Philadelphia, the second list to be an nounced, was made public today.

A BALLOT arrived in the mail yesterday from Kenesaw Mountain Smith, the indefatigable secretary of the Baseball Writers Association. It contains ten blank spaces for as many nominations to the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown. If the name of any player appears on threequarters of the ballots, he's automatically elected. If not, then the names of the top twenty men will be resubmitted to the diamond scribes for a final vote.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 The Army basketball team scored its most important victory of the season today by downing Pennsylvania, 51 to 39, in the Field House.
MIAMI, Feb. 4 (UP) -- National Airlines aid tonight that it had offered to arbitrate a dispute with the Airlines Pilots Association, AFL, which resulted in a strike by its pilots last night.

John M. Cannella, commissioner of water supply, gas and electricity, warned New York residents yesterday to be more careful in the use of city water. He asked Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, for an increase of $2,88,879 for the operation of his department during the fiscal year, beginning July 1.

New snows, ranging from four to six inches in depth, visited the Pennsylvania Poconos, northern New Jersey and Southern New York State's Hudson Highlands and Catskill Mountains yesterday while the line starting north of Albany and extending through the Adirondacks and Green and White Mountains was being surfaced with two to three inches powder.

With one dissenting vote (Russia's) the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of the Press has approved a report embodying the conclusions reached in its two weeks' session at Lake Success. The Soviet representative explained that he voted against the report because the subcommission had failed to take action on what he believed to be such important duties of the press as the exposure of "warmongers" and the "remnants of fascism."

City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the NewYork County Committee of the American Labor party, said yesterday that Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, and State Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, the Democratic legislative leaders, were sabotaging Mayor O'Dwyer's program for getting $84,500,000 from the state.
The cotton futures market closed easy and 9 to 71 points lower yesterday, following active trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

" FROM MY JOURNAL" is Andre Maurois' diary for the year 1946, which he spent in America, France and Switzerland. It is urbane, thoughtful and resolutely circumspect. A short story and a couple of articles are embedded in the text. So are a number of what might be considered bread-and-butter notes to pleasant hosts.
In the midst of our painful fuel short age and frigid houses it seems strange indeed that, unthinking and callous, we go on so overheating our homes and public buildings.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4 (UP) -The Iranian Government and United States Ambasador George V. Allen tonight denounced Russia's note to Iran on alleged American military activites in this country as baseless and as constituting improper interference in this country's internal affairs.

ATHENS, Feb. 4 -- In a statement addressed to the President of the Chamber of Deputies, eight Deputies from Messini, the southwestern district of the Peloponnesus, have castigated the Government for its failure to re-establish order in the Peloponnesus and "for incompetence in coping with the situation in the country generally."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The State Department has recommended to the National Advisory Council, top Federal agency on international financial policy, a China relief and assistance program totaling $510,000,000, it was learned today. The proposal was discussed by the council this afternoon.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- With the greatest of ease, Relic won the $10,000 added Bahamas Handicap at Hialeah Park today.

Secretary of State George C.h)0*0*0*iMarshall yesterday accepted an invitation to make the draw for the 1948 Davis Cup matches, it was announced by Lawrence A. Baker, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

The five-story apartment house for twenty families at 203 East Thirty-third Street, near Third Avenue, has been sold by Mollie G. Popper to a client of Max H. Zabronsky, attorney, in one of several East Side realty investment deals reported yesterday.

A charity racket in which women wearing nuns' habits solicit funds in the city's subways, bars, restaurants and railroad stations, paying $2.50 a day to an unnamed organization and keeping all the rest of their "take" was described yesterday by the Better Business Bureau of New York City.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Speaker after speaker in the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) warned todayh)0*0*0*ithat Russian industries must slash operating costs in labor and raw materials to return increased profits to the state.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- The United States gave its support today to the establishment of a neutral interim administration to govern the Princely State of Kashmir until a plebiscite could determine whether its people wanted to join Pakistan or India.

Study Shows Losses in '47, Dip in Taxes, Failure to Earn Interest, Analysis Saysh)0*0*0*iOIn a three-part study of the Tennessee Valley Authority, distributed yesterday to member companies of the Edison Electric Institute, the utility industry alleged that the $800,000,000 Federal power project had (1) "shown further losses in 1947," (2) that TVA's taxes "are getting smaller," and (3) that "TVA failed to earn the interest which the Treasury factually paid out on its behalf."

HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- Twin Star, sailed by Lockwood Pirie of Chicago's Sheridan Shore Yacht Club, captured the Bacardi Cup in the seventeenth international star class series with a total of 31 points by finishing third today in 1 hour 4O minutes 28 seconds. Sam Pirie acted as crew.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 Marshall Field 3d, president and publisher of The Chicago Sun and Times, has told the Chicago Federation of Labor that the strike of AFL printers "was a strong contributing factor" in the merger of his morning and afternoon newspapers into one around-the-clock newspaper.

In more than one public statement recently Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, has called attention to the need for pegging wages and profits if Britain was to win its "war for exports." Rising wages and profits, he pointed out, were drivingh)0*0*0*iBritish prices upward, making it increasingly difficult to sell British products abroad in competition with those of other countries.
That hardy perennial question about smaller motor cars blooms again, as evidenced by your editorial of Jan. 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) - Veiled threats of a Southern secession from the Democratic party kept the Democratic High Command jittery today and set House Republicans whooping for action on a Federal anti-lynching law.

Brought to market on the eve of the most drastic decline in stock prices since last summer, a block of 900,000 new shares of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation's capital stock was reported to have been placed for investment by the underwriting management yesterday after the stock broke on the New York Curb Exchange during the noon hour from the public offering price of 13 to 12.

Taking a look at the weather, hearing all the coughing and noseblowing going on in the office, the Health Department attacked the timely subject of the common cold yesterday and came up with some formidable statistics.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- President Juan Peron last night defended his regime against charges of profiteering in food at a time of world hunger. Moreover, he insisted that his Government was not "in business," and that its entire aim was to defend local production within the over-all plan to make the nation economically independent.
The Board of Higher Education proposed yesterday a record $18,066,641 budget for the operation of New York's four municipal colleges -City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- in the 1948-49 fiscal year.

h)0*0*0*iBUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- President Juan D. Peron, in keeping with the new university law, which gives him the right to choose the heads of Argentina's six national universities, has announced his selections for two such posts. He has named Dr. Horacio Raul Descole to be rector of the University of Tucuman and Prof. Ireneo Fernando Cruz to be rector of the University of Cuyo.

h)0*0*0*iLONDON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Prime Minister Attlee listed four principles "as a guide to all whose deliberations and actions contribute to the settlement of the amount of personal incomes from whatever source. Those principles are: (1) "In the present conditions, and until more goods and services are available for the home market, these is no justification for any general increase of individual money incomes."
The oil that the Navy consented to lend New York did not start toward homes and industrial plants yesterday because the major oil companies failed to agree on how it would be distributed and sold.

With a production schedule for this year of about 225,000 cars the backlog of Oldsmobile orders now exceeds 200,000, S. E. Skinner, vice-president of General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Oldsmobile division, said yesterday at a press conference at the Essex House.

Operations last year of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., resulted in a net income of $5,920,100 after all charges, including $3,600,000 provision for Federal income taxes, according to the 1947 preliminary annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

PRAGUE, Feb. 4 -- Bulgarian Premier Georgi Dimitrov has been invited by the Czechoslovak Government to visit Prague in the middle of February, but so far no reply has been received. So far as can be ascertained here the Czechoslovak Government suggested Mr. Dimitrov come to sign an alliance with this country.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, shareholders approved an increase in the authorized capital stock to 1,000,000 from 400,000 shares, with the per value remaining at $5 a share.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4 -- The Indian Government announced tonight the outlawing of the semimilitary Hindu extremist organization Rashtrya Swayam Sewak Sangh (roughly translated as United Volunteers to Serve the Country).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today took action in the field of consumer food conservation, a move prescribed by the Republican anti-inflation law.

Interest in travel among post-war Americans still has far to go before it regains pre-war volume and intensity -- but signs multiply daily that it is growing steadily. One of the most significant of these is the statement, in a report just compiled by the American Library Association, that there is a strong demand for travel books by readers all over this country.

A new wave of hunger strikes in protesth)0*0*0*iagainst the breakdown in the distribution of food has just swept through the merged American and British zones in Germany, from the borders of Denmark to Switzerland. These strikes are accompanied by rising criticism of the occupation authorities on the part of Germans taking advantage of the democratic principles impressed on them by these same authorities.

FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -Sweeping down from the Oregon coast, a "million dollar rainstorm," accompanied in places by snow flurries and hail, ended today the worst mid-winter drought California had experienced in seventy years of recorded weather.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- The New Jersey Department of Education has started a state-wide investigation into the racial policies of school districts to determine to what extent Negro pupils are segregated, it was announced here today by Joseph L. Bustard, assistant Education Commissioner, who heads the department's division against discrimination.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased by 2,387,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies at the week-end were 102,973,000 barrels, compared with 100,586,000 a week earlier and 98,696,000 on Feb. 1, 1947.

The most serious reaction since last April struck the stock market yesterday. Losses of 1 to 2 points were posted in a wide variety of key issues on the New York Stock Exchange, with the more volatile stocks affected most, and the price average falling to the lowest level since last June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The former Confederate States of the South, eleven in number, have 127 electoral votes, and a national issue that would impel any one of them to withhold its electors from the Democratic national ticket would mark the same trend in them all. The five border states, with 52 electoral votes, still have sufficient kinship with the Old South to be affected by its turning away from the Democratic party.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britain's Labor Government called a halt to mass wage increases today in its renewed battle against inflation.h)0*0*0*iPrime Minister Attlee, in a statement to the House of Commons, made it clear that general wage increases, unless accompanied by a corresponding increase in production, would be frowned upon by the Government.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Increased public participation in government, along the lines of theh)0*0*0*iold town meetings, was advocated here today at the Westchester County Conference for Community Development.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 In a bitter exchange of charges, Great Britain attacked the Soviet Union today for imperialist expansion and "economic exploitation" of the countries of Eastern Europe.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 4 -- The debate on the projected report to the Little Assembly over the impasse in the settlement of the Korean question by the United Nations Commission began here today. It was estimated that it would be at least two weeks before the findings of the commission were in the hands of the Little Assembly.

Coty's new make-up base, "pasteltint" was shown yesterday at noon in the Cotillion room of the Pierre Hotel with new fashions for spring and summer from the designers' rooms of leading New York creators.
With snow falling outside, flowers and ribbons were on parade yesterday in the millinery department of Best Co. as the season's new spring bonnets were presented for the fashion press.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Agreement was reached today by the Government and all political parties to discuss the reform of the House of Lords. This ends a controversy that has been raging off and on since last autumn, when the Labor Government announced that it was going to reduce the delaying powers of the Upper Chamber from two years to one.

A syndicate of sixty-three underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today 150,000 shares of new $100 par value, 4.3 per cent preferred stock of the Philadelphia Electric Company at par. The offering is part of a financing program which is to include the marketing of $25,000,000 of bonds by the company at competitive sale on Feb. 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has virtually decided on area elections as the solution of the union shop problem in the building construction industry.

A claim to the coast-to-coast record or a commercial airliner on a scheduled flight was made by the Transcontinental and Western Airline yesterday, when one of its planes landed at La Guardia Field 6 hours and 39 minutes after it left the Municipal Airport at Los Angeles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb., 4 -The deal whereby Jackie Robinson was to appear in a motion picture based on his life and athletic career for distribution by Eagle-Lion has been called off, Ben Stoloff disclosed today. Delays incident to independent financing of the Robinson picture precluded the possibility of completling it before Robinson reported to the Brooklyn Dodgers for spring baseball practice in March, according to Stoloff.

A Brooklyn mother, whose son was a victim of rheumatic fever when he was six years old, approved yesterday the plans of the Associated Cardiac Leagues, Inc.,h)0*0*0*ito establish the first summer camp in the state for children recuperating from cardiac conditions.

WARSAW, Feb. 4 A conference of Socialist parties from countries not participating in the Marshall Plan, but including the Italian Socialist party, will be called in Warsaw soon by the Polish section, it was reported today. The conference is planned to discuss economic and political questions.

Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, issued a graduation diploma yesterday to a boy who would not take a loyalty oath on the ground of conscientious objection to military service.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 4 -- The three Scandinavian Premiers, who also are presidents of the Socialist parties in their respective countries, will meet Saturday in Stockholm at the Socialist conference on Nordic cooperation.

LAKEVIEW, Ga., Feb. 4 (AP) -Walter Bowland, athletic coach at Lakeview High School, said tonight he had been warned to get out of town or be tarred and feathered. He said John B. Burks, school principal, received the warning:

An enthusiastic response from companies and organizations wishing to participate in the campaign of the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies to increase public understanding of the American economic system was reported yesterday by Don Belding, chairman of the board of the Foote, Cone Belding advertisingh)0*0*0*iagency and chairman also of the special joint committee, in charge of the drive.
Assistant Superintendent I. Victor Burger has recommended that Isadore Rubin, suspended teacherpicket, be reprimanded by the Superintendent of Schools and that he be restored to duty as of yesterday.

National advertising increased by a greater amount in newspapers during 1947 than in any other media, Printers Ink reported yesterday. Volume in newspapers was up 35.1 per cent, while total national advertising expenditures in all major media advanced 16.4 per cent over the previous year.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP) - Dogs have killed at least 1,000 snowbound deer in New York State in the last ten days, State Conservation Commissioner Perry B. Duryea said today.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A pretty Western housewife, her pigtails flying, plummeted down a zig-zag Alpine snow course today to accomplish something no American ever had done before her -- win a medal in an Olympic skiing event against Europe's masters.
Federal Judge John Bright refused yesterday to enjoin the owners of two apartment houses in Kew Gardens, Queens, from barring agents of the Federal Housing Expediter from their premises.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A Federal investigation of increases in oil prices about the country was recommended today by the House Committee on Commerce in an interim report on its long and continuing inquiry into the fuel shortage.

In his Town Hall recital last night Bernard Greenhouse had the Bach Suite in D minor for `cello alone in a place of central importance, which was the act of a brave man. For it is not easy to make the `cello on its own exciting throughout a long piece, and an attempt to do so with a difficult Bach score compounds the problem.
Assistant Superintendent I. Victor Burger has recommended that Isadore Rubin, suspended teacherpicket, be reprimanded by the Superintendent of Schools and that he be restored to duty as of yesterday.
Workers in 400 retail bakeries that produce a large part of the city's rye, pumpernickel and other baked specialties were scheduled to quit their jobs tonight at the end of the working day.

Use of television as a promotional device may increase merchandise sales as much as 200 per cent, according to results of a survey made public yesterday by the Bureau of Retail Research of the New York University School of Retailing. Conducted over a five month period for the Allied Stores Corporation, the survey was designed to appraise the sales promotional influence of intrastore television.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States both indicated today their alarm over inflation but differed completely as to what to do about it.

h)0*0*0*iGENEVA, Feb. 4 -- A Swiss Government spokesman in Berne said today that a Swiss delegation would soon call on the United States Treasury to discuss the effects of the newly-announced United States policy of vesting blocked foreign assets whose owners refuse to declare themselves.

Ricardo Odnoposoff, violinist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. He was warmly received in a program which contained Beethoven's Sonata in C minor, Op. 30, No. 2, Reger's unaccompanied Sonata in D minor, Op. 42, No. 1, the Glazunoff Concerto, and a final group of shorter offerings by Smetana, Nestoroff, Paganini and Szymanowsky.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 4 -Fritz Kuhn, deported former leader of the German-American Bund, escaped Tuesday under mysterious circumstances from the Dachau internment camp.

As discussion in Congress centers more and more on what effect the Marshall Plan will have on the economy of the United States we are apt to lose sight of what it can do and already has done for Europe. There is an obvious change in the European economic climate. One result is the new treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation which this country has signed with Italy.

By 1968 American physiciansh)0*0*0*iand scientists will "come close to stamping out syphilis as a major health problem" in this country, Dr.Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, predicted yesterday.

Imported British tweeds vied with fabrics of navy blue and its many complements like pink, mauve, kelly green and the polka dot, at Arnold Constable's fashion luncheon yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The imports, designed by Charles Kuperstein, have a completely international feeling, being British by fabric, French in influence and American in adaptability.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -The Senate today rejected House amendments to a bill raising the income ceilings at which veterans become ineligible for subsistence allowances under the GI educational and job-training programs. The measure now goes to Senate-House conference for adjustment of the differences.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 4 -Sweden will not join any Western or Eastern political bloc nor for the time being any Western customs union, Swedish Foreign Minister Gesten Unden and Minister of Trade Axel Gjoeres said at a session of both houses of the Riksdag today.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 4 -- British troops twice fought parties of raiders from across the River Jordan today in the northeast corner of Palestine near Lake Tiberias. The Army imposed a continuous curfew on Tiberias from 8 A.M. tomorrow until further notice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -The Soviet Union's budget message for 1948, full texts of which are available here today, is a frank and official admission that communism, as well as capitalism, is having serious post-war economic troubles.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 4 -- Governor Charles M. Dale of New Hampshire made known tonight hish)0*0*0*i"unequivocal" support of Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York for the Republican Presidential nomination.

New York and the entire shivering East Coast area are facing a critical period in the battle to maintain fuel oil supplies. Theh) 0*0*0*inext three weeks are likely to determine whether we are going to get by with only spotty shortages, or suffer far more serious and widespread hardships.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, will throw the full weight of his influence behind the Palestine Commission'sh) 0*0*0*idemand for an international armed force, it was learned today.

Hope that the states would enact legislation, giving "substance" to President Truman's recommendations for the extension of Federal and state civil rights laws was expressed yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -Text of a United States note to Rumania charging failure of the Rumanian Government to live up to the human rights requirements of the peace treaty:

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- With professional operators selling industrials in advance of Prime Minister Attlee's statement in the House of Commons today concerning the Government's wage policy, prices gradually declined to close at or around the lowest levels of the day.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- A reduction of 1,100 in the United States Military Government personnel has been ordered by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, it was learned today. This reduction will leave a staff of 3,500 when the State Department takes over occupation duties June 30.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Organized labor, is cool to the British Government's program for barring mass wage increases.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The Monmouth County Grand Jury here today handed up four indictments charging Charles Lowy of Asbury Park and two New York truck drivers with illegal storage or transportation of war surplus explosives allegedly destined for Haganah, the Jewish army in Palestine.

By systematic looting, torture, confiscation and a new type of "thought" persecution, Communists in China are engineering the complete annihilation of the Catho1ic Church in North China, according to a survey made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A 7-to-5 vote of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today released for a showdown the Ives bill to create a permanent National Commission Against Discrimination in Employment. This is the measure most resented and feared by Southern Democrats, already aroused to a pitch of threatening a party bolt by the program for civil rights legislation which President Truman sent to Congress on Monday.

By the end of this week two converted Navy landing ships operated by Trailerships, Inc., will have carried between 400,000 and 600,000 gallons of fuel oil from here to Albany in answer to an urgent appeal by Mayor Erastus Corning Jr. of Albany, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- The dismissal of two high Government officials, including Minister of Justice Nikolai M. Rychkov, and a ban on marriages between Russians and foreigners were approved by the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) at its final session last night, it was made known today.

ROME, Friday, Feb. 6 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government last night challenged the organized power of the Communist party by approving a decree outlawing all private associations of a military character.

WSHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Department-store sales in the week ended Jan. 31 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Jorge Pasquel, Mexican baseball leader, said today he doesn't think much of the informal gesture made recently to bring an end to the misunderstanding between him and the major leagues in the United States which arose when he started luring big league players to Mexico.

PERNIK, Bulgaria, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Bulgarian authorities proudly displayed today their showplace, the Pernik anthracite mine, partly manned by prison and conscript labor, but refused to allow visiting foreign correspondents to inspect living conditions of the forced laborers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman predicted today that the inflationary boom would plummet into an economic crash unless the rising spiral of prices was arrested.
ROME, Feb. 5 -- L'Osservatore Romano, in its weekly edition appearing next Sunday, praises the Marshall Plan as "the salvation of Europe."

Net-profit of the Noma Electric Corporation for the six months ended with last December, first half of its fiscal year was $2,762,890 after taxes, equal to $4.33 a share on 637,997 shares of common stock, the report revealed yesterday.

The chamber music repertory, which contains some of the noblest examples of composition, is not notably negotiable, save in some well-produced series like that of the New Friends of Music. It is a matter for surprise and rejoicing, therefore, when able musicians join to form a chamber music ensemble and propose to make a career of it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- After Winston Churchill had delivered his anti-Russian speech at Fulton, Mo., in March, 1946, President Truman offered Marshal Stalin a similar opportunity, it was confirmed today at the White House.
Time, not war, is the Soviet objective in the international struggle with the United States.

ON Oct. 5, 1937, President Roosevelt delivered his famous "quarantine speech" at Chicago. Ever since his inauguration, Mr. Roosevelt had been struggling desperately to restore normal conditions at home, with the result that he was at times hampered in giving full attention to our foreign affairs.

Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of the President's Air Policy Commission, said yesterday that "the future of the United Nations is now hanging in the balance of events that must be decided within the next few months." He suggested the United States call for a general conference of members of the United Nations to consider "armament of the United Nations and the corresponding disarmament of the member states."
BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Fines totaling $23,001 were imposed today on manufactures of surgical bandages by Federal Judge George C. Sweeney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Further substantial declines for agricultural commodities were mainly responsible for a decrease of 0.4 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended last Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Non-agricultural commodities continued their steady advance during the week -- the nineteenth consecutive increase.

Four foreign films are slated to arrive today. Opening at the Cinema Verdi is an Italian-made offering, "The Lady Is Fickle," starring Ferruccio Tagliavini, opera star. Mario Mattoli directed the romantic musical comedy and Fioretta Dolfi, Carlo Campanini and Carlo Micheluzzi are featured.
NANKING, Feb. 5 -- China's first national elections have produced a problem that is threatening to force another postponement of the National Assembly.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- The last wave of strikes throughout the bizonal area will not bring about much improvement in the food situation for Ruhr workers, Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, declared today.

City College's Associate Alumni has established the John H. Finley award for distinguished service to New York, Dr. Stephen Duggan, president of the group, announced yesterday. The award, to be presented annually to the citizen who has made the outstanding contribution to the welfare of the city during the year, will be in memory of the former editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and president of City College from 1903 to 1913.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Between 500,000 and 750,000 employes and their dependents would be excluded from certain provisions of the Social Security Act, it is estimated, under a bill reported to the House by the Ways and Means Committe, and the details of which were made public today.

DUBLIN, Friday, Feb. 6 -- Results of Ireland's general election Wednesday, with more than half of the 147 seats in the new Dail Eireann filled by the proportional representation count early today, show Premier Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail party doing well in its plan to hold an over-all majority.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was not driven back through the Kasserine Pass by Allied counter-attacks, but withdrew methodically, leaving only nine tanks behind after having created an "exceedingly grave" situation by his setback of United States troops in the Kasserine area.

Walter S. Franklin, vice president of the Long Island Rail Road told Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright yesterday that the railroad would spend an estimated $8,198,600 this year to improve its service. He said this was part of $17,500,000 the railroad had earmarked for improvements over a three-year period.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- For fifty minutes today, the United Nations Security Council listened to a tall, lean Moslem Sheikh who had come 8,000 miles to defend his right to govern the princely state of Kashmir.
New Yorkers and suburbanites slogged yesterday through the snowfall of Wednesday. The going generally was slushy, but most roads and transportation facilities were usable.

The two-story factory building at 39-29. Twenty-ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Coastal Toy Company, Inc., manufacturer of metal mechanical toys, from Gottfried Brothers. The new owner plans to occupy the building after extensive alterations have been completed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- An Actors Equity Association arbitration commission declared today that a recent anti-Communist play here had been closed down by telephone threats from Communist quarters.

Paul L. Ross, chairman of the City Rent Commission, has issued a correction of the commission's erroneous announcement that Mrs. Annette Jacoby, landlady, had received a three-day jail sentence in War Emergency Court for violating City Rent Laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- American industry was accused today by Walter P. Reuther, head of the CIO United Automobile Workers, of making "a deliberate effort to cut back production at a time when the whole answer to the world's problem is economic abundance."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 31, 1948, totaled 727,038 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 44,954 cars, or 5.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 108,013 cars, or 12.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 3,737 cars, or 0.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary broke her former mark for a quick turnaround here when the sailed from Pier 90, North River, at 6:25 A.M. yesterday, twenty-four hours and five minutes after arriving from England. The previous record was set by the ship on Jan. 17, when her lay-over lasted twenty-two minutes longer.

Columbia University is currently preparing offices on the main floor of Low Memorial Library and making changes in the president's house in anticipation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's assuming office as the university's thirteenth president on June 7.

Manufacturers of men's and boys' outerwear anticipate a decline in prices this year, according to a survey of production and price trends in the industry, released yesterday. A substantial segment of the industry, it was indicated, believed that the price decline will begin in the middle of the year, but the greatest majority felt that it would be deferred till the end of 1948.
BOMBAY, India, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Bombay police rounded up at least 150 persons today in a mammoth investigation of anti-Gandhi activities.

Major commodity prices in the nation's markets declined for the second successive day yesterday coincident with renewed selling on the New York Stock Exchange. The decline on the Exchange was not so severe as on Wednesday, however.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The Soviet Union today questioned the methods used by the United Nations in preparing its world economic survey and contended that the survey's compilation of population and production statistics was based on "old-fashioned" theories and incomplete reports.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The capture by Congress of the final directing power over the occupation policy in western Germany, with the United States in total economic control over both the British and United States zones, was formidably demanded today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -Laughter rippled through the House today when Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi suggested that New England and other areas short of fuel "secede from the Union and get in under the Marshall Plan."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The State Department today took sharp issue with British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin who said yesterday that Nazi-Soviet documents recently printed by the United States were "out of context."
GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- Plans are on foot to give Europe its first fast railway refrigerator freight service.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman again laughingly parried questions about whether he would be a candidate for reelection when he saw the press today at a news conference.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson said today that United States exports of wheat and wheat products this crop year may yet reach a goal of 500,000,000 bushels.

Apparently irked by the fact that it had been largely left out of the worldwide economic survey made by the United Nations, Soviet Russia has for the first time submitted to that organization data on its own economic situation. These data are dubious and unenlightening, since they deal in percentages of an undisclosed base, which leaves actual Russian production an enigma wrapped in mystery.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 5 -- Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, said here tonight that Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg would be invited to place their claims on Germany at the three-power talks in London on Feb. 19.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Canada virtually killed the United States' hopes for a hockey title by defeating America's Amateur Hockey Association team, 12 to 3, today in the unofficial tournament played in connection with the Winter Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- When the President prophesies a crash -- using that violent word -- strongly implying that Congress must adopt his proposed controls to prevent it, and when this is said in a Presidential election year, politics may take on a degree of heat in which very useful and worthy projects could be consumed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire learned today why his coffee was so expensive but not why his shortening was so high.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. Feb. 5 -- The security position in Palestine has become "more serious" as a result of the increasing incursion of bands of "trained guerrillas" from adjacent Arab states, the Palestine Commission was told today.
Cotton futures were moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with final prices 14 to 39 points net lower.

An over-all world shortage of oil, not in the ground but in production, is threatening grave consequences. It comes at a time when United States and world production are breaking all records, but are still unable to keep pace with the unprecedented demands.

Bus riders on lines of the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation and the East Side Omnibus Corporation were plagued yesterday by slow-downs on the vehicles entailing waits of as long as thirty minutes at curb stations.

Even though contracts haven't been drawn yet, various omens indicate that "You Never Can Tell" is a prospective tenant of the Martin Beck. Pending confirmation, it is understood that the George Bernard Shaw comedy, which is being produced by the Theatre Guild in association with Alfred Fischer, is to settle down there Tuesday night, March 16.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- To allay the widespread apprehension of a further freezing of the currency, Rene Mayer, French Minister of Finance, in a broadcast tonight told the public "the monetary operation is finished."

If the Federal Trade Commission is planning to use its authority for a psychological attack on prices, it is going contrary to the basic principles on which it was founded, according to W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

IF the recent competitive jaunt of Herb McKenley to Australia does nothing else it should quiet those American track fans who have been so critical of the failures of foreign runners over here.
