The great quarter-miler wasn't a complete failure Down Under, of course, but he hardly was the roaring ball of fire that his performances in the United States had led us to expect.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 5 -- Haj Amin el-Husseini, exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, and Fawzi el-Kawukji, prominent figures in the pre-war Arab revolt, have been overshadowed in the current Arab plans to oppose the partition of Palestine, it was indicated today.

Potential effects of a city-wide bakery strike scheduled to start this morning were materially reduced yesterday as bakery unions came to agreement with 138 retail handcraft bakeries, the bagel baking industry and a group of French and Italian bakers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An extension of rent control for fourteen months from its Feb. 29 expiration, allowing landlords and tenants to enter into leases at any figure agreeable to both, was recommended today by a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, the Australian nurse who developed the Kenny method of treating poliomyelitis, declared yesterday in Federal Court that she had applied every six months for several years for permission to demonstrate her system at the National Foundation For Infantile Paralysis, Warm Springs, Ga., but without result.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. charged tonight that the Truman administration was "willing to let the country go into an economic tailspin rather than cooperate with a Republican Congress."

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Emir Feisal al-Saud, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, has deferred indefinitely his trip to London for treaty talks with the British Government. Arab diplomatic quarters attribute this decision largely to the unfavorable atmosphere created by the Iraqi Government's recent rejection of a new pact with Britain.

Two books about Thomas Jefferson are scheduled by two concerns for publication a month apart. Philosophical Library will bring out on March 3 Eleanor D. Berman's "Thomas Jefferson Among the Arts," a study of his remarks on architecture, gardening, oratory and music.

The problem of a suitable war memorial, debated by artistic and civic groups since 1920, was explored last night by members of the Architectural League who met in open forum at their quarters, 115 East Fortieth Street.

The first post-war, large-scale demonstration of facsimile in New York will be started on Feb. 16 when THE NEW YORK TIMES begins a series of daily showings of the transmission of a newspaper by radio.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income last year of $75,666,792, compared with $57,206,352 earned in 1946, according to the 1947 annual report issued for publication today.

The Navy released yesterday from its oil reserves 4,200,000 gallons of light fuel for emergency distribution to heatless homes throughout New York State. This city will get the greater share, 2,730,000 gallons.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- The first race for the Cuba Cup in the seventeenth international Star Class regatta was won today by the American yacht, Twin Star, skippered by Lockwood Pirie of Chicago's Sheridan Shore Club. Twin Star carried off the Bacardi Cup series, which was concluded here yesterday.

Directors of the city Red Cross Blood Donor Service recommended yesterday that their plans to provide free blood through voluntary donors to medical patients in the city be discontinued after they had been informed by the New York County Medical Society that a petition asking for removal of restrictions on blood donor credits had been rejected.

THE publishers of Emily Harvin's novel, "The Stubborn Wood,"* have assured me that it is not a novel at all, but an accurate account in fictional terms of the author's own experiences. Mrs. Harvin (which is not her real name) spent more than two years in insane asylums, although she was perfectly sane. The shock of her husband's alcoholism, brutality and fragrant infidelity caused her to lose an unborn baby.

By this time everyone, including members of Congress, should be familiar with the "pipeline" element in the European Recovery Program. This is more than a figure of speech. There must actually be a continuous flow of goods, from points of origin to points of delivery, if the program is to do what is hoped for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark asked Congress today to strengthen present laws for curbing subversive activities but conceded that new measures might also be required to deal effectively with Communists.

Small neighborhood furniture stores have made a "substantial number" of cancellations on merchandise ordered at both the Chicago and New York markets, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday. Some view the situation as serious but a well-known wholesale salesman stated that cancellation volume is normal and does not indicate a disastrous volume drop in small furniture outlets.

The market success of the new issue of $27,000,000 San Francisco bonds early this week was underscored yesterday with the quick sellout of another issue of tax-exempt California obligations -- $4,000,000 of the. Metropolitan Water District.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The administration and the distillers strongly differed today at a hearing by the joint committee on the economic report on the question of limiting grain for liquor making to 2,500,000 bushels a month for the next eight months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan declared today at a news conference that the Navy has no intention of undertaking strategic air bombing, which he said was generally recognized throughout the department as the paramount responsibility of the Air Force.

Permanent arbitrators help to maintain industrial peace in 22,000 shops in fifty-six industrial branches in metropolitan New York, according to a survey recently made by the State Labor Department and disclosed yesterday.

MADRID, Feb. 5 -- Gordon Troeller, 30-year-old foreign correspondent and son-in-law of a New York couple, is being held in Seguridad jail where he was placed after his arrest on Friday. His arrest was linked to an investigation in connection with the escape of a political suspect wanted by the police.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 5 -- Orville Wright's will disclosed today he left the original Wright brothers airplane to an English museum, and close Dayton friends of the inventor, who died on Jan. 30, said this bequest resulted from his feud with Smithsonian Institution of Washington, D.C.

We in this newspaper office this morning are not thinking of Simeon Strunsky's intellectual brilliance, his gifts as a master of the English tongue, the wide range of his knowledge, the tireless zeal with which he worked to broaden that range, right down to his last working day.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 -- Northern Palestine was the center of activity today, and shooting was going on tonight at a number of points in the Safad area. Tiberias was under curfew until further notice, and in the areas between the town and the northern frontier thirty- eight Jews were arrested yesterday and a considerable number of Arabs were seized.

Mayor O'Dwyer called last night for a lifting of the "one-sided" State Department embargo on the shipment of arms to the Jews in Palestine and urged the formation of a United Nations International Police Force which would be ready to move into the troubled land when British troops depart.

No large price reductions in imported French wines and spirits are expected here as a result of the devaluation of the franc, liquor importers said yesterday. Prices for March will not reflect any downward trend in these lines, because the New York State Liquor Authority has not been petitioned by any importers to allow them either to amend their schedules filed on Feb. 2 or to file new low prices for March, it was learned.

If the Federal system is to survive as a way of government, Congress must find ways in which Federal and state powers can best supplement and reinforce each other, according to a report by the Legislative Drafting Research Fund of Columbia University, made public yesterday.

A newly formed stock company of radio actors in Hollywood, to be known as Twelve Players, is booked to make its WJZ-ABC debut Monday night at 8:30. The presentation will be "Dino Is Dead," an original drama especially written for the acting combine by Warren Specter and Dave Ellis.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- A strong plea for the establishment of rigid apprenticeship qualifications for all persons entering or re-entering theatrical professions was made here today at the opening session of a four-day British theatre conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Little Lebanon, challenging the influence of the great powers in the Middle East, is sponsoring a proposal in the United Nations Economic and Social Council to strengthen the economic authority of the local governments in the region, it was learned today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 5 -- A Hawaii contractor's contention that military orders forced him to violate the Fair Labor Standards (wage-hour) Act between Dec. 7, 1941, and Nov. 10, 1943, was upheld here today by Federal Judge J. Frank McLaughlin.

Frederick Housman, Wall Street figure since 1895, who died Dec. 28, 1945, leaving a net estate of $1,085,528, bequeathed $887,976 for benevolent purposes, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Official Washington is keenly interested in Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal for a Western Union of European States and in Winston Churchill's suggestion that matters should be brought to a head with the Soviet Union.

Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the United States Atomic Energy Commission warned a large gathering of radio executives at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that only with greater knowledge and understanding of atomic energy will we be "less likely to be scared by shadows, or stumble -- or be pushed -- without knowing what we are doing, into some desperate finality" involving the use of atomic weapons.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- General liquidation was on again in the grain and lard markets. Wheat closed 10 cents a bushel (the limit) lower in all American markets, with corn and soy beans down 8 cents a bushel (the limit for them).

The fine record of achievement by 2,141,984 members of the Boy Scouts of America in the last year was acknowledged yesterday by President Truman in a message commemorating the thirty-eighth anniversary of that organization and the official opening today of Boy Scout Week, which will end on February 12.

Frederick E: Vincent, marine manager of the American Foreign Insurance Association, plunged to his death yesterday from his office on the eighteenth floor of 80 Maiden Lane. His body landed on a second-floor extension roof.

Secretary Eddie Brannick of the Giants yesterday mopped a brow that had become feverish because of his efforts to arrange transportation and rooming accommodations for the Giant training party of players, scribes and wives who will head for Phoenix, Ariz., on Feb. 25 or 26, paused long enough to announce the thirtieth and thirty-first contract signers.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Major changes in the technique of airborne operations are essential, "Exercise Snowdrop" -- the Army's largest over-snow airborne maneuver -- has shown.

A banking syndicate headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association bid successfully yesterday for an issue of $4,000,000 of Colorado River Water Works bonds of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California.

A break between Mayor O'Dwyer and the American Labor Party was indicated yesterday when the Mayor at a press conference in City Hall told reporters: "The ALP is not the same party that supported me; the Amalgamated (Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America) is out."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- The Bulgarian Government demanded today a death sentence or life imprisonment against Dimiter Gitchev, one of the country's most popular peasant leaders, in an indictment against him and four others.

The speakers last night at the Meeting of Citizens on Universal Military Training compiled a persuasive argument for immediate adoption of such a program by the United States. A bill to set up this program is blocked now in a House committee, apparently with the approval of the Republican leaders.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Searchers intimated tonight Fritz Kuhn might be hiding out with some of his former colleagues in the German-American Bund. His escape from the Dachau internment camp was announced Wednesday.

Congressional investigation of the Office of International Trade in the Department of Commerce, together with major modification of its new export licensing regulations, was recommended in a resolution adopted yesterday by export members of the Commerce and Industry Association at a meeting held in the offices of the association.

A surprise arrival in the market yesterday was a shipment of red cabbage from Holland, the first to be received from that country in years. The consignment, which is being distributed largely to produce dealers in the metropolitan area, amounted to 1,000 crates, or 50,000 pounds, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

HAVANA, Feb. -- Britain today opposed a United States proposal for the admission of Germany and Japan to the projected International Trade Organization through representation by the occupying powers and offered three alternatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio, announced today that he would vote against the St. Lawrence seaway. The chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee made known his position in a statement, in which he said:

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Intensified research to preserve the productivity of the soil and conserve diminishing natural resources was advocated last night by Games Slayter, vice president in charge of research and development at the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation.
NANKING, Feb. 5 -- Gen, Chen Cheng, who was sent to Manchuria last August as field commander of Government forces in the northeast, returned here tonight by plane from Mukden.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Master Plumbers Associations and certain plumbing wholesalers and manufacturers are practicing a countrywide conspiracy to exact commissions on plumbing sales and installations, a House of Representatives Labor subcommittee was told here today.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Sir Godfrey Collins, Commissioner for the Jewish immigrant camps in Cyprus, categorically denied today that he had said, as quoted in a Reuters dispatch, there were no indications of Communist agents among Jewish immigrants from the ships Pan York and Pan Crescent, it was stated by a Colonial Office spokesman here today.

Promotion for the new Jaques-Frazer tractor of the Frazer Farm Equipment Corporation, a division of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, broke with "teaser" ads in morning papers on Wednesday, followed by full page ads this morning and smaller invitations scheduled for tomorrow.

A lively new vocabulary was flung at the fashion writers who attended Gimbels teen-timers showing yesterday. Such gay and unfashionable words as "sailing boat collar, "beau-catcher belt," "cream puff sleeves" and "icing" punctuated the comments that accompanied the dresses with their "twirling" skirts.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- National Airlines filed notice of a $5,000,000 suit in Dade County Circuit Court Thursday against the Airline Pilots Association, AFL, charging libel and slander.

An enlarged medical center for Brooklyn was urged yesterday at a testimonial luncheon in honor of Dr. Wade W. Oliver, professor of bacteriology at the Long Island College of Medicine, who recently was appointed associate director of medical science of the Rockefeller Foundation.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5 -- Claudio Martinez Payva, chief of the film censorship office, told American correspondents here today that American films would not be banned from Argentina for lack of official review. Recent action was taken to enforce reciprocity with Spain, Italy and Mexico, he said.

Unusually sensitive, musical and poetic playing was heard from Inez Palma, young pianist of New Rochelle, at her first New York recital last night in Times Hall. Modest and unassuming, but poised, Miss Palma, who possessed a pleasing stage presence, put self in the background in a series of comprehending and imaginative interpretations which proved her to be one of the most gifted and promising new artists this season has brought to light.

The snow depths in the North Country, already at a record mark, continue to increase as new covers, ranging from one to eight inches, surfaced the terrain extending from the Poconos of Pennsylvania through the Hudson Highlands, Catskills and Adirondacks of New York State, the Ramapos and Watchung Mountains of New Jersey, the Litchfield Hills, Green and White Mountains of New England to the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Efforts to clarify a Federal ban on admission of Negroes to white units of the New Jersey National Guard were being made today in Washington by Brig. Gen. Donald W. McGowan, deputy chief of the state military organization.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 5 -- A drop in Mexico's tourist business in 1947 was attributed today to post-war economic conditions and abuses by some tourist establishment operators here. Figures released by the Bank of Mexico and the Government Tourist Department showed only. 259,000 tourists had entered Maxico last year as compared with 272,000 in 1946.

American Communists may or may not take comfort from Attorney General Clark's opinion, given yesterday to a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, that it would not be wise and perhaps would not be constitutional to drive their party underground by federal legislation.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Prominent in the parade of winning favorites at Hialeah Park today was the Calumet Farm's Hail Victory, who skipped under the wire first in the once-around-the-track Florida Hammock's Purse, a $4,000 number for older horses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- American President Lines received word today that the Maritime Commission had approved the world-wide sea and air agreement signed last fall by George Killion, president of the APL, and Croil Hunter, president and general manager of Northwest Airlines.

Since the Chekhov one-act plays are famous, it is a pleasure to see them. Now that they are visible at the City Center, where they opened last evening, it is possible to wish that they were better written and better acted. Chekhov wrote them when he was an impecunious doctor and he had more time than patients on his hands.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- The American Federation of Labor was back at the beginning of the road today in its search for a political director to marshal the votes of its 7,200,000 members for the defeat of Congressional supporters of the Taft-Hartley law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, retiring Chief of Staff, today absolved the Soviet Union of any intention of deliberately provoking war. He made the statement during what his friends described as his valedictory public address as Chief of Staff, delivered at the National Press Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has taken two different moves in the wake of the collapse in grain and other commodity prices. On the one hand, its grain buyers have stepped out of the markets. Reports from the markets indicated the Government had curtailed its buying as soon as prices began dropping yesterday.

ATHENS, Feb. 5 -- Twenty-seven women's organizations in Greece, including the Red Cross and the Young Women's Christian Association signed "an appeal to American sympathy" today for the women of Epirus. They alleged that during January alone approximately 800 women and girls were killed, raped or abducted into foreign territory by "Communist rebels."

Reflecting repayment of recent borrowings by the New York Telephone Company, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $57,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

Recent price reductions by the General Electric Company were made in the hope that "we might start a parade that couldn't be stopped," Robert S. Peare, vice president, told more than 300 guests attending the Fifth National Conference of Business Public Relations Executives, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Fighting was reported south of Mukden today as Chinese Communist troops stormed into Liaoyang on the Dairen-Mukden railroad and attacked towns on the Peiping-Mukden line.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The possibility that several New York City Democrats may refuse to support Mayor O'Dwyer's transit fare proposal when it comes up for a vote during the present legislative session is giving Democratic leaders here serious concern.

A syndicate of 110 underwriters headed by Smith, Barney Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of 250,000 shares of new preferred stock of the Monsanto Chemical Company bearing a dividend of $4 and convertible into common stock within ten years.

The Joint Budget Committee representing both Houses of Congress is scheduled to meet today to consider its subcommittee's revision of President Truman's budget. In this revision the Government's anticipated receipts for the next fiscal year have been upped by $2,800,000,000 over Mr. Truman's estimate, while anticipated expenditures have been cut by $2,500,000,000.

This nation stands shamed before the world because of failure to do our fair share in alleviating the misery of Europe's displaced persons by permitting some to find refuge here. Only American leadership in opening our doors to a fair share among them can save these helpless people, 80 per cent of Christian and 20 per cent of Jewish faiths.

The war being waged against Greece by guerrillas supplied with weapons, ammunition, food and clothing "by the Communist rulers of Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Albania" shows that only a strong national defense will insure the peace and safety of the United States, former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson declared last night.

Business men here yesterday regarded the slump in commodity prices of the last two days as a long over-due correction. The decline, they said, will undoubtedly exert major psychological influence in checking further price advances.

An aggressive national advertising campaign utilizing virtually every type of medium reaching the public, with the objective of "making racial prejudice as unpopular as B.O." win be carried on by the Advertising Council, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Your editorial entitled "The St. Lawrence Seaway" is timely and broadminded. However, there are certain essential facts that should be stressed, to enable your readers to form opinions on the wisdom of spending half a billion dollars on the project.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- Bipartite control officials said today the present German food ration, which ranges from 1,400 calories in some areas to 1,200 in others, would remain the same for the rest of the fiscal year, which ends June 30.

New decorating materials have been put to exotic uses in a series of furniture groupings and corner settings that will go on display tomorrow at McCreery's. There is one complete room in the group, a dining room in which two Hunt tables are paired to make a round dining table.
I venture to take the liberty of inviting your attention to one or two points which arise out of your editorial headed "The Kashmir Case" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 29.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The big drop in prices on Wall Street yesterday caused the stock markets here today to open on a cautious note. When it was seen that selling was not above the average a more cheerful tone became apparent and one or two sections became brisker.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Molyneux has captured and modernized the charm of the women painted by Goya, Renoir, Manet and Toulouse Lautrec.

Mayor O'Dwyer gave blunt warning yesterday to building contractors and union leaders that if they want work the city is waiting to give them in a vast construction program, they will have to stabilize labor costs. The Mayor met for two hours with officials of the Building and Construction Trades Council, AFL, and the Building Trades Employers Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- The third-party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President was endorsed today by Grant W. Oakes, president of the CIO-United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, despite national CIO opposition.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The procreation of children one of the principal ends of marriage so far as the Church of England is concerned, the Most Rev. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, said in a formal statement today.
Meat prices have taken a freakish turn this week and pot roast is selling in many stores for as much as steak.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Farm equipment manufacturers said today there is a flourishing black market in farm machinery, and they are powerless to stop it.

MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Roy Conacher scored three goals in the last period tonight to lead the tail-end Chicago Black Hawks to a 7-2 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Climaxing an amazing comeback. America's men and women athletes dominated the seventh day of the Winter Olympics as they swept to clean-cut victries in two events, placed second in another and vaulted from seventh to third place in team standing.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The Dominion of Pakistan was twice involved in charges of genocide before the United Nations Economic and Social Council today -- once as accuser and once as accused.

Leading home-owning and taxpayer organizations throughout the city have formed a central group to defeat Mayor O'Dwyer's proposals for state legislation to increase real estate levies and municipal borrowing power, it became known last night.
The Board of Education voted yesterday to close all of New York's 731 public school buildings next Friday to conserve fuel. Fifty-one of the schools burn oil for heat, the others use coal.

A small part of Maine -- as firmly native to the state as the rocks, the earth, the flowing water and the tall trees, and possessing a quality that emerges only through close contact with these physical things -- has disappeared from sight. Warden Levi Dow is dead

Mayor O'Dwyer swore in yesterday the twelve city officials whose appointments he announced on Wednesday. Heading the list was Francis J. Bloustein of 3636 Greystone Avenue, the Bronx, who was named for an eight-year term on the City Planning Commission to succeed Newbold Morris, whose term expired Dec. 31.

Governor Dewey, in a message yesterday urging public support of the fifth annual Irvington House Coin Box drive, said the efforts on behalf of youngsters who suffer from heart ailments "constitute a most noble and warm-hearted activity."

The 20 per cent cut in steel for British shipbuilding announced in mid-January by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, came as a complete surprise to the country's shipbuilders, who had expected increased allotments in 1948, it became known yesterday.

Your editorial of Jan. 28 entitled "The St. Lawrence Seaway" is excellent. The importance of the project, nationally, demands that selfish sectional interests be disregarded. Even the local New York interest, however, calls for the hydroelectric development.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- During the week ended Feb. 4 member bank reserve balances decreased $221,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall made the draw today for the twenty-nine tennis-playing nations which would like to take the Davis Cup away from the United States.

Hotpoint, Inc., a subsidiary off the General Electric Company, will continue to allocate appliances to distributors for the first six months of the current year, Leonard C. Truesdell, vice president of marketing, said yesterday. At the same time, Mr. Truesdell revealed that present production is at "an all-time high" on all twelve appliances turned out by the company.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 5 -- Just two hours before he was to appear in the main court room of Palace of Justice this morning as a defendant in the final war crimes trial here, former Field Marshal Johannes Blaskowitz plunged to his death fro mthe top tier of cells in the jail adjoining the court house.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Instead of an extension of the Dunkerque treaty, proposed by the British to the Benelux countries, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have indicated that they would prefer a new accord closely linked with the United Nations Charter.

Bill Swiacki, Columbia's All-America end of 1947, received the Bernard M. Moynahan Trophy as the "outstanding Eastern college athlete" at Xavier High School's annual Block X dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night. He accepted the trophy from the Rev. John W. Tynan, S.J., president and rector of Xavier.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 5 -- Before leaving today for a conference of Southern Governors at Tallahassee, Fla., Gov. Fielding Wright issued a call for a statewide mass meeting of the Democrats of Mississippi to be held in the city auditorium here next Thursday.
Bernard Wetchler has been appointed buyer of domestics and draperies for Ludwig Baumann. He succeeds Reuben Abel, who has resigned.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 5 -- The country faces the greatest competitive battle in its history in a few years when production in the main lines of industry begin to reach effective demand, Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the Evening and Extension Division of New York's City College School of Business, declared here today.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The fear that penicillin will become useless as a remedy in a few years because the disease germs it now checks will all have developed resistance to its action is somewhat dispelled by a discovery of Dr. A. Voureka, working in the Wright-Fleming Institute in St. Mary's Hospital here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman predicted today that Congressional efforts to reduce his $39,700,000,000 budget would fail this year as they had last year. He immediately drew contradictions from Republican fiscal leaders. Billions of dollars in economies were effected at the last session, they contended, and billions could be saved this year.

In view of recent observations in this corner about the Russian Look which has brightened our winter of discomfort and discontent with our customary garb here in New York, a report from the Manchesters Guardian's Moscow correspondent has attracted our particular interest.

Today, as always, everyone delights in complaining about high taxes and waste in city, state and federal governments. At present our city is spending millions to clear away the ice and snow on the city streets. People enjoy criticizing the snow shoveler for not putting forth his best efforts in the job.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Universal-International has purchased "Illegal Entry," a screen story by Ben Bengal and Daniel Moore, for future production by Jules Schermer. The story, which deals with the work of the United States immigration and naturalization service in detecting passport frauds and guarding against illegal entry by aliens, will be filmed in the documentary style.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Three stunning upsets marked opening play in the women's international four-ball golf tournament here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- The Joint Commission on Social Action of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and Central Conference of American Rabbis announced today a ten-point program on social action for education within and without the liberal Jewish fold and for cooperation with like agencies of other religious and secular groups to further international peace and harmony and social justice.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 5 (UP) -The Government asked today that W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce and former Embassador to Russia, be "considered" a "co-conspirator" in the Justice Department's anti-trust suit against Western railroads.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall made public today a letter to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, in which he said that a new staff study is under way "to produce a sound solution" of the question of segregation of Negroes in the Army.

A larger number of girls with personal problems had been reached in 1947 than in any preceding year, Miss Margaret M. Stewart, executive director of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said at its thirty-seventh annual meeting yesterday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Community House, 109 East Fiftieth Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 5 -- Drury College, opening its diamond jubilee celebration, heard today a plea by Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright for universal military training as a means of insuring national security.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board denied yesterday a request made by Mackay Radio and Commercial Cables for a new collective bargaining election among their employes because of the failure of the American Communications Association, CIO, to file non-Communist affidavits in compliance with the Taft-Hartley Act.

In many respects the United States Government has been very generous to its war veterans. But in the field of Social Security there is still work for Congress to do in correcting present injustices to returned veterans. One of these has been pointed out to us by a man who was in service for more than four years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach said today he thought unions ought to file non-Communist affidavits before they ask the aid of the Government in settling a dispute.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Undefeated New York University thoroughly outclassed Boston University tonight, 61 -- 44, for its fourteenth basketball triumph. A Boston Garden crowd of 2,884 saw the New Yorkers triumph before a touring Texas Wesleyan quintet took the measure of Boston College, 56 -- 50.

The stock market received yesterday another, but lesser, jolt than on Wednesday in sympathy with further breaks in major commodity prices which, in most cases, were at the full permissible daily decline. Closely following Wednesday's pattern, prices of stocks slumped fractions to about 2 points, while a dip of 1.10 points in the combined averages carried the rate closer to the 1947 low.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 5, George M. Fuller, of Washington, D. C., vice-president of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, said today that continuation of rent control is the chief contributing factor to the housing shortage.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- British treaty talks with the Trans-Jordan Premier and Foreign Minister were concluded today by Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin. The Foreign Secretary saw the Trans-Jordanians for the third time this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The State Department today criticized sharply the manner in which Bulgaria is trying Dimiter Gitchev, a former leader of the Agrarian party, on charges that subject him to possible death sentence or life imprisonment. It compared this trial with that of Nikola Petkov, another Agrarian leader, who was executed over the protest of this Government.
Retail trade here continued active this week. The commodity slump found little or no reflection in consumer buying. Increases in department store volume ranged up to 10 per cent over last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Registration statements covering bonds, debentures and common and preferred shares were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A final plea to dismiss remaining individual defendants in the Western railroad anti-trust suit was made to Federal Judge John W. Delehant today.

The North American Company made known yesterday its plans for compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act through partial distribution to its stockholders of common stock of the Potomac Electric Power Company and an equity financing program to raise approximately $20,000,000 for three operating subsidiaries.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- This was a fine day for sunburn, but no afternoon for plunging on odds-on favorites at Hialeah Park. Two horses owned by Gustave Ring of Washington were clawed down to 7 to 20 and both finished second, a couple of lengths in arrears.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened last night in a dispute between the Safeway Stores and their 1,200 employes in 153 stores in the five boroughs, Westchester, Nassau, Rockland and Bergen Counties. The Mayor asked the company and representatives of Local 474, National Chain Store Employes, CIO, to meet with the City Labor Relations Division at 11 A.M. today.
BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this winter sports bulletin (skiing excellent unless otherwise designated):

The five-story Elks Club at 2851-57 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, N.J., has been purchased by Department Stores Properties, Inc., J.I. Kislak, Inc., reported yesterday. The buying group represents a merger of L.N. Rosenbaum Son and the First Bergen Corporation, the latter represented by the Kislak company, which had engaged in litigation over their bids in Chancery Court to obtain the property from Daniel T. O'Regen, receiver and trustee.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A men's table tennis team from the United States upset Britain's defending champions, five matches to two, tonight and moved into the semifinals of the world championship with increasing chances to take the Swaythling Cup.
The disappearance of Hollis Spaulding (Babe) Spotts, athletic director of Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn, who has been missing since Tuesday, became known yesterday.

ATHENS, Feb. 6 -- A Greek military spokesman tonight confirmed reports of guerrilla activity in the Athens area. He said that not since the Left-Wing Elas attempt to seize power in December, 1944, and January, 1945, had armed subversive elements struck so near the capital.

Winds of seventy to seventy-five miles an hour that "blew the tops right off the waves," according to Capt. Stanley H. Thompson, caused a sixty-hour delay in the arrival of the Ernie Pyle, which docked at Pier 61, North River, yesterday with 481 passengers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Dr. Florence R. Sabin of Denver, Col., nationally known physician and president of the Colorado State Interim Board of Health, said here today that of the 140,000,000 persons in this country, 40,000,000 live in areas which have no public health service and 95,000,000 live where such services fail to meet minimum basic standards.

Under the current Five-Year Plan, which ends in 1950, Premier Stalin and the Political Bureau have given the Russian people the tremendous task of expanding the economy of the Soviet Union to the point where its industrial capacity surpasses that of the United States.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi refused to permit the one precaution that would have saved his life, the searching of strangers attending his public prayer meetings at Birla House.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, threw his moral support today behind a modern publicity program for the Church of England.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 -- Asserting that the price structure of farm commodities and building materials, particularly lumber, are inflated "fantastically," A.W. Zelomak, statistician, declared today that sharp declines in these categories would shake business confidence and probably bring out supplies of other commodities that are held speculatively.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 6 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea will report to the "Little Assembly" at the end of next week on its "failure to exercise the functions conferred on it by the General Assembly" because of the "negative attitude of the Soviet authorities," it was announced here tonight.

The New York Curb Exchange has refused to grant union shop status to its 225 employes of all departments represented by Local 205 of the AFL United Financial Employes, John Cole, vice president of the local, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Dennis A. FitzGerald, director general of the International Emergency Food Council, told a joint economic subcommittee today that better crop prospects would make the European grain situation "substantially easier in the last half of 1948."
For the first time in many years British women with a talent for needlework have materials of pre-war standards with which to work. But their handicrafts are only for export.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug asked Congress today to establish federal control over timberland oil and gas fields "now being drained by wells on land not owned by the Federal Government."

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Misgivings over the Government's ability to get its wage-freezing policy accepted by the trade unions without eventually hitting profits and dividends, together with the fresh slump on Wall Street, depressed the stock markets here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Completion of Senate debate and voting on both its European Recovery Program and income tax reduction bills by April 1 was scheduled by the Republican Policy Committee today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Dr. Charles Seymour president of Yale University, today expressed concern over "the ignorance of history implicit in the attitude of certain political figures, who tell us that if we will honestly trust Russia, all will be well."

The proposed return bout for the world heavyweight title between Champion Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott is practically ready for th signing, with delivery to be made in the Yankee Stadium on the night of June 23, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- British troops had to go into action again today against Arabs in the northernmost area of Palestine near Salad. They had to use mortar fire before they could break up an attack on a Jewish settlement.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 -- Because Japanese textbook authors have cast doubt upon Bible miracles the occupation authorities have decided to appoint a board of chaplains to review all references to the Christian religion before they are permitted to go before the students.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 -- Imports from the United States into Canada fell by $33,000,000 in December after the import restriction program was imposed, it was announced today by Commerce Minister Clarence D. Howe.
GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- The drawing up of a new international schedule of radio broadcast frequencies is being seriously handicapped by Russian non-cooperation, it was learned today.

Race Relations Sunday will be observed widely tomorrow in churches of the New York area. The observance will extend all over the country as recommended annually by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America for the Sunday nearest the birthday of Abraham Lincoln.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Skiing conditions were reported "good" today at these thirty-three New York State sports centers, the State Commerce Department announced:
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- A woman legislator advocated today a New York State law to make it legal for men to patronize beauty parlors.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- An account of how the Soviet attempt with an atomic bomb had failed in the Ural region last August was published by the newspaper Figaro today.
BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- Dr. Howard A. Lane, Professor of Education at New York University, said tonight that "in most of American cities it is illegal to be a child."

A YEAR or so ago Robert Lewis Taylor published a novel called "Adrift in a Boneyard," which was a very funny book on a spectacularly solemn foundation -- the adventures of a few survivors on this planet after what was mildly called "the cataclysmic storm of the Nineteen Fifties." Mr. Taylor's new book, "Doctor, Lawyer, Merchant, Chief,"* illustrates the same genial point of view in various different ways.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- For the third straight day, wheat, corn, soy beans and rye broke today as far as they are permitted to fall in one day on the Board of Trade. Wheat closed at the bottom for the day, off 10 cents a bushel from yesterday and 50 1/8 cents under the mid-January high mark.

The American Water Color Society will open its eighty-first annual exhibition in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue, with a preview and reception tomorrow afternoon from 3 to 7 o'clock. Thereafter the exhibition will be open to the public daily from 1 to 5 o'clock through March 1.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- This is a historic day in the Allied occupation of Germany. The proclamation of Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Gen. Sir Brian Robertson defining the composition and powers of the economic administration of Bizonia marks the finale of one chapter of military government and the beginning of another.

Claudio Arrau was heard in his final New York recital of the season last night at Carnegie Hall. The pianist, who was enthusiastically received by an audience of good size, had planned to present a series of three recitals in that auditorium, but because of illness was unable to give the second, scheduled for the afternoon of Jan. 10.

RONNE ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- The height of summer is passing here in Antarctica, and, although the sun is only below the horizon for a few hours a day, there has been a gradual but noticeable increase in the hours of twilight between 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Ferenc Nagy, exiled former premier of Hungary, told Congress today that to halt imperialist communism, this country would need to give Western Europe political support along with the economic assistance of the Marshall Plan.
Random notes.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Newsprint supply will catch up with demand by 1950, Rep. Clarence J. Brown, Republican, of Ohio, told the Ohio Newspaper Association today.

NANKING, Feb. 6 -- Reasserting China's claim to a foothold in the Kowloon Leased Territory, the Foreign Ministry made public today a note to Britain characterizing the British colonial control of Kowloon as "the last vestige of an outmoded system" on the Chinese coast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A registration statement filed by the Coosa River Newsprint Company of Childersburg, Ala., covering 278,829 shares of $50 par value common stock to be offered publicly at $50 a share, was permitted to become effective yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In a sense, the death of a great teacher is his last contribution to those he sought to enlighten, since the shock snaps open their minds to a reconsideration of his highest teachings and ideals. The widespread consternation felt by Americans at the death of Mahatma Gandhi shows that his teachings made a deeper impression than we had allowed ourselves to realize.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- A state-trading section in the proposed World Trade Charter satisfactory to the United States and Britain, respectively the chief exponents of private enterprise and of state enterprise in the non-Communist world, was adopted today by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 6 -Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright was back home in Texas today, but he left behind in this Ozark center a lively debate on Universal Military Training and particularly on his statement that "compared with the life of the nation, the life of the individual is nothing."

More than a year ago the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution declaring "genocide" a crime and assigning the Economic and Social Council to draw up a draft convention on the subject for Assembly approval and adoption by member governments. This item is on the agenda for the meetings now going on at Lake Success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Joint Budget Committee, in what twenty Democratic members called "indefensible subterfuge," gave its approval today to expenditure estimates representing a $2,500,000,000 cut in President Truman's budget.

The sea routes to the California gold fields have been made the subject of a new book by Oscar Lewis, author of "Silver Kings," an account of the Nevada Comstock Lode. Tentatively titled "Sea Routes to the Gold Fields," the book is based on individual experiences drawn from diaries, journals and reminiscences.

Following the pattern of the two previous days, wheat and corn prices dropped their permissive limits on the nation's exchanges yesterday, but the stock market showed less sensitivity and closed on a fairly even keel.

An unsuccessful meeting between disputants in the five-days-old strike of 104 crew members of 14 oil tankers, tugs and barges of the Reinauer Transportation Companies, Inc., of Staten Island was held yesterday afternoon at the State Mediation Board offices, 270 Broadway.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that the new Russian-Rumanian treaty of mutual defense assumed especially important significance at a time when international reaction was trying to split off Western Germany and include it in a military-political bloc.
A deportation proceeding against Hanns Eisler, 49-year-old Hollywood film composer regarded by the Government as an alien Communist illegally in this country, lasted less than half an hour yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 6 (AP) Four of the lesser lights of the winter golf tour -- Ky Laffoon, Jim Ferrier, Eric Monti and Norman Von Nida -- led the greatest par- shattering rampage in the history of the Texas open today as they laid down blazing 65's in the rain and mud to tie for the first round lead.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- Gen. Jacob D. Devers, commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, today urged the people of this city to be as generous with the Red Cross in peace as they were during the war.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 -- The nation-wide fleet of Douglas DC-6 airliners, grounded last November after two of them caught fire in flight, should be back in service by summer, responsible aviation quarters said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6 -- The Peronista press, which has been busy defending the "freedom" of Argentine universities ever since it was seriously impugned in a series of articles published in the United States, changed its tactics today from defense to offense.

ALARMING dispatches poured to my desk in August, 1938, as the crisis over Czechoslovakia again seemed imminent. Feverish peace negotiations were under way principally between Britain and Germany. Walter Runciman, whom I had seen in Washington in 1937, had been sent by the British to Prague to mediate between the Czechs and the Sudeten Nazis.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- The United Nations Security Council handed the Kashmir case back to India and Pakistan today with a plea to try to come to an agreement by Monday.

Paul Boepple, leading the singers of the Dessoff Choirs last night in Town Hall, placed his audience immensely in his debt by a complete program of a cappella music by Josquin des Pres, and gave this program a most earnest performance.

In a sharp reversal of recent trends in secondary metal markets, prices of brass ingots were reduced by leading refiners yesterday by 1 cent to 1 1/4 cents a pound, reflecting some scares about price drops in other commodity markets, dealers reported here yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Former Gen. Otto von Stuelpnagel, who as Nazi commander was the absolute dictator of the Paris district for the first year and one-half of the occupation of Paris, hanged himself in his cell in Cherches Midi Prison here today. While he ruled here hostages from this prison were led to execution.

Few or no cancellations of outstanding orders in most lines of merchandise have resulted from the slump in commodity prices, buying executives here reported yesterday. Avoidance of delivery delays on spring merchandise continues a major factor.

The city administration was accused yesterday of going back to the "long-discredited spoils system" in sponsoring legislation that would enable the Fire Commissioner to circumvent the existing civil service eligible list for fire chief and appoint a deputy chief of his personal selection to the post.

Of the $359,572 estate left by Mrs. Emma Raub, widow of Frank Raub, former part owner of Consumers Brewing Company of Brooklyn, more than $190,000 was left for charitable purposes, according to a transfer appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Estate Tax Commissioner Charles W. Ferry.

The Judicial Conference of Senior Circuit Judges at its last session renewed the recommendation, annually advanced since 1944, for the repeal of the prohibition against filling the vacancy resulting from the retirement of the late Judge Woolsey and also recommended the creation of two additional permanent judgeships in the Southern District of New York.

Asserting that welfare needs would increase during the year, Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, asked Thomas J. Patterson, budget director, for $181,997,000 yesterday for the operation of his department in 1948-49. This amount represents an increase of $39,351,501.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Jean Desses contributes to the Paris season with a collection so imbued with the new feeling for femininity that not a single tailor-made item appears in it.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- The Arab Higher Committee of Palestine sent to the United Nations today a formal declaration of war in "self-defense" against any attempt to partition the Holy Land.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 6 -- After fourteen years in which Kentucky steadily has been going dry, the wet forces won a major victory in the General Assembly today.

The Experimental Theatre, an adjunct of the American National Theatre and Academy, will offer its third work of the season tomorrow evening at Maxine Elliot's Theatre. It is an adaptation of Gorki's "The Lower Depths," written by Randolph Goodman and Walter Carroll and entitled "A Long Way From Home."

The city's dark bread production -- rye and pumpernickel -- will be curtailed but its over-all bread supply is not expected to be impaired seriously by the strike of 4,000 bakers and 1,000 sales employes in retail shops called yesterday by American Federation of Labor locals to enforce demands for higher wages.

Francois Villon, an irresponsible poet and dreamer, could build a beautiful ballad on the refrain, "But where are the snows of yesteryear?" If Master Villon were a citizen of our town he might be less concerned with the snows of yesteryear, now safely lost in the Atlantic Ocean, and more concerned with the snows of this year.

A jury in Kings County Court late yesterday found Benjamin Feldman, Brooklyn pharmacist, guilty for the second time of murdering his 25-year-old wife with poison. The verdict -- guilty of murder in the first degree -- was returned by the all-male blue-ribbon panel after deliberating four hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Belgian Trade Union movement will shortly invite trade unionists of the sixteen Marshall-aid nations to a conference for the purpose of discussing the role of labor in the administration of European Recovery Program, it was reported authoritatively today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Train 506 of the New York Central Railroad's Harlem division pulled away from the Fleetwood station here almost on its scheduled time of 8:14 A.M. today.

There was decidedly less pressure on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday than during earlier sessions this week, and final prices were 3 points higher to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

Conditions point to an easing of the paper situation to the extent that the gray market in pulp will disappear before the end of the year, it was predicted yesterday by Loeb Cole, vice president of the International Statistical Bureau.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Claims totaling $42,500,000 against the old Insull "utility empire" were compromised yesterday for $1,600,000, ending more than fifteen years of litigation.

Knocked down twice in the opening round, first for a count of eight and then for nine, Eddie Giosa, Philadelphia welterweight, ran into his first defeat here last night, when Rocco Rossano, Brooklynite, won a ten-round decision at the St. Nicholas Arena.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 -- Solid gains for a European Customs Union were recorded by an international study group, which closed today after five days of discussion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Northwest Airlines in the first such move taken in commercial aviation, today announced that it will return five per cant of the ticket price to passengers whenever a flight reaches its destination more than 30 minutes late.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Messages of congratulation -official and otherwise-poured from Ottawa today as word was received that the city's favorite daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Scott, had won the Olympic figure skating championship,

Apparently headed nowhere so far as the national picture is concerned, St. John's University continues to make life unhappy for metropolitan basketball rivals. Opposed last night by a Manhattan College five which boasted an infinitely better record, the Brooklyn Redmen defeated the Kelly Greens, 49 -- 40.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Two secret letters came to light today to answer the question of whether return of the Kitty Hawk airplane to the United States ever was requested by its inventor.

The city's Commissioners of Health and of Hospitals voiced hope yesterday that the Red Cross and the Queens and New York County Medical Societies would reach an agreement so that the Red Cross Blood Donor Service could proceed with a plan to provide large quantities of free blood for medical work.

General Manager George Weiss of the world champion Yankees announced yesterday that he asked waivers on Bobo Newsom, veteran right-hander, "with the purpose of giving Newsom his unconditional release."

Consolidated earnings of the Sheraton Corporation of America and its subsidiaries, which are hotel-operating companies, for the six months ended with last October amounted to $769,218 after charges, taxes and minority interests, compared with $720,998 for the corresponding period of 1946, according to a report issued yesterday to stockholders.

Without the services of its playmaker, Sherry Marshall, and out of action since the middle of last month, Columbia's unbeaten quintet will seek to extend its eleven-game streak tonight when it meets Fordham in the Rose Hill gymnasium. The contest will provide the feature of a four-game program listed locally.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Mass unemployment and "real, desperate hunger" will face Britain if her export drive, already imperiled by rising prices, fails, Prime Minister Attlee warned tonight.

Warning that communism at home and abroad is busy selling the idea that the American way of life is decadent, Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday that "unless we can prove otherwise we are doomed to defeat and disaster."

Lewis Mumford, writer and a life member of the limited group of 250 distinguished authors, artists and musicians who make up the National Institute of Arts and Letters, resigned yesterday from that body because of its award of a gold medal to Charles A. Beard, one of America's best-known historians.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, of Atlanta, Ga., and Miss Jean Hopkins of Cleveland continued their advance in the third annual women's international four-ball golf tournament today.
The report of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net profit of $4,259,230 for the six months ended last December, after taxes and all charges.

"Two real dangers beset any attempt to sustain exceptional effort over a prolonged period," we are reminded by General Albert Orsborn of The Salvation Army in Great Britain. "The first is the fact that a repeated stimulus provokes a progressively weaker reaction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Navy today announced a new eight-ship modernization program that will include the early conversion of a fleet-type submarine into an underseas guided-missile craft.

Declaring that "the survival of freedom depends most of all upon the use to which freedom will be put," John Foster Dulles, adviser to the State Department, urged yesterday that the nation's youth be trained to preserve the principles upon which our nation was founded.

A resolution supporting the Universal Military Training bill was adopted by a narrow margin yesterday after a stormy debate at the 135th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Astor Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- In a sarcastic note published tonight Britain charged that the Bulgarian Government had been "deliberately conniving" in unauthorized Jewish immigration to Palestine or that a "serious error has been committed by the Bulagrian officials concerned."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A Senate committee refused again today to clear Edwin W. Pauley and Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham of any implication that they used "inside information" in commodity trading.

Following his vigorous speech of Jan. 22 with definite action, Foreign Secretary Bevin has now submitted to the French Government a draft treaty designed to form the basis for the creation of the West-European Union he then proposed. Simultaneously, Minister of State McNeil has arrived in Brussels to begin talks regarding such a Union with the Benelux countries -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today put off until Feb. 16 a decision on new rent legislation after failing to reach any conclusions on a controversial measure submitted to it by a subcommittee.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Blonde, blue-eyed Barbara Ann Scott, Canada's superb ballerina of the ice, won Sonja Henie's olympic figure skating crown today with a dazzling exhibition of grace and beauty that left her rivals nowhere.
Residential properties that had been held for many years by the sellers' families passed to new control in Manhattan deals reported yesterday.

A taxpayer building containing twenty-one stores is planned for the vacant plot at the southeast corner of Queens and Woodhaven Boulevards in Elmhurst, Queens, purchased from the Magdalene Boelsen estate by a client of John T. McCormick, attorney.

Municipal financing will occupy the center of interest in the market for new capital here next week. No major corporate financing is slated to come to market until the week beginning on Feb. 16. Municipal bidders are to compete on Tuesday for $6,000,000 of Dallas, Tex., bonds carrying maturities going to 1958, and for $6,256,000 of Cleveland, Ohio, bonds maturing up to 1973.

East River Apartments, Inc., of 504 Grand Street, yesterday filed plans for a twelve-story apartment building to be erected at 522 to 540 Grand Street at an estimated cost of $2,100,000. The building will house 265 families. George W. Springsteen is the architect.

DUBLIN, Feb. 6 -- With fifteen seats out of 147 yet to be filled, it is clear that Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's party will not get more than sixty-nine or seventy seats in the new Dail, or six to seven less than it had in the last Dail.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Last July, while sitting at a desk in the suite in the Muehlebach Hotel, Kansas City, that President Truman had occupied a few days previously, Richard L. Saunders of 517 Teaneck Road, Ridgefield Park, vice president of the Texas Company, reached for a telegraph blank and to his surprise found two containing messages in Mr. Truman's handwriting.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- French coal production for January reached the highest point since the liberation with 4,750,000 tons mined, it was announced today. The total was 120 per cent of the monthly average in 1938.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 6 -- Members of the executive boards of two powerful affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations met in adjoining rooms of a downtown hotel today to draft a wage-strategy campaign for 1948 which may call for a blanket increase of as much as 25 cents an hour.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- Two public opinion surveys, one conducted by the United States Military Government and the other by the British, have shown that "socialization of all industry gets surprisingly little support from the German public," officials of the Military Government's information control division disclosed today.

New models of heating and hot water units are now being housed in cabinets that resemble such familiar household appliances as automatic washers or large refrigerators. Many are intended for first-floor utility rooms in small houses without basements. As a result of technical improvements, the units are smaller and more compact than formerly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- President Truman today received the golden anniversary civic service award of the fraternal order of Eagles in recognition of "his contributions to the welfare of our country and its citizens."
ST. MORITZ, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The United States A.H.A. hockey team defeated Austria, 13 to 2, today while Switzerland was forging into the lead in the tournament.

The editorial attention which you devoted in your issue of Feb. 3 to my bill to recall outstanding United States currency and to substitute a new issue therefor, on a dollar-for-dollar basis, suggests that you did not have before you at the time all of the reasons which I made public here in Washington.

Advertisers, radio chains and industrial public relations departments were urged to participate in a national drive to obtain more iron and steel scrap, L.E. Roark, executive vice president of the National Founders Association, revealed in a statement yesterday.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- A second successive victory today gave Lockwood Pirie's yacht Twin Star of Chicago a commanding lead in the series for the Cuba Cup being sailed off the mouth of the Almendares River here. Sam Pirie again crewed for the winning skipper, who earlier in the week won the coveted Bacardi Cup, opening event of the International Star class regatta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Two devices designed to improve the landing gear of airplanes were among the 275 inventions listed for patent awards in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

New York's quota in the 1948 Red Cross fund drive will be $6,036,000, James M. Cecil announced yesterday at a "springboard" meeting of Red Cross leaders of the five boroughs in the New York Chapter House at 315 Lexington Avenue.

The city's emergency pool of light fuel oil dropped to zero yesterday as the transfer of 4,200,000 gallons borrowed from the Navy was delayed. At the same time 3,318 more homes were reported without fuel and 1,539 no-heat complaints were received by the Health Department.

Surprised in an attempt to hold up the Reda Liquor Store at 5 1/2 Fort Washington Avenue, 100 feet west of Broadway, three young men, one of them armed, were shot and captured at 8:20 last night by an experienced detective and a probationary patrolman.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The movement of Soviet factories to return their state subsidies to the Government gained momentum today.

A light snowfall that sifted down almost all day yesterday brought the winter's snowfall to 50 inches, more than recorded in any full winter since 1933-34, when there was 53.1 inches. In 1922-23 there was 55.2 inches. The record was set in 1892-93, when 77.6 inches fell.
TORONTO, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Billy Taylor, one of hockey's slickest stickhandlers, stepped into the National Hockey League's most-traded player class today.

There is little immediate hope of lower shoe prices without further declines in raw material prices than those now in prospect, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association. Decreases in hide prices which have taken place so far will have their chief effect on heavy sole leather, according to the association.

A fundamental change in the position of the United States with regard to oil is taking place, almost unnoticed in the flurry over shortages. After having been one of the greatest sources of exports through almost the entire history of the petroleum industry, the United States is becoming a net importer of oil.
ROME) Feb. 6 -- The Communist-dominated National Association of Italian Partisans declared itself willing today to comply with the Government decree forbidding all private armed organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -Picketing of a railroad not directly involved in a strike, to prevent it from carrying products of struck lumber mills, known as "hot cargo," is illegal, under a decision of the California State Supreme Court upholding a lower court injunction against the Lumber and Sawmill Workers Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The State Department informed Congress late today it would ask about $570,000,000 for aid to China in the fifteen months beginning April 1 and struck a global total of $9,333,000,000 for all such programs through fiscal 1949.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 6 -- King Leopold of the Belgians, while a prisoner in German hands during June of 1940, confided to a German officer assigned to supervise his movements, the hiding place of the Belgian state treasure, according to documents submitted here today in the trial of former Nazi diplomats.
Horace H. Silliman and Arthur C. Jordan have been named merchandising manager and distribution manager, respectively, for Bendix Radio Division of Bendix Aviation Corporation.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Coach Jimmy Littlejohn's Scarlet and Brown forces gained a commanding lead today in the quest of a fourth straight New York State crown while Queens University of Kingston, Ont., was showing the way to nine rivals in the western division Intercollegiate Ski Union championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Department of the Army announced today the assignment of Maj. Gen. James A. Van Fleet as director of the United States military groups in Greece. These groups of officers and enlisted men are advising the Greek Army on operations against the guerrillas, and are stationed at headquarters as far down as the divisional level.

Serge M. Rubinstein, the international financier, moved a step closer to deportation yesterday when the United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed his conviction on four of five counts of an indictment charging violation of the Selective Service Act of 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Action by the Air Transport Command in providing for the transport of Army dependents to Japan on non-scheduled air contract carrier planes as well as on scheduled lines was studied today in executive session by the Congressional Joint Air Policy Board.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- A bicameral economic government for the combined United States and British zones on approximately he traditional German pattern was proclaimed today, effective Monday. The reorganized structure includes a supreme court and will include a credit bank.

The performance of "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow night, with the leading roles being sung by Bidu Sayo, Ferruccio Tagliavini and Giuseppe Valdengo, will augment the Scholarship Fund of the Manhattanville College Alumnae Association.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Butter and fortified margarine have equal nutritional value, according to a survey reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association today.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Southern Governors, or their representatives, arrived today for an extraordinary session of the Conference of Southern Governors with an open challenge from one of their colleagues to use the meeting to initiate a regional secession from President Truman in November.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Reports that the campaign manager of Senator Albert W. Hawkes was preparing to offer the olive branch to the segment of the Republican party in this state opposed to Mr. Hawkes' renomination circulated in the capital today, but developments must await the recovery of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, who is in bed with a cold.

Dr. Abba Hillel Sfiver, chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared yesterday that unless the embargo was lifted to permit the arming of the Jewish people in Palestine the world would "build up to another Spain, just as bloody and as disastrous."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -United States exports and imports both hit record highs in 1947. The Census Bureau reported today that exports were worth $14,474,900,000, or 49 per cent more than in 1946. Imports were worth $5,738,600,000, up 17 per cent over 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The White House was shaken today by a "palace coup" in which Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, announced his own elevation to be "Chief Armed Forces Aide." He did not hold the position long.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 6 Much of today's testimony in the war crimes trial of thirteen members of the German High Command dealt with German directives ordering the slaughter of Russian political commissars during the war. Lieut. Gen. Waiter Warlimont and Former Judge Advocate General of the German Army Rudolf Lehman are accused of having framed and disseminated these orders.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Trud, Soviet trade-union newspaper, said today the United States was planning a war. In the lead editorial on its front page, the paper compared the budgets of the Soviet Union and the United States to prove it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Lee Pressman quit today as general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its biggest affiliate, the United Steel workers, in a disagreement over fundamental CIO policy, the candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President.

The enormity of the "back-stage" task involved in the largest piece of private corporation financing ever undertaken, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's marketing of $357,532,600 convertible debenture issue, was revealed with many sidelights in the winter issue of Bell Telephone Magazine.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- While Britain's Labor Party Government seeks to combat the expansionist strategy of the Soviet Union by a "Western union" diplomatic offensive, the Labor party itself is disciplining its organization and members to reduce Communist inflation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Representatives of Latin-American countries testified before the United Nations Economic and Social Council today on measures being taken by their countries to suppress illicit traffic in narcotics. The Council, after a discussion approved, in principle, the reports of its narcotics commission and of the central opium board, and re- ferred both to the Council's social committee.

Substantial increases in 1948 appropriations were reported for public relations budgets of more than half the manufacturers represented at the Fifth National Conference of Business Public Relations Executives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a canvass of representative members revealed yesterday.

The Rochester Radio City, built by the Stromberg-Carlson Company to house its broadcast facilities in the up-state city, will be opened next Friday, Feb. 13, with a week-long series of special events.

The stock market proved less sensitive yesterday to the decline in commodities and there was some firmness in the more active issues. On balance, the list ended on a fairly even keel with an increase of 0.19 point in the combined averages, due to gains in a few industrials.

Gilbert Dodds has set a double record objective for himself at Boston tonight. Besides launching a fresh assault on his brand new indoor mile mark of 4:05.3, Galloping Gil will attempt to lower Glenn Cunningham's ten-year-old indoor figures of 3:48.4 for 1,500 meters.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 6 (UP) -- Mrs. Michael Walker, 40 years old, became "one woman in fifty-four million" today when she gave birth to her second set of triplets within five years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -"Ethan Frome," Edith Wharton's 1911 novel, to which Warner Brothers has owned the screen rights since 1941, will be filmed as Bette Davis' next picture, with Bretaigne Windust directing, the studio announced today.

If puddings, which are best when they're served warm, can be said to have a season, that season is certainly winter, when a steaming dessert is a welcome finale to dinner. Aside from appealing to cold weather appetites, the baked puddings suggested here are attractive from an economical point of view, and because they are all easy to prepare.

Following the example of the Medical Society of Queens, the New York County Medical Society has refused a request of the Red Cross Blood Donor Service of the Greater New York Chapter to permit employes of firms and members of trade unions and other organizations to bank their gifts of blood for their own benefit and that of their families, free of charge.
PEIPING, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Government steel town and a Nationalist port in Manchuria were under heavy Communist attack today. The situation at both was described as critical.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The establishment of a division of records within the State Executive Department to set up standards and provisions for the protection and preservation of both state and local records was proposed here today in a bill.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- The 6,800 Ford Motor Company foremen became today an indispensable part of the management team by direction of Henry Ford 2d.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday that the return of seven American tankers transferred to Soviet Russia under lend-lease during the war was now being accomplished, and that the commission had been named sales agent in the eventual disposal of the ships to American buyers.

It is encouraging to see a report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 5 that the Republicans in Albany are urging an increase in proposed state aid for education. One hundred and three million dollars additional state aid, reccommended by the Public Education Association and the New York State Educational Conference Board, is embodied in a bill introduced by Senator Fred Young (S.I. 153) and Assemblyman Wheeler Milmoe (A.I. 147).

The 1948 line of Pontiac cars was announced here yesterday, with hydra-matic drive offered as optional equipment for the first time. The prices remain at the 1947 level, with the exception of the added deluxe series, which is $85 extra.

The St. Olaf Lutheran Choir, one of the country's oldest a cappella choral organizations appeared in Carnegie Hall before a large, enthusiastic audience yesterday afternoon. Olaf C. Christiansen led the sixty-odd students of St. Olaf's College of Northfield, Minn., in a program that featured Milhaud's "Cantata of Peace" and included many works by Scandinavian composers.
ON the Hawaiian radio Mrs. Nussbaum would undoubtedly talk pidgin, the jargon that wears a coconut hat, a holoku and a broad grin.
ANY author writing in the first person singular runs the risk of becoming identified in the reader's "I" of his story.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- A list of 226 persons from thirty-United Nations countries whom the United States considers entitled to immunity from arrest and taxation and to other special privileges under the headquarters agreement was disclosed here today.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The French Cabinet decided today to take quick and drastic action to check the rise in food prices since the devaluation of the franc. These prices have risen from 10 to 20 per cent in the last week.
