If they were to continue, they would strengthen the demands for further wage increases that experts believe would imperil the entire deflation program of the Government.

VANDERBILT--Latin America The first of five cooperative summer sessions dealing with Latin-American studies will be held at Vanderbilt University from June 11 to 17. Three other universities, Texas, North Carolina and Tulane, are participating in the project under a grant from the Carnegie Corporation.

The unprecedented resignation of Lewis Mumford from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, announced Friday, will receive no attention from the institute other than a formal notation at the next meeting, Douglas Moore, president of the organization, said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia won the men's team title in the world table tennis championships at Wembley tonight, defeating France, five matches to two, in the final after eliminating the United States squad in the semifinals by the same score.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. S. Neuwirth of Asbury Park and Dr. William Lipton of Newark won the mixed pairs championship early today at the seventh annual south Jersey contract bridge tournament with a score of 203 points.
There is hardly one shooter in the State of New York who will not be adversely affected by the passage of new firearms legislation just introduced at Albany in both the Senate and the Assembly.

Columbia's unbeaten team wrote a new chapter for basketball on Morningside Heights by winning its twelfth game of the season against Fordham last night, 58 to 46, before a capacity crowd at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx.

Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherlands representative at the United Nations, yesterday presented the Dutch Resistance Cross to be placed in the memorial to Europe's persecuted Jews to be built in Riverside Park at Eighty-fourth Street.

GENEVA, Feb. 7 -- There is general agreement among experts that a considerable increase in trade between Eastern and Western Europe is an essential condition for European recovery and for the success of the Marshall Plan.

MOTHERS sometimes ask what would happen if they just stopped reminding little boys to wash. Could they expect that, freed from reminders, the young would one day use soap and water on their own initiative ?

Prices stiffened further yesterday on the Stock Exchange as covering by short sellers helped to push the list away from the week's low marks. Fractional gains pre-dominated, with only a few wide swings. A better feeling prevailed in Wall Street as a result of cessation of some of the pressure on the commodities.

WORK on the proposed New York Thruway, originally scheduled to be open to traffic in 1950, has been seriously delayed by the road- building blight which has settled over this country. The great cross-state traffic artery linking New York and Buffalo is now almost three years behind its construction timetable, and there are indications that the major links will not be in full operation before 1955.

Of the 2,540 dogs entered in America's foremost bench show, the seventy-second annual event of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Wednes-and Thursday, five will be watched with particular interest if for no other reason than they were contenders for the top prize a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- India has sent to Pakistan two protests about frontier incidents -- one on the eastern and one on the western border -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, told the Constituent Assembly here today.

THE discussion of plans to assist Europe is beset by a profusion of ideas regarding the conditions to be attached to our aid. These must be sorted out quickly, and with a willingness to face circumstances as they are, not as we might wish them to be.

FOR many years the planes of scheduled airlines have carried as standard equipment a printed form asking the passenger to write down any suggestions for improving the service. One of these was placed in the pocket of each seat and over a period of years thousands of them were filled in and handed to the hostess or steward.

TANGIN PALACE, Suiyuan, China, Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- The United States China Relief Mission's investigators, here to determine the extent of the Ordos famine, find the lavish servings of mutton and repeated offerings of buttered tea, given to them at each Mongol palace that they visit, hard to take in the face of the hunger in the area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The "secessionist" tempest aroused among Southern Democrats in Congress this week by President Truman's message on civil rights was accompanied by a sober undertone from Dixie editors.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A reported plot to bomb Caracas in a revolution against the Venezuelan Government has been thwarted and six American fliers have been arrested.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- St. Lawrence University's formidable array of skiers swept every event in capturing the New York State championship for the fourth successive season, while R.P.I.'s resurgent squad turned back nine other teams in winning the Intercollegiate Ski Union western division title as St. Lawrence's ninth annual carnival wound up today in a heavy snowstorm.

KATHLEEN HUGHES' novel is excellent, taken in fragments; flashes of warm reality, moments of clear, quiet insight; pen sketches of human nature in three dimensions. These enrich and irradiate all that the author has to say, without in any way unifying her novel.

LIMA, Peru -- This city is twelve degrees south of the equator and geographically it is in the tropics. Meteorologically, and in many other ways, it is anything but tropical. This early February day feels like a perfect afternoon early in June in New York, which is only twenty-four hours away by plane.

THE assassination of Gandhi was like an electric shock. It jarred us all into consciousness of something we had been conveniently putting in the back of our minds. There were so many other things nearer home to worry about.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- After an unusually dull pre-season period (October through January) Arizona's winter resorts have picked up rapidly this month and the entire state now seems to be on its way to a record 1948 season.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Twenty-seven persons were killed, ten injured and 150 others arrested during the wave of strikes, sabotage and violence which swept South Korea yesterday as a protest against the United Nations Commission now in Seoul.
SALUDA, N.C., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Four soldiers were killed and six men were injured late today when C-47 Air Force cargo-type plane crashed into fog-shrouded Mount Page, two miles from here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 -- The Yale swimmers won their twenty-ninth consecutive duel meet in the Payne Whitney Pool tonight, submerging the Duke University mermen, 58 -- 17, with the loss of only one first place.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 -- The investigation of the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi began reaching into high places today.

Bernard Iddings Bell's article, "We Lack Leadership -- Is Education at Fault?" is an insult to the intelligence of the American people and a thinly veiled attack on the democratic faith of our country.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- A number of German officials and political leaders, including some who behind the scenes actively cooperated in drafting the bizonal economic government charter, made it clear today they would not accept any responsibility for the creation of the new Bizonal Economic Administration.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Chicagoans in general are becoming more aware of the gravity of the city's juvenile delinquency problem and the efforts to curb it. This is apparently the one definite result of the order of Police Commissioner John C. Prendergast issued to his district commanders two weeks ago to enforce Chicago's curfew ordinance, which was enacted in 1910 and ignored by law-enforcement authorities in recent years.

A nation-wide drive for funds to increase research into heart disease and to keep the medical profession and the public better informed on new developments in the treatment of heart and circulatory diseases will mark National Heart Week, opening today.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER, long the citadel of sleek conservatism in Hollywood, has abandoned the ivory tower of escapist drama and has decided to come to grips with reality, the news from the studio indicated last week.

James Brown was 42, an executive in an advertising agency. He worked long hours and under a great deal of tension. His last two life insurance examinations showed his blood pressure to be slightly elevated. During a board meeting one afternoon, after a heavy lunch, he suddenly felt an excruciating pain over his heart radiating down the left arm.

Spring coats tell their fashion story with a swing. The majority are made with skirts that flare, some in a wider arc than others. The largest ripples are likely to flow from the snuggest waistlines. The beltless models are made in silhouettes that sweep from the shoulders either with lines that hang straight or with a backward movement springing from gores or inverted pleats.

THESE "stories * * * are held together by a thread of enchantment that runs all through the book," says Miss Dalgliesh in her introduction. It is a slender thread, but strong. Here are twenty-one stories from various countries: "tales of enchanted princes and princesses, of animals that become human beings and humans turned into animals."

JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 -- A police report tonight accused Arabs of cutting both arms and an ear off a Jew in an attack on a food convoy in upper Galilee near the Lebanese border. The victim was found alive but he died before reaching a hospital.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The league-leading Detroit Red Wings preserved their three-point margin over the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs tonight when they breezed past the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before 11,181 fans.

With other airline executives and investors entertaining drab views of the future, C.R. Smith, chairman of the board of American Airlines and president of its subsidiary, American Overseas Airlines, declared yesterday that only a few things stood between the lines and prosperous, useful national service.

THE appearance of Stephen Spender's "Returning to Vienna" gives occasion for a rereading of his "Vienna," which appeared in 1934. There must have been several readers of that poem when it came out who were pleased to hear Spender, during a recent reading of his poetry, corroborate their original feeling that it was not one of his best works.

THE third annual "Tops in Photography" show will held on March 4, at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The program will include a panel of speakers, an international exhibition of prints, two of the year's finest amateur motion pictures, and the showing of outstanding color slides.

WHAT has become your critic's high standard of objectivity? In last week's article he again uses his quite legitimate critical prejudice against Bertolt Brecht's "Galileo" and in favor of Barrie Stavis' "Lamp at Midnight," in order to publicly shame Charles Laughton for having done the Brecht play at all.

In any consideration of the long-range outlook for oil, the question of whether the United States should embark at this time on a large-scale synthetic liquid fuel program, at an estimated cost of $8,000,000,000 or $9,000,000,000, becomes of paramount importance.

DUBLIN, Feb. 7 -- As to where the next government of Ireland is to come from, even with Eamon de Valera's lacking an over-all majority, this correspondent can outline tonight Mr. de Valera's certain prospects.
Matronly faces were red in some New York homes last night after the first session of a Saturday morning parent-child course at City College's School of Business, 17 Lexington Avenue.

Midnight jazz concerts are now a fixture in New York, but late Friday night Dean Dixon and the American Youth Orchestra introduced something new, a midnight symphony concert. It was given at Town Hall and, though it did not start till 11:30 P.M., it attracted an audience of 800.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 7 -- India without Gandhi is about to enter a new era of her turbulent history. The world will soon see whether India is to slide backward under a wave of internecine quarrels or is to move toward leadership in a forward-looking Asia.

The Theatre Owners of America yesterday announced that it had signed a ten-year agreement with the American Society of Composers and Publishers raising royalty payments by many movie houses, according to The Associated Press.

Bedding manufacturers will be forced to raise prices almost immediately following any appreciable increases in labor costs, J. Paul Fanning, general manager of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, declared yesterday. He said that no immediate increases are planned, but described prices as "awfully firm."

ONE dozen roses, please," might be the password at the florist shop these days, for at this time of year greenhouse roses -- so uniform in perfection -- are a reliable cut-flower purchase. Since they are a different breed from the ones grown in the garden last June, the hostess receiving them as a gift will do well to take her cue for arranging them from their strong stems and clear color.

The startling shakedown in raw materials prices last week does not threaten to impose cutbacks in industrial operating levels but may bulwark "high-level" production rates, materials experts revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A new concept of agricultural policy, focused on the farmer's share of the national income rather than on the parity price formula, was advanced today by a Senate Agriculture subcommittee.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 7 -- A wave of sabotage swept South Korea early this morning and throughout the day in a Communist-sponsored protest against the United Nations Commission's decision to place the Korean question before the Little Assembly.
Memorabilia of Abraham Lincoln and George Washington from the collection of the New York Public Library will be exhibited on Thursday in its main building, Forty- second Street and Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- Nearly six years after a major social and economic upheaval had struck West Coast residents of Japanese ancestry, the Nisei and their alien parents are following a living and work pattern somewhat altered from its pre-war character.
MANEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Twin Cities and Winnipeg entries dominated opening races of the Ten Thousand Lakes skating meet today.

ADAMS, Mass., Feb. 7 -- Per Klippgen, 22-year-old veteran of the Norwegian underground, showed record-breaking class as he outstripped a field of forty-nine expert skiers to take the Eastern downhill championship today on Mount Greylock's Thunderbolt Trail.

Recent discussions regarding the desirability of increasing reserve requirements of banks in the Federal Reserve System have revived suggestions that the traditional method by which such requirements are fixed be revised completely.

HAVANA, Feb. 7 -- Twin Star, sailed by Lockwood Pirie, of Chicago's Sheridan Shore Yacht Club, today won the Cuba Cup in the seventeenth International Star Class regatta with a perfect score of twenty-one points, accumulated by taking all three races in the series.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- A new stage of the battle against inflation has now begun in France, with the bullish effects of devaluation of the franc and perhaps an increased distrust of the currency added to the factors making for rising prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman's warning on Thursday of an economic crash, coupled with the skid of the commodity markets, has made the American people more conscious than ever of the inflation problem. While economists try to penetrate the significance of what is taking place, politicians and other less gifted seers have been making a hasty inventory of the situation.

PRAGUE, Feb 6 (Delayed) -- All citizens and residents of Czechoslovakia will be subject to punishment with about six months in prison if they violate a bill that will soon be placed before the Government to prevent the defamation of statesmen or institutions of foreign countries.

HERE are two books of more than casual interest to hunters, gun cranks or even to the owner of only one firearm. Charles Jacobs' ably edited "Gun Digest" has proved its worth through three editions. To restore hope and confidence to the followers of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, the United Nations should employ an international force to insure order between Moslem and Hindu, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal said yesterday in a sermon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

There will be no salary increases in the near future for sports writers whose publishers read Brown's expose of our charming circle and find it a strong argument for less money and longer hours.

Last week most New Yorkers were pretty tired of "fresh, deep" snow -- snow that became black with soot, turned to slush slowed transportation. On Wednesday 5.l inches of snow fell -- nothing like the Big Snow of last Dec. 26, but still a considerable fall -- and more came down on Thursday and Friday.

THIS is the third massive volume in which The Times of London tells the great tale of its heyday as "The Thunderer" -- that one and only newspaper in the Victorian era which, entrenched within the classic walls of Printing House Square, was held by statesmen of a former day to be more authoritative than any other organ of opinion then influencing the counsels of Europe.

Contracts for early deliveries of wheat and corn showed large declines on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday for the fourth successive day, while those for the most distant deliveries, which were closer to their support prices, closed higher for the first time since Wednesday.

The political jockeying in the Eightieth Congress reached a new pitch of intensity last week. It centered upon two issues whose outcome may affect the results of next November's election -- the issues of income taxes and the Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- At a moment when grain and commodity prices were beginning to seek lower levels under pressure of classic economic consequences of inflation -- even in markets that are only partly free -- the President made a press conference statement that appeared to its critics to be both politically and economically vulnerable.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Rutgers beat Rhode Island State at its own furious game tonight, trouncing the Rams, 86 -- 71, before the largest crowd of the season. IN his first novel Mr. Verdier is concerned only with telling a story -- 490 jam-packed pages of it -- about one Paul Landreau and his struggle to become an artist. WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith said today he would not conduct a campaign against his fellow Republican Senator, Albert W. Hawkes, in the New Jersey primary this spring, even though he might vote against him.

The Society for the Prevention of World War III, Inc., has endorsed the basic principles of the European Recovery Program. NANKING, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- A drive to develop South China as a major industrial base for the Central Government has been launched here as part of the "self-help" plan recently announced by Premier Chang Chun.

The executive committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects has already expressed its concern regarding President Truman's disregard of the opinion of the Fine Arts Commission concerning the now-famous balcony projected for the south facade of the White House.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The frontier between France and Spain, officially closed for two years, will be reopened beginning Tuesday as the result of an agreement between the two governments, the French Foreign Ministry announced today.

WASHINGTON. THE evaluation of Henry Agard Wallace has been a continuing preoccupation of editorial writers and political Analysts for the last fifteen years. He has been variously assayed as a harmless mystic, an inspired prophet, a ruthlessly practical politician and a dangerous radical.

Blozis' mark was 56 feet 1/2 inch.

Gen. Wallace C. Philoon, USA (retired), general chairman, announced here today.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- A major realignment of German political parties is probable in the near future with both the Social Democrats and the Christian Democratic parties -- the two strongest today -- losing in the shuffle.

With one engine out, a gaping hole in the fuselage and a flight steward dead as the result of what was described as either a power-plant or propeller failure, a four-engine Eastern Air Lines plane carrying sixty-three passengers and a crew of six made a safe emergency landing near Bunnell, Fla., yesterday afternoon.

UNUSUAL annuals add a touch of adventure to seed orders that are being made out now. They help to satisfy the gardener's unceasing curiosity about plants, provide uncommon flowers for borders and bouquets, and sometimes turn out to be real "finds."

The seizure of $150,000 worth of heroin smuggled from Turkey, one of the largest hauls of recent months, and the arrest of two seamen for its possession were announced yesterday by Col. Garland H. Williams, district supervisor of the United States Bureau of Narcotics.

According to specialists in international finance, recent developments affecting the defaulted external debts of Italy and Peru threaten to infringe two basic principles long observed here and abroad by associations recognized as responsible for negotiating settlements of debt arrears in behalf of holders of defaulted bonds of foreign nations.

I WOULD like to take exception to Kurt Pinthus' weeping jag last week over the lack of "expressive acting" in the United States. In my opinion, the blame should not be piled onto actors, but rather onto playwrights who have failed to realize the monumental effect that motion pictures and television have had on audience taste.
THE question "What makes a picture good?" was posed at the dinner meeting last week of the Village House Camera Club, and the answers from a panel of ranking authorities ranged widely.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Gilbert Dodds was his usual invincible self tonight but he found the clock a more formidable foe this time. Aiming at his week-old world indoor mile record of 4:05.3, Galloping Gil had to settle for a Boston track record of 4:08.1.

WAHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Proposals aimed at changing fundamental principles of the European Recovery Program and reducing its cost were formally presented to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg today on behalf of twenty organized Senate Republicans.

An encouraging subscription has been received for the Valentine Ball in behalf of Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, whom will be held on Saturday night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will further the charitable work of Irvington House which provides care and treatment for underprivileged children suffering from cardiac ailments.

LONDON, Feb. 7. (Reuters) -- Labor member of Parliament Tom O'Brien, general secretary of the British National Association of Theatrical and Kine employes, said tonight in Nottingham, England, that unless American and British film interests and the British Government found some accommodation 100,000 British cinema and studio workers would find themselves out of work.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Stanley Benham piloted his four-man bobsled down Mt. Van Hoevenburg four times today in a total of 4 minutes 40.4 seconds, to capture the James Hopkins Memorial Trophy.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 7 -- Four Midwestern Governors, all Republicans, meeting here today, decided to form a Midwestern Governors Conference of twelve states.
" WE have Swiss cheese, Swiss chocolate and Swiss watches, but there is no such thing as Swiss music," said Ernest Ansermet, founder and conductor of the Orchestra de la Suisse Romande of Geneva.

WHEN wild geese beat northward, spring has come to West Texas. The boy Chapo, 13 now, is filled once more with longing to take the trail north on the cattle drive to Dodge City. Only one other desire is as strong.

THE growth of American musical activity to the awesome status of a billion-dollar industry has brought with it a mushroom crop of guides to symphonic music, opera and general music appreciation. Some of these have done more harm than good by convincing the eager amateur that his duty at a concert is to listen for subordinate themes, recapitulations, quintuple counterpoint and similar mumbo-jumbo.
ROCKY NEVINS needs big money to squelch a frame up, and fast. But arriving in Los Angeles one jump ahead of the San Francisco police, the only job he finds is as dishwasher in a beanery.

Nineteenth-century scientists thought that the influence of molecules in a surface extends to just about the distance that can be observed in a good microscope. This turns out to be correct, according to scientists at Stanford University, who have just announced that they have measured the depth of a liquid surface and found it to be about 1,000 atoms or about a millionth of an inch.

HERE is one of the few authentic classics of North American angling literature, happily available again and within everyone's reach. The first edition, limited in number and high in price, has long been a collector's item. The new volume lacks the magnificence of the original; but, with good design and pleasing drawings of its own, it is still a nice book to see.

A call to American Christians to "practice brotherhood now," by making church membership available to all persons regardless of race was issued yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, 297 Fourth Avenue. The council's appeal was released to coincide with the twenty-sixth annual observance today of Race Relations Sunday.

It is now more than two months since the U.N. General Assembly, by a vote of 33 to 13, decided to divide Palestine into separate Jewish and Arab states, and appointed a five-nation Palestine Commission to go to the Holy Land and carry out partition. In that period, Arab-Jewish fighting has grown daily more intense, and the chances of the U.N. Commission's carrying out its assignment have seemed to become daily more remote.

" PHOTOGRAPHY ON PARADE," first of what is planned as an annual series, opened last week for a month's run at the Museum of Science and Industry, in the R.C.A. Building. In addition to a display of cameras, lenses, lights and supplies, the exhibit features an amateur photographic contest for the best pictures taken at the museum.

THE classic hands of bridge occur the proper number of times when one considers the billions of bridge hands that are dealt annually; but to the individual they seem very rare of occurrence. If he has gone to some trouble to learn how to play such hands, he is likely to feel cheated when the opportunity never arises.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 7 (AP) -- George Kotlarek, Duluth, Minn., and Billy Olson, Eau Claire, Wis., topped jumpers in the first day's competition of the St. Paul Ski Club's international tournament today.

DISMAL as the world may be as a whole, the theatre becomes increasingly cheerful. Among its current pleasures is the robustious comic acting of Nancy Walker in "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'!" As Leonard Lyons pointed out the other day, she is the funniest lady buffoon since Fanny Brice crossed her eyes and looked grotesquely comic in songs and revue sketches on Broadway.

WHILE the domestic companies have made a handful of recordings of operas in recent months, a good many of their releases of the lyric commodity will continue to be disks fashioned abroad. This is not necessarily cause for concern to the customer, since some of these foreign recordings are outstanding; but it may be saddening to our interpreters.
OMAHA, Feb. 7 -- The world's most ambitious "air-conditioning" program will make further great strides this year in a strip of land running from North Texas to the Canadian border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Production of silver in the United States increased 49 per cent in 1947 and returned to the level of 1944, according to the Bureau of Mines. The total for last year was 34,181,335 ounces.

OFFICIAL inauguration last Sunday of a new political state called the "Federation of Malay" is expected to have philatelic repercussions. Units within the Federation are Johore, Kedah, Kelantan, Negri Sembilan, Pahang, Perak, Selangor, Trengganu, each of which at times has had its own stamps, and .. erlis, which has never had individual postal paper.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Headquarters of the World Federation of Trade Unions put a damper today on an early meeting of the seven-member executive committee by saying that only two members -- the American Congress of Industrial Organizations and the National Union of the Netherlands -- had approved the idea of a meeting this month.

NANKING, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- At Yingkow, Manchuria's largest port, several thousand Communists who thrust along the railway after taking Kowpangtze, ninety miles southwest of Mukden, have begun probing attacks against outposts

THE United States is well-populated with the average man who has some understanding of Hamlet, listens tolerantly to Beethoven, has an inkling of nuclear physics, but doesn't understand, doesn't like, in fact, doesn't even look at art.

LINCOLN UNIVERSITY, Pa., Feb. 7 -- The oldest institution of higher education for Negroes in the United States, which was established here as Ashmun Institute in 1854 but renamed "The Lincoln University" the morning following the assassination of the Great Emancipator, today asked for greater opportunities for the foreign youth of African descent who seek preparation for their roles as "leaders of an awakened people."

Navy Diesel oil gurgled into dry fuel tanks of frigid homes in Queens yesterday, the first deliveries to consumers of oil borrowed by the city from Naval reserve stocks to meet the current emergency. Navy oil will be distributed only in emergency cases through authorizations from the Mayor's Emergency Fuel Committee.

Many reservations have been made for the annual luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters, which will be held on Tuesday at Sherry's. Several young women, headed by Miss Jane F. Murray, are aiding members of the executive committee in the plans for the benefit.

IT would seem that the reputation of Edwin Arlington Robinson's poetry is about to begin another one of its extraordinary cycles of appraisal, appreciation and critical indifference. In circles where poetry is fashionably discussed his poems are seldom "talked about," yet in academic quarters the enduring values of his finer lyrics and his major poems, particularly "Captain Craig" and "The Man Who Died Twice," are gaining an almost unforced momentum.

Thirty-five hundred law-school applicants in sixty-three cities will take on Feb. 28 the first standard admission test for law schools, it was announced yesterday. The examination will be administered by the Educational Testing Service (the College Entrance Examination Board) in cooperation with fifteen of the nation's law schools.
Patrolmen Thomas Williams and Thomas Byron roused and rescued a crippled man, his wife and five small children early yesterday morning as fire swept the family's home in Princes Bay, S.I.

JUST eighteen years ago this week in this Review: A new philosophy of history, "A Cultural History of the Modern Age," by Egon FriedeU, opened the section. Mr. Friedell asserted that a theory of history could not be scientific: "All history is legend."

Except for activity in toys, china and glassware, the wholesale markets were quiet last week, according to a weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers. Buyers of beachwear were committing themselves with caution and resisting high prices, the report stated.

Professors Paul F. Clark and Conrad Elvehjem of the University of Wisconsin have found that diets lacking certain vitamins or other nutritional factors inhibit the course of poliomyelitis in mice. Whether this discovery can be applied to mankind in the practical prevention of polio or cancer is not known beyond the apparent corroborative evidence presented by actuarial tables.

Severe winter storms in the North Atlantic have marred the "farewell performance" of the old Swedish American liner Drottningholm, causing her to be forty-eight hours late in arriving here, after having long enjoyed the reputation of being a "transatlantic train."
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of the pre-war British Union of Fascists, announced today that his plans for a national organization of his followers would now take effect.

Fifteen hundred Puerto Ricans in New York will be interviewed in a study of Puerto Rican migration undertaken by Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research and sponsored by the Puerto Rican Government.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- Col. His Highness Shri Sewai Maharaj Sir Tej Singhji Bahadur, Maharajah of Alwar, is 36 years old. He became ruler of Alwar in 1937, He is married to a member of the ruling family of Jodhpur and has two sons and two daughters.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- Approximately 110 tons of looted gold ingots and coins now stored in the vaults of the Reichbank in Frankfort on the Main will be shipped by air in the next few weeks to the United States and Britain, it was learned today.

IS the labor-union movement suffering from hardening of the arteries? That is the question that is worrying many persons in and out of labor's ranks. Once a union leader, always a union leader, has become the rule in many of the nation's most powerful labor organizations.

Beset by freakish weather for the second consecutive crossing, the United States Lines flagship America arrived here yesterday. Her officers reported continuous storms, high seas and a tropical-type hurricane accompanied by a plummeting barometer that reached a low of 27.40.

Industrial production, which was curtailed sharply last week throughout the Eastern States because of an acute shortage of various fuels, is likely to be cut back further on a national scale within two months if the threatened strike of coal miners materializes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Mediation of the strike of National Airlines pilots was stalled today when the company withdrew its offer to submit the dispute to a five-man board. The company said that the Air Line Pilots Association (AFL) did not accept the offer quickly enough.

Final installation of one of the largest cane sugar mills in existence, designed and built by the Farrel-Birmingham Company, Inc., Ansonia, Conn., has been completed in the plant of Ingenio de San Cristobal y Anexas, S.A., at Carlos A. Carillo, a town eighty kilometers from Alvarado, Vera Cruz, Mexico, officials revealed here yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Finishing first in eight of thirteen events, Army defeated Harvard and Princeton for the second successive year today in their triangular track and field meet in the field house.

THIS mystery, which introduces something called the Sultan's Harem series, features one William (spelled "Wm," for reasons known only to Mr. Austin) Sultan, sole remaining member of Sultan, Sultan Sultan, Counselors at Law.

A program half of old, half of new music was given by the All-Veterans Orchestra under its musicianly conductor, Sascha London, with the assistance of Grant Johannesen, pianist, at Town Hall last night. The evening's premiere was James Cohn's "Nocturne."
PEIPING, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Communists are actively besieging Suchiatun, a railway town seven miles south of Mukden, pro-Government Chinese press dispatches from Manchuria said today.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will conduct Beethoven's Ninth this season. He is preparing it for his final broadcast With the NBC Symphony on April 3. He will use Robert Shaw's Collegiate Chorale, and the broadcast will be fifteen minutes longer than usual.

NEARLY 1,700 doctors of medicine, philosophy or science and 3,800 scientifically trained associates were recruited and organized by the Committee on Medical Research after it had been created by an executive order of President Roosevelt in 1941 to meet the medical exigencies of national defense and of war.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission appealed directly to the United Kingdom today to "permit" the commission to begin arming and training Jewish and Arab militia in the Holy Land before the British pull out on May 15.

Another snowfall, but this time a light one, started at 6:30 o'clock last night and was scheduled to continue today, with a possible change to rain. In a special bulletin the Weather Bureau said that the fall might reach 2 to 3 inches, but that the higher amount was only a possibility.

THIS collection of eight books, each containing ninety-six pages and of vest pocket size, presents a considerable amount of informative and interesting material on ten of the all-time favorites in ballet repertoire. Printed and published in England, six of the volumes are given over to a single ballet each, while the two remaining volumes deal with two ballet works each.

MAX LIEBERMAN, who died in 1934 after achieving a considerable European reputation as perhaps the most celebrated German impressionist, is being given his first representative American exhibition at French Co. Gallery.

RADIO has had no better news in many a day than the practical beginning last week of the era of frequency modulation broadcasting. Though a proved art for a decade, FM in recent years has had to battle a succession of handicaps and delays, the most serious of late being the ban of the American Federation of Musicians on the full use of instrumentalists.

JOSE RUFINO BARRIOS is Guatemala's most distinguished choice for immortality as a martyr for Central American unity. He was a soldier, a patriot and a statesman. Born in 1835, he embarked early on that turbulent rebellion of spirit which in a Latin is the first step toward revolution.

MODERN gardens, as well as history, romance and poetry, are replete with red roses. With full acknowledgment of the wonderful colors and combinations produced by modern hybridizers, some sort of Gallup poll would probably find many other gardeners agreeing with my preference for this color.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- Arguments and snow failed to stop the Americans today as they pulled into second place in the winter Olympic Games with a championship in the four-man bobsled race.

MR. GORMAN'S novel of Mexico's ill-fated revolution of 1810 is a highly readable fusion of historical fact and romantic fancy. Better than most examples of its genre, in writing and purpose, though not supromely distinguished, "The Cry of Dolores" contains the usual agitations of war and love and the usual quota of spectacle.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- British officials replied today to the latest Soviet campaign of discrediting the Western Allies' policies with a clear indication that trilateral action would be taken in the field of price control. Heretofore the cooperation of the four occupation authorities in this field had provided one of the better examples of four-power cooperation.

BOTH Van Wyck Brooks and F.O. Matthiessen have written with enthusiasm about Horatio Greenough as a critic of art and a student of American life, and this volume makes generally available the essays that excited their admiration.

MORE important for the future of Europe than the question, "who shall control the Ruhr?" is the question "what will be the predominant attitudes and drives among the German people ten years from now?" If a large majority of Germans becomes convinced that the Hitler years were morally wrong, the long-range prospects for Europe will be vastly improved.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The rising tide of bold attacks on Allied policy in Germany reached a dramatic climax this week with an exhortation by the Rev. Martin Niemoeller to sabotage the United States zone's denazification law. While Pastor Niemoeller's pastoral letter said what many Americans have long thought about the "law for liberation," it was the first time a prominent German had called on his countrymen to adopt a policy of non-cooperation.

Showing no ill effects of a twenty-five day vacation City College's basketball team returned to action with a convincing 80 -- 46 victory over Montclair State Teachers College at the sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon.

THERE is a sharp and disconcerting line of cleavage in the Whitney's sculpture annual, between fundamentally representational work, which numerically makes up about half the show, and experimental pieces which make up the other half.

ST. MORITZ, Feb. 7 -- The Swiss Olympic Committee has every intention of awarding medals to members of the American Hockey Association team for taking part in the Olympic Games, it was learned tonight.

Bad weather slowed up activity at stores last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. However, the report stated, dress department trade was good, lingerie departments busy, infants' departments active, and millinery departments fairly good.

WITH the necessary research completed and with scripts actively under preparation, WOR-Mutual has scheduled its documentary series based on the report "To Secure These Rights" for four consecutive Tuesdays, Feb. 24 and March 2, 9 and 16.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Improved methods of disease prevention and treatment of the sick and wounded in the second World War saved more lives than the total lost through enemy action, Rear Admiral C.A. Swanson, Surgeon General of the United States Navy, declared in an address at the Harvard School of Public Health Forum today.

Revision of the Charter of the United Nations was debated yesterday at a meeting sponsored by United World Federalists at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York Both speakers favored an immediate attempt by the United States to reach a settlement of all issues with Russia.

Ernest Ansermet showed himself a superlative musician and conductor when he gave his fourth and last concert of the season yesterday afternoon with the NBC Symphony Orchestra in Radio City. The program consisted of the Mozart G minor Symphony, Debussy's "Gigues" and two parts of Stravinsky's "Petruchka" score.

In "By 'Flying Carpet' to Arabia's Oil N'ield"-Raymond Daniell says that 38 per cent of the Arabian-American Oil Company's net income goes to the United States Treasury in taxes. In an article in'THE TMES, published the day after Mr. DanieU's piece, I read that such foreign corporations pay no taxes to the 'United States.

PHILADELHIA, Feb. 7 -- The discovery in a green sand pit near Sewell, N.J., fifteen miles south of Philadelphia, of a partial skeleton of a dinosaur that lived more than 60,0000,000 years ago was announced today by Charles M.B. Cadwalader, president of the Academy of National Sciences.

Senator Albert W. Hawkes of New Jersey told members of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., last night at their annual dinner at the Commodore Hotel that he believed rent control regulations, expiring at the end of this month, would be passed again by Congress.
These are the questions which the nation has been largely concerned with since the end of the war, and which it asked, more insistently than ever, last week:

A RECENT visitor to our town was Billy Southworth, and baseball men all nod knowingly in his direction these days. "Watch out for Billy next Season," they say, "Watch out for the Braves. They'll be mighty tough to beat." The folks in Boston even are dreaming of a world series on a ten-cent fare because they're confident that the contending teams will be the Red Sox and the Braves.

IN bakeries that prepare fancy cakes for weddings and such occasions, the work of decorating usually is in the hands of a highly skilled specialist. Through years of apprenticeship, he has learned how to fashion intricate frosting designs with a few quick flourishes of a pastry tube.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Army and the Air Force have whisked thirty-two soldiers from Florida's sunshine and warmth to Alaska's winter to see what would happen if a "possible future war" should require such a sudden shift of climate.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Former Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin returned to the political arena tonight at a revival meeting of the old rightist party, Alliance Democratique.

THE essays contained in this slender volume commend themselves immediately for two qualities all too rare in discussions of contemporary social issues: genuine moral sensitivity and sustained, disciplined, logical effort.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The European Recovery Program is beginning to feel the tug and haul of domestic policies and Presidential politics.

DR. EVATT brings to his discussion of the United Nations the exact reasoning of a constitutional lawyer and judge, the acceptance of conflict and compromise of a politician, and the moral outlook of a man deeply concerned with social justice.

HAVANA, Feb. 7 -- Pessimism over the slow progress of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, which has now ended its tenth week, is decried in the weekly review issued today by the Department of Public Information of the conference.
THAT hard-hitting reporter, Garry Dean, is persuaded by a drunken friend to go to a wild studio party. He has been in the place only a few minutes when he finds a dead man and a bloody ice pick.

The Hunter College Elementary School, probably the only institution of its kind in the country, is to continue its experimental program in the field of education for another three years. Organized in 1940 under direction of the Board of Higher Education, the school admits superior children with a minimum Intelligence Quotient of 135.

A world federation of citizens supported by a federated police force to prevent wars was advocated yesterday by a majority of students who took part in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

Weather conditions rather than the commodities slump were the major factor affecting retail trade here last week. Department store volume was estimated as up 10 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, a slightly higher rate of increase than earlier in the year.

VIENNA, Feb. 7 -- The recent series of incidents between members of the United States and Soviet occupation forces in Austria culminated in a Tass dispatch today from Moscow. The report said that Col. Gen. L.V. Kurasov, Soviet commander, had protested to Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, United States commander, against attacks by United States soldiers against Russians and warned that if such incidents recurred Soviet soldiers would be forced to "defend themselves."
A BOY in the fifth grade said: "I like to listen to music. I like to sing in the auditorium, even if I'm a little bashful. I think if there was no music life would be awful dull."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Republicans in Congress differed today in interpreting the Government's action in the slumping grain markets.

THE final lecture in the midwinter garden course at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, will be "Framing the House With Trees and Shrubs" by R.P. Korbobo. It will be given this Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. and repeated at 8 P.M.

The teams of George Cummings and Tom Iannacelli and Tom Byrne and Ed Reid reached the final round of the open squash racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday. Each combination won two matches.

THIS is Mardi Gras week and through the South and throughout Latin America the carnival season will hit its peak. The biggest of them all, of course, is the New Orleans Mardi Gras, which will convert that city into temporary bedlam on Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Pennsylvania defeated Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet at Hutchinson Pool today, 54 -- 21, for its second victory in four starts. It was the Lions' third straight league setback.

Michael Rosenker, now in his fifth season as assistant concert-master of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, was the soloist with the orchestra at last night's concert in Carnegie Hall. With Charles Munch conducting, he played the Saint-Saens Concerto for Violin and Orchestra in B minor, No. 3.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- Doughty little Colchester, first non-league team to reach the Football Association cup round of sixteen in 37 years, was forced out of the competition today by a smooth Blackpool eleven, 5 -- 0.

AS we have mentioned once or twice before, Designer T.H. Robsjohn-Gibbings likes to create interior backgrounds which are predominantly neutral and spike them with one or two big splashes of clear, vivid color.

The president of each of the twenty-three voluntary hospitals in Brooklyn sent a telegram to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday appealing for more equitable payment for treatment of city patients as a means of preventing impairment or collapse of these hospitals.

A YEAR ago a new writer joined those whose pleasant and difficult occupation it is to write well about Mexico for readers in the United States. She bore the curiously bilingual name of Josephina Niggli, and in a book called "Mexican Village" she revealed a close knowledge of rural Mexico, a quick skill in presenting it.
An appeal was made yesterday to Americans to donate $250,000 so that a center can be equipped in Paris for seriously handicapped French veterans.

The Irish, after sixteen years, may have begun to tire of hearing de Valera called the Just. Tiring a little himself of his long rule as Erin's lawgiver, he must now look for tenure in office to the opposition he sought to override. The indications are that he will win it but with some loss of prestige and power, though the returns leave him well in the front of the picture.

WAKULLA SPRINGS, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The Governors of the South, meeting in extraordinary session, threw cold water today on proposals that they start a revolt against the Democratic party this fall and came up with unanimous approval of a plan for a forty-day "cooling-off" period.

IN case anyone should imagine that threat of the imminent extinction of the human race has diminished mankind's fascination for the sight of violence and death, let him skim through the "Great News Pictures" (Part of "U.S. Camera, 1948") which relate, with a clarity more shocking than words, some of the history of this planet during the year just passed.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The commander of British troops in Berlin declared war against Soviet-inspired rumors today. In a ten-paragraph memorandum, distributed to all British personnel, he warned all British subjects to be "alive to the fact that there is a great deal of anti-British or anti-Western propaganda" in Berlin.

The body of Hollis S. (Babe) Spotts, athletic director of Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn and general agent and superintendent of the St. John's Guild, was recovered from the East River at 11 A. M. yesterday.

Two bluebirds and a robin were seen last week, out in the nearby hills of Connecticut. Voices on the radio were talking about more snow and sleet and a new cold wave, but neither the bluebirds nor the robin seemed to hear. They settled down for a few minutes in an apple tree, twittered, fluffed their feathers, then flew off to inspect a snowbound hillside.

New frontiers in the human sciences still need to be explored if we are to safeguard the future of the American family, the Community Service Society declared in its centennial report, made public yesterday.

In 1934 Army engineers predicted that a St. Lawrence Seaway would carry a maximum annual tonnage of 27,000,000. The St. Lawrence Survey report arrived at the closely similar result of 25,000,000. Last year the National St. Lawrence Association raised these figures to 37,000,000.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Spain unblocked today the assets of twenty-two European and Far Eastern countries, frozen since the start of World War II. The move was an apparent effort to restore normal trade as soon as possible after the reopening of the French-Spanish frontier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Edwin W. Pauley, target of a recent Congressional inquiry into commodity market trading by Government employes, resigned today as Special Assistant to the Secretary of the Army, stating that his work was completed.
Otto Nathan's letter on the French franc, published in your edition of Feb. 1, deserves comment.

IN 1930, a physically small book of criticism was published in England; it was written by an extraordinarily young man (considering the contents), a disciple of I.A. Riehards, whose name was William Empson. The book turned out to be of an originality that instantly lifted its author from the category of beginner and gained for him a just reputation as one of the most independent and stimulating literary critics writing in English.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- A potentially dangerous over-emphasis on the technique of military operations in sub-zero temperatures and frigid zones has been revealed by "Exercise Snowdrop," the airborne training exercise that has just been concluded at this great military reservation.
VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- One of the biggest questions in Austria today, though one of the least discussed openly, is: What has become of the war prisoners in the Soviet Union who are not coming home?

The work of cleaning out useless city records to make efficient use of storage space and save money now spent for rent of private premises has already started, Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, director of the municipal reference library, declared yesterday.

In 1943 Dr. George N. Papanicolaou of Cornell University introduced the "smear" technique for the diagnosis of early cancer of the uterus in women. More recently the technique has been successfully used in diagnosing cancer of the lung, prostate, kidney, bladder, stomach and various body cavities.

Although bank credit will be tighter during 1948 than it has been recently, there is little evidence that there will be a greath)0*0*0*ishortage of investment funds during the year, according to the Bankers Trust Company.
ROME, Feb. 8 -- Pope Pius XII, calling the atomic bomb "the most terrible arm which the human mind has thus far conceived," urged today that the use of atomic energy for warlike purposes be outlawed.
ROME, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Pietro Nenni, leader of the pro-Communist Socialist party, said today that Italian Leftists would not revolt if they lose in the national elections April 18.
ASTORIA, Ore., Feb. 8 (AP) - The Coast Guard today saved six fishermen who were caught in a raging southwester that took the lives of five other seamen.

For a period of several months, it was learned yesterday, mystery stories on the shelves of the Montague Street Public Library in downtown Brooklyn lave been defaced systematically. All references in the stories to the Deity, expressions such as "Oh God," "Heavens" and "Lord help us," have been removed.
GREENWOOD, Ark., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Eight miners died in an explosion in the Sunshine Coal Mine near here this afternoon.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 8 -- On first returns tonight from the day's national election, the Presidential candidate of the Union Nacional, or Democratic party, Otilio Ulate, was leading in the Mesa Central, or Highlands region, and in this city.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market were under selling pressure most of last week, particularly those for the near-by months. Despite a recovery on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week at net losses of 29 to 86 points.

The decision of the Supreme Court in the case of Ada Lois Sipuel, a Negro woman who sought admission to the law school of the University of Oklahoma, may lead to one of the most realistic explorations of race relations that we have yet had in the long and troubled effort to solve the perplexities of what Gunnar Myrdal called "An American Dilemma."

TOKYO, Feb. 8 -- Buried on Pacific islands and in Japan and Korea are the bodies of 64,000 Americans who died for their country in World War II. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's command announced today that the first of these from the Far East would start home for eventual burial in the United States when the Army transport Walter Schwenk sails for San Francisco from Tanapag harbor, Saipan, on Feb. 26.h)0*0*0*iO

Seventy per cent of 9,289 landlord applications for eviction certificates disposed of by the City Rent Commission during the first four months that the Sharkey residential rent laws have been in operation have been denied, it became known here yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 8 -- Communist inspired sabotage and riots in protest against the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea have now continued for a second day throughout South Korea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Deferred deliveries of lard sold at new seasonal low prices last week on the Board of Trade. The liquidation that started in grains spread to that commodity and prices broke the daily limit of 2 cents a pound for two consecutive days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Attacks against adoption of Universal Military Training came from three quarters today.

Marooned all night on the ice in Gravesend Bay, Brooklyn, a small and bedraggled black-and-white dog resisted the combined rescue efforts of policemen, firemen, Coast Guardsmen, agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and three other men for six hours yesterday before it was finally brought safely to shore.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- From the beginning to the end of Jacques Fath's spectacular opening, excitement was sustained. Enormous pouffed faille bustles form a dramatic part of the story. Of navy or black, they are crushed underneath jacket peplums of plain wool or of print suits.

The brand of winter we have had this year will serve one useful purpose if it brings home to us the magnitude of the traffic congestion problem. As nothing else could, the buried cars, which, during the Big Snow, were estimated at 10,000, showed the increasingly perplexing problem of the private automobile in congested central urban areas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Official endorsement of the guaranteed wage -- as a buffer against depressions -- is expected this spring from the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Feb. 8 -- Elise Mestra Wolff, 43 years old, died of a heart attack this morning in the five-room frame house she shared with her sister, Edith Wolff, 51, since the death nine years ago of their father, a dry goods merchant.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Other editorials and articles in Izvestia and in Pravda, the official Communist party newspaper, said that the United States was restoring German militarism, that the Western Allies were forming a bloc of countries including Germany, that United States "imperialism" was trying to draw Finland into its web, and that the United States was negotiating to include Spain in the Marshall Plan.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (AP) -- J. Sigfrid Edstrom of Sweden, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today the fifth winter games had been a wonderful success."

A recent rift within the Presbyterian Church involving a protest by Negro ministers was disclosed yesterday. It centers on the failure of authorities to sanction joint visits with white ministers to the homes of white residents in Westchester County in the nation-wide drive to recruit former and new church members.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The United States finished third in the turbulent fifth winter Olympic Games which closed today with all the informality of a country church picnic.

A conviction that the ship transfer features of the European Recovery Program, or Marshall Plan, have been grossly overestimated, is spreading among private shipping operators and government authorities concerned with the aid program.

TANGIER, Morocco, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Spanish troops opened fire today on a Moorish nationalist procession in Tetuan, chief town of the Spanish zone of Morocco, killing and wounding an unknown number of people.

" An Evening of Two Plays," consisting of Lennox Robinson's "Church Street" and Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute," is the second presentation of New Stages. Beginning tonight, it will be offered at the new group's citadel, 159 Bleecker Street, for a minimum period of four weeks.

WAKULLA SPRINGS, Fla., Feb. 8 -- An unprecedented step in the educational annals of the country was taken today when the Governors of nine Southern states affixed their signatures to a compact that would establish a geographical district with cooperatively owned and operated regional schools to provide higher education for whites and Negroes.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 8 -- Two semi-military Moslem organizations were outlawed today by the Government of India in the pursuance of its campaign to eradicate communal hatreds after the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Abolition of stage censorship, which is controlled in Britain through the office of the Lord Chamberlain, was urged here today by the British Theatre Conference in itsh) 0*0*0*iclosing session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Episcopal Bishop of the New York Diocese, today described the Marshall Plan for European recovery as "an issue of supreme importance" that should have the support of Christians everywhere.

The Joint Conference of Allied Postal Employes of Greater New York and vicinity, representing 18,000 post office workers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, held a public rally yesterday afternoon in the Washington Irving High School Auditorium, Irving Place between Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets.

Representative Sundstrom of New Jersey offered a suggestion last week "for strengthening the European program" which commends itself chiefly for its well-meant but misdirected zeal. NEW DELHI, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, his Deputy, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, and Defense Minister Sardar Baldev Singh made another appeal for an end to communal killings at a mass meeting today.

Bruno Walter, musical adviser of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, will continue with the orchestra next year and will conduct more concerts than he is scheduled to direct this season, it was indicated last night at a dinner in honor of the world-famous 71-year-old conductor given by the Town Hall Club, 123 West Fortythird Street.

Tonight's events: "The Magic Flute." Metropolitan Opera Company, 8 o'clock; Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Reginald Stewart, conductor, Ferruccio Tagliavini, tenor, Carnegie Hall. 8:30; Leonard Pennario, piano. Town Hall, 8:30; Huddie Ledbetter (Lead Belly), folk songs, Times Hall, 8:30; Concert Forum, observance of National Negro History Week, Louise Parker, contralto; George Walker, piano; Birneresis Young, violin; Theresa Green, soprano; Paul Robeson, Fannie Hurst, Edward Smith-Green, Jerome Nathanson, speakers, Society forh)0*0*0*iEthical Culture, Two West Sixty fourth Street, 8:30.

Robert Brink, violinist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. For his chief offering the young artist had chosen Handel's Sonata in E major, Mozart's Concerto in G major, Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in minor and Hindemith's Sonata in E.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 8 -- Various influences stimulated buying of equities during the first half of last week on the Stock Exchange here. The recent devaluation of the French franc imparted great strength to international securities such as Royal Dutch, Unilever andh) 0*0*0*iPhilips Lamps.

Prejudice is one of the most sinister elements in the life of the world today and threatens to destroy the essential values of Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday. Prejudice divides us in religion as well as on political and national levels, he declared.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Warning that "France's security has never before been in such danger," PierreEtienne Flandin tonight resurrected his old right-of-center Alliance Democratique on a platform of combating Communist propaganda, and a return to free initiative and private enterprise as opposed to the present closely controlled economy.

The disturbance in the stock and commodity markets last week passed over without incident so far as the main body of the foreign exchanges was concerned. At least there was no comparable erratic swing of rates. Markets were quiet and values showed no great change over the preceding week.

Bounding to the fore after the first few minutes of play the New York Knickerbockers gained a firmer grasp on the Eastern Division lead by whipping the Boston Celtics, 80 to 68, in a Basketball Association of America contest at Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York Province of the Newman Club Federation held its twenty-ninth annual communion breakfast at the Commodore Hotel yesterday. Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary to Cardinal Spellman for education, addressed the 1,500 students.

Net sales of the Ward Baking Company for the fiftytwo weeks ended on Dec. 27, last, reached a new peak of $80,547,804, which was $10,019,675 more than the previous record volume of $70,528,129 in 1946, Faris R. Russell, chairman of the board, reported in the annual statement mailed yesterday to stockholders.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Canada won the Olympic hockey championship today by beating Switzerland, 3 -- 0, while the United States' Amateur Hockey Association outfit was losing to Czechoslovakia, 4 3.

PARIS, Feb. 8 The serious shortage of gasoline has arisen in France at an inconvenient moment. It has gravely affected road transportation from country to cities. Arrivals of food in Paris and other centers have diminished considerably in the last two weeks.
A new cold wave moved upon the city last night as police officials completed arrangements for delivery of the Navy-lent fuel oil today to homes in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Discordant factions on the French political scene staged rival demonstrations in France today, seeming to open the campaign for the unannounced elections that all sides expect this year.

Benjamin Mintz, president of Paole Agudas Israel, religious Jewish labor organization in Palestine, emphasized yesterday the precarious position of the Jewish people in Palestine and pleaded for the immediate lifting of the State Department's arms embargo.

A ten-page campaign guide to its new 1948 safety program is now being distributed to 10,000 advertising agencies, advertisers and media, the Advertising Council announced over the week-end. The program, prepared in cooperation with the National Safety Council, has high acceptability.

Ch. Apollo of San Joaquin, a dog that never had been shown outside his native California before, trotted off with the best of breed prize in the fifth and biggest annual specialty of the American Boxer Club at the Twelfth Regiment Armory last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- The nursing problem, particularly that phase concerning the shortage of registered practitioners, is probably the most serious consideration confronting American medicine, Dr. Thomas P. WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will embark tomorrow on his second major speaking tour through the West, traveling this time as an avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination. The trip will last eight days and take him into six states -- Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska and Colorado.

The seasons follow each other in their appointed rounds. Earth swings on its orbit around the sun. Twice a year the heavenly bodies wheel into ordained formation and the time of the solstice marks the great change. But within each of the major climatic periods there are infinite variations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -Signet Productions, Irving Cummings' independent company, which recently completed "Sign of the Ram" for distribution by Columbia, has acquired "The Pasadena Story," a screen comedy by Leo Rosten, from Michael Curtiz Productions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Debates here in the United Nations on atomic power, jet propulsion and other developments in a swiftly moving world are throwing China's brush-wielding calligraphers into a dither. YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Seventyeight-year-old Ederle Garbols, a junk collector, sulked in the local jail here today. He could not convince the health authorities and City Judge Albert L. Fiorillo thath) 0*0*0*ihe could withstand the wintry blasts in his old, dilapidated shack.

The Boy Scout movement was praised for developing leadership, high character and fellowship among individuals of various faiths, at church ceremonies and services yesterday marking Boy Scout Sunday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Black Hawks and the New York Rangers engaged in a 2-2 tie before 16,461 here tonight in a National Hockey League game unusual for the clean play. Only two penalties were called, both on the Hawks.

TENDE, France, Feb. 8 -- The French Government has confirmed that it looks with favor on a plan to promote extensive winter-resort facilities in the Brigue-Tende [Briga-Tenda] region. CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Much of the decline in wheat and oats on the grain markets last week, according to brokers, could be traced to sympathy with corn, the first of the major grains on the Board of Trade to break the permissible limit last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The slump in commodity prices, led by a drop of 60 cents a bushel in the price of wheat since Jan. 17, is being watched with concern by high Government officials. However, there apparently is among them the general belief that there will be a leveling off on lower ground.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- As St. Petersburg was once Russia's window on the West, Berlin is now the Western Powers' window on the East. It is the strange destiny of this spectral capital to be the farthest outpost in the East-West conflict. It is by all odds the most highly competitive place in the world.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT agreed to call a White House meeting of the Senate leaders of both parties for the evening of July 18, 1939. The city acted yesterday in an effort to head off a threatened shutdown of large wholesale bakeries of dark bread - rye and pumpernickel -- in a dispute between the Metropolitan Bakers Guild and three locals of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, AFL.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Grain markets scored a record decline in prices last week. May wheat dropped the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel for three straight days and at the low mark yesterday was 52 cents below the high of Tuesday. It was the most violent break in such a short period in the 100-year history of the Board of Trade.

Dodds, president of the university, reported today to the board of trustees.

Your editorial "A Big City's 'Real' Values" is an inspiring picture of New York City as it is. But back of it lies its historic traditions, which are even more inspiring -- for here were established some of the foundations of this nation -- freedom of religion, freedom of the press, the establishment of the United States Government, and other dramatic events that helped to build the American way of life.

Unbalanced management in both small and big business must be corrected during 1948 to prevent continued uneconomic practices, more than 500 business executives in the home roofing, supply and contracting field were told yesterday by Dr. Charles Reitell, partner in Stevenson, Jordan and Harrison, management engineers.
WEMBLEY, England, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Richard Miles of New York and the Thall sisters, Leah and Thelma, of Columbus, Ohio, advanced tonight in the world's table-tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The United Nations presented today its first economic survey of he world's less-developed countries and territories and reported that many governmental programs -- the Five-Year and Seven-Year Plans -- were "more impressive on paper than in reality."

NANKING, Feb. 9 -- Despite official disapproval of the Lunar New Year celebrations as an outmoded custom, China ushered in the "Year of the Rat" tonight with the age-old traditional fourishes. Firecrackers exploded, good-luck streamers were pasted on doorways, families gathered for an entire night of feasting and gambling, and debtors sought refuge from their creditor in out-of-the-way places.

The case for greater state aid to New York City will not be put to the joint legislative hearing by Mayor O'Dwyer. His decision to send William Reid, chairman of his Executive Committee on Administration, to speak for him gives assurance, however, that the city's arguments will be presented competently, quietly and with a minimum of political display.

Two policemen who shot it out with three bandits in a Manhattan liquor store hold-up last Friday night were commended yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall. At the same time the Mayor gave the city's certificate for "outstanding public service" to a cab driver who helped the police to capture an escaping bandit from a hold-up last Tuesday.

MADRID, Feb. 9 -- The scheduled reopening of the French frontier has strengthened the belief here that Spain is inevitably being received into the society of Western nations. Optimism for Spain's future appeared higher than at any other time in the last ten years.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Over Democratic objection that the bill did not go far enough, the Senate and the Assembly tonight adopted the Graves-Wilcox Bill suspending for one year the prohibition against the use of oleomargarine and other butter substitutes in instititions receiving public aid.

One match went through 129 points yesterday in the continuation of the Class C championship tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, at the New York Athletic Club. It was between Paul Hoffman of the home forces and R.M. Keefe of the Yale Club.

Dr. Nathan E. Van Stone, vice president and director of research for the Sherwin-Williams Company, went down on his hands and knees yesterday and scrubbed a board painted with Kem-Tone to show that the flat water-mix paint was washable.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Last week we departed from a 17-year custom by publishing THE NEW YORK TIMES Index as a twice-monthly. It had formerly appeared monthly. The speedier tempo of publication is a response to the increasing use of recent newspaper files for reference and study. The trend in this direction is not new.

A cold wave that drove the temperature down to 7.2 degrees at 7:55 A.M. yesterday in the city and to subzero levels in the suburbs may retain its icy grip on the metropolitan area for several days, a Weather Bureau spokesman said last night With bitter cold covering the nation from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic Coast, only slight moderations from day to day were predicted.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- King Ranch's Assault, arch rival of the mighty Armed, arrived today by train from Columbia, S.C., to prep for the $50,000 Widener Handicap at Hialeah race course Feb. 21.
Random notes.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Franco-British conversations, which will open here Feb. 17, to deal with African colonies, will be extended to include economic coordination and a possible agreement between the two Governments on a common African political policy, it is learned today.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Another British trade union tonight joined the growing list of those that had made known their intention of pressing demands for increased pay, notwithstanding the Government's announced policy of stabilizing wages.
Andrew F. McIntyre, general manager of the Long Island Rail Road, testified yesterday that the Long Island was different from any other railroad in the country.

Price advances of 8 to 12 per cent over spring levels were announced yesterday by the American Woolen Company on men's wear standard worsted suiting fabrics for next fall. Company officials said the fabrics will be sold on an allotment basis.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 9 -- Christianity will succeed where communism and capitalism have failed only when it is prepared to act on the thesis that inequities of wealth, opportunity, and privilege are incompatible with a Christian society, the Rev. Dr. Leland S. Albright of New York, assistant secretary of the International Missionary Council, declared here today.

Joe (Sandy) Saddler, East Side battler, defeated Joey Angelo of Providence in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The contest was dull and the crowd of 2,375 frequently, shouted for action.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Duquesne University basketball team rallied in the closing moments of the second half to down Seton Hall, 54 -- 51, tonight at the Gardens. It was an important game, each team having lost only once during the season.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- Nearly 70 per cent of the post-war reconditioning of British merchant vessels has now been completed, according to the Ministry of Transport, which has to return to their owners all ships in the same condition as when they were requisitioned for war service.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The effective end of the World Federation of Trade Unions has come.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Mississippi House of Representatives today urged Gov. Fielding L. Wright to call an early south-wide meeting of Democrats to force the national party to "respect and perpetuate the rights of the South."

More than 1,300 cases were disposed of last month in the Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx. This was announced yesterday by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, who said that the accelerated rate of dispositions had reduced the backlog of cases by two months.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Joe Louis, heavyweight champion, with a roll of fat around his midriff, was forced to step briskly by Leo Matricciani in a four-round exhibition tonight. There was no official decision, but the crowd of 3,520 which put up a gate of $14,125, evidently thought their Baltimore heavyweight at least held his own.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury investigation of charges that the Congress of Industrial Organizations violated the political section of the Taft- Hartley Act began here today with an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as the first witness.

WARSAW, Feb. 9 -- The Polish Government has demanded that the Catholic Church actively support the Government's program of reconstruction and "stabilization" as a prerequisite for resumption of church-state relations, Wladyslaw Wolski, Vice Minister of Public Administration, said today. M. Wolski has been the Government's representative in negotiations with the church.

Plans of the RKO Fifty-eighth Street Theatre to show on its screen last night the St. Nicholas Arena prize fights televised by the National Broadcasting Company were canceled yesterday at the insistence of the network. NBC raised the question of ownership rights to remote pick-ups by television.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 9 -- The Iraq Petroleum Company is moving its administrative staff from the pipeline terminus and refinery at Haifa, Palestine, to Beirut and Tripoli in Lebanon. Only a skeleton staff will remain at Haifa.
