PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell announced today the National Football League is ending its working agreement with the American League, a minor circuit affiliate. Bell's announcement said simply: "We were unable to arrive at a mutual understanding for the continuance of the agreement."

Four hundred fuel trucks drained 585,000 gallons of Navy oil yesterday from seven storage terminals and delivered it to homes throughout the city on emergency authorization from the police, as the cold spell continued.

Leonard Pennario, talented young pianist who appeared with the Philharmonic as an Army private in 1943 and made his Town Hall debut last season, played a return engagement at that hall last night. He is a pianist of unusually clean technique which often gave the impression of dryness, but which, once accepted, revealed the music with freshness and strength.
Striking cable workers adopted "filibuster" tactics yesterday to tie up for three hours the counter of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company in the basement concourse of the RCA Building.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- William H. Standley, retired admiral and former Ambassador to Russia, testified today that Communist influence prompted post-war demands for higher pay.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The decision to exclude Franco Spain from any European discussions on the European Recovery Program or Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal for a Western European union was reiterated firmly today by Hector McNeil, Minister of State, in the House of Commons.

The revised estimate of $59,225,100 that this city's public schools would receive in state aid, as announced by Governor Dewey's committee on education, was citicized yesterday as inadequate by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 -- Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its powerful affiliates, the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, made unqualified attacks today upon the third-party Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace.

Informed opinion seems generally to agree that last week's sharp break in the commodity markets (the sequel to which was witnessed yesterday in declining quotations for hogs and live stock) represented a readjustment of prices to changes in the statistical position and outlook for grain.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Finds of capital importance in the Gallo-Roman archeology of Paris are reported in a paper on excavations in the gardens of the Cluny Museum read to the Academy of Inscriptions by Paul Marie Duval, director of Gallo-Roman studies at l'Ecole des Hautes Etudes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, asserted tonight that the Government would not permit a coal strike.

A demand by Detroit Local 191 of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, that international officers sign the non-Communist affidavit as required under the Taft-Hartley Law or resign their offices was rejected yesterday by the executive board of the union at its semi-annual meeting at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate and House passed today similar bills to double the present authorization for a Government experimental program for synthetic fuel. This would make the authorization $60,000,000.

Ash Wednesday will be observed widely tomorrow in the New York area by evangelical as well as by ritualistic churches. Special prayers will be offered tomorrow, and on each of the thirty-nine other days of Lent, that a permanent peace eventually may be attaineed among nations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 12 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The percentage increase was the largest weekly gain thus far this year.

Maggie Teyte, English soprano will sing the role of Melisande in a revival of Debussy's "Pelleas and Melisande" to be presented this spring by the New York City Opera Company, it was announced yesterday by Laszlo Halasz, musical and artistic director of the company.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An improvement budget totaling $30,000,000 was authorized today by the board of directors of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

The stock market gave further evidence yesterday of an oversold condition but absence of demand kept price changes mixed. After selected gains in the oils, the list gave way to a slightly easier trend. Fractional changes predominated except in a few instances, and despite the fact that more individual increases appeared at the close the combined averages slipped 0.09 point.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Twelve yachts, headed by the defending champion Revonoc, 45-foot yawl owned by Harvey Conover of Larchmont, N.Y., were poised today for the start of the fourteenth annual 184-nautical-mile Miami-to-Nassau race tomorrow morning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Unless the medical profession takes steps to meet the need for more family doctors, the politicians who promise free medical care to everyone will find ready followers, Dr. Wingate M. Johnson of Winston-Salem, N.C., warned today.

It is "extremely dangerous" to tamper with the nation's bank credit mechanism, "particularly at this time," Joseph M. Dodge, president of the American Bankers Association, warned yesterday. Urging increased caution in credit matters by the banks themselves, instead of government-imposed regulations, he also warned bankers against repeating "mistakes" of the past when banks were "unable or unwilling" to extend credit in a depression period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Truman urged Congress today to extend promptly the rapidly expiring remaining controls on key raw materials deemed vital to the domestic economy and the carrying out of international obligations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Emergence of a hydro-electric power network covering New York, New England, Ontario and Quebec that in case of emergency could supply power from any part of the network to any other part was forecast today by a Canadian utility executive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Government today halted exports of heating oil from east coast ports. It also asked foreign countries whether already reduced petroleum quotas could not be cut further.

TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The three young veterans who have been under Chancery Court order to demolish their $15,000 dry cleaning establishment here because it violated an old deed restriction have met the deadline, which was set for today.
The Dowager Marchioness of Reading, in a presentation ceremony at the Hotel Pierre last night, received the 1948 National Achievement Award sponsored by Chi Omega.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (UP) -- United States Olympic officials dug deep into their pockets tonight to settle the mountainous bills left behind by their departed athletes, and back of their polite official smiles there was plenty of private grumbling.

Improved efficiency in the handling of ocean cargo offers the major hope for a competitive American merchant marine in the future, according to studies now being made by private maritime companies and by Government shipping authorities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Secretary of the Army Royall's visit to the Panama Canal this week is one more indication of the apprehension in Washington about the future of the interoceanic waterway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Increased freight traffic at higher tariff rates resulted in a net income of $480,000,000 for the country's class I railroads in 1947, compared with $293,000,000 in 1946, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, reported today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's statei raen asserted that th Ruiarl had approached the British in 1945 and insisted that the Soviet Union should be represented in a study of the captured documents. "

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- When Harold E. Stassen decided to enter the Presidential preference primaries in Ohio against Senator Taft, the Senator remarked that it was contrary to the "usual practice" among those who want to maintain party harmony. Some of his supporters have charged Mr. Stassen with violating the rules of politics as well as shattering the amenities.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Three officials of Local 600, United Automobile Workers, CIO, today signed non-Communist affidavits on the eve of union action against them. Two others refused to sign. Local 600 is composed of workers at the Ford Motor Company.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -- The American President Lines' new passenger ship, the 23,500-ton President Cleveland, returned today from its maiden voyage to the Orient, carrying 500 passengers.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Feb. 9 -- "Our industry should set as its goal a minimum average of one suit per man per year; this would double our volume and enable us to sell our goods for lower prices," said Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co. and member of the board of the National Clothing Manufacturers Association.

Improved comfort and riding qualities are emphasized in the 1948 Cadillac line of cars introduced yesterday by the Cadillac division, General Motors Corporation. There are eleven models in four series. Hydra-matic equipment is optional.

Leonard Bernstein, Eleazar de Carvalho and Robert Shaw have been invited to be guest conductors of the Boston Symphony Orchestra during the month-long Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., it was announced yesterday.

The real sufferers from the Nazi upheaval are still in Europe as a result of the policy of many countries, which permit immigration of skilled workers only, Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, declared yesterday.

THE Winter Olympics have ended without anyone drawing a knife and without anyone tossing a dornick at Avery Brundage's balding pate. Presumably the Games are to be considered a success but they caused enough friction, controversy and bad feeling to become memorable. Historians of the future always will cite the Battle of St. Moritz when they begin to recall all the unpleasant incidents of a show which is designed to create international brotherhood and good-will.

Although Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute" has a garish title, it is a sharp, scornful play about a lynching bee in the United States. When it was produced in Paris there was something of a scuffle about the tastelessness of the title and the propriety of the theme.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 9 -- Further measures aimed at restoring pre-war trade levels with sterling sources, announced here today by the Wartime Supplies and Currency Control Board, include a new dollar quota basis of c.i.f. value of goods instead of f.o.b. which is estimated unofficially to represent a reduction in actual goods of between 15 and 20 per cent.

A 5-year-old boy, whose parents left him in their apartment at 310 East Ninety-fourth Street with his sister, 4, and brother, 6, was bitten severely yesterday at 2:30 P.M., by the family's pet German shepherd dog, the police reported.

The Electric Power Board of Chattanooga, largest municipal customer of the Tennessee Valley Authority, reported yesterday that operations in 1947 resulted in net revenues of $3,047,722, an increase of $554,671 over 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Truman will make his first official visit to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands this month, winding up a five-day tour of these American possessions with a vacation of about ten days at Key West, Fla.

HAVANA, Feb. 9 -- The possibility of a break in the long deadlock at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment appeared tonight. At a meeting of the new Coordinating Committee appointed to seek a compromise, Ramon Beteta, of Mexico, withdrew his delegation's original demand for a completely unqualified right to use import quotas and other quantitative restrictions on trade without the prior approval of the proposed International Trade Organization.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The sharpest fall in prices of securities since last February's fuel crisis and industrial shutdown were recorded in the stock markets here today.

In a letter and memorandum addressed to Senator Vandenberg, Secretary Marshall has given what must be regarded as the authoritative Administration answer to widespread criticism of the continued dismantling of German plants and the shipment of some of these plants to Russia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark charged today that a group of motion picture companies restrained trade illegally by a "monoply" of the distribution and exhibition of films.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Noisily cheered by his supporters, Aneurin Bevan, Great Britain's pugnacious Minister of Health, issued a warning today against "organized sabotage of an Act of Parliament" by the country's doctors when the National Health Service Act comes into effect next July 5.
BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Gil Dodds, the nation's greatest mile runner, was hospitalized today with mumps and probably has run his last indoor race for the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The 1948 Democratic bid to the women voters will be straight-out New Deal, Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, made amply clear today.
PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Another bombshell is tossed into the couture world by Christian Dior. He shortens skirts to fourteen or fifteen inches from the floor, so that they barely cover the calf.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for an organization of owners of job printing shops said tonight that AFL printers in four major Chicago shops voted today not to set any more advertisements for newspapers because of a newspaper printers' strike here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The volume of loans granted by the nation's 15,000 banks increased $7,452,000,000 in 1947, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. They totaled $43,100,000,000 on Dec. 31.

The sabotage and disorders the last few days in South Korea are a preview of what could be expected if United States troops were to be withdrawn forthwith from that occupation zone, as Soviet Russia and the so-called People's Government of North Korea have been demanding. Were that done, Korea would almost certainly be plunged into civil war.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Formally proclaiming the existence of an Arab "attempt to alter by force" the United Nations plan for partitioning the Holy Land, the Palestine Commission will ask the Security Council in its special report this week to determine that "a threat to the peace" exists.
In no other field of endeavor is the restrictive character of the Soviet regime so evident as in literature and the arts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Truman urged Congress today to act soon to extend the Federal aid highway program so that badly needed road planning and construction in the states could go forward without interruption.

" Who started what rumor?" could very well have been the theme of yesterday's "seminar" as the basketball writers gathered for their weekly luncheon at Leone's. With the college rules controversy -- a hot issue in recent weeks -- apparently tabled until next month when the rules committee convenes, the professionals proceeded to take over the spotlight.

The dismissal from his post of Anton R. Zhebrak, internationally known Soviet geneticist, was merely the latest chapter in the prolonged Vavilov-Lysenko controversy, which already has led to the death of one world-famous Russian scientist in a Siberian concentration camp, it was learned here yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 11 points higher to 24 points lower, with the strength most pronounced in the near months.
A strong desire to be considered grown-up is the mainspring of teen-age conduct, but this does not mean that youngsters do not need and welcome a guiding hand.

New York is getting its share of visiting orchestras this week. Sunday night it was the Minneapolis Orchestra that played at Carnegie Hall; last night it was the Baltimore Symphony, and tonight it will be the Cleveland Orchestra. Perhaps it would be better to have them more widely spaced, but all are welcome.

Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, called yesterday for public support of the National Heart Week campaign. He urged all persons to get physical examinations regularly to reduce the number of deaths from heart disease, now the nation's leading killer.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 9 -- The AFL International Typographical Union went into Federal District Court today prepared to press a sweeping attack on the validity of injunction proceedings brought by the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, but a fight over four petitions to intervene delayed all other arguments until tomorrow.

Net income of the National Supply Company and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $8,591,807, equal to $5.47 each on 1,434,463 common shares, compared with $3,027,836, or $1.48 each on 1,154,928 shares, for 1946, A.E. Walker, president, reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Ike Williams, lightweight champion, snapped Livio Minelli's string of twelve straight victories in this country tonight, outpointing the Italian welterweight in a 10-round non-title bout before a crowd of 9,311 at the Arena.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Criticisms of and grievances against British newspapers as presented by the National Union of Journalists to the Royal Commission on the Press (an investigating board set up by Parliament) were published today.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Defense Ministry headquarters disclosed tonight detailed plans for the strewing of Mohandas K. Gandhi's ashes into the Ganges and Jumna rivers, sacred to the Hindu faith.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The United Nations Security Council will be asked tomorrow by India, with Pakistan concurring, to postpone consideration of the Kashmir question indefinitely, it was reliably reported here tonight.
ROME, Feb. 9 -- The manpower conference of the sixteen countries participating in the European Recovery Program concluded its work today after two weeks of morning and afternoon sessions.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg, former major league home run king, conferred with Cleveland Indians' officials tonight, and a Tribe spokesman said, "It's a fair assumption that Greenberg will sign a contract with the Indians as a player-coach."
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 -- There was plenty of talking it up after the main event at Hialeah Park today, for the longest-priced horse in the race was first and the favorite was an up-the-stretch last.
The second performance in the subscription season of the Ballet Society at the City Center last night was an all-Balanchine program, comprising one new work and revised versions of two older ones.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A further substantial rise in prices as well as a gain in volume during 1947 were reflected in manufacturers' sales of $169,000,000,000 last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. This figure exceeds the 1946 level by a third.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Lee B. Mailler, Assembly majority leader, announced tonight that a special legislative committee would be created to recodify the state's military law. Its recommendations will not be submitted for legislative action until next year.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Twenty-six commuters using the New York-bound 9:10 A.M. train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad from this city protested to the railroad today against being forced to ride in the baggage car.

Ambitious programs for increasing currently high notions sales by improved manufacturing methods, a greater amount of supplier-dealer information, more modern packaging and closer tying-in of merchandising with fashions and consumer needs were outlined yes terday in the first National Notion Clinic at the Hotel McAlpin.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 -- An injunction to restrain the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation from selling 1,500,000 shares of common stock was sought today in Wayne County Circuit Court in behalf of James F. Masterson, a Philadelphia attorney who owns 100 shares of Kaiser-Frazer stock.
The opening of a branch of the Urban League of Greater New York in the Bronx is assured, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, at 161st Street.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 10 -Premier Tetsu Katayama and his Cabinet -- fifth since Japan's surrender -- announced their formal resignation this morning at 11:15. The informal decision to resign was reached yesterday and communicated to Gen. Douglas MacArthur last night.
Gray iron foundries are the first of America's billion dollar industries to suggest a formula for evaluation of "normal output" during the next ten years.

ALL three of the writing Sitwells, Edith and her brothers Osbert and Sacheverell, delight in a precious and filigreed prose as artificial as a lace valentine and as formal as the gardens at Versailles. But Sacheverell Sitwell in his newest book, "The Hunters and the Hunted,"* has gone about as far as he can go. Rarely since the heyday of Edgar Saltus has there been such an orgy of purple language.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 9 -- Charges of electoral frauds were made today by the Union Nacional, or Democratic party, after incomplete returns had given their Presidential candidate an inconclusive lead.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said today that passage of a bill barring Communists from teaching in public and private schools would be "welcome news to the rulers of Soviet Russia."

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, strongly criticized sections of the report of the President's Commission on Higher Education, in an address last night at the ninety-fourth annual dinner of the Fordham Alumni Association at the Hotel Commodore.

George Estin of Boston, Mass., a director of the Alleghany Corporation submitted a plan yesterday to Robert R. Young, chairman, and the management of Alleghany, through which bank loans of the company would be paid off and the prior preferred stock, plus back dividends of $33 a share, would be retired.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 -- Authorities in Tel Aviv reported today the discovery of arms in a Synagogue that was searched after an armed post had been found in an adjacent building. Four Sten submachine guns with eleven magazines were found hidden along with four grenades beneath the rostrum, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell at competitive bidding $45,000,000 of debentures that will mature in 1973.
Whether employes with only one employe may sign union-shop agreements under the Taft-Hartley Law will be tested in negotiations covering midtown loft buildings in this city, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- A de facto partitioning of Germany over disagreement on currency reform is a fifty-fifty possibility before the end of the month, and the issue may crystallize tomorrow. This is the reasoned view in informed circles here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The level of aircraft production necessary for security must be established before the end of this year, the President's Air Coordinating Committee said in a report transmitted today to Congress by Mr. Truman.

OMINOUS developments in northeastern Europe were drawing our anxious attention while Congress debated the neutrality bill. Russia was engaging in a wide movement to outline new strategic borders for herself along the Baltic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- "Dames Don't Cry," a photoplay by William Sackheim, went before the cameras today at Warner Brothers as the third of Saul Elkins' low budget productions under the studio's new policy of utilizing story properties in its library as vehicles for young players.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 9 -- Defense contentions that "the Balkan mentality" was an underlying reason for the behavior of former German generals now on trial here, especially for their having ordered the slaughter of great numbers of hostages, were attacked this morning by Prosecutor Theodore Fenstermacher of New York.

British military and civil awards to sixty-eight Americans for war service will be presented today by Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General. The ceremony will take place at 3:30 P.M. on British "soil" -- aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth at Pier 90, North River.

PARIS, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- The French Government announced measures to check the sharply upward trend of food prices, which is regarded here as a threat to the Cabinet and to the whole range of the Governments' stabilization plan.

Plans to raise $450,000 in the next three years to study one of the least known and most insidious nervous diseases were announced last night by the recently formed National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
Grain prices on the Chicago market turned upward yesterday for the first time since the tumble that started last Wednesday, but livestock prices hit the toboggan.

The ranks of dissatisfied Dodgers underwent one important reduction yesterday. Ralph Branca, the club's pitching ace, signed a contract at an unspecified increase in pay. President Branch Rickey declined to divulge the terms, but a source close to the ball club's executive indicated the hurler accepted $14,000, doubling the $7,000 he is reported to have received last season.

A prize of $1,000 was won yesterday by Jacques Berlinski, French composer, for his orchestral work "Kenaan" in a contest for music "reflective of the spirit of the Jewish people." A prize of $500 was awarded to Jacob Avshalomoff, music instructor at Columbia University for his chamber work "Evocations."

Directors of the North American Company declared yesterday a 25-cent dividend on the common stock and a partial liquidating dividend of three shares of Potomac Electric Power Company for each 100 shares of North American common held, both payable on April 1.

Seven large wholesale bakers in rye and pumpernickel bread locked out their employes yesterday. Their shutdown, coupled with the continuing strike against 200 specialty bakers, cut off about 70 per cent of the city's supply of dark bread, according to union estimates.

Analyzing the Bevin Plan for a United States of Europe from the viewpoint of an objective historian, it is quite clear that such a blueprint would not ameliorate the multiplicity of problems which confront Europe and the rest of the world today. Economically, a unified Europe would be highly desirable.

PRAGUE, Feb. 9 -- Marshal Tito, Premier of Yugoslavia, today accused the United States of encircling "peace-loving nations" in an effort to "enslave Europe," Tanjug, the official Yugoslav agency, reported.

The Presidential message to Congress urging implementation of the program suggested by the Civil Rights Commission ought to be made compulsory reading for every citizen of the United States. Since our entrance into World War II, we have inherited the world's moral, economic and political leadership.

Irving Haim, whose license to operate a $12,000,000-a-year wholesale liquor business is at stake in a hearing before the State Liquor Authority, denied yesterday he ever had been a business associate of Frank Costello, slot machine king.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 9 -- Henry J. Haskell, editor of The Kansas City Star, marked his fiftieth anniversary with the newspaper last night, receiving the congratulations of 100 Missouri and Kansas friends who attended a dinner in his honor, as well as messages from national leaders in many fields.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The Soviet Union today accused the United States and Great Britain of trying to keep the Latin-American republics in a "semi-colonial" status through financial and economic pressures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The White House moved quickly today to scotch a report, attributed to a "highly placed Senate source," that President Truman was considering modification of his civil rights program to appease rebellious Southern Democrats.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 9 -- The Communist-led "strike" in protest against the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea went into its third day, with a death toll estimated at forty-seven in South Korea.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A new heart operation that offers hope to thousands of rheumatic fever victims and other persons whose diseases have clogged valves inside their hearts was performed successfully here ten days ago by Dr. Horace G. Smithy, assistant professor of surgery at the Medical College of South Carolina.

Chicago Transit Authority's issue of $105,000,000 of tax-exempt term and serial revenue bonds was marketed last year by means of 7,931 separate sales, with about $83,148,000 placed at retail and $22,281,000 with dealers, according to a study released by Harris Hall Co., First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc., the underwriting managers.
IOWA CITY, Ia., Feb. 9 (AP) -- University of Iowa athletic director Paul Brechler announced this afternoon that Lawrence (Pops) Harrison would remain as Iowa's head basketball coach.

Having twitted the gentlemen of Japan, the British Navy, the aristocracy and the rest of the butts of Gilbertian satire, those superbly versatile troupers of the D'Oyly Carte Company got around last night to "Patience," that sprightly lampoon of the aesthetic cult.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Mississippi Supreme Court today quashed an indictment of a Negro sentenced to die for raping a white woman. It held his constitutional rights had been violated when Negroes were excluded from the grand and petit juries.

As president of China Aid Council, a member agency of United Service to China, I was very much interested in your editorials of Jan. 12 and 19 discussing the association of American Overseas Aid with the United Nations Appeal for Children. China Aid Council is the principal agency of United Service to China working on behalf of Chinese children, and its program is therefore included in the American Overseas Aid Appeal.

A spring collection for the "tall girl," who Peg Newton considers is 5 foot 7 and taller, was shown yesterday at a luncheon at the St. Regis. Miss Newton's basic principles of design appeared to be a strong belief in a firm though never overly padded shoulder in a rounded, up-tilted collar, with suits and dresses usually buttoned right to the neckline.

Warnings that "over-zealous" extension of credit will greatly increase the dangers of inflation were coupled yesterday with recommendations for increased development of wise credit and a forecast of record-breaking volume for the credit business in sessions at the Credit and Collection Conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Big guns of the stakes campaign go back into action this week with the tenth running of the $50,000 San Antonio Handicap -- virtually a preview of the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 28.

WASHTNGTON, Feb. 9 -- National officers of the American Association of University Women today called upon the association's branches in more than a thousand communities to give all possible support to the European Recovery Program as embodied in the Eaton bill.

Ireland's well-known stage company, the Dublin Gate Theatre, will be introduced to United States audiences tonight at the Mansfield Theatre in the first Irish comedy of a repertory of four. The unit, here under the combined auspices of Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers in association with Brian Doherty, will offer as its initial bill Bernard Shaw's only play about his native land, "John Bull's Other Island."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A Congressional investigation of the break in grain prices, based on Republican accusations that "insiders" had made money on the falling market, was begun today.

Competitive skiing along with recreational activity, will continue in high gear over the holiday weekend with the thirty-seventh annual Dartmouth winter carnival, oldest intercollegiate event in the world, highlighting the program. On Friday and Saturday, at least nine colleges will seek the honors that the Big Green carried off a year ago.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Harry Reoux, chairman of the Assembly Judiciary Committee, denounced as inadequate tonight the increase in state aid for schools recommended by Governor Dewey's committee on a state educational program.

THE General Public Utilities Corporation reported yesterday that net income last year rose $1,812,447 to $15,439,907. Share earnings for 1947 amounted to $2 each on the 7,698,001 shares outstanding, compared with $1.79 a share on the 7,628,322 shares outstanding at Dec. 31, 1946.

One of the latest devices designed to provide a supplementary heating unit for young housewives who have to prepare meals on perhaps no more than a single-burner hot plate is the electric casserole made by the General Electric Company.

More Americans are planning to go abroad this year than in 1947, according to "American Foreign Travel Trends," a new analysis of foreign travel prospects just published by THE NEW YORK TIMES. As before the war, most Americans will travel abroad for pleasure, the report says: 61.6 per cent of those responding to the questionnaire gave this as their reason for visits to Alaska, Canada, Hawaii, Mexico, as well as inter-continental journeys.

CORBIN, Ky., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Angelo Iudicanni, superintendent of a strip coal mine near here, today reported a group of about 300 unidentified men, several of them armed, forced him to sign a union contract.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A Swiss financial delegation is expected to leave for Washington shortly to discuss the disclosure of Swiss non-certified blocked assets in the United States, a spokesman of the Swiss Political Department said today.

The threat of a strike that would upset the transportation habits of 500,000 New Yorkers was removed last night through the efforts of Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Division of Labor Relations.

" Upon the outbreak or during the progress of war between or among two or more foreign states, the President shall proclaim such fact, and it shall thereafter be unlawful to export arms, ammunition or implements of war from any place in the United States to any port of such belligerent states, or to any neutral port for transshipment to, or for the use of, a belligerent country."
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Five hired hands of baseball took a chance on oil lands some time ago. Today they're on their way into the money.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Orders of the Civil Aeronautics, Board concerning overseas and foreign operation by American citizens cannot be reviewed by the courts if approved by the President, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision, today.

After an illness of six weeks Burns Mantle, drama critic emeritus of The Daily News, died yesterday at his home in Forest Hills. It might almost be accurate to say that he withdrew. For he had been failing steadily ever since Christmas Day and no longer had much enthusiasm for living.

The American Society of Miniature Painters opened its forty-eighth annual exhibition yesterday at the gallery of Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue, with twenty-five members and non-members represented by more than forty miniatures.
The term "cold justice" had literal meaning yesterday in the Queens County General Courthouse in Jamaica where dry fuel tanks kept oil furnaces inactive.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Despite prospects for its best wheat crop since the war, a crop close to a good pro-war average, France still faces the need of importing wheat because the Government has found no politically safe way of forcing or persuading farmers into turning over all their crops to normal milling channels.

The South is ahead of the North in its rate of improvement regarding race equality, Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, general secretary of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, declared yesterday at the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women, 1819 Broadway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 9 -- Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, announced today the names of twenty-two Yale alumni selected to serve on the University Council recently organized "to develop plans for constant improvement of Yale's academic and administrative affairs."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 -- The new Anglo-Argentine trade pact, which will be initialed Thursday, was tied to the Marshall Plan in a last-minute compromise by President Juan Peron, it was learned last night.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- Pope Pius XII today told twenty-eight members of the overseas delegation of the United Jewish Appeal during a special audience that he was seriously concerned over the fate of Jewish children and anxious to spare no effort for their welfare.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- The Soviet Union, replying to publication of secret Russian-German diplomatic documents by the United States State Department, charged tonight that the United States, Great Britain and France had made World War II possible by financing Adolf Hitler's war industry and appeasing Germany.

Plans for a "pilot project" to provide 800 apartments in Queens for veterans under the state's limited dividend laws were announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman. State Housing Commissioner, in behalf of Governor Dewey.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 10 -- Appealing to Koreans not to be misled "by the latest Communist effort at sabotage and destruction in South Korea," Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander here, today issued a 1,500-word statement to the Korean press and radio.

"Killer McCoy," which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Mickey Rooney is starred in the prizefight drama, which was produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, with Brian Donlevy, Ann Blyth, Sam Levene, James Dunn and Tom Tully among the featured players.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Miss Gretchen Merrill of Boston, who finished eighth in the women's Olympic figure-skating competition, tonight said that she is withdrawing from the world championships which start tomorrow because "I'm over-trained and over-tired."
Samuel Yachter, the Brooklyn landlord whose tenants would not take his house even as a gift, lost a round in court yesterday, but he consoled himself that he had gained an uncle and two cousins.

With more than $9,000,000,000 in insurance, held by 8,500,000 policy-holders, Paul F. Clark, president of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, reported yesterday at the eighty-fifth annual stockholders meeting that insurance in force increased $728,814,038 during 1947.

ATHENS, Feb. 10 -- A British soldier was among four persons killed and two others were seriously wounded early this morning when mortar shells hurled at Salonika by rebel forces exploded in a guard room where the men were lodged.

An evening of musical satire of highest quality was presented by Anna Russell, singer, pianist, diseuse and mime, at Town Hall last night. Blending a devastating perception of concert singer's and pianist's mannerisms with well-timed wit and low buffoonery, she often had to pause for laughter from her large audience.
Wage increases of $3 to $7 a week were awarded yesterday to 45,000 workers engaged in the manufacture of women's coats and suits in 750 factories in the metropolitan area.

The voluntary allocation program for steel products now being drawn by the Government in cooperation with representatives of the industry reportedly is making very slow progress. Steel officials say it may be summer before any concrete plans materialize, if then.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,547, compared with 1,072 last week and 2,005 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 899 arrivals yesterday against 628 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An Air Force general was assigned today to the United States mission in Greece. He is Brig. Gen. William A. Matheny, now deputy commander and chief of staff of the Twelfth Air Force based at Riverside, Calif.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Britain challenged Russia today to join Britain, the United States and France in publishing without censorship all German Foreign Office documents on Adolf Hitler's dealings with both the Eastern and Western Allies. But Britain wants all four powers to agree to present their documents "as a historical and not a political record."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Ohio Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell at competitive bidding, $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1978.

Cancer research furnishes the theme of "Doctor Social," opening tonight at the Booth. Although credited, to Joseph L. Estry, the authorship has assumed the proportions of a minor mystery. Scouts tell us the play, first called "Unseen Scar," was originally written by Dr. Maxwell Maltz, a plastic surgeon, who occasionally takes a flier as an "angel."

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- A drastic economic shake-up in the Soviet zone, with greater authority for the Germans and rationalization of reparations from current production, is being considered by the Soviet military administration.
Establishment of a Federal post of Cabinet rank for the administration of an expanded Federal housing program was urged yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, Governor Dewey's Commissioner of Housing.

The tendency among many shooters today is to take quite an interest in the muzzle velocity of the various calibers and loads in which they are interested, but to ignore the velocity of the bullet at ranges of from 100 to 300 yards.

Restaurants, other business establishments and occupants of apartments on Madison Avenue between Fifty-eighth and Sixtieth Streets and on Fifty-ninth Street half a block east and west of Madison Avenue, were severely affected most of yesterday and last night with a shortage of gas for cooking and other purposes.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Minister of Fuel and Power, told the House of Commons today that the Labor Government's bill to nationalize the gas industry was an essential part of the plan to reconstruct and coordinate the country's fuel and power industries.

New York University's Reginald Pearman, who has won five out of seven races at 600, 880 and 1,000 yards this winter, will step up to the mile tonight in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate championships at the Twenty-Second Regiment Armory.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- A tense situation exists throughout Apulia, in the "heel" of Italy, and a general hungry strike has been declared in the Province of Foggia as a result of a shooting affray yesterday between Communists and members of the Common Man Front in the town of San Ferdinando di Puglia.

A little fellow with curly hair, a quiver slung over his shoulder, a small bow in his hand, wearing a pair of wings and a bright smile, projected himself into this department the other day and, after accepting the offer of an overcoat to ward off drafts, introduced himself as the advance man for the coming St. Valentine's Day extravaganza, which is playing a one-day stand next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A disciplinary purge of certain officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for refusing to "go along" with its policy in support of the Marshall Plan and opposition to a third party is in the offing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- The Indian delegation to the United Nations complained tonight that the six-week-old Kashmir debate was showing an unfavorable trend and asked for a month's delay in the Security Council hearings.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, proved today that he had not been exaggerating in describing Britain's economic situation as extremely grave. He published an emergency White Paper showing, among other things, that Britain's adverse balance of payments in 1947 was 675,000,000 (about $2,700,000,000).

Cleveland, Ohio, sold new issues of bonds totaling $6,250,000 yesterday to a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.3625 per cent. The bonds will come due from 1948 to 1973. The winning bid was 100.074 for 2 1/2s and 2 1/4s.
Named best of breed in the Afghan Hound Club of America's specialty show at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday was Champion Karan of Khanhasset, owned by Mrs. Leah P. McConaha of Great Neck, L. I.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Following is the text, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, of a statement issued yesterday by the Soviet Information Bureau as the first installment of a reply to publication by the United States State Department of Russian- German diplomatic documents:

New York University's new Law Center will be built on Washington Square South in the block bounded by Sullivan, West Third and Macdougal Streets. Announcement of the site was made last night by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, to 1,000 alumni of the Law School at their sixtieth annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Mile Champion Gil Dodds, hospitalized with mumps, tonight was reported running a high fever.

After two days of stormy hearings, the State Liquor Authority abruptly rested its case yesterday against Irving Haim, head of International Distributors, a $12,000,000-a-year wholesale liquor concern, whose license to stay in business expires Feb. 29.
HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- Students of the high school located across the street from Central Park rioted for several hours today, attacking street cars, blocking traffic and shouting against the Government.

I should like to be permitted to reply to the letter in THE TIMES recently in which Dr. John Bentley, an English physician, indicates the position of the British Medical Association toward the proposed National Health Service in his country.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today an exhibition of work by two brothers, Naum Gabo and Antoine Pevsner, who were pioneers in what has come to be known as constructivist sculpture. The earliest piece shown dates from 1913; the latest from 1947.

The Associated Radio Servicemen of New York, Inc., has utilized successfully the threat of legal action to force recalcitrant radio repairmen to satisfy legitimate customer complaints, Max Liebowitz, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Republican fiscal leaders eyed the continued commodity market slump today in the light of its possible effect on tax reduction plans.

Bruno Walter, musical adviser of the Philharmonic-Symphony, has accepted the post for another year, and is expected to open the season on Oct. 7. He will add to his conducting duties with a six-week Beethoven cycle in the second half of the season.

Although Mr. Shaw's "John Bull's Other Island" is a shrewd and witty play, it is long, it is verbose and a good deal of it is based on political situations that no longer exist. Although the Dublin Gate Theatre company is amiable, it is not brilliant enough to make so much talk continuously incandescent.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- The Security Council agreed today to put the problem of an international armed force for Palestine on its agenda "as soon as it is practicable."

TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson of Woodbury, moved forward tonight as the preferred choice of New Jersey Republican leaders to oppose Senator Albert W. Hawkes for the party's Senatorial nomination.

Orders being placed currently for new machinery for sand processing plants in typical companies average between $100,000 and $150,000 per company, and equipment buying for the whole industry will be up over 1947 purchases, A. Y. Gregory, president of the National Industrial Sand Association revealed here yesterday.

Mature singers do not generally improve as they grow older, but Helen Alexander showed last night that it can be done. For in her recital at Times Hall she was so much better than she used to be that it was almost hard to recognize her as the same soprano who first began giving concerts here seven years ago.

The renewed price decline yesterday in basic commodities, which included a drop of the permissible trading limit of 200 points or $10 a bale on raw cotton, increased the caution of textile buyers and apparel manufacturers.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- No British objection will be raised to Soviet publication of documents relating to Nazi Germany's relations with Britain and other Western powers, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. He was referring to the Soviet announcement yesterday that such documents would be published.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Off to a slow start and trailing for the first eight minutes, the Holy Cross Crusaders suddenly caught fire tonight and defeated the Temple Owls, 71 -- 44, for their ninth consecutive basketball victory.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- With the introduction of two bills in the State Legislature today, New York City sought to eliminate a loophole in the penal law which has made it possible for policy writers to escape punishment by recording bets on the walls of buildings.

John Hewlett, author of two novels that dealt with various aspects of Negro and white relations, has a third one on the Prentice-Hall fall list. The book is titled "Harlem Story" and deals with a Negro girl who "passes" as white in New York.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The public has an unbelievably large stake in a coordinated national effort to prevent deaths from diseases of the heart and blood vessels, Dr. Arlie R. Barnes, president of the American Heart Association and chairman of the board of directors of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., asserted here tonight.
The Moore-McCormack liner Uruguay became yesterday the forty-first unit of the American Merchant Marine to be accepted into the Naval Reserve in a ceremony aboard the vessel at Pier 32, North River.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- There are two Berlins -- on top the shaky seat of quadripartite government, creaking under all the strains and stresses of divided Europe -- and the submerged city in which Berliners, about three million of them, live an agitated or apathetic life.

A Federal court jury awarded $100,000 yesterday to Robert A. McAllister, 27-year-old marine engineer, of 584 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, in his negligence suit against the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, Inc., of 42 Broadway. He charged that he had contracted infantile paralysis while employed on one of the concern's ships as a result of the "carelessness, recklessness and negligence" of the company's employes and agents.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Four officials of interdenominational church groups, representing several faiths and more than 120 prominent clergymen, called today on Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, president of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, to urge immediate adoption by the council of a convention outlawing genocide, the extermination of peoples.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Air Vice Marshal D. C. T. Bennett said tonight that he had been dismissed as chief executive of the British South American Airways Corporation because of his public criticism of the direction of Britain's state-owned airlines.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Leveling-up purchases by jobbers short of stock on the last day of the account led to small recoveries in industrials and oils in the stock markets here today. But once the closing was finished most sections were quiet as buyers preferred to stay out in view of the forthcoming balance of payments statement by Sir Stafford Cripps, which is likely to disclose a serious position.

The sale of 900,000 new shares of Kaiser - Frazer Corporation common stock at a price that would have yielded the company $10,260,625 has been called off. Announcement of the termination of the financing was made yesterday by the underwriting managers, Otis Co. and First California Company, within twenty-four hours of the filing of a suit in the Detroit Circuit Court demanding that the stock sale be stopped.

VIENNA, Feb. 10 -- Mrs. Sinaida Kao, an Estonian woman recently saved by United States military policemen from forcible repatriation by the Russians here, declared inan interview today that she had refused to go because she feared she would be taken not to Estonia but for munitions work behind the Urals.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., today won the medal in the women's golf championship of Palm Beach, firing a 74 over the 6,000-yard course.

The administration of justice in Municipal Term Court, which last week vied unsuccessfully with the din of wailing babies and cranky youngsters, progressed more smoothly yesterday during a day-long session of heat-complaint proceedings because of a lollipop "bribe" distributed by assistant Corporation Counsel Bernice Rogers.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 -- The major victory by Indian Army troops in a battle at Naoshera last Friday has left public opinion here less amenable to a compromise in the dispute with Pakistan before the Security Council over the Kashmir case.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- British labor leaders have begun formulating plans for a closer association with American labor inu a joint effort to stimulate workers' support for the European Recovery Program, it was learned tonight.

A second reaction struck the stock market yesterday in the severest slump in more than eight months. Accompanied by a sharp increase in selling and a further crack in commodities, prices were reduced 1 to 4 points to within striking distance of the 1947 low set last May.

The home games of the Brooklyn Dodgers this season will be play on the air by WCBS-TV under the co-sponsorship of the Ford Motor Company and P. Lorrillard Co. for Old Golds cigarettes. It is reported that the baseball team will receive more than $300,000 for the television rights.
MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Buddy O'Connor, center of the New York Rangers, enjoys a comfortable 5 point margin in the National Hockey League's individual scoring race today.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The question of whether Hank Greenberg will don a Cleveland Indian uniform this year remained unanswered today as the former American League home-run king returned to New York.

Although deflationary forces are beginning to grow in strength, the inflationary trend continues, and "it remains to be seen which of these forces will prevail' during 1948, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, told the twenty-ninth midwinter conference of the American Bankers Association yesterday.

Daniel Rubin has been named sales and merchandising representative for the Northeastern area for Belvedere Hosiery Company, Charlotte, N. C., with headquarters at 47 West Thirty-fourth Street, New York.

Asbestos fiber shortages are the most serious problem of the asbestos cement products industry, Albert H. Fay, manager of the building product development department of Flintkote Company, building supply manufacturers, declared yesterday.

MANILA, Feb. 10 -- President Manuel A. Roxas today submitted to the Congress the national budget for the fiscal year 1949. In it, for the first time since the war, estimated expenditures are fully covered by the estimated normal revenues, amounting to 250,000,000 pesos ($125,000,000).

Dorem Display, miniature Schnauzer that won in his group at Westminster a year ago, gave evidence of being in shape for the big canine carnival that begins in the Garden today by capturing the specialty of the American Miniature Schnauzer Club at the Twelfth Regiment Armory yesterday.

Negotiations were completed yesterday for a ten-round bout between Marcel Cerdan, European middleweight champion, and Lavern Roach, Plainview, Tex., boxer, to be held in Madison Square Garden March 12. The contest will be the fourth in this country for Cerdan, who is expected here from Paris next week.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 -- The Indian Government moved in today on still another Princely State -- Bharatpur -- in the purge of communal activities following the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

Credit representatives were urged yesterday to work for more progressive methods and policies in order to cut operating costs and to ward off the possibility of permanent government controls. They received this advice, along with new statements that sound practices will assure a prosperous immediate future for their business, in addresses delivered at closing sessions of the Credit and Collection Conference in the Hotel New Yorker.

Proposals for ending the labor dispute that has cut off three-quarters of the city's production of unwrapped pumpernickel and rye bread were put before union and employer representatives last night by Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Labor Relations Division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall gave his unqualified endorsement today to a movement begun in Bethesda, Md., for a "Junior Marshall Plan" through which Cub Boy Scouts of America will "adopt" children in Western Europe by providing funds for their care.

Belatedly, our attention has been called to certain statements made in your editorial on Jan. 9, "Marshall States the Case," as follows: "The ERP is no rivers and harbors bill. It is a practical undertaking motivated by self-preservation."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Government drastically revised its rationing system today and introduced a three-level price system in an attempt to channel more farm produce into Government - controlled markets, the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug said tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Phillies today acquired baseball's current "bad boy" -- Eddie Miller.

While the last performance of Sonja Henie's ice carnival was occupying the main arena last night the depths of Madison Square Garden were taking on the aspects of a gigantic dog show, with row on row of benches in place, the barking of some of the 2,540 entries ringing hollowly through the wide confined spaces and the flanks of the basement lined by booths of commercial exhibits.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asked yesterday that the public support the Wiltwyck School for Boys at Esopus, N. Y., and called it one of the few places operated for the care and training of wayward boys between 8 and 12 years old.

After more than two weeks' consideration of the documents on the Stalin-Hitler alliance that lit the torch for the Second World War, the Soviet Government has now made its first reply. This reply, so far unsupported by documentary evidence, which it is promised will come later, is couched in familiar terms and follows a familiar line.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Columbia's "The Jolson Story" was "the most popular screen entertainment of 1947" and Ingrid Bergman and Bing Crosby were the most popular actress and actor of the year, according to a survey by Dr. George Gallup's Audience Research Institute, Photoplay Magazine, which engaged the services of the institute for the poll, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Veterans Administration plans to reduce its administrative personnel, now exceeding 90,000, by 8,500, Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator of Veterans Affairs, announced today. The reduction was ordered completed by June 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Five yachts of the eleven that started the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau race today had rounded Great Isaac Light by 10 P. M. (Eastern Standard Time), the Coast Guard was advised tonight.

The detailed plans to relieve traffic congestion in the garment district were announced last night by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, chairman of the Mayor's Traffic Committee. The schedule will become effective March 1.

The importance of a well-in-formed public opinion in a democracy was stressed yesterday by four members of THE NEW YORK TIMES 116th forum in a series on "What's on Your Mind?" The forum, broadcast from the Columbia University School of Journalism over station WQXR, considered the problem "What Makes Up Your Mind?"

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The first trains to cross the French-Spanish frontier for nearly two years passed shortly after noon today from Hendaye to Irun and in the opposite direction. Large crowds along both sides of the border witnessed the event.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 11 -- Joseph B. Keenan, American chief prosecutor, today asked the International Military Tribunal to impose the severest penalty known to law -- death -- on former Premier Hideki Tojo and the twenty-four other defendants charged with major war crimes, as a lesson to the world that "irresponsible militarism" must be eliminated from future history.
THE Russo-Finnish War went on amid the snows of the north, with Finnish heroism converting the Soviet's expected walkover into a desperate three-months' battle.

Bound for Brooklyn with 236,000 gallons of oil, the 500-ton motor-driven tanker Richmond was rocked by an engine-room explosion at 9:30 A. M. yesterday that caused injuries to two crew members. The ship, her fuel cargo intact, was towed to her destination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Department of the Army made public today the text of the final order to the troops by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, issued on the occasion of his retirement as Chief of Staff last Saturday.
HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- Further progress toward breaking the deadlock in the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment was made today.

I have read with interest in THE TIMES of Jan. 22 the news item headed "Soviet Birth Rate Twice That of U. S." in which the National Committee on Immigration Policy in one of their pamphlets. "Immigration and Population Policy," is reported to have warned that the growth of population in the United States is on the decline and that its economic effects are particularly to be feared.

The Communist party of the United States, in a statement of principles issued by its national committee, has decided that war between the United States and Russia is not inevitable, that the decision whether there is to be such a conflict rests with the peoples of the world, acting "democratically" with mass pressure for peace.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- A conference of all labor unions not dominated by Communists in fifteen of the sixteen nations that will benefit from the Marshall Plan will be called within a few days as the first step in a move to create a free federation of world trade unions.

Today's events: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 P. M.; Giuseppe Costa, tenor, and Julia Dinore, soprano, assisted by the Fine Arts Ensemble, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Wanda Landowska, harpsichord, Town Hall, 8:30; United Nations Festival, Eugene O'Neill Jr., narrator; Valerie Bettis, dancer, Central High School of Needle Trades, 8:30; Guilet String Quartet, Lexington Avenue, Y. M.-Y. W. H. A., 8:40; Marjorie Mitton, soprano, and Charlotte Smale, piano, Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, 8:15.

The building at 24-29 and 24-33 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, containing a theatre and two stores, has been sold by the Wiscon Realty Corporation, Molvinia Weissberg, treasurer, to the Idle House Theatre Properties, Inc., of which Sam Koenig is president.

A course in basic small-boat seamanship will be presented at Brooklyn College stating on Feb. 19, it was announced yesterday. Consisting of ten Thursday night sessions, the course will be free and open to men and women interested in boating.

Ample parking facilities and motor entrances on two levels are among the features of the two-story store of striking design that John Wanamaker will erect on part of a sixteen-acre tract west of the so-called Augustine Cut-off at Wilmington, Del., John E. Raasch, president of the store, announced yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 10 -- Thousands of uncounted ballots cast in Sunday's Presidential election were burned early today in a fire that destroyed part of a school and ruined the roof of the building.
One of the earlier motion-picture "palaces" along Broadway -- the Rivoli Theatre at 1614-20 Broadway through to 750 Seventh Avenue -- has passed into new ownership, it became konwn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Thirty Republican members of the House from seventeen states asked Secretary of State Marshall in a letter today to disclose what the United States was "prepared to do to help" enforce a partitioning of Palestine.

The American Red Cross announced here yesterday that the Red Cross Regional Blood Program at Rochester, N. Y., had been termed an "unqualified success" on the basis of the first monthly report made by Dr. Hubert E. Brown Jr., medical consultant of the Rochester Regional Blood Center, who is engaged in research in the department of medicine at the University of Rochester.

In less than three minutes yesterday three men with heavy automatic pistols stole more than $38,000 from a branch of the Bank of the Manhattan Company in Whitestone, Queens. They got away over icy, snow-mounded streets in a gray car.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Apparently alluding to the Soviet Union, Foreign Secretary Bevin said tonight that any country that expected to gain advantage out of the "little disagreements" between Britain and the Middle East countries was "going to be mistaken in the end."

An important member of the Communist party high command, who has directed Communist policy in this country's trade unions, was arrested here yesterday by the Department of Justice and held without bond on Ellis Island awaiting deportation proceedings.

In her third collection of original ready-to-wear costumes, one feels that Harriette Harra has come into her own. Her styles are handled with a deft and sure touch. While bowing to the present-day trends, she had found a way of expressing them in her own manner.

For the first time this winter, heavy fuel oil was distributed yesterday -- 228,925 gallons of it -- through the city's emergency pool to large apartment houses and some industrial plants certified by the police as distress cases.

Columbia University will increase tuition fees one-third -- the present rate of $15 a point is to rise to $20 -- and will raise room rents 17 per cent in men's dormitories and 7 per cent in women's quarters, it was announced yesterday. The tuition increase will begin next fall. The rental rise will take effect in the summer.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 10 -- H. W. Wilson, Philadelphia, president of the National Association of Refrigerated Warehouses, said today that the industry, through modernization and scientific research in both cooler and freezing operations, has helped make possible the huge increase in the nation's consumption of health-giving food.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10 -- Injunction proceedings against the AFL International Typographical Union were recessed today until Federal District Judge Luther M. Swygert rules on the union's motion to dismiss the case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach today argued for the "women's equal pay act of 1947" both on economic grounds and as "a matter of simple justice."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- A preliminary report of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe was received with muffled praise today by the Economic and Social Council, which established the commission last year.
Rescue craft were on their way last night to aid an American and a British freighter, both wallowing in the stormy North Atlantic.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 10 -- Probate Judge Rodney M. Love today appointed executors and appraisers of the estate of Orville Wright and said one of the first duties of the executors would be to bring back to the United States the plane first flown by the Wright Brothers at Kitty Hawk, N. C.

The "most comprehensive advertising, merchandising, sales promotion, research and public relations program" in the history of the paint industry will be undertaken this spring by a group of middle-size independent paint manufacturers, George W. Householder, president of the Duron Paint Association, Chicago, announced yesterday.

ONE of the risks inherent in the reading of literary biographies is the contagion of their authors' enthusiasm. Often such biographies inspire a sense of guilt for not having read all the wonderful writings of the subjects. The enthusiasm of M. P. Willcocks for the works of Henry Fielding as shown in his "A True-Born Englishman"* is a good example of this.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Samuel Goldwyn announced today that he has asked the officers of Samuel Goldwyn Productions, Inc., to take a 50 per cent salary cut as the beginning of a program "to put his economic house in order." The officers, he said, had agreed to the salary slash "for the good of the company."

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Speaker Oswald D. Heck today called a conference of Republican Assemblymen for next Tuesday in an attempt to subdue a threatened rebellion against Governor Dewey's program increasing state aid to education by $30,000,000 which many regard as inadequate.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Feb. 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted here tonight that government should be run so that every individual might have true liberty, equal justice under law, equality of opportunity, particularly in youth, and a standard of living which would make happiness possible.

The housewife who plans to stock up on canned fish for the Lenten period will find that while stores have larger supplies of some varieties than they have had in recent years, prices are at the same level as they were when these items were scarce.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- Study of the full text of United States plans to help European governments to get control of hidden dollar assets of their nationals brought unusually sharp protests in Switzerland today.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, Democratic minority leader in the State Assembly, used a state-owned automobile on a recent vacation to Florida, but the only expense to the state was the wear and tear on the vehicle.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- George L. Hinman, Binghamton attorney, was nominated by the Senate and Assembly today as a member of the State Board of Regents to replace Thomas J. Mangan, who died recently.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 10 -- Protestanism can no longeer afford the "selfish luxury" of denominational sectarianism at a time when Christian civilization is in peril Wilbur La Roe Jr., Washington lawyer and Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, said here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Nyasaland, African territory under British protection, will be the setting for a "pilot project" in education by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in collaboration with the Nyasaland Government and British authorities.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 10 -- Arabs attacked and occupied today a large part of the Montefiore (Yemin Moshe) Jewish quarter in the heart of Jerusalem in the course of a five-hour battle before British troops forced them to retire.

The New York Knickerbockers and the Providence Steamrollers come to the parting of the ways in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America with their game in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

Contemporary design with an old-fashioned look and documentary prints that look as if they might have been designed yesterday distinguish the latest collection offered by Greeff Fabrics, Inc., 49 East Fifty-third Street. Three groups are presented: Greeff decorator fabrics, Mallinson fabrics and Greeff hand-screened wallpapers, the first offered by the concern.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- The filly with the uncomplimentary name of Silly Gyp led every step of the way today to win the best of Hialeah Park's races -- a $4,000 purse at six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Airport developments costing $1,048,500,000 are needed in the United States in the next three years to meet anticipated requirements, the Civil Aeronautics Administration said today.

Purple and mauve tones came to the fore in a new group of floral wallpapers shown yesterday by the designer studio of A. K. Bartholomew, 124 East Thirtieth Street. In many instances, the wallpapers, as well as new slipcover fabrics, cotton rugs and printed plastics by the same artists, have been put to actual use in a studio-home.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Grain and lard markets broke the daily limits on American grain exchanges again today, with the close at the bottom. Wheat and rye were off 10 cents; corn and soy beans, 8 cents and oats 6 cents a bushel, while lard was down 2 cents a pound.

Aggregate dollar expenditures for advertising, rising with expected sales increases, will be greater this year than in 1947, but will be absorbed by higher advertising costs, forcing most companies to hold to present schedules and some to cut back slightly, according to a monthly survey of business practices released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Dr. Robert L. Levy, Professor of Clinical Medicine, College of Physicians and Surgeons, was elected president of the New York Heart Association yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization's board of directors at the Guaranty Trust Company, 522 Fifth Avenue.
Joseph Vissarinovich Stalin, the cobbler's son from Gori, is 68. This is the most important political fact in the Soviet Union.

Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of the board of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., who died on Feb. 2 at his winter home in Boca Grande, Fla., willed $9,535,000 for charitable and educational purposes, including $5,000,000 to Harvard College, it was made known yesterday.

The first attempt in history to break a strike of commercial airline pilots will be made today by National Airlines, with nonunion pilots replacing members of Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, the line announced yesterday.

Symphonic orchestras from other American cities which have visited New York within a week have a certain instances apprised our public of the relatively small distance, in point of excellence, which now exists between the greatest orchestras of the East and those from other centers than New York or Boston or Philadelphia.

The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously upheld a decision by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan that World War II veterans seeking "disabled veterans' preference" in civil service must in the future have a rating of not less than 10 per cent disability by the Veterans Administration.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- At a meeting of the majority of the Cabinet, sitting as the Economic Council under the chairmanship of Premier Robert Schuman, the fear was expressed today that French industries might be paralyzed in April, May and June if further dollar credits for imports were not forthcoming.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, hitting back in a dispute over falling farm prices, accused Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, today of contributing to a "further upset" in the market.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The results of a confidential survey made by the Automobile Club of New York among 1,734 automobile owners in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens shows that garage rents have increased on an average of 64 per cent over rents of March 1, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Government waited nineteen days to respond to the publication by this Government of the Nazi-Soviet documents that told the story of the Hitler-Stalin alliance, which enabled Hitler to start. World War II and was shattered by his attack on Russia.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- As usual, Madame Gres' collection is one of beautiful clothes designed by a great fashion artist.

Price cutting in meats, flour, butter and sugar developed fairly generally in the nation's grocery stores yesterday as a reaction to the continued slump in prices on the basic farm commodities markets. While many stores took part in the movement, according to dispatches to The Associated Press from various parts of the country, others waited to see how the situation would develop.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, with 41 per cent of its business and 50 per cent of its securities in the United States, last year broke all records with new business of $380,659,514. The total in force on Dec. 31 was $3,837,724,159, according to the seventy-seventh annual report issued yesterday.

One way of insuring a relatively quick return on proposed loans under the Marshall Plan would be the earmarking of a certain percentage of the funds for the rebuilding of the tourist industry throughout Europe, J. W. Boreel, managing director of the Netherlands Tourist Office, The Hague, said yesterday.

Those of us who are fortunate enough not to have become involved in court cases at one time or another may not appreciate the bewilderment, even terror, that possesses hapless individ uals who suddenly find themselves enmeshed with the law. When such persons have no financial resources to employ lawyers' services their plight is even worse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Housing Expediter Tithe E. Woods reported to President Truman today that the "weakening" of rent control last year was responsible for widespread illegal rent increases and an abnormal increase in evictions.

Henry A. Wallace, third-party candidate for President, last night appealed over the radio for the election of Leo Isacson to Congress from the Twenty-fourth Bronx District. Mr. Isacson is the candidate of the American Labor party, which is scheduled to put Mr. Wallace's name on the Presidential ballot in this state in November.

Johnny Williams, Montgomery, Ala., gained a split decision over Buster Tyler, Newark, N. J., welterweight, in a eight-rounder featuring the Broadway Arena boxing show in Brooklyn last night. There were no knockdowns. Williams weighed 140, Tyler 143 3/4.

Fifteen women, who described themselves as housewives, picketed City Hall for half an hour at noon yesterday in protest against the Sharkey bill banning the serving of drinks to unescorted women in bars.

Heavy liquidation hit the grains and a broad list of farm commodities yesterday. Meanwhile, prices of securities on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 1 to 4 points in the severest slump in more than eight months.

Membership in the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association in 1947 was the largest in the organization's history, Louis M. Loeb, the president, said last night in his annual report. He called for large-scale expansion of physical plant and facilities.

Dr. Peter Marshall Murray, staff member of Sydenham Hospital, an interracially operated hospital in Harlem, said yesterday that four of the last five appointments to the staff of the institution went to Negroes, mainly because there are few other hospitals to which they can be assigned that will give them "the proper advancement to the medical staff."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to place the European Recovery Program in the hands of an administrator of cabinet rank, who would head a new independent agency and have broad discretionary powers to make grants or loans to participating countries.

The announcement by Representative Andresen of Minnesota that Congress is going to investigate the break in grain prices has a decidedly familiar ring. For it is an imperishable part of the American tradition that while the speculative markets may defy every rule of reason with impunity so long as they are going up, the moment they turn down, even for a few days, the public attitude changes completely.
