CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The legal battle between Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard and her brother, Fowler McCormick, board chairman of the International Harvester Company, over custody of Mrs. Hubbard's two adopted children ended today in a settlement arranged by Judge John A. Sbarbaro, before whom the case has been in progress for ten weeks.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- Organized emphasis on the cultural aspects of the Military Government's program, hitherto sadly lacking, was announced today with creation of a new education and cultural relations division, headed by Dr. Herman B. Wells. Dr. Wells, on leave from the presidency of the University of Indiana, has been special adviser on cultural affairs to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the Military Governor.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Over solid Democratic opposition, the Assembly today approved the Hammer-Barrett bill providing for creation of a Tenth Judicial District by dividing the existing Second District into two parts. Having already passed the Senate, the bill now goes to Governor Dewey for his approval.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- Plans for a food incentive scheme that would embrace virtually the entire population of the combined Anglo-American zones and largely widen that area's trade relations with the Scandanavian and Low countries are being drawn up by the Joint Export-Import Agency, it was learned today.

BACK in the old days, the general supposition was that no man was eligible to play polo unless he owned a string of ponies and had his name in the Social Register. But of recent years Tenth Avenue has muscled in on Park Avenue, so to speak, with red-blooded men of modest income mingling with the Blue Bloods both on the playing surface and in the grandstands.

Secretary of the Army Royall's visit to the Canal Zone to check its defenses calls attention anew to the diffusion of responsibility in Washington for overseas territories of the United States. There is a need, we believe, for a reappraisal of policy and a concentration of responsibility, perhaps in a new department with a head of Cabinet rank.

Results of the operations of Devoe Raynolds Co., Inc., paint manufacturers, for the fiscal year ended with last November were the most successful in its entire 193 years' history, Elliot S. Phillips, chairman and president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday.

Charley Conerly, Mississippi passer slated to sign with the New York Football Giants after finishing his college baseball career this year, could have collected $120,000 for four years of play with the Brooklyn Football Dodgers -- $40,000 of it as a bonus for signing.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- Arab leaders meeting here are considering the establishment of an Arab shadow government for Palestine in the Arab stronghold of Nablus, north of Jerusalem.

In one of the heaviest selling movements in many months cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange broke yesterday to losses of 142 to 200 points. The near months, March, May and July, finished at the 200-point decline, the limit of fluctuation permitted by the exchange rules.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 10 -- The Bulgarian Assistant Foreign Minister and Press Director, Vladimir Topencharov, asserted today that NEW YORK TIMES correspondent William H. Lawrence was a disseminator of "lies and false information'' and a defender of Bulgaria's former monarchy in his dispatches concerning the Fatherland Front Congress.

NANKING, Feb. 11 -- Dispatches from the front said tonight that the sound of artillery was reaching Mukden from a new battlefield on the south bank of the Hun River, just eight miles below Manchuria's leading city. The Communists have launched an attack in the area northeast of Sunkiatun, which guards the southern approach to Mukden.

Organization candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention have been selected in Manhattan except in the Twentieth Congressional District, it was announced yesterday. Because of a rule adopted by the Republican National Committee, all candidates are residents of the districts for which they have been named, thereby eliminating some of the prominent Republicans residing in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Robust male members of Parliament quailed and burly policemen got fidgety when four hundred middle-aged British spinsters invaded the Palace of Westminster today, bustling and chattering. His Majesty's Minister of National Insurance, James Griffiths, whom the ladies had come especially to see, suddenly became inaccessible.

Headlining the basketball battles along the Eastern seaboard tonight will be the clash between Columbia's undefeated team with Penn in an Ivy League contest at the Lions' gymnasium and the head-on meeting between St. John's and Fordham at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Returning from a tour of eight countries of Europe, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, acknowledged here today that he had found a fear of war on the Continent.

Dean Alfange, Liberal party candidate for Representative in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District, called upon all New York members of Congress yesterday to support a measure to continue rent control.
BERLIN, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A United States military court today convicted Dr. Werner Raabe, Berlin dentist, of having murdered a United States soldier. He was immediately sentenced to death.

Production of steel ingots and steel for castings during January by domestic companies set a new peace-time record of 7,463,112 net tons for that month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This tonnage compares with 7,213,246 tons in the same month of 1947 and with 7,592,603 tons in January, 1944, the record.

The Bond-a-Month Plan is making rapid strides, according to figures by the Savings Bond Division of the United States Treasury Department. At the first of the year 500,000 persons were signed up under the plan. Deductions averaged $63 a person, and monthly purchases totaled more than $31,000,000 or $375,000,000 yearly.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) -- J. K. Houssels' Bymeabond, a 8-year-old, took the featured seventh race at Santa Anita today by four lengths from Pleasure Fund, with Faucon third, over the mile and one-eighth. The first three finishers ran the entire route without changing positions. Bymeabond paid $13.29, $6.60 and $4.30. The winning time was 1:50 2/5.
New York will honor Booker T. Washington today, the anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
GREENSBURG, Pa., Feb. 11 ((AP)) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenburg was compared to Abraham Lincoln tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles Harbough of Cleveland, Ohio, today upset Miss Margaret Gunther of Memphis, Tenn., 1 up, in nineteen holes in the opening round of match play in the women's golf championship of Palm Beach.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party today accused Russia's three leading composers and the Soviet music world in general of creating and encouraging anti-democratic works.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 11 -- A Protestant strategy to cope with whatever decision the United States Supreme Court may reach regarding the constitutionality of teaching religion in public school buildings on a released-time basis, was outlined here today by the Rev. Dr. Erwin L. Shaver of Chicago, director of weekday religious education for the International Council of Religious Education.

Probable settlement of the labor dispute that has cut off three quarters of the city's normal supply of unwrapped rye and pumpernickel bread was predicted last night by Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Labor Relations Division.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- Russia charged tonight that Great Britain and France had connived with Adolf Hitler in hatching World War II by appeasing him, and that they had sought to get him to attack the Soviet Union. In the process, it was asserted, Britain and France betrayed Austria and Czechoslovakia.

News reports from Eastern Europe, Washington and London make it increasingly apparent that the Kremlin is engaged ever more actively in seeking to crush all political elements within its reach in the Eastern European countries that might conceivably crystallize into effective opposition to their ultimate complete Sovietization.

A consumers' cooperative organization has been formed here to acquire apartment buildings on a group ownership basis, with a view particularly of meeting the housing needs of many war veterans, it became known last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Rallying in the last half, the Cornell basketball team defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 68 -- 57, to avenge the 56-54 setback received on its home floor last Saturday.

IT was inevitable, of course, that Eddie Miller would be traded by the Cincinnati Reds. As soon as he performed that most acrobatic trick of opening his mouth and putting his foot in it, Eddie was finished as a member of the Red Stockings. Somehow or other, baseball clubs just don't seem to care for having hired hands criticize their managers, players and policies.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Governor Dewey called tonight for immediate adoption of universal military training as part of an "integrated program of national security.

Carl Braun, former Colgate athlete, led the Knickerbockers to a 86 -- 63 triumph over the Providence Steamrollers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night by setting a local individual scoring record.

An extra dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock, together with the regular quarterly of 15 cents were declared yesterter for payment on April 1 by the Dominion Textile Company, Ltd. This is the first extra distributed in several years.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Feb. 11 -- An ironic failure of fuel supply just as they had located a safe landing place after blind circling through snow and clouds brought two pilots of the Howard Hughes Aircraft Company down in a crash landing here this afternoon after a flight from Miami.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 11 -- A state-wide meeting of 100 Negro leaders endorsed with cheers today a resolution commending President Truman for the ten-point civil rights program to outlaw lynching and Jim Crow practices which he submitted to Congress on Feb. 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A policy of fighting the foes of democracy from the right and the left by stripping the "nightshirts" from all groups in the "marketplace of thought" was advocated today by Morris Ernst, New York lawyer and author.

A three-point drive to help home owners obtain maximum efficiency in their use of fuel oil is being started immediately by more than 1,000 salesmen of eighty distributors of oil burners in eastern states, M. L. Judd, sales manager of the Delco Appliance Division of General Motors Corporation revealed yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Identical bills to outlaw racial and religious discrimination in educational institutions at every level were introduced today by Senators Arthur Wachtel, Democrat, and Paul Fino, Republican, both of the Bronx, and Assemblymen Eugene F. Bannigan, Democrat, of Brooklyn, and Samuel Roman, Republican, of Manhattan.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 11 -- The three most powerful South Korean Rightist leaders last night reached an agreement on "the necessity for holding separate elections in South Korea if Soviet cooperation is unobtainable."

Proctor Electric Company will terminate all automatic iron allocations on Feb. 15, Robert M. Oliver, vice president, disclosed in an interview yesterday. He said the company does not expect to terminate its automatic toaster allocations this year.
Baron Guy de Rothschild, senior partner of the House of Rothschild in Paris, declared here yesterday that a major depression for the United States in the near future was "out of the question."

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Opening guns were fired here today in a secession movement organized by residents of the northeastern tip of New Rochelle who would like to have their $3,000,000 worth of rolling lands and modern homes annexed to adjacent Scarsdale.

The youngest and most picturesque fragment of the old British Empire to establish Dominion status within the Commonwealth of Nations, Ceylon now embarks on a career of her own under auspicious circumstances. This 25,000 square reties of tropical isle is only a "jewel on the brow of India," but it is a valuable one.

Tacit support of pending legislation in Albany to place all child offenders under 15 years of age within the absolute jurisdiction of the Juvenile Courts was announced yesterday by the National Probation and Parole Association, with offices at 1790 Broadway.

Prof. Albert Einstein was unanimously designated yesterday as One World Award Winner for 1948. The award committee's decision was announced by Jacques F. Ferrand, executive secretary, at a reception in honor of Sir Norman Angell in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The United States Government revealed today it had protested sharply to the Soviet Government against the arrest of two United States Army officers by Russian soldiers on Hungarian territory and their "abduction" to Vienna, Jan. 14.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb 11 -- West Virginia eked out a 38-37 victory over Navy today but not before the underdog Middies gave the Mountaineers the scare of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Truman does not plan to take any new statement on the Palestine situation, the White House said today, and later Secretary of State Marshall stated that there had been no change in American policy with respect to Palestine.

Giuseppe Costa, Italian lyric tenor, who has appeared extensively abroad in important opera houses and on the radio, was heard for the first time in New York last night at Carnegie Hall. He was issisted by Julia Dinore and Laura Millard, sopranos, Gilda Pasqualoni, contralto, and the Fine Arts Ensemble.

Gasoline stocks in the United States rose 2,112,000 barrels last week to 105,100,000 barrels, compared with 102,988,000 a week earlier and 99,759,000 on Feb. 8, 1947, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Carl F. Johnson has been appointed director of sales for Dynamic Electronics-New York, Inc., distributors in the Metropolitan Area for Hotelevision, Inc. He formerly was manager of the Belmont-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Drastic revision of the European Recovery Program to require cash payment for all goods obtained here except "essentials of life" distributed free among their people by participating countries was urged today by Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 4:

I am appalled that THE NEW YORK TIMES should have printed the biased, confused and irresponsible story on the Costa Rican elections which appeared on Feb. 8. Notwithstanding the outcome of the elections, there is bound to be a good deal of controversy before the new President is inaugurated in May, and the present serious crisis warrants a more thoughtful analysis.
The American Jewish Congress yesterday criticized proposed regulations that would place new restrictions on the movement of foreign visitors to the United States.

AT 10:50 o'clock on the night of May 9, 1940, the telephone rang in my apartment, and the excited voice of Ambassador Cudahy in Brussels informed me that heavy German air forces were over Luxembourg and flying into Belgium and were reported over the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A couple of buckaroos from the Northwest rode up to the White House today and, parked their steeds and their packhorse where limousines usually stop. The visit brought out the farm boy in President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Truman and other high officials of the Government, as well as many members of the diplomatic corps, attended a memorial service for Mohandas K. Gandhi this afternoon in which the Indian leader was extolled as an apostle of peace and non-violence.

The Rev. George B. Ford of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church, 531 West 121st Street, was nominated yesterday for president of the Willkie Memorial Building of Freedom House, to succeed Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, declined today to comment on whether the problem confronting the country at present is inflation or deflation. He did announce, however, that a new security loan campaign, designed to "promote savings and fight inflation" would begin on April 15 and continue through June 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and the CIO itself were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of violating the Taft-Hartley act's ban against unions making "a contribution or expenditure in connection with" any Federal election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Pope Pius XII today asked the 3,000,000 children attending Catholic parochial schools to pray and sacrifice during Lent to help the children of war-torn countries. In this way, he added the children can best follow the example of Jesus -- "His one great lesson of love."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Eleven types of destructive competition were cited yesterday as practices to be avoided by small business managements. They were compiled from a management survey which included more than 102 case studies, and were presented during the third management clinic session of the convention of the Northeastern Roofing, Siding and Insulating Contractors Association, Inc., at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

Safeway Stores, Inc., reported yesterday that its 153 stores in the metropolitan area might be closed Saturday as a result of a strike threat against the company's decision to operate some stores until 9 P. M. on Fridays.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A policeman was killed and several persons wounded tonight in post-election demonstrations by members of the Government Republicano Nacional party, apparent loser in last Sunday's balloting.

The ninety-day validity period for export licenses to Europe under the new policies of the Office of International Trade is "impractical and insufficient" for automotive items, members of the Overseas Automotive Club said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the organization in the Hotel Woodstock.

By putting together some medical facts and some old customs and habits of the theatre, Joseph L. Estry has come up with a play about cancer, "Doctor Social," acted at the Booth last evening. Although the basic medical fact is printed in the program, your theatre correspondent is not qualified to express an opinion about it.

ATHENS, Feb. 11 -- An official report from Salonika today stated that the Greek air force and contingents of the Army scouring the area north and east of Salonika had killed fifty-eight rebels and captured twenty-two.

Marking the 109th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, the National Republican Club will hold its traditional Lincoln dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tonight. Senator Homer Ferguson and Joseph W. Martin. Speaker of the House of Representatives, will speak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- If the temptation to save face had not often proved too strong for the best of men in public life, it would be incomprehensible how State Department officials could say and cause friendly newspaper men to write that the Senate committee's administrative plan for the European Recovery Program is pretty much what the department wanted from the first.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 11 -- The laboratories and the library where Thomas Alva Edison worked from 1887 until he died in 1931 were opened to the public today on the 101st anniversary of the birth of America's most famous scientist.
A radio program featuring interviews with two officials of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America immediately provoked a "substantial" protest yesterday morning.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Solution of the German problem and the problem of colonies and dominions are major obstacles to the customs union program of the Benelux [Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg] and other European nations, Alois de Louvencourt, French representative on Franco-Benelux Cooperation Council, declared at a press conference here today.

If they knew the facts and could speak freely the Russian people would repudiate the enmity toward the United States that the Soviet Government and the Communist party are building up in the Soviet Union.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 11 -- In his first official visit here since his recent election as president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, Clinton B. Snyder of Hoboken disclosed that three out of every five families in the state no wown their homes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- The Little Assembly will meet on Feb. 19, five days earlier than the previously scheduled date, to discuss the Korean question, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The State Senate passed by a wide margin today the bill sponsored by Senator Frederic E. Hammer, Queens Republican, to increase the annual pay of members of the State Legislature from $2,500 to $5,000.

DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- Outlining 1948 prospects for the Lincoln-Mercury division, of the Ford Motor Company, of which he is director. Benson Ford who is also company vice president, today predicted $440,000,000 gross business as the result of $150,000,000 expansion program.

With both mills and buyers marking time in appraisal of the raw cotton price situation, trading in cotton textiles yesterday continued of small proportions. Continued weakness in hides affected the firmness of leather quotations, while the woolen fabric trade noted the declines registered in markets for both wool tops and grease wool.

With ten passengers and mail, National Airlines flew the first flight yesterday by a scheduled airline with non-union pilots since the formation of the Airline Pilots Association. The union pilots and co-pilots went on strike last week.

The stock market refused yesterday to follow the plunging commodities and, while the stiffening was limited, there was sufficient buying to change the course of prices. Movements generally were narrow and, aside from the oils, no individual group monopolized attention.
H. De Witt Smith, vice president of the Newmont Mining Corporation, has been elected a director of the St. Joseph Lead Company, succeeding Edward V. Peters, resigned.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Calumet Farm cut loose with all three barrels of its main battery, in the $10,000 added Seminole Handicap at Hialeah Park today, and brought down first and third money.

The Washington Toll Bridge Authority, operating in the State of Washington, announced yesterday that it would receive on Feb. 24 bids on $14,000,000 of Tacoma Narrows Toll Bridge revenue bonds dated March 1, 1948, and due March 1, 1978.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active again yesterday and final prices were 33 points lower to 9 points higher than the day before.

As long as New York University has Irving Mondschein on its side, the Violets have little to fear from their local track rivals. Coach Emil Von Elling's twinkling all-around star contributed 20 points to N. Y. U.'s winning total of 73 3/5 in the sixth Metropolitan intercollegiate indoor championships yesterday.
Children of the city's four All-Day Neighborhood Schools got together yesterday for a special Negro History Week program given by boys and girls of Public School 194, 242 West 144th Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Edwin T. Maynard, a veteran grain speculator, put at only about $200,000 his profit in four days of selling short in the falling grain market. He said that he was aided by paying attention to the published statements of the Secretary of Agriculture.

Negotiations between the Red Cross and the five county medical societies will be resumed soon in an attempt to compromise differences over establishment of a city-wide blood bank, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer opened yesterday the 1948 fund-raising campaign of the Police Athletic League (PAL) with an appeal to the public to help raise the $1,000,000 to carry on the organization's program this year.

Interrelated and sensitive as they are, it is inconceivable that there could be a serious downward readjustment of prices in any one of the nation's organized speculative markets without the others feeling something, at least, of the passing backwash. Traders in the market where the readjustment is taking place, for example, often find it necessary to liquidate some part of their holdings in another market to rebuild depleted margins.

Representatives of Columbia University students called upon the university administration yesterday to reconsider its announced plans to raise tuition fees one-third and increase room rents 17 per cent.
Poets call Korea the land of morning calm. Politicos know it to be a land of conflicts, conflicts not only internal but international.

New formulas for by-passing the limitations on union security imposed by the Taft-Hartley Law have been devised by unions of New York department store and warehouse workers that have refused to file non-Communist affidavits.

As the long-drawn-out trial of the Japanese war criminals nears its end, Joseph B. Keenan, American chief prosecutor, has asked the International Military Tribunal to impose on former Premier Tojo and his twenty-four co-defendants "the sternest punishment known to law," which means death by hanging.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 11 -- The Bulgarian Government fined William H. Lawrence, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, 10,000 leva today and directed him to leave Bulgaria within twenty-four hours for failure to observe a law requiring the registration of foreigners by the militia.

The Security Council of the United Nations has agreed to put the question of an international armed force for Palestine on its agenda. The circumstances being what they are, we do not see how it could have failed to reach this decision. It is to be regretted only that the matter will be taken up "as soon as it is practicable."

The appointment of Sol Mishkin, former minor league player and manager, as head coach of the City College baseball team was announced yesterday by Prof. Frank S. Lloyd, chairman of the college's hygiene department. Mishkin succeeds Sam Winograd, who became faculty manager of athletics last June and who recently decided to devote all his time to the new position.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Sweden received the right through an agreement reached with the State Department today to limit sharply United States imports into that country to protect her dwindling dollar resources.

The Sculptors Guild will hold a tenth anniversary party on the evening of Feb. 20 in the Colonnades Room at Essex House, to raise funds for its annual spring outdoor. sculpture exhibition, which has been suspended since the beginning of the war.

It is peculiarly appropriate that ceremonies for the launching of the Booker T. Washington Birthplace Memorial Fund should fall on Lincoln's Birthday. Both in their degree, the Great Emancipator and the former slave, extended the frontiers of human freedom and each now occupies his own niche in the American Hall of Fame.

Lou Oshins, head football coach at Brooklyn College since the start of the sport at the Flatbush institution twenty-one years ago, has been relieved of his duties, it was announced yesterday. Oshins will continue his full-time physical education instructor's post.

A transatlantic airliner from Paris with eleven passengers aboard, its pilot hampered by an ice covered windshield, was "talked down" safely last night at La Guardia Field through the radar ground controlled approach system.

FRANKFURT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- German miners have accumulated large credits in United States dollars for the purchase of anything they want, including food, but they have been unable to buy what they want, despite the fact that they get many offers.

Contracts were signed yesterday whereby the Theatre Guild production of Bernard Shaw's comedy, "You Never Can Tell," will set up shop at the Martin Beck Theatre on Tuesday evening, March 16. Alfred Fischer, European producer-director, for many years associated with Max Reinhardt, will be associated with the Guild in the venture.

The report of E. R. Squibb Sons and wholly owned subsidiaries in the Western Hemisphere, issued yesterday, showed consolidated net earnings of $1,349,126 for the six months ended with last December. This is equal to 70 cents a share on 1,514,694 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with $3,010,610 or $1.79 a share for the final half of 1946.

MANILA, Feb. 11 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine delegate to the United Nations, gave the Philippine Congress his estimate of the probability of war today -- not within a few years. Later he told a gathering of leading Manila citizens that the United States was humanity's only bulwark against global destruction until the United Nations progressed to a true federated world government with armies to support its moral decisions.

Several hundred passengers on two northbound Third Avenue Elevated local trains were shaken at 6:47 P. M. yesterday at the Forty-second Street station when ice on the rails caused the second train to crash into the rear of the first which was at the platform.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Appointment of Marcel-Edmond Naegelen, Minister of Education, to succeed Yves Chataigneau as Governor of Algeria today left the French Cabinet with two vacancies and the possibility of a reorganization of the Ministries in the near future.

In an effort to determine the most satisfactory and at the same time most economical form of trout stocking in various types of streams, the New York Conservation Department has been carrying out a series of experiments on various streams.

The annual penitential season of Lent was opened yesterday at religious services attended by thousands of devout Christians here and in other cities. Prayers were said for peace. Ashes were blessed and imposed on the foreheads of Roman Catholics during the day.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The fifty-two-foot cutter, Ciclon, owned and skippered by Alfonso Gomez-Mena of the Miramar Yacht Club, Havana, today won the tenth Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.

Believing that nothing gives quite as much of a springtime lift to a wardrobe at this season as a shower of snowy polka dots or trim tailleurs in crisp checks, Russeks devoted an entire showing to these fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The complete text -- hitherto unpublished -- of notes written in his own hand by Abraham Lincoln, to guide his oral argument in the only case in which he ever appeared before the Supreme Court of the United States, is herewith reproduced from the original for publication on the 139th anniversary of Lincoln's birth.

A list of eighteen standards to improve films for children was presented yesterday by the United Parents Associations of New York City, Inc., at a meeting of members and representatives of the motion picture industry.

We wish people, this winter, would not have their pictures taken, for use in this or other newspapers, bathing amidst chunks of ice in Long Island Sound or other bodies of water. People who fall into the water while skating, or from boats while proceeding on lawful errands, may be understood, pitied, hauled out, thawed out and forgiven.

Of the composers under fire in the Soviet Union, the three best known in this country are Shostakovich, Prokofieff and Khatchaturian. Scarcely a week goes by in which they are not represented on concert or radio programs.

DAVIS PLATZ, Switzerland, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Performing in a driving snowstorm, Micheline Lannoy and Pierre Baughniet of Belgium scored their second triumph within a week today when they won the world pairs figure skating championship.
Competition among food merchants in cutting prices on advertised items intensified yesterday as liquidation continued on many of the farm commodities markets.

Since last Feb. 12 new information about Abraham Lincoln has been made available in the form of many thousands of items long held secret by his son, Robert Lincoln. It was Robert Lincoln's belief that the publication of these papers at an earlier date would have been unfair to living men, or perhaps to the first generation descended from leading figures of the Eighteen Sixties.

In a cash deal reported yesterday Frederick Brown purchased the five-story warehouse building occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 300-04 West 124th Street, near St. Nicholas Avenue, from the estate of James Rozell. Assessed at $78,000, the building is occupied on a month-to-month basis by the Park Storage Warehouse.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Charges that advertisers unduly influence newspapers are denied in a memorandum to the Royal Commission on the Press by the Advertising Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- All deliveries of grain dropped the permissible limits at one time on the Board of Trade today except September and December oats, but, with the exception of May corn, all staged a strong rally from the low marks, with wheat working up 10 3/4 cents a bushel and corn as much as 6 cents, from the bottom.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has informed the British Government that he intends to do everything he can to carry out the General Assembly's partition plan for Palestine.
Two men, two women and a husband-wife team will receive from the American Institute of Decorators awards for designs in home furnishings introduced to consumers in 1947, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Following Sir Stafford Cripps' disclosure of Britain's financial position yesterday, there was heavy selling when the stock markets opened today. However, by the close many losses had been wiped out as confidence returned.

A "purge" of Communist party trade union leaders as the result of a new party line was indicated yesterday in the second of the articles in The Daily Worker announcing the party's position in this country. The new line was laid down at a meeting of the national committee last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The State Department experts are studying the break in commodity markets to determine whether European aid funds can be cut as a result of lowered prices here.

GARY, Ind., Feb. 11 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, today delivered in this highly industrialized city and stronghold of organized labor a comprehensive defense of the Taft-Hartley act. He said it was in no need of any "immediate revision."
Covered from stem to stern with icicles, the Swedish American liner Drottningholm ended her westbound service for her owners at 10:10 A. M. yesterday when she arrived here from Goeteborg.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 11 -- With the game officially over and the score knotted at 52-all, Center Bernie Adams stepped to the foul line and sank a free throw to give Princeton a 53-52 Eastern League basketball victory over Yale before 2,800 spectators in the new Dillon Gym tonight.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday that it would cancel its air cargo agreement with Railway Express Agency on Mar. 1 to conform to a cargo-agency resolution adopted by the International Air Transport Association last October.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Rutgers' strong quintet downed a stubborn Army team at the Field House today, 40 to 37.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- Canada's vital concern in the European Recovery Program was strongly stressed by Graham F. Towers, Governor of the Bank of Canada, in his annual report presented to the Government today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Former football coach Ed McKeever of the University of San Francisco charged today in a "white letter" that members of his squad had received "substantial" sums of money and that they had played at as many as two or three other schools before coming here.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "To the Ends of the Earth," a topical drama, starring Dick Powell and Signe Hasso and produced by Sidney Buchman for Columbia. Jay Richard Kennedy, the associate producer, wrote the story and screen play, and Robert Stevenson directed.

Since weather is the determining factor in prices of fresh vegetables and fruit, the freezing temperatures in the South this winter have eliminated to a great extent the possibility of price declines on many of these products.

Mayor O'Dwyer has developed a "coronary heart condition" that should not interfere with his official duties, but urgently requires that he drop all outside activities, such as night engagements, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, the Mayor's personal physician, announced yesterday.

The nationwide campaign of American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children is now impending with a 60-million-dollar goal. Some critical comments have been published that only 35 per cent is allocated for direct aid to children, but the campaign prospectus adds that: "Of the remainder, it is estimated that 48 per cent will go into children programs of the member agencies."

Two best-selling novels attacking anti-Semitism have been barred from the library of De Witt Clinton High School, the Bronx, on the grounds that one allegedly contains immoral passages and that the other gives offense to the Roman Catholic Church.

Announcement of plans for the fifth annual nation-wide "Paintings of the Year," art competition, conducted by the Pepsi-Cola Company, embodies sweeping changes in the program of selection and an increase in the total amount of prizes and fellowships from $21,250 to $28,000.

Two hundred thousand barrels of heavy oil from the Navy and 300 extra railroad tank cars to keep household fuel flowing were assured yesterday for this city and up-state. The Navy bunker oil will be brought here from Norfolk, Va., in two tankers, the first due in New York Harbor next Thursday and the other about March 1.

One of the best tests of management in industry at present is its attitude toward research, Roland P. Soule, vice president of the American Machine and Foundry Company, stated yesterday. A speaker at the closing sessions of the midwinter trust conference of the American Bankers Association, in the Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Soule urged the trust men, in formulating their investment policies, to give increased attention to those companies with diversified markets and products.

A miniature schnauzer, a Boston terrier, a Pomeranian and a greyhound, all four candidates for best in show at the world famous canine classic a year ago, led the parade in the breed judging that opened the seventy-second annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The task of the United States mission to Greece is a "lot bigger than originally envisaged by Congress," and this country's representatives there should have a sufficient period of time to prove themselves, Paul Block Jr., newspaper publisher, said yesterday.

Grain futures prices slumped again yesterday as liquidation continued in the country's farm commodities markets. Buying reappeared, however, late in the trading sessions for the first time since Monday and lifted all oats and most wheat contracts above the day's lows.
Federal Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday ordered a hearing on the legality of the imprisonment of John Williamson, Communist party labor secretary arrested Tuesday for deportation proceedings.

A new kind of Passion Play, described as the most elaborate ever planned, will be presented by Austria in late spring or early summer in the Cathedral Square of Salzburg, it was announced yesterday by the Austrian State Tourist Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Young-Milmoe bill proposing an increase in state aid for education of $90,000,000 to $103,000,000 served as a rallying point for hundreds of educators and representatives of parent, labor and other organizations who converged upon the state capital today to plead at the annual executive budget hearing for additional funds for schools.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- The United Nations moved forward today toward establishing an economic commission in the Middle East that would accelerate economic activity and raise living standards in the seven Arabic nations and other surrounding countries.

A reduction of 40 cents per 100 pounds in the price of corn sugar was announced yesterday by Corn Products Sales Company. Prices for starch in bags and barrels were cut 40 cents per 100 pounds. The new schedule was occasioned by the break in corn prices, it was said.

" THE GESTURE,"* by John Cobb, might be considered a companion piece to "Command Decision," since it also is a novel about American airmen stationed in England during the war. And like "Command Decision" it gives a wonderfully realistic picture of life at an air base. Another similarity is in the planning for an extraordinarily perilous mission.

The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation will not take "lying down" the action of underwriters in terminating a contract to buy 900,000 new shares of the automobile manufacturing company's common stock at 11 1/2 a share, Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the board, and Joseph W. Frazer, president, said here yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 11 -- John P. H. Perry, vice president, Turner Construction Company, told the American Warehousemen's Association today that "If the law of supply and demand is any guide to the future of construction costs, there is little likelihood of any substantial or enduring decline in the cost of buildings."

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- Russian reparations demands will not be reduced but occupation costs will be cut, Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander, announced today. Other concessions announced by the Soviet Governor were:...

Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett officially opened WNYC-FM's new ten-kilowatt transmitter yesterday at ceremonies in the station's Municipal Building headquarters. At 4:15 P. M. he flipped the switch which restored the city's FM outlet to the air after an absence since Jan. 11.

Gene Hermanski, 26 - year - old muscle man from Newark, dropped into the Dodgers' office yesterday, affixed his neat signature to a 1948 contract and then voiced the hope and belief that the coming season would see him installed as a regular outfielder.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 -- Some of the ashes of Mohandas K. Gandhi will be deposited tomorrow by his son in the sacred confluence of Ganges and Jumma rivers at Allahabad. The solemn Hindu ceremony, which symbolizes the final emancipation of the soul after a period of homeless wandering following cremation, is expected to be witnessed by 1,500,000 persons who have gone to the holy city from all parts of India.

Shifts and cuts in some advertisers' budgets will result from a permanent drop in prices, but total volume will not be affected, since others, particularly food processors, can be expected to increase expenditures enough to offset reductions, it was learned yesterday from key advertising and business executives.
DALLAS, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Government is ready to step into building industry labor disputes for the first time.

The Dragoon Realty Corporation, headed by Jacob J. Siegel, obtained from the Prudential Insurance Company of America a fifteen-year mortgage loan of $1,450,000 at 4 per cent interest on the twenty-three-story store and office building at 1384-1390 Broadway, southeast corner of West Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Administration appealed to Congress today, in an atmosphere of great and rising political bitterness, for authority to put on strong regulatory controls to quiet the upset commodity markets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- The United Artists Distributing Company has disposed of its Mexican releasing division to Credito Cinematografico Mexico, the company disclosed in a letter to UA producers whose pictures will be affected by the switch.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 11 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, voted overwhelmingly today in favor of five moves directed against communistic influences in the American labor movement.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Trade union representatives whose followers form the backbone of the British Labor Government's support sharply questioned the Cabinet's income-stabilization policy at a two-hour meeting tonight with Prime Minister Attlee and four other Ministers.

LIVERPOOL, England, Feb. 11 -- The mounting claims for losses in post-war world trade has forced insurance companies in this port to launch a world-wide drive to cut down thefts, Oscar Prentiss' of the Sea Insurance Company and chairman of a special committee on the problem said today.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Discussions with the International Monetary Fund of the effects of the franc devaluation on other currencies was said here today to be one purpose of the mission to Washington of Pierre Mendes-France, French member of the Fund's Board of Governors.
Owners of country and suburban homes should improve the front part of their property annually, R. F. Korbobo, landscape architect, declared yesterday at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- For the first time in at least eighteen years a former justice of the Supreme Court argued a case in that court today. James F. Byrnes appeared as lawyer for Twentieth Century-Fox, one of five major film companies which the Federal Government wishes to divest of theatres throughout the nation.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 -- Twenty-five incidents of violence throughout Palestine during the past twenty-four hours took the lives of three Jews and one Arab. In addition, forty persons were injured, some seriously, in the same period ended 9 o'clock tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Marcel Rochas captures the charm of the new femininity in a collection minus a single tailored suit or slender skirt. The old-fashioned corset is here again, for his new guepieres, on which all models are built, rise to cup the bust and what is more, lace down the back.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced this afternoon that it was "inquiring into the facts concerning the recent stock offering by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation to ascertain whether there is any basis for a formal investigation."

With the Lincoln's Birthday holiday period on hand, the outlook for skiing in the North Country is most encouraging. That is, for the high areas, where more snow and cold weather are expected to prevail the next forty-eight hours. In the lowlands, along the coast in particular, rain, changing into sleet, is forecast.

Whether or not Wanda Landowska regards herself as a high priestess of her art, her public evidently does. The audience that turned out at Town Hall last night for the first of her three harpsichord recitals devoted to Book I of Bach's "Well-Tempered Clavier" was as worshipful as might be a gathering interested in physics at a discourse by Albert Einstein.

Following publication of your editorial on Jan. 22 entitled "Housing Law Loophole," the writer went to Washington to find out what Senator Cain's subcommittee on Rent and Housing Control intended to do about it. He was not able to find out their intention, but did testify in favor of restoring federal control over "co-opping" and entered your fine editorial in the official record of the committee.

Rain washed away last night most of the three-tenths of an inch of snow that fell in the city yesterday, but sleet and freezing rain made roads in the metropolitan area slippery and driving hazardous.

The Save Washington Square Committee reported yesterday that it would intensify efforts to prevent New York University from erecting a $3,000,000 Law Center on the south side of the square. The university announced Tuesday evening that the center would be built on the block between Sullivan and Macdougal Streets, facing Washington Square Park.

The Save Washington Square Committee reported yesterday that it would intensify efforts to prevent New York University from erecting a $3,000,000 Law Center on the south side of the square. The university announced Tuesday evening that the center would be built on the block between Sullivan and Macdougal Streets, facing Washington Square Park.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has pledged its support to Britain's Trades Union Congress in an effort to avert a split in the World Federation of Trades Unions over the European Recovery Program, it was learned today.

The City Planning Commission reserved decision yesterday after holding a public hearing at City Hall on its own proposal to amend the city's Zoning Resolution by lifting existing restrictions in order to encourage private investment in construction of parking garages and parking lots.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Democratic National Committee, probably will open Presidential campaign headquarters in New York City in advance of the party's national convention in Philadelphia in July.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- For the second straight day, the Indian delegation tried hard today to be allowed to go home. There were arguments and pleas -- almost seven hours of them -- but when it was over all the delegation had to show for its pains were two sets of cancelled plane reservations.

The forthcoming international maritime conference in Geneva, Switzerland, will offer to the maritime nations of the world a forum for the exchange of ideas and the standardization of technical maritime problems, American delegates to the meeting declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Appearing for Mayor William O'Dwyer at a public hearing on Governor Dewey's $799,000,000 budget, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, today presented seven allegations of state discrimination against New York City in support of the city's claim for $84,500,000 more assistance from the state.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Marcel Rochas captures the charm of the new femininity in a collection minus a single tailored suit or slender skirt. The old-fashioned corset is here again, for his new guepieres, on which all models are built, rise to cup the bust and what is more, lace down the back.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Robert Grant 3d, national open racquets champion, and James R. Leonard, national amateur titleholder, had little difficulty in winning their matches in the first round of the Gold Racquets tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

Imports in several textile lines are continuing to increase. In the case of fine decorative fabrics for home furnishings, unobtainable in the country, imports were said to be approaching pre-war levels for the first time in seven or eight years.

The creation of a new Federal agency to assist Puerto Ricans who wish to migrate to the continental United States in settling in areas more favorable for them than this city was urged yesterday by the Welfare Council's Committee on Puerto Ricans.

The Heywood Broun Memorial Award, an annual tribute to outstanding journalism, was conferred yesterday upon Bert Andrews, chief of The New York Herald Tribune's bureau in Washington. Besides a prize of $500, Mr. Andrews received a citation for his reporting of the State Department's practices in dismissing its employes for security reasons.

A peculiar stoop and two missing front teeth, physical defects of one of their number, led yesterday to the arrest of four men accused of having been involved in the passing of about $50,000 in bad checks from Washington D. C., to northern New England in the past ten months.
BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The United Fruit Company reported today a net income of $54,140,794 for 1947 equal to $5.37 a common share, compared with $39,610,206, or $4.51 a share in 1946.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 12 -- British troops were fighting superior forces of Arab raiders from Syria tonight near Jisr Banat Yakub, site of a bridge along the upper reaches of the Jordan River, a Jewish source in Safed reported. He added that the engagement followed day-long skirmishes in the same region.

Early this week the Schomburg Collection of the New York Public Library had its mention in the news when its director, Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick, announced the Honor Roll of Race Relations for 1947. But perhaps many of those who read this announcement knew little of what the Schomburg Collection is.

Larry Ellis, New York University's freshman star, yesterday was added to the field for the Baxter Mile, featured cup race of tomorrow's New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden. Coach Emil Von Elling feels that his 19-year-old prodigy can hold his own with the rest of the milers now that Gil Dodds is out of the picture.

Any easing of supply in industrial materials which develops in metals, machine parts, foundry and tubular products will be quickly absorbed by continuing strong demand, industrial purchasing executives revealed here yesterday. Furthermore, there has been no weakening of high prices asked on black market offerings of pipe, nails, sheet steel, pig iron and galvanized products, they said.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- The recent break in the commodity markets has "permanently broken the dangerous high price curve" and also is removing "speculative and unrealistic values," Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared here this afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- The Palestine Commission reached agreement today on "all major points" of its special report to the Security Council calling for an international armed force to enable it to implement the partition of the Holy Land.

Though some perishable foods now are priced as much as 6 to 8 cents lower than they were a week ago, this doesn't mean that the housewife who always shops for thrifty items is going to spend considerably less for them this week-end than she did last.

The labor dispute that has cut off three-quarters of the city's supply of unwrapped rye and pumpernickel bread since Monday was settled yesterday through the efforts of Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Labor Relations Division.

HAVANA, Feb. 12 -- A new controversy between economically developed and undeveloped countries at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment came to a climax today in a debate over the number of countries needed to put the World Trade Charter into force if it is approved by the conference.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- New standards for the smashing of Japan's concentrations of economic power have been announced. They are considerably less drastic than those prepared last autumn, eliminating all ironclad rules and stipulating that companies will not be forced to fragment themselves if they can show that either the quantity or the efficiency of their production would suffer as a consequence.

The Securities and Exchange Commission decided yesterday to make a full investigation of the circumstances surrounding the withdrawal by the underwriting managers of a public offering of 900,000 shares of common stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, which would have yielded the company $10,260,625.

"Uncle Henry" Swain, 87-year-old Negro who lived in the days of slavery, came to New York from his home in Rocky Mount, Va., and placed wreaths on the busts of Lincoln and Booker T. Washington in the Hall of Fame at New York University, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday, as the 1948 campaign for the Booker T. Washington birthplace memorial was launched.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman asserted today that inflation was still a major economic threat, despite the break in commodity and security prices, and insisted that his ten-point anti-inflation program was needed to cope with the situation.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12 -- A resolution calling upon "all true white Jeffersonian Democrats" in the country to assemble here at a date yet to be determined and "formulate plans" opposing President Truman's civil rights program was adopted unanimously today in a voice vote by 4,000 wildly cheering and stomping Mississippians.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 13 -- Pope Pius XII today named Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre, Coadjutor Archbishop of New York, to be Archbishop of Los Angeles, and promoted the Most Rev. Gerald T. Bergan, Bishop of Des Moines, to Archbishop of the Metropolitan See of Omaha.

Surely something ought to be done for the organizing and regulating of national and international charities in this country, such as has been done for the local charities by the "Community Chest" or "Fund." At present there seems to be waste of money and labor in administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The politicians are standing pat while economic laws are operating to deflate some swollen prices. It is a rule of the political trade that you must never admit error. If, for instance, a condition for which you have proposed a remedy improves before your remedy has been administered, you repeat the old prescription anyhow, saying if it isn't required as a cure it is necessary as a preventive.
Gov. Thomas E. Dewey urged in a Boston speech that aid for Europe be used to promote the establishment of a federation of free European nations.

An exhibition of old silver covering four centuries will open this morning at Georg Jensen, Inc., 667 Fifth Avenue. The 200 articles shown are from the collection of Francis E. Fowler Jr., president of the Southern Comfort Corporation.

Sir Oliver Franks, named yesterday to succeed Lord Inverchapel as British Ambassador to the United States, was the chairman and guiding spirit of the Sixteen-Nation Conference at Paris last summer. His achievement is possibly the more remarkable (it all depends on one's point of view) in that he began his career as a professor of philosophy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman announced today that he had selected Paul R. Rowen of Boston to fill the vacancy created on the Securities and Exchange Commission by the resignation on Dec. 31 of James J. Caffrey, chairman.

Retail grocery chains girded for a price war in advertised items yesterday as the competition among food merchants to take part in price cutting enlisted even the consumer cooperatives, which normally shun "loss leader" selling.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Definite progress toward Germany-wide currency reform was achieved at yesterday's secret meeting of the Allied Control Council.

Sale here for delivery in Germany of coal at $130 a ton, fourteen times the Marshall Plan estimate, and of cigarettes, the importation of which into Germany is illegal, have come under Government inquiry, it was learned yesterday.
NANKING, Feb. 12 -- Four Communist columns under Gen. Chen Yi were reported today to be moving northeastward across the broken Lung-Hai railway toward their old bases in western Shantung.

GRAND RAPIDS, Feb. 12 -- An international trade association of church publishing houses in the United States and Canada was formed here today at a meeting of Protestant publishers held in connection with the annual meeting of the International Council of Religious Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Personal income in the United States increased to a record high of $197,000,000,000 in 1947, the Department of Commerce announced today. The total was $20,000,000,000 above the previous peak level established in 1946. Incomes in December, 1947, reached an annual rate of $209,700,000,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Winthrop Rockefeller, 36-year- old heir to the oil millions left by his grandfather John D. Rockefeller, will marry Mrs. Barbara Sears, 31, shortly after midnight tomorrow.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, the attraction is "Voyage Surprise," a French comedy satire, starring Sinoel and Martine Carol. Pierre Prevert directed from a scenario by Claude Accursi and Jacques and Pierre Prevert, with Maurice Baquet, Jacques Henri Duval and Rene Bourbon among the featured players.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Rochester women will pay tribute to Susan B. Anthony tomorrow in the first of a series of week-end events marking the 128th birth anniversary of the pioneer women's rights leader.
The City College basketball team sped to an 81-52 victory over Dickinson College before 2,435 fans Armory the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon.

Foormation of a Joint Council on the Resettlement of Displaced Persons to facilitate the reception and relocation in this country of Europe's homeless of all faiths was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph P. Chamberlain, professor of law at Columbia and world authority on the problem.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- The United Nations Security Council put aside the Kashmir case indefinitely today but prepared to begin hearings next week on other controversies that have been straining relations between India and Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission, without Russia's vote, today ordered an early completion of the disarmament of Japan.

At Boston last night Governor Dewey put the blame for most of our present difficulties in the field of foreign policy on wartime concessions made to Soviet Russia. "Marshal Stalin had repeatedly proclaimed the Soviet ambition to rule the world. In the face of that fact our own Government blundered and compromised from conference to conference, each time aiding and abetting that very scheme of Soviet world conquest."
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- United Nations headquarters restored its communication lines to the outside world today after an eerie icebound night.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- Pierre Balmain, a master hand at dramatizing simplicity, shows a collection essentially modern only faintly imbued with a feeling for things old fashioned, stoles, ribbon cravats tied in back, ribbon sashes -- lingerie dresses, starched white Buster Brown collars and cuffs on striped shirtwaists.

In the wake of the Russian Communist party's castigation of the Soviet Union's leading composers, the Metropolitan Opera Association reaffirmed yesterday its plan to put on "War and Peace," an opera by Sergei Prokofieff, one of the Russian composers under fire in Moscow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- The United Nations' long-discussed Economic Commission for Latin America was finally established, for all practical purposes, today with the approval of its draft terms of reference by the Economic and Social Council's Economic Committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman today called for millions of American volunteers to fight against inflation by door-to-door selling of savings bonds.

That navy and spring go hand in hand was strongly set forth yesterday by Rosette Pennington, who planned the show seen at the Plaza Hotel around this color, with few exceptions. Smooth gabardine suits with slim or gently flaring skirts were liked for those first bright days.

ATHENS, Feb. 12 -- Army reports from northern Greece today said that Regular troops in an offensive action in the Kastonochoria region of western Macedonia had killed 120 guerrillas, wounded 100 and taken about thirty-six prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The State Department said today it is not urging shipments of United States newsprint to Europe or anywhere else. Moreover, it said it has no plans to send newsprint to Europe under the Recovery Program even though an ample supply of paper would help maintain a free press there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The appointment of Sir Oliver Franks as British Ambassador to the United States is regarded here as the selection of an official who is especially qualified for the post both from the standpoint of governmental experience and equipment for dealing with the Marshall Plan after it comes into operation.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 12 -- Robert Boylan, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, expressed the opinion here today that "in so far as the markets are concerned prices have about stabilized.''

ROME, Feb. 12 -- A decisive step toward an Italo-French customs union, which may eventually develop into a full-fledged economic union, was taken today when the Cabinet Council approved it in principle and instructed Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza to make the necessary arrangements with the French Government for putting it into force.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Coach Ed McKeever of the Chicago Rockets may be hauled on the carpet by All-America Conference officials because of his "smear campaign" against University of San Francisco athletics, Tony Marabito, president of the San Francisco Forty-Niners, said tonight.
SALONIKA, Greece, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Frenzied Greeks jeered, pelted and jabbed 121 captured guerrillas who were forced to march in an army victory parade through Salonika's streets today.

The annual report of the Detroit Edison Company issued yesterday for publication today showed a net l income for last year of $11,112,568, equal to $1.59 a share, corn:pared with $10,631,040 earned in j 1946.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 12 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers absorbed today about 70,000 members of the United Railroad Workers of America to renew its position, lost since the post-war decline in shipbuilding, as one of the largest affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Changes in the New York City administrative code to remove the requirement that the Fire Department be organized on a three-platoon basis was proposed today in the Assembly by Irwin Steingut, minority leader. One of the effects of the proposal would be to cut the work week of firemen from forty-eight hours to forty-five hours and twelve minutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Josh Lee, former Senator from Oklahoma, was mentioned in the capital today as a possible appointee to the chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board, of which he is a member. This speculation, not confirmed in official circles, was based largely on the fact that after May 1, Mr. Lee will be the only experienced Democratic member remaining on the board.
I beg to differ with your interpretation of the significance of the publication of the Communist Manifesto about this time one hundred years ago.

PARIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Despite a slight recovery after a weak opening, prices of both gold and stocks in the markets here continued yesterday's downward movement today. Trading was slow, with bids limited largely to day-to-day traders.

New Jersey surfcasters have announced that they have neither "died nor surrendered," so far as the battle to introduce striped bass conservation legislation is concerned. The bill, which failed last year when State Senator W. S. Mathis of the Senate Fish and Game Committee refused to permit it to reach the floor for vote, will be introduced again by State Senator David Young.

Two international yachting matches have been arranged to be held in Bermuda in April, with craft from this country being sent for both. Final arrangements were concluded yesterday. One will be between the International Class sloops of both countries and the other between Luders "Sixteens." The racing will cover two weeks.
Lou Little is still undecided on whether or not to accept the offer to go to Yale as head football coach.

Can they understand that this is Peace * * * that the forces of darkness have been routed * * * that they can grow up with a clear conscience into crippled, tubercular men * * * that they are now free to starve?

Anton R. Zhebrak has been dismissed from his scientific post in Russia for having suggested in the journal Science, over two years ago, that Soviet biologists have no high opinion of Academician T. D. Lysenko, a plant breeder who has been proclaiming since 1935 that genetics is a bourgeois fraud invented to perpetuate ancestor worship and aristocratic snobbery.

ALLAHABAD, India, Feb. 12 -- The ashes of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi were consigned to the holy waters of the Ganges at 1:55 P. M. today amid pageantry epitomizing the ancient civilization that the little man in a white loincloth molded into free membership in the modern family of nations.

Current pleas for compromise in Palestine are misleading and dangerous. They are misleading because they are based upon two untenable assumptions; dangerous because they becloud the issue and give encouragement to the aggressors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman said today that the Government of the United States was supporting the United Nations' settlement of the Palestine issue.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, at Broadway and 122d Street, has established a School of Jewish Education in Los Angeles as the first unit in a projected West Coast University of Judaism, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis Finkelstein, the president of the seminary.

Opening of boys' and students' clothing lines for fall has been set for April 19. Selection of the date has been made by the Association of Boys' and Students' Clothing Manufacturers, it was announced yesterday.

Exploding dynamically near the finish of a tense, tight struggle that was strongly reminiscent of the metropolitan basketball of a decade ago, Fordham handed St. John's its first subway circuit defeat of the season last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Milchman Sons, builders, have purchased thirty-eight lots on 203d Street, north of Horace Harding Boulevard, in Bayside, Queens, from Daniel Charles and plan to improve them with eighteen dwellings. Lane Realty, broker in the deal, has been appointed sales representative for the development.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Rising temperatures may have caused some apprehension in metropolitan areas on the skiing outlook for this week-end but reports from the Northlands last night indicated that skiing ranged from good to excellent, with a few exceptions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, for twelve years Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, today joined the list of Roosevelt appointees ruled out by President Truman for reappointment His term expires April 6.
Octogenarian Edward M. Waring has gone back to his slate-carrying days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Hanns Eisler, Hollywood figure and brother of Gerhart Eisler, has been ordered deported from this country and it is understood that he will leave voluntarily, Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced late today.

Hunter College may accept a limited number of out-of-town students, tuition free, when the new five-year state-aid teacher training program starts, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, told 1,000 alumnae at a luncheon commemorating the seventy-eighth birthday of the college in the Grand Ballroom of the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday afternoon.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Web II, hailed as the champion 3-year-old of Ireland, ran dead last in his American debut at Santa Anita Park today. Mr. Ace, owned by William G. Helis of New Orleans, won the race, the $5,000 Abraham Lincoln Purse for 3-year-olds, in runaway fashion.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- A voluntary "freeze" of the wages and prices prevailing in Britain at the end of January was asked by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- James F. O'Neil, national commander of the American Legion, accused the House Rules Committee today of "political cowardice" in allowing the bill for universal military training to languish without a vote on the floor.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, attacked the foreign policy of the Roosevelt and Truman administration tonight for a series of failures, arising largely from an "inept and futile policy toward communism," and asserted that they had sole responsibility for "losing the peace, thus far."
By the narrow margin of two points, Columbia defeated Pennsylvania, 52 to 50, in University Hall last night to remain with N. Y. U. as the two major unbeaten college basketball teams.

After an inspection yesterday of Bedloes Island with its stockpile of discarded WPA rubble and decayed, untenanted old Army buildings, Representative Ellsworth B. Buck of Staten Island declared he would rather see it closed to the public unless the Government appropriated enough money to surround the Statue of Liberty with the proper environment.

SIBI, Baluchistan, Feb. 12 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Governor General of Pakistan, arrived here today on a visit, during which it is hoped the ground will be prepared for the accession of the strategically important state of Kalat and its feudatories and the consolidation of the Baluchi tribal territories.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain denied today Russian charges that she had a secret anti-Soviet "deal" with Hitler in 1938.

The world's rarest postage stamp, the British Guiana 1-penny magenta, reported in a Los Angeles news dispatch on Wednesday as having been stolen in that city, will be publicly displayed here during the first week in March, it was announced here yesterday by Finbar Kenny, manager of J. H. Stolow, stamp dealers at 50 West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today voted broad discretionary powers in an economic cooperation administration over the foreign economic relations of Marshall Plan countries and authorized the cutting off of aid to any nation out of step with the program.

Twenty Columbia University students who picketed an Alumni Day luncheon held in the University's John Jay Hall yesterday were advised to stop by Thomas A. McGoey, director of Columbia's Residence Halls.

Mayor O'Dwyer made an open appeal last night for Henry A. Wallace to abandon his third-party venture and rejoin the Democratic party. The Mayor spoke in the Hunts Point Palace in the Bronx at the opening of the campaign of Karl Propper, Democratic nominee for Congress in the special election to be held in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District next Tuesday.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- France's problem of prices and wages today became acute while the Government was pushing a price-control bill through the National Assembly and labor was advancing claims that a 20 per cent price advance required a corresponding rise in wages.

The threat of a strike this morning in 153 Safeway stores in the metropolitan area was removed last night when company and union representatives agreed to accept a peace formula drafted by Joseph E. O'Grady, deputy director of the City Labor Relations Division.
Woven decorative fabrics specially loomed to blend with wallpapers were introduced yesterday in two model rooms by Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street.

The one and two-story garage buildings occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 312-14 East Forty-ninth Street, near the United Nations site, have been sold by the Trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral to S. E. Prince in a transaction reported yesterday by John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker in the deal. They were held at $75,000.

This has been an excellent year for the chimney fire, the best, perhaps, since that other winter drifted slowly to a spring snow flurry in '88. It has been prolonged, it has been intense. Already some seven weeks have passed since the formal opening of the season, and there is as yet no sign it will end abruptly. Living is good this year.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company last year attained new high marks in the number of policyholders, amount of life insurance in force and payments to policyholders, Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board, and Leroy A. Lincoln, president, announced yesterday in the 1947 annual report filed with the New York State Insurance Department.
The opera "Peter Grimes," music by Benjamin Britten to the libretto of Montagu Slater, had its New York premiere last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. It was well received by a big audience.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A demand that the organization and training of Army and Air Force Reserves be brought up to the standard set by the Navy was made today by Brig. Gen. E. A. Evans, president of the Reserve Officers Association.
Mayor O'Dwyer rattled the city's rapidly depleting oil can yesterday and asked the Federal Government for more.

Consolidated net sales of the United States Rubber Company last year rose $86,215,063 to a new high, but earnings declined $1,454,624 from 1946, F. B. Davis Jr., board chairman, and Herbert E. Smith, president, reported in the fifty-sixth annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The livestock market at Chicago, one of the few primary markets in this country to be open in spite of the Lincoln's Birthday holiday, set a firm undertone yesterday for the resumption of trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- The Catholic Church in Italy will use its power and influence to bring about the victory of the pro-Catholic Christian Democratic party, headed by Premier Alcide de Gasperi, in the national elections, Vatican circles said today.

An entirely new type of metal lens capable of Channeling fifty to 100 television programs, or tens of thousands of telephone messages, into a single beam for transmission over an inter-city radio system, now is under development at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, it was announced yesterday.

The fact-finding committee of the theatrical unions, headed by Solly Pernick of the stagehands' group, is demanding that the scenery of "Skipper Next to God," starring John Garfield, be re-built, despite the fact that the set now in use cost $4,912.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Hans Gerschwiler of Switzerland, 26 - year - old defending champion, took a small lead over Dick Button of the United States today in the compulsory portion of the world's figure-skating championship for men. Button was expected to come from behind in his specialty, free skating, to win the crown tomorrow.

The dream situation of the same dog winning America's indoor and outdoor bench classics occurred before 10,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night when Champion Rock Ridge Night Rocket, young bedlington terrier belonging to Mr. and Mrs. William

The John Harms Chorus, under John Harms' direction, gave a performance of Bach's "St. Matthew Passion," last night at Town Hall. Iona Harms, soprano; Pauline Pierce, contralto; John Priebe, tenor; Martial Singher, the Metropolitan baritone, and Donald Wheatcraft, bass, were the soloists.

ONE of the better kept secrets of the current track season has been the identity of the various milers who have been pursuing Gilbert Dodds. The Perambulating Parson has been observed crouching at the starting line with a group of strangers and then he leaves them so abruptly that no one ever notices who they are -- or why.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- A description of the disaster that overcame an American airborne attack in the invasion of Sicily is contained in the official dispatch of Viscount Alexander, then commander in chief of the Fifteenth Army Group, published today.
