Athens was the most beautiful and enlightened city of the ancient world because it dedicated its best efforts to the welfare of its people. On reaching manhood each of its citizens took the Ephebic oath, pledging himself to transmit to his children a better and finer city than he found.

Mrs. Busch Greenough will give a tea and reception in her apartment at the St. Regis Wednesday for persons in charge of arrangements for the benefit theatre party of the Grenfell Association of America, which will take place the evening of March 11 at the performance of the Maurice Evans production, "The Linden Tree," at the Music Box.

Domestic steel companies last year spent approximately $496,000,000 for new equipment and expansion, and plan to spend $565,000,000 for the same purpose in 1948, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

Saying that only a strong United States can possibly combat the threat of world communism, Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, declared last night that the Republican Congress was going to cut President Truman's budget of nearly $40,000,000,000 and pass a bill to reduce taxes.
The extent and intensity of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union is surprising in a country that boasts of its lack of racial prejudice.

The American passenger ship fleet, which now consists of sixty-three ships in operation, building or being reconverted, compared to 127 in operation before the war, is at its lowest ebb in its history, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Watching the American price slump, Britain finds herself in the position of the American housewife, hoping for cheaper food but dreading a financial collapse.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 12 -- Fawzi el-Kawukji, tough lifelong re olutionary who commands the "Yarmuk," Arab volunteer army in Palestine, predicted tonight that "big events" would begin in Palestine soon after Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Establishment of a repository for historical documents connected with the Supreme Court was a possibility considered by the justices following publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES today of the complete notes used by Abraham Lincoln in his only argument before that tribunal.

Awards sound the "death knell of camp life" for many children, Dr. Roma Gans, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the opening of the first convention of the Association of Private Camps in the New Yorker Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Soviet accusations that Britain and France were first to conclude nonaggression pacts with Hitlerite Germany did nothing to ruffle the outward calm of Foreign Office spokesmen today. One of them made the bored comment that some of the documents cited by the 'Soviet Information Bureau seemed so colorless that he would not have taken the trouble to find them.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Two veterans of the tournament trail -- Clayton Heafner and golf's fashion plate, Jimmy Demaret -- skipped over 6,045-yard Harlingen Municipal course today in six-under-par 65's to lead the first round of the $10,000 Lower Rio Grande Valley open.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Although British forces in Palestine are seeking to check the flow of volunteers, a Foreign Office spokesman said today, measures to eject Arab bands after their entry into the Holy Land would require considerable forces that might be needed in more vulnerable parts of the country.
Stanley Park has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Payne Cutlery Corporation, Newark and Brooklyn,
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- To a 5-year-old gelding named Stud Poker went first money and a new turf course record in the best of the skirmishes at Hialeah Park before 14,785 racegoers today.

Recent cancellations of orders placed by small furniture stores at wholesale markets on varied merchandise are being followed by "hold-ups" from larger furniture outlets and delays in confirmations from a few department stores, manufacturers' representatives and buyers reported yesterday.

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, addressing 550 members of the National Urban League and its New York component, told last night of some of his efforts as Secretary of the Navy to end the inequalities that have existed in that service between Negro and white personnel.

The three-story building at 3022 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, containing a store and two apartments, has been sold by Mrs. Maria Louise Geurra to Langella DiGiovanni, who occupy the store premises as a meat market. Sale of the property, on a plot 20 by 75 feet, was for cash above a mortgage of $17,000. M. C. O'Brien, Inc., was the broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Elliott Nugent was named today by Paramount to replace John Farrow as the director of "The Great Gatsby," Farrow having withdrawn from the assignment because of a disagreement over casting with Richard Maibaum, producer of the picture.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 12.1 per cent in January, compared with the corresponding month in 1947, according to a compilation covering forty companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase in December was 22.4 per cent.

Ebco Manufacturing Company, Columbus, Ohio, will launch a $150,000 advertising and public relations program to promote sale of its Oasis electric drinking water coolers, it was announced yesterday. "Better water for better living" will be the keynote theme of the campaign, A. R. Benua, president, said, adding that the drive will be aimed at the "80 or 85 per cent of potential electric water cooler users who have not yet been sold by the industry."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 7 totaled 747,394 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,356 cars, or 2.8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 19,907 cars, or 2.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 34,154 cars, or 4.8 per cent. more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.
Bernard M. Baruch defended the United States yesterday against foreign detractors and praised this nation for its efforts to help the rest of the world recover from the devastations of the war.

In the plans for improved rail and transit connections between Northern New Jersey and New York City, recently put forward by Governor Driscoll of New Jersey, apparently one "obvious" development has been overlooked and far more expensive duplicating facilities proposed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Spokesmen for labor, industry and the Government expressed enthusiasm today over the adoption of an arbitration plan by the Associated General Contractors of America for settling jurisdictional disputes in the building and construction industry without strikes
Plans for building expansion at Barnard College were outlined yesterday by Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh before the Barnard College alumnae at their annual reunion luncheon in Hewitt Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Average primary market prices rose fractionally during the week ended Feb. 7, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The majority of prices of commodities traded in organized markets, which are included in this index, are taken as of Feb. 3, and the sharp break in commodity markets that began on Feb. 4 is not reflected in the index for this particular week.

City College paid tribute yesterday to the late John H. Finley, president of the college from 1903 to 1913 and retired editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the annual luncheon of the school's Associate Alumni at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted permission to the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners to intervene before it in proceedings involving the reorganization of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that registration statements covering $13,000,000 of bonds and 600,000 shares of common capital stock were filed with it by three companies.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 12 -- Communists are trying to cash in on the present strike wave in Belgium's coal mines and gas and electricity plants, which today tied up a good deal of the country's industry.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- Some 500 delegates to the third annual analytical symposium of the Pittsburgh section of the American Chemical Society here today were told to improve their housekeeping if they want to improve their professional standing.

Bruno Walter, renamed musical adviser of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony for next season, was back on the podium last night with his favorite orchestra and in generous mood. The program, one of the longest of the season, gave John Corigliano, the orchestra's concertmaster, an occasion to be soloist and it introduced to New York the "Symphonia Serena" by Paul Hindemith.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- A statement that Germany has paid $71,700,000,000 in reparations was put forth in a report issued today by a group of German economists headed by Gustav Harmssen, Bremen Senator and member of the Bizonal Advisory Council on foreign trade.

Gene Burton, Harlem welterweight, will trade punches with Bernard Docusen of New Orleans in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight tops an all-star card that has considerable appeal, and a crowd of 13,000 fans is expected to witness the activity.

Mild weather pushed the mercury up to 42.8 degrees at 3:10 P. M. yesterday to give New Yorkers their warmest day in a month and the second hottest one of the season. The thaw was expected to continue today, with highest thermometer readings near 40.

NO government ever made a more sincere effort to keep another government from going to war than did we in the case of Italy. Five months of appeal and pressure from us preceded Mussolini's entrance into the conflict.
A practically noiseless personal airplane has been developed and flown at Boston by the Aeronautical Research Foundation, a non-profit organization.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Sir Oliver Shewell Franks has been appointed British Ambassador to Washington in succession to Lord Inverchapel, it was announced by the Foreign Office tonight. He is expected to take up his post in May.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Apart from British Government stocks and gold mining issues, most sections of the stock markets here today were quiet. Buyers held off, pending the outcome of the debate in the House of Commons on the Government's wage stabilization proposals.

The Interim Committee of the General Assembly of the United Nations will face a dilemma on Feb. 19 when it meets to consider the report of its Commission that has visited Korea in an attempt to carry out its mandate to hold free elections and establish a stable government in that small, unhappy country.

An account of the methods employed to assess the capacities of men and women recruited for the Office of Strategic Services will be issued on March 18 by Rinehart, under the title "Assessment of Men." The book was prepared by the OSS Assessment Staff.

Three hundred Columbia University alumni were assured yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university "that every effort will be made to resolve the seeming misunderstanding between me and the students."

WQXR's frequency modulation affiliate will return to the air at 7 A. M. tomorrow on 96.3 megacycles (Channel 242) and hereatfer will be known as WQXR-FM, it was announced yesterday. The FM station has operated since Nov. 1942, under the call of WQXQ.

Until somebody beats him out of the job, Jackie Roosevelt Robinson will be the 1948 first baseman of the National League champion Dodgers. The Negro star signed his contract yesterday and, sitting beside President Branch Rickey in the Montague Street offices, announced that he was happy and "hope Mr. Rickey is, too."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A bill to change some tax laws that have been annoying corporations was being drafted under Republican auspices today for possible enactment this session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The capital's partisan controversy over the fall in farm prices was denounced today by Charles Slaughter, a director of the New York Cotton Exchange, as a contributing factor in the nervousness of the market.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Lincoln's Birthday anniversary was recommended tonight to the Republican party by Gov. Earl Warren, a Presidential candidate, as a time for "introspection to make sure that it remains today a party, not of expediency, but of principle.

A hold-up man carrying a toy pistol in a brown paper bag, who stole $150 last Dec. 5 from the Trans-Canada Air Lines ticket offices at 16 East Fifty-eighth Street, attempted a second robbery there last night and was shot dead by two detectives hiding in a rear room.

Prayers for "peace with justice and a time of brotherhood" will be offered today, the annual "World Day of Prayer" held under the auspices of the United Council of Church Women in sixty-eight countries and in some 15,000 communities.
The Palestine problem is entering its crucial stage as the Security Council of the United Nations opens a debate of tremendous potential significance to the future of the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- James A. Farley, who sat on the sidelines during the Roosevelt campaigns of 1940 and 1944, will sit on the dais next Thursday night as President Truman makes the principal speech at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner here.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey proposed tonight in a Lincoln Day address that aid for Europe under the Marshall Plan be used to speed the establishment of a federation of free European nations.

WQXR's frequency modulation affiliate will return to the air at 7 A. M. tomorrow on 96.3 megacycles (Channel 242) and hereatfer will be known as WQXR-FM, it was announced yesterday. The FM station has operated since Nov. 1942, under the call of WQXQ.

The New York Knickerbockers, who had One winning streak snapped in Baltimore Thursday night, will try to stretch another against the Philadelphia Warriors tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The local entry in the Basketball Association of America, stopped on the road after eight straight victories, will be shooting for its sixth consecutive triumph at home.
BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these winter sports conditions and forecasts:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- The most scathing denunciation of a colonial power yet to come before the United Nations trusteeship division was leveled against Britain in a petition just made public here.

The city's general fund revenue for 1948-49, one of the vital factors in determining the basic real estate tax for the fiscal period beginning July 1, will be $45,256,031 less than in 1947-48, Lazarus Joseph, Controller, estimated yesterday in a report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, joined leaders of other faiths yesterday in endorsing the proposed expansion of the Sydenham Hospital into a social and medical institute that would serve the Harlem and Manhattanville areas of New York.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Communistbacked demands on the Government for an immediate new rise in wages of 20 per cent were rejected today in a committee of the French Advisory Economic Council. Leon Jouhaux's Workers Force did not take part in the vote and the Catholic Union representative abstained.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 13 -- One of the most important political aspects of the trade agreement signed by Argentina and Britain yesterday is the fact that Argentina will not definitely take over the British-owned railways March 1.

Public utility companies, railroads and state and local governments will be prominent in the market for new capital next week. Topping a schedule of municipal bond sales totaling $140,112,850 is the last $85,000,000 installment of the Illinois veterans' bonus issue, which will come up for bidding on Tuesday.

Veterans from near-by Army and Navy hospitals have been invited to sit in the boxes at tomorrow evening's gala operatic performance of the Metropolitan Opera Company, as guests of the various unions it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 -- Steel entered the age of high speed here this week, when officials of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation held an inspection Thursday of the new Aliquippa five-stand tandem cold strip mill, capable of pouring steel strip through its length at the speed of over seventy miles per hour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Proposed authorization of the sale of up to 200 Government-owned merchant ships to countries participating in the European Recovery Program was eliminated from the Marshall Plan legislation by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Dick Button, 18-year-old skating marvel from Englewood, N. J., in one of the most brilliant performances ever seen on European ice, today became the first American ever to win the men's world figure skating championship, while Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Ottawa made a good start in defense of her women's crown.

The possible reformation of Hoboken, New Jersey's most criticized community, started yesterday to get an unscheduled airing when a report that opens with the line "the people of Hoboken have been robbed" became available against the wishes of the present "reform" administration.
This letter is to protest the headline of the article entitled "Health Group Asks Military Training," by Lucy Freeman, in the news section of THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, Feb. 1.
Many lessons were learned from the paratroop maneuvers recently completed at Pine Camp, N, Y., but none more important than the discovery that gremlins are back at work in the Amy Air Forces.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Saturday, Feb. 14 -- Winthrop Rockefeller, heir to oil millions, took Mrs. Barbara Sears, former actress, as his bride at 12:14 A. M. today.

A second day with temperatures above freezing, which Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander described as being "as good as a ship-load of oil," yesterday eased the city's fuel emergency. Up to 6 P. M. the Mayor's Emergency Fuel Committee had received 3,334 requests for fuel oil.

ATHENS, Feb. 13 -- Elections in the Greek Federation of Labor have thus far indicated that no more than one-fifth of those voting are Communists or have Communist leanings, according to the findings of Clinton S. Golden, labor adviser of the American Mission to Aid Greece.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Izzadeen Shawa Bey, London representative of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, reiterated that his Arab Political Mission was not engaged in recruiting for the Palestine Arab cause but had only acknowledged applications of volunteers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, today transmitted to Trygve Lie, Secretary General, the United States and Chinese proposal to the Little Assembly for studying new methods for the pacific settlement of international disputes.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 13 -- A self-styled "all right" slate of candidates swept every position today on the general executive board of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 -- Security measures around the Eden Hotel, in the heart of the Jewish area in Jerusalem were tightened for the protection of thirty Americans who arrived today on behalf of the United Jewish Appeal in the United States.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for Irving Haim, head of a $12,000,000-a-year wholesale liquor concern, asserted yesterday that even if his client had done business with Frank Costello, slot machine king, that fact would not be grounds for revoking his license.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 13 -- A deliberate attempt is being made to discredit the entire process of speculation, Robert P. Boylan, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, stated tonight at a joint meeting here of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

A loss of more than $5,500,000 was sustaned by New York's voluntary hospitals in caring for the city's public charge patients in 1946, according to a statement issued yesterday by the United Hospital Fund of New York. The fund has requested the city government to increase the pay for the care of these patients "in order to insure the continued maintenance of services vitally important to the health and welfare of the community."

Sales of F. W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary last year reached the highest volume in its history, while earning were the largest for any year since 1928, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Consolidated net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company amounted last year to $161,188,623, equal to $7.66 for each of the 21,034,761 common shares outstanding, compared with $208,551,507, or $10.23 a share in 1946, when 20,384,750 shares were outstanding, according to the annual report issued for release today.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 13 -An improved "electric eye" was described here today as the latest scientific aids in detecting poisons in foods, drugs, alloys, metals and plastics.
Last season set a new high for Nova Scotia tuna angling, according to the report just received, which gives the total catch as 495 fish, having an aggregate weight of 235,450 pounds.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret swung in with a blazing 7 under par 64 today to take over leadership in the Lower Rio Grande Valley $10,000 open golf tournament at the halfway mark with a thirty-six-hole total of 129.

Large chunks of New England and Adirondack forest, complete with lakes, streams, fish and wildlife, were transposed to various parts of Grand Central Palace during the past few days, and at noon today the doors of the Palace will be opened to another National Sportsmen's Show.

ALL novels are stories of conflict in varying degrees. This is natural enough, since the clashing of wills and issues is the life of the novel. No United Nations compact could ever change that. The conflict may take the form of pageantried battles in historical novels and grimmer engagements in more recent wars. It may take the form of family rivalries and the competing interests of different generations.

For the first time since the end of the war, virtually all of the 7,000 different automatic controls and industrial instruments of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company and its Brown instrument division can be shipped promptly from factory stocks, Arnold Michelson, vice president in charge of the Eastern zone, declared following a meeting of more than 300 salesmen at the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Patent 2,435,819 was awarded for an improved construction of aircraft cabin pressure control arrangements to Frederick E. Crever of Scotia and Lawrence A. Burton of Schenectady, N. Y., as one of the 387 issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

After an absence of six years from the local concert stage, Rosa Bok, former Metropolitan soprano, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Since she was last heard here, Miss Bok's light voice has definitely gained warmth and color.

It is an unusual American who has ever heard of Kalat. If Mohammed Ali Jinnah's visit to Baluchistan is fruitful we may hear more of this lost land. The leader of Pakistan's mission is to persuade Kalat, the southern section of Baluchistan, to join the new Dominion. The tribesmen have already voiced their allegiance, but the Khan of Kalat is hesitant.

European Bus Line Ads Due A. Johnson Co., agent for Swedish Trans-European Bus Lines, will break a metropolitan newspaper test campaign on March 17 to inform prospective American tourists of the lines' services and special excursions throughout Western Europe, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- China will receive 18,600 tons of wheat and 47,752 tons of rice from the United States under the $18,000,000 interim aid program voted by Congress in December, according to allocations announced by the State Department today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Calumet Farm's Armed "horse of the year" in 1947, and the King Ranch's Assault, who held the same title in 1946 are entered in successive races at Hialeah Park tomorrow, and the outlook is for the mutuel ticket-sellers to put in their most strenuous afternoon of the meeting to date.

A great master, Robert Casadesus, sat at the piano last night in Carnegie Hall and made us his intimate and honored friends as he discoursed masterpieces. He did this with such modesty, sincerity, depth of thought and communication of beauty that everything he played was absorbing.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 13 -- Announcement by State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson today of his candidacy for the Republican nomination for United States Senator brought quick pledges of support from leaders in seventeen of New Jersey's twenty-one counties.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 13 -- Secretary of the Treasury John Snyder said here tonight that he was opposed to "a hasty tax reduction" but urged that the "first step in changing our tax structure should be to iron out" inequities. He addressed the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Communism was described by Prime Minister Attlee tonight as "an inverted Czarism" that had "turned its back on civilization."

Based on studies which show that industrial production costs can be reduced, an industry-wide project aimed at opening large new markets for machine tools is being started by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, Cleveland, Tell Berna, general manager, revealed here yesterday.
The impending debate on Palestine in the United Nations Security Council confronts the United States with a major dilemma. This country is in a position of "damned if we do and damned if we don't"

Rose Halprin, President of Hadassah, takes objection to the publication in your issue of Jan. 31 of pictures of the leader of the Arab forces in the Old City of Jerusalem giving safe conduct to a convoy of Red Cross ambulances carrying Jewish invalids from the invalid home in Jerusalem.

They don't call off track meets just because Gil Dodds is down with the mumps. The New York Athletic Club games will go on as scheduled tonight before a capacity crowd of 15,000 at Madison Square Garden and the program is such that the absence of the puissant parson can be dismissed with a passing sigh of regret.

An aged "prospector" with his office in his pocket was arrested yesterday on orders of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein on a charge of selling stock in a Canadian gold mine unregistered in this state.

NANKING, Feb. 13 -- The National Economic Council announced today that it had fixed China's commercial import quota for the first half of 1948 at $74,720,000 (United States). In the last six months of 1947 $128,000,000 in foreign exchange was allotted for commercial imports.

The city's week-old bakery strike in the dark bread and specialty fields was practically back where it started yesterday when two of the larger locals of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, AFL, rejected the offer of a wage increase of 50 cents a day made by employer groups.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- As demolition of the old Berlin gets under way there is less talk of the "New Berlin' than there was last year or the year before. A year ago the manager of the heatless and dismal back wing, which is all that is left of the Adlon Hotel, dreamed of building a modest little inn out of the wreckage of the former luxury hotel.
A former German Communist, who said he renounced the party before entering this country, has been arrested on a deportation warrant, it was reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The gradual development of anti-Communist fronts in Europe is making for some curious ideological combinations and odd political bedfellows. Almost every important coalition in countries hoping to receive Marshall Plan aid is doing its utmost to appeal to the Left and appear somewhat leftist itself to gain workers' support and avoid accusations of being reactionary.

Two of the world champion Yankees' alleged holdouts departed from those ranks yesterday when Johnny Lindell and Yogi Berra indicated they are ready and willing to work in 1948 for the wages offered by General Manager George Weiss.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- A new chief for the British Navy was named tonight in an Admiralty announcement that Admiral Lord Fraser of North Cape would succeed Admiral of the Fleet Sir John Cunningham as First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) u The Government reimposed its wartime allocation controls on general purpose synthetic rubber today to insure better distribution of scarce supplies for automobile tires and other essential needs.

A total of 7,325,134 tons of cargo was shipped during 1947 to European and Mediterranean theatres under the authority of the New York Port of Embarkation, Maj. Gen. Ewart G. Plank, commanding general, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, today told a news conference that Dr. Thomas Parran was not reappointed surgeon general of the Public Health Service because it always had been contemplated that the job should be rotated, as was that of chief of staff of the Army.

The Theatre Guild's radio dramatization of "The Barretts of Wirepole Street" will originate on Sunday, Feb. 29, from Constitution Hall, the broadcast coinciding with the formal opening that evening of the 1948 drive of the American Red Cross.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today authorized a four-year European Recovery Program with $5,300,000,000 for the first twelve months' operations beginning April 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- As of mid-January, retail prices still were on the rise, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Officials here have discovered no substantial evidence of a change in the Soviet Union s foreign policy, it was said authoritatively today. However, they were said to be scanning recent indications of a possible relaxation of the stand of the Kremlin in its relations with the West.

AS a former associate of the late Hon. George N. Peek, special adviser to the President on foreign trade, I have been greatly concerned over some misrepresentations concerning his policies which have just appeared in the memoirs of former Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

UTICA. N. Y., Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Eleven persons, eight of them children ranging in age from one month to 10 years old, were burned to death today when fire destroyed a two-family tenement which housed twenty-five persons.

The hope that before the next winter they would have a home, with heat and hot water, was conveyed yesterday to seven nuns who since 1942 have been living in a Bronx garret. The nuns are members of a community of thirty- three Sisters Of Christian Charity, who teach at the parochial school of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception, 150th Street and Melrose Avenue, the Bronx.

Archbishop-designate J. Francis A. McIntyre of Los Angeles, whose appointment to that post was made public yesterday, expressed regrets in an interview at the chancery of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue, that he was to leave New York. He said the date of his going was not yet fixed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- RKO announced today that Dudley Nichols will produce and direct "Story X," a photoplay which he will write from a screen story by Samuel Grafton which the studio bought last November under the title "A Modern Ecstasy."

" The Origins of Russia," by Jan Kucharzewski, a Polish historian, will be published by the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences on Feb. 28. It is a study of the Russian Tsarist system and of the spirit that found expression in Bolshevism.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 13 u Bertram M. Betsch, 42 years old, an executive of the Electric Bond and Share Company, New York, was shot four times in the back tonight as he was walking on Montrose Avenue here, a few blocks from his home.

Reporting the news in two areas thousands of miles apart, two reporters for this newspaper were in trouble with "the law" this week. In Sofia, Bulgaria, William H. Lawrence, Balkan correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, was first officially denounced, then fined and ordered to leave the country because of an article he had written about the Communists there which they did not like.

VIENNA, Feb, 13 -- Col. Gen. L. V. Kurasov, Soviet High Commissioner for Austria, tried to persuade the Allied Council for Austria today to nullify the interim aid agreement recently concluded by the United States and Austria and all other agreements concluded by Vienna with individual occupying powers.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 -- A "king's ransom" of jewels -- diamonds, emeralds, sapphires and other precious stones valued at more than $2,000,-000 -- combined with music, ballet and the newest "new look" to make tonight's preview of the symphony of fashion the most spectacular, as well as the most entertaining style show ever seen here.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The Association de Couture en Gros, wholesale dressmakers, gave an afternoon showing today. In his opening address the president, Albert Lempreur, said that his federation planned to return last October's visit of California dress manufacturers.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 -- An economic study showing that income payments to persons living in states west of the Mississippi is increasing more rapidly than in other parts of the country was published here today. The book, "The American West: an Inventory of Greatness," was prepared by Donald L. Henry of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and published by W. C. D'Arcy, past president of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Council of Economic Advisers has scheduled six conferences with leaders of industry, labor, farmers, and consumers so as to furnish a definitive appraisal of the break in the commodity and security markets for President Truman by the end of March.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade staged a strong rally at one time today, with May corn, after opening 8 cents lower a bushel, the daily limit, advancing 6 3/4 cents from the low only to weaken again in the late trading and close at the bottom as did the July.

Thomas A. Monroe, vice president and European representative of the United States Lines, has been selected by the National Federation of American Shipping as the American steamship industry's delegate to the United Nations Conference on Intergovernmental Maritime Organization, which opens in Geneva Thursday.

Retail trade here showed only slight gains this week. Many stores reported decreases in volume due to unfavorable weather conditions, but others reported sales increases. The gain for department stores was estimated at 5 per cent over last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal has renewed his efforts to obtain actual, as well as legalistic unification of the three armed services making up the National Military Establishment. He disclosed today that he has forbidden unauthorized public discussions of controversial subjects by high officials and officers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 u Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 7 were 10 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) u It will be California-bred On Trust against seventeen rivals in the $50,000 added San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita tomorrow.
Accepted resignation of Dr. Frank P. Graham from United Nations Indonesian Peace Committee.

A suspension of seven months, along with a fine of $1,000, yesterday was imposed upon Jake LaMotta, Bronx middleweight, by the State Athletic Commission, for "conduct detrimental to the best interests of boxing."

Newly added to the, roster of Broadway prospects for next fall are "Forward the Heart" and "The Children's World." The first of these, described as a romantic play with a social theme by Bernard Reines, was acquired by S. Emerson Golden.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 13 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio outlined his views on farm policy today in this food processing center. Carrying his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination into Nebraska and Iowa, he told a luncheon gathering sponsored by the agricultural and livestock interests of Nebraska that Government support of the parity program should be cut below the 90 per cent level at which it now begins.

PRAGUE, Feb. 13 -- Voting solidly against the Communists, all other parties in the Czechoslovak Parliament passed a resolution today demanding a report from the Communist Minister of the Interior on the misuse of the police for political purposes.
Bernard Docusen, New Orleans welterweight, won a decision over Gene Burton, Harlem boxer, in ten unexciting rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A British museum is prepared to return immediately the Kitty Hawk plane which Orville Wright sent to London in 1928 because of a dispute with the Smithsonian Institution. The plane is the first to fly under power with a man.

A major program to reduce and stabilize construction costs in the oil refinery steel and chemical industries through the advancement of labor-management relations has been forwarded, G. F. Bayes, president, revealed yesterday, following the first annual meeting of the National Constructors Association at the Biltmore Hotel.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- "Good" skiing at twenty-one New York centers was reported today by the State Commerce Department. "Fair" conditions were reported at two other centers.
John Holt of Christopher Columbus High School turned in a fine performance to take the honors in the mile run at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 13 -- An interdenominational Protestant radio commission will be formally organized in New York on March 17, the Rev. R. Roy G. Ross, general secretary of the International Council of Religious Education, said today, The council is holding its annual meeting here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Government has named some 2,750 oculists in its price- fixing suits against two large optical concerns. The suits contend the oculists and the concerns conspired to fix prices on eyeglasses and violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The largest volume of new financing that has been proposed in recent months was presented today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for clearance when four companies filed registration statements covering $75,000,000 of debentures, $10,000,000 of bonds and 20,250,000 shares of common stock.
BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- An economic administration for the Soviet zone, comparable to that of the bizonal area, was proclaimed today by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander in Germany.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Tuesday on an issue of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes dated Feb. 20 and due Oct. 15.

Once upon a time there was a Secretary of the Treasury who decided that it was not in keeping with the dignity of the fiscal department of the Government to issue an educational bulletin for the benefit of the syphilitics cared for by its Public Health Service.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- An appropriation of $7,000,000 for the expansion of the public libraries of the state, with $3,700,000 of this earmarked for New York City, was proposed today in identical bills introduced by Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic legislative leaders.

Failure to publicize changes, in and additions to, traffic regulations was cited yesterday as an outstanding cause of automobile accidents, at a meeting of the continuing committees of the Eastern States Highway and Motor Vehicle Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

De Witt Clinton's basketball team, city champion, moved into a tie for the lead in the Bronx Division of the P. S. A. L. by bringing an end to the William Howard Taft winning streak at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday.
Dr. A. B. Kinzel has been elected president of Union Carbide and Carbon Research Laboratories, Inc., it was announced yesterday by William J. Priestley, board chairman.

In writing a few weeks ago of a wholesale tea company in the city, we mentioned that its president was, to our knowledge, the only woman executive in the industry. But we were reckoning without Miss Gertrude H. Ford, who since 1909 has conducted the Gertrude H. Ford Tea Company, Inc., Peckham Road and Dutchess Turnpike, Poughkeepsie.
Freezing rain in many suburban sections glazed roads yesterday with ice that caused many accidents, made driving hazardous and hampered other means of transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Two of three witnesses before the Gray board today expressed doubt of the efficacy of universal military training compared to a vigorous, financially backed training program for the various military reserves already in existence.

The eighteenth annual masters individual contract bridge championships tournament opened last night at the Park Central Hotel. There are two sections in the event. One group of thirty-six players was selected from the life masters, players who have accumulated 250 or more master, points in championship events.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The State Tax Commission began mailing tonight the 1947 income tax forms that will go to 3,200,000 potential taxpayers, whose tax returns are due by April 15. Alger B. Chapman, president of the State Tax Commission, said it was "purely coincidental" that the first forms would be delivered on St. Valentine's Day.
A shy second-grader, 8 years old, a little owlish in spectacles, left two Valentines for teacher yesterday in the three-story red brick school on Fourteenth Avenue in Newark, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- An examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today to that body that it require Rockland Coaches, Inc., and the Spring Valley Motor Coaches Company, Inc., operating between New York and points in New Jersey and Rockland County, N. Y., be required to set up bus fares on the following bases:...

The grain markets attempted successive rallies yesterday, including a strong one in May corn, a futures contract that had been a leader in the grain price break of Feb. 4. But the contract, like the July one, closed off the 8-cent daily limit as liquidation overcame many sharp upturns in the day's grain trading.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 5 to 32 point net lower yesterday after fluctuating over a wide range.

After having been held by one family for nearly seventy-five years, the industrial block bounded by Thomson and Forty-seventh Avenues, Thirty-first Place and Van Dam Street, in Long Island City, has been sold.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 - The housewife's decision ultimately will determine the prices of meat, a convention of Western States meat packers was told here today by Albert T. Luer, president of the Luer Packing Company of Los Angeles.

Title to the six, six-story apartment houses at 217 to 227 East Sixty-sixth Street has been given by the Brindsley Realty Company, Julius B. Raynes, president, which sold the property recently to the New York Life Insurance Company. The houses are north of the old Third Avenue carbarn block which Joseph Day, Inc., sold at auction to the New York Life in November, 1947, for improvement with apartments for 595 families.

Seven-year-old Murray Green was recovering in Queens General Hospital yesterday after a week-long vigil at the side of his dead "granny," Mrs. Tilly Borman, 64 years old, who provided a foster home for the child.

Reporting on last year's operations of the General Baking Company, George L. Morrison, its president, informed stockholders in the annual statement mailed yesterday that dollar sales and items sold were the largest on record. Sales for 1947 of $103,439,444 were $24,450,000, or 31 per cent more than those of the year before.

Mrs. Mathilda Burling of 95-75 114th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, filed a counter suit in Supreme Court yesterday in her answer to an action by the American Gold Star Mothers of the World War, Inc., which sought to restrain her from representing herself as the "national president of the American Gold Star Mothers of the World Wars, Inc."

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Chinese Communist radio today broadcast a notice to the United States Navy western Pacific headquarters demanding complete withdrawal of United States forces from China as the price of safety for four United States marines held prisoner by the Communists since Christmas Day.

Mayor O'Dwyer, who had been at home since Wednesday afternoon because of a coronary heart condition, returned to harness yesterday afternoon and despite a cold drizzle made an inspection trip to Staten Island.

Tonight the foot-racing fraternity returns from Boston to Madison Square Garden to renew a matching of athletic endeavor that dates from the dawn of democracy. Indoor track and field games, however, are peculiarly American. During the winter, run-of-the-mile Europeans and even our own strictly outdoor competitors rarely show their normal form.

A further stiffening took place yesterday on the stock market despite erratic movements in the commodities, and final prices of securities were mixed with little change in either direction. There were contrary movements in several important industrials divisions which, brokers explained, was the usual reaction to any sharp price fluctuation.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 13 -- Warren Harding Hofmann, 24 years old, of Bayville, L. I., was brought from the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane to the Nassau County Jail here Tuesday to await arraignment on charges of attempting to assault Mrs. Bennett E. Meyers, it was learned today.

The Bowsteel Distributors Corporation of New York City has purchased a tract of six acres of land on Linden Avenue in Linden, N. J., for Improvement with a warehouse. The David T. Houston Company was the broker. Plans call for the construction of a building containing 20,000 square feet for the storage and warehousing of stainless and tool steel.

Combined net operating earnings of the seventy-four bank affiliates of the First Bank Stock Corporation for 1947, amounted to $5,989,795, against $6,234,031, the year before, according to the nineteenth annual report, issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- During the week ended Feb. 11, member bank reserve balances decreased $47,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) -- In defiant terms, Miss Vivien Kellems, Westport, Conn., industrialist, declared today she will no longer withhold Federal income taxes from her employes unless she is paid for it.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- A formula designed to break the deadlock between the economically developed and underdeveloped countries over use of import quotas and other quantitative restrictions on trade was submitted to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment tonight by three of the underdeveloped countries.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution in Washington, asserted tonight that the hallmark of a profession was "ministration to the people" and asked for patience in the development of engineering to that stature.

The Russian Government has issued another installment of its reply to the Nazi documents about the Stalin-Hitler alliance that plunged the world into the Second World War. If the first installment directed its fire mainly against the United States, the second is directed almost wholly against Britain and France and their role at Munich.

DES MOINES, Feb. 13 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall asserted tonight that the success or failure of the European Recovery Program would determine the survival of the kind of world in which democracy, individual liberty, economic stability and peace could be maintained.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 13 -- It became known today that German economic officials had requested in a memorandum that $400,000,000 be set aside for imports to get the bizonal economy going.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- With high praise from President Truman for his service in bringing about a settlement in Indonesia, Dr. Frank Porter Graham resigned today from the United Nations Security Council Committee of Good Offices on Indonesia. He will resume his duties as president of the University of North Carolina.

Frederick Brown has purchased the one-story taxpayer at 1287 North Avenue in the Wykagyl Gardens section of New Rochelle, N. Y., from Tradewell Foods, Inc., through John J. Meenan, Inc., broker. The property, on an irregular plot about 79 by 96 by 147 feet, contains two stores and is under lease for a ten-year term at $7,000 a year to Shopwell Foods, Inc.

LONDON. Feb. I3 -- The Science Museum, South Kensington, London, made known tonight that the Kitty Hawk, first powered aircraft to carry a man in sustained flight, will be returned to the United States from the museum. Museum authorities are awaiting instructions from Orville Wright's executors regarding the future home of the machine.
SENDAI, Japan, Feb. 13 -- Communist leaders in rural sections of Japan seem to have adopted the obstruction of occupation aims as their No. 1 objective, even ahead of instruction in party ideology.

Protestant Episcopal churches of New York will join with the churches of that communion all over the United States in observing tomorrow, the first Sunday in Lent, a "Churchwide Corporate Communion for the Peace of the World" in compliance with a call issued by the Right Rev. Henry K. Sherrill, Presiding Bishop, and concurred in by all the bishops.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- A preliminary contact was made in London today between British and French representatives on the question of a new meeting of the sixteen Marshall Plan nations.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 13 -- A fighting Middlebury team gained the lead today as the opening program of Dartmouth's thirty-eighth annual winter carnival was concluded in a raging snowstorm.

Protestant Episcopal churches of New York will join with the churches of that communion all over the United States in observing tomorrow, the first Sunday in Lent, a "Churchwide Corporate Communion for the Peace of the World" in compliance with a call issued by the Right Rev. Henry K. Sherrill, Presiding Bishop, and concurred in by all the bishops.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- A preliminary contact was made in London today between British and French representatives on the question of a new meeting of the sixteen Marshall Plan nations.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 13 -- A fighting Middlebury team gained the lead today as the opening program of Dartmouth's thirty-eighth annual winter carnival was concluded in a raging snowstorm.

Representative Ellsworth B. Buck has made an inspection tour of Bedloes Island. He finds, as others have found before him, that conditions around the site of the Statue of Liberty are disgraceful. He speaks of "inexcusable neglect," of squalor, of an environment for a revered shrine so demeaned that he would rather see the island closed to the public than to continue the present course.
MANILA, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Amnesty for more than 1,000 Filipinos charged with wartime treason, including top collaborators Jose P. Laurel and Jorge B. Vargas, was approved tonight by Congress.

The Columbia University Student Council will hold a referendum to get the reaction of the student body to the university's plans to increase tuition fees by one-third and raise room rents from 7 per cent to 17 per cent, beginning this Monday.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company is seeking to absorb the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York in a deal which would return about $12,500,000 to the latter's stockholders and transfer about $190,000,000 in resources to the Chemical Bank, it was learned yesterday.
J. G. Crost, former counsel of the Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives, has been appointed assistant to the president of Finch Telecommunications, Inc.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 13 -- A strike of photo engravers on this city's three daily newspapers was averted today when members of Local 24, Photo Engravers Union (AFL) voted to accept an $8.80 weekly wage increase offer.

A majority of the membership of the National Institute of Arts and Letters has opened a sharp attack on the House Committee on Un-American Activities and has called on Congress to remedy the procedure used by its investigating committees.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, came up today with pay demands against Chrysler Corporation exceeding 35 cents an hour.
" Bohemian Rapture," a romantic drama produced in Czechoslovakia and distributed here by Artkino Pictures, will have its first local showing today at the Stanley.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- In a resume of foreign affairs that left an impression of gloom despite expressions of hope, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault told the National Assembly today that the "division of the world into two blocs" had been accentuated ever since the Moscow conference last spring.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 -- Full and immediate inquiry was ordered tonight by Lieut. Gen. G. H. A. MacMillan, British commander in Palestine, into allegations that British troops last night handed over four Haganah youths to Arabs who murdered them.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Despite Sir Stafford Cripps' insistence in the House of Commons yesterday that there must be an over-all reduction in profits and dividends, the fact that he made no concrete proposals for such limitation caused the stock markets here today to open on a decidedly cheerful note.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council today reaffirmed its previous decision to hold its next session this summer in Geneva, rejecting by 8 votes to 7 a British proposal to return the scheduled meeting place to Lake Success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A bipartisan movement was under way in the Senate today to attempt an important revision of the Legislative Reorganization Act with the objective of improving the present system of drafting Congress' own estimates of Federal expenditures and receipts. Republican leaders of the Senate and House have informally agreed that the procedure must be changed if the so-called "legislative budget" is to mean anything.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Robert Grant 3d, national open racquets champion, defeated W. W. Chipman, Canadian star, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 6, in the second round of the Tuxedo Gold racquets tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

PREMIER REYNAUD, just before leaving Paris with his Government a few hours after Mussolini declared war, cabled a dramatic appeal to President Roosevelt to declare publicly that the United States would support the Allies by all means short of an expeditionary force.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The text of Secretary Marshall's speech tonight on the European Recovery Program follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The State Banking Department announced today it has approved a certificate of increase of capital stock of the Bank of Athens Trust Company, j205 West Thirty-third Street, from $650,000, consisting of 65,000 shares of a par value of $10 to $700,000, consisting of 70,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A nation-wide program to strengthen American democracy through the classroom and alert the country's 32,000,000 students to the dangers of Communism and Fascism has been undertaken by the United States Office of Education.

LONDON, Feb., 13 -- Backtracking by the Soviet delegation again snarled the deliberations of the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers today on the future of the former Italian colonies in Africa.
The Greater New York Chapter of the American Red Cross drew up final plans for its 1948 campaign to raise $6,036,000 at a "general mobilization" luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Several thousand persons watched a five-alarm fire late last night and early today that swept a four-store loft building at 451-53 East 147th Street, the Bronx, and spread to two buildings in the rear at 448 and 450 East 148th Street. The blaze, which was punctuated by muffled explosions within the building, sent smoke and flames several hundred feet into the air.

WARSAW, Feb. 13 -- The Polish Government considers recent Polish language broadcasts of the "Voice of America," particularly those quoting from articles by ex-Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, as interference in Polish internal affairs and an "unfriendly gesture" on the part of the United States Government, Brig. Gen. Wiktor Grosz said today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Philip Noel-Baker, British diplomat and a former Olympic star, sees a big season ahead for Britain in the Olympics at London this summer.

SENDAI, Japan, Feb. 14 -- For the first time since the surrender, the Japanese Government this year, according to every indication, is about to obtain 100 per cent of the foodstuffs demanded from the farmer at low, fixed prices in order to issue lowcost rations to hungry cities.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 14 -- Despite the price breaks in the grain and other commodity markets, there is no evidence of pessimism among midwestern farmers. The declines, they contend, had been due for eighteen months.

Playing without the services of the injured Joe Fulks, their high scoring ace, the Philadelphia Warriors were seldom in the running last night as they went down to a 78-to-47 defeat at the hands of the Knickerbockers in a Basketball Association of America game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Air Force and the Army Signal Corps announced today the development of a facsimile service for the transmission of weather maps which, for the first time, puts at the disposal of ground force and flight personnel, factual and up-to-the-minute weather data in the form of a map that requires no further plotting.

The recent drop in food prices is not sufficient to relieve the stresses caused by the cost of living, according to junior high school pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

NEW ORLEANS -- Last week's Mardi Gras was not the coldest carnival day New Orleans has experienced, though 35 degrees was cold enough, but it was, by all accounts, the biggest Mardi Gras in history. More out-of-town visitors came to town.

LOGAN, Utah, Feb. 14 -- Western farmers and ranchers are banding together to ward off dustbowl conditions, which they fear may endanger their holdings. Over-planting of wheat, disregard of proved practices such as contour plowing, and refusal by some farmers and "suitcase operators" to cooperate with conservation experts have been causing considerable worry at such institutions as the Utah State Agricultural College here in Logan.
POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON announced last week that six special stamps would be issued before the end of 1948, but information about denominations, colors and designs was withheld.

DENVER, Feb. 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, in a presentation of his views on national defense, reiterated tonight his opposition to universal military training, as proposed by the Administration, and called for an air force capable of giving us complete control of the air as our principal defensive weapon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A selling move which got under way late in the session in corn wiped out early gains for that grain on the Board of Trade today. Wheat and oats retreated from high marks made earlier but held much better than corn.

I READ with great interest Mr. Downes' article about money and music, and thought your readers would be interested in a detailed report of how city support of a symphony orchestra works in Indianapolis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Government has protested against the United States, British and French conference on long-range economic plans for Germany in London next week.

THIS history of Canada as a whole, by Prof. A. R. M. Lower, of the University of Manitoba, is a contribution, and an important one, to the movement which has sprung up in the country to develop a consciousness of a common Canadianism among all its racial groups.

THE radio was playing an old record of Frank Sinatra's when the fuse blew out. There was no warning. The room just went dark, and the mahogany box over in the corner fell silent. In 1948, of all things, there was a house without a radio.
Turbulent flood waters from rain and snow - swollen rivers surged in eight states yesterday, taking at least seven lives. This increased to sixteen the death toll of a two-day attack by the elements.

A LETTER from Fritz Stiedry, who has completed the musical direction of his first "Ring" cycle at the Metropolitan, is of timely interest as retailing the first-hand experiences of experienced conductors of Wagner and many other operas with the vexing problems of "tempo" in interpretation.

ROY HARRIS, the one-time Oklahoma farm boy who gave up chickens for music, was 50 on Lincoln's Birthday and it takes him less than five seconds to tell you what he considers the main achievement of his first half century.

With no Gilbert Dodds around to hog the headlines, the milers were pushed into the background last night at the annual indoor games of the New York Athletic Club. However, there were plenty of other heroes to take up the slack and give a crowd of 13,000 at Madison Square Garden its quota of thrills.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Abolition of closed shop contracts in the building and construction industry will cost the government $1,000,000 to $1,500,000, official sources estimated today. Contractors and unions will have to spend additional sums.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- Gennaro Cardinal Granito Pignatelli di Belmonte, 96-year-old dean of the Sacred College of Cardinals, was said by Vatican circles this evening to be in a serious condition. He is suffering from a kidney ailment.

Dr. Ernest O. Melby, dean of the New York University School of Education, warned yesterday that, unless America's educators "take the lead" in teaching the youth of the United States the virtues of freedom, world democracy would be lost.

Indications that some manufacturers of industrial materials, worried about commodity trends, are pushing large scale deliveries ahead of schedule, were revealed in a canvass of leading purchasing executives here yesterday.

KETCHUM, Idaho -- This is the one town in the nation where winter-sports enthusiasts can step nonchalantly from a dog-sled, imbibe such tasty Basque dishes as arroz con polo, chorizos or patatas en salsa verde, and then, well fortified against the Idaho climate, listen to the clanking of silver dollars in a slot machine, watch a spinning roulette wheel or follow the antics of expertly rolled dice.

Mayor O'Dwyer, pointing out that more than 40 per cent of all deaths in New York City in 1947 were caused by diseases of the heart and circulation, yesterday called upon citizens, schools, churches, scientific bodies, civic associations and business establishments to observe this week as National Heart Week.

The United Nations Security Council this week will take up one of the most potentially explosive questions it has ever faced -- the question of an international army to enforce the partition of Palestine. The outcome of the debate will have great bearing not only on the future of Palestine but on the future of the world organization itself.

FOR a long time there has been weeping and wailing in these parts because the younger and less known dramatists were not being given the breaks, and loudest in the doleful chorus has been the voice of your correspondent. Nor does he yet feel that the time for lamenting is over.

With the completion of the final volume of its far-reaching report the President's Commission on Higher Education has outlined a significant program for American colleges and universities of the future. Many sweeping reforms are suggested to strengthen the role of higher education in our democracy.

THE curtain is brought down so quickly that no one in the audience is aware that Lilith (the Bosom) Devine, star of the burlesque show, has been killed -- no one, that is, excepting Sam Phelan, the best detective on the police force, according to Chief Jones.

DUBLIN, Feb. 14 -- The net result of the general election just held in Eire is to return a new Dail without the over-all majority Prime Minister Eamon de Valera sought. He will have only sixty-eight seats as against the seventy-six he held in the last Dail.

THIS week's note on Truman Capote would say that, while not all the returns are in, enough newspaper reviews of his "Other Voices, Other Rooms" have arrived to indicate that Mr. Capote reminds the reviewers of a lot of other authors.
The New York State Legislature has now an opportunity to undo a legislative blunder made nearly a year ago. And there are reasons to believe that Governor Dewey will not disfavor the undoing.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Assault made it, but Armed didn't. After the King Ranch's 5-year-old had staged a triumphant return to the races in a seven-furlong dash at Hialeah Park today, Armed, the Calumet Farm's "horse of the year" in 1947, ran third in the once-around-the-track McLennan Handicap.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Winston Churchill, Conservative party leader, called upon all Britons tonight to cooperate in increasing the nation's productive capacity and exporting power "by every possible means."

The first outdoor sculpture show in New York since 1942 will be held early this spring. On Friday, the Sculptors Guild, now ten years old, will celebrate its anniversary with a party in the Colonnades Room of Essex House to raise funds for the exhibition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Illinois manufacturers, business leaders in Chicago, officials of big mail order houses, grocers and other retailers, and even the farmers of the Central West apparently believe that the sharp downward trend of security and commodity market prices in the last eleven days will make for a healthier national economy.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 14 -The solid black miniature poodle, champion Ensarr Salute, belonging to Mrs. W. French Githens of Bernardsville, N. J., got best in show tonight in the nineteenth fixture of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard.

The European Recovery Program took a long step forward on Friday when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously for an initial appropriation and a four-year authorization. Friends of ERP need not be concerned over such changes as were suggested by the committee under Senator Vandenberg's skillful guidance.

THERE is no dichotomy in the title of William Martin Camp's "San Francisco: Port of Gold." The city, sea-born, with brine in her veins and the snuff of ocean forever in her nostrils, and the landlocked harbor have been one for a hundred years.

Five New York newspaper women were honored yesterday for outstanding work last year, both here and abroad, at the thirteenth annual luncheon of the New York Newspaper Women's Club in the Biltmore Hotel.

SALT HARBOR. THE way people around New York City have been carrying on -- a reported here by radio news broadcasts and by The Manbury Evening Messenger -- about their hardships this winter has met with mixed reaction in Salt Harbor, which is widely esteemed as a summer resort. One extreme is the high-decibel derision of Captain Sylvanus Emery; the other is the deep solicitousness of Emma Ella Edmunds.

An exciting surprise marked last nights session of the life master section of the masters individual contract bridge championship tournament being conducted by the American Contract Bridge League at the Park Central Hotel, when Mrs. Albert Shmukler of Philadelphia took the lead with 386 points.

ALTHOUGH the good earth is buried beneath tons of snow, seeds can be sown now for the outdoor garden. In the home greenhouse, or even on a sunny windowsill, vegetables and flowers started soon will be weeks ahead of any that wait until the ground thaws.

MR. SYLVESTER'S first novel, "Dream Street," was the result of two decades of active leg-work, as a theatrical columnist in Broadway and its environs; in it he captured (and skinned alive) assorted sharks and pilot fish from those chill canyons, achieving a chamber of horrors of sorts.

A new lease on life for many victims of coronary thrombosis, one of the deadliest and most widespread diseases of the heart, is promised by dicumarol, a drug made from spoiled sweet clover. Dr. Karl Paul Link, professor of biochemistry at the Wisconsin Agricultural Experiment Station, University of Wisconson, discussed this remedy at the meeting of the Northeastern section of the American Chemical Society on Feb. 12.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 -- As thirty visiting Americans here on a mission for the United Jewish Appeal toured a basic training depot of Haganah, Zionist defense organization, on the hilly outskirts of Jerusalem today, desultory fire from Arab snipers echoed across the rock-strewn area.
There have been quite a few articles of late on the subject of folk music becoming overpopularized, commercialized and altered.
SO far as can be determined, no encyclopedia or guidebook has yet appeared with an entry like this:

Just as there are many types of pneumonia so are there many types of influenza. The commonest of the influenza types are designated by the letters "A" and "B." Tens of thousands of Americans have been vaccinated this winter with prepared viruses of "A" and "B," largely as the result of Army experience during the war and the findings of the Commission on Influenza of the Army Epidemiological Board.
WASHINGTON. STRANGERS who wander into the funeral-parlor atmosphere of the House Appropriations Committee have been startled by a foghorn voice emerging from the inner sanctum:

NO novelist, of course, can get very far in the delineation of character without the gift of imagination. But his possession of that quality lays pitfalls for him too. That was a wise and suggestive observation of Somerset Maugham in "The Summing Up" when he remarked that "Much pessimism is caused by ascribing to others the feelings you would have if you were in their place."

Sam Pope Brewer has been assigned to cover a spot which is being allowed to become another Spanish battleground, yet (in "Jerusalem Diary: Notes of a Tense Week") he seems chiefly concerned with the lack of good restaurants.

Industrial plant expansions are being pushed to completion despite major price declines in commodity markets, New York consulting engineers and contractors revealed here yesterday. Furthermore, a canvass of leading companies revealed that in seven out of eight fields demand for new contracts for large-scale industrial plant expansions continues strong and no cutbacks or cancellations are reported or expected.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 14 -- The International Council of Religious Education today became the first major church organization to take official action toward establishing headquarters in a proposed national Protestant center at Columbus, Ohio.
SALONIKA, Greece, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A delegate to the United Nations Special Balkans Committee said today he believed the shelling of Salonika was intended as a signal for a rebel uprising in the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Administrator of the Federal Security Agency, announced today that in response to a request from President Truman he is calling a national health assembly May 1 to 4 to set up national health goals for ten years.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 14 -- In an uneasy political atmosphere, Paraguay's Presidential election tomorrow will elevate Finance Minister J. Natalicio Gonzalez to President-elect. He is the only candiate on the ballot.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 -- The Dartmouth hockey team routed Yale University, 9 -- 4, today before a capacity Winter Carnival gathering.

MACK SENNETT, the sultan of cinema slapstick, sat in his old-fashioned room at the Garden Court Apartments on Hollywood Boulevard eating an apple. On a side table near his chair lay a playbill from the Broadway musical comedy success, "High Button Shoes," which features a hilarious ten-minute Mack Sennett ballet, replete with period bathing beauties, Keystone Kops, mad children and a gorilla.

A fire yesterday afternoon in a five-story warehouse at 52 West Fifteenth Street, connecting with the Hecht Department Store on Fourteenth Street, damaged merchandise and closed the store for the day.

WHAT is the measure of genius? How does a man, a foreigner, visit a strange country, spend there a small space of time, talk with its people, study its history, its geography, its literature, sort out his impressions, ponder them, and then, after arranging his thoughts into a coherent whole, set them down on paper, lucidly and with a dry humor and insight that penetrates with the sureness and swiftness of a surgeon's knife?

MIAMI -- The word paradox probably would best describe the 1947-48 South Florida winter season, supposedly now at its height. Various travel barometers indicate that it's about as good as ever before, but still it doesn't measure quite up to par.

As the American Red Cross makes ready its annual campaign, which seeks to raise $75,000,000 this year, it is appropriate to take stock of its services in 1947 and to examine the needs ahead. The past year was unusual in its demands for disaster relief. Nearly $12,000,000 was spent, which was the largest sum so used in a decade.

HAVING acquired considerable prestige and also a comfortable debt-load with Barrie Stavis' "Lamp at Midnight," the New Stages troupe has come up with a singularly trenchant melodrama. It is Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute," which opened in Bleecker Street last Monday evening.

MADRID, Feb. 14 -- The terse announcement today that Foreign Minister Martin Artajo had talked to the Cabinet last night on Arab activities as they affected Spain was one of many indications this week that the Government was becoming somewhat concerned with the possibility of the Nationalist problem in Spanish Morocco.
KATHARINE CORNELL is celebrating tomorrow her fiftieth birthday, a career of thirty-one years on the stage, and seventeen years as a successful actress-manager.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- A Moscow radio English-language commentator, who calls himself "Analyzer," said today that reports of the current United States markets reminded him of the 1929 crash.

SISTER MADALEVA is one of a number of nuns who have won a faithful public by their gentle and pious verses. There is little doubt that she is the most distinguished of them, and by collecting her books Macmillan has paid a tribute to her gifts and to the loyalty of her public.
General Dwight D. Eisenhower has won another victory and Lou Little will remain as Columbia's football coach.

FROM Cicero and Fronto, through Mme. de Sevigne and Gray and Horace Walpole, Charles Lamb and Byron and Dickens, the great letter writers have given more pleasure and, perhaps, more insight to their readers than any other type of author save the great novelist and the poet.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Feb. 14 -- Manilal Gandhi, son of Mohandas K. Gandhi and three other prominent Indians were charged today with aiding and abetting passive resisters in violating the immigration regulations by crossing the Natal border into Transvaal without permits.

To those concerned with administering the nation's elementary and secondary schools, report cards have long been a source of difficulty. While it is generally agreed that school reports need improvement, educators have been divided as to how this can be accomplished.

The crowd that thronged all four floors of Grand Central Palace yesterday for the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show was not as large as the first-day gathering of last year, but if anything it was more enthusiastic over the thousands of hunting and fishing items and the elaborate state and provincial displays.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The All-America Football Conference, opening its winter meeting today, re-hired Jonas Ingram as commissioner, named Quarterback Otto Graham of the champion Cleveland Browns the most valuable 1947 player and handed a pleasant welcome to new Coach Ed McKeever of the Chicago Rockets.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The benefits of the withdrawal of 5,000-franc banknotes will be limited mainly to sums that will be paid off in taxes or state loans.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- The United States and British Military Governors agreed today to permit the Germans to manufacture virgin aluminum, although the Potsdam treaty expressly prohibits its production.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- From all indications, the District of Columbia may soon find itself responsible for its own government.
The New York Infirmary will be the beneficiary of the Manet Loan Exhibition in the Wildenstein Gallery at 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, which will open on Feb. 25 with an invitation preview.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Secretary of State Marshall informed Congressional questioners in a letter, made public today, that it was impossible at this time to say what the United States was prepared to do to help enforce the partitioning of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Navy is altering its submarines to put them ahead of those which the Germans perfected at the end of World War II, plans for which are in the hands of the Soviet Union, it was announced today.

Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer and "economic czar," last week gave the British people a picture of how they were making out in their battle for a stable economy. There were bright spots in the picture, but on the whole it was dark.

IN the cinema, the well-oiled projection machine has turned "The show must go on" from a rallying cry into a mechanical banality. But after a ten-year absence Henry Fonda is acting again in the hardy medium where an interviewer may have to catch him between penicillin shots.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 14 -- With another heavy campaign year coming up, the South's notorious hooded order, the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, is again on the march with hopes of electing the Governor of Georgia and capturing as many minor offices as possible.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Almost 400 delegates representing Presbyterian laymen from forty-eight states, the District of Columbia and five foreign countries today formed the National Council of Presbyterian Men. This new group will aim to affiliate the demonination's men's organizations, brotherhoods, fellowships and Bible classes in more than 1,500 churches.

Frederick Polnauer, violinist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. A scientist, as well as a musician, Mr. Polnauer is a pioneer in the application of biomechanics to the playing of musical instruments, whereby a minimum amount of physical effort may be expended in performance.

The Rev. John H. Johnson, Police Department chaplain and chairman of a special committee that has been looking into charges of brutality made by Negro organizations against the Police Department, denied yesterday that his committee's delay in reporting was due to an effort to choke off investigations.
