A comprehensive collection of Kipling first editions will be offered at auction on Tuesday and Wednesday in a sale of books from the estate of the late Elizabeth V. King of Goldens Bridge, N. Y., and other owners at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- This week's collapse of the livestock markets was the worst in the eighty-three-year history of the Chicago Stock Yards, a comparison of values disclosed today. The general level of meat animal prices for the six days averaged $2.15 under the average of all kinds the week previous.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- In its first dual meet of the season, Yale overwhelmed the Princeton track team, 83 -- 26, in the Coxe Memorial Cage today.

AS Janet Lambert's books tell about the traditions which surround the life of an Army "brat" (a youngster whose father is regular Army) so "Anchor for Her Heart" tells the story of Joan Andrews, pretty 16-year-old whose father is an officer in the United States Navy.

THIS week the "spring" season breaks upon us in force, with the Ballet Russe settling down for four weeks at the City Center tonight, and Martha Graham and her company moving into Maxine Elliott's Theatre on Tuesday for two weeks.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Dewey's Committee on the State Educational Program made public today figures prepared by the State Education Department showing that the central school districts of the state would gain $4,936,510 in state aid under the revised Friedsam formula recommended by the committee.

THE author's thesis is that the root cause of our economic, political and social ills is the machine. The machine spawned big business, which in turn has been responsible for overconcentration in industry, agriculture and labor unions.

THE Camera Magazine celebrates its fiftieth anniversary with the March issue, just out. Originally the house organ of the Columbia Photographic Society, The Camera began publication in Philadelphia in March, 1899, with Frank V. Chambers as publisher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- By its action this week, the Justice Department took a momentous step toward judicial clarification of one of the Taft-Hartley law's most controversial features, the ban against political expenditures by unions.

FRANKLIN, N. J., Feb. 14 -Hysterically sobbing, "I love her, I didn't mean to hurt her," Marion Russo, 15 years old, was accused formally today of killing her mother, Mrs. Lillian Russo, 35, in a bitter fight Friday evening in the cellar of their home here.
The Securities and Exchange Commission last week found in its lap the following questions:

There seems to be a healthful trend toward more walking for recreation. It may be that as time goes on we shall learn to use leisure time for leisurely pursuits. This is not to say that crowded ball parks, massive stadia filled with roaring humanity and radio comedians who suffer barbed gibes for a few thousand per week have not earned a place in the contemporary scene.
CARACAS, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Special diplomatic missions from thirty-seven countries presented their credentials to the Foreign Ministry today for tomorrow's inauguration of President-elect Gallegos.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Leaders of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg agree in taking a skeptical attitude toward British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin's proposal for some kind of Western European union and toward the British-French suggestion made to the Benelux countries at the same time, it may be said on the best of authority.

The American economy is a sensitive mechanism. A shock in any large element of it can set up chain reactions affecting all other elements. Thus whenever such a shock occurs there is posed a test for the whole economy.

THE experts were hard at it last week trying to decide whether the country's problem is now deflation instead of inflation. President Truman appeared to think at his press conference that it is still inflation while his Treasury Secretary Mr. Snyder was not ready to accept the new trend as positive one way or the other.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Oct. 16, General de Gaulle's program was carried by a landslide in the French municipal elections. If Parliamentary elections had been held at that time, the experts claim the National Assembly would have reflected that landslide. Immediately, a new stop de Gaulle movement began in France. The machine called itself the Third Force. The Third Force has found an echo abroad.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- The Government this evening denied a statement attributed by some newspapers to "a Ministry of Interior spokesman" to the effect that the general election scheduled for April 18 will be postponed "if the Communists do not follow the rules of the democratic game."

AJACCIO, Corsica, Feb. 14 --United States lard went on sale here the other day for about 105 francs a pound and black market lard operators were forced to cut their prices by half to meet the competition.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has won a month's breathing spell for Britain in her desperate fight against inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) plans to intensify its efforts to remove obstacles to press, radio and other means of spreading ideas and information.

Ignacio Aguirre -- Artists Gallery -- Mexican landscape and incidents from village life that catch something of the primitive character and discouraged stoicism of the peasants, in flat, understated, mural forms.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: "Henry Adams," a brief biography by James Truslow Adams, took the spotlight -- which spot found the reviewer a little melancholy because, believing that "The Education" was the main document, he had to write: "No biographer can hope to compete with that."

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- Tourists who enjoy leisurely voyages aboard small boats in tropical waters now have an opportunity to sail aboard freighters plying between Trinidad and Jamaica. The 1,000-mile trip takes about five days, and the rate varies from $80 to $100 a person for first-class accommodations.

Prices of shares drifted narrowly in yesterday's short session on the Stock Exchange and prices at the close were irregularly higher after the dullest session since last November. Sales dropped to 280,000 shares, the smallest number since Nov. 4 last, compared with 330,000 shares the previous Saturday.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 14 -Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago shot into the lead in the $10,000 Lower Rio Grande Valley open golf tournament today as two pros exchanged blows and the head of the P. G. A. rules committee quit in a huff.

Two 1947 champions repeated and one was dethroned yesterday at Columbia's South Field in the outdoor field events of the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior track championships, postponed from last month. On the basis of the results, the New York Athletic Club won the district team title, for the first time since the war.

LEE SHIPPEY became a self-made Californian twenty-seven years ago. As is the case with most converts, he has shamed most native sons with the unflagging fervor with which he has tried to show other heathens the true light.

The Association on American Indian Affairs, Inc., 48 East Eighty-sixth Street, denounced yesterday proposed Federal legislation that would authorize the lease of salmon sites in Alaskan waters as a move that "will pauperize the peoples of Alaska to bloat the profits of an absentee salmon monopoly."

The European Recovery Plan last week cleared its first major hurdle. On Friday an ERP bill received the virtual approval of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, subject only to final review on Tuesday. The bill that will be reported out differs from the measure requested by the President in three principal categories: (1) amount; (2) administration; (3) conditions of aid.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Pravda, Communist party newspaper, printed four columns of praise today from musicians, writers and workers hailing the party's program to drown out "bourgeois" music.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment which opened here Nov. 21 has entered its decisive stage. It should soon be possible to tell whether this far-reaching project to put a solid economic foundation under the United Nations structure will end in success or failure.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Winston Churchill called again today for a general election in Britain and the elimination of all but the most essential government controls.

Despite the deflationary implications of the continuing decline in the commodities market, banking leaders are aggressively promoting their anti-inflationary program. Formally announced early last month as an organized activity under the direction of the American Bankers Association, the series of "pilot meetings" in key financial centers throughout the country is going forward with little reference to the break in commodities.

IMPROVED vision which blends in with advanced styling is an outstanding feature of the Futuramic "98" series of cars announced by Oldsmobile. By the use of curved glass and new design, the windshield and rear window areas are expanded about 45 per cent. In these days of crowded highways this "extended look" is an important safety factor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Dr. Alexander Wetmore, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, was appointed by President Truman today chairman of the Interdepartmental Committee on Research and Development which he established by executive order in December.

The "Gray Committee," appointed by Secretary of Defense James Forrestal to study the "civilian components" of the armed forces, commenced hearings last week that may lead to reorganization of the National Guard and Organized Reserves and that will certainly induce verbal fireworks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A country-wide system of civilian defense intended to filter "the fantastic from the practical" is being sought by the National Military Establishment, Secretary of defense James Forrestal said today. An interim organization will be set up, he said, as soon as he can find the man to head it.

A COURSE in camera mechanics and repair the only one of its kind in a recognized American photographic school, is included in the curriculum of the Progressive School of Photography, 217 Park Street, New Haven 11. Intended for students with an aptitude for mechanics, who wish to qualify for a career in this field, the course takes 375 hours spread over fifteen weeks.

HAMAR, Norway, Feb. 14 (AP) -A pair of U. S. speed skaters tied for first place in the 500-meter (547-yard) sprint in the European championships today. But Americans could no no better than fourteenth place in the 5,000-meter (3 1/8 mile) marathon.

NOT many American readers are familiar with the simple, pastoral life of village and farm that once existed in Eastern Europe and serves as the setting for "In My Father's Pastures." That is another reason, in addition to the interest of the story and the excellence of the writing, why many Americans would do well to read this book.

THROUGHOUT America museum directors, acting as impresarios, are busily staging their own exhibitions. Independent of the big annuals, which are little more than road shows from Fifty-seventh Street, and the packaged traveling exhibits, these original enterprises are the ones which have box-office appeal, form the special personality of each institution and develop a general awareness of art.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 14 -- Pleading for the unity of all communities as the most fitting memorial to Mohandas K. Gandhi, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, denied in a broadcast tonight the strongly rumored rift between himself and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister and Jai Prakash Narain, Socialist leader.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Columbia's Lions stayed on top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by defeating Cornell, 40 -- 37, in a slam-bang game before 8,000 tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- The Household Finance Corporation in 1947 made 1,362,225 loans for a total of $295,379,682, the largest amount for a year in its history, B. E. Henderson, president, reported today in his annual report to stockholders.
With a moderate volume of business, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, closed yesterday 42 to 53 points net higher than on Friday.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 14 -In a game that furnished several surprises, Army's basketball team today overwhelmed Fordham, 85 to 57, in its most impressive performance of the season.

Great warriors in America have often been considered Presidential timber. Some rejected, others seized, the idea, successfully or otherwise. Here are portraits of six men of war, with an utterance by each about the Presidency. Can you identify them and their words? Answers below.

ONE of the most heartening promises of post-war progress in the dance world is the reorganization of what used to be the Bennington Festival and the Bennington School of the Dance, directed from 1934 to 1942 (until the war put an end to it) at Bennington College by Martha Hill and Mary Josephine Shelly.

The Lawrence Scientific School was liquidated more than forty years ago. Nevertheless Harvard has just celebrated not the hundredth but the hundred-and-first anniversary of the defunct school. In a felicitous commemorative address President Conant of Harvard had no difficulty in explaining these two anomalies.

IT is indicative of Kay Boyle's approach in this short novel that one of its most dramatic moments is not based on fact but is an internal staging of a conscience-prompted vision. It is 1939, and Ferdl, a young Austrian living in France, is on the verge of renouncing his national identity to fight the war as a Frenchman and human being.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 14 -- Despite the furor in Southern Democratic ranks in recent months over Federal Administration and court moves to strengthen Negro civil rights, there is nothing to indicate that the Negro has yet become a solid political power in Dixie.

THE man from Mars, sitting in the kibitzer's seat at an American bridge game, would no doubt be puzzled by the fact that "everybody plays the same system" and yet there are constant disagreements about the meanings of seemingly simple bids.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The New York State Fair Commission recommended to Governor Dewey and the Legislature today the creation of a public benefit corporation to manage a greatly expanded state exposition near Syracuse, representing all phases of the state's economic and cultural life.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- St. John's of Brooklyn, on the short end of a 15-1 count in the early moments, came back to win a 41-38 basketball decision over Canisius tonight before a Memorial Auditorium double - header crowd of 9,059.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- An attitude of caution mixed with a remarkable degree of optimism was displayed by business men in this area as they watched prices tumble on the commodity markets this week.

ATHENS, Feb. 14 -- Reports today from Levadia, in Boetia, about fifty miles northwest of Athens between Thebes and Lamia, said that fifteen citizens had been carried off by an armed Communist group that attacked the town yesterday.

NANKING, Feb. 14 -- The center of the fighting south of Mukden shifted today to Anshan, Manchurian steel city, where two Communist columns are attacking. The garrison was cut off by the recent Communist capture of Liaoyang, thirty-five miles southwest of Mukden.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 14 -Talon, dappled gray from Argentina, swept to victory in the $50,000 added San Antonio Handicap today and emerged as a powerful threat for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 28.
New uses for old chemical compounds are being uncovered in experiments sponsored by the National Research Council's Chemical-Biological Coordination Center, it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -Attorney General Tom C. Clark said tonight that Communists were seeking converts among American children -- "the younger, the better."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The continued downward trend of the commodity markets this week was being treated cautiously by all except consumers. They were enjoying it despite the uncertainty of economists, officials and business men as to whether it was the harbinger of a recession or merely a healthy adjustment of a bloated condition.

WHETHER or not you hanker after the kind of occult speculation Pamela Kellino deals with you will have to admit she has written a highly ingenious novel. The author, if you don't already know, is the wife of James Mason, the actor, and an actress in her own right.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- The Boston Bruins gained a firmer grip on the National Hockey League's fourth and last play-off berth by deadlocking the third-place New York Rangers, 4 to 4, tonight before a crowd of 12,900 at the Boston Garden.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Clarence C. Pell Jr. of New York defeated Robert Grant 3d, former national amateur racquets champion, in three out of four games today in the semi-final round of the Tuxedo Gold Racquet Tournament at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

The first test of the strength of Henry A. Wallace, third-party candidate for President and of the American Labor party, which is supporting him, will take place Tuesday at a special election in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District to fill the vacancy in the House of Representatives caused by the resignation of Benjamin J. Rabin on his election as Supreme Court Justice.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have read with a great deal of interest a letter written by Charles D. Hyson, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 1, and in which Mr. Hyson discussed the grain and meat situation.

DESPITE a paucity of imports, which is not unexpected in view of world food supplies, there should be cheese enough in 1948 to permit our savoring at least as much as we did in the last year before the war, and probably a bit more.

INDEPENDENCE is normally achieved when, for one thing, we rid ourselves of logophobia, the irrational fear of words. Every epoch in history, every stage of personal development, every school and coterie has its own little dictionary of depreciation, list of words to be used as missiles to terrify the timid; and hold the loyal in line: bourgeois, old-fashioned, modernist, fascist, heretic, reactionary, unscholarly, superficial, unscientific, authoritarian, radical and the rest.

IT is not the fault of our novelists if Military Government in Germany has failed in its mission. Their books remind us that brass hats, directives, channels and other occupational diseases of the Army life have not vanished with victory.

A TRIUMPHANT graduate of The New Yorker, Time, the Newspaper PM, and World War II, Ralph Ingersoll, casting about for new worlds to conquer, has turned novelist. Well, "novelist" may be rather a sweeping term to apply to the creator of "The Great Ones," but if we start splitting hairs we'll get nowhere.

THE name of Frank O'Connor is too little known to readers of contemporary fiction in this country. He is without doubt the most talented, versatile and prolific writer living in Ireland today. No better book than "Guests of the Nation," his first, published more than twenty years ago, has been written on the Troubles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Twenty-eight reporters, radio men and cameramen will accompany President Truman on his Caribbean trip next week.

LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -Mighty Arsenal, English league leader since the season opened, took a long step toward clinching the championship today when it handed second-place Burnley a 3-0 setback. The victory gave the Gunners an eight-point lead with only thirteen games remaining on the schedule.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 -- The Arab League meeting that has been going on since last Sunday is to be adjourned in a day or two with few concrete results achieved. There are still no agreements on the formation of an Arab Palestine government or on Britain's plan for a collective military alliance with Arab states.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 -- A fighting Big Green team made a remarkable but futile comeback in relinquishing its honors by the slim margin of two-tenths of a point -the smallest in the games' thirty-eight-year history -- to Middlebury's Panthers as the annual
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Russia said tonight that she had been forced to sign a non-aggression treaty with Germany in 1939 in a fight against time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- There was a definite leveling off of business activity during the past week. The entire district stood only 1 per cent above the same period last year as a result of slight gains in the Los Angeles and San Francisco areas.

ONE of the finest single disks to come along in months has Rose Bampton singing Marguerite's romance D'Amour l'ardente flamme, from the fourth act of Berlioz' The Damnation of Faust (Victor). Here is music of touching simplicity and ardor, wedded to an orchestral background of imagination and originality.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Department stores last week in this district reported a four weeks' gain of 6 per cent over the like 1947 period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 115,856 as against 128,541 a year ago, a decrease of 9.9 per cent, and for 1948 to date totaled 699,006 to compare with 794,009 last year, a decrease of 12 per cent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Domestic supply and demand in the construction equipment industry have about balanced, but the potential foreign demand resulting from the Marshall Plan may change the picture radically, according to W. A. Danner of Boston, president of the Associated Equipment Distributors, and J. H. How of San Francisco, general manager of the Edward R. Bacon Company.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 14 -- India's first reaction to Mohandas K. Gandhi's assassination, after the initial hours of stupefied horror at the loss of its leader and idol, was a drastic purge of the secret and semi-secret societies which had become a sinister influence in the life of the newly freed nation.

Three players, whose combined ages total only 70 years, have signed their Brooklyln Dodger contracts, it was announced yesterday, and, considering the extreme accent on youtl. President Branch Rickey has placed on his 1948 club, a may wind up as regulars for Lippy Leo Durocher.

IT IS proof of the persuasiveness of Lincoln's thought and the sinewy power of his prose that his writings and speeches continue to interest readers -- and attract editors and publishers to new feats of rearrangement and repitition.

VIENNA, Feb. 14 -- The whole oil picture in Austria, the background of the Austrian treaty negotiations, have been changed by the discovery that the Russians have been secretly constructing a cracking and hydroforming plant in Moosbierbaum in their zone.

The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that Elmer H. Bobst of Montclair, N. J., an industrialist who headed the society's $12,000,000 campaign last year, had accepted reappointment as national campaign chairman for the 1948 drive.

FIVE operas, Gluck's "Orpheus," Beethoven's "Fidelio" and Mozart's "Magic Flute," "Abduction From the Seraglio" and "Marriage of Figaro," will be done at the Salzburg Music Festival this summer. The festival will open July 27 and continue till the end of August, with the events so arranged that visitors staying about a week will be able to hear most of the works in the repertoire.

THE National Broadcasting Company is planning an ambitious series of documentary programs designed "to set Americans thinking more about currently important issues and arouse them to intelligent action."

METUCHEN, N. J., Feb. 14 -- The new Lincoln-Mercury $10,000,000 assembly plant covering seventy-eight acres on Route 1, four miles from New Brunswick, N. J., is scheduled to go into production on 1949 Mercury models on March 15, according to information received today from the Ford Motor Company.

National and international figures will discuss problems of immediate urgency at the seventeenth annual session of the United States Conference of Mayors, to open tomorrow morning in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Two New York City trade associations and twenty-five manufacturers of rubber heels, soles and accessory products have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from a nationwide combination and conspiracy to fix and maintain prices for their products.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14 -President Juan D. Peron believes a "clash between capitalist imperialism and Communist imperialism" is coming, and the "fate of all countries * * * will be decided in Europe, where there may be a war similar to or worse than the last," it was disclosed officially today.

THE last eight weeks have been rough on railroad men, not so much because of the great snowbanks and drifts that have cluttered up the tracks and disrupted schedules, as because of the intense and persistent cold. Operating difficulties begin to pile up as soon as the temperature gets down and stays down well below freezing.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- European officials and economists followed American price trends this week with great interest. It was immeasurably enhanced by the growing belief that the fate of the democratic world depends mainly upon the ability of the United States to conserve its tremendous economic power by avoiding in the next few years a disastrous slump.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 14 -Three owner-skippers of sailing yachts tonight were made flag officers of the Larchmont Yacht Club for 1948.

To the Drama Editor: THE plan of the League of New York Theatres to publicize and promote the legitimate theatre on a nationwide scale is most praiseworthy. However, as a local manager, endeavoring to bring to the cities of Lancaster and Harrisburg, Pa., at least an occasional presentation of a so-called legitimate production, it would seem to me that more and better bookings would be the best hearts of furthering the project.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Council of Economic Advisers, it was learned today, plans a survey of Federal grants-in-aid, which amount to about $1,000,000,000 yearly, with a view to revising the policy of assistance to states and municipalities.

IT'S more than a week since Bobo Newsom received his walking papers from the Yankees. Less respectful commentators than this one immediately rushed into print with snap-judgment essays. But that's no way to treat the Great Showboat. Bobo wouldn't like it. He'd prefer to be viewed as a connoisseur would view an original by Rembrandt: carefully, admiringly and appreciatively.

For lack of the necessary steel pipe to extend its transcontinental system of gas-carrying ducts, the natural gas industry's $1,150,000,000 post-war pipeline construction program has fallen so far behind schedule that it may be 1950 before the current shortage of gas, which has severely affected American industries and homes this Winter, can be overcome.

GENEVA, Feb. l4 -- The second quarter of 1948 will see the end of Europe's need for maximum United States coal exports, it was learned today. It is doubtful that there has been any more important development affecting European self-help and recovery since the beginning of the discussion of the European Recovery Program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is an interesting parallel between the censure of leading Soviet composers by the Communist party in Russia and a similar censure of outstanding artists of his day by Plato in the Republic. In terms which bear a startling resemblance. Plato denounced Homer and other great Greek authors for demoralizing youth, much as the current Soviet regime objects to its artists as "anti-democratic" influences.

ATLANTA, Feb. 14 -- The man in the street in Atlanta, along with the business executive, is openly curious about the possible effect of recent price declines in the nation's organized markets, but neither appears unduly worried.

SOAP opera, in a bowdlerized British form, has divided the nation by a Mason-Dixon line. The particular cause is a thriller serial called "Dick Barton -- Special Agent." On one side are ranged all the boys from 8 to 80 in support of daring Dick.
The stock market along with the commodities ran headlong last week into a hailstorm of political bickerings.

Anton R. Zhebrak, a distinguished Soviet biologist, is in trouble. News came by way of Paris last week that he had been removed from his post as president of the White Russian Academy of Sciences. All this is another incident in the Lysenko-Vavilov controversy which began in 1936 and resulted in Vavilov's arrest and sentence to a concentration camp where he died in 1942 under circumstances that have not been officially disclosed.

RECORDS of previous seasons reveal some interesting facts about several perennials used in the flower borders. Some are old favorites, others more recent introductions, but each has shown characteristics that are drawbacks unless time and space are allowed for varying degrees of coddling.

PEIPING, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Student leaders and some professors here are apprehensive over what may happen on the Peiping college campuses within the next few weeks. Some observers believe that a new wave of Government suppression of the students has begun.
DENVER, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today a $5,300,000,000 outlay for twelve months of European aid was "too large."

HORIZON Pictures, independent producing company headed by director John Huston and Sam Spiegel, is more than passively interested in "Rough Sketch," recently published second novel by Robert Sylvester. According to the author who already has received "a down payment of $1,500 against a profit participation arrangement," Huston plans to film the story in Cuba and is waiting for an okay from the State Department and the necessary approval from the Johnston office.

ONCE again Mr. Tunis explores the problems of a rookie baseball player -- and Cecil (Highpockets) McDade was a problem to the Dodgers if ever they had one. He was a brilliant right fielder -- seventeen homers up to the 15th of June, but it was very evident that he was more interested in his batting average and a good contrast than in the team.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The New York University won its sixteenth straight basketball victory as expected, handing Georgetown a 74-58 defeat at the Armory here tonight before 2,561 fans.

LEONE RICE GRELLE'S "Remembered Weather," her second book of poems, deals almost exclusively with physical nature as the poet observes it in rural Connecticut. A number of the poems use nature as a background for memories of love or evocations of the past, but most of them find in nature their beginning and their end.
MOST pruning of fruit trees will be done between now and April 1, for few modern gardeners subscribe to the old and inaccurate advice to do this job "any time your shears are sharp."

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- In view of the Soviet Union's advocacy of the partition of Palestine into Jewish and Arab states and of the quiet anti-Semitism that still obtains in many areas of the Soviet Union it is interesting to report on the province of Birobidjan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered today its first "decertification" election.

INTO the story of Caw-Caw the crow, an avowed crow-lover has crowded a vast wealth of bird and woodland lore. Little Caw-Caw begins life badly, a fledgling in a fallen nest who sees his brothers eaten by a prowling raccoon.

FOR THIS WEEK: Complete the seed orders and send them off as soon as possible. There is no reason to delay ordering fruit and roses either. . . . By now, leaves of poinsettia have undoubtedly started to turn yellow. Reduce watering and move to a lighter and cooler place. When all foliage has dropped, store the plant down in the cellar. . . .

The American tour of the famous Amsterdam-Concertgebouw Orchestra has now been set for the fall of 1949 and plans have been brought so near completion that little is likely to change them. The clinching negotiations, it was learned yesterday, were made on Friday in New York.

REPORTS on this side of the Atlantic concerning American films would appear to be justified in so far as there does seem to be a decided vendetta being carried on by certain British film critics who make it their business to depreciate anything that's labeled "U. S.," and, at the same time, overlaud anything captioned "British."

ATHENS, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Greek Government, acting in the face of increasingly daring guerrilla activity, called up five more military classes today in an accelerated effort to obtain a force of at least 200,000 fighting men.

The Patrolman Thomas Wynn Youth Center, Brooklyn divisional title-holder, captured the city indoor track and field championship of the Police Athletic League yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. More than 800 boys and girls competed in the nineteen-event program, which included a special mile relay between the Police and Fire Departments.

MADRID, Feb. 14 -- The reopening of the Spanish-French border this week has had an enormous effect on this nation's morale in regard to its status in international society. It has provided for the apologists a peg on which to hang all arguments as to why any Western society of nations would be incomplete without Spain.

GEORGE WASHINGTON'S birthday, so faithfully remembered and celebrated by resort hotels and transportation systems, will be especially gala this year, for it falls on next Sunday and is observed on Monday.

Two women and five firemen were injured slightly last evening in a four-alarm fire that swept a seven-story tenement building at 1854 Seventh Avenue, at the northwest corner of 112th Street. One hundred and fifty persons were evacuated from the building, from an adjoining tenement at 1852 and from a five-story structure at 201 West 112th Street.

IT is "Donuts for Donors" now as the Salvation Army conducts its million-dollar drive for funds to carry on its work in New York. But giving doughnuts to donors is nothing new for this organization. Thirty years ago this month I saw a middle-aged Salvation Army "lassie" handing out doughnuts to donors while a wheezy phonograph played "The Missouri Waltz" in a shot-up house not far behind the front-line trenches in France.

ONE of the most difficult problems for a dealer or a collector of antiques and objects of art is the matter of a fair price. So many things can cause wide variance, such as quality, rarity, age, condition, and association value.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14 -- The move to put on a world's fair here in 1953 developed without audible opposition until early last month, when the fair's sponsors announced that they wanted to use 300 of the 1,360 acres of the city's Forest Park as a part of the site.

FLORIDA'S "high season," which runs from about Jan. 20 to the end of February, is now at its peak. In a boom winter, such as they had last year and anticipated for this season, resort hotel operators at this point would be struggling to balance a large demand against a smaller supply of accommodations.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 14 --Miss Barbara Ann Scott, Canada's pretty ice skating ballerina, increased her lead for the women's figure skating championship of the world today and appeared virtually certain of winning the crown either tomorrow or Monday.

This is the first of a series of four reports which will cover as many types of spring fashions -- women's fashions from 14 to 40 (illustrated here); young sophisticates, sizes 10 to 20; juniors, sizes 7 to 15, and teenagers, aged 8 to 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- There are at least two ways to plan any aspect of a foreign policy. The first is to decide what you want, work out a plan of achieving or implementing it, and then announce it. The second is to announce it first and then improvise ways and means of implementing it as you go along.

THE City Center's drama season which came to a close last night went better than had been expected. To be sure, no one yet has had a look at the final tell-tale figures, but on the basis of rough estimates there'll be a profit and the guiding spirits feel sufficiently encouraged to begin thinking of spring and another season starting the first week in May.

THOSE audio - visual tub-thumpers whose patiently entertained hopes for a sudden post-war expansion in the use of "think films" have been somewhat depressed might do well to turn their eyes westward toward the regions beyond the "Eastern states"' and gander the surging interest in such motion pictures out here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United States Government took occasion to express its wholehearted appreciation to the Portuguese Government for its cooperation during and since the war on the signing of the air agreement announced in Lisbon today for a lease by the United States of the Lagens airport in the Azores.

THREE anniversary celebrations will bedeck Prague this year with flags and fill the ancient streets. Twenty years ago the independence of the Republic was proclaimed; one hundred years ago the first Pan-Slav Congress met in Prague, a manifestation of loyalty to Austria and to Western liberal ideas; six hundred years ago Charles IV, King of Bohemia and German Emperor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Protracted delay in the enactment of the European Recovery Program would force stop-gap aid to Austria and several other countries, it was said by informed Congressmen today.

DENVER, Feb. 14 -- The general reaction of Colorado business leaders to the current commodity and stock market decline is that the nation is undergoing a needed period of price readjustment. None expressed fear of a general depression such as the United States experienced in the early Nineteen Thirties.

IN the last dozen years or so, our movie makers have run through any number of story cycles -- periods of varying duration when it seemed that every time you looked up at a marquee, there glaring at you was a backstage musical, a biographical drama, a zany comedy or a psychological murder mystery.

THE Garden Club of New Jersey has selected Greenbrook Sanctuary in the New Jersey section of Palisades Interstate Park as the site for a twenty-seven-acre arboretum. It is to be known as the Nell Saunders Memorial, in honor of Mrs. Reginald Saunders, who started the club's $10,000 fund-raising campaign in 1938.
An exhibition of prints, photographs and other material relating to the "Early Days of New York Railroads" opens on .Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The world's largest commercial coal producer is ready to begin construction of a pilot plant to convert coal into gasoline, fuel oils and gas.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 (AP) -With Lou Little no longer a candidate for the Yale football coaching job, an Eli spokesman tonight sadly confessed "we'll have to start all over again."

If, as ex-Representative Jerry Voorhis says, in "A Call to Congress to Lead, Not Follow," a Congressman is better qualified to arrive at a decision (because of his experience and special contacts) than are his hundred thousand-odd constituents, then surely the leader of the House is better qualified than its members, who might as well be dismissed. * * *

Despite the evidence that rats know what is good for them in the way of food, their appetite is not a fool-proof guide. Rats in a test conducted by Dr. E. M. Scott at the University of Pittsburgh failed to select essential accessible protein and almost starved to death.

There is not much resemblance between the majestic airliners that sweep daily across the Atlantic and the frail "flying crate" Wilbur and Orville Wright launched from Kitty Hawk in 1903. But of all the wings of the air none will be so honored as the old relic when it is returned to the United States, where it was born to open a new era in the progress of mankind.

EVER since the first man died, man has been baffled by what happens after death. When this corporeal lies empty, is all lost? What of the soul, the spirit? Surely, no matter how insignificant I am, some little part of my individual I must go on forever?

Members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra will come to New York this week to audition young instrumentalists for the student orchestras to be formed this summer at the Berkshire Music Center, which will hold its sessions at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., from July 5 to Aug. 15.

ST. PETERSBURG -- At the season's midpoint, most West Coast resorts are lagging behind last year in number of paying visitors. But that this has not, for the most part, been the lean season predicted in some quarters for this winter playground is borne out by hotel registrations.

Playing their rivals even on the flat, the unbeaten Squadron A regulars took the first match of the two-out-of-three series for the Metropolitan High Goal League indoor polo championship last night by halting Al Parsells' 15-goal Ramapo Polo Club, 13 to 9, in the star attraction of a twin bill at the Sqaudron A Armory last night.
OMAHA, Feb. 14 -- Reaction to the commodity market break in this area ranged this week from consumers' jubilation to the average farmer's acceptance that a dip had to come sooner or later.

Officials of the Agriculture Department's Bureau of Animal Industry reported yesterday that seizures of meats among the effects of passengers from the Mediterranean countries have fallen off considerably in the last few months. Meats from that area are under a ban here because of the prevalence of the hoof and mouth disease along the Mediterranean.

JERUSALEM, Sunday, Feb. 15 -- A serious Arab attack on Tel Aviv along the boundary with Jaffa began last evening and was still going on after midnight. Only scanty details were obtainable but heavy fire from machine guns and mortars was reported, with the Haganah forces standing off repeated Arab efforts to break through the border area into the Jewish city.

Emma Irizzary, 13 years old, of 77 East 109th Street, was wounded over the left eye yesterday afternoon by a shot fired from the street below while she was standing in the living room of her second floor apartment with other members of her family.
Orderly trading returned yesterday, for the day at least, to most of the nation's primary markets as some grain contracts scored modest gains and cotton futures closed strong after a brisk recovery.

A LIBERAL in a hurry is something of an anachronism nowadays, but a liberal in a hurry to rouse his readers and his country against Soviet Russia is almost unique. Mr. Lehrman is not only in a hurry; he is almost running in his urgent desire to issue his warnings.

HIGH school students -- and their parents -- can get accurate up-to-date information and sound advice from these authors who take the guess work out of "after high school, what?" Following a chapter on the financial and cultural advantages of finishing high school, the book is divided into two parts.

Lewis Nichols' "Lament for the Age of Clowns" offers retrogression, a throwback to the times when the great comics had small audiences -- the thousand or so people who could jam into the Music Box or the Shubert Theatre to see Ed Wynn, Jimmy Durante, Cantor, et al.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 14 -- Romulo Gallegos, President-elect of Venezuela, expressed the hope today that the United States would cooperate in helping to provide the agricultural and industrial machinery needed to develop the nation's economy and improve the standard of living.

Steps which pave the way for clear and concise language to replace past confusion in meanings of marketing terms have been taken by experts in business training. By the end of next month a report containing standard marketing definitions for a new American Marketing Association glossary of technical words will be ready for publication.

IT is a moot point whether Clarence Day's father or the atom bomb started the literary mass stampede toward the horse-and-buggy days. In any case, it is too late now to speculate. Nostalgia guides our reading taste inexorably.

WHEN President Coolidge came to San Antonio he was, like every other visitor to that city, distinguished as well as undistinguished, conducted to the Alamo. Standing inside the ancient walls he finally broke his silence by asking, "What is the Alamo, anyhow?" Texans have never forgiven his ignorance. It was as if a stranger in Boston asked, "What is Bunker Hill, anyhow?"

In a move to strike a balance between prerequisites and electives, Yale University has revised its curriculum leading to the Bachelor of Arts degree, effective next September. Ten new divisional fields of study which cut across departmental lines have been added to the curriculum.

OF one thing we can be quite certain. The success or failure of the European Recovery Plan will not turn on the facts that we know today or on the confident predictions we are able to make. It will turn upon hundreds of imponderable factors -- on wind and weather and chance and on ideas which are not yet born in people's minds.

GEORGE SELDES' latest enterprise in book form is timely collateral reading for a Presidential election year. It is not about the one thousand who may aspire, with perhaps some reason, to be President or Vice President, but about men who may have a good deal to say about who does win that office -- and who, in their way, are just as important, if not more so.

William O'Dwyer, now 57, started the toughest job of his life when he took office on Jan. 1, 1946, as New York's Mayor. He puts in an eleven-hour office day. Often he spends his evenings working on city business at home -- when he is not making public speeches.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A foul goal by giant Larry Foust with but a fraction of a second to play, gave La Salle College a 53 to 52 victory over St. Francis College of Brooklyn tonight in the second game of a basketball doubleheader at Convention Hall.

A well-known automobile manufacturer who is presumably interested in all forms of locomotion reports that scientists have kept a snail moving on a treadmill for a day and found a more precise definition of a "snail's pace." It is .000363005 m.p.h.

The sharp decline in the last two Weeks in commodity prices, during which market values of the major cereals have fallen about 25 per cent, is bound to be reflected in the national economy. However, with Government price supports mandatory on this year's crops, the immediate effect may be less than normally would have been the case.
Declines of retail food prices were the outstanding development of the past week in the retail trade here. Reductions followed the commodity slump and ranged from 5 to 10 per cent in food lines.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 14 -- The police of this town were joined today by investigators from the Essex County Prosecutor's Office in a search for three unidentified youths who last night shot and seriously wounded Berthram E. Betsch, 42 years old, a resident here, and assistant secretary-treasurer of the Electric Bond and Share Company, 2 Rector Street, New York.

DID Barclay Sturdevant die a hero's death in the war, or did he survive and become a traitor to his country? The entire plot of this novel hinges upon the answer to that question. The uncertainty concerning his son's fate causes Henry Sturdevant to contemplate retiring from public life, where he has long been an outstanding and highly respected figure, mentioned as a possible candidate for the Presidency.

THE name John Steinbeck is attached to some of the best and most successful films of recent years -- "The Grapes of Wrath" and "Of Mice and Men," based on his most famous novels, and "The Forgotten Village," a documentary, which the author himself made in Mexico in collaboration with the director, Herbert Kline. Still another picture bearing the Steinbeck imprint, "The Pearl," will open at the Sutton Theatre on Tuesday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 14 -- The police of this town were joined today by investigators from the Essex County Prosecutor's Office in a search for three unidentified youths who last night shot and seriously wounded Berthram E. Betsch, 42 years old, a resident here, and assistant secretary-treasurer of the Electric Bond and Share Company, 2 Rector Street, New York.

The uncertainty concerning his son's fate causes Henry Sturdevant to contemplate retiring from public life, where he has long been an outstanding and highly respected figure, mentioned as a possible candidate for the Presidency.

THE name John Steinbeck is attached to some of the best and most successful films of recent years -- "The Grapes of Wrath" and "Of Mice and Men," based on his most famous novels, and "The Forgotten Village," a documentary, which the author himself made in Mexico in collaboration with the director, Herbert Kline. Still another picture bearing the Steinbeck imprint, "The Pearl," will open at the Sutton Theatre on Tuesday.

KEITH VAUGHAN'S show at the George Dix Gallery (the young Englishman's first in America) seems to indicate that the primitive antiquarianism and personal romantic approach to nature of Henry Moore and Graham Sutherland have taken such a firm hold on the imagination of younger artists in England as to be extended into an actual convention within which they are profitably working.

Section 304 of the Taft-Hartley Act, which became law last June 23, provides: "It is unlawful for * * * any labor organization to make a contribution or expenditure in connection with any [Federal] election * * * primary election or political convention or caucus."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 14 -- Romulo Gallegos, President-elect of Venezuela, expressed the hope today that the United States would cooperate in helping to provide the agricultural and industrial machinery needed to develop the nation's economy and improve the standard of living.

HANNAH JAYNES is frightened, as she has good reason to be considering the company she keeps in the ghost town of Jaynesville, where she and her late husband made their millions out of a mine which is now abandoned. What frightens Hannah most is the trust fund set aside in her husband's will to provide for his possible illegitimate offspring.

Of the great medical and surgical advances made during World War II, none was more spectacular and life-saving than the developments in the use of whole blood and its by-products. We learned many new uses for blood in the treatment of disease, and scores of research projects cast new light in many obscure fields of medicine.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Feb. 14 -The five-story Delaware Hotel on the beach front at Third Street was damaged severly today by a fire that had smoldered undiscovered for six hours. The loss was estimated at $150,000 by A. C. Baggs, manager of the 175-room hotel, which was closed for the winter.

IN spite of some rather imposing tonnage figures, international air freight is still in the earliest stage of its development. No one in the business is dogmatic, or even reasonably sure, about how it should develop in the future, but most of them agree it has a future.

Florence Quartararo and Ramon Vinay, who joined the Metropolitan Opera the season before last, assumed new roles there last night in the season's fourth performance of "Pagliacci." The young San Francisco soprano sang Nedda and the Chilean-French tenor sang Canio, the jealous husband.

The repercussions of the recently introduced "ammunition control" bill apparently have been loud and long, and some of the letters of protest came from points as far removed as Winnipeg, Canada. The bill, as proposed, would prevent an individual from buying, selling, lending or giving away any ammunition that would fit a pistol or revolver.

Bad weather last week curtailed retail store activity, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Activity in the various departments was described as follows: Sportswear "good," blouses "busy," lingerie "active," men's furnishings "good" and housewares "busy."
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- The United States and British Military Governors will proclaim tomorrow the creation of the Bank of German States.

Accosted last night by an armed hold-up man on a Brooklyn street, a 71-year-old watchman wrested a .32-caliber pistol from the thug's grasp and then chased him several blocks. The watchman fired three shots after the fugitive with the pistol but the man got away.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Russia asserted tonight that during the months just before World War II Britain and France played a "double game" in which they conferred with the Soviet Union about defense against aggressors but sought to make an appeasement deal with Germany.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- The sixteenth annual Yale swimming carnival got off to a fast start tonight when Joe Verdeur of La Salle set a new world breaststroke record for 200 meters and a new American record for 220 yards, bettering in each instance his own previous marks.

ATLANTIC CITY -- This resort city's business men are keeping warm and happy during the unseasonable winter -- and it has truly been an "unusual winter" here -- by studying the prosperous statistics of last year, which was one of their best.

HOW much -- or how little -- does a novice need to know to get started making movies? If the experience of one average beginner may be taken as typical, all he needs is what he can learn from the instruction material that comes with the camera, the film and the projector, and whatever he can pick up from his friends.
YONKERS, N. Y., Feb. 14 -Robert Craig Montgomery submitted his resignation tonight as City Manager of Yonkers. He had informed the Common Council on Jan. 13 that he would retire today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

THE part played by Andre Maurois in shaping American foreign policy on France remains an important and unwritten chapter in the secret history of the war. Did Maurois, as much as Alexis Leger, help determine our intransigent attitude toward the intransigent Charles de Gaulle, and our backing of no less than three wrong horses?

TO American readers the least well known of the English Sitwells is Sacheverell, younger brother of Edith and Sir Osbert. He has made an art of writing books that are best described as "unfamiliar essays." His studies of "The Gothick North," "Valse des Fleurs," "Dance of the Quick and the Dead" are perhaps as unfamiliar to the general reader as "The English Mail-Coach" papers of Thomas De Quincey.

WINTER is the trapper's season. The pelts of animals are thick and luxuriant. Their tracks in the snow tell him where to set traps and snares. In the sharp, frosty air they are easily enticed by the scent which he sprinkles about the steel claws of his traps shrewdly concealed beneath sod and ice, pine sprigs and spruce boughs.

Many city and suburban dwellers who plan to build homes in the next few years will locate outside the population centers but within commuting distance of their work. The movement has made a sizable beginning, and momentum will increase rapidly this spring.
BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- Recent developments in the stock and commodity markets have injected a note of caution into the New England business man's approach to his future plans.

Financial wizards of New York and Amsterdam put aside thoughts of stocks and bonds yesterday as ten of their leading chess experts devoted themselves to a study of games which started at 10:30 o'clock in the morning.

The wholesale markets passed the last "jittery" week without experiencing any undue surprises, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- The section on subsidies in the proposed world trade charter was adopted by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today. Subject to final approval by a plenary session this action was taken by the committee on commercial policy after the United States had won a partial victory in its demand for the total exemption of primary commodities such as wheat, cotton and tobacco from the anti-subsidy provisions

FRANK CAPRA is being viewed with awe and amazement these days by the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer economists. The reason is the screen version of "State of the Union," which Capra finished fifteen days ahead of schedule and $450,000 under his $2,600,000 budget.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- The Germans are having exceptional difficulty in choosing officials for the new bizonal economic government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Farmers who sold their land to the Government during the war are buying it back at about one-third less than the Government paid them.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll gave his formal endorsement tonight to State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson as a candidate for the Republican United States Senate nomination in New Jersey. He pictured Mr. Hendrickson as one who could be counted upon to support Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's "nonpartisan, coherent and constructive foreign policy."

Winter-weary New York had its third day of respite yesterday from freezing temperatures but a new cold wave was due to strike the city early today. Highest temperatures today were expected to be in the mid-twenties. The thermometer registered 53 degrees at 6:30 A. M. yesterday, the highest it has been since Dec. 16, when the high was 55.

Organized religion in America was hailed yesterday as "the most forward-looking constructive social force of any organized religious force in the world" by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.

ALBANY -- The ill, chill winds that have brought metropolitan centers more snow than they have any need for, have brought plenty of good to the up-state winter resorts -- good, deep snows, good skiing weather, good big crowds of outdoor enthusiasts.

It isn't wholly an illusion that the withes of the weeping willows have an amber-colored glow even among the snow drifts. It may seem unduly bright in contrast to the darkness of the other trees; but something is happening down at the roots of the willows, something that always happens about this time of year. There's a stirring of life.

The permanent injunction that Rector Homes, Inc., obtained Feb. 10 from Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan in Queens against tenants of sixty one-and-two-family houses it owns in Sunnyside, applies specifically to fifteen tenants, Benjamin M. Zelman, attorney for Sunnyside Tenants Association, explained yesterday.

Columbia University announced yesterday plans for the development of an arts center that eventually will "provide a gathering place for the promotion of mutual interests of the drama, music, painting, sculpture, architecture and associated arts" and that will serve as a meeting place of leaders of the nation and the world.

BIRDS become so tame in severe winter weather that they sometimes arouse the hope they will stay and build their nests in the boxes which we put out for them. Most of the birds we see now are merely visitors, but some are permanent residents, and for either group It is worth our while to provide housing.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Arab guerrilla forces in Palestine have acquired at least 4,500 additional rifles in the three months since the United Nations decision to partition the Holy Land, Zionist quarters in London alleged today.

When Lotte Lehmann, who has given more than thirty recitals in New York in the last half dozen years made her first appearance of the season yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, the soprano and her accompanist, Paul Ulanowsky, had to thread their way through listeners seated on the stage to reach the piano.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who is in Paris to make a second attempt to persuade the World Federation of Trade Unions to support the Marshall Plan, will meet no less opposition from pro-Communist leaders in the WFTU than he faced several months ago with the same proposal, it was apparent today.

A resolution urging Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate to appropriate $100,000 to save the Schomburg Collection of the New York Public Library was passed yesterday by the New York Branch of the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,910,723.242. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

A fifteen-story arts center costing well over $1,000,000 and housing students of architecture, music, the dramatic arts, painting and sculpture, will be erected by Columbia University, Leopold Arnaud, dean of Columbia's School of Architecture, announced yesterday.

Members of New York Typographical Union No. 6, AFL, voted yesterday to ask the International Typographical Union for authorization to take a strike vote among 4,000 printers employed in commercial printing shops in this city.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 15 -- The European Recovery Program appears to rank in interest among Iowans and other Midwesterners today on a par with the break in grain prices, the high cost of living, taxes and Russia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Zionist leaders declared today that friends of the United Nations plan to partition Palestine must rally against a "last determined attack" on the projected Jewish homeland.

Two things above all Europe must have to restore a balanced economy of self-support -- food and coal. There are signs of improving crop conditions. In France, for example, winter wheat is well above the ground beyond the danger of late frost. In England and Germany the fields are green.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A top Federal labor official said today that the Government "cannot and will not permit" big strikes in coal, oil, atomic energy, railroads or shipping this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The National Farmers Union today suggested that the decline in commodity prices might be a "deliberately engineered affair."

Charles N. Schmidt, formerly advertising manager of the American Steel and Wire Company, a United States Steel subsidiary, has been named assistant director of advertising for the United States Steel Corporation.

The educational phase of the plan to relieve traffic congestion in the garment sector will open today with distribution of 1,000 placards, explaining the program, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Making his first appearance in New York as a third party Presidential candidate, Henry A. Wallace told an overflow crowd of 8,500 in the Bronx yesterday that he had been invited by Mayor O'Dwyer to rejoin the Democratic party because "the Democratic high command in Washington is scared to death."

Appointment of the Manufacturers Trust Company as a .depositary I for funds that may be contributed I to provide housing loans for vetterans was announced yesterday by Herman T. Stiehman, State Housing Cornissioner. Pie also made known the composition of a board of trustees to administer the funds.

The American people are not "giving to the poor, dollar for dollar, as much as their fathers gave a century ago," the Rev. Theodore Thormahlen declared yesterday at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street. Mr. Thormahlen is executive director of the Bethlehem Lutheran Children's Home, Staten Island, and director of Lutheran welfare agencies in the New York metropolitan area.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Statements by leading members of the Communist-directed General Confederation of Labor indicate that preparations have been made to open a new campaign of social agitation about Feb. 25. Increases in wages have been demanded already by Benoit Frachon and Pierre Lebrun of CGT, who ask, unless a drop in prices comes immediately, for a general wage advance of 20 per cent.

PRAGUE, Feb. 15 -- The difficulty Czechoslovakia is experiencing in obtaining normal commercial credit has been increased by the Finance Ministry insisting on the principle that debts due to foreign suppliers can be reduced by taxation of such debts.

ATHENS, Feb. 15 -- Radio broadcasts from the capitals of near-by governing parties are states whose members of the Cominform indicate a determined effort to support the Greek rebel regime of Gen. Markos Vafiades morally and materially.

The police of the Safe and Loft Squad announced yesterday the arrest of four men who, they charged, had stolen $15,000 worth of merchandise and then, unwittingly, stored the booty in a warehouse from which it had been removed originally for shipment to Puerto Rico.

Sixty-seven thousand students in all phases and sessions of the four municipal colleges will return to classrooms this week for the spring semester. Of these, 34,600 are expected today at City College.
DAVOS PLATZ, Switzerland, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Canada gave another dazzling performance today, despite soft ice, to retain her women's world figure skating championship.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15 -Arthur L. Valpey, 32-year-old assistant coach at the University of Michigan, was officially named head coach of football at Harvard here tonight by William J. Bingham, director of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Carroll Reece, Republican national chairman, charged tonight that the Democratic party has "produced nothing tangible to support its professions of devotion to the cause of civil liberties."

The Metropolitan Opera employes did not quite achieve their goal of a sold-out house, but their benefit operatic performance last night at the Broadway house nevertheless ensured their newly formed welfare fund of $24,000.

The independence day of Lithuania, which is today, was observed by 3,000 Persons yesterday afternoon at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, under the auspices of the Lithuanian American Council of Societies of Greater New York.

The Western Electric Company, Inc., manufacturing and supply subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday that net income last year amounted to $32,291,123, compared with $11,326,676 in 1946.

IT probably was inevitable that Ralph Ingersoll would write a novel some day. Except for poetry (and he must have written that in school), he hasn't overlooked any other kind of literary or journalistic chore. He was a reporter himself once, on The New York American.

Eighty New York citizens yesterday joined William Jay Schieffelin, chairman emeritus of the Citizens Union, in demanding prompt seating of Simon W. Gerson as a member of the City Council to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Real and important accomplishments have emerged from the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, now under way here, although they seem to have been obscured by the difficulty in reaching any agreements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Prominent educators and clergymen today urged Representative Les E. Allen chairman of the House Rules Committee, to "reject pressure" for hasty consideration of Universal Military Training.

A 32-year-old sheet metal worker was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with kidnapping, rape, assault and robbery for abducting a registered nurse, the mother of two children, and driving her for several hours in his automobile through Bronx streets before pushing her from his car.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- The Selznick Releasing Organization has announced that it will move its headquarters from New York to Hollywood in April and that the present New York home offices will become eastern district headquarters.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Four American films and and one British production were nominated today for the best picture award of 1947 by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The International Maritime Conference will convene in the Peace Palace at Geneva Thursday to decide whether to establish a world shipping organization.

An orderly world demands three creative forces -- education focused on goals common to the world, a cooperation expressed in an aggressive spirit of good-will, and faith in God and mankind, the Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared here yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- German prisoners of war, especially selected and trained in democracy in the United States, show a high level of political and social consciousness as well as a strongly critical attitude toward fellow Germans, according to a United States Military Government opinion survey.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 -- Steel ingot output for the country declined 1 point to 93 per cent of rated capacity last week, but this drop was in no way connected with the slump in commodity prices, according to steel officials here. Furthermore, they said the underlying factors supporting the strong steel market were such as to remain unaffected by action in the grain and stock markets.
Eight new films, including importations from England and Mexico, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- The Arab delegations to the United Nations are drafting statements for the Palestine partition debates in the Security Council and the Trusteeship Council.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks advanced to within two points or one game of fifth place Montreal tonight by defeating the Canadiens. 2 -- 1, before 16,503 fans.

A 300 per cent increase in gross sales volume has been achieved during the last eight years by the Harwood Manufacturing Corporation as a result of an intensive series of experiments in improved human relations as applied to personnel administration, Dr. Alfred J. Marrow, president, disclosed last week.

ASPEN, Col., Feb. 15 -- After an all-night search, the body of Alexander McFadden was recovered at 5:30 A.M. today, ten feet below the surface of a snow avalanche that struck him while he was skiing half way up 12,095-foot Independence Pass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Truman will name James F. Pinkney as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned today, provided that last-minute objections, raised by the Democratic organization of North Carolina, can be eliminated.
An unexpected reprieve from the cold wave that rolled out of the West helped the fuel-short metropolitan area to get through the week-end with a minimum of hardship.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 15 -- The declines in the United States commodity markets were a principal topic of discussion here last week. All quarters agree that the reaction will assist greatly in restoration of the equilibrium of European balances of payments and materially reduce the shortage of dollars here.

PARIS, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Paul Reynaud, the financial expert who predicted the 1929 stock market crash one month before it happened, said today that the present slump in the United States is a crisis of price readjustments and will not flame into world depression.

B. Jay Becker of New York was declared the winner of the life master individual tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, which came to a close last night at the Park Central Hotel. This made Mr. Becker a two-time winner.

Man evolves new instruments of power and increases his tempo of living. But Earth is infinitely patient and the cycling seasons follow their appointed rounds with unhurried regularity. Man gropes toward the ultimate sources of power and learns to speed himself and his products around the planet.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer has gained a victory in part in the Moore committee which has been studying his request for more real estate taxing and borrowing power for New York since December, it became known today.
People should realize, William A. Chambers said yesterday, that the weather man does not manufacture the weather.
I have read with special interest and sympathy your Topics of The Times of Monday, Feb. 9, concerning the attitude of the Fifth Avenue bus drivers.
Sportsmen's Show highlights:

The Montreal Royals made a definite impression on the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Making their initial New York appearance of the season, the speedy Dominion skaters halted the Red Shirts, 4 to 3, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League clash before 12,250 fans.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Worth, who has always stressed individuality in clothes, selects clear flower tones, mauve, parma, lettuce green, daffodil, cornflower blue and poppy red to replace the faded Edwardian tones popular in many houses this season.

The strategy of yanking the goalie in the closing seconds of play paid off for the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The move did not bring the Toronto skaters the victory, but it set the stage for a goal that brought about a tie.

A well-lighted place for studying will help to expedite the children's homework, and can be provided inexpensively, according to the General Electric Company. Pin-up lamps, bulletin boards and desk blotters were used recently in a demonstration by lighting specialists at the Nela Park laboratories in Cleveland.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 15 (AP) -- United States Ambassador John Leighton Stuart arranged an urgent conference in Nanking tomorrow with Admiral Charles M. Cooke Jr., on efforts to release four United States Marines held prisoner by Chinese Communists since Christmas Day.

B'{Ar LEBORO, Vt., Feb. 15One of 'the greatest exhibitions of ski -'-roping in. many years took place this afternoon as Arthur Tokle,' Norway S. C. star, triumphed over a brilliant field in the annual Brattleboro Outing Club fixture held under ideal conditions.

NANKING, Feb. 15 -- Communist troops attacking Anshan, Manchurian steel center, were reported today to have penetrated Nationalist positions to within three miles of the city after stepping up their assault from all directions.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- A priest who had participated in meetings organized by left-wing parties has been excommunicated by Alfredo Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 15 -- With special delegations from thirty nations in attendance, Romulo Gallegos, the first President of Venezuela to be elected by popular vote, was inaugurated today in a colorful ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Although prevention of war pays vaster dividends than winning a war, it may be a generation, or a century, before the world's nations develop practical measures to banish war, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said in his final report as Chief of Staff of the Army to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 14 (Delayed) -- Soviet authorities and Communist party chieftains are rushing to complete a North Korean puppet government. It is predicted here that it will be pronounced the "Government of All Korea" before the completion of the Little Assembly debate on the questions introduced by the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 15 -- J. Natalicio Gonzalez, 50-year-old poet and economist, was elected President today for a five-year term. He was the only candidate on the ballot. Senor Gonzalez will take office Aug. 15.

Many of those tenants who, last year, agreed to a 15 per cent rent boost did so not because they were particularly intimidated but because they felt that the landlord should get a moderate increase in rent, in addition to the great benefits he is deriving from full-rented accommodations.

ATHENS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, who is coining to Greece to head the military groups of the United States Aid Mission, will be a member of the Greek National Defense Council. As such, he will have a voice in the fight against the Greek guerrillas and in the composition of the Greek Army.

President Branch Rickey's Brooklyn Dodger "youth movement" received another shot in the arm yesterday with the announcement by the National League club that three young pitchers, two southpaws and a right-hander, had signed 1948 contracts.

Dr. Lynn L. Bollinger was on sound ground when he told the New York Aviation Trades Association that, to prosper, the airplane must become a good neighbor -- primarily not a noisy neighbor. He was on sound ground when he said that design of personal airplanes, those particularly concerned with neighborliness, has lagged since the war.

Following the example of the American Embassy in China, the British Embassy has now likewise issued a warning to British nationals to evacuate North China because of "unsettled conditions" there. This means, of course, that the Chinese civil war is spreading, and that the Communists, who already hold most of Manchuria, are gaining strength in Northern China as well.
HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Cubans and Americans today observed the fiftieth anniversary of the sinking of the battleship Maine in Havana Harbor. A joint ceremony was held at the Maine monument.

Close attention to the experiment of extending hours of delivery and pick-up in the garment area of Manhattan may be expected on the part of all those who are seeking to improve the city's traffic situation. This area, from 34th to 42nd Street and from Sixth to Ninth Avenue, has become so overburdened with trucks that the movement of goods and of all vehicles has been slowed to a snail's pace.

"Ghosts," the Henrik Ibsen tragedy, will open a two-week engagement at the Cort this evening in a modern adaptation by Eva Le Gallienne, who heads the cast. It will mark the resurrection, in diminished form, of the American Repertory Theatre, which shares sponsorship of the offering with Louis J. Singer.

The on-again, off-again settlement of the strike affecting 250 specialty bakeries in this city was on again last night. Henry Mayer, counsel for Local 164 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union, AFL, reported that a tentative agreement had been reached by representatives of the employers and three union locals at a meeting at the Riverside Plaza Hotel under the auspices of Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the industry.

A bitter battle for the profitable ocean air traffic this summer is forecast by developments over the week-end. Chief of these is the conference in Washington between The Netherlands Government mission and the State Department to implement the bilateral air treaty between the two governments.

Fred T. Caldwell, a director and vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been elected president of the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation, manufacturing subsidiary of I.T. T. it was announced yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 -- The Austrian Government has prepared a statement that Austria herself might raise $150,000,000 to repay the Soviet Union for industries in eastern Austria seized by the Russians as German assets under their interpretation of the Potsdam pact terms. The Soviet Union had requested $200,000,000 for the return of these industries to Austria.

An appeal to preserve the historic character of Washington Square, block the construction there of a proposed tall apartment building and turn the site into a "living art center" was made yesterday to representative citizens interested in the city's cultural life.
