A "golden way," or ramp, eight feet wide and ninety feet in circumference, spiraling from the first to the second floors of Grand Central Palace, will symbolize New York's fashion industry at the exposition marking the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Chairman Arthur H. Vandenberg of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is backing Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican, of Massachusetts, as head of a joint Congressional committee to supervise the administration and progress of the European Recovery Program, it was learned today.

Fifteen of the nation's business and civic leaders, including Nelson Rockefeller, Henry R. Luce, Spyros P. Skouras, Eric Johnston and Beardsley Ruml, have formed a committee to press for favorable Congressional action on the Ives-Fulton bill against discrimination in employment.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Anund Dalen of the Norway Ski Club won the metropolitan skiing championship by scoring 427.8 points in the two-day meet which ended today. Aaleiv Nedberg, also of the Norway club, was second with 414.4.

The final $85,000,000 installment of the Illinois veterans' bonus bond issue, which will come up for bidding on Tuesday, is the center of interest in the municipal bond market here this week. The state has asked bidders to figure on a choice of four maturity schedules, the shortest -- a 7 1/8-year average -- ranging from 1950 to 1960, and the longest -- an 11 3/4-year average -- ranging from 1949 to 1972.

Moviegoers in 1975 will be able to watch events at the instant of their occurrence anywhere in the world through the medium of guided missiles containing photographic pick-up units, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, predicted yesterday.

Three New York City exporting concerns have had their license privileges suspended because of improper and irregular practices in applying for and using exporting licenses, the Department of Commerce announced over the week-end through its Office of International Trade.

The executive board of the Teachers Union, CIO, adopted a resolution yesterday urging the withdrawal of the orders banning "Gentleman's Agreement" by Laura Z. Hobson and "Focus" by Arthur Miller from the library of De Witt Clinton High School, the Bronx.

Two new tenors will make their debuts next week, the sixteenth of the Metropolitan Opera. They are Brian Sullivan, American singer, who will be heard in the title role in the second performance of Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes," and Giuseppe di Stefano, Italian singer from La Scala, who will sing the Duke in "Rigoletto."

Telecoin Corporation will launch Feb. 20, through its 1,300 "Launderette" stores, a mail-order merchandising program under which customers selecting from a special brochure will be able to get c.o.d. delivery of wearing apparel and household commodities, it was announced over the week-end.

After fifteen hours of continuous play in the radio chess match between the New York and Amsterdam Stock Exchanges, the prolonged struggle came to an end at 1:30 o'clock, yesterday morning, New York time, with Amsterdam the victor by the score of 5 1/2 -- 4 1/2.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 15 -- The word "capital" applied to Frankfort is frowned on by the Military Government. It has political connotations that the British and Americans are most anxious to avoid. In writing the charter and setting up the administration for an unprecedented entity called Bizonia they pruned away anything that suggests a political merger of two zones.

Soft goods retailers have adopted a watchful attitude in purchasing because of the break in commodity prices, according to the weekly market reports prepared last week especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
A serious shortage of men trained to think of mineral resources on a national and international scale was reported here yesterday by Dr. James Boyd, director of the United States Bureau of Mines.
SEATTLE, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Heavy winds and rain squalls lashed the Pacific northwest today with little prospect of relief for twenty-four hours.

Paul Hindemith appeared not only as composer but also, for the first time at a public concert in this city, as conductor at the concert of the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Conducting an excellent chamber orchestra in the performance of his "Herodiade," Mr. Hindemith proved just as efficient with the stick as he is with his pen.

Leading the local art events of the week is a loan exhibition of twenty-three Renoir and Delacroix paintings opening today at the Paul Rosenberg Galleries for the benefit of the New York Heart Association's drive for funds to support its 1948 program.

A recital unusual for its direct musical appeal was given by Harry Adaskin, violin, and his wife, Frances Marr, piano, at Times Hall last night. Instead of the usual balance of musicology and virtuosity, the fare consisted of four twentieth century compositions, offered in unpretentious, communicative performances.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Successful control of runaway pulse caused by disruption of the human heart's timing mechanism was reported today at the University of Oregon Medical School.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 15 -- The Belgian Government will take firm action to crush strikes of more than 100,000 workers in essential industries.

Services at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, were conducted yesterday by members of the Princeton Theological Seminary Choir. Different members of the group, all of whom are students for the ministry, delivered the invocation, the benediction and read the lesson from the Scriptures.

Wages and salaries in the steel industry last year totaled $1,986,661,000, or 28 per cent more than in 1946. The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Hourly rates of pay were high during the last nine months of the year and employment was 14 per cent larger than the wartime peak of 1944, when payrolls amounted to $1,745,019,700.

Drastic reorganization of the Health Department through consolidation of twenty-six bureaus, divisions, boards and separate offices into five coordinated sections headed by able public administrators is planned by Commissioner Harry S. Mustard, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A thirty-day emergency extension of the present Rent Control act, which is due to expire in two weeks, appeared to have growing Congressional support, as Senate and House committees prepared today to renew deliberations on new rent legislation.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Dewey's pre-convention campaign managers are counting heavily on primary victories in New Hampshire, Wisconsin and Oregon to win him the Republican Presidential nomination again and to put an end to convention deadlock and dark horse talk.
President Truman's letter to the United States Conference of Mayors, which opens a three-day meeting here today, follows:
LATROBE, Pa., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Quadruplets -- the birth that occurs only once in 650,000 -- were born today to the 26-year-old wife of a metal works inspector.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation is preparing a $7,762,500 court action against the investment banking house of Otis Co. of Cleveland for alleged "repudiation" of stock-purchase contracts, it was disclosed today by papers filed here with the Secretary of State.

First details of methods to simplify pricing and billing, which conserve clerical time, reduce costs and eliminate delays in distribution of industrial supplies, were revealed here over the week-end in the first copy of a comprehensive pricing analysis presented recently by R.H. Russell, treasurer of J. Russell Co., Inc., Holyoke, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- A spritely little miniature pinscher from California, Champion Rajah V. Siegenburg, defeated the great Eastern Pomeranian, Champion Little Timstopper, in the toy group, then went on to prove his class by taking best-in-show in the twenty-sixth annual all-breed event of the Elm City Kennel Club tonight.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 15 -- The organization Protestants and Other Americans United for the Separation of the Church and State was defended from imputations of Communist sympathy tonight in a radio address by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church in the New York area.

To mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of his debut as a conductor in this country, a silver recording was presented to Bruno Walter yesterday afternoon during the intermission of his concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Financial markets again have run into heavy weather, heavier than anything experienced since the fuel crisis of a year ago.

Three men, one of them armed, bound and gagged a maid in a Brooklyn home Saturday night, smashed open a bedroom safe and escaped with $39,000 in jewelry and an undetermined amount of cash and bonds, the police of the Snyder Avenue station reported yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's final report as Chief of Staff, made public last evening, outlines two security programs, one "short-term" and one "long-range." The short-term program looks hard facts in the face and deals with them as an engineer might deal with a construction problem.

ITHICA, N.Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Assemblyman Stanley Shaw, Tompkins County Republican, broke openly tonight with Governor Dewey in a radio address and chided members of the Legislature for "failing to properly represent their constituents."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- James R. Leonard, national racquets champion, had little difficulty in winning the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament here today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club when he defeated Clarence C. Pell Jr. in three straight games.

The response of the foreign exchange market to the calendar of events of international significance generated out of receding values for stocks and commodities here and England's wage stabilization and price control program was a pattern of rates ranging from irregularly lower in some units to a sharply deflated value for the pound sterling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The nationwide small independent business membership of the National Federation of Small Business has given almost unanimous approval to a Senate Foreign Relations Committee proposal to require European nations to exercise maximum self help in order to qualify for American aid.

The Council Against Intolerance in America, 17 East Forty-second Street, announced yesterday the winners of the Thomas Jefferson prizes for the advancement of democracy during 1947. Officials of 1,000 civic organizations and editors of 500 newspapers throughout the country cast ballots indicating their choice for the awards.

PERHAPS it's too selfish a reaction to be worthy of putting into print. But there is a profound feeling of relief in this corner that Lou Little has elected to stay at Columbia. Lou has become such a part of our town that for him to have shifted to Yale would have been as unthinkable as to transfer the Empire State Building to New Haven.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The dispatch of the cruiser Nigeria is a sequel to the diplomatic stalemate that has been reached on the Falkland Islands controversy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Rockets, Baltimore Colts and Brooklyn Dodgers today were bolstered by a total of 20 football players transferred by stronger clubs in the All-America Conference in an effort to make the 1948 title campaign better balanced.

A young woman -- one of our esteemed colleagues -- deplores the fact that most of the newer houses in the suburbs are without front porches. Her reasons for wanting front porches are the precise opposite of the reasons cited by the President of the United States for wanting an upstairs back porch on the White House.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Rex Cook of Baltimore, Md., won the men's novice title of the Eastern States figure skating championship meet today. Miss Patsy Kerrigan of Philadelphia claimed the ladies' novice crown with first places in both compulsory school figures and free skating.

The Cunard White Star Line again will make Cherbourg, France, a regular port of call for its express liners, the company has announced. The change will be effective with the departure of the Queen Elizabeth from Southampton, England, on April 7 and from New York one week later.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 -- Zionist forces in the early hours today took the offensive in the troubled region of northern Galilee, where Arab raiders hays been attacking road traffic.

WARSAW, Feb. 15 -- The Polish Communist party has opened a strong campaign in its press and in a joint party meeting with the Socialists against the thesis that was accepted at a recent Socialist congress as a working basis to formulate a new party program.

An appeal by President Truman to the mayors of 250 cities in the United States to back his anti-inflation program was made public here yesterday. The President warned that unless the rise in the cost of living was checked, "the living standard of millions of families will be critically endangered."

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Prices of corn broke the permissible limit of 8 cents a bushel in seven out of the last ten trading days on the Board of Trade. Except yesterday, at no time did May corn close higher than on the preceding day, although the December contract, representing the new crop, showed definite resistance to selling pressure.
Turbulent flood waters were receding yesterday in eight states after an excessive two-day rainfall.
Cotton prices in the domestic market last week were under considerable selling pressure, influenced in part by liquidation in outside markets.

DENVER, Feb. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, said today that he regarded the results of his six-state speaking tour of the Midwest as "extremely encouraging," but declined to evaluate the results in terms of convention delegates won to his cause.

When a recipe says simply, "one cup flour," some housewives are uncertain as to what type should be used. Formerly there were three varieties -- pastry, bread and cake flour. Though cake flour still is available in the same cardboard box, the first two have been replaced by an all-purpose product. It's this that causes the confusion.

With twelve players on a side, including two women experts, play in the match by cable between the Marshall Chess Club of New York and the Capablanca Club (if Havana was held yesterday. After a session which lasted from noon to past midnight, the Americans came out victorious, 7 to 4.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Third-round co-of-living wage increases are averaging 11 cents an hour, the National Foremen's Institute reported today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 15 -- On urgent orders from the Admiralty in London, the cruiser Nigeria, flagship of the British naval forces of the South Atlantic station based on Simonstown, sailed this evening "for an unknown destination."

BOSTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- One of the most spectacular of Frankie Brimsek's many brilliant goal-tending exhibitions enabled the Boston Bruins to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1, tonight before 13,900 at the Boston Garden. Brimsek was called upon to kick out forty-one shots, while rival Harry Lumley was handling seventeen in clean fashion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- One of the most sensational breaks in grain and commodity markets in general came to a halt yesterday when grains turned upward after having been on the downgrade for eleven days. In that period May wheat declined 61 cents a bushel and May corn went down 56 1/4 cents to the lowest levels for those grains since last August.

This column was recently given over to a discussion of production and its relation to inflation. The title of the piece was "The Over-Emphasis on Production." Its theme was that, however, important production might have been during the transition from war to peace, the edge of its effectiveness had been blunted with the achievement of full employment and with the development of serious bottlenecks in the economy.

SAINT HELIER, Jersey, Channel Islands, Feb. 15 -- Remnants of feudalism and twentieth-century democracy will do battle here this week when a bill for the reform of Jersey's Government is introduced in the States, or Parliament, of Jersey.

The world is heading for catastrophe on a cosmic scale, but the only catastrophe human beings have to fear is loss of their souls, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday in the first of a series of Lenten sermons in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Canada's first immigration ship, Canadian Pacific Steamships' Diesel-electric vessel Beaverbrae, is now en route from St. John, N.B., to London and Bremerhaven, according to an announcement last week. A former German submarine depot-repair ship in World War II, the vessel-has been extensively reconditioned and has accommodations for 773 displaced persons and other immigrants on each westbound voyage.

Names are programs. They should therefore be chosen carefully. A new name has become necessary for the European group of sixteen states that have responded to the Marshall Plan and made up their minds to integrate their economic systems.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its semi-annual season at the City Center last night with a familiar program. It consisted of two sprightly modern works sandwiched between two elderly ones, at least one of which was weary and dispirited.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 -- The California section of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, embroiled in a factional battle over adherence to national CIO policies, today undertook to resolve the dispute by promulgating a "hands-off" policy.

Christianity is not a "bed-of-spikes" religion that "mortifies the flesh just for the sake of being miserable," the Rev. Franklin P. Cole, pastor of the Church-in-the-Gardens (Congregational), 50 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, said yesterday in his sermon.

The Associated Hospital Service announced yesterday that it would grant an additional $1,000,000 to 260 hospitals in the metropolitan area in the first four months of 1948. In that time, it was estimated, normal payments would total $9,000,000.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 15 -- The United States and British Military Governors proclaimed today the creation of a central bank for the bizonal area to be known as the Bank of German States. The bank will start operations March 1.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 -- Wilhelmina Busch, 64-year-old heiress to the Busch brewery millions and youngest daughter of the founder of the Anheuser-Busch Brewery, will be married next Sunday to Sam E. Woods, United States Consul General at Munich, Germany, it was learned tonight.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago and Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., finished in a tie for first place in the $10,000 Lower Rio Grande Valley open today with 269 for 72 holes and will meet tomorrow in a play-off for first money.

ROME, Feb. 15 -- The break between the Christian Democrats and the Communists is final and no collaboration between them is possible inside or outside the Government, Premier Alcide de Gasperi said this morning in a speech that began his party's electoral campaign.

While economists still were trying to decide whether last week's gyrations in commodity and stock markets meant that inflation had run its course and prices were headed lower, housewives were concerened yesterday with costs at local meat and grocery stores.

The letter from Harry J. Carman in THE TIMES of Jan. 22, opposing the restoration of Fort Clinton, interested me not only because of the logic of his argument, but also because it moves me to suggest a means of memorializing the fort and its historical setting at the Battery without going to the expense of a full-scale restoration.

Retail prices continued to rise during January, according to the Fairchild Publications' retail price index issued over the week-end. All five of the major components of the index registered advances during the month. The index on Feb. 1 was 4.7 per cent above a year ago, 11.7 per cent compared with July 1, 1946, and 39.7 per cent over the pre-war average.

ROME, Feb. 15 -- The break between the Christian Democrats and the Communists is final and no collaboration between them is possible inside or outside the Government, Premier Alcide de Gasperi said this morning in a speech that began his party's electoral campaign.

While economists still were trying to decide whether last week's gyrations in commodity and stock markets meant that inflation had run its course and prices were headed lower, housewives were concerened yesterday with costs at local meat and grocery stores.

From now on, several important industrial organizations will insist on being protected against future declines in materials and labor costs through "two-way" escalator clauses, it was revealed here yesterday.
Boxers of the Salem-Crescent A. C., dominated the twenty-second annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament of The News Welfare Association in Madison Square Garden last night.
The conviction that he still has a couple of good ball games in his system will this year see Frankie Crosetti back on the active player list with the Yankees.

Reginald Pearman, New York University star, who is being looked upon as a top 880-meter Olympic prospect as a result of his impressive work this season and last, will bid for the 1,000-yard title when the sixtieth national A. A. U. indoor championships are held at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 16 -- A personal income tax, never levied in New Jersey, was proposed today in a measure offered to the Legislature by Assemblyman Lewis M. Herrmann, Republican, of Newark.

Because many cases of delinquency among Puerto Rican pupils in the New York public schools are attributable to the children's inability to speak English, the Board of Education is experimenting with a program to teach the youngsters the language by means of special phonograph records, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration has tightened certain operation requirements for National Airlines which is using new, nonunion pilots because of a strike, it was disclosed today.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 16 -- In establishing a puppet government supported by a large army in North Korea the Soviet authorities have "flouted international agreements, violated the Moscow decision and attempted to render the United Nations Korea Commission impotent," a highly placed United States military spokesman declared here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Distributors of construction equipment were told today that the era of easy bank credit is ending. Credit is and will be increasingly tighter and will cost more, said Kenton R. Cravens, vice president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis.
Fairly active buying by retailers was reported yesterday at the convention and marketing showing of the Men's Apparel Clubs of New York City, Inc., at the Hotel New Yorker. Prices were firm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Which Soviet Government bulletin do you read?

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- That old political gladiator Winston Churchill unsheathed the sword of his scorn in the House of Commons today to do battle for two ancient privileges imperiled by the egalitarian reformers of the Labor party -- special representation in Parliament for the London financial district and for the universities.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 --Following is the text, made public today, of the first report of the United Nations Palestine Commission:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Concerned over the decline of shipping through West Coast ports, transportation and port executives are about to endeavor to establish a coastwise organization to compete aggressively for some of the business now going to Atlantic and Gulf ports and otherwise to tackle post-war shipping problems.
PARIS, Feb. 16 -- Beginning next Sunday, France will hold national celebrations of the Revolution of 1848 that will continue throughout the year, it was officially announced today.
I wish to endorse fully the suggestions made by Raymond A. Schultz in your issue of Jan. 31, regarding the grading of restaurants to conform with their observance of sanitary conditions.

The Canadian Government's Department of Mines and Resources plans to survey large areas for mineral deposits by means of the airborne magnetometer, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The present training of reservists in the United States suffers from a military ailment known as "hardening of the categories," the Gray Board heard today from Col. Robert J. Smith, president of the Air Reserve Association.

BADEN, Germany, Feb. 16 -- Nearly thirty years after he was first tried -- in absentia -- by the French in 1919 as a war criminal, 75-year-old Nazi industrialist Hermann Roechling faced another tribunal this afternoon -- in person -- at Rastatt, twelve miles from Baden.
American Federation of Labor electricians in this city believe they have found a legal way to short-circuit the Taft-Hartley law's ban on the closed shop.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- President Truman's letter transmitting his second quarterly report to Congress on the Greek-Turkey aid program today follows:

The 1948 national knockout team-of-four contract bridge championship for the Vanderbilt Cup opened last night in the Pierre Hotel when 45 teams started the first qualifying round. This established a new entry record for the event. Last year 44 teams competed.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Hugh Thompson, regional director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, stepped into the affairs of the United Chemical Workers today to straighten out what he called "a chaotic condition."

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 16 -- Two men alleged to have been top conspirators in the plot to kill Mohandas K. Gandhi were arrested here over the week-end, it was revealed today. Investigating officers assert that with these arrests all the nine persons directly connected with the assassination are in custody.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, promised the steel industry today that he would not call a strike to support wage demands the union intends to make in April.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The "ownerless" Chicago Rockets of the All-America Conference had a new problem on their hands today when John Rapacz of Oklahoma, star center, an alleged "gift" from the Cleveland Browns, announced he had not signed a professional football contract.

Joy of creating and skill in collecting provided thousands of items that the American Hobby Federation presented yesterday at its eleventh annual show in Hearns Auditorium. The display of hobbies in the department store at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street will continue through Feb. 28.

American neglect of its merchant marine potentialities amounts almost most to a complex, in the opinion of Andrew W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a member of President Truman's advisory committee on the merchant marine.

Gross revenues of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company last year reached a new high of $30,433,976, exceeding the 1946 total of $27,676,174 by $2,757,802, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- Efforts to find quarters for an advance party of the United Nations Palestine Commission's secretariat, which is expected to arrive this week, have failed because of the animosities aroused by the strife here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- A demonstration of modern physical rehabilitation techniques to return the disabled to productive life was given for the United Nations Economic and Social Council here today by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the rehabilitation department at the New York University College of Medicine, and several of his colleagues.

Buying at the twenty-third semi-annual National Domestic and Linen Show in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday was selective, cautious and generally light. While some large orders were placed, both exhibitors and retailers agreed that the "shopping" characteristic of Sunday when the show opened continued throughout the day.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Agreements for the passage of legislation clearing the way for construction of a new $20,000,000 Madison Square Garden in New York City and for exemption of $150,000,000 for new hospital construction from New York City's debt limit are understood to have been reached by legislative leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Truman has appealed to heads of Arab states for moderation in the Palestine turmoil, the White House disclosed today. The number of states addressed was not specified.

Prices of stocks, along with those of the major commodities, snapped back sharply yesterday, gaining fractions to 2 points and pushing the combined averages up a point. The recovery was fairly broad, and represented the first reversal in trend of major proportions in about two weeks.

A new novel by C. S. Forester, author of the Horatio Hornblower novels, has been tentatively scheduled for April 21 publication by Little, Brown. "The Sky and the Forest" is a story set in Central Africa, the scene of an earlier Forester novel, "The African Queen."

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Delays in the calendars of the Supreme Courts in New York City have reached "serious proportions," the Judicial Council of the State of New York declared in its annual report, submitted tonight to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Three members of Congress and Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach today argued in favor of a bill which would give to workers the same opportunity for education in the field of labor relations as Federal statutes afford farmers through the agricultural extension service.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 -- The military committee of the Arab League has recommended to the league's council that any United Nations troops sent into Palestine to implement partition be opposed by force. The council will meet tomorrow in probably its last session of the current meeting to consider this drastic proposal.

The establishment of a state university to serve Long Island by expanding and enlarging Queens College in Flushing has been requested in resolutions sent to the Governor, the Queens Borough President, the Mayor and all members of the State Legislature, it was announced here yesterday.

The wonder and incredulity with which Wall Street has been following the Kaiser-Frazer stock financing fiasco settled into a kind of saturnine dismay over the weekend, as word got around that what had started off as $20,000,000 of new financing was winding up in a $7,762,500 lawsuit.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A movement to coordinate all overseas civilian aid programs under the Administrator of the European Recovery Program is developing on Capitol Hill, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- Russia accused the United States tonight of conducting negotiations for a separate peace with Germany in 1943 with the idea of erecting a diplomatic wall to prevent the westward spread of Bolshevism. Great Britain was accused of conducting similar negotiations with Germany in 1941.

Labor unions are entitled to the facts of a company's condition, "not the misleading subtle interpretive summaries, which are the operating statements," it was declared last night by William Gomberg, director of the management engineering department of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, (AFL).

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Four months before expiration of the present longshore contract on the West Coast, waterfront employers have requested a meeting with longshoremen to discuss changes to bring the agreement in conformity with the Taft-Hartley Law, and longshore leaders were considering the request today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith endorsed Robert C. Hendrickson today for the seat in the United States Senate now held by Albert W. Hawkes, his fellow Republican from New Jersey. Mr. Hendrickson is State Treasurer.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Many local health departments have broken down and one-fourth of the country's population is without adequate health service, a New York physician said today.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- Jewish colonists beat off today a five-hour attack by a strong force of Arabs on Tirat Tsvi, a settlement in the Jordan River valley five miles southeast of Beisan. The police reported that thirty Arabs and one Jew had been killed and three Arabs wounded.

A sharp-eyed scout reports that, appearances to the contrary, spring is just around the corner. This cheerful bit of intelligence is based, he says, on what he calls his toy store window barometer, which he swears is almost infallible.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Paris was chosen today as the site for this year's General Assembly session in a unanimous decision that immediately plunged 2,900 United Nations employes here into dreamy competition for 600 choice job assignments.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 -- President Juan Peron today appointed his Ambassador to Washington, Dr. Oscar Ivanissevich, to head his newly created Secretariat of Education, a post that holds Cabinet rank.

Ferdinand C. Smith, one of the nation's top Negro labor leaders and a founder and national secretary of the militant National Maritime Union, CIO, was arrested and held for deportation yesterday as an alien Communist illegally in this country.

One of the most valuable features of the show, especially to those who have acquired one of the foreign military rifles, pistols or revolvers, is the booth operated by the War Trophy Safety Committee. Those who are puzzled as to just what ammunition to use, and what American loads are adaptable for use in some of these foreign arms, will appreciate the forethought of the United States Treasury Department in operating the booth.

Neils Francis Rebholz, the 16-month-old boy who will live in Denmark for a year before returning to United States to become eligible for United States citizenship, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday from Chicago and will leave today for Copenhagen by air.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- An attack on the constitutionality of the authority of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to conduct its own investigations was rejected by the Supreme Court today. The tribunal declined to review an appeal by Leon Josephson, who was convicted of contempt for refusing to be sworn to testify before a subcommittee, in New York, March 5 last.
The fifth annual report of the Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company, released yesterday, shows more than one hundred American firms are now doing business in Puerto Rico.

A tenant who appeared in mid-Manhattan Court yesterday as a witness in a complaint involving alleged failure by his landlord to provide adequate heat became so aroused when the case was postponed for a fourth time that he punched the landlord in the face.

THE third term was an immediate consequence of Hitler's conquest of France and the specter of Britain standing alone between the conqueror and ourselves. Our dangerous position induced President Roosevelt to run for a third time.

Austin, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 4 on bond issues aggregating $3,120,000. Dated March 16, 1948, the bonds are to come due July 1 from 1949 to 1973. Interest must not exceed 3 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- The Palestine Commission bluntly told the Security Council today that it could not carry out the United Nations plan for partitioning the Holy Land unless the commission received "military forces in adequate strength."

Bela Urban, young violinist who made his New York debut last night at Town Hall, has been molded by diverse elements. His life span has included birth in Budapest, rearing in Chicago, violin study in Brussels and service in the United States Army.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 -- A rightwing movement was disclosed to be under way today for the removal of Abram Flaxer, international president of the United Public Workers, CIO, and three other officials, at the insistence of members of a Michigan local.
City College's 1948 baseball team and it's new coach both got off to an early start yesterday afternoon when the Beavers held their first practice of the season at the College's Tech gymnasium.

" The Pearl," Mexican-made adaptation of the John Steinbeck story, will have its local premiere today at the Sutton Cinema. Pedro Armendariz and Maria Elena Marques head the cast of the drama, which is spoken in English and presented by RKO.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Federal Judge Edward M. Curran today rejected a defense motion to dismiss charges of contempt of Congress against the ten Hollywood figures who refused to tell the House Committee on Un-American Activities whether they were Communists.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A People's Court today sentenced Miss Elizabeth Proiszl-Pallos, 31, a citizen of the United States, to six months in jail for neglecting to report alleged subversive activities to the police.

WARSAW, Feb. 16 -- The Warsaw radio announced today the decision of Polish authorities to establish "house committees" for every apartment building in the capital, with supervisory powers over the leisure time of its residents.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- All through the stretch, Big Dial, a Belmont Stakes nominee, and Beau Dandy, one of the Calumet Farm's junior varsity 3-year-olds, fought head and head at Hialeah Park today and at the wire even the camera couldn't separate 'em.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- With buyers finding nothing in week-end developments to attract them, the stock markets here today opened the week on a quiet note and with no decided tendency.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 -- Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, speaking in Jammu Province of Kashmir State yesterday, declared that the United Nations Security Council had "got lost in power politics" in its deliberations on the Kashmir issue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Ninety-six railroads in the West and South today received permission to raise their passenger coach fares 13.63 per cent.
BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- The first major walk-out of a number of high officials in the Soviet-sponsored Socialist Unity party was predicted here today by Socialist party members.

Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of New York public school personnel, denied yesterday reports that numerous teachers seeking promotional increments had been refused admission to courses in local colleges because of overcrowded conditions.
Samuel A. Lerner heads the syndicate which purchased the old Central Opera House at 205-13 East Sixty-seventh Street from Max Verschleiser.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Net profits of the 6,900 banks in the Federal Reserve System were 14 per cent lower in 1947 than in 1946, the Federal Reserve board reported today.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- An unequivocal declaration was made today at the Foreign Office that no change had occurred in the British Government's attitude toward the United Nations plan to partition Palestine. This attitude has been manifested by a firm refusal to contribute anything to implementation of the program.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Prize money totaling $525,000, a figure more than double the previous high for the tournament, awaits the onslaught of a record-breaking field of 36,740 bowlers in the 1948 renewal of the American Bowling Congress opening here on March 11.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Yugoslavia today leveled a battery of charges against the United States and blamed this Government for impairing its national economy by refusing to turn back $47,000,000 that the Belgrade Government banked here in 1941 before the German invasion.

A 20 per cent increase in the amount of newspaper advertising that will be given this year to promotion of Father's Day, June 20, was forecast yesterday by Alvin Austin, director of the National Father's Day Committee. Retailers are finding that promotion is now "the order of the day" to meet buyer resistance, he asserted, and Father's Day offers one of the best promotional occasions.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 -- A Finance Ministry announcement today that the country's trade balance continued unfavorable explained why importers were learning almost daily of a further tightening of import restrictions.

Sales of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company last year were $670,772,647, a record peacetime volume that compared with $616,508,162 in 1946, P. W. Litchfield, the chairman, reported yesterday to stockholders.

The tempo of the pre-convention national political campaign stepped up all over the country yesterday. In New York eyes turned to the special Congressional election in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx, where there will be a test today of the potential strength of the third-party movement headed by Henry A. Wallace.

The Board of Higher Education postponed action last night on the case of Samuel Margolis, a former library assistant at City College, who is the last of several teachers accused by the Rapp-Coudert Committee of being Communists, to face dismissal. The others have been dismissed.
The official summary of the Temporary Commission on the Need for a State University, outlining its twenty-two specific recommendations, follows:
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 17 to 52 points net higher on the day. The strength was most pronounced in the near months.

Seven men sat around a circular table yesterday sipping tea. They will continue to sip it for the next three to five days, yet when they are through they will still be able to "look a cup of tea in the face."

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations is prepared to rally the rank and file of the World Federation of Trade Unions to prevent the Soviet Union's attempts to sabotage the European Recovery Program, James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the CIO, said today.

The $100,000 production fund, with which the Metropolitan Opera Guild underwrote the Metropolitan's new production of Wagner's "Ring" cycle, has been fully subscribed, Mrs. August Belmont, president of the Guild, announced yesterday morning.

THIS is written with extreme reluctance but it must be written for the sake of the record. The first time I met Ed McKeever I was swept away by his charm and vibrant personality. Ever since I've been one of his warmest and most enthusiastic supporters. In my liking for him, however, I was not alone because he'd also captivated wiser and smarter sports writers and coaches.

THE land of Limbo cannot be found on any map of India, which is a pity because Limbo is an enchanting place. But it bears sufficient resemblance to an actual district for Aubrey Menen to withhold the name of the particular state he visited as an officer of the Political Department of the Government of India several years ago.

Bernard M. Baruch declared yesterday that the nations of Europe cooperating in the Marshall Plan should form a joint union for defense against aggression, and that the United States should join it to help them.

New York University will place its unblemished record in jeopardy again tonight as college basketball returns to Madison Square Garden after an absence of nearly a month. The Violets, victorious in sixteen straight games, will face Manhattan College in the second game of a twin bill which also pairs L. I. U. and Duquesne.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, will meet Monday with the special committee named by the Conference of Southern Governors to bring to the Administration's attention the problems created in the solid South by the President's civil rights message.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 16 -- Natives of this ski-jumping town where three national championships have been held since 1922 were still discussing yesterday's spectacular competition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Most management men believe that the Taft-Hartley Law will be a long-term factor in bringing about labor peace, E. H. Van Delden, director of industrial relations of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, said today.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, which has refused to qualify under the Taft-Hartley Act, astounded officials of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday by charging them with violating the law.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that owners of wartime plants who suffered losses in strikes called before the thirty-day "cooling-off" period can collect damages from employes.

William A. Chambers, retiring after thirty years with the local station of the United States Weather Bureau, felt free on Sunday to speak out. The Bureau doesn't make the weather, he told a reporter for this newspaper. The public, he added, "should be a little more lenient with the Weather Bureau boys."

As a means of clarifying tournament play, Ed Dudley, president of the Professional Golfers Association, said here yesterday that hereafter tournaments sponsored by his organization "would be played under the rules of the United States Golf Association," with one slight deviation.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Playing in conjunction with the National Women's Squash Racquets Association tournament which gets under way here tomorrow, the Boston team defeated New York in a Class A inter-city team match, 5 to 0, on the courts of the Greenwich Field Club today.

The temporary withdrawal of the Indian delegation from the argument of the Kashmir case before the Security Council of the United Nations should not be interpreted as mere petulance or pique. This is not a game in which one or another "picks up his marbles." The Indians, in bringing this problem before the Security Council, raised some profound issues.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 1 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 16 (UP) -- President Romulo Gallegos, who was inaugurated yesterday, today named a twelve-man Cabinet that included eight hold-overs from the Government of his predecessor, provisional President Romulo Betancourt.

Those inventors who think up ingenious gadgets for making kitchen chores easier still are at work. On a recent shopping tour, we discovered in the housewares department at Macy's three of the latest devices they've perfected to overcome culinary problems.

With every detail of the murder of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner known to them, the police yesterday sent out a nation-wide alarm for the slayer. He is believed to be carrying the same weapon with which he fired five bullets into the ex-convict on the night of Jan. 13.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A registration statement covering 100,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Pet Milk Company of St. Louis. The shares are to be offered first to the company's preferred stockholders by an underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., New York; G. H. Walker Co., St. Louis, and Julien Collins Co., Chicago.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A United States-British-French conference on Western Germany was postponed today until next Monday to allow Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas time to return to London from Washington and prepare to lead the United States delegation.

ROME, Feb. 16 -- The Archbishops and Bishops of Southern Italy have issued a joint pastoral letter urging the clergy and the faithful to bring about needed social and agricultural reforms. They also call upon Catholics to use even "material force" if necessary in defense of their rights.

Beneficial effects of the Taft-Hartley Act on the shipping industry are reflected in the sharp decline in the number of man days lost by strikes during 1947 in comparison with the previous year, the Association of American Ship Owners declared yesterday.

An undetermined number of burglars came to dinner over the week-end in the office building at 150-152 and 154 Chambers Street. When they were through, the floors were covered with tuna fish cans, whisky bottles and safes -- all empty.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Fire and casualty insurance companies were told today by Robert E. Dineen, state Superintendent of Insurance, to expect commission wars if legislation to forestall them were not adopted at the current session of the Legislature.
WARSAW, Feb. 16 -- Ambassador Stanton Griffis returned to his post today after two months in the United States for holidays and consultations with the President and State Department.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade from the opening on the Board of Trade today under leadership of corn. The May and July deliveries of corn and all futures of soy beans advanced the 8-cent-a-bushel daily limit and closed at the top.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Failure of the Government to go to court last November should cost it the opportunity to seek an injunction now, the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, contended today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Despite increased school support during the past year, a serious school crisis confronts the United States, a nation-wide survey conducted for the National Education Association asserted today. Millions of children are attending obsolete schools and are receiving a meager and inferior education, the report charged.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The State University Commission, headed by Owen D. Young, recommended today the establishment of a state university system to consist of several four-year colleges in various areas, professional schools, teacher colleges and a number of two-year community colleges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Supreme Court today wrote the final chapter to the controversy over the bargaining rights of foremen by excluding them from coverage of the Taft-Hartley Act.

HAVANA, Feb. 16 -- The functions of the proposed International Trade Organization were expanded today to make it responsible for broader action to promote the development of economically backward countries. This step was taken by the full Committee on Economic Development, which represents all fifty-eight countries participating in the Havana Conference.

A program to establish brand-name acceptance for plastic products made by manufacturers using Dow Chemical Company materials was announced yesterday by the company. Main emphasis will be on Styron, Dow's polystyrene, because of its wide use in household items.

A rent survey similar to one in 1945 will be made here in cooperation with accountants from the office of the Federal Housing Expediter, Joseph D. McGoldrick, chairman of the New York City Rent Advisory Board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The largest profiter, so far as is known, in the recent fall in farm prices, E. T. Maynard of Chicago, was quickly and unanimously cleared today by a Senate investigating committee of any impropriety in his trading.

BRUSSELS, Belgium Feb. 16 -- While thousands of striking coal miners went back to the pits today and gas and electricity workers decided to resume work, the Communists were trying to provoke strikes among Brussels street-car conductors.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Trustees of the Institute of Modern Art of Boston announced today a change of name to the Institute of Contemporary Art and with it issued a formal statement of principles and future policy. These steps, the trustees said, were aimed at eliminating "double talk, opportunism and chicanery at the public expense."

Otis Co. said yesterday that a compelling factor in their decision to cancel the underwriting of 900,000 shares of Kaiser-Frazer stock was the refusal of the Kaiser-Frazer directors to reimburse them automobile manufacturing concern for $2,500,000 it spent in buying its own stock in the market before the offering to stabilize the price.

Members of the executive committee of the Columbia University Student Council will meet with several members of the Columbia Board of Trustees to discuss tuition and rent increases today at 4 P. M. at an unspecified place, Albert E. Marten, chairman of the council, announced yesterday.
A program for retarded children was outlined yesterday by Dr. Earl A. Taylor, director of the Washington Square Reading Center, 15 Washington Place.

Declaring that the Long Island Rail Road failed "to provide reasonable accommodations to the public," the Public Service Commission ordered the railroad yesterday to obtain and to place in service fifty new cars of modern design.

Much of the current discussion of the Marshall Plan is based on the wholly erroneous assumption that it involves disinterested benevolence, commonly called charity, on the part of the American Government. The only proper argument for the adoption of the Marshall Plan by Congress is that such action should promote our national interest.

The first phase of the plan to relieve traffic congestion in the garment district opened yesterday when 1,000 posters, announcing trucking pick-up and delivery changes effective March 1, were placed at strategic spots in the area.
ST. HELIER, Jersey, Channel Islands, Feb. 16 -- The gloom that hangs over Britain has not yet touched the Channel Islands, where the people are prosperous and the shop windows full.

City and state officials and oil and railroad men took steps yesterday, while continued mild weather took the sting out of the fuel oil shortage, to rush additional supplies before the next cold wave hits here.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg dismissed yesterday an action brought by eighty owners of thoroughbred race horses who sought to prevent the State Labor Relations Board from conducting a trial on charges of unfair labor practices, made by an AFL union representing grooms and exercise boys.
Highway engineers agreed ruefully yesterday that the city's main roads are in "the worst shape ever."

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Britain is moving forward today to meet what Hector McNeil, Minister of State, called "the challenge to our authority" in what the British officially term the Falkland Island Dependencies of Antarctica.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Continued Federal rent controls were upheld unanimously by the Supreme Court today.

The quick thinking of a 68-year-old widow foiled an attempted hold-up by three youths who confronted her with a bayonet in her jewelry shop at 2346 Broadway yesterday afternoon, and resulted in the capture of a 16-year-old boy, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Did the two press releases issued by the Department of Agriculture on Feb. 5, the first Thursday after grain prices began to drop, represent a deliberate attempt to restore high prices, and for political purposes?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that South Carolina may not compel separate incorporation by the Seaboard Air Line Railroad Company, a Virginia corporation.

Let's consider that Eva Le Gallienne has done her duty by Ibsen's drama about duty. She plays the leading character in "Ghosts" as intelligently as Ibsen wrote the part. With the assistance of Margaret Webster, who directed the performance, she has mounted the play respectfully at the Cort, where it opened last evening.

Prices on the nation's primary markets in stocks, grains, livestock and commodities generally surged upward yesterday. In the retail field a minor price war seemed to be developing in meat and a few other staples among the large chains.
New bond issues of public utility companies totaling $21,000,000 were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to underwriting managers as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Britain's Labor Government had apparently won a preliminary skirmish with organized labor tonight in a drive for a "freeze" on general wage increases. The Trades Union Congress "crisis committee," which had been in revolt against the Government's demand for a moratorium on demands for wage advances, concluded a four-hour meeting by adopting a recommendation that the Government proposals be accepted by union labor.

This newspaper began delivery yesterday from its own radio station to receiving sets in fourteen New York City department stores of a four-page facsimile edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES. It is not, nor is it intended to be, a substitute for the regular editions. The facsimile edition, for instance, has only four pages, each less than one-quarter the size of a regular newspaper page.

ROME, Feb. 16 -- The municipal election yesterday in Pescara -- the result of which was awaited eagerly throughout Italy for an indication of the latest political trend -- showed a considerable increase in Left Wing strength compared with a similar election on April 7, 1946.

When the General Assembly of the United Nations voted last November to recommend partition as a solution of the problem in Palestine, it took several steps which were intended to give effect to its recommendation. It created a special Commission, consisting of representatives of five smaller nations (Denmark, Czechoslovakia, Panama, Bolivia and the Philippines), to serve as its agent in this matter.

Mayor O'Dwyer told the United States Conference of Mayors yesterday that its members had arrived here just in time to find New Yorkers "up to our ears" in a fight with the state over financial problems. He admitted he was afraid it would be a long while before the fight would be won.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Charges against the Greater Newark Industrial Union Council for alleged repudiation of national policies of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will be filed this week with Philip Murray, CIO national president.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A wheelchair basketball team of paraplegic combat veterans appealed to President Truman today to "come to our rescue" by permitting three Army hospital staff members to accompany them on a cross-country exhibition tour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Truman said today that he would request further military assistance for Greece and Turkey "at the appropriate time." He will act, presumably, before June 30, for he explained that the request would be made under the Greek-Turkish aid law, which expires July 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The reconstruction of education in war-devastated regions and the exchange of persons will occupy the fourth meeting of the United States Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization at its two-day session starting here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation annonuced today that it had agreed to lend an additional $24,000,000 to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority of New York so that it may complete the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

PRAGUE Czechoslovakia, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Vladimir Clementis, Deputy Foreign Minister, declared in a broadcast tonight that the initiative for the German affairs conference, summoned to meet here tomorrow, had come from Poland. He indicated that it would be concerned principally with averting the emergence of a "new danger from Germany."

Against an attractive decor by William Pahlmann, the second of the Anson-Jones shops, which feature dresses at a single price, $29.95, will open its doors today at New Street and Exchange Place. Created to cater to the busy young women of Wall Street, this shop will specialize in youthful daytime and cocktail fashions in misses, and junior sizes.

Differing views on the advisability of a temporary gas rate increase for the Consolidated Edison Company were submitted yesterday to the Public Service Commission by two Congress of Industrial Organizations groups.

In submitting his second report on American aid to Greece and Turkey, President Truman has notified Congress that he will soon ask for additional funds to expand military assistance to these two countries, apart from any economic help that Greece may receive under the Marshall Plan.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- An anesthetic being given to a patient in the New Rochelle Hospital exploded today. The patient, Carlo di Iorio, 47 years old, of 23 Birch Street, New Rochelle, had been undergoing a leg operation. Tonight he was on the hospital critical list because of internal injuries caused by the explosion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Supreme Court declined today to order the immediate admittance of Mrs. Ada Lois Sipuel Fisher, a Negro, to the University of Oklahoma Law School. In an unsigned opinion, the tribunal denied Mrs. Fisher's argument that Oklahoma courts had disobeyed the Supreme Court ruling, issued on Jan. 12, that she must have an equal education "as soon as applicants of any other group."

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Senate Republicans, in an hour-and-a-half meeting behind closed doors, agreed unanimously tonight to support the $30,000,000 education aid program of Governor Dewey, thereby killing all chances for the enactment of the more liberal Young-Milmoe bill.

Gene Boland of Detroit made his main bout bow in the middle-weight feature last night in the St. Nicholas Arena. His opponent was Harold Anspach, of Milburn, N. J. Weights were even, each 156 1/2. The attendance was 1,710 and the receipts $3,608.

To the unusually large number of important exhibitions this season the Paul Rosenberg Gallery has added a philanthropic one. Yesterday afternoon it opened with a reception and preview an all-loan exhibition of paintings by Delacroix and Renoir which will continue until March 13 for the benefit of the New York Heart Association, which is seeking to raise a half million dollars for research, education and service in fighting cardiac afflictions.

NANKING, Feb. 16 -- A new Chinese approach to the problem of getting Export-Import Bank loans is being tested in a preliminary agreement concluded here between the National Resources Commission and the Reynolds Metal Company for developing Formosa's aluminum industry.

Harold Rubens, who appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has the makings of a first-rate pianist. He is a good one now, and at times he plays brilliantly. To become a major figure he needs more depth and maturity, and since he is only 26, there is reason to suppose that he will find more and more of his own to say as time goes on.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder declared here today that the "cold facts" of the present economic situation preclude reductions in Federal taxes now.

The Dublin Gate Theatre, which launched its first New York engagement last week with a revival of Shaw's "John Bull's Other Island," will turn this evening to Denis Johnston's "The Old Lady Says 'No'!" at the Mansfield Theatre.

A threatened strike of 250 warehouse and office workers against the Miles Shoe Company and the A. S. Beck Shoe Company was averted yesterday when company and union negotiators reached agreement on a new contract.

The City Council voted 13 to 5 yesterday for a committee report opposing the seating of Simon W. Gerson as a Communist member to succeed the late Peter Cacchione of Brooklyn. The action was taken on the ground that the Communist party was not a political party as defined by the Election Law and the Court of Appeals.

Slates of delegates to their respective national conventions were named here yesterday by the Democratic and Republican leaders of New York County. Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader, and Secretary of State in the Dewey Administration, made public a slate which he said was "unequivocally" behind the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for President.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- "One Woman," a 1933 novel by Tiffany Thayer to which Paramount has owned the screen rights for more than ten years, has been revived by the studio as a probable vehicle for Alan Ladd and assigned to Robert Fellows for production.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago fashioned a six-under-par 65 today to win the $10,000 Lower Rio Grande Valley open golf tournament in a play-off with Jim Demaret of Ojai, Calif.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Blonde Suzanne Zimmerman of Portland, Ore., carried home today four titles of the Southern California A.A.U. indoor swimming championships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, warned Marshall Plan advocates today that his group would require "much more information" before endorsing the $5,300,000,000 voted by the Foreign Relations Committee for the first twelve months of operations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- The working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission took up again today the long-debated Soviet proposals for international control of atomic energy, and heard Russia and the United States accuse each other of going constantly over old ground, and getting nowhere.

Harrison Williams, financier, gave testimony in Federal court yesterday in a pre-trial examination by Government attorneys, in connection with the Department of Justice's anti-trust action against seventeen leading investment firms and the Investment Bankers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A bill to extend social security coverage to all employed persons, except Federal and railroad workers, and clergymen, was introduced in the House today by Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican, of New Jersey.

MADRID, Feb. 16 -- Official Spain is attaching the utmost importance to the Eisenhower statement, published yesterday, and especially with reference to the general's remarks on the Mediterranean. The statement has been received here as the first definitive outline of United States military and political policy in this area, and one in which Spain inevitably must be brought into the picture.

The annual report of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its subsidiaries showed yesterday a net income for 1947 of $13,376,662, equal to $4.22 a share. Net income for 1946 totaled $9,699,533 or $3.06 a share.

Ross Anzalone, Harlem welterweight, and Al Victoria, Brooklyn, yesterday were reported in fighting condition for their eight-round bout which features the card at the Park Arena, the Bronx, tonight. In the semi-final Eugene Hairston, Bronx lightweight, tackles Cazk Taylor, Brooklyn.

In mid-July, 1946, Governor Dewey appointed a thirty-member commission to study the need for a state university. That commission, established by the Legislature and headed by Owen D. Young, has now reported that there is such a need. It finds that by 1960 additional four-year facilities to accommodate 30,000 full-time students may be needed in the state.

The new FM short-wave station of WOR, a mobile unit using the call letters WOEP, received its initial demonstration yesterday. The installation was used to relay a regularly scheduled news commentary back to WOR for broadcast while on its way to cover a local news story.

Facsimile newspapers were received yesterday at leading department stores in the first post-war demonstration of the new medium on a large scale. The papers were written and edited by a staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES and transmitted over WQXR-FM.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 -- Recalling more than 150,000 employes to their jobs tomorrow, following a three-week shutdown caused by a shortage of gas fuel, the automotive and other industries in this area faced the prospect today of witnessing a contemporaneous wage drive against the General Motors and Chrysler Corporations.

The Real Estate Board of New York, in an open letter to Mayor William O'Dwyer, charged yesterday that the Tax Department methods of assessing real estate for 1948-49 were "haphazard," "capricious" and likely to work "grave financial injury to the city." The letter was signed by Jones W. Mesereau, executive vice president of the board.

Manhattan College's basketball team was no match for unbeaten New York University last night, the Violets recording their seventeenth victory, 73 -- 58. Long Island University vanquished Duquesne, 55 -- 48, in the opener as the college sport was resumed at Madison Square Garden after nearly a month's lapse.

We know that we cannot live forever, and we also know that when the heart stops life stops too. Perhaps for this reason we are more reconciled to death from some failure of the heart and circulatory system than we are to death from cancer or some infectious disease. Yet so far as statistics go we ought to be horrified at the toll that so-called "heart failure" takes.

WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- The rapidly deteriorating French-Polish relations touched a new low tonight when the Polish Government delivered what was considered a deliberate diplomatic insult to the French Ambassador Jean Baelen by boycotting an official reception at the French Embassy.
A jurisdictional strike brought to a virtual standstill yesterday work on two big public housing projects and threatened to tie up a third project unless it is settled by next week.

A horrifying picture of what would happen to an American city if an atomic bomb should explode over it was presented yesterday to the United States Conference of Mayors by Maj. Gen. Harold R. Bull, deputy chief of the Army General Staff.
Nationwide support for a dog and cat Marshall Plan was solicited yesterday by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, defied the formally expressed opposition of fifteen major league clubs to give Jackie Robinson, Negro star, his chance at organized baseball.
James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, tripped over one of his own bans yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Department of Commerce announced tonight that it had halted the granting of export licenses for gasoline and fuel oil for forty-eight hours to permit "a survey of the oil requirements of foreign countries."

The North American Light and Power Company plans to retire its publicly held 109,255 shares of $6 preferred stock on or about March 3, it was announced yesterday by D. E. Ackers, president. The total amount payable on retirement will approximate $194 a share, equivalent to $100 each and accrued dividends to the date fixed.

Discussing in these columns ten days ago the break in commodity prices, then in its early stage, we emphasized the absurdity of prophesying its extent or duration. Adjustments of this kind, we pointed out, are almost invariably effected by a series of pendulum-like swings, the violence of which is completely unpredictable.

Obviously Denis Johnston's "The Old Lady Says 'No'!" is for the ears of Irishmen. And obviously too much of it is too close to gibberish. The faults of the romantic drama that the Gate Players put on at the Mansfield last evening are easy enough to perceive and define.

Application of wool, linen and rayon fabric labeling has brought great improvement in the merchandising of textiles, Henry Miller, director of the Bureau of Trade Practice Conferences and Wool Act Administration of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Assembly Republicans, after a two-and-a-half-hour conference behind closed doors, voted 3 to 1 this afternoon to support Governor Dewey's program for increasing state aid to education by $30,000,000 a year in preference to the Young-Milmoe bill, which would increase it $90,000,000.

Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto, who, if he never does anything else, will go down in baseball history as the fellow who both broke up a world series no-hitter and won a game with a pinch double, is ready to come back and try it all over again.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Speaking at a dinner of representatives of the exporting industries tonight, Premier Robert Schuman insisted that "great efforts be made to reduce the prices of our goods sold abroad by every possible means.

I have heard it related as a joke that an Irish legislature once passed a bill providing for the construction of a new jail from the materials obtained by tearing down the old jail -- the prisoners to remain in the old building until the completion of the new one.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 -- Arabs attacked members of the British forces in the "old city" of Jerusalem on two separate occasions today. They killed two British policemen and seriously wounded four soldiers.

As the second qualifying round of the Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship was played last night at the Pierre, interest centered around the Chinese team consisting of L. S. Sun, I. T. Sun, Victor Shen, D. L. Chang and Kingman Dong.

Anthony Campagna, owner of the block on Washington Square South between Thompson Street and West Broadway, flatly rejected yesterday a proposal by Bishop William T. Manning and several residents of Greenwich Village that the site be converted into an art center.

Allocations of steel pipe to distributors for the second quarter in this area have been reduced 15 per cent by leading producers, it was learned yesterday. Announcements to that effect are being sent to distributors.

Banking syndicates headed by The First Boston Corporation will offer to investors today two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $40,000,000, and consisting of $25,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds of Philadelphia Electric Company and $15,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds of Illinois Power Company.

The promptness of American export collections paid by Latin America as a whole improved during January, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the latest monthly survey, based on figures supplied by the twelve participating New York City banks, the number of prompt collections increased to 59 per cent of all Latin-American collections, compared with 57.5 per cent in December and 55.4 per cent in November.
TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- Attempts to sell to the Japanese former Premier Hideki Tojo's testimony before the international tribunal have been an almost complete failure here.

NANKING, Feb. 17 -- Communists broke through the northeastern and southern suburbs of Anshan today. According to the semi-official Central News Agency, the isolated government garrison is trying to beat off "waves of rebel daredevils."
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The Security Council decided today to discuss the Palestine problem next Tuesday.
I WAS ill at home when word of Hitler's invasion of Russia on June 22, 1941, reached me. Immediately I telephoned the President and then Under-Secretary Welles. To each I said, in effect:

The educators and clergymen who approve bottling up the bill for Universal Military Training in the House Rules Committee seem to us to be condoning undemocratic procedure. Why should not this measure, so strongly recommended by President Truman and General Eisenhower, be permitted to come to a vote?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Any early Congressional action to give the Administration a strong controlling hand over speculation in the nervous commodity exchanges appeared doubtful today as the Senate Committee on Agriculture concluded its open hearings on the issue.

Continued balmy weather, topped by a high of 56 degrees at 3:15 P. M. yesterday saw the remains of the winter's accumulated snows disappearing from streets and sidewalks. Their going posed a special problem for the Department of Sanitation in the clearance of exposed refuse.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- "Wholesale" violations of the law to regulate lobbying were reported to Congress today by the Department of Justice.

Leo Isacson, the candidate of Henry A. Wallace, was elected to Congress yesterday in a special election in the Twenty-fourth Congressional district in the Bronx. He scored a sweeping and surprising victory over Karl Propper, candidate of Edward J. Flynn's regular Democratic organization, in a four-man race in which Dean Alfange, Liberal party nominee, finished third and Joseph A. De Nigris, Republican, was last.

First market reports suggest that the banking syndicate whose single bid bought in the $85,000,000 final installment of the Illinois soldiers' bonus bonds did a good pricing job. Confined to maturities not running beyond 1960, bonds both short and long were said to be finding a receptive market, with jumpiness evident only in the 1959 and 1960 serials, which were oversubscribed and bid to premiums from the start.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,200, against 1,547 last week and 1,247 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 508 arrivals yesterday, compared with 899 last Tuesday.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, asserted today that "blood, death and fears" raging in the world resulted from secret agreements made by the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Appointment of Thomas J. Shanahan as a member of the New York City Housing Authority to succeed Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch was announced by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Increased living allowances for veterans in school will be granted only to full-time students. In announcing this today, the Veterans Administration said that part-time students, on-the-job trainees and others are not entitled to the rises provided in a bill signed by President Truman last Saturday.

"We could have a war tomorrow; I could name a half dozen spots in which it could break out," Ray H. Brannaman, commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars declared yesterday, Mr. Brannaman was speaking for his organization's program of national preparedness and Universal Military Training, in a press interview at the Astor Hotel.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Debate was opened today on Finance Minister Rene Mayer's bill to repress illicit price rises. The issue is expected to be settled tomorrow.

The industrial, historical and cultural advantages of southern New England as "a great place to live, work and play" are condensed in a new exhibit on the east balcony of the Grand Central terminal for which the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is sponsor.

The new and the old are always in conflict in a changing, growing city. Usually sentiment has to give way. Washington Square is only a small bit of New York, but there are many who love it. On one block of the square a large apartment house is planned. Another site has been chosen by New York University for a law center.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- It's getting to be a habit. For the second afternoon in succession the "dead heat" neons were turned on after the main event at Hialeah Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A spokesman for twenty-three Eastern railroads estimated today that natural gas could take $39,000,000 to $59,000,000 a year from the railroads' pockets. He was William Wyer, of Newark, N. J., a consulting engineer. His specialty, he said, was railroad problems.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Feb. 17 -- A four-year fight to establish his innocence on a vote fraud charge ended successfully today for John R. Longo, 34-year-old political foe of State Democratic Leader Frank Hague, when Hudson County Quarter Sessions Judge John Drewen directed a verdict of acquittal.
