VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- Russian occupation authorities sent out Soviet soldiers today to confiscate copies of former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes' book "Speaking Frankly" in the three Russian-occupied districts of Vienna and the Soviet zone of Austria.

We do not recall any instance when Joseph Szigeti gave a more impressive demonstration of his art than he did when he played last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Szigeti put before his audience a program that reversed every rule of popular appeal to an audience, and that asked everything of the violinist but sensational effects and pyrotechnical feats calculated to catch superficial applause.

Four new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Roxy the attraction is "Call Northside 777," a Twentieth Century-Fox topical drama starring James Stewart. Henry Hathaway directed and Otto Lang produced, with Lee J. Cobb, Richard Conte, Helen Walker, J. M. Kerrigan and Betty Garde among the featured players . . .
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 17 (AP) -- A total of 2,747 stock corporations were chartered in New York State last month.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 17 -- The Hofstra College basketball squad, which had resigned in a body yesterday because of "general dissatisfaction" with Head Coach John B. MacDonald, thereby following a step taken last week by Co-Captain Roy Triebel, today agreed to finish the schedule under a new mentor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Trailing Georgetown by 13 points with five minutes to play, Fordham staged a desperate rally to capture its fourteenth basketball victory, 51-50, tonight at the National Guard Armory.

About $38,000 of a fund collected in 1940 to further the candidacy of Wendell L. Willkie for President has been donated to Indina University to establish Willkie memorial scholarships, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Willkie, a native Hoosier, was graduated from the university in 1913.

Two top Communist officials and a maritime workers' labor leader -- all under arrest by the Department of Justice as subversive aliens illegally in this country -- lost legal battles yesterday for release from Ellis Island.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Acting in response to the Government's request, British industry began today a rapid study of the means for reducing production costs and selling prices.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 17 -- The Connecticut General Assembly opened a special session today to revise the state sales-and-use tax, which has yielded nearly double the revenue expected.

Considering this city's size, it's cramped living quarters, lack of space for the challenging, normal things children need and like to do, "it is a miracle they turn out so well," Mark A. McCloskey declared yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 17 -- One of the greatest changes that has taken place in Germany during the past year is the change of mind first of the Germans and then of the occupying forces. In Berlin the Germans are all but forgotten in the general absorption in relations among the great Powers, but in Frankfort one sees the other side of the picture.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Organized labor has been assured recognition in the administration of the Marshall Plan.
DUBLIN, Feb. 17 -- The sixteen-year rule of Premier Eamon de Valera will come to an end in the Assembly session tomorrow.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman accused the British last night of shipping arms to the Arabs for the Palestine conflict and particularly to contiguous countries where Arabs are preparing for attack.

Avoidance of bias and freedom to deal with controversial subjects were declared yesterday to be the first principles of news presentation and the ideals for teaching of current affairs in the city's schools.

The ten-story loft building at 648 Broadway, adjoining the corner of Bleecker Street, has been acquired by Thomas Moffa, operator, who reports that a resale is pending to a purchaser who intends to use the building for his business.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- The unexpectedly long time that it is taking to write a book of rules for world trade in keeping with United Nations ideals can be explained by the size, variety and nature of the obstacles that have been encountered.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The Republic of Indonesia made a direct bid to the Security Council today for United Nations supervision of the intricate political negotiations with the Dutch that are expected to end in the creation of a sovereign United States of Indonesia.

Harrison Williams, chairman of the North American Company, was excused yesterday until April 15 from testifying further in his pretrial deposition in the Governments suit against the Investment Bankers Association of America and seventeen investment firms.

NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- University of Oklahoma Center John Rapacz admitted tonight he "recently" had signed a contract with the Cleveland Browns of the All-America Professional Football League but charged he "was treated unfairly."
The Navy turned down yesterday Mayor O'Dwyer's request for another loan of diesel oil and explained it had no more of this type of fuel available for civilian use.

Meditation following perusal of the plans for that world - renowned event, the music festival at Salzburg in Austria, to be held during next July and August, has brought a lot of retrospective pleasure to one reminiscent New Yorker.

Six of the eight men arrested after the attempt last month to ship TNT to Palestine pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges involving the filing of false export declarations. Judge Sylvester J. Ryan suspended sentence but put the men on probation for a year with the stipulation that they did not have to report to a probation officer but were not to violate any law "of any kind" during that period.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Surprise was caused in London diplomatic circles today by the Soviet declaration in favor of trusteeship for Italy over her former colonies in Africa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall urged the House tonight to reverse a Senate decision and permit the Administration to sell or charter American merchant ships to foreign countries.

The health of the American people is inferior to that of "quite a few other countries" and Federal aid for medical education is essential if we are to avert a public health crisis because of a shortage of trained personnel, Oscar R. Ewing declared yesterday.

As regional rent-control executives reported approvals of 234,561 voluntary leases in New York increasing residential rents by as much as 15 per cent, the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee announced yesterday that it had protested to the New York Rent Advisory Board against further delay in a decision on its application for a general 15 per cent rise here.

Harold Green, Brooklyn middleweight, knocked out Joe Falco of Philadelphia in 1:11 of the second of the main bout listed for eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Green, 160, stopped Falco, 156 1/2, with a right to the jaw.
John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council came forth yesterday with an idea on buying fish that is as practical as it was new to us. He said:

There is no reason why a table lamp should not be both functional and decorative, with neither quality sacrificed to the other, according to Arpad Rosti who exhibited his newest designs yesterday at his studio, 343 East Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight the names of the eight men missing in the swamping of a motor launch en route to the carrier Midway. It added that it had no details on the accident and that no bodies had been recovered.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, an early upturn in wheat was failing to hold and the close was 3 1/4 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel lower. May corn, however, showed independent strength and at one time was 4 5/8 cents higher, only to react later with wheat and finish 2 1/8 cents higher.

The Socony-Vacuum tanker Mobilube, repaired recently after being badly damaged by a Japanese torpedo in 1943, is en route here from San Pedro, Calif., with 4,936,974 gallons of fuel oil, which will be distributed to consumers in the New York area to help offset the critical oil shortage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- In the face of revolt by Southern Democrats in an election year, President Truman is ready, it was learned today, to take a dramatic step in his efforts to get his civil rights program through Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- "Left wing" unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, standing on their "autonomous rights," are disregarding the CIO's policy declaration against formation of a third party.

The final chapter in the fabulous story of Mrs. Laura Mae Corrigan, widow of James W. Corrigan, Cleveland steel magnate, was written in Surrogate's Court yesterday where her will was offered for probate. The legatees looked like a list taken from Burke's Peerage or the Almanach de Gotha.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Dewey signed today the first of two measures advanced by the Public Service Commission to give the commission power to distribute gas supplies more effectively during periods of emergency. The new law empowers the commission to enjoin gas manufacturers from supplying additional customers or from supplying gas to present customers for purposes prohibited by the commission.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, already charged with perjury, was indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today on a charge of evading $15,658 in 1941 income taxes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- In a special meeting tonight, All-America Football Conference representatives reached agreement on a 1948 playing schedule. A spokesman announced that the schedule had been adopted and that each of the eight clubs, following the pattern of the past two years, would disclose its slate of home games separately and at its convenience.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are working on complaints from thousands of ex-GI's that they were cheated on veterans housing. The Department of Justice today said reports of chiseling by builders have come in from nearly every part of the country, the largest number being from Los Angeles, Baltimore, New York, New Orleans, Miami, Dallas and Chicago.

Mr. and Mrs. William Dayton Holmes will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 1 East End Avenue, for members of committees aiding plans for the Leap Year supper dance for the benefit of the Crusade for Children of the United Nations, to be held Feb. 29 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Republican policy committee of the Senate decided today to press for long-term extension of rent control rather than a stop-gap 30-day continuance. It recognized, however, that the House might not be able to act on full-scale rent legislation before control expires Feb. 29 and indicated a willingness to suport an interim extension in that contingency.

Several countries are in agreement with the United States Olympic Committee that the Ligue Internationale Sur Glace should be reorganized as a result of its policies in the recent Winter Olympic Games, Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, said last night upon his arrival on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Favorites won their matches in the first round of the sixteenth national tournament of golf club champions today but several of them advanced only by close margins.
Fifteen children with heart ailments in a ward at Bellevue Hospital received toys, games and books yesterday from Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable Co.

An informal cooperative effort between American business and philanthropy to aid social and educational development of the countries of the Near East will yield good-will and increased business potentials, Dr. W. Wendell Cleland, chief of the division of research for the Near East and Africa, Department of State, aid yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 17 -- The five commissioners of this city's "reform" administration officially accepted today the controversial report on the city's government that begins with the words, "The people of Hoboken have been robbed."

Verbally presented with a key to the city of fashion, delegates to the United States Conference of Mayors and their wives were entertained yesterday with a showing of spring and summer fashions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the New York Dress Institute and United States and foreign airlines.
When Joe Louis sails tomorrow aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for England, he will not be particularly worried about food rationing on the tight little isle.

Limited gains were made yesterday by the stock market, but buying proved timid and lack of bids permitted a mixed tone to develop near the close. Uneasiness developed in the commodities and Wall Street doubted that even the share list had completely recovered to a more normal basis.

Many commodity prices, and particularly most grain prices, turned downward yesterday as waves of selling overcame early strength in the primary markets. Wheat and oats dropped lower in all the country's grain markets. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat, which had advanced Saturday and Monday, closed 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel lower.

Plans for the construction of new television studios, involving the expenditure of "several hundred thousand dollars," were announced yesterday by Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The studios will be erected in the Grand Central Terminal Building, where CBS has its present television headquarters.

Restoration of the port facilities of Rotterdam probably will be complete by the end of the year but resumption of traffic through the port on a pre-war scale will depend largely on the rehabilitation of Germany, Pieter J. Oud, Mayor of Rotterdam, said yesterday.

DISCOVERY BAY, South Shetland Islands, Feb. 17 -- Chilean President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla landed today on Greenwich Island to lay claim personally to territory lying south of Cape Horn that is in dispute between Chile and Great Britain.
There will be no carrier delivery of mall in the city on Monday, which will be observed as Washington's Birthday, it was announced yesterday.

The police looked in vain yesterday for Santo Bretagno, wanted for the murder of Benjamin Weiner, who was shot to death the night of Jan. 13 on the fifth floor at 68 East First Street beside the crib in which his six-month-old son slept.
A maritime program involving purchase and operation of eighteen passenger and cargo ships in and to the Mediterranean awaits establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine, it became known yesterday.

Italy will cast its national vote, corresponding to our Congressional elections, on April 18. Forecasters have been watching for some indication of what the trend will be. It remains to be seen whether they have found the clue in the municipal election in Pescara.

THE death of Mordecai (Three-Fingered) Brown inevitably raises two questions. One is: Why hasn't the great Cub pitcher been named to the Hall of Fame? The second is: Was Fred Merkle really out at second base in that unforgettable Cub-Giant game of 1908, an episode which has become known to posterity as "Merkle's Boner"?
Frank E. Hadley has been appointed foreign sales director of the Wallace, Burton Davis Company division, Airline Foods Corporation. He formerly was general manager of Hadley Delbrick Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 -- The Affiliated Fashionists of California have endorsed the "soft look" for summer. The eight top-ranking designers of this group, who create styles from bathing suits to formal evening wear, are wholeheartedly for feminine curves.

The first official actions starting nation-wide purchasing information service to about 200 plants in the soap and glycerine industry were taken here yesterday by Lewis A. Jones, director of the purchase information bureau of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., 295 Madison Avenue.

The anticipated annual world demand for oil will reach four billion barrels, or more than 160 billion gallons, in 1951, according to a study presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Pennsylvania Hotel, by C. J. Bauer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The anti-Communist Force Ouvriere, backed by the American Federation of Labor, will represent France at the meeting of labor representatives from fifteen Marshall Plan nations.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- All parties agreed in principle this morning to avoid all violence and disturbances in the period leading up to the general election scheduled for April 18 and to declare a "political truce" until the election was over.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Texas Electric Service Company of Fort Worth asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to issue and sell at competitive bidding $5,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1978, and $5,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, due in 1973.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Dr. Oscar Lange, Poland's delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, today sharply criticized the European economic policies of the United States and contended that such "dividing" tactics were costly, futile and politically dangerous.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman today told a conference under the auspices of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, celebrating a century of feminine progress that organized women could use the weapon of consumer buying power to "combat one of the enemies that now threatens us -- the high cost of living."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Christopher P. Mayhew, British Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, declared here today that the world refugee problem could be solved by the continued cooperation of governments with the International Refugee Organization and with the United Nations itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman said today that he was an "optimist" about peace. He expressed his optimism at a White House reception for the delegates to a meeting here of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Neils Francis Rebholz, the 16-month-old boy who is being sent by his parents to live in Denmark for a year as the result of difficulties in establishing United States citizenship for him, left La Guardia Field for Copenhagen yesterday on an American Overseas Airlines plane.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 -- The question of the privacy of political party connections became a state issue today as the California Senate Committee on Un-American Activities resumed legislative hearings conducted intermittently for nearly a decade into subversive activities in the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur told Congress today that Japan would be plunged into a "blood bath of revolutionary violence" unless his occupation forces wrested economic control from its "discredited masters."

Universal-International will release twenty-four top budget pictures during the next nine months, according to a tentative releasing schedule disclosed yesterday by W. A. Scully, vice president and general sales manger, at a regional meeting of the company's Eastern sales representatives in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Alexander Cushing of Glen Head, L. I., a brother-in-law of Alexander McFadden and one of Mr. McFadden's skiing companions last Saturday when the latter was killed under a snow avalanche, denied yesterday that guides had warned them of danger during their fatal ski run near Aspen, Colo.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Charging a conspiracy to violate the Taft-Hartley Act, the Allied Printing Employers' Association and twenty-seven member concerns filed suit today in Common Pleas Court against the Philadelphia Typographical Union and the International Typographical Union, AFL.

ATHENS, Feb. 17 -- The press today voiced unanimous approval of President Truman's report to Congress yesterday on Greece, all papers seeing it as an accurate account of what had taken place and a fair assessment of this nation's present and future problems.
Martha Graham and her dance company opened an engagement of fourteen performances at Maxine Elliott's Theatre last night before distinguished and enthusiastic audience.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today an extension through June 30, 1949, of Government controls on tin, antimony, fats and oils and certain other commodities in short supply.

The State of Illinois yesterday sold $85,000,000 of serial bonds maturing from 1950 to 1960 to a syndicate headed by five Chicago banking institutions at an interest cost of 1.9485 per cent. Only one bid was submitted for the bonds, which represented the final financing installment for the state's $385,000,000 service recognition bonus for war veterans.

Recent drop in consumer demand for oriental rugs, attributable primarily to steadily increasing supplies of machine made domestic carpets, has led not only to retail price reductions but also to markdowns and growing merchandise consignment practices by importers and wholesalers, Hilton H. Hodges, president of the Oriental Rug Institute, revealed yesterday.

PRAGUE, Feb. 17 -- Antonio Zapotocky, most powerful Communist in Czechoslovakia next to Premier Klement Gottwalt, and chief of all the labor unions, has created a major scandal by declaring in a speech on Sunday: "Away with Parliament if it will not fulfill the program of the General Confederation of Labor."

TOULON, France, Feb. 17 -- Eight members of the crew of the U.S.S. Midway were reported missing following an accident to a liberty boat while en route back to the aircraft carrier early this morning. [Press services said no bodies had yet been recovered.]

MADISON, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Dr. Fred G. Hollaway, dean of Drew Theological Seminary, was elected president of Drew University at a meeting today of the board of trustees in the office of the New York Society of the Methodist Church, 150 Fifth Avenue, New York, it was announced here.
TULSA, Okla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Sunray Oil Corporation reported today that its gross operating income for 1947 was $38,138,450.

All industries in the garment area and the Police Department will cooperate fully to make the new voluntary traffic control plan for the area a success, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declared yesterday after conferring at headquarters with members of the joint committee of the garment industry.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Miss Mary Lee Kenyon of Anchorage, Ky., today provided a thrilling climax to the feature match of the invitational mixed foursomes golf tournament with a hole-in-one to win on the twenty-first hole.
PARIS, Feb. l7 -- The coordination of French and British policies in the West African colonies is the subject of an Anglo-French conference that opened here today.
DENVER, Feb. 17 -- The Denver Post reported today that the Kansas and Nebraska wheat crop is threatened by dust-blowing winds and lack of sufficient moisture.

BADEN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Chief Prosecutor Charles Gerthoffer today attributed to Hermann Roechling, Nazi industrialist now on trial at Rastatt, a dominant role in influencing the population of the Saar to choose annexation to Germany in the plebiscite of 1934.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 17 -- Army headquarters here released today a report on the mistreatment of two American liaison officers by north Korean police during a Pyongyang parade of the north Korean People's Army Feb. 8.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Despite open opposition of Catholic clergymen, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York area of the Methodist Church will keep a speaking engagement here next Monday.

I read THE TIMES' report of the Rev. Gannon's speech on the Truman Education Plan made at the Fordham University dinner with much interest, but, speaking as a Fordham graduate, I heartily disagree with it, and hope all "thinking" Fordham men disagree.

WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- The five-man crew of the plane that brought United States Ambassador Stanton Griffis back to Warsaw yesterday was released by Polish authorities today after twenty-two hours' detention for landing without visas. The crew immediately took off for Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The United States' embargo on the shipment of arms to Palestine is being carefully studied and reviewed in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed unanimously today to authorize use of $3,000,000,000 of this year's revenue surplus for financing the Marshall Plan in its first twelve months, beginning April 1.

MONTREAL, Canada, Feb. 17 -- The plastics industry should set up consumer goods standards below which it will not go, it was urged here today by Ephraim Freedman, director, Macy's Bureau of Standards, Macy's, New York. He spoke at the sixth annual international plastics conference of the Society of the Plastics Industry at the Mount Royal Hotel.

Peg Fischer has a knack of making wearable hats. Her spring and summer collection, seen yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, while not extreme, incorporated many lively features. Carioca, a reddish orange, brought a frequent vivid accent.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Apart from dealings in copper and gold mining shares, the stock markets here today were quiet.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- The United States today lost its effort to bring the occupied areas of Germany and Japan under the proposed International Trade Organization through the automatic acceptance of responsibilities on their account by the occupying powers that subscribe to the world trade charter.

Consolidated net sales of Aldens, Inc., mail order concern, last year reached a new high of $79,248,308, an increase of 13 per cent over the 1946 volume, Robert W. Jackson, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate Armed Forces Committee put off until early next month the decision on whether to consider or abandon the bill to establish a universal military training program.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 17 -- A proposal by a Newark legislator for a New Jersey personal income tax failed today to arouse support among the Republican majorities of the Senate and House and the party leadership in the state.

The letters to you of Milton R. Konvitz and Bartley C. Crum as well as your editorial, "A Test Case for the U. N.," are hammering the widely publicized argument of prestige into the public mind at the time of decision.
The Hunts Committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association has approved twenty race meetings for this year, including a renewal of one at Harrison, H. Y.

Universal military training is being sought as the cornerstone of indoctrination for young Americans rather than as an instrument of defense, Mrs. Alexander Stewart, president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, said last night.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Notes of both pessimism and optimism regarding the present situation in France, with the former predominating, were sounded by speakers on "What Hope for Democracy in France?" this afternoon at the Woman's Club of Maplewood.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (UP) -- No explanation has been issued yet for the replacement earlier today of Arseny Zverev as Soviet Minister of Finance by Alexei N. Kosygin. Mr. Zverev had held the post for nine years. He has stepped down to the position of First Deputy Minister.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Widespread adoption of profit-sharing would have marked stabilizing effect on our economy, by providing a needed measure of flexibility to our wage system, whose rigidity worsens the effects of both inflationary and deflationary swings, W. H. Wheeler Jr., president of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., Stamford, Conn., told the American Management Association today.

Thomas L. L. Ryan, chairman of the Fund-Raising Committee of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, named yesterday Dominic J. Marcello, executive director of American Relief for Italy, Inc., chairman of the Italian division of the All-Nations Committee, Red Cross 1948 Fund in Greater New York, at a ceremony at the Red Cross office at 130 West Forty-second Street.
Cotton futures prices turned lower on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 33 to 46 points net lower than Mondays closing levels.

Having become the only Columbia basketball player ever to score 1,000 points by raising his career total to 1,001 at Cornell Saturday, Walter Budko, Lion center, will try for a more significant record at Princeton tonight.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Parliament today approved a bill calling for the purchase of $10,000,000 worth of war materials, including tanks and planes, from the United States. The vote was 79 to 6, with 10 abstentions.

Once a hit opens in the hinterland, the grapevine invariably bears about it with incredible swiftness. Faster than it takes to split the atom, theatregoers seize upon the good news with alacrity on their haste to get tickets. How to those connected with the production feel about this state of affairs? They complain about the mounting interest, fearing the critics will be led to expect too much.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A 24-year-old former Harvard University student has become a man without a country because he wants to be a citizen of all the world.

Because Mrs. Annie Morgenlander could not tell the IRT from the BMT subway "and had to ask people all the time," she decided to learn to read and write English forty years after she arrived in this country from Poland. Yesterday Mrs. Morgenlander, who is a great-grandmother, lined up with eighteen classmates to receive certificates of merit for proficiency in their studies at the Grand Street Settlement, 283 Rivington Street.
The Detroit Red Wings will be at Madison Square Garden tonight for their first meeting with the Rangers since the 4 -- 4 tie at their home rink two weeks ago.

When the Little Assembly takes up, this week, the problem of Soviet non-cooperation in respect to a government for Korea, we will be well advised to remember that Korea is only part of the picture. The Russian refusal to allow a United Nations commission to enter North Korea is not an isolated act of obstructionism.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was considered to hold a lead over other Republican Presidential candidates in Nebraska today as the state Republicans endorsed delegates for the national convention. At the same time it was believed that his margin would slip away fast unless he put an organization into the field and actively campaigned before the April 13 primary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Warner Brothers has acquired "Miss Richmond Takes Grant," a screen comedy by Lester Fuller, which deals with a school teacher who fights and defeats a corrupt political machine in a small town. Alex Gottlieb will produce the film and Charles Hoffman has been assigned to write the photoplay as a probable vehicle for Barbara Stanwyck or Ann Sheridan.

The oil industry's fuel conservation campaign will continue on an all-out basis despite any amount of warm weather that develops during the balance of the winter, H. L. Curtiss of the Shell Oil Company and chairman of the American Petroleum Institute's special publicity and advertising committee, stated yesterday.

Some of the men who spend the long winter evenings whittling away at decoys are due to encounter opposition this year, for a number of women, hearing that Mrs. Florence Lewis of Stratford, Conn., won some of the prizes at the decoy contest, are planning to start work on some entries for next year's show.
GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- Few European countries are ready to carry out the United Nations Appeal for Children on Feb. 29, the projected date.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- G. R. Strauss, Minister of Supply, said in Birmingham tonight that automobile manufacturers who could not meet their export quota -- three-quarters of total output -- within a quoted reasonable time would have their allocation of steel reduced and thus be forced to close down their plants or turn to other engineering work.

Six members of the Columbia board of trustees who met yesterday with the executive committee of the Columbia University Student Council will recommend to the entire board at its next meeting, March 1, the further consideration of the problem of tuition and dormitory fees, Albert E. Marten, Student Council chairman, announced.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- The appeal by President Truman to the Arab states to use restraint in dealing with the Palestine problem has fallen on deaf ears. Arab leaders said today that there would be no change in the Arab League's decision to use regular Arab armies if an international military force were used to carry out partition.

Harry Lumley was just too much for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The stocky goalie for the Detroit Red Wings gave a superb performance as he helped his mates carve out a 3-to-1 victory and take first place undisputed in the National Hockey League, breaking a tie with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The world's food production is now clearly shaking off the war's long paralysis and with good luck the 1948-49 output will be big enough for a "moderate relaxation" generally in a supply position that so long has been so tight.

Industrial plants are going to cost more, construction interests reported here yesterday following a canvass of price and supply trends. In one case, that of cement, rising prices were projected ahead as far as 1951, purchasing executives revealed, citing cement manufacturers as the first group which has indicated that it expects continuously rising prices for the next four years.

Grain prices moved lower in early trading yesterday, but a late rally pulled some of them above Tuesday's closing prices. Deals on the Chicago Board of Trade and the country's other grain exchanges continued orderly, with fluctuations narrowing.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 18 (AP) -- A high State Department official said tonight United States aid to Greece had been largely offset by increased counter-assistance from the Communist-dominated Balkan states.
Sportsmen's Show highlights:

Banking syndicates will place on the market today issues of new public utility and railroad securities totaling $16,680,000, including an issue of $10,680,000 of equipment trust serials of the Southern Railway Company awarded yesterday at competitive sale.

Generally accepted estimates that the United States reserves of coal are sufficient to last 3,000 to 4,000 years were characterized yesterday as "fantastic and unbelievable" at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

MASS insomnia is due to strike a certain portion of the populace next week for the first time in ten years. The epidemic once hit annually to the complete bafflement of not only medical men but also of some of our better psychiatrists. It was caused by the insidious entry into the bloodstream of a strange virus known as the six-day bike race.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins kept the Chicago Black Hawks in last place tonight by defeating them, 4 -- 2, in a game whose third period developed into a coin-throwing shower of protest by the 16,461 fans. It was climaxed by some stick swinging by Pat Egan and Gaye Stewart.

Worried about the possible collapse of his program to stabilize construction wages in this city, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had summoned representatives of contractors and unions in the plumbing and electrical trades to a City Hall meeting at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, of the American Federation of Labor, reopened contract negotiations today between Chicago Typographical Union Local 16 and the Franklin Association, bargaining group for 400 Chicago-area commercial printing plants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The British Government believes that an international force will be needed to enforce the partition of Palestine and will not oppose the creation of such a force in the Security Council, Arthur Creech Jones, Britain's Colonial Secretary, indicated in a press conference today.

NANKING, Feb. 18 -- Dr. Shih Chao-ying, Foreign Ministry spokesman, declared today that China would "strongly urge" the United Nations General Assembly to proceed with free elections wherever possible in Korea, despite the establishment of a Soviet-dominated North Korea regime.
A production slump has thrown 10,000 dressmakers in this city out of work or put them on a part-time employment basis, employer and union spokesmen reported yesterday.

There was an extra man on the basketball court at Brooklyn College last night, where the Kingsmen defeated Queens, 68 -- 50. The irregularity was caused by experimental use of a third referee, suggested by Coach Al Baggett of Brooklyn several weeks ago.

President Truman has sent a special message to Congress requesting $570,000,000 for aid to China. This sum is to be part of a broad program of foreign aid that will include the European Recovery Program, additional military assistance to Greece and Turkey, relief in occupied areas and other items, the total of which is estimated at $9,333,000,000 for the fifteen months beginning April 1.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 18 -- The first heavier-than-air machine ever operated by man in sustained flight will be returned to America and placed on permanent exhibition in the United States National Museum, a section of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 18 -- Though the New Look, and the argument between style-conscious wives and budget-minded husbands, may by now be old skirt, it promises in this community to be of real social significance. Boys are ignoring girls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Key responsibility for preventing a House vote on the universal military training program was put on Representative Leo E. Allen of Illinois, chairman of the Rules Committee, by former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts today.

Martha Graham and her dance company, in their season at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, last night presented for the first time this season "El Penitente" and "Punch and the Judy," along with a repetition of Miss Graham's new work, "Night Journey," which had its premiere on Tuesday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 18 -Half of the' macfdnery o a com plete textile plant was:being loaded. aboard a freighter at the municipar' dock here today for shipment to IVfadras, india. The second half o.: the Old Yarn Division of the Inter-: national' Braid C0mpany,will f0110 in April.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that there was "no basis for criminal proceedings" on charges that records in Welfare Center 23, at 157 East Sixty-seventh Street, had been fabricated.

The Palestine Economic Corporation is determined to continue and expand its operations in Palestine in the belief that several of its important projects can be carried on effectively, Julius Simon, founder and president of the corporation, said in an interview here yesterday at its local offices, 570 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A decision has been reached, approximately, on the instructions that will be given the United States representative on the Security Council for dealing with the report of the United Nations Commission on Palestine when the Council meets next Tuesday, Secretary of State Marshall said today.
Washington, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today asking $570,000,000 in aid for China:

Mars is now about 63,000,000 miles from the Earth -- as close as it will come this year. Accordingly, astronomers of the University of Chicago have spent much of February in studying the planet spectrographically in the hope of determining whether or not the polar caps are hoarfrost or snow and whether or not the arid red areas turn green in spring and summer because trees are in leaf and other vegetation is flourishing.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Dewey's program for increasing state aid to education by $30,000,000 received overwhelming approval in the Senate and Assembly today after Democratic amendments to swell the increase to $90,000,000 had been voted down.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Social Democrat George Narosan announced the purge of about fifty Right-Wing Social Democrats from Government and party posts today and said Hungary must choose between the Soviet Union and "American imperialism."

As tears streamed from his eyes, a father stood yesterday in General Sessions and pressed a grand larceny charge against his son whom on six previous occasions he had saved from a possible jail sentence by making good on money allegedly stolen by the 24-year-old youth.

There are times when man, in attempting to improve upon articles in general use, overshoots his mark with lamentable results. For example: it has been announced that bakers throughout the country soon will begin distribution of a doughnut product revolutionary in design.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, headed by Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican, recommended today the establishment of municipal traffic control boards to tackle parking and traffic congestion problems.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Great Britain's organized labor acquiesced tonight in the Government's request for a curb on demands for increased wages, but made its acceptance conditional upon restrictions on profits and prices.

AMBASSADOR GREW cabled me from Tokyo on Jan. 27, 1941, that the Peruvian envoy there said to him he had heard from many quarters, including a Japanese one, "that a surprise mass attack on Pearl Harbor was planned by the Japanese military forces in case of 'trouble' between Japan and the United States; that the attack would involve the use of all the Japanese military facilities.''
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The future of the United Nations plan for setting up an independent Korean Government will be thrown open for debate tomorrow before the Little Assembly.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Educational facilities for all the American people, with compulsory schooling from 6 to 60, was advocated, today by a commission of the American Association of School Administrators. The group said education would be the most powerful defense in the world against wars, either "cold" or "hot."

Five guests and the host's butler were imprisoned for an hour and fifteen minutes last night in a stalled self-service elevator while on their way up to a penthouse cocktail party on the twenty-first floor of an apartment house at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue.

HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- The principle of general most-favored-nation treatment in its unconditional form was adopted today by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment. This action established non-discrimination as a basic rule of the World Trade Charter to be administered by the proposed International Trade Organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The State Mediation Board sought today to bring about a settlement in the strike of about 260 employes of one of Albany's largest hotels, the Ten Eyck, as about 600 guests of the hostelry, including some legislators, made their own beds.
The East Coast is "over the hump" with its fuel supply for the rest of this winter, the petroleum industry's regional advisory committee found yesterday after an all-day appraisal.

The text of a proposed agreement between the New York City chapters of the Red Cross and the medical societies in the city, which would settle the controversy over blood banks, was made public yesterday by Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard and Hospitals Commissioner Edward Bernecker.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 18 -- In a bitterly contested game which saw fifty-one personal fouls called, the Dartmouth basketball team defeated Yale, 76 -- 68, tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Grain markets made a strong close today after a sharp break on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a 3-to-1 decision, handed down today an opinion permitting the Standard Gas and Electric Company to solicit proxies for its annual stockholders' meeting on March 11.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman urged yesterday that the United States embargo on arms for Palestine be lifted. This, they said, would improve the chances for success of the United Nations plan to partition Palestine into Jewish and Arab states.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- The French Government won its first skirmish in its move to hold down prices, when the National Assembly late tonight voted the first part of a bill to prevent illicit price increases. The vote was 326 to 228, with the Communists and scattered Deputies on the Right in opposition.

Today's events: "Louise," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Greta Kirsten, soprano, and Henry Strickrodt, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Collette Chambeau, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Ethyl ise, soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; Josephine Borzone, song recital, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Brooklyn Tambouritza Orchestra and Ukrainian Youth Chorus, Lexington Avenue Y.M.H.A., 8:40.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 -Columbia's hopes for an undefeated basketball season were shattered rudely tonight. The Ivy League champions, in quest of their fifteenth straight victory, bowed in overtime, 59-54, to an underdog Princeton quintet that refused to succumb even in the face of a 7-point deficit, slightly more than three minutes before regulation time ended.

Net income of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company for 1947 after all charges, including taxes and $400,000 provision for contingencies, rose to $21,665,011 from $15,239,520 earned in 1946, Walter H. Aldridge, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Business was slow in the stock markets here today.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Adjutant General released the following Guard orders today:

The tonal splendor of the orchestra and the fine musicianship of Richard Burgin, the concert-master, who conducted in Dr. Koussevitzky's place at the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra lastnight in Carnegie Hall, were warmly recognized by the audience.

Amending an application originally filed last September, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for authority to sell $57,382,600 of convertible debentures.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the truce agreement, signed in the Netherlands Indies under United Nations auspices, amounted to a betrayal of the Indonesian people in favor of colonial interests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A group of Southern Democrats tonight canceled plans to attend the annual party dinners tomorrow night because of a "no segregation" policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Prominent industrialists today went on record as favoring the principle embodied in the Senate Labor Extension Service Bill which would provide wage-earners with the type of education that the Agricultural Extension Service supplies to farmers.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, whose theatrical output since 1943 when they wrote "Oklahoma!" has reached the local boards under the banner of the Theatre Guild, announced yesterday that they will put on one of their own shows next season in association with Leland Hayward and Joshua Logan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared today that the United States was interested in the present controversy involving the claims of Britain, Argentina and Chile to Antarctic islands of the Falkland group, but that it was maintaining a hands-off policy.

Tremendous increases in material and construction costs have forced the Board of Education to alter its plans for eighteen new public schools scheduled to be started this year at an expenditure of $28,390,000.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "A Double Life," a drama starring Ronald Colman and released by Universal-International. Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon (Mrs. Kanin) wrote the story, which was produced by Michael Kanin and directed by George Cukor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18 -The Yale swimming team ran its consecutive dual meet winning streak to thirty-one by defeating Rutgers University, 48 -- 27, in the Payne Whitney pool tonight. In a preliminary, the Yale freshmen defeated the Rutgers yearlings, 40 -- 26.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 18 -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla of Chile formally established a second military base near the Antarctic Circle today in defiance of British protests. Gen. Ramon Canas Montalva, Chilean Army Chief of Staff, was quoted in a press dispatch sent by radio as having said the action constituted a step toward "building up Chile as a Pacific power."

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, the defending champion from Toledo, Ohio, today set the pace in the qualifying round of the thirtieth Houston invitational golf tournament, scoring a two-under-par 69 to finish a stroke ahead of two Houston entries.

Resident buyers reported yesterday they were beginning to see more action on spring coats and suits. After a long quiet spell, retailers found trade last week-end improved and milder weather is expected to continue the betterment.
Victor Lebow has been elected vice president in charge of sales and advertising of the Chester H. Roth Company, Inc.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pic- tures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that at the close of business on Feb. 13 the short interest in stocks dealt on the Exchange was 1,226,304 shares, compared with $1,248,526 shares on Jan. 15. On Feb. 13 the short interest in all odd lot dealers' accounts was 76,583 shares, compared with 58,095 shares on Jan. 15.

By rounding up a crew of American ruffians, Thomas Heggen and Joshua Logan have written the ideal romantic play about the war. They call it "Mister Roberts." With Henry Fonda giving a winning performance, it was wonderfully well acted at the Alvin last evening.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Betty Field, Ruth Hussey and Shelley Winters have been signed by Paramount to appear with Alan Ladd in the studio's remake of F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1925 novel, "The Great Catsby." Miss Field will be seen as Daisy Buchanan, Miss Hussey as Jordan Baker and Miss Winters as Myrtle Wilson, while Ladd will play the title role.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Defying the Labor Government and its majority in Parliament, 86 per cent of Britain's medical practitioners, specialists and consultants have voted against working for the universal free medical service scheme scheduled to take effect July 5.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Six batterymen today joined Manager Mel Ott of the New York Giants at Buckhorn Mineral Springs for early conditioning. Pitchers Gene Thompson, Jack Hallett, Andy Tomasic, John Carden and Lou Lombardo, and veteran catcher Walker Cooper, were in the party.

Leroy A. Wilson was elected yesterday president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, succeeding Walter S. Gifford, who was elected chairman. Mr. Wilson also was elected a member of the board. Charles P. Cooper was made vice chairman, a newly created office.

Some stores now have working inventories of top-brand automatic electric washers and refrigerators and are offering them for immediate delivery, representatives of different types of appliance outlets reported yesterday. The supply-demand balance was attributed to special factors in the last thirty days and dealers warned that it is probably temporary.

The five-story building containing four stores and twelve apartments on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 300 East Eighty-ninth Street has been purchased by Ernest W. Stegemann for investment for cash over a mortgage of $31,000.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 18 -The four seeded players remained undefeated as the women's national squash racquets championship tourney went into the quarter-finals today at the Greenwich Country Club and the Greenwich Field Club.

American industry, particularly that segment supplying dyestuffs, finishing materials or chemicals used in textile processing, must now begin to do a better selling job abroad, John B. Wathey, vice president in charge of research and development off the Bocon Chemical Corporation, declared here yesterday.

With a three-round sparring drill Beau Jack, former world lightweight champion, yesterday concluded training at Stillman's Gymnasium for his ten-round bout tomorrow night against Terry Young of the East Side, in Madison Square Garden.

The departure of the Porto Rico liner Borinquen, scheduled for noon today, was canceled by the company late yesterday afternoon following the refusal of her crew to sign articles. About 300 passengers were booked to sail in the vessel.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 18 -- The Jefferson National Expansion Memorial Association's $40,000 award for a Mississippi River front memorial design to commemorate Thomas Jefferson, the Louisiana Purchase and the opening of the West was won tonight by a group of architects headed by Eero Saarinen of Bloomfield, Mich.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Two bills to implement the program of the Division of Housing in providing additional housing for veterans in limited dividend projects were introduced in the State Legislature today by Senator Irwin Pakula, Republican, of Queens.

Niagara, of Buffalo, unbeaten in previous games at Madison Square Garden, will face St. John's in the second part of the college basketball double-header at the arena tonight. Canisius, another Buffalo team, meets City College in the first game.
The full facilities of Freedom House were pledged last night to winning "the battle for the civil rights of all Americans."

Restoration of controls of consumer credit, vigorously opposed by bankers and other lenders who contended that voluntary restraints would be sufficiently effective during peacetime, now seems extremely remote, according to informed observers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A Senate Civil Service subcommittee today recommended a rise of $1,000 a year for most Federal workers and an increase in salaries of top executives to $18,600 and $21,000.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Feb. 18 -- A million dollar collection of photographic lenses from Germany has put the United States years ahead in the field of optics, the Army Signal Corps said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A joint Legislative committee recommended today a long-range, state-aided program of medical care, rehabilitation and special education for children afflicted with cerebral palsy.
An exhibition of 100 examples of modern Greek embroidery will open this morning at 10 o'clock at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Mr. Marcantonio's tribute to the "excellent discipline" of those who worked for Mr. Isacson's victory in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District seems to us to be well deserved, and probably as accurate a comment as can be made on the result of Tuesday's special election.

The election of former Assemblyman Leo Isacson, American Labor party candidate for Representative in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx, by a plurality of 10,119 over Karl Propper, Democratic nominee, in Tuesday's special election, had many repercussions yesterday.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina refused yesterday the request of a Congress of Industrial Organizations union that he enjoin the National Labor Relations Board from proceeding with a hearing to determine whether a collective bargaining election should be held in the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's plant at Bloomfield, N.J., where the union has a contract.
BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- Dartmouth took another step toward the Pentagonal Hockey League crown and the N.C.A.A. tournament in Colorado next month by defeating Harvard, 10 to 5, at the Arena tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Two speeches at the Women's Bureau Conference on "The American Women" resulted today in calls from the floor for "a domestic revolution equivalent to the industrial revolution." Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the New York Board of Higher Education, declaring that women were psychic as well as economic sufferers because men set the prevailing working patterns, presented a seven-point program for the next century of women's progress.

Originality and wearability combined to give the Tatiana du Plessix hat collection its unusual charm. It was shown by Saks Fifth Avenue, for whom Madame du Plessix designs exclusively, at a luncheon in the St. Regis Hotel yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 18 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, today sent a strong protest letter to the Soviet commander in Korea. General Hodge complained of the manhandling by North Korean police of two United States Army liaison officers on Feb. 8 in Pyongyang, capital of the Soviet zone.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The American Federation of Labor will find it "impossible" to send delegates to a conference of trade unions from Marshall Plan nations if it is held on March 8-10.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin reaffirmed today that the British Government could not leave troops in Jerusalem to protect holy places after the departure of British forces from Palestine next Aug. 1.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, argued yesterday that, in the light of the "present grim international situation," the United States should adopt a policy of Federal aid to education to strengthen its own chances of survival.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Britain's Trades Union Congress announced today that it would invite labor bodies from the fifteen other nations concerned with the European Recovery Program to meet in London March 8 to 10 to discuss the plan.
The use of color for spring was hailed by I. Miller yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in an interpretation of the "new look" in accessories.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- A former national amateur champion, Dick Chapman of New York, was among the victims today as upsets featured second-round play in the thirteenth invitational mixed foursomes golf tournament at the Everglades Club.

PRAGUE, Feb. 18 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party published today a manifesto announcing that certain measures would be taken to safeguard the republic and summoning all its members and sympathizers to be on the alert for action.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 -- Maj. Gen. William G. Livesay, chief of the Army group of the United States mission here, announced today that Maj. Gen. James A. Van Fleet was scheduled to arrive in Athens within a few days and that Brig. Gen. William A. Matheny, recently appointed chief of the Air Section, probably would arrive before the end of the month.

Confidence in the strong financial stability of national advertising and the importance of maintaining one-year rate protection for national radio advertisers were reported yesterday to have been among the main topics reviewed by the American Association of Advertising Agencies' board of directors in a meeting earlier this week.

Olympic competition with six-meter racing yachts will be held again this summer after a twelve-year lapse, and the United States will be a leading contender. The last such event with those sizable and fast craft was held in 1936 and won by Great Britain. Sweden was the victor the previous time, and Norway twice before that. The United States never has won with a "Six."

An exhibit of arts and crafts made by hospitalized veterans and blind, handicapped or tubercular civilians was opened at a tea yesterday afternoon at the Arts and Skills Studio of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross in the old Putnam mansion, 70 Willow Street, Brooklyn.

The Department of Justice continued its drive against alien Communists yesterday with the arrest of Mrs. Beatrice Johnson, former promotion manager of the defunct left-wing magazine, New Masses, and a longtime minor official of the party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Virginia Electric Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of Series F, first and refunding mortgage bonds, due March 1, 1978, and $11,753,800 of convertible debentures, due April 1, 1963.

The 1947 operating expenses of the Children's Aid Society reached a record high of $1,538,891, an increase of $93,742 over the previous year, Edwin G. Merrill, society treasurer, reported yesterday at the ninety-fifth annual meeting of the society's board of trustees, held at the Bank of New York, 48 Wall Street.
A.B. Harris has been appointed purchasing agent for Anaconda Copper Mining Company. He replaces Edwin E. Littler, who has retired.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Truman was awarded a medal and a citation today by the National Conference of Christians and Jews for his efforts in behalf of brotherhood and interracial amity.

The 250 first citizens of 250 cities who have been meeting here in the United States Conference of Mayors are on their way home now. If they hoped to cast off the cares of office in this brief holiday, they must have been aghast at the new burdens pinned on them at the convention.
Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, admitted yesterday that the administrative body of the university had erred in not consulting students about increases in tuition and room rentals.

There are few good causes on which state funds could be spent that would show a greater return in benefits to the people than the public libraries. The Democratic leaders, Senator Quinn and Assemblyman Steingut, have introduced in the Legislature a good bill that would provide $7,000,000 for expansion of library service.

SPARROWS POINT, Md., Feb. 18 -- Arthur B. Homer, president of the Bethlehem Steel Company, announced today that the BethlehemSparrows Point Shipyard, Inc., had closed contracts for the construction of three 28,000-ton tankers. Two other ships of that class may be authorized, he said.

The Book-of-the-Month Club was described as "one of the curses of America" last night by the Rev. Alfred J. Barrett of the Society of Jesus for choosing as its January selection the novel "Raintree County," by Ross Lockridge Jr., which won a $150,000 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer novel prize last year.
May I add two footnotes to the chapter of Cordell Hull's memoirs published by you on Saturday, Feb. 14?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -America's meat-on-the-hoof supply has dropped to the lowest level Since 1939.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Industrial democracy is the greatest challenge to American management in the post-war world, H.W. Brown, president of the International Association of Machinists, told 2,000 persons at the personnel conference of the American Management's Association today.

A twelve-day strike of 4,000 bakers and retail clerks employed in 350 neighborhood specialty bakeries ended yesterday. It was the second "settlement" of the bakery end of the dispute, but employer and union representatives expressed certainty this one would stick.

Matthew G. Ely, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a further expression of opposition to Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to relax constitutional limits on realty taxes, criticized yesterday what he characterized as "the reputed willingness of Albany legislators to 'compromise'" on the proposals.

The Barich Company, headed by Joseph Harris, builder, has acquired for improvement with garden-type apartments seventeen lots on the blockfront on Beach Channel Drive, between Beach 138th and 139th Streets, Belle Harbor, Queens, from Charles Baier and Fred Bauer.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- British impatience with Soviet impediments to the international control of atom bombs came to a head in the House of Lords today. Lord Pakenham, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, declared at the end of a grave and gloomy debate that a "time limit must be set" and that Britain must be prepared to pursue some other line" if Russia continued to frustrate any agreement on control.

Thirty-two teams started the first of the knockout rounds in the Vanderbilt Cup contract bridge tournament last night at the Pierre Hotel. These thirty-two teams were qualified after two sessions of play from a starting field of forty-five teams.

The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., completed in 1947 twenty years of uninterrupted dividend payments on the common stock and for the first time annual sales exceeded $100,000,000, F.J. Lunding, president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday for publication today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 18 -- The Balkans as a whole have enjoyed their mildest winter in many years, but the lack of snow cover is a cause of concern to those who know that a sudden, sharp frost probably would wipe out the winter wheat crop in this great bread basket for eastern Europe.

Mississippi awarded yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of highway revenue bonds due from 1962 to 1970 to Blyth Co., Inc., and associates at an interest cost of 2.9389 per cent. The bid was 100.38, with 3900,000 of the total designated as 3.10s, $1,650,000 as 3s and $2,450,000 as 2.90s.

PRAGUE, Feb. 18 -- The Foreign Ministers of Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia issued a declaration today at the conclusion of their meeting protesting against United States and British policies in Germany.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The American Labor party victory in the special Congressional election in the Bronx may force Mayor William O'Dwyer to drop his plan to seek legislative approval of a transit fare increase because of Democratic opposition, it developed today.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 18 -Syria and Lebanon signed an agreement in Cairo yesterday under which the Lebanese Government pledges itself to try to persuade the Lebanese Parliament to reject the financial agreement with France that the Government signed only twelve days ago.

In a decision expected to have a salutary effect on the merchant marine, the office of the Controler General of the United States reaffirmed yesterday the authority of the Maritime Commission to grant long-term operating differential subsidies to shipping lines.
DUBLIN, Feb. 18 -- John A. Costello, former Attorney General, was elected Prime Minister of Ireland by the Assembly this evening. The vote was 75 to 68.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 18 (ANETA) -- Requisitioning of Dutch-held American shares was announced today by Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck. Drastic restriction of dollar imports also was announced.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- With manifest indifference and little discussion, the Senate adopted today a resolution to cut President Truman's budget by $2,500,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (AP) -- McCormick Co., dealers in spices, had a net income of $257,990 for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, 1947, Charles P. McCormick, president, reported yesterday. After preferred and common dividends, $121,133 was added to surplus, bringing that item up to $1,457,811.

Kenneth C. Collins, New York advertising and public relations executive, has been awarded the highest honor the University of Washington can bestow upon a distinguished alumnus, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Collins was named "alumnus summa laude dignatus" for 1948.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Mr. Henderson also warned the Soviet Union and its satellites that the United States would "not stand idly by" and let Greece fall victim to international communism.

A six-hour program of continuous classical music will be offered under commercial sponsorship on Friday evenings over frequency modulation Station WABF, it was disclosed yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, president of the station. The first program will be tomorrow and will run from 6 P.M. to 12 midnight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- Petitions bearing 464,000 signatures have been collected in the move to qualify a third party for the California ballot and will be filed before Tuesday with county clerks and registrars all over the state, it was stated today by Hugh Bryson, chairman of the organizing committee of the Independent Progressive party.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18 -- The Argentine Foreign Office, which apparently was taken aback by Britain's sending of the cruiser Nigeria to the Falklands, insisted today that the Antarctic question was not one of "tonnage," but of international right.

The stock market lapsed yesterday into a state of such dullness as to render price changes meaningless. After a narrow drift most of the session, the list closed mixed to slightly lower and the combined averages fell 0.21 point. Business on the Stock Exchange dwindled to 610,000 shares, the lightest five-hour volume since late last September, compared with 720,000 shares on Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 18 -- The governments of peoples of Europe see in the Christian religion the only means of preventing future wars and founding a new World order, the National Commission on Evangelism of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. was told today.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Persons who have seen first models of the 1949 Mercury and Ford cars say they may touch off the long-awaited competitive battle in the automobile industry, not just between Ford and Chevrolet but in the entire low and medium priced fields.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- A record high in dollar volume of construction activity can be attained this year provided the Marshall Plan does not create crippling shortages of materials in this country, Dwight W. Winkelman, president of the Associated General Contractors of America, said today.

TOKYO, Feb. 18 -- The United States and Russian members of the Allied Council for Japan quarreled again today. This time it was over the Soviet's attempt to obtain from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters a statement of reasons for the recent resignation of the Katayama Cabinet.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Drastic centralization of the police organization and an advance call to part of the Army class of 1948 constituted France's answer today to the threat of Communist-inspired disorder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board, voting 3 to 2, put twelve factory inspectors in the same unit with production and maintenance employes today. The minority argued that inspectors were agents of management and should not be represented by a rank and file union.
Pressure lessened on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices ended 8 to 17 points net higher.

One of the saving features of the recent commodity price decline is that it has centered in farm prices; and farm prices operate under a special dispensation. They can fall just so far, and no farther.

WARSAW, Feb. 18 -- The Polish Government issued a blunt warning today that American airmen flying into Poland without visas in the future would be jailed, tried for trespass and be liable to one year's imprisonment in a Polish jail.

Two sharp controversies between the executive heads of all the airlines serving New York and the Port of New York Authority were discussed yesterday, it was learned, at a closed luncheon meeting attended by representatives of the two groups at the Wall Street offices of the Bankers Trust Company.

Unless the grain market breaks sharply again, eggs prices probably will not go much lower this spring than they are right now. This is the prediction of the Urner-Barry Company, reportorial agency for the trade. The fact that no further decrease is expected should not prevent housewives from serving eggs often during Lent.

Flat dark colors popular for living room walls were among coated fabric wall coverings shown yesterday by Philan Inc., distributors of Wall-Tex, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Since the deep tones have a fabric base, they are easily removed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Carlos Muniz of Brazil gave high praise here today to the United States for proposing the European recovery program and said that i t would open new horizons to Europe and to the world.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 -- Alvin N. (BO) McMillin, for 13 years head football coach at Indiana University, flew into Detroit today presumably to cast his future with the professionals. President D. Lyle Fife of the Detroit Lions said that the National League club's board of directors would meet at noon tomorrow, probably to confer with McMillin.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- The 16,663 in attendance at Hialeah Park today saw considerable of a race horse. In fact, they saw two of them in the $10,000 added Everglades Handicap, for while the Calumet Farm's 5-year-old Citation won in impressive style the Belair Stud's Hypnos was only about a length behind him at the end of the mile and an eighth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Decreases of $524,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $582,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $249,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $249,000,000 in borrowings.

Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company in 1947 amounted to $2,745,634, equal to 52 cents a common share, Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the board reported in a letter sent yesterday to the company's shareholders.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 18 -The Department of Antiquities said today it had discovered traces of perhaps the world's earliest civilization. The department said the discovery, in southern Iraq near Ur of the Chaldees, was "a civilization older than the Alubeid civilization, which dates more than 4,000 years before Christ."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Top figures of the military establishment paid tribute today to the women who served in the war and urged Congress to give permanence to their integral role in the armed services.

NANKING, Feb. 18 -- President Truman's recommendation of a $570,000,000 China-aid program was disclosed here tonight, with accidental but striking appropriateness, on the fourteenth anniversary of the "New Life Movement."

The Wollf Chamber Players gave its first New York concert last night at Times Hall. Originally scheduled to make its local debut on Dec. 26, the group had to postpone its appearance at that time because one of its members was unable to get to the hall on account of the heavy snow storm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -By a vote of 7 to 3, the Senate Banking Committee today recommended confirmation of M.S. Syzmczak for a second fourteen-year term as a Federal Reserve Board member.

Major revisions in zoning regulations to modernize them and to help stimulate private real estate and building investment will be undertaken soon, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, announced yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Stan Sorota stepped to the free-throw line in the last fifteen seconds of play and sank two shots to give the University of Connecticut a 50-to-49 victory over Army's quintet at the field house today.

MADRID, Feb. 18 -- Machinery for Generalissimo Francisco Franco's law of succession, which was ratified by a referendum last July, will be completed Feb. 26 when the full Regency Council will be named.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, ending a two-day session here, today adopted a resolution for the broadest possible study of international communications.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the nation for the week ended last Saturday is estimated at 5,347,175 barrels, an increase of 14,600 over the previous week, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute. The total for the week ended on Feb. 15, 1947, was $4,757,650 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Truman requested Congress today to appropriate $570,000,000 for aid to China, based on the limited objective of allowing that strife-torn country "a respite from rapid economic deterioration."

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 19 (AP)--Correspondent's criticizing press policy in Japan told Gen. Douglas MacArthur today that Army agents had raided one newsman's home and that nine others were embarrassed by critical letters that his officers had sent to their employers.

Unfurnished apartments in New York City hotels are under Federal Rent Control, and the New York City Temporary Rent Commission is without power to grant applications by landlords for rent increases, Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church ruled yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The Hungarian nation was duly cemented into the Eastern alliance today when the Soviet Union and the Hungarian Republic signed a twenty-year mutual assistance and cooperation pact in Moscow. It completed a network of treaties between the Soviet Union and her western neighbors from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

New coloring as well as modern arrangements of traditional motifs distinguish a group of luxurious English and Italian fabrics introduced here yesterday. Printed chintzes and linens for draperies and upholstery were shown by Updecor Fabrics, Inc., and woven lengths by Ramson Fabrics, Ltd., at the opening of their joint showroom for decorators at 554 Madison Avenue.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- The Haganah radio announced tonight that a party of twenty-eight United States citizens, including several women comprising a delegation of the United Jewish Appeal, had been ambushed and fired on by Arabs today while approaching Haifa in two armored buses.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 19 (Aneta) -- Following the rally of Wednesday on fears of compulsory liquidation of American securities, stocks steadied today on official assurance the new plan would be on a limited scale.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- More than $1,000,000 to be paid by the British authorities here to the Moslem Supreme Council will be used against the Jews, a spokesman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine charged today. The Agency, he said, was demanding outside supervision of use of these funds.

Prices for original models at the recent couturier openings in Paris were about 25 per cent higher in francs, but about 40 per cent lower in terms of American dollars as a result of franc devaluation, Simon Cohen, garment manufacturer, at 512 Seventh Avenue, said in an interview here yesterday.

In a move to improve service on the Long Island Rail Road and to better its relations with the public, M. W. Clement, president of the road, announced yesterday the creation of two new posts -- a general manager and a traffic manager.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman issued yesterday a warning of dangers facing the United States in delaying adequate appropriations for the European Recovery Program.

After the close of the final edition newspaper men are fond of indulging in earnest discussion on assorted irrelevant trivia. Did they suspend the running of the Kentucky Derby in 1918 because of the war?

The best orchestral performance of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, was that of Douglas Moore's Second Symphony. When it had ended the composer was called to the platform to acknowledge the applause.
