PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Two maintenance men attached to Princeton's Frick Chemical Laboratory were dead and three men were overcome trying to rescue them here today when a storage tank failure flooded the three-story building with hydrogen sulfide fumes.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 19 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States Army commander in Korea, has demanded that Lieut. Gen. G.P. Korotkov, commander of the Soviet forces in North Korea, investigate the manhandling of two American officers by Korean po lice at Pyongyang and punish the guilty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Estimates of Government revenues were being reviewed by the Congressional tax staff today in the light of the recent commodity market drop. It was possible that the reappraisal would affect Republican tax reduction plans, but this was not considered likely in the absence of a further price slump.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 19 -- Unfavorable weather conditions in the Antarctic were reported to have prevented President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla and his party from starting early today from the newly established Chilean base of Sovereignty Bay, formerly called Discovery Bay, at Greenwich Island in the Shetlands.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- New Swedish furnishings outstanding in design and quality but considered everyday wares by families of average income in Sweden go on exhibit at noon tomorrow in the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street.

The Artists Equity Association will honor John Sloan today in recognition of his "continuous interest in and aid to artists." Yasuo Kuniyoshi, president of the association, which was formed to protect the economic interest of artists, will present a rare edition of "Bosch" by Ludwig yon Baldaas to Mr. Sloan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today the House probably would have to adopt a special resolution to create a committee post for Leo Isacson, newly elected American Labor party representative of New York's Twenty-fourth District.
Following a rather quiet day, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 17 to 28 points net lower than the day before.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Despite the virtual elimination of American competition, the British movie output is dwindling, and tonight the Film Industry Employes Council, representing almost all organized workers in British motion pictures, asked the Government to consider "the steadily deteriorating position" of the industry.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Home state boys took the honors today in the first round of the $10,000 New Orleans Open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Everybody in this political community is speculating on the effects of Tuesday's Bronx election on the Presidential race, but a more immediate question is what effect it will have on next week's United Nations debate on Palestine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Horizon Pictures, the new independent company formed by John Huston and Sam Spiegel, today concluded a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the release of their productions for a minimum period of three years.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined sharply last week, falling $75,000,000 to $5,215,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the data issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the week ended on Wednesday, about $40,000,000 of the drop was the result of repayments by tobacco companies, but repayments by some finance companies were also prominent factors.

In his letter of Feb. 10 Kim Yongjeung expressed an opinion contrary to the expressed wishes of the majority of the Korean people. For the benefit of Americans who have shown great sympathy for Korea, I should like to speak on behalf of my people, whom I am honored to represent at the United Nations.

The Porto Rico liner Borinquen remained idle in port yesterday despite a change of heart on the part of her crew, which voted in the morning to sail the vessel. Originally scheduled to leave here yesterday afternoon, the voyage was canceled on Wednesday when her crew refused to sail in a dispute over quarters.

Terming the present conflict in Palestine far more dangerous to world peace than most Americans realize, seven prominent Americans, headed by Virginia C. Gildersleeve, former dean of Barnard College, urged yesterday immediate suspension of United Nations proposals to police the disputed area.

MONTREAL, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Scoring once in each period, the Montreal Canadiens downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, tonight in a rough and tumble National Hockey League encounter that was highlighted by the calling of twenty-four penalties.

A favorable report on economic, medical and climatic conditions in Surinam, Dutch Guiana, made by a five-man commission after a two-months' survey has advanced plans for the colonization there of 30,000 displaced European Jews, it was announced yesterday.

The Commercial Credit Company in 1947 had consolidated net income from operations of $9,019,937, an increase of 85.90 per cent from the $4,851,808 income on the same basis the year before, according to the thirty-sixth annual report to stockholders signed by Alexander E. Duncan, board chairman, and Howard L. Wynegar, president, released today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- The Arab League decided here tonight to enforce economic sanctions against any country that implemented or helped to implement partition in Palestine. Details of the projected boycott or how it would be brought about were not disclosed.

With prices of some meats lower and with poultry tariffs also down, Sunday's dinner may cost a little less this week-end than last. Pork especially is cheaper, with regular smoked hams at 59 cents a pound, 6 cents below the average last Friday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- A strike was planned today by the United Packinghouse Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, of 100,000 employes of the leading meat packing companies, but the date of the strike was not revealed by the union's strike strategy committee.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to acquire, by purchase at private sale or through condemnation, Seton Hospital, a private institution operated by the Sisters of Charity of the St. Vincent de Paul Society on Henry Hudson Parkway between West 232d and West 235th Streets.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Former Field Marshal Gen. Wilhelm List and former Lieut. Gen. Walter Kuntze were sentenced to life imprisonment today for war crimes. Six other defendants tried by a United States Military Tribunal received shorter prison terms and two were acquitted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee brought out today for consideration by the full committee a measure imposing allocation and inventory controls on grain used by distilleries through Oct. 31.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Alvin N. (Bo) McMillin notified Indiana University officials by telephone today that he had signed with the Detroit Lions and wished to be relieved of his contract as I.U. coach and athletic director.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Commerce Department announced today an additional cut of 599,000 barrels of gasoline and fuel oil in the first quarter export quota to divert more oil to American homes. Simultaneously, the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce demanded that the department put an embargo on all foreign oil shipments for the next four days.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Turning from a career of more than twenty years as a college football coach, Alvin N. (Bo) McMillin, colorful gray-haired Indiana University mentor, moved into the professional ranks today by accepting a long-term contract as head coach and general manager of the Detroit Lions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Recording one of the sharpest breaks for a seven-day period since the inception of the weekly index in 1932, average primary market prices declined 2.5 per cent during the week ending Feb. 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The United Nations Korean Commission presented to the Little Assembly today the responsibility of taking action to prevent a "blow-up" that might spread from divided Korea to all Asia and then to the rest of the world.

The County of Dade, Fla., sold yesterday to B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and associates an issue of $3,000,000 of international airport revenue bonds, described by the bankers as the first major airport bond flotation secured solely by airport income.

Joe Louis held out the bold threat yesterday that he would sidetrack a match with Jersey Joe Walcott in June unless the latter quickly made up his mind to accept the conditions offered him by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, which plans to promote the fight.

Edward Molyneux again is a visitor in the United States, this time for a brief stay. He arrived on the last trip of the Queen Mary and leaves for the West Coast today. Commenting on the new look in Paris, he said French men like it.

The Chemical Bank's proposal to absorb the Continental Bank and Trust Company, although acceptable to Continental's directors, is apparently receiving closer scrutiny before being presented to the bank's stockholders, according to reports in Wall Street yesterday.
Following is the text of President Truman's address at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner at Washington last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 -- Organized labor was criticized sharply from within its own camp today for its failure to seek actively the complete fulfillment of civil rights guaranteed by the Federal Constitution.

Two leading chapters of the local Red Cross voted approval yesterday of the compromise proposal for the handling of blood banks, made public on Wednesday by Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard and Hospitals Commissioner Edward Bernecker.

With rehabilitation and production increasing, exports from the Netherlands Indies may be expected to increase at least 25 to 30 per cent over last year, Dr. W. A. Foote, consul general at Batavia, said yesterday in an interview at the local offices of the Department of Commerce in the Empire State Building.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Control by the United Nations of the oil in the Middle East to lessen the possibility of war was urged here tonight in Bayfront Park by Henry Wallace. He charged that the Truman Doctrine was intended to protect American oil interests in the Middle East.

A building boom is on among the nation's colleges. An Associated Press survey of planned expenditures for athletic plants, field houses and improvements in stadia used by colleges shows that approximately $30,000,000 is being spent for construction work this year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- A Presidential emergency fact-finding board reviewing the wage and working rule dispute between the railroads and three operating unions was told today that approval of the workers' pay demands would "totally disrupt the pay structure which has been developed over the years for operating employes through negotiation and collective bargaining."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Miss Frieda Miller, director of the Women's Bureau, today closed the Seneca Falls centenary conference on "The American Women" by saying that a great deal of discussion would have to precede action on the many new ideas presented here.

ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 19 -- Hodding Carter, Mississippi editor, said today a general breakaway of Southern states from the Democratic fold in protest against President Truman's civil rights program was unlikely. He predicted, however, that Mississippi and probably South Carolina would send uninstructed electors to the Electoral College.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- President Truman has pared the Federal budget "to the minimum which he considers consistent with the country's domestic and international responsibilities," Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told 2,500 persons here tonight.

D. McCall White, former vice president of the Cadillac Motor Car Company, has been appointed special assistant to the president of the Tucker Corporation, Chicago, in charge of engineering, inspection and testing.

Raw materials for making folding boxes are now in good supply, a spokesman for the Folding Paper Manufacturers of America reported yesterday. Some materials are still required, but this is not interfering with current production, he stated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In an unusual statement Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador, declared today that certain amendments he recently offered unsuccessfully before the Far Eastern Commission to "improve and clarify" a policy directive adopted for disarming Japan were "very important."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- American consumption of aspirin and vitamin compounds has soared in the last few years, the Pacific Coast section of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association was told today. Penicillin and streptomycin also are on a sharp upgrade, while the use of sulfa compounds seems to have passed its peak, it was said.
Some time late Wednesday night or early yesterday morning someone hacked away a lock in a desk in Room 2618 in the skyscraper at 270 Broadway.

Refusing to reduce their jail terms on the grounds of being excessive, Supreme Court Justice William H. Munson ruled yesterday that Joseph S. Fay and James Bove, convicted labor union officers, must serve sentences of seven and one-half to fifteen years in state prison.

A warning against using the prices being paid by insurance companies for investment property as a measure of the market value of comparable properties without consideration of the lease terms involved was voiced by Frank D. Hall, second vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, at the dinner meeting of the New York Metropolitan District Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers last night at the Advertising Club.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 30, 1947, under a Kansas City date line of Dec. 29, appeared an article, "Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES," which stated that at the meeting in Kansas City Dec. 27-29 of the Methodist Federation for Social Action I introduced a resolution which "hit at Catholic matters in this country."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Ever since President Roosevelt as party leader made his political alliance with all the leftist groups in the country, the Democratic party, going Achilles one better, has had two vulnerable spots. It was always only a matter of time when wounds that might prove mortal would be inflicted in one heel or the other.

Harvard University Press has arranged with the Committee on Research in Economic History, Social Science Research Council, for the publication of a series of books on aspects of the economic history of the countries of North and South America.

The right of possession of the St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, rests with the Patriarchal group of the Russian Orthodox Church, affiliated with the Moscow Patriarchate, and "its use is not subject to the direction of the Russian Church in America," Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein ruled here yesterday.

PRAGUE, Feb. 19 __ Czechoslovakia's Communist labor leadership is putting through resolutions demanding that the Government nationalize every industry in the foreign and wholesale trades with more than fifty employes, in mass meetings at industrial establishments throughout the country.

Metropolitan area members of the New York State Food Merchants Association are considering a joint institutional newspaper advertising campaign in support of the association's state-wide "Thanksgiving in Spring" sales and good-will promotional drive schedule for April, it was learned yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 19 -- Minister of Agriculture Hernan Zamora Elizondo and Dillon S. Meyer, president of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs, signed a supplemental food supply agreement here today that provides for establishment of an inter-American agricultural cooperative service.

George E. Spargo, general manager and secretary of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, declared yesterday that some conditions of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's offer of a $24,000,000 loan for completion of the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel "will have to be changed" before it can be accepted by the Authority.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The commander of the Argentine fleet en route to disputed Antarctic islands was quoted today as saying it was probable he would hold a rendezvous with Chilean warships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The House Rules Committee released today for floor action a resolution to enable a special Congressional group to investigate the income tax returns of both Democratic candidates for Governor of Louisiana -- Earl K. Long and Sam Houston Jones.

The press was introduced to young Howard Fox, newly appointed president of I. J. Fox, yesterday, and he in turn presented his latest collection of cloth suits and coats, as well as rare and recent mink mutations. Minks, to keep the record in order, can now be had in pure white, tones of honey, beige, gray, white, flecked brown and in the familiar rich dark brown.
Many major commodities continued yesterday a modest price climb that was marked by frequent fluctuations within a narrow range.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Immediate creation of a citizens' unified military force, 16,000,000 strong, was urged on the Gray board today by Col. William H. Neblett, president of the Reserve Officers Association. The first members, he suggested, would be the veterans of World War II who are not 45 years old.

The Central Trades and Labor Council of the American Federation of Labor voted unanimously last night to "support to the utmost the current, city-wide campaign to raise $15,575,000 for the projected New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The House Rules Committee paved the way today for House consideration next week of a month's extension of the Rent Control Law expiring Feb. 29.

Aroused over the defeat of the Young-Milmoe bill that would have increased state aid for the city's public schools by $40,000,000, representatives of nineteen civic organizations at an indignation meeting yesterday pledged themselves to a campaign "to free New York education from its political straitjacket."

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Although professing a determination that Great Britain should continue to play the role of a great power, the Government announced tonight that the nation's armed forces would be reduced to the lowest level since 1939.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd declared tonight that some of President Truman's civil rights proposals "could very conceivably lead to dictatorship."

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A breach of promise suit against a United States vice consul in London was halted today by the British Foreign Office which certified that the defendant was entitled to diplomatic immunity.

IF you are willing to spin back the clock a dozen years, you'll find that the National AAU indoor championships supply a reasonably accurate guide as to likely candidates for the Olympic team the following summer. It may not disclose the winners but it does give a pretty fair line on the talent. That's why tomorrow's title show at the Garden will be watched with more than normal interest.
For the first time a way to protect industry against overpayments for incoming deliveries during a period of declining prices was revealed yesterday.

Almost a dozen years ago, "Tonight at 8:30" (originally a series of nine short offerings bearing Noel Coward's imprimatur) arrived at the National and proceeded to capture the town. Two incomparable performers, Mr. Coward and Gertrude Lawrence, were in it then.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- Retirement of Capt. Henry Nelson, commodore of the American President Lines and master of the new liner President Cleveland, after a sea-going career of more than a half century, was announced today by T. J. Cokely, operations vice president of the American President Lines.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- Ira Gershwin, J. Edward Bromberg and Rose Hobart were among the theatrical people who came under the scrutiny today of the state Senate Committee investigating Un-American activities.

If business follows cycles of the past, a research expert said here last night, the current downward trend will end some time this year, according to The Associated Press. He added that it may resume on a more serious scale in 1951 and 1952.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- One favored team won and another lost in today's semi-finals of the thirteenth invitational mixed foursomes golf tournament at the Everglades Club.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Creation of a permanent bureau to control international advertising ethics was announced here today by the International Chamber of Commerce whose committee on advertising yesterday completed a conference here on advertising techniques.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb 19 -- Establishment of a single, unified organization of teachers is one of the prime requisites for building a better teaching profession to meet the need of the times, the American Association of Teachers Colleges was told today.

The much-feared thaw has been in skiing's midst for several days and the damage to snow covers in the Northlands has been considerable for the Washington's Birthday week-end. Close to home, the word ranges from none to good skiing, thus checking the uninterrupted period of superb sport that has prevailed in the East from late December until last week-end.

For fourteen years Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch has served this city faithfully as a member of the Housing Authority. During those years she gave abundantly of her time and strength without compensation. She brought to the work long years of experience as director of Greenwich House.

Beau Jack returns to Madison Square Garden tonight to tackle Terry Young, East Side warrior, in the star bout of ten rounds. It will be a year almost to the day that the Beau was last seen in the Garden, having been stopped in four rounds by Tony Janiro on Feb. 21, last.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday that while operating revenues rose $6,596,870 in 1947 to $62,889,038, or 11.72 per cent, net income was off $622,794 to $7,027,243, due to an increase of $7,261,530, or 21.95 per cent, in operating expenses, to $40,349,562.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- A sharp challenge to the strong maritime nations to submit their shipping policies to international examination was issued by India today in the opening session of the first United Nations Maritime Conference.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Baguio, representing Jule Fink's Marlet Stable, was the winner of the turf course feature at Hialeah Park today, with foreign-bred horses taking the next four positions in the field of nine.
Sportsmen's Show highlights.

The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation turned yesterday to one of Wall Street's major "traditional" investment banking establishments -- the First Boston Corporation -- for "advice and counsel" in putting back on the market the issue of common stock that the original underwriting managers, Otis Co. and the First California Company, terminated last week.

Britain, Chile and Argentina now dispute the possession of the Falkland Islands. This dismal archipelago was unheard of for a hundred years after Columbus discovered America. John Davis and Sir Richard Hawkins touched there, but no British landings were made until 1690.

The popularity seesaw in evening radio entertainment is tipping in favor of the "Radio Theatre," according to the C.E. Hooper organization's formula for determining such things. Deposed from first to fourth place is Fred Allen, it is stated in the latest report of the arbiter on listenership.
A committee of Italian-Americans has been formed to help feed families in 100 "forgotten towns" in Italy, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 14 were 3 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:
New life insurance issued in 1947 by the Equitable Life Assurance Society totaled $1,170,000,000, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of directors.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week declined a little more, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. Although most of the drop resulted from a decrease in the volume of trade, industrial production and freight shipments were reduced further.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Edward Allen Tamm, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, took the blame today for what he said was the agency's failure to carry out fully instructions to conduct a Kansas City vote fraud investigation.
Here's how greatly the fuel oil situation has improved in the last week:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The United States is "the No. 1 target" of a Soviet imperialist communism which expects in time to move with massive conquering force over the world, Dr. Georgi M. Dimitrov, the exiled Bulgarian peasant leader, told a Congress group today.

C. B. Baldwin, campaign manager for Henry A. Wallace, third party candidate for President, said yesterday that Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, "might as well cease his invitation to Mr. Wallace to return to the Democratic party."

While the Western democracies still grope in a fog of innumerable practical difficulties to find a way to a West-European Union, the Russian Government has completed forging the last link in a system of military alliances which establishes a solid East European bloc from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

Employes in 310 Manhattan office and loft buildings voted almost unanimously in a National Labor Relations Board election yesterday to authorize a union shop for Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, told the Palestine Commission today that Britain would be prepared to "discuss" the possibility of allowing the United Nations to import arms into the Holy Land for the equipment of militia.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Insistence of the Trades Union Congress' general council on reduced profits and prices kept buyers out of most sections of the stock markets here today.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Prince Seif el Islam Abdullah, one of several sons of the Imam Yahya of Yemen, has left London apparently without knowing that the death of his father had been confirmed by reports from Cairo.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 19 -- Minnesota supporters of Henry A. Wallace suffered a setback here today as Truman forces won a series of important preliminary tests in a one-day meeting of the state central committee of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party. The margin of victory was about 3 to 1.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Southern Democratic members of the House were planning a new "revolt" move today to follow tonight's Jefferson-Jackson Day dinners. They will gather in closed session tomorrow to organize for cooperation with the Southern Governors' Conference in resisting President Truman's civil rights program.

In recognition of a "long period of sustained good behavior," Eudalia's Cleo, an 18-month-old pedigreed pug dog, received a gold medal from the Greenwich Village Humane League at exercises yesterday afternoon at the league's headquarters, 57 Eighth Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The National Assembly today passed another law to control prices. The vote was 336 to 188 votes against it. The Communist bloc voted against it, while the extreme Right Republican Liberty party abstained from balloting.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and other underwriters will offer to investors today a new issue of $10,000,000 of thirty-year 3 1/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Ohio Public Service Company. The price will be 100.75, representing a yield of about 3.086 per cent.

The shift of prices to irregularly lower levels continued yesterday on the stock market. The changes again were fractional and the combined averages were reduced 0.26 point. Due to interest in a few scattered issues and some buying in the oils, transfers on the Stock Exchange expanded to 680,000 shares, against 610,000 shares on Wednesday.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Declaring that the New York City Rent Commission had failed to effectively control rents in hotels, Senator Harold I. Panken, Democrat, of Manhattan, proposed today to put control of hotel rents, including apartment hotels, with the state.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Dewey administration has decided to sponsor measures increasing unemployment insurance benefits to a maximum of $26 a week and setting a $900,000,000 ceiling on the unemployment insurance reserve fund.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, May corn showing a strong undertone as the result of buying by cash interests who were removing hedges against shipping sales of 430,000 bushels of the cash article, the largest day's business in a month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 14, totaled 734,262 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,132 cars, or 1.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week. 65,715 cars, or 8.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 27,208 cars, or 3.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Five operating divisions were abolished and two new ones created today in two drastic orders by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor. The orders were designed to streamline his organization and accommodate it to the revised bizonal structure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's impromptu remarks before guests at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner at the Hotel Statler after being introduced by former House Speaker Rayburn as "my leader" was as follows:

With present high wages and the unsatisfied demand for housing as well as many consumer goods, sharply reduced building costs and consequent lowering of realty values seem to be several years away, Max H. Foley, president of the New York Building Congress, told the New York Society of Residential Appraisers last night at their meeting in the Hotel Shelton.

SEATTLE, Feb. 19 -- A demand that "Communist infiltration" into labor organizations be "cleared up" was made tonight by Harold E. Stassen, as he carried into Seattle his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The number of signed baseball Giants was increased to thirty-five with the announcement by Secretary Eddie Brannick yesterday that Joe Lafata, outfielder, and Andy Hansen, right-handed pitcher, had turned in their attested contracts.

LITTLE good as we had had to expect from the Konoye Cabinet, we had even less to expect from the Cabinet headed by Premier General Hideki Tojo after Oct. 17 [1941]. Tojo, who had been Minister of War, continued even as Premier to be an active army officer.

Tournament-conscious City College and St. John's, which would not turn a deaf ear to a post-season bid either, were victorious over Canisius and Niagara, both of Buffalo, in the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. C. C. N. Y. routed the Golden Griffins, 51 -- 39, whereupon the Brooklyn Redmen conquered Niagara, 57 -- 48.
Most of the favorites ran true to form in the second round of knockout matches in the Vanderbilt Cup contest bridge championship tournament at the Hotel Pierre last night.

A recession, "or orderly readjustment" in the fourth quarter of this year was predicted last night by Dr. Lionel D. Edie, economist and head of the investment advisory firm bearing his name, at the annual banquet of the New York Credit Men's Association in the Hotel Commodore.

Complying with the wishes of the Director of the Office of Alien Property, the board of directors of the North American Rayon Corporation and its affiliate, the American Bemberg Corporation, have called a special meeting of stockholders for March 25 to elect new boards.
The board of trustees of Barnard College have voted unanimously to increase the tuition fee $150, it was announced yesterday.

All domestic producers of steel announced yesterday price increases of approximately $5 a ton for semi-finished products. This will add many millions of dollars to the nation's steel bill immediately and may be reflected ultimately in higher prices for a broad line of industrial items, ranging from automobiles to small appliances.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, continued his below par golf today to maintain a favorite's role after the first round of match play of the thirtieth Houston invitational tournament.

A vast expansion of the nation's educational system to permit all talented students to go to college regardless of economic status was proposed yesterday by Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College. Dr. Taylor urged New York State to take the lead in passing an education fair practice law to reduce discrimination against students of minority groups.

It was an all-American evening in the dance last night, for not only did Martha Graham present three of her own works at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, but the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo offered an "American Choreographers' Evening" at the City Center.

PEIPING, Feb. 19 -- Four former Manchurian generals, now living in Peiping and Tientsin, are scheduled to leave Feb. 22 for a conference in Nanking. All have been virtually shelved by the National Government for several years.

NANKING, Feb. 19 -- Ambassador John Leighton Stuart told China in a statement today that the United States aid program was designed to benefit the "common people." He said it was intended to protect them from the "extreme radicals" and the "extreme reactionary or selfish elements."

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Members of 850 local unions of the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, have voted overwhelmingly to increase their ITU strike assessments from one half per cent to 5 per cent of their weekly pay, Don Hurd, ITU secretary-treasurer, said today in Indianapolis.

Operations last year of the General Cable Corporation resulted in a net profit of $6,158,265 after taxes and all charges, according to the annual report issued for publication today by Dwight R.G. Palmer, president.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 19 -- More than 100,000 lay members will be recruited and trained in evangelism this year under a program drafted today by the National Commission of Evangelism of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. at the closing session of the annual meeting here.

"My Girl Tisa," which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Sam Wanamaker and Lilli Palmer are starred in the romantic drama, which was produced by United States Pictures for Warner Brothers release. Elliott Nugent directed and Milton Sperling produced from a screen play by Allen Boretz and a play by Lucille S. Prumbs and Sara B. Smith.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza envisaged today the possibility that if the Marshall Plan succeeded the Soviet Union would regret some day its failure to participate and would recognize that decision as a mistake.

The Black Diamond Steamship Corporation and the Arnold Bernstein Line announced yesterday that they would reapply to the United States Maritime Commission for operating differential subsidies on the Government trade routes between North Atlantic ports and the Antwerp-Hamburg range in Europe.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The Benelux countries -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- will participate in most of the three-power talks on Western Germany opening here Monday, it was learned today. Moreover, all recent signs have pointed to a willingness on the part of the British to meet the Benelux criticisms of draft proposals for British Foreign Secretary Bevin's Western union treaties.

Both state and Federal agencies have given preliminary approval to a general 12 per cent increase in rents at Knickerbocker Village, it was learned yesterday. If finally approved, after tenants have had a chance to present whatever facts they may have in opposition to the increase, the rent rise will be retroactive to Feb. 2.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19 -- More than half the 850 Arkansas Democrats on hand quietly left the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner tonight as President Truman's speech was tuned in on the loudspeaker system.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- The Soviet Military Administration has formally charged the United States and British Military Governments with "sabotaging" the demilitarization of Germany, it was learned today.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A blanket finish had the spectators jumping up and down in excitement at the Fair Grounds today when six horses dashed under the wire neck and neck. The race was the second division of the Fair Grounds Dinner States, in which society leaders sponsored each juvenile.

Consolidated net earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation last year amounted to $7,282,086, equal to $2.03 each on 3,580,948 common shares outstanding, the report to stockholders disclosed yesterday. This compared with $4,547,187, or $1.27 a share, earned in 1946.

Mayor O'Dwyer was ordered yesterday by a heart specialist to enter Bellevue Hospital this morning for a week of thorough medical observation to be followed by a thirty-day vacation away from the city.

Within three months it is hoped that preliminary plans will be ready to bring the Presbyterian, Methodist, Baptist and Congregationalist national headquarters together in a single "Protestant Center.''

The order excluding "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Focus," novels attacking anti-Semitism, from the library of De Witt Clinton High School, the Bronx, will stand despite approval of the books by a special committee of five teachers.

Samuel Wolchok, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, announced yesterday that the union's membership had voted by a margin of 58,000 to 1,200 in favor of constitutional changes designed to permit the union to qualify for recognition under the Taft-Hartley Law.

We wonder whether the New York City Democratic delegation in the Legislature realizes what a damaging effect it would have on Mayor O'Dwyer's prestige if he permitted the results of a light vote in a special Bronx election to reverse the City Administration's course on the transit fare.

JAMES HILTON, who is an occasional critic as well as an extremely popular novelist, recently wrote to the publishers of a new novel, "It has the stature of 'The Forsyte Saga' but is to my mind superior to the Galsworthy book in unity and clarity of purpose." It would be difficult to praise a several-generation novel more highly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- During the week ended Feb. 18, member bank reserves balances decreased $287,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has been invited by Vassili V. Kuznetsov, Soviet member of the executive bureau of the World Federation of Trade Unions, to come to Moscow to confer on Marshall Plan aid, it was learned here today.

With a wide dispersal of points indicated by a nation-wide entry of nearly 300 star athletes, the best estimated yesterday was that a total of fifteen would suffice to win the team title in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Standard Accident Insurance Company, Detroit, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 140,750 shares of $10 par value common stock that will be offered first to the company's common stockholders at the rate of one share for each two and one half shares now held.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19 -- Public and press reactions to the creation of the first inter-party government in Ireland was very favorable on the whole. Apart from Eamon de Valera's own newspaper, the Irish Press, which dismissed the new cabinet as "a lawyer's contrivance," leading daily newspapers hailed the experiment, with praise for Prime Minister Costello and those who entered his Cabinet.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia, top favored contender, today led the way into the semi-final round of the women's national squash racquets tournament being held on the courts of both the Greenwich Field Club and the Greenwich Country Club.

The Paris center of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace has completed plans for a reopening, Dr. Howard E. Wilson, associate director of the organization, with offices at 405 West 117th Street, announced yesterday. The center will promote, he said, a realistic study of international affairs and is intended to strengthen the ties between Western Europe and the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Head Coach Carl Snavely of North Carolina has an offer to coach the Los Angeles Dons of the All-America Football Conference. The Dons, late today, in a formal statement, admitted yesterday's report that the post had been offered, and said the matter rested with the veteran mentor.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- Yahya Hamid el Din, 85-year-old ruler of Yemen, three of his sixteen sons and a chief adviser are dead and a new king and government proclaimed, a dispatch from that Arabian kingdom said today.

Copies of the first volume of the war memoirs of Winston Churchill arrived in New York from London by air yesterday and were delivered to THE NEW YORK TIMES and Life Magazine, holders of the newspaper and periodical publishing rights in this country.

For sixteen years a New York-born son of a Spanish father was Prime Minister of Ireland, and perhaps no man in the country was more proudly and deeply Irish than he. Now Eamon de Valera, still head of the overwhelmingly largest party in the Dail Eireann but no longer commanding an absolute majority, has stepped aside.

A comprehensive educational program designed to counter widespread misconceptions concerning installment selling is now an integral part of social study classes in New York high schools, Nathan S. Sachs, vice president of Sachs Quality Stores, disclosed yesterday.
DUBLIN, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Prime Minister John A. Costello said today that his new multi-party Government would help the Marshall Plan by exporting more food to Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The world situation is too grave "to put an isolationist in the White House," President Truman declared tonight as the Democrats officially launched their campaign for 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman signed and made law today a bill giving the armed services considerable latitude in buying certain services and equipment, even in peacetime, without going through the process of advertising for competitve bids.

The United Nations Economic and Social Council was given a demonstration this week by Dr. Howard A. Rusk and his colleagues of the Department of Rehabilitation of New York University's College of Medicine of what can be done to restore disabled persons to a productive and happy life.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 19 -- In a speech to a joint session of the State Legislature, Judge Lamar Hardy, a member of the New York Bar and native Mississippian, upheld today the doctrine of state rights, and denounced the anti- South bills now shaping up in Congress.

Directors of Dresser Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the resumption of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 37 1/2 cents a share, payable on April 1. The last payment on Dec. 15, 1945, was 30 cents.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 19 -- Five Flint locals of the United Auto Workers, CIO, proposed today a plan by which the General Motors Corporation would set aside $15 for each car that it produced, to be used to provide a pension fund for GM workers.

An estimated $50,000 worth of silks and rayon were stolen from two trucks in a parking lot at Tenth Avenue and Thirty-third Street early yesterday morning, police of the West Thirtieth Street station reported.

A former member of the National Committee of the Communist party testified yesterday that 30,000 members of the party in New York were receiving military training in 1932 in preparation for revolution.

Benjamin Feldman, who was convicted Feb. 6 for the second time of murdering his wife by poison, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Carmine J. Marasco in Kings County Court to die in the electric chair in Sing Sing the week beginning March 21.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -The Bureau of the Budget recommended today that Congress cut out pure hobbies from the study courses the Government pays for under the G.I. Bill of Rights.
The Pennsylvania Tunnel and Terminal Railroad Company and the Pennsylvania Railroad have been granted a $15,000,000 reduction of tax assessment valuations in Manhattan and Queens.

With reports rife in financial circles that another banking institution was making a bid to take over the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York, Frederick E. Hasler, the bank's chairman, announced yesterday that "final details" in the offer by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company are now being concluded.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 20 -President Truman arrived here this afternoon on the first stop of his Caribbean tour and vacation, feeling well satisfied with the reception given his speech at the JeffersonJackson Day dinner in Washington.

Pleading for the just treatment of minorities in the United States, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt presented yesterday a citation to the public schools of Gary, Ind., for abolishing racial discrimination and for successfully overcoming a school strike there last fall.

Now that the grip of snow has been relaxed in the city streets and on many roads in suburban areas the damage done to surfaces of many kinds becomes all too apparent. Bad potholes are the rule rather than the exception. Even the best concrete highways show extensive cracks.

A proposed course in "History of the Jews and Jewish Communities" has been rejected by Brooklyn College's Faculty Council, it was announced yesterday. The Faculty Committee on Curriculum and Admission Requirements recommended in its report to the Faculty Council that the course should not be added to the undergraduate curriculum because of its highly specialized nature.

NANKING, Feb. 20 -- Ten thousand tons of American munitions stored on the Marianas Islands are to be turned over to China under a surplus property bargain sale requiring the payment of 1 cent on every dollar of he original cost.
Extended negotiations at City Hall failed yesterday to stem a growing fear that Mayor O'Dwyer's entire plan to stabilize wages and spur activity in the construction industry was endangered.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- All major problems of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment appear to have been solved and, barring unforeseen developments, the session can now be brought to an early and successful conclusion. This statement was l made today by Clair Wilcox, act-i ing chairman of the United States delegation.

The increase in numbers of junior colleges in the last twenty years represents another major advance in American educational opportunities. In many ways the movement is comparable with the growth in public high schools during the early years of the present century.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall works on the theory that he has enough to worry about without tangling with either domestic politics or Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

NANKING, Feb. 20 -- The loss of the Manchurian steel city of Anshan, sixty-five miles southwest of Mukden, to the Communists was virtually conceded by Government quarters here today. The Reds had been besieging the city for two weeks.

Eugene Istomin, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The program he presented before an enthusiastic audience comprised Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2; ten Preludes of Chopin, the Preludes in B major and A minor from the Opus 32 of Rachmaninoff,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi raised the state's rights issue today in opposing enactment of a Federal anti-lynch law. He told a Senate judiciary subcommittee that the Federal Government lacks the Constitutional power to put such a bill into effect or to enforce it.

Mayor O'Dwyer entered Bellevue Hospital at 10:45 A.M. yesterday to begin a week of thorough medical observation under the supervision of Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, the heart specialist who examined him on Thursday and found him recovering from a "transitory coronary episode."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A Senate banking and currency subcommittee approved unanimously today a bill providing for a ten-year extension of the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, but which would trim the agency's resources and powers.

Don't look now, but twelve years have disappeared somewhere since Noel Coward's bills of one-act plays first startled this town. The years were not much good for any of us, and they have not passed Mr. Coward's plays by. With Gertrude Lawrence outdazzling the

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Armed or Assault? That's the question at Hialeah Park, where the Calumet Farm's great gelding and the King Ranch flier will hook up again tomorrow in the $50,000 added Widener Handicap. Eight others are entered, but few view the race as anything except a duel between the two former holders of the money-winning crown.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Benjamin J. Davis, Communist member of the New York City Council, denied today that his party advocates use of force and violence to bring about political change.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- An ensign and two enlisted men, among the eight missing due to the swamping of a launch from the USS Midway at Hyeres, France, last Monday, were cited for heroism today by the Navy Department.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 (UP) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla is bringing back from Antarctica samples of what may be uranium ores, extracted from the lands he has just "annexed" below Cape Horn despite British protests.
Two men beat and robbed an employe of the Charles Francis Press, 461 Eighth Avenue, yesterday morning and escaped with $2,700, part of a payroll that was being distributed to workers in the plant.

Dr. Willard E. Goslin, president of the American Association of School Administrators, urged last night that the nation's junior high schools adopt "drastic revisions" in their curriculums in order to provide children in the early adolescent years with subject matter that will stimulate their desire to study.

A large property along "auto row" at the northern fringe of Times Square passed to new control yesterday when the Tishman Realty and Construction Company reported its purchase of the four-story auto sales and office building at 1731-37 Broadway, northwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, told Congress today that the rapid deterioration of China must be checked promptly for the world's good.

A campaign to take over 450 employes of the Triboro Coach Company of Long Island City who belong to the American Federation of Labor was announced yesterday by Austin Hogan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.
Governor Dewey, without any specific reference to President Truman's proposals to Congress for Government intervention in that field, made a bitter attack last night on socialized medicine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The United Public Utilities Corporation, Flemington, N.J., received today permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell, as a step in its liquidation program to the Dayton Power and Light Company for $7,830,000, all of the outstanding securities of seven of its subsidiaries.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, will deliver a special radio address on Sunday, Feb. 29, urging peoples of all faiths to aid the needy of Europe and Asia.
Food prices to consumers dropped 3 to 4 per cent in large cities, including New York, during the grain market break, a special survey of the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed yesterday.

The horrifying picture given the United States Conference of Mayors of the damage that would be done to an American city by an atomic bomb probably represents the start of a belated attempt to "educate" the American people to the importance of civilian defense.
One of the greatest welterweight battles seen here in recent years provided one of the biggest upsets last night in Madison Square Garden.

Conditions in the North Country remain speculative for the vast throng of holiday skiers who started converging on popular areas last night. Instead of the deep and packed powder snows that have prevailed since Christmas week, the followers of the hickory boards will find frozen granular, breakable and unbreakable crusts, with the prospect of hard-surface running for the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -The Army said today it did not plan to buy "large amounts" of Argentine corn. This announcement was made after Senator Milton R. Young, Republican, North Dakota, complained that the Army had stopped purchases here and was acquiring Argentine grain.

THE proposal I handed Ambassadors Nomura and Kurusu on Nov. 26 (the ten-point peace settlement plan) was an honest effort to keep our conversations going, with the forlorn hope that even at this ultimate minute a little common sense might filter into the military minds in Tokyo.

Next Saturday has been designated as Red Cross Sabbath and Feb. 29 as Red Cross Sunday. The 1948 Fund chairman for Protestant churches is Mrs. William Barclay Parsons Jr.; for synagogues, Mrs. Naaman Glick and for Roman Catholic churches, Mrs. Henry Mann.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Development of the crisis in Czechoslovakia from differences of principle within the Cabinet to a show-down between Communist and non-Communist elements in the Government is considered likely by British diplomatic quarters.

A cold wave that weather forecasters expected would be shortlived was carried into New York from the Northwest on a twentysix-mile wind last night, ending the balmy spell. It brought back freezing temperatures to New York and subzero temperatures to some sections of the Midwest.

SALEM, Ore., Feb. 20 -- Encouraged by his reception in Washington State, Harold E. Stassen began a four-day campaign today for the votes of Oregon's twelve delegates to the Republican national convention. They will be elected at the May 21 primary.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Russia approved today in principle the investigation by the United Nations of the gumchewing habit in the United States.
ATHENS, Feb. 20 -- The Populist-Liberal Government of Greece received a vote of confidence of 190 to 90 in the Chamber of Deputies tonight.

VIENNA, Feb. 20 -- The Russian Commandant in Vienna's Tenth District yesterday informed a gathering of newsboys and newsdealers that they would be held responsible for the sale of newspapers containing material directed against the Soviet Union.

The indoor track and field season reaches its annual climax tonight in the sixtieth National A.A.U. championships at Madison Square Garden. In the first significant title competition of the Olympic year an impressive array of American candidates for summer glory at London, plus the leading hopes of Canada and Jamaica, will turn out.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- The big shipping nations took hold of the United Nations Maritime Conference today after a general first round airing of views had revealed wide divergencies among the thirty-five countries present.

Many furniture stores handling quality merchandise have substantial inventories of certain types of bedroom and dining room furniture and are making consumer deliveries within a week to ten days, it was learned yesterday. It is pointed out that this delivery period may be called "immediate" when one considers the handling necessary to furniture store operations.
Price-fixing against exports to Germany and covering of shorts on the New York Cotton Exchange lifted cotton futures prices yesterday to net gains of 15 to 21 points on active months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Decisions of next week's three-power conference in London on Western Germany will be provisional, the State Department declared today. The discussions will be frank and out of them a clear-cut policy can be determined by the United States, British and French Governments, the department statement added.

A vacant plot 92 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 134th Street in Belle Harbor, Queens, has been sold by Meyer Albala to Carrie Goldberg and Joseph Olkin through Earl H. Stitt, broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

With the arrest of two men and recovery of 800 carats of diamonds with a rough wholesale value of $128,000, customs agents fitted a logical explanation yesterday to an unbelievable tale of diamonds lost in flight over the Atlantic.

The loan exhibition of paintings by Delacroix and Renoir at the Rosenberg Gallery for the benefit of the New York Heart Association will be open on Washington's Birthday from 12 to 5 o'clock. Admission is 50 cents plus tax.

A proposed set of eighteen standards to improve motion picture films for children has been offered to the industry by the United Parents Associations of New York City with the assurance that the proposal has the support of parent groups throughout the country.

A certificate commending Mayor O'Dwyer as a "good neighbor" was accepted yesterday at City Hall by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett from a group of 400 school children from East Harlem and Yorkville. The youngsters, attending ceremonies marking the third annual Good Neighbor Festival in their areas, bowed their heads for a moment of silent prayer for the Mayor's recovery from the heart condition that had caused him to enter Bellevue Hospital for medical observation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A new and improved method of pollinating the blossoms of plants and fruit-bearing trees through the utilization of controlled activities of honey bees was patented this week (No. 2,435,951) by Leo C. Antles of Wenatchee, Wash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A net increase of 200,000 in the number of concerns in existence brought the country's business population fully into line with the level of business activity last year for the first time since the outbreak of the war, the Department of Commerce reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -Robert Lord has obtained his release from his producing contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to join Mark Hellinger Productions, the independent company of the late Mark Hellinger, as executive director, it was learned today. Associated with Mr. Lord in the management
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- An American Medical Association spokesman took issue today with G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist Bishop, over the cause of a serious shortage of physicians.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- The text of today's statement by Larry MacPhail, former president of the Yankees, answering the recent charge by President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers that the major leagues had sought to bar Negroes from organized baseball follows:

Defending the price increases announced Thursday by the steel industry for semi-finished materials, the presidents of the first and third largest steel companies in the United States declared yesterday that the advances had been made necessary by rising costs of materials and had not been instituted to cushion any anticipated wage demands by employes.

Information unearthed by a Congressional committee of the alleged gray market transactions of Isidore Ginsberg, portly dealer in building materials, resulted yesterday in his indictment here for grand larceny.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- An institute of racial and cultural relations has been inaugurated by the Board of Christian Education and the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., it was announced today.

In another column on this page we print a letter from Julius C.C. Edelstein, Special Adviser to Secretary Marshall, regarding the Allied reparations and dismantling program in Western Germany. The problems discussed in it are fundamental, not only to the fate of Germany but to the recovery of Western Europe and the success of the Marshall Plan.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20 -A Russian told the United Nations today that an Alabama husband could legally beat an erring wife with a club not more than two inches thick.

Martha Graham last night added to the repertory of her season at Maxine Elliott's Theatre "Herodiade" and "Cave of the Heart," along with repetitions of "Appalachian Spring" and "Every Soul Is a Circus."

Joseph S. Fay, former labor union official, was taken to Sing Sing prison yesterday morning from Rikers Island penitentiary to start serving a seven and one-half to fifteen-year term for extortion. The 55-year-old convict was driven to the prison in a bullet-proof limousine and was handcuffed to Benjamin Feldman, twice-convicted Brooklyn murderer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Fiftytwo Southern Democrats in the House bitterly and formally defied President Truman today on the issue of his civil rights program.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The Soviet Union adhered firmly to its proposals for a solution of the problem of German assets in Austria and turned aside two questions involving an easing of the terms at the opening meeting of the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, former part owner of the New York Yankees, said today that Branch Rickey "lied" in his speech at Wilberforce University last Monday night.

Protests will be taken to Governor Dewey and to Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, against the preliminary approval by state and Federal authorities of a 12 per cent rent increase at Knickerbocker Village, it was announced yesterday.

The nation's security and commodity markets and banks throughout the country will be closed on Monday in observance of George Washington's birthday. Canadian and European security exchanges will remain open, as will the Winnipeg Grain Exchange.

The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation had a net income last year of $6,056,340 after all charges, including $3,755,000 provision for taxes, according to the annual report of Clarence E. Searle, president, issued for publication today.
Two big upsets marked the Vanderbilt Cup National Knockout Teams of Four Contract Bridge Championship Tournament last night at the Pierre Hotel.

Charles Anthony Doyle, up-state regional director of the United Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers of America, CIO, who was excluded from the United States last month as an alien Communist surrendered here yesterday to immigration officials.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- James Spillance, regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has assigned James Cleland, a conciliator, to try to avert a threatened strike of the United Packinghouse Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, against the country's leading packers.

OCANA, Spain, Feb. 20 -- Prison sentences of one and one-half to six years were imposed by a military court here today on fourteen students charged with belonging to the clandestine organization, Federacion Universatario Escolor, One student was acquitted.

When Dorothy Heyward's play, "Set My People Free," reaches the boards next season the Theatre Guild, which once held the script and then let it go, will be involved in the presentation. Although no formal contracts have been signed, the Guild has agreed to co-produce

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- Both houses of the Japanese Diet will meet tomorrow afternoon to elect a new Premier in a chaotic political situation in which minor parties and insurgents against the majority leadership hold the balance of power.

ESSEN, Feb. 20 -- The Ruhr miner is the most favored person in Germany. In the huge incredible palace from which the Krupps ruled their industrial empire sits a board of experts headed by Robert Estill on the American side and Henry Collins on the British. They watch the production graph as anxiously as doctors read the pulse of a sick patient.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet economic proposals for Austria submitted to the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers Jan. 24 and now under consideration:
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20 -- Argentina and Chile today officially opened the new railway that will carry steam trains across the Andes at an altitude usually considered suitable only for planes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- The Ukrainian Government charged today that big business and diplomacy of the United States were helping the Dutch "crush" the Indonesian people and shared responsibility for the bloodshed in the Netherlands Indies.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 20 -- Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia and Miss Elizabeth Howe of New Haven reached the final round of the women's national squash racquets championship at the Greenwich Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Grain markets showed a heavy undertone today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with professional traders inclined to favor the bear side, despite much less favorable crop comments from Kansas and the failure of the country to offer cash corn.

Support of the recommendations of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems for the establishment of municipal traffic control boards should be forthcoming. This committee, headed by Senator S. Halpern, has held hearings and made studies in the principal cities of the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today approved a measure imposing curbs through Oct. 31 on the use of grain by distilleries.
I appreciate the editorial and position you are taking in connection with the Red Cross plan for blood donors for the benefit of the hospitals in Greater New York.

"THE BEST IS NONE TOO GOOD,"* by Ralph G. Martin, is an excellent account of one man's rediscovery of America. It should interest a great many people, since it tells the story of what Mr. Martin found when he wandered all over the country inquiring into what had happened to Americans who had been in the armed services, what they were up to, how they were making out.

Thirty-five mothers of pupils in Public School 27, on St. Anns Avenue between 146th and 147th Streets, the Bronx, protested yesterday at a sidewalk meeting in front of the school against older children in the institution molesting younger ones there.

Trees as well as roads have suffered heavily this winter. In the suburban areas of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut fine old giants that gave character and dignity to many a home, and young ornamental trees, tenderly planted and nurtured, alike have been defaced and too often destroyed by the sheatling mantle of ice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, pleaded not guilty today to a criminal charge of spending union funds for political purposes. He entered a similar plea in behalf of the CIO as an organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- A measure to alleviate the plight of stateless persons was adopted by the United Nations Economic and Social Council's social committee today by 15 to 3, Russia, Poland and Byelorussia [White Russia] voting in the minority.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- With stock brokers reporting the quietest day for months, the stock market here today sagged, excepting a few individual favorites.

Keys and papers that belonged to the late Mrs. Frederick B. Lloyd of the Salisbury Hotel turned up yesterday in William G. Rowan's office at 270 Broadway, from which they had been stolen some twenty-four hours.

More informative and more colorful advertising was described yesterday as primary need of the insurance business. This, along with a program of "attractive" public relations, was urged in addresses before the Insurance Advertising Conference in the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri and other city officials who returned last night from Berwick, Pa., where they inspected the first of the 750 modern subway cars being built for the city by the American Car and Foundry Company, disclosed that the first consignment of forty cars would be delivered in June, four months later than originally scheduled.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Board of Regents voted today to extend free tuition to "a limited number" of foreign students who may wish to enter state teachers' colleges, state agricultural and technical institutes and the State Maritime Academy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Federal aid to higher education is essential if the serious crisis facing American colleges and universities is to be met, Dr. Ralph McDonald, of the National Education Association, warned here today.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- A plan for voluntary limitation on the amount of money spent to advertise scarce and luxury goods will be presented to the nation's advertisers this week by the Federation of British Industries. The plan evolved by a special committee has been accepted by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of Exchequer, as a substitute for the unpopular Government suggestion for cutting tax exemptions on advertising expenditures by business concerns.

Henry A. Wallace, third party candidate for President, stepped off an Eastern Airlines Constellation from Miami at Newark Airport yesterday afternoon and indicated to reporters that he had no expectation of returning to the Democratic party.

Jesse Stuart, author of "Taps for Private Tussie," will speak at Town Hall today at 11 A.M. on "Folk Literature and the Author's Craft." Other authors who will speak there soon are: William L. Shirer, Feb. 28; Norman Cousins, March 3, and Robert St. John, March 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The French Ministry of Foreign Affairs has learned that the United States is no longer willing to maintain the offer of a treaty of guarantee made by former Secretary of State Byrnes in September, 1946. The object of that treaty was to keep Germany fully disarmed for forty years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -Harry Bridges refused to comment today on the notification from the national office of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to comply with CIO policy or face dismissal as CIO director for Northern California.
ROME, Feb. 20 -- Two Albanian Bishops were condemned to death and executed recently while a third received a twenty-year jail sentence, Vatican circles said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate opened debate today on a bill to extend rent control, with some modifications, from Feb. 29, the date set for its expiration, to April 30, 1949.
GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- The Swiss have tentatively rejected French proposals to create a free market for the Swiss franc in Paris, it was learned today.

The fate of the local Red Cross' plans for a free blood donor service for New York City may be decided at a meeting of the New York County Medical Society to be held next Monday evening in the Academy of Medicine Building at 2 East 103d Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- A three-month "truce" in the Holy Land, "freezing" the situation there until another attempt at conciliation could be made, was one of several forecasts of United States Palestine policy circulating at United Nations headquarters today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Highranking New York Democrats used the occasion of Washington's $100-a-plate Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner, it was learned today, to impress again on the party high command that President Truman must take immediate and forceful action in the Palestine situation.

Retail trade here showed substantial percentage gains this week. Much of the increase over last year, however, was due to the six-day week t!ais year, compared with figures based on a five-day week in 1947 when Washington's Birthday was celebrated on Saturday.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- Fifty million European children will be tested for tuberculosis in the next few months and as many as one-third of them will be vaccinated against the disease, Dr. J.B. MacDouglass of the World Health Organization said today.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 20 -- The meeting here today of 350 leaders of the Indian National Congress party and the expected release in a few days of the draft constitution for India are two events calculated to reshape and direct the political life of the six-month-old dominion.

Saturday night is a good night. It is the night most distant from the morning of Blue Monday, and so it should be celebrated suitably. It is the most distant, that is, in the point of view of a man looking backward, which is his normal vision.

One of the busiest programs of the season is in store for collegiate basketball fans tonight as thirteen quintets from the metropolitan district take part in nine games on local courts. Heading the bill is the Eastern Intercollegiate League contest between Columbia and Harvard at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Ten 3-year-olds monopolize turf interest at Santa Anita Park tomorrow in the $50,000 added San Vicente Handicap. Heading the array named are Norman W. Church's May Reward and Royal Chance, William G. Helis' Salmagundi and Mr. Ace and Mrs. Nat Goldstone's Solidarity.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- Letters requesting the governments that are members of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization to support the establishment of special funds for shipping and for the mass resettlement of displaced persons were addressed today to twenty-one governments.

The 216th anniversary of the birth of George Washington will be celebrated tomorrow in the churches of New York. The synagogues of the city will hold observances today and patriotic organizations will attend special Washington services on Monday.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 -- Middlebury College took the lead in the first half of the men's events in the McGill winter carnival today, unofficial placings indicate. McGill appeared to be second in the standing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Federal internal revenue collections from all sources in 1947 totaled $39,420,845,446, an increase of $780,787,586, over 1946, the Treasury reported today. Collections from the states totaled $38,640,057,860 in 1946.
Sportsmen's Show highlights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations virtually ousted Harry Bridges today as regional director for Northern California because he is supporting Henry Wallace for President and opposing the European Recovery Program.

Latest reports on the recent high water in the Tennessee Valley again confirm the efficiency of TVA's system of tributary and main-river dams. The great reservoirs of Norris, Cherokee, Douglas, Fontana and Hiwassee, on the tributary streams, took all the water that was poured into them and had plenty of room left.
A landmark on the downtown waterfront passed into new control yesterday, but the railroad tenants will keep their offices there under a leasing arrangement.

The Committee on Social Welfare and Relief Problems, affiliated with the Council of State Governments, recommended yesterday that Congress pass immediately legislation to expand old age and survivors insurance and to reimburse the states for the care of nonresidents.
Debutantes of next season are aiding final plans for the benefit performance of Noel Coward's "Tonight at 8:30," starring Gertrude Lawrence, on Wednesday night at the National Theatre.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 20 (AP) -Bids on a $200,000,000 bond issue to finance Ohio's bonus for war veterans will be received at the office of Gov. Thomas J. Herbert March 16, the State Sinking Fund Commission announced today.

I was happy to see, in your Feb. 10 editorial commenting on Secretary Marshall's defense of our German reparations policy, that THE NEW YORK TIMES now gives substantial weight to the political factors justifying a continuation of reparations deliveries.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Foreign Minister Bidault told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assembly today that the Berlin agreement, with preceding ones covering Ruhr coal, would enable France to get from the Ruhr and the Saar 463,000 tons of coal monthly in the second quarter of this year, 642,000 tons monthly in the last quarter, 750,000 tons monthly by the end of 1949 and more than 1,000,000 tons monthly by the end of 1950.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Premier Robert Schuman today staked the life of his Cabinet on a vote of confidence that he demanded from the Assembly on the Government's decision to reject a proposal for a rapid, unconditional reimbursement of the 5,000-franc banknotes withdrawn from circulation.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 20 -- Her holds bulging with 107 tons of food and clothing, the Maine "Rotary Friend Ship" sailed at 2:20 P.M. today from Maine State Pier for Nantes, France, where her cargo will be distributed among the residents of that city.

The stock market came close yesterday to matching the low marks reached early last week, but a creeping recovery in the late afternoon permitted a steadier close. Price changes were insignificant in the majority of issues traded, with the top price stocks the only exception.

A new union shop agreement covering superintendents in 150 midtown loft buildings was announced yesterday by the Midtown Realty Owners Association, Inc., and Local 164, Building Service Employes International Union AFL.

A large building to contain a garage and repair shop for trailer trucks, together with a dormitory and restaurant for the drivers, is planned for a blockfront in Long Island City, Queens, which has been vacant and unimproved since the early Nineteen Thirties. The parcel,

CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 -- A broad cross-section of representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations gave its support today to President Truman in his fight for the preservation of civil rights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Congress today transmitting his second annual report on the United Nations:

Douglas was there for more than three hours, along with several other members of the United States delegation to tripartite discussions, which will begin Monday.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Bruno Walter and Walter Hendl, conductors; Barbara Goldberg, piano, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; "Aida" 2 P.M. and "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera Company, 8:30; Boston Symphony,

"If You Knew Susie," a comedy with music, not to mention Eddie Cantor and Joan Davis, will have its local premiere this morning at the Palace. The title of the picture, which Cantor produced for RKO, is taken from the popular song written by Buddy De Sylva...
