CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 -- A broad cross-section of representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations gave its support today to President Truman in his fight for the preservation of civil rights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Congress today transmitting his second annual report on the United Nations:

There was standing room only at the beginning of last night's concert of the National Association for American Composers at Times Hall. Most of the listeners were guests of station WNYC, which broadcast the program as part of its annual American Music

Wartime rationing educated thousands of housewives to use oleomargarine instead of butter. Consumption of oleomargarine by the American family has more than doubled since the period just before the war. Consumer resistance to the high price of butter also has been a factor in the exceptional demand for oleomargarine, those in the industry say.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 -Arthur Krock, chief of the Washington bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be the principal speaker of Princeton's thirty-fourth annual midwinter alumni day program here tomorrow. More than 1,000 persons will attend the meeting, beginning at 12:30 P.M., in the new Dillon Gymnasium.

Speaking caustically of "typically MacPhailian distortions, untruths and inventions," President Branch Rickey, of the Dodgers, last night dismissed Larry MacPhail's lengthy statement, issued by the former Yankee president from Miami, Fla., in exactly thirty-seven words.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers joined today the ever-growing group of investigators who are trying to "get the facts" behind the recent withdrawal by underwriters of a public offering of 900,000 shares of common stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- Amid charges and insinuations of the concealment of military installations, members of the Allied Control Council agreed today to assemble all documents on the subject of demilitarization to see where they stand.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The export of crude oil without a license was halted today by the Department of Commerce in another move to divert more oil to critical shortage areas in this country.

Industrial plants here are tightening up on purchasing terms and conditions in two way, industrial executives revealed here yesterday. They are vigorously protesting unauthorized over-charges on invoices for which purchased materials for prices have been advanced without notification and refusing to pay excessive cancellation charges when vendors resell canceled products without loss, spokesmen disclosed.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 -- Shelling, in which the Jews used mortars, and bitter street fighting, turned Haifa into Palestine's main battleground today, while in Jerusalem twelve Jewish prisoners broke out of Central Prison by tunneling under the prison wall.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (AP) -The local golfing pride, Fred Haas Jr., swung his way to a five-stroke halftime lead in the $10,000 New Orleans open here today after filing four of his clubs to meet a protest over the size of the grooves.

The Atlas Corporation added two major holdings to its portfolio last year according to the annual report released yesterday by Floyd B. Odlum, president. The additions consisted of 131,900 shares of common stock of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, with a market value of $1,780,650 on Dec. 31; and 177,400 common shares of Barnsdall Oil Company, valued at $6,741,200.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Rescued by a banana boat after drifting nine days in the Gulf of Mexico, a flier related today that sharks snatched the body of his companion from their raft after their plane had crashed into the sea.
BERLIN, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The United States and Great Britain formally agreed with France today on the separation of the Saar from Germany and its economic annexation to France.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Legislation to create a permanent reapportionment commission to make a continuous study of Congressional and Legislative reapportionment was proposed today in a bill introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux, Republican, of Warren County.

The strife in Palestine is an open Arab revolt against the decision of the United Nations partition plan in which Palestinian Arabs have been agitated and aided by neighboring Arab nations, Julius Fligelman of the United Jewish Appeal said yesterday. Mr. Fligelman is co-chairman of a delegation that spent a month abroad studying the needs of Jews. in Europe and Palestine in connection with the appeal's campaign to raise $250,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board awarded routes to nine airlines in the Middle Atlantic area today.

Olga Coelho, who appeared in recital at Town Hall last night, has a gift for making music charming and charm musical. The Brazilian soprano, who accompanies herself on the guitar, has carved out a special style for herself.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Blitzed industrial areas of Germany can provide enough scrap to make an "immense difference in the world steel situation," John L. Haynes, of the Department of Commerce and chairman of a United States Government scrap iron and steel mission to Germany, said at Southampton today.

Pistol Pete Reiser yesterday found President Branch Rickey a little softer target than the outfield walls the young Dodger star has been crashing into with such distressing regularity the past few years.

PRAGUE, Feb. 20 -- Communist Premier Klement Gottwald's Cabinet broke up tonight because of fears of the creation of a police state. The Czechoslovak Premier did not resign, however, but asked President Eduard Benes for authority to replace the eleven Ministers who left the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Truman declared today in a report to Congress on "The United States and the United Nations" during 1947 that the United Nations "is making headway" notwithstanding the failure of Russia and her satellites to cooperate in some of its major decisions.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 -- Problems inherent in the use of radioactive materials in drug manufacturing were described today to the annual midwinter conference of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, West Coast section.
Net income of the Erie Railroad for January declined to $152,687 from $334,591 for the same month a year ago, R.E. Woodruff, president, reported yesterday.

A thorough survey of pier rentals showing the limits that can be charged for city-owned piers in their present condition will be included in the exhaustive report by the Port of New York Authority on waterfront rehabilitation that will be made public Tuesday.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Taking command in the first few minutes, Cornell's tall and spirited basketball team tonight defeated Harvard, 71 -- 59, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before 6,507 fans at Boston Arena.
Stormy weather, which brought floods, cold, snows and freezing rains to various parts of the country yesterday, brought New York a threat of still more snow and lingering cold today.

I FEEL obliged to confess that not all the treasurers of hit shows are chronic grouches and boors. Last week a friend and I set out happily to see "Medea," having bought tickets some three months before. We climbed in our usual fashion toward the last row in the balcony; I suddenly noticed to my horror that my tickets had been for the previous night.***

"Improved human communications" in industry were called for last night by Austin S. Igleheart, president of the General Foods Corporation. Mr. Igleheart was the only scheduled speaker before 2,500 persons attending the annual dinner of the Traffic Club of New York at the Commodore Hotel.

As the debate on the European Recovery Plan moved nearer to a conclusion, ways of making the aid to the countries participating in the Marshall Plan less burdensome to our economy were suggested last week by two leading Government officials.

THIS hard-hitting book by a veteran journalist and crusader voices a plea for the rapid removal of all trade barriers as an aid to peace and prosperity. Frankly a tract for the times addressed to the layman, it makes no claim to economic originality, but it skillfully digests past events and current facts and canvasses future prospects in lucid, non-technical language.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The State Department rejected flatly and sharply today a Russian protest against the forthcoming United States-British-French meeting on the economic future of Germany.
TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- Adm. Kichisaburo Nomura, Japanese Ambassador to Washington at the time of Pearl Harbor, is homesick for America.

A conference on regional planning in higher education in the South will highlight the two-day inaugural ceremony of Dr. J. Hillis Miller as fourth president of the University of Florida on March 4 and 5. The Governors of fifteen Southern states and leading officers of prominent Southern universities and colleges have been invited to attend.
TORONTO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs moved into a tie with the Detroit Red Wings for the National Hockey League leadership tonight by beating them, 3 -- 2, before 14,567 fans.

WASHINGTON -- The significance of international travel, capable of bringing millions of dollars to foreign countries desperately seeking means of rehabilitation and recovery, has attracted the attention of legislators currently concerned with the European Recovery Program.

ONE of the most provocative exhibitions of the season brings together paintings by Delacroix and Renoir at the gallery of Paul Rosenberg. Writers and artists have placed them poles apart. In their temperaments and in the background of their times the dissimilarity is at once apparent.

ON April 30, 1929, the National Institute of Social Sciences awarded its gold medal to Mrs. Valeria Langeloth "in recognition of distinguished social service in maintaining and developing * * * Valeria Home, where men and women are provided with opportunity to find recreation and renewed health amid helpful and beautiful surroundings at minimum cost."
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 21 -- The Cornell University basketball team handed Dartmouth a 66-49 drubbing tonight before a near capacity crowd of 3,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The publishers of the best-selling novel "Raintree County," say that the winner of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's $125,000 novel prize is not "1,066 pages of rank obscenity, blasphemy and sacrilege" as charged by Father A.J. Barrett of Fordham University.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 -Front-running Fred Haas Jr. slowed his pace somewhat today but still held a lead of two strokes at the end of fifty-four holes in the $10,000 New Orleans open golf tournament.

THE thesis of Ansel Adams, famous for his meticulous photographic technique, that photographers should visualize the final print before snapping the shutter, and then working toward a planned end result, underlies his "Basic Photo" series of books, the first volume of which, "Camera Lens" (New York: Morgan Lester. $3), has just been published.

"LUCINDA BRAYFORD" is a substantial novel in the objective, well articulated, Victorian tradition, to which many novelists are returning today in reaction against those who have broken with it. Quietly, and with considerable narrative skill, it tells the story of four generations of an Anglo-Australian family.
All of the favorites were eliminated in the semi-finals of the Vanderbilt Cup national knock-out team-of-four contract bridge tournament last night at the Hotel Pierre.

THE work known to history as "The Federalist" originally appeared in eighty-five numbers more than a century and a half ago. "In my opinion," says the historian Charles A. Beard, "it is the most instructive work on political science ever written in the United States; and, owing to its practical character, it ranks first in the world's literature of political science."

FOR over thirty years William Richards was one of several newsmen assigned to report the daily extracurricular activities of the world's richest man. He has brought together in this longish volume a host of reminiscences about the Maharaja of River Rouge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Plutonium poisoning, responsible for thousands of deaths at Nagasaki and Hiroshima, and a constant danger to United States atomic scientists, may be treated in the event of future atomic bombings by using a rare metal called zirconium to "bump" the radioactive plutonium out of human bodies.

THE last time I saw John Maynard Keynes was at a press conference immediately after the negotiation of the Anglo-American loan agreement. I asked him why there had not been included in the agreement a clause pledging both nations to seek full employment.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- A constitutional amendment that would give nondisabled veterans a permanent preference in appointment to civil service jobs is under consideration by the bipartisan veterans conference of the state Legislature.

Boys High School's track and field squad accounted for one of its greatest triumphs yesterday when it captured the National High School championship at Madison Square Garden. Sharing honors with the Brooklyn school was Seton Hall Prep of South Orange, N.J., which retained the crown in the prep school division.

For the first time in history three nations made a show of force in the Antarctic last week to support their conflicting claims. In the area as a whole, no less than eight countries have newly established or projected bases.

On June 20 the Republican Convention meets in Philadelphia to nominate its national ticket. On July 12 the Democratic Convention meets in the same city to renominate President Truman (a virtual certainty) and to name a Vice Presidential candidate.

The battle for third place in the National Hockey League will be raging at Madison Square Garden tonight when the New York Rangers tackle the Boston Bruins. Although the Rangers have had the spot since Christmas, the Bruins have always remained within hailing distance.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature announced today that they had reintroduced the discarded Republican-sponsored Young-Milmoe bill increasing basic state aid to education by $103,000,000 and that they would seek Republican help in a move to force the measure from committee for a floor vote.
The countries within the Soviet sphere of eastern Europe number eight. They are Finland, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Albania.

The release last week of a report by the House Select Committee on Foreign Aid, better known as the Herter Committee, has drawn the fire of local shipping men who describe many of the committee's recommendations as "ethereal, and not readily workable."

THIS is the time of the year when many college students begin planning their summer vacations, with thoughts of working their passage to Europe on a transatlantic liner, of sailing on a cruise ship and of a combination work-holiday summer at a resort hotel.

DWIGHT MACDONALD has hardly written an impartial book about Henry Wallace. But he has written a brilliant, slashing attack with a cogency of evidence and a keenness of insight which may give the book much more than the fleeting interest of campaign polemics.

Marked progress has been made by the anti-inflation drive of manufacturers and distributors of industrial supplies and machinery, W.W. Kemphert, chairman of the marketing methods committee of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association, Pittsburgh, Pa., declared here yesterday.
The annual report of the Greater New York Fund, showing the distribution of $4,136,419 among 423 local hospital, health and welfare agencies in 1947 was issued yesterday.

RECKLESS driving continues to be a major factor in the nation's highway problems and last year caused the revocation or suspension of an estimated 318,000 drivers' licenses. The estimate is a conservative one, according to Otto Messner, president of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators.

GLORIA ROUSTON is convinced that the atmosphere of her home is not conducive to long life. Either her husband or one of the other parasites who are living on her money has tried to kill her by tossing her off a bridge. When Gloria finds that she is still alive she decides to disappear.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Richard T. West of Washington, and Donald J. Sterling Jr., of Portland, Ore., today received a dual award of the M. Taylor Pyne Honor Prize, highest general distinction which Princeton University may confer upon an undergraduate.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Rutgers upset a scrappy Colgate five, 80 -- 79, today, when Paul Lynner scored three baskets in the last two minutes of play before 3,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 21 -- A 53-year-old accountant told the police here today how he pyramided $2 lost on a horse race at Belmont Park in the summer of 1946 into a shortage of $55,060 in his accounts.

The twenty-third annual report of the Chrysler Corporation, issued for publication today, shows net sales of $1,362,626,751 and net earnings of $67,181,221 for 1947. In 1946 net sales were $870,000,412, and net income was $26,889,290. As of Dec. 31, last, cash and marketable securities amounted to $216,220,463; accounts receivable, to $47,643,421, and net value of inventories on hand, to $111,567,568.

Sportsmen's Show personalities. Joe LaFlamme, of Gogama, Ont., whose beard is anathema to the razor blade manufacturers, and his collection of Ontario wildlife. Joe has had just about enough of civilization at this point, and is ready to go back to his cabin and traps.

WARSAW, Feb. 21 -- The deadlock between church and state in Poland is best illustrated by two remarks made to this correspondent this week. "The only thing that will satisfy the church is a change of government," said a Government official. "The only thing that will satisfy the Government is our complete subservience to Marxism," said a high churchman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Representatives of the newsreels, television and radio were informally told today by spokesmen for the House Committee on Foreign Affairs that they would not be permitted, at least until further notice, to record committee hearings on the European Recovery Program.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The European Recovery Program, the British Labor Government's alleged "subservience" to the United States and failure to solve current economic problems were bitterly attacked today by Harry Pollitt, general secretary of the British Communist party, at the opening of a three-day party convention.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 21 -- The Russian-sponsored North Korea Government has set next Wednesday as the date of payment in new currency for the confiscated Korean yen ordered deposited in state banks last Dec. 5.

MR. WEAVER'S "Ideas Have Consequences," a return to the party line of the neo-humanists of the Twenties, reinforced by a little Southern agrarianism, is a sincere, fanatical, and, for my money, irresponsible piece of writing.

Something of a storm in the sports world has been stirred up this week by the remarks of Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, of the National Baseball League, concerning the former attitude of his fellow baseball officials toward the use of Negro players. Whatever the intention of Mr. Rickey in rattling this skeleton, some facts of the situation in baseball are incontrovertible.

OUR favorite weather man is Alvin Tresselt who, with rare foresight, gave us last fall "White Snow, Bright Snow" and a year ago "Raindrop Splash." Now, employing a different narrative technique but equal charm, he describes for children of 4 to 7 the moods of the wind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Republican leaders in the Senate and the House agreed today on a month's extension of the rent-control law expiring Feb. 29.

The verbal battle over inflation or deflation waxed even warmer last week; nothing new was added; the public remained perplexed; the stock market lapsed into a state of tiredness -- so tired, in fact, that, on only a minimum of selling, prices breathed on the year's lows.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago this week modem art was introduced to America. The "International Exhibition of Modern Art," organized by adventuresome members of the Association of American Painters and Sculptors opened in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

THE legal fraternity has long recognized the lasting contribution of Judge Cardozo to the substance and spirit of the law. The publication of his selected works brings to a wider audience his extrajudicial writings, including his classic "Growth of the Law" and "Nature of the Judicial Process" as well as several hitherto unpublished essays and addresses.

GERMANY'S plan systematically to weaken or exterminate "inferior" civilian populations almost succeeded with one group -- the Jews of Europe. Today an estimated 1,500,000 Jews survive out of a pre-war population of 7,500,000; concentration camps and ovens such as those of Treblinka, Oswieczm, Chelmne, Dachau took the others.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Now the people must be heard.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 -- Only one Arab and one Jew were reported killed today. Reports were received, however, of the death of eight Arabs during the night and of one shot by a sentry in Jerusalem yesterday.

"JANE'S," like death and taxes, is always with us. Year after year these fat and ample pages, profusely illustrated, come to our shores showing the annual "progress" man has made toward annihilation. Year after year "Jane's Fighting Ships" and "Jane's Aircraft" serve as indispensable reference books for aerophiles, ship lovers, newspaper and library morgues.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Europe is dollar hungry. Yet even more avidly than Governments and exporters, it is the man in the street who is seeking dollars. The quantities may be modest, but as an Arab proverb says, it is drops of water that make the sea.

THE recent drop in commodity prices focused attention on the problem of deflation. But it would certainly be premature to bury inflation and proclaim deflation king. The old monarch may still be very much alive. Some day, though, the end will come to the inflation, and deflation will begin. It is never too soon to ask ourselves:

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Loafers and those who live by their wits -- spivs and drones, or eels and butterflies, as they are variously called here -- are far from extinct despite the new government measures, a survey of the situation discloses.
It is twelve weeks since the fateful evening of November 29 -- the evening that the United Nations General Assembly voted to divide Palestine into sovereign Jewish and Arab states.

Throughout New York City patriotic organizations tomorrow will hold special exercises in celebration of the 216th anniversary of the birth of George Washington. Yesterday various synagogues noted the birthday in their religious services and today the official birthday of the First President of the United States will be observed in churches.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- After a Cabinet meeting today it was indicated that the Government would issue on Monday a decree fixing the time for the reimbursement to owners of the recently recalled 5,000-franc banknotes.

NANKING, Sunday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- An American Embassy spokesman today quoted Ambassador John Leighton Stuart as declaring "the best possible solution" of the Chinese war "is still a coalition government by the Kuomintang and the Communists."

BRYAN FOY, production chief at Eagle Lion and a realist who apparently knows where he is going, should be en route by now to Colorado State Prison to survey the scene and cast some of the inmates in "Canon City," a semi-documentary about the recent prison break there.

WAGNER'S "Parsifal" is the only further work the Metropolitan Opera will add to its repertoire this season. It will be presented on March 10 in the final week of the subscription season and again during the usual extra performances of Holy Week.

The destructive powers of the atomic bomb should induce present day civilization to turn to the constructive uses of atomic energy in preparation for world peace, according to students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

JUST twelve years ago this week in this Review: A survey of racial problems, "We Europeans," by Julian Huxley and A.C. Haddon, led the rest. Stimulated by previous researches into the elusive Aryan ("He is a round head and a long head. He is blond and he is dark."), the book, the critic wrote, "is not a polemic but an excellent popular work."

MURDER is being plotted by three persons: two against one and one against two. The one who stands alone is so much cleverer than her two opponents that when she becomes aware of what they are planning she is able to turn the tables on them, killing one of them in such a way that all the evidence points to the other.

The State Liquor Authority made known yesterday a decision reached on Friday in which it refused to grant a license to International Distributors, one of the largest liquor wholesalers in the East with an annual business volume of between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- A leading London newspaper, commenting recently on the "uneasiness and unhappiness" underlying the parliamentary debate on the withdrawal of British forces from Palestine, said that the Roman Senate must have felt much the same way in deciding to recall its legions from Britain in 410 A.D.

MISS Park's novel has a weight and solidity that puts fancier books to shame. It is a little squat and homely, perhaps -- like an old-fashioned stove -- but it gives out enough heat to warm the chill print of half a dozen of our streamlined models.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- As the depressed Administration Democrats survey their broken party lines on the eve of the battle for the Presidency, they are much more troubled by the defections on the Northern flank than on the Southern. In fact, if they had only the Southern insubordination to deal with they would not be worried very much, and -- whether they are right or wrong -- for this they have two particular reasons.

A wild round-about automobile chase through a small section of lower Harlem ended last evening in the escape of the chauffeur of a privately owned car after he had successfully dodged seven bullets fired at him by a probationary patrolman and the serious injury of the chauffeur's 15-year-old niece, who fell out of the machine during the unsuccessful pursuit

I want to correct some of the statements and implications in the letter written by Norman Draper, Director of Public Relations, American Meat Institute, which appeared in THE TIMES of Feb. 15. He attempts to draw a clear line of distinction between food and feed grains.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 -- The Arab League has decided not to permit any American companies to lay pipelines across the territory of its member countries until the United States policy toward a partition of Palestine is altered, it was learned tonight.

THE thirty-second International Flower Show to be held at Grand Central Palace on March 8 through 13 will have 255 main classes. New this year is a class called "suburban home planting," for which gardens that are appropriate for small properties will be set up.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- A major flood threat in the upper Ohio River Valley has been eased in the last week as rains and unseasonably warm weather carried away a heavy blanket of snow on the mountains and in the valleys.

Britain's Prime Minister, Mr. Attlee, recently explained to an audience of Oxford students and teachers the fundamental difference between Western European socialism and Russian communism. Mr. Attlee does not often take part in the debate between London and Moscow, but when he does he can be counted upon to contribute light rather than heat to the controversy.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 21 -- In what was termed here a milestone in the history of American education, the three leading national teacher organizations merged today into a single organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- It is a familiar statement in Washington that a Senator is most effective when he is past 60 and has stopped running for President. The success of Senator Vandenberg as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee seems to illustrate the wisdom of the statement, and the progress of the European Recovery Program on Capitol Hill emphasizes it.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The first stage of one of the greatest concepts in modern history -- a Western union of European nations -- is over. It has left many of the statesmen involved, as well as many observers, curiously baffled; and yet there are no reasons for pessimism.

ALTHOUGH "The Ides of March" is a novel, Thornton Wilder, who wrote it, is a philosopher. Not that the offices of novelist and philosopher are in opposition. In the present instance they are not identical since the distinction of are Ides of March" -- Mr. Wilder's first novel since 1935 -- lies more in the philosophy than the fiction, but the philosopher is also a novelist.

THE encouraging response of the public to the recently concluded City Center drama season provides still another argument in favor of plays at lower prices. The success of this enterprise should also help explode the peculiar belief held in certain quarters that only musicals can be counted upon to fill our larger auditoriums.

An experimental research project aimed at demonstrating that prepackaged produce can be marketed as cheaply as in bulk is being studied by the Folding Paper Box Manufacturers Association of America, it was learned last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A twelve-member committee of Southern Democrats in the House opposed to President Truman's civil rights program was named today to meet with Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, Monday.

Experiments conducted at White Sands, N.M., with German V-2 rockets fired as high as 100 miles, have shown that at an altitude of thirty-four miles the intensity of cosmic ray bombardment is constant. This is the beginning of what scientists call the "cosmic-ray plateau."

WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 21 -- Given four years and a few more good wheat crops, the staid Kansas countryside should be a new utopia for enterprising salesmen of electric gadgets. By that time some thirty-seven small Rural Electrification Administration cooperatives expect to double their capacity and raise the state's lagging electrification rate from 40 to about 90 per cent.

THE announcement last week that the Civil Aeronautics Board intends to revise the safety regulations for non-scheduled airlines to bring them closer to the rules applying to the certificated air carriers did not come as a surprise to anyone in the air transport business.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 21 -Salmagundi captured the $50,000-added San Vicente Handicap over nine rivals today to pop up as the big threat for the Santa Anita Derby.

THANKS to prevailing counsel on infant care ("Take your time" is its general tenor) many a baby is now spared the brisk regimens of feeding and "training" that once were in all the books. But baby is not altogether off the assembly line.

Only three of nine defending individual champions repeated last night at Madison Square Garden in the sixtieth annual National A.A.U. indoor track and field championships, which emphasized again the wealth of talent the United States has available for the 1948 Olympics.

BOURKE COCKRAN was one of the country's ablest lawyers, greatest orators, leading Democratic politicians and principal advocates of the Irish and Catholic causes from the Eighteen Seventies until his death in 1923. James McGurrin -- to whom Cockran is a great hero -- is well equipped by his knowledge of political, Irish and Catholic affairs to write this adulatory biography.

Members of the Ladies Auxiliary of the House of Calvary have arranged their annual linen shower and tea in behalf of the institution for the afternoon of March 13 in the auditorium of the House of Calvary, Featherbed Lane and Macombs Road, the Bronx.

State Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn told Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that members of the city's Democratic delegation at Albany advocated abandonment of his plan to seek legislative approval of a fare rise on the municipal transit lines this year.

SAN FRANCISCO newspaper woman and author of last season's success "Tell Your Sons" (a jumbo Napoleonic novel that was also a fairly convincing wedding of Freud and Sabatini) Miss Gibbs now returns to her own home grounds to pitch a nohitter against the American Communists.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- The All-India Congress party committee, comprising 650 leaders of the dominant Congress party, adopted a resolution today calling for the abolition of communalism.

VANCOUVER, Wash., Feb. 21 -- Intense rivalry has broken out in the Northwest between groups which demand new hydroelectric dams for industrial development and organizations which assert the region is far too civilized and settled already.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Gov. Kim Sigler of Michigan, who is campaigning for revision of his state's forty-year-old constitution, spent five hours in Newark today conferring on procedure with the men who played important roles in revising New Jersey's charter.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- France will work "tirelessly and stubbornly" for the building of a United Europe and will thus play her part in "the defense of our civilization," Premier Robert Schuman told the American Club of Paris at a Washington's Birthday dinner tonight.

CHIN LING started life under a handicap, being considered over-small, even by the Chinese, who dote on crickets as pets. But because he was so small Little Mushroom, who was very poor, could afford to buy him at bargain rates.
IF religious, moral or physiological scruples preclude your nibbling hasheesh, a brief survey indicates that the same effect can be obtained by a little serious attention to Hollywood's animal lore.

Ready-to-wear retail business, particuarly in medium and better-priced coats and suits and junior dresses, picked up last week as a result of fair weather in most parts of the country, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 21 -- Minister of Labor Delio Jaramillo Arbalaez announced today that he had rejected as "impertinent" a proposal of Lionel Weidey, manager of the Tropical Oil Company, for the handling of issues of the forty-day strike of 6,000 of the company's workers.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, national squash racquets champion since 1941, had to put on a terrific finishing drive to defeat Lawrence Blair of Pittsburgh, 16 -- 17, 15 -- 8, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 6, in a second-round mach today at the Harvard Club.

Mars is a little more than thirty million miles away at present -- the closest that it can ever be to the earth. Accordingly, University of Chicago astronomers have gone to McDonald Observatory, Fort Davis, Tex., to make still another examination of the Martian surface for signs of life.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- One of the latest jet fighters to go into production for the United States Navy is fitted with a British gas turbine -- the Rolls-Royce Nene, developing 5,000 pounds of static thrust or the equivalent, in a 600-mile-an-hour fighter, of some 12,000 horsepower as delivered through a propeller.

VIENNA, Feb. 21 -- The Hungarian Socialist party having been virtually absorbed by the Communists through the forced resignation of twenty of its more conservative leaders, the expulsion of five others and the arrest of one of its Cabinet Ministers, Istvan Barankovics' People's Democratic party is reliably reported here to be next on the list to be made to walk the plank.
Algo D. Henderson, Associate Commissioner for Higher and Professional Education, New York State Department of Education, urged last night "more equality and opportunity in higher education."

LONDON, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- Britain's soccer grounds took on the appearance of skating rinks today as zero temperatures accompanied by blinding snow swept across parts of the country. While players slithered on some grounds which were declared fit, nine league games in England and Scotland were postponed.

THE title of James Warner Bellah's informal memoir derives from the remark of an English gentleman's gentleman concerning his former master, a man who could decide between lunch and dinner to leave for Africa and be on his way by tea time.

Bruno Walter has received still another gift in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his association with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. This time it was a first edition of Beethoven's Seventh Symphony, presented by Mrs. Melvin E. Sawin, chairman of the Young People's Concerts Committee, with the explanation that her organization's anniversary coincided with the conductor's.

MEMBERS of the Photo League have become amateur plumbers, electricians, carpenters, masons and painters overnight to bring to realization the dream of years -- a photographic center. Recently they leased 2,600 feet of space in the basement of the Albert Hotel, on Tenth Street, but they were faced with the problem of building their quarters without funds to hire professional help.

A six-year undergraduate program leading to the engineering degree, which would enable evening students to supplement their formal studies with daytime positions, will be established at the Cooper Union School of Engineering on July 1.

ALTHOUGH he preferred to call himself a logician, Morris R. Cohen was primarily a critic and moralist. THERE is a conflict of premieres this week in the concurrent seasons of Martha Graham and her company at Maxine Elliott's Theatre and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center. On Tuesday evening Alexandra Danilova will give her first New York performance of "Giselle," and on the same occasion Frederic Franklin as Albrecht and Mary Ellen Moylan as Myrtha will also be making their respective bows hereabouts.

Richard Burgin led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a provocative and unusual program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. As its chief offerings it contained Hindemith's "Symphonia Serena," Ives' "Three Places in New England" and Tchaikovsky's Second Symphony. The Bach-Mangiagalli "Prelude" completed the list.

THE North Atlantic in midwinter is a place of darkness, violence and cold. It is the most important sea and air lane in the world just now, carrying the commerce Europe needs so vitally, the diplomats and economic experts concerned with that commerce, and less important people whose lives and hopes dictate a crossing one way or the other. Those who travel it at this season know discomfort, possibly danger.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Herb Lyon, sophomore from Tarrytown, N.Y., found the mark for 29 points tonight in leading the University of Pennsylvania basketball team to a 58-53 victory over Navy at the Palestra in the thirty-eighth game of their series.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 21 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority's extensive dam system averted flood damage of at least $6,000,000 to this industrial city last week when rivers swollen by rain and snow surged to near-record crests, according to figures released today by TVA officials.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 21 (AP) -- John Werket of Minneapolis led the field at the half-way mark in an international speed-skating competition today. Werket, a sergeant in the 101st Airborne Division during the war, was second in the 500-meter (547-yard) event and then finished sixth in the 5,000-meter (3 1/8-mile) race for 96.23 points.

If political freedom were all that Puerto Rico needed or wanted, the people of that lovely island would have been fully satisfied by the kindly words President Truman addressed to them on his arrival at San Juan yesterday. They already have the right, under a law Mr. Truman signed last August, to choose their own Governor by popular vote.

PETROLEUM is in many respects Strategic Mineral Number One in world affairs. Almost everywhere we look, as we try to utilize the earth's resources for the benefit of mankind, petroleum holds a central if not dominating position. Indispensable to our civilization, it is a compelling factor in relations between the major powers.

No doubt personal preferences, perhaps sentimental, will show up somewhere, but on the whole, roses chosen for this purpose should be vigorous and, most important, must do well in your particular locality.

The Citizens Union, now in its fifty-first year, will hold its annual meeting for the election of officers and city committee members next Thursday evening at the Willkie Memorial Building, 20 West Fortieth Street. The main feature of the meeting will be a "Town Meeting" discussion on the transit fare and city finances.

Dr. P.N. Swift of the County Hospital, Farnborough, England, tells in Lancet with what success he used aerosporin in treating ten children ranging in age from one month to two and one-half years for whooping cough.

A theatre party at the performance of "Iolanthe" by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company of London on the night of March 30 at the Century Theatre has been arranged by the Women's Committee of the Near East College Association to raise funds for American colleges in the Near East.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Washington's Birthday will be observed at a luncheon Monday of the Washington Association in the museum adjacent to Washington's Revolutionary War headquarters here, when Dr. Francis Ronalds, director of the Morristown National Park, will report gifts to the museum received during the year from the Washington Association.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 21 -- The Progressive Party of Michigan was formed today to support the Presidential aspirations of Henry A. Wallace. About 1,000 delegates from the seventeen Congressional Districts attended the meeting.

ENCOURAGED by the spectacular popularity of the first edition of the Information Please Almanac, John Kieran and his associates have brought out a new one for 1948. Mr. Kieran, avowing his own belief that the 1948 version is better than its predecessor, modestly attributes the improvement to hundreds of readers of the first work who became volunteer proofreaders and research experts.

The slow and moderate downward trend in retail meat prices continued yesterday with some chain and independent outlets announcing additional reductions in some cuts. Among these stores, the Grand Union Company announced reductions of 2 to 6 cents a pound in twelve meat and poultry items, effective tomorrow.
One of the busiest periods in the passenger shipping field will come to a close today with the arrival of the Italian liner Saturnia and the Gdynia America liner Sobieski.

Two new tools have been developed for reducing costs of production by analysis of industrial problems, Leonard A. Seder, quality control engineer of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, revealed to more than 200 members of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers on Friday night.

The man slept peacefully on a bench in the IRT subway station at 135th Street and Lenox Avenue early yesterday morning as another man stuck his hand in a pocket of the sleeper and two detectives of the pickpocket squad, who had been watching, arrested the pocket rifler and took him away.

The reports currently appearing in your paper about the deliberations of the IRO Council now just ended at Geneva cannot but fill with apprehension those of us who are concerned with the relief and rehabilitation of the war's most tragic victims, the refugees and DP's. Here are some of the reasons for this feeling:

Vice Admiral F.E.M. Whiting, retired, now president of the Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., declared yesterday that restrictive legislative devices such as discriminatory grain curtailment against one industry formed a new pattern for the drys in attempting to "strangle the liquor industry" and bring about a return of prohibition.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- The fourteen-nation working party of the United Nations Maritime Conference, meeting in a private session today, reached agreement on three important points of principle affecting the scope and purposes of the proposed International Maritime Organization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen challenged Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today to a series of radio debates on "The Vital Issues of American and Republican Policy."

Dr. Clarence (Buddy) Combs, the highest-ranked polo player indoors, led Manhattan to a 14-9 triumph over the Jockey Hollow Polo Club of Morristown, N.J., in the feature match of a twin bill at the Squadron A Armory last night.

CUBA is currently plagued with a gasoline shortage and tourists are being advised not to take their cars to the island at this time. So short have rations become that the Government has issued an order to "gas" stations to sell one gallon of "carburate nacional" for each three gallons of gasoline sold.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 21 -- The Government's anti-trust action against the leading motion picture concerns, which was taken under consideration by the Supreme Court this week, has capped Hollywood's winter of extreme discontent.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Art Commission of the City of New York, the body of distinguished art and lay members that approves the artistic worth of designs for public works, will be celebrated on Thursday at the Del-monico Hotel. Twenty-three professional and civic organizations, together with the Municipal Art Society, are tendering the dinner.

There was unusual excitement at the New York City Center yesterday afternoon several hours before the curtain went up. One hundred children roamed over the hall and finally took their seats in the first four orchestra rows. They attended the matinee as guests of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo.
Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh announced yesterday that he was investigating charges that Communist influences have affected policies of the city's Welfare Department.

PRAGUE, Feb. 21 -- President Eduard Benes issued a statement today on the governmental crisis in which he took a position regarded as barring the Communists from establishing a totalitarian regime in Czechoslovakia.

Still mystified by the sabotage which overtook them on the eve of competition at the St. Moritz Winter Olympic Games, but satisfied with one Olympic Games victory and two third places in the team events, the United States bobsled squad returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington, completing her first round trip as a passenger liner since the end of the war.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- After a slow start, grains rallied today on the Board of Trade. Wheat led the advance, which carried the bread cereal several cents a bushel above the preceding close.

Mrs. Blanche E. Rossett will give a tea and cocktail party on Wednesday at her home, 71 East Seventy-first Street, for members of the committee sponsoring the premiere showing of the motion picture, "The Naked City," to be held on the night of March 3 at the Capitol Theatre for the benefit of the New York Heart Association.

VIENNA, Feb. 21 -- The only floating dock owned by the Danube Steamship Company was transported down the Danube last night from Vienna into Hungarian waters. Soviet occupation authorities rejected an appeal by Chancellor Leopold Figl to cancel an order for its confiscation given by Col. Gen. Alexei Zheltov, Soviet deputy commissioner for Austria.

Despite high building costs, new construction work is providing one of the major counter-inflationary forces in many industries, industrial engineers revealed here yesterday. By placing leading companies in a position to compete on a basis of lower costs and larger production, a continuation of construction work in more than five important lines has been fully justified, they said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Joint Economic Committee of Congress, whose chairman is Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, voted today to call steel producers before it next Thursday to explain the recent increase of $5 a ton in the price of steel.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- The sole outstanding issue of major importance between the United States and European delegations to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment apparently has been settled subject to approval of certain European capitals, particularly London, it was learned today.

THE battle for the humanities in our scheme of education goes on. In a time as technologically conscious as ours, those who uphold the value of literary studies find themselves continually on the defensive. But they argue their cause with an intense conviction; while they believe it to have been always important, it seems to them more vital today than it has ever been.

Dr. Jose M. Hernandez of the Philippine Republic described yesterday an $88,519,000 electrification program for his country that he said would revolutionize its industry and spur American investment in the islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The value of the homemaker's dollar went up three or four cents this week in the average grocery store. That is, food prices went down that much. In virtually every other kind of store her dollar looked as ragged as ever.

Since the adoption of the surtax on personal holding companies some family corporations have unknowingly been placed in jeopardy of heavy penalty taxes not only for failure to distribute earnings but for failure to file returns. Moreover, the classification of a personal holding company may apply to one taxable year and not to another.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 22 -- Palestine ceased to be a member of the sterling currency area last midnight, the British Government announced today. The withdrawal was initiated by the British Government which took steps also to block sterling balances of about u100,000,000 (roughly $400,000,000) that Palestine holds.

TWO years after Argentine voters swept him into office on Feb. 24, 1946, President Juan Domingo Peron is back in the good graces of the United States and the hemisphere. Pending next month's important Congressional elections, he has full control of the situation on the Rio de la Ptata.

Arthur Krock, in his article "Again It Will Be 'The Smoke-Filled Room.'" writes that Speaker Joseph Martin will be handicapped in the Presidential race because he comes from "a small northeastern state."

THE Government of France has long been this country's biggest name in show business. Perhaps it would be better to say the "governments," using the plural, because the French National Theatre has remained a vital, functioning part of French cultural life for more than 250 years, surviving a series of major wars and numerous revolutions.

Any hope that the general price spiral was about to reverse its post-war trend was dashed, seemingly, last week as the nation's steel companies, whose products affect the price graphs of at least 40 per cent of American industry, posted sharply higher quotations for pivotal raw materials.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Army's basketball team bounded back into the winning column today by overwhelming Lehigh with a near-record cadet score of 88 to 28.

TERRY and Bunky, two boys known to many young readers through books on football and baseball, have now become interested in basketball. Chuck Chandler, star of the university basketball team, shows the youngsters the fine points of the game, and even takes them to see his team practice.

NEARLY every singer of consequence in the past half century or more has sung in America, but none has ever caught the imagination of our people as did Enrico Caruso. Though the great Italian tenor has been dead for almost twenty-seven years, his fame has not waned but has grown to legendary proportions.

THE bride told her mother she must have an electric mixer. After long search the mother found one and bought it for her. Some weeks later she noticed the mixer stowed away on a high shelf in the cupboard in her daughter's kitchen.

UNDAUNTED by the presence of both Martha Graham and the Ballet Russe in extended seasons, the concert and recital world is carrying on in force. Everything from free lectures at the Public Library (which, incidentally, have been turning away two or three hundred people each week) and the Museum of Natural History, to dance programs in almost any style you choose can be had for the seeking.

A BEDRAGGLED little mustang, drooping at the end of a horse-trader's string, cocks his head and winks at young Jim Meadows, and Jim knows that Ticktock is his horse, even though it means parting with his cherished possession, his grandfather's watch.

A GOOD deal of interest was shown in the British press recently as to why I was entering the film industry as the financial backer of my friend, Filippo del Giudice of Pilgrim Pictures, Ltd. Interest was possibly the greater because, as an industrialist in the Midlands engaged in a very different business, my arrival was highly unexpected and obeyed none of the rules.***

IN Jules Verne's day it took grown-up scientists quite a while to get to the moon, but the rocket driven by atomic power in this story is the work of three teen-age boys and their uncle, who get some "fissionable material" and in a few days are far out in space.

The road to the presidency of the world's largest corporate enterprise, the $8,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was traversed with intentional deviations by Leroy August Wilson, who was elected to that office on Wednesday, three days before his forty-seventh birthday.
LEXINGTON, Va., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dr. Harold C. Urey said today the United Nations was "one of the most inadequate organizations for the enormous problems before it that could possibly be devised."

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands -- President Truman's name has been added to the fast-growing list of vacationists who are discovering the American-owned Virgin Islands to be a beautiful and unspoiled frontier with an excellent resort climate.

Once again the problem of how to dislodge hoards of United States currency has been brought to the fore through the introduction of a bill in Congress by Representative Frank L. Sundstrom of New Jersey calling for the replacement of our present currency in circulation with a new series of equal exchange.

ARNOLD STANG, at 24, is probably the most harassed, most frustrated and most often stepped-on individual on the radio. A slightly built young man, barely topping 100 pounds in weight, he found that serving as a verbal doormat to some of the air waves' top comics can have its advantages.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the design of the 3-cent stamp (color to be announced) which will be issued on April 7 to mark the sesquicentennial of the establishing of Mississippi Territory.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 -- Frustrated by the meagerness of the import-export trade and general economic activity in Shanghai, American business men here are turning their attention to the possibilities of new fields of enterprise in Formosa. This parallels a similar shift of interest to South China.

PERIODICALLY some correspondent will ask the writer of this column for his "favorite bridge hand." It may happen two or three times in a single year or, in a lean year, only once. Last week was the week for it and, as always, the following hand went out:

TWO places in the garden that are likely to be planted with the same blooms year after year are flower beds and edges. Too many gardeners seem to feel that once they have found an attractive plant for each of these purposes, they must stick to it through thick and thin.
MONTREAL, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins just about wrote finis to the Canadiens' chances for a National Hockey League playoff position tonight by defeating the Montreal six, 3 -- 1.

It costs an average of $234 a year to educate each public school pupil in New York State. Of this the state pays 34 per cent, but state aid is not apportioned on a simple per pupil basis. Under a complicated formula an attempt is made to equalize educational facilities between wealthy and poor districts.

ON the voyage from Scotland to America an old Irish woman told the three McTavish children: "Ye'll rub elbows with fear and regret, but hopes and happiness will lighten yet step." And during the year in Oregon when the family was deciding if they liked America well enough to stay the prophecy all came true.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The Republic of Indonesia charged in the United Nations Security Council today that the Netherlands was trying to sidestep fair plebiscites in the Netherlands Indies by moving quickly to set up new puppet states.

A NEW amateur black-and-white safety reversal film, Dassonville double-8mm and 16mm, is announced by Dassonville Company, Ltd. Three types are offered: orthochromatic, very fine grain, Weston 12; fine-grain panchromatic, Weston 40, and medium fine-grain panchromatic, Weston 80.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The third-party candidacy of Henry Wallace was strongly opposed and the Marshall Plan whole-heartedly endorsed today by speakers at the first annual convention of the Americans for Democratic Action.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii, within the limited scope of its tourist accommodations, today is enjoying a mild tourist "boom." The big beach hotels at Waikiki are doing a capacity business and the smaller hotels in Honolulu and on the other islands are handling heavy bookings.

Herbert Matthews, in his enlightening article, "Volcanic Forces Rumble in India," refers to the Malthusian theory in mentioning that India's population grows at the staggering rate of 5,000,000 a year. But Malthus specified that populations increase by geometrical progression.
BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- The battered city of Frankfort on the Main has become the capital of Western Germany and, like Berlin, is rapidly assuming a completely international aspect.

Communist capture of Anshan, in Manchuria, is an urgent warning that the collapse of China will not wait on further debate. Immediate aid must be forthcoming or our own position in the Far East will collapse too. The Red armies aim at nothing less than the complete destruction of the tottering Nationalist regime in Nanking and prompt dissection of the corpse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The weather man will move on to television screens in three Eastern cities next Tuesday. The Federal Government announced tonight it had assigned J.C. Fridler, former radio announcer, to represent weather information on a ten-minute evening show over the Dumont Television Network.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- City College of New York continued its stretch drive for an invitation to a post-season basketball tournament with a 71 -- 59 victory over St. Joseph's in the feature game of a Convention Hall double-header before 5,789 tonight.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 19 (Delayed) -- Secretary of State Marshall's announcement that a decision had been "approximately reached" on United States policy toward enforcement of the partition of Palestine has aroused both hope and apprehension among Arab political quarters.

American Brotherhood Week is a reminder that organized labor and organized religion "have not risen as vigorously to the defense of civil rights as the people have reason to expect," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said yesterday in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 21 -- Utilizing a new atom-smashing linear accelerator, constructed under the direction of Howard L. Schultz, Assistant Professor of Physics, Yale University physicists have attained energies of 1,000,000 volts, and eventually expect to unlock new secrets of the atom, it was disclosed here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- While there are no indications of the beginning of a feminist movement in the Central States this Presidential year, there is ample evidence of women's lively interest in polities and of efforts by their clubs to induce more women to seek public office.

The remaining art objects from the once-famous collection of the late Henry Goldman, banker and co-founder of Goldman, Sachs Co., will be auctioned on Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Under distinguished patronage a gala concert will be given the night of March 12 at Hunter College Assembly Hall, Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, for the benefit of the Teatro Comunale of Florence, Italy, which was a casualty of the recent war.

OTTAWA, Feb. 21 -- Canada's import restriction program has been making slow progress through Parliament this week while in another room the committee investigating the rise in price levels has done little better.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Hitting its stride in the final period, the Princeton hockey team swept from behind to drub Yale 6 to 3, tonight before a capacity crowd of 2,600 in Baker Rink.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- With Albany's two largest hotels, the Ten Eyck and the De Witt Clinton, picketed by representatives of 460 striking employes, about 150 members of the Legislature will face a difficult situation when they return for the Monday night session.
BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- After two and one-half years of study United States and British officials have agreed on a basic plan to break up the huge combines of the Ruhr coal mining industry.

NANKING, Feb. 22 -- United States military sources, commenting on the bargain sale of 10,000 tons of surplus American ammunition to China, said today that Nanking had the right to buy any amount of surplus materiel.

CONSIDERING its subject-matter, this book should be as dated as last week's crullers. It concerns the veteran, just after he came home, and whale he was still being reconverted in the public press. Mr. Martin, in fact, wrote most of the pieces in this volume for The New Republic, on a sort of free-wheeling junket through the country to see just how the ex-GI was making out.

THE prospect that the film industry's annual feast of self-applause, the Academy awards, may become a source of serious embarrassment to Hollywood's top-policy makers loomed last week with the nomination of Edward Dmytryk as one of five candidates for the best director award.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 21 -The Southeastern Conference today formally approved the "purity code" of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and named Coach Bernie Moore of Louisiana State as commissioner.

Activity in all sections of retail department stores last week held up well, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Dress, drapery and upholstery departments were experiencing good business, yard goods was busy and millinery departments were crowded, the report stated.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 -- Palestine's exclusion from the sterling bloc, announced here tonight a few hours in advance of the scheduled announcement in London, caused widespread worry that the currency might lose some of its value.

A seven-month search by the Post Office Department for Basil Hanioti, 48 years old, Panamanian shipping executive, ended Friday when he surrendered voluntarily to the United States Attorney here on a warrant charging mail fraud, it was made known yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were from 6 points higher to 13 points net lower than on Friday.

FOR both artistic and economic reasons the prominent playwrights of the theatre traditionally have looked with disdain on the world of radio. The number who have catered to the needs of the microphone, in fact, have been practically infinitesimal, the writing honors on the air too often having gone by default to a selected coterie of masters of tricky pretension.

A far-reaching program of higher education for New York State, to include the establishment of two medical and dental schools as well as junior and senior colleges, is recommended by the special commission appointed two years ago to study the educational needs of this state.

ALMOST anything can happen at a national political convention and sometimes does. Because it is almost certain that the Democrats will nominate President Truman, the chief speculation about the forthcoming party convention is what will happen at the Republican gathering; the bewildered GOP elephant, who never forgets, doesn't want to do anything he wouldn't like to remember.

Applications for export licenses on all commercial shipments to Europe, effective March 1, are now beginning to reach the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce in sharply rising volume, it was learned last week.

IF father doesn't come home nights, if Junior seems headed for the reformatory and little Susie shows every sign of becoming a problem child, maybe the house is at least partly at fault. Room arrangements, furniture arrangement, closets and equipment can make or break a family, we are told.

THE history of American railroads is the story of making big ones out of little ones. The Nickel Plate in its present form, for instance, is the result of its absorption of the Clover Leaf, and the Lake Erie Western, both earlier consolidations of smaller roads.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 21 -- President Truman told the people of Puerto Rico, who accorded him a hearty, boisterous welcome here today, that they should have the right to determine their own political destiny.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- The need for administrators on the lower level of Government and business with a general liberal arts background rather than with training as specialists was emphasized here today by Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Two highly important Dodgers and one equally important Yankee were added to the respective pitching staffs of the two world series opponents of 1947 yesterday.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 21 -- The Robert McDowell Fund, to aid 18-year-old Robert McDowell of near-by Medford to complete his education, was started today by business men of this village. The purpost is to reward him for saving three boys from drowning in Patchogue River.

HOW are symphony orchestras launched, kept going and built up in smaller communities? Recent reports from five of them suggest that though the pattern changes, certain elements are fairly common. One thing shines out: enthusiasm is essential.

Twenty-three artists and art patrons were cited last night by the American Artists Professional League for outstanding achievement in the profession or for distinguished services to art in America. The League held its annual dinner at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue.
Play in the Eastern indoor tennis championships started late yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Indoor Tennis Club in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 142d Street.

In other columns of this newspaper today Dr. Howard Rusk, who is a member of the National Consultants Committee to the Administrator of Veterans Affairs, discusses the crisis that daily grows more acute in VA hospitals resulting from the hospitalization of veterans with non-service-connected disabilities.

Enough gasoline and oil to meet the nation's total demand for 1,500 years can be manufactured from only a quarter of our known coal reserves, Dr. Homer Z. Martin of the Standard Oil Development Company's laboratories recently told the New York section of the American Chemical Society.

Thirty-two Air Force soldiers, selected for high physical and mental capacity from a group of volunteers, have been flown from the semi-tropical climate of McDill Field, Fla., to a sub-Arctic cold area of the Far North in the most extensive test of acclimatization yet undertaken.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A proposal to establish, within the framework of the European Recovery Program, a "Peace Production Board" to facilitate private loans to speed Europe's economic recovery was advanced tonight by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

Periodically twenty-five of the nation's top medical specialists meet in Washington as the National Consultants' Committee to the Administrator of Veterans Affairs to determine policy and discuss problems of veterans' medical care. At their meeting in October and again in January two of the principal items on the agenda were the need for more personnel and the feasibility of placing a fixed ceiling on the number of hospital beds that the VA will operate.
Fordham easily captured its fifteenth basketball victory last night, defeating Hofstra, 50 -- 37, before 2,800 at the Rose Hill gymnasium.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, banged the rostrum in the Luxembourg Palace, where he was delivering Russia's views on the Italian peace treaty, and sent the glass of water on the lectern tumbling over the heads of the interpreters below him.

In the U.S. budget for the fiscal year 1949, the second largest item (national defense is first) is labeled "International Affairs and Finance." Under this heading, the President estimates, the U.S. will spend $7 billion between July 1, 1948, and June 30, 1949.

"A WARRANT of deportation against Hanns Eisler, the German-born Hollywood composer, was issued yesterday permitting him to go to any country for which he can get a visa * * *" (News item, Feb. 13, 1948.)

TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- Hitoshi Ashida, head of the Democratic party, a professional diplomat and politician, tonight was named by the Diet's lower house as the next Premier of Japan. He will now attempt to form a new coalition Cabinet and try to continue the execution of the left-of-center policies initiated last year by Socialist Tetsu Katayama who resigned the Premiership twelve days ago.

With both teams cracking a 44-year-old Eastern Intercollegiate League record for high scoring, Columbia last night recorded its sixth triumph in seven starts by downing Harvard, 71 -- 59, and taking undisputed possession of first place in the loop.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called on the Administration today to support the establishment of "a moderate force" by the United Nations in Palestine.

TO Westerners accustomed to individualistic expression in art, the political discipline of artists in Soviet Russia seems perplexing. Since the summer of 1946 the Communist party, now tightly organized to promote the current Five-Year Plan, has been issuing scornful broadsides at Soviet writers, composers and artists in general.

The stock market ended the week yesterday on a firmer tone after a dip to within reach of the lows of the year. During the Saturday short session prices drifted narrowly, and they closed moderately firmer with selected gold and shipping issues strongest. Price changes generally were fractional. The composite rate was raised 0.24 point.

Mayor O'Dwyer, who entered Bellevue Hospital on Friday for a week of rest and medical observation, was reported yesterday to be "well rested and really beginning to feel like himself again." The encouraging report was made by Hospital Commissioner Edward M. Bernecker, who said that the Mayor had a good night's sleep Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The usual atmosphere of crisis accompanying last-minute efforts to pass a bill before a deadline was missing in Congress this week, even though only a week remained for the present rent-control law. The reason was plain: There was no doubt in anyone's mind that the restraints governing rents would not be allowed to lapse at the end of this month.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 21 -- President Truman, it was learned this evening, will send a special message to Congress on Monday in which he will request action on a short-term housing program, as well as a long-term one.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 21 -- The real issue in the Palestine problem is no longer partition. The crucial question before the Security Council next week will not be a complicated controversy between Jews and Arabs. What is at stake is simply whether the United Nations is to become a reality.

FOR THIS WEEK: Examine material in the coldframes as soon as snow has thawed sufficiently. Some of the plants may be dry; all of them need ventilation, however brief, during sunny middays. . . . Don't start seeds too early in the house. February is good timing for vinca, lobelia and stock but too early for tomatoes, snapdragon and most of the annual flowers. . . .

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The United States and Britain frustrated persistent Russian attempts to win approval "in principle" of the Soviet Union's proposals for a settlement of the German assets issue in Austria during today's meeting of the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

ROME, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Sir John Boyd Orr, Director General of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, said tonight that "Europe's food position will be very grim between now and next August."
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP) -Bob Hamilton of Reynold, Ky., sank an 8-foot putt on the eighteenth green today to win $2,000 first-prize money in the $10,000 New Orleans open by a single stroke.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 22 -Higher education here is to put more and more emphasis on the practical to prepare youth for its proper place in the life of the new, dynamic Argentina. This is the underlying theme that emerges from every public utterance made by the new Secretary of Education, Dr. Oscar Ivanissevich, since he assumed the Cabinet post last Thursday.

The Juilliard Orchestra, under Edgar Schenkman, gave the first of a series of three concerts for the benefit of the Student Aid Fund of the Juilliard School of Music last night at Carnegie Hall. The program featured the first New York performance of David Diamond's Fourth Symphony and also included Stravinsky's "Symphony in Three Movements" and the Seventh Symphony of Beethoven.
