Wallace, was voted today by 150 delegates to a six-state conference of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO.

A father and son grappled on the southbound local platform of the BMT subway station at Fortyninth Street and Seventh Avenue at 9:30 o'clock last night, then they fell to the tracks as a train bore down. The motorman reversed his power, but both men were run over and fatally injured.

The American Merchant Marine Institute said here yesterday that the sale of eighty-seven American merchant ships to Russia as advocated by the State Department would increase the Soviet Union's tonnage almost 50 per cent and give the country the fourth rankingh)0*0*0*imerchant fleet of the world.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs kept pace with Detroit, by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 3 to 2, before 16,649 fans. It was the Leafs' eighth victory, along with one tie, in ten games against the Hawks this season.
Henry A. Wallace, third party candidate for President, issued a statement yesterday opposing President Truman's request for an additional $570,000,000 for aid to China.

Legislators who object to "deadlines" in their consideration of the European Recovery Program might consider a dispatch from Rome, published yesterday and dealing with food prospects on the Continent. Experts from seventeen nations spent five days discussing this matter, under the auspices of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Southern Governors here to read the riot act to the Democratic National Committee on the civil rights message President Truman sent to Congress Feb. 2, held a five-hour council-of-war today, then called in Southern members of Congress for further long discussions.

New York art audiences will have a further opportunity to review the achievement of French nineteenth century painting this week when the Wildenstein Gallery on Wednesday holds a preview of its Eduard Manet loan exhibition. Coming a week after the Rosenberg Gallery's presentation of work by Delacroix and Renoir, this exhibition has been arranged for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

Nobody ever worked harder in office than Mayor O'Dwyer. Nobody not trained to the tough routine of a working cop could have stood it. Now he is in the hospital hoping through rest to escape the penalty of his labors. Every voter in Bagdad-on-the-Hudson wishes him a quick recovery.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Two top-ranking labor leaders -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO -- today denounced the third-party candidacy of Henry Wallace.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- In recent stock market developments here the rapidly falling note circulation of the Bank of England has been advanced, for the first time since contraction commenced many months ago, as an additional reason for hesitation and perhaps mild anxiety of investors and speculators.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- With this city's two principal hotels, where they normally stay, still strike-bound, many legislators today were looking for quarters in near-by Troy and Schenectady, or trying to find accommodation in smaller hotels here. There are twenty-four smaller hostelries in the city, most of them second or third rate houses.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 -- The steel industry was unable last week to raise its operating rate beyond 93 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the week before. Lack of pig iron and scrap metal was said to be the major reason why additional capacity cannot be brought into operation.

With retail stocks ample for Easter and spring needs, merchants last week were holding down purchases with the result that the wholesale market experienced one of its slowest periods in many months, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident-buying offices.

Ruth Kisch-Arndt's recitals have generally been off the beaten track, with assisting artists and an emphasis on early music. But last night at Town Hall the contralto gave a program that followed conventional lines, and Ernst Victor Wolff, the accompanist, was the only other participant.

Declaring that past efforts to promote a real American merchant marine had utterly failed, Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway, called last week for a fresh approach to his goal.

A sunny, late-winter day when the temperature holds in the twenties is a good time to study pennants. If the snow s deep and skyh)0*0*0*cloudless there is beauty on the countryside as one looks across fields and meadows to distant dark-green hills. The soft purples, steel blues, deep reds and topaz shades remind one of the colors in the windblown sand dunes above the ocean's

Mounting home discord, money worries, disturbing child behavior and "a frantic fear of relief status" are common factors found among families who apply for and cannot get day care services for young children. This new light on the city's day care problem was made known yesterday by the Brooklyn Jewish Child Care Council, 44 Court Street.
A. Hammell has been appointed sales manager of Vanguard Fabrics, Inc., which has moved its sales offices to 246 Fifth Avenue.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Tony Callipare of Rochester, N.Y., sped over the ice of Mirror Lake today to win the men's senior title of the Lake Placid invitation speed skating meet with victories in four of six events.

PRAGUE, Feb. 22 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist labor leadership disclosed today far-reaching economic demands and announced that a general strike would be called if they were not met. It also ordered a one-hour demonstrative general strike of all workers for Tuesday as a test of the strength of organized labor.

ROME, Feb. 22 Speaking to 1,500 street-car motormen and conductors, Pope Pius today put in clear-cut terms what he believes the issue will be in the April national elections: Catholicism against Communist atheism.

The Rev. George B. Ford of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church and the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Atkinson, a Protestant clergyman and chairman of the Church Peace Union, were the recipients yesterday of Brotherhood Day awards presented annually by the Men' Club of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West Eighty ninth Street.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 -- A thirty-six-hour suspension by the United States Embassy here of the issuance of visas to Mexicans because it was felt that the 1925 reciprocal passport agreement was being violated by Mexico has resulted in hasty activity by the Foreign Office here to aid Mexican business men whose departure for the United States was being held up.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 22 -More than 6,000 wildly enthusiastic Bavarians today signified their delight and approval as Dr. Josef Baumgartner, former Minister of Food and Agriculture in Bavaria, assailed three of the four occupation powers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- Port authorities and transportation leaders of the West Coast have organized with a view to obtaining "a fair and reasonable share" of Pacific shipping, on the ground that Atlantic and Gulf ports have been getting more and more tonnage which rightfully belongs to this coast.

Worry is atheism, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday in the second of a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Martha Graham and her dance company at Maxine Elliott's Theatre played three performances over the week-end to packed houses, with standees on each occasion. Saturday evening's program was the only one which boasted a novelty, and that was the season's premiere of "Errand into theh)0*0*0*iMaze."

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- The thirty-fifth and biggest all-breed show of the Eastern Dog Club began its two-day run in Mechanics Building today with breed judging bringing most of the 1,367 dogs before the arbiters afternoon and evening. The total was an even two dozen over last year's record, and the great crowd that swirled through the building was bigger too, despite snow-cluttered roads and streets.
GENEVA, Feb. 22 -- Drafts prepared by the United States provided the basis for agreement today on two controversial sections of the proposed United Nations Maritime Organization charter.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 22 -- Announcement of the calling up or requisitioning of Dutch-owned American securities means that the last Dutch dollar resources are being drawn on. The step is regretted greatly in Dutch financial circles because dollar resources were one of Holland's most valuable assets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark spoke for President Truman today at the opening here of a private campaign to raise $250,000,000 for Jewish relief.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- French economic and financial circles are observing with interest the effects of the recent reopening of the FrancoSpanish frontier. They expect it will pave the way for renewal of trade relations between the two countries and look forward to important consequences in the European economic field.

FOLLOWING Pearl Harbor, our informal relations with General Charles de Gaulle were embittered by his unwarranted action in ordering the forcible occupation of the French islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, off the Newfoundland coast, by Free French forces.

To clear many types of Government surplus goods in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area, six new spot sales and three special sales by negotiation of Navy propulsion reduction gears, various lots of pneumatic drills and cable cutters were announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -The American Council on Education said today that "nearly three educators in four oppose universal military training."

CHATANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 22 -- The threat of a Southern revolt against the Democratic party in the national election this year because of resentment against President Truman's civil-rights program is steadily becoming the most discussed subject in this region.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 22 -- The Dutch airline KLM, supported by The Netherlands Government, is determined to press for an agreement with the United States providing for a "fifth freedom," the right to land and pick up passengers on American territory, despite the opposition of the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was revealed here today.

New York City contains the largest concentration of small business in the country, and possibly in the world, according to a tabulation compiled by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., and released over the week-end by Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary.

The church has only itself to blame if many in the secular world as well as many in the church itself regard it as a "pressure group," it was charged yesterday by Canon Cyril E. Hudson of St. Albans Cathedral, England. He delivered the sermon at the morning service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Pressures and demands for overseas relief and resettlement of Jewish peoples are infringing on the allocations for Jewish education and community work in this country, it was charged yesterday by Michael A. Stavitsky, president of the American Association for Jewish Education.

ATHENS, Feb. 22 -- About 200 heavily armed, Communist-led guerrillas entered the town of Gythion in the southern Peloponnesus yesterday, according to official reports. The rebels overcame a small force of gendarmes, killing three of them and then attacked the prison where last spring an illegal band of Nationalists had slain about thirty Left-Wing prisoners.

The public has been confused lately by the emergence of what appears to be a controversy between the Red Cross and the New York County Medical Society over blood banks. An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Feb. 15, by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, gave a partial resume of the background of the trouble and concluded that a definite divergence of opinion would be "tragic."

Americans have underestimated the potential economic and political value to this country of many of Europe's displaced persons, Walter H. Lillard, chief of the resettlement division of the International Refugee Organization in Austria, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 22 (AP) -The Senate War Investigating Committee said today the laws should be changed to prevent unfair profits on any future war contracts.

John B. (Jack) Kelly Jr., more than likely next summer to match his father's 1920 triumph in the Olympic single sculls, yesterday was formally initiated into the most exclusive fraternity in American amateur sports.

The Mutual Broadcasting System's original intention of employing the dramatic form for a documentary series on the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights will be abandoned in favor of straight readings, in the interests of "fairness" to the report, it became known yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Lee M. Friedman of Boston, a lawyer and author of five volumes of Jewish history, was elected today president of the American Jewish Historical Society at its annual meeting in Dropsie College. He succeeds Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, noted Philadelphia Bibliophile, who retired from the presidency after twenty-seven years and was named honorary president.

NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 22 (AP) -President George Cross and Football Coach Charles (Bud) Wilkinson of the University of Oklahoma today issued a statement in which they said the university considers John Rapacz a professional football player and will make no effort to have him reinstated

DUESSELDORF, Feb. 22 -- This is the capital of the most important state in Germany. North Rhine-Westphalia includes not only the Ruhr valley but the interlocking complex of heavy industry which made this region the workshop of Europe. It should be the workshop for Europe now.

The first primary fight against the carefully screened slate of Dewey-pledged delegates in New York County came to light yesterday. It was learned that Lester Baum, leader of the Fifth Assembly District North, had placed in circulation petitions designating himself as a candidate for delegate, against Melvin C. Osterman, leader of the Fifth Assembly District South, who is on the Dewey slate.

BEMUS POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Lucius H. Bugbee, 73 years old, former editor of church school publications of the Methodist Church, and executive secretary of the church's editorial division, board of education, was fatally injured today when struck by a truck.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 22 -- Two years after his election, President Juan D. Peron, in a statement to this correspondent, declared that his administration had realized all its objectives to date.
TSINGTAO, China, Monday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Chinese air force cancelled flights into Mukden today as the plight of that Manchurian city became desperate.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Britain's business community was informed today that orders "freezing" prices of nonessential goods at levels prevailing in the two-month period ended Jan. 31 would be issued by the Board of Trade next week. Harold Wilson, president of the Board, said at Oxford today that the orders, which are part of the Government program to stabilize wages, prices and profits, have been completed.

The United Jewish Appeal, which begins today its annual campaign, is the combined fund-raising organization for three major American agencies. One of these is the Joint Distribution Committee, which this year requires $98,547,000 for its far-flung program of relief, rehabilitation and reconstruction for more than a million Jewish survivors in Europe.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 -- The electorate of this state will choose a new Governor Tuesday in a runoff primary in which Earl K. Long, brother of the late Huey P. (Kingfish) Long, is an odds-on favorite to win on the basis of his wide margin of victory in the general primary a month ago.

OXFORD, England, Feb. 22 -- An era of increased cooperation between the United States and Britain to achieve permanent stability in western Europe was forecast here today by Sir Oliver Shewell Franks, British Ambassadordesignate to Washington.

VIENNA, Feb. 22---Diplomatic representatives of the United States and Great Britain tonightwalked out of a celebration of thethirtieth anniversary of the SovietArmy when Col. Gen. L. V. Kurasoy, Russian High Commissionerin Austria, accused the "imperialistic" powers of having helpedGermany launch the second WorldWar and of preparing a new cOnflict against the Soviet Union.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -Assault, winner of triple crown honors and the "horse of the year" title in 1946, has run his last race. He's to be retired to the stud.

ABOARD THE S.S. SANTA CLARA, at Sea, Feb. 22 (UP) -- A seaman who fell overboard and swam about for nearly three hours, before his nearmiraculous rescue, kept hope alive in his heart because a seabird hovered over his bobbing head like a "good spirit," he said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Prices of corn at the top last week on the Board of Trade, showed a recovery of 20 1/2 cents a bushel from the low of the previous week, reflecting short covering, a revival in the shipping demand and very limited hedging pressure, in strong contrast with the condition that prevailed the preceding week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Notable tightening of mortgage credits throughout the country threatens to disrupt the whole home building program, which on the threshold of its era of greatest expansion, leaders in the industry admitted here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The shape of aeronautical things to come, with electronics all but replacing human handling of air traffic, was outlined today in proposals prepared for President Truman's Air Coordinating Committee.
The wind, the snow and the resultant slush did not stop the Chin Association from staging its annual picturesque celebration in Chinatown all through the day and late into the evening, yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Grabbing the first score and matching goal for goal the rest of the way, the Detroit Red Wings beat the Montreal Canadiens 4 -- 3 here tonight. The Detroit six remains tied for the National Hockey League lead with the Maple Leafs as Toronto matched the Red Wing triumph with a victory tonight over the Black Hawks at Chicago.

Winter played a return engagement along the Eastern Seaboard yesterday with a snowstorm that spread from six to ten inches over the Middle Atlantic and New England States. In New York the storm stopped at noon after six inches had fallen Another storm center headed this way from the South swung out to sea before reaching here, ending a threat of continued snowfall.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 22 -- Millions of children will be deprived of an adequate schooling during the next decade because of an acute shortage of elementary teachers, educators attending the opening session of the American Association of School Administratorsh) 0*0*0*iwarned today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The country's top labor leaders joined today in endorsing the drive of the American Red Cross for $75,000,000 which begins on March 1.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman renewed his plea yesterday for quick and united support of the European Recovery Program.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Legislature is slated to start clearing its decks this week for final adjournment by taking up and passing Governor Dewey's $79,100,000 budget in both branches despite Democratic opposition, based on the contention that it fails to provide enough state aid for schools and local governments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Demands upon the services of the National Labor Relations Board and the General Counsel jumped 45 per cent in January, although many unions were still not qualified to request their help.

The bill pending in Albany to place hotel rentals under state control was opposed yesterday by the Hotel Association of New York City. James A. McCarthy, association executive secretary, defended the City Rent Commission against tenant complaints that it was too generous in granting rent increases to hotel operators.

h)0*0*0*iUnionized employes of the New York Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges have completed preparations for a strike that may be called at any time after midnight next Monday, M. David Keefe, president of the United Financial Employes, Local 205, AFL, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named Judy Garland, Mickey Rooney, Janet Leigh, Betty Garrett and Vera Ellen to play the leading roles in "Words and Music," a photoplay based on the songwriting career of Richard Rodgers and the late Lorenz Hart, which Norman Taurog will direct starting early next month.
A plan for rehabilitating displaced persons outside Europe on a business basis rather than as charity was announced here yesterday by Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, chairman of Common Cause, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Exploratory, informal talks on the future of Western Germany will begin here tomorrow among the United States, Great Britain and France. Within a day or two, the Benelux countries -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- will be invited to join the discussions on all subjects that interest them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - The National Federation of Small Business protested to the Department of Commerce today the "deplorable situation" in permitting steel shipments to foreign countries while small business in the United States -- even those owned and operated by veterans -- are severely handicapped by inability to obtain steel.

A new individual modernization service to help their retail stores remodel rug and carpet departments along "lines of tested sales effectiveness" was announced over the week-end by Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company and C.S. Masland Sons.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- Somehow one had received the impression that Berlin was an armed camp, the United States, British, French and Russian armies mixing more than slight suspicion and mistrust. If such is the case, it is not discernable to this correspondent's eye.

A letter appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 14 concerning the situation in the Old City of Jerusalem. As the statements contained in this letter appear to be based upon wrong information, it appears desirable to put on record the true facts of the case.

A recent security survey of a Brooklyn warehouse presented an excellent example of operation with "negligible" losses from theft and pilferage, E. E. Conroy, executive vice president of the Security Bureau, Inc., declared yesterday. He said the storage center was one of the city's largest, with facilities for truck, rail and waterborne shipments.

HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- What does the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment mean to the United States and its ordinary citizens? How will its success or failure benefit or injure the United States? Why does the United States delegation consider it so important to resist weakening amendments and to bring home a world trade charter strong enough to hold the support of leading business, labor and farm organizations for ratification in Congress?

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The chief United States prosecutor of war crimes in Germany aimed an unprecedented blast today at the American judge who presided over the trial of German generals that ended Thursday.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The "victorious Soviet Army," equipped with "first-class arms," is the "royal guardian of the Soviet Union and of durable peace and is always in constant readiness for battle" to preserve the principles of communism, the official Russian Army newspaper Taegliche Rundschau said here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Chicago Tribune, in a copyrighted story from Nuremberg tonight quotes Judge Wennerstrum as saying that "the victor in any war is not the best judge of the war crime guilt."

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- A period of what is best described as an anxious calm in the stock markets here has followed the highly disturbed conditions created by publication of the Government's statement on its wages policy and the spate of speeches and newspaper publicity that accompanied it.

The twelfth annual communion breakfast for Consolidated Edison System Men was held yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. Sponsored by the Edison Anchor Club, Branch 20, it was attended by 1,000 guests. Franklin G. Edwards was toastmaster.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Business circles here are puzzled by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's statement that Japan will see a "blood bath" unless the economic pyramid is flattened even more.

Importance of safety from an engineering as well as a humanitarian standpoint was emphasized during the successful meeting of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences. Jerome Lederer, who has served on the Safetyh)0*0*0*iBoard of the CAB and is an acknowledged expert in the field, stressed the importance of applying sensible yardsticks to studies of safety in flight.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, Feb. 22 -Welcomed warmly here today as a champion of human rights, President Truman promised the Virgin Islanders to seek wider self-rule for them and to work for freedom from fear and want on a global scale through the United Nations.

The victory on Tuesday of Leo Isacson, American Labor Party candidate backed by Henry A. Wallace for Representative in the Twenty-fourth New York Congressional District, has given additionalh)0*0*0*iimpetus to the third-party candidacy of Mr. Wallace for President, according to reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in key states.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Advertising expenditures of the Radio Division of Stewart-Warner Corporation, based on present production schedules, will be slightly in excess of $1,000,000 in 1948, including cooperative expenditures of distributors and dealers, Fred Cross, StewartWarner advertising director, has announced.

As everyone should know by now, New Year's Day is the birthday for all horses and they all automatically become one year older on that date. Somehow or other, though, there's only one age bracket where this anniversary seems to be of transcendent importance. That's when the juveniles advance to the 3-year-old stage and become eligible for the Kentucky Derby, Preakness, Belmont and the other big stakes which proclaim that they've finally come of age.

The spectre of devaluation of the pound sterling was uppermost in the minds of bankers and dealers in foreign exchange last week, and notwithstanding official disclaimers of any intention of adopting this course -- for the present at least -- it did have an unfavorable effect upon the pound, particularly in forward contracts.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Playing steady and at times sensational basketball, the St. Louis Bombers scored their first victory in four games with the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 80 to 71. The victory enabled them to regain a first-place tie with the Washington Senators in the Western Division of the Basketball Association of America.

A busy pair of detectives of the Stagg Street police station solved two different burglaries in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn over the week-end, in one of which a watchman had been beaten and critically injured, and recovered loot valued at $32,000.
NANKING, Feb. 22 -- The first official Communist reaction to the United States aid program for the Nanking Government came today in a broadcast from north Shensi by a Communist.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 - Students who have passed an approved driver training course in high schools would be eligible for full driver licenses at 17 years of age under a bill to be introduced tomorrow by Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican and chairman of the joint legislative committee on motor vehicle problems.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Feb. 22 -Dorothy Graves Mucha of the Edelweiss Club scored a splendid triumph in the Class A competition on the reconstructed Salisbury Winter Sports Association hill today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The United States will ask the United Nations Little Assembly to set machinery into motion for national elections in Korea that would leave one-third of the seats open for delegates from the Sovietoccupied zone, it was revealed here today.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Russian Deputy Premier and Minister of the Armed Forces, declared tonight that the world situaon compelled the Soviet-Union to live "in constant fighting preparedness," the Moscow radio said.

An unusually affecting song recital was presented by Ingrid Rypinski, mezzo-soprano, yesterday afternoon in Times Hall. She is gifted with a naturally-rich and colorful voice and has developed it with an obviously-thorough training.

The 1948 Vanderbilt Cup national knockout team-of-four contract bridge champions are Robert Appleyard, Henry Sonnenblick, Alexander Weiss, W. M. Lichtenstein and Jay T. Feigus. In a fiftysix board match last night at the Pierre, they defeated the team of Fred Hirsch, Ambrose Casner, Mrs. Ira Strasser, Herman H. Goldberg and Albert Wolf.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- The withdrawal of all candidates of the present Third Force parties resulted in a de Gaullist victory over the Communistsh)0*0*0*iin a Departmental election today at Versailles that was regarded as the first out-and-out test of strength between France's two militant opposition forces.

Three errors in human relations are hampering the efficiency of American industry, according to Alfred R. Lateiner, supervisor of a human relations program sponsored by the City College extension division. Mr. Lateiner, who announced his conclusions over the week-end for publication today, said they can be summarized accurately in one word: "teamwork."

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market tended last week to back and fill after the sharp declines of the previous week. At the week-end, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the period net changes ranging from an advance of 24 to a loss of 34 points.

A new booklet has come to our desk with the happy title, "Interesting Variations From Everyday Meat Dishes." We say "happy" advisedly. The publication deals with the organ cuts of which Americans are as suspicious as cats are of rain.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 A heavy explosion wrecked Ben Yehuda Street, one of the two main shopping streets of Jewish Jerusalem, at 6:25 o'clock this morning.
Ten midshipmen from the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis defeated a New York Athletic Club chess group in a hard-fought contest yesterday by 6 -- 4.

A rapproachement was reached yesterday between George Weiss, general manager, and Allie Reynolds, leading pitcher of the world champion Yankees, thereby erasing from the records Allie's reported "pop-off" of a few weeks ago when he enlisted in the ranks of the Yankee holdouts.
Five productions have been announced for presentation this week off Broadway. They are:

The second program of short plays in Noel Coward's "Tonight at 8:30," in which Gertrude Lawrence is starred, will be trotted out tonight at the National by Homer Curran, Russel Lewis and Howard Young, sponsors of the revival series.

Spotting their rivals the first goal, the New York Rangers managed, nevertheless, to subdue the Boston Bruins without much trouble in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A five-year survey of 7,500 women who received continuous caudal analgesia during childbirth at Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, shows that 96.2 per cent obtained complete relief from pain, an announcement by the hospital revealed yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Two former runners-up, Andy Ingraham of New York and Stanley Pearson of Philadelphia, gained the final round of the national squash racquets championship after the 1947 champion, Charlie Brinton of Philadelphia, had been eliminated in the quarter-finals today at the Harvard Club.

Joseph Szigeti, violinist, and Mieczylslaw Horszowski, pianist, were the artists at yesterday's concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. Appearing as a team, they played three of Beethoven's ten Sonatas for Violinh)0*0*0*iand Piano.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 -- Less than a minute after this morning's blast in the center of Ben Yehuda Street, screams welled up to this correspondent's bedroom in the Hotel Eden, 100 yards from the scene of the explosion.

CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- If the United Nations Security Council approves an international police force for Palestine, the Arab states will call a master military conference in Syria to create an "Arab Liberation Army," composed of units from the regular armies.

2LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 22--The Jewish AgeIlcy for Palestine, presenting to the United Nations a formal indictment of British rule in the Holy Land, todayaccused the Palestine Governmentof abetting Arab attacks and deliberately undermining peace andsecurity in that p.art of the world.

Three youths and a 14-year-old boy, the latter said by the police to be so strong he could pry apart iron bars with his hands, were arrested yesterday accused of having committed at least thirteen burglaries and safe-cracking jobs in the East Side in the last few months.

Still perched on top of the collegiate basketball world as the only unbeaten major quintet in the nation, New York University once again will put its record on the line tonight. Victorious in seventeen games since the start of the campaign, the Violets will oppose St. John's in the feature game of a twin bill at Madison Square Garden.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 22h)0*0*0*i-- Hundreds of teen-age youngsters will gather this week at the United Nations headquarters to hear recorded messages from all over the world pleading for help for the remaining 230,000,000 hungry and war-sick children.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- Analysis of balance sheets and scrutiny of business reports of all five Swiss commercial banks, published last week, show that 1947 was a year of marked prosperity for the banks.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The renewed downtrend of prices for American commodities has prompted the reflection here that probably the gilt has been worn at last from the post-war boom and that industrial activity in the United States may now settle down to levels satisfactory enough in themselves but not up to the recent feverish pace.

Mayor O'Dwyer's 1948 legislative "package," including his bill to pave the way for an 8-cent fare on all municipal transit lines, will be introduced in the Legislature this week, it was learned yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,808,852,242. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Proper regulation of the electric power industry is one of the major problems facing the American people, according to a report issued yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund, a privately endowed foundation for research and education on economic questions.

John Dickson Cart, author ofmany detective stories under hisown name and a pseudonym, Carter Dickson, has arrived here fromEngland, where he has made hishome for sixteen years. He broughtwith him the manuscript of hisnew book, '",e Life of Sir Arthuri Conan Doyle, which Harper hastentatively listed for fall publication.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Grain markets, although fluctuating in an extremely nervous manner within a fairly wide range, showed increased evidence of stability last week. Corn evinced the most strength, reversing its action of the preceding two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that the 3 to 4 percent drop in retail food prices during the past month was "in the best interest of the American people as a whole," but that the CIO still would demand further wage increases and enactment of an effective anti-inflation program.

Having crushed all opposition in the rest of Eastern Europe, and having organized that area into a solid bloc of Communist-dominated satellites, Soviet Russia now appears to have embarkedh)0*0*0*ion a drive to bring under its iron heel the last nation within that bloc which has still shown some signs of independence Czechoslovakia.
CAIRO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said tonight a state of civil war existed in Yemen following the death of the kingdom's 82-year-old monarch.

PIEKARY SLASKIE, Poland, Feb. 22 -- The Kosciuszko Hospital, which will stand as a tribute to the joint Polish and United States efforts to reconstruct this war-shattered country, was formally opened in this little Silesian town today in the presence of Polish Government and United States Embassy officials.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 22 -The Dartmouth Outing Club of New York today won the New York City Interclub team race by defeating last year's winner, the Amateur Ski Club of New York, by seven seconds.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 22 (AP) -Big John Barnum, long-driving golfer from Chicago, upset defending champion Frank Stranahan of Toledo, 3 and 1, today in the semi-finals of the thirtieth annual Houston Country Club invitation tournament.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 22 (AP) -John Werket, little speed demon from Minneapolis, outraced some of the world's fastest skaters today to win the international meet in Bislet Stadium.

Under a Washington dateline in THE TIMES of Feb. 17 was the statement that the RFC had granted $3,500,000 of additional financing to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to be used to construct the Battery parking garage.

A Canadian-American festival dedicated to a future union of the churches of the world was held yesterday on the anniversary of Washington's Birthday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -Business circles in this city are discussing today both the utterances on foreign capital investments in Brazil made by members of the Sao Paulo Commercial Association and measures recently recommended by the Council of Foreign Trade and the Inter-American Cooperation Council in the United States.

St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street, celebrated yesterday the 110th anniversary of its consecration. At special services the rector, the Rev. Richard A. D. Beaty, dedicated the new and permanent binding of the Book of Remembrance.

Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, dean of American Negro scholars and writers, who will be 80 years old today, joined Cicero yesterday in reciting the observation by Cato: "Those who say old age has no activeh)0*0*0*iduties, talk as if the pilot of a ship is unemployed"
Five new films, all imported from France, Italy and Sweden, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Mayor O'Dwyer, who entered Bellevue Hospital last Friday to begin a week of rest and medical observation under orders of Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, heart specialist, was reported yesterday to be showing "very definite signs of improvement."

One of the questions most frequently raised during the recent (or current) decline in commodity prices was the question, "Is this simply a readjustment of price relationships, or are we heading into another 1920-1921?"

Sportsmen's Show Highlights: Some of the former "highlights" have dwindled away to a faint glow by this time, and by tonight they will have faded into obscurity for another year. Today is the closing day of the show, and Joe La Flamme looks almost as tired as his moose.

One of the questions most frequently raised during the recent (or current) decline in commodity prices was the question, "Is this simply a readjustment of price relationships, or are we heading into another 1920-1921?"

Sportsmen's Show Highlights: Some of the former "highlights" have dwindled away to a faint glow by this time, and by tonight they will have faded into obscurity for another year. Today is the closing day of the show, and Joe La Flamme looks almost as tired as his moose.
A report that Santo (Sal) Bretagna, suspect in the fatal shooting of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, had been seen in Newark, N.J., proved groundless yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- A resolution limiting the personnel of the United States Supreme Court to one chief justice and eight associate justices, and requiring the retirement of all justices upon reaching the age of 75, was approved today by the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association.
Freddie Russo, Rahway, N.J., lightweight, and Dennis (Pat) Brady, Hartford, Conn., fought to a draw in the ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night before a crowd of 2,265.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- On the eve of a Security Council meeting to discuss the Palestine problem, four leading Americans proposed today a four-point program for enforcing the United Nations plan to partition the Holy Land.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb., 23 Opposition to Federal "interference" in collegiate education was expressed today by Dr. Charles Seymour, President of Yale University. He spoke to 1,000 persons at the university's thirty first annual Alumni Day.
LAKE PLACID, Feb. 23 -- Stanley Benham and his Majestic Bobsled Club squad of Lake Placid swept to a clear-cut victory today in the National Senior A.A.U. four-man bobsled championships.

h)0*0*0*iTOKYO, Feb. 23 -- A committee of representatives of Japan's upper legislative chamber, the House of Councillors, today refused to recognize the election of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida as the next Premier of Japan. Dr. Ashida will become head of the next Japanese Government in any case, but he will represent one house only, and a slim majority in that one.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Senate tonight approved and sent to the Assembly for concurrence a bill of Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican, of Kingston, making permanent the temporary cuts in personal income and unincorporated business taxes of recent years.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Political uncertainties cast a cloud over the stock market here today but the fall in prices was due more to lack of demand than to selling pressure.

NANKING, Feb. 23 (Reuters) - Strong columns of Chinese Communist troops were today converging on Yingkow, newly reopened seaport in South Manchuria, where Government troops were reported landing large-scale reinforcements.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- More than fifty members of the Legislature, mostly Democrats, refused to cross picket lines tonight to occupy their usual rooms in Albany's two strike-bound hotels the DeWitt Clinton and the Ten Eyck. Many Republicans crossed the lines, but a few declined to do so.
Negro baseball, wabbly at the box office after the loss of Jackie Robinson, claims it was turned down cold last December when it asked admission to organized baseball.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox SherrilI, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, said yesterday that communicants of his faith were "only playing" with their opportunities and responsibilities for creating a better world through the church.

The three-story apartment and store structure on the north side of Forty-eighth Avenue, approximately sixty feet east of Forty-sixth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been acquired by Frank and Marcel R. Pelletier from Ernest Drewitz through Hosinger Bode, brokers.

The young singers who formed the cooperative Lemonade Opera last spring did so to get themselves a hearing. One of them who gained especially favorable attention was Ruth Kobart, Iowa soprano, who sang the Witch in "Hansel and Gretel." Last night she came uptown and gave her first New York recital at Times Hall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The National Founders Association's drive to get scrap metal onto the market is bringing "good results," declared L. E. Roark, executive vice president, but he added the warning that greater effort will be required in view of the fact that little relief can be expected from European sources.

William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that the city's 750 new subway cars were satisfactory in every respect, when he was asked to comment on reports that the handrails in the new cars were too high for comfort.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Universal military training is essential in this country if an adequate program of national defense is to be developed. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, declared here today.

GENEVA, Feb. 23 -- The United Nations maritime conference reached agreement today on the first of three key paragraphs of a draft convention defining the scope and purposes of the International Maritime Organizaion.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (UP) -President Juan D. Peron declared today that Argentina would maintain her rights in the Antarctic territory claimed by Great Britain. He spoke to a workers' meeting in San Martin Plaza, Cordoba.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 23 -- The State Department informally rejected today protests from Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia against developments in respect toh)0*0*0*iWestern Germany.

A broad port rehabilitation program to cost $114,000,000 over a twelve-year period and involving the leasing of city-owned waterfront properties to the Port of New York Authority for fifty years was made public yesterday by the bi-state agency.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Still another deadlock between the Soviet Union and the Western powers took place today at a meeting of the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, who are considering the future of the Italian colonies.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Bills to give the State Education Commissioner and the Board of Regents broad powers to act in connection with complaints of discrimination in higher education were being prepared today for introduction with bipartisan backing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, politely but firmly rebuffed today Southern Governors who sought to get the party high command to backtrack on President Truman's civil rights program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -Refusal by the House Foreign Affairs Committee to permit radio and newsreel coverage of Henry A. Wallace's testimony on the European Recovery Program tomorrow was denounced by his third-party headquarters today as "an outrageous act of censorship."

Declines in credit and collection ratings for the second time in six and one-half years was indicated by the thirty-ninth semi-annual survey of credit and collection in Latin America markets for the last half of 1947 conducted by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association ofh)0*0*0*iCredit Men.

HAVANA, Feb. 23 -- A Czechoslovak proposal to stipulate the relations between members of the proposed International Trade Organization and nonmembers has been accepted as the basis of discussion by a subcommittee of the Havana conference, it was learned today.
An experimental program for treating advanced cancer patients at home has proved so successful that the New York City Cancer Committee will allot $50,000 to the project, it was announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Francis P. Keough tonight became the eleventh Archbishop of Baltimore, premier Roman Catholic see of this country, in simple ceremonies in his new residence.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a letter to the National Conference of Christians and Jews made public here yesterday, strongly endorsed the current observance of Brotherhood Week. He wrote:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Relic, the Circle M Farm's flashy black colt, is out of Saturday's $50,000 added Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park -- and out of the Kentucky Derby and the other spring classics for three-year-olds as well.

Favorites continued to advance without incident in the Eastern indoor tennis singles tournament yesterday as play reached the fourth round on the courts of the Metropolitan Tennis Club in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

h)0*0*0*iOur Bill of Rights is embedded in the law. If its principles were embedded in the heart there would be no need to invoke the law. It is to help establish these principles as a rule of life in this country that Brotherhood Week, now being observed throughout the nation, was organized.

JUST about the ablest living Irish writer (not counting G. B. S., who generally writes as if he were above or without nationality) is a scholarly librarian named Frank O'Connor. Mr. O'Connor says that he never had any education worth mentioning; but he is a linguist, an authority on eighteenth-century music, the author of a book on Turgenev written in Gaelic, volumes of novels, verse, biography and short stories and the co-author of four plays.
Under a bright winter sun, the 216th anniversary of the birth of George Washington was observed yesterday with outdoor ceremonies in various parts of the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 - Governors and other officials of states from California to Florida urged Congress today to give the states clear title to the lands and natural resources under their coastal and inland waters.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (UP) Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Minister of the Armed Forces, said tonight in a speech at the Bolshoi Theatre that the Soviet Army had completed its conversion to a peacetime basis, but was being re-equipped with the latest weapons.

The Greater New York Red Cross 1948 Fund has adopted "The Greatest Mother" theme popularized for the Red Cross in 1919 by Howard Chandler Christy, the artist, for its current poster publicity, it was announced yesterday. The artist chosen to portray the symbol is 34-year-old David Stone Martin of Hightstown, N.J.

The Board of Educations' proposal to save $5,000,000 by instituting various economies in its $28,390,000 program for the construction of eighteen schools and additions this year will not affect the educational efficiency of the new buildings, it was reported yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 23 (Aneta) -- Stocks were steady in quiet trading today, featured by firmness in plantations. Deli Tobacco displayed strength on the announcement that its plantations may be back in condition soon, leading an upswing in other tobacco issues as well as rubber and sugar.

Frank Shea probably will not be on hand when the Yankees start spring training in a week at St. Petersburg, Fla. The Naugatuck hurler failed to reach a contract agreement with General Manager George Weiss in the Yanks' Fifth Avenue offices yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- French officials said today that they expected the Steering Committee of the sixteen-nation conference on the Marshall Plan would meet in Paris March 8 to decide whether to create a permanent organization to oversee the application of the plan and of European production under it.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 23 The new Council of States, which is to act as a sixteen-man upper house (two from each state) in the economic legislature of the merged United States and British zones, met today and elected Dr. Hans Ehard, Minister-President of Bavaria as its chairman.h)0*0*0*iO

George Atkins, 29 years old, of 2217 Eighth Avenue, and Ruth McDuffy, 27, of 1337 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were injured seriously last night when they fell in front of an approaching train from a platform of the IND subway station at 125th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- National production in 1947 totaled $230,000,000,000, 13 per cent above the 1946 aggregate of $204,000,000,000, while national income for 1947 rose to $203,000,000,000, an increase of $25,000,000,000 over 1946, the Commerce Department announced today.
TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Changes in the Moscow policy regarding social dancing have caught the Japanese Communist party red-faced and tongue-tied. Not to say flat-footed.

The suggested "federation of Western Europe," which has been projected as a possible outgrowth of the Marshall Plan, was strongly pressed last night by former President Herbert Hoover. Speaking at a Washington's Birthday dinner of the Sons of the Revolution at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, he urged that the sixteen nations cooperating in the Marshall Plan formally constitute themselves as a regional federation under the United Nations Charter.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 23 -- Six British soldiers were wounded today in an aftermath of the explosion yesterday in Ben Yehuda Street, heart of the modern Jewish section of Jerusalem. The death toll in the bomb outrage rose to fifty-four, according to a Jewish burial society.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Prices will be higher next fall for men's worsted wool suits, W. O. Swanson, Omaha, Neb., president of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, said today. He made this comment at the association's thirteenth annual convention in the Palmer House.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Federated Ku Klux Klan, Inc., today asked the Anti-Nazi League of New York to stay out of Alabama.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 23-- Mr. and Mrs. H. Alan Gregg and their four children perished early today in a fire that swept their fifteen-room home on Brewster Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The bill proposed by Representative Sundstrom of New Jersey to get into the national treasuries of Western Europe and out of hoarding here what he estimates to be from $6 to $8 billions in American currency has been attacked on several grounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho read himself out of the Democratic party tonight and cast his lot with Henry A. Wallace as Vice Presidential candidate on the Wallace Independent ticket.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Powerful Senate opposition to an income tax cut as large as the $6,500,000,000 reduction voted by the House was formally manifested today as the Senate Finance Committee prepared to act on the issue.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 23 -- Retail advertising is due for a "new look" with special emphasis on factual, informative selling, it was predicted here today by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Two productions, both slated for limited runs, will be offered to Broadway first-nighters this evening. At the Mansfield Theatre, Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers, in association with Brian Doherty, will put on "Where Stars Walk," a comedy by Micheal MacLiammoir, as the third bill by the well-known Dublin Gate Theatre Company.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Guards on Government buildings in London were instructed to be especially alert tonight after a bomb was found at a building used by some departments of the Colonial Office. No extra guards were mounted, but there was fear of attacks as an aftermath of the bombing of Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem, for which the Haganah blamed British personnel.

Maurice Wilk's violin playing at Carnegie Hall last night had that most precious of gifts -- a personal, deeply rooted and sound musical instinct. Nearly every work heh)0*0*0*iundertook bore the stamp of a musician with something to say. The result was that the music came out vibrant and expressive.

ABOARD U.S.S. GREENWICH BAY IN THE CARIBBEAN, Feb. 23 -- President Truman headed for the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo, Cuba, this afternoon following a tour of St. Croix Island, during which he was welcomed in Calypso lyrics and rhythm.

IF Branch Rickey's motive was other than self-glorification -- and Larry MacPhail insists that the Mahatma is muscle-bound from patting himself on the back -- the Deacon of the Dodgers would seem to be well within his rights to exhume the Negro issue in his Wilberforce speech last week as a striking example of the fact that such an issue no longer exists.

Port congestion in Souh American harbors, a source of concern to American shippers since the end of the war, shows no sign of immediate improvement, James L. Bates declared here yesterday. He is chief of the technical department of the United States Maritime Commission.

Africa will be brought a thousand miles closer to New York when Pan America. Airways opens tomorrow its law service to Johannesburg by way of the Azores, with stops at Dakar, Accra and Leopoldville. The first flight will be made at a leisurely schedule by a party of magazine and newspaper editors and publishers as guests of Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American, and other officials of the line.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The fiftieth anniversary issue of "Who's Who in America" came out today, listing 41,194 persons, 5,430 of whom made the grade for the first time.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- United Nations officials have received from a Bulgarian child a poem written in appreciation of the help that the Children's Emergency Fund is giving to 4,000,000 young European war victims.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -Awards for the construction of new schools in the United States during 1947, as compared with 1946 figures, increased 157 percent to $319,000,000, the highest level in the last seven years, the Federal Works Agency disclosed today in its regular report on public construction.

Mayor O'Dwyer's heart condition is now considered the product of excessive fatigue, and he will suffer no permanent impairment if he gets proper rest, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospitals Commissioner, said yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- Alfredo Idelfonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, today spurred the offensive of the Catholic Church in Italy against "atheistic communism" by issuing a pastoral letter in which he instructed the clergy of his diocese to refuse absolution to "Communists or members of other movements contrary to the Catholic religion."
RIDGELAND, S.C., Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Democratic Committee of Jasper County formally quit the national party tonight.

Helena Morsztyn, pianist in the grand tradition, appeared at Town Hall in a recital last night. Her known command of the keyboard's mechanical problems and her unusual ability to evoke delicate Shades of color were both much in evidence. But this listener was most struck by the sense of her forceful personality bent on giving a full-blooded impression of musical forms.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 23 -Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church assailed in a Washington Birthday speech today "the impostures of a pretended patriotism." He asked that Americans face their problems with a "realism" he ascribed to the first President's Farewell Address.

There has been almost as much moral fervor in the Southern "revolt" against President Truman's civil rights program as there is behind the program itself. The Southern Governors who met recentlyh)0*0*0*iat Wakulla, Fla., and their committee of four who yesterday descended on the Democratic National Chairman, Senator J. Howard McGrath, seemed to think they were defending something worth defending.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Ryan Aeronautical Company reported yesterday that a contract for production of "pilotless aircraft or guided missiles" for the United States Air Force has been increased recently for the third time.

An "Intercollegiate News Roundup" will be presented Saturday evenings on WINS by the Intercollegiate Radio Guild of Newh) 0*0*0*iYork, beginning March 13. The quarter-hour summary of college news will be compiled by collegiate newspaper editors and the guild.

BEFORE President Roosevelt left for Quebec in August, 1943, he requested Sumner Welles to resign as Under-Secretary of State. He called Welles to his office at the White House and made this clear to him.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- A wire-haired foxterrier with a scanty ring record became best in show tonight in one of the East's foremost indoor bench events, the thirty-fifth fixture of the Eastern Dog Club. He was Mrs. R. C. Bondy's Radar of Wildoaks from Goldens Bridge, N.Y., chosen by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt.

City after city throughout the country reports that its voluntary hospitals are confronted with mounting deficits. The tragic effect may be to deprive many persons of adequate hospital care, according to a survey just completed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- The Arab League's political committee decided before its seventh session ended yesterday that no member state should sign a pact, military or otherwise, with any foreign power without approval of the League.

ALBANY, Ore., Feb. 23 -- Harold E. Stassen, continuing his vigorous campaign for the votes of Oregon's twelve delegates to the Republican National Convention, visited rural communities today which never before had seen a candidate for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today on housing and rent control:

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Edward R. Carr, president of the National Association of Home Builders, defended the industry today against charges of lobbying, lack of progress and failure to provide low-cost housing.

WARSAW, Feb. 23 -- The Polish Government announced today that it had informed the Dutch Government of the recall of Benedict Elmer, Polish Minister to The Hague -- after M. Elmer had announced in The Hague that he was breaking with the Warsaw Administration on a political matter.

LONDON. Feb. 23 -- Britain is devoting special training to her bomber forces "to enable a substantial weight of air power to be developed at short notice in any area where it might be required," Air Secretary Arthur Henderson stated in the House of Commons today.

It is sometimes regrettable that news requirements make it essential to review the first performance of a new opera off the baton immediate contact, for the morning after. Because the second performance is so likely to be better, more secure, more . eloquent, and therefore to do more justice to the composition.

Attendance at Broadway's first run film houses, traditionally largeh)0*0*0*ion Washington's Birthday, was excellent yesterday, a survey of midtown theatres revealed. According to many managements, Broadway throngs were as great as any seen in recent years and, while business tapered off toward the end of the day, most of the attendances were estimated at capacity and near-capacity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23 -The fundamental causes of inflation must be found in order to combat it effectively, Irving S. Olds, Chairman of the Board of the United States Steel Corporation, declared today. Speaking here at a Yale Alumni luncheon, Mr. Olds said that the inflation problem has two distinct phases.

Eleven new singers, besides twoh)0*0*0*ialready mentioned, have been signed by the New York City Opera Company for its spring season, March 19 to April 25, it was announced yesterday by Laszlo Halasz, the company's artistic and music director.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- The Americans for Democratic Action adopted today a political platform which not only did not mention President Truman, but actually committed the pro-New Deal organization to withholding endorsement of any Presidential candidate until both major parties had chosen their nominees and adopted their platforms.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23 -- Enthusiasm among local Russian expatriates for returning to their motherland has dropped sharply in the last few months. It now appears as if the Soviet program for taking home almost all local Russians registered as Soviet citizens will fall far short of original expectations.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 23 -- The disintegration of the Hungarian Socialist party is proceeding rapidly. The Socialist Mayors of Gyor and Pecs have resigned and a number of party members of the board of the Budapest Transportation Company and civic gas works are being replaced.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -President Juan D. Peron today hailed the new regime in Argentina's universities, which he said had long been "despoiled' by "cold-hearted, faithless and unpatriotic men, with no love for their country, affection for their parents or tenderness for their children."

SHANGHAI, Tuesday. Feb. 24 (AP) -- The first American traveler to return from Soviet-occupied Dairen in six months said today that Russian troops were still in that Manchurian port. [Communist sources have asserted recently that Soviet troops had withdrawn and left the city in the hands of Chinese.]

The recent ruling that the Maritime Commission has the power to authorize long-term operating-differential subsidies has cleared the way for the American South African Line's plans for two passenger vessels on its route between New York and South and East Africa, it was announced yesterday.

On the eve of the meeting of the United Nations Security Council to consider the setting up of an international force to handle the Palestine disorders, Henry A. Wallace issued a statement yesterday demanding that the United States take the lead in implementing the partition program.

Members of the New York County Medical Society voted last night to approve a compromise agreement under which the Red Cross will proceed with plans to provide "free blood" for the city's hospitals. The action was taken at a meeting in the New York Academy of Medicine Building, 2 East 103d Street.

Maintaining the upward trend in sales that began twelve years ago, the Union Bag and Paper Corporation transacted in 1947 a peak volume of business of $63,511,527, or 42 per cent over the previous year's record of $44,871,180, Alexander Calder, president and chairman, reported in the company's preliminary annual statement released for publication today.

United Sates production of rayon broad woven goods was 11 per cent higher than in 1943, according to a survey made by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, issued yesterday. The 1947 production figure of 1,902,000,000 yards of goods is the highest figure recorded since the surveys were started in 1943, it was estimated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -Paramount has concluded its pending deal with Arthur Ripley and Rudolph Monter for acquisition of screen rights to Thomas Wolfe's 1930 novel, "Look Homeward, Angel," the studio announced today.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- The Economic Council voted today to advise the Government to try to reduce the prices of consumer goods 10 per cent below the level of Feb. 1. The Council added that if this reduction were not achieved by the end of March, it would be obliged to urge wage increases sufficient to re-establish the wage-price ratio that had existed on Dec. 1, 1947.

PRAGUE, Feb. 23 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Minister of the Interior and the Minister of War announced officially tonight that groups within the Czech National Socialist party -- second largest party in the country -- were conspiring for an armed revolt against the state.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, have sold the four-story vacant dwelling at 54 East Eighty-first Street to the 243 East Seventy-first Street Corporation, of which James E. Casale is president. The property, assessed at $45,000, occupies a lot about 20 by 102 feet in the block between Park and Madison Avenues.

Playing aggressively all the way, Newtown High's quintet clinched the North Queens Public Schools Athletic League championship yesterday by defeating Bayside, 43 -- 20, before 8,000 schoolboy enthusiasts at Madison Square Garden.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 23 (Canadianh)0*0*0*iPress) -- Oats and barley prices remained steady during dull trading today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, with oats prices closing 1/2 cent higher to unchanged and barley 7/8 to 1/2 cent higher. Lack of outside interest was attributed to the closing of the American markets due to the national holiday in the United States.

Edwin A. Salmon, director of the proposed $15,575,000 New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, announced yesterday that clearance had been obtained on the university section of the center and that construction work would begin either in the middle of next summer or early next fall.
No shrinking Violets are the young men who last night at Madison Square Garden fashioned the eighteenth straight N.Y.U. basketball victory of the season -- a season that has not known defeat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Southern Governors Committee issued the following statement tonight after conferring with Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, on President Truman's civil rights program:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- a message today President Truman urged Congress to extend Federal rent control to April 30, 1949, and to provide immediate encouragement for intensive housing construction. The message was sent from the White House during the President's absence in the Caribbean area.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 -- Declaring that the alternative to immediate military aid to China would be the loss of all Manchuria to communism, Senator Robert A. Taft brought his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination into Michigan today with a sharp attack upon the foreign policies of the Roosevelt and Truman administrations.
A former fire buff was arrested yesterday morning on a charge of arson after he had started three fires in hallways on upper Second Avenue and sent in alarms for them, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United States attitude during the Palestine debate that will open in the United Nations Security Council tomorrow was studied at length today by Secretary of State Marshall and Warren R. Austin, United States representative at Lake Success.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Assemblyman William T. Andrews, Manhattan Democrat, introduced a bill tonight to liberalize the state's divorce laws in line with recommendations of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
h)0*0*0*iCHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Porkon-the-hoof dropped sharply in price at many big Midwestern livestock centers today because of unusually heavy shipments from farms to market.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Failure to build or even plan defenses on the northern shore of Singapore Island, lack of cooperation between the military and civil authorities and the "superior mobility, training and preparation" of Japanese troops all contributed to the "half-hearted and disappointing" resistance of British, Australian and Indian troops there and to the loss of the fortress of Singapore, according to Field Marshal Viscount Wavell.

Any time Norman E. Hyams wants to leave Rockaway Park, Queens, for Russia he is entitled to preferment in housing there. He can get free railroad and bus transportation, and he rates a 6,000-ruble income tax exemption.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The auto industry again is building more than 100,000 cars and trucks a week.

With three separate plans for rehabilitation of the city's waterfront facilities now in their hands, Mayor O'Dwyer and his special committee handling the problem began yesterday preparations for analyzing and comparing the proposals.

Handblown Mexican glassware in vibrant blues and greens, handloomed cottons from the mountains of Guatemala, and rich-toned rugs from Chile, Peru and our own Southwest make a gay spot of Bloomingdale's "Latin-American Market," which opens for business this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- William L. Hutcheson, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, AFL, testified today that he had made an agreement with the AFL Executive Council in 1945 to have a three-member arbitration committee hand down a "final and binding" award in the Hollywood jurisdictional dispute.

The New York Society of Ceramic Arts opened its forty-seventh annual exhibition with a preview for members last evening at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. The display will be open to the public at noon today. Hours are from noon to 6 P.M. daily, including Sundays, through March 6.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 23 -- The first congress for unification of the "Social Democratic" parties of Rumania ended today after adopting a resolution pledging friendship to the Soviet Union, charging "Anglo-American imperialists" with seeking another war, and establishing the new Rumanian Workers party.

Benjamin Fielding, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday that his program for improving the department's personnel included the replacement this year of provisional employes, numbering 40 percent of the department's strength, with civil service employes.

ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- Maj. Gen. William G. Livesay, chief of the Army Group of the United States mission here, said today that 257,400 (about $1,029,600) "donated by patriotic Greeks" would be used at once toward the purchase of 35,000 rifles of the latest British Army type for the Greek Army.

The Department of Commerce is carrying, in "Foreign Commerce Weekly," a series of articles by Henry Chalmers, consultant on commercial policy, reviewing world trends in foreign trade during 1947. The picture is not a pleasing one from the standpoint of those who had hoped for a speedy return to multilateral trade at the end of the war.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, has completed its preliminary work in connection with the union's coming general elections. Nominations for offices will close on Feb. 29 and the election will begin next month, and be carried through June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -Representative Forest A. Harness, Republican, of Indiana, announced today that the House Subcommittee on Publicity and Propaganda, of which he is head, is investigating the activities of Secretary Krug and high reclamation aides in the Department of the Interior.

President Truman's Caribbean vacation tour and his cordial receptions and encouraging talks at San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Charlotte Amalie, the Virgin Islands, should have the effect of focusing more public and Congressional attention on those outlying possessions of the United States.
ATLANTA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Adherents of Herman Talmadge won legal control of the Georgia Democratic party machinery today, ending ten months of contest and confusion.

" The Goebbels Diaries," edited and translated by Louis P. Lochner, which will be brought out by Doubleday on April 29, is the Book-of-the-Month Club's May choice. The manuscript was found in the courtyard of Goebbels' Ministry, where it was overlooked by the Russians and narrowly escaped burning.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23 -To the great delight of the Old Blues who were gathered for Alumni Day ceremonies, two Yale major sports teams scored smashing triumphs over traditional rivals today.

The Sportsmen's Show is over, and your correspondent, in company with certain other luckless individuals forced to spend ten days among a few outdoor exhibits and a collection of miscellaneous hardware, home furnishing and honky-tonk displays, is glad to see it go.
I note with gratification your editorial commending to the citizens of this state the report of Mr. Young's Commission on the Need for a State University.

With the climate in these parts subject to change at any time, with or without notice, Felix Elderby hoped he'd be forgiven for taking a moderately retrospective view. He thought that the weather man must have mislaid his calendar when he gave us a white city on Washington's birthday.

Two young boys died and their parents and baby sister were burned seriously early yesterday morning by a fire in the four-story apartment building at 30-90 Thirty fourth Street, Astoria, Queens. The lads, sons of Mr. and Mrs. Harold May, were Harold Jr., 6 years old, and Michael, 5,

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Illinois State Athletic Commission today ordered Mike Spinelli, New York textile trucker, to show cause on March 8 why he should not be suspended as a boxing manager in connection with the ring death of Sam Baroudi.

Planning for expansion, the Michael Goldberg Plumbing and Heating Supply Company of 1853 Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn, has purchased the two-story warehouse at 200 Bay Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, from the City Freight Forwarding Corporation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23 -To the great delight of the Old Blues who were gathered for Alumni Day ceremonies, two Yale major sports teams scored smashing triumphs over traditional rivals today.

The Sportsmen's Show is over, and your correspondent, in company with certain other luckless individuals forced to spend ten days among a few outdoor exhibits and a collection of miscellaneous hardware, home furnishing and honky-tonk displays, is glad to see it go.
I note with gratification your editorial commending to the citizens of this state the report of Mr. Young's Commission on the Need for a State University.

With the climate in these parts subject to change at any time, with or without notice, Felix Elderby hoped he'd be forgiven for taking a moderately retrospective view. He thought that the weather man must have mislaid his calendar when he gave us a white city on Washington's birthday.

Two young boys died and their parents and baby sister were burned seriously early yesterday morning by a fire in the four-story apartment building at 30-90 Thirty fourth Street, Astoria, Queens. The lads, sons of Mr. and Mrs. Harold May, were Harold Jr., 6 years old, and Michael, 5,

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Illinois State Athletic Commission today ordered Mike Spinelli, New York textile trucker, to show cause on March 8 why he should not be suspended as a boxing manager in connection with the ring death of Sam Baroudi.

As a Chinese student carrying back to China technical knowledge and pleasant memories of American hospitality, I should hate to see our Chinese people ever fight the Americans. I am disturbed because such a possibility definitely exists should the "dyed-inthe-wool" Chinese Communists come into power.

The solid and in several respects ingenious program for modernization of New York City's waterfront presented to Mayor O'Dwyer by the Port Authority is, in quality and in use of creative imagination, exactly what we would expect from that organization. The Authority had only ninety days, including week-ends, to survey the piers and develop its plan.

Reflecting the greatest rubber consumption in its history, sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company in 1947 were the largest for any peacetime year, but net income delined 7.8 per cent from the year before, the annual report showed yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP) -Earl K. Long, brother of the late Huey Long, was chosen today as next Governor of Louisiana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Henry A. Wallace, third party Presidential candidate, accused the Truman Administration today of "laying the foundations" for war with Russia. He said new faces were needed at the head of this Government before an understanding could be reached with Soviet leaders.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 24 -Final preparations were made today for this community's participation as a unit Sunday in the "give one day" campaign for the United Nations Appeal for Children. Feb. 29 has been designated by United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie as the day when persons all over the world will be expected to contribute a day's wages or produce to aid the 400,000,000 children suffering from years of war and lean harvests.

Bill Mathis of Illinois was selected by fans attending last Saturday night's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships as the outstandingh)0*0*0*iperformer of the meet, director Dan Ferris announced yesterday. Mathis, who also holds the National A. A. U.

First draft choice in both major professional gridiron circuits, Anthony (Skippy) Minisi, backfield ace of the University of Pennisylvania, has decided to cast his lot with the New York Giants of the National Football League. The announcement, hardly a surprise, was made yesterday at a luncheon at Leone's.

In his article in your issue of Feb. 15, James Reston states that one of the hopes on which support for the resolution on the partition of Palestine in the'U. N. Assembly was originally based was "that the Jews in Palestine, lacked by the' well-organized militia of Haganah, would be able to deal effectively with the more numerous but poorly organized Arabs."
