BOWIE, Md., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Having seen two kings of the turf beaten in the Widener Handicap on Saturday, Trainer Hirsch Jacobs came back North today to play his ace in the hole, Stymie. Jacobs returned from Florida, where he had watched Assault and Armed run out of the money, to prepare Stymie, along with thirtyseven horses he already has galloping at Bowie.

For the first time in any section of the railroad industry the five day, forty-hour work week will become effective on March 4 for 4,700h)0*0*0*idrivers and garagemen employed by the Railway Express Agency in the metropolitan area.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation, which operates 90 per cent of the five-cent bus lines in Manhattan omitted a quarterly dividend yesterday for the first time since the lines were converted from trolley cars eleven years ago.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Albuquerque," a Western made by Clarion Productions for Paramount, which is slated to arrive at the Victoria on Saturday. The cast of the picture, which was photographed in Cinecolor, is headed by Randolph Scott, Barbarah)0*0*0*iBritton and George (Gabby) Hayes.

Georgie Small, 161 1/2, Brownsville, won a decision over Nick Kashuba, 163 3/4, Brooklyn, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Small outboxed Kashuba throughout the fight. In the eight round semi-final, Tom McKeagney, 164, Quincy, Mass., defeated Ben Perry, 161 1/2, Brooklyn.

First disclosures were made here yesterday of an $8,700,000 plant expansion program of the alkali manufacturing industry of Colombia, South America. At a luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club, John Oman, president of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders, and representatives of the Instituto de Fomento Industrial, Colombian Governmental agency, declared that the new plants will be located near Bogota, and will make soda ash and caustic soda among other chemical products.
To survive the present emergency the voluntary hospitals must become everyone's business, according to authorities interviewed during a survey just completed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Two Republicans in the Legislature called today for an investigation' of Communist "infiltration" in New York State public life, politics and schools. Senator Fred A. Young of Lowville and Assemblyman Frank J. Becker of Nassau County submitted a resolution to create a nine-member committee and appropriate $50,000.

An evening of modified rapture might be the verdict on last night's concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra led by Eugene Ormandy, eighth of its season at Carnegieh)0*0*0*iHall. There was plenty of polished, gleaming playing, and not too much first-rate music.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg and Representative Christian A. Herter, the Senate and House leaders in legislating a recovery plan for Western Europe, exchanged letters overnight in an effort to solve a serious problem that will automatically exist if Congress fails to pass the European Recovery Program by April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A one-month's extension of the Rent Control Law expiring Feb. 29 swept through the House today, while the Senate several hours later, approved a continuance of rent control, with some modifications, through April 30, 1949.
A group of writers and actors undertook the organization here yesterday of a New York movement to resist "censorship in the arts" wherever it may appear.

Operations last year of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and its subsidiaries resulted in an income of $69,326,121, an increase of 49 per cent over 1946 and 66 per cent over 1941, the last prewar year, John S. Coleman, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

In the Security Council of the United Nations yesterday our delegate, Mr. Austin, answered the question that has been asked most insistently in recent weeks, as violence has continued to mount in Palestine and new threats have been heard of Arab armies marching into that country to oppose by force the recommendation of the General Assembly in favor of partition.

In the light of your very welcome editorial "Crisis in the College," on the problem of recruiting the thousands of additional teachers required by higher education, I thought your readers might be interested in a plan which we have evolved at Princeton to give able young men a chance to test the possibfiities of academic life.
CHICAGO, Feb. 34 (AP) -- Another 50 to 75 cents a hundred pounds was pared off hog prices today, while cattle were steady to 50 cents lower and lambs steady to 25 cents lower.

The Home Insurance Company in 1947 wrote premiums totaling $114,774,675, an increase of $19,709,328 over the preceding year's record, Harold V. Smith, president, declared in the annual report issued for publication today. Last year's premiums, he said, were the largest ever attained by a firemarine insurance company.

QUINCY, Mass., Feb. 24 (UP) - Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Coolidge of Massachusetts declared tonighth)0*0*0*ithat Russian agents were infiltrating Hawaii in a move tantamount to "a new surprise attack on Pearl Harbor."

The National Lutheran Council, as the United States Committee for the Lutheran World Federation, has reached an agreement with the British Government under which it will assume complete charge of Lutheran missions in Palestine, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul C. Emple, assistant executive director of the council.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Mayor William O'Dwyer plans to get $104,600,000 more next year for operation of the New York City government by increasing transit fares, imposing an automobile use tax, doubling business taxes and increasing real estate taxes, it was disclosed today when his legislative "package" arrived here for presentation to the Legislature.

Twelve paraplegic veterans of World War II, all members of the Birmingham Hospital Basketball Charioteers, Van Nuys, Calif., arrived in New York by plane yesterday for their clash against the Halloran General Hospital team in Staten Island tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Chile's "annexation" of part of the Falkland Island Dependencies makes it almost certain that Britain will now resore to the United Nations for judgment, it was learned tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United States proposed formally today that the United Nations go ahead with national elections in Korea. The proposal met with opposition from Canada and Australia but piled up the beginning of a good-sized majority in the United Nations Little Assembly.

A selection of papers written by George Washington is being arranged and edited by Saxe Comins to give a view of the history made in Washington's time as he saw it. The volume, entitled "Basic Writings of George Washington," will contain explanatory notes for each item.
Without a greater flow of equity capital the Government may have to take over the task of financing business, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday.

Forty-nine addresses in the Second New York District where Government tax assistants will give free help required for the preparation of Federal income tax returns daily, except Saturdays and Sundays, from March 1 through March 15 were made public yesterday by William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the district.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- Unless the inflationary spiral is halted, a financial collapse, "possibly unbelievably near," will bring some form of collectivism to this nation as happened elsewhere in great countries of the world, Gov. James H. Duff of Pennsylvania warned here tonight.

Beginning the week of March 1, Artistic Foundations, Inc., will launch through the American Newspaper Advertising Network a newspaper campaign for Flexees girdles and brassieres described as the most extensive in the company's history, it was announced yesterday.

The American War Correspondents Association, composed of men and women who were accredited to the United States armed forces during World War II, has requested in a resolution that any grant of assistance by this country to any foreign country be accompanied by a demand for complete freedom for the American press in reporting the use of such aid.

ABOARD U.S.S. GREENWICH BAY, in the Caribbean, Feb. 24 -- President Truman declared this afternoon that Warrenh)iR. Austin's speech on Palestine accurately explained this country's position on a problem that he said was "the deep concern" of this country.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- Rebuffing the united Scandinavian bloc, the United Nations Maritime Conference approved today broad powers for the proposed international maritime organization to deal with matters of discrimination in world shipping.

LONDON, Feb. 24 The United States, Great Britain and France accused the Soviet Union today of trying to undermine the negotiations for settlement of the problem of German assets in Austria. The accusation was made at the meeting of the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Educators attending the annual conference of the American Association of School Administrators expressed concern today over the strike in Minneapolis. By coincidence, when the administratorsh)0*0*0*imet here for their 1947 convention, the teachers of Buffalo were on strike.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -Union public school teachers walked out here at 8 A.M. today in a pay dispute, and 65,000 pupils began an unscheduled vacation.

National Airlines made good last night its promise to open its Newark Miami-Havana run with nonunion pilots. A DC-4 with-thirty five passengers arrived at Newark at 9:30 P.M. and took off on the return trip at midnight.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- The Italian clergy were instructed today to vote at the April national elections to aid Catholic organizations and pro-Catholic parties in their battle against extreme left-wing parties.

An injury to his eardrum as a youth led Dr. John R. Gregg to devise a method of shorthand so that he could copy notes in school. He was only 10 years old when his hearing was impaired; by the time he was 21 his system for writing by code had become a popular thing and was widely employed by business men, educators and lecturers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Holy Cross, the defending champion, tonight was named to represent New England in the N.C. A.A. basketball tournament, which will open March 18 in Kansas City and New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic floor leader, has given to Republican members of the Finance Committee a strong hint that they may expect Democratic support for a tax reduction bill, if the cut is not too deep.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The last day of the account saw stock markets here today subdued.

An exhibition of paintings, water-colors, drawings and other graphic work by Edouard Manet has been arranged by the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the New York Infirmary. It will open with a preview this evening and to the public tomorrow.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Bespectacled Jack Wilkins, hometown veteran skier, and youthful Andy Tommy and Geogg Crain, Ottawa high school speedsters, dominated the combined Alpine and giant slalom events that concluded the Lake Placid Club Snow Birds twenty-seventh annual Washington Birthday games today at Rimrock Run of Mount Jo.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP) -Repand romped home by four lengths today at the Fair Grounds to win the featured $1,500 Quatrain Purse. Jockey Willie Saunders was in the saddle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) __ The rubber industry today urged Congress to get the Government out of the synthetic rubber business as soon as possible.

Tom C. Clark, United States Attorney General, last night attacked the Reed-Bulwinkle bill, now pending before Congress, as a measure that would "confer upon carriers a status of special privilege and exemption from the anti trust laws."

As the Senate approaches a vote on the proposed St. Lawrence seaway project a fair appraisal of the arguments, in the debate that began a month ago, would seem to be that the advocates of this venture have failed to prove their case for construction now. From President Truman down the line these advocates have relied for the'most part on generalizations not adequately supported.

I was shocked to read in THE TIMES of Feb. 13 the report of your correspondent from Salonika in which he described the parade of the captured rebels. As he so rightly put it, "had it not been for the display of modern war equipment, the spectacle might have come out of the fourth century B. C."

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- New York State's five-year $840,000,000 highway construction program was described today as a "blueprint dream" at the board of directors' meeting of the New York State Automobile Association here.

After exhausting every legal maneuver to stay free, John Porter Monroe, 50-year-old Washington lobbyist, surrendered to United States Marshal James E. Mulcahy yesterday to begin serving a twoyear sentence imposed on him in April, 1946, for black market textile operations.

A Hollywood press agent who turned his high-pressure methods to promotion of stock in an idle silver mine came under the scrutiny yesterday of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein. He is N. James Elliott, Near York associate of Paul Ross of Hollywood, press representative of a number of movie stars.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company, one of the largest writers of fire insurance in the country, yesterday reported in the 1947 annual statement total admitted assets increased to $208,875,711 from $189,607,237 on Dec. 31, 1946.

Ed Lopat, chunky southpaw pitcher, yesterday was headed back for the place where he was born -- New York -- and the only man possibly happier about it than Lopat himself was Manager Bucky Harris, of the world champion Yankees.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Military Government officials disclosed today that the much publicized ambitious textile export program of the combined Anglo-American zones has encountered such great buyer resistance that a large portion of production will be diverted into the home market.

When the S. S. Vulcania arrived here from Genoa last week its cargo included the first post-war shipment of Italian gorgonzola. Like the Bel Paese recently reported here as having returned to our markets, Gorgonzola is among Italy's most celebrated cheeses.

TORONTO, Feb. 24 (UP) -- All members of the Boston Bruins in hockey team have denied gambling on a National Hockey League game, General Manager Art Ross said tonight. The Boston team met tonight by order of Ross and Coach Dit Clapper.

Through arrangements with Iron States Military Government officials, tourists will be Brazil may not be permitted to visit areas of Austria and Germany this summer, Louis S. Kelly, travel American Express Company, said yeaterday on his return aboard Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, after a Six-week survey of European travel conditions.

If the voluntary hospitals are to survive their present crisis they must become the community's responsibility. This is the opinion of leading hospital authorities, according to the survey of voluntary hospitals made by this newspaper, the last article of which appears today.

The Communist party in New York State paid its first penalty yesterday for its consistent declination to re-establish itself as a legal political party and come under the provisions of the state election law governing political parties.

PRAGUE, Wednesday, Feb. 25 -The "action committees" of Communist Premier Klement Gottwald were taking over authority in the capital and throughout Czechoslovakia yesterday in what looked like a revolution. The country was rapidly being turned into a "People's Front" nation of the typical Eastern European variety.

ALBANY, 6 Feb. 24. The Assembly adopted today Governor Dewey's record budget for the state's 1948-49 fiscal year, calling for appropriations of $801,106,080. This was $1,507,806 beyond Mr. Dewey's original request in his budget message of last Jan. 30.

Gen. T. S. Airey, commander of the Anglo-American forces guarding Trieste, reports to the United Nations that the five-month-old Free Territory is now a dead city, rotting away into a plague-spot. There is not a note of encouragement in his entire report.

In the first concrete proposal to be put before the Little Assembly the United States has urged that the United Nations carry out the resolution of the General Assembly on Korea, despite Russian defiance, and proceed with nation-wide elections, where these are possible, as a first step toward the restoration of Korean independence.

LONDON, Feb. 24 --- The United States-British-French conference held some cautious conversations today on the relationship of Western Germany to the European Recovery Program. The Benelux countries --- Belgium, the Netherland and Luxembourg---which today accepted an invitation to join the conference, wfil appear tomorrow, and since all economic problems concern them it was not possible to get far today.

After studying three acts of "Where Stars Walk," which the Irish players acted at the Mansfield last evening, it is not possible to swear that Micheal Mac Liammoir believes in fairies. Probably he does. For he is under no compulsion to write about them, and he has.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United States expressed conditional willingness today to consult with other great powers under the Charter of the United Nations on the possible constitution of an international armed force to preserve peace and order in Palestine.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 24 Dr. Benedykt Elmer, 65 year-old Polish Minister to the Netherlands and his wife were driven out of their rsidence here last night under threat of force by employes of the Polish Legation, acting on orders from Warsaw.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -The screen version of "The Turquoise," Anya Seton's 1946 novel about Santa Fe, N.M., in the Eighteen Nineties, will go before the camera late next month, with Viveca Lindfors and Dennis Morgan in the leading roles, if they are available, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- The rise in retail clothing prices, expected to continue throughout the year, can be checked only by increased output per worker in the garment industry, Bertram J. Cahn, president of B. Kuppenheimer Co., said today.

Resistance to higher semi-finished steel prices announced last week was reported to be very small throughout industrial circles here yesterday, according to leading purchasing agents for New York companies making finished iron and steel goods with an annual output of more than $200,000,000.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 24 -- Machine-gun fire was trained tonight on British headquarters in the King David Hotel, apparently from Abu Tor, an Arab section, in the course of wild outbursts of shooting.

Years ago -- in fact, when the tribe lived in the river valley -- there were some whose business it was to report on the stages of the river and the likelihood of floods. They were very competent, these river men. Under file leadership of one Ike and another Omar they studied rivers and devoted their full time to that particular task.

Fritz Reiner, who announced in Pittsburgh yesterday that he would not return to lead the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, will be one of the principal conductorsh) 0*0*0*iat the Metropolitan Opera next season, it was learned here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 - Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, today was drafting a reply to an ultimatum from national headquarters of the Congress of Industrial Organizations impliying that he must adhere to CIO policies or step out as CIO regional director for northern California.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 24 -- After two weeks of often heated debate the Canadian Government emergency measures bill for the conservation of dollar exchange reserves was passed in the House of Commons today, by 102 to 92. The vote showed one of the smallest majorities that the Government has had on a major issue.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 23 Christianity's gravest problem is the "tremendous" grip by communism on the youth of Asia, the Rev. Dr. Lloyd S. Ruland of New York, secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in She United States of America, declared here tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Willie Pep successfully defended his world featherweight championship tonight before 10,000 rain-drenched fans by knocking out Humberto Sierra of Cuba after 22 seconds of the tenth of a scheduled 15-round fight in the Orange Bowl Stadium.

To the ballet's long list of Giselle add now the name of Alexandra Danilova, who made her debut in what is perhaps the most famous of all ballerina roles with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center last night. Frederic Franklin made his bow as Albrecht at the same time and Mary Ellen Moylan danced her first Myrtha.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered today the first election under the Taft-Hartley Act in a plant where a strike is in progress.

Continued high production and maintenance of good labor relations during 1948 were forecast yesterday for the paper and paperboard industry at the annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association and affiliated organizations in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Knickerbocker Village Tenants Association, fighting a proposed rent increase of 12 per cent for the 1,600-unit housing development, is taking its case out of the hands of the Area Rent Director and has arranged for a hearing in Washington on Friday, Philip Good, head of the association, announced last night.

Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, was the guest of honor last night at the first annual dinner of the New York Sportscasters' Association, held in the taproom of the Ruppert Brewery, 1639 Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A House subcommittee on small business began today an investigation of the Department of Commerce's administration of export controls by calling for the personnel files of every employe of the department's Office of International Trade who "has anything to do with the granting of export licenses."

HAVANA, Feb. 24 The United States today put forward its "final position" in its long controversy with Latin-American and other economically undeveloped countries at the United Nations trade conference here.

AT about the time of the Quebec Conference (August, 1943), a portion of the Soviet press suddenly put forth the idea that, although a meeting of the chiefs of the American, British and Russian Governments was impossible because of Stalin's pre occupation with directing the stupendous battle in the east against Germany, a meeting of the Foreign Ministers could well and fruitfully be held.

IN his neat and quiet way Peter de Polnay is a novelist of unusual professional competence. Quite persuasive in his understanding of human psychology and briskly sure of himself in his story-telling, Mr. de Polnay can be counted upon to produce superior fiction. But there is a cold-blooded quality to his work, an ironic detachment, which makes his novels intellectually interesting without being emotionally moving.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Candidates for office who "pander" to the Communist vote were assailed by the American Bar Association in a resolution passed today by the association's House of Delegates at its midyear session here.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A mother's repeated warning to her five children to stay off a porch roof of their tiny mountaintop home was blamed by a son for the death of four of them in a fire today. A housekeeper also died.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United Nations drew up a contract here today under which it will make "easy installments," ending with a 1982 payment, in paying back the proposed United States loan of $65,000,000 for construction of the U.N. capital.

The National Biscuit Company, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, reported yesterday in its annual statement to stockholders that its volume of business in 1947 reached a high record with peak sales of $263,893,660, up $43,698,172 over the 1946 total.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- By a majority of twenty-three votes, the Schuman Cabinet today obtained a vote of confidence from the National Assembly on its schedule for reimbursing the owners of the demonetized 5,000-franc notes. The vote was 291 to 268.

Sales of New York City department stores increased 35 per cent in the week ended Feb. 21, compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash report" of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The sharp increase was mainly attributed to six shopping days last week, compared with only five a year ago, when Washington's Birthday occurred on a Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Gov. William F. Tuck of Virginia will take first direct action in the revolt against the Truman Administration that is surging through the South by asking the state legislature to rewrite the law to permith)0*0*0*iselection of uninstructed Presidential electors.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 -- All of the elements of a major scandal involving intracircuit betting by players of the National Hockey League were unfolded today with the disclosure of details leading up to the arrest a few days ago of a convicted bank robber.

Having failed successfully to resurrect "Ghosts" last week, Louis J. Singer and the American Repertory Theatre tried again with Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler" last night at the Cort. The unhappy conclusion must again be that this "Hedda Gabler" lacks the power to come across the footlights and, leaves one with the impression that perhaps it should be left on the shelves of the library.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 24. -- In a swift session of less than two hours, the bizonal area's Economic Council, now doubled in size to 104 persons, reconstituted itself today as the "Lower House" of the new economic parliament.

The current musical season is setting a record for performances of Palestinian music. Many programs have featured it and the total was increased still further last night with an all-Palestinian program presented by Joachim Stutchevsky, cellist-composer, at Carnegie Recital Hall.

LONDON, Feb. 24 Angry members of Parliament demanded today that the British Government take harsh measures to halt the killings of Britons in Palestine and to punish those who had spread the accusation that Britons were involved in the bombing of Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem.
Walter Florell presented spring hats in many silhouettes yesterday at the Ritz.

Four men, two of them described as tank truck drivers for an oil company and two as helpers on the trucks, were being questioned last night at the Kings County District Attorney's office about a complaint by the oil company that 1,000,000 gallons of No. 2 household fuel oil had been diverted by thirteen of its drivers from the company's regular customers to the drivers' personal customers during the recent oil crisis.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- New England bankers, called to attend an "antiinflation meeting" by the American Bankers Association, today were counseled to lend cautiously andh)0*0*0*ionly when loans would not add to inflationary pressures.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 24 -- The first session of the enlarged Economic Council was held today in a bare hall in a dilapidated but still impressive stock exchange, the symbol of Frankfort's former importance as a financial capital. The hundred and four members, including the first, five women in the Council, sat in rows .behind unpainted wooden tables covered with sheets.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- In the view of informed but unofficial British and Arab circles in London, the latest United States proposals for dealing with the Palestine situation are as naive as the earlier American assumption that partition could be imposed, without military force.

Hanns Eisler, composer and brother of Gerhart Eisler, who recently arranged to leave the United States voluntarily, found yesterday that it is almost as difficult to get out of the United States as it is to stay in.

MIAMI, Fla, Feb. 24 -- Pipette, who cost John Barry Ryan Jr. $38,000 at a Belmont Park auction last year, made another return on that investment at Hialeah Park today when she led all the way in a $4,000 purse that served as a tune-up for next week's Black Helen Handicap.

World shipbuilding last year dropped slightly under the 1946 volume despite the fact that nine of the eleven leading maritime countries launched a considerable larger tonnage of merchant vessels than in 1946, according to the yearly review of launchings released here yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 22 to 83 points net higher, with the March position leading the advance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- An annual budget of eight billion dollars is necessary to provide an adequate school program for the nation's children, educators attending the annual conference of the American Association of School Administrators declared here today.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. submitted yesterday the highest bid for $6,000,000 of sanitary sewer plant and system bonds of San Antonio, Tex. The bid designated 3s due from 1949 to 1967 and 2 3/4s due from 1958 to 1968, and represented an interest cost of 2.798 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The European Recovery Program ran today into a new Congressional hurdle, with the fate of the American Merchant Marine being raised as a fighting issue. Men at key Senate points predicted that this obstacle might not be taken by the ERP, even though it concerns a concededly vital factor in the shipment of recovery program supplies abroad.

Even if the Long Island Rail Road receives the full amount of the permanent fare increases it is seeking, it will have a deficit in net income at the end of this year of $3,887,000. This figure was included in a forty-six page brief filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission by Richard R. Bongartz and Louis J. Carruthers, attorneys for the Long Island.
The initial sentence of your editorial entitled "Storm over the Falklands" in your edition of Feb. 20 is, perhaps, misleading to the ordinary casual reader.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The Czechoslovak Government has ordered its consulates to refrain, until further notice, from issuing any visas to persons desiring to enter Czechoslovakia, it was disclosed by Czechoslovak officials here today.
The settlement of a persistent labor dispute in the construction industry was announced yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city's labor relations division.

Continued brisk business marked the second day of the thirty-fourth semi-annual New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels yesterday but exhibitors reported buying more cautious than on Washington's birthday when the show opened.

Complete accord between the Red Cross and the five local county medical societies on their compromise plan to establish a free blood donor program for the city was assured last night as the Queens and Bronx County societies approved the text of the proposed agreement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers went on trial today on charges of inducing a business associate to lie to Congress.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday he had accepted the voluntary resignation of Mrs. Beatrice Feingold Behrman as assistant to Mrs. Crystal M. Potter, Second Deputy Welfare Commissioner.

Showing continued improvement yesterday from the heart condition that hospitalized him last week, Mayor O'Dwyer received a telegram from President Truman expressing the hope that he would soon be able to resume full-scale activity.

There is less moral confusion among young people than among their parents, it was agreed yesterday by five speakers who took part in a forum in the junior League clubhouse. 221 East Seventyfirst Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents began questioning executives of sixteen leading steel companies today as the Administration; by order of President Truman, undertook a three-way investigation of last week's price increase of about $5 a ton.

Leonid Andreyev once wrote a tale about an old offender who grew to love his Russian prison after spending many years within its walls. Released by a kindly administrator, he was unable to cope with the problems of life in his changed community, and came back to his prison to spend his last days.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Following is the text of the statement on the Palestine question made today by Warren R. Austin, United States Representative, before the United Nations Security Council:

Unranked Lester Hirschfield registered the first upset of the Eastern indoor tennis singles championships last night. He defeated fifth-seeded Nathan Goldstein of Brooklyn in a fourthround encounter on the Metropolitan Tennis Club courts in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

Friends of William Katzell and Joseph Kipness assure us that the producers are really serious about putting on a joint musical. The one referred to is "Alfred the Average," equipped with a book by Hollywood's Epstein brothers -Julius and Philip G. -- and songs by Harold J. Rome.

WASHINGTON, Feb 24 -- Southern Governors today presented their proposed fifteen-state compact for regional schools of higher education to the Senators and Representatives of their states. Accompanying the program was a request for immediate Congressional sanction.

Several sections of the stock market attempted yesterday to push forward, with only limited success due to the lack of buying power. There were few price changes in excess of fractions and the combined averages rose 0.28 point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Acceding to the plea of high British sources, the American Federation of Labor today reversed itself and decided to send representatives to an international trade union conference on the Marshall Plan in London on March 8-10.

Fira Benenson, always a good designer, has truly come into her own. In her spring and summer collection, exhibited yesterday morning, she has expressed to the fullest her knowledge and experience in the art of dressmaking. Every line and detail is carefully thought out.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United States policy statement on Palestine was studied with the greatest care today by delegates and officials at the United Nations, and there seemed to beh)igeneral agreement on the follow ing conclusions:

Columbia and Yale, meeting for the ninety-third time since 1902, will clash on the former's floor in the outstanding college basketball game on the localscene tonight. Heading a triple-header at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Fordham will oppose Manhattan.

According to a grapevine report from the Outer Banks, dispatched by Bill Sharpe, surfcsaters who arrive there this spring for the big red drum are going to be amazed at the "up and coming" conditions.
The New York Rangers will attempt to equal their National Hockey League point total of last season, 50, when they meet the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- An appreciable swing away from the extreme Left Wing parties and toward the I Christian Democrats has been revealed in the just concluded election of labor union officials in the Confederation of Textile Workers in the Province of Milan.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Holy Cross Crusaders tonight downed a hard-fighting Loyola of Chicago quintet, 62 -- 46, before a crowd of 7,045 at Boston Arena.

The Wonder millions of persons of in this country Stairs whose only concern about stairs is whether they are steep or narrow and who probably would express surprise ff told that there are, at a conservative estimate, thousands of other persons to whom stairs are wonderful and rare.

The Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team has made application to the Federal Communications Commission for a new frequency modulation radio station, it was learned yesterday. If granted, the licenseh)0*0*0*ireportedly would be the first to be issued to a bail club.

Traditional Italian crafts and advanced modern designs with a strong leaning toward the international school are presented side by side in an exhibition that opened yesterday at the House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Forty-ninth Street.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- The Italian police arrested four Russians and ten other Slavs on Dec. 30, 1947, on a request from the Soviet Government, which accused them of war crimes. Several others whose custody the Russians had demanded escaped.

The City Council voted 14 to 4 yesterday to refuse a seat to Simon W. Gerson, legislative representative of the New York State Communist party, as the Communist successor to the late Peter V. Cacchione of Brooklyn.
Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the World Trade Corporation, issued a statement yesterday criticizing the city waterfront rehabilitation plan of the Port of New York Authority.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The tensest atmosphere yet felt in this international headquarters accompanied the long-awaited Palestine debate that opened today in the United Nations Security Council as disrupting crowds twice forced the Council's president to rap angrily for silence.

Merril Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane reported yesterday that net income last year fell $4,388,698 to $1,827,952, due mainly to a smaller volume of security trading on the security exchanges. The firm and its partners are members of forty exchanges and have eighty-eight memberships on exchanges in the United States, Canada and Great Britain.

Reduced activity in the dress manufacturing industry is reflected in attempts to abrogate rayon textile contracts, it was learned yesterday. A marked increase in arbitration cases and refusal to accept deliveries is already apparent, according to fabric trade sources.
WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Feb. 24 Judge Charles F. Wennerstrum of the Iowa Supreme Court remained firm today in his conviction that "justice had been denied" in the German war crimes trials.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Orders freezing prices on practically all goods not already price-controlled as essentials were issued by the Board of Trade today. The new regulations became effective March 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee trimmed $131,542,889 today from President Truman's money request for nonmilitary functions of the Army and sent the bill to the House floor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- An agreement under which Norway settled her war-time lend-lease account of $47,000,000 with the United States was signed today by Secretary of State George C. Marshall and Ambassador Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne.

ABOARD U.S.S. GREENWICH BAY, in the Caribbean, Feb. 24 President Truman today disclosed that he had ordered appropriate Federal agencies to investigate the reasons why the steel industry recently decided to raise the prices of steel.

The Rev. Fabian Flynn, delegate in Germany for War Relief Servicesh)0*0*0*iof the National Catholic Welfare Conference, sailed for Germany yesterday on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam to continue the work of the agency, it was announced by the conference offices here.

Events tonight: Verdi's "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Wollf Chamber Players andh)0*0*0*iFaye Elizabeth Smith, soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichord, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40; Brotherhood Week concert, sponsored by United Nations Festivals, Kenneth Spencer, basso; New York Junior Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Walter Mantani, and New York Interracial Singers, conducted by Clifford Kemp, Central Needle Trades High School, 8:30.
The custo-made collection seen at Jay Thorpe yesterday divided honors between Wilson Folmar and Aileen Rice, who contributed a group of handsome handknits.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The Soviet Union today blasted the Marshall Plan as an "American weapon for economic and political expansion" designed to split Europe and give this country control over the economies of Western European countries.

ATHENS, Feb. 24 - Lieut. Gen. William A. Van Fleet, the new leader of the United States military mission to Greece, said today on his arrival that he intended to visit units in the zone of the fighting with guerrillas as soon as he had become acquainted with conditions in Athens.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A spokesman for the Labor government took issue today with Henry A. Wallace's assertion to the House Foreign Affairs Committee that nationalization of Great Britain's steel industry had been indefinitely postponed as the result of American pressure.

To help alleviate traffic congestion in the garment area the present ten-hour no-parking period there will be extended to fifteen hours, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday. The new restriction will become effective next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb 24 -- Recommendations for overhauling the "present cumbersome" methods of calling the National Guard into Federal service were offered to the Gray board today. The witnesses were Maj. Gen. Ellard A. Walsh, president of the National Guard Association and former commander of the Thirty-fourth Division, and Maj. Gen. M. A. Reckord, head of the Adjutants General Association and former commander of the Twenty-ninth Division.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP) The Assembly unanimously approved today a bill mandating American history instruction in public high schools.

Directors of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company yesterday declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable March 15. This is the first distribution on the common stock since the plan of reorganization was consummated last April.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 -- Registration statements covering $50,000,000 of debentures. $17,090,000 of first mortgage bonds and 115,000 shares of preferred stock have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday that the Marshall Plan was intended to block Communist domination of Western Europe, but that the Russians were wrong in charging that the United States was seeking to dominate Western Europe.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- Harold E. Stassen, aspirant for theh)0*0*0*iRepublican Presidential nomination, urged tonight that this country "take the lead in calling a major amending convention in 1950 to rewrite the United Nations Charter."

Formal disclosure of the name of the banking institution which has made a bid to take over Continental Bank and Trust Company in competition with the earlier proposal by Chemical Bank and Trust Company is likely to be made in the next day or two.
The election of Arthur H. Rogow as president and a director of Eversharp, Inc., was announced yesterday by Martin L. Straus chairman of the board.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 -The number of candidates for the$100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on Saturday isn't determinedyet, but the dappled iron grayfrom Argentina, Talon, remainsj the solid favorite.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 The Government section of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Headquarters today took a hand in the troubled Japanese Cabinet situation with the assertion that the election of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida as Premier was "thoroughly democratic and in complete harmony with specific provisions of the present constitution."
The American Council for Judaism, in a message yesterday to Secretary of State Marshall, called for full implementation by the United Nations of whatever decision is reached on Palestine.

Spurred on by mild weather and criticism of the rate of removal of extra rubbish bequeathed by the snow, Sanitation Department workers yesterday turned the tables on the public by opening so many hydrants that lowered water pressure caused many faucets in the city to run dry.

Hospitals giving blood under the Red Cross Blood Program in the city should receive between $7 and $10 a pint to cover the cost of testing the blood for the patient, Murray Sargent, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill to make lynching a Federal crime. The vote was 4 to 2. The measure was sponsored by Representative Clifford P. Case of New Jersey. It contains some provisions of a similar bill by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican, of New York.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Stud Poker, who missed by a head in the Widener Handicap last Saturday, made it by a nose in the $15,000 added Miami Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park today -- and set a new American record of 2:29-1/5 for a mile and a half on the grass.
William J. Hogan has been appointed manager of the New York office of the Miehle Printing Press and Manufacturing Company. He has been with the company for twenty-three years.

After announcing the signing of the veteran Arky Vaughan and the youthful Gene Mauch, President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers yesterday left in his private plane for Vero Beach, Fla., with the Brooklyn holdout list reduced to Peewee Reese, Eddie Stanky and Bruce Edwards.

Nelson A. Rockefeller said last night that the principles of brotherhood, on which the National Conference of Christians and Jews was organized formed the true basis on which the world can achieve a peace which "respects individual freedom and human dignity everywhere."

Emphasis on hip detail, interesting use of buttons and exquisite laces for evening wear were highlights of the custom-made collection previewed yesterday at Milgrim. In this presentation, the aim was to prune off all heavy exaggeration, leaving fashions gracious and graceful.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 25 (AP) -- To Charles (Bud) Wilkinson has been offered the head football coaching job at Yale, Dr. George L. Cross, president of the University of Oklahoma, said tonight. "It is my understanding that the job has been offered to Bud," Dr. Cross said.

On leaving Elizabeth Arden's second floor fashion salon yesterday afternoon one carried away the memory of enormously full chiffon skirts of pastel tint swaying over taffeta underskirts; of palest blue taffeta draped into pouffs and bustle loops over the hips; of a sun-gold satin jacket over a silk net gown.

Dumb-waiter dinners are the latest proposal in cookery. As the "househusband's" key turns in the lock on an evening the housewife pulls up the meal prepared in a central kitchen below. Those who don't live in apartments need not feel the Modern Age has left them behind.

After a year's departure, the Goodall round-robin invitation golf tournament will return to the metropolitan district May 6 to 9 with the entire gate receipts going to New Rochelle Hospital. Elmer Ward, sponsor, yesterday announced sixteen leading professionals would be invited to compete at the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 25 -- A crisis is threatened in the Liberal party as the result of a meeting of leaders here to determine the extent of cooperation in the Pan-American conference next month, and cooperation with the Conservative Government by Liberal members of the coalition Cabinet, and the support of Liberal Ministers by Liberals in Congress.

Received formal United States resolution calling for a Big Five committee to decide what to do about Palestine crisis, and heard the Egyptian representative warn that Arab states would "rush to the rescue" of Palestine if the United Nations sent a force there.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation to the Conference on Trade and Employment, today cabled for a showdown on his proposals to settle the major outstanding issues with Latin-American and other economically undeveloped countries.
PRAGUE, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The new Czechoslovak Cabinet, as announced today, follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Establishment of an Economic Commission for Latin America, to help coordinate the economies of the twenty republics, speed up industrialization and raise living standards, was approved here this afternoon by the Economic and Social Council.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin firmly stood his ground today against the claims of Argentina and Chile to ownership of the Falkland Islands dependencies in the Antarctic.

The National Gypsum Company, in its twenty-second annual report, mailed yesterday to stockholders, announced that sales of $51,764,236 for 1947 exceeded the 1946 volume by $13,707,414 or 36 per cent and that earnings increased $1,249,168. Net profit for the twelve months ended with December amounted to $5,273,120 equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.89 a share of common stock, compared with $4,023,952 or $2.21 a common share for 1946.

Despite a belated spurt by the Rams, Manhattan's basketball team turned back Fordham, 63 -- 56, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. The Jaspers saw a 20-point margin with ten minutes left to play whittled down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Pan American Union transmitted to the Governments of the twenty-one American republics today a preliminary draft of a proposed basic agreement to govern economic relations among them on an enlightened and cooperative plane.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission today cleared the way for the Railway Express Agency to increase its rates on newspapers, magazines and a number of other items.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Tinian, from which the B-29's of the Twentieth Air Force mounted their early strikes against Japan, is to be the scene of the first attempt to improve the agricultural welfare of the region, the Navy Department announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- A small minority within the Labor party has formally voiced its disagreement with the British Government's policy of doing nothing to assist in the formation of an international military force to implement the partition of Palestine.

WARSAW, Feb. 25 -- Rumania's Premier Petru Groza, accompanied by Foreign Minister Ana Pauker and other officials of his Government, will arrive in Warsaw tomorrow morning to sign a cultural agreement with Poland and to begin talks for a military alliance.

Baseball practice began at Fordham yesterday as twenty candidates for battery positions, most of them returnees, reported to Coach Jack Coffey. Naming New York University as "the team to beat" in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference, the Ram mentor declared at the close of the first drill that Fordham would be a strong contender for the title this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, served notice on the National Labor Relations Board today that it was withdrawing from hearings on unfair labor practices charges filed against it.

The transatlantic liners Washington, Saturnia and Sobieski sailed from North River piers yesterday with a combined passenger complement of 531 persons, compared to an actual combined carrying capacity of 3,432 persons.

Your editorial of Feb. 18 states that the argument of Robert Hutchins, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick and others who appeal to the Rules Committee for postponement of action on U.M.T. "is not a strong one."

The novelty of Martha Graham's program last night in her season at Maxine Elliott's Theatre was the first appearance of Ethel Winter, a leading member of the company, in Miss Graham's monodrama, "Salem Shore," which previously only she herself has danced.

After announcing that net, income of $48,806,417 last year was the greatest in the history of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Gwilym A. Price, president, declared yesterday at a press conference that private capital can be attracted for additional industrial investment only by immediate over-all tax relief, particularly for the corporation and the investor.

A man arrested yesterday charged with having used matches, lighted cigarettes and broken glass to torture a potential victim of robbery in the Hotel Alamac for fifteen hours last Monday and Tuesday, became a murder suspect last night.

Directors of the Packard Motor Car Company yesterday declared at a meeting in Detroit a dividend of 15 cents a share payable to stockholders on March 29. Last year the company distributed a similar amount on April 1, the only payment of 1947.

PRAGUE, Feb. 25 -- President Eduard Benes gave Communist Premier Klement Gottwald permission this afternoon to install a Communist dominated Czechoslovak Government of the type found in other Eastern European countries now considered satellites of the Soviet Union.

Because of the public-inspired, Congress-abetted rush to demobilize at the end of the war, the United States Navy, desperate for men to keep the fleet manned for its peacetime duties, dropped its enlistment span to two years. It is being faced now with the consequences of the action that was forced upon it then.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, ruled today that a House Labor subcommittee should receive testimony about an alleged Communist plot to seize control of Hollywood movie studios.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Hammer Bill doubling the pay of the 206 members of the State Legislature. The new salary for the legislators, effective at once but not retroactive, is $5,000. It is the first pay increase for the Legislature since 1927, when the salary of Senators and Assemblymen was raised from $1,500 a year to $2,500.

"IRREGULAR GENTLEMAN,"* by James Warner Bellah, is a gaudy and entertaining autobiography. Mr. Bellah, an American writer of moderate age, has been around places where exciting things were happening and he has a facility for recalling what he has seen in a lively and pungent way. He can also make the apparently commonplace look vital and important, which is an appealing gift.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 25 -- Federal Judge Luther M. Swygert, in a Circuit Court decision handed down here today, upheld the constitutionality of the Taft-Hartley law's provision that the National Labor Relations Board may seek injunctions while labor-management dispute hearings are in progress before the board.

City College and Long Island University, definite possibilities for post-season tournament berths, are favored to defeat Brooklyn College and Seton Hall, respectively, in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Beavers' record is 14 and 3 for the season, while the Blackbirds have won 15 and lost 4.

In his letter to Legislative leaders and in his "package" of legislation introduced at Albany yesterday Mayor O'Dwyer returns with a vengeance to the battle for more state aid for New York City. More aid to education, reimbursement for the indigent sick and the care of neglected and dependent children, and an upward revision of per capita aid to cities under the Moore plan are among features of the package.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Earl K. Long accepted the Democratic nomination as Governor of Louisiana today with a promise of $50 a month "for the poor old gray-haired folks." The brother of the late Huey P. Long said he would put the old-age pension into effect "if I don't accomplish another thing."

Prospects for solid support of Mayor O'Dwyer's 1948 legislative "package," including his higher fare bill, by the city's Democratic delegation at Albany appeared to be brighter yesterday as the result of a long conference held in the Mayor's suite at Bellevue Hospital.

The Metropolitan Opera wasted no time in putting its latest tenor find on the stage. Less than a week ago Giuseppe Di Stefano arrived from Milan in Italy, and last night he made his debut at the Opera House as the Duke in "Rigoletto."

A dangerous precedent for care of veterans will be set if three bills now in the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee are approved by Congress. These bills are House Concurrent Resolution 54, House Resolution 3814 and Senate Bill 1035. The first would force the Veterans Administration to take over and operate Shick General Hospital, Clinton, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A representative of the New York Port Authority told the House subcommittee on small business today that the Authority was opposed to granting export licenses on the basis of price criteria, as set up by the Department of Commerce, because it would result in discrimination against the port and the loss of millions of dollars.

When the major steel companies marked up their prices on semi-finished products a week or so ago, it directly affected only about 4 per cent of all the steel they sell. But that action, however insignificant it may have been from the standpoint of the industry, has now become a matter of national interest and importance.

Daniel Francis Ahearn, author of "How to Commit a Murder and Get Away With It" and with a record of eighteen arrests and three felony convictions, got away with a disorderly conduct charge in mid-Manhattan Court yesterday but was arrested a moment later on a 1947 assault and robbery charge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- "Tokyo Joe," a photoplay by Steve Fisher about a group of discharged fliers who establish air freight lines in occupied Japan, has been purchased for a reported $80,000 by Mark Hellinger Productions, independent producing company of the late Mark Hellinger, which has been taken over by Humphrey Bogart, Robert Lord and A. Morgan Maree.

Mrs. Henry A. Wallace made her first appearance here yesterday as wife of the third party candidate for the Presidency. After accepting a bouquet of roses at a rally of the Brooklyn Women for Wallace, she quoted her husband as saying that "women's votes will play a more important part in this year's election than in any other campaign in American history because they want peace for their children and grandchildren."

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, threatened today to bring "chaos" to the commercial printing industry in Chicago unless the employers acceded to the union demands.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Edward Nash Hurley Jr., chairman of the board of the Thor Corporation and a leading Chicago industrialist for many years, died today in his Wheaton (Ill.) estate. His age was 55.

The common nature of the military problems in China and in Greece was underscored this week by Congressional reaction to the President's request for $570,000,000 in economic aid to the Chiang Kai-shek government.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, which bought the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines from the Government last year for $143,270,000, announced yesterday that operation of the natural gas pipelines from May to December resulted in a net income of $1,670, 329 after taxes of $2,694,079.

Francis M. Johnson, area rent director of the Office of Rent Control, was reported yesterday to have said that under Federal regulations an increase of only 17 1/4 cents a room a month could be justified for the 1,585 apartments at Knickerbocker Village.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 25 (AP) -- The University of Kentucky has accepted an invitation to participate in the Eastern play-offs of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament in Madison Square Garden March 18-20.

THE three Foreign Ministers met in the Kremlin on the evening of Oct. 18 with every appearance of cordiality and cooperation and a strict attendance to business. We quickly agreed on no speech-making, on the advisers who would sit in with us, on the meeting place and on the first communique to be issued.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 25 -- President Truman fought that familiar inward fight against seasickness today and won out by staying in his bed while the yacht Williamsburg made a rough trip across the Windward Passage. His face lobster red and his nose peeling, the Chief Executive arrived here tonight after winding up his Caribbean tour with an inspection of the big United States naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Foreign Minister Bidault, addressing a luncheon of the Anglo-American Press Association today, declared that the Czechoslovak crisis was evolving in a manner extremely dangerous for France and Europe, and that serious results might be expected before long.

Once again the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is figuring in proposals for new bond issues of local government agencies. While the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is pondering RFC proposals for refunding debt now held by the Federal Agency and for additional borrowings to complete the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, word comes from the West Coast that the Washington Toll Bridge Authority may invoke the credit facilities of the RFC for financing construction of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge.
A slump for the first two months of the year amounting to about 50 per cent of sales volumes for the comparable 1947 period has hit tool and equipment distributors here, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Heavyweight champion Joe Louis, plump but natty in a blue-striped suit, made a new hit today in London, where he already had been popular for sharing the buzz bombs in khaki.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- A shift in the allocations of coal among European countries to make possible an increase in over-all European steel production was approved today by the Coal Allocations Committee of the Economic Commission for Europe.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- The players, if any, of National Hockey League teams who allegedly engaged in gambling through the offices of a Detroit racketeer will be banned for life if found guilty, it was stated today by Clarence S. Campbell, league president.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The fall of democratic Czechoslovakia, easternmost bastion of parliamentary democracy in Central Europe, has produced anxiety, bitterness and surprise in British Governmental and diplomatic circles.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 25 -- American relief credits and the prospect of larger scale economic aid to the Chinese Government have not arrested the panicky flight from the Chinese dollar. Amid a horde of wild rumors the black market exchange rate here skyrocketed today to $328,000 (Chinese) for $1 (U.S.) and rice was quoted by dealers at $3,000,000 (Chinese) a picul (about 135 pounds).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 18: Decreases of $157,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $275,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $235,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $200,000,000 in borrowings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate whisked through a one month extension of the existing rent control law today, following up swiftly yesterday's enactment of the measure by the House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The resignation of directors from two Government-controlled rayon yarn mills was attributed today "primarily" to a disagreement over pricing policies.

Henry A. Wallace, third party candidate for President, yesterday denounced the United States proposal for "consultation" on the possible formation of an international armed force to preserve peace and order in Palestine as "a complete sellout of the people of Palestine and a serious blow at the United Nations."

As the result of a Communist revolution which has forced President Benes to acquiesce in something that was "not in complete accordance with his wishes," Czechoslovakia has today become a totalitarian police state under a Communist dictatorship and the last flickering lights of freedom that shimmered through the Iron Curtain are going out.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 -- Jews raided the British military court building here today and killed one Arab auxiliary policeman, wounded another and escaped. An effort to destroy the building failed because the home-made incendiary bombs did not ignite.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Territorial rights today were termed the big obstacle to admitting Negro leagues to organized baseball. President George M. Trautman of the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues said most of the Negro clubs played in major and minor league parks in territory controlled by those clubs.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Mrs. Dorothy Evans, 23 years old, and her three children ranging in age from 1 to 3 died today when a three-alarm fire here swept a row of old two-story brick-front houses on Watson Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, told Congress today that the Marshall Plan might bring on a domestic depression far more serious in its consequences than the combined effect of European economic collapse and further expansion of communism on the Continent.
Accounts Stumpp and Walter Company, seeds, to Bourne Associates, Inc., effective March 1. Newspaper, radio, trade paper and consumer publications will be used.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week were increased 2,123,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end the stocks amounted to 109,886,000 barrels, compared with 107,763,000 a week earlier and 101,832,000 on Feb. 22, 1947.

The form charts were upheld yesterday as the round of eight was filled in the Eastern indoor men's singles tennis championships. All five of the seeded entrants who saw action on the Metropolitan Tennis Club courts located in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory captured their fourth-round matches without the loss of a set.

Twenty-three paraplegic World War II veterans -- everyone of whom had been seriously wounded and decorated for heroism -- demonstrated last night that the wheelchair offered no handicap when it came to playing bang-up basketball.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Following is the text of the resolution on the Palestine question presented to the United Nations Security Council today by Warren R. Austin of the United States:

LAKE SUCCESS N.Y., Feb. 25 -- In a rare display of unanimity, the United Nations Economic and Social Council unanimously endorsed today the work of the Children's Emergency Fund, which is supplying milk and supplementary food to 3,715,000 children in twelve European countries.
A possible basis for settling at least part of the Wall Street strike threat was put forward yesterday by representatives of the New York Cotton Exchange.

Despite bad weather this winter the domestic airlines have taken long strides to eliminate delays and improve the regularity of schedules, representatives of United Air Lines and American Airlines told a forum of travel agents and airline representatives yesterday in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The political upheavel in Czechoslovakia may blow the lid off secret documents explaining Soviet-American wartime arrangements for liberating that nation. These papers would supply Washington's official answers to such questions as why American forces did not aid in the liberation of the Czech capital, Prague, from the Germans and why the United States troops stopped short just inside the Czech western border.

Charging that the speculator has replaced the business man, merchant and the farmer, Joseph J. Rosen, president of the Butter and Egg Merchants Association, Inc, urged last night that the Government place restrictions on the futures boards of the commodities markets. He spoke at a meeting of the association, at which new officers were installed in the Hotel New Yorker.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 25 -- The "voluntary aloofness" of the Roman Catholic Church from Protestant evangelical Christianity was deplored here today by the Rev. Dr. Georges A. Barrois, assistant Professor of Biblical Literature and Theology at Princeton Theological Seminary.

The New York State Banking Department announced yesterday that it has admitted to the list of investments legal for savings banks fifteen bond issues aggregating $187,405,000. Included are $25,905,000 of railroad equipment trust obligations, including $11,685,000 of the Delaware, Lackawana Western Railroad; $12,600,000 of the New Yor Central Railroad, and $1,620,000 of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The proposed voluntary agreement for brewers under the Anti-Inflation Act. which has been pending since the meeting of that industry held here on Jan. 20. was announced today by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson.

Striking cable workers filed an action in Federal Court yesterday to compel two overseas communications companies to bargain with their Congress of Industrial Organizations union and to collect $1,000,000 in damages.

Cotton textile sellers at the primary level have adopted an attitude of watchful waiting with few goods being offered at present, a check of the Worth Street market revealed yesterday. Sitting, on orders which will utilize plant capacity through the second quarter and a good part of the third quarter, mills have indicated that they are prepared to wait out a period of uncertain pricing.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Feb. 26 -- The draft constitution for India, published today, would reshape the six-months-old Dominion into a "sovereign democratic republic."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Prized invitations for the National Invitation Basketball Tournement, March 11 to 7, at Madison Square Garden, were mailed yesterday, but Asa Bushnell, head of the selection committee, refused to name the lucky teams.

MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- An attack by Henry A. Wallace on Winston Churchill, accusing Britain's war-time Premier of having given "an ultimatum" to the Soviet Union led the liberal dally Manchester Guardian to state today theft "Wallace has long been suspected of having lost his political judgment, he is now losing his respect for truth."

Although the volume of business subsided yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange compared with previous sessions in the last week, prices at the finish were 3 to 19 points net lower than on Tuesday.

In all discussions concerning the European Recovery Program we read or hear about "stability of currencies" and "realistic exchange rates." The free convertibility of currencies, which is more important from the point of view of free economics, is practically never mentioned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Bituminous coal operators today were concerned over the possibility of "unofficial" stoppages by members of the United Mine Workers of America in the immediate future.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association put the association on record today as opposed to creation of an international court of human rights and other proposals connected with the covenant and declaration on human rights as tentatively made by the working group of the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A drastic reorganization of the country's elementary schools, to provide services for all children on a year-round basis, was outlined here today by the country's leading educators. Twenty million public-school pupils would be affected.

The Department of State will welcome suitable documentary or technical films of private companies for distribution overseas in conjunction with its information and educational service, according to Barton W. Underhill, special assistant to the director of the Office of Information and Educational Exchange.

B.Z. Goldberg, a Jewish leader who has traveled in Russia, denied yesterday reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES that anti-Semitism was increasing in Russia, according to a statement released by the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.

The Yankees are on the horns of a dilemma, not to mention where Bill Wight is going to find himself in a day or two. The young southpaw, traded to the White Sox in the deal for Ed Lopat, wasn't reached by Red Patterson to inform him of the deal and Wight was reported driving his car from Healdsburg, Calif., en route to St. Petersburg, Fla.

A Bronx landlord was left wondering yesterday what to do about a one-family house crowded with nineteen persons who had just received judicial advice not to pay their rent. The advice to the tenants came from Municipal Court Justice Agnes M. Craig, as a totally unexpected result of an eviction action filed by the landlord.

George Estin of Boston announced yesterday his retirement from the board of directors of the Alleghany Corporation, effective at the annual meeting of stockholders in May. This announcement followed a detailed statement made earlier at a directors' meeting concerning the paying off by Alleghany of $24,000,000 of shortterm bank loans and the elimination of its prior preferred stock and arrears of dividends through an offer of exchange for Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock.

Four Manhattan College freshmen were caught green-handed and red-faced yesterday. Patiently they had inscribed twenty large "M's" in green and white paint on and near the buildings and streets of Fordham University in the Bronx when they were discovered by police of the Bronx Park Station.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet Union's intention of setting up special industrial enclaves in Austria under the terns of the proposals now being discussed by the deputies of the Foreign Ministers was admitted by Nikolai P. Koktomov, Soviet delegate, at today's meeting.
DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The boom that made fortunes for many used-car dealers appears to have come to at least a temporary halt.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The United States presented a formal resolution to the Security Council today calling for a committee of the Big Five to decide whether the Palestine situation constituted a threat to peace, and, if so, what to do about it.

Direct air service between New York and the Union of South Africa was begun yesterday by Pan American World Airways with the departure from La-Guardia Field of the Clipper Southern Cross. The big four-engine Lockheed Constellation took off for Johannesburg at 5:43 P.M. to carry twenty-one passengers over a 8,512-mile route that cuts a thousand miles off the former course and eliminates a stop at Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- The House rejected today President Truman's proposal to make the Labor Department stronger by giving it control over the United States Employment Service and the Bureau of Employment Security.

The stock market emerged a little further yesterday from its recent set-back, and moderately higher prices appeared in all key sections on the Stock Exchange. Extreme gains were not held in most cases, due more to lack of a continuation of buying than to selling pressure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Scientific research is "the first line of defense" and more money must be devoted to it if the United States is to have air supremacy, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics said in an annual report which President Truman sent to Congress today.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Developments in Czechoslovakia and Palestine coupled with the Board of Trade's first price-freezing order, kept the stock markets here today quiet as the new account opened.

THE companion literary gem to the American League's Red Book, which already has been discussed here, is the National League's Green Book. Editor Charlie Segar, turning out his best job to date, has assembled about every shred of information that could be assembled, with the possible exception of the color of Johnny Mize's eyes, an item which is of little concern to anyone except Mrs. Mize.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Five bills designed to maintain home rule for the state's insurance industry were introduced today in the State Legislature by members of the joint legislative committee on insurance rates and regulations. They are based on a study in the last year, which included hearings here and in New York.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 25 -- The Navy basketball team scored its ninth triumph of the season today by defeating Virginia, 48-41, in a wild contest. The Middies' superior foul shooting provided the margin of victory.
A lieutenant in the Naval Reserve, traveling on orders from the Navy Department, was found strangled yesterday afternoon in his room at the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- An indication that rebels were disguising themselves as policemen was contained in statements published by the Ministry of Public Order today on Monday night's attack on Aigion. The Ministry asserted that preceding the attack a group of persons wearing police uniforms together with confederates dressed as peasants entered the town and took up positions in houses belonging to members of the "self-defense" Communist organization.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- Preparations have been started here in anticipation of a far-reaching agreement at the London talks on Western Germany, it was disclosed today. There were indications that the United States and British Military Governments were banking on at least a three-zone merger and possibly something close to a West German state.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 -- Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham told the assembled British community of Jerusalem today that the British could have made a success of the mandate here except for "outside interference." General Cunningham did not specify the nature of that "interference," but apparently he was alluding to American pressure for the establishment of a Jewish state.

With the opening of the trout season about six weeks distant, now appears to be a good time to check your fly box for needed replacements and to go over the rod thoroughly to see if repairs are necessary.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Soviet painters, examining their work in the light of the recent Communist party censure of composers, have uncovered a "spirit of decadence and bourgeois estheticism" in their own ranks, the magazine Moscow Bolshevik said today.

My ire was indeed aroused on reading in the News of the Week section of THE TIMES of Feb. 8 that "Eamon de Valera was born sixty-five years ago in a New York City slum -- the site where the Chrysler Building now stands."

Retail shoe volume between now and Easter will assume considerable importance because of the effect of unit turnover on both price and competitive trends in both the shoe and leather industry, reports here yesterday indicated.

An almost complete version of New York's Lord Taylor, from a tiny Blum's candy counter to their very own restaurant, the "Bird Cage," has been transplanted to Wilmot and White Plains Roads, Scarsdale. The new white brick and glass walled store opens its doors officially this morning.
Fuel oil truck drivers have diverted into illegal channels approximately 10 per cent of the oil scheduled for delivery to consumers of the city by using false receipts, it was charged yesterday.

For the first time since Manhattan elevator operators and other classes of building service employes became organized fourteen years ago, a union contract covering service workers in midtown skyscrapers was signed yesterday without a strike or the threat of a strike.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Kaiser, the military homing pigeon that has confounded experts by tripling the normal life span of his breed, will be 31 years old tomorrow.
