The existence of a formal proposal by the New York Trust Company to take over the Continental Bank and Trust Company was acknowledged yesterday by the presidents of the two banks. According to well-founded reports, the proposal is more advantageous than that recently made by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously reversed yesterday a ruling by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert dismissing a libel suit for $2,000,000 in damages brought against Westbrook Pegler, newspaper columnist, and Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., by the International Latex Corporation and A.N. Spanel, its president.

CAIRO, Feb. 25 -- Reports reaching here from Yemen indicate that small-scale fighting has broken out on the outskirts of Sanaa, where the Imam and his three sons are said to have been assassinated in last week's revolt. It is understood that King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia, a neighboring state, is ready to send in troops to aid the new Imam, Sayed Abdullah Ibn Ahmed el Wazir, if the situation gets out of hand.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress and founder of the Zionist Organization of America, assailed yesterday the United States Government's statement on Palestine as "not a decision, but sheer surrender to the Arabs."

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Gov. Robert F. Bradford told the Massachusetts Legislature today that the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad would abandon all passenger service on Oct. 1 on its Old Colony Division, which serves about 750,000 persons in seventy-five communities in the southeastern section of the Commonwealth.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer's "legislative package" for New York City was submitted formally in full to the Legislature today despite reports that it would be cut to less than half its size before it is approved.

Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, declared yesterday that the godlessness found in many American public schools and colleges and threats of increased atheism through communistic propaganda among children constituted a challenge for a spiritual mobilization of Americans.

Signed bill increasing pay of legislators from $2,500 to $5,000. Addressed organization meeting of Fire Advisory Council. Conferred with Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley, Senators Arthur H. Wicks and Benjamin F. Feinberg, and Earl Foster, deputy Commissioner of Agriculture.

Gaye Stewart's three goals provided the margin in the 7-to-4 triumph of the Chicago Black Hawks over the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The sharp-eyed forward's hat trick in a sizzling battle thrilled a crowd of 14,714.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- Military Government officials are investigating an illegal type of Soviet-zone export competition in dollar countries, it was learned today. The Soviet-zone plant of the B.M.W. Bavarian Motor Works is producing automobiles and motorcycles in competition with its parent plant in the United States zone.

American exporters were urged last night to support the current proposals of steamship companies for minimum packaging regulations before foreign competition develops. The appeal for cooperation in setting up a code to be administered by the carriers was made by J.F. Neal, assistant to the vice president, Grancolombiana, Inc., lines, at an open meeting of the National Export Traffic League in the Park Central Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The question whether the House will consider universal military training during this election year was put up to the House itself today by one of its republican leaders, Leo E. Allen, chairman of the Rules Committee.
Spring fashions designed and made by Sada Sacks, Inc., and sold as ready-to-wear, were introduced yesterday at the Hotel Pierre.

Cardinal Spellman has appointed John S. Burke, president of B. Altman Co., as chairman and John A. Coleman of the Stock Exchange firm of Adler Coleman as executive chairman of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for the 1948 Appeal of the New York Catholic Charities, it was announced yesterday at the committee's first organization meeting in the Empire State Club.

Major League basketball scouts -- at least one was in attendance -- could not have chosen a more opportune time to appraise Columbia's Walt Budko than last night on the Morningside Heights floor. The burly captain of the league-leading Lions was a one-man riot as he sparked the Lions to a 61-54 victory over Yale.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Knight today prohibited the Kidde Manufacturing Company, Bloomfield, N.J., from selling devices for whipping cream with nitrous oxide.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- New reports of impending changes at the top level of the Republican State Administration swept the capitol today despite previous denials from all of those affected. Generally they were regarded as interesting but of questionable authenticity.

Reports of protests in London against a scheme afoot there to use for commercial purposes the horse in Young Street, Kensington, where Thackeray wrote some of his most famous books provide new and impressive proof of the formidable numbers of Thackeray's admirers and the depth of their loyalty to him.

Fifteen members of the American Friends of Slovak Freedom picketed for an hour yesterday in front of the headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations at 680 Park Avenue. As soon as the pickets departed, the Russians sent out an aproned employe with a rubber hose to wash off the sidewalk.
A banking group headed by John Nuveen Co., submitted yesterday the highest bid for $2,500,000 of revenue bonds of the Consumers Public Power District Nebraska.

Reporting on operations for 1947, Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, said yesterday that the steel company last year established new high records for its earnings, sales and payrolls. Consolidate net income, after taxes, amounted to $25,002,211, equal to $7.44 a common share, compared with $18,552,491, or $5.35 a share, in 1946.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Norway called today for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly to debate the future of Korea but no other country seemed happy about the idea.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The United Nations is a good place to hear objective criticism of one's own country. The delegates, on the whole, are intelligent and friendly. The delegates' lounge is comfortable, and open to reporters; and while speeches are being translated into French or English, the opportunities for corporate international kibitzing are frequent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Grain markets showed a strong tone generally on the Board of Trade today, corn leading, and affecting other grains. Corn futures closed 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents higher, September leading, with May up 3 cents at one time, 27 cents above the recent low, having recovered about 40 per cent of the break from the high on Jan. 16.
PRAGUE, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Following are the texts of a from President Benes to the presidium of the Communist party and the presidium's reply:

NANKING, Feb. 25 -- Official Chinese sources here tonight confirmed Moscow's appointment of Maj. Gen. Nikolai V. Roschin as the new Soviet Ambassador to China. General Roschin, who for eight years has served as military attache in China, succeeds Appolon Petrov, who last year left Nanking for Russia on vacation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Ernest T. Weir, one of the largest independent steel producers in the country, made it plain today that his company would not raise prices and that he frowned upon the increases announced last week by major steel producers.

The fuel oil policy and operating committees of the major oil companies in the New York area set up committees and subcommittees yesterday to work with the eastern seaboard district advisory committee of the National Petroleum Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Senator William E. Jenner continued silent today on his plans for the future in the face of a demand by Indiana Republican editors that he withdraw his name from consideration as Republican candidate for Governor.

The council of the Actors Equity Association has decided to "request" stars of the Broadway theatre, when they are approached to appear on the radio, to "insist upon the inclusion of the name of the plays with which they are connected and where those plays may be found."

A "natural" in track competition is scheduled for the twenty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night when Phil Thigpen and Reggie Pearman meet in the 1,000-yard race.

The highest award of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, the Medal of Honor, presented annually for distinguished work and the highest professional standing, was made last night to Wallace K. Harrison, director of planning of the United Nations Headquarters Commission.
These words, addressed to Dr. Eduard Benes and his National Social party, were spoken by Klement Gottwald in his maiden speech in the Czech Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate's Republican majority forced today a grant of $170,000, the largest such sum ever given at one time, to a powerful committee with almost limitless jurisdiction to investigate the Truman Administration.

The New York City Opera Company, which will open its season with "Don Giovanni" on Friday, March 19, announced yesterday the entire repertoire for its six-week stay at the City Center. Casts for all performances also were listed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The State's Attorney's office today began an investigation into the boxing match last Friday night that resulted in the death of Sam Baroudi after a knockout by Ezzard Charles.

Store Inventories in 8% Drop Inventories of New York City department stores at the end of January were 8 per cent under those of the same period of 1947, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Apparel store stocks showed a decline of 7 per cent.

After possessing for four years a heart-shaped diamond pin valued at $3,000 that she found, a New City, N.Y., housewife will receive the piece of jewelry legally from the New York City Police Department property clerk, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- "The Czechoslovak people displayed a remarkable degree of political activity," the Moscow radio said tonight in its first interpretation of the Communist coup. An English-language commentator named Gofman noted that the "activity" had been "coupled with magnificent discipline and organization," and added:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- New financing in the amount of $12,000,000 was proposed in applications filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- With high-scoring Ernie Vandeweghe leading the way with 26 points, the Colgate basketball team, after a somewhat listless first half, played superbly in the second half to smother Army, 64 to 44, in the Field House today.

The future of aviation in the United States depends in large part on the safety factor. With this consideration in mind, the Radio Technical Commission for Aeronautics has submitted a plan of action to President Truman's Air Coordinating Committee.

Sales and earnings of the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company last year were the highest in its forty-two years of operations, according to the annual report of A.E. Staley Jr., president, issued for publication today.

With good companions around him Will Irwin could pour out picturesque reminiscence with the easy and endless flow of a fountain. One felt he would have been a welcome guest at the Mermaid Tavern. Yet in these stories he was only reliving what he himself had experienced and noted with a shrewd eye and a warm heart. He could make even a dead city come to life.
A provision of the Portal-to Portal Act limiting workers' rights to claim overtime pay was held unconstitutional yesterday by City Court Justice Samuel C. Coleman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The House approved today a record $538,863,300 flood control and navigation construction program for the twelve months beginning July 1.

Tourist motor travel will not be scared off the highways this year by "the phantom of a widespread gasoline shortage that does not exist," delegates were told yesterday at the international travel conference of the American Automobile Association at Roosevelt Hotel.

Discontinuance of the suit brought by Milton Solomon, former deputy controller, against the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia for malicious persecution and defamation of character was announced yesterday by former Council President Newbold Morris, counsel for the La Guardia estate.

A cost-of-living wage increase of 6.3 per cent in base pay and overtime rates for the 90,000 members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was awarded yesterday by Frederick R. Livingston, arbitrator in the wage review dispute of the union and the committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operation.

William Roy Roeder has acquired from Elizabeth D. Lonergan the two-story garage and auto repair shop at 525 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash over a mortgage of $23,500. The property is 40 by 100 feet. The American Realty Company was the broker and the title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The attorneys were Donovan, Mahoney Williams for the seller and Charles Burston for the buyer.

Sanitation' Commissioner William J. PoweU announced yester-[ day that 170 new garbage removal! trucks on order with the General Motors Corporation would be de-] livered to the city within the next two months., The announcement was made in the course of an offictal inspection of twenty of the new trucks at the departmental training school, East River and Twenty-second Street, by Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri and other city officials.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- A secret wartime report of the Federal Communications Commission charging that horse-race wire companies received priority over the Army for Western Union wires and equipment was made public today by Warren Olney 3d, attorney for Gov. Earl Warren's Commission on Organized Crime.

Long-smoldering antagonism between Commodore Harry Manning, master of the nation's largest merchant ship, the United States liner America, and union crew members flared up here yesterday after the ship arrived from Europe with 773 passengers.

At 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon came the simultaneous announcement from General Manager George Weiss, at St. Petersburg, Fla. and Frank (Spec) Shea, at Naugatuck, Conn., that the Yankees' 1947 freshman pitching ace had agreed to terms for this year.

General agreement that any subway fare increase should not be used to reduce real estate taxes was in evidence last night at a discussion of the five-cent fare, held under the auspices of the Citizens Union, in the Willkie Memorial Building on West Fortieth Street.

Asserting that the passenger business of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway is a necessary adjunct to its freight business, Robert J Bowman, president, in a letter of thirty pages to George S. Jackson, a stockholder, maintained yesterday that it was good business judgment to sustain a deficit "even of several million dollars annually," in providing a service which gives essential support to the road's freight volume of nearly $300,000,000 a year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Princeton's varsity basketball team moved into a second-place tie with Cornell in the Eastern League standings tonight, defeating Harvard, 71 -- 55, in a free-scoring contest before 2,300 persons in the new Dillon Gym.

Ruth Posselt, violinist, and Albert Gillespie, pianist, were the soloists at the Debut and Encore Concert given last night at Town Hall. Miss Posselt was the artist with an established reputation at this event. Mr. Gillespie appeared for the first time in this city.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 26 -- Albania today challenged Britain's competence to hale her before the International Court of Justice to answer charges arising from the mining of two British destroyers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary of State Marshall urged Congress today to authorize promptly $275,000,000 of additional expenditures for continued and sustained military aid to Greece and Turkey in resisting communism.

ATHENS, Feb. 26 -- The Chamber of Deputies adopted early today, at the end of an overnight sitting, a Government-backed resolution to adjourn until May 10, the Monday following the week after Easter by the Greek Orthodox calendar. The vote was 147 to 73.

Skiing will be enjoyed on a limited scale this week-end. A mixture of reports from the Northlands tell of new powder, wet snow, frozen granular, breakable and unbreakable crusts surfacing depths that remain huge in the high country and have been reduced considerably in the lowlands as a result of recent warm spells and rain.

It might be a good idea to check your shotgun, if you use a pump or autoloader, and if you happen to have switched to the new folded crimp or flat-top shells. Ithaca reports that two hunters, checked last fall by a warden, were using pump guns. Both guns were plugged, but the shooters were using the new shells, which are slightly shorter, and the warden was able to force three shells into the magazine.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The delay in attacking a Japanese troop convoy lying off the coast of Malaya in the early morning of Dec. 8, 1941, was the result of British concern with sentiments of isolationists in the United States, it was stated in official dispatches made public tonight.
PRAGUE, Feb. 26 -- President Eduard Benes accused Premier Klement Gottwald of "talking to me like Hitler," one of the Czech President's closest friends said tonight.

Two books about Germany are scheduled for publication next month. Yale University Press will bring out on March 9 a study of the German people entitled "Post-war Germans: An Anthropologist's Account," by David Rodnick. Mr. Rodnick was sent into Germany by the United States Army soon after the close of hostilities to study German society at first hand.
In an editorial on Nov. 24, 1946, THE NEW YORK TIMES favored amnesty for conscientious objectors and Jehovah's Witnesses, and quoted a resolution of the CIO also favoring amnesty.
MERIDIAN, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP) -- The crash of a B-29 near here today killed four members of the crew. Nineteen other bombers in the flight continued a routine mission to the West Coast and back.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 26 -- The Jewish underground organization Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Haganah, unofficial Zionist militia, clashed tonight in the center of the all-Jewish city of Tel Aviv. Two bombs were thrown but so far as could be ascertained tonight the encounter consisted chiefly of fist-fights.

A warning against a posible future break in the steel market is contained in a report of the national committee on steel of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, compiled by a seventeen-member committee of leading purchasing agents geographically distributed in sixteen cities.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Arthur Calwell, Australian Immigration Minister, announced today that Australia would recondition the former luxury liner Monarch of Bermuda (22,424 tons) as an immigrant ship at a cost of 1,000,000 ($4,000,000).
Two alleged torturers, Bruce G. Bowers and Bernard Webel, were held in $75,000 bail each on kidnapping charges by Magistrate Samuel Orr in Felony Court yesterday pending a hearing March 4.

Pia Tassinari, soprano, who joined the Metropolitan Opera Company this season, sang her first Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme" with that company last night. The warmth and conviction which she brought to the part was perhaps abetted by the appearance of her husband, Ferruccio Tagliavini, in the opposite role of Rodolfo.

Stockholders of the Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation were informed by Albert A. Garthwaite, president, at the annual meeting yesterday that sales for the first quarter of the fiscal year starting on Nov. 1 fell to $8,885,000 from $9,272,000 in the similar period of the previous year.

Taking a leaf from the pages of history, Carrie Munn turned to the romantic figures of the gardens of Fontainebleu, to the courtiers and their ladies of the court of Louis XVI, for the inspiration of her custom-made fashion collection seen yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue.

Shocked by the Communist coup d'etat in Czechoslovakia into their first joint action on Russo-Communist expansion, the Governments of the United States, Britain and France have condemned what they characterize bluntly as the establishment of a one-party dictatorship disguised under the cloak of a Government of National Union. They are conferring on the advisability of refusing to recognize this new regime.

Floating a $200,000 revue of the type of "Inside U.S.A.," which goes into rehearsal today with Beatrice Lillie and Jack Haley starred, requires more than pluck. Especially when the basic material has to satisfy an array of forty-one backers, one of whom is Mrs. Henry Ford 2d, with a stake of $4,000.
Meat prices declined again yesterday in many of the city's retail food stores. The City Markets Department reported that the latest meat price declines ranged from 2 to 12 cents a pound.

An unusually large collection of authentic French Provincial furniture fashioned for everyday use by rural craftsmen was added yesterday to Gimbels antique department on the fifth floor. Cabinets and cupboards often used in kitchens by farm families predominate among approximately a hundred hand-picked pieces.

A small group of experts from the Rockefeller Foundation will leave probably within a month to help the depressed and wars-scarred island of Crete return to some measure of its ancient glory, it was learned yesterday.

We would owe George Szell a debt for last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, when Yehudi Menuhin was soloist, if it were only for bringing back to a program the D major Serenade, No. 9, of Mozart.
NANKING, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Chinese Communists tightened their ring around Mukden in savage fighting today, leading to predictions that the Manchurian city soon would face frontal assault.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 26 -- South Korean Communists launched another wave of sabotage and civil disturbances last night.

Despite high employment, increased earnings and record production in the nation generally, relative inertia characterized the securities markets during 1947, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday in the annual report of the Exchange and its affiliated organizations.

Oldric Royce has taken as the basis for his spring collection the sharply fitted suit, with squared shoulders and deep hips, and the shirtwaist dress. Models shown yesterday at 16 East Fifty-second Street developed each of these patterns in excellent quality silk failles, shantungs and crepes, with fine dressmaker details of tucking, lace appliques and stitching.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- For the second time within two weeks Britain has found it expedient to make a show of her sea power in Latin American waters. The Admiralty disclosed today that the heavily gunned cruiser Sheffield had been ordered to Belize in British Honduras to counteract the belligerent behavior of the little republic of Guatemala in the century-old border quarrel with Britain.

Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe recently celebrated their tenth anniversary as a duo-piano team. Their concert Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, their second since getting out of the Navy, revealed both how far they have come since and how far they still have to go.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26 --The Foreign Office today renewed its word battle with Britain over the Falkland Islands and dependencies, which the Argentines call the Malvinas.

HOECHST, Germany, Feb. 26 -- Important trade discussions, which are expected to provide a spring- board for real German participation in the European Recovery Program, are taking place here. They will reach a climax next week when a British delegation will arrive to negotiate Britain's first trade treaty with Germany since the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In an unusual step, the Governments of the United States, Great Britain and France officially condemned today the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia. Identical statements were issued simultaneously here, in London and in Paris.
PARIS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A new battle over the barricades at Marseille raised fears today that the Communist victory in Czechoslovakia would be followed by a second round of strike troubles for France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- George F. Kennan, director of the State Department's policy planning staff, has been sent to Tokyo for a conference with Gen. Douglas MacArthur and his staff, Secretary of State Marshall announced at a news conference today.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A constitutional amendment which would permit New York City to conduct a lottery for the support of hospitals is before the Legislature. Senator Richard McCleery, Republican, of Brooklyn, introduced the measure yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Three conferences that may determine the final shape of Mayor William O'Dwyer's "legislative package" for New York City are scheduled for tomorrow, it was learned tonight. Two are in Albany, involving top Republican advisers to Governor Dewey and the legislative majority, and the third is in New York City, involving the Mayor and Democratic county chairmen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Dorothy Stickney, who has been absent from the screen for five years, has been signed by Paramount to play opposite Monty Woolley in "The Tatlock Millions," which Richard Haydn will direct and Charles Brackett will produce.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 -- The crew of a United States Army Transport Command plane making its first scheduled flight between Dharan, Saudi Arabia, and Manila was incarcerated by Pakistan authorities at Karachi for three hours yesterday for lack of yellow fever inoculations, crew members said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, warned today that there could never be "total medical care" for orthopedically handicapped school-age children in hospitals and convalescent center unless education was included as an integral part of their treatment.

William L. Shirer has been designated for the 1948 One World Award for radio, it was announced yesterday by Prof. James H. Sheldon, chairman of the nominations committee of the One World Award committee. Dore Schary, vice president in charge of production for RKO has been selected for this year's award for motion pictures.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 26 -- An optimistic picture of this country's economic future was painted today in the annual report of the Bank of Mexico. At the same time, leading business organizations got behind a movement for the resumption of normal trade relations with Franco Spain.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Forty members of the Labor party majority in the House of Commons stepped out of line with the British Government's policy and went directly to the United Nations Security Council tonight with an appeal for measures to preserve peace in Palestine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An army lieutenant and three captains asserted today that despite crippling war wounds, they had not been able to get disability retirements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Nothing in the Constitution or in any high court ruling thus far interposes a legal bar to the proposal of Governor Tuck to the Virginia Legislature that Presidential electors chosen by the popular majority in November shall be free to vote for any citizens they may wish for President and Vice President.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Britain's nationalized aviation industry was sharply criticized in the House of Commons today as being in a state tantamount to "bankruptcy."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Challenging an underlying assumption of United States policy on Palestine, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that the Holy Land would become the sole responsibility of the United Nations after the termination of the British mandate on May 15.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Legislative leaders have agreed to defer action this year on proposals to make New York a community-property state in the hope that state action will be made unnecessary by revision of the Federal income tax law.

The chief executives of the United States Steel Corporation may be fully cognizant of their obligation to furnish enlightened industry leadership and of their responsibility to the public, but neither is shown by their actions.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 26 -- Gov. William M. Tuck asked the Virginia General Assembly today for legislation to keep President Truman's name off the state's Presidential ballot next November. rTo an applauding joint session of the Assembly, the Governor urged a new election statute iwhich would leave Virginia Democrats free to secede from the national party.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System shrank $7,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The statistics issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York put the total of such loans outstanding at $5,208,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Basil O'Connor, president of the American Red Cross, announced today that its annual fund-raising campaign, with a $75,000,000 goal, would be opened by President Truman in a broadcast on the major networks at 10 P.M. Sunday.

Dispatches to this newspaper from Basle indicate that the Bank for International Settlements, established eighteen years ago to facilitate reparations payments under the Young Plan, is finding an important place for itself. The development of strong regional machinery for achieving common action in the monetary field has become a major preoccupation with European financial leaders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Congressional foreign policy committees appeared agreed today on a $5,300,000,000 authorization for starting the Marshall Plan.
NANKING, Feb. 26 -- The possibility of the Government's reopening peace negotiations with the Communists was emphatically denied by Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, Foreign Minister, in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Communist triumph in Czechoslovakia is increasing pressure on the United States to enter a United Nations regional security pact with Great Britain, France, Belgium and the Netherlands.
Alfred N. Hackman Sons Company, Inc., to Gerald Lesser, Inc., for Comfort Corsets. Newspapers, trade papers and magazines.

The best years of the lives of the twenty-three paraplegic World War veterans who played a game of basketball from their wheel chairs at St. Nicholas Arena Wednesday night are behind them. Those best years were the ones when they were younger and strong and active, before the ill fortune of war brought the wounds and injuries that now chain them for the years ahead to their wheel chairs.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 26 -- This city will "adopt" the Italian town of Pontecorvo Tuesday night at ceremonies in Glen Cove High School.

Ike Williams, holder of the lightweight championship of the world, will appear in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be the Cuban warrior, Kid Gavilan, who has become a local favorite on the strength of his performances hereabouts through the past eight months.
City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that New York City has borrowed $30,000,000 from twenty-six local banks on 1 1/8 per cent tax anticipation notes dated Feb. 27 and due April 30.

Fifteen newspaper editors will attend a three-week seminar on telegraph and cable news opening on Monday at Columbia's American Press Institute. Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

A section of the Port of New York Authority's report on the city's waterfront makes clear one of the many reasons why New York cannot pursue a do-nothing policy any longer. Field investigation showed, according to the report, "that an alarming number (of the 110 municipal piers) can no longer be regarded as earning assets for even ten years, without a substantial capital investment in rehabilitation."

Reports that the official Argentine export trade agency, IAPI, has increased the export price of quebracho more than 50 per cent have caused sharp resentment in United States tanning circles, it was indicated here yesterday. At the new reported price basis, the cost to American tanners of this important vegetable tanning material, produced largely in Argentina, would be approximately 12 3/4 cents per pound.

Forthwith implementation of the United Nations decision on partition of Palestine was demanded last night of the United States by sixty-two organizations at an emergency conference called by the American Association for the United Nations.

The Winter Olympic Games must undergo complete revision if they are to attract competitors worthy of the name in the future, according to George Dudley, secretary of the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association, and Walter Brown, vice president of the Amateur Hockey Association of America.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 26 -- A charter was today granted by Rhode Island's Secretary of State to a society with a nation-wide membership that will have among its objectives the upkeep of Touro Synagogue in this city as a national historic shrine and an annual observance on or about Aug. 19 of George Washington's pronouncement on religious liberty.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 26 -- The Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, New York City, was elected chairman of the western section of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance today at the close of its three-day annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Points likely to be raised tomorrow before the Interstate Commerce Commission, when it will hear arguments for and against the right of Robert R. Young, chairman of the board, and Robert J. Bowman, president, of the Chesapeake Ohio, to sit on the board of directors of the New York Central, are indicated in correspondence placed in the file for that proceeding by the ICC.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- By a 31-to-2 vote, the United Nations Little Assembly called on the Korea Commission today to go ahead with the setting up of a national Government despite the Russian closed-door policy in the northern part of the country.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- He's only a member of Calumet Farm's junior varsity team of 3-year-olds, but the colt named Coaltown rates immediate award of a varsity "C."

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 26 -- Dartmouth threw a scare into Holy Cross' National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament bound quintet today, but the Purple cut loose with 13 points in the last five minutes to beat the Indians, 67 -- 56. The Crusaders notched their fourteenth straight victory before 2,800 fans, who jammed the Alumni Gym.

After hearing an hour of impassioned speeches by various union representatives supporting Isadore Rubin, suspended teacher-picket, the Board of Education decided yesterday to reserve decision until its next meeting, March 18, or a special meeting. Four votes are necessary for a decision.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Birdies were pars for Ben Hogan in the St. Petersburg open golf tournament today as he bounced around the course in 63, nine under par.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- By unanimous resolution, the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom called today for peak priority for the materials and labor needed for shipbuilding and repair. The resolution called for the immediate restoration of the British mercantile marine to its pre-war level (Just below 17,000,000 tons) as a minimum essential to insure sufficient service to the nation.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation realized in its last fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, last the highest sales and earnings in its nineteen-year history, Victor Emanuel, chairman of the board, declares in the annual statement sent yesterday to stockholders. Consolidated net income was reported as $6,960,658, equal to 96 cents a common share, against $1,514,094 or 13 cents a share in the preceding year after giving effect to a tax carryback credit of $1,550,000.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Fisticuffs at dawn today marked what Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, described as the "opening gun" of a union campaign to organize aircraft manufacturing workers up and down the Pacific Coast.

DURING a recess in the conference session that followed my meeting with Stalin, I buttonholed Molotov and re-emphasized the arguments I had presented to Stalin for a meeting of the three chiefs of state at Basra. Molotov asked me what were the programs of international cooperation I had said I thought should be settled now.
HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- Delegates to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment struggled today with a new obstacle to the settlement of the economic development issue.

The paper industry, now leading all others in the amount of capital investment per worker employed, need not fear that continued expansion will produce a slump, Reuben B. Robertson, executive vice president, Champion Paper and Fibre Company, said last night in an address at the annual banquet of the American Paper and Pulp Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 26 -- President Truman expects to receive the stop-gap Rent Control Bill tomorrow or Saturday and act on it before the Sunday midnight deadline.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- During the week ended Feb. 25 member bank reserve balances increased $49,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Warner Brothers will produce "Fighter Squadron," described as a story of America's flying might in the recent war approved by the Air Force. Seton I. Miller, who collaborated on the screen plays of two versions of Warners' "Dawn Patrol," air combat film of the first World War, which were made in 1930 and 1938, is writing the screen play and will produce "Fighter Squadron."

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The National Assembly indicated today that the French Government was counting on United States interim-aid transactions to make available about 30,000,000,000 francs to aid in the reconstruction and re-equipment of nationalized industries.

A gentleman with his right hand neatly bandaged found his way to this corner the other day to register his belief that the compilers of dictionaries unquestionably are learned and nice enough fellows, but that there were indications that some of them are dreamers and theorists, at a safe distance from life's nudges and bumps.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg had an opportunity today to present their views on Western Germany for the first time since the war ended. They joined the conference of the United States, Britain and France that started Monday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 26 -- United States prosecutors in the trial of former I.G. Farben executives here accused certain members of the German defense staff today of misappropriation and destruction of tons of documentary evidence obtained from archives to which both sides had equal access.

Western Kentucky (24-1), St. Louis (19-2) and Texas (18-4) are the first three teams to accept bids to compete in the eleventh national invitation college basketball tournament, it was announced yesterday. The post-season carnival, won last year by Utah, will be played at Madison Square Garden starting March 11.
THE NEW YORK TIMES has printed several letters complaining of the city's failure to clean streets promptly and adequately. I write to describe the "other half" of the picture.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott tonight agreed to meet champion Joe Louis in a 15-round heavyweight title bout at the Yankee Stadium in New York on June 23. Walcott's attorney, A.D. Malandra, said a contract would be signed tomorrow at 2 P.M. in the New York office of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Unless Congress passes suitable legislation within the next six weeks, the whole program of resettlement for the displaced persons of Europe will be set back another year, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director of the War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Strong support for the European Recovery Program with the qualification that the door should be left open for the participation of Eastern European states, is expected to be expressed soon in the British Labor party's official statement of policy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee reorganized its publicity section today to get fully ready for the 1948 campaigns.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate, by a voice vote, passed and sent to the House today a bill authorizing the Government to ration through Oct. 31 the use of grain by distilleries.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- Gov. Kim Sigler consolidated today the mushrooming rackets and murder investigations set off two days ago by the re-arrest of a paroled bank robber accused of acting as go-between for intracircuit betting by players of the National Hockey League.

The decision of the Little Assembly to instruct the Commission on Korea to proceed with elections in South Korea and with establishment of a government in Seoul is the only decent, realistic decision that could have been reached. The alternative was for the United Nations to throw up its hands resignedly and drop any action to which the Soviet bloc is opposed.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Following is the United States resolution on the Korean question adopted today by the Interim Committee of the United Nations General Assembly :

Carrying forward its worldwide fight against Communist-inspired misrepresentations of the Marshall Plan, the Congress of Industrial Organizations decided yesterday to send one of its vice presidents to Mexico City next month to urge support of the plan by unions in South and Central America.

NBC plans before next fall to explore the possibility of having the concerts of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony offered under cooperative sponsorship. Under such a plan the total expenses of the program, estimated to amount to $1,000,000 annually, would be shared by different advertisers in each city where the concerts were heard.

Bulova's new Photo-Timer, a device which takes all the guesswork out of finish judging, was introduced formally yesterday before a large gathering of track coaches, officials and writers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Heaviness in industrial shares, particularly the automotive, produced yesterday a generally lower trend in the marke on the Stock Exchange and eliminated the gains made on Wednesday. Losses in some pivotal issues were more than a point, and the combined averages fell 0.74 point.

A second-half collapse almost cost Long Island University its basketball game with Seton Hall last night at Madison Square Garden. In the end, the Brooklyn Blackbirds staggered to a 40-38 victory over the visiting Pirates, gaining little stature from their sixteenth conquest of the campaign.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- The question of the membership of the council of the proposed International Maritime Organization produced today the greatest disagreement so far shown in the United Nations maritime conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Small Business heard a representative of the Department of Commerce and spokesmen for various trade associations urge today that effective date of the department's new policy requiring licenses for all exports to Europe, be postponed.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 26 -- The Sister Kenny Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will establish a 100-bed clinic at the Medical Center here for the treatment of poliomyelitis victims in the East, it was learned today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- American officials here said today that they expected "pressure" against the Czech-German border by Czechoslovaks seeking to leave their country because of the Communist coup. There is a 135-mile border between Czechoslovakia and the United States zone of Germany.
Last year, for the first time since 1942, the city gained more housing than it lost, figures supplied by the Department of Housing and Buildings Bureau of Records showed yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 26 -- America's public school system is in danger of a serious breakdown unless Federal aid is granted at once, the nation's top educators warned here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today warned in letters to the chairmen of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees that his department will let Steagall price supports lapse on their termination date Dec. 31 unless otherwise directed by Congress.

Next Monday morning Macy's will open a new dress floor on the Seventh Avenue side of the building. The large space, located on the third floor, will be subdivided into six dress shops. The Little Shop will be one of them. Others are two misses' shops in two price ranges -- from $10.29 to $18.74 in one, from $18.74 to $37.50 in the other -- a maternity shop, one for women and one for brides.

Washington's grain conservation drive deserves applause, but what sins are committed in that name! I have before me the report of a joint Congressional committee on the allocation and inventory control of grain, dated Feb. 9. It proposes substantial restrictions in the distilling industry because of diversion of large quantities of whole grain to "non-essential" use.

Guatamalan journalists who have been attacking British policy in this hemisphere had a tangible evidence yesterday of the power of the press when a British cruiser started from Colombia for Belize, in British Honduras. An Admiralty spokesman in London said the ship was sent "because of possible incidents staged by irresponsible elements in neighboring Guatemala."

A proceeding to close Public School 54, at 104th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, because of a lack of sanitary facilities was brought yesterday in Supreme Court by Arthur Leibowitz of 225 West 106th Street, father of Edward B. Leibowitz, a 6-year-old pupil.
PRAGUE, Feb. 26 -- The Communist-dominated Government of Czechoslovakia, headed by Premier Klement Gottwald, moved today along many fronts to extend its control of the country.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, is expected to protest to Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander, against a "sharp increase" in troop incidents along the borders separating the United States and Soviet zones, Military Government officials disclosed today.

THE old college try, that last despairing effort to attain the unattainable, has long been scorned by professional ball players as being beneath their dignity and their talents. They regard it as a grandstand play which is designed for amateurs who don't know their limitations. The pros don't try for those shoestring catches unless they have a reasonable chance of making them.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Nine hundred union printers employed by twenty-eight of the city's major commercial book and job printing concerns stayed away from work today in a move to enforce a demand for higher wages.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Organized medicine today struck back at critics who have implied that restrictive forces are at work in this country to bring about a threatened shortage of from 30,000 to 50,000 physicians by 1960.

Yuriko, a featured dancer of Martha Graham's company, last night presented a solo of her own creation entitled "Tale of Seizure" on Miss Graham's program at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. This was the second performance of the piece, and it was added to the regular program on this occasion to compensate for the fact that its premiere earlier in the week conflicted with the premiere of "Giselle" by the Ballet Russe.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- In spite of the effect of the veto on the Security Council, the United Nations as a whole is making great strides toward establishing peace, security and higher standards of living, Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, told a group of more than 500 educators here today.

The probability of large-scale production of a synthetic gasoline of a quality and cost comparable to the popular types of this fuel now used by motorists was forecast yesterday by engineers of the Cities Service Company and the M.W. Kellogg Company, petroluem engineers.

Two hundred and fifty of the 1,150 workers engaged in the re- conversion of the Moore-McCormack liner Brazil walked off the ship in the Atlantic Basin Iron Works yards in Brooklyn yesterday in a dispute over premium pay.

The owner of a knitting mills concern and one of the employes were asphyxiated, a fireman was overcome by smoke and five other persons were rescued when flames swept a paper box factory in the Williamsburgh section of Brooklyn early last night.

Will you please permit me to record the appreciation of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) for your splendid editorial support and for the space which THE TIMES has so generously given in its crowded news columns to the Fund's progress.
Jess Sweetser, who won fame by annexing the British amateur golf championship at Muirfield in 1926 when illness almost downed him, has come through with another sporting gesture.

Declaring that the corporation's seemingly high profit in 1947 was insufficient to provide adequately for replacement of existing facilities and raw material properties and for modernization purposes, E.G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. warned yesterday that the full effect of the inflationary trend of wage and costs might be still to come.

The New York Piece Goods Buyers' Group has voted to affiliate with the National Retail Dry Goods Association and will hereafter be known as the Piece Goods Buyers Group of the NRDGA, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the group's executive committee

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A leading producer of eyeglasses today was ordered to turn over to the government the names of 1,500 oculists who the Government alleges received rebates on glasses sold to patients.

Exchange Issues In the annual report of the New York Stock Exchange released yesterday, it was noted that during 1947 there was a net increase of 135,000,000 in the number of shares of all companies listed on the Exchange. Listed shares on the Exchange at the year-end numbered 1,907,000,000 a new high record.

George Kastanos, 7 years old printed his name yesterday on an application to Congress for permission to remain in this country. His mother, Mrs. Anastasia Kastanos, signed another application for her daughter Helen, 4, who also faces deportation to Greece as an illegal immigrant.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 26 -- Coinciding With an allegation by Manilal Gandhi, son of Mohandas K. Gandhi, that Communists control passive resistance by Indians against the "ghetto law," two leaders of that movement were sentenced by the Durban Magistrates Court today to six months at hard labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The most powerful Senate investigating committee in history, with an unrestricted and primary mandate to inquire into the acts of the Executive branch, was organized today to confront the Administration across the bitterness of this election year.

Having chronicled the Goldbergs over the radio for sixteen years, Gertrude Berg has brought some of them on the stage in "Me and Molly," acted at the Belasco last evening. Although her theatre script is about as artless as you are likely to find out of the amateur theatre, the artlessness is genuine and her family drama makes no pretentions to literature.

Supporters of grandmother's theory that "a mess of spring greens" remedies end-of-winter blues will be interested in the leafy vegetables offered this week-end. Plentiful as they are at present, however, not all stores carry them. It depends on neighborhood demand which, with these particular varieties, is unpredictable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Public Service Company of Oklahoma received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell at competitive bidding $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series B, due Feb. 1, 1978.

VIENNA, Feb. 26 -- The Communist coup in Czechoslovakia has shaken Austrian public opinion and dissipated some of the optimism felt in official circles over the prospects of a state treaty that would end the occupation.

Electric power production for the week ended Feb. 21 declined to 5,254,002,000 kilowatt-hours from 5,384,945,000 in the preceding week, Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Feb. 22, 1947 was 4,777,740,000.

The Queens Chamber of Commerce endorsed yesterday the creation of Federal and state commissions to study means of eliminating the overlapping and duplication of taxes. Another resolution approved a ten-cent subway fare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Testimony that Herbert K. Sorrell signed a Communist control card, No. 42782, in 1937, was read into a House labor subcommittee's record today, but two long-time associates denied that Mr. Sorrell was a "Red."

WASHINGTON. Feb. 26 (AP) -- A railroad spokesman today described the Inland Waterways Corporation as a "socialistic experiment." He asked the House Commerce Committee to "get the Government out of the barge business."

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The brightest spot in a generally quiet stock market here today was provided by British Government issues. Not much was doing in the early trading but buying increased just before the close and prices improved all round as much as 7/16 point.

Detectives decided yesterday that not one man, but two, and possibly three, killed Harvey Haeberle, civilian employe of the Navy, two days ago in the Henry Hudson Hotel at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Keith M. Philbrick has been appointed personnel director of Saks Fifth Avenue, New York. He formerly was director of selling services. Loy B. Wilkenson, formerly a floor superintendent, has been named director of selling services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- House Democrats blocked Judiciary Committee approval of anti-lynching legislation today by invoking a rule which prohibits a committee from sitting while the House is in session.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- In joining with the United States and Britain in their condemnation of the Communist seizure of power in Czechoslovakia, the French Government for the first time formally protested against Soviet methods of domination in Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Navy confirmed today that the 27,000-ton carrier Valley Forge would visit the Persian Gulf on a trip from the Pacific to the United States.
With milder weather and the relief of the fuel oil shortage in the city, the emergency schedule of the heat complaint service of the Health Department will be relaxed today.

The similarity of the design for an arch as the central feature of the Jefferson National Expansion Park in St. Louis to the huge parabola that Benito Mussolini had approved for the proposed international exposition in Rome in 1942 as a celebration of twenty years of fascism, was called "purely coincidental" yesterday by Luther Ely Smith, president of the Jefferson Memorial Association.

The Greater New York CIO Council charged yesterday that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been visiting the offices of "left wing" CIO locals here to intimidate them and curtail their political activity in behalf of Henry A. Wallace.

Dr. Nissim Mevorah, Bulgarian Minister to the United States, when asked to comment on the Communist seizure of Czechoslovakia, asserted yesterday that the American people were inclined to view European events in a "little too tragic light."

Reflecting the rise last year in gross sales and other revenues to a record $171,787,585 from $122,854,309 in 1946, earnings of the Union Oil Company were the highest in the company's history, according to the annual report of Reese H. Taylor, president, issued for publication today.

Net income of the Radio Corporation of America increased last year $7,784,504 to $18,769,557, according to the twenty-eighth annual report released for publication today. Earnings on the 13,881,016 outstanding common shares were $1.12 a share, compared with 56 cents a share in 1946.

WARSAW, Feb 26 -- Rumania's Premier Petru Groza and Foreign Minister Ana Pauker -- the latter very smart in a black silk "new look" dress under a Persian lamb coat -- arrived in Warsaw by special train today to sign a cultural pact with Poland.

A resolution petitioning Congress to eliminate price criteria as a factor in the granting of export licenses, and to set next Monday as the date for expiration of general export controls instead of Feb. 28, 1949, as provided in the current law, was adopted unanimously yesterday at a mass meeting of exporters held by the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Astor. About 480 were present.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y. Feb. 26 -- In a caustic statement, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the United States today of trying to "strangle" the Republic of Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Lower prices for dairy products, cereal products and meats were chiefly responsible for a fractional decline of 0.3 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ending Feb. 21, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The similarity of the design for an arch as the central feature of the Jefferson National Expansion Park in St. Louis to the huge parabola that Benito Mussolini had approved for the proposed international exposition in Rome in 1942 as a celebration of twenty years of fascism, was called "purely coincidental" yesterday by Luther Ely Smith, president of the Jefferson Memorial Association.

The Greater New York CIO Council charged yesterday that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been visiting the offices of "left wing" CIO locals here to intimidate them and curtail their political activity in behalf of Henry A. Wallace.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Although Britain, France and the United States jointly condemned the new Czechoslovak Government today as a "disguised dictatorship," the British Government apparently has no immediate intention of withholding recognition from Premier Klement Gottwald's Government.

Three Tammany Negro Assembly District leaders sent a telegram yesterday to Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, notifying him of their support of President Truman's civil rights program and attacking Southern Democratic officials and members of Congress for opposing it.

HAMBURG, Germany, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Thirteen former Gestapo members were hanged today for having helped to carry out the personal order of Adolf Hitler to slaughter fifty Allied airmen who attempted to escape from a prison camp in July, 1944.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- Wage increases of 4 to 7 per cent have been awarded to members of four seagoing unions by Hubert Wyckoff, arbitrator, it was announced today.
Trading in cotton futures continued slow yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices were off 16 to 24 points net on the day at the close.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Veteran British troops were ordered today to proceed to Belize, capital of British Honduras, aboard a second heavy cruiser dispatched to the Central American crown colony as a precaution against possible incursions from Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that registration statements covering $18,000,000 of bonds, 210,000 shares of common and 45,000 shares of preferred stock were filed with it by six companies.

The Army transport Admiral E. W. Eberle, virtually a new ship after extensive reconversion work, will be renamed the General Simon B. Buckner, in honor of the Tenth Army commander, who was killed during the Battle of Okinawa, in a ceremony at 1:30 P.M. today at the Brooklyn Army Base.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Once an annual event the household equipment exhibit opened here today at the Grand Palais for the first time since 1939. A huge audience of housewives and their husbands gazed at shiny new equipment unavailable at any price and examined a lot of shabby material offered at exorbitant prices.

Decorative pictures made of wire, surplus gears, patches of steel strainers and similar unusual materials by Howard Grigs Brooks, New York artist, went on exhibit yesterday in his studio workshop at 230 West 139th Street.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- Two officials of the People's party of Czechoslovakia said here today that they expected a committee to be formed, possibly in London, to carry on activities approximating those of a government in exile.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -Three of five members of a Senate judiciary subcommittee favor admitting 100,000 displaced persons to the United States from Europe in the two years, starting July 1.

After an extensive and successful road tour, Maurice Chevalier returns to Broadway tomorrow evening. The noted French entertainer, who made his first postwar appearance in New York last spring at Henry Miller's, will set up shop at the John Golden Theatre for four weeks.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, ordered today the dissolution of all denazification commissions in the Soviet zone by March 10. He declared that the zone had been cleared of active Fascists and militarists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The House concurred today in a Senate-approved resolution to cut President Truman's budget by $2,500,000,000, but Republican sponsors conceded it was "a stab in the dark."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Dr. Elise H. Martens of the United States Office of Education called today for teamwork among all the professions associated with hospitalized children to make their instruction a more important part of the public educational program of every state.

Indoor track and field's big varsity show, twenty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships, will take over Madison Square Garden tonight. New York University is favored, but somewhat precariously, to retain its team title against the challengers of Manhattan, Yale, Army, Penn State and Seton Hall.

Earl G. Harrison, vice president of the University of Pennsylvania and dean of its law school, received the thirtieth presentation of the Guggenheim Award last night at a dinner in his honor at the Pennsylvania Club of New York, 106 West Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- It is "most improbable" that the effective date of the new policy to license all exports to Europe will be postponed, a spokesman for the Department of Commerce said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The reconstitution of a national bituminous coal wage-negotiating committee to meet possible demands by John L. Lewis was discussed here today by operators from all parts of the country. No decision was reached.

More than 100 representatives of Jewish women's organizations and communities from all parts of the country attended yesterday the opening campaign luncheon of the United Jewish Appeal national women's division in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 27 -- A southwide conference on human and civil rights here today agreed with "the principle of Federal anti-lynching legislation," called for enactment of a FEPC law and urged that segregation be eliminated in all graduate and professional schools, both state and private.
A threat to tie up the liner America fizzled yesterday when union leaders and the ship's crew rejected an ultimatum served on the line by Walter Avellar, ship's committeeman, or delegate.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 27--The urgent need for technicians in the field to help farmers with the critical job of saving the country's valuable top-soil was stressed today by the men who lead the volunteer farmer soil conservation districts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A ceiling of $4,500,000,000 on expenditures for the European Recovery Program in the year beginning April 1 was recommended today by the House Committee on Foreign Aid. It was the smallest amount yet proposed by an official source for starting the Marshall Plan.

Mayor O'Dwyer will leave Bellevue Hospital tomorrow at 2 P.M., Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday. The Mayor, who has been in the hospital since Feb. 20 under treatment for a heart condition brought on by fatigue, will spend several days at his official home, Gracie Mansion, before leaving for a California vacation.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Headed by the favored Talon from the Argentine, fourteen candidates were named today to race in the famed $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- At least $1,000,000 in additional revenue can be raised annually by leasing store and business space on the mezzanines of the Independent Division of the city's subway system, according to William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation and one of Mayor O'Dwyer's chief fiscal advisers.

T.B. Gittings, vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, denounced as "completely false" yesterday "any charge that Western Union gave racing-wire subscribers preference over war agencies during World War II."
PRAGUE, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The text of Premier Gottwald's address when he presented his new Cabinet to President Benes follows:

ATHENS, Feb. 27 -- Greek Army reports from Epirus today said that army units, which were stated yesterday to be taking the offensive northwest of Yanina, had recaptured the town of Delvinakion from the Markos guerrilla forces and had pushed northward in the Albanian frontier zone.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Ezequiel Navarra, champion of the Argentine, won his first match tonight in the national 3-cushion billiard tournament. He defeated Jay Davenport of Philadelphia, 50 to 46, in 58 innings. The national pocket billiard meet also opened here today.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 27 -- The Communist coup in Czechoslovakia did not surprise military government circles here. Intelligence services have known for some time that such a move was in preparation. But the speed and ease with which it was carried out was unexpected and disturbing.

Hand-printed wallpaper by Inez Croom, Inc., were put on display yesterday at Arthur H. Lee Sons, Inc., 501 Madison Avenue, where they are now available through decorators. Fresh variations on florals and scenic patterns designed by contemporary artists are colored by Miss Croom. Several blend in tone with new Lee Chintzes designed by the French artist, Pierre Frey, who has combined birds and other motifs into provincial type of patterns.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Gen. Bohumil Ecer, a supporter of the new regime in Czechoslovakia, said today that extra-legal methods had been used in installing the Leftist Cabinet in Prague. Due "revolutionary legality" was applied in some instances, he declared.

Herbert J. Pennock, the great southpaw pitcher who died last Jan. 30, and Harold Joseph (Pie) Traynor, the Pirate third baseman who spoiled a world series no-hitter for Herb in 1927, were voted into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Placing its support squarely behind the European Recovery Program, Britain's Labor party criticized the Soviet Union and its satellite states today for an "unjustified and regrettable" refusal to take part in the program.

North Carolina State became the fourth team to accept a bid to compete in the eleventh national invitation college basketball tournament, it was announced yesterday. The competition will start at Madison Square Garden March 11.

The American Bankers Association's campaign to combat inflation is not limited to influencing what is done by banks, but is designed to stimulate the use of banking opinion in directing public thinking along the lines of constructive anti-inflation action, Joseph M. Dodge, president of the ABA, declared yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- The Union of Burma, the newest independent country in the world, applied today for membership in the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Top officers of the Army Nurse Corps from all theatres and corps areas conferred today on problems involved in recruiting 2,000 reserves for active duty and 25,000 for inactive status this year.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Shortstop Marty Marion signed his 1948 contract today, but three other front line Cardinals have not come to terms with the club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- Three bids for reconversion of the liner Monterey into a luxury-class ship had been received today by the Matson Navigation Company.
Seventeen contributions amounting to $175 have been received by THE NEW YORK TIMES for its Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Department of the Army has summarily dismissed for security reasons seven employes at its administration center in St. Louis, it was announced today. The discharges occurred in the last several weeks.

Prospective expenditure of American dollars in Latin America under the European Recovery Program should carry the stipulation that the "new" foreign exchange dollars resulting from these transactions should be made available to liquidate obligations now owed to American exporters, according to comments in foreign trade circles here yesterday.

We lost hope back in one of those snowstorms that March would ever arrive. Nevertheless, the month that brings the first day of spring will start on Monday. Apropos of its coming, the Department of Agriculture offers data on what foods will be especially plentiful throughout the country during that period.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America will press for establishment of a government agency to provide a secondary market for housing mortgages immediately, it became known today.

Just one year after it had handed up its first interim report warning of the "existence of conditions and abuses which jeopardize the integrity of boxing," the February, 1947, grand jury seeking links between underworld and prizefight figures was discharged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A wire line communication system for installation under conditions of otherwise insuperable operational difficulty was one of 412 inventions listed as getting patent awards in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

While indications yesterday were that the America would sail on time next Wednesday, the one-day threat against the ship again reminded prospective travelers how uncertain are the waters on which the American merchant marine sails.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- "The Sound of Years," a 1947 novel by Merriam Model, has been purchased for the screen by Hal Wallis, independent producer at Paramount, and will be adapted to the screen as a vehicle for Barbara Stanwyck, Wallis announced today.

Declaring that the state's provision for its mental patients fell below the minimum standards set by the American Psychiatric Association, the Association for Improvement of Mental Hospitals, Inc., called on Governor Dewey yesterday to raise the level of mental care from $2.50 a day a patient to $7.50.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- In an effort to ward off another -- possibly the severest -- food crisis in Germany, Stanley Andrews, bip tite chief of food and agriculture, was scheduled to fly to the United States tonight.

A special committee of the country's rail executives, appointed by the Association of American Railroads to study the problem, has filed a report urging the establishment of a single agency to regulate all types of interstate commerce.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Democratic organization supporters picked up Governor Tuck's proposal to bar the name of President Truman from the November Presidential ballot and hustled it through the House Privileges and Elections Committee today by a unanimous vote.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Christian Dior's "boutique" collection of fifty models has beach wear and holiday clothes for all occasions.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The state's crop of babies last year was the largest on record, the Health Department stated today.
The establishment by Columbia University of an Institute for Urban Land Use and Housing Studies was announced last night by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university.

Teachers at the De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx voted 86 to 47 in support of a petition seeking the restoration to the school's library of two novels, "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Focus," it was announced yesterday. The books, which deal with anti-Semitism, were banned recently by Dr. John V. Walsh, the principal.
PARIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Former King Michael of Rumania Will renounce his abdication in a statement next week, a reliable Rumanian source said tonight.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 27 -- A new rice and wheat rationing system for 10,000,000 persons is scheduled to begin in the next two weeks as part of the Sino-American plan to curb unrest in five major cities.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 27 -- Communist-led attacks on police and public officials increased in intensity last night and early this morning.

Promotion ceremonies for twenty-one Fire Department lieutenants to captains and eleven firemen to lieutenants were held at 11 A.M. yesterday in the headquarters of Engine Company 31, 91 Lafayette Street. The men were sworn into their new ranks by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, who told them that "never in the history of the department has the morale been higher."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The step-by-step development of a transaction in the "gray" market in steel was unfolded today by each participant in turn before a steel subcommittee of the Senate Small Business Committee.

PRAGUE, Feb. 27 -- Premier Klement Gottwald today attacked the three-power statement of the United States, Great Britain and France condemning the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia. A Government declaration denied the three powers had the "slightest legal right to intervene in Czechoslovak affairs or even to criticize."

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 27 -- Middlebury College's team enjoyed a slim advantage in its effort to retain the Intercollegiate Ski Union championship, for which competition began today as part of the seventeenth annual Middlebury Winter Carnival.

With the Senate due to begin its foreign aid debate on Monday and the House Foreign Affairs Committee believed ready to support Chairman Eaton in an early and favorable report, the European Recovery Program approaches its final battle lines. No really damaging changes were made, under Senator Vandenberg's extraordinarily skillful guidance, in the Senate committee and none are indicated in the House committee.

IN "Explosion,"* Dorothy Cameron Disney gets away with murder in fine style. This is a quality we wish many other authors of who-shot-whos might emulate. They don't all have to write as well as Dashiell Hammett or Dorothy Sayers. But there is no reason why they shouldn't give themselves as much depth and range as the writers of other kinds of novels, no matter what the mechanical purists of the form tell you.

Initial razing operations on the old Criminal Courts Building, several blocks north of Foley Square on Centre Street, have begun, but it was revealed yesterday that plans remain indefinite for the use of that site and the adjoining one on which stands the old City Prison.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Ben Hogan continued to lead in the St. Petersburg open golf tournament today, but his margin was trimmed to two strokes.

Reflecting the record volume of sales by the Electric Auto-Lite Company, net earnings rose last year to $10,714,986, from $4,071,609 earned in 1946, Royce G. Martin, the company president, reported yesterday in the preliminary annual statement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Tenants of Knickerbocker Village and Hillside Homes in New York today carried their battle against proposed rent increases directly to the housing expediter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Legislation designed to meet the housing shortage, with a short-range objective of cheaper rental housing through greater incentives to builders and a long-range aim of standardization of building codes and measurements, was outlined today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- An agreement with about 600 members of four unions of the American Federation of Labor employed on the three daily newspapers in Detroit was reached today when the publishers granted a flat increase of 12 per cent in wages to the pressmen, stereotypers, photo-engravers and paper handlers.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- Procedures for the settlement of differences among members of the proposed International Trade Organization were adopted by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today. The full committee on organization expanded and clarified this part of the proposed charter as submitted by the preparatory commission at Geneva last year.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Annabelle Bucar, an American, resigned her job at the United States Embassy today, revealing at the same time she had been married to a Russian operatic baritone for thirteen months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Senate shelved the $720,000,000 Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway and power project today.

The United States has become the favored customer of Italian and Swiss yarn producers and weavers who formerly sold the bulk of their goods in the Near East and South America, according to Howard Levy of the American Supercraft Corporation, importing concern, who returned yesterday from a trip abroad. Rayon filament yarns, he said, can be obtained at a price which, including duty, makes them competitive in the second-hand yarn markets here.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Heavy disbursements by the British Government including repayment on next Monday of over 300,000,000 of the 3 per cent conversion loan, caused some advance reinvestment buying of gilt-edge issues in the stock markets here today.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson, a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, selected today his campaign manager and disclosed that final efforts of New Jersey party leaders to prevent a primary contest had failed.

Plans for the Berkshire Music Center, at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., which is sponsored by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, have been announced by Serge Koussevitzky, director of the school. The six-week session will run from July 5 to August 15, through the period of the Berkshire Festival Concerts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (Science Service) -- Preventing accurate radar spotting of planes through sowing the air ahead of them with quantities of wave-scattering aluminum "window" was a technique used during the recent war. Now comes a method whereby the plane itself in effect becomes its own "window."

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Soviet Russia, participating in the world speed skating championships for the first time, threw the organizing committee into a quandary today with the demand that it be allowed to race eight skaters instead of the international limit of four.

Dr. Frank Fremont-Smith, vice president for the United States of the International Committee for Mental Health, declared yesterday that the social sciences and psychology must be combined to eliminate the unconscious blocks to world peace.
