A group of dog lovers got together yesterday at 250 Park Avenue and organized the Dog Owners Protective Committee of New York City. It is opposed to a proposed revision of the Sanitary Code which would prohibit owners from keeping three or more dogs in their homes.

Wholesale butter prices, which have been jumping up and down on the New York Mercantile Exchange all week, declined 1 1/2 to 2 cents a pound yesterday, the second successive day of weakness in that commodity in the country's leading cities.

According to Bill Depperman, the Winchester promoter, who has been making a survey of the "stunt" or "trick" shooting field, any one of the three top shooters in this category could make Buffalo Bill or Annie Oakley look like a boy plinking at tin cans.

The Zionist Organization of America protested yesterday the failure of the United States Government to set a meat export quota for Palestine at a time when a food crisis was said to be rapidly developing in that country.
KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 27 -- President Truman tonight signed the resolution extending the life of the Maritime Commission for another year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The State Department made it clear today that it would reject a Soviet note urging the acceptance of Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia into the London conference of the United States, Britain and France on economic planning for the Western zones of Germany.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The consensus in this theatre of turf operations is that first money is earmarked for the Calumet Farm's Citation in tomorrow's nineteenth edition of the $50,000 added Flamingo Stakes. Seven other 3-year-olds are entered for the mile-and-a-furlong race, but all hands figure it as a one-colt run, that colt being Citation.

While most people will agree that fair rent control is necessary, the present legislation and regulations grant no consideration whatever to the many, many thousands of small taxpayers who are the owners of two-family properties.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- Adept handling of the discussion by the chairman, J. J. Oyervaar of the Netherlands, backed by the major shipping nations, put through the United Nations Maritime Conference today provisions for a self-perpetuating council of the International Maritime Organization.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Only six New York State resorts reported "good" skiing conditions today. The State Commerce Department said ten others had "fair" skiing.
Lubbock, Tex., sold $2,295,000 of various purpose bonds due from 1949 to 1968 to First Southwest Company at 100.003 for 2 1/2 s, 2 3/4 s and 3 1/4 s, an interest cost of 3.081 per cent.

Crafty practices adopted by "suave sharpers" operating in this city to ship cars into "closed" South American countries through tourist permits were described yesterday by J.S. Gavigan, manager of the automotive overseas department, American Automobile Association.

NANKING, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Dispatches to Nanking said the Communists had captured Penki, southeast of Mukden; broken into Sinmin, thirty miles west of Mukden, and into Kaiyuan, fifty-five miles to the north on the railroad between Mukden and Changchun, and pierced the outer defenses of Yingkow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today assured Mrs. Christos Kastanos, New York, that her two children, both born in Greece, would not be deported.

Frank Bowden and Ed McGrath, seeded Nos. 1 and 2 respectively, moved into the semi-final round of the Eastern indoor singles tennis championships yesterday on the Metropolitan Tennis Club courts in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

Announcement by Dr. Fackenthal of the formation of an Institute for Urban Land Use and Housing Studies at Columbia University coincides with increased public interest everywhere in the planning function in our cities and with continued irritation over the tardiness with which we are coming to grips with the housing shortage.
The cotton futures market closed 21 to 37 points net higher yesterday after early weakness on the New York Cotton Exchange.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 27 -- A Government spokesman announced today that in the first year of the five-year plan Yugoslavia had exceeded her program despite grave shortages of machinery and other industrial equipment.
WHEN the Russian Army began to push into Rumania in April, 1944, the relationship between the Soviet Union and the Balkans came to the forefront of our diplomacy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The annual Yale Junior Promenade was held tonight in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium, with 1,250 couples attending. For the first time in Yale history the freshmen class held its prom on the same night, with 600 students and guests present in the Armory.
A proposal to supplant the Girls Term of Magistrates Court with a new court having wider jurisdiction was approved in principle yesterday by spokesmen for several leading social agencies.

A middle-aged, well-dressed hold-up man, who obviously knew where to find what he sought, entered a two-story brick dwelling house in the Bronx at noon yesterday and stole $15,000 worth of jewelry from an antique bureau drawer and $6,000 in cash from a strongbox that was hidden behind the bricks of an artificial fireplace.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, will preach tomorrow what is being called "A Million Dollar Sermon." It is his hope to induce 1,612,090 communicant members to contribute $1,000,000 to his War Relief Fund. The "Million Dollar Sermon" will be only ten minutes long.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The FBI in checking the loyalty of about 85,000 Federal workers found reason to suspect fewer than 150 of them.

As one of your regular readers, I must protest against your obviously malicious attacks upon Majority Leader Halleck of the House of Representatives in your editorial columns of Dec. 12, to which I have delayed answering until I had checked certain figures and dates. You specifically criticize Mr. Halleck's remarks made during the debate on the Interim Bill to aid Europe, but you fail to mention that Mr. Halleck voted for this bill.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Two newspaper men on The Newburgh News were jailed today for contempt of court in declining to reveal confidential sources of information.

Although New York University defeated Rutgers, 83--66, for its nineteenth straight victory of the season, the unbeaten Violets did not enjoy a romp last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. On the contrary it was a rough, tough tussle that at times threatened to develop into a brawl.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these winter sports conditions and forecasts:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Government will limit the use of tin in can-making after this week to leave more of the metal for the Government's strategic stockpile.

We believe the Senate acted wisely yesterday in sending the St. Lawrence seaway project back to committee for further study. The size of the vote was impressive, nearly two to one. The lack of urgency for constructing the seaway now and the greater urgency of other needs for federal funds were a valid basis for rejection.

A dispute between the Hanscom Baking Company and Local 50 of the Baking and Confectionery Workers International Union, AFL, over the discharge on Dec. 1 of fifty-three employes was resolved yesterday in favor of the union.

For the second time in three days, Justice Agnes M. Craig in Municipal Court, the Bronx, yesterday dismissed eviction proceedings and instructed the tenants involved -- and their fellow tenants -- to pay no more rent until their quarters at 650 East 164th Street, the Bronx, had been certified as habitable.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- A Moslem employe of the French Residency who had incurred the displeasure of the household of the Sultan of Morocco was thrown recently into the Sultan's den of lions, official sources said today. This incident, according to these sources, has complicated the already strained relations between the Sultan and the Resident General, Pierre-Alphonse Juin.

"Stop the Music," a new contest show featuring Harry Salter and his orchestra, is now scheduled to have its premiere on March 21 over the ABC network (WJZ). It will fill the period between 8 and 9 P.M. on Sundays. Listeners will be called on the telephone and asked to identify musical selections being played on the program, the prizes including merchandise and $1,000 savings bonds.

The one-story industrial building at 29 Spring Street, West Orange, N.J., has been sold by Dr. Albert Blum to the G.N. Coughlin Company, manufacturer of furnace and flue cleaning compound, which has occupied the property under lease for about five years.

A large new market for low-priced canned spray insecticides has been opened with the development of a low-pressure type container made by Continental Can Company, Inc., and advertised for the first time by Gimbel's at 98 cents last Thursday, trade sources revealed here yesterday.

Appliance inventories of some smaller independent dealers now are so heavy that price cutting of top brand television receivers, automatic electric washers and even refrigerators is quietly occurring in a few instances, dealers and distributors reported yesterday. Both hastened to add the situation does not yet apply to large and experienced independents with adequate financing, to furniture and appliance chains or to department stores.

With the deadline for nominations only two days away, Frederick (Blackie) Myers, former vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, announced yesterday his candidacy for the office of president of the organization. He will run against Joseph Curran, incumbent, who also has announced his candidacy for another term.

The appearance of further complications on the international scene was reflected yesterday in a new retreat by the stock market. Although losses were reduced by a late rally, final quotations were irregularly lower, with most declines limited to fractions.

A new wage program for the nation's millions of white collar workers, calling for salary increases of $15 a week and minimum pay of $1 an hour was outlined yesterday by the executive board of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

The market for new capital will be occupied mostly next week with New York State's $300,000,000 soldiers' bonus bond issue. The big flotation is to come up for bidding on Tuesday. A syndicate of more than 200 investment houses headed by the National City Bank and the Chase National Bank is expected to make the only offer for the issue.

JERUSALEAM, Feb. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham, High Commissioner for Palestine, set machinery in motion today for the British withdrawal from Palestine with the announcement that he would assume special powers, beginning next Monday.

Alexander's Department Store, through its Biscayne Realty Corporation, has acquired title to the property at 2962-64 Third Avenue, the Bronx, which is part of its Third Avenue store. The parcel, 50 by 200 feet, extending through to Bergen Avenue, was purchased from the Mina S. Weaver Corporation.

The annual report of the Continental Motors Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net loss of $2,049,216 for the fiscal year ended with last October after giving effect to a tax refund of $7,680,000.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 -- The Government of India today declared Pakistan foreign territory for the purposes of customs and excise duties, effective next Monday. It was explained that the hoped for negotiations between the two dominions on reciprocal import-export arrangements had failed to materialize.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey sent to the Senate for confirmation today the reappointment of Edward P.F. Eagan of Rye, N.Y., to the State Athletic Commission. The designation is expected to occasion a bitter debate in the Senate, where Mr. Eagan already has been attacked this year for alleged inefficiency in coping with underworld elements in the boxing field.
The United States Golf Association has announced the recodification of its rules on amateur status, including some of the changes recently made known at the annual meeting of the organization.

With pre-match bickering at an end, Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott can get down to training for a real fight. The last obstacle to a return bout between the Brown Bomber and his challenger from Camden, N.J., was eliminated yesterday when Walcott signed to meet Louis on June 23 at the Yankee Stadium.

VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- L.V. Kurasov, Soviet High Commissioner, refused at today's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria to define "war booty" or say how much Austrian property he intended to claim in his zone under that category.

Three suspects roughly answering the description of one of the men sought for the murder of Harvey Haeberle in the Henry Hudson Hotel at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street last Wednesday were questioned and freed yesterday.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Feb. 26 (Delayed) -- There was some cautious optimism in Arab political circles today after Warren R. Austin's statement in the United Nations Security Council that an international force should not be used to enforce partition but to maintain order in Palestine and that a Big Five committee should look into possible threats to international peace arising out of the Palestine situation.

Hezekiah Cobb says that down in Virginia he was reading in this corner about the memories stirred up in a transplanted New Englander by a visit to the copy of a New England village Main Street set up in New York's Grand Central Station to lure travelers to a part of the world that can show them many examples of the real thing, aged in the wood.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 27 -- Prime Minister Stalin has sent a handwritten letter to Finnish President Juho K. Paasikivi urging the conclusion of a mutual defense pact between Finland and the Soviet Union, it was disclosed today. Disclosure of the Soviet demand struck the Finnish public like a bombshell.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, chairman, announced today the appointment of a sixteen-member executive committee of the Democratic National Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Arthur Valpey, new Harvard football coach, tonight named two fellow Michigan alumni as assistants, Forrest Russell Jordan as line tutor and David Nelson as back field mentor. The announcement, through the Harvard A.A. office, added that Valpey would select an end coach in a few days.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 27 -- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to lease the Suffolk County Army Air Field at Westhampton Beach to Walter F. McGinty, consultant aviation engineer of Stony Brook, L.I.

Dorothy Berliner Commins played a piano recital straight from the heart at Times Hall last night. Her return to New York's concert halls after an absence of several years gave her many admirers the opportunity to sit back and be charmed by her intimate, unhurried playing of music from the sixteenth century to the present day.

The Citizens Union has requested Governor Dewey to bring about the removal of County Judge Franklin Taylor of Brooklyn for physical disability. The union, in a letter written by Richard S. Childs, chairman, asks the Governor to act under the amendment to the State Constitution approved by the electorate last November whereby the Court of Appeals can remove a county judge for disability.

ATHENS, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A C-47 transport plane of the United States Aid Mission today dropped 2,500 pounds of medical supplies to the residents of Dhidhimotikhon, in Thrace near the Turkish border, which had been encircled by guerrillas for about a week.

A limited plea of not guilty to an indictment for grand larceny was withdrawn yesterday before County Judge Peter T. Farrell in Queens County Court by Isidore Ginsberg, 53 years old, of 33-32 Eighty-ninth Street, Jackson Heights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The anti-poll tax bill was quickly and unanimously approved today by a Senate Rules subcommittee over rising Southern protests against this and other aspects of President Truman's civil-rights program.

Tibor Serly, composer and conductor, had himself a time at Town Hall last night. With the aid of an orchestra of forty-odd players and two soloists, Mr. Serly had an opportunity to show what he could do in both capacities. He put on a concert that had enough music for two programs, and you could hardly blame him, since hiring an orchestra is an expensive proposition.

The first free chest X-ray service for the Greenwich Village area opened yesterday at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, with hundreds of teen-agers, housewives and veterans arriving from 3 to 8:30 P.M. to be tested for tuberculosis.

Three new films, including two from abroad, will open at local houses today. The Hollywood entry, via Paramount, is "Albuquerque,"' a Western in color, arriving at the Victoria. Randolph Scott is starred with Barbara Britton, George (Gabby) Hayes, Russell Hayden, Catherine Craig and Lon Chaney. . . .

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Clinton P. Anderson, proposed today a voluntary agreement for the more than 12,000 wholesale bakers. Its main purpose would be to conserve wheat through the elimination of consignment selling of bread.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today recommended that Pan American Airways be authorized to operate a domestic route connecting its Miami terminal with New York City, but that permission not be granted for a requested intercoastal network of Pan American Airways.

The Security Council has about completed its debate on the work of its Committee of Good Offices in Indonesia. The question is whether to continue the Committee and to expand its authority as a mediating agent between the Netherlands and the Republic during the critical period between now and Jan. 1, 1949, when the Netherlands is to turn over authority in the Indies to a United States of Indonesia.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Foodstuffs to be imported in the Government drive to bring down prices were decided today at a Cabinet meeting dealing with the question of prices and wages.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Foreign Minister Bidault expressed in carefully measured sentences in a speech to the Assembly today the profound disquietude the French Government feels because of the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia and indications of impending similar moves in other countries.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination will lose the interest of its firmest supporters unless it is willing to tackle discrimination problems from a wider range than mere employer-employe and trade union relations, Roderick Stephens of the city group of the organization declared yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers reached the end of the first stage of their negotiations on an Austrian treaty today without coming any nearer to a settlement of a vital question of German assets in Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee discussed today the investigation into the handling by Attorney General Tom C. Clark of vote fraud charges in the 1946 Congressional election in President Truman's home state of Missouri.

"The Diary and Sundry Observations of Thomas Alva Edison" has been scheduled for publication on April 22 by the Philosophical Library. The book has been edited by Dr. Dagobert Runes, who also edited "The Selected Writings of Benjamin Rush," published late last year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Home planners and women delegates attending the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders here this week are returning to their offices with some new ideas about the comforts and conveniences which the residences of the future will provide.
Rate increases that will add $2,500,000 to the gross revenues of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was granted by the Public Service Commission yesterday.

After pleading guilty in Federal Court yesterday to a forty-one count indictment charging mail fraud, David J. Steinberg, 57-year-old furrier of 294 East 162d Street, the Bronx, won leniency from Judge Sylvester J. Ryan because he had assisted authorities in convicting three Boston forgers after hearing them discuss their activities at the Federal House of Detention.

NANKING, Feb. 27 -- The Communists' radio broadcast from north Shensi tonight the announcement of their capture yesterday of Yingkow, important port on the Gulf of Liaotung, 120 miles south of Mukden.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Paul Dillon of St. Louis, a lawyer, has been served in Newton Mass., with a subpoena to appear Monday before a Federal grand jury in Chicago investigating the obtaining of paroles for four Capone gangsters, Federal Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee cut today $84,417,168 from the $587,837,431 President Truman asked for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments and the Federal courts.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that the net income for 1947 amounted to $9,141,346, in contrast to a deficit of $11,000,699 for 1946.

Ike Williams, lightweight champion of the world, had a close call against Kid Gavilan, speedy Cuban, in their ten-round non-title bout at Madison Square Garden last night. The 135-pound king received a unanimous decision, but to the majority in the crowd of 14,907 the verdict was unsatisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, sued today for a quick court review of the Taft-Hartley Law ban on union political spending. The objective is a Supreme Court ruling on the rights organized labor may legally exercise in the 1948 campaign.

Four hundred thirty-eight probationary patrolmen were graduated yesterday from the New York Police Academy at exercises held in the Washington Irving High School, Sixteenth Street and Irving Place, after completing a twomonth training course. All except two of them are veterans of World War II.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Grain markets made a weak start and a strong finish today on the Board of Trade.

The American Labor party charged yesterday that recent private conferences between Governor Dewey and Republican leaders in Albany and between Mayor O'Dwyer and Democratic leaders at Bellevue Hospital on the Mayor's higher fare proposal usurped the power of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 21, 1948, totaled 805,376 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 71,114 cars, or 9.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 38,687 cars, or 3.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 82,995 cars, or 11.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The Moscow request that Finland enter a military mutual assistance pact with the Soviet Union is the first move in the implementation of a long and carefully prepared plan for the seizure of power by Finnish Communists and the complete inclusion of Finland in Soviet satellite system, according to British sources best informed on events in Finland.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- The United States has advised the United Nations that Nicholas Kyriazidis, Greek journalist whose detention on Ellis Island for six days in December precipitated a minor crisis between the world organization and its host country, might be subject to deportation or restriction if the United Nations chose to renew his accreditation.

Percentagewise, retail trade here dropped sharply this week in comparison with a year ago. Department store volume was estimated as off 20 to 25 per cent. The chief factor was that there were five selling days in the week against six a year ago, due to the fact that Washington's Birthday was celebrated on Monday. In 1947 it was on Saturday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Criticizing United States policy on the Holy Land as likely to jeopardize the United Nations partition plan, the Jewish Agency for Palestine told the Security Council today that it was prepared to go ahead with the setting up of a Jewish state even without the backing of an international force.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 27 -- "The Czechoslovakia story" will be repeated in other countries as long as the United States continues its "get tough" policy toward Russia, Henry A. Wallace said here tonight.
Twenty-one Puerto Rican young women arrived here by plane yesterday to take up duties as domestic employes under an arrangement with the New York State Employment Service.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Southern Governors Conference was summoned today by Governor Lane of Maryland to meet March 13 in Washington to hear a committee's report on the civil-rights proposals of President Truman.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- British boxing enthusiasts saw Joe Louis in action tonight in his first exhibition bout of a month-long series at Earls Court Stadium.

A documentary motion picture produced by Madeleine Carroll in France and designed to show what the nations of Europe are doing to salvage their displaced children from the effects of war was screened yesterday under the auspices of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures and the Museum of Modern Art.

Kensley Rosen, 28-year-old violinist from Seattle, gave his second New York recital before a large and enthusiastic audience last night at Carnegie Hall. The program he presented contained the Tartini-Kreisler "Devil's Trill" Sonata, Beethoven's Sonata in D major, Op. 12, No. 1; the Adagio from Buch's "Konzertstueck," Bach's "Chaconne," Schumann's Sonata in A minor and Bartok's "Rhapsody," No. 1.

Business booked at the New York Gift Show which ended yesterday in the New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels was definitely satisfactory but "not extremely heavy," exhibitors stated. They agreed that the event saw far more orders placed than the Chicago show of several weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An ex-Communist testified today that his former comrades hounded him with "filthy gossip and lies" and drove him from his home after he quit the Communist party.

Today's events: "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," 2 P.M., and "The Barber of Seville," 8:15 P.M., Metropolitan Opera Company; eighty-piece orchestra, conducted by Ferruccio Burco, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Alton Jones, piano, Town Hall, 3; Children's Music of Mozart, Norma Dorfman, conductor; Rosalie Landres, piano, Brooklyn Museum, 3; National Music Festival, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; Edison Harris, tenor, Town Hall, 5:30; New York Jazz Club, Roosevelt Hall, 5:30.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27 -A complete revision of the New Jersey railroad taxing system, pegging annual taxes for the next five years to about $16,000,000 and giving the lion's share to municipalities, was proposed today by the State Tax Policy Commission.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 -- A bomb placed in a car killed five Arabs and wounded twenty-five more in Haifa today in the worst of a series of violent incidents.

The question as to whether you can have a lot of foxes and a lot of pheasants in the same area may never be answered to the satisfaction of all concerned, but the New York Conservation Department has been carrying on a project that promises to give some of the answers.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Communist-sponsored Socialist Unity party has absolute control of the Berlin police, with thirty- seven of sixty-one key posts and an estimated 70 per cent of the total force, the British-licensed newspaper Telegraf reported today.

THE planned American tour of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra in the fall of 1949 is not only the first postwar visit by a European ensemble to take form so far, but may also develop into history's first transatlantic airborne musical invasion.
DUSTY PEARSON'S athletic ability gets him into trouble. His family is billed for furniture damaged in a prank. "You'll take that summer job at Camp Wahtoka," his father says, "and pay me back."

WHEN the cold March wind shrills outside the windowpane, then it's time for pancakes, hot and fluffy from the griddle. It matters not the time of day or night. Apple pancakes come to breakfast on Sunday morning with spicy little pork sausages. Pancakes rolled around creamed chipped beef (or chicken or what you will) tempt guests at a noontime lunch or midnight supper.

A MONTH has been completed which will be known for its break in commodity prices and might be known for ushering in a readjustment similar to that of 1920. There are points of difference, however, when comparison is made with the first collapse after World War I, so that perhaps the period will be called a "recession" rather than a primary post-war "depression."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28 -- The impasse created two days after the British trade mission had commenced parleys last week with the Brazilian Government ended today when Brazil tentatively agreed to continue the talks for a trade agreement based on barter trading.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb.28 -- The average white Southern voter appears to be unalterably opposed to President Truman's civil-rights program, but undecided as to whether the South should leave the Democratic party.
A FRENCHMAN enters a restaurant in Paris and, to his great surprise, sees a rare item on the menu: boiled beef. He hails the waiter excitedly and orders the dish, but the garcon shakes his head.

AFTER a trying semester or two as a CBS executive, the wry Goodman Ace has abandoned his pursuit of a vice-presidency and, with the not inconsiderable help of his wife, Jane, returned to radio in the nick of time.

HAVANA, Feb. 28 -- Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations conference on trade and employment, tonight withdrew the United States compromise proposal on new preferential tariff systems in a protest against the "extreme" views incorporated in amendments filed by Walter Muller of Chile.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Feb. 29 -- The only worthy memorial that India can build for Gandhi will be a full realization of his dreams for India's freedom. M. Asaf Ali, India's Ambassador to the United States declared this afternoon at a press conference before the opening of a two-day Art of Asia exhibit at Wilson College.

Employes of the Cotton Exchange won a modified union shop agreement yesterday, ending the threat of a strike against that market, but this settlement apparently had little bearing on contract negotiations between the United Financial Workers, Local 205, AFL, and the Stock and Curb Exchanges.

Drs. Joe V. Meigs and Howard Ulfelder for almost two years have been adapting smear techniques to early detection of cancer in hard-to-reach areas of the body in the Massachusetts General Hospital. As this column has pointed out in the past the technique was first perfected by Dr. George N. Papanicolaou of New York who detected early uterine cancer by microscopic study of cells from vaginal fluid.

SOMETIME this fall Harcourt Brace will publish Carl Sandburg's first novel, tentatively titled, "Remembrance Rock," which, even in this day of voluminous tomes, stands pretty close to the record class with a total of some 1,500 pages.

Mayor O'Dwyer has suffered no permanent heart impairment because of the condition of extreme fatigue that caused his physicians to send him to Bellevue Hospital on Feb. 21 for at least a week of rest and physical check-up, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, heart specialist.
A twin attack upon slave labor in the Soviet Union and the remnants of peonage in the United States was delivered yesterday at a conference called by the Workers Defense League hi the McAlpin Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Employers asked Common Pleas Court today for an injunction against a work stoppage by 900 members of the International Typographical Union in twenty-eight commercial printing plants here.

A STEADY stream of letters flows into this corner from people who buy records, and a good many of them contain gripes about the hazards of record purchasing. Count that week lost that has not at least one note about atrocious surface noises on some precious new set of disks, and judging by the records I have been hearing lately, there will be an increase in this complaint.

Surely few statesmen have faced more poignant tragedy in their official lives than has President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia. Twice within ten years he has felt obliged to yield to the pressure of powerful neighbors to save his country from disaster. The first lime it did not work; what will happen the second time no one can yet tell.

Milder weather last week spurred interest in spring goods of all types, increasing activity at retail, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. This increased activity at retail, however, did not reflect itself in the wholesale markets, the report stated.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 28 -- The United States must regard itself as the "arsenal of democracy" in the field of ideas and rally to the defense of freedom and liberty with the same determination it applied to its role of democracy's arsenal for military supplies in the war years, George V. Allen, former Ambassador to Iran, declared tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- S.W. Labrot Jr.s' Bovard, racing in his best form, won the $15,000 added Louisiana Derby today at the Fair Grounds.

MALCOLM ROSS has known labor conditions, at first-hand, for many years. He has worked in copper mine and oil-field -- and seven years with the National Labor Relations Board. Finally, he was chairman of the Fair Employment Practices Committee from 1943 until it withered on the vine in 1946.

ONE hundred years ago tomorrow Augustus Saint-Gaudens was born in Dublin, Ireland. Brought to America when he was scarcely 6 months old, he lived and went to school on the Bowery in New York. When he died, in 1907, he left America one of her great legacies of art.

Coming through with high inspirational fervor, in some cases against heavy odds, New York University hit the jackpot again in the twenty-seventh annual indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. at Madison Square Garden last night.

It is our habit, and even our tradition, to think that March means spring; that once February is over, the sun is going to turn warm and friendly, the days will lose their chill, and the little flowers of the woodland will burst bud and deck our world with color.

The most distinguished French psychologist of our time was probably the late Pierre Janet, who died last year at the age of 88. One of his disciples, Professor Elton Mayo of Harvard, has just published "Some Notes on the Psychology of Pierre Janet," for the purpose of telling Americans about the French psychologist's views on the problems of society -- views concerned with the nature of obsessions.

Manufacturing employment in New York State showed a drop of 13,000 workers between December, 1947, and January, 1948, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday. This was the third successive month that jobs in industry had declined.

WHETHER new films from the studios of Hollywood will be shipped to England before the dwindling supply or pre-embargo pictures is exhausted may well be decided during the next several days. Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, is in London at the moment, having left New York on Friday by plane, accompanied by his executive assistant, Joyce O'Hara, and Allen Welsh Dulles, legal adviser on foreign affairs.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The west coast of Florida is currently disturbed by an argument whose bitterness is none the less because it all began 410 years ago when Hernando De Soto arrived in search of the Fountain of Youth.

Recently compiled figures show farm tenancy is at the lowest figure since 1890. About 30 per cent of the nation's 5,900,000 farms are now operated by renters. The peak of tenancy was in 1930, when renters worked 42.4 per cent of the farms. Several factors contribute to this important economic and sociologic reversal of a long-term trend.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 28 (UP) -- President Paasikivi advised the Soviet Ambassador of Finland's reaction to Mr. Stalin's alliance proposal at a brief meeting today. He informed General Savonenkov of the steps that were being taken to produce a definite reply to the Soviet request.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- With the Soviet Union abstaining on all counts, the United Nations Security Council voted today to continue its good-offices work in the Netherlands East Indies and ordered a full report on charges that the Dutch were setting up a puppet regime in West Java.

NANKING, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Chinese Government forces were reported today to have surged out from behind the Great Wall into Manchuria to launch a counter-attack against Communist columns threating Mukden.

Two of the six new housing developments for the city that were made possible by adoption of the $135,000,000 increase in state capital loan funds in the election last fall came a step nearer realization yesterday when Commissioner Herman T. Stichman of the State Division of Housing announced approval of applications by the New York City Housing Authority for Bronx River Houses in the Bronx and Albany Houses in Brooklyn.
GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- There are more refugees from Communist totalitarianism in Europe today than there were refugees from Nazi and Fascist totalitarianism in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The development of the European Recovery Program from premature child to Goliath of the Eightieth Congress is a story of political necessity and the legislative dexterity of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg.

WHEN Columbia University recently announced a jump to $600 a year for tuition as of next year (about 33 per cent) and a 7 to 17 per cent rise in dormitory rents, and Barnard also raised tuitions, it looked like the start of a new "wave" of higher charges for education in American college.

A NEIGHBOR'S well-filled tool rack can supply information to any gardener who is considering the purchase of equipment. Scratched blades and worn handles indicate the most useful, necessary tools. Less battered equipment may be handy, but it is probably not in constant demand.

WHEN you can get 100 actors to agree on something, that's news. When they back up their agreement with investments, that's New Stages Inc., which has sprung from the grass roots of Shubert Alley and Radio City to become the town's most exciting new producing organization.

The skepticism of seasoned investment counselors about the ability of the power and light industry to finance its $6,000,000,000 expansion program in the face of apathetic public reception to offerings of securities in general in recent months was displaced with finality last week as another in a series of utility stock offerings was oversubscribed.
Tomorrow two packers from the Louvre in Paris will enter the Metropolitan Museum of Art and begin packing into three by four-foot boxes the acre of priceless tapestries lent by the French Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- The United Nations was warned today that twenty-one devastated countries in Europe, Asia and Africa would undergo an exhaustion this year of their foreign credits and a rapid depletion of their foreign exchange unless more outside help was forthcoming.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had sent laudatory letters to Charles C. Lockwood of Brooklyn, recently retired as a Supreme Court Justice, and Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, founder of Greenwich House, whose term as a member of the City Housing Authority expired recently and was not renewed.
WARSAW, Feb. 28 -- The Polish Government announced tonight it would soon sign a military alliance with Rumania.

John Allen Cromar, 24 years old, of 127 West Eighty-first Street, who served during the war as a truck driver with the Eighth Armored Division in Great Britain and France, was turned over to military authorities on a charge of desertion yesterday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.
Mr. Gorman is a radio director, one of his current assignments being "Young Doctor Malone."

CHARLES ATLAS, muscleman extraordinary, once strapped a harness to his head and pulled a seventy-ton railway observation car a hundred feet along a track after it had defied the sinews of six section hands. This and a wealth of other biographical curiosa are revealed by Robert Lewis Taylor in this collection of his pieces which have appeared in The New Yorker, The Saturday Evening Post, Life and Red Book over the past half-dozen years.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Bills permitting five upstate cities to exclude from their two per cent constitutional tax limitation the amount to be raised by taxation on real estate for educational purposes during the two fiscal years commencing after January 1, 1949, were signed without comment today by Governor Dewey.

When the curtain went down on free Czechoslovakia in the fall of 1938 President Eduard Benes, resigning his office, told his fellow-countrymen: "I remain what I have always been, a convinced democrat." Last week, as another curtain fell, he again defended democracy as "the only reliable and durable basis for a decent and dignified human life."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, in a statement today challenged the announcement made by the Air Force and the State Department to Congress last night that the United States had delivered 936 combat and bombing planes out of 1,071 that were promised in 1945 to be made available to China over a period of three years.

BUCHAREST (By Wireless). ANA PAUKER is both architect and builder of the new Rumanian Communist state. She not only plans but she translates political, economic and social blue-prints into action as secretary of the Rumanian Communist party and Minister for Foreign Affairs of the newly proclaimed republic -- the first woman in the world to hold the title of Foreign Minister.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 28 -- President Truman tonight signed a bill revising and liberalizing the civil service retirement system. He also approved a measure extending export controls on scarce materials and on rail transportation for three months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The United States has turned over $38,391,000 to France as final payment for French services and supplies to United States troops during the war.

With hearings on the Ploeser bill (HR 5470) scheduled to be held on Wednesday by the House Banking Committee, exporters will enter a major phase of their battle against the price criteria principle of export control as announced by the Office of International Trade.

MADRID, Feb. 28 -- The official cancellation of the requiem mass commemorating the seventh anniversary of the death of Alfonso XIII was followed today by demonstrations and street fights between monarchists and Falangist youths.

NOW that travel is fighting its way back to normal, books about it are multiplying on the tables and shelves of the bookshops. To the total are now added these three volumes by two excellent writers. Both Mr. Clark and Mr. Roberts write in an engaging style; both feel deep affection for the lands which they describe.

The undefeated Squadron A Regulars registered their eleventh consecutive polo triumph last night by turning back the Ramapo trio, 16 -- 12, in the feature of a double-header at the victors' armory. Scoring honors were shared by Al Parsells of the losers and Paul Miller of the Regulars with six goals each.

IN the course of this novel Bruce Hamilton tells of the travesties of justice perpetrated by an English jurist, Sir Francis Brittain, the "Hanging Judge." The opening scenes establish the tempo: an innocent man, sentenced by Brittain, goes to his death while Sir Francis, at home, partakes of his breakfast.

A BRISK efflorescence of French films in local art theatres last week, manifested by three Gallic imports popping out within a span of six days, briefly aroused wistful memories of activities in this line in years gone by. It also gave cause for reflection upon the French films we've seen here since the war.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- The Egyptian Government is expected to sign tomorrow its reciprocal trade agreement with the Soviet Union to exchange cotton for wheat and corn, it was learned today.

A temporary stay of the New York State Liquor Authority's action refusing to renew the wholesale liquor license of International Distributors, 5 East Fifty-second Street, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora. The board's denial will be reviewed on March 8 in Special Term, Part 1, Supreme Court. The concern's current license expires at midnight tonight.

With the Manhattan Homicide Squad slated to be separated into two sections tomorrw, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced last night a series of changes in the detective division to enable the units to function at top efficiency.

A railroad passenger ticket delivery service, using Western Union facilities and intended to eliminate waiting lines at ticket windows, will be started here tomorrow, the New York Central, New Haven, Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley Railroads announced yesterday.

THOUGH Mary Ann welcomed every gift her family gave her for becoming 7, what she really liked better than the necklace or even the piggy bank was the birthday box of paints. She would have set about making a picture at once, but having to go to Mrs. Pennyfeather's for eggs delayed her.

Frank Bowden and Eddie McGrath of the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club successfully hurdled their first and second-round opponents as play in the Eastern indoor doubles championship got under way at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory last night.
ATLANTA, Feb. 28 -- The Southern Governors' revolt against President Truman's civil-rights program unquestionably has the support of an overwhelming majority of white voters in this area.

HERE are cartoons, quizzes and anecdotes, all having to do with crime and detection. The first things to catch the eye as one leafs through the book are the cartoons, which make crime seem much funnier than it has any right to be.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Strictly according to the script, Calumet Farm's Citation, apparently the best 3-year-old in the land, scampered home first in the $62,100 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park today. It was considerable of a scamper; he took it by half a dozen lengths.

Readers of Michael O'Keefe's quiz, "Arms and the Office," were instructed to pair the picture of each well-known general with the statement with which he is credited. Each picture had a number, each statement had a letter.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 28 (UP) -- President Juan Jose Arevalo called on the United States today to defend the interests of Latin-American nations in their territorial disputes with Great Britain.

OURS is a short-memoried country, brief in its enthusiasms. So many a public man has learned in bitter disillusion. We seem constantly to crave new objects for our admiration. Let a man depart from the pattern to which we had given our approval, and we soon forget what it was that we admired in him before.

THE North African scene, now so firmly in the news, deserves first-class treatment in fiction. Moslem life, colorful and ambiguous to the westerner, is, for the most part, unfamiliar. A good novel could give a more accurate picture than the bare, cold facts of history.

ISAMU NOGUCHI is neither a dancer nor a choreographer, but he has nevertheless made a stimulating and important contribution to the dance, as any one who has attended Martha Graham's past few seasons with any degree of regularity must be aware.

A laboratory course for journalist students has been inaugurated at the University of Notre Dame. The course is designed for journalism majors now in the second semester of their junior year. Its purpose is to enable them to put into practice theories learned during the first semester by providing actual problems in writing, editing, copyreading, typography and layout.
CLAIRTON, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Ivan Bucar, a Yugoslav immigrant, disowned today his blond daughter Annabelle who quit her United States Embassy job in Moscow and married a Russian singer.

UNDERBODY coating of motor vehicles, to serve as a preservative and to reduce sound effects, has come into popularity during the past two years. There are several types of compounds utilized in the process, which has demonstrated its worth on new and old cars.

THIS is the season when motorists begin to get fidgety over winter driving and think seriously of quick trips across the Mason-Dixon Line to meet spring half way. It may surprise many drivers, as it did this one, to learn that less than a day's driving will take them not only into a climate that is nearly always temperate, but also to a stepping-off point for a wide choice of interesting trips.

The picture of earnings in the film industry is not "top-notch" performance, judging by the financial statements of several companies. Rising operating costs converged against declining income, has reduced profits substantially from the "lush" war years. The industry, however, has taken a serious part in the major role of cost-cutting which may be reflected eventually in the financial reports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- President Truman told home-seeking veterans today he hopes they can "stimulate a dilatory Congress into action" on housing legislation.

OUR world, it has often been charged, is incapable of symbolism and grandeur. When our architects build monuments, so the argument goes, they turn to the obelisks of the Egyptians or the triumphal arches and domed temples of the Romans, or create such trivia as the World's Fair trylon and perisphere.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- Town meeting season, surest harbinger of spring to New Englanders, bursts into full bloom beginning Monday. In hundreds of town halls in the area, it will mark the opening of a month-long reign of democracy in its purest form.

Wider participation in community projects, athletics and group play among present day youth is most likely to remove prejudices in later life, junior high school pupils declared yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman will officially open the 1948 Red Cross Fund campaign with a radio broadcast from Key West at 10 P.M. tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Grains advanced several cents a bushel in a firm market on the Board of Trade today. Soy beans and lard followed cereals upward.

ATHENS, Feb. 28 -- Beginning in the small hours of this morning, Athens and Piraeus Security Police began what they described as a systematic effort to clean up Communists and other subversive elements in the rear of the war front against Gen. Markos Vafiades' rebel forces.
PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Invitations to a meeting of the sixteen-power Economic Conference in Paris have been issued by the French Foreign Office, according to an official statement issued here today.

THE author of "A Study of History," Arnold J. Toynbee, was as surprised as anyone who didn't know history when his one-volume abridgment hit the best-seller lists. But he can explain it. It was luck, he says -- his book was published by Oxford just about the time that Mr. Marshall became Secretary of State and Americans were conscious of the possibility of a new chapter in their history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- As a measure of America's increasing involvement in the intricate affairs of the world, nothing could be more illuminating than a file of this week's front pages. For there, crowding such traditional top-line subjects as Presidential politics and management-labor disputes into secondary position, were the following headlined items:

INSPECTOR FRENCH, who is much admired by many grownups, plays a part in this mystery, but with customary tact he assumes a minor role, leaving the major one to a schoolboy. Young Robin, ardent amateur detective, and his friend Jack are spending a peaceful vacation together when they discover that workmen are trafficking in tools stolen from the railroad which Jack's father is building.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 28 -- President Truman's civil-rights doctrine has created almost solid resistance among white voters in Alabama.

American educators must take the responsibility for preserving international freedom, Dr. Ernest O. Melby, dean of the New York University School of Education, declared yesterday at the closing session of a three-day United Nations Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Martin Wagner, president of the United Chemical Workers Union, CIO, announced today dismissal of two New Jersey staff members for "promoting communism." He identified them as David Elliot and Gerard Mullica.

A broad retrenchment operation is under way in the metalworking industries in the New York area, it was learned here yesterday. Steps now being taken to reduce costs, curtail expenditures and adjust to reduced levels of operation include cutbacks in purchasing, curtailment of some plant expansion plans and reduction of inventories.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 28 -- Dartmouth moved close to its sixth Quadrangular Hockey League title in eight years by beating Harvard, 8 -- 5, tonight in a rough battle marked by a third-period fist fight before 1,700 fans in Davis Rink.

MATTRESSES are not supposed to last indefinitely, we are told by the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers. Plenty of housewives expect a mattress to stay shapely and bouncy for a dozen years or more, but hotel housekeepers are less optimistic.

ONE would suppose that a compendium of auction records might make dreary reading, and one would seldom be disappointed. Actually, this volume, designed for utilitarian purposes, flies in the face of tradition and makes good browsing.

NANKING, Feb. 28 -- The question of who was elected to the National Assembly remained unsettled today after a week of heated discussions and political maneuvering. The squabble over Assembly seats and the prospect of a similar dispute over the new Legislative Yuan may result in postponement of the program for bringing the new Constitution into operation this spring.

ANYONE unaccountably discovered chuckling in the neighborhood these days is probably recalling a performance of "Mister Roberts." For this robustious saga of the crew of a cargo ship during the war is much funnier than the war and a memorable piece of comic entertainment.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 28 -- School leaders representing every section of the country reported here this week that the crisis in American education had reached alarming proportions. More than 12,000 teachers, superintendents and college officials, meeting in sixty major school organizations affiliated with the National Education Association, considered the vital issues facing schools and colleges.

WMCA's interracial dramatic series, "New World A Coming," heard on Tuesdays at 9:30 P.M., will start its fifth broadcasting year in March and will celebrate its "anniversary month" with repeat performances of four outstanding scripts.

ONLY a layer of mink separates the women that Clare Boothe gave the rough side of the tongue to some years back and the women that Virginia Chase treats with such penetrating sympathy in the current novel, "Discovery."

The appeal for expanded programs of fundamental aeronautical research, made in the annual report of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, should not be ignored. Basic research such as that conducted at the laboratories of the National Advisory Committee at Langley Field, Moffett Field and Cleveland is fundamental to security.

Only for a few minutes, as the opening half drew to a close, did an upset appear likely in the City College of New York-Fordham basketball contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon. The Rams had cut a 12-point deficit to 3 and though Nat Holman's favored Beavers were in command, 31 -- 28, they seemed to have forfeited something.

AS a "veteran" of frequency modulation broadcasting and programming, I feel rather strongly that the beginning of regular simultaneous broadcasts over both FM and standard radio is a coup de grace that ends for the present the progress that we should be making in realizing FM's true potentialities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Countries holding out their hands for aid are the very ones that treat American airlines worst, a report from a House Commerce subcommittee said today. It urged "a more aggressive attitude" of support for United States lines abroad.

Last held here in November of 1939, when Cecil Yates and Caesar Moretti won the event at Madison Square Garden, six-day bicycle racing returns to New York tonight, when a field of fourteen teams in the sixty-seventh international event at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory.

Two items from yesterday morning's newspaper report bear far too close a relationship to comfort Americans who stand four-square for freedom of the press. In Newburgh, N.Y., two reporters have been fined and jailed for refusing to reveal the source of their news.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Two Newburgh News employes who went to jail rather than betray a confidence received presents and messages of congratulations today while their lawyers tried unsuccessfully to get them freed.
DURING the performance of "Peter Grimes" last week at the Metropolitan a neighbor leaned over and whispered, "I could understand the music so much better if I didn't have to make out the words!"

ABOUT a century ago a desperate band of Germans tried to kidnap Clio from the slopes of Parnassus and shut her up in the kitchen of a dusty pedant they called Science. It is doubtful whether the abduction was really successful, or whether the goddess was merely amusing herself with a casual flirtation.
BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Nearly half of the members of Adolf Hitler's general staff and high command are alive and at large with no definite evidence of war crimes charges pending.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, Democratic national chairman, tonight called on "all true liberals" to unite behind President Truman in this election year. He was the principal speaker at an Indiana Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner, with plates at $25 each.

PROBABLY no other foreigner in China during recent years has acquired a legend to equal that of William Henry Donald, the Australian newspaperman who, from the last days of the Manchus until 1940, was adviser and self-styled Dutch uncle to whoever was in power and willing to listen to him.

Today, in many countries of the world, this extra day of February belongs to the children. But not in a holiday or carnival sense. Far from it. For nearly 230 million children in the war-ravaged and famine areas -- on the European Continent, in India and China -- are in desperate need of protection from starvation and disease.
The battle between New York City and New York State over money last week reached the floor of the Legislature.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- The twin villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, traditional rivals in this Sleepy Hollow country of the Hudson Valley, appeared to be near marriage today when latest revisions were made in a proposed city charter.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Paced by Paul Campbell of Worcester, Mass., Dartmouth defeated Pennsylvania for the second time this season in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Palestra today, 66 -- 62.

An audience of almost 3,000 packed Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon for the American debut of Ferruccio Burco, 8-year-old Italian conductor, whose fame has been spreading since he appeared in Rome last June. There is only one word to describe what he did to his listeners. He "wowed" them.

Three University of Wisconsin biochemists, Reid H. Leonard, W.H. Peterson and M.J. Johnson, have devised a process for converting the sulfite waste of paper mills into lactic acid, which is used in the tanning, lacquer and food-processing industries. American paper mills dump six billion gallons of sulfite waste liquor into rivers and lakes each year.

HELSINKI, Feb. 28 (AP) -- John Werket of Minneapolis finished second in the 500-meter (547 yards) world speed skating championship today. He also took sixth place in the 5,000-meter (3 1/8-mile) event.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Italy's general election is only seven weeks ahead and all parties have thrown themselves into the electoral struggle with a vim unusual even in a country like Italy, where the people take their politics more seriously than in most.

Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw, who started with the Travelers Aid Society of New York as a volunteer case worker and now is vice president, will celebrate her twentieth anniversary with the organization this week.

THIS is the second of Irving Brant's volumes on James Madison. The first, bearing the subtitle "The Virginia Revolutionist" and carrying Madison to the age of 29, appeared in 1941. This one covers only seven years, during most of which he was in the Continental Congress or the Virginia General Assembly; it ends on the eve of the Federal Convention, where he gained his clearest title to enduring fame.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets made by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The distinguished collection of books, autograph letters and manuscripts formed by Nathan M. Wallack of Washington will be dispersed tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
IN the Sunday Times of Feb. 8, an article by Delbert Clark reviewed the wartime activities of Walter Gieseking from, what seemed to me, a rather biased viewpoint.

The Canadiens of Montreal will skate against the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Flying Frenchmen, seeking a play-off spot in the league race, promise to put up a furious battle against the New Yorkers, who are pretty sure of reaching the post-season championship rounds.

The death of 47-year-old J. Lester Lehrenkrauss, the only son of the late Julius Lehrenkrauss, one-time head of a $13,000,000 concern in Brooklyn, was caused by a "general congestion of viscera," it was said after an autopsy yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

A comedy of errors in which a detective mistook two brothers for hold-up men while the brothers in turn took the detective for a hold-up man was recited in Brooklyn Week-End Court yesterday. As a result of the ensuing fistcuffs all were profusely decorated with court plaster about the face and head when they appeared in court.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Manchester United, favorite to win the Football Association Cup, crashed past Preston North End, 4 -- 1, before more than 74,000 fans to enter the semi-finals in the feature match on today's soccer card.

WHEN Gilbert Dodds, the Perambulating Parson from Boston, broke the world indoor mile record with his unexpected and stunning 4:05.3 performance at the virtual start of the current footracing season, he touched off a chain reaction of atomic intensity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Although Tony Lavelli of Yale was high man with 18 points, Army defeated the Elis, 53 -- 42, at basketball before a junior prom week-end crowd of 2,100 in Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight. Lavelli now has 463 points this winter and a three-season varsity total of 1,202.

WILTON PARK, England, Feb. 28 -- On a Georgian estate twenty miles from London Britain's own unique experiment in "democratizing" selected German prisoners and civilians from the occupied zone is entering upon its third year.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Alarmed by the westward advance of Communist totalitarianism in Czechoslovakia, Anthony Eden, deputy leader of the Parliamentary Opposition and former Foreign Secretary, made an urgent appeal today for immediate close cooperation between Western European powers and the United States.

ATHENS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A high Greek official said today that the Greek Government had received information of extensive military preparations in Albania. Two Russian colonels reportedly are directing some of the work.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 28 -- Strong opposition to the Little Assembly's decision to hold elections in South Korea has been voiced by two influential Rightist leaders.

IN this novel two themes that have held man's attention in drama and philosophy for several thousand years conjoin: predestination and the pursuit of the individual by his own personal "demon." The story concerns Roy Calvert, a brilliant young Cambridge scholar of 24, engaged in translating from the "Early Soghdian" certain unique documents concerning the Manichaean heresy.

HARRY S. TRUMAN, who is a plain man at heart, is still rather astonished after almost two years in office at the number and variety of gifts that day by day reach the White House. People just like to send presents to the President of the United States; they have been doing it since the early years of the Republic.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 -- The newspaper Prensa has received exchange permits from the Central Bank covering the importation of nearly 34,000 tons of newsprint, it was learned yesterday. During 1947 Argentina's leading independent newspaper, which has been in a continuing battle with the Peron Government over newsprint since last spring, used about 31,000 tons.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 28 -- Democrats believe their chances of carrying the Pacific Northwest states for the fifth successive time in a national election have been dealt a hard blow by the decision of Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho to run for Vice President on the Henry Wallace third-party ticket.

Although in the cellar of the Western Division virtually all season, the Baltimore Bullets certainly look like a first-place club when opposing the Knickerbockers. Last night proved no exception as the Maryland five handed the New Yorkers a 78-to-56 drubbing before 5,367 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory in a Basketball Association of America game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Labor's demand for a "third round" of wage increases has been strengthened by the rise in steel prices and the economic situation generally.

After two years of intensive study that has included numerous hearings all over the state, visits to clinics and consultations with leading specialists, a Joint Legislative Committee to Study the Problems of Cerebral Palsy recently has filed its report with the New York Legislature.

The stock market improved slightly yesterday during the two-hour session and closed irregularly higher, with transportation issues in the lead. Price changes were narrow, but the combined averages on the Stock Exchange were raised 0.56 point on the day.

SIMON TEMPLAR, otherwise known as the Saint, is still at large, but only because the police of many cities have been unable to prove that he has ever engaged in any illegal activities. Two more of the Saint's exploits are recorded in this volume.
CAIRO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Civil war has broken out in Yemen, Sayed Ali al Muayed, the tiny Arabic kingdom's representative in Cairo, said tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Young Henry Ford believes that "fantastically crowded" traffic conditions in America's big cities have opened a new market for small, low-powered British-made automobiles. The 30-year-old president of the Ford Motor Company announced here that his company's British affiliate would ship 6,000 small cars and trucks for sale in the United States in the next six months.

In October, 1944, the Philadelphia Board of Education, anticipating the needs of returning service men, assigned the facilities of the Benjamin Franklin High School to their veterans' educational program. Realizing that the post-war emphasis would be on college and specialized training, the Philadelphia school was set up for the large numbers of ex-GI's who had not completed high school.

GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- The United Nations maritime conference split into three working parties today in a drive to complete the work of drafting a charter for the International Maritime Organization by the middle or end of next week.

In behalf of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association, Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon will give a reception tomorrow afternoon in the small ballroom of the Colony Club for the Very Rev. John W. Suter, Dean of the Washington Cathedral; Canon Merritt F. Williams of the cathedral, and the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo.

CERTAINLY the oddest motion-picture studio this side of Chungking is that of Grandview Films, which, appropriately enough, specializes in the production of Chinese movies and is the only company which regularly makes Chinese films in this country.

MRS. FREMANTLE'S distinguished semi-fictional study of James I of Scotland, the poet-king, does not belong to the swashbuckling variety of historical novel. This is no superman-with-sword extravaganza, but rather a serious and successful restoration of a vanished time and its ways.

The United States Department of Labor reported yesterday that the purchasing power of American factory workers had doubled, in the thirty-five years since the department was established by President William Howard Taft.

THE theme of this work is that calligraphy, the drawing of letters with a pen, is the proper basis for the study and use of type. While this idea is not new, perhaps it has never been so well presented. Outstanding among contemporary designers of books are a number of exponents of this theory, and some effective examples of their work are here reproduced.

It has recently been suggested (Financial Section, THE NEW YORK TIMES, Feb. 8) that in place of accepting the special reserve plan of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Congress should reconsider the entire matter of member bank reserve requirements and place them on a sounder and more equitable basis.

A program of "Hanns Eisler Music" was given last night in Town Hall, under the auspices of a group of leading American composers of today -- Leonard Bernstein, David Diamond, Roger Sessions, Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Walter Piston and Randall Thompson.
In exactly eleven weeks -- on May 15 -- the 25-year-old British mandate over Palestine will end. The tragic Holy Land will become a ward of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON -- Travel-loving Americans, with a penchant for acquiring souvenirs of their trips abroad long have been bumping up against a ceiling of $100 on the value of goods that may be brought in duty-free by returning tourists.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this Review: "Reminiscences of an American Scholar," by John W. Burgess, took the spotlight and took the reviewer, too: "This is a book which America should be proud to have placed in the libraries of the world. . . .

AMERICANS spent about $690,000,000 for foreign travel last year, according to estimates prepared by the office of Business Economics, United States Department of Commerce. This was approximately the same as in 1929, the previous peak travel year, and an increase of roughly one-fourth over the 1946 figures.

Universities should establish departments for the education of trade unionists that compare in staff and courses to other departments within the institution, Prof. Theodore Brameld of New York University urged yesterday.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Talon, colorful come-from-behind son of the Pampas, rolled through on schedule today to capture the $139,600 Santa Anita Handicap.
C.B. Palmer's piece on Gander, "Chromium Meets Caribou," was good. That's an understatement. It was more than good. It was excellent.

THERE is much ado and a deal of reading to be done in the active pages of this novel by George U. Fletcher -- a pseudonym, so the publisher's jacket tells us, for a successful writer best known for works outside the field of fiction, "a student of myth and language * * * a man with an encyclopedic knowledge of history."

TED GREER, a young war veteran who appears to have been unable to adjust himself to civilian life, is suspected of having caused the explosion which wrecked his parents' house and killed his mother's stepsister, Arabella Rixey.

WITH GREEK ARMY ON THE MOUNT OLYMPUS FRONT, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Markos rebels before dawn today outmaneuvered Government forces guarding the Kozani-Larissa highway, and 500 to 1,000 guerrillas disappeared into the wilderness of Mount Olympus -- a spot from which they can harass Government troops during the forthcoming American-guided spring offensive.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 28 -- A majority of the election jury announced officially today that Otilio Ulate, the candidate of the Democratic Union, had been elected President by a margin of 10,000 votes in the balloting on Feb. 8.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 28 -- A scrappy underdog Navy basketball team gave favored Columbia a defensive lesson this afternoon and only the middies' inability to match the Light Blue at the charity lane gave the Lions a 40-37 victory before 4,350 partisan fans.

"THE Officers of the Information Control Branch cordially invite you to a reception in honor of Jean-Paul Sartre and Jurgen Fehling following the premiere of 'The Flies.'" That is the text of an invitation sent out last month by the Office of Military Government, Berlin Sector, Germany.

Replying yesterday to complaints over increased rentals in Knickerbocker Village, Irving Broun, president of the Fred F. French Company, owners, said the increases recently approved would give investors in the project their first return since 1934.

LONDON. IN general, the limelight has been turned off the great Nazis. Who could now state exactly who was executed and who survived the judgment day at Nuremberg? 'The truth is that most of them had been greatly overrated. Inflated pantaloons, the factual evidence of Nuremberg reduced them to their proper stature and showed that individually they were not worth the study which for so long they had claimed.

Ordinarily one is more likely to hear singers with good, natural vocal quality than strong technical development. Edison Harris, tenor, reverses the procedure, having built a creditable voice from rather undistinguished raw material. He deserves credit for all the merit in his Town Hall recital, late yesterday afternoon.

MAIL carried by rockets will be flown in California from Inyo County across Searles Dry Lake to Trona on March 27 to mark the fifth anniversary of the Reaction Research Society, a nonprofit organization working on designs for a high-altitude meteorological rocket for making recordings of weather conditions in the atmosphere and stratosphere.

THE publisher of a Lonely Hearts magazine calls on Perry Mason with a problem which Mason solves in jig time. That is how Mason comes to meet Marilyn Marlow, his next client. Miss Marlow stands to inherit a fortune unless certain other claimants succeed in breaking the will, as they are trying their best to do.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 28 -- During a blinding snowstorm that forced postponement of part of the program Dartmouth's team today assumed the lead in the bid for the Intercollegiate Ski Union championship being held in conjunction with the seventeenth annual Middlebury College winter carnival.

The United Nations Little Assembly -- boycotted by Russia and the Russian bloc -- last week made its first major decision. On Thursday it adopted an American-sponsored resolution calling on the U.N. Temporary Commission on Korea to go ahead with elections in the American occupation zone of that strategic Asiatic country.

Randy Philpotts of Morris won his first mile race of the indoor season yesterday afternoon. He annexed the feature event of a special program of high school races at Madison Square Garden in in conjunction with the trials of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships.
Temporary changes in the city's traffic pattern to allow repairs to parts of the Willis Avenue Bridge and the Williamsburg Bridge were announced yesterday by Police Commisisoner Arthur W. Wallander.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The spectacular college football career of Chalmers (Bump) Elliott, dazzling 22-year-old halfback at the University of Michigan, is ended.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Delegates of the United States, Britain, France and the Benelux countries, who have been meeting here this week to discuss the future of Western Germany, must have drawn a moral from what happened in Czechoslovakia.

A public hearing tomorrow afternoon in the Glen Cove, L.I., City Hall will be an influencing factor in a novel scheme of Thorsten E. Peterson, Long Island boat builder. He wants to construct a seventeen-acre marina on the south side of Glen Cove Creek in a land-locked lagoon that will be accessible from Hempstead Harbor via a quarter-mile channel that Army engineers are expected to dredge next month to an eight-foot depth.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 28 -- President Truman's civil-rights program has created quite a controversy among Democratic party leaders in Arkansas, but the average voter does not appear so excited.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Breaking the Academy record in the 300-yard medley relay and winning six of the nine events, Army's swimming team registered its eighth victory of the season today by defeating Brown University, 44 to 31, in the Academy Natatorium.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 28 -- The average Tennessean is against the Truman civil-rights program and angry enough about it to seek the President's defeat. How to bring it about is the problem. The leadership is in the ranks of the professional Democrats, who will stick by the President for the sake of expediency.
PHILADELPIA, Feb. 28 -- Nine years after he last played for the title, Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., won the National Amateur Court Tennis Championship today for the sixth time.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- James A. Farley predicted here tonight that Henry A. Wallace would draw "better than 75 per cent" of his vote from normally Democratic voters, and said that Mr. Wallace's candidacy ywas a "challenge to Democratic leadership in every state in the nation."

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- With an 8-point surge midway through the second half, Cornell took control of its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game with Princeton tonight and defeated the Tigers, 59 -- 49.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 -- A single word sums up Jerusalem's atmosphere this week-end as violence continues and the United Nations argues the Palestine problem. It is "apprehension." Arabs, Jews and outsiders all feel it and if there is any elation among the Arabs who hope that partition may still be dropped, it is overshadowed by the possibility that that that may not happen.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft told a home-state audience tonight that the Democrats had become a regressive pary split into three factions and were making impossible demands of the Republican Congress.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony will make a two-week tour before it opens its season here next fall. One of the cities it will visit is Cleveland and Leopold Stokowski is known to be one of the conductors who will go with the men.

An unmarried 20-year-old girl who stammered so badly that she could speak only in occasional monosyllables now talks freely and even sings as a result of treatment with electric shock at the Owen Clinic, Huntington, W. Va. Four electric treatments were given before there was any improvement.
