RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 28 -- This week found Virginia Democrats in a helpless and an angry mood.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Resentment against Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney's order to the Japanese Supreme Court to reverse the action of a lower court broke into the open today. General Whitney is chief of the Supreme Command's Government Section.

With only a moderate volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 4 points lower to 10 points higher than on Friday. Only the May, 1949, declined.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The swift, sure erasure of Czechoslovakia from the roster of free nations by the Communists is the most dramatic victory yet scored by the foreign policy of the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- The public feud between French and Soviet personnel has reached a point where Russians refuse to eat or drink with the French even on the most routine occasions. This is introducing minor complications into the work of the Allied Control Authority.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Unanimity was attained today in a conference chamber of the United Nations. It took teenagers to do it.

FOR THIS WEEK: Cut branches of early spring flowering shrubs or trees, such as larch and red maple to force indoors. Forsythia now requires little more than two weeks. . . . Start seeds of stock indoors for summer bloom. . . . Receding snow will carry grass seed scattered on the surface into the soil where it will germi nate early.

In view of the current tension which has arisen between Chile, Argentina, and Great Britain over conflicting claims of sovereignty in the Antarctic, it would seem profitable to recall the relevant principles of international law to aid in forming a just evaluation of the situation.

FEEDER-LINE air service for passengers, mail and cargo within New York State and air-commuter service between New York and Connecticut were given a mighty boost by the latest route decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

A currently much debated subject is whether income tax reduction is inflationary or deflationary. A favorite argument asserted against tax reduction is that high taxes are one of the most powerful influences and strongest weapons against the inflationary process.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 28 -- A 12-year-old boy has admitted shooting and seriously wounding Bertram M. Betsch, an official of the Electric Bond and Share Company of New York, on the night of Feb. 13 in a hold-up "plotted" with two schoolboy companions, Police Chief John R. Preston said today.

SEVEN classes of photography will be featured in the twelfth annual exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York, to be held March 20 through April 18, at the Veterans Center, 500 Park Avenue. The show is being selected from nearly 600 prints by press photographers and press services, who submitted news, feature, sports, pictorial, portrait, magic-eye and color photographs.

THE amateur's desire to experiment with new processes finds elaborate expression in the exhibition of multiple-toned prints by Rene P. Piperoux, opening tomorrow for a month's run at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street.

URBANA Ill., Feb. 28 -- The first of a projected series of annual competitive exhibitions of contemporary American painting opened here this evening with a reception and preview at which ten purchase prizes totaling $7,500 were announced. The exhibitions are to be conducted under the auspices of the Fine Arts Department of the University of Illinois.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 28 -- Bobby Layne, Texas passer, said today he had signed a three-year contract with the Chicago Bears of the National Football League, turning down a $77,000 bid by the Baltimore Colts of the All-America Conference that would have paid him more money.

A FAIR sampling of recent short stories must survive discouragement Popular fiction seems formula-ridden, too soft under its bright crust, essentially unreal. The literary and "little" monthlies, quarterlies and reviews offer mostly dreary reading, bowed down with what has been called a "graceless disillusionment."
The stock market revealed fewer clues last week as to its immediate behavior than the average "guess-who" radio program supplies to contestants or listeners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States is expected to explore with Britain and France measures for withstanding the Soviet advance in Europe. Such action would be taken in the light of the three-power joint protest against the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia and of the developing crisis for Finland.

NEW abstract paintings by Arshille Gorky, at the Julien Levy Gallery, have taken an unexpected, happy turn from former heaviness of color, opaque pigment and constricting line toward a thinner modulation of tone and transparent handling of surface.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 -- The jobs of 8,000 crew members of the merchant marine on this coast, as well as of thousands of shore-side workers, were made "more secure" by President Truman's signing of the Tobey bill this week, Albert W. Gatov, president of the Pacific American Steamship Association, asserted today.

PRAGUE, Feb. 28 -- Czechoslovakia has served the world as a laboratory for a test of whether communism and democracy can govern together in the same state and participate in the direction of the same society. The destruction of democracy has been the result of the experiment.

DDT and the sulfa drugs gathered dust on laboratory shelves long before their usefulness was discovered. Many other potentially valuable compounds, classed as mere chemical curiosities, still lie dormant. A far-reaching reform has therefore been launched by the National Research Council Chemical-Biological Coordination Center in Washington.

GANDHI -- considered Ramakrishna a living embodiment of godliness; Romain Rolland called him the "Prophet of New India." Few of us know about Ramakrishna or that missions devoted to his teachings are now found all over the world, including our own country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board decided today that 207 Kansas City newspaper carriers who operate home delivery routes under contract are "independent contractors." As such, they are not protected by the Taft-Hartley Law.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 28 -- If the rest of the South is as angered by President Truman's bill of rights as is the average Mississippian, the entire 127 Southern electoral votes may be in doubt when the electoral college meets.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- With Gordie Ritz scoring from a face-off with 26 seconds left of a ten-minute overtime period tonight, Yale's hockey team gained a 2-1 victory over Princeton before a junior prom week-end crowd of 3,100 at the New Haven Arena.

IRGUN HAGANAH -- the Jewish "defense organization" -- today faces its greatest test. For the next few weeks it will continue to strive to maintain order and to advance Jewish aims in Palestine. Some time after May 15, when the British mandate over Palestine ends, Haganah will take over defense of the Jewish state.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Lawson Little, who is no Johnny-come-lately to the golf tour, tonight had established himself as the man to beat for the St. Petersburg open title.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The British blockade today intercepted a ship carrying more than 1,000 Jews seeking to enter Palestine without immigration certificates.

Scoring heavily in all eight events, Fordham Prep successfully defended its Catholic High School Athletic Association city swimming championship in the Brooklyn College pool yesterday. The Little Rams tallied 54 points. Iona Prep was second with 31 markers and Cardinal Hayes third with 15.
March 1 is the anniversary of Korea's Declaration of Independence in 1919. On March 1, 1948, Korea's fate for another generation is hanging by a thread.

The trend to increase national industrial production has stopped during the past month and a slight downturn, partly due to weather conditions, has occurred, according to the composite opinion of 200 top purchasing agents who comprise the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

As California is observing this year the centenary of the discovery of gold in that state, it is interesting to recall that it was a New Jersey man who touched off the gold rush to the West a century ago. The man was James W. Marshall, a wheelwright, who was building a millrace in the little village of Coloma, about fifty miles west of Sacramento.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 28 -- Although the Finns will try to stall for time it appeared certain tonight that they were resigned to accepting Premier Stalin's proposal for a treaty of mutual military assistance.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Establishment of the Scientific Research Society of America, a new national organization with headquarters at Yale University, was announced today.

Cabell Phillips, in his article "That Baffling Personality, Mr. Wallace," criticizes the former Vice President's views on Soviet-American relations, but I think Wallace is on firm ground in calling Russia's so-called "expansionism" merely a quest for security.

The stake is Europe. On one side there are the United States and countries of Western Europe. They seek to halt the sweep of communism across the Continent. Their great weapon is the European Recovery Program (the Marshall Plan).

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- Thurman Arnold, counsel for the Screen Writers Guild, hinted today that the organization would bring conspiracy action against motion-picture concerns for their industry-wide agreement not to employ Communists.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Despite Gen. Douglas MacArthur's warning that full utilization of home-grown Japanese foods was a condition for further relief imports, the total amount of the Japanese crop continues to be minimized in official reports, according to charges now again appearing in the Japanese press.

Wall Street, which has experienced many innovations in recent years, has been closely watching something brand new in bank consolidations in the proposed liquidation of the Continental Bank and Trust Company. The deal, whereby Chemical Bank and Trust Company, and/or New York Trust Company would take over the thriving, 80-year-old institution has been hanging fire since before Feb. 13.

NEW house plants win be shown by E.J. Alexander at the Members' Day Program in the Museum Building of the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, on Wednesday. He will introduce them in connection with a lecture on "Recent Horticultural Collecting in Puerto Rico."

AFRICA, says the schoolboy tag, can always dish up something new, and young Mr. Reeve, a London newspaperman assigned to look the old place over, came, saw and concurred. His paper fancied that armchair travelers in austerity-stricken Britain might get a vicarious thrill following their reporter's flight from Cairo to the Cape.
Mr. Kurz apparently has access to a completely different set of records from those I had in writing the article.

The opening of a fast passenger and cargo service by the Khedivial Mail Line, an Egyptian-flag company, between New York and Mediterranean ports, was announced yesterday by Stockard Co., 17 Battery Place, as agents for the line. The first sailing will be made by the Khedive Ismail which leaves here on April 3.

HALLAM TENNYSON, great-grandson of the poet and author of these accomplished and entertaining stories, might easily have filled a couple of oversize novels with the exotic material derived from his service with the Friends' ambulance unit in Egypt and Italy during the war.

IT IS a temptation to praise this second novel by William Woods beyond its weight, there is so much good in it. The powerful but not hasty pace it keeps; its well lit characters; its tempered prose; its solid texture, and the sense it holds of the dilemmas, apathies and disasters that, on the heels of war, invade the peace.

Representation by this country in the six-meter yachting of the Olympics was reduced to one of three craft, it was learned yesterday with confirmation of the sale of the Djinn to a syndicate in the Argentine. The latter will compete with her in the contests to be held at Torbay, England, in July.

Another foreign baseball invasion will begin today when the champion Brooklyn Dodgers and their farm club, the Montreal Royals, take to the air at 9 o'clock this morning from La Guardia Field, headed for Ciudad Trujillo, Republica Dominica.

George Washington, the first President of the United States, once wrote of the rigors and fatigues of the Presidency this way: "Public meetings, and a dinner once a week to as many as my table will hold, with the references to and from the different departments of state and other communications with all parts of the Union, are as much, if not more than I am able to undergo * * *."

George Chaffee, dancer and dance historian, will lecture at 4 o'clock this afternoon on "Dance and the Visual Arts" in Room 213 of the Central Building of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. An exhibition illustrating the lecture opens today in the Music Division, Room 84.

OUT of the shadows of the ninth century Miss Leighton has brought an almost forgotten figure to life, making her the vividly appealing heroine of a richly tapestried romance. Intrigue and jealousy swirled around Judith, great-granddaughter of Charlemagne, when she dutifully married Aethelwulf, King of England, who was old enough to be her grandfather.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 28 -- A warning that some university professors will probably be accused of Communist activity, and a pledge of support if they are, regardless of whether they may be Communist party members, was given by a committee of The American Association of University Professors at the final session of its annual meeting here today.

MEXICO CITY -- After a bad beginning in late fall, Mexico's tourist business has begun to pick up toward the end of the winter season. Despite stricter immigration regulations affecting all visitors except those using the simple tourist card (good for a single entry and a stay of six months in the country) the tourist industry's slump appears to be definitely ended.

THE renewal of legislative interest in Hollywood during the last ten days, after a two-month lull, failed to arouse the town in the old way. The Kearns Congressional committee, which has been raking the embers of the moribund motion picture strike, has raised academic issues only, as far as Hollywood is concerned.

Retail trade here went behind last year's figures for the corresponding week. The major factor in the decline, however, was the fact that the week had five selling days against six last year, because of the celebration of Washington's Birthday on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Communist coup in Czechoslovakia and mounting Soviet pressure upon Finland have given fresh impetus to the European Recovery Program and made imperative prompt Congressional action on the measure, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg declared today.

Sunsets can be beautiful in any season, but there is often something especially fine about them during the period when winter is alternately loosening its grip and reasserting its power. Now that one can hear the first faint whispers of the oncoming resurrection, the sunsets of mellowing days paint glorious pictures.

Fanny Brice's characterization of the impish "Baby Snooks" is being canceled by General Foods, after an eleven-year run on the kilocycles under its sponsorship. Her final broadcast in the weekly series for the concern is set for May 28.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks tonight whipped the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 1, before 16,543 fans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Associates said today that Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan has stopped trying to keep his name off the ballot in the April 13 Presidential primary in Nebraska.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- Robert McGowan Barrington-Ward's association with The Times began in 1913 when he joined its staff as an editorial secretary. That year he had been graduated from Balliol College, Oxford, after taking a first class in classical moderations in 1911 and a third class in literae humaniores.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 29 -- Twenty-eight British soldiers were killed when three cars on a Cairo-to-Haifa train were blown up by land mines near Rehovoth, south of Tel Aviv, today. Two of thirty-five men detained in a hospital died later, and it was feared that the final death toll might be heavier.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Ray Morrison today refused to confirm or deny published reports that he would become head football coach at Yale University.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 29 (UP) -- Two Newburgh News employes who went to jail rather than reveal a confidential news source were holding open house today -- in jail.

In a recent paper before the American Meteorological Society, Dr. Irving Langmuir of the General Electric Research Laboratory prophesied that within three years scientists should have enough basic knowledge of manmade rain to divert large snowstorms and rainfalls from centers of population to relatively isolated areas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Government acted today to help countries in the European Recovery Program get at about $1,100,000,000 in assets of their citizens which are "frozen" in this country.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 29 -- A plan by Guatemalan President Juan Jose Arevalo to assist revolutionists to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government was charged by Secretary of the Presidency Telesforo Calderon.

The last British troops have pulled out of India. Something goes with them -- some tradition of law and order, of stability and discipline. Something remains -- thousands of lonely graves of simple men who fought and died loyally for what they believed was right. Now their faded battle flags are furled and the long sacrifice is over.

The performance of Chopin's Concerto in E minor by Sigi Weissenberg, 18-year-old Bulgarian pianist, was the special feature of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under George Szell, Saturday night, at Carnegie Hall.

A 3-goal lead with less than half the game left to play did not make for a New York Rangers' walkaway against the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. Indeed, the fiery Frenchmen tied matters up at 3 -- all before the second period ended, and the New Yorkers had to insure their victory by starting all over again in the final chapter.

Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that its activities during 1947 had reached 416,676 individuals in the metropolitan area. It will seek $2,500,000 to carry on its work this year.

With the stagger system of truck pick-ups and deliveries set for its first test today in the garment sector, it was learned yesterday that it would be backed by enforcement of a traffic rule that has been dormant for the last ten years.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company for 1947 declined $5,083,969 to $34,458,112, it is announced in the annual report of the company released for publication today. Earnings on the common stock were $8.18 a share, compared with $9.39 in 1946.

Large spot bid sales at the War Assets Administration Customer Service Centers in Newark, the Bronx and Buffalo are among ten more Government offerings that will be initiated this week in this region, it was announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director of the WAA.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 29 -- Finland's envoy in Moscow, 48-year-old former dentist, Cay Sundstreom, arrived here tonight on a special mission from the Soviet Union. It is believed in well informed circles that he is here to present the detailed terms of the proposed Russian-Finnish pact to President Juho K. Paasikivi and the Finnish Government.

PRAGUE, Feb. 29 -- The reorganization of Czechoslovakia into a totalitarian-type state and society will be carried out by radio instructions, it was learned today. The action committees will receive their instructions by radio beginning tomorrow.

An anti-Communist group announced yesterday that it would oppose the present leadership of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, at the union's seventh biennial convention opening this morning at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

Three fellowships of $5,000 each will be offered annually to young men and women of proved journalistic ability for study abroad under the Reid Foundation, established by the late Ogden Reid, editor of The New York Herald Tribune.

Closing the doors after the visitors had snared two goals thirty-two seconds apart in the first period, the New York Rovers returned to winning ways yesterday afternoon by defeating the Quebec Aces, 6 to 3, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League fracas at Madison Square Garden.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 29 -- Twenty-four Dodgers, Lippy Leo Durocher and a dozen reporters stepped off a Pan American plane approximately seven hours and fifteen minutes after leaving New York this morning and ran into a reception that took their collective breath away.

Several months ago, soon after my return from a ten months' stay in China, you printed a letter from me which was definitely at odds with your editorial policy regarding American policy in China. The influence of THE NEW YORK TIMES is indicated by the fact that the aforesaid letter was reprinted in both Chinese and English language papers in several of the large cities of China.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Britain's Royal family, President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia and Mme. Chiang Kaishek of China joined today in pledging whole-hearted support to the United Nations efforts to feed and cloth 230,000,000 needy children by collecting one day's pay from peoples throughout the world.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- The plumbing and heating industry will have a substantially increased production capacity this year, but industry sources today revealed doubts that full use will be made of it because of increasingly critical raw material shortages. Demand is expected to continue at a high level.

The recent spell of relatively spring-like weather ended for New Yorkers last night with the arrival from Canada of a cold wave that was expected to send the temperature down to between 10 and 15 degrees by daybreak.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The Czechoslovak surrender to communism has not brought the Western powers visibly nearer to settling their differences over Germany.

VIENNA, Feb. 29 -- The realization in Austria of the full significance of the overturn in Czechoslovakia led the Communist party newspaper here today to accuse the Western powers of bringing pressure on the Austrian Government to reject Russian economic proposals and defer a state treaty.

ATHENS, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis announced today that agreement has been reached between the Greek Government and the Allied missions on the composition of the Greek regular army to minimize political influence on command personnel.

The European Recovery Program goes to the floor of the Senate today with the unanimous approval of the seven Republicans and six Democrats who compose the Foreign Relations Committee. In its details it has been somewhat altered from the original proposals of Secretary Marshall and President Truman, but it has not been weakened at any critical point.

The list of steamship arrivals at this port during the last week included three "strangers" -- two reconverted U.S.-flag vessels and one new British ship. The two of United States registry are returning to private operation after transport duty in World War II.
New York will welcome the trim, new Swedish American liner Stockholm this morning when the ship arrives from Goeteborg with 271 passengers on her maiden voyage.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 29 -- The clipper ship, Twentieth Century version, whisked over the slate gray water of the Atlantic for hour after hour, then the lush tropical vegetation of the Dominican Republic hove into view and finally the sprawling white buildings of the capital city itself. Straight as a homing pigeon the big plane flew for the criss-cross checkerboard pattern of the airport.

Housewives, husbands and, in fact, everyone who visits Lewis Conger stops to admire the Parsons Pureaire Kitchen on display there. One-room apartment dwellers are most impressed with this compact unit, which fits stove, refrigerator and sink into eight square feet of space.

Arthur Koestler, author of "The Yogi and the Commissar," "Darkness at Noon" and "Thieves in the Night," will arrive in New York on March 18 from England for a speaking tour of the United States. He will speak at Carnegie Hall on March 26 under the auspices of the International Rescue and Relief Committee, which arranged his release from the concentration camp of Vernet after the collapse of France.

The recent banning of two current books, "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Focus," from the library of De Witt Clinton High School by the principal of the school, Dr. John B. Walsh, has serious implications. Dr. Walsh's action will have the same effect as the banning of certain books by the censors in Boston.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Robert Strand, 28-year-old war veteran and former religious seminary student, leaped to his death today from an airplane 3,000 feet above the San Fernando Valley.

Basking in the warm glow of success, the New Stagers are definitely moving Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute" along with Thornton Wilder's "The Happy Journey" from the downtown headquarters, 159 Bleecker Street, to the Cort on March 16.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 29 -- Delegates to the special constitutional convention of the State Industrial Union Council, CIO, voted today to raise from 3 cents to 4 the per capita tax and gave a qualified endorsement to Dr. Frank Kingdon as an independent candidate for the Democratic United States Senate nomination.

A 25 to 50 per cent decrease in last year's record volume of American radio receivers will occur this year as a result of sharp quotas imposed by importing nations, foreign dollar shortages and other factors, several industry spokesmen predicted last week.

Regardless of the outcome of the general elections to be held this month by the National Maritime Union, CIO, control of the organization will not change hands, because all major decisions of the union are now subject to the approval of its membership, it was stressed yesterday.

Gracita Faulkner, British West Indian soprano, made her New York, recital debut yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. She proved to be a singer of taste and charm, with a pleasing, fresh, light lyric voice.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Ezequiel Navarra, Argentine champion, and Irving Crane, Binghamton, N. Y., remained locked in the lead of the national three-cushion billiard championship meet tonight.
MOSCOW, Feb. 29 (UP) -- The Soviet press said today the London conference on Germany was the first step toward renewed German aggression.

When children take a book from a library shelf and say "read it to me," they choose the same stories a librarian would pick for the purpose, according to a statistical record kept through 1947 at the Nathan Straus branch of the New York Public Library, 348 East Thirty-second Street.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in February totaled $60,896,000, the smallest amount in three months and the lowest figure for any February since 1943. The total compared with $103,107,000 in the preceding month, $95,421,000 in February, 1947, and $25,409,000 in February, 1943, the next smallest corresponding month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Employer and union at the laboratories of the Atomic Energy Commission at Oak Ridge, Tenn., were asked today by Cyrus S. Ching, head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to meet with members of the service here tomorrow to continue negotiations for a collective bargaining agreement.

This is a year for the politicians. From now until a certain evening of November, when they will lie down, mercifully hoarse, they will be with us. They will get into the closed house by radio and through those pamphlets which hint it would be good to have someone open them, even for postal inspection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Communists and the Russian Government have only one goal -- world revolution -- and it cannot be accepted that they are friends of democracy. That was the gist of a report by a subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on "the strategy and tactics of world communism" made public today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Corn showed a strong undertone last week in the Board of Trade. At no
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The new Military Air Transport Service, merging facilities of the Army Air Transport Service and the Naval Air Transport Service, was born today.

BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Class A ski-jumping championship of North America was won today by Hans Kaarstein of Oslo, Norway, before a crowd of 10,000 in the first post-war revival of the event. Kaarstein took the title with 229.5 points.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Stanley Benham and his Lake Placid crew wound up a perfect season today by capturing the North American four-man bobsled championship.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 29 -- On the eve of the opening of the Giants' spring training camp here tomorrow, the heavy hand of authority fell upon one of last year's stars and menaced another player.

Mayor O'Dwyer was back in Gracie Mansion last night after eight days in Bellevue Hospital for a rest and complete physical check-up, which showed that he had suffered no permanent heart impairment. He was still under the care of Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, the heart specialist who ordered him to Bellevue.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The State Division of Veterans' Affairs handled 891,493 requests for assistance and counseling in 1947. This was in the Division's annual report issued today. "Increasing demands" by veterans for "expert and extended counseling," were noted.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,712,096,242. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 29 -- Several hundred Westport residents appeared at the Town Hall here today in response to the opening of the "Give One Day" campaign of the United Nations Appeal for Children, and offered contributions or pledges to volunteer workers.

The National Committee for Labor Palestine, at an emergency rally at the Hotel Commodore yesterday attended by 2,000 delegates, unanimously adopted a resolution calling the American statement on Palestine at the United Nations Security Council "a retreat."

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- All the fortitude that stock markets were able to summon to their aid was required last week to deaden the effects of another series of blows to confidence. From Palestine, Prague, Moscow and South America, news was sufficiently disturbing to warrant a realistic assessment of the investment picture.

TOKYO, Monday, March 1 -- With collections for the 1947 crop year almost complete, Allied headquarters has launched a nationwide drive with the slogan, "10 per cent more food in 1948." J.H. Boulware, chief of headquarters agricultural production branch, told the Prefectural Governors this morning that the year's quotas would be assigned this week and incentive goods for farmers would be provided.

Lucie Bigelow Rosen, who began her recitals on the theremin thirteen years ago, gave a brief program for the electrical instrument last night at Town Hall. Carlo Salzedo, who has played for her the last two seasons, was again the accompanist.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 29 -By virtue of a comeback role in the concluding event, Middlebury College's ski team retained the Intercollegiate Ski Union championship, bringing the Middlebury carnival to an end today.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft finished a two-day swing through this city and its environs today with repeated demands for a slash in Federal taxes. Also, he promised that the Republican Congress would do everything possible to make an immediate reality of the civil rights program which has threatened to split the Northern and Southern Democrats.

There is merit to your Feb. 6 editorial entitled "An Injustice to Veterans." Few people will deny the validity of your conclusions "that a veteran should not suffer any provable loss * * * because of war service. * * *" To the same effect is your further statement "that veterans should not be penalized in this way or any other, in their Social Security benefits, because they served their country."
The United States and the Soviet Union should cooperate for peace, James P. Warburg, author and economist, declared yesterday morning in Rodeph Sholom, Synagogue, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

Six-day bicycle racing, absent from the local scene since November of 1939, returned to New York last night as 28 riders started the long grind to nowhere at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory. Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri fired the opening gun promptly at 9 o'clock and the sixty-seventh international race was under way. A crowd of 9,000 was present.

Having swept through their first nineteen games this season without a defeat, New York University's Violets face what many consider their toughest assignment of the campaign tonight when they encounter Notre Dame's quintet at Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature manifested today a disposition to require Mayor William O'Dwyer to concede that he overstated New York City's need for additional state aid as a price for approving the remainder of his legislative "package" for the city.
The General Electric Company will oppose any wage increase for its 100,000 unionized employes in negotiations opening here tomorrow.

Another crowded week in the art galleries gets off to a brisk beginning today and tomorrow with more than thirty openings. Today's events include an exhibition of ten portraits by Gilbert Stuart at the Harry Shaw Newman (Old Print Shop) Gallery; recent paintings by Russell Cowles at the Kraushaar Gallery; paintings by Raphael Soyer at the Associated American Artists Gallery; and paintings by Sidney Laufman at the Milch Gallery.

The National Distillers Products Corporation last year transacted net sales of $395,375,828, second largest in its history, comparing with $450,279,941 in 1946, according to the twenty-fourth annual report, released for publication today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, Ga., and Sammy Byrd of Detroit today defeated Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias of Denver, Colo., and Al Besselink, University of Miami star, 2 and 1, in an exhibition golf match at the Biltmore Club.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, which provides pre-paid medical service for employed New Yorkers and their dependents, reported a membership of 116,000 men, women and children as of today, its first anniversary.

A new silhouette in clothing for young gentlemen from infancy to 4 years of age was previewed on Friday at Merry Hull's studio, 2 Beekman Place. It will be sold in Altman's Merry Mite shop starting today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Lawson Little, 37-year-old veteran golfer, shot his best round of the tournament to win the $2,000 top prize in the St. Petersburg open today. His 72-hole total was 272, 16 under par.

ROME, Feb. 29 -- A complete radio blackout took place in Italy this afternoon when about 3,000 technicians and workers of Italy's thirty broadcasting stations went out on strike. Work ceased completely, even foreign news broadcasts being suspended.

Yeshiva University will establish the first non-sectarian medical school under Jewish auspices in the United States, it was announced last night by Dr. Elihu Katz, chairman of the Society for the Advancement of Pre-Medical Sciences at Yeshiva University.

PARIS, Feb. 29 -- After the Soviet moves in Czechoslovakia and Finland, France today was turning toward a consolidation of Western Europe and toward organizing her home defense against the threat of communism's boring from within.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 29 -- The Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, situated on the site of the former Herbert Lee Pratt estate on Long Island Sound, is completing a ship model basin at the water's edge that will be ready for use in May by the class that will be graduated next July.

Insurance in force in the New York Life Insurance Company at the end of 1947 was $9,063,604,614, George L. Harrison, president, announced yesterday in the company's 103d annual report. Assets on Dec. 31 amounted to $4,234,184,598, an increase of $207,495,318 in the year.
Prices of cotton in the domestic market fluctuated irregularly last week but closed the period at net gains.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 29 -- The Germans in the French zone of occupation number only six million, less than one-tenth of the population within the present boundaries of Germany. The Saar for all practical purposes is now a province of France and is so indicated on a topographical map in an excellent exhibit of French-ruled territory displayed in a long gallery of the Hotel Stephanie where visitors to Baden Baden used to bask in the sun.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- In a strong condemnation of what he called the "rape of Czechoslovakia," Hector McNeil, Minister of State, accused the Communists of seeking chaos and misery in Europe. His speech at his constituency in Scotland resulted in a turbulent meeting with much heckling.

Mainbocher's spring and summer collection is dedicated to "prettiness." We quote the creator of the handsome clothes -- made in a great variety of fabrics ranging from cotton to silk satins, with an accent on cottons -- exhibited last Friday in his showroom at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street.

On a goal in the last three minutes of play the Philadelphia Nationals defeated the New York Americans, 1 -- 0, in an American Soccer League match at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, before 3,000 fans yesterday.

With contracts on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges expiring at midnight tonight, the United Financial Employes, Local 205, AFL, summoned its strike strategy committee to a meeting this afternoon at its headquarters, 40 Exchange Place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, today appointed Col. Kenneth D. Nichols, former engineer for the Manhattan District atomic project, head of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project. He succeeds Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, who retired today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 29 -- During the past week in Amman, capital of Trans-Jordan, this correspondent found no evidence to support rumors that King Abdullah and his Arab Legion were planning under the present circumstances to seize Arab parts of Palestine.

Foreign exchanges displayed a greater degree of stability last week. Business was of fair proportions in which offerings were no greater than buyers could absorb as of the moment. Contributing to the steadiness were operations for the month-end, and some covering by earlier sellers. As a result "positions" were generally in order at the close.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The wreck of the Cairo-Haifa express, with its heavy death toll of British soldiers, seems today to have clinched beyond the slightest shadow of a doubt British determination to get out of Palestine on schedule.

At this late date, everyone ought to know how he feels about Maurice Chevalier, the boulevardier who has been around about as long as the boulevards. And M. Chevalier's admirers ought to know whether they like him well enough to subscribe to a whole evening of the man at the price of admission to, say, "Mister Roberts" or "A Streetcar Named Desire."

ROME, Feb. 29 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi drew a parallel today between recent events in Czechoslovakia and what the Italian Communists were alleged to be planning, and warned his hearers that Italy was in very grave danger.
Six new films, including an importation from Italy, will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- An attack on Cyrus L. Sulzberger, chief European correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was printed today by Pravda, official organ of the Soviet Communist party. The article, which was written by a Pravda correspondent and received in London by the Soviet Monitor, an affiliate of the official Soviet news agency, Tass, commented as follows upon an article by Mr. Sulzberger in THE NEW YORK TIMES that was sent from Paris:

HAVANA, Feb. 29 -- Assuming that a Havana charter is ultimately adopted by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment which has been debating its provisions here since Nov. 21, the next step to bring it into effect will be its submission to the parliaments of the world for ratification.

The New Friends of Music called Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, to a return engagement at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. He played the Sonata for Piano and 'Cello, Op. 102, No. 1, with Karl Ulrich Schnabel in the all-Beethoven program, which included the quartets, Op. 59, No. 2 ("Rasoumovsky"), and Op. 132 in A minor played by the Paganini Quartet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Senate will begin debate tomorrow on the controversial measure which will determine the amount and kind of recovery aid the United States will provide sixteen wartorn countries of Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Governor Dewey today named Milton O. Loysen, director of State Placement and Unemployment Insurance, to an expanded interdepartmental committee to improve working and living conditions of migrant labor.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 29 -- Considerable comment has been aroused by a notice sent by the Bank of the Netherlands to holders of balances and security deposits in the United States. Unless they obtain certification of their holdings before a certain date, probably June 1, the holdings will be transferred to the Office of Alien Property Custodian in Washington, the notice said.

BERLIN, Feb. 29 -- The Soviet Military Administration has greatly increased its attempts to get control over education in this city in the last month, United States Military Government officials say. Control of education is an objective of the Soviet Union second only in importance to control of labor, according to these officials Recent moves by the Russians include:

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 29 -- A new division for the formulation and sales of basic agricultural chemicals was announced here today by the Pittsburgh Coke Chemical Company. The organization will be known as Pittsburgh Agricultural Chemical Company and will have its executives offices in the Empire State Building, New York City.

AS autumn, 1944, approached, my associates and I began to wonder whether Marshal Stalin and his Government were commencing to veer away from the policy of cooperation to which they had agreed at the Moscow conference and which, with a few exceptions, they had followed since then.

Top quality at fair prices will keynote "Nationally Advertised Brands Week," April 9-19, the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., announced over the week-end. More than 200 variety chain store companies, comprising approximately 6,000 stores throughout the country, will participate in the program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Labor and management circles are keenly interested in a new test of the Taft-Hartley law which will be begun tomorrow at Atlanta. It affects the future of unionism among professional employes and of industrial unionism itself.

A plaque in memory of aj. Gem' ][aurice Rose was unveiled yesterday in the synagogue of Chapel Hall in Bellevue Hospital. It was presented to the city by the Jewish War Veterans "as a reminder to those who slander American Jews," Brig. Gen. Julius Klein, their national eomartder, explained.

The Red Cross, as Honorary Chairman Harry Truman said in opening the annual fund-raising campaign last night, "belongs to the people." It does so literally, for, again quoting Mr. Truman, "an average of one person in every family in the United States now holds a junior or senior Red Cross membership."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Out in the ice-free harbor with a swinging North wind and bitter cold, seventeen sailing dinghies went through five races this afternoon off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Bob De Coppet won two events with his boat Zotom to emerge as the point leader.

A mother's plea that bail for her son, charged with disorderly conduct, be increased because both she and his wife were afraid to have him return home was granted yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court.

Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, former United States Military Governor in Germany, declared last night that world conditions required this country to arm so strongly that other nations would fear to attack or would be stopped early in an assault.

PARIS, Feb. 29 -- The unblocking of French accounts of less than $5,000 in United States funds combined with the threat of seizure of accounts of higher figure, should, it is hoped here, help release French capital hidden abroad and permit the French Treasury to add to its credits in the United States.

Wagner's "Parsifal" will be presented March 10 during the final week of the Metropolitan Opera's subscription season, it was announced yesterday. Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes" will also receive its fourth performance during the week, being chosen for the final Saturday afternoon broadcast.

A concert devoted to compositions by Wallingford Riegger was presented by the Metropolitan Music School for the benefit of its Scholarship and Building Fund, last night at Times Hall. The offerings stemmed from various periods of the composer's career and included songs, choruses and works for many different instrumental combinations.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Johnny Werket, American Olympic ace from Minneapolis, today won the 1,500-meter event and finished a close second for the all-around title in the world speed skating championships.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 29 -- The elements of a three-ring circus and an old-fashioned political rally will be combined tomorrow night when Argentina marks the formal acquisition from Britain of ten railway lines totaling 17,400 miles of track. The ceremony will also dramatize the larger fact that, after tomorrow, no foreign-owned railroads will remain in Argentina.
How much longer will it take for Congress to get back to the Displaced Persons problem?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- A Federal agency prepared today to dig further into charges of price fixing in steel, and on Capitol Hill new criticism was hurled at the industry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- The Milton Reynolds-Boston Museum China expedition airplane, a C-87 named The Explorer, took off from the Chicago Municipal, Airport this morning on the first leg of a mission to explore from the air the virtually inaccessible Amne Machin mountain range in northwestern China and the source of the Yellow River.

In attaining a sales volume of $819,631,122 last year, the American Tobacco Company and consolidated subsidiaries established new high records both in dollars and units, Vincent Riggio, president, reports in the annual statement sent yesterday to stockholders.
Officials of Sydenham Hospital, interracial institution in Harlem, said yesterday that it would be forced to close at midnight Wednesday unless $50,000 were raised before that time.

In the midst of all the rejoicing over New York University's repeat victory in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships last Saturday night, Coach Emil Von Elling yesterday struck a sober note.

Former Postmaster General James A. Farley warned yesterday that the United Nations must not "retrace its steps" from its original resolution on the partition of Palestine. Failure to carry out the plan, he asserted, would result in a breakdown of the United Nations
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A Congressional survey covering many states and cities shows the country still in "urgent" need of Federally aided, low-cost housing, Senator Robert F. Wagner said today.

Spurred by the need for speed in cutting high claims losses due to inadequate export packaging, a special steamship company committee working on a code of minimum standards has decided to set up a central technical bureau to frame the specialized regulations required for different world trade areas, it was learned last week.
Jerome H. Debs, former executive vice president, has become president of the Chicago Metallic Manufacturing Company.

French airlines and airlines of other nationalities escaped heavy losses upon the devaluation of the French franc through the clearing house of the International Air Transport Association, the association announced in London.

Without disclosing details, the board of directors of the Continental Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday that it had approved a proposal of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company to take over the assets and liabilities of Continental.

In the annual report of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation mailed over the week-end, Fred H. Haggerson, president, discloses the expenditure of $104,235,456 by the corporation during 1947 for construction and acquisition of facilities.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 29 -- Steel output for the country was lifted 1/2 point last week to 93.5 per cent of rated capacity. According to sources here, the movement of scrap metal to steel mills was slightly better. The half-point increase in raw steel output, however, was not considered significant but as representing only minor fluctuations.

ATHENS, Feb. 29 -- Constantin Rentis, Minister of Public Order, told the press today that the mass arrests carried out in Athens, Piraeus and other centers yesterday were a preventive measure against possible disturbances that might hinder the fight against the rebels.

"The political crisis in Czechoslovakia is a sign of the despair and terror which has gripped civilization and the freedom-loving peoples of the world for the last twenty-five years," the Rev. Dr. Harold T. Donaldson, minister of Ward's Chapel, Dundee, Scotland, declared yesterday at the morning services of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 29 -- Harold Stassen, Republican Presidential aspirant, back at his home in South St. Paul for a brief rest before going to New Hampshire Tuesday in preparation for the March 9 primary, said today that he regarded his third airplane campaign tour, just ended, as "the most successful of the three."

All sections of the wholesale markets last week were quiet except for giftware and cotton wash goods, where mail was heavy, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

EVERETT, Wash., Feb. 29 -- (UP) -- The Master and three other officers of the freighter Augustine Victory were hospitalized and six seamen were jailed here today after a battle aboard the ship which the officers termed "mutiny."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29 -- With Manager Bucky Harris in high command and Secretary Arthur E. Patterson and Head Scout Paul Krichell majestically bringing up the rear, the main contingent of Yankees moved into this steaming town today to launch another training campaign in the Sunshine City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 29 -- Bing Crosby and Walt Disney have closed a deal whereby Crosby will record narration for "Ichabod Crane" and will sing three songs in the picture, a combination of cartoon animation and live action which Disney expects to release next year in a package with "Mr. Toad" under the title, "Two Fabulous Characters."
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Higher costs of materials and increased operatling expenses reduced net income ofI i Hart, Schaffner la.rx, makers I

By means of a nationwide radio broadcast, an estimated 10,000,000 persons in this country heard a "Million Dollar Sermon" preached yesterday by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 29 -- A black miniature poodle, Champion Seafren High-Falutin from the Seafren Kennels of Malvern, Pa., became the final best-in-show winner of the February round of dog shows tonight, taking the top prize in the thirty-second Providence Country Kennel Club event.

Telephone contact between this country and Palestine has been broken for the last two days, a spokesman for the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday. It is uncertain, it was added, when the connection will be restored.

A long-smoldering antagonism between two factions of the congregation of the Day Star Baptist Church, 512 West 157th Street, developed into an open scuffle at morning service yesterday. Policemen who have been stationed outside the church for weeks in anticipation of just such an occurrence promptly ended the disturbance.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 29 -- The Premiers and Foreign Ministers of the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium met in Brussels today to discuss practical steps for the implementation of the Anglo-French offer of alliance in a union of Western countries.
KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 29 -- President Truman called on all Americans tonight to contribute toward the $75,000,000 which the American Red Cross desires to raise for its humanitarian services this year.
Remorse is "one of the greatest gifts God can give to sinners," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday.

Senator Glen H. Taylor, candidate for Vice President on the third party ticket headed by Henry A. Wallace, declared yesterday that the chance of their withdrawal, if the Democrats should name a candidate for President ther than Harry S. Truman, was so remote that it was not worth talking about.

New financing in February showed an uneven pattern -- bond offerings declining while stock emissions increased over the preceding month. Compared with a year ago, however, both classes of flotations were higher.

The volume of cargo moving from the African Continent to this country is steadily increasing and now includes a wide variety of commodities such as asbestos, zebras, gold, ivory tusks, cocoa and chrome, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange dropped last month to the lowest total since last November; it also was the dullest for a corresponding month since 1942. Sales crossed the million-share mark in only four sessions, the largest of which was 1,486,620 shares on Feb. 11.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Although excellent weather prevailed over the winter belt last week, the price of that grain failed to recede to any extent. Also, there was strong bearish professional sentiment and a slow demand for the cash article, with only moderate sales of flour to the domestic trade.

Science is gradually reducing the death toll of children from disease but accidents continue to kill as many children in the 1 to 14 age group as pneumonia, diarrhea and enteritis, measles, diphtheria, meningitis, poliomyelitis, whooping cough and scarlet fever combined, the Medical Society of the County of New York reminded parents yesterday.

HAROLD ROBBINS, who has had considerable experience of poverty, menial occupations and the grimier aspects of life on the streets of New York during the bottom of the depression, and who now is a successful budget analyst with a motion picture company, has written in "Never Love a Stranger"* an ambitious novel about the life of a gangster.

HAROLD ROBBINS, who has had considerable experience of poverty, menial occupations and the grimier aspects of life on the streets of New York during the bottom of the depression, and who now is a successful budget analyst with a motion picture company, has written in "Never Love a Stranger"* an ambitious novel about the life of a gangster.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 29 -- As feeling against President Truman's civil-rights program spreads throughout the South and Dixie politicians threaten to bolt the Democratic party, reaction in this normally "liberal" state is commanding some attention.

A steady gain in the size of congregations and the number of Reform Synagogues in the United States was reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the Eastern Presidents Conference of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, held in the Isaac M. Wise Memorial Hall, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

An alternate site in the tenblock area surrounding Hamilton Fish Park, on the lower East Side, instead of Tompkins Square, where a new public housing project is being considered, could be acquiredh)0*0*0*iat a saving of $1,700,000, Joseph Platzker, former City Commissioner of Housing and Building, declared last night.

OBELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 Fundamental economic reforms affecting Yugoslavia's 15,000,000 inhabitants came into effect today. The first result noted was a sharp decrease in the amount of goods brought by peasants for sale to urban consumers at free market prices.

Malcolm P. Ferguson, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, reported yesterday to stockholders that consolidated net income for the year ended Sept. 30, 1947, amounted to $5,248,999 on sales of $141,625,820. He said operations finally were on a normal peacetime basis.

Representatives of the shipping industry and labor are hopeful that the recent appeal by Mayor O'Dwyer to Federal authorities to divert more export grain to the port of New York will bring results, it was reported here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 1 -- William C. Benton, former Assistant Secretary of State, will lead the United States delegation to the United Nations Freedom of Information Conference opening March 23 in Geneva, it was learned here today.
A wide diversity of spring costumes selected for their wearability as well as their femininity was presented by De Pinna yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.

Generous trims of flowers, tulle and veiling, and such fanciful ornaments as small imitation gas lights gave interest to the millinery designed by Keneth Hopkins and presentedh)0*0*0*iyesterday at Gunther. The designer favored a soft coral tone and a light almond green, his other color groups being black, black and white, natural and beige.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 1 (UP) -Democratic leaders of South Carolina and Tennessee turned thumbs down today on President Truman as the party's 1948 candidate for the White House.

Relief Column on Wayh)0*0*0*iOPEIPING, March 1 (AP) -- A Chinese Government column, blasting its way toward Communist-surrounded Mukden, reported today that it was seventy miles away, with much of the intervening area clear. The report broke days of unrelieved Government gloom over the Manchurian situation.
A possible link between birth control and rent control was suggested yesterday by Municipal Court Justice Charles H. Breitbart in Brooklyn.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Marchh)0*0*0*i1 -- The Costa Rican Congress announced tonight that the election of Feb. 8 in which Otilio Ulate was picked as President had been annulled by a vote of 27 to 19.
Secretary of Defense James Forrestal is tackling tomorrow a problem as old as the history of man -- the problem of reconciling "security" with freedom.

The Lamp and Shade Institute of America, representing approximately 250 lamp and shade manufacturers in four key production centers, will oppose proposed new lamp-packaging specifications for rail shipments, Benjamin M. Robins, executive secretary and counsel of the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, disclosed yesterday.

Senator Vandenberg brought the ERP bill to the Senate yesterday at a moment when every new dispatch from abroad emphasized its terrible urgency. We may visualize a different and happier scene if Russia had followed a cooperative international policy after the end of the Second World War.
Anti-Communist forces beat a strategic retreat after seeking a test of strength yesterday with the leadership of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO.

LONDON, March 1 -- Great Britain has less than $60,000,000 in unencumbered dollar securities in the United States and many of those holdings are not readily marketable, according to a report issued by the Treasury today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Representative Richard F. Harless, Democrat, of Arizona, and a member of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, declared today that he had heard of "deliberate attempts to sabotage the foreign policy of the United States by mismanagement of export licenses."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 1 -- An agreement on a union between Britain and France and the Benelux states may be concluded befere March 15, it was learned here today from a highly reliable source. Negotiations among the five countries is progressing most satisfactorily, it was stated.

An aeronauticallyminded New Yorker reports to this department that the sight of a long, cigar-shaped cloud over Manhattan the other day reminded him of the big silver lighterthan-air craft which not so many years ago used to soar across this island's canyons, making a pretty picture, their graceful symmetry in striking contrast to the sharp angles of skyscrapers.

Business volume of the A. S. Beck Shoe Corporation last year reached a new high of $68,319,369, according to the annual report of Saul Schiff, president, issued for publication today. Net sales, after deducting inter-company sales, increased 14.3 per cent to $44,014,245 from the $38,509,106 volume for 1946.

h)0*0*0*iOWASHINGTON, March 1 -- It is expected that a further statement of United States policy on the proposed partition of Palestine will be made soon in the Security Council, Assistant Secretary of State Norman Armour indicated today. It will be made by Warren R. Austin, United States representative.
GENEVA, March 1 Panama has withdrawn from the United Nations Maritime Conference, it was announced today by the conference chairman, J. J. Oyevaar.

While the Long Island Rail Road's new general manager promised yesterday to use patrons' complaints as a guide for corecting inefficiencies, the Public Service Commission closed its inquiry into the road's breakdown as a result of the record snowfall of Dec. 26.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, March 1 (AP) -- United States Army agents announced today the arrest of Mrs. Gertrude Schlotz-Klink Heissmeyer, 46, former Nazi leader who had urged German women toh)0*0*0*iheed Hitler's plea to bear more children.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast labor leader, has refused to resign his post as Northern California director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations or, alternatively, to follow the CIO's policy, which is opposed to support of a third party and Henry Wallace's candidacy.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Charles D. Breitel, counsel to Governor Dewey, advised the Citizens Union today that proceedings for the proposed removal of Judge Franklin Taylor of Kings County Court should be initiated with the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

PRAGUE, March 1 (AP) -- Antonin Gregor, Communist Minister of Foreign Trade, said that Czechoslovakia hopes to maintain tradeh)0*0*0*irelations with the West. He told the Cabinet news conference today that a delegation had left Satur day for Brussels to discuss trade with Belgium.
Mrs. Norrie Sellar will leave tomorrow for St. Augustine, Fla., to visit Prince and Princess Boris Scherbatow for several weeks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Gary Cooper will play Orville Wright in the studio's projected film on the careers of the Wright brothers. Cooper is expected to do the picture after he completes "The Fountainhead," which will be his first assignment under his new multiple picture contract with Warners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Mar. 1 -- A British-Australian resolution seting up broad principles for international reduction of armaments was rejected today by Russia soon after its introduction before the working committee of the United Nations Commission for Conventional Armaments.
PARIS, March 1 (AP) -- The price of gold reached a new high in Paris today after a day that saw the biggest advance and heaviest trading since the free gold market was opened on Feb. 4.

A third-degree assault charge against Peter Arno, the cartoonist, was dismissed yesterday by Justice Irving Ben Cooper in General Sessions. An information had been filed by a grand jury against Mr. Arno, who is 44 years old and lives at 417 Park Avenue, alleging that last Oct. 26 he had threatened Andre Lepelettier, a doorman of the Hotel Drake, 440 Park Avenue, with a .38 caliber pistol.

Of the 632 unlicensed crew members of the United States liner America, 496 had signed on yesterday for the scheduled sailing of the ship tomorrow to Cobh, Southampton and Cherbourg, Capt. William H. Lee, assistant general manager of the line, announced.

PARIS, March 1 -- Success in the efforts for a strong and durable cooperation among the Western European powers is believed hereh) 0*0*0*iOnow to hinge upon getting a close understanding between Britain and France.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 1 -The Conservative party announced its opposition to negotiation of a Russo-Finnish military alliance today a few hours after President. Juho K. Paasikivi had discussed the proposed pact in a secret session with Finland's top political and military leaders.h)0*0*0*iO

THE first time I ever fired an old-fashioned, ivory-handled forty-five revolver, the kind with which Hopalong Cassidy of the Bar 20 used to shoot the buttons off his enemies' shirts, my target was a prairie dog. He was sitting up like a tent peg about thirty yards away, and to make sure of my aim I lay flat on the ground and hunched as closely over the gun as I could.

True to the spirit of the Fighting Irish, the Notre Dame basketball team erased an early 9-point deficit and came roaring down the stretch to conquer New York University, 64 59, in their fifteenth annual court clash last night at Madison Square Garden.

MONTREAL, March 1 (Canadian Press) -- St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., a newsprint holding company announced today it has instituted proceedings in Superior Court to upset an order issued on last Jan. 27 by Justice Louis Boyer, ruling against a plan of reorganization of part of the company's financial structure.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 1 -- A Russian attempt to get the United Nations to press for the return to their native land of children now in foreign countries as a result of the war was defeated today in the Economic and Social Council.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 (AP) Yale's Athletic Association called a hasty press conference today to announce what a lot of folks already suspected that it didn't have a football coach.

LONDON, March 1 -- The feature of the stock market here today was the set-back in Uruguayan rail stocks following reports that the Uruguayan Government had bought the railways for 7,200,000 after the negotiators had asked 8,000,000.

Favor Newspaper Frequency American Tobacco Company will break a $500,000 national campaign March 15 for Herbert Tareyton Cigarettes, putting heavy emphasis on consistent newspaper insertions, it was learned yesterday. This will be a notable contrast to the campaign last year, when no newspaper space was used.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 1 -President Truman declared today that the politics of a Presidential campaign year, as well as the comparatively large number of Republican candidates for President, were hampering the settlement of vital domestic and foreign problems.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Allied Commander in the Pacific, was formally invited today to return to the United States to testify regarding the effectiveness of the proposed $570,000,000 aid program for China.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee has voted to cut off substantial Federal aid funds toh)0*0*0*istates not offering equal employment and educational opportunities to persons of all races.

A five-man Army recruiting team of members of the Eleventh Airborne Division and the First Cavalry Division, stationed in Japan, was greeted yesterday by Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commander of the First Army, on Governors Island.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -Dr. Condon issued the following statement tonight in comment on the report of the House Subcommittee:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A House Subcommittee on Un-American Activities today denounced Dr. Edward U. Condon, head of the National Bureau of Standards, as "one of the weakest links in our atomic security" and an associate "knowingly or unknowingly" of "alleged Soviet espionage agents."

Hervey Allen, author of "Anthony Adverse," has completed the third volume in his series of novels, "The Disinherited," and Rinehart has scheduled it for publication on June 26 under the title, "Toward the Morning." The earlier volumes were "The Forest and the Fort" and "Bedford Village."

One of the results of the recent decline in sensitive food prices, it would appear, has been to dampen any tendency in the direction of inventory speculation and inflation. According to the National Association of Purchasing Agents, sixty days is at present "the most desired objective," so far as buying ahead is concerned, with 92 per cent of those canvassed reporting their average forward commitments at ninety days or less.

JERUSALEM, March 1 -- Unidentified terrorists attacked the automobile of the British commanding general in Palestine today a few hours after the Government has issued an official condemnation of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The nation-wide A P food chain today filed arguments to support its appeal from a Federal Court decision that it conspired to control a substantial part of the nation's food business. The 351-page brief was filed in the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here.

The romantic appeal of sterling silver remains constant whether it is fashioned with the austere simplicity of the early American craftsmen, the elaborate intricacy of the Victorians or the suave lines of today's designers.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Congressional Aviation Policy Board recommended today an air defense program which would raise Government expenditures well above the $40,000,000,000 level annually for at least the next five years.h)0*0*0*iO

Reviewers hied themselves with eagerness to the concert last night at which three new works, by as many American composers, were performed by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, in Carnegie Hall. The soloist of the occasion was Joseph Knitzer, who played the second violin concerto of Prokofieff.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that he would ask the city to take over Sydenham Hospital if the Harlem interracial institution could not weather its financial difficulties.
NEW ORLEANS, March 1 - Conversion of atomic energy into electrical power can be expected in the next twenty years, one of the nation's top nuclear fission researchers said here today.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 1 -- The championship second-base combination of Peewee Reese and Eddie Stanky will operate again for the Dodgers this year.
It was a murky night in February, 1943, when the Yankee Clipper smashed into the waters of the Tagus River near Lisbon, Portugal. The airplane ripped open and went down.

Public response to the start yesterday of a railroad passenger ticket delivery service here, using Western Union messengers as delivery agents to eliminate waiting lines at ticket windows, was "very good," according to a passenger agent of the New York Centralh)0*0*0*iSystem, one of the four railroads offering the plan.

A four-alarm fire yesterday afternoon that started at 132 Bowery and spread rearward to 116 Elizabeth Street snarled rush-hour traffic, including that on the Grand Street approach to Manhattan Bridge, endangered the Third Avenue elevated structure and forced evacuation of near-by structures.
Net sales of the Underwood Cortotal of $57,101,261, compared with the 1946 volume of $37,164,347, acporation last year reached a record cording to the annual report issued for release today.

Thousands of Red Cross volunteer workers began yesterday to canvass business and professional offices, factories, apartments and homes throughout the city in a drive to raise $6,036,000, the city's quota in the national goal of $75,000,000.

WASHINGTON March 1 -- James E. Webb, Budget Director, told Congress today not to expect material reductions in Government spending for two years. Addressing the Senate Finance Committee as it began consideration of the House bill calling for $6,500,000,000 of cuts in personal income taxes this year he urged the Senators to hold this in mind as they deliberated.

GENEVA, March 1 -- Substantial increases in Europe's coal output were recorded in January, according to figures released today by the coal committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

The Pure Oil Company, in its thirty-fourth annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday by Henry M. Dawes, chairman of the executive committee, disclosed the highest sales volume in the company's history.

For the benefit of scores of handicapped persons who suffer from impaired vision or hearing, or who are victims of heart disease, palsy, orthopedic disabilities and other ailments, it is important that the newly opened 1948 campaign of Goodwill Industries of New York for $150,000 be a success.

The approach of municipal bond specialists to the flotation of $300,100,000 of New York State bonus bonds up for sale today would suggest that competitive bidding has no "monopoly" on the headaches generated in syndicate bond-pricing meetings.

Ed (Moose) Krause, Notre Dame basketball coach, in charge of the West All-Stars, who will oppose the East All-Stars for the benefit of the Tribune Fresh Air Fund, March 25 at Madison Square Garden, announced the names of five of his players yesterday while addressing the weekly luncheon meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 6 per cent in February, paralleling the increase in the preceding month, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Grain markets advanced rapidly today onh) 0*0*0*ithe Board of Trade, with May and July corn and all deliveries of soy beans soaring the daily limit of 8 cents a bushel. May wheat at one time was up 9 3/4 cents, or within 1/4 cent of the permissible upturn.

By a vote of fourteen to five the City Council approved a measure yesterday asking that the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority be empowered to build a new Madison Square Garden and a 2,000car parking garage near Columbus Circle through a bond issue of $25,000,000.

Harold E. Goldsmith has been appointed sales manager in the Boston region for the fabrics and finishes department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. He succeeds Sumner B. Woodbridge, who has retired after forty-one years in the finishes business.

LONDON, March 1 -- The rioting Saturday in Accra, in which sections of the Gold Coast city's shopping district were looted and burned by African war veterans, was "almost certainly" instigated by Communists, David R. Rees Williams, Under-Secretary for Colonies, told the House of Commons today.

Rayon textiles which were selling at peak prices at second hand toward the end of 1948 are now being offered at figures which indicate a definite drop in demand, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday.

Notable in Sophie's custom-made collection, offered for review in Saks Fifth Avenue's Salon Moderne yesterday afternoon, are handsome fabrics and countless fine details. In both Sophie has made clever use of her imagination.

PARIS, March 1 -- French newspaper publishers charged in a press release today that the Government policy of higher newsprint prices threatened the freedom of the press. The press release was a reply to a Government communique stating that the present lower newsprint price, as taxed by the Government, constituted a Government subsidy to the press, and that such a subsidy was contrary to Government policy.

ELYRIA, Ohio, March 1 -- Strikersh)0*0*0*iat the Brown-Lipe-Chapin Division of the General Motors Corporation tonight smashed windows in automobiles of non-striking employes while Elyria police and Lorain County deputy sheriffs watched without protest.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 19 per cent in the week ended Feb. 28 compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, March 1 -- A solemn House of Commons heard today a strong condemnation of Zionist terrorism in the Holy Land and a hint that steps might be taken about the activities of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, chairman of the United States Olympic Committee, said today he would recommend that his group adopt a rule barring Olympic Committee members from coaching or managerial positions on Olympic athletic squads after the London summer games.
The Liberal party yesterday termed Mayor O'Dwyer's second legislative "package" unacceptable and called for its rejection if its final form consisted largely of a subway fare increase.

Mayor O'Dwyer continuing his recovery yesterday at Gracie Mansion after eight days in Bellevue Hospital for a heart condition, conferred in the afternoon with Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, and four local leaders on national affairs.

The problem of aggression in human beings and in nations, and its place, if any, in leading to war, was discussed yesterday at the allday annual conference of the Child Study Association of America in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- With a Friday deadline facing them, employers and the union of the Oak Ridge (Tenn.) plant of the Atomic Energy Commission today explained the basis of their dispute to the Federal Mediation and Concillation Service.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg restated today that he was not a candidate for the Republicanh)0*0*0*iPresidential nomination as he sent a last-minute telegram requesting that his name not be filed for the Nebraska primary on April 13.

A New York broker who was expelled from the Stock Exchange twenty years ago and five of his current associates were accused yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein of having defrauded customers of $50,000 by a usurious "beat-the-margin" scheme.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $57,382,600 of 3 per cent convertible debentures, due April 15, 1963.

The Grandview Company, contracting and engineering concern, has purchased a plot of land containing 26,000 square feet on South Fulton Avenue in Mount Vernon, N.Y., from Jay S. Klotz. The property, between the Metaplast Bui]ding and the Ward Motor Vehicle Building, adjoins a parcel in the rear, containing 46,000 square feet, which the Grandview Company acquired some time ago.
Commission for Conventional Armaments, Working Committee -- Received revised British draft resolution on general principles for regulation and reduction of armaments.
