WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Truman appealed to Congress today to extend for three years the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act as an "essential" to all the vast enterprises now under way or being studied for the world's economic recovery.

The practice of having two separate grand juries each month inh) 0*0*0*iKings County Court was ended yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz after a five-month trial. The plan was adopted last Oct. 1 at the suggestion of District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 1 -- A habeas corpus proceeding for the release of the two Newburgh newspaper men who are serving jail sentences rather than reveal a confidential news source was begun today in Supreme Court.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 1 -- A political crisis forced the postponement for one day of today's special session of the Bizonal Economic Council and threatened the Right Wing Christian Democratic party with loss of control over the bizonal Legislature.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Assembly tonight approved the CondonWadlin bill increasing benefit payable under the Workmen's Compensation Law in death and disability cases. The proposal had already received Senate approval and now goes to Governor Dewey for signature.

In the face of the continuing housing need, it is perfectly clear that something must be done to stimulate private construction. While home building throughout the nation has attained very high levels, the industry in New York City has not kept pace.

h)0*0*0*iOCIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 1 -- Don't look now, but our Beloved Bums are lolling in the lap of luxury. The Brooklyn Dodgers formally opened spring training this morning and surprisingly enough didn't seem to object too strenuously to toiling with their hands. It was, however, a sad comedown for gentlemen of their lofty station and mode of living.

Ruling that controversial points had been raised in a proceeding brought in Supreme Court by the American Gold Star Mothers of the World War, Inc., to restrain Mrs. Mathilda Burling of 95-75 114th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, from representing herself as national president of an organization with a similar title, Justice E. L. Hammer directed yesterday that the proceedings be placed on the calendar.

The reduced volume of selling of long-term Government securities and the slight recession in yields on high grade corporate bonds in recent weeks "appear to reflect greater confidence in the prospect for stability in long-term interest rates than prevailed some weeks ago," the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in its Monthly Review, issued yesterday.

VIENNA, March 1 -- A joker slipped into the Italian peace treaty has turned out for the refugee subjects of the former Baltic states to be something like the famous Potsdam clause about Germanh)0*0*0*iexternal assets, so far as Austria is concerned.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 1 -President Truman left open the possibility today that this country might seek a military alliance with Western European countries to counter Russian pressure on Czechoslovakia and Finland.

TOKYO, March 1 -- Much troubled Japan now has a new problem. The water is too cold for the fish. Porgy, eels and yellowtail, all deep water creatures, are dying, say the Japanese, and middle depth fish such as bonito and mackerel are heading south for warmer climes.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The World Trade Corporation urged today the immediate modernization of New York City's dock and pier system as an essential first step toward maintaining the city's competitive position in world trade.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- The United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, its post-war membership soaring again to nearly 1,000,000, began today to draft an intensified program against a third political party in 1948 and in favor of immediate adoption of the Marshall Plan.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Amendments to the state's stand-by residential rent controls so as to validate New York City's emergency curbs on evictions until March 1, 1949, and to recontrol of dwelling space that might be released from Federal controls were agreed upon today by the Joint Legislative Committee on Rents.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 1 (AP) -Bids will be received by State Controller Frank C. Moore tomorrow at 11 A.M. on $300,000,000 New York State war bonus bonds. A confusing news release by the Controller's office previously led to the understanding that the bonds would be sold today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, March 1 (AP) Trial of eight companies charged with conspiring to create a monopoly in the flat glass industry began this afternoon before Federal Judge Frank L. Kloeb.

The long-standing question of increasing the rentals on city-owned piers, which is scheduled to go before the Board of Estimate again on Friday, may be postponed once more pending study by municipal authorities of the port rehabilitation program proposed by the Port of New York Authority, it was reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Dr. Dominick F. Maurello, Brooklyn physician, has been picked for election to the State Board of Regents as a member of the new Second Judicial District, it was disclosed tonight. He is to be nominated formally tomorrow and elected on Wednesday.
I believe now is the time for Congress to bring about:
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 1 (AP) -- Michigan won the Big Nine basketball crown tonight when it upset Iowa, 51 to 35.

Lester Hirschfield of the Bronx, unseeded, gained the semi-final round of the men's singles division by upsetting the No. 4 entrant,h) 0*0*0*iJ. Gilbert Hall, four-time national veterans' champion, 9 -- 7, 4 6, 6 -- 3, in the Eastern indoor tennis championships yesterday on the Metropolitan Tennis Club courts at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

The William Waldorf Astor Estate, through the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, has purchased the large store and apartment properties at 400 and 420-430 Park Avenue from the New York State Realty and Terminal Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Central Railroad.
The first industry-wide price increases in end-products using steel, reflecting in part, recent mill price increases, were reported here yesterday in the metal furniture field.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 1 -- A tenpoint program for setting up a Jewish republic in the Holy Land without the aid of any international force was put before the United Nations Palestine Commission today.

BERLIN, March 1 -- A proposal to sell a half interest in a principal Ruhr industry to a French syndicate was recently made at a secret meeting by Rudolf Pferdmenges, wealthy and influential Cologne banker. Information regarding any further steps in this direction is not immediately available.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 1 -- A twofold medical program to try to stamp out tuberculosis and prevent the spread of venereal disease in war-wrecked European countries was presented today to the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund.
PRINCETON, N.J., Mar. 1 -Scoring in each period, the Williams hockey team defeated Princeton, 3 -- 2, in a rough battle marked by fist fights in Baker Rink tonight.

ALBANY, March 1 -- A measure which would give newspapermen the privilege of refusing to disclose sources of confidential information to grand juries and in judicial proceedings was introduced into the state Legislature tonight by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, and Assembly Majority Leader Lee B. Mailler, both of Orange County.

A proposal to immediately allocate to the European Recovery Program 200,000 or more surplus machine tools now either held by the War Assets Administration or set aside and "frozen" by other branches of the Government -such as the Joint Army and Navy Munitions Board -- was advocated here yesterday.

Robert McGowan Barrington-Ward, editor of The Times of London since Geoffrey Dawson retired in 1941, was a modest, unobtrusive man, and because of this quality little known in this country. He was, however, a person of remarkable attainments himself and a member of a remarkable family.
NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP) -The National Association of State Racing Commissions, meeting here today, voted uniform rules for prevention and detection of horse doping.

TOKYO, March 1 - Occupation officials have been watching with some signs of discomfort recent changes in the policy of Japan's Communist party: Its leaders have been steadily playing down internationalism. Instead, they have been emphasizing racism in an obvious appeal to bring former Rightist totalitarians within their ranks.

SHANGHAI, March 1 -- Talks with Chinese business men, bankers, intellectuals and technicians indicate that President Chiang Kai-shek, once a sacrosanct political symbol, has suffered a widespread loss of personal prestige here as a consequence of the Government's military defeats, the disastrous inflation and Nanking's inability thus far to cope with its serious financial problems.

In its first decline in six months, the Amott-Baker realty bond price averages, comprising 200 issues, dropped 0.6 per cent in February to $782 per $1,000 bond. The average price was listed at $787 on Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg challenged the Senate today to reply in kind to Soviet Russia's undeclared war on democratic governments everywhere by approving the European Recovery Program as an undisguised counteroffensive against the march of communism westward.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -A bill to let 100,000 of Europe's "displaced persons" enter the United States moved one short step forward today with Senate committee approval.

LONDON, March 1 -- Enthusiastically cheering an announcement that conversations would begin next Thursday in Brussels on the formation of a Western European Union, the House of Commons approved tonight a defense program intended by the Labor Government to give firm military backing to this association of Western powers.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 1 -- Eight former German generals who have been collaborating with the United States Army in writing its history of World War II were acquitted by a special German denazification tribunal, Army headquarters announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Four Senators and nine Representatives outlined to the National Veterans Housing Conference tonight a strategy designed to save the TaftEllender-Wagner Housing Bill, which has been reported as permanently shelved.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The FrenchRussian feud, which had culminated in the Russians' refusal to dine as French guests at the Allied Control Authority for the last week, apparently dissolved over the week-end with the discontinuance of the Soviet-licensed newspaper that had been the most unprincipled and malicious in its attacks on the Western powers.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 1 -- If it is true that a sour rehearsal augurs well for the performance ahead, and vice versa, then the Yankees may be in for some trouble later. For it is doubtful whether any major league club ever got off to a more auspicious spring training start than did Bucky Harris and his world champions today.
Threatened strikes against the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, whose union contracts expired last midnight, were postponed yesterday and last night.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The right of radio stations equally with newspapers to have editorial opinions of their own and, if they choose, to make use of their facilities to give expression to them was advocated before the Federal Communications Commission today by the presidents of the American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.
When Marc Langevin, director of the Paris subway, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday his words had a familiar plaintive ring.

Reversing the trend of the previous eighteen months, deposits of state-supervised banks in the United States and Hawaii increased, during the last half of 1947, by $3,651,170,000, or 4.78 per cent, the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks announced today.

Whether principals of New York public schools shall be permitted to continue their practice of judging the fitness of gift books for school libraries will be taken up today by the Board of Superintendents, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, March 1 -- General elections under United Nations supervision will be held here on May 9, Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, announced today.

The report yesterday of the withdrawal of "This Land Is Mine" after a one-day showing in a Prague theatre came as a surprise to members of the Motion Picture Export Association, representing the major American film companies in Czechoslovakia.

An employe of the Consolidated Edison Company was burned fatality and four others also suffered burns yesterday from a flash fire. The blaze was laid to a short circuit in a transformer on which the men were working in the company's Brooklyn substation at 6501 Fifth Avenue.

The British Broadcasting Corporation's "Mystery Theatre" dramas are to be broadcast from transcriptions by WNYC for thirteen weeks, beginning Saturday, March 13, from 8 to 8:30 P.M. Six of the scheduled presentations are in the "Adventures with Julia" series; seven are from the "Journey Into Fear" group:

SOMERVILLE, N.J., March 1 -A group of high school students, intent on combating racial and religious prejudice, began such steps as canvassing soda fountains and sweet shops here today on their attitude toward serving Negroes. They won a promise from the proprietor of one favorite teen-age resort that he would no longer discriminate against Negro youths.

March came in like a numbed and shivering lion yesterday, indicating the traditional possibility of a lamblike exit. The temperature dropped to a low of 18.4 degrees at 2:30 A.M. and remained below the freezing level throughout the day. Snow began to fall at 12:45 A.M. today, but a rise in the mercury to the upper thirties is expected to cause a change to street-cleaning rain.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 -Mort Cooper's career as a ballplayer is ended as of today, after fourteen years in organized ball, most of them spent as a chattel of the St. Louis Cardinals.

WHEN the President decided to meet with Prime Minister Churchill for the second Quebec conference, in September, 1944, he asked me whether I wished to accompany him. The conference, however, was intended to be largely military.

It is apparent from letters reiceived that the dog thieves are still working overtime, despite legislation to increase the punishment of those apprehended. Several letters have been received from mid-Western sportsmen concerning the Natlonal Dog Identification Bureau, an organization with headquarters at Monroeton, Pa., which hopes materially to reduce dog thefts in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Three grain allocation and buying officials of the Department of Agriculture told Congressional investigators today that they did not believe a halt in Government wheat buying was responsible for the sharp drop in commodity pricesh)0*0*0*iearly last month.
LANSING, Mich., March 1 (AP) -Charges of an alleged gamblerplayer tieup in the National Hockey League will be threshed out in Gov. Kim Sigler's office here tomorrow.

NANKING, March 1 - Progress in the Government's drive to reopen land communications between China proper and Mukden was reported here today. At the same time statements were made by President Chiang Kai-shek and other Government leaders that the Government was determined to retain its positions in Manchuria.

ATHENS, March 1 -- The head of the Greek Fleet, Admiral Constas, said tonight that within the last ten days "a group of sailors" had been arrested in connection with subversive acts allegedly committed a year ago. Those apprehended, Admiral Constas said, had been removed from the Navy.

The immediate lifting of the United States embargo on arms to Palestine and enforcement of the United Nations partition plan for that country, if necessary by means of an international police force, were demanded in addresses and messages yesterday afternoon at a meeting in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- A great nationalist demonstration tonight marked Argentina's acquisition of the British railways, while President Juan Peron lay hospitalized as the result of an emergency and successful appendectomy.

An exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Augustus Saint-Gaudens, famous American sculptor, opened yesterday at the Century Association, 7 West Forty-third Street. The show was arranged by James Earle Fraser, a student of SaintGaudens and his assistant in the last years of his life.

WASHINGTON, March 1 h)0*0*0*iCalling for "an alert and ready America," President Truman today proclaimed April 6 as Army Day. The proclamation was issued by the White House in the President's absence in Florida.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Henry Wallace's third-party forces will bid for a big Negro vote this fall by running Negro candidates for Congress in favorable districts throughout the nation, it was learned today.

HAVANA, March 1 -- The Coordinating Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment reached a general settlement tonight, breaking the deadlock on the economic development issue that has existed since December.

The Department of Justice continued its drive against alien Communists in this country with the arrest yesterday of Irving Potash, member of the National Board of the Communist party and manager of the Furriers Joint Council of New York.

While sharing the keen appreciation the writer of Topics of The Times shows for the fact that there still are things which do not lend themselves to improvement, I should like to put in a word for the geometrical principle ofh) 0*0*0*ithe coming "dunkerett." That principle is older than the word and it is also much better.

The stock market yesterday made a strong attempt to advance, although gain proved selective in trading marked by emphasis on the aircraft and air transports sections. Major improvements, which ranged to 2 points and more, were scored by the two groups, although elsewhere changes were fractional, the combined averages rising 0.52 point.

With the arrival of the five masters, representing the United States, the Netherlands and Russia who will compete this month and in April, for the chess championship of the world, a preliminary meeting of players and officials was held at the Grote Zaal in the Zoological Gardens.

Leopold Stowkowski, who will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony for four weeks, beginning March 11, will include one work by a contemporary composer on each program, it was announced yesterday. The first Thursday, Friday and Sunday programs will introduce to New York Robert Casadesus Piano Concerto in E major, with the composer as piano soloist.

The possibility of a strike by the 4,000 union printers employed in New York's book, magazine and job printing shops moved nearer yesterday. A conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania between representatives of the employers and the International Typographical Union failed to break a deadlock in positions that have been maintained for several weeks by both sides.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The Argentine threat in the threecushion phase of the national billiard tourney increased today when Juan Navarra of Buenos Aires capturedh)0*0*0*ihis fourth game in five starts.
RICHMOND, Va., March 1 (AP) The Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals today ruled, in effect, that a state disorderly conduct law cannot be used to maintain racial segregation on buses.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold the five-story altered building at 1998 Second Avenue, southeast corner of 103d Street, containing stores and eighteen apartments, to Bernard Gordon. R. Solove was the broker.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 1 (AP) The Red Sox today launched a new era under Manager Joe McCarthy -- and it got off to a promising start as even Ted Williams showed up for the first day of spring training.

In a cash transaction, Stone Motors Corporation, agent for KaiserFrazer automobiles, bought the one-story taxpayer containing sevenh)0*0*0*istores at 800 Southern Boulevard, northeast corner of Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, from Margaret MacRossie, Charles K., F. J. and G. Johnson Hamilton.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1--In a pulsating overtime encounter at the Payne Whitney gym tonight the Dartmouth quintet, paced by Paul Campbell and Ed Leede, eked out a 68-63 decision over Yale.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- Lord Bicester's 9-yearold gelding, Silver Fame, replaced Roimond today as favorite to win the 4 1/2mile Grand National steeplechase at Aintree March 20.

It's smart to be thrifty, particularly in this day with food. Mrs. Elizabeth Bussing came to Macy's yesterday to show how to eat well for less money. Her show went on at the store's home center at 2:30 P.M. It will be repeated todayh)0*0*0*iand Thursday at the same time.

Alvaro Giorgetti and Angelo De Bacco, the Italian team which set a blistering pace during the opening session, found the going much more difficult yesterday as the sixty-seventh international sixday bicycle race went into its second phase at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory.

For a solid hour early yesterday morning Miss Josephine Ostoloco, 20 years old, of 143 Amsterdam Avenue, fed quarters into the juke box of the Arco Bar and Grill, at 916 Ninth Avenue, and listened with obvious relish to a recordingh)0*0*0*iof "Civilization," a popular song that opens with the phrase, "Bongo, Bongo, Bongo."
Cotton futures prices turned strong yesterday in the late trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, and the close was 22 to 96 points net higher than Saturday's final levels.

LONDON, March 1 -- The foursided conference on Western Germany began its last week of daily sessions today with what was called "a useful conversation." However, with the customary secrecy on details being maintained, it seemed fairly certain that no official information would come from the conference until its close on Friday.
JERUSALEM, March 1 (AP) The text of a statement issued today by the Palestine Government follows:

Broadway will see a friendly, benign Boris Karloff this evening at the Music Box Theatre in J. B. Priestley's new play, "The Linden Tree." The noted screen menace will portray an English professor who "indulges in kindly philosophies, in whimsy and in a very justifiable rebellion against his family and against his college when it is decided he must retire from active teaching on his sixtyfifth birthday."
SEATTLE, March 1 (AP) -- One of the world's largest ferry fleets closed down passenger operations today, leaving an estimated 100,000 persons with only emergency transportation.

A warning that we must thoroughly overhaul our military and civil aviation policies and re-establish a strong aviation industry if we are to have national security was given yesterday by the Congressional Aviation Policy Board, after a six months' study of the problem.

PRAGUE, March 1 -- Czechoslovakia's omnipotent action committees, which are taking over the state for the regime of Communist Premier Klement Gottwald, have as their legal basis only "the will of the people," as interpreted by the regime, it was disclosed today at a full-dress Cabinet press conference.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- The 15,685 at Hialeah Park today established the right favorite in the $5,000 sprint for 3-year-olds that headed the penultimate program of the forty-day meeting. That one was the Rarco Stable's Tight Squeeze, who had an 8-to-5 listing and won by five lengths or so after tossing away some yardage at the start.

The New York Rangers oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash will be the last of the regular campaign on local ice for the league-leading Leafs and a capacity crowd of more than 15,000 fans is expected to see them.

A hundred dog lovers made the auditorium of the Health Department ring with their shouts of disapproval yesterday at a publich)0*0*0*ihearing on a proposed regulation that in effect would prevent noncommercial owners from keeping more than two dogs in their homes.

Sent message to Legislature recommending a fund of $1,250,000 for loans to school districts in anticipation of Federal aid for school lunches. Received the Rev. Ervelle Maynard, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Albany.
Everybody but the manufacturer was designed to help cooperated yesterday in the plan to ease traffic congestion in the garment sector by staggering truck pickups and deliveries.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Frank Kenna, Republican leader of Queens, announced tonight that the entire Republican delegation from his county in the Legislature would oppose Mayor William O'Dwyer's request for increased real estate taxing powers for New York City.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1 - State Labor Commissioner Harry C. Harper made plain today that he intended to remain a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator despite continuing pressure to withdraw.

A glimpse of fall fashions was given yesterday at a show sponsored by the National Shoe Retailers Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Eleven dress andh)0*0*0*icoat designers cooperated with the shoe houses of I. Miller, Newton Elkin, Palter DeLiso, and Schwartz and Benjamin in the forecast.

Bedecked from stem to stern with multi-colored signal flags, the trim, white motor-liner Stockholm completed her maiden run to New York at 10 A.M. yesterday, amid the whistling acclaim of scores of harbor craft.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1 - State Labor Commissioner Harry C. Harper made plain today that he intended to remain a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator despite continuing pressure to withdraw.

Ruth Page is never at a loss for an idea. Her ballet, "Billy Sunday," which had its premiere last nighth)0*0*0*iin the season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center, is a hilariously original conception whatever reservations must be made about its execution.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -The Department of Agriculture reported today 1947 domestic wool production dropped to the lowest level since 1925.

Rocky Graziano, middleweight champion of the world, will get back into competition on April 5 when he will fight George (Sonny) Horne of Valley Stream, L.I. in a non-title bout in Washington, D. C. Graziano, who is under suspension in this state, has not been in a ring since he took the 160 pound championship from Tony Zale in Chicago last July.

" Great Mischief," a new novel by Josephine Pinckney, author of "Three O'Clock Dinner," will be published by Viking on March 22. It is a story set in Charleston in the 1880's and the two central characters are an apothecary and "a beautiful blue-eyed hag."

Princeton, only conqueror of Columbia in eighteen basketball games this season, will try to repeat its overtime upset of two weeks ago in the Lion gymnasium at 8:30 tonight, in a contest important to both teams' Eastern League championship hopes.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -The House decided today against looking into the income tax returns of Earl K. Long, Democratic nominee for Governor of Louisiana.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- Backing the United States proposal that the Security Council accept partition as the solution of the Palestine question, the Soviet Union today urged "direct negotiations" between the Big Five as the best approach to the whole problem.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities acted today to seize and examine the files of a Department of Commerce board which cleared Dr. Edward U. Condon of any disloyalty to the United States.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 15 you printed a letter by the famous playwright Henri Bernstein. He paints a sympathetic picture of de Gaulle and gives the impression that the majority of French people share his complete confidence in the General's motives. Judging from numerous articles in THE TIMES by Harold Callender, this is now the case.

SAN JOSE, March 2 (AP) -- The followers of Senor Ulate immedi ately asked the foreign diplomatic corps to intercede with the Government in his behalf. It had been predicted that Senor Ulate would be arrested or sent into exile when he was found.
Directors of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company declared yesterday the first dividend since 1930 on the preferred stock, amounting to $5 a share, payable on March 22.

Two groups of prominent executives of the oil industry have been commissioned to make a world wide investigation into the availability of petroleum products for use in the United States, it was announced yesterday by William R. Boyd Jr., president of the American Petroleum Institute.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- Nonmember countries of the United Nations are taking special efforts to see that relief supplies for underfed youngsters are faithfully and fairly distributed through the overseas offices of the Children's Emergency Fund, Maurice Pate, executive director, reported today.
GENEVA, March 2 -- The United Nations Maritime Conference today unanimously selected London as the headquarters of the new International Maritime Organization.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -Bobby Thomson came to terms with the Giants today. Bill Rigney checked in, two days late because of a housing problem in not-too-distant California. This left two of the club's regulars absent, along with a rookie prospect, as Manager Mel Ott put his squad through the second day of training at a slightly stepped-up tempo and under conditions that were ideal.
Ernest Schwadron suggested some pleasant ideas for bedroom furniture in a display that opened yesterday in his shop at 754 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -Negotiations for an agreement covering 900 employes at an atomic energy plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., became deadlocked today as the conferees held their first night session.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Registration statements covering $40,000,000 of bonds, 117,048 shares of common and 40,000 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

LONDON, March 2 -- At least nineteen of the passengers and crew of a Belgian Sabena airliner died in the blazing wreckage of the plane at London Airport tonight. Total passengers and crew numbered twenty-two. Rescuers fought impotently in a thick fog, unable to approach closely because of the intense heat.

A new thirty-two-foot-long mural by Joan Miro, Spanishborn abstract painter now working in this country, makes its first public appearance today at the Museum of Modern Art. It is destined for a curving wall in the circular glass-enclosed Gourmet Restaurant atop the nearly completed Terrace Plaza Hotel in Cincinnati.
Operations of the Certain-teed Products Corporation last year resulted in the largest sales and earnings in the history of the company, Rawson G. Lizars, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

Another discordant note was sounded yesterday in the program to liquidate the Continental Bank Trust Company. John K. McKee, president, in a statement to the press, protested the use of his name in connection with the most recent announcement that the bank's board of directors had accepted the proposal of the Chemical Bank Trust Company to take over the Continental's resources.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Favorable action on bills giving the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority power to erect a new $25,000,000 Madison Square Garden was assured today when they received the unanimous approval of the Senate Finance and Assembly Ways and Means Committees.

C. B. Baldwin, national campaign manager for Henry A. Wallace, declared yesterday that "while there is no doubt that in some districts third-party candidates [for Congress] will be Negroes, as there are many outstanding Negroes who deserve a seat in Congress, selection of candidates is entirely up to our state organizations."

HELSINKI, Finland, March 2 -Seven questions have been put to Premier Stalin by President Juho K. Paasikivi of Finland about the proposed treaty of mutual military assistance and friendship, it was announced today.

Irving Potash, union leader andh)0*0*0*imember of the National Board of the Communist party, joined yesterday on Ellis Island a hunger strike begun on Monday by four other persons accused by the Government of being alien Communists.

The Jewelry Industry Council will back up organized individual membership advertising with a $200,000 magazine campaign, beginning May 15, it was learned yesterday. Added to the amount spent for ad and sales-aid kits sent to members, the council will spend some $400,000 on its campaign by March 15, 1949.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 2 -- Newspaper ethics call for protection of confidential news sources today even more than in the past if public interests under rapidly changing conditions are to be safeguarded, counsel seeking to free two Newburgh newspaper men from contempt of court convictions contended this afternoon before Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne.

WRIGHTSVILLE, Ga., March 2 (AP) -- About 300 hooded and robed Klansmen paraded here tonight and heard their leader declare that "blood will flow in the streets of the South" if the Negro took a place at the side of white men "through force of Federal bayonets."

The General Electric Company, the nation's largest electrical manufacturer, formally notified the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, in negotiations yesterday that the company did not intend to grant a third round of post-war wage increases.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP) -- Completely mystifying their opponents at times, the Holy Cross Crusaders tonight overwhelmed Brown, 90 -- 35. The basketball game was delayed fifty minutes because of the late arrival of the Bears, who were held up by weather conditions.

Bulldozers are slashing away on Welfare Island, preparing excavations for two major city projects -a chronic disease hospital of 2,000 beds on the north end of the island and a combined laundry, garage and firehouse just north of the Queensboro Bridge.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union,h)0*0*0*iwhich since last Feb. 21 has been conducting a strike at the two leading Albany hotels, gave permission to members of the State Legislature today to cross picket lines.

A jury's recommendation of mercy in behalf of Samuel Tito Williams, 19 years old, was disregarded yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court as he sentenced the youth to die in the electric chair during the week of April 4.

Without a mess sergeant in the vicinity, the Army began a test yesterday to see how well eleven enlisted men can get through the next six weeks on a daily food allowance of five ounces of "special" biscuits and three glasses of water a day.

Bloomingdale's displayed yesterdayh)0*0*0*ia collection of forty-nine costumes in this season's favorite color, navy. Glimpsed throughout the promenade were rippling skirts as well as others that clung slimly to the knees, where they burst into a flare and jackets made individual by small tiers of peplums that flared to the front or godets of pleats released at the back.

D.W. May Corporation, appliance and radio distributors, yesterday exhibited for the first time in the metropolitan area the dishwasher and garbage disposal line produced by Kaiser Fleetwings, Inc. and two new room air-conditioners turned out by FeddersQuigan Corporation.

JAMES A. FARLEY has spent most of his life in professional politics and is generally conceded to be a consummate master of the craft. And, although numerous professional politicians have been justly viewed with alarm by many of their fellow-citizens, Mr. Farley is not one of them. Respected and even admired by his opponents, he is beloved by thousands who know that his personal integrity is as absolute as his personality is engaging.

A rain-soaked boy of 16, whose chief protection from the weather was a white sweater pulled over a red hunting shirt, slipped into the East Fifty-first Street police station at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, identified himself as William Callahan of Montgomery, Ala., and asked to see the captain, confidentially.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 2 -- Lippy Leo Durocher's keystone kids and his leading pitcher donned their Dodger togs and scampered around briskly in the second workout held by the club today. Pee Wee Reese, Eddie Stanky and Ralph Branca, along with the veteran Frenchy Bordagaray, all checked in via various routes and received a warm welcome from their boss.

The North American Wildlife Conference will be held in St. Louis, Mo., this year, and will open for its three-day run on March 8, with scientists as well as sportsmen gathering to discuss the current wildlife problems.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) Michigan's newly crowned championsh)0*0*0*igained two berths, but Iowa's Murray Wier and Minnesota's Jim McIntyre, only repeater from last season, were the only unanimous choices for the All-Big Nine basketball team named today by the Associated Press.

DUBLIN, March 2 -- The decision of Prime Minister John A. Costello's Government to postpone inauguration of the transatlantic service by the Irish Airlines this month has given the new administration one of its first and biggest headaches.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 The lightweight and the highweight lunged for the finish line as a team in the $20,000 added Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah Park today, and even the camera couldn't separate 'em.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Perhaps this could be as good a time as any to sound a warning note for Yankee fans lest they becomeh)0*0*0*iunduly alarmed a little later.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -A five-month-old ban on exports of home heating sizes of coal will be lifted April 1, the Department of Commerce said today.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) Highly rated Andy Ponzi of Philadelphia suffered his second defeat in eight starts, bowing to Onofrio Lauri, Brooklyn, in today's pocket billiard phase of the national billiard championships.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Frank C. Moore, State Controller, and other state officials were highly pleased today by the bids received in connection with the sale of $300,000,000 in state World War II veteransh)0*0*0*ibonus bonds to a syndicate of 215 concerns.

Senator Revercomb's bill to admit 100,000 displaced persons from Europe, having been whittled down from the 400,000 originally suggested by President Truman, has now moved out of the Senate Judiciary Committee. It was approved there ten to one. Only Senator Langer voted against it.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -Max Thornburg, former oil adviserh)0*0*0*ito the State Department, challenged Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine today to cite "a single instance" where he had put the interests of oil companies ahead of the interests of the United States.

More efficient use of time was termed the essence of increased sales force productivity yesterday by Dr. H. C. Nolen, vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc. He supported his contention with detailed data from a "stop-watch" study of 12,000 sales in an address before the Sales Executive Club's luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt.
Ways of bringing an atmosphere of normal living into child-care institutions were outlined yesterdayh)0*0*0*iat an all-day conference sponsored by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.
LONDON, March 2 -- The United States today rejected on five counts the Russian proposals for settlement of the Soviet Union's claims on German assets in Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, indicated today that action on a $350,000,000 loan requested by Czechoslovakia would be impaired by the Communist seizure of power in that country.
PARIS, March 2 -- About 150 persons were killed yesterday in a massive Viet Nam attack upon a French convoy midway between Saigon and Dalat in southern Annam, it was reported here today.

Immediate tax reduction and revision of the revenue laws to provide relief on income tax payments and to stabilize the economy, were advocated yesterday by authorities on various phases of this subjecth)0*0*0*iat a forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.
An oddly mixed-up storm laid a mantle of snow yesterday upon the city and then washed it away with a downpour of cold, penetrating rain.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- Taking a long view of the problems of keeping the peace, the United Nations Little Assembly today created a fifteen-nation committee to formulate a new rule of international law for settling political disputes by peaceful means.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Accused of "conducting concerted slowdowns," thirty-nine members of Local 16 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, were discharged in four commercial printing plants here today.

Prices of carpet wool have increased by 15 per cent and jute yarn prices have gone up 7 per cent since December, Steele M.h) 0*0*0*iWinterer, vice president in charge of sales, A. M. Karagheusian, disclosed yesterday. Speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Floor Covering Distributors Council in the Pennsylvania Hotel, he said that the industry can absorb no further increased production costs without raising prices.
Heard Soviet Union urge "direct negotiations" among Big Five as best approach to Palestine problem, and support United States proposal that Council accept partition as solution of question.
BOSTON, March 2 -- Despite the relative decline in New England's position in the national economy, the New England economy is still growing and has some excellent opportunities for further growth.

The Elgin National Watch Company transacted last year the largest volume of sales in its history, with the total of $22,157,658 exceeding the 1946 volume of $17,800,519 by 24.5 per cent, according to the annual report of T. Albert Potter, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 2 -- Listing nine claims regarding the treatment of infantile paralysis, Sister Elizabeth Kenny urged today that a conference of physicians and laymen be appointed to investigate her methods and the results obtained by them.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Claude Harmon of Palm Beach today led professional golfers in the ninth annual pro-amateur tournament at the Seminole Club with a 67. Harmon, playing the 6,008-yard par-72 course he knows so well, teamed with Ellsworth Alvord of New York to tie at 63 for the lead in team play with Sam Snead of Hot Springs, Va., and George T. McCarthy Jr. of Bridgeport, Conn.

JERUSALEM, March 2 -- British troops went into action with the two-pounder cannon of their heavy armored cars today to blast out Arab positions that had disrupted traffic during the past two days on the main Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway.

Sloshing through the slush-laden streets of the garment sector between 7:30 and 9 A.M. yesterday, ignoring the sleet that pelted him, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander found a "slight improvement" in cooperation by manufacturing houses with the plan to relieve traffic snarls there by staggering truck pick-ups and deliveries.

The Sofdor Realty Corporation sold to Elizabeth Schmidt the five story apartment house at 712 West 175th Street, containing 127 rooms laid out in suites of two to five rooms. The building occupies a plot 100 by 90 feet.

h)0*0*0*iThe net interest cost of 1.79 per cent for which New York State yesterday financed its veterans' bonus is the culmination of a program of businesslike handling of the bonus that has prevailed since the beginning. A combination of good fortune and good timing, accompanied by shrewd management by the state's fiscal officials, makes it a very successful deal from the state's point of view.

A time honored Army trick known as "bucking the line" -- or getting some place out of turn -has turned up to worry the Veterans Administration in its handling of admissions to the ten VA hospitals in the state.

James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, contended yesterday that the United States should make a clear-cut commitment, under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, to use its physical power against any overt Communist drive toward either the Atlantic or the Mediterranean.

The stock market gained more ground yesterday with a shift of emphasis to the oils and some of the industrials although the aviation group still remained in favor. Best progress was made by the petroleums and a few thin-market issues, and the combined averages rose 0.44 point.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- wheat advanced today 3 1/4 cents a bushel and corn 2 1/2 cents in the early trading on the Board of Trade, going to a new high since midFebruary, but heavy profit-taking developed on the advance. May wheat then broke 5 1/4 cents and corn 5 cents from the top with a rally from the low later on short covering.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -President Truman asked Congress today for legislation enabling him to reappoint Dean Acheson as civilian member and chairman of the American Section of the Joint United States-Canadian Defense Board.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Demands for an affirmative policy to halt further Soviet aggression in Europe punctuated Senate debate of the European Recovery Program today as managers of the bill conceded that it was no guarantee against war between the United States and Russia.
OTTAWA, March 2 -- From their haven in a Quebec convent, the Polish treasures, brought to Canada shortly after the outbreak of war in 1939, have again been secretly "smuggled" to a new hiding place.

TORONTO, March 2 (Canadian Press) C. P. McTague, chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, announced today that registrations of three Toronto brokerage houses have been canceled. They are: Canadian Securities (W. F. Bradley), Walter Richardson and Associates, Ltd., and G. F. Cockburn Co.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- About one-quarter of the goods authorized under the $522,000,000-interim aid program has, to date, been shipped to Austria, France and Italy, according to a progress report today by the State Department.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The Congressional aviation policy board's recommendations for expenditures intended to assure world air supremacy for the United States until 1953 found a welcome reception today in Air Force and Navy circles, although some of the board's criticisms drew unofficial expressions of resentment.
Henry A. Wallace was assailed yesterday by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, as an appeaser who would lead the nation to "another Munich and its inevitable outcome -- war."

Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, yesterday made a satisfactory debut in the tournament for the world chess title by drawing his game in the first round, according to a report from The Hague in the Netherlands. Forty-one moves were recorded.

The municipal buses in Brooklyn, privately operated buses in Manhattan and Queens, garbage trucks in the four boroughs, a Long Island fuel oil truck and a Bronx milk wagon are among the safest vehicles in the metropolitan area, the Greater New York Safety Council found yesterday.

Acting on the recommendation of United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey, Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard dismissed yesterday charges against two of the eight men arrested in connection with the attempt early in January to ship 60,000 pounds of TNT to Palestine.

OSLO, Norway, March 2 -- Sweden's dynamic ski racers, Ake Nilson and Olle Dalman, thrilled a wildly cheering throng of 3,000, including Crown Prince Olav, by sweeping today's exacting holmenkollen slalom at Redklevia. Adding their slalom performances to Sunday's downhill, the Swedes also gained combined Alpine honors.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, had an operating surplus of $330,263 for the three months ended Feb. 29, an average membership of about 950,000 in good standing throughout the quarter and liquid assets on March 1 of about $1,250,000, Emil Mazey, secretary-treasurer, reported today to the quarterly meeting of the union's international executive board.

New York public school principals may continue to accept or reject gift books for school libraries, but in a case of doubt as to the suitability of a book must refer the matter to the associate superintendent in charge, according to a ruling issued yesterday by the Board of Superintendents.

Among evening radio programs, Jack Benny's continues to draw the largest audience in metropolitan New York, according to the February popularity measurements by The Pulse, Inc. The comedian also led in January.

William H. Baldwin, chairman of the board of directors of Sydenham Hospital, asked yesterday that the institution be kept open as a non-city institution to show its worth as an interracial experiment.

No surgeon in this city had more friends and followers than Dr. J. Bentley Squier. This was not due alone to his eminence in his profession or his ability as a practitioner. His personal qualities established a warm bond of personal friendship with those who sought his wide knowledge and greath)0*0*0*iskill.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan said "No" again today but found that, despite that, his name will be entered in the Nebraska Republican Presidential primary.

By a margin of slightly less than two to one, the state executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted yesterday to set up a state-wide Political Action Committee to oppose the third party headed by Henry A. Wallace, support the Marshall Plan and seek the nomination and election of pro-labor candidates for Congressional and Legislative office.

ROME, March 2 -- The atmosphere of Italy is like that of a warm day with an undercurrent of icy wind. Here is a country putting a lost war and two decades of fascism behind it with something of a flourish. It is making more progress in reconstruction than any other heavily damaged country.

PRAGUE, March 2 -- Rudolf Slansky, secretary general of the Czechoslovak Communist party and chief of the Central Action Committee, announced today that the elaborate network of action committees, which are tantamount to soviets, would be "permanent organs of the people."

The hockey game at Madison Square Garden last night was a throwback to the old days. Only one goal was scored, the Rangers winning by 1 to 0, and there were enough fights, bumps, kicks and various other forms of belligerence to satisfy the most blood-thirsty pioneer mind in the crowd of 14,916 on hand.

Nikita Magaloff, former accompanist and son-in-law of Joseph Szigeti, gave his second Carnegie Hall recital last night. Brahms' early Sonata in F minor, Mozart's C major Sonata, K. 279, and de Falla's Fantasia Baetica were the chief works of his program.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -Administration officials differed today on when the Government should give up its control over the synthetic rubber plants it built during the war.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Krug wants the Government to keep the trade-mark on "Government House Rum."
A special securities bureau was set up yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to handle the increased volume of complaints by investors against stock swindlers.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Dewey's reappointment of Edward P. F. Eagan to the State Athletic Commission was confirmed in the Senate today after a debate which included Republican charges that the Democratic organization in New York City is controlled by the same gangsters who allegedly dominate professional boxing.

If all goes well the date of May 9, 1948, can be placed by the Koreans alongside that of March 1, 1919. Both will be days for them long to remember. It was no accident that the date for the forthcoming election of an independent Korean government was announced on the twenty-ninth anniversary of the Korean Declaration of Independence.

The appeal of the cheese tray, like that of fine art, seems to be universal. Prince and peasant both like it. Whereas an apple dumpling might be too gauche or meringue glacee too sophisticated, cheese is never too homely or too elegant.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active all day yesterday, fluctuating over a fairly wide range, and closing 3 points higher to 10 points lower.

WINNIPEG, Canada, March 2 -The recent realty boom has come to an end, and the continuance of residential rent controls probably will result in a wave of foreclosures in the United States before the end of 1948, in the opinion of Robert Armstrong, of Armstrong Associates, of New York.

PRAGUE, March 2 -- The reiteration that Americans are engaged in spying on Czechoslovakia and in conspiracies against her and her allies is running into conflict with the strong effort being made here to turn the eleventh Sokol games into a major propaganda effort of the Communist-dominated regime.

HAVANA, March 2 -- No formal reservations will be attached to the world trade charter or the final act of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment. This was decided today by the General Committee of conference, at the suggestion of Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 2 -- In a stormy all-day session today, the Bizonal Economic Council elected Dr. Hermann Puender, former Secretary of State in the Weimar Republic, as chief executive of the bizonal administration, although a majority of the members expressed disapproval of him.
LONDON, March 2 -- The British consider the Mediterranean the key in the military-political strategy that must be adopted in the face of the Soviet Union's policy in Europe.
0*0*0*iOPARIS, March 2 -- For the first time since the Franco-Spanish border was reopened, a freight train crossed over into France at Hendaye today with a load of wine destined for Switzerland.

Mozart's chamber music, including the serenades and divertimenti, will be presented by the New Friends of Music in a cycle that will take two years to perform, Ira A. Hirschmann, president, announced yesterday, in revealing the organization's plans for the next two seasons.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Leading steel manufacturers were taken to task today by both Republican and Democratic legislators for failure to exercise economic leadership and for raising prices of certain products despite peak profits.

The cold wet weather yesterday made it a poor day for workers in Red Cross booths throughout the city but there was evidence that the public is responding generously, as it has in the past, to the annual drive for funds for next year's Red Cross work.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 2 -- Providing that the negotiations toward a Western European pact, which will begin in Brussels on Thursday, work out as well as expected, the Governments of the Netherlands and Belgium will press for the immediate signing of such an agreement within the next ten days if possible.

With the fabric situation continuing strong from both the price and supply standpoints, allotments on men's clothing will continue when fall lines are opened next month, it was reported here yesterday.

BOSTON, March 2 -- John W. Guider of Littleton, N.H., that state's chairman of the Stassen for-President Committee, said tonight that former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota had notified him that he was boarding a plane in Minneapolis at 10 P.M. and was due in New York at 4:30h)0*0*0*iA.M. Snow-bound airports in theEast prevented an earlier scheduled start.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Dewey hinted at a press conference today that he may take the stump to bolster his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination after the business of the present legislative session is concluded around April 15.
The New York Football Giants will usher in their 1948 National Football League home campaign Oct. 17 against the champion Chicago Cardinals, President John V. Mara announced yesterday.

A strike threat against the major motion picture theatre circuits developed yesterday when 750 members of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, AFL, rejected ratification of a contract negotiated two months ago with the six leading theatre chains.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, predicted today that the House-approved Tax Reduction Bill would be trimmed to $4,500,000,000 or $5,000,000,000.

Eleven per cent of Columbia University students who answered a survey conducted by the Columbia University Student Council said they would have to leave the university if plans to increase tuition fees one-third go into effect in September, Albert E. Marten,h)0*0*0*istudent council chairman, announced yesterday.

PEIPING, March 2 -- Under Peiping's outward calm plans are now being made in at least some Chinese homes for the day when the Communists may enter the city. Conversations with middleclass Chinese during the last three days showed that within a single circle of friends one property owner, one doctor, two professors and one research worker already have taken the initial steps toward moving south.
LONDON, March 2 -- Security against aggression will be the key subject of discussion when experts of five countries meet in Brussels Thursday, it was learned here today.

New York office furniture distributors are "holding the line" on prices and are continuing a steady price level, it was learned here yesterday during a canvass of leading dealers. Moe Turman, general manager of Metwood Office. Equipment Corporation, Robert Fowler of Macey-Fowler, Inc., and Seymour L. Nathan of Charles S. Nathan, Inc., revealed these facts in interviews on current priceh)0*0*0*itrends.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Controversy over ownership of film rights to Gerald Butler's 1946 English novel, "Kiss the Blood Off My Hands," which is scheduled to go before the cameras at UniversalInternational March 15, has been taken to court by Charles K. Feldman Group Productions in a $1,000,000 damage suit against U-I and Burt Lancaster, Joan Fontaine, and others participating in the projected picture.

A banking group headed by Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., announced yesterday the offering of a new issue of $5,850,000 of 3 1/4 per cent serial electric revenue bonds of Clark County, Wash. The issue, maturing from Dec. 1, 1949 to 1977, was priced to yield 1.75 per cent to 3.25 per cent.
The affairs of TACA, once prosperous Central American airline, were complicated further yesterday by an action brought before the Civil Aeronautics Board by Pan American Airways.
CHELTENHAM, England, March 2 (AP) -- Nine Grand National steeplechase entries were beaten by a novice today at the opening of the National Hunt Festival, Great Britain's biggest jumping race meeting.
Despite yesterday's snow and rain, a touch of spring bloomed at the Pennsylvania Hotel as the Metropolitan Retail Florists Association presented its Easter floral fashion preview.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 2 -- President-elect Otilio Ulate was arrested tonight with six other party chiefs. He was charged with complicity in the murder of two policemen, who were killed in the siege of Dr. Carlos Valverdes' house last night.

SECRETARY MORGENTHAU returned to Washington from Quebec, while the President went first to Hyde Park, where Prime Minister Churchill paid him a visit. Morgenthau was wildly enthusiastic over what he had accomplished and came rushing to Secretary of War Stimson and me and others with the latest copies of his plans [for converting Germany into a primarily pastoral country].

Demands for third-round wage increases by union leaders are untimely, according to the National City Bank's monthly comment, for publication today. Higher wages will raise prices of goods, because many manufacturers cannot absorb increased costs, the institution declared.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall, in a closed-session discussion of new developments in the world picture, today urged members of the Senate Armed Services Committee to take action on the universal military training program.

BOSTON, March 2 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called on the American people tonight to halt the "rapacious and extortionate profiteering" of the steel industry by reimposition of price controlh) 0*0*0*ion that and other "segments of big business."

Within five years, Japanese imports must be at least $275,000,000 more than in 1937 in order to permit the Japanese people to reach even the 1930-34 standard of living, according to the summary of the 175-page report to theh)0*0*0*iDepartment of the Army by Overseas Consultants, Inc., it was learned here yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Several bills were introduced today which have Administration backing, including one which would carry out Governor Dewey's plans for interstate cooperation in removing oppressive inspections in the milk industry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- Journalistic experts and representatives from at least sixty governments, including several nations outside the United Nations, will tackle a controversial agenda at the forthcoming world-wide Conference on Freedom of the Press, officials here agreed today.

ATHENS, March 2 -- Greek Army troops, continuing their offensive in the Philiates and Pogoniani areas along the Albanian frontier, have wrested more heights from the rebels, according to information available here tonight.

The doughty Italian combination of Alvaro Giorgetti and Angelo Debacco, though pressed constantly in a number of jamming sessions, managed to hold onto their lead at the end of the fiftieth hour in the Sixty-seventh International Six-day Bicycle race at the Twentysecond Engineers Armory last night.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The anti-lynching bill was approved today, 18 to 8, by the House Judiciary Committee over fresh cries of protest from Southern Democrats. As this second item on President Truman's "civil rights" agenda was thus being moved along toward foreordained passage by the House itself, the most politically threatening speech against Mr. Truman yet delivered by a Southerner was being uttered on the floor.

For a progressive man, J. B. Priestley can write astonishingly old-fashioned dramas. Like most of his plays, "The Linden Tree," put on at the Music Box last evening, proceeds from admirable premises. Mr. Priestley is declaring himself in favor of the people who accept responsibility and keep faith with a troubled world.

Felix Elderby, New Yorker, dyed in the wool, said that in the blue-sky interval before the last snowfall he had been visiting over on Staten Island -- the only part of our city you normally get to by shipping down the bay as if you were starting an ocean voyage.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Freedom of radio station licensees to go on the air and speak for themselves, on matters of public interest scheduled for discussion over their facilities, was urged at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission by Nathan Straus of New York, president of Station WMCA, and Dr. Robert E. Cushman of Cornell University, licensee in Ithaca, N.Y., of Station WHCU.
LONDON, March 2 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, accompanied by Princess Margaret, opened today the twenty-fifth Daily Mail Ideal Home Exhibition at the Olympia London's Madison Square Garden.

The New York Zoological Society'sh)0*0*0*ianimal collector, Charles Cordier, traveled 3,500 air miles, then safaried three months in the Belgian Congo looking for a rare Congo peacock. Finally he heard the peacock's call on Feb. 3. He could do nothing about it, however, because he lay in a swamp with a broken leg, it was learned yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,404, against 551 last week and 1,144 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 504 arrivals yesterday compared with 76 last Tuesday.
LONDON, March 2 -- International politics and the continued drain on Britain's gold reserves had a disturbing effect on the stock market here today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 3 -The Soviet Union today demanded the removal of Japan's newly designated Prime Minister, Dr. Hitoshi Ashida.

Martin's, of Brooklyn, presented yesterday a family album for spring and summer. Out of it stepped the matron, the young sophisticate, the junior, the teenager, the younger children, father and the boys. All were very ship shape in their new look.

The effort to restrict publication of Government information, particularly of military information, which has assumed many forms in the last year, will open a new chapter today in Washington when Secretary of Defense Forrestal meets with representatives of newspapers, magazines and other information media.

The statement of Benjamin F. Fairless, president of United States Steel Corporation, yesterday, before the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report, concerning the recent rise in prices on semi-finished steel, was not calculated greatly to change the average man's ideas concerning that episode.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Accusing the State Department of "blindness and apathy" toward China, which he called "the key to the entire Far East" in resistance to Communist world conquest, William C. Bullitt, former American Ambassador to Russia, urged Congress today to authorize at once $100,000,000 of outright military aid to China.
The Patent Office is getting pushed around. I have just surveyed the sitution, on foot, so I am in a position to interpret the situation in terms of New York geography.

With Suzanne Bloch as the guiding spirit, a group of musicians brought back to life some of the music of the sixteenth, seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries at Times Hall last night. The evening was refreshing in its unpretentiousness.

The next real depression is not likely to cause "another banking Dunkirk," according to Arthur A. Ballantine, New York attorney, writing in the current issue of the Harvard Business Review. Mr. Ballantine, of Root, Ballantine, Harlan, Bushby Palmer, points out that stability of the assets of the banks is "far more assured" than it was in 1933, and in the aggregate, not less than one-half of such assets consist of Government securities.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, March 2 Frenchy Bordagaray, an amiable whack who is a distinct throwback to the glorious days of theh)0*0*0*iDaffiness Boys, today joined the Dodgers. Whether he'll contribute greatly to his destined role as a right-handed pinch-hitter remains to be seen, but it can be guaranteed that he'll contribute heavily to the comedy department of our beloved Bums.

ALBANY, March 2--Mayor William O'Dwyer's request for additional real estate taxing power for New York City today received the approval of a special committee headed by Frank C. Moore, State Controller.

Joe Nowicki, former Fordham ace, was disclosed as an addedh)0*0*0*istarter in the 1,000-yard run, one of the featured events on the program of the twentyninth annual New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

The Palestine situation has fallen to an ominously critical stage. Arabs, supplied with British light arms, defy the U.N. On the forthcoming decisions of the U.N. depends the course of civilization for several generations.

LONDON, March 2 -- Some 1,500 striking coke oven employes in the British steel center of Sheffield, whose idleness is imperiling the production of vital export products in steel, silver and cutlery factories received a back-to-work ultimatum today from the National Coal Board, which manages Britain's nationalized coal industry.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 -India has joined other members of the British Commonwealth in limiting dollar purchases, it became known today with the release of correspondence between the Indian Government and the Interim Sterling Committee from the United Kingdom.

GENEVA, March 2 -- A revised international convention for the protection of migratory labor and emigrant workers was approved today by the permanent migration committee of the International Labor Office. Most of the changes from the 1939 convention are designed to meet conditions created since the war on many countries conducting large-scale immigration programs to meet critical manpower shortages.

Henry A. Wallace came vigorously yesterday to the defense of Dr. Edward U. Condon, head of the National Bureau of Standards, whom a House subcommittee on Un-American Activities has linked to Soviet atom spies.

Six married women who collected unemployment insurance in the Bronx while they held jobs in Manhattan were sentenced yesterday by Justice Thomas F. Doyle in Bronx Special Sessions to jail terms. The women had pleaded guilty.

Amid charges and countercharges, Ruth Weston left the cast of "Oklahoma!" Sunday night, it became known yesterday. She had played the role of Aunt Eller in the local company for three years and three months. Miss Weston said last night that the Theatre Guild, sponsor of the long-run musical, had breached agreements with her affecting salary increases, vacations and billing.

Milchman Sons, builders, have started a new development of eighteen dwellings in the Bayside area of Queens, Lane Realty, sales representative for the houses, reported yesterday. The buildings, two stories in height and each with three bedrooms and a garage, will occupy thirty-eight lots on 203d Street, north of Horace Harding Boulevard.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At Loew's State the attraction is "The Sign of the Ram," a Columbia presentation marking the return to the screen of Susan Peters, who was injured in 1945. Heading the cast of the drama with Miss Peters are Alexander Knox, Phyllis Thaxter.

At 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon quiet settled on the fourth floor showrooms at Bergdorf Goodman's. The parade that sets forth this Fifth Avenue specialty store's credo of the season's trends was about to begin.

LANSING, Mich., March 2 -Clarence S. Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, emerged today from a conference with Gov. Kim Sigler of Michigan to state that he had received what he described as evidence of gambling in hockey so complete as to warrant "expulsions without a doubt."

Reduced prices of leather resulting from the recent drop in commodity markets brought a record turnout yesterday for the semi-annual leather show staged by the Tanners' Council of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

At 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon quiet settled on the fourth floor showrooms at Bergdorf Goodman's. The parade that sets forth this Fifth Avenue specialty store's credo of the season's trends was about to begin.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) - Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today wheat prices "very likely" will drop below the Government support level by July 1 unless Congress repeals a law restricting exports.

Reduced prices of leather resulting from the recent drop in commodity markets brought a record turnout yesterday for the semi-annual leather show staged by the Tanners' Council of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Two schools -- one in the Bronx and one in Harlem -- were emptied of their 2,500 pupils and teachers almost simultaneously yesterday afternoon, when each had a small fire. Neither blaze did much damage, but the one in Public School 44, at 176th Street and Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, sent enough smoke through the building to give the 1,600 boys and girls there the rest of the afternoon off.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3 -- Defective commitments were used in the jailing of the two Newburgh newspaper men found guilty Friday of contempt of court, Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne ruled here tonight. He sustained writs of habeas corpus, canceling further imprisonment. He ruled only on technical aspects of the legal procedure.

BERLIN, N.H., March 3 -- Revocation by Big Steel of its recent price increase, and a White House conference at which a moratorium would be arranged on steel price increases and steel wage increases, was urged here tonight by Harold E. Stassen.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, March 3 -- Price reductions of $10 and $20 on two models will mark the 1948 Westinghouse Electric Corporation refrigerator line, G. H. Meilinger, household refrigerator department manager, announced here today. The seven-cubic-foot unit will carry a suggested list price of $229.95, against $239.95 for the comparable 1947 unit and the nine-cubic-foot unit will have a suggested list price of $279.95, a reduction of $20.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 2 (Delayed) -- The Soviet military administration today made an open offer to buyers from all over the world to pay the Russian reparation demands by purchases from current German production. The products offered ranged from Melssen china to fertilizer.
GENEVA, March 3 -- The outline of the form of the International Maritime Organization now is fully visible.

KEY WEST Fla., March 3 -- President Truman spent today quietly, but he was preparing for a Cabinet meeting at 4 P. M. Friday in the White House. He and his official party will leave here by plane Friday morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 3 -- National defense as the principal consideration in road construction throughout the country and express routes as a solution for New York's traffic congestion were emphasized today at the annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States here.

AN entirely new and startling proposal was unexpectedly injected into the discussions by the Soviet representative, Ambassador Gromyko, as the second week of the Dumbarton Oaks conference opened on Aug. 28, 1944.

Of the 550 pending applications by foreigners for purchase of war-built American-flag merchant vessels, 480 were turned down by the Maritime Commission before such sales were barred by legislation extending certain of the commission's powers, it was announced yesterday. Since the first of the year only seventy miscellaneous ships, all unwanted by American operators and all of laid-up status, were sold by the commission.
Suits and dresses for day through evening were presented by Harry Collins in his salon at 647 Fifth Avenue yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The text of the statement by Secretary of State Marshall to the House Foreign Affairs Committee today on Greek and Turkish aid, as reported by The Associated Press, follows :

Some sincere opponents of Universal Military Training read into the failure of the House membership to push for discharge by petition of the UMT bill from the House Rules Committee evidence that the bill would not secure a majority if a vote were taken. They present this as an excuse for the action of Representative Allen of Illinois, chairman of the Rules Committee, in refusing to clear it for the House calendar.

James G. McDonald, in his letter published on Feb. 13, has sought to place the unique responsibility for the present situation in Palestine on the Arabs. "The Arabs alone are the aggressors," he declares. Mr. McDonald, like many of his Zionist friends, is trying to convince the American public that the history of Palestine began on Nov. 29 and that what happened before has no relevance.
Charles F. McNamee and Carl J. Heiles have been promoted from assistant vice presidents to vice presidents of Manufacturers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, president.

Twenty-one youngsters, eight boys and thirteen girls, proudly received their diplomas yesterday as the first graduates of six-week child care courses given at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, 331 East Seventieth Street. The boys specialized in home nursing, the girls in the care of babies.

A landlord's failure to obtain an eviction certificate from the City Rent Commision provided the legal basis yesterday for the granting of an indefinite respite to a Bronx family of thirteen persons. Justice Christopher C. McGrath in Municipal Court, the Bronx, said he would not hang a "sword of Damocles" over the thirteen by taking final action on the landlord's suit to evict them from the seven-room house at 290 East 164th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson announced today both April grain export allocations and the manner in which the Government, after being out of the grain market since wheat prices tumbled a month ago, will "feel its way" back to buying.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- The Giant infield practice at Municipal Stadium today stirred up a holdout situation which is beginning to irk Manager Mel Ott. It involves Buddy Kerr, the gangling shortstop, and Ken Trinkle, rescue man of the pitching squad.

NANKING, March 3 -- A private mission of loyal Chinese from Manchuria petitioned President Chiang Kai-shek today to dispatch more reinforcements to the northeastern provinces, to send food supplies to Mukden by air and to call a halt to the inflationary issue of Northeastern Currency notes.

NANKING, March 3 -- Dr. Hollington K. Tong, an official Government spokesman, declared today that China was determined to convoke the National Assembly as scheduled on March 29, despite a series of disputes among the delegates for a number of the seats.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., March 3 (AP) -- Bob Fitch will be missing when American athletes compete in the Olympic Games at London this summer. The recognized world discus throw record-holder is through with amateur athletics.

The current number of Air Affairs, a Washington quarterly devoted as much to philosophical as to practical implications, offers a well-rounded survey of education in the Air Age. Under the guest editorship of Dr. Paul R. Hanna of Stanford University, it contains some solace and some cause for concern.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted a union of the American Federation of Labor which had openly expressed the hope that it would be prosecuted on a charge of violating the Taft-Hartley Act.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 3 -- Leading elected officials, committee chairmen and party chiefs of the bizonal economic government -- about thirty persons in all -- were called to bipartite headquarters today where they received an admonition on the necessity of getting down to work and producing results.
I read the hospital series by Lucy Freeman, and your editorial "Plight of the Hospitals," with keen interest.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Congress was warned today by three men in the highest echelons of foreign policy and defense that military problems at key danger points abroad must be solved before economic recovery programs could hope to be successful.

The other night, when the frost put brittle edges on the stars and sharpened neon lights a quarter-mile below the Empire State Building Tower, on which we stood, we thought, somehow, of an editor of another day who had dreamed a dream of New York City -- a most fantastic dream.

Warren Wright, former Illinois State Treasurer and leader in that state of a movement to draft Gen. Douglas MacArthur for President, reported here yesterday that he would depart today for Washington to open national headquarters for the Douglas MacArthur Campaign Committee. He expects to open headquarters here later.

Tanners exhibiting current lines at the semi-annual leather show in the Waldrof-Astoria Hotel reported an unprecedented amount of sampling which indicates, they said, heavy demand by manufacturers of leather products.
