Reporting on operations last year of the General Tire and Rubber Company, William O'Neil, president, informs stockholders in the thirty-second annual statement to be issued today that net sales reached a new high record of $126,136,242.

PATERSON, N.J., March 3 -- Cut flowers can be preserved for years with their original form and colors through a process developed over a period of twenty years by two Paterson physicians and their inventor uncle, a retired New York school teacher.

Departing from its established policy favoring payment of full municipal taxes for all enterprises erected by a public authority "other than recognized public utilities," the Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday its support of the plan for a new Madison Square Garden in the Columbus Circle area.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The files of a Department of Commerce review board which recently cleared Dr. Edward U. Condon of any disloyalty to the United States were subpoenaed today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The stock market lapsed again yesterday into aimlessness despite another flurry in the oils and a few of the aircrafts and airlines. Only a few issues made more than fractional gains, and the combined averages lost 0.03 point, although the list still leaned to the higher side in terms of the number of stocks to advance.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Great Britain has exhausted the $3,750,000,000 loan made by the United States in July of 1946, the Treasury disclosed today, issuing a statement showing that on Monday the British Government had taken out $100,000,000, all that was left of the loan.

PETER TAYLOR is a 31-year-old Tennessean whose perceptive, well-wrought stories have appeared in some of our better-known literary quarterlies. At least three of the stories in "A Long Fourth"* -- "The Fancy Woman," "Rain in the Heart," "The Scoutmaster" (which appeared in The Southern Review, The Sewanee Review and Partisan Review, respectively, -- have been chosen for inclusion in one or another of the annual "Best American Short Story" volumes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio are prepared to "go all out," it became known today, in an effort to win the Nebraska Republican Presidential primary and thus discredit public opinion polls which show their candidate running poorly.
PARIS, March 3 -- Indications that the Communists plan to seek a European labor showdown in Italy next month on the Marshall Plan became apparent here today.
Continued debate on Palestine question and heard representatives of Canada, China and Egypt. Referred Burma's membership application to Membership Committee.

Moviegoers in Loew's and RKO theatres in various parts of the city saw spots before their eyes yesterday as films flickered on and off the screen. The sporadic interruptiond were an outgrowth of a dispute between the theatre chains Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, AFL.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Notre Dame closed its successful Eastern trip by defeating the Pennsylvania quintet at the Palestra tonight, 60 -- 56, before 5,100 spectators, the biggest turnout of the season.
Random notes.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The post-war home building program is being held down by 200,000 dwelling units annually because construction workers' unions have interferred with completion of a new large plant of the United States Gypsum Company, W. I. Keady, the company's president today told stockholders at their annual meeting.

Muriel King makes evening gowns with a lavish hand. She swathes the figure in handsome fabrics, draping them, puffing them and permitting them to sweep into graceful scarf trains. Her new spring and summer custom-made collection was presented yesterday at Stein Blaine's.
Three Democratic and six Republican contests for Assembly district leaderships were indicated yesterday by petitions filed with the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representatives of the press, radio and newsreels appointed a committee today to consider the request of Secretary of Defense James Forrestal for a voluntary system for safeguarding information vital to the national security. The committee was instructed to report within one month.

SHANGHAI, March 3 -- The money paid on electricity bills here will go to finance a brigade of garrison troops for Shanghai if a proposal placed by Mayor K.C. Wu before the City Council today, is approved.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 3 -- Tropical Park, as pleasant a small-scale racing establishment as any horse-player could ask, drew a piping hot afternoon, a welcome wind and 11,554 customers for the opening of its 40-day meeting today. It also had a hotly contested duel in the main event -- the $5,000 added Damon Runyon Handicap.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed slightly lower yesterday, 8 to 23 points on active months.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 25:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 3 -- Pleading for a supreme effort at conciliation, Canada today called on the five permanent members of the Security Council to make a last-minute attempt to find an agreed solution of the Palestine problem.

A protest against the banning of "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Focus" from the library of DeWitt Clinton High School, the Bronx, was registered yesterday by the executive board of the school's Parent-Teacher Association.

TORONTO, March 3 (AP) -- Montreal's lowly Canadiens turned back Toronto, 3 to 2, in a rough contest tonight. The loss enabled Detroit to move into a tie with the Maple Leafs for the National Hockey League lead.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Sixty-three changes in tax laws mainly affecting business and estates were proposed by the Treasury today for Congressional action this session as the first step toward correcting inequities and clarifying present statutes.

Renominated Reginald B. Taylor of Buffalo for six-year term on Board of Parole. Signed bills permitting members of armed forces to take fish and game without a license and exempting them from tax on race track admissions. Received delegation of Disabled American Veterans.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 3 (AP) -- The Farmers Elevator Association of Minnesota adopted today a resolution expressing "determined opposition" to Government interference with hedging facilities offered by the organized grain futures market.
Willard Larsh has been appointed operations manager of Gertz, Jamaica. He formerly was with Macy's, New York.
HANOVER, N.H., March 3 -- Harvard's victory-starved basketball team held off Dartmouth for thirty minutes tonight, but faded soon thereafter to succumb to the Indians, 56 -- 48.
ATHENS, March 3 -- Greek rebels have made an attempt to revive the Elan or naval equivalent of the Elas, according to official sources.

The drinking of milk, which had increased steadily in this city since 1934, fell off last year, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. Milk receipts in the metropolitan area last year were 4,466,280 quarts below those in 1946.

HAVANA, March 3 -- The heads of the delegations of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment tonight approved a general settlement of economic development issues, subject to reservations made by five of the fifty-eight participating Governments. Britain, Argentina and Poland were among the five who took reservations. The group also fixed March 19 as the target date for the end of the conference.

It was revealed yesterday that on Monday of this week the British Government drew down the last $100 million of the $3,750 million loan made by the United States in 1946. Thus, the proceeds have been exhausted in less than twenty months from the time the loan terms became operative, instead of the three and one-half years on which the original calculations were based.

LONDON, March 3 -- A conflict between the Soviet idea of a settlement of the German assets based on percentages and a Western proposal for agreement on specific properties blocked progress in the Austrian treaty negotiations today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -Eighteen radio stations today joined the major networks in their attack on the rule which bars them from editorializing.
Many new dealers with out-of-town stocks of antiques are scheduled to take part in the Fourth Annual National Antiques Show, which will open Monday at 1 P.M. at Madison Square Garden.

The two-day truce under which unionized employes of the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges had agreed to defer strike action expired last night with no break in the deadlock between the union and the Exchanges.

Irving Potash, union leader and high Communist party official, was freed from Ellis Island yesterday. Released in $5,000 bail ordered by Federal Judge William Bondy, Potash ended his participation in a five-man hunger strike in an Immigration Department cell where four other alleged alien Communists are lodged awaiting deportation proceedings.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Federal district court jury found Harold R. Christoffel guilty tonight on six charges of perjury growing out of his denial that he is a Communist.

WRIGHTSVILLE, Ga., March 3 (UP) -- Negroes stayed away from the polls in today's Democratic primary after the Ku Klux Klan chose this rural mid-Georgia county for a public warning that racial equality programs would lead to blood-letting in the South.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 3 -- Pierre-Andre Ordonneau, the French representative, today was elected chairman of the United Nations Little Assembly's new subcommittee to study an international conciliation system. Dr. Philip C. Jessup, the United States representative, was elected rapporteur.

Touring the garment sector between 7 and 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning with union and management representatives on the area's joint traffic committee, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander was "much encouraged" by increasing acceptance of the plan for staggering truck pick-ups and deliveries.

STUTTGART, Germany, March 3 -- Germany has "touched the bottom" economically and henceforth will register a slow but gradual improvement in industry and in living conditions, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said at a press conference here today.

The unusual argument that construction of a large motion-picture theatre would help to keep rents in its neighboring residential buildings down was used successfully by the New York Life Insurance Company in connection with its plans for carrying forward its Fresh Meadow housing project in Flushing Queens, it became known last night.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Adjournment of the Legislature on March 12 was indicated today. The Assembly adopted a resolution fixing that date. It was put forth by the majority leader, Lee B. Mailler, and opposed by all Democratic members.
Pinball machines, barred from the city during the administration of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, have been reappearing quietly in bars, candy stores, restaurants and other small business shops.

American-flag steamship companies that are operating Government-owned vessels on bareboat charters and also have foreign-flag ships under time or bareboat charter have been notified by the Maritime Commission that their chartering contracts were canceled as of March 1, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations is preparing to "crack down" on the New York City Industrial Council and its political action committee in a double barelled offensive, it was learned today.

Fourteen representatives of the Amateur Hockey Association team that participated in the winter Olympics at St. Moritz, Switzerland, after a stormy controversy over their right to compete, arrived home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A proposal of four Senate Republicans, that the United States take the lead in creating a new international agency to prevent further Communist aggression, was flatly rejected today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg during debate on the European Recovery Program.

What is it that it is about subways? Here we have M. Langevin, director of the Paris subway, telling us it costs his line eight francs to transport a passenger. The fare charged is five francs per passenger. A fare increase, Monsieur? How can Place de la Concorde succeed where Times Square has failed? Logic, yes. Economics, yes. But politics -- ah!
Arthur Schwartz, head of Fredrica Furs, predicted yesterday at his showroom in 345 Seventh Avenue that "little furs" would be popular.

One bowler suffered a matchless "hotfoot" and the feet of several others figured directly last night in seven suspicious fires that occurred within an hour in midtown bowling alleys. Fire Department inspectors said all the blazes apparently had resulted from someone having spread on the floors some flaky or powdery substance, probably containing phosphorus, that ignited when walked upon.

Favorable reports on the time being taken by the Office of International Trade for licensing of exports to Europe not on the "positive" list were made yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Members from the floor reported that licenses were coming through within a week or so. No report was made on positive list exports, which are subject to greater delay.

I am back from three months in Germany, Austria, Czechoslavakia, Italy and Greece, where I went at the suggestion of the United Nations Preparatory Commission of International Relief Organization and the United Nations Committee of International Children's Emergency Fund to see camps where the Displaced Persons and the unaccompanied or lost children are living under the administration of the United Nations and also to learn about the condition of European children generally.
The Roman-Caswell Company was the broker in the sale of the garage at 42-12 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, by Gladys R. Murphy and others to the Island Pontiac Corporation.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 3 -- Forty-four shipments of radioactive isotopes have been sent abroad to individuals and research groups in eight countries since the start of the foreign distribution program, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The ultimate fate of Mayor William O'Dwyer's transit fare bill was put in doubt today by a dispute over a provision giving the city the right to lease store and business space in subway mezzanines.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Grain markets fluctuated in an extremely nervous manner today on the Board of Trade, reflecting professional operations. May wheat was off 2 2/3 cents a bushel and corn, 2 1/3 cents at one time, but the markets turned strong later on reinstating of lines sold out recently, with wheat advancing 4 1/2 cents and corn 5 3/4 cents from the low.
VIENNA, March 3 -- It now seems to be generally recognized by Austrian political leaders that the Czechoslovak coup will almost inevitably result in the postponement of a treaty for Austria.

The United States liner America, center of a heated dispute on her arrival last Thursday involving the vessel's skipper, Commodore Harry Manning, and a demand by crewmen for the dismissal of a chief crew steward, sailed at 4 P. M. yesterday, as scheduled, from her West Twenty-first Street pier.

Restoration of pre-war trade-in allowances for gas ranges are being instituted for the first time since the end of the war by small appliance and gas range dealers, it was learned yesterday. One dealer in Queens will advertise a $50 trade-in allowance in a forthcoming issue of a Long Island newspaper.
The final date for registration of vocal soloists and Catholic school groups participating in this season's twenty-fifth annual auditions of the Music Education League has been extended to March 15.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States District Court urged yesterday that Legal Aid Society help for indigent persons, which has been provided in the Criminal courts of New York County, be extended to the Federal courts and those of other counties.

PARIS, March 3 -- Foreign Minister Bidault today told the Cabinet that the French-British negotiations were "tending toward a union of the Western European countries in the political, economic and colonial fields."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett today officially confirmed reports that United States troops had stopped on the Pilsen-Karlsbad line in Czechoslovakia and had not advanced to Prague in the spring of 1945 solely because the Russians requested it.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- It was with considerable reluctance that this tourist wrenched himself away today from the tropical paradise which is the Brooklyn Dodger training base. The big Clipper plane dropped Ciudad Trujillo behind and headed for Florida by way of Port au Prince in Haiti and Kingston in Jamaica. The more prosaic part of the southern jaunt now lies immediately ahead.

Fall Lines to Open May 24 Members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America will introduce fall lines beginning May 24, it was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary. Fall openings last year began May 19. The market period, it was indicated, will be about two weeks. Lines presented will be the only ones shown during the entire season, according to Mr. Gendler.

Gravely concerned over the economic condition of their own country and of the rest of Europe, top financial and political interests in England are convinced that the only salvation for the critical situation lies in the development of Africa's immense resources through the use of British and American private capital, Kenneth de Courcy, prominent British publisher, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Goods and services valued at $19,600,000,000 were exported from the United States in 1947, setting a new peacetime record, the Department of Commerce said today in a report on the balance of payments.

The daily average gross production of crude oil for the week ended on last Saturday set a new record high of 5,387,125 barrels, or 44,800 barrels more than the week before. The amount compared with the 4,771,350 daily average produced in the corresponding week of 1947, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Several political deals affecting the New York City judiciary are under discussion here. Their implementation is subject to passage of bills creating a new surrogate judgeship in Kings County and an additional county judge in the Bronx.

A committee has been formed to formulate plans for participation of the American silk industry in the International Silk Congress in Lyons and Paris, France, the week of June 14, it was announced yesterday by Paolino Gerli, president dent of the International Silk Guild, Inc., who will serve as chairman.

A short time ago I acted as trial counsel in a case where an 8-year-old child died as a result of horrible burns inflicted when the chaps of a cowboy suit which he was wearing became ignited. The case resulted in a verdict of $64,500 in favor of the parents and received considerable public notice.

BAY SHORE, L. I., March 3 -- A delayed pass thrown by Santa Claus last Dec. 23 descended on the Town of Islip today in the form of overdue Christmas cards and overdue bills from the Long Island Lighting Company.

With a crowd of more than 8,000 looking on, the sixty-seventh edition of the six-day bicycle race completed its seventy-fifth hour of competition last night at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory with the same leader it had opening night. This was the Italian combination of Alvaro Giorgetti and Angelo De Bacco, who were still going strong despite strong attempts to overtake them.

Bananas, we should all know by this time, do not belong in the refrigerator. And neither, it has just been announced, does the new Fleischmann yeast. It is a granular product in a small sealed envelope that feels as much at home on a pantry shelf as sugar and flour.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 3 -- Otilio Ulate, Opposition candidate who defeated the Government's nominee in the recently voided election for President, left the penitentiary after noon today in a United States Embassy car. He was accompanied by Ambassador Nathaniel P. Davis and Msgr. Victor Manuel Sanabria, Archbishop of Costa Rica.

Rose Franken's new play, "The Hallams," opens tonight at the Booth Theatre, where two of her previous plays, "Another Language" and "Claudia," enjoyed successful runs in past seasons. The opening night curtain is scheduled to go up at 8; later curtains at 8:40. William Brown Meloney, in private life the author's husband, is sponsor of the production.

Columbia avenged its only defeat of this basketball season, moved a step closer to retention of the Eastern Intercollegiate League title and kept alive its hopes of representing District 2 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament by routing Princeton last night, 76 to 50.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 3 -- A children's center for the treatment of the emotionally maladjusted from pre-school to high school age will be opened at Adelphi College Tuesday, it was announced today by Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president.

An order setting up the new Tenth Judicial District of the State Supreme Court, consisting of the counties of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk, was issued yesterday, effective April 5, by the Appellate Division, sitting in Brooklyn.

Although he was the loser to another youth last fall in a wrestling match in a Bronx park, the bout proved to be a $300 windfall for 15-year-old Richard Dundon of 506 West 173d Street, Manhattan, it was discovered yesterday at the office of the police property clerk.

A single head to coordinate the efforts of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the interchange of Army, Air Force and Navy personnel front West Point and Annapolis were recommended yesterday by James H. Doolittle, former commanding general of the Eighth Air Force, as moves to strengthen our national defense establishment.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 3 -- Training really became official for the Dodgers today, when Brooklyn's best-known tavern keeper donned uniform No. 25 and gave a thousand Dominican fans a treat by impersonating Pee Wee Reese at shortstop.

At the end of the third day of the 1948 Red Cross fund drive in New York $552,847 had been collected in Manhattan and the Bronx, Thomas L.L. Ryan announced yesterday. Mr. Ryan is chairman of the Manhattan committee for the campaign.

With both dividend income from subsidiaries and net income about 50 per cent higher than in 1946, the United Corporation for the first time in seven years realized in 1947 a sufficient amount to cover the annual dividend on the preferred stock and had $362,061 available for the common stock, William M. Hickey, president, reports in the financial statement sent yesterday to shareholders.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett indicated at a news conference today that State Department policy on the project for a Western European union was well advanced.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 (AP) -- My Request romped home an easy winner of the $5,000 Audubon Handicap at the Fair Grounds today. On the basis of that performance, owner Ben F. Whittaker said the winner would be a formidable candidate in the Kentucky Derby.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 3 -- Richard Henry Whitehead, 62-year-old industrial engineer of New Haven, Conn., was named today as bizonal representative in the European Recovery Program. Mr. Whitehead, one of the builders of the Panama Canal and its first superintendent of operations, will leave for Washington within ten days.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 3 -- After nearly eleven years of negotiation arrangements have been completed by the Essex Foundation of Montclair for the purchase of Montclair Academy, 61-year-old preparatory school for boys, it was announced today.
PRAGUE, March 3 -- The Gottwald Government has taken measures to restrict higher education in Czechoslovakia to those who at least profess loyalty to Prague.

Banks that participated this week in the buying of New York State's $300,000,000 issue of veterans' bonus bonds have been called on to weigh at the same time whether to sell back to the State at par any of their holdings of the $100,000,000 issue of 0.80 per cent one-year bonus-financing notes sold on Jan. 6 by Controller Frank C. Moore.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 3 -- It is a rule of politics that the fellow who asks the questions has an advantage over those who are expected to give the answers. And after an unhappy week of trying to supply answers about its Palestine policy, the State Department is now beginning to ask a few questions on its own.

LONDON, March 3 -- The only two occurrences of interest in an extremely quiet stock market here today was the support given by the Government's broker to gilt-edge stocks and the further selling of Uruguayan rail stocks.
CHICAGO, March 3 -- The Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists assailed today the statement of a subcommittee of the House Un-American Activities Committee, criticizing Dr. Edward U. Condon.

Newspaper advertising linage in New York City newspapers totaled 11,302,838 lines during February, compared to 10,270,457 for the like period of 1947, or an increase of 10.05 per cent, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. All categories recorded gains except financial, which showed a .64 per cent loss.

A last-minute "miracle gift" of $25,000 from a New York business man took the emergency campaign for Sydenham Hospital, Harlem's interracially operated organization, "over the top," directors announced yesterday.

Six state conventions to establish third-party support for Henry A. Wallace for President will be held in March and April, C.B. Baldwin, Wallace campaign manager, announced yesterday. The schedule follows:

BOSTON, March 3 (AP) -- Fighting back from a three-goal deficit, the Boston Bruins, cheered by 13,500 Boston Garden fans despite the shadow of a gambling investigation hanging over them, tonight scored three times in the final period to tie the Chicago Blackhawks, 4 -- 4, in a National Hockey League game.
DETROIT, March 3 (AP) -- Wider use of aluminum in motor-car construction was foreseen by speakers before the passenger car and production meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers here today.

Coley Wallace, 20-year-old New York University freshman, the most talked-about amateur boxer since Joe Louis was a simon-pure, won the heavyweight title in the nineteenth annual tournament of champions last night at Madison Square Garden. Many in the crowd of 17,926 remarked about Wallace's resemblance to Louis, but there the comparison ended.

Paul Keres of Estonia, champion of Russia, was the first to gain a victory in the world title chess tourney yesterday, by defeating Dr. Max Euwe, former world champion, in their adjourned game from the first round, according to a report from The Hague in the Netherlands.

Talented 'teen-agers are featured in the presentation of "Accent on Youth," the Detroit production to be moved up to a network position by CBS on Saturday at 4 P.M. The program, created at WJR to combat juvenile delinquency, has been on the air locally for a year, originating in the Detroit Music Hall.

As one who has delved into the intricacies of navigation both as a hobby in yachting, and more seriously as a lieutenant commander in the United States Coast Guard, I read with the greatest interest the news dispatch of the rescue of a seaman who fell overboard from the S.S. Santa Clara. You showed a picture of the young man who was rescued.

The Collegiate Chorale, under Robert Shaw, gave its third annual sponsors' concert last night at Carnegie Hall. Mozart's "Requiem" was the principal work presented. Before the performance of this masterpiece, the chorus was heard in Charles Ives' "Sixty-seventh Psalm" and "Thee Harvest Home Chorales" and Hindemith's "Five Songs on Old Texts."

ALBANY, March 3 -- Hamilton Fish, former isolationist Republican Congressman, is attempting a political comeback, it was disclosed today when he was entered as an insurgent candidate for election as a delegate to the Republican National Convention.

Alarmed by what has happened in Czechoslovakia and what may happen in Finland, representatives of Britain, France and the three Benelux countries will meet today in Brussels to discuss a military alliance. This conference is being held in pursuit of the plan for a West-European Union proposed by Foreign Secretary Bevin six weeks ago and hailed then by the American Government as the most hopeful consummation of the European Recovery Program.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 3 -- Apart from the Communist-dominated unified Socialist group, which endorsed the idea of negotiating a Russo-Finnish pact in a message to President Juho K. Paasikivi, none of the Parliament party committees had announced or even hinted at its decisions tonight.

PRAGUE, March 3 (UP) -- The official radio said tonight that the resignation of Dr. Slavik as Ambassador to Washington was "dishonorable and dishonest," and predicted that other "reactionary" Czechoslovak diplomats would follow his lead.

The Marion Power Shovel Company last year transacted net sales of $19,880,380, the largest volume in its history and $10,464,394 above the $9,415,986 volume for 1946, Elmer G. Diefenbach, board chairman, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

The Save Washington Square Committee will hold a public meeting Tuesday evening in the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, to protest erection of the New York University Law Center on Washington Square, Harold M. Fleming, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday. Community and civic organizations throughout the city have been invited to send representatives.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Dr. Slavik in resigning his post as Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States:

JERUSALEM, March 3 -- Stern group terrorists killed fourteen Arabs and wounded at least twenty-six in Haifa today when they detonated an army truck filled with explosives in front of the Salam building. The building was wrecked.

GOSHEN, N. Y., March 3 (AP) -- A reporter for The New York World Telegram said today he had "respectfully declined" to reveal to an Orange County grand jury sources of information about alleged vice and gambling conditions.

Two admirable artists, Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist, and Alexander Schneider, violinist, gave a recital of sonatas as scored for their combined instruments last night in Town Hall. These sonatas ranged from a sonata by "Bach" -- not J.S. -- to a recent work by a living composer, Walter Piston.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -- A Congressional committee's proposal for an 11 per cent increase of Panama Canal tolls on commercial shipping drew a sharp protest today from West Coast ship operators. They asserted that intercoastal steamship men already were "in a fight for their very existence."

A banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., G. H. Walker Co. and Julien Colins Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of 100,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock of Pet Milk Company. The stock is priced at par.

A scrawled plan for destroying communications in Manhattan by 150 rush-hour bomb explosions, believed to be the work of a crank when it was found by postal employes but sufficiently detailed to cause the police to take no chances, put strategic parts of the borough under heavy guard yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman's plan to name Thomas B. McCabe to the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board was attacked today by Senator Charles W. Tobey, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, who challenged Mr. McCabe's record as head of the Foreign Liquidation Commission.

OTTAWA, March 3 -- The elusive Polish treasures, which have been clandestinely removed three times from their places of custody since the war began, seem likely to become a matter of internal Canadian politics as well as international dispute.
NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru told the Indian Parliament today that there was no foundation for reports that raiders in Kashmir were equipped with Russian arms.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Dr. Juraj Slavik, Ambassador of Czechoslovakia, today resigned his post here and announced that he would fight for a free Czechoslovakia. He informed the State Department that he could not represent the new Communist-controlled Government at Prague.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 -- Application abroad of the experience of the United States in the development of the power industry would be a vital force in aiding foreign nations toward recovery, it was declared here tonight by E.G. Bailey, president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

Long, tightly molded bodices and full skirts of released or deep pleats marked the second group of American adaptations of Jacques Heim Jeunes Filles designs, which were presented with the French originals yesterday at B. Altman Co.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Ezequiel Navarra, three-cushion billiard champion or Argentina, tonight won his eighth match without a defeat when he downed Tiff Dentoi of Kansas City, Mo., 50 to 34, in forty-two innings in the national three-cushion tournament.

Eleven Army enlisted men who in the interests of science are living through their third day under simulated shipwreck conditions in a ward at Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island found mealtime a pretty glum occasion yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- More than 100,000 workers in the meat packing industry throughout the country will go on strike at 12:01 A. M. Tuesday, March 16, Ralph Helstein, president of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, announced here today.

The special benefit showing last night at the Capitol Theatre of "The Naked City," produced by the late Mark Hellinger, drew a capacity audience of more than 5,000 persons, who paid admissions ranging from $3 to $250 per seat.

DETROIT, March 3 -- While Clarence Campbell, who is investigating the current hockey scandal, sat in the stands, the Detroit Red Wings scored a 4-2 victory over the New York Rangers before 13,241 fans tonight.

Irving Potash, following his release on bail, joined 2,000 union shop chairmen of the Furriers Joint Council of New York at a meeting in Manhattan Center where he received a standing ovation. In an unscheduled address he urged the union members to throw their support behind other labor leaders held on Ellis Island as alien Communists.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board rejected today the request of the Jersey Publishing Company of Hudson County, N. J., to classify one group of Jersey Observer editorial employes as professional workers and to create for this group a separate bargaining unit.

PRAGUE, March 3 -- The Communist-dominated International Student Union here appears to have been largely wrecked by the Czechoslovak political crisis. William Ellis, American vice president of the organization, has resigned, as has his representative here, James Smith.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 3 (AP) -- Siena College of Albany will replace Manhattan of New York City as this district's representative in the N.A.I.B. tournament, the district chairman said tonight.

The thirty-first seeason of summer concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium will open on June 14, it was learned yesterday. The eight-week season will run until Aug. 7 and it is planned to tie the concerts in with the celebration of the city's golden jubilee.

Anne DeRamus, a gifted young Negro pianist from Chicago, gave her first recital in this city last night at Times Hall. She confined her program to Mozart, Schumann, Liszt and Albeniz, so the full range of her talents can not be gauged, but they are certainly considerable.

A preview reception for the exhibition of Art of Tibet will be held this afternoon at 4:30 o'clock at the Asia Institute, 7 East Seventieth Street. The exhibition will open to the public tomorrow and continue until April 17, Mondays through Saturdays from 1 o'clock to 5.

If a customer shopping at Bloomingdale's hears "Oui, Madame" instead of "Yes, Madam," from the salesgirl, the clerk probably belongs to an employe group learning French as the result of the adoption of a 10-year-old girl, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 3 -- Manufacture of heavy electrical equipment for steel mills, power stations and railroads was halted today by a wildcat strike of 5,000 employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's East Pittsburgh plant in a dispute over job time study of a new-size generator bearing.
LONDON, March 3 -- Britons of all parties during the House of Lords debate on foreign affairs today showed their determination to organize Western Europe against the threat of communism.

LONDON, March 3 -- In a poorly printed, unsigned pamphlet, received from Jerusalem today by several Members of Parliament, an anti-Jewish organization calling itself the "British League of Servicemen and Ex-Servicemen" claimed responsibility for the bombing of Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem on Feb. 22 causing the death of fifty-four Jews.

Delegates to the seventh convention of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, crushing ineffectual right-wing opposition, voted overwhelmingly yesterday not to sign the non-Communist affidavits required under the Taft-Hartley law.

ALBANY, March 3 -- A bill outlaw racial segregation in the National Guard obtained a good chance for Assembly approval today after William E. Andrews, Harlem Democrat, its sponsor, had agreed to make one minor amendment.

Dan Golenpaul, owner of the radio program "Information, Please," has started a $500,000 suit against the Mutual Broadcasting System for alleged mishandling of the half-hour network show, it was made known yesterday.

OSLO, Norway, March 3 -- Clinging tenaciously to his lead despite the handicap of a broken ski, Harald Eriksson, Sweden's Olympic runner-up, today out-lasted the former Norwegian champion, Hallvard Eggset, in a thrilling 50-kilometer Holmenkollen cross-country ski race.

A charge of malicious mischief was dismissed yesterday in Special Sessions against an apartment house superintendent and manager who had removed the television antenna of a tenant. In announcing the unanimous decision of the court, Presiding Justice Irving Ben Cooper said the prosecution had failed to establish a "prima facie" case in this particular action.

A Laetare campaign to collect at least $5,000,000 will be conducted next Sunday in 15,000 Catholic parishes throughout the United States to aid the needy victims of the war, it was announced yesterday. The drive will be led by the Catholic Bishops of the United States under the auspices of the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

Former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City may be pardoned if he seems unduly pleased over some of the recommendations of the State Tax Policy Commission for revisions in New Jersey's railroad tax laws. It is proposed henceforth to give the predominant share of the state's estimated $16,000,000 annual railroad property taxes to municipalities.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- As the Yankees' training campaign continues to move smoothly along with a serenity reminiscent of those pre-MacPhailian days when Joe McCarthy quietly conditioned his Bombers here, Manager Bucky Harris today began outlining plans which aim to take up two highly constructive jobs as soon as present preliminary workouts permit.

Retailers are doubtful whether they can hold the gains shown in the first two months of the year, according to reports made at the annual meeting of the Central Council of National Retail Associations in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 3 -- A comprehensive overseas program was outlined today to 327 representatives of 118 Protestant mission boards here for the annual meeting of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America. It is built around reports presented by nine area committees.

Overcoming physical handicaps, in several instances involving numerous surgical operations, forty-eight crippled, homebound children receiving their education from visiting teachers of the New York public school system have passed their state Regents examinations, and one has earned a scholarship for advanced study in art.

" The Mirror of Magic," by Kurt Seligmann, will be published by Pantheon Books on March 15. It is a "condensed account" of the growth and development of magical ideas and operations in the Western world, beginning with the propitiatory rites of Mesopotamian magic. The volume contains 250 illustrations.

STUTTGART, Germany, March 3 -- Princess Pauline of Wuerttemberg, 70 years old, was indicted this afternoon by a United States Military Government court for having concealed two prominent Nazis since October 1945. She admitted having deliberately provided a haven for Frau Gertrud Scholtz-Klink, whom she had known as chief of all Nazi women's organizations, but denied that she had been aware of the identity of her husband, former Maj. Gen. August Heissmayer of the SS.
Greenville County, S. C., announced yesterday that it would receive on March 23 bids on $1,500,000 of hospital bonds dated Nov. 15, 1947, and due on Nov. 15, 1948 to 1967.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Warner Brothers has announced the purchase of "Be Nice to Emily," a screen comedy by Matt Taylor, as a vehicle for Viveca Lindfors. The story deals with a Swiss girl who sheltered two American fliers during the war and comes to the United States to see what has become of her proteges. Lester Fuller has been assigned to work on the scenario and Alex Gottleib will produce the film.

The one-story taxpayer containing eight stores at 82-62 to 82-66 Grenfell Avenue, corner of Eighty-third Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by Henry Goelet, operator, from the Glorsam Realty Corporation. The property, which occupies an irregular plot about 127 by 87 feet, was sold subject to mortgages of $90,000.

Long Island University and City College, both eagerly awaiting bids to the national invitation basketball tournament, will be on inspection tonight in a double-header at Madison Square Garden. Clair Bee's Blackbirds will oppose Muhlenberg, after Nat Holman's Beavers tackle Lafayette.

LONDON, March 3 -- A scorching British note accusing the Guatemalan Government of having allowed a "disgraceful" demonstration against the British Legation in Guatemala yesterday was published by the Foreign Office today.

Among the many interesting and beautiful sights that one may see on the island of Manhattan there is one that has been noticed by few people. It is a performance of the much-maligned starling at eventide. As the setting sun drops behind the Palisades these birds come in great streams from their feeding grounds in New Jersey, upper Manhattan and the Bronx to their roost under the Riverside Drive viaduct over 125th Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 3 -- The Government narrowed today the scope of an injunction it is seeking against the International Typographical Union by voluntarily throwing overboard the so-called "featherbedding" issue.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- President Truman told Congress today that complete revision of the Federal Employes' Classification Act, as recommended by the Civil Service Commission, "is long overdue."
The United Office and Professional Workers of America, belonging to the CIO left wing, failed yesterday to give official endorsement to the third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace.

RICHMOND, Va., March 4 -- Governor William M. Tuck's "anti-Truman bill" to change Virginia's Presidential election laws ran into rough going at a public hearing here tonight, but observers expected it to reach the floor of the House of Delegates tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The text of Dr. Edward U. Condon's letter to Chairman Bourks B. Hickenlooper of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, was as follows:

After a two-month investigation into a series of thefts from the Railway Express Agency, Bronx detectives seized yesterday a truck containing stolen express packages that had been insured for $40,000 and rounded up more than twenty persons for questioning.

OTTAWA, March 4 -- Louis St. Laurent, Minister of External Affairs, gave a flat denial in the House of Commons today to the statement made yesterday by Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec on the subject of the elusive Polish treasures.

Purchasing agents here have opened an attack on huge "conversion" profits in steel finishing and final manufacturing, compared to which recent price increases in semi-finished products are very small, purchasing spokesmen declared here yesterday.

TRIESTE, March 4 -- The Free Territory of Trieste has become a Western democratic outpost whose very existence is now threatened by a political double envelopment similar to the striking military formula of Cannae.

PRAGUE, March 4 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist chiefs are throwing the doors wide open to get the maximum number of persons lined up within either the now tightly organized National Front movement or within the Communist party itself.

A collection of writings and speeches by Jawaharlal Nehru about the late Mahatma Gandhi has been scheduled for April publication by the John Day Company, under the title "Nehru on Gandhi." The book will contain excerpts from Nehru's autobiography "Toward

Ten teams will ride in the annual Sherman Memorial tournament starting tomorrow night at the Morristown (N.J.) Armory, it was announced yesterday by the Indoor Polo Assocation of America. In all, sixteen trios are listed in the Sherman, national junior and national senior Eastern eliminations for the right to take part in the championship finals against the Western victors starting in Chicago April 1.

A last-minute gift of $25,000 and other contributions will enable Sydenham Hospital to pay its immediate debts and keep its doors open for at least part of the current year. About $90,000 has so far been raised, much of it in the form of small donations by residents of Harlem, labor unions and the hospital medical staff.

"Paisan," the Italian-made topical drama directed by Roberto Rosselini, who was responsible for the noted Italian film, "Open City," has been booked for the World Theatre, to follow the current tenant, "To Live in Peace," it was announced yesterday by Mayer and Burstyn, the distributors.

Tradition will be breached if tomorrow's New York Chapter Knights of Columbus games, the season's final assembly of the track and field brigade in Madison Square Garden, do not produce the fastest clockings and best performances of the indoor campaign.

With trading on the New York Stock Exchange at the lowest level in five months, the United Financial Employes, Local 205, AFL, made no move yesterday to carry out its strike threat against the Stock and Curb Exchanges and 100 Wall Street brokerage houses.

Refunding of borrowings by finance companies into other long-term commitments was a major factor in a $44,000,000 reduction of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System last veek.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Dr. Juraj Slavik, who has resigned as Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States rather than serve "a police state," was denounced over the telephone by Vladimir Klementis, Czechoslovak Deputy Foreign Minister and a member of the Communist party, as soon as word of his resignation had reached Prague.
JERUSALEM, March 4 -- Arabs ambushed and killed seventeen Jews of the Haganah forces near Beituniya, seven miles northwest of Jerusalem, this morning in a fight that lasted several hours.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- May wheat advanced 10 cents a bushel, the daily limit, at the opening on the Board of Trade today as the result of buying induced by announcement the Government would purchase flour equal to more than 9,000,000 bushels of cash wheat.

BERLIN, March 4 -- The end of the westward march of Communist totalitarianism "must" come in Czechoslovakia, just as the end of Nazi totalitarianism began there, an official United States Military Government speaker told the Germans by radio tonight.

Cornell's indoor poloists, who last won the championship in 1937, moved into the intercollegiate indoor title final last night, along with the unbeaten Miami University trio, at the Squadron A Armory.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 4 -President Truman intervened this afternoon to avert a strike which he said would have grave consequences at the Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy laboratory.

Stockholders of Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York will vote on Chemical Bank and Trust Company's proposal to take over their bank on April 12, it was disclosed yesterday in the following announcement by Continental's board:

VIENNA, March 4 -- After having heard a report from its Foreign Minister on the London negotiations, the Austrian Cabinet said today that a treaty should be sought "provided it grants Austria full sovereignty and independence within her 1937 frontiers, assures the possibility of local defense of her frontiers and guarantees her ability to support herself economically."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- At her own request, Joan Crawford has been withdrawn from the cast of Warner Brothers' "Kiss In The Dark" and Jane Wyman has been named to replace her in the starring role, opposite David Niven, the studio announced today.

LONDON, March 4 -- The British pound sterling will remain at its present international exchange value indefinitely, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today. Sir Stafford described as "nonsense" a report from Paris that a simultaneous devaluation of the pound, the Belgian franc and the Netherland florin was under consideration.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce found today that the supply of many types of cotton fabrics is "fairly in balance with demand." Therefore, the department said, the cotton textile industry will not be asked now for a voluntary agreement to parcel out primary fabrics or unfinished goods.

Two stockholders in the American Woolen Company, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here to enjoin the concern and four of its directors from adopting a proposed retirement plan for salaried employes.

The custom order collection of Henri Bendel, shown yesterday at the shop, presented fashions of polished perfection, essentially of today. Theirs was a sure simplicity, authoritative from tip to hemline. The designs were by Mrs. Berthe Stern Simmons and Priscilla.

Some exporters who appear more or less reconciled to the new export licensing policies of OIT nevertheless are strongly urging that the valid period of the license be extended. Most licenses now are for ninety days, but an average life of about double that figure would be far more desirable, it was said.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The American Optical Company, Southbridge, Mass., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of twenty-year sinking fund debentures that are to be offered publicly through a group of underwriters headed by Harriman Ripley Co. and Estabrook Co.
LONDON, March 4 -- Arthur Henderson, Air Secretary, told the House of Commons today that a powerful aviation striking force was being built up in Britain as a deterrent to aggression from overseas.

John R. Suman, vice president and director of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, accepted the chairmanship yesterday of the Greater New York Division for the fifth annual campaign of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced by fund officials.

James H. Van Alen of New York and William L. (Sammy) Van Alen of Philadelphia, titleholders in 1940, were eliminated from the national amateur court tennis doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 4 -Needless perils encountered by motorists when driving at night were called "ever-increasing shadows of death over the roads" at today's session here of the annual meeting of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States.

President Truman said last night in a message marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the elevation of the Department of Labor to Cabinet status that additional social legislation, especially the increase in the minimum hourly wage, was "imperative" in the light of the nation's rapidly changing economy.
LONDON, March 4 -- Former King Michael of Rumania broke his silence on his abdication today and said that it had been imposed upon him by force and he did not consider himself bound by it.

Opposing suggestions that the Security Council should refer the Palestine case back to a special session of the General Assembly for reconsideration, the newly formed Emergency Conference to Save the United Nations by Supporting the Palestine Resolution declared yesterday that such a course would "destroy the capacity of the United Nations to reach decisions."
A stricter discipline in fashion controlled the collection with which Hattie Carnegie opened her spring and summer season yesterday afternoon in her East Forty-ninth Street establishment.

In letters sent yesterday to Governor Dewey and all members of the Legislature the Commerce and Industry Association of New York urged rejection of Mayor O'Dwyer's request for permission to double the city's present tax on gross receipts of general and financial businesses.

HONOLULU, March 4 -- News of the scuttling of the venerable battleship Pennsylvania, survivor of two world wars and the atomic bomb, was officially announced here today. The sinking took place near Kwajalein last Feb. 10. The destroyer Trippe was sunk Feb. 3 and the Army attack transport Banner Feb. 16.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- In a statement issued here tonight Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, said:

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4 -- The veil of secrecy surrounding the Buddy Kerr case was officially lifted today, revealing a Giant hold-out situation which must go back for a parallel to the days when Billy Southworth was calling Bill Terry to accept terms and a "get tough" policy by the club which is similarly rare.

TAMPA, Fla., March 4 -- In the field of international politics the Reds always seem to fear encirclement, but Johnny Neun, the commissar of the Cincinnati Reds, actually would welcome encirclement provided the teams which surrounded his people's army were first-division clubs. As a matter of fact, his lightly regarded forces almost infiltrated into the upper bracket last season, finishing an astonishing fifth.

Swedish cooperatives, with 1947 consumer sales at new high figures, are aggressively pushing programs in the petroleum and building supply fields, Mauritz Bonow, organizational director of the Kooperativa Forbundet (KF) in Stockholm, said yesterday at the offices of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A. at 23 West Forty-fifth Street.

The statement that corporate profits in 1947 were "exorbitant," or "unconscionable," has been repeated so often of late that a special interest attaches to two articles on this subject which have just appeared. One is contained in the annual review of current business of the Department of Commerce,

An expanded program through which the churches and social agencies, regardless of denomination, may help the increasing portion of the population over 65 years old "to make a happy adjustment to the changing condition of their lives," was recommended yesterday in a "Survey for the Protestant Churches and the Aged in New York City."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The National Labor Relations Board today stated that the Taft-Hartley Law did not require it to investigate the authenticity of non-Communist affidavits filed with it but that those desiring to establish the truth of the affidavits would have to apply to the Department of Justice.
In the heart of Rockefeller Center the Soviet Union yesterday opened its first large exhibit in this city since the World's Fair of 1939-40.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 -- The Yugoslav official news agency, Tanjug, charged today that the Greek Army was planning military raids across the Albanian frontier to take prisoners who would be exhibited in Athens as proof of Greek complaints that Albanian troops were fighting in the ranks of the Greek Partisans.

A member of the United States Olympic Basketball Committee asked yesterday that the winner of the National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball tournament be eliminated from Olympic consideration because Negroes are not permitted to play in the Kansas City meet.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Strong opposition to editorializing by radio networks or broadcasting stations as such, but none to the broadcasting personally by a licensee of his own views over his own facilities, was expressed at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission by representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Radio Writers Guild of the Authors League of America, the National Farmers Union, and M.S. Novik, of New York, public service radio consultant.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- Congress called on the Federal Bureau of Investigation today for fingerprint tests of a Communist party card allegedly issued to Herbert K. Sorrell in 1937 under the name of "Herb Stewart."

Seventeen years have not improved the minds or toned the systems of the Hallams. When Rose Franken first wrote about them in "Another Language" in 1931, they fascinated theatregoers, who saw in them the morose images of family life. Miss Franken came back to them last evening in another family saga impulsively labeled "The Hallams" and put on at the Booth, where "Another Language" first opened its eyes.

Arguing that if America had been prepared, both World Wars could have been avoided, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York asked yesterday for an immediate Congressional debate on Universal Military Training.

BERLIN, March 4 -- Although Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was a best seller in Germany for many years, few of its purchasers read the book, according to a Military Government survey made available today. The survey revealed that only two out of ten Germans living in the American zone admitted to having read all or part of the book.

PATERSON, N.J., March 4 -Relief for hay fever suffers who love to look at flowers but cannot tolerate their pollen is one of the many benefits that two local physicians expect to result from use of their newly announced solution for preserving freshly cut foliage.

Five new freighters, three of them 7,000-ton vessels designed for speeds in excess of 17 knots, have been ordered by the Swedish American Line for entry in the North Atlantic service, it became known yesterday.

ATHENS, March 4 -- A Balkan Youth Congress meeting in Belgrade has resolved that "12,000 children living in the areas of Greece controlled by Markos shall receive hospitality to continue their studies in various Balkan countries until the cessation of hostilities in Greece," according to a Belgrade radio broadcast heard here today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Spokesmen for the Atomic Trades and Labor Council, AFL, announced today compliance with the request of President Truman that its members remain at work until March 19, pending a report by a board of inquiry.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 4 -Manhattan College won its twentieth basketball game of the season tonight by defeating St. Bonaventure, 35 -- 31. The Jaspers led at the half, 16 -- 12.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- After a survey of military hospitals in the United States, lasting sixteen days, Rear Admiral Joel T. Boone said today there is little immediate prospect of the organization of an armed forces medical service.

I was interested in reading Dr. Rusk's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 25 entitled "Brooklyn Bureau Provides Homework for Shut-Ins." Basically, I am very much in accord as to the value of homework activities for the disabled.

HAVANA, March 4 The executive board of the proposed International Trade Organization will be representative of the major geographical areas, of the diverse types of economic systems and of the different stages of economic development among the ITO members.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- Pennsylvania mapped plans today to prevent serious injuries to boxers in the ring.

The Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Ridgewood has purchased a vacant plot at Forest and Halleck Avenues in Ridgewood, Queens, as the site for a new bank building, which it plans to occupy. The irregular parcel, about 65 by 100 feet, was acquired from the Ridgewood Presbyterian Church in an all-cash transaction.

In the face of what the Long Island University basketball team accomplished last night at Madison Square Garden, it will indeed be difficult to withhold a post-season tournament bid from Clair Bee's Blackbirds. Concluding their regular season, the Brooklynites defeated Muhlenberg, 56 -- 54, for their seventeenth victory which to 16,122 fans must have been the campaign's most incredible comeback.

Elimination of double taxation on corporate incomes and enactment of the community property basis of taxation for married couples in all states were among thirty specific recommendations for revision of Federal tax laws mailed yesterday to Congressional committees by the Committee on Federal Taxation of the American Institute of Accountants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 4 -- Children of ten nations, wearing costumes of their native lands, presented a Red Cross flag to the United Nations today as a symbol of the common purposes of the two organizations striving for Internanational understanding and world peace.

WASHINGTON, March 45 -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman refused tonight to honor a subpoena of the House Committee on Un-American Activities which called for the records of a departmental hearing that absolved Dr. Edward U. Condon of disloyalty to the United States.

A six-story apartment building for eighty-nine families will be erected at 4507-17 Broadway, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by H. I. Feldman, the architect. Tryon Park Apartments, Inc., of 19 West Forty-fourth Street, is the owner.

Undoubtedly, the success of "Mister Roberts" will stimulate the production of other war plays in the lighter vein. In their second try (let's forget about the first one), Herbert H. Harris and Lester Meyer hope to hit the bullseye with "At War With the Army," a comedy by James B. Allardice.

ROME, March 4 -- The Vatican is about to lodge a strong protest with the Greek Government, which has seized Roman Catholic churches and other ecclesiastical property in the Dodecanese Islands, it was learned today.

The arts of remote and isolated Tibet, assembled from museums and collectors to form the first comprehensive exhibition ever brought before the American public, were shown at a preview yesterday in the Asia Institute, 7 East Seventieth Street.

As an answer to the competitive implications of recent magazine promotional surveys, moves to improve present newspaper readership surveys are expected soon to produce broader data in this field, it was learned yesterday. One suggestion would expand present sampling and interviewing to obtain facts more representative of the population in a paper's circulation area, rather than solely of the group studied.
In this, our diminutive segment of Little America, when one alternates between shoveling coal and heaving masses of ever-recurring snow, the birds are, indeed, a comfort and diversion.

SOME time before Franklin D. Roosevelt was nominated at Chicago on July 20, 1944 for a fourth term, he again proposed to me at the White House my nomination as Vice President. He said he knew I could have the nomination if I would take it.

Securities are merchandise and brokers must learn to sell them better if the industry is to expand, Lucien O. Hooper of W.E. Hutton Co. of the New York Stock Exchange told 1,200 members of the National Federation of Financial Analysts Societies yesterday at their first annual convention.

Philip Stack, the "Don Wahn" who wrote heartbreak verse for Walter Winchell's column for the last twenty-four years, plunged to his death just after midnight yesterday from the twelfth floor of the Goodhue House Apartments, Thirty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue. He was in his forty-seventh year.

The economy and efficiency of the Port of Philadelphia in the movement of grain account for its handling a larger volume of the commodity than the Port of New York, the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce said in a statement yesterday.

If anything more were needed to discredit the procedure of the House Committee on Un-American Activities the case of Dr. Edward U. Condon, head of the National Bureau of Standards, has done it. This agency's subcommittee, dealing with the special field of national security, stated that the
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- G.T. Strother's Salvo, running to his fast morning trials, led a field of veterans all the way in today's featured Insulaire Purse at Tropical Park.

BUENOS AIRES, March 4 -- Argentine customs authorities today ordered the independent daily newspapers Prensa and Nacion to pay back duty on all imported newsprint used for advertising purposes since 1939.

The American Physical Society and members of the Departments of Physics and Mathematics of Princeton University dispatched yesterday telegrams to several branches of the Federal Government attesting to the loyalty toward the United States of Dr. Edward Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 4 -- With the prospects for carrying out the partition of Palestine at their lowest ebb since the United Nations General Assembly adjourned Nov. 29, several Arab representatives here have swung back to their earlier proposal for a federal regime in the Holy Land, it was learned tonight.

The four alleged alien-Communists held on Ellis Island without bail who are entering the fifth day of a hunger strike were notified yesterday by the Department of Justice that their deportation proceedings would be opened this month -- three of them on Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- During the week ended March 3, member bank reserve balances increased $753,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged during the week ended Feb. 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Increases in prices of farm products and foods and some industrial commodities were offset by substantial declines in hides and leather and cotton goods.

Jamaica and Stuyvesant were the winners yesterday at Madison Square Garden as first-round play opened in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship. Jamaica defeated Seward Park, 52 to 43, while Stuyvesant eliminated Franklin K. Lane, 42 to 35.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 4 -- There was a new lift to local enthusiasm for los Dodgers today. The upward propulsion for fan hysteria was supplied by Jackie Robinson's arrival and first workout.

ALBANY, March 4 -- An Assembly vote on Mayor William O'Dwyer's transit fare bill was assured today despite grumblings from both Democratic and Republican legislators from New York City that its passage could terminate their political careers.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 4 -After one week of work here as domestics, Puerto Rican young women brought north by Government agencies to help solve the housemaid shortage agreed today on their first day off that the transition in their lives was wonderful.

A plea for increased military and economic aid to the Chinese Nationalist Government in its campaign against communism is being made by eighteen Chinese university professors in "an open letter to America."

ROME, March 4 -- The Vatican announced today that it had asked Italian police to arrest Msgr. Edoard Prettner Cippico of Trieste, a former official of the Secretariat of State, who escaped last night from an apartment inside the Vatican grounds, where he had been detained.

Tiny manikins paraded custom-made diapers, as well as sober little Eton jacketed suits at Franklin Simon's amusing luncheon show at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. To create the atmosphere of Central Park, there was a lamp post, a policeman, a starchy nurse and a real organ grinder and his monkey.

PARIS, March 4 -- In an atmosphere of sharp division, the French National Assembly today voted to debate tomorrow night the proposals to revise the unpopular tax-loan bill. Premier Robert Schuman has agreed to stake his Cabinet against any fundamental modifications of the bill, which Rene Mayer, Minister of Finance, insists is essential to his recovery program.

Your correspondent John Case is, of course, entirely correct in his letter published Feb. 18 pointing out that comparisons between Diesel-electric railroad motive power and steam in the fields of tractive power, draw-bar pull, operating efficiency, availability and such, are invariably made between the

Paul Keres of Estonia, third representative of Russia in the international tournament for the chess championship of the world at The Hague, repeated his triumph of the first round by defeating Vassily Smyslov of Moscow yesterday, according to a report from the Netherlands.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- The need of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and other railroads for more revenues to pay for expansion and improvement and to cover increased operating costs was stressed today in the annual report of Fred G. Gurley, president
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -Three Negroes who sued the Southern Railway Company because it made them sit in the Negro section lost their case today.

LONDON, March 4 -- The withdrawal of the remainder of the United States loan to Great Britain, together with the uncertain international situation, kept buyers from the stock market here today. However, there was no selling pressure and prices generally held firm.

Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., last year transacted sales totaling $81,325,286, the highest in its history and 164 per cent above the $30,836,262 volume for 1946. Judson S. Sayre president, informed stockholders in the tenth annual statement mailed yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, closing with gains of 15 to 45 points.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Senate-House conferees dealing with veterans legislation agreed today on a measure to allow former service men greater earnings and still qualify for subsistence allowances under the GI job-training programs.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate adopted today the Condon-Wadlin Bill fixing a ceiling of $900,000,000 on the unemployment insurance reserve fund and increasing maximum benefits from $21 to $26 a week. Likely rebates to employers are estimated at about $165,000,000. The fifteen Democrats and the single American Labor party member opposed the measure.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 4 -A rough draft treaty for the creation of an all-inclusive political, military, economic and cultural union in Western Europe was laid on the conference table in the Foreign Ministry here today by the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg for consideration by Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman thinks the time has come for the Federal Government to contemplate a permanent arrangement for disaster relief. He expressed the idea in a letter to Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Federal Works Agency, made public by the White House today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The top leadership of the Democratic party, eager to restore party unity, is looking ahead hopefully to next week's two-day meeting of the next national executive committee.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee overrode its chairman, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, today and supported President Truman's Reorganization Plan No. 1 of 1948.

Mrs. Mary McLeod Bethune, who was born of slave parents and who founded a college for Negro youth in Florida "on $1.65 and a song," was honored last night by friends with a dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel. She thanked the group for coming together

Surpassing all previous records in its thirty-three-year history, earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation last year were almost four times as large as those made in 1946, according to the annual report of E.T. Stannard, president, released for publication today.

Portraiture gets the major share of attention this week in two exhibitions by an American "old master" and a contemporary Russian now residing in this country. At the Harry Shaw Newman (Old Print Shop) Gallery a group of portraits and a landscape by Gilbert

Plans for reconstructing two buildings in the Columbus Circle section that were gutted by fire recently were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 1780-82 Broadway and 225-27 West Fifty-seventh Street by the 1780 Broadway Corporation to an investor.

LONDON, March 4 -- Last minute efforts were made here today between French and British representatives to reach an agreed version for the draft treaty for a Western European union to be presented in Brussels.

The nice thing about winning a checkers championship at the Children's Aid Society West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, is that "you get to meet the boys that way." This comment was made by Lena Sparto, 10 years old, of 321 West Thirty-eighth Street, after defeating Nina Moretto, 8, of 507 Ninth Avenue for the title of "checkers champ" of the center's Girls Club.

In recognition of the urgent need to provide funds for rehabilitation of Jews in Europe, Palestine defense and refugee aid in the United States, $35,000,000 in cash has been contributed in less than two weeks. Henry Morgenthau Jr., General Chairman of the United Jews Appeal Campaign, said yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 4 -It became certain tonight that the Finns would agree to discuss a defense pact with the Soviet Union with the acceptance of such discussions by one of Finland's key political groups, the Social Democratic party.

The grim realities and even grimmer implications of the present world situation have been emphasized anew by two further developments in Europe and in Washington. In Europe, the first battlefront of freedom, five Western nations -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., New York City, to stop unfair competitive practices in connection with its purchase of milk from cooperative milk producer associations.

Patricia Benkman, talented young pianist appeared in recital at Times Hall last night. Dark hair set off by a white dress, she graced the platform with her attractive presence, and threw herself into the music with commendable self-effacement.
A number of recent incidents have aroused fears that freedom of the press -- traditional safeguard of our civil liberties -- is being modified or slowly impaired.

KEENE, N.H., March 4 -- The Stassen-Dewey fight for delegates to the Republican National Convention from New Hampshire took on today the aspects of a fight by Mr. Stassen against the state machine run by Gov. Charles M. Dale.

Three hundred American students and teachers, half of them from New York City, are to go to Europe this summer for a twelve-week course to study the Marshall Plan at first hand. The former battlefields and industrial areas are to be used as the classroom in this project, the first ever attempted in this country.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Manager Eddie Dyer barely escaped serious injury today when he was hit on the head by a sizzling line drive at a workout by the Cardinals. The accident occurred minutes after holdout Stan Musial, slugging St. Louis first baseman, had agreed to terms with president Robert E. Hannegan.
Earle Larimore, matinee idol and star of many Broadway successes, was almost penniless when he died in his apartment at the Marlton Hotel, 3 West Eighth Street, last Oct. 23, at the age of 48.

GAINESVILLE, Fla. March 4 -In a surprise move, the newly formed Regional Council on Education opened the South's educational doors today to increased negro participation by recommending that each Governor of fifteen Southern states name an "outstanding" negro educator to work with the council.

LONDON, March 4 -- British official quarters indicated today that the British Government intended to proceed with its plans for increased self-government in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan in spite of the refusal of the Egyptian Government to enter into negotiations on the plans.

Virginia Morley and Livingston Gearhart, duo-pianists, gave their first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Their exacting program had as its chief offerings Stravinsky's "Concerto per due pianoforti soli," Debussy's "En blanc et noir," and Chopin's Rondo in C major.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 4 -- The Chilean and Argentine Governments announced today further agreement regarding their Antarctic claims.

Although the system's operating revenues reached a new record high of $129,005,000 in 1947, the consolidated net income of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiary companies last year declined more than $1,200,000 to $14,860,000 mainly because of high production costs, Earle J. Machold, president of the utility organization, informed stockholders in the annual report mailed to them yesterday.

Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, charged last night that President Truman, by promoting committal of the Federal Government to high spending and taxing policies, was encouraging subordinates to sabotage economy efforts by Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Feb. 28 totaled 791,089 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,287 cars, or 18 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 58,902 cars, or 6.9

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt came back to Washington today, the fifteenth anniversary of her husband's first inauguration, to explain to fifteen civic groups the international covenant and declaration on human rights drafted under her chairmanship of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

Thousands of ill and needy New Yonkers are being deprived of hospital care because the municipal hospitals are unable to meet present needs, according to a survey of the city hospitals just completed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Defense Secretary Forrestal's proposal for a voluntary system of censorship by newspapers and other media of news dissemination of military or scientific information that might be of use to a potentially hostile nation or nations appeals as a reasonable solution of a controversial and complex question.

The domestic airlines of the United States face an increase of some $15,000,000 in their gasoline and oil bill this year. They charge that there is no competition for their $34,000,000 business the major oil companies asserting they have too much trouble getting aviation gasoline and oil to enter competitive bids.
