LONDON, March 4 -- Britain and France joined the United States in flatly rejecting the Soviet proposals for the settlement of Russian claims on German assets in Austria at today's meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies.
MANILA, March 4 -- Congress has begun wrestling with the most important legislation yet submitted -- a basic change in the Philippine financial system.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 4 -- A publishers' spokesman asserted in Federal District Court today that if the AFL-International Typographical Union's bargaining policy continued unchecked, the consequences to the newspaper industry would be "disastrous."

Your leading editorial of Feb. 22 states: "U.N. is as much handicapped as the League was in enforcing a decision against a major power. This is not because of the Security Council veto or any other weakness in the Charter, but because enforcement would mean a major war."

Reports from diocesan directors indicate that the $5,000,000 goal of the Bishops' Fund for Victims of War being conducted by the Bishops' Emergency and Relief Committee and War Relief Services, National Catholic Welfare Conference, will be surpassed, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director, said yesterday.

Reserves of crude oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids in the United States increased in 1947, according to reports issued yesterday by committees of the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

OCANA, Spain, March 4 -- Sentences of two to thirty years were asked by the prosecution for the sixteen men tried before a court-martial here today charged with membership in the clandestine Union of Free Intellectuals.

The "Amateur Hour," presented at 7 o'clock Sunday nights over WABD and the DuMont Network, has scored the highest rating in the first popularity poll of television programs to be conducted by C.E. Hooper, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Mullins Manufacturing Corporation will drop franchised distributors who are found using Youngstown kitchen equipment as inducement for forced tie-in sales to appliance dealers, Charles A. Morrow, vice president in charge of sales, warned yesterday.

The one-story taxpayer building at 498-514 Central Avenue, East Orange, N.J., containing twelve stores, has been leased by the Studio Building Corporation from Stein, Haas Bergman for forty-nine years at a rental in excess of $1,500,000.

CLEVELAND, March 4 (AP) -The M.A. Hanna Company, iron ore, coal and shipping concern, reported today a record net profit of $7,282,506 for 1947, equal to $6.67 a common share. The profit, the third successive new high record, compares with $5,611,654, or $5.05 in 1946.

LONDON, March 4 -- In a second note to Guatamala, Published today, the British Government firmly rejected any implication that its control of British Honduras was illegal, and it renewed its offer to submit the conflicting British and Guatemalan claims to the International Court of Justice.
The Ithaca monthly meeting of the Society of Friends wishes to express its opposition to conscription, now offered to the country under the name of Universal Military Training.

George Szell began the program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall with an operatic piece which had not been previously heard at these concerts, Verdi's overture to "Forza del destino." There are few overtures of length to the Verdi operas.

Our lawmakers at Albany seem to be having a painfully difficult time in doing the right thing about transit. First one small issue and then another blows up into a controversy that threatens for a time to throw the fare rise into jeopardy. Neither major party is free of these touching inner wrestlings with conscience.

Meat remains a stumbling block in the way of economical food buying this week-end. Although it is possible to purchase many vegetables for 6 cents less a pound than a week ago, prices at the meat counter are at the same levels they were last Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The United States must back up its economic foreign assistance programs with military aid, or "pray in blood," Congress was told by Lieut. Gen. A.C. Wedemeyer, a wartime commander of the China theater, today.

YESTERDAY'S newspaper has long been a popular synonym for something of small interest because it is out of date. But compared to it a book of topical reporting based upon circumstances as they were a year and a half before publication day seems an extraordinary blunder on somebody's part. Such books, since they are only hasty journalism in the first

The continuing firmness in Government bond prices showed up in the dealers' market yesterday as all the bank-ineligible bonds except the 2 1/4s of 1962-59 changed hands at prices slightly above the pegs established by bids of the Federal Reserve System on Christmas Eve.

International Distributors, wholesale liquor dealers of 5 East Fifty-first Street, lost the first round of its legal battle to regain its liquor license yesterday, when the Appellate Division voted 3 to 2 to reverse a ruling handed down last Saturday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, which directed the State Liquor Authority to issue a temporary permit to the liquor dealers.

The ten-story apartment building containing ninety-four small suites on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 102 East Twenty-second Street has been sold by Morton Wasserman and others to an investing client of Benjamin Pollack, attorney. It is assessed for $520,000 and was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $464,797 in a deal negotiated by Alfred Lipschitz and Sybil Block, brokers.

GUATEMALA, March 4 -- President Juan Jose Arevalo, because of the "crucial moments" through which the country is passing, today granted general amnesty to all Guatemalans who had been exiled from the country, according to an official announcement.

I.V. Cohen, operator and builder, has purchased the property at 4054-4064 Park Avenue, the Bronx, from the Wyckoff-Bent Corporation. The parcel, 127 by 150 feet in the block between East 174th and East 175th Streets, is now improved with a gasoline service station and several buildings.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Dewey declared today that a "profligate waste" of public funds by the Democratic National Administration was threatening a ruinous inflation and that the handling of domestic problems and foreign relations had been "weak and incompetent."

The $700,000 fire at Pier 8, Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, on Jan. 6 illustrates that lessons taught by previous waterfront blazes here have not been applied, the New York Board of Fire Underwriters said in a report released yesterday.

LONDON, March 4 -- Russia has filed a second protest against the activities of United States airplanes in the Far East, the Moscow radio said tonight. A broadcast heard in London said the Soviet Union had made a new complaint over "continued violations of the freedom of merchant shipping" by United States planes off Japan.
PARIS, March 4 -- A total of 7,791,483,000 francs is now in a special account in the Bank of France as a result of United States interim aid, the French Foreign Office indicated today.

There are 967 nominations, a record number, by 146 individuals for the fifteen stake races during the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting that will open at Jamaica on April 1. The stakes that cover a 39-day program, marking the beginning of the New York racing season, have a gross value of $380,000 added, while the nominations exceed the. previous record of 770 in 1947.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 4 -- On the eve of the meeting of the Council of States, which must ratify the election of Dr. Hermann Puender as bizonal Chief Executive, vital political difficulties were disclosed today within the bizonal administration.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The European Recovery Program was attacked today by Senate "revisionists" as carrying potential benefits to Soviet satellite state in the projected revival of trade between eastern and western Europe.

A gain of $10,343,207 in sales to a new high record of $107,339,534 was reported yesterday by the Lerner Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries in the statement for the fiscal year ended with last January.
GENEVA, March 4 (Reuters) -The United Nations Maritime Conference decided today to set up a new specialized agency of the United Nations to deal with shipping.

TOKYO, March 4 -- The visit of George Kennan, chief of the State Department's Planning Bureau, to Japan, has again started the Japanese talking interestedly about the possibility of a peace treaty with the United States or, in the absence of a treaty, an agreement, under which the two nations might unofficially find accord.

Films ran upside down, weird wails emanated from the sound equipment and confusion was widespread in RKO and Loew theatres yesterday as projectionists continued their protests against contract terms offered by their employers.

Last night's performance by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center, a second "American Choreographers' Evening," found the Ruth Page-Bentley Stone ballet, "Frankie and Johnny," with a new Frankie in the person of Harriet Toby.

Billy Fox, hard-punching Philadelphian, who failed in his first effort to dethrone Gus Lesnevich as light heavyweight champion of the world a year ago, will make a second attempt tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Felix Elderby cherishes all the traditions of Old New York and is averse to changes in places hallowed by those traditions. But he says that what is happening down in Washington Square reminds him that in any case we can take comfort in a fair assurance that the Square will remain an open space.

Relinquishing the lead which they had held since the opening night for two hours, the high-flying Italian combination of Alvaro Giorgetti and Angelo De Bacco rode back into a tie for the leadership with Emile Ignat and Henri Surbatis as the sixty-seventh international six-day bicycle race started its fifth day in the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

Mrs. Annie M. Candelario, 30-year-old mother of two children, who admitted she received city relief while having a bank account of $5,000, received a stay of executtion of a three-year penitentiary sentence yesterday in Bronx County Court provided she paid back $2,068.10.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- There is a battle of first basemen about to break loose in these parts that could develop into something of a tussle. It might, in fact, provide a final answer to a tantalizing problem that has been plaguing Yankee managers these many years.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 4 -- A United Nations committee today refused on procedural grounds to consider Yugoslavia's charges that her economy had been damaged by the freezing of $70,000,000 of reserves, including $56,000,000 in Yugoslav gold, by the United States.
Random notes.

PORT STANLEY, Falkland Islands, March 4 (AP) -- An Argentine naval vessel warned a Norwegian fishing ship she must have Argentine permission to anchor at British-claimed Deception Island, South Shetlands, it was learned today.

Prices on the stock market gave way yesterdey under mild selling pressure in the slowest trading since late last September. It was a highly selective session, with emphasis on some issues seldom traded to the extent of more than a few hundred shares.
Pittsburgh announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 1 on a new issue of $4,000,000 of public improvement bonds.

Aside from a flurry in the motion pictures group and continued interest in some issues ordinarily traded in small parcels, the stock market exhibited yesterday only a moderately firmer tone. The final hour provided the exception to a lukewarm performance by the list.

Jack Morgan's jumping one-handed shot from just inside the foul-line on an out-of-bounds play with 13 seconds to play climaxed a stirring rally by St. Francis that gave the Terrier quintet an upset 51-to-50 triumph over St. John's at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5 -- A fresh approach to the Kashmir problem will be tried when the Security Council meets on Monday to resume its discussion of the India-Pakistan dispute.

More than half the suites have been rented in the 115-family Pershing Crescent Apartments at 141-30 Pershing Crescent in Kew Gardens, according to the Kraham Realty Company, renting agent. Occupancy is due in July. Albert Watkins and James and Michael Kennedy are the builders.
IN THE three-quarters century of my life I have seen this nation grow from a continental to a world power, with interests in every corner of the globe.

St. Francis Prep, Brooklyn champion, and LaSalle Academy, Manhattan-Bronx ruler, were the victors in the semi-final round of the city Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball play-offs in the Twelfth Regiment Armory last night.

Rotterdam, Europe's greatest port, is rapidly recovering its previous position and is now able to handle over 70 per cent of its prewar cargo capacity of 40,000,000 to 45,000,000 tons, Dr. J.P. Oud, Burgomaster of Rotterdam and president of the Association of Netherlands Municipalities, said yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

Gus Lesnevich smashed challenger Billy Fox of Philadelphia into complete defeat in less than two minutes of fighting at Madison Square Garden last night. The 32-year-old light heavyweight champion of the world first put his title on the line and then put his youthful rival out of action in 1:58 of the first round of their scheduled fifteen-round clash.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Assembly gave unanimous approval today to two bills already passed in the Senate which would enable cities to use their powers of condemnation to acquire sites for the private development of parking facilities and for the rehabilitation of substandard areas by private enterprise.

An anonymous warning by telephone threatening bodily harm failed to prevent Miss Betty Berman, a resident buyer, of 210 West Seventieth Street, from appearing in Felony Court yesterday to press a robbery charge against Daniel F. Ahearn, 45-year-old ex-convict.

A primary election contest among Manhattan Assembly district leaders for election as a delegate to the Republican National Convention from the Twentieth Congressional District was avoided yesterday at a conference between County Chairman Thomas J. Curran and the persons directly interested.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 5 -- The bizonal Council of States ratified Dr. Hermann Puender as Chief Executive of the bizonal Economic Administration at a closed session today.

HAVANA, March 5 -- A new obstacle to the prompt and successful closing of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment has developed in a controversy over the relations of the proposed International Trade Organization with the United Nations on political matters, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Grain markets fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade today. Business was much smaller than of late, as brokers waited for announcement of the amount of flour sold to the Government.

TRIESTE, March 5 -- The fledgling creation of the Paris Peace Conference -- the Free Territory of Trieste -- is going broke and can be saved from bankruptcy only by continual injections of food, material and money from the United States.

Articles published today and yesterday in other columns of this newspaper confirm the fact of a really desperate situation in the city hospitals. These hospitals are overcrowded, understaffed and in need of renovation or expansion of facilities. The sick lie packed in corridors, solaria and porches, subject to the hazards of drafts, noises and lack of privacy, all of which retard their recovery.

Advertising will run the risk of "some crackdown" if used for special pleading or as a "club" of big business, Gardner Cowles, president of Look Magazine, declared last night. He sounded this warning at the Annual Advertising Awards dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5 -- The United Nations Security Council decided today to ask the Big Five to consult and to submit to it by March 15 recommendations for instructions to the Palestine Commission "with a view of implementing the resolution of the General Assembly."

Recent uncertainty concerning the status of New York University and Columbia in post-season basketball was cleared partially yesterday when the Violets accepted a bid to play in the National Invitation tournament starting at Madison Square Garden next Thursday night.

Creation of an entirely new family of fourteen radioactive isotopes, at least one of which will provide an abundant new element for use in atomic bombs and for atomic power, was announced last night by Prof. Glenn T. Seaborg of the University of California, co-discoverer of the man-made fissionable element, plutonium (element 94), and of elements 95 and 96, americium and curium.

Tomorrow morning at 8 o'clock the Adirondack fish car, with some 12,000 rainbow and brown trout, will pull in at the Brewster railroad station and begin unloading these trout for the stocking of several watershed lakes and streams.

Application of the directors of the Continental Bank Trust Company to sell the bank's assets to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been approved by Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, it was announced last night.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday of an issue of $3,000,000 of Harris County (Tex.) Flood Control District bonds due on each March 1 from 1949 to 1963 at a bid of 100.845 for 3s, an interest cost of 2.643 per cent.

Five hundred fathoms down, under the blue waters of the South Pacific, the scarred old hulk of the battleship Pennsylvania rests quietly today, her duties completed, her day gone. What neither the Japanese nor two atomic bombs could accomplish was done by sixteen United States Navy men who opened her sea cocks and removed the plates on her condensers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- Maybe the gentleman was merely whistling to keep up his courage, but one Bucky Harris never has been known to be short in that commodity. Be that as it may, the Yankee skipper made it clear today that, considering the problems confronting Joseph V. McCarthy, he wouldn't trade shoes, or ball clubs, with Marse Joe for anything in the world.

With the cold weather giving no encouragement to the sale of low-end and popular price dresses, manufacturers' despondency over poor business reached a new low during the week, a survey of the market revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The House Appropriations Committee stepped away from the Congressional battle over civil rights today, but in a way which virtually assured a floor showdown on equal rights in education and employment early next week.

The recommendation by the General Assembly to the Security Council of the United Nations for the partition of Palestine was a mistake. First, because, though it was only a recommendation, Arabs and Jews alike assumed that recommendation to be a binding decision of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman returned from his Caribbean tour and vacation today deeply tanned and rested and met with his Cabinet for the first time in more than two weeks.

Reconstruction of the ten-story apartment building at 362 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 109th Street, into smaller suites for sale to war veterans on a cooperative basis will result from the sale of the property yesterday by the Estate of John C. Wellwood to Group Homes, Inc. The present lay-out of forty-three apartments will be converted to 140 units of one and one-half to four rooms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will begin operation of a West Coast frequency modulation radio transmitter in May under the call KMGM, the studio announced today. The new transmitter and an associated broadcasting studio will be located at the summit of Coldwater Canyon, between Beverly Hills and North Hollywood, and, because of the transmitter's elevation, the project is regarded in the trade as a possible precursor of Metro's entry into the television field.
Wine has an ancient and honorable history where fish cookery is concerned. Lent seems a good time not to forget that a dash of sauterne can add a bit of glory to the humblest haddock.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Department of Commerce twice defied the House Committee on Un-American Activities today, declining either to surrender the loyalty files of Dr. Edward U. Condon or to give any testimony materially connected with them.

After a week of pleading for cooperation to make successful the plan to relieve traffic congestion in the garment sector by staggering truck pick-ups and deliveries, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander publicly warned the industry yesterday that if necessary "we will force cooperation by applying the regulations."

In line with the program of equipping its inhabitants to compete more successfully in the world's labor market, the Government of Puerto Rico will open soon the largest industrial arts school in the world, it was said yesterday.
LONDON, March 5 -- The conference on Western Germany will end tomorrow when the pall of secrecy will be raised and an agreed communique issued.

An eight-day conference of the Youth for Christ International will start at 11 A.M. tomorrow at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. Sessions will be held at 3 and 7:30 P.M. daily, except next Saturday. Dr. Torrey M. Johnson, president of the organization, will speak tomorrow morning.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -- The screening stage was reached today in the training camp of the Giants. With five days of systematized exercising behind them the Polo Grounds squad enters tomorrow upon the competitive grind through thirty-nine spring exhibition games calculated to fashion the pennant threat.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Marty Furgol of Brooklyn and Al Smith of Winston-Salem, N.C., shot 3-under-par 68's to share the opening-day lead in the sixth annual Gainesville open golf tournament.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Bills embodying the Young Commission recommendations for the establishment of a state university and the outlawing of racial and religious discrimination in college admissions were introduced today under bipartisan sponsorship.

JERUSALEM, March 5 -- The Haganah forces in a night attack on Arab forces at Bir Adas, five miles north of Petah Tiqva and near Tel Aviv, killed fifteen Arabs belonging to a band that had been attacking Jewish settlements, Jewish sources reported today.

ATHENS, March 5 -- As the matter of the mass abductions of children from northern Greek villages by the Markos rebels became of growing concern here, Cortas Rentis, Minister of Public Order, said today his Ministry possessed positive information that the rebels planned to kidnap 15,000 children from the Florina area.

The "abandonment" of a project to build a large housing community in the west Bronx was made known yesterday by Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company. He cited the case as typical of the way large investors in building will react if Mayor O'Dwyer's proposals for increasing realty taxes are adopted. Mr. Dowling was host at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel, attended by leaders of civic and business associations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 5 -- A New York State stripped of agricultural resources because of the drain on top soil from farms for road construction, landscaping and similar uses was visualized today at the closing session of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States meeting here.

VIENNA, March 5 -- Foreign Minister Dr. Karl Gruber told the Executive Committee of the Austrian Parliament today that before Austria could expect or accept a treaty her 1937 frontier must be established beyond dispute and she must be allowed to begin now by rebuilding of an Austrian Army capable of protecting them.

Taking cognizance of hundreds of complaints of "insolent" taxicab drivers refusing to carry passengers on long interborough hauls, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander ordered yesterday that cabs display a sticker noting that the law requires them to drive to any location within the city.

LONDON, March 5 -- Another royal tour was announced tonight. King George, accompanied by Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret, will go to New Zealand and Australia early next year on the first visit ever paid by a reigning British sovereign to those most remote of the British Dominions.

Conditions governing the contemplated merger of the Home Insurance Company and nine fire-marine insurance companies affiliated with it were made known yesterday in a letter from Harold V. Smith, president of Home Insurance, to stockholders of the companies involved.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Terms of the long-negotiated international wheat agreement, to be signed by this country tomorrow as the first of thirty-six signatory nations, were disclosed unofficially today.
A Holy Cross basketball team heading for the defense of its N.C.A.A. championship had a brisk workout in beating the New York A.C., 80 -- 37, in the Winged Foot gymnasium before 1,000 last night.

Clarence R. Knickman, president of the Jamaica Real Estate Board, in an investment purchase has acquired the four-story thirty-nine-family garden type apartment building at 82-60 116th Street, southwest corner of Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, from Stately Builders, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, in a significant speech on the Jammu and Kashmir situation, informed the Indian Parliament today that the Maharajah, Sir Hari Singh, ruler of Jammu and Kashmir, had appointed Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah state Premier at the head of an interim "popular" government.

A jamming session that had promised to produce the best riding of the six-day bicycle race to date ended abruptly at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night when the Torchy Peden-Bill Anderson combination suffered the most serious spill of New York's sixty-seventh such grind.

PRAGUE, March 5 -- A public announcement was made for the first time today that in the new cleansed Parliament, all deputies supporting the Government will sit together in the plenary session, indicating the formation of a front organization that will largely replace the political parties as it develops.

LONDON, March 5 -- First indications of a break in the deadlock over the British tax on American films was reported today. Negotiators for American producers and the British Government were said to have agreed upon elimination of the 75 per cent ad valorem duty upon imported films.

IN the reign of Ivan the Terrible, the first of the Muscovite princes to call himself Czar of all the Russias, an English traveler and adventurer, Anthony Jenkinson, who made a journey from Moscow to Bokara, asked a pertinent question that other observers have been asking ever since: "How could the Russes show compassion to other nations when they are not merciful to their own?"

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts, himself a Republican, said tonight that responsibility for American military unpreparedness in a deteriorating international situation must be placed "squarely on the doorstep of the Republican leadership in Congress."

Mullens Manufacturing Corporation, maker of Youngstown kitchen equipment, will back a strong fall promotional drive with a heavy campaign of local newspaper advertising, Marshall Adams, advertising manager, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Herbert K. Sorrell told a House Labor Subcommittee today that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios hired Culver City, Calif., policemen for $32 a day for protection during a 1946 strike.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senate leaders abandoned today their plan to bring the European recovery measure to a final vote next week as sponsors of the bill prepared to meet an organized effort to cut the first year's authorization to $4,000,000,000.

In an editorial, "The American Islands," in THE TIMES of Feb. 24 you say: "There is one further step in the self-determination of Puerto Ricans that should not be delayed too long. That is to give them the right, in a plebiscite, to decide their own political status.

In an article in THE TIMES of March 2, concerning an attack on Dr. E.U. Condon, the eminent physicist and Director of the United States Bureau of Standards, a subcommittee of the Committee on Un-American Activities it quoted as follows: "There is no evidence that Dr. Condon is a member of the Communist party.

Sevellon Brown, editor and publisher of The Providence (R.I.) Journal and Bulletin, was elected chairman of the advisory board of Columbia's American Press Institute for the 1948-49 academic year at the board's annual meeting, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, March 5 -- Difficulties with the Imperial Diet are preventing the new wage-price stabilization procedure planned by Gen. Douglas MacArthur from coming into effect before the beginning of the new fiscal year on April 1.
ATLANTA, March 5 (AP) -- Gov. M.E. Thompson used four prisoners today to demonstrate his belief that this state did not fear mob violence.

Results of operations of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries, in 1947, made known yesterday, showed a net income for last year of $120,009,760 after depreciation and obsolescence, a $68,720,000 provision for Federal income taxes and a reserve of $20,900,000 for excessive construction costs.

ROME, March 5 -- The dollar rose to 695 lire today, this being the highest quotation reached since last November, when artificial exchange rates were abolished and the lira was left free to find its true level.

For some time recently rumors have been prevalent that Britain, Belgium and Holland were planning a simultaneous devaluation of their currencies. So far as Britain is concerned, however, the report, according to Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's economic generalissimo, is "complete nonsense."

ATHENS, March 5 (AP) -- After five days of heavy fighting Greek Army troops captured Kakavi on the Greek-Albanian border, a press dispatch said today. The action marks a major gain in the Epirus campaign, which has been under way for ten days.

The Association of Dealers in American Art will sponsor a multiple exhibition of living American art in sixteen New York galleries from March 22 to April 3 for the benefit of Artists Equity Association.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 5 -- An additional professional touch was added to the Dodgers today with the arrival of the two veterans, 36-year-old Arky Vaughan and 34-year-old Cookie Lavagetto. Traveling by train from California to New York, the pair spent twelve hours last night on the airways and checked into the hotel about 10 o'clock this morning.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5 -- The principle that women should receive the same pay as men for equal work was adopted today by the Social Committee of the United Nations after protracted debate.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Devices ranging in diversity of purpose and design from shock absorbers to hand grenades, from lighting and landing gear for airplanes to a drainage system for stables, and from an adding machine to a toy ferris wheel, were among the 452 inventions listed in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office -- a high number.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Speedy Congressional passage of the Vandenberg-Connally Bill for European Recovery was urged today by the committee for the Marshall Plan, made up of about 206 leaders of public opinion all over the United States.

ROME, March 5 -- It is full spring in Rome and the old city is flooded with life and light. Cafe tables are pushed out on the sidewalks and people sit sipping real coffee, the first in years. The long-idle fountain in front of the railway station spouts and sparkles again for the incoming traveler.

Rug cleaning plants this year will do a business of $5,000,000, an increase of more than $1,000,000 compared with 1947, Jerome Eisenberg, president, New York Rug Cleaners Institute, predicted yesterday. Interviewed during the group's annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel, he estimated 1947 volume of its forty-four member plants at between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today discharged Harry Bridges from his appointive post as CIO regional director in northern California.

American foreign policy -- particularly the Marshall Plan -- was assailed yesterday as "Taft-Hartleyism on an international scale" by delegates to the final session of the seventh convention of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended Paul J. Eakin, an allied member and a partner in the firm of Hornblower Weeks, for six months and censured Percy W. Brown for violation of Exchange rules.

The Police Department swore in 325 probationary patrolmen, twelve of them sons of policemen, in a ceremony yesterday afternoon in the line-up room at Police Headquarters. The oath was administered by Vincent E. Finn, chief clerk. Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander made a brief welcoming talk.
LONDON, March 5 -- Denial that currency devaluation was contemplated, together with the possibility of labor troubles in the Rand, caused a setback in gold shares in the stock market here today.

The Maytag Company, producer of washing machines and other home appliances, had last year the largest sales and earnings in its fifty-five-year history and more than doubled the corresponding results for 1946, Fred Maytag 2d, president, told stockholders in the annual report mailed yesterday.

A tentative agreement ending the threat of a strike against 120 of the principal Broadway and neighborhood motion picture theatres was reached early yesterday morning, after a nineteen-and-a-half-hour conference between representatives of the theatres and Local 306, Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, AFL.

Dr. Juraj Slavik, Czechoslovakian Ambassador to the United States, who resigned when the Communists took control in his native land, appealed last night to all Czechs in the free countries to extend a helping hand to the "martyrs of freedom and democracy."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Long shots fared well at Tropical Park today and the featured Rataplan Purse provided one of the milder surprises when Seaton Pippin, a 6-1 shot, earned a photo triumph.

Seton Hall College, in South Orange, N. J., announces the start of construction work on its educational frequency modulation station, WSOU. Msgr. James F. Kelley, president of the college, advises that studios for the station are expected to be completed within thirty days, with the transmitter going on the air in mid-April.

PARIS, March 5 -- The "Wallace Plan," as opposed to the Marshall Plan, is expected to be approved by the executive committee of the World Federation of Trade Unions, meeting in Rome on April 30, according to opinions expressed today at WFTU headquarters here.

E.M. (Ted) Edwards and William E. Lingelbach Jr. of Philadelphia will defend the national amateur court tennis doubles title today against Ogden Phipps, the singles champion, and Alastair B. Martin, runner-up for the crown, at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 5 (UP) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, commander of the most potent military force in the Arab world, called upon the Islamic world today to avenge the murder of Imam Yahya, aged ruler of the Arabian kingdom of Yemen.
SEOUL, Korea, March 5 -- Subcommittee No. 2 of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea, which has been consulting Korean leaders, issued today a statement in which it charged:

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has placed orders for two more super tankers, each with a capacity of approximately 228,000 barrels, it was announced yesterday. This order increases to six the number of such tankers contracted for by the company within the last four weeks.

When the new year has trekked along far enough so that two moons have waxed and sailed among frost-bright stars, there comes the first real hint of spring. Sometimes January sends a respite of transitory delusion and a thaw temporarily loosens the taut crust. But there is no question about the intent of this message.

JERUSALEM, March 5 -- Arms and ammunition purchased in European countries by the Jewish Agency for Palestine are being concentrated in Mediterranean ports "on a large scale" ready to be shipped to Palestine for arrival on May 16, the day after the end of the British mandate administration, an Agency spokesman disclosed today.

The executive committee of the Columbia University Student Council charged yesterday that Columbia's plans to increase tuition fees one-third and room rents 17 per cent were unjustified in view of what the student group termed "the university's reserve fund of $3,500,000 and its policy of deficit financing."

Returning to Carnegie Hall after a five-year absence, John Charles Thomas proved last night he could still touch the hearts of his most callous listeners. Although his voice has lost some of its richness with the passage of years, he has retained the unique ability to make singing sound like super-expressive talking, without loss to musical values.

Lord Beaverbrook, British newspaper publisher and former Cabinet member, said yesterday that the Marshall Plan is "splendid for Europe," but so far as Britain is concerned, "it is my hope that she will stand on her own feet."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Government attorneys today declared that the Taft-Hartley Law's ban against expenditures by labor unions in connection with Federal elections permissibly limited Constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech and of the press.

An Assembly committee at Albany, unmoved by Fort Clinton's claims to historical interest, has killed the bill that would have permitted New York City to cede land at the Battery to the Federal Government for restoration of the erstwhile fort, immigration station and aquarium. This presumably dooms any prospect now of passing the bill.

PARIS, Saturday, March 6 -- By a vote of 301 to 285, the French National Assembly early today refused to abrogate the special anti-inflation tax that Finance Minister Rene Mayer had maintained was an integral and essential part of his recovery program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Commercial exports dropped in January to the lowest value since November, 1946, the Commerce Department reported today. Commercial exports are those paid for in cash, including cash from nations borrowing from the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5 -- Following is the amended United States resolution on the Palestine question, voted on by the United Nations Security Council today. The sections in italics were rejected.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Pullman Company today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission what was in effect a notice of intention to increase certain charges for its "luxury accommodations" in April.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The National Association of Manufacturers, abandoning hope for enactment at this time of its own tax program, endorsed the House-approved Knutson Bill today as "a step in the proper direction."

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Election of the President and Vice President of the United States by popular vote was recommended unanimously today by a House Judiciary subcommittee in a deliberately aimed blow at minority influence on major party policies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5 -- Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chief Zionist spokesman before the Security Council, contended today that the Jewish community in Palestine would be threatened with annihilation if the partition plan failed. In that event, the Jews of the Holy Land would have to act in the interests of self-preservation, he said.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 5 (AP) -- A compact field of eight colts, topped by William G. Helis' Salmagundi, was named today for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby on the final day of the meeting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company of Denver filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $25,000,000 of thirty-year debentures, due April 1, 1978, and 191,881 shares of $100 par value common capital stock.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- Dr. Howard E. Kershner of the International Children's Emergency Fund of the United Nations left for New York today. He had tried for more than six weeks to get a contribution of $10,000,000 from Argentina.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday an application for permission to increase gas rates for non-house-heating domestic consumers by approximately 24 cents a month for an annual revenue increase of $3,200,000.

The twenty-ninth annual indoor games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, will ring down the curtain on the track and field campaign at Madison Square Garden tonight. Showdown competition among most of the champions and leading performers of the banked-track season will feature the thirty-two event program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Department of Agriculture today was urged by its citizens' advisory groups to "continue and intensify its grain conservation effort, at least until the 1948 crops are harvested."

LOS ANGELES, March 5 -- Dispatching to Harry Bridges his walking papers as a CIO regional director, Allan S. Haywood, CIO director of organization, hinted today that early disciplinary action was in order for other politically recalcitrant units of the organization.

Denouncing the Revercomb bill for admission of displaced persons to the United States as totally inadequate, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, called yesterday for its defeat and urged passage of a bill to admit 400,000 displaced persons during the next four years, as proposed by President Truman.

The committee appointed in November by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to review cases of alleged police brutality in Harlem has been disbanded and a new group formed in its place to serve as an "advisory committee" to the Commissioner on Harlem affairs.

NANKING, March 5 -- Although the Government now holds less than five per cent of Manchuria, Gen. Wei Li-huang, Nationalist commander in Mukden, has informed American observers there that he could get 200,000 more troops in south Manchuria if he had supplies for them.
Seventy-five per cent of the fires on New York City piers are caused by carelessness in smoking, the General Insurance Council of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce has reported to Mayor O'Dwyer.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Dewey, in a proclamation issued today, declared that the recent Communist coup in Czechoslovakia had laid waste the life work of Thomas G. Masaryk, first President of the Czech Republic.

Two scientists, who have developed a sensitive test for poisons in the human blood, reported yesterday that all mental disorders liberate toxins into the blood and that they can be measured in quantity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5 (AP) -- The defeat of defending champion Pete Landry of McGill University spiced the opening rounds of the intercollegiate squash racquets championship which started today at Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium. Landry fell before R.H. (Adam) Foster of Harvard, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 11, in the last third-round match of the day.

Examination of the two games played in the first round of the tournament for the world chess championship at The Hague, the scores of which arrived from the Netherlands, show that Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, was at his best in the draw with Vassily Smyslov of Russia.

New York City needs $150,000,000 to modernize its hospitals. The emergency is so acute that the city can no longer postpone its responsibility to the sick, the aged and infirm, in the opinion of leading municipal hospital authorities interviewed during a survey of the city hospitals conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
GREENVILLE, Miss., March 5 (AP) -- The dangerous current of the swollen lower Mississippi River smashed the towboat Natchez against a bridge last night and thirteen crewmen are dead or missing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5 (AP) -- Art Valpey, new Harvard football coach, set the pattern tonight for the Crimson's 1948 gridiron attitude with the declaration: "I don't think there's a game on the schedule that can't be won."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active and closed 15 to 35 points net higher yesterday with the strength most pronounced in the near months.

The S.E. Nichols Company has purchased the one-story taxpayer building at 1275-1277 Broadway, Brooklyn, from J.S. Gould Son's Company and others for a new outlet in its chain of retail variety stores. The Brown Company and Abraham Yanoff were the brokers.
Mrs. Douglas Quick has been appointed chairman of the annual bridge party and tea to be given by the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church on March 30 in the Roof of the St. Regis.

With all signs pointing toward a definite improvement in the quota allocations of burlap to shippers in Calcutta, importers here are more confident that they will soon be able to fill their backlog of orders, it was learned yesterday.
ROME, March 5 -- The 400th ship bearing supplies under the post-United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation program arrived in Reggio Calabria today.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, world 3-cushion billiard champion, tonight defeated Ezequiel Navarra, young Argentinian invader, 50 to 35, in the third game of their 450-point challenge match. Hoppe now leads the South American cue stylist, 150 to 127.

A variety of new issues of securities is to come to market next week. It will include the first issue of first mortgage railroad bonds since December of 1946 -- $37,396,000 of twenty-year bonds of Central Pacific Railway Company, to come up for bidding on Tuesday.

Joseph Auslander, poet, writer and anthologist, and his wife, Audrey Wurdemann, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1934, have collaborated on a novel, "My Uncle Jan," which will be published by Longmans, Green March 24. It is a story about a Czech and his family and their life in Wisconsin.

The proposal by Bishop William T. Manning and several associates urging the establishment of an art center on the block between Thompson Street and West Broadway facing Washington Square Park received added support yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 5 -- Newspaper executives from two small cities testified in Federal District Court today in the Governments injunction suit against the International Typographical Union, AFL, to show a countrywide pattern of union pressure to increase wages without bargaining or making contracts.

Retail volume here this week just about held to last year's levels Department store sales were estimated as showing little change with snowstorms and cold weather holding down turnover of early spring goods.

Ten men seized by detectives Thursday in connection with the theft of $30,000 worth of merchandise from the Railway Express Agency were arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court on charges of grand larceny and acting in concert.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The National Catholic Welfare Conference News Service said today that Pope Pius had refused a dispensation for Danish Princess Anne, a Roman Catholic, to marry former King Michael of Rumania. Michael is a member of the Greek Orthodox Church.

Out on the West Coast a search is on for a star of the magnitude of John Garfield to replace him in the role of the Dutch sea captain in "Skipper Next to God." Mr. Garfield, it seems, cannot remain in the Jan de Hartog play much longer than three weeks because of film commitments.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, denied at a Senate hearing today that his department was blocking the development of Alaskan paper mills.

Elmer Bernstein, New York pianist, gave his first local recital last night at Times Hall before a large and responsive audience. The young artist proved, as yet, in the formative stage as technician and interpreter, but his work, though decidedly uneven, was fraught with promise.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- National headquarters of a movement to elect Gen. Douglas MacArthur President on the Republican ticket were set up today. Incidentally, the offices are right next door to the Republican National Committee on Connecticut Avenue.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the inspector generals of the Army and Navy have been utilized recently to investigate the publication in newspapers and magazines of so-called confidential or secret information.
The Coca-Cola Company yesterday reported that earnings were substantially larger in 1947 than in 1946, and declared an increased dividend on the common stock.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 5 -- Dr. J. Hillis Miller, who served as Associate Commissioner of Education for New York State from 1941 to 1946, was officially installed today as fourth president of the University of Florida.

TRENTON, N. J., March 5 -- Senator Albert W. Hawkes, denied support of the New Jersey Republican organization for re-election, retired today from the race with a bitter denunciation of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and other party leaders.

The cause of aid for the needy of foreign lands will be well served through the Laetare Sunday collection to be taken tomorrow in 15,000 Catholic parishes throughout the United States. Conducted by the Catholic Bishops of the country under the auspices of War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference, the drive will seek to raise at least $5,000,000 for the suffering people of Europe and the Far East.

The indignation about the treatment of Greek guerrillas expressed in the letter of Josephine E. Parker, in your issue of Feb. 25, would certainly be most justified if the information upon which it is based were corresponding to the facts. This, however, is not the case.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 5 (AP) -- Skiing was reported good today at twenty-two New York State centers. The State Commerce Department listed these snow conditions:
Further attempts to mediate the dispute between the Curb Exchange and Local 205, United Financial Workers, AFL, ended last night with the parties still in disagreement.

Thirty-nine championship regattas were listed on a tentative schedule submitted yesterday to club delegates and race chairmen at a meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- P.C. Keith, president of Hydrocarbon Research, Inc., of New York, told the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today that the Government should spend $1,000,000,000 immediately to promote production of synthetic liquid fuels instead of $400,000,000, as proposed in a House bill.

That old story about the farmer at the zoo who saw a giraffe for the first time and exclaimed: "There ain't no such animal!" occurs to one nowadays when one catches a glimpse of what is left of the Manhattan elevated railroad.

Larger awards covering less floor space is the trend in construction contracts, it was disclosed here yesterday by Thomas S. Holden, president of F.W. Dodge Corporation. Contracts awarded in the thirty-seven Eastern States between Jan. 1 and Feb. 15 amounted to $945,190,000, compared with $782,485,000 in the corresponding period of 1947, he said.

KANSAS City, Mo., March 5 (AP) -- The National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball opened its tournament to Negro players today to make sure of representation in the play-offs for the United States Olympic berth.

Customers are becoming increasingly interested in the care and performance of the fabrics they purchase, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by the Bureau of Retailing Research of the New York University School of Retailing.

GENEVA, March 5 -- The final text of the convention establishing an inter-governmental consultative maritime organization was approved today by a vote of 18 to 1 in the United Nations Maritime Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman issued an executive order today creating a board of inquiry in the labor dispute at the Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy laboratory. Negotiators reported some progress toward a settlement.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Harold Christoffel a former labor leader in Milwaukee who was convicted of perjury because he swore he was not a Communist, received a two-to-six-year prison sentence today. Defense lawyers said that they would carry the case to the Supreme Court if necessary.
Federal Judge William Bondy reserved a ruling yesterday on a petition by the American Communication Association, CIO, to compel Mackay Radio and Commercial Cables to enter into collective bargaining.
Religious leaders appealed yesterday for prayers for the success of the Sydenham Hospital campaign for funds to preserve the institution as a privately managed, interracially operated institution.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The National Security Resources Board has completed its organization chart, it was announced today by Arthur M. Hill, chairman. It came into existence last November 13.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 5 -- The Foreign Missions Conference of North America urged today that the United Nations General Assembly reconsider its plan to partition Palestine. It called on the Security Council to "appeal to all groups to avoid further hostilities while the question is being reconsidered."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- A new investigation of Harry Bridges is under way and a third attempt to bring about his deportation may result if the evidence warrants it, according to reliable sources here today.

LONDON, March 5 -- The Soviet Union refused today to accept the requirements of Austria as a basis for the settlement of its claims on German assets in that country and accused the three other members of the Council of Foreign Ministers of trying to wring "further concessions" on the peace settlement from Moscow.

Braving frigid temperature and icy winds without the comforts of present-day cars, drivers and passengers of fourteen ancient automobiles arrived yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Three of the four alleged alien Communists, who are in the sixth day of a hunger strike on Ellis Island, spent four hours off the island yesterday while their counsel tried in Federal Court to obtain their freedom. The prisoners returned to a hospital room late yesterday to resume their self-imposed fast after Federal Judge William Bondy had reserved decision on their petitions for release on bail pending the outcome of deportation proceedings.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 5 (AP) -- A majority of the Finnish Parliament favored tonight the opening of treaty negotiations with Russia, but opposed entering any fax-reaching military alliance.

PRAGUE, March 5 -- Jim Smith, United States delegate to the International Student Union here, issued a declaration today repudiating the use of his name in connection with a statement of the union on the suppression by the police of student demonstrations against the installation by President Eduard Benes of the new regime headed by Communist Premier Klemen Gottwald.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman recommended to Congress today the liquidation of the War Assets Administration by June 30 and the integration of the remaining task of war surplus disposal in the Federal Works Agency.

THE rock garden is invaluable to its owner. It provides the ideal setting for many beautiful plants which do not grow so well, or show up as favorably, on other parts of the property. Rocks are an emphatic foil for the small and minutely perfect flowers which many gardeners like, but find unsatisfactory in more open places.
BUENOS AIRES, March 6 -- President Juan D. Peron tomorrow will face his greatest electoral test since barely 55 per cent of the voters chose him as President in February, 1946.

SOUND, straightforward storytelling make this an entertaining novel of a modern marriage. Mary Kent, its leading character, is a woman of inherent goodness and integrity who finds herself married to an irresponsible young profligate.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Two recent strike threats at Oak Ridge, Tenn., prompted the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy today to schedule hearings opening Tuesday on methods of assuring continuity of production at atomic plants.

Retail trade here showed little change last week as compared with the corresponding period of last year. Department store volume was affected by adverse weather conditions which prevented expansion of consumer interest in spring merchandise.

MERWYN BLAKE, in his own opinion the brightest star in Australia's literary firmament, dies suddenly from causes which no one is able to determine until Inspector Napoleon Bonaparte takes over the investigation. Bony, as the inspector prefers to be called, is not accustomed to mingling with the literati, nor is he much impressed by the members of the coterie of which Blake was the leading spirit.
THE long-rumored appearance here next season of London's Sadler's Wells Ballet has definitely been called off. No suitable New York theatre is available.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- In a suit on file in the Federal District Court here, the Metropolitan Opera Association of New York asserts that there is more than coincidence in the name of the Metropolitan Opera Association of Chicago.

A SUITABLE planting for a slope or bank is one of the most difficult choices to make for the garden. Only a few of the various ground covers that will become established under trees, in shady corners and in front of shrubs are adaptable to the inclined area.

IN principal cities across the country, flower shows blossom forth at about the same time that New York sees the opening of its show at Grand Central Palace. Following is a brief description of some of the biggest of these spring exhibitions.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, opens a week of diversified auction offerings with a sale tomorrow and Tuesday of Japanese color prints, part two of the collection of the late Carl Schraubstadter, New York.
THE Erie Railroad expects to have in operation by May 1 what it describes as the most comprehensive mainline system of very-high-frequency radio telephone equipment yet installed by any railroad.

SLEUTHING is furthest from Peter Clancy's thoughts when he opens the trunk of what he thinks is his own car and finds a corpse neatly wrapped in a sheet. Thereby hangs a preposterous-sounding tale told by Mr. Forestall, the owner of the car, who says that the trunk should have contained a pig which he was going to barbecue.

TO promote the cause of racial tolerance, the United Automobile Workers made an animated color film based on a pamphlet on the same subject issued by an organization called the Public Affairs Committee, Inc.

LONDON. IN 1943, when Anglo-American cooperation on the battlefield produced its first triumph in Tunisia, General Eisenhower in a burst of optimism said: "Well, thank God, after this war I won't have to listen to twenty years of argument about who won the war!"

Emanuel Celler, veteran representative from the Fifteenth (Brooklyn) Congressional District, characterized yesterday as "absurd" the reports that had him withdrawing as a candidate for delegate to the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The State Department was pleased over the scope of the agreements announced today by the conference in London on Western Germany while at the same time being prepared for a strong Soviet protest against them.

OVER at the Theatre Guild they are making elaborate preparations to celebrate the fifth anniversary of "Oklahoma!" on March 31 and if the Guild's brass is inclined to get sentimental about the event, even the toughest cynic in Shubert Alley will not mind.

It was unjust of Cabell Phillips, in "That Baffling Personality, Mr. Wallace," to draw an analogy -- however oblique -- between Henry Wallace's ideas and aspirations for peace and universal well-being and Hitler's paranoiac striving toward war and murder.

TOMORROW the International Flower Show opens in Grand Central Palace. This thirty-second edition appears earlier than any previous show and more than ever marks a pause in the harsh winter. For a week at least spring will be found under one roof in Manhattan.

It is agreed by wise and informed persons that the United Nations is the only organization in the world which can prevent another world war. But this it cannot do until it has the means to enforce its decisions. To enable it to do so the Charter provides that it shall have under its control and at its command a military force.

ONE of the complaints frequently made about contemporary fiction is the prevalence of characters whom a great many readers can view only with indifference, distaste or disgust. Yet nothing would more quickly bring about a decline of interest in the novel than its invasion by a host of paragons of virtue.

The stock market closed moderately firmer in yesterday's abbreviated session, with selected issues strongest. Prices drifted within a narrow range. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the smallest in two weeks, the turnover aggregating 320,000 shares compared with 350,000 on the preceding Saturday.

Because of Arab violence against Jews in the British protectorate of Aden, the Joint Distribution Committee, 270 Madison Avenue, has appropriated $50,400 for emergency aid and relief of the Jews there, it was made known yesterday.
One year ago this week -- on March 12, 1947 -- President Truman in a special message to Congress enunciated the Truman Doctrine of "containment" of communism.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's track and field team, which was dethroned as the city's Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association's senior champion last year after winning the crown thirteen times in a row, yesterday regained its laurels at the twenty-first championship meet at Madison Square Garden.
Fifteen years ago last Friday -- on March 5, 1933 -- New Yorkers read this headline:
Things were calm again in Prague last week -- at least on the surface.

IN this psychological-thriller, the protagonist resembles "The Stranger" of Albert Camus' novel, but on a sub-human, bestial level. He is too ineffectual to be taken seriously, even when he kills. He is not sensitive enough to be pathetic, nor cowardly enough to be comic, nor infantile enough to be a case study.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 6 (UP) -- Public school teachers scaled down their immediate pay demands by more than 50 per cent today in a new effort to settle the city's twelve-day school strike.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, world's 3-cushion billiards champion, today defeated Challenger Ezequiel Navarra, Argentine titlist, 50 to 35, in 38 innings -- the shortest game of their 450-point match.

ALBANY, March 6 (AP) -- Members of two AFL unions voted tonight to end their strike at the Ten Eyck and DeWitt Clinton hotels and accepted a 10 per cent wage increase offered by management. Picket lines were withdrawn immediately.

RICHMOND, Va., March 6 (AP) -- The Democratic State Central Committee today condemned President Truman's civil rights proposals and requested that funds be withheld from the National Committee. The group commended Governor Tuck for his "courageous stand" against the Truman proposals.

THE year advances, and spring comes, bringing garden days. The steady retreat of snow leaves widening patches of earth; crows caw as they fly overhead; the peepers shrill their first concert. When they have given three and the bullfrogs start their bass music in the pond, spring is here to stay.

HANOVER, N.H., March 6 -- Trailing by 18 -- 14 at the half, Columbia cut loose with a rapid-fire second-period attack tonight to pull ahead of Dartmouth and win going away, 44 -- 35, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game before 2,000 fans in alumni gymnasium.

SOMEWHERE in England's "Middle West" there is and there is not a market-town called Elmbury. It and the villages which encircle it (Brensham is one of these) are as actual as any town in Barsetshire (both Mr. Trollope's and Mrs. Thirkell's), Wessex, or the Ridings of Winifred Holtby and Storm Jameson.

LONDON, March 6 -- The conference on Western Germany ended today with an agreement in principle to internationalize the economy of the Ruhr. An economic merger of the French zone with the United States and British zones also was brought somewhat nearer to accomplishment at these talks among the United States, Britain and France, in which Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg joined.

Mostly for political reasons, the bill introduced by Harold Knutson, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and passed by the House of Representatives by a vote of 297 to 120 (H.R. 4790) has been described and criticized as being unequivocally a tax-reduction measure.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Laboratory tests now are being used to tell whether a person has the makings of a business executive.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- An all-Western Europe military defense pact to back up American economic assistance under the European Recovery Program was urged today by a select House investigating team after it had appraised the United Kingdom's position in the present world picture.

On last Wednesday four men and two women were driven by heavily armed British police in armored cars from the Jerusalem airport to a small three-story building in a barbed-wire enclosure. The building was next to the King David Hotel (British headquarters). The new arrivals were not allowed in the hotel because the British thought their presence might endanger the whole headquarters.

A legislative battle reminiscent of that which marked passage of the Tariff Act of 1930 is expected on the extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act which expires on June 12. The foreign trade community would like to see the Act renewed without crippling amendments, but foresees considerable political controversy in the next three months.

Huge hoards of excellent quality scrap metal, estimated to be between 5,000,000 and 10,000,000 tons, are lying idle at industrial centers in western Germany because the owners of this vital steel-making ingredient are reluctant to consummate sales with British and American purchasers, it was found by a special mission of the United States Department of Commerce during its recent survey of Europe's scrap supplies.

ROME, March 6 (AP) -- Eugene Cardinal Tisserant confirmed tonight that Pope Pius had refused to issue a dispensation that would permit Michael of Rumania and Princess Anne to marry in the Catholic Church.

Hope for an ERP vote in the Senate this week died on Friday. It died largely under the oratory of Senator George W. Malone of Nevada, who used up all but half an hour of Friday's session. It was Mr. Malone's contention that "European governments care nothing about hungry people."

MUNICH, Germany, March 6 -- About 100 Czechoslovaks who fled into the United States zone during the past week are protesting against living in a displaced persons sons camp with Sudeten Germans whom they helped to expel from Czechoslovakia.

The Immigration Act of 1918 states that any aliens "who believe in the overthrow by force or violence of the Government of the United States * * * shall, upon the warrant of the Attorney General, be taken into custody and deported."

THAT curious fellow, the platypus, is the subject of this whimsical story. Neither fish nor fowl, he has a duck's bill, webbed feet, a fur coat and the sleeping habits of an owl. Obviously a queer duck, he wants to be accepted by the rest of the animal society.

BECAUSE most gardeners and even experienced farmers look upon pest control as an unpleasant task, they are inclined to defer necessary precautions until the damage is done. However, with the right materials and equipment, plus a schedule, pest control becomes a routine matter which will consume only a small part of the time allotted for gardening chores.
TUBEROUS-ROOTED begonias add some of the most brilliant and spectacular flowers to our summer gardens. Yet they are simple to grow.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- A coroner's jury today cleared Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati (Ohio) light-heavyweight boxer, in the death of Sam Baroudi, Akron and New York fighter, after their bout Feb. 20.

The recent acquisition of a file of seventeenth century English newspapers covering the period from 1646 to 1665, was announced yesterday by the New York Public Library. Lewis M. Stark, chief of the reserve division, called the addition to the rare books department the most important of the past year.

* * * A.H. Raskin performed a service by writing "The Unions Face a Leadership Problem." The fact that he exposes the political tyranny of the American Federation of Labor's leadership will lend new encouragement to those within its ranks who are endeavoring to democratize the organization. * * *

A GARDEN without a pool is like a good play without a star. For a pool can be the finishing touch that makes the garden a place of charm and beauty. Unfortunately too many small gardens lack this architectural detail which would set them apart from the ordinary garden.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6 -- By virtue of their performance in the fancy diving, Army's swimmers defeated Navy 39 to 36 today.
A SWEDE wended his way into the buffet car of a long-distance train in his native land. He wanted a bottle of beer to wash down the sandwiches he had brought with him, like the thrifty Swede he was.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 6 -- Rumania will nationalize her mines, oil and mineral rights, transport, telegraph, telephone and radio services under a draft constitution published today. The draft is expected to be approved by the Constituent Assembly early in April.

ROME, March 6 -- Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma will receive a Vatican dispensation to marry former King Michael of Rumania only if she and Michael sign a written pledge to raise their children as Catholics, Vatican circles said today.

SALVADOR'S promised series marking the centenary of the death of Manuel Jose Arce (1783-1847) has been received by Leon Monosson. In values and colors of 8 centavos blue for postage use and 12c green, 14c rose and 1-colon brown-violet for air mail, the stamp bears Arce's portrait above the inscription "Procer de la Independencia y Primer Presidente de Centro America (Outstanding Figure of the Independence and First President of Central America)." Nicaragua'

MIAMI, Fla. -- America's newly created national park is still nature in the raw. During the few months since it was dedicated in December there has not been enough time -- or money -- to build lodges, roads, restaurants or the facilities for sightseeing that are a part of the older national playgrounds.

John Twomey, capturing the spotlight with a 4:13.1 mile; Phil Thigpen, George Guide and Curtis Stone were the cup-race victors last night in the twenty-ninth annual indoor games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus.

OSLO, Norway, March 6 -- Sweden, which dominated the Olympic cross-country events, gave another clear-cut demonstration of its supremacy today by sweeping the first five positions in the famous Holmenkollen eighteen-kilometer (11 1/4 miles) race.
WE heard the other day that owners of a certain farm near New York City are "very nice" about letting children visit their barnyard animals.

ROSES in all their glory of color and fragrance always draw eager throngs at the flower show. An admiring public looks forward to seeing this flower, which they have spontaneously made most popular of all, displayed to perfection.

THIS is the final week of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center, with the closing performance next Sunday. Naturally there are no novelties on the bill at this late date. Outside the Broadway district, Haydee Morini, dancer from Vienna, will make her American debut in a solo recital at the Barbizon-Plaza on Tuesday.

BY taking the Goldberg family off the air and pushing them on to the stage, Gertrude Berg has presented literature with quite a problem. Any first-year student of drama criticism can recognize "Me and Molly" as an inexpert play.

PARIS, March 6 -- The seizure of five tons of assorted arms, supposedly destined for the embattled Jews in Palestine, and the arrest of seven persons in connection with this illegal arsenal, were reported today by the Paris police.

WITH sure knowledge and an engaging sense of humor, the author has written a lively yarn about high school sports -- football, baseball, basketball, swimming, and even skiing. The young hero bears the unfortunate nickname of "Peeps," and is further handicapped in his struggle for athletic laurels due to the fact that his father was a famous athlete and is now a nationally known coach.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 6 -- Ch. Mighty Sweet Regardless, Boston terrier, scored another victory today when she won breed honors in the opening day's session of the show held in the Sixty-fifth Regiment Armory by the Kennel Club of Buffalo.

THE sections of seed and nursery catalogues devoted to "new and novelty flowers" contain a liberal sprinkling of outstanding introductions this year. Chosen from advance trials and tested for quality by leading growers, the new annuals and perennials may, in some cases, supersede older varieties.

A ONCE noted bridge player, whose reputation was based as much on the soundness of his bidding as on the regularity of his winning, was asked "When should you bid a grand slam?" He answered, "When you have at least fourteen tricks."

CHAMOIX, France, March 6 -- Frau Annelise Schuf Proxauf of Austria won the women's downhill race in Alpine combined competition of the Kandahar ski meet today, with pretty, pigtailed Andrea Mead, 15-year-old United States Olympic star from Rutland, Vt., sixth.

TORONTO, March 6 -- Penalties told a major part of the story as the Toronto Maple Leafs gained undisputed hold of first place in the National Hockey League tonight by downing the third-place New York Rangers, 2 -- 1, before 14,278 fans.

ALTHOUGH it is pleasant to think of lilies raising their trumpets above spires of campanula or masses of phlox, no lily bulb can flourish in the crowded conditions of the perennial border. They have to be planted where there is sufficient space for air to circulate so that leaves can dry quickly after rain or heavy mist, thus discouraging mold development.

Fire caused by a short circuit badly damaged four cars of a six-car wooden work train yesterday on the BMT tracks under Centre Street at the Criminal Courts Building, and stopped BMT service over Manhattan Bridge for an hour and for nearly two hours over Williamsburg Bridge.

THE hero and narrator of "Temper the Wind" is a somewhat unlikely young man named Floyd (Cowboy) Shandy. After the war Shandy returns home to the Wyoming town of Buell, gets a job driving a tow truck for a garage, takes up residence in a boarding house operated by a retired prostitute, and tries to work himself up as a fighter.

SET in Los Angeles, this novel of suspense hinges on the strange compulsion of Marine Major James Foraker to move the still warm, dead body of a strange woman, later identified as Letitia. Furthermore, the woman's necklace had been made by Foraker.

BOSTON, March 6 -- Any idea that Yale was strictly a one-man basketball team vanished into thin air tonight when the Elis routed Harvard, 80 -- 51, at the Boston Arena with very little assistance from their top scorer, Tony Lavelli.

CORNELIUS VAN TOLLER is a patron of the arts. So much so that he subsidizes "the most atrocious play Broadway ever conceived" and sits trough the performance nightly. The explanation for Van Toller's behavior lies in his obsession for Kay Forester, the leading lady.

In the orthopedic wards of a large New York hospital is a bright-eyed 13-year-old boy named Bruce who has been hospitalized for nearly two years as a result of infantile paralysis. He is recovering from what both Bruce and the orthopedic surgeons hope will be his last operation and will leave the hospital within a few weeks.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 6 -- Mel Ott unveiled two dozen members of his 1948 squad here this afternoon in a bold bid to lift the opening game of the inter-league spring series from the Cleveland Indians, but he had to come up with the twenty-fifth unit in a bewildering succession of changes before the Giants bagged the decision, 4 to 3.

The Massachusetts legislative proposal to make it a crime to teach communism in schools is certainly the worst way to meet the infiltration of communism in educational institutions. Such a law would simply eliminate honest courses in comparative political theory and embarrass some candid idealists. Several states already have such useless and unenforceable statutes.

The style of Prof. Paul A. Samuelson's "Deflation Need Not Mean Depression" violates the need, rigorously stressed in engineering colleges, for writing critical articles and reports with simple clarity. Rhetorical expressions like "frenetic rotations of this cry-wolf group," "counting embryos and not fryers," and other embellishments used lavishly throughout the article, obscure the salient points of discussion.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A group of Southern Democrats were ready, some said tonight, to "stand guard" against a move to bring any of President Truman's civil rights measures to the floor. They added that would be prepared "at a moment's notice" to filibuster any civil rights bill that might be brought forward.

After an absence of eight years from the local concert stage, Harriet Cohen, the English pianist, was heard late yesterday afternoon in a recital given at Town Hall. For the event she had prepared an unusual and engrossing program of early and contemporary works, in which she was assisted by a string ensemble conducted by Alfredo Antonini.

MARGARET BELL is a native of Alaska known for her exciting adventure stories of that country, "Pirates of Icy Strait" and "Danger on Old Baldy." Now she has written a novel, much of which is based on fact, of a young girl's sturdy pioneering in the Alaskan wilderness.

ATHENS, March 6 -- Panayotis Pipinelis, Greek permanent Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, said today that "Greece will, of course, remain faithful to the principle of freedom of worship in the Dodecanese Islands."

TROY, N.Y., March 6 (AP) -- Frolicking newspaper reporters who usually write serious political stories at Albany's Capitol waved Governor Dewey off to the White House at the annual show of the legislative correspondents tonight and installed Joe R. Hanley, Lieutenant Governor, as his successor in New York.
Cotton futures were moderately active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices fluctuated in a comparatively narrow range and closed unchanged to 9 points lower than the day before.

New York's Knickerbockers and Washington's Capitols battled through four periods to a 59-59 dead heat at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. But the "official" sign didn't go on.
