They went back on the court for another five minutes of skirmishing, and at the end of that time the New Yorkers were on top, 69 -- 64, in their penultimate game of the regular home season in the Baskteball Association of America.

THE canna -- darling of a bygone day -- shows signs of a revival in popularity. Newer varieties do not grow so tall and their flowers are less gaudy. Their display of bloom is magnificent and usually lasts from July until frost.
So spring is just around the corner. Close the book and open the window. Whew, feel that wind! Right off Hudson Bay. Shut the window and raise the curtain. A perfect day. Not a cloud in the sky.

THE subtitle of this book, "A Guide to Hobbies," is indicative of the treatment of its subject-matter. The author, an amateur botanist himself, regards the study of plants as a fertile field for an endless number of fascinating hobbies, from collecting seaweed to experimenting with a new chemical hormone which stimulates plant growth.
OMAHA, March 6 -- The Tide lands Bill, S-1988, introduced in Congress to benefit coastal states, has kicked up some unexpected opposition in this inland area.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The barometer of President Truman's popularity, which has registered some extreme fluctuations in the past, seems at the moment to be in a particularly depressed state. In view of the obvious imperatives of this election year, this is a matter of acute concern to his party.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Governor Dewey approved today the new state-aid-for-education program and accused its critics of unwarranted and inexcusable distortion of the facts as to New York's financial contribution for the support of schools.

MR. HUBLER has staked out for his quiet kingdom a small, isolated group of coral islands in the British West Indies, the Inaguas. Here a British lady reigns firmly but justly over her two pretty daughters and several hundred Negro fishermen and salt-farmers and their families. For recreation Dame Scott knits, reads Ambrose Bierce and writes a history of her quaint matriarchy.

LONDON, March 6 (Reuters) -- Gallant Queens Park Rangers suffered the loss of Goalie R.A. Allen in the first half of their sixth-round Football Association Cup replay with Derby County and fell before the highly rated Midlanders, 5 -- 0, in the feature game of today's soccer program.
FLOWER SHOW WEEK, which starts officially at noon tomorrow when the International Flower Show opens at Grand Central Palace, is chosen by many horticultural organizations for special meetings.

The traditional enmity between the fly fisherman and the bait fisherman, which waxes and wanes with the seasons, often has resulted in debates which reached the shouting stage within a few minutes, but today both these schools seem to have united in waging war on the man with the spinning outfit.

HOWARD THORNTON, my neighbor, is not talkative. We have been acquainted for a good many years -- grange meetings, church suppers, an occasional chat on the post office steps. At such times there isn't much to say.

THOMAS WOLFE received very little serious critical attention in his lifetime. An essay by the late John Peale Bishop, "The Sorrows of Thomas Wolfe," probably remains the best thing that has yet been written about his work.

NO rationalist in one of Mr. Heard's stories can long ennjoy the complacencies of modern materialism. Sooner or later, on some dark night in a village lane or a deserted Norman chapel, he becomes aware of a Presence breaking through an "awful rent in the safe net and curtain of the everyday world."

ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 -- Swinging into high gear in the drive through the stretch, the favored Salmagundi captured the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby in a photofinish with Call Bell today as Santa Anita Park ended its 1948 horse racing meeting.

SEVERAL species of phlox more than do their share to make gardens gay during April and May. Discriminating use of these early flowering kinds lend engaging color to many spots, from the problem bank near the garage to the flower border itself.

A SERIES of weekly tours to Virginia gardens and other points in the Midsouth is announced by the American Express Company. The first trip is scheduled to leave New York on March 27. Stops will be made at Williamsburg and Yorktown and at the Caverns of Luray.

The shipping industry here is watching with interest the progress of legistlation introduced in Albany last week which would make mandatory the fingerprinting of all private guards and watchmen employed on this city's waterfront.
THIS is the height of the season -- coming to an end in a week -- when a strange and unusual commodity is being dispensed at a great rate in drug stores, barber shops and bars all over America.

IN these days when progress is thought of in terms of supersonic and jet propelled travel, it is refreshing, and somehow highly reassuring, to recall through Robert Denhardt's work that the modern American republics owe their rapid expansion and advancement to the use of horse power, the non-electrical type.

ALL annual flowers share the happy trait of blooming the first year from seed, but they vary a good deal among themselves in the exact number of weeks they take. Some need to be started now if they are to blossom by midsummer. Others wait until April and May.

The Arab Office in Washington announced yesterday that the Government of Trans-Jordan had ended an unofficial mission of Omar Dajani, who had been the center of stories that King Abdullah was negotiating to take over the Arab part of Palestine under the partition program.

BRUNSWICK, GA. -- Jekyll Island, for sixty-one years an exclusive retreat for Eastern millionaires, last week officially became a "paradise for plain people." The Golden Isle, which the State of Georgia acquired by condemnation for $715,000, was opened to the public with no ceremony but with near-capacity crowds for its hotel, clubhouse and cottages.

The independent secondary school aids democracy by development of leadership among selected students, John F. Gummere, headmaster of the William Penn Charter School in Philadelphia, declared yesterday. He spoke at the twenty-second annual conference of the Secondary Education Board, representing 288 institutions, in the New Yorker Hotel.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 (AP) -- The Big Four began today a study of what to do with Libya, a potential base of United States and British power to resist communism in Europe.

FOR the beginning craftsman, who is likely to find his first efforts in design lacking in interest and originality, here is a fine elementary guide in this particular aspect of the field of arts and crafts. With the use of a few simple motifs, the author sets down a basic procedure for the development of good design.

Activity in retail department stores last week was brisk, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Leaders, according to the reports, were dresses, millinery, blouses, sportswear and lingerie.

AS an area grows from the frontier or colonial stage toward maturity, it passes through a period of literary "regionalism." This is an ethnocentric and adolescent phase, vigorous and ambitious and given to manifestoes.

Sharply lower backlogs in key industries have set up warning signals which are being heeded in some important durable goods lines, spokesmen for multi-billion dollar interests revealed here yesterday.

LIGHT and shadow filtering through trees and playing over a shaded flower border, perhaps highlighting glistening snowdrops in early March, make a charming picture. Such a setting, however, does not just happen.

HOME-OWNERS without fruit trees are apt to regard rather enviously those they see blossoming in a near-by orchard in spring. Yet thinking they have neither the space for such a project nor the time to devote to it, they just go right on looking, doing nothing.

Czechoslovakia and Palestine demonstrate that adherence to religious and democratic ideals in international affairs, rather than reliance on the diplomacy of expedience, is necessary to lead the world to peace and security, rabbis declared yesterday in sermons here.

IT is almost impossible to imagine a garden without shrubs. Flowering kinds particularly add so much to the property that they are essential to the list of choices to be considered at spring planting time.

While definitive action on the European Recovery Program was stimulated last week because of the grave situation abroad, traders in commodities and securities continued to act cautiously. Both markets, however, showed firmer prices, but wheat broke at the week-end. Not in a generation, except for war, have we been faced with so many uncertainties.

THIS volume, which explains step by step twenty-eight popular needlecrafts, is designed for the novice, the experienced needlewoman, the student, the teacher, and even the professional designer. Fourteen color plates and over 1,000 black-and-white photographs and drawings are included to assist the reader to understand the art.

Two years of the Treasury's program for retiring the war-swollen Government debt has been completed. Initiated on March 1, 1946, the campaign, which was the first large-scale attempt in more than fifteen years to whittle the debt, has continued interruptedly.

Another snowstorm was headed for New York yesterday and was expected to reach here early this morning. But the snow will likely be short-lived and will be replaced by rain by afternoon if not sooner. The amount of snowfall is not expected to be sufficient to hamper travel, though driving conditions may be bad because of combined snow and slush.

IN "East of Fifth," Alan Dunn presents a lively picture-and-text comment on apartment-house life in New York City. This little book is, in its own modest way, unique. Without sacrificing the crispness that marks his New Yorker work, Mr. Dunn has managed to combine with it the sort of journalistic approach that movie-makers call documentary.
Charles E. Bohlen, counselor to the State Department and its expert on Russian affairs, delivered yesterday a strong attack on the opponents of the European Recovery Program.

"BASIC," "indispensable" and "backbone of the flower garden" are words that define ten kinds of perennials that can be ordered now and set in the garden next month. The big ten will bloom beautifully, year after year, with a minimum of care.

MANY a fine spring plan for a Freedom Garden can be made even finer by the addition of a few herbs. The vegetable plot's raw utilitarian look is thus tempered, and decorative effects are worked out with herb edgings and interplantings.

THOMAS McGRATH, in this collection of forty poems, has continued the tradition of the English poets of the Thirties with their deep concern for those disturbing elements of social life -- poverty, injustice and war. But he does not suffer from some of their weaknesses which Virginia Woolf describes in her essay on poets of the "Leaning Tower."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 6 -- All Western Germany and many other areas are noting with satisfaction the unprecedented post-war coal production figures in the Ruhr. Yesterday a new occupation record of 291,000 tons for a day was established. Possibly Monday, but certainly during the next week, the long-sought production of 300,000 tons a day is anticipated.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A three-point Congressional action program was recommended today in the annual report of Education Commissioner John W. Studebaker to Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing.

ROSES appear high on the list of plants ordered every spring. Although it may be another month before they can be set in the ground, it is none too soon to start looking over and selecting from among the many kinds listed in the catalogues.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 6 -- A capacity crowd of 5,500, that included high-ranking officers of the service, saw Navy send Army's basketball team down to a 49-36 defeat at the field house court today to end the season for both squads.
TELEVISION, in some instances, is showing highly commendable indications of not offering obeisance to the traditional radio taboos.

THIS collection of short cuts and "tricks of the trade" is not the work of one, or even a group of editors. It is a collection that has been gathered by hundreds of readers and workers who wish to share their ideas with others who build and make things.

WHAT with the motion-picture people being sorely oppressed just now with headaches of major proportions and anxieties of worse ones yet to come, ranging broadly from the loss of foreign markets to the possible loss of their jobs, it may seem a trifle unsporting for this reviewer to come bouncing in, loudly blowing a figurative whistle and pounding noisily on our favorite message-drum.

TO Manhattan dwellers springtime is symbolized by the return of old dobbin pulling his flower cart through the less fashionable sections of the city, while his driver calls out in uninspired tones, "Plants for sale!"

VISITORS who spend a month or more at the shore can get woefully weary of sea and sand and sun. Before long they find themselves yearning for light that is filtered through green leaves, or for the simple luxury of a few annuals on the luncheon table.

The redbird's function in life obviously is to make this a better world to live in. A more beautiful world, one with more delight to the ear and eye. His whistled song can light up a gray sky and bring brightness to a dull morning. His color itself, one of the richest reds in the whole bird kingdom, can lift the heart and make it sing.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Truman attended tonight the annual dinner of the White House Correspondents' Association. Among the 700 guests were members of the Cabinet and of Congress, ranking Army and Navy officers, publishers, editors and reporters.

A drive to obtain the cooperation of the sixteen Marshall Plan countries of Europe to return iron and steel scrap to this country was opened last week by the five billion dollar foundry industry, L.E. Roark, executive vice-president of the National Founders' Association, revealed here yesterday in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Immediate enactment of Federal legislation to prevent discrimination in employment because of race, religion, color or national origin was urged last night at a dinner for officials of the National Council for a Permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DANIEL BERKELEY UPDIKE, in his fourscore years and one, made a distinguished contribution to the development of printing, both as art and as successful business. In 1893, after a brief term of service with Houghton Mifflin Company and the Riverside Press, he "hung out his shingle as a typographic adviser."

Argument on a taxpayer's suit to restrain the New York City Housing Authority from proceeding with Woodside Houses, a low-rent veterans project planned with city guarantees and subsidies in the Woodside section of Queens, will be heard in Supreme Court, Jamaica, next Friday.

EIRE has exchanged a tall, gaunt, world-renowned Prime Minister, whose avocation is very abstruse mathematics, for a short, broad-shouldered one, comparatively unknown in international dealings but whose vocation as a barrister has made him an unparalleled reputation in Dublin, where the bar is unusually dignified and honored.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 6 (UP) -- The city school system today virtually banned Scholastic Magazine, a national weekly for high school students, because of its purported stand for President Truman's civil rights proposal. Members of the Board of Education alleged that the editors had lined up politically with Mr. Truman's "anti-South" program.

Although many third-party movements have preceded the current one led by Henry A. Wallace, only one has managed to develop into a major and permanent party. The one successful group was the Republican party, which displaced the Whig party.

JERUSALEM, March 6 (AP) -- In Jerusalem today a station wagon belonging to the United States Consulate was held up and stolen from in front of the Damascus Gate to the Old City by a band of armed Arabs. They stopped the car and forced Manuel Mitchell and another consulate employe named Swedenborg -- both Ameri cans -- the Arab driver and the messenger to leave the car.
The problem of preserving essential military secrecy in the atomic age without infringing basic democratic freedoms cannot be solved by Government censorship, no matter in what guise.

THERE is no major work by Michelangelo in America. But at the Metropolitan Museum there is a red chalk drawing -- a study for the "Libyan Sibyl" of the Sistine ceiling. In this one feels the grandeur of the master, the bigness of his conception, the certainty of his means.

MILLIONS of American youth know something of the services of Kosciuszko to our nation during its fight for freedom; few are aware of the struggles of his youth or of the defeats and frustrations of his old age. A fellow countryman, now residing in America, has written a remarkably complete biography of the great Polish patriot.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A thirty-six-nation five-year wheat agreement putting a ceiling price of $2 a bushel on wheat exported by the United States, Canada and Australia was announced formally today by the International Wheat Council. It is subject to approval by the United States Congress and to ratification by the other governments concerned. If they consent, it will take effect on Aug. 1.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6 -- About twenty sparrows have become the first American birds to choose at least temporary citizenship in an international community on United States soil.

THE adventurous gardener who has planted some of the newer varieties of bulbs this year goes about with an air of anticipation. The bulbs have been highly recommended, but whether or not they will come up to expectation remains to be seen.
PRAGUE, March 6 -- Communism in Czechoslovakia has a one-word program: unity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- The employment of contract actors and actresses in the motion picture industry has dropped 37.8 per cent in the last year, it was disclosed today by the Screen Actors Guild.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 6 -- Eddie Stanky, whose aggressive spirit and hustling play have marked the Dodgers for three and a half years, today was traded to the Braves for Ray Sanders, first baseman, and an undisclosed bundle of cash.

"PATRIOTISM," it has been remarked elsewhere, in another connection, "is not enough." In Miss Sears' book, admirable in many ways for its reproductions of the works in her collection (she is the founder of Fruitlands and Wayside Museums, Inc., at Harvard, Mass.), there is an excess of that commodity.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

Acceleration of the trend toward lower textile prices will be apparent in the next sixty days, it was predicted in the trade last week. Rayon goods prices which have held firm until now at the primary levels will show considerable softness, observers said, if the dress manufacturing business does not take a definite turn for the better.
That article by Howard Taubman. "Were Singers Better in Caruso's Time?" has a familiar ring to it. It is not a very original story idea.

MARTHA OSTENSO has undertaken in her latest novel to present in cross-section a small Midwestern town, using the device of a milkman's route to introduce a variety of characters. Ben Start is the milkman, and one way or another he has seen into the lives of all these people. Ben, however, has his own problems.
LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today after the recess of the conference on the future of western Germany:

WHEN Actors' Equity let down the bars to the masses of theatre aspirants to climb over into its exclusive realms, it let loose a flood of unemployed, embryonic and other forlorn actors. This disillusioned group is now knocking at the doors of Equity companies and finding them closed.

IN tracing the pedigree of the ancient art of tying knots, Mr. Day takes into account the highly specialized nature of his subject and provides a diverting introduction that delves into the history, folklore and religious practices of peoples the world over from the Aztecs to the Zulus.

THIS coming week-end the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati will induct Dr. Nelson Glueck as its fourth president. Founded in 1875 by Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise for "the preservation of Judaism in the American scene," it is today the heart of Reform Judaism in this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 6 -- If the heavy gloom and skepticism of the atmosphere at Lake Success can be taken as a reliable barometer, the United Nations has already suffered a severe setback on the Palestine issue.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York will consider at its meeting on Tuesday at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, a report of its special committee on military justice. There is a sharp division of opinion in the association on the report and a vigorous fight on the floor is expected to develop.

PRAGUE, March 6 -- The Communist Foreign Trade Minister Antonin Gregor made today a gesture to reassure business men abroad in order to minimize the effect of recent events on Czechoslovakia's commerce and on the Prague Trade Fair this month.
Emanuel List, basso, who has been a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company since 1933, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

MARCH is the month when the gardener hopes to get his vegetable plot started. He keeps a sharp eye on the weather, because he knows that some crops will be most successful if they can be sown by the middle of this month or sometime early in April.

TO this reader "The Strong Room" offers disturbing evidence that the historical novelist in search of a hero is beginning to scrape the bottom of the barrel. Mr. Wheelwright writes about pre-Elizabethan England as briskly as the next man, knows just as much about sixteenth-century weapons, dress, penal methods, food and drink.

WHEN I was in Rome in 1945, on what I have since come to consider a kind of military scholarship extended to me by the War Department, I was lucky enough to meet and to work with Roberto Rosselini, the director of "Open City."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6 -- The legal experts have had their day in the debate on Palestine in the United Nations. American, British, Zionist and Arab lawyers, by the simple device of jumping through loopholes in the Charter and seizing or evading the parts of the Palestine resolution they like or dislike, have proved, to their own satisfaction, that each is right and the others are wrong.

MEASURED by shelter, protection, depth of water, shorefront mile- age, variety and beauty of shore and near-by countryside, opportunities for recreation, sites for residence and commerce, New York is the peer of American harbor cities. San Francisco is a close second, excelling, however, in sheer beauty and, thanks to the Japanese current, in all-year-round climate.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 6 (AP) -- Ohio State dethroned Illinois in a fight-to-the-wire finish as Buckeye Lloyd Duff gave the greatest Big Nine track and field performance since Jesse Owens, another Ohioan, in the thirty-eighth Western Conference indoor meet today.

THE Orchestre National of Paris, which is subsidized by the French Government, plans to come to this country next fall for a six-week tour that will open at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 17. Charles Munch will be the conductor in New York and on the road. The plan is to visit forty cities, including four in Canada.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Congress showed great interest this week in allegations of subversive connections maintained by one prominent individual -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, Director of the United States Bureau of Standards. On the other hand, the analysis of the global revolutionary aims of Soviet communism by a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee has been received with relative calm.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee moved today to look into some of the charges leveled by a House Un-American Activities subcommittee against Dr. Edward U. Condon, head of the Bureau of Standards of the Commerce Department.
The four alleged Communist aliens who have been on a hunger strike on Ellis Island for six days were released late yesterday on bail of $3,500 each.

Classroom lessons have proved harder than business for 46-year-old Arthur L. Thexton, who gave up a $30,000-a-year manufacturing position to begin work this year at Columbia University on a master's degree in political science.

A large number of the nation's public schools are failing to give their pupils adequate psychological guidance and counseling, according to a survey conducted by the Association of Psychologists of the New York City Public Schools.

WITHIN the past year a new crop of books on gardening and allied subjects has made its appearance -- perhaps a hundred or more titles. A selection is here offered of some thirty books of special significance to the amateur gardener.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, South Africa and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago were tied with Sam Byrd of Detroit and Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., after 39 holes in the opening round of the $10,000 international four-ball golf tournament today.

THE breadth and strength of contemporary American painting are illustrated anew in four of the current one-man shows by outstanding American artists. All four of these -- Lyonel Feininger, Russell Cowles, Raphael Soyer and Sidney Laufman -- are represented in many public and private collections and regularly in big national annual exhibitions.

PANAMA, March 6 -- A poster carried in the students' and workers' demonstration in Guatemala on Tuesday protesting Britain's possession of Belize, in British Honduras, and the presence of British cruisers in Belize waters, had the question, "Where is the United States' continental solidarity?" and its own reply, "With John Bull, the Pirate."

LOS ANGELES, March 6 -- California's drought, highlighting again the state's protracted feud with Arizona over division of Colorado River water, has had some unexpected results. Most spectacular among these has been a suggestion from an official quarter that California should seek its water from the sea.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6 -- Thanks to contributions from the Rotary International and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the United Nations has completed plans to bring forty students from as many member nations to work here as "internes" this summer.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 6 -- Delegate, sprint star of the Florida season, today found it an easy matter to stretch his speed to a mile and a sixteenth and capture the Coral Gables Handicap by five lengths at Tropical Park.

ROME, March 6 -- In a strongly worded editorial, l'Osservatore Romano today attacks Unita, the Communist party new_paper, for what it terms "ignoble speculation" on the case of the defrocked Msgr. Edoardo Prettner Cippico. He is the former minor official of the Secretariat of State who is being sought by the Vatican and Italian police for fraud and embezzlement.

THE passing of the front porch in recent years has been partly due to the rise of its modern counterpart -- the terrace. A terrace, as generally known, is an area of the garden, usually paved, often enclosed and normally adjacent to the house. A more accurate definition of it would be an "outdoor living room."

THE Warner Brothers, who have not been averse to lifting some of their sturdy old films off the shelves for "re-release" tours of the circuits, soon will be dusting off another trio, but with a slight twist. First on the revival docket is "The Adventures of Robin Hood," the 1938 Technicolor number in which Errol Flynn was the boss of Sherwood Forest and which arrives at the Warner Theatre on Wednesday.

GRAPHOLOGY, the art of character analysis through handwriting, is combined with photography in a new portrait idea introduced by Elli Marcus and soon to be exhibited publicly. Miss Marcus studies samples of her subject's script and from the knowledge of characteristics thus gained, tries to interpret her sitter's personality through pose, lighting and background. In making the print, she prints into the picture details of the script that have decorative and descriptive value.

Coordination of correctional policy by New York State, and specialized treatment for chronic alcoholics and sex offenders were among eighteen recommendations made to the Legislature yesterday in the 104th annual report of The Prison Association of New York.

Fifty women met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Seth M. Milliken, 951 Madison Avenue, in support of the Protestant Fund's campaign for $650,000 to bolster the community services of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., and the Protestant Council of the City of New York, Inc.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 6 (AP) -- Governor Dewey signed today two bills giving municipalities broader authorities to "protect" cooperative public markets operated by the Central New York and Lower Hudson Regional Market Authorities.
Among the many versions of the birth of Leap Year, I like this one best:

Wholesale markets last week were generally quiet, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey. Werring and Howell Company, resident buyers. Activity was highlighted, the report said, by a considerable number of orders for navy and skipper gabardine suits wanted in the better medium-priced ranges.

NANKING, March 6 -- The concern being displayed by American public leaders over the state of things in China constitutes an accurate reflection of the increasingly critical position of the Chinese Government. The Nanking regime is slowly losing ground militarily, economically and politically and its survival has come increasingly to depend on assistance from the United States.

HAVANA, March 6 -- An agreement on new preferences in a general settlement of the issue of economic development was approved today by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment in the subcommittee stage, subject to the outcome of the debate on the most-favored-nation principle.

Thirty-five hundred students representing elementary and secondary school newspapers are expected to attend the twenty-fourth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association starting on Thursday, Joseph M. Murphy, director of the association, announced yesterday.

The training of merchant marine officer personnel is falling far short of the steamship industry's needs, with the present facilities turning out fewer than one-half of the deck and engine department officers sought by American-flag companies, Rear Admiral R.R. McNulty, supervisor of the United States Merchant Marine Cadet Corps, said yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 6 -- The first large contingent of British forces evacuating Palestine -- about 1,000 troops of the Sixth Airborne Division and 500 policemen accompanied by 300 members of their families -- embarked at Haifa today aboard the Cunard liner Franconia.

SHANGHAI, March 6 -- The Government's Import-Export Board announced today a new measure to cope with the problem of continuing imports of acutely needed basic materials while conserving dwindling foreign exchange reserves.

A GREAT many gardeners moving into newly constructed homes this spring are apt to have a soil problem similar to the one we faced in our new home early in 1947. Of course, the problem will vary with the type of soil, the size of plot and the geographic location, but the application of certain fundamental principles will benefit any soil, whether it be located in Virginia or southeastern Connecticut.

A CUTTING garden is a term too often associated only with large estates. But for the owner of a small place usually planted with annual and perennial flowers, a cutting garden is an even greater asset. Why? Because half the fun of having a garden is being able to cut all the flowers you want.

The fate of the two key items in Mayor O'Dwyer's 1948 legislative "package" -- the higher fare bill and the bill to increase the city's real estate taxing power -- may depend upon the results of a conference to be held at Gracie Mansion this afternoon between Mayor O'Dwyer and Democratic leaders at Albany and the city's county units, it was indicated last night.
Raymond Daniell in his article "Are We Making Headway in Germany?" quoted from comments in an obscure German provincial paper about an address by Father Roth, chaplain at Dachau internment camp.

PEIPING, China, March 2 (Delayed) -- The issue here between university students and Government authorities over student arrests has been heightened by the release on bail for medical treatment of a 22-year-old National Peiping University sophomore named Teng Teh.

Announcement that those veteran travelers, the King and Queen of England, will spend the coming winter in Australia and New Zealand should make history in the antipodes. It marks the first time that two reigning monarchs have ever visited these far dominions.

Suppose you live in the suburbs, that you are in town on your way to some South Sea island or some backward country where medical and dental care are unheard of, and suppose that you have exactly twenty-four hours in which to have ten teeth filled and one porcelain inlay and four jacket crowns prepared.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6 -- Cornell's varsity basketball team kept its hopes for the Eastern League championship alive today with a 54-48 victory over Princeton in the Dillon Gymnasium. The contest was Princeton's last at home this season and saw the Tigers bow to the Big Red for the sixth consecutive time in three years.
LONDON, March 6 -- The pieces of the Western European jig-saw puzzle are at last being put together. The leisurely, comfortable pace of recent months has given way to feverish haste.

The immediate establishment of three new state colleges, one in Los Angeles, the second at Sacramento and the third in the Compton-Long Beach area, has been recommended by the California Commission on Higher Education. In a recent report to the State Legislative Interim Committee on Higher Education the commission also urged the creation of public-supported junior colleges where needed.

THE panic is on at last in British studios. Not since September, 1939, when the outbreak of war seemed likely to paralyze the British film industry, has such gloom and despondency prevailed around Wardour Street.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- The Yale hockey team defeated Harvard, 4 -- 3, on a three-goal scoring outburst in the third period tonight.

FAR down the peninsula of Florida and just north of the tropical wonderland of the Everglades for which it forms the wellspring, lies Lake Okeechobee, the second largest body of fresh water entirely within the United States.
READERS of THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine will not have forgotten the imaginative, "unexpurgated" writings of third-grade children in an Evansville (Ind.) school, published last June.

NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP) -- Star Reward, 4-year-old colt left at the post his previous time out, returned today to romp in the $25,000 added New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds and Steve Brooks got $1,980 for his winning ride instead of the poke in the jaw that an irate bettor inflicted when Star Reward failed to get going in a lesser race two weeks ago.

AS an antidote to winter a bowl of forced dwarf iris can accomplish wonders on the window-sill. While this Iris pumila is usually included in the foreground of the perennial border or planted in groups in the rock garden, few gardeners are aware of its possibilities for indoor forcing.

GOOD news for lawn owners -- and that probably means most gardeners -- is the comparatively new chemical for eradicating crabgrass. First put on the market last year, it has not yet come into general use, but all tests and experiments indicate its great effectiveness.

Professional and amateur gardeners will be swarming over Grand Central Palace today, putting the finishing touches on sixteen gardens and more than one thousand other floral exhibits for the opening of the thirty-second International Flower Show at noon tomorrow.

More than an outraged sense of injustice spurred the American Physical Society, seven thousand strong, the Federation of American Scientists, an Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists, of which Drs. Albert Einstein and Harold C. Urey are, respectively, chairman and vice chairman, and some outstanding individual scientists to defend Dr. Edward U. Condon against the accusation of disloyalty leveled at him by the House subcommittee on Un-American Activities.

REPRESENTATIVE PATMAN'S 1,001 questions and answers constitute a popular encyclopedia of the American Government, compiled by one of its most active and alert public figures. The book is well indexed, upon which feature much of its practical value rests.

Tent caterpillars, a common but depressing sight in June, can be attacked at several stages of their development. Nests such as the one at left may, be wiped out of tree crotches with swabs soaked in gasoline or kerosene. Never burn the nests!

THE system of competitive capitalism, still dominant in western Europe and America, has been defended often enough against hostile critics both left and right. For the most part, however, defenders of the competitive system have been content to proclaim its merits but to ignore its problems.

IN February of 1846, Anson Jones, M.D., President of the Republic of Texas, delivered his valedictory address at a ceremony transferring the border commonwealth into statehood in the American Union. In the course of his remarks he took cognizance of his widespread unpopularity, but he expressed his "assured belief that history and posterity will do me no wrong."

INCREASINGLY numbers of bird songs herald coming spring. Song sparrows that have been quiet while at the feeding station pour forth one of the sweetest and earliest melodies. Cardinals are heard whistling more frequently.

Widely divergent views concerning the relations between Russia and the United States were expressed yesterday by senior high school students at the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today a $3,000,000 program to encourage research in the use of radioactive materials for determining the nature of cancer and for its diagnosis and treatment.

The withdrawal of Czechoslovakia behind the 'iron curtain' of Russia has created new tasks for the machine tool builders of the United States, Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association, Cleveland, revealed in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. This event, coupled with the existing disorganization of the German machine tool industry, has left very few sources for machine tools in Western Europe today, he said.

BRUSSELS, March 6 -- The promise of a broad and effective regional defense and economic pact uniting Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg was bright today after completion of the first full conference session.
THE many kinds of power lawn mowers now on the market leave the average home owner tempted but bewildered as to which one best suits his needs.
OUR press reports of the recent esthetic dictum and composer confessionals in Russia are so significant in current musical history that we cannot ignore them.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The more than 200 priceless German-owned paintings that were brought to this country for safekeeping in 1945 will be displayed for three weeks at the National Gallery of Art here and then shipped to Germany some time in April.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A new Navy rocket has spurted seventy-eight miles into the sky and hit a speed of 3,000 miles an hour, the Army and Navy said today. This is the highest and fastest an American missile is disclosed to have gone.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -- West Coast shipping operators demanded today that the longshore contract to be negotiated by June 15 with the Congress of Industrial Organizations omit provisions giving preference of employment to union members; putting exclusively into union hands the selection of dispatchers in the hiring halls, and permitting the union to deny registration to any applicant longshoremen.
BERLIN, March 6 -- Six of the seven highest Nazi war criminals sentenced to serve their terms in Spandau prison are in extremely bad health.

APROPOS, of Edward Tatnall Canby's letter last Sunday, may I give another -- and I believe fairer -- side of the question of program duplication on AM and FM stations? As a yokel, I'd like to remind you that New York is by no means typical of even a large part of the rest of the country -- in radio listening or anything else.

SINCE Lawrence's death in 1930 it has been ever harder to follow his thought into the dark extremities of its human nihilism. At the same time, by his apparent disregard of literary form, he seemed to lay traps against the simple appreciation of his writings as works of art.

THE terrifying experiences which fall to the lot of Dr. Hugh Granville during his first day in New York after an absence of some years appear to him, in the beginning, to be entirely unmotivated. Later he is to learn why he is kidnapped at the point of a gun, driven to a New Jersey resort camouflaged as a skating rink and told that he must remain there until further orders.

Bankers in all sections of the country are still concerned over the inflationary problem, despite the recent break in commodity prices. The consensus is that any outright recession is at least six months away. This view is based on the observations of officers of the American Bankers Association who have just completed a two-month tour of thirteen key cities throughout the United States.

A NEW photographic enlarging paper, Rembrandt chlorobromide, is announced by Remington-Rand, Inc. Warm in tone, the paper offers wide developing latitude and may be processed in standard developer formulas. The paper is currently available in one contrast, double-weight stock, and five surfaces, with four more to be added later.

Harold J. Laski's excellent article ("Ever Sincerely Yours, O.W. Holmes") turns an interesting spotlight on the recently revealed Holmes-Cohen correspondence, but fails to point out that the letters between the jurist and Prof.

MOST home gardeners are as keenly interested in fruits as in flowers and vegetables, but all too frequently the fruits are tucked in out-of-the-way places. Little thought is given to cultural requirements or possible artistic values.

THE centralization of the theatre on a few blocks near Broadway is an old story and sad, but as they tell it, there are certain exceptions. Of these there are not many, to be sure, and almost all are concerned with surprising places and things.

HIS friends were and still are agreed that Henry Fielding was not only a true-born Englishman but also, for all his shortcomings, the salt of the earth. A south-of-England man, born at Sharpham Park, Somerset, in 1707, he was bred at Eton along with the younger Pitt, whose politics he shared, though their paths seldom crossed in the world that lay beyond the Thames-side playing fields of the ancient school.

IN the spring of 1947, when Edgar Maass must have been well along in the writing of The Queen's Physician," a British scrivener named John Fitzgay published the American edition of his novel, "Royal Physician." Both novels celebrate the singular career of Johann Friedrich Struensee, doctor of physic and dictator of Denmark.

Congress will take up at this session President Truman's request for a $65,000,000 interest-free loan to the United Nations to finance construction of the East River world capital. This is a proposal embodying both high purpose and solid tangibility, and it should be approved without delay or dissent.

GARDEN paths are like the hallways of a house. Their chief function is to provide the easiest and quickest access from one place to another. In planning the locations of the paths on the home grounds, common sense should dictate that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points.

Flashing a burst of power in the sprints that obtained all through the final hour the Italian team of Alvaro Giorgetti and Angelo DeBacco churned through to victory in the six-day bicycle race which came to a close at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

ONE of the favorite American variant's of the Ugly Duckling story is the tale of the young man who comes to some college with fire in his eye and Original Genius burning in his breast and is told after a few weeks that he will never be a writer, and will save himself and others much trouble if he will get into an occupation better suited to his talents.
Specialists on the New York Stock Exchange are banding together to eliminate what they term "sharp practices" and other unethical procedures by floor brokers on the Exchange.

NAUSET ON CAPE COD, Mass., March 6 (AP) -- A breeches buoy hauled five fishermen to safety across roaring surf from their breaking dragger today as the ancient alarm of "wreck" raised villagers to help Coast Guardsmen.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- (AP) -- Wheat led a general downturn in grains today in the Board of Trade. More snow in the Southwest and failure of the Government to announce purchases of flour brought about the selling. Corn and oats slumped in sympathy with the bread grain.

AT the time of going to press, the tyro-gardener was up in the attic room to which his family long ago consigned him, his garden guides, his seed catalogues and his old newspaper clippings. At last report he was a pretty happy man, living in a world of illusion, the smile of a mystic on his face and before him an elaborate chart labeled "successive bloom."

Faced with a recent sudden influx of pinball machines in all parts of the city, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander ordered a city-wide police survey yesterday with the promise that any machine used for gambling would be confiscated immediately.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Dr. Juraj Slavik, who resigned as Czechoslovak Ambassador this week rather than serve "a police state," has joined a relatively large colony of former ambassadors, attaches and political leaders from Europe who have found refuge in the United States

A new all-time high for number of exhibitors and amount of display space will be set by the American Toy Fair when it opens tomorrow at the McAlpin and Breslin Hotels, 200 Fifth Avenue, 1107 Broadway and other buildings, according to McBeith P. Fallon, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., sponsors of the show.

ANTONINA VALLENTIN is a talented and respected biographer. Born in Poland, educated in Germany, she later adopted France and the French language. She is a true cosmopolitan. Her best book is her penetrating story of Leonardo da Vinci.

A PROBLEM which has deadlocked top corporate and union officials with no prospect of satisfactory solution is the determination of the appropriate subjects for collective bargaining and the definition of spheres of authority which are of sole concern to management.
CHICAGO, March 6 -- In a pamphlet titled "It Costs Us Nothing," W.T. Couch, director of the University of Chicago Press, assails American book publishers for what he terms "cartel-like practices."

MAURICE GROSSER paints; he also cooks. That is no accident, he argues. Painting and cooking have a lot in common. To do either, you must be good with your hands. Also, your senses must be acutely developed, particularly one.

PARIS, March 6 -- On the eve of the expected drive by the Communist Information Bureau (Cominform) for the disruption of this country, the Communists here are weaker in one sense and stronger in another than they were last year, when they endeavored unsuccessfully to call a general strike and thereby ultimately to defeat the Marshall Plan.

Dr. William N. Takahashi of the University of California College of Agriculture reports in Science that Malachite green, a chemical dye, almost stops the growth of the mosaic virus that attacks tomatoes and tobacco. The dye actually penetrates the plant cells and markedly slows down the growth of the virus without hurting the cells in any way.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 6 -- It almost seemed like old times. The square-jawed fellow in the baseball uniform stood near the base lines, peering intently at everything that went on and never missing a trick. But there was one eye-catching difference. The word "Boston" was lettered across his shirt-front instead of "New York." Otherwise it was the same Joe McCarthy, back in baseball after a self-imposed year-and-a- half absence from the game.

After adopting and announcing the date of Sunday, May 23, for the sixteenth Hudson River marathon from Albany to New York the bigwigs on the committee found last week some conflicts with previously scheduled regattas and, therefore, on the request of several drivers, the Albany marathon date for this spring has been shifted to Sunday, June 13.

OTTAWA, March 6 -- Invitations have been issued to some 1,800 delegates all across Canada to attend a national convention of the Liberal party in Ottawa from Aug. 5 to 7 for the purpose of electing a new leader to replace Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

Ten years ago the four municipal colleges in New York City began an important experiment in democratic government that startled the traditional members of the academic world. More power was given to the faculty members in the operation of the college program.

NOT too long ago the poultry raiser considered himself lucky if he brought to maturity one-half to one-third of the flock he acquired hopefully. Whether the chicks were brooded artificially or raised a few at a time with a mother hen, seemed to make little difference.

TWO group shows of modern French painting, two one-man shows by familiar Americans and a show by a group of young unknowns this week seem to indicate that no single recipe assures vitality in painting and that it may occur here as naturally by insulation against international tendencies as by association with them.

FREEZING home-grown fruits and vegetables pays big dividends in the quality of food that is eaten all year round. The Freedom gardeners this year have one great advantage over the Victory gardeners, for today home-freezing equipment in all sizes is obtainable and locker plants have mushroomed everywhere.

IN his review of Eva Le Gallienne's revival of "Ghosts," your critic admits that Ibsen's play "was planned and written by a master craftsman of the old school," and, concerning Miss Le Gallienne's portrayal, reports a little later that "the Mrs. Alving she plays is no doubt Ibsen's character."
Accessories add the finishing touch to a garden. They are often the important factor in changing a mediocre collection of plants into an effective outdoor scene.

BOSTON, March 6 -- Army revealed a whole flock of secret weapons, all of them wearing short sharp spikes, at the Garden tonight, and scored a smashing victory in the first indoor Heptagonal Games. The cadets carried favored Yale right down to the mile relay final and then outlasted the Elis for second place to complete a point compilation of 48 against 45 for the Big Blue.

MANILA, March 6 -- President Manuel Roxas today formally declared the Hukbalahap organization of central Luzon and its political affiliate Pambansang Kaisahan Manggagawa [PKM] illegal associations organized and maintained to overthrow Philippine Government through force and intimidation.

THE term fertilizer is generally accepted as referring to the factory-made product which comes in powder or granular form and is sold in bags. This is considered distinct from the bulky materials, manure and compost, which are forms of organic matter.

IT might be well to comment first on the title, which mightn't entice a lot of people who ought to be enticed. The best deer in Maine, for instance, get up on the beech ridges at times, and many a sportsman's heart has been quickened by the sight.

ACCORDING to the book-jacket, Harold Robbins has known Manhattan from the seamy side out; his sojourn in New York's depressed areas, one gathers, has produced enough human interest material to provide steady entertainment for several hours' reading.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association winds up another New York subscription season at the end of the week. Since the casts for the remaining seven operas have been announced, it is now possible to survey the programs of the season and see how many times the different singers performed, which conductors were busiest and how great was the toll of that old operatic bugaboo, "indisposition."

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- The cruiser Tonga with Gregory Peck, film actor, and Leslie Charteris, mystery story writer, on board was in safe anchorage today after riding out a storm. Three other persons were missing.

BAD weather, generally recognized as the greatest obstacle to all sorts of flying, received ample consideration in the air transport section of the report made last week by the Congressional Aviation Policy Board.
Many statements about the psychology of Americans made by Geoffrey Gorer in his article "Are We Uncle Sam or Enlightening Liberty?" are valid, but I taste sour grapes.

THE artist as kingpin of the universe is the theme of this garrulous, pleasant and provocative book. With an assortment of Shavian barbs and a sprinkling of salty sense, we are told that painters, especially, are the elite of the earth.

THE Congressman leads a happy life. He has everything that a philosopher would prescribe for a man who likes folks. He has the assurance of past approval by thousands of voters, and often also a stimulating fear of what they may do next time. He has a constitutional right to complain whenever he feels like it, for which "he shall not be questioned in any other place."

TOKYO, March 5 (Delayed) -- Japanese who live along the west coast of Honshu are becoming increasingly worried by Communist activities in that area of Japan, which is closest to Russian-occupied Korea, Tatsuo Tanaka, Governor of Yamaguchi Prefecture, said in an interview today.

A NUMBER of years ago a seedsman advised other members of the trade, "Don't make your lawn seed mixture too good, for then property owners will have permanent lawns and will buy no more seed." The advice, of course, was facetious, for today we have splendid grasses adapted to every purpose.

CINCINNATI. FOR six months now Cincinnati has been trying out a plan to arouse more local interest in international affairs. The main objective of the plan is to teach the adult population of the city something about the United Nations -- what kind of an organization it is and what it is trying to do; and to convince the average citizen that he has a highly personal stake in the future of the United Nations.

TOKYO, March 6 -- Despite endorsement by the government section of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, Dr. Hitoshi Ashida, Premier-designate of Japan, is continuing to encounter grave difficulties in his attempt to form a new coalition government.

LONDON, March 6 -- In a letter to a Conservative candidate for Parliament, published today, Winston Churchill said that "not only bankruptcy and privation approach us in this island but the menace of a third world war rolls toward us with every act of Russian imperialist aggression and Communist violence and intrigue."

As one nation to another, Argentina has lately taken a severe tone with us in the matter of personal cleanliness. In future, the Argentine Postal Administration informs United States postal authorities, parcels of used clothing or table or bed linen mailed from this country will not be allowed to enter unless accompanied by a disinfection certificate.

LONDON, March 6 -- In a letter to a Conservative candidate for Parliament, published today, Winston Churchill said that "not only bankruptcy and privation approach us in this island but the menace of a third world war rolls toward us with every act of Russian imperialist aggression and Communist violence and intrigue."

As one nation to another, Argentina has lately taken a severe tone with us in the matter of personal cleanliness. In future, the Argentine Postal Administration informs United States postal authorities, parcels of used clothing or table or bed linen mailed from this country will not be allowed to enter unless accompanied by a disinfection certificate.

IT IS apparently impossible for Americans to write fictionally about Latin America without falling into one of two groups. On the one hand there is what might be called the darkness and death school. The country in question is stifling with threatening overtones.

DOROTHY MARTIN has written an intelligent, understanding story of wild life on the Game Preserve in South Africa. She has avoided the foolish interpretations and the stiff educational attitudes frequently found in animal stories.

PARIS, March 6 -- Having gained his objectives by the passage of the first three of nine Articles summarizing a sheaf of amendments to the unpopular anti-inflation tax law, Premier Robert Schuman at midnight agreed to postpone the critical discussion until Sunday afternoon.

SWAINSBORO, Ga., March 6 (UP) -- Gov. M.E. Thompson scored a point in his argument against anti-lynch laws today when a prisoner accused of murder was returned to the scene of the crime in view of hundreds of citizens.
Eighteen veteran amputees working here for the Veterans Administration have been assured by Congressional leaders that their plea for job protection will receive a hearing.

A NOTED authority on landscape recently told his audience, "You needn't hide your entire house front with plants, because your friends and neighbors will know it is there anyway." Exaggerating though he was, he succeeded in pointing out one extremely important mistake to be avoided in making a foundation planting.

LIKE so many visitors to MacArthurland -- which occupied Japan might well be called because it so bears the mark of one man -- Mr. Busch of Time, Life, Fortune, and Architectural Forum, Inc., went, saw and was conquered.

ANNUAL flowers for the garden may be chosen in much the same way a woman chooses accessories for a good basic suit. The part annuals play in relation to more permanent perennials and bulbs is usually an auxiliary one.

Too tall, too fast and too deep, New York University's talented basketball team romped to a 73-54 victory over Fordham before 5,284 persons at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday. At no stage in the encounter did the Rams threaten the Violets, who took the lead in the opening twenty seconds and by half-time enjoyed a commanding 35-23 margin.

THE quiz show format undoubtedly has become one of the more abused in radio. More often than not, it serves merely as a camouflage for a routine give-away opus on which a determined extrovert manages to display his own particular brand of hysterical eagerness.

AT one time the taking of bitters for medicinal purposes became so popular that the making of them developed into one of the country's important industries. The "Bitters Era," which covered at least a century of America's history, also gave added impetus to the nation's already rapidly growing glass industry.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today the arrest in Cleveland of David Francis Almeida and his wife, Anna Mainart Almeida, in connection with the $114,000 bank robbery in New Orleans on Jan. 9.

BOSTON, March 6 -- Although general rehabilitation of New England's fire-ravaged forests must wait at least another year because of the pales weevil threat, an experiment in reseeding 2,600 acres in Maine by air is being watched with interest.

THE scene is a mountain valley in the high Sierras. Luke Benning arrives there with the intention of remaining only long enough to settle the estate of his brother, Jim, who died some months earlier as the result of a skiing accident on the slope of near-by Mount Diablo.

JERUSALEM, March 6 -- The British plan to make the quiet island of Cyprus not only a strategic outpost for armed forces but an advanced diplomatic listening post and a center of propaganda for the Middle East, it was learned here today.

The programs of the Boston Symphony's three subscription series at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., in the Berkshire Festival, were announced yesterday by Serge Koussevitzky, the orchestra's director. Dr. Koussevitzky will be assisted by Eleazar de Carvalho, Leonard Bernstein and Robert Shaw, guest conductors.

NO plant is quite so graceful as a vine, or, in many cases, so serviceable. Climbing hydrangea, for instance, and wistaria and clematis rank among the most beautiful flowers in cultivation, and at the same time they perform such prosaic work as covering fences and arches, shading porches and giving them privacy and disguising a builder's mistakes.

AN impressive demonstration of what the motor car industry has achieved in almost half a century awaits those who visit the first post-war automobile show in this city, which opens tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

IN his second book, "Jim Farley's Story," subtitled "The Roosevelt Years," the former Democratic National Chairman has taken a position in regard to Mr. Roosevelt's third nomination for the Presidency which is certain to lead to controversy -- and, in fact, already has.
GENEVA, March 6 -- Eighteen nations, including the United States, signed a convention today establishing an inter-Governmental consultative maritime organization.
Congress was warned last week to strengthen the nation's air power as the best means of discouraging an attack against the United States.

MORE than a little confusion now prevails in business quarters. Volume in most lines keeps running at boom levels but there is a questioning of the future which seems to find few satisfactory answers. Hence, the confusion.

THE gardener who has a border devoted to one flower as a hobby is the catalogue and flower-show connoisseur. He not only reads the general catalogues but also he goes to many shows, usually with the hope that even in unlikely places a new variety or another cultural hint may turn up.

ROUND-EYED, rotund Hattie McDaniel is losing weight and radio is the cause. More specifically, the assignment of portraying Beulah five nights a week on CBS is doing to Hattie what seven shows a day in vaudeville, long hours under hot movie lights, one-night stands with bands and singing in smoky night clubs never did: taking off McDaniel pounds.

EVERY trade has its tools. The number does not determine the skill of a gardener, for his equipment may be so limited that it can be tucked on a shelf or extensive enough to line one wall of the garage.

GROWING gourds provides more than seasonal interest. Unlike the transience of ordinary garden plants, gourds have huge bright blossoms in early summer, followed by rapid growth of curious fruits that will last for months after harvest.

Because of the effort of Moscow to spread Communist domination into Western Europe, great importance is attached to the Italian elections which take place on April 18 and for which the country is now preparing. The basic issue is whether the Italian Communists will get a larger or a smaller vote than they received in the elections of 1946, when they polled roughly 20 per cent of the vote.
DISEASE control in the garden can be a fairly easy operation or an endless and futile chore, depending on how intelligent a job is done. Well handled, plants should suffer from few ailments.

PRAGUE, March 6 -- The Ministry of Social Welfare disclosed today that persons who had been dismissed from either public or private employment during the recent Czech purge that gave control of the Government to the Communists would be sent to work in mines, quarries, foundries, on construction projects, in agriculture or in lumber camps.

LONDON, March 6 -- Reform in wage policies in Britain's cotton-weaving industry could result in a 20 per cent increase in productivity, according to an interim report issued today by the Cotton Manufacturing Commission. The report deals with wage arrangements and methods of organization work in the industry.

IN a world of confusions and issues upon which it seems difficult for mankind to agree, there is one issue upon which nations appear cooperative. We refer to the matter of musical pitch, an issue which is not unimportant.

MODERN dahlias boast a rainbow of colors, variation in form and size, and continuous bloom for four months. Hybridizers have taken this wildflower of Mexico and produced a wide selection except in blue.

MORE trees were planted along the sidewalks of New York in 1947 than in any year during the past decade. In all, 3,946 specimens were set out, bringing the total number of trees in the five boroughs to 520,990.
GLADIOLUS seem adaptable to all kinds of soil found in the United States. They are easily grown and provide an abundance of color.
BERLIN, March 6 (AP) -- The United States accused the Russians today of sabotaging the four-power agreements for liquidation of the huge I. G. Farben chemical trust.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 6 -- Members of the Finnish Cabinet were ordered by President Juho K. Paasikivi today to remain on call in or near the capital over the week-end. The order was believed to reflect Soviet pressure on Finland to speed up the naming of the delegation to discuss Prime Minister Stalin's invitation for the conclusion of a mutual defense treaty.

SEOUL, Korea, March 6 -- K.P.S. Menon of India, chairman of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea, and Dr. Victor Hoo of China, representing the United Nations Secretary General, arrived by plane tonight from the United States.

While utility executives last week discussed the demise of private power in Great Britain when it becomes completely socialized on April 1, Frank McLaughlin, president of the $140,000,000 Puget Sound Power and Light Company, resignedly foresaw the encroachment of public ownership throughout the 5,000-square-mile area which the company serves in the Pacific Northwest.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- As the Yankees, aided by a spanking breeze that at times almost reached gale proportions, literally swept through their first week of training today. Manager Bucky Harris seemed willing to concede that the situation looks well in hand.

THE atmosphere around the garden is getting pretty thick with scientific talk of hormones and vitamins, blossom thinners, apple stickers, wound healers, root promoters, weed killers, fungus fighters, and bug blasters -- to say nothing of such things as tetraploids.

AFTER a period of comparative quiet, Hollywood's Liberal-to-Left Wing took up the cudgels again last week in behalf of the ten witnesses cited last fall for contempt of Congress because they refused to disclose to an investigating committee whether or not they were members of the Communist party.

BERLIN, March 7 -- A strong denunciation of Soviet totalitarianism was delivered last night in Berlin by Jakob Kaiser, whom the Russians had ousted at the end of 1947 as chairman of the Christian Democratic Union in the Russian zone.

Relations between Christians and Jews in this country will steadily deteriorate if both do not maintain stability and common sense in attitudes toward the great social issues of our time, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday. He preached in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- An individual employe who challenged a CIO union's bargaining rights, then changed his mind, was permitted to withdraw his petition today by the National Labor Relations Board.
Theodore Houck has been appointed sales promotion manager of the Crosley Distributing Corporation.
Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived in New York yesterday from London, where he represented this country in the conference on Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- While critics of the European aid bill will take the floor as the Senate opens its second week of debate tomorrow, there were predictions that before the next week-end legislation calling for the full $5,300,000,000 authorization sought by its backers might be passed and sent to the House.

Ulysses, pagan hero of Homer's epic poem, "The Odyssey," used "the Christian method of dealing with evil" when he drowned out the songs of sirens by playing more beautiful music on his own harp, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 7 -- The Soviet Government has abolished subsidies to the nation's theatres and has told actors they must work a full schedule, the weekly Soviet Art said today.
The four alleged alien Communist leaders released on bail late Saturday were reported on a light diet and resting comfortably in their homes yesterday following their hunger strike.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., March 7 (AP) -- Twenty-one stranded seamen waited tonight for help while heavy seas pounded their water-filled ship on a North Carolina sand reef.

Forty-year-old Mrs. Doreen Waskett cooks for a nation. She blazes a culinary trail for Britain's badgered housewives. No need for them to experiment with precious rations when Mrs. Waskett does it for them. It is she who is behind the recipes issued by the Ministry of Food.

The International Flower Show opens at noon today in Grand Central Palace. These are magic words for those to whom this thirty-second spring event is an old story, for they know that during the next six days all the color and variation of that long-awaited season have been captured within four walls.

The relationship between organized labor and government in the democracies has been subjected to a particularly severe test in the eastern states of Australia, which have been paralyzed by a railroad strike for several weeks. This test is all the more interesting because both the state and federal governments involved are Labor governments and the railways are owned and operated by the state.

Seven volumes of a new series, "Teach Yourself History Library," have been scheduled for publication on April 13 by Macmillan. Each book tells of an age in terms of a great man or woman. The series will be under the general editorship of A.L. Rowse, whose "The Use of History" will be the key volume.
Several changes concerning the chairmen of the various committees of the United States Golf Association have been announced by Fielding Wallace, president of the organization.

In the complex problem of providing medical care one fact stands out clearly. The average person in the middle-income brackets simply cannot afford the mounting costs of first-rate medical care without some financial assistance or prepayment insurance.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 7 -- Eddie Stanky, stricken with lobar pneumonia coincident with announcement of his being traded to the Boston Braves, today was resting comfortably in a local hospital after a penicillin treatment.

The New York Rovers, never able to match the speed and more effective play of the visitors, absorbed their worst beating of the season yesterday afternoon in bowing to the Montreal Royals, 15 to 2, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden.

NANKING, March 7 -- The Communist central committee has issued a new land reform directive to end peasant dissatisfaction in red-controlled areas. It charges that some local commissars "utilize their political position to commit evil deeds and usurp the fruits of agrarian reform."
Five new films, including importations from Germany and Russia, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

SHANGHAI, March 7 -- China may seek a readjustment and further compensation in the deal by which the Chinese are taking over large amounts of surplus American war properties in the Pacific and on the Asiatic mainland.

Lack of dollar credits is seriously threatening recreation and housing facilities maintained here by foreign agencies for their merchant seamen. Inquiries among foreign sea groups in the port have disclosed that at least one club is operating on reserve funds and others face the problem of getting additional funds without straining their governments' overburdened resources.

NEW DELHI, India, March 7 -- The free exchange of currency between India and Pakistan will be halted in April and monetary rations between the two Dominions will be enforced, according to decisions to be made by an inter-Dominion conference scheduled this week in Bombay, according to the New Delhi Hindustan Times.

A loan exhibition of paintings by Salvator Rosa, one of the prominent representatives of seventeenth-century Italian baroque painting, opening today at the Durlacher Gallery, is among the oustanding are events of the week in local show places.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 7 -- For the second year in succession, the English springer spaniel Ch. Frejax Royal Salute captured best in show honors at the Kennel Club of Buffalo's all-breed event at the Sixty-fifth Regiment Armory tonight.

YORK, Pa., March 7 -- Strong action must be taken now "to break the grip of the steel monopoly on the American economy." Henry A. Wallace declared here today in accepting the Presidential nomination at a founding convention of the Progressive Party of Pennsylvania.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market showed irregularity last week but the trend was higher. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close on Saturday were up 32 to 149 points above the level of the previous week. The improvement was most pronounced in near-by deliveries.

The Citizens Committee on Veterans Preference has announced its approval of the Mitchell bill to modify the constitutional civil service preference accorded to war veterans and its disapproval of the Condon bill, which would extend until 1951 the present provisions.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Dewey is being importuned by his supporters in Wisconsin to make a personal appearance in their state before the Republican Presidential preference primary April 6 so as to improve his chances of winning a majority of the twenty-seven delegates to be picked there.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Independent trade union members who are attempting to oust the Communist leadership of this city's Free German Trade Unions (F.D.G.B.) have achieved unexpected success in the first week of voting, a tabulation of returns showed today.
NEW ORLEANS, March 7 (AP) -- Passengers stranded for six fogbound days before removal from a grounded transport at the mouth of the Mississippi were critical today of the army's "fumbling around."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 7 -- The Benrook Kennels' stylish wire-haired foxterrier, Chief Barmaid, imported from England early this winter, went to best in show at the second all-breed event of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club in the new country-club-like National Guard armory tonight.

The time has come for the New York Yankees and the New York Giants to place Negro players somewhere in their organizations, Dr. Dan W. Dodson, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Unity, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks racked up their largest score of the year tonight when they downed the Montreal Canadiens, 9 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 16,463.
LONDON, March 7 -- The Labor party today issued a pamphlet suggesting a basis for selecting industries to be nationalized if Labor won the next general election in 1950.

CONCORD, N.H., March 7 -- The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign, which ends Tuesday with the election of delegates to the Republican National Convention, has furnished a preview of the campaign methods and tactics of the two contenders, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Harold E. Stassen.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 7 -- Ross F. Lockridge Jr., 33, author of the best-selling novel "Raintree County," was found dead in his locked garage late last night and authorities announced today he was killed by carbon monoxide poisoning.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- On the eve of drives by a number of key unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations for higher wages, the labor organization's research staff produced figures today to show that "substantial increases" were necessary to maintain the worker's standard of living.

With Goalie Jim Henry watching the proceedings from the sidelines, Tony Leswick banged a short shot into the nets to give the New York Rangers a tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A native New Yorker, transplanted to New England, where he spent the greater part of his educational and political life, James L. McConaughy was regarded among college heads not only as a practical executive but also as a leader in pedagogic theory.

Offerings of new bond issues by Allegheny County, Pa., and by Chicago Sanitary District, Ill., head a schedule of municipal bond sales estimated at $48,853,507 for this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with $334,643,386 for last week and a weekly average for the year to date of $84,984,352.
AMSTERDAM, March 7 -- Requisitioning of dollar securities owned by Dutch citizens is now imminent, the Bank of the Netherlands having been authorized last week to put this into effect.

Evidence that strong resistance is growing against the recent ruling of the Federal Trade Commission banning advertising use of the word "free" where a purchase is required, was revealed over the week-end following a survey of legal and organization representatives of the food and drug industries.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 7 -- The first public rally in Helsinki against accepting Premier Stalin's invitation for a mutual defense treaty was broken up today by Communists and the police. A speaker at the demonstration, Prof. Ernesti Hentunen, a Municipal Councilor, was taken into "protective custody" by the police, to the accompaniment of jeers and cat-calls from the crowd, which started to beat the Communist sympathizers in protest.

Balbina Brainina, pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. The program consisted of Mozart's Fantasy in D minor and Rondo in D major; Schumann's "Arabesque:" Chopin's Fantasy in F minor, Etude in C minor, Op. 25, No. 12, and the rarely heard Waltz in F sharp minor; Debussy's "Arabesque," No. 1; Ravel's Sonatine, Kabalevsky's Sonatina, No. 1, two Scriabin etudes, and items by Prokofieff and Mussorgsky.
JERUSALEM, March 7 -- The Haganah, the Zionist militia, took the spotlight in Palestine today in two developments:

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday awards to 392 members of the force for outstanding conduct in line of duty in 1947. With this latest list the honor committee of the Police Department has acted on all cases involving heroic deeds by policemen last year.
