MANILA, Monday, March 8 (AP) -- Nine persons were killed in week-end disorders after President Manuel A. Roxas outlawed the rebellious Hukbalahap Peasant Army and the National Peasant Union. A Government round-up of hundreds of suspected outlaws is expected shortly.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 -- The master's touch was needed today to erase some of the embarrassing developments of the Giants' first "home" spring exhibition game, and it came from a couple of pros on the Cleveland Indians.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Jack Kroll, director of the CIO Political Action Committee, suggested today that any changes in the "Mayflower decision" by the Federal Communications Commission to give the right to editorialize to radio stations might be in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Buddy Rogers, who has been absent from the screen for seven years and whose recent activity has been confined to producing motion pictures in partnership with Mary Pickford, his wife, will resume his acting career in "An Innocent Affair," with Fred MacMurray and Madeline Carroll, according to an announcement by James Nasser, the producer.

The broadcasts of the Milton Berle show are now numbered, notices having been received by the entire cast that the sponsor does not intend to retain the program after the present agreement runs out late in April. Philip Morris cigarettes is the retiring sponsor.

After a plainclothes patrolman received a "free play" on a penny pinball machine, an East Harlem storekeeper was arrested Saturday night, the police reported yesterday. He was the first person to be apprehended in the Police Department's intensified drive to check pinball gambling in the city.

Readjustments in the wholesale markets last week have had a stabilizing effect. Although manufacturers were willing to make some concessions, there have been no wide market breaks, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

In its 103d annual report, transmitted to the Legislature at the end of last week, the Prison Association of New York again urges that the state give scientific attention to the study and treatment as well as the punishment of sex offenders. A program for doing this already exists in the form of a report from a committee appointed by Governor Dewey to look into the problem.
COMPIEGNE, March 7 (UP) -- Charles de Gaulle in the course of his address here today said:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 7 -- The United Nations took a brief holiday today from high-pressure political headaches and turned a sociologists' spotlight on its smallest but fastest-growing trust, the islands of Western Samoa.

Sixteen doctors have been named by the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation as "Scholars in Medical Science" to teach and perform research in medical schools of the United States and Canada, it was announced yesterday. The foundation also allocated $400,000 to the schools to help support the doctors in the next five years.

Eight hundred exhibitors will preview more than 100,000 toys to the trade in eight acres of exhibits at the American Toy Fair which is scheduled to open today in the McAlpin and Breslin Hotels and in permanent exhibits at 200 Fifth Avenue, 1107 Broadway and other buildings, under the auspices of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. The show will continue until March 20.

EVEN if a sequel is as good as its predecessor, which it rarely is, it hardly ever seems as good, because it is bound to lack the freshness and novelty of the original and it is bound to seem imitative. That is the trouble with John Moore's "Brensham Village."* Mr. Moore is a gifted English writer who struck a good many critics all of a heap with his utterly enchanting book, "The Fair Field."

Invading a story area which has been pretty well trampled by Hollywood -- that of mystery fiction and the dramatic detection of crime -- a group of French film makers have emerged in "Quai des Orfevres" (or "Jenny Lamour," as it is known here) with a fascinating and penetrating film.

Reflecting the development of new products and new markets, sales and earnings of the Commercial Solvents Corporation last year were the largest in the company's history, according to the annual report issued today.

JERUSALEM, March 7 -- The Haganah, the Zionist militia, claims the right to mobilize even United States citizens if they are of military age and reside in Palestine, a spokesman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared today.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., had a consolidated net income of $12,809,543 for 1947, according to the annual report issued to stockholders over the week-end by Hans A. Eggerss, president. The net income was equal to $3.88 each on 3,157,781 common shares after dividends on the $3.75 preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Col. George S. Eyster, former press officer at headquarters of the American Army in Germany, will become deputy chief of the Army Department's public-information division here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Tomorrow is to see the climax in the battle of butter versus oleo-margarine.

The two key measures in Mayor O'Dwyer's 1948 legislative "package" appeared last night to have the solid support of the city's Democratic delegation at Albany, despite increasing pressure from business, civic, real estate, labor and political groups for their defeat.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The Government re-entered the market for wheat flour last week for the first time in about a month. The announcement that flour equal to 9,000,000 bushels of wheat would be taken to cover April export allocations sent prices soaring, the May delivery being 10 cents a bushel, the daily limit, higher at one time on Thursday.

A new method of group instruction for patients in veterans hospital, enabling them to play the piano in six weeks, has been developed by Miss Lorene McClintock, a Gray Lady of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7 -- With little more than two months to go before Britain surrenders the League of Nations mandate over Palestine, representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, China and France will meet tomorrow to discuss means of implementing the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to partition Palestine.

Work will begin within two weeks on elevating Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive along the East River between Eighteenth and Twenty-fifth Streets, Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, said yesterday.

KILKIS, Greece, March 7 (AP) -- One hundred pounds of dynamite were removed from rail tracks about ten miles south of this town three hours before a train carrying Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, new head of the United States military mission, and the Greek Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Demitrios Yantzis passed the point this morning.

Perhaps the result of our victory in the War of Independence was "the division of the peoples with Anglo-Saxon traditions of religion, law and culture which has weakened their opportunity to realize their dream of a world order of liberty and justice," the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving said yesterday.

PRAGUE, March 7 -- Czechoslovakia turned today to the memory of Thomas G. Masaryk on the traditional occasion of the anniversary of the birth of her first President. This was the ninety-eighth anniversary.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- Payrolls along the West Coast waterfront increased $17,000,000, or about 40 per cent, last year while employment among seafarers on this coast decreased 10 per cent, according to a report issued today by the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast, and the Pacific American Shipowners Association.

LONDON, March 7 -- An attempt to stage a rally in the stock markets here last week was not altogether unsuccessful, although it was a very half-hearted affair and merely made the markets look steadier rather than actually better.

The Douglas DC-6, first postwar air transport -- grounded after two fires last autumn despite the fact that it had proved the best money maker in the domestic airline fleet -- will begin its return to scheduled service a week from today on American Airlines, it was announced yesterday.

HARRISON, N. J., March 7 (AP) -- A 23-year-old plant service man was arrested yesterday charged with the theft of $45,000 worth of radio tubes from the Radio Corporation of America, Police Capt. Arthur R. Ford announced today. He identified the prisoner, held for grand larceny, as Edward Nichadowicz, of 4 West Hamilton Place, Jersey City.

Leonard Bernstein, who has headed the New York City Symphony since 1945, has resigned as music director rather than agree to conduct the group next fall with the orchestra operating on a reduced basis.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 7 -- Stephen Chambers, manager of the 254-family Van Tassel apartments at 95 Beekman Avenue, was honored today by his tenants as the "ideal landlord" at a reception and tea in the apartment house auditorium.

In show business it isn't unusual for the unexpected to descend like a bombshell. First announced to close March 20, "Happy Birthday," Helen Hayes' starring vehicle, will say goodbye to the Plymouth a week earlier, which means Saturday night.

A nostalgic past will meet an alluring present in the ever-changing automotive world when the first postwar automobile show in this city opens today at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, under the auspices of the Veteran Motor Car Club of America.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, and the ITU's executive board were charged today with fostering "confusion, fear and uncertainty" among the union's 87,000 members.

World peace and international security are dependent largely on United Nations support of the Palestine partition plan, speakers declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting of 2,000 delegates at the annual conference of the Council of Organizations, United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 7 -- The human mind that conceived the need for smashing the atom must feel an equal compulsion for improving relations between nations, races and individuals if there is to be peace and progress, Dr. Fred McCuistion, associate director of the General Education Board, New York, declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A new organization, known as Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State, today released an open letter replying to the "pronouncement" of the National Catholic Welfare Conference issued by the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of Cincinnati.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- Comes the day when the Yankees launch their quest for another American League pennant you can take it for a reasonable certainty they will have one Charlie Keller in the line-up playing left field.

ALBANY, March 7 -- If New York City transit fares are increased to eight cents, as appears probable, bus operators and vending machine companies are planning a drive to have the Federal Government mint an eight-cent coin that would be larger than a dime and smaller than a nickel.

LONDON, March 7 -- An appeal to every citizen to view Great Britain's economic plight as an individual problem that could be solved only by everyone's working harder was made by Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, speaking in Grimsby today.

The major incident of the week in the foreign exchange market was the strength of sterling "forwards." At Friday's close, ninety-day contracts were quoted at $3.96 1/2, or 6 3/4 cents under spot, compared with 10 cents in the preceding week, and 12 and 14 cents, in the prior week. Contracts of nearer maturities revealed comparable strength.

The fear of being hypocrites, the bad conduct of some churchgoers and the idea that church is no longer fashionable are some of the excuses given by people who stay away from services, the Rev. Dr. Howard William Hintz, pastor of the Old Spring Presbyterian Church, Spring and Varick Streets, declared yesterday.
LONDON, March 7 -- Prof. Nikola Dolapchiev, Bulgarian Minister in Britain, resigned today in protest against the policy of the the contrary, and what has re-and abroad.

LACONIA, N.H., March 7 (AP) -- A crowd of some 10,000 turned out today, despite a steady snowfall, and saw Hans Jacob Haanes of Norway win the Eastern American ski jumping championship with a total of 200.04 points.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7 -- Pablo Picasso, founder of cubism and for many years a storm center in art circles throughout the world, has offered to paint a large mural for the projected mid-Manhattan world capital of the United Nations, it was learned today.

Preliminary reports on the Laetare Sunday collection yesterday in the 15,000 Roman Catholic parishes of the country for the Bishops Fund for War Victims indicated that last year's donation of $5,000,000 had been exceeded, it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The value of food shipped abroad last year was the second highest in United States history. The Department of Commerce reporting this today, said.

HAVANA, March 7 -- If the final act of the World Trade Conference is signed here late this month, as now seems likely, the Havana Charter will be an unprecedented document in the history of world commerce.
BUENOS AIRES, March 7 -- The Argentine Congressional elections went off peacefully today in ten Provinces and the Federal District.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 7 -- A ground and aerial census of deer in the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park shows a population of only 369, it was announced today by Gus Hlaverty, chief of the Palisades Interstate Park police, who directed the survey.

ATHENS, March 7 (Reuters) -- Evacuation from rebel-held or rebel-threatened areas of all Greek children between the ages of 3 and 14, probably running into tens of thousands, was discussed here today.
MOSCOW, March 7 (AP) -- The Soviet press said today that the United States, Britain and France had taken a new step toward the partition of Germany through the three-power conference in London.

BUENOS AIRES, March 7 -- Continuance of anything like Argentina's present uneasy prosperity depends upon the adoption of the Marshall Plan to such an extent that becomes plainer every day that the Peron Government is as concerned as any European country in the United States Congressional debate.
Philip Blumenson, broker who has been active in the management of Ehrlich Estates, Inc., and other properties for many years, has expanded his offices at 620 Lenox Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Tuberculosis could be virtually eradicated in a ten-year program using current medical knowledge, the National Planning Association said today.

OSLO, Norway, March 7 -- Undaunted by the heavy fog from the Oslofjord which made visibility extremely poor and conditions hazardous, 236 jumpers from eight countries thrilled 65,000 spectators at the Holmenkollen jump today as Norway's entrants dominated the final phases of the week-long international competition.
ATHENS, March 7 -- Greek Army troops late yesterday inflicted casualties on a guerrilla unit with twenty-five miles west of Athens.

On May 15 Britain will give up her Palestine mandate and withdraw her troops from the Holy Land. Unless the United Nations acts decisively before that date this withdrawal will certainly be followed by disaster. The United Nations is now in the position of having issued the partition decree and having taken no steps to enforce it.

Greater use of private enterprise facilities in the European Recovery Program is urged by the National Foreign Trade Council in communications sent to Senator Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and Representative C.A. Herter, vice chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Aid, it was announced over the week-end.

Three buildings with a total of twenty apartments at 951-3-5 St. Marks Avenue, in Brooklyn, have been resold by the Equity Funding Corporation, a syndicate headed by Jerome Dansker to the Perman Realty Corporation. They late assessed for $50,000 and were sold through the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation, broker.

As the champion of public libraries THE NEW YORK TIMES is waging a valiant fight for the people of New York and for the best in American civilization. Your cogent and perspicacious editorial "Albany and the Libraries," in your issue of Feb. 19, is but one in a powerful series.

One can hardly say that the international crisis in the Antarctic is nearing the fighting stage, but three nations are firmly deploying their forces. From here the issue can be viewed only through a drapery of heavy fog, but the echo of high talk still sounds in from those remote waters.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the Old Master, retained his world's three-cushion billiard title tonight by Beating Ezequiel Navarra, youthful Argentine champion, 50 to 35, in the 33-inning final match of the challenge series.
COMPIEGNE, France, March 7 -- Addressing the nation from the Place du Palais here today Charles de Gaulle made his supreme bid to the French people to put him back in power.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 7 -- Gov. James Lukens McConaughy, Chief Executive of Connecticut since January, 1946, died unexpectedly today at the Hartford Hospital. He was 60 years old.

Proctor Electric Company will begin this month what it calls "the biggest promotional effort ever put into the merchandising of automatic electric flatirons." In addition to expanded national magazine advertising and retail sales training through distributors, the "promotion package" includes a new full-color sound movie, a graphically illustrated ironing manual and other promotional material for dealers, and increased emphasis on the company's "sit down ironing" demonstration.

Two antique shows prepared yesterday for one-week exhibitions here. The Antique Auto Show, sponsored by the Veteran Motor Car Club of America, held a press preview at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, and the fourth annual National Antique Show got ready for its opening today in Madison Square Garden.

BUENOS AIRES, March 7 (AP) -- Argentina has taken another step toward self-sufficiency of her tinplate supplies with the signing of a contract for the purchase of 40,000 tons of fine tin from Bolivia during the next five years.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Unions won 685 and lost four of the 689 union-shop elections held in the first four months of the Taft-Hartley Law.

Motion picture and theatrical interests in the city expressed opposition yesterday to a bill introduced in the State Legislature authoring any Fire Commissioner to assign at least two uniformed firemen to every performance at fees of $10 a man for each show.

NANKING, March 7 -- With Government forces reportedly forging steadily ahead in Manchuria, the Communists have won a major victory in Shensi, according to their broadcast tonight from north Shensi. Thirty thousand Nationalist troops were reported defeated in a three-day battle at Ichuan, sixty miles southeast of Yenan.

Columbia's basketball team still needs a victory over Cornell tonight to clinch the Eastern Intercollegiate League title, but the Lions already are assured of a place in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
IN NORTHERN PALESTINE, March 7 (AP) -- The veteran Arab warrior Fawzi el-Kawukji inspected his armed forces today and declared: "Everything is ready. The battle starts when I give the word."

Gloria Chappell, gifted young violinist, made her New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Times Hall before a responsive throng. Her playing was notable for the keen sense of style and strong feeling of energy it displayed.

PARIS, March 7 -- With the final decision postponed until tomorrow, the Schuman Government, battered but unbeaten, came through the third day of its National Assembly struggle over its anti-inflation measures, thanks to a majority that twice shrank to fourteen votes.
A flat-car named Whirlwind may be the answer to the subway cleaner's prayer.

Matthew G. Ely, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, made public yesterday a letter he has sent to Frank C. Moore, State Controller, sharply criticizing the Moore Committee's report recommending an increase on constitutional limits on real estate taxation from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent of total assessed valuations.

Prof. Henri Peyre of Yale has remarked that "a grave blow was dealt to our culture when, approximately half a century ago, history ceased to be a part of literature." He added that "biographers stepped in where historians feared to tread and their art has become an important province of literature."

BAYONNE, N. J., March 7 -- The fire that swept the U.S.S. Lafayette, formerly the French Line flagship Normandie, and left her a blackened keeled-over hulk in 1942, was responsible for a Navy project that since that time has saved ships and other property valued at more than $2,000,000,000.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, South Africa, and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago went into their second extra-hole match in the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament today.

The twelve-story office building on a lot 37.5 by 100 feet at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street and 5 East Thirty-eighth Street, adjoining Ovington's on Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by the Great Northern Radar and Electronics Corporation, a Western concern, for its headquarters and experimental station in the East.

PARIS, March 7 (UP) -- France, Hollywood's biggest pre-war European market, has asked the United States State Department through the French Foreign Office for negotiations aimed at cutting in half the number of weeks in every year in which American films can be shown in France.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 -- The steel ingot rate last week for the country gained 1 point to 94.5 per cent of rated capacity. On a tonnage basis this matches the high level of operations which were prevalent late last year. The fact that steelmakers have been able to move their operations upward indicates, it is said, that the flow of scrap metal has increased and that repair and maintenance programs are well in hand.

Prompt action by a crew of firemen of Hook and Ladder Company No. 2 saved the life of 2-year-old Michael Weiss of 209 East Fifty-first Street yesterday. They kept the infant's heart beating by artificial respiration after the baby suffered convulsions, the police of the East Fifty-first Street station reported.

The communion service was canceled yesterday in the small Wesleyan Methodist Church, on the first floor of a two-story building at East Thirty-fourth Street and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Instead, a dozen women prayed silently for the life of Mrs. William Curl.

Community relations programs during 1948 will generally follow last year's pattern, but top management is taking a more active part in the programs, and practices which experience has shown to be most successful are being amplified, according to the monthly survey of business practices conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board and made public over the week-end.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Lard developed a much firmer undertone on the Board of Trade last week. This was partly in sympathy with edible oils and fats and buying induced by prospects that the movement of hogs to leading markets would fall off soon.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer's transit fare and other "package" bills are expected to furnish the major drama for this, the probable closing week of the 1948 legislative session. They were the key topic of discussion at a conference of republican legislators here today and a meeting of democratic leaders in New York.

Constituents of mine have inquired from me as to how I voted on Feb. 24 on the budget bills. They inform me that, although your paper customarily records the names of those legislators who vote for opposition proposals, they noted that on this occasion your account failed to set forth such information.

" Hollywood on Trial," the story of the ten movie writers who were indicted for contempt of Congress, will be issued on April 12 by Boni Gaer. The book was written by Gordon Kahn, editor of The Screen Writer. Thomas Mann, in his foreword, "compares 'this persecution' of the ten to what happened in Germany."

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 9 -- Two P-39 fighter planes with Soviet markings attacked a Chennault commercial transport plane late yesterday while it was over the Gulf of Po en route from Mukden to Tsingtao, North China, the airline reported today.
Local internal revenue collectors reported yesterday that Federal income tax returns were being filed early this year. The deadline for filing returns is midnight next Monday.
In a press release yesterday, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers denied the "raiding" charge of Coach Bud Wilkinson of the University of Oklahoma.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Russiah charged tonight that the United States was leading a Western power plot to split Europe and build up military might in Germany "with the purpose of aggression against the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics."

TAMPA, Fla., March 8 -- There were two out in the ninth and two strikes on the batter, 'Bama Rowell, for the elongated Ewell Blackwell of the Cincinnati Reds. This was a tense moment. He gulped hard and fidgeted nervously on the mound. Grady Hatton, the Cincinnati third-baseman and Blackie's roommate, strolled casually toward him.

Seeing the conductors and soloists always winning the ovations, every member of an orchestra must dream now and then of some day -- perhaps just once -- being the star of a concert of his own. Last night such a thing came true for Bruno Labate, who was the oboist of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony for twenty-four years.
KANSAS CITY, March 8 (AP) -Louisville University today defeated South Dakota State, 63 to 60, to enter the second round of the National Intercollegiate basketball tournament.

Wholesale druggists must carry on more aggressive programs of additional service to retailers and manufacturers to meet growing competition from chains, super markets and direct account retailers, members of the Federal Wholesale Druggist's Association were told yesterday.

ATHENS, Tuesday, March 9 (UP) -- Reports that Greek guerrilla artillery fired on an observation team of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans were confirmed today by a United Nations spokesman.

The dull routine of making a tennis draw, usually nothing more than a prosaic process of pulling names out of a hat or cup, proved to be anything but that yesterday as the players were marshalled in battle order for the national indoor championship.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 (AP) Jim Ferrier of San Francisco and Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, Tenn., today joined Ed Furgol of Pontiac, Mich., and Ellsworth Vines of Los Angeles in the final of the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament.

New fuel was added yesterday to the feud between the KaiserFrazer Corporation and the underwriting firm of Otis Co. over the latter's withdrawal from a stock sale contract. In a letter to employes of his automotive company Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the board, charged that Cyrus Eaton, largest stockholder of Otis, "tried to coerce us into canceling the contract by making a number of threats against KaiserFrazer."

I hope every one of your thousands of readers will comprehend and take to heart the message of the editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 25 entitled "Modern Fable." If enough of us were to do so, perhaps the medicine men in the Long House would listen to Ike and Omar.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Strong military assistance, to back up the proposed $570,000,000 of American economic and relief aid to the Nationalist Government of China in its civil war with Communists, was pressed further today as the House Foreign Affairs Committee studied this program.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 8 -- The "insularity of academic curricula" has been a principal factor in creating a strong feeling of nationalism and a pressing problem of race prejudice in this country, J. Curtis Dixon, president of the Southern Education Foundation, declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Public hearings on measures designed to build up the nation's defense -with universal military training as the base -- were ordered today by the unanimous vote of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Cotton futures turned active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and in one of the heaviest selling movements in months, prices declined to net losses of 70 to 135 points on active contracts.

One of the best mirrors for seeing the British Commonwealth of Nations as it stands today, new in concept, individual in national sovereignty, united on the gravest world political issues is the United Nations. Here, in the councils of the fifty-seven-government association for peace, seven of the eight dominions of the British Commonwealth play their self-determined political roles with greater freedom and greater individuality than ever before.

A sharp break in the conmmodities yesterday produced a sympathetic decline in the stock market and while losses were not great, except in a few issues, the list leaned heavily to the lower side. Before stocks slumped in the afternoon, shortly after wheat dropped the permissible limit in Chicago, the aircrafts made some sizable gains.

Daintiness associated with Paris characterized the showing held by Mme. Nicole in her salon, 23 East Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday morning. The clothes shown were not French, however. They were created here under Paris inspiration and had the wearability that Mme. Nicole -- French born and American trained -- knows her clientele likes.

Net earnings of the National Lead Company reached a new high last year, although the increase was not comparable to the rise in dollar sales, which also were the largest in the company's fiftysix-year history, Joseph A. Martino, president, reported in the annual statement issued yesterday.

Irving Haim's association with Frank Costello and Phil Kastel figured in the three-hour argument yesterday in Supreme Court where Justice Morris Eder is hearing an action brought by Mr. Haim, president of International Distributors, to compel the State Liquor Authority to renew the concern's wholesale liquor license.

Attorneys for five alleged alien Communists whom the Justice Department seeks to deport will carry appeals for writs of habeas corpus into the United States Circuit Court this morning at 10:30 o'clock.

In two investment purchases, David A. Schulte has acquired the twenty-four-story office building at 44-46 Wall Street from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and the twenty-one-story office structure at 501 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-second Street, from the Oceanic Investing Company.

Prices broke yesterday on the nation's commodity markets in the sharpest decline since the slump of a month ago. The new break came suddenly after a week in which prices had made their biggest advances in three months.

HAVANA, March 8 --- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today adopted changes in the Charter of the proposed International Trade Organization, fixing its relations with the general agreement on tariffs and trade in keeping with the over all settlement of economic development issues here last week.

HOLYOKE, Mass., March 8 (AP) -- Thompson Harmon, 134, of New York, was removed to Holyoke Hospital tonight after he had collapsed twice in the ring at Valley Arena where he lost an eight round bout on a technical knockout to Sandy Sadler, 129, of New York.

Port Richmond and Newtown moved into the quarter-final round of the city-wide Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday by scoring over Long Island City and Curtis, respectively, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

LONDON, March 8 -- Although the stock market here today opened on a slightly better note due to the encouraging news regarding the western alliance, absence of buyers caused most sections to sag just before the close.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court declared today that religious instruction in public school buildings was unconstitutional.

LARAMIE, Wyo., March 8 -- The University of Wyoming athletic board said tonight that a play-off with Utah University to decide which team would represent District 7 in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament in Kansas City is "impossible."

SEOUL, Korea, March 8 At the reopening session of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea here today, George Patterson, Canadian delegate, announced that Canada refused to regard the United Nations Little Assembly resolution to hold elections in South Korea as more than "advice" to the commission.

The three-story building at 108-09 101st Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, containing a store and five apartments, has been sold by Joseph Berman and Max Sherman to Vincent Guarino and James A. Defarari. William G. Suttmeier was the broker.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 8 -Preservation of the Christian family unit is more important to the future of civilization than all the "schemes" and "compromises" worked out by world statesmen, according to speakers at the opening here of the annual convention of the National Catholic Conference of Family Life.

Your obituary on Edward T. Devine, who died in Chicago on Feb. 27, accurately described him as one who had pioneered in the field of social welfare in this nation and had contributed much to its professional development here in New York City.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8 Any disappointment he might have felt over the week-end exposure of his yearling pitchers to actual combat was carefully concealed today by manager Mel Ott. To seasonal wildness, which was to be expected, the Giants' skipper attributed the split of two games with the Indians, which brought ten flipping possibilities under fire, one of them for a flash.

Six indictments, totaling ninetytwo counts, were returned yesterday by a Kings County grand jury against seven professional bondsmen and three alleged runners, accused of having violated the state insurance law by conspiring to solicit business.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The convictions of two groups of manufacturers for violating the antitrust laws by fixing prices were upheld by the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate-House Committee on Atomic Energy ordered today an investigation of its own based on Dr. Edward U. Condon's accusations that "public smears of scientists" were endangering the scientific position of the Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- The Soviet Union is pressing for a prompt decision on steps to carry out the partition of Palestine while the United States still hopes that a settlement satisfactory to both Jews and Arabs can be worked out, it was learned tonight after the first meeting of the great powers on the question.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 8 (UP) -- The Rev. A. Ray Cartlidge, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, said today that the United States Supreme Court's decision challenging the teaching of religion in Champaign schools "seems to commit the United States to a definite irreligious attitude."

WASHINGTON, March 8 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that theh)0*0*0*iTexas Power and Light Company had filed a registration statement covering $7,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, due 1978, and $2,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1978.

The mysterious loss on paper of almost 5,000 gross tons of shipping was reported last week by the American Export Lines, operators of the Italian liners Vulcania and Saturnia. The company has written to its office in Rome asking for an explanation of the fact that the two vessels, built as twins in 1927 and 1928, no longer are of the same size.

After a lapse of three days, play was resumed yesterday in the international masters tournament for the world chess championship at the Grote Zaal in the Zoological Gardens at The Hague, according to a report from the Netherlands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- "The Burning Bush," a Conrad Nagel film dealing with antiSemitism in Hungary in the nineteenth century, which William Lee Wilder produced last fall, will be distributed by United Artists, the producer announced today.

MONTREAL, March 8 (AP) -- Bill Mack of Michigan State won the Canadian Legion mile tonight, setting a new meet record in 4:16.6. Mack's time bettered by two seconds the Legion mark set last year by Gil Dodds.

Sunday Night Supper Sunday night supper is the worst meal of the week. It is composed of diluted soup, dry crackers and a lettuce leaf which was weary even as a seed. It is eaten in the kitchen, from a minimum of chipped dishes.

CORAL GABLES PARK, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Beauchef, latest Chilean star to race in this country, failed in the role of an odds on favorite as Love Sonnet captured the Ingomar purse, chief attraction on today's scratch-riddled program at Tropical Park.

Seventy per cent of the people believe radio is doing either an excellent or a good job, according to the results of the second poll conducted by the National Opinion Research Center for the National Association of Broadcasters. Results of the poll were announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A contributor to many philanthropies recently asked in your column: "How can one tell which charities are wisely and faithfully managed, which not?" He further suggests supervision of charitable organizations and a system of "certification."

OSSINING, N.Y., March 8 -After 138 executions of murderers and 11,000 on-the-scene investigations of homicides and other sudden deaths -- a record without many parallels in the country -- Dr. Amos O. Squire of this village intends to retire from public office on June 1, it was learned today.

There is the artists' artist, the authors' author and now the GreekAmerican's Greek restaurant. It is the Apollo, at 259 West Fortysecond Street, and the food, although definitely prepared in New York, is a delight to anyone homesick for Near East fare.

Because films condemned by religious groups invariably attract the biggest audiences, the Protestant Motion Picture Council will draw attention to good motion pictures instead, Mrs. Jesse Bader, president, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, March 8 -- A unilateral British decision to abandon quadripartite control over the German price structure has presented a serious threat to hopes of achieving a four-power agreement on currency reform throughout Germany, Military Government economists said today.

h)0*0*0*iODisregarding warnings from both majority and minority leaders that they had no business dealing with international affairs, members of the City Council approved yesterday a resolution favoring a Jewish homeland in Palestine, after a long debate.
LONDON, March 8 -- The prospect of the Big Four's reaching an agreement on the basic problem of an Austrian settlement, already remote, receded even farther today.

CONCORD, N.H., March 8 About 60,000 New Hampshire Republicans are expected to go to the polls tomorrow to participate in the contest between adherents of Thomas E. Dewey and Harold E. Stassen for all or some of the eight seats the state will have in the national convention in Philadelphia in June.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 8 -- Full eight-man teams from the six schools in the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association will compete in its twenty-fifth annual tournament at the University of Virginia Friday and Saturday.

Some maple bedroom furniture manufacturers have priced themselves out of the market and are now using other hardwoods to bolster lagging retail orders, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers' representatives report some success in boosting volume whereh)0*0*0*ibeech has been substituted for maple.

MONTREAL, March 8 (Canadian Press) -- Miss Barbara Ann Scott, Canada's figure skating queen, arrived here by plane early today on her way to her home town of Ottawa after a long and weather-delayed flight.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Asserting that adoption of the state university bill in its present form would set back education in this state forty-five years, the State Board of Regents asked today for the support of Governor Dewey and legislative leaders for an amendment which would strip the proposed board of trustees of administrative responsibility.

The rising tide of talk in the United States in favor of a European federation should make Burton K. Wheeler, former Senator from Montana, veryh)0*0*0*ihappy indeed. Several years before Governor Dewey, Mr. Wheeler was urging European Union. When Congress was going overwhelmingly for the Fulbright and Connally resolutions on world organization, Senator Wheeler was talking European Union.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Imposition of state controls on garage rentals in New York City was declared impractical today by majority members of the Joint Legislative Committee on Rents in recommending continuation for another year of the commercial and business rent controls applying to New York City and the state's standby residential rent-control law.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 8 -President Juho K. Paasikivi accepted today Premier Stalin's proposal to negotiate a Soviet-Finnish treaty of friendship and mutual assistance and has suggested that subsequent talks take place in Moscow rather than in Helsinki.

FRANKFOR ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 8 -- German governmental officials are to be told to make a greater attempt to conduct their affairs in the open, it was learned today. No official communication is planned by the American-British Control Office, but this issue will be taken up either through normal liaison channels or by a message delivered through bipartite public information officials.

Legal action to force the dropping of released-time religious instruction from the New York public school system's program was forecast yesterday as a result of the Supreme Court's decision in the Champaign (Ill.) case.

A synthetic compound resembling the chemical structure of poison ivy, and producing the same physiological effects as the plant, has been developed by Charles R. Dawson, associate professor of chemistry at Columbia University, and Dr. David Wasserman, a former Columbia graduate student.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Looking as fit and trim as he did at the close of last season, and feeling considerably less tired, George McQuinn, the Yankees' "Cinderella man" of the 1947 campaign, breezed into camp today and in practically no time at all solved another holdout problem.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- John D. Goodloe, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that the agency had authorized the installation of a new open hearth furnace, estimated to cost $3,000,000, and related facilities, at the Fontana, Calif., plant of the Kaiser Company, Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -President Truman's formal announcement that he is a candidate today failed to shake Southern revolt against him.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 8 -Three robbers who appeared to be amateurs and anxious to avoid violence, although one displayed a pistol, entered the home of Mrs. John J. McLaughlin in the Meadow Spring estate section here at 5:45 P.M. today.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Taking the shackles off capital funds is leading business along new paths.

Albert (Buster) Tyler, Newark, N.J., welterweight, survived two trips to the canvas to gain a close decision over Tommy Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
Mme. Jacob Lomakin, wife of the Soviet consul general here, was hostess yesterday afternoon at a tea in the consulate, 7 East Sixtyfirst Street.

Eamon de Valera, American-born former Premier of Ireland, returned yesterday for a visit to his native land -- his first in eighteen years. He arrived at La Guardia Field at 4:58 A.M. on an American Overseas Airlines plane from Shannon Airport, accompanied by Frank Aiken, former Irish Minister for Finance, and Liam MacGowan of the Dublin Irish Press, a publication supporting the Fiana Fail party, of which Mr. de Valera is leader.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts sold yesterday $5,000,000 of notes dated March 12 and due June 25 at 0.687 per cent to J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Second National Bank of Boston.

The estate of Mrs. Fannie L. Harrison, widow of President Benjamin Harrison, has sold the one-story taxpayer building at 732 Ninth Avenue to the tenants, Samuel Lichtenstein Sons, dealers in hardware and house furnishings. The building occupies an irregular plot 20.6 by 100 feet near Fiftieth Street.

The Pan American World Airways clipper Southern Cross, returning from a flight to Johannesburg that marked the opening of a new air route to South Africa, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday with twenty newspaper and magazine publishers, Government and airline officials aboard.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Michigan's "one-man grand jury" system was condemned by the United States Supreme Court today, as it ordered William Oliver freed from a sixty-day sentence for contempt of court.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -with the approval of the United States Treasury, a drive got under way on Capitol Hill today to end Federal taxes on oleomargarine.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -President Truman declared this afternoon that he was willing be a candidate for President if the Democratic party nominated him.

Jaeckel's presented its spring showing yesterday noon in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel. Having costumes, millinery and furs at its disposal, this East Fifty-seventh Street house completed the fashion picture in good style.

The St. Regis Paper Company's achievements last year included the establishment of new high records for sales and earnings and total assets exceeding $130,000,000 for the first time, Roy K. Ferguson, president, informed stockholders in the annual report, which is being released today.
Comment last night by members of Congress on the announcement by Gen. Douglas MacArthur that he would accept the Presidency was generally favorable.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that net income last year was $48,806,417, equal to $3.58 a common share, contrasted with $8,823,846, or 65 cents a share in 1946 when production was slowed by a fourmonths' strike.

Business groups and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Motion Picture Machine Operators, CIO, appealed yesterday to legislative leaders in Albany to defeat the pending bill that would authorize any Fire Commissioner to assign two uniformed firemen to every performance in a theatre or other place of amusement at fees of $10 a man for each show, the money to go into firemen's pension funds.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer's transit bill, intended to pave the way for increasing New York City subway fares to 8 cents, appeared headed for the legislative scrap heap tonight as Republican and Democratic legislative leaders exchanged recriminations and charges of bad faith.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- Holding that the United Nations Palestine Commission will become the legally constituted Government of Palestine after Britain surrenders the mandate on May 15, United Nations legal experts have upheld the legality of the Security Council's taking action in the event or Arab resistance.

LOS ANGELES, March 8 -- The twenty-five words which Mrs. Florence Hubbard of Chicago wrote about the American Heart Association to win the $22,500 radio "Walking Man" contest will cost her up to $8,000 in income taxes.

For two years a unified group, comprising conservation and sportsmen's clubs, outdoor clubs and others interested in the preservation of our State Forests, fought to prevent the construction of a dam on Moose River which would have inundated a large part of the state woodland.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 8 -Artificial production for the first time of the meson, a cosmic ray constituent scientists look upon as a major key to unlocking the remaining mysteries of the atom's core and to determining the ultimate particles of matter and why they exist, was announced today at the University of California.

In answer to alleged violations of the Commodity Exchange Act, charged by the Department of Agriculture last week, Irving Weis Co. issued yesterday the following statement through its counsel, Corbin, Bennett Delehanty:

CHICAGO, March 8 -- March and May wheat broke the 1O-cent-abushel daily limit on the Board of Trade today and the old-crop liveries of corn and soy beans were down the 8-cent permissible limit as the result of general liquidation that showed lack of support.

Behind the statistics of the past year's work of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, as presented in the Society's recently issued annual report, lies the story of a great social task that is carried out with good judgment, considerateness and every effort to achieve a necessary end through cooperation rather than coercion.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Lighterage Company, Inc., of Hartford, Conn., will be authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission to transport general commodities between Hartford, Middletown, New Haven and Saybrook, Conn., and points in the New York Harbor area, if the ICC follows recommendations, submitted today by one of its examiners, Otto A. Hanson.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- India told the Security Councilh)0*0*0*itoday that she was prepared to hold another plebiscite in the disputed State of Junagadh, this time under United Nations supervision.
BATAVIA, Java, Tuesday, March (AP) -- A Netherlands East Indies Interim Government will be installed this afternoon at the Governor General's palace.

VIENNA, March 8 (AP) -- United States Army authorities said today that the shooting of Private Grunden was the "boldest act yet perpetrated against a member of the occupation forces in Vienna by a Russian soldier."

HYAK, Wash., March 8 (AP) Arne Ulland, flying Norwegian and youngest of the three famed jumping Ulland brothers, won the United States National Class, a ski jumping championship, this afternoon with leaps of 251 and 280 feet.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander reported yesterday that the week-old stagger trucking plan for the garment area had "definitely caught on." He also announced that a plan to keep empty trucks out of the congested garment center by sending them to a parking area until the shipment was ready for loading was now being studied.

Recently the newspapers carried a cable datelined in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, announcing that Congress had called the people to cast its votes on Oct. 10 for a successor to Gen. Tiburcio Carias Andino, the present incumbent of the Presidency.

A collection of documents depicting the growth of civil liberties in New York State went on display yesterday in Madison Square Garden in conjunction with the opening of the National Antiques Show. The forty-three documents, dating back to 1657, comprise an exhibit that will be shown throughout the state on the New York Freedom Train, which will start a tour in October.

Close bidding yesterday on the new issue of Public Service Company of Oklahoma bonds furnished another testimonial to the keen appetite which underwriting groups have been showing for the small and medium sized bond issues that have come out since the turn of the year.

Andre I~iostelanetz, conductor,underwent an emergency appendectomy early yesterday morningin Palm Beach. On Sunday, whileon his way with his wife, LilyPons, from 1Vliami Beach to PalmBeach, he was stricken ill at thewheel. As Miss Pons does not knowhow to drive, a garageman on theroad drove them to Palm Beach.where ~r. Kostelanetz receive~emergency treatment.He then was taken to St. Mary'~~Hospital, where the operation was~performed. His condition is report' ed to be good.

WASHINGTON, March 8 - There were indications today that the Administration had shelved, at least temporarily, its once ambitious project to restrict the flow to the public of information believed to be potentially damaging to the national security.

Flowers in such profusion that even an estimate was staggering composed the thirty-second International Flower Show, that opened yesterday in Grand Central Palace. Every day this week visitors may wander among thousands of exhibits that range from the common crocus to the exotic orchid and acacia.

ROME, March 8 -- Pope Pius called yesterday for free international economic collaboration and deplored the "materialistic spirit" of some nations. These nations, he said, are attempting to raise barriers against the exchange of goods between peoples as part of a policy designed to attain political hegemony.

TRENTON, N.J., March 8 -Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell handed in his resignation today as chief of staff of the New Jersey National Guard with a charge that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll wanted to dictate his political activities or "liquidate" him.

An overwhelming majority of 430 community leaders in twentyone cities in the United States favor long-term assistance for Europe as proposed by Secretary of State George C. Marshall but have misgivings about many aspects of an American aid program, according to a survey conducted by the Council of Foreign Relations, 58 East Sixty-eighth Street, and made public yesterday.

Your discussion of "stairs" in Topics of the Times for Feb. 25 is quite to the point and could be amplified considerably. Stairs are sure, while the best mechanical substitutes fail occasionally; thus stairs are never eliminated even where they are seldom used.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- The Ukraine accused the United States and Great Britain here today of favoring an arms race by turning out heavy quantities of war weapons. The delegate charged further that Anglo-American policy was encouraging Japan and Germany to launch future aggressions.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 8 (AP) Two American women employed by the United States State Department were shot to deathh)0*0*0*inear Saigon last night. Their attackers were presumed to be anti French guerrillas.

A call for a state-wide conference to be held here on April 3, at which the third-party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace and Senator Glen Taylor of Idaho will be placed on a "permanent" basis, was issued yesterday by an initiating committee under the chairmanship of O. John Rogge, former assistant United States Attorney General.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 8 -- A prominent Czechoslovak industrialist who asked that his name be withheld said in an interview today that an underground movement already had been formed in Prague.

LONDON, March 8 -- Spokesmen for the British Government and the Parliamentary Opposition took occasion in the debate on naval appropriations in the House of Commons today to remind potential international aggressors and gadflies that the British Navy still was the second strongest in the world, second only to that of Britain's powerful friend the United States.

Ready acceptance of Japanese silk fabrics in the domestic market has given a new aspect to the problem of moving silk stocks controlled by the Army, it was learned yesterday. The Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers (SCAP) will be more than able to salvage its investment in the Japanese silk industry by expanding Nippon silk fabric production, according to trade sources here.

GENEVA, March 8 -- Cooperation of the bizone authorities in low level all-European economic planning has grown steadily in the past few months while high level efforts to integrate British and American policy in Germany with European recovery have been traveling a difficult road.

LONDON, March 8 -- Unanimous agreement to abide by provisions of a voluntary limitation of advertising has been expressed to date by more than 2,400 companies that have replied to questionnaires sent out by the Federation of British Industries, it was learned today.

Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of President Truman's Air Policy Commission, stressed yesterday the need for the United States to develop at once a peerless protective air force, and to promote the Marshall Plan and measures to give European nations political security.

The favorable report by the Assembly Judiciary Committee and the Senate Public Education Committee on the Wachtel-Fino-Roman-Bannegan Bill a bill which will make admission to a college of one's choice based on facts free from discrimination -- is heartening.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) -- A foreign trade zone -- an "island" in a busy port -- will be established soon in San Francisco.

The news from Albany reporting several political deals in the making for creating new judgeships, and then filling them with judges chosen after careful weighing of political considerations, fills the air with a bad odor. One of these deals would give an additional county judge to the Bronx.

PARIS, March 8 -- Premier Robert Schuman's Cabinet surmounted a Communist and conservative attack on its anti-inflation law today in the National Assembly. This action came despite and perhaps in some measure because of Charles de Gaulle's recent open appeal for power.

William G. Maguire, chairman of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, told stockholders at the nineteenth annual meeting here yesterday that he was "not worried about" the threatened competition from the Michigan-Wisconsin Pipeline Company in the vast Detroit-Ann Arbor industrial area now served by Panhandle's natural gas.

A net income of $5,515,925 for 1947 was reported yesterday by P. Lorillard Company and its subsidiaries after taxes and all charges, equal to $2.15 a share on the common stock Net income for 1946 was $3,512,213, or $1.26 a common share.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Republican majority teamed up with Southern Democrats in the House today to snow under a move to restore anti-discrimination provisions that were in the original appropriations bill for the Department of Labor and the Federal Security Agency.

The final "Meistersinger" of the Metropolitan Opera season last night brought with it Set Svanholm's first appearance here as Walther. It is a notable interpretation: notable, aside from the brilliancy of the voice which has what it takes for Walther's tessitura, for such passages as the finale of the first act.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 8 (UP) -- The Communist-dominated Social Democratic party of Hungary voted itself out of existence today and decided unanimously to merge with the Communist party.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Two Curtis Cup team players, Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, and Miss Polly Riley of Ft. Worth, Tex., tied today for medalist honors in the twentieth annual Florida East Coast women's golf tournament.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 8 -- Today's final batting practice round brought the first accidental bean ball of the spring, with Al Gionfriddo the unfortunate victim.

Mischief-making gremlins were exorcised from a cranky old car as an added attraction at the Antique Auto Show, which opened yesterday in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-h)0*0*0*ifourth Street. The vehicle had shown signs of stubbornness for several hours and creaked protests on being disturbed.
Reports of widespread lawlessness in junior high schools in the Bronx were denied yesterday by principals of the schools and by Dr. William Jansen, superintendent of schools.

While no additional arrests were reported yesterday in Police Commissioner Arthur A. Wallander's city-wide survey of the return of the pinball game, Miles F. McDonald, Brooklyn District Attorney, announced he had been conducting his own investigation since last December.

ALBANY, March 8 -- A bill, the announced purpose of which is to make Surrogate James P. Delehanty of Manhattan, eligible for appointment as an official referee of the Supreme Court at twothirds his present pay when he leaves the surrogate's bench this year on reaching the age limit, came up in the Assembly tonight, but action was deferred until tomorrow.

JERUSALEM, March 8 -- The Haganah, Zionist militia, and Irgun Zvai Leumi, Zionist terrorist organization, have reached an agreement for "coordination of activities" under the over-all command of the former, a Jewish source said tonight.

Noel Coward's set of short plays, "Tonight at 8:30," starring Gertrude Lawrence, will retire from the National Theatre after Saturday night's performance, it was announced yesterday. Revived by Homer Curran, Russell Lewis and Howard Young and directed by the author himself, the plays will have eked out a total of twenty-seven performances.

War Assets Administration sales of surplus machine tools now being conducted in the Bronx. Buffalo, N.Y., and Linden, N.J., warehouses were criticized sharply her yesterday by Charles A. Simmons, president of the Simmons Machine Tool Corporation, Albany, N.Y.

The basketball front was humming with news and activity yesterday. Starting with the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's, there was not a dull moment. Even St. Francis College of Brooklyn bobbed up with an announcement of major importance.

Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last Week showed a decrease of 3 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

While delegates to the United Nations differ over the international control of fissionable materials and of the production of atomic bombs it is a relief to learn that, in accordance with the mandate it received from Congress, the Atomic Energy Commission will distribute radioactive isotopes free to cancer laboratories, except for small handling charges.

Based on the company's need for conserving cash to finance its expansion program, Pressed Metals of America, Inc., plans to pay a stock dividend of one share for each twenty held, J. W. Leighton, president, declared yesterday. The payment date will be set at a directors' meeting on March 27.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 9 -Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today he would accept the Presidency "if called by the American people," but would not actively seek it.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Dewey signed today the administration bill granting emergency pay increases involving $20,000,000 to 67,000 state employes.

VIENNA, March 8 -- An American military policeman was shot in the back by a Russian guard in Vienna at 1 o'clock this morning. Tonight after several blood transfusions he has a good chance of surviving but an even chance of losing his left arm.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) The Illinois State Athletic Commission today deferred action on its threat to suspend the managerial license of Mike Spinelli, New York, in connection with the ring death of Sam Baroudi, Akron, Ohio, Feb. 21.
NORFOLK, Va., March 8 (UP) -The Coast Guard raced to the rescue of a disabled tanker today soon after its men snatched twentyone sailors from a vessel being smashed by heavy seas.

Columbia clinched its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship last night by conquering Cornell, 73 -- 68, before a standing-room crowd of 3,000 at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

A veteran customs officer, investigating a flour barrel in the bake shop of the transport Marine Marlin after the ship arrived here yesterday from Europe, uncovered the first of thirteen packages of pure morphine valued at $500,000 in the illicit market.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 8 -- Differences of opinion on the meaning of security may have slowed the five-power negotiations here for a Western European pact, but it is expected that the treaty will be completed before the end of the week.
Despite the shortage of steel last year which restricted its production to 55,477 cars, the Packard Motor Car Company reported yesterday a net income for 1947 of $1,100,691, equal to 7 cents a share.

]uyer attendance was heavyyesterday at the opening qf theI American Toy Fair at the McAlpinand Breslin Hotels, and manufac-turers' showrooms at 200 FifthAvenue and 1107 Broadway. Aregistration of some 3,000 traderepresentatives, who viewed thelines of more than 800 exhibitorswas reported.

The National Federation of American Shipping reiterated its stand yesterday against the sections of the Marshall Plan that would authorize the transfer under charter of up to 300 United States merchant vessels to Western European nations.
BALTIMORE, March 8 (AP) The All-America Football Conference has taken over the franchise of the Baltimore Colts.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Executives of some of the country's largest steel companies told the Federal Trade Commission today that to the best of their knowledge there was never any consultation or agreement between competing companies with regard to the price charged for their products.

The fourth annual National Antiques Show opened yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden with 131 exhibitors displaying a variety of old-time furnishings. Exhibits range from a wooden lock 3,000 years old to a 1910 Cadillac -- as well as everyday furnishings from early American homes.

Bowing to persistent Russian pressure, the Finnish Government has decided to obey Stalin's summons and to send a delegation to Moscow to negotiate a "pact of friendship, cooperation and mutual assistance" with the Soviet Union similar to those cynical compacts which became Russian instruments for the subjugation of all Eastern and Central Europe.

The two-story L-shaped industrial building at 248-250 Union Street and 48-50 Westfield Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J., erected in 1903 by the late Hyppolite A. deRaismes, has been sold by the deRaimes estate to the Transportation Supply, Inc., at a price reported to have been between $35,000 and $40,000.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 8 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported today that 1947 production reached the highest peacetime level in the company's 146-year history.

LONDON, March 8 Spokesmenh)0*0*0*ifor American film interests and British officials were still seeking a formula tonight under which imports of American films into Britain could be resumed. A meeting between Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and Harold Wilson, president of the British Board of Trade, ended after five hours with a compromise still not worked out.

Sydenham Hospital announced yesterday gifts from business groups and churches that brought its emergency drive total to $174,400. The largest gift, $34,400, represented the combined efforts of men's clothing and woolen interests all over the nation and wash)0*0*0*igiven in memory of Louis Bachman, who, at the time of his death last July, was honorary president of the hospital.
LONDON, March 8 -- A second small group of Laborites added their challenge tonight to the British Government's policy on the partition of Palestine.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- One million new teachers will be needed in this country during the next decade, yet fewer than 500,000 will be trained, the National Education Association reported here today.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that its refusal to grant wage increases to its 100,000 unionized employes would not be altered by Congress of Industrial Organizations figures intended to prove that higher wages were justified by high corporation profits and high living costs.

The combined efforts of French and American milliners to create charmingly feminine hats for spring were evident yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman in a showing of Paris originals and models from the store's own custom-made department.

KANSAS CITY, March 9 (AP) -- Manhattan College of New York weathered a storm blown up by an unheralded Arkansas Teachers quintet to lead three more favorites into the second round of the National Intercollegiate basketball tournament today.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Republican legislative leaders indicated strongly today that they would pass their transit fare bill, over Democratic opposition if necessary, unless Mayor William O'Dwyer made a new request for the enactment of the transit legislation sponsored by the New York City administration.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Opposition to some aspects of the pending state university bill is developing among Catholic and other private colleges and universities, it was learned tonight, with the result that another bill to overcome objections will be introduced with administration backing.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- John R. Steelman, assistant to the President, sent back two Congressional subpoenas today and said Mr. Truman had told him to disregard them.

Surely the off-again-on-again news lately on prospects for a fare rise on the New York City transit system does not make good sense. Democratic legislators from the city are apparently seeing bogeymen in their dreams. And we suspect that they have even been able to infect the man in Gracie Mansion with some of their nervousness.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- The United Nations Security Council again got nowhere today in its search for a Governor for the Free Territory of Trieste. The United States and Britain again turned down Russia's candidates and Russia again made it clear that she did not think much of theirs.

FOR thirteen years, from 1933 to 1946, Joseph George Hitrec lived in India, earning his living in an advertising agency, writing short stories and in journalism and steeping himself in Indian life and thought as few non-Indians have done. perhaps the fact that Mr. Hitrec is a Yugoslav by birth aided him to shake off the constraint which handicaps so many AngloSaxons in their half-hearted efforts to understand India.

LONDON, March 9 -- Britain rejected the contention of the Guatemalan Government that doubts exist as to the validity of this country's sovereignty in British Honduras in a note presented to Guatemala by the British Minister there today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 9 -- The nominees for the bizonal High Court were disclosed today after bipartite officials had prodded German authorities to make public the list on which both houses of the new economic legislature have agreed.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Ordinary sprinters were running faster than stake horses during the first half mile of six-furlong dashes at Tropical Park today, thanks to a strong wind behind them and a track that had changed from sloppy last night to lightning-fast this afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 -- With daylight saving time almost certain to go into effect throughout California at 2:01 A. M. Sunday in an effort to conserve power, almost general observance of the change was indicated. Exceptions are transportation systems having operations extending outside the state.

Producers of standard brand appliances in short supply are adopting punitive measures against distributors using their merchandise for forced tie-in sales of unwanted items, distributors and dealers reported yesterday. One large distributor declared that manufacturers have decided to follow the lead of Mullins Manufacturing Corporation and the Proctor Electric Company, both strongly opposed to forced tie-ins by distributors.

Pace-setters from start to finish, the De Witt Clinton and Erasmus Hall basketball teams won their first-round games and moved into the quarter-finals of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs before a crowd of 6,000 at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

An amendment to the rules that will confine classes for "specials only" at dog shows to champions of record was approved by the delegates of the American Kennel Club at their annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday. Later the directors met and re-elected all officers, with Dudley P. Rogers of Danvers, Mass., again president.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 9 -- Driven forward by the pressure of events elsewhere in the world, the negotiators of a five-power Western European pact made today "a tremendous lot of jumpy progress," in the words of one who attended the conference.

A new variety of tinned tuna has arrived in town for the fish casseroles, sandwiches and salads starred during Lent. It's the method of canning that makes it new. Cut open a container, and the cook is confronted for the first time with appetizing bite-sized chunks.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 9 -- At a stormy meeting of the Yonkers Common Council tonight in City Hall, Thomas V. Kennedy, city controller for two years and acting city manager since last Feb. 14, was appointed city manager unanimously.

Accusing the International Typographical Union, AFL, of having made normal collective bargaining relationships "impossible" in the city's $300,000,000-a-year commercial printing industry, the Printers League Section of the New York Employing Printers Association announced last night that it would post notices in all its composing rooms today lengthening the standard work week without overtime pay.
Borough President James A. Burke of Queens declared yesterday he had received many complaints of dirty streets in the borough and lack of garbage collection.

These are the days when the foresighted gardener begins to think about his agricultural equipment. If his seed packets, ordered after profound thought from the catalogue, have arrived, and he has read at least three times every word of the directions for planting on each packet, he now grows restless and finds it soothing to check over his digging tools.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall made public tonight a civilian survey of Japan which recommends scrapping present Allied policy on Japanese reparations and the rebuilding of key Japanese industries such as steel to levels higher than their wartime peak.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Augustus E. Giegengack, the Public Printer, resigned today.
BRUSSELS, March 9 (AP) -- Negotiators at the Western European conference were reported tonight to have reached a basis for converting their projected union into a solid five-way military alliance.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Truman will share a speakers' platform with Gov. William M. Tuck of Virginia, a leader in the Southern revolt against the President, on April 2 at Williamsburg, Va.

PARIS, March 9 -- French cardinals and archbishops issued today a joint statement urging the release of France's German war prisoners and suggesting a general amnesty for Frenchmen doubtfully accused of war time collaboration. They did not follow Italian prelates' sanctions against Catholics supporting communism.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered part of Monday's losses, and closed 30 to 62 points net higher.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 9 -- Efforts of "agitators" who seek to stir up debate between Roman Catholics and Protestants on birth control, were assailed here tonight by Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston. The prelate spoke at a meeting in the Bushell Memorial Auditorium in connection with the sixteenth annual convention of the National Catholic Conference on Family Life.

Paul S. Hitlin has sold to the 70 Irving Corporation the two vacant five-story buildings at 68 and 70 Irving Place, on a plot 52 by 106.8 feet. The buyer is reported planning to remodel the two houses immediately into small suites for thirty-five families.

Technicolor, Inc. and its subsidiary, Technicolor Motion Picture Corporation, in the report for 1947 yesterday showed net profit after all deductions of $1,422,752, equal to $1.55 a share, compared with $436,168 or 48 cents in 1946. Net sales for 1947 were $17,407,975 against $13,057,510 in 1946.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Atomic Energy Commission told Congress today that it was searching for a basic labor policy that would assure unbroken plant operations and at the same time avoid the use of arbitrary Government authority every time a dispute arose.

LONDON, March 9 -- According to well-authenticated reports here tonight, differences between the British Government and American film interests on the British tax on imported films have finally been adjusted.

Attendance in the Broadway theatres suffered a sharp decline during the last fortnight. This became noticeable last week when grosses began to tumble. For example, one of the sturdy attractions was off $9,583 in comparison to the previous week's receipts.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House by 337 to 37 granted $200,000 today to its Committee on Un-American Activities. This was the largest sum ever singly authorized in the ten years of its life. As a matter exclusively the concern of the House, the approval was final and required no Senate concurrence.

The reconverted Panama liner Cristobal is due to arrive here today from the Bethlehem shipyard in Quincy, Mass., and to re-enter regular passenger service between New York and the Canal Zone next Wednesday.

Hanson W. Baldwin, military and naval editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and William L. Laurence, science reporter, agreed yesterday that the United States would have a protracted breathing space before Russia could match it in quantity and quality of atomic bombs.

New York's Rangers have no intention of appealing Billy Taylor's expulsion from hockey, Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick said yesterday. Kilpatrick is president of Madison Square Garden, which owns the club.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 9 -- When a fellow gets to looking at the Detroit Tigers he begins to appreciate that there's a certain amount of truth to Branch Rickey's thesis that satisfied ball players don't make good ball players.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- The right of Britain to call upon the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund for help in feeding children in the German occupation zones was upheld here today by legal experts of the United Nations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 10 -- The first figures on Soviet production turned over to the United Nations by the Russian Government -- including statistics for twenty-four major industries -- was made public here today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- House and Senate leaders were deadlocked tonight in an effort to find a mutually acceptable formula for speeding legislation on the European Recovery Program to enactment before the Communist bid for power in Italy April 18.

Voting 130 to 48, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted last night a resolution urging that Army courts-martial authority be taken out of the hands of commanding officers and placed with an independent Judge Advocate General's Department.

My attention has been drawn to a dispatch from your foreign correspondent, Cyrus L. Sulzberger, in THE TIMES of Feb. 14. The implications in the statements attributed to Andre Malraux are so palpably false that, unavoidably late as is this rejoinder, I urgently request that you publish it.

LONDON, March 9 -- Britain's "Economic Survey for 1948," issued today as a Government White Paper, demonstrates with frightening clarity that Britain's fate depends on aid this year through the European Recovery Program.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, was defeated by Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia in the fourth round of the tournament for the chess championship of the world contested yesterday in place of the adjourned match between Botvinnik and Smyslov, according to report from the Netherlands.

In your editorial "The Seaway Case Unproved" you write: "From President Truman down the line these advocates have relied for the most part on generalizations not adequately supported.
