Then you proceed to generalize wholly and irresponsibly on certain points put forward by those who advocate the Seaway.

Net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., and its subsidiaries operating in the United States in 1947 rose to $276,131,392 from the total of $252,493,278 in the preceding year. Consolidated net profit last year amounted to $8,119,349, compared with $13,947,960 in 1946, Joel S. Mitchell, president, reported yesterday.
On Feb. 27 THE NEW YORK TIMES stated editorially that:

ALBANY, March 9 -- Operation of the fair trade program by which uniform liquor prices are fixed for the entire state has been "satisactory and encouraging," the State Liquor Authority said today in its annual report to the Legislature.

ALBANY, March 9 -- While the State Legislature was passing a number of bills today relating to housing and the rights of tenants, Governor Dewey announced he had signed two measures designed to encourage housing projects through part tax exemption.

The custom salon of Henri Bendel was charged with the excitement of the Paris openings yesterday when the shop's French imports were shown. Skirts spread over stiffened net or canvas, shoulders were unpadded, waists indented.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer today named Donna Reed to play the leading feminine role of "The Story of Monty Stratton" with Van Johnson and Frank Morgan. Preliminary testing has already begun; film and natural camera work is scheduled to start early next week with Royal Rowland directing.

JERUSALEM, March 9 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine cabled to Lake Success today details of an agreement for a provisional Jewish Government comprising all political groups, including one Communist.

In these transitionary times the world must fall back on religion for "the inner strength to bring about a new epoch," Dr. Leo Baeck, president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism, said last night at the annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues.

BOSTON, March 9 -- Don Gallinger, suspended Bruins' wing, promptly declared his innocence today when informed he had been sidelined indefinitely by Col. Clarence S. Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, pending further investigation of his association with a Detroit gambler.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 10 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that he would not discuss politics with correspondents and that the Allied occupation of Japan would not "change in the slightest" as the result of his entry into the American political campaign.

LONDON, March 9 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor, rivals in the United States, formally joined hands here today to urge all-out support for the European Recovery Program by Europe's trade unionists.

Banking groups headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., bought yesterday at competitive sales $37,396,000 of first mortgage twenty-year bonds of the Central Pacific Railway Company and $10,000,000 of first mortgage thirty-year bonds of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

While the "new look" was evident in the Jonai collection, seen yesterday noon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton, it was strongly controlled, for Jonai approves of style but not extremes. There was a pleasant swish and sway in skirts with a few rippling into wide hems, but there were also slender lines in woolens and town crepes.

Diametrically opposed views of the course the United States should follow in relation to China were offered yesterday at the 120th forum in the series. "What's On Your Mind?" sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- The United States entered the point-by-point discussion of Soviet atomic proposals today and charged that Russia was unwilling to grant to the proposed international control agency any power to search out dangerous activities.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., March 9 (AP) -- Thirteen of twenty printers employed by The News-Sun, a daily newspaper here, resigned today from the International Typographical Union, AFL, in protest against the ITU's employer relations policy.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Charles R. Seal, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Water Carriers and Freight Forwarders, advised the ICC today to deny a request of the American Trucking Associations, Inc., that the ICC regulate the rates of the Delaware-New Jersey Ferry Company.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 9 -- Playing their first exhibition of the year, the Yankees for eight innings today appeared to be heading into some stout opposition. There was a stiff gale blowing out of the west and off the mound there came some even stiffer Detroit pitching.

An analysis of the cultural, political and economic changes in the Latin-American countries, written by Carleton Beals, author of "Dawn Over the Amazon," will be published by Bobbs-Merrill on April 12. It will be entitled "Lands of the Dawning Morrow: The Awakening from Rio Grande to Cape Horn."

ROME, March 9 -- Gen. Leone Zingales, who was ordered last year to investigate what happened to the treasure taken from Benito Mussolini before he was executed, said in an interview in the Risorgimento Liberale today that most of it went to the Communist party.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative on the United Nations Security Council, issued a statement tonight declaring that the Soviet Union's demand for measures to carry out the partition of Palestine had pre-judged the case.

The stock market eased further yesterday to within striking distance again of the year's low. The further deterioration of prices extended to every major section of the market and left the combined averages 0.73 point lower on the day, with the industrials down even more sharply.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 9 -- Former Maj. Gen. Royal B. Lord, of the United States Army, whose year's contract with the Peron Government to analyze the five-year plan and assist in getting it started has not been renewed, said today he planned to continue working here as head of his own construction company.
ATHENS, March 9 (UP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis predicted today that Government troops would defeat guerrilla forces by the end of the summer.

That we are now in fact on the road that leads to the great conventions, to the choice of party candidates and to the election of a President who will be called upon to serve his country in a critical period is made clear by the day's news. Yesterday New Hampshire voted, the first state to hold a 1948 Presidential primary.

Signed Desmond Bills extending to July 1, 1949, provisions for the partial tax exemption of uncompleted state-aided housing, and permitting cities to grant partial tax exemption to public housing company projects completed by Jan. 1, 1952. Received Milton Saaulpaugh, Columbia County chairman; Mrs. Betty Hawley Donnelly, member of the New York City Board of Education, and a delegation of members of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.

This week there has been a French fashion invasion of New York City, with imports being shown in several of the big uptown specialty shops. Yesterday morning two houses displayed the couture creations. They were Bonwit Teller and Henri Bendel.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Should Gen. Douglas MacArthur win the Republican Presidential nomination he would have to retire from the Army to campaign. This is provided in a joint Army-Navy agreement announced March 10, 1944, and still in effect.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Union Producing Company, Shreveport, La., received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to redeem for cash, on or before March 26, $1,000,000 of its $37,000,000 of 6 per cent debentures, due on March 1, 1952.

Advertisements of new securities issues, although generally condensed to bare essentials because of the implications of the Federal Securities Act, are read by a large portion of the persons intended to be reached thereby, according to a poll taken by Roland Palmedo, a partner in the banking firm of Lehman Brothers.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 9 -- Purchasing agents will be remiss in their duties unless they study the requirements of their companies and get ready now to take any actions which will be required if over-all business in the United States drops off 20 to 25 per cent later on this year.

Substitutions in an undermargined securities account without the requirement that additional margin be put up will soon be allowed under a new ruling by the Federal Reserve Board. The substitutions in such an account, that is one having a margin of less than 75 per cent, may be made by sale of one security and purchase of another, according to the board.

Fitzhugh Lee Minnigerode, whose death in San Antonio was announced yesterday, was, indeed, as Philip Gibbs said -- and it was at Queen Alexandra's funeral in Westminster Abbey that he said it -- a dramatic figure: the very pattern of a cavalry officer, homegrown American model.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Plans to speed the collection of voluntary contributions from among nearly 8,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor for "educational" purposes in the national political campaign were advanced here today at a meeting of Labor's League for Political Education.

The local basketball beehives will be buzzing today and tonight, with action listed for scholastic, professional, collegiate, paraplegic and industrial league fives at Madison Square Garden and the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
Anticipating sharp competition in the soft goods field, Julius Kayser Co. has reorganized its sales operation for more intensive selling and customer contact, it was announced yesterday.

CONCORD, N. H., March 9 -- The forces supporting Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination scored a satisfactory but not sweeping victory in today's New Hampshire primary, the first in the country at which delegates to the 1948 Republican National Convention were elected.

Production, sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in 1947 were at higher levels than ever before, Perley S. Wilcox, chairman, and Thomas J. Hargrave, president, informed stockholders in the forty-fifth annual report, to be made public today.

Jakob Gimpel, Polish pianist, gave first performances of two works by contemporary composers when he played last night at Carnegie Hall in his sixth New York recital since his debut here nine years ago.

William Gage Brady Jr., president of the National City Bank of New York, has been appointed chairman of the board to succeed the late Gordon S. Rentschler, it was announced yesterday, after a meeting of the board. Mr. Rentschler died last Wednesday in Havana, Cuba.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- Dr. Jose Arce of Argentina challenged the opinion - giving powers of the United Nations Secretariat today and started a controversy that involved Secretary General Trygve Lie, the Security Council, the Palestine Commission, the Charter and the press.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- The "urgent need" for immediate preparedness in every phase of our national defense was stressed here tonight by United States Senator Edward Martin and Gov. James H. Duff, Pennsylvania Republicans.

Hal Weber, vice president in charge of media and research of Fote, Cone Belding, yesterday called on the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association to abandon group discussion meetings in their present form.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 9 -- Flying squads of Communists, calling themselves workers' committees, entered the editorial offices of all Helsinki daily newspapers today, warning the managing editors that all "anti-Soviet propaganda" must forthwith disappear from the news and editorial columns "or else."

Negro workers received a much larger measure of justice from employers than most people expected during the last year, Lester B. Granger, executive secretary of the National Urban League, said yesterday at the league's annual meeting in its headquarters, 1133 Broadway.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 9 -- Two of Leo Durocher's player problems for the coming campaign received much attention in a workout today. Ray Sanders put on a Dodger uniform for the first time and Handsome Harry Taylor, the ace righthander who had arm trouble last year, gave his valuable flipper its initial test in a long warmup.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- With the March 15 income tax deadline less than a week away, the Internal Revenue Bureau today closed a legal loophole which it suspects commodity speculators have been using to dodge their tax payments. Commissioner George J. Schoeneman announced that in their March 15 returns commodity traders will not be permitted to stretch out their trading accounts artificially to make them long-term instead of short-term transactions.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- President Weston W. Adams of the Boston Bruins said today that Don Gallinger was off the payroll. Then he told a news conference: "Of course I hope he's exonerated, but we want the facts either way. The case is not closed.

LANSING, Mich., March 9 -- Denouement of the strange case of what happened, when, to whom and where gained new stature today in the National Hockey League when William (Billy) Taylor of the New York Rangers was banned for life and Don Gallinger of the Boston Bruins was suspended indefinitely by the president of the circuit, Clarence S. Campbell.

Theodore Heilig, 50 - year - old chemical manufacturer, and two Brooklyn concerns he heads were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on four counts charging that they had filed false financial statements in connection with the renegotiation of 1944 and 1945 war contracts totaling $3,946,000.

Members of the Parents Association of Public School 8, at the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge, think they have found at least one way to prevent their children from catching colds. They have organized a unique cloakroom checking service so the youngsters do not have to eat their lunches while wearing their overcoats, scarves and hats.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to the Fino-De Pasquale bill creating an additional county judgeship in the Bronx. It now goes to Governor Dewey for signature or veto.

A showing by Esther Dorothy, at 68 East Fifty-sixth Street, is always a treat with its unusual designs in furs. The one yesterday was no exception. There were fabulous fur handbaskets, oversized ascots, blazers of red and blue fur and a quilted taffeta suit with an Indian lamb-lined jacket.

"Sitting Pretty," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy, which arrives at the Roxy, is this mornings lone film newcomer. Robert Young, Maureen O'Hara and Clifton Webb head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Walter Lang and produced by Samuel G. Engel from a screen play by F. Hugh Herbert, Richard Haydn, Louise Allbritton and Ed Begley appear in supporting roles.

Ignored by the National Invitation tournament, shunned by the National Collegiate A. A., the C. C. N. Y. basketball team expressed its sentiments most eloquently by upsetting New York University, 60 -- 57, in a feverish struggle at Madison Square Garden last night.

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, was honor guest yesterday afternoon at a reception in appreciation of his activities as chairman of the general committee in charge of the Fifteenth Annual Brotherhood Week series of meetings, from Feb. 22 to 29, under auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
VIENNA, Austria, March 9 (AP) -- United States Army doctors reported today that the shattered left arm of Pfc. Jack Grunden, who was shot by a Russian sentry Sunday night, probably could be saved.
Maier R. Pfeffer has been appointed merchandise manager of Barney's Clothes, Inc. He formerly was for more than twenty years with the Larkey Company, Newark.
NANKING, March 9 -- Strategic and tactical advice was listed today by United States Army sources here as the most important requisite for any program of large-scale military assistance to China.

Commissioner of Health Harry S. Mustard reported yesterday that the city's 18,000 tuberculosis patients included 7,700 new cases, of which only 17 per cent were in the minimal stage where most good could be done, while 48 per cent were in the advanced stage.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Senate approved today an amendment to the Motor Vehicle Law providing for the use next year of this year's automobile license plates with the addition of a metal sticker showing that they have been renewed.

DUBLIN, March 9 -- At a press conference here tonight Prime Minister John A. Costello outlined his attitude toward the suspended Irish Airlines transatlantic tri-weekly service from Shannon to New York and Boston.

Finland must be saved from Russian domination or absorption in the Russian phere. If Finland is forced to capitulate the position of Sweden will become untenable. With Sweden gone, Norway will be lost.
Opened meetings of new Labor-Management Board.

Directors of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock for payment March 31. Last year, shareholders received 50 cents quarterly plus extras of 50 cents each in September and December.

The retail druggist was described yesterday as the "bottleneck" confronting manufacturers' and wholesalers' efforts to cash in on the greatly increased potential market for drug store products. The condition, and its cure, keynoted the address of Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of media and research of the J. Walter Thompson Company, before a joint manufacturer-wholesaler session of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman from New York State, gave his endorsement yesterday to President Truman for a full four-year term in the White House.

Isadore B. Bernstein, 48-year-old sportswear manufacturer, of 840 South Serrano Avenue, Los Angeles, won an award of $102,500 from a Federal jury yesterday as the result of injuries he suffered in July, 1945. A seven-pound globe slipped from a chandelier and struck him on the head while he was purchasing textiles from a concern at 257 West Thirty-ninth Street.
SEOUL, Korea, March 9 -- Korean hopes for the scheduled general elections on May 9 under United Nations sponsorship suffered a severe setback today.

Eight striking cable workers and sympathizers were arrested on disorderly conduct charges yesterday while conducting a "filibuster" at the offices of the All-America Cables and Radio Corporation, a Rockefeller Plaza.

LONDON, March 9 -- An elderly cherub with a cigar almost as big as the butt end of a billiard cue, Winston Churchill rode around the electoral district of North Croydon this afternon in an open sports car drumming up votes for the candidate of his Conservative party in the Parliamentary by-election there.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 9 -- A two-man delegation purporting to represent the conservative elements of Palestine Jews was reported here today to have approached Haj Amin el-Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem and chairman of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, a few days ago, on the question of a compromise in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In the first trial of its kind in the country, the Air Force and Civil Aeronautics Administration have joined hands to reduce the dangers of bad-weather airplane landings here, it was announced today. Some officials believed the plan might be applied to other congested air spaces.

WASHINGTON, March 9. The State Department is obsessed these days with the rush of great events in Europe. The minority revolution in Czechoslovakia -- much neater and quicker than the Nazi effort in 1938-1939 -- and the Communist electoral challenge to the de Gasperi government in Italy next month make our plodding legislative process seem extremely slow.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The industry-Government scrap iron and steel mission to Germany released a report today on its discovery that there are more 10,000,000 tons of scrap available for export in Germany. It also set forth a program containing eleven recommendations for expediting the sale and export of substantial amounts of this scrap to the United States, Great Britain and Western European countries.

For the second day in a row a heavy calendar forced the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday to postpone until today hearing of appeals by five alleged alien Communists who have been denied writs of habeas corpus.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,276, compared with 1,404 last week and 1,510 in the corresponding week of 1947, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 719 arrivals yesterday against 504 last Tuesday.
CHICAGO, March 9 (UP) -- Unemployment funds built up by the states for payments to workers who lose their jobs total almost $7,000,000,000, a survey indicated today.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., last year transacted sales of $95,715,638, the largest peacetime volume in its history, and 38 per cent above 1946 sales of $69,313,127, according to the annual report issued to stockholders today. Sales for the last pre-war year of 1941 approximated $20,000,000, the report notes.

The eleventh-hour rallying of citizen support in meeting the financial crisis at Sydenham Hospital was one of the most dramatic events in the long annals of the public's generosity to causes which capture their imagination. From the nickels and dimes to the splendid and clinching $25,000 gift of Samuel Rubin, the response was deeply moving in its generosity and effective in its collective result.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Dr. John P. Hubbard, director of the two-year study of child health services in the United States being conducted by the American Academy of Pediatrics, today told a Senate Health subcommittee that at least 19 per cent of children younger than 14 are in counties where there are no organized school-health services.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Fino-Clancy bill to require New York City theatres to make large payments to the Fire Department pension fund was virtually killed today when its sponsors introduced a series of amendments limiting its application.
BATAVIA, March 9 (Aneta) -- The Interim Federal Government for Indonesia, installed today is as follows:

The largest remaining singly owned block of stock in the banking establishment of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., -- 25,000 shares held by the estate of the late Thomas W. Lamont -- is to be offered for sale to the public soon by an investment banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Smith, Barney Co., Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. and Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.
Allegheny County, Pa., sold issues of bonds aggregating $12,750,000 yesterday to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.3099 for 2 1/2s.

HAVANA, March 9 -- An Ecuadorean amendment committing the proposed International Trade Organization to establish "equity" between the prices of raw materials and of manufactured goods was voted down by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today. The vote was 27 to 14 with thirteen abstentions after Ecuador insisted on a roll-call.

ALBANY, March 9 -- With affirmative action by the Assembly today, the State Legislature completed ratification of the proposed amendment to the Federal Constitution that would limit the tenure of the President to two terms. Approval of the proposal had been urged by Governor Dewey in a message to the Legislature in January.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 -- Buddy Kerr, star shortstop, came to terms with the Giants today and is expected to arrive at camp in time to get in some practice during the week-end series with the Chicago White Sox.
LONDON, March 9 -- Business was almost at a standstill in the stock market here today, buyers preferring to wait details of the Government's economic survey before entering into new commitments.

In his annual budget message at the end of January, Governor Dewey discussed at some length the salaries of state employes, steps previously taken to make them more equitable, and recommended an adjustment upward to cost $20,000,000. That promise has now been kept, with the signing of a bill passed by the Legislature.

A consolidated net profit of $23,553,951 was reported yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation for 1947 after taxes and all charges, an increase of $4,787,518 over the $18,766,433 earned the year before.

Eamon de Valera, former Prime Minister of Ireland, received yesterday the welcome of the city where he was born. From Park Avenue, through the East Side, Fulton Fish Market, South Street, the financial district of lower Broadway, and City Hall Plaza New Yorkers turned out to wave cheery greetings to "Dev" as he rode in an open car through the streets for the city's traditional greeting to distinguished visitors.

The smiling Aegean isles which make up the Dodecanese once more fly the flag of Greece after languishing for more than four centuries under foreign rule. It was appropriate that King Paul and Queen Frederika should proclaim renewed sovereignty from the deck of the destroyer Themistocles, for the name of the victor who saved Greece at Salamis weaves the islands again into the network of universal history.

An atmosphere of relaxation filled Grand Central Palace yesterday on the second day of the International Flower Show. Before exhibitors had put the finishing touches on their new entries by 10 A. M., visitors were lined up at the doors.

Customs officers will increase their vigilance in searching ships coming here from France and Mediterranean ports to frustrate attempts to smuggle narcotics, Herman Lipski, deputy surveyor in charge of the service's enforcement division, said yesterday.

LONDON, March 9 -- The British Army, the largest, best-equipped and most experienced national force between the iron curtain and the United States, is to be reshuffled and drastically reduced in this critical year, Emanuel Shinwell, Secretary for War, told the House of Commons today in a frank speech on this year's Army appropriation.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- In a hat-hoisting finish which had some 13,000 Boston Garden fans screaming, the N. C. A. A. defending champions of Holy Cross tonight beat a speedy, stubborn Colgate basketball team, 65 -- 62. George Kaftan dropped in the last five points to overcome Colgate's 62 -- 60 lead.

Gloria Swanson, who has not been very active recently in the entertainment world, will undertake a new television program this summer. Over The Daily News video outlet, WPIX, which is scheduled to go on the air on June 15, she will offer a weekly show devoted to fashions, home making, kitchen hints and interviews.
BATAVIA, Java, March 9 (AP) -- The Dutch formally installed an Interim Netherlands East Indies Government today and renewed the invitation to the Indonesian Republic to join.
The Gdynia America Line announced yesterday that the liner Batory in 1947 carried 13,588 passengers on nine round trips between New York and Southampton, Copenhagen and Gdynia.

Something new in men's fashions in neckties was displayed yesterday at the eleventh annual hobby show of the New York Medical College of Flower - Fifth Avenue Hospital in the college building at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street.
BERLIN, March 9 -- Czechoslovak refugees entering the United States occupation zone of Germany will receive full protection, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, said today.

ROME, March 9 -- Figures as well as forces play an important part in Italy's political war. Italians are inclined to personalize ideas. They speak oftener of de Gasperi, Togliatti, Nenni, Saragat, Lombardo and the rest than of the parties they represent. Economic policy is "Einaudi," Minister of Finance.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 (AP) -- The Midvale Company reported today a loss of $1,186,727 on sales of $14,829,373 in 1947, compared to a loss of $1,861,284 on sales of $14,665,297 in 1946.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 -- Concern over proposed Federal legislation to aid wildlife conservation and the lack of Federal aid to help certain species of fish, birds and animals threatened with extinction were expressed today by speakers before the thirteenth annual North American Wildlife Conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 9 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council refused tonight to consider Yugoslavia's complaint charging the United States with damaging her economy by withholding her gold reserves. The 14-to-3 vote, with one abstention, was recorded toward the end of an acrimonious, ten-hour session, and it found the three nations of the Soviet bloc on the defeated side of a particularly bitter parliamentary battle.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The timing of President Truman's announcement that he is willing to run for another term was entirely his own, it was learned today as highly placed Democrats, often irked by past independent action, conceded the effect this time should be helpful.

Employes in the warehouse of R. H. Macy Co. in Long Island City, Queens, voted yesterday to transfer their union representation from the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Attorneys for some of the country's largest steel manufacturers charged the Federal Trade Commission with "unfair" treatment today after they lost a legal battle in which the agency's lawyers gained possession of price lists covering thousands of items produced by the companies.

Permanent guests at the Beacon Hotel will pay less rent because their landlord was successful in a legal action for a cut in its tax assessment, it was learned yesterday. The nearly 300 tenants affected recently had their rents raised by 25 per cent, but because the hotel succeeded in obtaining a reduction in its assessment, the rent rise has been cut back to 15 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Grain markets closed on a strong rally after an early break on the Board of Trade today, wheat closing 1 cent lower to 1 1/4 cents higher after being off as much as 7 1/2 cents on May at the opening. Corn was 3 1/8 cents lower to 1 1/4 cents higher.

A hundred years ago New York was still an overgrown village gradually creeping north on the island of Manhattan. Broadway between Twenty-first Street and Twenty-fifth Street was just being converted from a cow-path to a city street. An ambitious project to bring water from the Croton River, forty miles away, and to store it in a reservoir on Murray Hill near Forty-second Street had just been completed.

Prizewinners have been announced by the Village Art Center in the non-jury exhibition of "Scenes of Old New York," at the galleries, 224 Waverly Place, through March 28. The winners include Mario Bacchelli, Bertram Goodman, E. B. Savage and Sandy Sutherland.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Some 1,600 stockholders of the Tucker Corporation, including one from Capetown, South Africa, today unanimously re-elected nine of ten directors.

TOKYO, March 9 -- After seventeen days of interparty negotiations, Dr. Hitoshi Ashida, Japanese Premier-elect, tonight succeeded in forming a new coalition Government. The ceremonies of its investiture will be held tomorrow before Emperor Hirohito.

Courtrooms ranging from an "antiquated Civil War era firetrap" to space that a Magistrate's Court must vacate when a Court of Special Sessions wants to sit were depicted yesterday by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in his annual report to Mayor O'Dwyer.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- W. Averill Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, told Congress today that inflation was still the country's major economic problem despite recent price drops.

LONDON, March 9 -- Three British Foreign Secretaries, past and present, spoke tonight of the spontaneous unity of the English-speaking peoples -- particularly the unity of Britain and the United States -- and expressed the opinion that this unity was the world's greatest hope for peace and security.

The decision of the Armed Services Committee to proceed immediately with hearings on the question of Universal Military Training should be welcomed by everyone, we believe, including those who are opposed to this proposal. In open hearings these opponents, as well as those who favor UMT, will have an opportunity to present the arguments on which a decision can be made.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Jim Ferrier and Cary Middlecoff won the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament today, 1 up, in thirty-six holes after nearly tossing it away. They defeated Ellsworth Vines and Ed Furgol with a par 4 on the 385-yard thirty-sixth hole in the finals.

An unemployed restaurant baker, seriously wounded, was arrested on a homicide charge last night, sixteen hours after he allegedly shot and killed one patrolman and wounded another in Washington Heights, about 4:30 A. M.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that there would be no change for the present in this city's program of permitting children to leave classes during school hours for religious instruction.

The Port of New York Authority, in connection with its comprehensive program for the development of the city owned waterfront, has made a thorough study of the possible destruction of subsurface pier pilings by marine borers, such as the Teredo Navalis, or shipworm, and the Limnoria, a minute crustacean.
A new program, costing less than $100,000 a year, that would save the lives of hundreds of babies annually in New York has been proposed by the city Health Department, it was reported yesterday.

KONGSBERG, Norway, March 9 -- Flashing flawless style in flights of 191 and 192 feet before his hometown crowd, Petter Hugsted, Norwegian Olympic champion, outscored an international field of 150 skiers in winning the famous Hannibal jumping competition today, under ideal weather conditions.

PRAGUE, March 9 -- Andrew Spiro, a Slovak employe of the United States consulate in Bratislava, was arrested shortly after the consulate was opened March 1, it was learned today. Espionage and conspiracy charges are expected to be brought against him.
Random notes:

NEWARK, N. J., March 9 -- The longest work stoppage in the history of building construction in this state ended today when members of the North Jersey District Council of Ironworkers, AFL, returned to their jobs at a $3 an hour scale, fifty cents more than they were getting when the strike was called Dec. 16.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 9 -- Philip S. Shannon Jr., counsellor to veterans at Columbia University, is an admitted Communist, Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff declared here today in a decision granting temporary alimony of $50 a week, custody of the couple's children and counsel fees of $400 to Mr. Shannon's wife.

Joe Yancey, Negro coach of the Pioneer Club, was honored yesterday when the New York Track Writers announced that he had been selected to receive their award "for long and meritorious service" in behalf of track and field athletics.

Problems of successful competition in a buyers' market can be met by modernization of product design, more than 400 leading corporate sales managers were told by four leading industrial designers yesterday during the luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Twelve milliners presented their hats before nearly 400 members of the Fashion Group, millinery division, at a luncheon yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel for the benefit of the Red Cross.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Matthew Alexander Henson of New York City, 81-year-old Negro credited with having played an important part in the late Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary's expedition to the North Pole on April 6, 1909, tonight received the gold medal of the Geographic Society of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate's new seven-member investigating subcommittee agreed unanimously today to begin at once a behind-the-scenes inquiry into the acts, policies and authorities of Attorney General Tom C. Clark and the Department of Justice.

In closed meeting, heard Argentina criticize Secretariat document affirming Council's right to take action in Palestine. Heard United States and Britain turn down Soviet Union's candidates for Trieste Governorship.

PRAGUE, March 10 -- The conversation between Czechoslovak President Edward Benes and Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk yesterday may hold the key to M. Masaryk's death, in the opinion of some who knew him well.

The Bronx court-packing bill creating an additional county judgeship, born of a political deal between Democrats and Republicans, has made amazingly smooth progress in the Legislature. Hardly had John J. Knewitz, Republican leader of the Bronx, completed his mission to Albany when the Fino-De Pasquale bill was reported out of both Senate and Assembly committees in a remarkable showing of simultaneous unanimity.
John R. Gregg, inventor of the Gregg system of shorthand, who died Feb. 1, left an estate of between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000, it was learned yesterday.

Most agencies of the Youth Activities Division of the New York Catholic Charities were unable to meet the demand for camp facilities last year, the Rev. Harold S. Engel, director, reported yesterday. They had to be expanded to serve 568 boys and girls for the 1947 season.

PRAGUE, March 10 -- Jan Masaryk, veteran non-party Foreign Minister of the new Communist-dominated Czechoslovak Cabinet, jumped to his death at 6 o'clock this morning, the Prague Government announced at noon today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- James and William Cagney and the United Artists Distributing Company have settled their legal differences and the Cagneys have agreed to deliver "The Time of Your Life," which they completed last year, to UA immediately for release by that company, it was disclosed today in a joint announcement.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP) -- Boston's Bruins tonight scored three goals in the final period to defeat the New York Rangers and move within 2 points of clinching a National Hockey League post-season play-off berth before a capacity crowd of 13,909 at the Garden

Jews who are trying to rebuild their communal life in Europe are as much in danger from Communism as from anti-Semitism, Joel David Wolfsohn, director of European operations for the American Jewish Committee, told the group's New York chapter at a meeting yesterday in the Martinique Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault of "Flying Tigers" renown, told Congress grimly today that China was preventing Russia from precipitating aggressive warfare in Europe.

KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Beloit College today became a top favorite in the National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball tournament by eliminating Lawrence Tech of Detroit. Manhattan College of New York and Xavier University of Cincinnati also won impressive victories in second-round afternoon games.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in connection with the fashion showing under the auspices of the East Side Settlement and Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery held during the luncheon hour in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. William G. Cavanagh headed the benefit committee.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Fervent, winner of the 1947 Pimlico Special and American Derby, scored an impressive half-length triumph today in the six-furlong Bucksnort Purse at Tropical Park, for his second straight success of the new season.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 10 -- Switzerland's 130-year-old neutrality policy is being carefully re-examined.

Visitor With a Mission Our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn, lover of children, last seen in these parts before Christmas taking off for the North Pole to lobby in behalf of indestructible toys for the young, has returned, and with a new project.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- It could very well have been a preview of the 1948 World Series, the clash today between the Yankees and the Cardinals at Al Lang Field, just off the waterfront at Tampa Bay. Pelicans flew lazily overhead and a goodly gathering of local ancients deserted their shuffleboard games to sit in the sunshine and enjoy the festivities.

Ever since Eddie Foy Jr. bowed out of the picture in favor of a leading part in the road duplicate of "High Button Shoes," Hunt Stromberg Jr. and William Berney, who are reviving "Sally," have been at wits' end to find a worthy successor.

For the first time an Army transport will be renamed in honor of a Japanese-American soldier when the Wilson Victory becomes the Pfc. Sadao S. Munemori at the New York Port of Embarkation. The ship has been under repair and the renaming ceremony has been set tentatively for Tuesday.

A telephoned warning that James Monroe High School in the Bronx was to be blown up led the police to assign fifty patrolmen and detectives to a search of the building yesterday afternoon, and to post a heavy guard for a Zionist meeting in the school auditorium last night.

Group chairmen of the American Marketing Association's New York chapter will confer soon on criticism of meeting programs raised Tuesday by Hal Webber, vice president of Foote, Cone Belding, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Webber's contention that many of the group meetings were little more than a "pitch" on new and "re-warmed" research services brought some counter criticism in a survey of group chairmen opinion.

Stock of two major banking establishments -- J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Bankers Trust Company -- will figure today in secondary distributions by underwriting syndicates. The Morgan stock to be marketed consists of the 25,000 shares held by the late Thomas W. Lamont, former chairman of the bank.

Representatives of the twelve unions whose members work at the Metropolitan Opera met with representatives of the management yesterday afternoon in the first of a series of discussions on whether Metropolitan employes come under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

American Airlines and United Air Lines announced yesterday their schedules for the resumption of coast-to-coast and other services with the Douglas DC-6s, voluntarily grounded for four months to remove the cause of two accidents.

LONDON, March 10 -- The international labor conference on the European Recovery Program ended here today after issuing a unanimous declaration of faith in the program and calling upon all workers in the participating countries to support it by their "effective cooperation."

The Most Rev. Daniel Ivancho, Coadjutor Bishop of the Carpatho-Ruthenians in the United States, with residence in Mulhall, Pa., will be the principal celebrant of a Byzanine liturgy (the mass) Saturday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The first "Parsifal" that the Metropolitan Opera Association will give in New York this season was presented last night. It is reasonable to believe that the second and third performances of this opera, to be given in a fortnight between weeks of the company's spring tour, will achieve a greater degree of finish and cohesion than obtained unswervingly on this occasion.

A new mediation session by officials of the New York Curb Exchange with employe representatives broke up yesterday afternoon after only six minutes and a union official declared again that a strike would be called "suddenly" and without advance notice.
CHICAGO, March 10 (UP) -- A severe blizzard swept across the Southwestern wheat belt today and a biting cold wave benumbed residents of the North Central states.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 10 -- With President Rafael Trujillo posing to toss out the first ball, but not throwing it, the international baseball season was off to a rousing start today before some 6,500 Dominican fanaticos.

The half-way mark of International Flower Show Week, reached last evening, was the occasion for freshening many of the exhibits. Visitors to Grand Central Palace during the last three days of the show will have little cause to complain of wilted blossoms.

Fordham's basketball team which closed its regular campaign last week with sixteen victories and six defeats, added a post-season triumph over Canisius to its record in the feature attraction of a Jesuit mission relief bureau benefit double-header at the Sixty- ninth Regiment Armory last night.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Legislature set the stage today for a final adjournment of the present session either Friday or Saturday by approving revision of the Unemployment Insurance Law, bills providing for regulating the insurance business and several hundred other measures.

The arrest of a 26-year-old long-shoreman, alleged contact man for a narcotics selling gang, and the seizure of forty ounces of pure heroin with a potential value of $500,000 along the Brooklyn waterfront, was announced yesterday by detectives attached to the Narcotics Squad at Police Headquarters.

Dick Button, the 18-year-old Englewood, N. J., athlete who recently won the Olympic, world and European figure-skating crowns, returned home yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth along with other sports notables.

Wage increases ranging from $10.52 to $32.27 a month have been won by members of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, employed on dry cargo ships operated by six lines, it was announced here yesterday.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- The American horse, Caddie II, and forty-five other entries were accepted today for the Grand National Steeplechase. The race will be run March 20 at Aintree.

Enough natural gas to meet all demands in the eastern seaboard area in 1949 was indicated yesterday when the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation made known that it had filed an application with the Federal Power Commission to build a $152,000,000 twenty-six-inch pipeline to bring 386,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily into New York, New Jersey and New England.

NANKING, March 10 -- Twenty thousand casualties were suffered by Government forces in a major battle west of Ichuan, in Shensi Province, a Ministry of National Defense source stated today. He said that the Communists had lost 7,000 men last week during a three-day battle in which the Communist radio claimed a victory over 30,000 Nanking troops.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -- The first test of two important cogs in the new Giant machine will be undertaken Friday in the first of the three-game week-end series against the White Sox. Manager Mel Ott announced today he would send Whitey Lockman and Bobby Thomson into action then.
Fears that a bill introduced in the New York State Senate early this week may restrict production and sale of many types of toys were expressed yesterday at the American Toy Fair being held here.

NUREMBERG, Germany, March 10 (UP) -- An American tribunal today found eight former SS (Elite Guard) officers guilty of directing the mass extermination of people in twelve "inferior" nations overrun by the Nazis. Their sentences ranged from ten years to life.

Never in front, though they fought back once from an eleven-point deficit to a tie, the New York Knickerbockers succumbed to the St. Louis Bombers, 82 to 73, in a Basketball Association of America encounter at Madison Square Garden last night.

In your issue of Feb. 29 was an article from Rome which called attention to the probability that, after the coming elections for the Italian Parliament, "the minor parties would hold the balance of power," as between the Left Wing (Socialists and Communists) on the one side, and the Catholic (Christian Democrat) party on the other.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Passage of a thoroughly revised and deflated version of Mayor William O'Dwyer's "package" for New York City was promised tonight by Republican legislative leaders following a long conference with Governor Dewey and state administration officials.

A vision of victory, evolved in a child's mind forty years ago, became reality yesterday when "Old 16" a 1906 Locomobile racing car and winner of the Vanderbilt Cup contest in 1908 received highest honors at the Antique Auto Show in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

TOKYO, March 10 -- The occupation authorities are giving careful screening to material that the Japanese are allowed to read regarding the American reaction to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's announcement that he would be willing to become a Presidential candidate at the people's call.

The undermining of parliamentary government in Czechoslovakia is hard to take. Every act of Russia or her satellites toward the extension of police states makes it more difficult for us to cooperate in reaching an understanding on world peace, just as our own inept attempts to "block" Russia create retaliation and strengthen the Communist forces.

CONCORD, N. H., March 10 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was assured tonight of six of New Hampshire's eight delegates to the Republican National Convention and whatever campaign stimulus goes with the first ballot victory of this year's Presidential primaries.

First prize at the graduation exercises of twenty-one nurses of the class of 1948 from the Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing last night went to Miss Gertraud F. Gunzenhauser, 25 years old, a refugee from Bavaria, Germany.

Two books about Georg Friedrich Handel, one a biography and the other a critical study, have been scheduled for publication this month. Scribners will issue on Monday "Georg Friedrich Handel: His Personality and His Times," by Newman Flower.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Eamon De Valera, former prime minister of Ireland, said today that Ireland was eager to cooperate economically and otherwise with Western Europe. However, he cautiously avoided a definitive answer on the question of joining Great Britain in a union of Western countries.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- George F. Bauer, New York, said today export controls are a "terrific waste" and should be abolished.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee approved today the Government subsidy of ship salvage operations.

PARIS, March 10 -- France added her voice to those offering condolences to Czechoslovakia on the tragic death today of Jan Masaryk. President Vincent Auriol in a message to President Benes said he was "profoundly moved by the death of M. Masaryk, whose noble personality and illustrious name evoke many dear memories in France."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 10 -- There is not the ghost of a chance of ending the partition of Ireland for as far into the future as calculations can go. No one who spends even a short while in Belfast or a long while in London can come to any other conclusion.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Early, favorable action on the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, which provides that "equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex" was urged today at a hearing by a House judiciary subcommittee.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Jump to death by Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, was widely interpreted as a gesture of defiance to his country's new Communist rulers today as the British Government and people mourned the loss of an old friend and associate.

MUNICH, Germany, March 10 -- Efforts were made to smuggle the late Jan Masaryk out of Czechoslovakia, but they failed because twenty-three secret police were assigned to guard him, a former Czechoslovak official said here today.

HAVANA, March 10 -- Boycotts, emborgoes and other measures of economic warfare imposed for political reasons will be outside the jurisdiction of the proposed International Trade Organization and will be left to the United Nations. This was decided today by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations got stern today with its state and local councils on the "third party" and Marshall Plan issues.

RKO's adaptation of the John Van Druten stage success, "I Remember Mama," will have its local premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Irene Dunne, Oscar Homolka, Barbara Bel Geddes, Philip Dorn, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Edgar Bergen, Rudy Vallee and Barbara O'Neil head the cast of the comedy-drama.

One hundred chronic traffic violators living in Connecticut wilt have the choice on Monday of submitting to tests designed to discover the causes for their "accident proneness" or of being tried for recent traffic violations.
CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) -- The Erie Railroad today reported that its net profit shot up to $4,860,350 last year but said it needed a still higher return on investment.

The Charles Beseler Company of New York, manufacturer of stereopticon and other opaque slide projection equipment, plans to move soon to the building at 52-72 Badger Avenue, Newark, N. J., which it has leased with an option of purchase.

BERLIN, March 10 -- Decentralization of the German film industry has been directed in the first formal order issued under the United States zone Decartelization Law, promulgated more than a year ago. The order was effective March 8 and is designed to illegalize any such centralization as prevailed before the war.

THOSE of us who survived the Big Snow of December, 1947, may not think so, but those twenty-six inches of white stuff were only a mild flurry compared to the Great Blizzard of 1888. That is made perfectly clear right here in Albert E. Idell's "The Great Blizzard."* Mr. Idell is continuing the adventures of the Rogers family, which have already made two lively, popular volumes: "Centennial Summer" and "Bridge to Brooklyn."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 10 -- The Czechoslovak crisis exploded in the United Nations today when Prague's chief delegate charged that the Soviet Union had installed a Communist dictatorship in his country by threat of arms and he demanded an investigation by the Security Council.

Directors of Adam Hat Stores, Inc., took no action on the payment of a common dividend due at this time. The firm stated that the action on the payment was deferred because of general economic conditions. The company had been paying 15 cents at quarterly intervals, but the rate was reduced to 7 1/2 cents on Jan. 2.
"I am the small son of a great father, and I hate to have all this publicity because it belongs to him."

Legal action will be taken to force the New York public school system to discontinue released time instruction in religion, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Lewis, president of the Freethinkers of America.

In installing an Interim Netherlands East Indies Government in Batavia, to function until the establishment next January of a United States of Indonesia within a Netherlands-Indonesian Union, the Dutch have fulfilled a promise and the Indies has taken another step toward self-government and independence.

GENEVA, March 10 -- On April 3, 1941, Count Paul Teleki, Prime Minister of Hungary, killed himself with a pistol in Budapest. He left a letter stating he did not feel "able to carry on his difficult and unhappy task." The task he referred to became known three days later.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, will resign this week and be reappointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to his former post as License Commissioner, it was reported reliably last night. The shift will be made not later than tomorrow, when the Mayor is scheduled to leave for El Centro, Calif., to begin the month's vacation ordered by his physicians.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 10 -- Following is the text of the statement delivered today by Dr. Jan Papanek, permanent Czechoslovak delegate, to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations:
PARIS, March 10 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault today told the French Cabinet that the prospects were for a union of Western Europe on a wider basis than had ever thus far been expected.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Columbia, recently crowned Eastern Intercollegiate League champion for the second straight year, closed its regular basketball season by defeating Pennsylvania, 67 -- 52, tonight at the Palestra, before 2,500 spectators.

VIENNA, March 10 -- The first attempt by the Austrian Communist party and its ally -- the Soviet Army of occupation -- to panic Austria into concessions on the heels of the Czechoslovak coup appears to have failed.

A warning against over-expansion of plants in the chemical industries was issued yesterday by W. P. Marsh Jr., executive vice president of United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., in addressing the luncheon session of the Commercial Chemical Development Association at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Michael of Rumania, the 26-year-old monarch who abdicated and left his country last December under pressure from Communists, arrived here last night on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.
Utterly American were the 125 costumes presented by Adrian at Gunther's yesterday morning. All expressed what that designer thinks the American woman wants to wear -- and should.

Lightweight chairs, settees and tables of Chinese peel were the stars of the first summer furniture show of the season, presented yesterday at Gimbels. These old favorites, which have been missing from the scene for five years, are made of woven peel fiber and designed especially for tropical use.

Heavy reduction in profits on securities and increase in expenses relative to earnings accounted for the sharp decline in net profits of all member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District in 1947, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.
Only 40 per cent of New Yorkers who are expected to file Federal income tax returns for 1947 had done so by last night, according to a survey of local tax offices.

Successful in drawing his third-round game with Vassily Smyslov in the tournament for the world chess championship at The Hague, Mikhail Botvinnik, Soviet grandmaster, yesterday led the field of five aspirants, according to a report from the Netherlands.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 10 -- Henry W. Safarik, a regular defenseman on Princeton's varsity hockey sextet, has been suspended from the team pending investigation of his eligibility for intercollegiate competition, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.

Your editorial of March 5 on corporation profits brings out a number of important points which critics of "exorbitant" corporation profits refuse to see -- that inflation is distorting the figures. The critic knows that he is not necessarily better off than in a prior year simply because he is now receiving more wages.

JERUSALEM, March 10 -- The capture of three British deserters from the Palestine police by British forces fighting Arabs today confirmed for the first time that deserters are fighting alongside the Arab forces.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee concluded tax-reduction hearings today with a majority apparently determined to trim the $6,500,000,000 of annual relief voted by the House to about $4,600,600,000.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Truman today praised the cooperation of business and Government at a savings bond meeting in the White House attended by about sixty representatives of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Scenic wallpaper panels and repeat design papers produced by a new printing process on distinctive background colors were exhibited yesterday by George Laszlo of Rembrandt Products Inc. at his studio, 165 East Sixtieth Street.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday but closed unchanged to 14 points net lower.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 -- Crowds gathered in the streets before election bulletin boards tonight as the count began in last Sunday's Congressional election. The first returns in the Buenos Aires area indicated the expected advantage of Peronista candidates.

Mildred Waldman, pianist, gave her second New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her playing could be praised for its agreeable tone, its clarity, accuracy and precision, its careful phrasing and pedaling. But, as interpreter, the youthful artist proved more in her element in the modern works on her program than in the classic and romantic offerings, which disclosed her limitations in matters of imagination and coloring to a greater extent.

Public health nurses in this city are under such strain that they will "go into a stage of chronic frustration and distress" unless a shortage is remedied, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, declared yesterday at the Women's City Club in the New Weston Hotel.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for $125,000 to set up his own temporary street cleaning department because of the alleged shortcomings of the present city-wide Sanitation Department.

LONDON, March 10 -- The seriousness of Britain's position as shown by the economic survey caused no liquidation in the stock market here today. On the contrary, buyers were quick to appreciate the pre-eminent position accorded to the textile industry in the revised export program.
